title: 15th International Conference on Human Retroviruses: HTLV and Related Viruses
abstract: There are 253 papers in the trial. Topics discussed include: CD4+/CD8+ T-cell ratio in splenocytes of human T-cell leukemia virus type I tax transgenic mice with inflammatory arthropathy; viral expression directs the fate of B cells in BLV-infected sheep; tet-inducible lymphoma in a novel tax transgenic mouse model; bovine immunodeficiency virus as an enhancer cofactor for experimental bovine leukemia virus infection in sheep; bovine MHC class II DR molecule plays an important role in bovine leukemia virus (BLV)-induced lymphoma; comparative proteomic analysis of cancer stem cells in a tax-transgenic (Tax-Tg) mouse model of adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma; a life-reduced BLV deletant as a candidate vaccine to inhibit viral transmission in cattle herds; and high-throughput sequencing reveals new microRNAs in a bovine leukemia virus (blv)-induced ovine model of leukemia.

title: 102nd Annual Meeting of the American Society of Immunologists, IMMUNOLOGY 2015
abstract: The transactions contain 1758 papers. Topics discussed include: de novo detection and HLA-association of public t-cell responses against cytomegalovirus using high-throughput immune repertoire sequencing; Abolition of CD59 function restores the activities of neutralizing and non-neutralizing antibodies in triggering antibody-dependent complement-mediated lysis of HIV-1 virions and provirus-activated latently infected cells; evaluation of bone marrow in cowpox virus infection in cynomolgus macaques; glycosylphosphatidylinositol deficiency weakens infectious HIV-1 production and renders virions susceptible to complement attack; and immune restoration, activation, and viral reservoirs in gut-associated lymphoid tissue in SIV-infected long-term non-progressed Chinese rhesus macaques on antiretroviral therapy.

title: Recommendations for Standardized Avian Coronavirus (AvCoV) Nomenclature: Outcomes of Discussions in the Framework of European Union COST Action FA1207: "Towards the Control of Avian Coronaviruses: Vaccination, Diagnosis and Surveillance Strategies"
abstract: Viruses within the family Coronaviridae show variations within their genome sequences, particularly within the main structural protein, the Spike (S) glycoprotein gene. Therefore, many different antigenic forms, serotypes or variant strains of avian coronaviruses (AvCoV) exist worldwide. Only a few of these, the so-called protective types, provide cross-protection against different serotypes. New serotypes arise by recombination or spontaneous mutations. From time to time, antigenic virus variants appear that differ significantly from known serotypes. The result of this variability is an inconsistent nomenclature and classification of virus strains. In addition, there is currently no defined standard classification method. Within the framework of COST Action FA1207 "Towards the control of avian coronaviruses: diagnostic, surveillance and vaccination strategies" (working groups "Molecular virology" and "Epidemiology"), we aimed to define and develop a unified and internationally standardized terminology. Classification of AvCoVs. We recommend using "CoV Species/AvCov/host/country/sample ID/year" to refer to AvCoV strains.

title: First genome sequence of Genotype VIII Newcastle disease virus from Jordan
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) was detected by reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) from total RNA isolated from chicken spleen of a backyard flock in Jordan. The complete coding genome sequence of NDV/chicken/Jordan/J11-spleen/2018 was obtained by MiSeq (Illumina) sequencing. Phylogenetic analysis of the assembled coding sequences classified the virus as class II subgenotype VIIi.
authors: Ababneh, M.;Ferreira, H. L.;Khalifeh, M.;Suarez, D. L.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Genotyping of bovine leukemia virus isolates circulating in the Stavropol region
abstract: The bovine leukemia virus (BLV) circulating on the territory of the Stavropol Territory of Russia is characterized according to the modern classification of subspecies membership. The proviral deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) of BLV was isolated from the peripheral blood of animals naturally infected with this virus. Subsequent amplification, sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of a fragment of the env-gene 444 pairs nucleotide (pn) long made it possible to classify the studied isolates as genotypes 4 and 6. Apart from the isolate clusters of all eight known genotypes, this made it possible to classify it as atypical. During the sequencing of a portion of the env gene of BLV provirus isolates separated in this area, the presence of 31 point mutations, 11 of which were significant, was detected at the examined locus: 2 transversions and 9 passages.
authors: Abakin, S. S.;Krasovskaya, T. L.;Surgikova, E. S.;Gendzhieva, O. B.

title: Identification and phylogenetic analysis of sheep pox during a sheep epidemic in Sharkia province, Egypt
abstract: Sheeppox virus (SPPV) is one of the listed and notifiable diseases affecting sheep production, which greatly affects the trade in new breed sheep. This study was conducted to identify sheep pox using cell culture, electron microscopy (EM), and open reading frame (ORF) 103 gene during an outbreak in local breed sheep in Sharkia Governorate, Egypt, in April 2017. Skin pox lesion on face, inner lips, inner thigh and under tail. In young lambs aged 3 to 6 months, the incidence of infection was 23.5% and the mortality rate was 8.2%. Forty-three shell and tissue samples were collected from clinically diseased adult sheep and dead lambs and cultured in Vero cell. The cytopathic effect (CPE) was observed in 40 samples within 3 to 7 days. A typical Poxvirus was a brick-like shape with rounded ends on negative staining of EM and oval-like structure with dumbbell-shaped DNA cores with concave body edges on positive staining of EM. Conventional PCR using the ORF103 gene and the resulting bands of about 570 bp referred to SPPV. The sequence amplicon was analyzed by NCBI-BLAST and registered in the GeneBank under the N. MG873537 entry, and phylogenetic tree was designed revealing that the isolated SPPV strain is similar to other SPPV strains isolated in Egypt, India, China, and the USA. Finally, both EM and PCR are considered sensitive, fast and powerful methods to identify SPPV from tissue and shell samples without the need for further culture, in addition to the convenient and easy use of the ORF103 gene to distinguish SPPV from other Capripox viruses. . .
authors: Abd-Elfatah, E. B.;El-Mekkawi, M. F.;Bastawecy, I. M.;Fawzi, E. M.

title: Isolation and Molecular Characterization of Novel Infectious Bronchitis Virus Variants from Vaccinated Broiler Flocks in Egypt
abstract: This study aimed to determine the molecular characteristics of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) strains circulating in vaccinated broiler flocks in Giza and Fayoum provinces. Thirty-four isolates were collected and egg dispersal revealed their ability to induce typical IBV lesions after three to five consecutive passages. Three selected isolates were identified as IBV using a real-time reverse transcriptase-PCR assay targeting the nucleocapsid (N) gene and further characterized by partial spike (S) gene sequence analysis. Phylogenetic analysis revealed their clustering in two variable groups. Group I consisted of a variant (VSVRI_F3) with 99.1% nucleotide sequence identity to the Q1 reference strain. Group II consisted of variants VSVRI_G4 and VSVRI_G9 showing 92.8%-94.3% nucleotide identity with the Egyptian variants Eg/12120S/2012, Eg/12197B/2012 and Eg/1265B/2012. Regarding the deduced amino acid sequence, the three variants had 77.1%-85.2% similarity to the vaccine strains currently used in Egypt. These findings highlight the importance of monitoring the prevalence of IBV variants in vaccinated broiler flocks as well as adopting an appropriate vaccination strategy.
authors: Abdel-Sabour, M. A.;Al-Ebshahy, E. M.;Khaliel, S. A.;Abdel-Wanis, N. A.;Yanai, T.

title: Retrotransposable elements in the W chromosome of the silkworm, Bombyx mori
abstract: The sex chromosomes of the silkworm Bombyxmori are named ZW(XY) for females and ZZ(XX) for males. The W chromosome of B. mori does not recombine with the Z chromosome and autosomes, and no genes for morphological characters have yet been mapped to the W chromosome. Also, femininity is determined by the presence of a single W chromosome, regardless of the number of autosomes or Z chromosomes. To understand these interesting features of the W chromosome, it is necessary to analyze the W chromosome at the level of molecular biology. To initially isolate W chromosome-specific DNA sequences as randomly amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) markers, we compared genomic DNAs between males and females by PCR with random 10-mer primers. So far, we have identified 12 W-specific RAPD markers, and with the exception of one RAPD marker, all of the deduced amino acid sequences of these W-specific RAPD markers are similar to previously reported amino acid sequences of reversible elements from various sources. organisms. After constructing a genomic DNA lambda phage library of B. mori, we obtained two lambda phage clones, one containing the W-Kabuki RAPD sequence and one containing the W-Samurai RAPD sequence, and found that these DNA sequences contain nested structures of many retrotransposable elements. To further analyze the W chromosome, we obtained 14 W-specific bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) clones from three BAC libraries and subjected these clones to shotgun sequencing. Combining the resulting sequences did not produce a single contiguous sequence due to the availability of many reversible elements. Therefore, we combined PCR with shotgun sequencing. Through these analyses, we found that many long terminal repeat (LTR) and non-LTR retrotransposons, retroposons, DNA transposons and their derivatives accumulate as a layer on the W chromosome. These results strongly suggest that retrotransposable elements are the major structural component of the W chromosome.
authors: Abe, H.;Mita, K.;Yasukochi, Y.;Oshiki, T.;Shimada, T.

title: Isolation of a novel sapelovirus-like virus from wild boar
abstract: new sapelovirus-like virus was isolated from a wild boar (Sus scrofa). In this study, partial viral genomic nucleotide sequences were determined using the rapid detection system of viral nucleic acid sequences (RDV). 3.1, which we have recently developed to discover new viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the VP1 and 3A proteins and their encoding nucleotide sequences of enteroviruses and sapeloviruses showed that the isolated virus was closely related to porcine sapelovirus. RT-PCR detected viral sequences in six of 48 wild boar stool samples. © 2011 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Abe, M.;Ito, N.;Sakai, K.;Kaku, Y.;Oba, M.;Nishimura, M.;Kurane, I.;Saijo, M.;Morikawa, S.;Sugiyama, M.;Mizutani, T.

title: Genomic and single nucleotide polymorphism analysis of infectious bronchitis coronavirus
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is a Gammakoronavirus that causes a highly contagious respiratory disease in chickens. A QX-like strain was analyzed by high-throughput Illumina sequencing, and genetic diversity across the entire viral genome was investigated at the sub-consensus level by single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) analysis. Thirteen open reading frames (ORFs) in the 5'-UTR-1a-1ab-S-3a-3b-EM-4b-4c-5a-5b-N-6b-3'UTR sequence were predicted. Missense: the relative frequencies of silent SNPs were calculated to obtain a comparative measure of variability in specific genes. In descending order, the most variable ORFs were E, 3b, 5'UTR, N, 1a, S, 1ab, M, 4c, 5a, 6b. Protein products E and 3b play key roles in coronavirus virulence and RNA folding showed that mutations in the 5'UTR did not alter the predicted secondary structure. The frequency of SNPs of 0.67% in the spike (S) protein ORF was below the genomic mean of 0.76%. Only three SNPS were identified in the S1 subunit, none located in hypervariable region (HVR) 1 or HVR2. The S2 subunit was significantly more variable, comprising 87% of the polymorphisms detected throughout the entire S protein. The S2 subunit also contained a previously unreported multi-A insertion site and four sequentially mutated amino acid sequences that mapped to the stem region of the spike protein. Template-based modeling of protein structure produced the first theoretical model of the IBV spike monomer. Given the lack of diversity observed at the sub-consensus level, the principle that HVRs in the S1 subunit are very tolerant to amino acid changes produced by genetic drift is questioned.
authors: Abolnik, C.

title: Evolution of the highly pathogenic avian influenza of H5: sequence data show gradual changes at the cleavage site
abstract: The genetic composition of an H5 subtype hemagglutinin gene quasitype obtained from ostrich tissues infected with the H5 subtype influenza virus was analyzed using a next-generation sequencing approach. First evidence has been provided for the repeated duplication of a poly(U) stretch in the binding peptide region of the hemagglutinin cleavage site (HACS) by viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp). Multiple non-consensus-dependent RNA strains were detected in the infected host, corresponding to possible intermediate sequences between the putative low pathogenic precursor nucleotide sequence of the H5 influenza strain and the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus gene sequence. In silico analysis of identified RNA sequences predicted that the intermediate H5 sequence PQREKRGLF plays an important role in subsequent mutational events that reposition the HACS coding region from stable base-pair RNA regions into a single-stranded overhang, thereby preparing the junction peptide coding region. For the RdRp shift.
authors: Abolnik, C.

title: Outbreaks of avian influenza H6N2 viruses in chickens resulted from the reclassification of H6N8 and H9N2 ostrich viruses.
abstract: The first recorded avian influenza (AI) outbreak (low pathogenicity H6N2) in South African chickens occurred in Camperdown, KwaZulu/Natal Province (KZN) in June 2002. We identified phylogenetic relationships among the various H6N2s to identify the source of the outbreak. isolates and previously unpublished gene sequences of an H6N8 virus isolated from ostriches in the Leeu Gamka region in 1998 (A/Ostrich/South Africa/KK98/98). We show that two distinct genetic H6N2 strains (sublineage I and II) circulate in the Camperdown region and then spread to other regions. Sublines I and II shared a recent common H6N2 ancestry that emerged from a reclassification event between two South African ostrich isolates A/Ostrich/South Africa/9508103/95 and (H9N2) A/Ostrich/South Africa/KK98/98 ( H6N8). In addition, H6N2 sublineage I viruses had a variety of molecular genetic markers, including a 22 amino acid stem deletion in the neuraminidase (NA) protein gene, a predicted increase of N-glycosylation, and a D144 mutation of the HA protein gene. Associated with the adaptation of AI viruses to chickens. The H6N2 NS1 and PB1 genes shared recent common ancestry with those of contemporary Asian HPAI H5N1 viruses. Our results support other reports that ostriches are potential mixing vessels for avian influenza viruses (AIV) epidemic strains and that H6 viruses can form stable strains in chickens. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Abolnik, C.;Bisschop, S.;Gerdes, T.;Olivier, A.;Horner, R.

title: Phylogenetic analysis (2001-2005) of low pathogenic avian influenza H6N2 viruses from chicken outbreaks indicates that they are reassortants of historical ostrich low pathogenic avian influenza H9N2 and H6N8 viruses.
abstract: Low pathogenicity (LPAI) and highly pathogenic (HPAI) avian influenza viruses are periodically isolated from South African ostriches, but in 2002 the first recorded LPAI (H6N2) outbreak in South African chickens occurred on commercial farms in the Camperdown region of KwaZulu. /Natal (KZN) Province. Sequence analysis of all eight genes was performed and phylogenetic analysis was performed based on the hemagglutinin and neuraminidas sequences. Results from phylogenetic analyzes showed that H6N2 chicken viruses most likely arose from a reclassification between two South African LPAI ostrich isolates: an H9N2 virus isolated in 1995 and an H6N8 virus isolated in 1998. last common ancestor. One of these sublines was confined to the KZN province. The neuraminidase gene contains deletions of 22 amino acids associated with adaptation to growth in chickens in the NA stem region, while the other group lacks the NA stem deletion but has spread to commercial farms in other provinces. The persistence of certain H6N2 types in some regions for at least 2 years supports reports suggesting that H6N2 viruses from Asia and Southern California can form stable strains in chickens. It is likely that the ostrich H6N8 and H9N2 progenitors of chicken H6N2 viruses were introduced into ostriches by wild birds. Ostriches, where AI infections are often subclinical, can serve as mixing vessels for LPAI strains that occasionally spread to other poultry.
authors: Abolnik, C.;Bisschop, S. P. R.;Gerdes, G. H.;Olivier, A. J.;Horner, R. F.

title: Complete genomic sequence of an African avian paramyxovirus type 4 strain isolated from a mallard
abstract: random amplification/deep sequencing approach was applied to determine the complete genomic sequence of the Avian Paramyxovirus Type 4 (APMV-4) strain isolated from a wild duck in South Africa in 2010. publicly available sequence databases and the first for the African continent. A total of 87,402,081 Illumina paired-end reads were obtained, of which 47,338,867 (54.16%) mapped to the EU877976 reference genome. The entire genomic sequence of 15,054 nt, including intact ends, was recovered at a high redundancy (coverage per base: mean = 198,861.06, minimum = 52 and maximum = 1,790.889). Pairwise comparison of whole genomic nucleotide sequences, sequence identity of APMV-4/Egypt goose/South Africa/N1468/10 97.3% with APMV-4/KR/YJ/06, 96% with APMV-4/mallard/Belgium, It showed that it shares 4 sequence identity /15129/07 and 90.8% nucleotide sequence identity with APMV-4/duck/HK/D3/75. Genomic features were consistent with previously sequenced viruses, including predicted open reading frames for the NP, P, F, and L genes, but variations in coding regions were identified for the M and HN genes. The sequencing approach adopted in this study can successfully display half-species in the viral stock.
authors: Abolnik, C.;de Castro, M.;Rees, J.

title: Characterization of pigeon paramyxoviruses (Newcastle disease virus) isolated in South Africa from 2001 to 2006
abstract: Pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1), a variant of the Newcastle disease virus that primarily affects pigeons and pigeons, has been isolated in South Africa since the mid-1980s. Phylogenetic evidence indicates that pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 viruses have been introduced multiple times to South Africa, based on the existence of two distinct lineages, 4bi and 4bii, which have been circulating in Europe and the Far East since the early 1990s. In 2006, a PPMV-1 virus was isolated from an African black hornbill (Bucorvus leadbeateri), which was acutely infected with PPMV-1 and died, possibly after clearing infected pigeon carcasses in the area, because a closely related strain of PPMV-1 was from pigeons collected nearby. has also been isolated. Eagles isolate had ICPI and MDT values characteristic of PPMV-1 strains. The threat of PPMV-1 to poultry production and biodiversity in South Africa highlights the importance of monitoring the spread of this strain.
authors: Abolnik, C.;Gerdes, G. H.;Kitching, J.;Swanepoel, S.;Romito, M.;Bisschop, S. P. R.

title: Characterization of the highly pathogenic influenza A virus of the H5N2 subtype, isolated from ostriches in South Africa in 2004.
abstract: Objectives: The strain HPAI H5N2, which caused an epidemic in ostriches in the Eastern Cape Province of South Africa in 2004, was characterized. Design: Hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and agar gel immunodiffusion (AGID) and intravenous pathogenicity (IVPI) tests, reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), nucleic acid were applied in sera from ostrich farms in the epidemic region. Sequencing and phylogenetic comparisons were performed on HPAI H5N2 virus isolated during the epidemic. Results: The deduced amino acid sequence at the HA0 cleavage site, determined by RT-PCR and nucleotide sequencing, was PQREKRRKKRGLF, and thus the virus entered the definition of a highly pathogenic virus, but the virus isolated from the index is in an IVPI test condition in chickens and is highly pathogenic in this in vivo test. A value of 0.63 was recorded, which was below the criterion for viruses. A second IVPI was performed after another pass in embryonated eggs, yielding a high value of 1.19. Cloak swabs were taken from the first IVPI birds, inoculated into embryonated chicken eggs, and then a third IVPI was performed on the resulting hemagglutination, infective allantoic fluid. An index of 2.73 was recorded. Results: When testing antibodies to avian influenza in serum, HI tests appeared to be more sensitive as compared to AGID. An ostrich-derived virus with a virulent HA0 cleavage site was not initially virulent in chickens, but increased in chickens after transmission. Phylogenetic analyzes showed a link between AI viruses carried by wild ducks and those infecting ostriches. © 2009 Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Abolnik, C.;Londt, B. Z.;Manvell, R. J.;Shell, W.;Banks, J.;Gerdes, G. H.;Akol, G.;Brown, I. H.

title: Complete genome sequence of a velogenic Newcastle disease virus isolated in Mexico
abstract: In Mexico, the number of cases of the highly virulent Newcastle disease virus is rising. In 2005, an outbreak of Newcastle disease occurred at a laying farm in the state of Puebla despite being vaccinated with the LaSota strain. Farmers have suffered a massive drop in egg production as a result of a field-challenging virus. In this study, we characterize the APMV1/chicken/Mexico/P05/2005 virus responsible for the outbreak. The virus was categorized as a velogenic virus with an intracranial pathogenicity index of 1.99 and a chicken embryo mean death time of 36 hours. The full genome length of the virus was sequenced to consist of 15,192 bp. In addition, phylogenetic analysis classified the virus as a member of class II, genotype V. The highly pathogenic nature of the virus, multiple basic amino acids (RRQKR; F). © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: AbsalÃ³n, A. E.;Mariano-MatÃ­as, A.;VÃ¡squez-MÃ¡rquez, A.;Morales-GarzÃ³n, A.;CortÃ©s-Espinosa, D. V.;Ortega-GarcÃ­a, R.;Lucio-Decanini, E.

title: Avian influenza: Global assessment of the potential pandemic of the twenty-first century
abstract: The emergence and subsequent spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) from Asian ancestry, and the continued spread of the Eurasian-African H5N1 epidemic to domestic, wild birds and humans, have generated unprecedented interest and threat in recent times. potential pandemic through bird-human connection. Historically, from 1878 to 1955, poultry plaque was described as a disease with high mortality in poultry in many countries in Europe, Asia, North and South America, and Africa, and its etiology proved to be a filterable virus. From the 1930s to the 1950s, poultry plaque disappeared as an endemic disease in most parts of the world. In 1949, the first report of low virulent disease in chickens caused by the LPAI virus was reported. In 1955, the etiology of poultry plaque was determined as influenza A virus, which was later identified as the H7 subtype. In 1959, a "chicken plaque-like" outbreak in chickens was described, the first report of poultry plaque caused by a non-H7 AI virus, namely the first poultry plaque outbreak from the H5 subtype of AI virus. In 1961, the first wild bird infection and deaths were reported in South African ordinary terns. The first H5 and H7 LPAI viruses were identified in 1966 and 1971, respectively; before this period, only HPAI viruses had H5 and H7 subtypes. In 1970, the AGID serological test was introduced, allowing easy and rapid identification of AI virus-infected poultry flocks. In 1972, the first isolation of LPAI viruses was made in asymptomatic wild birds: ducks in the United States and shorebirds in Australia. In 1981 the term "highly pathogenic avian flu" was adopted as the standard nomenclature for poultry plaques and related synonyms. In 1983, LPAI virus was observed to mutate into HPAI virus during the LPAI field epidemic, and specific genomic changes were identified in the proteolytic cleavage site of hemagglutinin responsible for the virulence change. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, recognition molecular criteria were added for the classification of an AI virus as HPAI. In 2002, there were the first reported infections and deaths from the AI virus H5N1 HPAI virus in a wide variety of wild bird species. The primary purpose of this review is to highlight the global status of HPAI and provide essential information to illustrate the potential pandemic nature of the virus so that control and prevention strategies can be developed.
authors: Abubakar, M. B.;Aini, I.;Omar, A. R.;Hair Bejo, M.

title: Phylogenetic and molecular characterization of the coronavirus affecting bovine and avian species in Cuba.
abstract: Avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) and bovine coronavirus (BCoV) are veterinary important pathogens affecting birds and cattle in Cuba; however, the molecular characteristics and genetic diversity of these viruses are unknown. This study aimed to determine the molecular characteristics and genetic diversity of both agents based on the spike S gene. A molecular analysis was performed from BCoV field strains collected between 2009 and 2011, and phylogenetic studies were performed using partial or complete S gene sequences as phylogenetic markers. In addition, phylogenetic inference studies have been carried out recently in the S1 region of IBV isolates. All Cuban bovine coronavirus sequences were placed in a single cluster supported by 100% bootstrap and posterior probability values of 1.00. Cuban BCoV sequences were also clustered with US BCoV strains corresponding to GenBank accession numbers EF424621 and EF424623, suggesting a common source for these viruses. This phylogenetic cluster was also the only sequence group in which no recombination events were detected. Of the 45 amino acid changes found in Cuban strains, four were unique. On the other hand, two putative genotypes that were genetically different from the Massachusetts genotype H120 used in the Cuban vaccination program were found in the evaluated herds. Also, a potential nephropathogenic IBV isolate has been found for the first time in Cuba. This research won the 2012 Prize of the Cuban National Academy of Sciences. Â© Biotecnologña Applikada 2013.
authors: Acevedo, A. M.;MartÃ­nez, N.;BrandÃ£o, P.;Perera, C. L.;FrÃ­as, M. T.;Barrera, M.;PÃ©rez, L. J.

title: Viromic Analysis of Incoming Wastewater Input into a River Basin Reveals Diverse RNA Viruses Community
abstract: Detection of viruses in the medium is highly dependent on PCR-based approaches that require reference sequences for primer design. While this strategy can accurately detect known viruses, it will not find new genotypes or emerging and invasive viral strains. In this study, we investigated the use of viromics, such as high-throughput sequencing of the viral fraction of the biosphere, to detect human/animal pathogenic RNA viruses in the Conwy river basin in Wales, UK. Using a combination of filtration and nuclease treatment, we extracted the viral fraction from wastewater and estuarine river water and sediment, followed by high-throughput RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) analysis on the Illumina HiSeq platform for the discovery of RNA virus genomes. We found a higher RNA virus richness in wastewater samples than in river water and sediment, and we generated a complete norovirus genotype GI.2 genome from wastewater effluents, which was not detected simultaneously by conventional reverse transcription-quantitative PCR (qRT-PCR). . The simultaneous presence of various rotavirus signatures in wastewater demonstrated the potential for zoonotic infection in the region and suggested streams from pig farms as a possible source of these viruses. Our results suggest that viromics can be an important tool in the discovery of pathogenic viruses in the environment and can be used to inform and optimize reference-based detection methods provided appropriate and rigorous controls are included. IMPORTANCE Enteric viruses cause gastrointestinal disease and are usually transmitted by the fecal-oral route. When wastewater is released into river systems, these viruses can contaminate the environment. Our results suggest that we can use viromics to find the range of potentially pathogenic viruses found in the environment and identify common genotypes. The ultimate goal is to inform reference-based detection methods and water quality management by tracking the fate of these pathogenic viruses from the source to the point where they pose a threat to human health.
authors: Adriaenssens, E. M.;Farkas, K.;Harrison, C.;Jones, D. L.;Allison, H. E.;McCarthy, A. J.

title: Prevalence of swine parvoviruses in some South African pig herds with a history of swine circovirus type 2 infection
abstract: Classical swine parvovirus is an important pathogen of reproductive disorders in pigs with a confirmed history of global distribution. However, detection of many new porcine parvoviruses has been increasing over the past few years, but there is a lack of information about the occurrence and prevalence of these viruses in South Africa. Molecular detection of some known parvoviruses, namely porcine parvoviruses (PPVs) - 1, 2, 3 and 4, porcine bocavirus-like virus (PBo-likeV) and porcine bocaviruses (PBoV1/2) was carried out from 110 randomly selected archived pigs. Samples were collected in 2015 and 2016. Samples were obtained from farms previously screened and confirmed infected with porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2), with incidence at farm level ranging from 5.6% to 60%. The findings showed that all parvoviruses screened were present as: PPV1 (29.1%), PPV2 (21.8%), PPV3 (5.5%), PPV4 (43.6%), PBo-likeV (21.8%), and PBoV1/2 (44.6). %). The frequency of double infections of viruses was as high as 18.2% of PPV2/PPV4 and PPV4/PBoVs; 17.3% and 7.3% of the scanned samples showed multiple infections of three and four viruses, respectively. Further phylogenetic analyzes of the partial sequences PPV1, 2 and PBoV1/2 showed two major divisions for each of the viruses. This study reports the first epidemiological investigation and molecular characterization of classical and emerging swine parvoviruses in South African pig herds. It also provides information on the diversity and distribution of these viral pathogens within flocks in the study area and confirms their potential for co-infection with PCV2.
authors: Afolabi, K. O.;Iweriebor, B. C.;Obi, L. C.;Okoh, A. I.

title: Biological characterization and next-generation genome sequencing of the unclassified cotia virus SPAn232 (Poxviridae)
abstract: Cotia virus (COTV) SPAn232 was isolated in 1961 from sentinel mice at the Cotia field station in Sao Paulo, Brazil. Attempts to classify COTV within a recognized genus of Poxviridae have produced conflicting findings. Studies by different researchers showed some similarity to myxoma virus and swine pox virus, while another study characterized COTV SPAn232 as a strain of vaccinia virus. Due to the lack of consensus, we performed an independent biological and molecular characterization of COTV. Virus growth curves reached maximum efficiency at approximately 24 to 48 hours, accompanied by virus DNA replication and a characteristic early/late viral protein synthesis pattern. Interestingly, COTV did not induce detectable cytopathic effects in BSC-40 cells until 4 days after infection and only formed viral plaques 8 days later. We determined the complete genomic sequence of COTV using a combination of next-generation DNA sequencing technologies 454 and Illumina. A unique contiguous sequence of 185,139 bp was obtained, containing 185 genes, including 90 conserved in all cordopoxviruses. COTV has an interesting panel of open reading frames (ORFs) related to host defense evasion, including two novel genes encoding CC chemokine-like proteins, each in duplicate. Phylogenetic analysis revealed the highest amino acid identity scores with Cervidpoxvirus, Capripoxvirus, Suipoxvirus, Leporipoxvirus and Yatapoxvirus. However, COTV was grouped as an independent branch within this branch, which clearly excludes its classification as an Orthopoxvirus. Therefore, our data suggest that COTV may represent a new genus of smallpox virus. Â© 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Afonso, P. P.;Silva, P. M.;Schnellrath, L. C.;Jesus, D. M.;Hu, J.;Yang, Y.;Renne, R.;Attias, M.;Condit, R. C.;MoussatchÃ©, N.;Damaso, C. R.

title: Implementation of emergency immunization and genetic differentiation between rough skin disease outbreaks, field isolates and vaccine virus strains in Greece during 2015-16
abstract: The aim of this study is to present epizootiological data on tuberous skin disease (LSD) outbreaks in Greece in 2015-16, together with laboratory data on genetic differentiation among field isolates after emergency vaccination and complete eradication. and live attenuated vaccine virus strains. Descriptive geographic chronology analysis was performed to present the progressive westward shift of outbreaks as well as the absence of other outbreaks in previously affected regional units where high vaccination coverage was achieved. Isolation and molecular characterization of LSDV was performed from the first case recorded in Greece (Evros/GR/1 isolate). Two live attenuated LSD vaccinia viruses currently used for emergency immunization in Greece were sequenced and compared to the Evros/GR/15 isolate at 3 genomic regions (GPCR gene, RPO30 gene and partial LSDV126/LSDV127 genes). Sequence comparisons revealed significant differences between the Evros/GR/15 isolate and vaccine strains. The phylogenetic analysis resulted in the Evros/GR/15 isolate being classified in the same sequence as all field LSDV isolates, while the vaccine strains were grouped in a separate cluster within the LSDV sequence. Additional samples from animals presenting skin nodules (NÂ =Â 13) were characterized by sequencing in the 3 genomic regions mentioned above. Among them, attenuated vaccine virus was detected in 5 vaccinated animals. A PCR-RFLP method targeting the LSDV127 gene was developed and proved to be able to discriminate between the characterized area and the vaccine strains. The findings of this study confirm the importance of timely and intensive vaccines for epizootic control of LSDV and the genetic differences between the Evros/GR/15 isolate and vaccine strains. This provides the basis for the development of PCR-based DIVA assays that will be of paramount importance for effective disease surveillance and stigma during LSD vaccination campaigns.
authors: Agianniotaki, E. I.;Tasioudi, K. E.;Chaintoutis, S. C.;Iliadou, P.;Mangana-Vougiouka, O.;Kirtzalidou, A.;Alexandropoulos, T.;Sachpatzidis, A.;Plevraki, E.;Dovas, C. I.;Chondrokouki, E.

title: Spread of newly emerging infectious laryngotracheitis viruses in Australia
abstract: Infectious laryngotracheitis (ILT) is an important viral disease of chickens in many countries around the world. In this report, the status of ILT in Australia was used as a model to assess the evolution of ILT viruses (ILTVs). Due to its geographic isolation, Australia was home to a distinct lineage of ILT viruses (ILTV) until 2007. However, an examination of the ILT viruses (ILTV) involved in the outbreaks between 2007 and 2009 revealed that two new viral viruses were responsible for most of the outbreaks. genotypes, class 8 and class 9. These two recombinant viruses were found to arise as a result of recombination between previously existing live vaccine strains (SA2 and A20) and another live vaccine strain (Serva), which was introduced to the country in 2007. recombinant ILTVs were also shown to have significantly higher virulence and replication capacity compared to the previously dominant ILTV, class 2. In the current study, examination of multiple ILTVs isolated from outbreaks between 2009 and 2015 revealed the emergence of another recombinant virus. (class 10) It appears to have become a dominant genotype in New South Wales. But in Victoria, recombinant class 9 gradually became the dominant virus, replacing class 2. Therefore, there was an unusual pattern in the geographic spread of newly emerging viruses in different states of the country. These results show that ILTV is rapidly evolving towards greater transmittance and hence its capacity to diffuse into ILTV-free areas.
authors: Agnew-Crumpton, R.;Vaz, P. K.;Devlin, J. M.;O'Rourke, D.;Blacker-Smith, H. P.;Konsak-Ilievski, B.;Hartley, C. A.;Noormohammadi, A. H.

title: Detection and phylogenetic analysis of Orf virus in the Kashmir Himalayas
abstract: Orf virus (ORFV) is a zoonotic pathogen that primarily infects sheep and goats and is responsible for significant economic losses. ORFV is endemic in all major sheep and goat breeding regions of the world, including the Indian subcontinent. However, the nature of ORFV circulating among sheep and goats in the Kashmir Himalayas has not yet been characterized. In this study, we described natural outbreaks of ORFV in sheep and goats of the Kashmir Himalayas. We detected the presence of ORFV in the crustal lesion by PCR amplification of the major envelope protein (B2L) gene. We sequenced the virus interferon resistance (VIR) gene and determined their phylogenetic relationships to published reference sequences. Phylogenetic analysis based on the VIR gene revealed that ORFV isolated from the Kashmir Himalayas split into two main clusters. Sheep isolates showed genetic homology with sheep strains reported from Greece and Italy, while the goat-specific strain showed homology with goat strains reported from China. This study demonstrates the presence of ORFV infection in sheep and goats and reports the first phylogenetic analysis of ORFV strains common in the Kashmir Himalayas.
authors: Ahanger, S. A.;Parveen, R.;Nazki, S.;Dar, Z.;Dar, T.;Dar, K. H.;Dar, A.;Rai, N.;Dar, P.

title: Host-parasite relationships of bacteria and phages can be revealed by Oligostickiness, a measure of relaxed sequence similarity.
abstract: Motivation: Recent metagenome analysis produces large numbers of host unassigned viruses. Assigning viruses to their hosts has been a painstaking and difficult task to date, although fundamentally important not only for virology but also for the prevention of epidemics. The only effective method for this purpose has been to find them in the same microscopic appearance. We have now tried a computational approach based on genome sequences of bacteria and phages and introduced a physicochemical parameter, the oligo-adhesiveness-derived SOSS (oligo-adhesiveness similarity score set), a measure of the binding affinity of the oligonucleotides to template DNA. Results: We were able to confirm host-parasite associations and phages of bacteria by SOSS analysis: all phages tested (25 species) had a significantly higher SOSS than host-unrelated bacteria. Interestingly, based on SOSS values, lysogenic phages such as lambda phage (host: Escherichia coli) or SPP1 (host: Bacillus subtilis) have markedly higher similarity to their host than non-lysogenic (jumping or virulent) ones such as fd and T4. (host: E. coli) or phage gamma and PZA (host: B.subtilis). This finding is very promising for assigning unknown viruses to the host. We also investigated the association in codon usage frequency or G+C content of genomes to interpret the phenomenon revealed by SOSS analysis, and obtained evidence supporting the hypothesis that higher SOSS values are the result of co-existence in the same environment and may cause common-bias mutation. . Thus, lysogenic phages that stay inside for a longer period of time become host-like. Â© Author 2009. Published by Oxford University Press. All rights reserved.
authors: Ahmed, S.;Saito, A.;Suzuki, M.;Nemoto, N.;Nishigaki, K.

title: Genetic diversity and comparison of diagnostic tests for characterization of foot and mouth disease virus strains from Pakistan 2008–2012
abstract: We report the laboratory analysis of 125 clinical samples from suspected cases of foot and mouth disease (FMD) in cattle and Asian buffaloes collected in Pakistan between 2008 and 2012. Of these samples, 89 were found to contain viral RNA by rRT-PCR. It was found that 88 of them contained virus isolation (VI) and infectious FMD virus (FMDV), and there was a strong correlation between these tests (ÎºÂ =Â 0.96). Samples that were VI-positive were serotyped by antigen detection ELISA (Ag-ELISA) and VP1 sequence collection and analysis. Sequence data identified FMDV serotypes A (nÂ =Â 13), O (nÂ =Â 36) and Asia-1 (nÂ =Â 41), including three samples in which both Asia-1 and O serotypes were detected. Serotype A viruses were classified into three different Iran-05 subsets: HER-10, FAR-11 and ESF-10. All serotype Asia-1 were in Group VII (Sindh-08 strain) in a genetic clade different from viruses isolated before 2010. All serotypes O were classified as PanAsia-2 in two distinct subsets: ANT-10 and BAL-09. Using VP1 sequencing as the gold standard for serotype determination, the overall sensitivity of Ag-ELISA to accurately detect serotype was 74%, and the serotype-specific sensitivity was 8% for serotype A, 88% for Asia-1, and 89% for O. The serotype-specific specificity was 100% for serotype A, 93% for Asia-1, and 94% for O. Interestingly, 12 of the 13 serotype A viruses were not detected by Ag-ELISA. This study confirms previous accounts of regional genetic diversity of FMDV in Pakistan and highlights the importance of continued validation of diagnostic tests for rapidly evolving pathogens such as FMDV.
authors: Ahmed, Z.;Pauszek, S. J.;Ludi, A.;LaRocco, M.;Khan, E. U. H.;Afzal, M.;Arshed, M. J.;Farooq, U.;Arzt, J.;Bertram, M.;Brito, B.;Naeem, K.;Abubakar, M.;Rodriguez, L. L.

title: Human endophthalmitis caused by pseudorabies virus infection, China, 2017
abstract: We report human endophthalmitis caused by pseudorabies virus infection after exposure to sewage on a pig farm in China. High-throughput sequencing and real-time PCR of the vitreous humor showed pseudorabies virus sequences. This case showed that pseudorabies virus can infect humans after direct contact with contaminants.
authors: Ai, J. W.;Weng, S. S.;Cheng, Q.;Cui, P.;Li, Y. J.;Wu, H. L.;Zhu, Y. M.;Xu, B.;Zhang, W. H.

title: Whole genome analysis of porcine cobuviruses from pig feces in Japan
abstract: Porcine cobuviruses (PoKoVs) are ubiquitous in pig populations worldwide and are thought to be enteric viruses in pigs. Although PoKoVs have been detected in pigs from Japan, complete genome data are not available for Japanese PoKoVs. In this study, close to 24 complete or complete sequences of the PoKoV genome from 10 diarrheal stools and 14 non-diarrheal stools of Japanese pigs were analyzed using a metagenomic approach. Japanese PoKoVs shared 85.2%-100% identity with their full coding nucleotide (nt) sequences and 85.1%-98.3% closest association with PoKoVs from other countries. Twenty of the 24 Japanese PoKoVs performed a 90 nt deletion in the 2D coding region. Phylogenetic tree analyzes revealed that PoKoVs were not grouped according to geographic origin regions and phylogenetic trees of L, P1, P2 and P3 genetic regions showed divergent topologies. Similarity plot analysis using strains from a single farm revealed somewhat different patterns of similarity between strains from the same farm origins, suggesting that recombination events occurred. These results suggest that various strains of PoKoV are common and not geographically restricted in pig farms worldwide, and coexistence of multiple strains leads to recombination events of PoKoVs and contributes to the genetic diversity and evolution of PoKoVs.
authors: Akagami, M.;Ito, M.;Niira, K.;Kuroda, M.;Masuda, T.;Haga, K.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Naoi, Y.;Kishimoto, M.;Sano, K.;Omatsu, T.;Aoki, H.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Oka, T.;Ichimaru, T.;Yamasato, H.;Ouchi, Y.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Two new 'legumoviruses' (Begomovirus genus) naturally infecting soybeans in Nigeria
abstract: Two novel 'legumoviruses' (genus Begomovirus; family Geminiviridae) that naturally infect soybean (Glycine max L. Merr.) in Nigeria were molecularly characterized. Based on the characteristic symptoms in Soybean, the two viruses are tentatively named Soybean mild speck virus (SbMMV) and Soybean chlorotic spot virus (SbCBV). SbCBV has a bipartite genome, whereas SbMMV has only one DNA A component. The DNA A component of SbMMV is 2,768 nucleotides (nt) long, and the DNA A and DNA B components of SbCBV are 2,708 and 2,647 nt in length, respectively. In pairwise comparisons, the DNA component of SbMMV and SbCBV showed 62% nt sequence identity, indicating that these two viruses were different. DNA A of SbMMV contains two virions and four complementary-sense open reading frames, while that of SbCBV lacks virus-sense AV2, a signature gene found in 'Old World' begomoviruses. A pairwise comparison with the corresponding nucleotide sequence of other begomoviruses in the databases showed that SbCBV had a maximum identity of 74% with cowpea golden mosaic virus, and SbMMV had a maximum identity of 65% with mungbean yellow mosaic India virus and kudzu mosaic virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the DNA A component of SbCBV and SbMMV along with those of other begomoviruses found in databases showed clustering of the two viruses within the 'legumovirus' clade of the begomovirus phylogenetic tree. In addition, the DNA A and B components of SbCBV from Centrosema pubescens Benth were found to be identical to those from soybean, suggesting that the legume wild species is a potential alternative host for the virus. As soybeans are an promoted crop, the identification of two different begomoviruses that naturally infect soybeans in Nigeria suggests the emergence of 'legumoviruses' in plant species native to Africa and underlines potential threats to sustainable soybean cultivation on the African continent. © Springer-Verlag 2010.
authors: Alabi, O. J.;Kumar, P. L.;Mgbechi-Ezeri, J. U.;Naidu, R. A.

title: Serological and Antigenic Characteristics of Malaysian Orf Virus Isolates - An In-Vitro Comparative Study
abstract: Three Malaysian orf virus isolates from goats (GV1, GV2 and GV3) were compared with three orf viruses from sheep (LBV Malaysia isolate, ORFII and NZ2 reference strains) for serological properties and protein profiles. Serological tests such as the cross-agar gel precipitation test (AGPT), serum neutralization test (SNT), ELISA, indirect immunofluorescence test (IIF), and indirect immunoperoxidase test (IIP) revealed that the viruses were highly correlated. However, serotyping of these isolates using homologous and heterologous titration of hyperimmune sera (HIS) in SNT and ELISA showed opposite results and did not allow classification of these viruses as of goat and sheep origin. Protein analysis of these isolates was performed using SDS-Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE), Western blot and physical staining, and immunodetection of blotted protein profiles. The results revealed that these isolates differed mainly in the 41.5, 39.5 and 37.5 kD polypeptide bands. These analytical techniques allowed these isolates to be classified into four groups, GV1 and GV2 in the first, GV3 in the second, LBV and ORFII in the third, and NZ2 in the fourth.
authors: Alajeeli, K. S. A.;Iskander, F.;Ibrahim, A. L.;Zamrisaad, M.

title: Insights into Reston virus spreads and adaptation from virus whole genome sequences
abstract: Reston virus (family Filoviridae) is unique among viruses of the genus Ebolavirus as it is considered non-pathogenic to humans, unlike other highly virulent members. However, the virus has been associated with multiple fatal outbreaks of hemorrhagic fever in non-human primates (NHPs), particularly cynomolgus monkeys (Macaca fascicularis) originating in the Philippines. In addition, Reston virus has been isolated from domestic pigs in the Philippines. To better understand virus spread events and potential adaptation to novel hosts, whole genome sequences of representative Reston virus isolates were obtained using next-generation sequencing (NGS) approach, and comparative genomic analysis and virus fitness analyzes were performed. Nine virus genome sequences have been completed for new and previously described isolates from a variety of hosts, including a human case, non-human primates, and pigs.
authors: Albarino, C. G.;Wiggleton Guerrero, L.;Jenks, H. M.;Chakrabarti, A. K.;Ksiazek, T. G.;Rollin, P. E.;Nichol, S. T.

title: A molecular epidemiological study of avian paramyxovirus type 1 (Newcastle disease virus) is isolated by phylogenetic analysis of a partial nucleotide sequence of the fusion protein gene.
abstract: For 174 isolates of Newcastle disease virus (avian paramyxovirus type 1), a 375 nucleotide long sequence containing the region encoding the cleavage activation site and the signal peptide of the fusion protein gene was determined. These were compared with the sequences of 164 isolates published in GenBank, and the resulting alignment was analyzed phylogenetically using maximum likelihood. The results are presented as unrooted phylogenetic trees. In summary, the isolates were broadly divided into six distinct groups (lineage 1 to 6). Lines 3 and 4 are further subdivided into four sublines (a through d) and line 5 into five lineages (a through e). Significant genetic heterogeneity was detected in avian paramyxoviruses type 1, which appears to be affected by host, time, and geographic origin. It was concluded that using this dataset, it would be possible to quickly write future virus isolates according to their nucleotide sequences and make inferences about their origins.
authors: Aldous, E. W.;Mynn, J. K.;Banks, J.;Alexander, D. J.

title: Genome characterization of a pathogenic porcine rotavirus B strain identified in the Russian republic of Buryat in 2015.
abstract: In November 2015, an outbreak of enteric disease of unknown etiology occurred on a farm in the Russian Republic of Buryat, with 60% morbidity and 8% mortality in weaning piglets. Metagenomic sequencing revealed the presence of rotavirus B in the feces of diseased piglets, while no other pathogens were identified. Clinical disease was reproduced in experimentally infected piglets, yielding 11 RVB gene segments for strain Buryat15 with the RVB genotype constellation G12-P[4]-I13-R4-C4-M4-A8-N10-T4-E4-H7. This genotype constellation has also been described in the United States. Although the Buryat15 VP7 protein lacks unique amino acid differences in predicted neutralizing epitopes compared with previously published porcine RVB G12 strains, this RVB report in Russian pigs adds to our epidemiological knowledge of the global prevalence and genetic diversity of RVB.
authors: Alekseev, K. P.;Penin, A. A.;Mukhin, A. N.;Khametova, K. M.;Grebennikova, T. V.;Yuzhakov, A. G.;Moskvina, A. S.;Musienko, M. I.;Raev, S. A.;Mishin, A. M.;Kotelnikov, A. P.;Verkhovsky, O. A.;Aliper, T. I.;Nepoklonov, E. A.;Herrera-Ibata, D. M.;Shepherd, F. K.;Marthaler, D. G.

title: Long view: a selective review of 40 years of Newcastle disease research
abstract: This review was written for the series, which celebrates its 40th anniversary since the first issue of Avian Pathology. The authors' aim was to cover the advances in Newcastle disease (ND) research that they have deemed important over the past 40 years. During these 40 years there have been various panzootics of this serious disease in poultry, and for the last 30 years there has been a continuous panzootic spread to wild birds and poultry in domestic pigeons. The 40-year period began with severe worldwide epidemics of ND, which served as a major impetus for ND research work. Although early studies were concerned with controlling disease, particularly by developing and developing new vaccines and vaccine regimens, even before the 1970s the ND virus was seen as a useful laboratory virus for replication and virulence studies. This review covers historical developments in the following areas: understanding the molecular basis of virulence; epidemiology and relationship of both antigenic and genetically different ND strains; emergence of virulent strains and their relationship to low virulence viruses; sequencing and understanding the viral genome and genes; development of rapid molecular-based diagnostic tests; and the phylogeny and molecular taxonomy of the ND virus. The authors suggest areas where future research can or should be done. Â© 2012 Copyright Crown Copyright.
authors: Alexander, D. J.;Aldous, E. W.;Fuller, C. M.

title: Development of methodology based on commercialized SERS-active substrates for rapid differentiation of Poxviridae virions
abstract: Surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) can be made an attractive approach for the identification of Raman-active compounds and biological materials (i.e. toxins, viruses or intact bacterial cells/spores) through the development of reproducible, spatially uniform SERS-active substrates. Recently, reproducible (substrate-to-substrate), spatially homogeneous (over large areas) SERS active substrates have been commercialized and are now commercially available. We used these patterned surfaces to obtain SERS spectral signatures of intact bovine papular stomatitis, pseudocowpox and Yaba monkey tumor viruses. The distinctive spectral signature features make it possible to distinguish between these genetically distinct Poxviridae-Chordopoxvirinae virions. In addition, partial least squares, a multivariate calibration method, has been used to develop useful personal computer-derived algorithms for the classification of unknown Parapoxvirus (for example, bovine papular stomatitis virus and pseudocowpox virus) samples based on SERS spectral signatures alone. To our knowledge, this is the first report detailing the application of commercially available (COTS) SERS active substrates to the identification of intact pox viruses.
authors: Alexander, T. A.

title: Etiology and pathology of epidemic outbreaks of avian influenza H5N1 infection in maize poultry farms.
abstract: Epidemic outbreaks of the avian influenza (AI) virus H5N1 have been frequently reported in Egypt over the past nine years. Here, we investigate the role of AI H5N1 in the acute respiratory disease outbreaks that occurred in several commercial poultry farms in Egypt in 2011 and describe the pathology caused by the virus during the epidemic. 21 poultry farms with a history of acute respiratory symptoms and high mortality rates were screened for AI H5N1. Virus identification was based on the hemagglutination inhibition test and PCR detection and sequencing of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes. Virus distribution was determined by immunohistochemical staining of AI antigens in the organs of infected birds. Standard H&E staining was performed for histological examination of the affected organs. 81% of the birds examined, representing 100% of the screened farms, were positive for AI H5N1 virus. Phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of isolated virus, 2.2.1. Viral antigens were localized in endothelial cells of the heart, liver, lungs, and skin, where pathological lesions such as congestion, hemorrhages, multifocal inflammation, and necrosis were observed simultaneously. Based on the pattern of viral antigen and lesion distribution in visceral organs, we propose cardiovascular and circulatory disorders as the possible cause of death during these outbreaks. In conclusion, this study further confirms the epidemic status of AI H5N1 virus in Egypt and reveals the highly pathogenic nature of local isolates.
authors: Ali, A.;Elmowalid, G.;Abdel-Glil, M.;Sharafeldin, T.;Abdallah, F.;Mansour, S.;Nagy, A.;Ahmed, B.;Abdelmoneim, M.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analyzes of the complete genomes of two novel field isolates of cowpea chlorotic mottle virus
abstract: Cowpea chlorotic mottle virus (CCMV, family Bromoviridae) is found worldwide and has long been used as a model virus, but there is no data on the genetic diversity of field isolates. Recently, two new field isolates of CCMV from cowpea (Car1 and Car2) showed distinct phenotypic symptoms when inoculated into cowpea. CCMV-Car1 induced severe mosaic and intervascular chlorosis, while CCMV-Car2 produced mild mottling and leaf curl. Both isolates produced asymptomatic infection in Nicotiana benthamiana. The complete genomes of both isolates were amplified, cloned and sequenced by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction using specific primers against the CCMV sequences available in the GenBank database. Both nucleotide and amino acid sequences were compared between novel sequenced CCMV isolates and three previously characterized CCMV strains (T, M1 and R). Phylogenetic analysis of the RNA 1 sequence showed that CCMV-Car1 was in a separate branch from the rest of the CCMV isolates, while CCMV-Car2 was grouped together with CCMV-R. Two main groupings were obtained on the basis of RNA 2 and RNA 3 sequences. One group contained isolates CCMV-Car1 and CCMV-Car2, while the other contained strains CCMV-T, CCMV-M1 and CCMV-R. Recombination programs detected a potential recombination event in the RNA 1 sequence of the CCMV-Car2 isolate, but not in the RNA 2 and RNA 3 sequences. The results showed that both mutations and recombination play an important role in the genetic diversity of these two novel CCMV isolates. © 2011 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Ali, A.;Shafiekhani, M.;Olsen, J.

title: Hendra and Nipah infection: Emerging paramyxoviruses
abstract: Since their first appearance in the mid-1990s, henipaviruses have continued to reappear almost annually in Australia and South East Asia. In total, more than 12 outbreaks of Nipah and 48 Hendra virus have been reported in South East Asia and Australia, respectively. These outbreaks are associated with significant economic and health damage that most high-risk countries (especially in Southeast Asia) cannot bear the brunt of such economic threats. Until recently, there was no real cure to cure or prevent these deadly infections. However, an international collaborative study resulted in the identification of a potential equine Hendra vaccine that could provide antibody protection against Hendra virus infections. In conclusion, with the current findings and nearly 20 years since their first detection, are we there yet? This review summarizes the history of henipavirus emergence and briefly reviews potential anti-henipavirus vaccines and antivirals. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Aljofan, M.

title: [Genetic characterization of Wad Medani virus (WMV) (Reoviridae, Orbivirus) isolated from ticks of Hyalomma asiaticum Schulze et Schlottke, 1930 (Ixodidae: Hyalomminae) in Turkmenistan, Kazakhstan and Armenia, and ticks of H. anatolicum Koch, 1844 in Tajikistan]
authors: Al'khovskiÄ­, S. V.;L'Vov D, K.;Shchelkanov, M. Iu;Shchetinin, A. M.;Deriabin, P. G.;Gitel'man, A. K.;Aristova, V. A.;Botikov, A. G.

title: A virus discovery method involving DNase therapy and its application to the identification of two bovine parvovirus strains
abstract: The identification of previously unrecognized viral agents in serum or plasma samples is of great medical interest, but remains a major challenge primarily due to the abundant host DNA. Current methods, library screening or representative difference analysis (RDA), are very laborious and require selected sample sets. We developed a simple and reproducible method to discover viruses in single serum samples, based on restriction enzyme digestion and sequence-independent single primer amplification (SISPA) of fragments following DNase treatment of the serum, and evaluated its performance on known ones. viruses. Both DNA viruses and RNA viruses were reproducibly identified in 50 µl of serum at a concentration of â‰ˆ106 genome equivalents per mil. Two previously unknown parvoviruses were discovered in bovine sera used as diluents when evaluating the method. The nearly complete genome sequence of each virus was determined; Their classification as two species (provisionally designated bovine parvoviruses 2 and 3) was confirmed by phylogenetic analysis. Both viruses were found to be frequent contaminants of commercial bovine serum. DNase treatment of serum samples can be a very useful tool for virus discovery. The DNase-SISPA method is suitable for screening large numbers of samples and also enables rapid sequencing of high titer viruses.
authors: Allander, T.;Emerson, S. U.;Engle, R. E.;Purcell, R. H.;Bukh, J.

title: Cloning of a human parvovirus by molecular screening of respiratory tract samples
abstract: Identification of new virus strains is a key issue for infectious disease studies, but is technically very challenging. We developed a system for large-scale molecular virus screening of clinical samples based on host DNA depletion, random PCR amplification, large-scale sequencing and bioinformatics. The technology was applied to pooled human respiratory samples. Initial experiments detected seven human virus strains without the use of any specific reagents. Among the viruses detected were a coronavirus and a parvovirus, both of which were unidentified at the time. Parvovirus, provisionally termed human bocavirus, was in a retrospective clinical study that was detected in 17 additional patients and was associated with lower respiratory tract infections in children. The molecular virus screening procedure provides a culture-independent solution to the problem of detecting unknown virus strains in single or pooled samples. We propose that a systematic discovery of viruses infecting humans, the 'human virome', can be initiated.
authors: Allander, T.;Tammi, M. T.;Eriksson, M.;Bjerkner, A.;Tiveljung-Lindell, A.;Andersson, B.

title: Estimation of viral richness from shotgun metagenomes using a frequency counting approach
abstract: BACKGROUND: Viruses are important drivers of ecosystem functions, but little is known about the vast majority of viruses. Viral shotgun metagenomics enables exploration of broad ecological questions in phage communities. An ecological feature is species richness, which is the number of different species in a community. Viruses do not have a similar phylogenetic mark to the bacterial 16S rRNA gene to predict richness, and thus contiguous spectra are used to quantify the number of virus taxa in a given community. A contig spectrum is constructed from a viral shotgun metagenome by pooling random sequence reads into groups of overlapping (contig) sequences and counting the number of sequences grouped in each contig. Available tools for analyzing adjacent spectra to estimate phage richness are limited based on sequencing abundance data. RESULTS: We present statistical estimates of virus richness from contig spectra. The CatchAll program (http://www.northeastern.edu/catchall/) was used to analyze adjacent spectra for frequency number data rather than sequencing abundance, thus making formal statistical analyzes possible. Also, the effect of potentially spurious low-frequency counts on wealth estimates was minimized by two methods, empirical and statistical. The results show higher viral richness estimates than previous calculations in almost all media analyzed, including pig feces and purified fresh water. RESULTS: CatchAll yielded consistent richness estimates among viral metagenomes from the same or similar environments. In addition, analysis of pooled viral metagenomes from different environments via mixed contiguous spectra resulted in greater richness estimates than that of component metagenomes. Using CatchAll to analyze contig spectra will provide statistical richness measures, improving richness estimates from viral shotgun metagenomes, particularly large datasets.
authors: Allen, H. K.;Bunge, J.;Foster, J. A.;Bayles, D. O.;Stanton, T. B.

title: Antibiotics in feed induce prophages in pig fecal microbiomes
abstract: Antibiotics are a cost-effective tool to improve feed efficiency and prevent disease in agricultural animals, but the full extent of their side effects is not understood. Antibiotics have been shown to mediate gene transfer by inducing prophages in certain bacterial strains; therefore, a side effect may be prophage induction in the gut microbiome in general. Here we used metagenomics to evaluate the effect of two antibiotics in feed (carbadox and ASP250 [chlortetracycline, sul-famethazine and penicillin]) on porcine intestinal phage metagenomes (viromes). We also monitored bacterial communities using 16S rRNA gene sequencing. ASP250, but not carbadox, caused significant population shifts in both phage and bacterial communities. Antibiotic resistance genes, such as multidrug-resistant efflux pumps, were identified in viromes, but in-feed antibiotics did not cause significant changes in their abundance. The abundance of phage integrase-encoding genes was significantly increased in medicated porcine viromes than in unmedicated porcine viromes, suggesting that prophages were induced by antibiotic treatment. Phage-bacteria population dynamics were also examined. We observed a reduction in the relative abundance of Streptococcus bacteria (prey) when Streptococcus phages (predators) were abundant, supporting the "kill the winner" ecological model of population dynamics in the pig fecal microbiome. The data show that gut ecosystem dynamics are affected by phages and prophage induction is a side effect of in-feed antibiotics. Â© 2011 Allen et al.
authors: Allen, H. K.;Looft, T.;Bayles, D. O.;Humphrey, S.;Levine, U. Y.;Alt, D.;Stanton, T. B.

title: Baltic Sea virome: diversity and transcriptional activity of DNA and RNA viruses
authors: Allen, L. Z.;McCrow, J. P.;Ininbergs, K.;Dupont, C. L.

title: ICTV virus classification profile: Asfarviridae
abstract: The Asfarviridae family includes the only species of African swine fever virus whose isolates have linear dsDNA genomes of 170-194 kbp. Virions have an inner core, an inner lipid membrane, an icosahedral capsid, and an outer lipid envelope. Infection of domestic pigs and wild boars results in acute hemorrhagic fever transmitted by contact or ingestion or by ticks of the genus Ornithodoros. Domestic pigs serve as reservoirs in Africa, where infection is endemic and introductions to Europe occur periodically. This is a summary of the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV) Report on Asfarviridae taxonomy available at www.ictv.global/report/asfarviridae.
authors: Alonso, C.;Borca, M.;Dixon, L.;Revilla, Y.;Rodriguez, F.;Escribano, J. M.;Lefkowitz, E. J.;Davison, A. J.;Siddell, S. G.;Simmonds, P.;Sabanadzovic, S.;Smith, D. B.;Orton, R. J.;Harrach, B.

title: Epidemiological study of air filtration systems to prevent PRRSV infection in large herds of pigs
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) is the most economically important pathogen in the US swine industry. Aerosol transmission between flocks is a major concern in pig-dense areas, and filtration of incoming air along with standard biosecurity procedures has been shown to prevent PRRSV from infecting sensitive flocks. To quantify the effect of air filtration on reducing the risk of PRRSV outbreaks, we compared the incidence rate of new PRRSV entries in 20 filtered and 17 unfiltered control pig herds in a pig-dense region of North America during a 7-year study period. Novel virus entry events were detected by phylogenetic analysis of PRRSV ORF5 gene sequences. Putative novel viruses were identified as exogenous (introduced) based on ORF5 nucleotide sequence differences compared to previous farm isolates. The effect of rank difference cut-off values between 2% and 10% on case definition and relative risk was evaluated. Unfiltered farms suffered about 0.5 outbreaks per year with a seasonal increase in risk during cold periods. Prior to filtration, the baseline risk was about 0.75 per year on treatment farms, about 50% higher than on control farms. Air filtration significantly reduced the risk of PRRSV entry events to 0.06-0.22 outbreaks per year, depending on the thresholds used to classify a virus isolate as new to the flock. Overall, air filtration resulted in an approximately 80% reduction in the risk of introduction of new PRRSV; this suggests that in large pig farms with good biosecurity in pig-dominated areas, about four-fifths of PRRSV outbreaks can be attributed to aerosol transmission. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Alonso, C.;Murtaugh, M. P.;Dee, S. A.;Davies, P. R.

title: Characterization of the H5N1 influenza a virus that caused the first highly pathogenic avian influenza outbreak in Saudi Arabia
abstract: Introduction: Saudi Arabia (SA) experienced a highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 outbreak in domestic birds in 2007. Methodology: 43 hemagglutinin (HA) and 41 neuraminidase (NA) genes of HPAI H5N1 viruses were sequenced and phylogenetic analyzes were performed. Fully sequenced genes were made for comparison with other viral HA and NA gene sequences found in public databases. Results: Molecular characterization of H5N1 viruses revealed two genetically distinct segments of H5N1 viruses circulating in the region, 2.2.2 and 2.3.1. Amino acid sequence analysis of the HA gene showed that the virus of 2.2.2 contained the sequence SPQGERRRK-R/G at the cleavage site, while the virus of 2.3.1 contained the sequence SPQRERRRK-R/G. In addition, several mutations with amino acid substitutions, such as M226I, at the N-bond glycosylation site were detected in two of these isolates. The amino acid sequence of the NA gene showed a deletion of 20 amino acids in the NA stem region, which is essential for increased virulence of influenza viruses and their adaptation from wild birds to domestic chickens. Because close contact between humans and birds is inevitable, a thorough understanding of virus epidemiology, factors influencing virus spread, and molecular characterization, such as the phylogeny and substitution rates of H5N1 viruses circulating in the region, is needed. Conclusion: Two genetically distinct clades were found circulating in the country, possibly leading to recombination and the emergence of more virulent viral strains. These findings could help authorities develop control measures against these viruses.
authors: Al-Qahtani, A. A.;Mubin, M.;Almajhdi, F. N.;Alarifi, S.;Cruz, D. M. D.;ul Rehman, M. S. N.;Ismail, M. M.;Ahmed, N.;Al-Blowi, M. H.;Khalak, H.;Al-Ahdal, M. N.

title: ARTIFICIAL DISTRIBUTION OF CHICKEN ANEMIA VIRUS IN TISSUE, FEET AND ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES UP TO DAY 56 â€¦
authors: Alsharari, M.;Islam, Afmf;Renz, K. G.;Burgess, S. K.

title: Molecular characterization of the first strains of bovine herpes virus 4 (BoHV-4) isolated from in vitro bovine embryo production in Argentina
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus 4 (BoHV-4) is increasingly recognized as responsible for various problems of the reproductive system. The virus mainly infects blood mononuclear cells and shows specific tropism for vascular endothelium, reproductive and fetal tissues. Epidemiological studies reveal its impact on reproductive performance, and its presence at various sites in the reproductive system highlights its potential contamination in transfer-stage embryos. This study describes the biological and genetic characterization of BoHV-4 strains isolated from an in vitro bovine embryo production system. BoHV-4 strains were isolated in 2011 and 2013 from granulosa cells and bovine oocytes from batches of ovaries collected at a local abattoir, which were used as "starting material" for the in vitro production of bovine embryos. Compatible BoHV-4-CPE was observed in co-culture of MDBK cells with granulosa cells and oocytes. The identity of the isolates was confirmed by PCR experiments targeting the three ORFs of the viral genome. Phylogenetic analyzes of the strains show that they are evolutionarily unrelated. Thus, it is possible, at least in Argentina, that BoHV-4 ovarian infections have occurred regularly throughout the evolution of the virus, and this may have implications for in vitro embryo production systems. Thus, although BoHV-4 does not appear to be a common risk factor for in vitro embryo production, data are still limited. This study demonstrates the potential for BoHV-4 transmission through embryo transfer. Furthermore, the high variability among BoHV-4 strains isolated from cows aborted in Argentina highlights the importance of further research into the role of this virus as a potential agent to cause reproductive disease in cattle. Genetic characterization of isolated strains provides data to better understand the pathogenesis of BoHV-4 infections. It will also lead to fundamental understandings of the molecular aspects of the virus and the circulatory pathways of these strains in flocks.
