title: Broad-spectrum, single-step reverse transcription PCR amplification of the neuraminidase gene from multiple subtypes of influenza A virus.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The emergence of highly pathogenic strains of Influenza A virus in a variety of human and animal hosts with wide geographic distribution has highlighted the importance of rapid identification and subtyping of the virus for epidemic management and treatment. Type A virus can be subtyped according to viral envelope glycoproteins, hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. Here, we review the current specificity and amplification of published primers for the subtype of neuraminidase genes and describe a novel broad-spectrum primer pair capable of detecting all 9 neuraminidase subtypes. RESULTS: Bioinformatic analysis of 3,337 full-length influenza A neuraminidase segments in the NCBI database revealed semi-conserved regions not previously targeted by primers. Two degenerate primers with M13 tags, NA8F-M13 and NA10R-M13, were designed from these regions and used to construct a 253 bp cDNA product. One-step RT-PCR testing was successful in 31/32 (97%) cases using a contact protocol with RNA from more than 32 different cultured influenza A virus strains representing 9 neuraminidase subtypes. Frozen blind clinical nasopharyngeal aspirates were also tested and mostly belonged to the N2 subtype. The amplified region was directly sequenced and then used in database searches to confirm the identity of the template RNA. The generated RT-PCR fragment contains H274Y, one of the mutation sites associated with oseltamivir resistance. CONCLUSION: Our one-step RT-PCR assay after sequencing is a fast, accurate and specific method for detecting and subtyping different neuraminidase subtypes from a range of host species and different geographic locations.
authors: Alvarez, A. C.;Brunck, M. E.;Boyd, V.;Lai, R.;Virtue, E.;Chen, W.;Bletchly, C.;Heine, H. G.;Barnard, R.

title: Double-stranded RNA high-throughput sequencing reveals a novel cytorhabdovirus in the common bean transgenic line resistant to bean gold mosaic virus.
abstract: Using double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) high-throughput sequencing, we identified five RNA viruses in a common bean transgenic line resistant to bean gold mosaic virus (BGMV) with symptoms of viral infection. Of the viruses identified, four have already been identified as infecting beans (cowpea mild spot virus, bean rugose mosaic virus, Phaseolus vulgaris alphaendornavirus 1 and Phaseolus vulgaris alphaendornavirus 2), and one is a new plant rhabdovirus (genus Cytorhabdovirus), tentatively named. bean-associated cytorhabdovirus (BaCV). The BaCV genome presented all five open reading frames (ORFs) found in most rhabdoviruses: nucleoprotein (N) (ORF1) (451 amino acids, aa), phosphoprotein (P) (ORF2) (445 aa), matrix (M) (ORF4) (287 aa), glycoprotein (G) (ORF5) (520 aa), and an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (L) (ORF6) (114 aa), as well as a putative movement protein (P3) (ORF3) (189 aa) and the hypothetical small protein P4. The predicted BaCV proteins were compared with homologous proteins from the closest cytorhabdoviruses, and a low level of sequence identity (15%-39%) was observed. Phylogenetic analysis shows that BaCV clusters with yerba mate chlorosis-associated virus (YmCaV) and rice strip mosaic virus (RSMV). Overall, our results provide strong evidence that BaCV is indeed a new strain of virus from the genus Cytorhabdovirus (family Rhabdoviridae), which was the first rhabdovirus to infect beans.
authors: Alves-Freitas, D. M. T.;Pinheiro-Lima, B.;Faria, J. C.;Lacorte, C.;Ribeiro, S. G.;Melo, F. L.

title: Sprinkles, viruses and virome: new directions in therapy
authors: Ambadapadi, S.;Chen, H.;Zheng, D.;Liu, L.;Dai, E.

title: Bovine-like coronaviruses in domestic and wild ruminants
abstract: Coronaviruses (CoVs) produce a wide range of disease syndromes in different mammalian and avian host species. These viruses are recognized for their ability to alter tissue tropism, overcome interspecies barriers, and adapt to ecological variations. The natural genetic diversity of CoVs, caused by the accumulation of point mutations and the high frequency of homologous recombination, is predicted to be the main determinant of these competencies. Various CoVs (eg, severe acute respiratory syndrome-CoV, Middle East respiratory syndrome-CoV) have been noted to cross the interspecies barrier and induce different disease conditions in variable animal hosts. Bovine CoV (BCoV) is the leading cause of gastroenteritis and respiratory disease in cattle calves, winter dysentery in lactating cows, and transport fever pneumonia in livestock cattle. Although long recognized as a restrictive bovine pathogen, CoVs closely related to BCoV have been identified in dogs, humans, and other ruminant species. Biological, antigenic and genetic analyzes of the so-called 'bovine-like CoVs' suggested that these viruses be classified as host-range variants rather than distinct virus strains. This review discusses the different bovine-like CoVs identified in domesticated ruminants (buffalo, sheep, goat, dromedary, llama, and alpaca) and wild ruminant animals (deer, buffalo, antelope, giraffe, and wild goat). in terms of epidemiology, transmission and virus characteristics. The presented data demonstrate the importance of these viruses in the survival of BCoV in the wild, its spread to new geographic areas, and the continued emergence of disease outbreaks in cattle farms.
authors: Amer, H. M.

title: Metagenomic analysis shows the diversity of fecal virome in asymptomatic pigs from East Africa.
abstract: Pigs harbor a variety of viruses closely related to human viruses and suspected of having zoonotic potential. Little is known about the presence of viruses on small farms where pigs are in close contact with humans and wildlife. This study provides insight into the prevalence and characteristics of viral communities and enteric viral coinfections in small farm pigs from East Africa. Sequence-independent amplification and high-throughput sequencing were applied to metagenomic analysis of viruses in faeces collected from asymptomatic pigs. A total of 47,213 de novo-assembled contigs were generated and compared to sequences in the GenBank database. Blastx search results revealed that 1039 contigs (>200Â nt) were associated with viral sequences in the GenBank database. Of 1039 contigs, 612 were not assigned to any viral taxa as they had little similarity to known viral genomic or protein sequences, while 427 contigs had a high level of sequence similarity to known viruses and were assigned to viral taxa. The most common contigs associated with mammalian viruses similar to members of the viral genera Astrovirus, Rotavirus, Bocavirus, Circovirus and Kobuvirus. Other less abundant contigs were related to members of the Sapelovirus, Pasivirus, Posavirus, Teschovirus and Picobirnavirus genera. This is the first report of the fecal virus diversity of pig populations in East Africa. The findings of this study help to elucidate the etiology of diarrheal diseases in pigs and to identify potential zoonotic and emerging viruses in the region. More research is needed to compare the incidence of these viruses in healthy and diseased pigs to better elucidate their pathogenic role.
authors: Amimo, J. O.;El Zowalaty, M. E.;Githae, D.;Wamalwa, M.;Djikeng, A.;Nasrallah, G. K.

title: Association of increased condemnation of broiler carcasses due to liver abnormalities and immunosuppressive diseases in the broiler industry in Saskatchewan
abstract: The aim of this study was to determine the hepatitis agents observed during processing in broiler chickens. Livers of chickens with severe hepatitis lesions were collected during processing from 16 broiler farms in Saskatchewan. In addition to routine bacterial isolation and histopathological examination, serological studies for infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) and Chicken anemia virus (CAV), calculation of the ratio of Fabricius (BF) bursa weight to body weight (BBW), and histopathological examination of BF were performed. Of 264 livers with large lesions, 83% had confluent multifocal necrotizing hepatitis, 16% had perihepatitis and 1% had bleeding. No definitive causative microorganisms were isolated from the hepatic lesions; however, no significant bacterial isolation has been performed. Bursal atrophy, low BBW rate, and high antibody titer to IBDV correlated with overall rejection rate (P = 0.0188, P = 0.0001 and P = 0.0073, respectively). The nucleotide sequence of IBDV isolated from BF identified Delaware-E and 586 variant strains. Conflict due to hepatic lesions correlated with antibody titer to IBDV and BBW (P = 0.016 and P = 0.027). The results of this study suggest that hepatic lesions in Saskatchewan chickens are currently not caused by a primary bacterial pathogen, but are associated with indicators of immunosuppression, possibly due to variant IBDV.
authors: Amini, K.;Zachar, T.;Popowich, S.;Knezacek, T.;Goodhope, B.;Willson, P.;Gomis, S.

title: Kiyoshi Tajima1 and Rustam Aminov2* National Agriculture and Food Research Institute, National Livestock Institute
authors: Aminov, R.

title: Pet rodents and fatal lymphocytic choriomeningitis in transplant patients
abstract: In April 2005, 4 transplant recipients fell ill after receiving organs infected with lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV); 3 later died. All organs came from a donor exposed to an LCMV-infected hamster. The hamster was tracked through a Rhode Island pet store to a distribution center in Ohio, and more LCMV-infected hamsters were discovered in both. Rodents from the Ohio facility and its main facility in Arkansas were tested for the same LCMV strain as 1 that has been implicated in transplant-related deaths. Phylogenetic analysis of virus sequences linked rodents from the Ohio facility to the Rhode Island pet store, index hamster, and transplant recipients. This report details animal backtracking and supporting laboratory research.
authors: Amman, B. R.;Pavlin, B. I.;Albarino, C. G.;Comer, J. A.;Erickson, B. R.;Oliver, J. B.;Sealy, T. K.;Vincent, M. J.;Nichol, S. T.;Paddock, C. D.;Tumpey, A. J.;Wagoner, K. D.;Glauer, R. D.;Smith, K. A.;Winpisinger, K. A.;Parsely, M. S.;Wyrick, P.;Hannafin, C. H.;Bandy, U.;Zaki, S.;Rollin, P. E.;Ksiazek, T. G.

title: Genetic characterization of 2008 reassortant influenza A virus (H5N1), Thailand
abstract: In January and November 2008, avian influenza outbreaks were reported in 4 provinces of Thailand. Eight Influenza A H5N1 viruses were rescued from these 2008 AI outbreaks and were extensively characterized and analyzed for nucleotide identity, genetic kinship, virulence determinants and possible reclassification sites. The results show that 2008 H5N1 viruses exhibit genetic drift features (genetic differences of less than 3%) as commonly found in influenza A viruses. Based on the phylogenetic analysis, the 1st division viruses in Thailand were divided into 3 distinct clades (subdivisions 1, 1.1 and 1.2). Six of the 8 H5N1 isolates were identified as reclassified H5N1 viruses, while the other isolates belonged to an original H5N1 strain. These viruses have undergone interlinear reclassification between subgroups 1.1 and 1.2 and thus represent the newly reclassified 2008 H5N1 viruses. The reclassified viruses acquired gene segments from H5N1, subsection 1.1 (PA, HA, NP, and M) and subsection 1.2 (PB2, PB1, NA, and NS) in Thailand. Bootscan analysis of the combined whole genome sequences of 2008 H5N1 viruses supported reclassification regions between subdivision 1.1 and 1.2 viruses. Based on an estimation of the time of the most recent common ancestor of the 2008 H5N1 viruses, the potential point of genetic reclassification of viruses can be traced back to 2006. Genetic analysis of 2008 H5N1 viruses showed that it was the most virulence determinant of all 8 viruses. genes of viruses remained unchanged. In summary, two dominant H5N1 strains were in circulation in 2008. The original CUK2-like lineage circulated mainly in central Thailand, and the reclassified lineage (sub-clans 1.1 and 1.2) circulated predominantly in sub-northern Thailand. To avoid reclassification, consideration should be given to the prevention of H5N1 viruses circulating in high-risk areas. In addition, surveillance and whole genome sequencing of H5N1 viruses should be routinely performed to monitor genetic drift of the virus and newly reclassified strains, particularly in light of the potential reclassification between avian and mammalian H5N1 viruses.
authors: Amonsin, A.;Lapkuntod, J.;Suwannakarn, K.;Kitikoon, P.;Suradhat, S.;Tantilertcharoen, R.;Boonyapisitsopa, S.;Bunpapong, N.;Wongphatcharachai, M.;Wisedchanwet, T.;Theamboonlers, A.;Poovorawan, Y.;Sasipreeyajan, J.;Thanawongnuwech, R.

title: Multi-year evolutionary dynamics of West Nile virus in suburb of Chicago, USA, 2005-2007
abstract: West Nile virus evolved in concert with its spread in North America, but little is known about the evolutionary dynamics of the virus at the local scale. We analyzed viral nucleotide sequences from mosquitoes collected from a known transmission 'hotspot' in the suburbs of Chicago, USA in 2005, 2006 and 2007. Within this approximately 11 × 14 km area, the viral envelope gene increased in genetic diversity at the nucleotide level by about 0.1% per year. Each year, viral diversity was higher in 'residential' areas characterized by dense housing than in more open 'urban green space' areas such as cemeteries and parks. Phylodynamic analyzes showed an increase in incidence around 2005, consistent with a higher-than-average peak in mosquito and human infection rates that year. Recent analyzes of common ancestry suggest that WNV in 2005 and 2006 may have predominantly originated from viruses present in 2004 and 2005, respectively, but WNV in 2007 had an older common ancestry, perhaps predominantly mixed. or indicates an external origin. These results suggest that the WNV population in suburban Chicago is a mix of viruses, both locally derived and brought from elsewhere, containing evolutionary information gathered over a wide spatial and temporal scale. © 2010 Royal Society.
authors: Amore, G.;Bertolotti, L.;Hamer, G. L.;Kitron, U. D.;Walker, E. D.;Ruiz, M. O.;Brawn, J. D.;Goldberg, T. L.

title: Genetic analysis of Akabane virus isolates from cattle in Korea
abstract: Bayesian Inference (BI) and Neighborhood Joining (NJ) analyzes of phylogenetic relationships between the nucleotide sequences of the N gene of Akabane virus revealed an uncertain topology between genogroups I-III, possibly resulting from genetic reassortment or recombination between these genogroups. In contrast, nucleotide and amino acid phylogenetic tree analyzes of the M RNA segment were in agreement with topologies obtained using the BI and NJ methods. Therefore, differential genogrouping of Akabane virus isolates should be performed using the M RNA segment. Four Korean isolates were classified in genogroup II, with Akabane virus strains isolated from all regions of Japan, including Okinawa Island. However, more isolates nationwide and clinical data from Korean cattle farms will be required in the future to confirm precise relationships between genotypes and pathogenicity. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: An, D. J.;Yoon, S. H.;Jeong, W.;Kim, H. J.;Park, B. K.

title: The UL31 to UL35 gene sequences of duck enteritis virus correspond to their homologues in herpes simplex virus.
abstract: Five ORFs in the Duck enteritis virus (DEV) genome corresponding to the UL31, UL32, UL33, UL34 and UL35 genes of herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) were amplified, cloned and sequenced by a modified "target gene walk" PCR. The UL33, UL34, and UL35 genes were oriented from left to right of the genome, while UL31 and UL32 had an opposite orientation. Comparison of the deduced amino acid sequences of DEV ORFs with alphaherpes virus homologues showed well-conserved regions outside the UL34 and UL35 genes. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that DEV is closer to the Mardivirus genus than any other genus of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily. Based on this evidence, we proposed assigning DEV to the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae.
authors: An, R.;Li, H.;Han, Z.;Shao, Y.;Liu, S.;Kong, X.

title: Whole genome analysis of epizootic hemorrhagic disease virus identifies restricted genome constellations and preferential reclassification
abstract: Epizootic hemorrhagic disease virus (EHDV) is an orbivirus transmitted by Culicoides that causes hemorrhagic disease in wild and domestic ruminants. A collection of 44 EHDVs isolated from 2008 to 2012 were fully sequenced and phylogenetically analyzed. Serotype 2 viruses were the dominant serotype in all years except 2012, when serotype 6 viruses represented 63% of the isolates. High genetic similarity (>94% identity) between serotype 1 and 2 virus VP1, VP3, VP4, VP6, NS1, NS2 and NS3 segments precluded the identification of reclassification events for these segments. In addition, there was little genetic variation (>96% identity) within the VP2, VP5 and VP7 serotypes. Preferential reassortment within homologous serotype was observed for VP2, VP5 and VP7 segments for type 1 and type 2 viruses. In contrast, type 6 viruses were all reassortants containing VP2 and VP5 derived from an exotic type 6, and the remaining segments were most similar to type 2 viruses. These results show that reclassification between type 1 and type 2 viruses requires preservation of the VP2, VP5, and VP7 segment constellation, while type 6 viruses only require VP2 and VP5 and are limited to the type 2 lineage VP7. Because type 6 VP2 and VP5 segments are specifically identified in viruses with type 2-derived VP7, these results indicate functional complementation between type 2 and type 6 VP7 proteins. © 2014 SGM.
authors: Anbalagan, S.;Cooper, E.;Klumper, P.;Simonson, R. R.;Hause, B. M.

title: Dietary energy drives dynamic response of bovine rumen viral communities
abstract: BACKGROUND: Rumen microbes play a greater role in host energy gain than gut-associated microbes in monogastric animals. While genome-powered developments provide access to a wide variety of uncultivated microbes, our understanding of the variables that shape rumen microbial communities is in its infancy. Viruses have been shown to affect microbial populations through numerous processes, including cell lysis and reprogramming of host metabolism. However, little is known about the processes that shape the distribution of rumen viruses or how viruses modulate microbial-driven processes in the rumen. To this end, we investigated how rumen bacterial and viral community structure and function responded in five cattle fed four randomized dietary treatments in a crossover design. RESULTS: Total digestible nutrients (TDN), a measure of dietary energy, best explained variation in bacterial and viral communities. Additional ecological drivers of viral communities included dietary zinc content and microbial functional diversity. Using partial least squares regression, we demonstrated significant associations between the abundance of 267 viral populations and the variables that drive variation in rumen viral communities. While rumen viruses were dynamic, 14 almost ubiquitous viral populations were identified, suggesting the existence of a core rumen virus composed largely of novel viruses. Furthermore, analysis of virally encoded accessory metabolic genes (AMGs) indicates that rumen viruses have glycosidic hydrolases to potentially increase the breakdown of complex carbohydrates to increase energy production. Other identified AMGs have a role in reorienting carbon to the pentose phosphate pathway and a carbon pool with folate to increase viral replication. RESULTS: We showed that rumen bacteria and viruses have differential responses and ecological drivers to dietary disruption. Our results demonstrate that rumen viruses have implications for understanding the configuration of the predefined core rumen microbiota and influencing microbial metabolism through a wide variety of AMGs. AMGs in the rumen appear to have results that are largely consistent with the established paradigm for microbial metabolism in marine systems. This work provides a basis for future hypotheses regarding the dynamics of viral-mediated processes in the rumen.
authors: Anderson, C. L.;Sullivan, M. B.;Fernando, S. C.

title: Characterization of swine flu A viruses circulating together in North America and identification of a novel H1 genetic lineage with antigenic significance.
abstract: Multiple genetically and antigenically distinct hemagglutinin genes of H1 and H3 influenza A virus (IAV) subtypes circulate together in North American pigs. This diversity has evolved through repeated transmission of IAVs from humans to pigs followed by antigenic drift in pigs. To understand the evolutionary dynamics of these diverse HA lineages in North American pigs, we performed phylogenetic analysis of 1576 H1 and 607 H3 HA gene segments, as well as 834 N1 and 1293 N2 NA gene segments and 2126 M gene segments. These data revealed annual co-circulation of H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 viruses with three HA sequences representing the majority of HA sequences: 42% of H1 viruses were classified as H1Î´1 and 40.6% as H1Î³, and H3 viruses 53%, cluster IV. -A is classified as H3N2. We identified a genetically distinct minor segment, which we classified as H1Î³-2, consisting of 37 H1 viruses isolated between 2003 and 2013. We estimated that this clade has been circulating in pigs since about 1995, but was not detected in pigs until 2003. Although this guideline represents only 1.07% of porcine H1 sequences reported over the last 10 years, hemagglutination inhibition (HI) assays show that this group of viruses is antigenically distinct and is about 7 antigenic units from other H1Î³ viruses when measured using antigenic cartography. Therefore, vaccines against contemporary H1Î³ viruses are unlikely to provide cross-protection against Î³-2 viruses. The long-term circulation of these Î³-2 viruses, given their long branch lengths and gaps in detection, suggests that small virus populations may be underreported in the national dataset. The identification of these Î³-2 viruses illustrates the need for robust surveillance to capture the full range of IAVs in pigs in the USA and the importance of antigenic drift in diversification and the emergence of new antigenic variants, which complicates vaccine design in pigs.
authors: Anderson, T. K.;Campbell, B. A.;Nelson, M. I.;Lewis, N. S.;Janas-Martindale, A.;Killian, M. L.;Vincent, A. L.

title: Phylogeny-Based Global Naming System and Automated Annotation Tool for H1 Hemagglutinin Genes from Swine Flu A Viruses
abstract: The H1 subtype of influenza A viruses (IAVs) has been circulating in pigs since the 1918 human influenza pandemic. Over time and with the aid of additional inputs from non-swine hosts, porcine H1 viruses have diversified into three genetic lineages. Due to limited global data, these H1 strains were named according to colloquial context, leading to a proliferation of inconsistent regional naming conventions. In this study, we propose strict phylogenetic criteria to establish a globally consistent nomenclature of the evolution of the porcine H1 virus hemagglutinin (HA). These criteria, applied to a dataset of 7,070 H1 HA sequences, gave rise to 28 different sequences as the basis for terminology. We have developed and implemented a web-accessible annotation tool that can assign these biologically informative categories to new sequence data. The annotation tool assigned the combined dataset of 7,070 H1 sequences to the correct sequence more than 99% of the time. Our analyzes showed that 87% of porcine H1 viruses from 2010 to the present have HAs from 7 contemporary common circulations. Our nomenclature and web-accessible classification tool provides researchers, diagnosticians, and paramedics with an accurate method for assigning clade assignments to HA sequences. The tool can be easily updated to keep track of evolving terminology as new branches emerge, ensuring continued relevance. A common global nomenclature facilitates comparison of IAVs infecting humans and pigs within and between regions and may provide insight into the diversity of swine H1 influenza virus and its impact on vaccine strain selection, diagnostic reagents and test performance, thereby simplifying such communication. data. IMPORTANCE A basic purpose in biological sciences is to identify groups of organisms based on evolutionary history and to name these groups. For influenza A viruses (IAVs) in pigs, understanding the genetic lineage of the hemagglutinin (HA) of a circulating strain aids vaccine antigen selection and allows inferences about vaccine efficacy. Previous reports of the H1 virus HA in swine often relied on incriminating and stigmatizing geographic place names and colloquial names, making comparisons between studies difficult. To overcome this, we developed an adaptive terminology using quantifiable criteria for historical and contemporary evolutionary patterns of H1 globular porcine IAVs. We've also developed a web-accessible tool that classifies viruses according to this terminology. This classification system provides terminology to aid agricultural production and pandemic preparedness through the identification of significant changes in swine IAVs, and allows swine IAVs to be discussed in a common context between animal and human health initiatives.
authors: Anderson, T. K.;Macken, C. A.;Lewis, N. S.;Scheuermann, R. H.;Van Reeth, K.;Brown, I. H.;Swenson, S. L.;Simon, G.;Saito, T.;Berhane, Y.;Ciacci-Zanella, J.;Pereda, A.;Davis, C. T.;Donis, R. O.;Webby, R. J.;Vincent, A. L.

title: Genetic classification of 'Norwalk-like viruses'
abstract: The reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction has been used worldwide for the diagnosis of Norwalk-like virus (NLV) infection, but a generally accepted genetic classification scheme has not been established. Amino acid sequences from four regions of open reading frame 2 (ORF2) were used to analyze 101 NLV strains, including 2 bovine strains. On the basis of this analysis, a genetic classification scheme is proposed that divides 99 human strains into 2 main genetic groups consisting of 5 and 10 genetic clusters, respectively. The 2 cattle strains form a newly identified third major genetic group consisting of 2 putative clusters represented by each strain. This classification scheme is well supported by analysis of all ORF2 sequences from the 38 strains selected to represent the genetic diversity of the human strains used above. This scheme should provide a solid scientific basis for the unified classification of NLV strains detected worldwide.
authors: Ando, T.;Noel, J. S.;Fankhauser, R. L.

title: Nipah virus infection
abstract: Nipah virus, a paramyxovirus related to Hendra virus, first appeared in Malaysia in 1998. The clinical presentation ranges from asymptomatic infection to fatal encephalitis. No other cases have been reported in Malaysia since 1999, but outbreaks continue to occur in Bangladesh and India. In the Malaysia-Singapore outbreak, transmission occurred mainly by contact with pigs, while in Bangladesh and India it was associated with ingestion of contaminated palm juice and human-to-human transmission. Bats are the main reservoir of this virus, which can cause disease in humans and animals. There is currently no effective therapeutic and supportive care and prevention are the mainstays of management.
authors: Ang, B. S. P.;Lim, T. C. C.;Wang, L.

title: Molecular epidemiology and phylogeny of Nipah virus infection: a mini-review.
abstract: Nipah virus (NiV) is a member of the Henipavirus genus of the Paramyxoviridae family, which is endemic in South Asia and is characterized by high pathogenicity. It is classified as a Biosafety Level-4 (BSL-4) substance. The case fatality rate ranges from 40% to 70%, depending on the severity of the disease and the availability of adequate healthcare facilities. There are currently no antiviral drugs available for NiV disease and treatment is only supportive. Phylogenetic and evolutionary analyzes can be used to aid understanding of the epidemiology and temporal origin of this virus. This review provides an overview of evolutionary studies on Nipah viruses circulating in different countries. Between 2000 and 2015, thirty phylogenetic studies were published in pub-med searching using the keywords “Nipah virus AND phylogeny”, and from 2006 to 2015, twenty-eight molecular epidemiological studies were performed by typing in the keywords. €˜Nipah virus AND molecular epidemiology'. Overall data from the published study, shown as phylogenetic and evolutionary analysis, represent promising tools for proving NiV outbreaks, studying their origin and evolution, and finally acting with effective preventive measures.
authors: Angeletti, S.;Lo Presti, A.;Cella, E.;Ciccozzi, M.

title: Emerging Coxsackievirus A6 that Causes Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease, Vietnam
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a major public health problem in Asia and has the potential for a global pandemic. Coxsackievirus A6 (CV-A6) was detected in 514/2,230 (23%) of HFMD patients admitted to 3 major hospitals in South Vietnam between 2011 and 2015. 93 (18%) of these patients had severe CHF. Phylogenetic analysis of 98 genome sequences revealed that they belonged to cluster A and circulated in Vietnam for 2 years before appearing. While CV-A6 movement among settlements in Vietnam occurred frequently, viral movement across international borders seemed rare. Skyline plots identified fluctuations in the relative genetic diversity of CV-A6, corresponding to major CV-A6-associated HFMD outbreaks worldwide. These data demonstrate that CV-A6 is an emerging pathogen, emphasizing the necessity of active surveillance and understanding of the mechanisms that shape pathogen evolution and emergence necessary for the development and implementation of intervention strategies.
authors: Anh, N. T.;Nhu, L. N. T.;Van, H. M. T.;Hong, N. T. T.;Thanh, T. T.;Hang, V. T. T.;Ny, N. T. H.;Nguyet, L. A.;Phuong, T. T. L.;Nhan, L. N. T.;Hung, N. T.;Khanh, T. H.;Tuan, H. M.;Viet, H. L.;Nam, N. T.;Viet, D. C.;Qui, P. T.;Wills, B.;Sabanathan, S.;Chau, N. V. V.;Thwaites, L.;Rogier van Doorn, H.;Thwaites, G.;Rabaa, M. A.;Van Tan, L.

title: Origin of the 1918 pandemic H1N1 influenza A virus examined by codon usage patterns and phylogenetic analysis
abstract: The 1918 pandemic was caused by an H1N1 influenza A virus, a negative-strand RNA virus; however, little is known about the nature of their direct ancestral lineage. Here, we performed a broad genetic and phylogenetic analysis of a wide variety of influenza virus genes, particularly the PB1 gene, to gain insight into the phylogenetic relevance of the 1918 H1N1 virus. We compared the RNA genome of the 1918 strain with many other influenza strains of different origins in various ways, including relative synonym codon usage (RSCU), effective codon number (ENC) and phylogenetic relationship. We found that the PB1 gene of the 1918 pandemic virus had ENC values similar to H1N1 classical porcine and human viruses, but different ENC values from avian as well as H2N2 and H3N2 human viruses. Furthermore, according to the RSCU of the PB1 gene, the 1918 virus is grouped with all human isolates and "classic" porcine H1N1 viruses. Phylogenetic studies of all eight RNA gene segments of influenza A viruses may indicate that they originated from the 1918 pandemic strain. an H1N1 swine virus that may itself have been derived from an H1N1 avian precursor that long ago separated from the bulk of other avian viruses. The high stability of the RSCU pattern of the PB1 gene, the integrity of the RNA, the structure is more important to the evolution of the influenza virus than previously thought Copyright Â© 2011 RNA Society.
authors: Anhlan, D.;Grundmann, N.;Makalowski, W. H.;Ludwig, S.;Scholtissek, C.

title: Characterization of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N8 virus from Egyptian domestic waterfowl in 2017
abstract: In 2016, the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 virus was detected in wild birds for the first time in Egypt. In this study, we identified the HPAI virus H5N8 of clade 2.3.4.4 from domestic waterfowl in Egypt and suggested transmission of this virus from migratory birds to domestic poultry. Based on the partial hemagglutinin gene sequence, this virus has a close genetic relationship with subtype H5N8 viruses circulating in Asia and Europe. Pathologically, in the hybrid duck, the H5N8 virus caused neural manifestations accompanied by encephalomalacia, hemorrhages, nonsuppurative encephalitis, and nonsuppurative vasculitis. The granular layer of the cerebellum showed areas of multifocal hydropic degeneration and Purkinje cell neurons necrotized or disappeared. There was also lung, kidney, and spleen obstruction, and necrotizing pancreatitis was also observed. The co-circulation of both HPAI H5N1 and H5N8 subtypes with the low pathogenic avian influenza H9N2 subtype complicates the control of avian influenza in Egypt with the possibility of emergence of new reassortant viruses. Therefore, continuous monitoring with the implementation of strict control measures is necessary. Research highlights: HPAI H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 was detected in domestic ducks and geese in Egypt in 2017. Phylogenetically, the virus was closely related to HPAI H5N8 viruses identified in Asia and Europe. Nonsuppurative encephalitis was commonly observed in ducks infected with HPAI H5N8 virus. Degeneration of the cerebellar granular layer was found in most of the brain tissues examined.
authors: Anis, A.;AboElkhair, M.;Ibrahim, M.

title: Two new strains of bocaparvovirus identified in wild Himalayan marmots
abstract: Bocaparvovirus (BOV) is a genetically diverse group of DNA viruses and is a possible cause of respiratory, enteric and neurological diseases in humans and animals. Here, two highly different BOVs (provisionally named Himalayan marmot BOV, HMBOV1 and HMBOV2) were identified in the livers and feces of wild Himalayan marmots in China by viral metagenomic analysis. Five of 300 liver samples from Himalayan marmots were positive for HMBOV1, and five of 99 stool samples from these animals were positive for HMBOV2. The nearly complete genome sequences are 4,672 and 4,887 nucleotides long, respectively, with a standard genomic organization and containing the protein coding motifs typical of BOVs. NS1, NP1 and VP1, HMBOV1 and HMBOV2 are most closely related to porcine BOV SX/1-2 (about 77.0/50.0%, 50.0/53.0 and 79.0/54.0% amino acid identity, respectively) . ). Phylogenetic analysis of these three proteins showed that HMBOV1 and HMBOV2 form two separate independent branches in BOVs. According to these results, HMBOV1 and HMBOV2 are two different new species within the genus Bocaparvovirus. Their identification expands our knowledge of the genetic diversity and evolution of BOVs. More studies are needed to explore their potential pathogenicity and effects on Himalayan marmots and humans.
authors: Ao, Y.;Li, X.;Li, L.;Xie, X.;Jin, D.;Yu, J.;Lu, S.;Duan, Z.

title: Various novel astroviruses identified in wild Himalayan marmots
abstract: With advances in viral surveillance and next-generation sequencing, a wide variety of new astroviruses (AstVs) and different animal hosts have been discovered in recent years. However, the presence of AstVs in marmots has not yet been demonstrated. Here, we identified two highly different strains of AstV (provisionally named Qinghai Himalayanmarmot AstVs, HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2) by viral metagenomic analysis in liver tissues isolated from wild Marmota himalaya in China. Overall, 12 (12.1%) of 99 M. himalaya stool samples were positive for the presence of genetically diverse AstVs, with only HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2 identified in 300 liver samples. The complete genomic sequences of HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2 were 6681 and 6610 nt in length, respectively, with the typical genomic organization of AstVs. Analysis of the complete ORF 2 sequence showed that these novel AstVs were most closely related to rabbit AstV, mamastrovirus 23 (with common amino acid identity of 31.0% and 48.0%, respectively). Phylogenetic analysis of the amino acid sequences of ORF1a, ORF1b and ORF2 indicated that HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2 form two distinct clusters among mamastroviruses and may share a common ancestor with rabbit-specific mamastrovirus 23. These results indicate that HHMAstV1 and HHMAstV2 are two novelties. Species of the Mamastrovirus genus in Astroviridae. The remarkable diversity of these new AstVs will contribute to a better understanding of the evolution and ecology of AstVs, but additional studies will be needed to understand the clinical significance of these new AstVs in humans as well as marmots.
authors: Ao, Y. Y.;Yu, J. M.;Li, L. L.;Cao, J. Y.;Deng, H. Y.;Xin, Y. Y.;Liu, M. M.;Lin, L.;Lu, S.;Xu, J. G.;Duan, Z. J.

title: Wild-type gross leukemia virus: classification of soluble antigens (GSA)

title: Airborne infection by enteric bacteria among poultry
authors: Applegate, T.

title: Phylodynamics of avian influenza clade 2.2.1 H5N1 viruses in Egypt
abstract: Background: Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) viruses of the H5N1 subtype are widely distributed in poultry populations in Egypt and have caused multiple human infections. Linking epidemiological and sequencing data is important for understanding the transmission, persistence, and evolution of the virus. This study describes the phylogenetic dynamics of H5N1 based on molecular characterization of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene from isolates collected from February 2006 to May 2014. Methods: Full-length HA sequences of 368 H5N1 viruses were generated and genetically analyzed. evolution. They were collected from different poultry species, production sectors and geographic locations in Egypt. The Bayes Markov Chain Monte Carlo (BMCMC) method was applied to estimate the evolution rates between different virus clusters; In addition, an analysis of selection pressures in the HA gene was performed using the Single Likelihood Assignment Counting (SLAC) method. Results: Phylogenetic analysis of the H5 gene from 2006-14 showed the presence of a virus entry in the classical clade (2.2.1) from which two major subgroups originated, the variant subgroup further subdivided into 2 (2.2.1.1 and 2.2.1.1a) and endemic subgroup (2.2.1.2). The 2.2.1.2 sequence showed a high rate of evolution over a 6-year period (6.9 × 10-3 sub/domain/year) compared to the variable set 2.2.1.1a (7.2 × 10-3). 4 years). These two clusters are under positive selection because they have 5 positively selected regions in the HA gene. Mutations in HA antigenic regions 120, 154, and 162, and two other mutations occurring between 2009-14 (129Î”, I151T) were found to be stable in the 2.2.1.2 guideline. In addition, 13 groups of H5N1 HPAI viruses were identified based on their amino acid sequences at the cleavage site, with "EKRRKKR" becoming the dominant pattern from 2013. Results: Continuous evolution of H5N1 HPAI viruses was observed in all poultry and poultry farming in Egypt. Production systems in almost all regions of the country. The extensive circulation of the 2.2.1.2 flap, which carries triple mutations (120, 129Î”, I151T) associated with increased binding affinity to human receptors, is a finding of major public health concern.
authors: Arafa, A.;El-Masry, I.;Kholosy, S.;Hassan, M. K.;Dauphin, G.;Lubroth, J.;Makonnen, Y. J.

title: Whole genome characterization of avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 from a commercial quail flock in Egypt.
abstract: The suspected presence of avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 in poultry in Egypt is of great concern as this subtype is widely distributed in different countries in the Middle East, here we describe the complete genetic characterization of an avian influenza A virus (Qa/Egypt/11 ; H9N2) subtype H9N2 was previously isolated in May 2011 from a clinically normal quail flock in Giza, Egypt. %) circulating between 2006-2010. Sequence homology and phylogenetic analysis showed that the Qa/Corn/11 isolate belongs to the A/quail/Hong Kong/G1/1997-like lineage group with novel mutations identified in all viral proteins. Phylogenetic analysis for the eight genes showed that the Egyptian virus was placed in the same lineage of H9N2 viruses that have been circulating in the region since 2006, specifically a group of new Israeli strains. However, phylogenetic analysis of internal genes such as the PB2, NP and PA genes identified possible reclassification events for these genes with individual Israeli strains. This study demonstrates the gradual evolution of this subtype in the Middle East region and the possible mechanism of virus adaptation in terrestrial poultry such as quails. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Arafa, A. S.;Hagag, N.;Erfan, A.;Mady, W.;El-Husseiny, M.;Adel, A.;Nasef, S.

title: Characterization of Sri Lankan rabies virus isolates using nucleotide sequence analysis of the nucleoprotein gene.
abstract: In 1995-1996, 34 suspected rabid brain samples were collected from 2 humans, 24 dogs, 4 cats, 2 mongoose, 1 jackal and 1 buffalo in Sri Lanka. Total RNA was extracted directly from brain suspensions and examined using a one-step reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for the rabies virus nucleoprotein (N) gene. Twenty-eight samples were found positive for the virus N gene by RT-PCR and also for virus antigens by fluorescent antibody (FA) testing. Rabies virus isolates from different animal species from different regions of Sri Lanka were genetically homogeneous. The sequences of the 203 nucleotide (nt) long RT-PCR product obtained from 16 of 27 samples were found to be identical. The sequences of 1350 nt N genes of 14 RT-PCR products were determined. The Sri Lankan isolates studied constituted a specific cluster that also included an earlier isolate from India but did not include known isolates from China, Thailand, Malaysia, Israel, Iran, Oman, Saudi Arabia, Russia, Nepal, Philippines, Japan, and India. few other countries. These results suggest that one type of rabies virus circulates among humans, dogs, cats, mongoose, jackals, and buffaloes living near Colombo City and five other remote areas of Sri Lanka.
authors: Arai, Y. T.;Takahashi, H.;Kameoka, Y.;Shiino, T.;Wimalaratne, O.;Lodmell, D. L.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of classical swine fever virus isolates from Peru
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF) is considered endemic in Peru, with outbreaks reported to the World Organization for Animal Health as recently as 2008 and 2009. However, little is known about the genetic subsets of the CSF virus circulating in Peru. or their association with recent CSF viruses isolated from neighboring South American countries or other parts of the world. In this study, we molecularly characterized CSF viruses isolated from domestic pigs in different regions of Peru from mid-2007 to early 2008. have been identified from other South American countries. Although Peruvian isolates are most closely related to viruses from Colombia and Brazil, they form a monophyletic lineage suggesting a distinct evolutionary history. Â©2010 Canadian Food Inspection Agency.
authors: AraÃ­nga, M.;Hisanaga, T.;Hills, K.;Handel, K.;Rivera, H.;Pasick, J.

title: Migratory birds in southern Brazil are the source of multiple avian influenza virus subtypes.
abstract: BACKGROUND: There is insufficient information about the relationship of avian influenza virus (AIV) with migratory birds in South America. Accordingly, we examined specimens obtained from wild birds over a 4-year period (2009-2012) at a large wintering site in southern Brazil. METHODS: We obtained 1212 oropharyngeal/cloacal specimens from wild birds in Lagoa do Peixe National Park and screened them for influenza A virus by RT-PCR amplification of the matrix gene. Virus isolates were subjected to genomic sequencing and antigenic characterization. RESULTS: Forty-eight samples (3.96%) of 1212 contained detectable influenza virus RNA. Partial viral sequences were obtained from 12 of these samples, indicating the presence of H2N2 (1), H6Nx (1), H6N1 (8), H9N2 (1) and H12N5 (1) viruses. As H6 viruses predominate, we generated complete genomes from all 9 H6 viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that they were most similar to viruses of South American ancestry. H6N1 viruses caused no signs of disease in infected ferrets and were antigenically similar to North American isolates despite genetic differences. CONCLUSIONS: Lagoa do Peixe National Park is the source of several AIV subtypes, with avian influenza virus levels being highest in this region at the end of the overwintering period. H6N1 viruses were the dominant subtype identified. These viruses were more similar to viruses of South American ancestry than those of North American ancestry.
authors: Araujo, J.;Petry, M. V.;Fabrizio, T.;Walker, D.;Ometto, T.;Thomazelli, L. M.;Scherer, A. L.;Serafini, P. P.;Neto, I. S.;Krauss, S.;Webster, R. G.;Webby, R. J.;Durigon, E. L.

title: Isolation and rapid identification of Kerala isolate of duck enteritis virus using polymerase chain reaction
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) is a herpes virus that causes an acute, contagious and deadly disease. In this article, we present a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay for DEV DNA. The method used primer sets targeting the viral DNA polymerase gene (UL30), membrane protein type I that binds to heparin sulfate (glycoprotein C), and glycoprotein E of DEV, and was able to amplify DNA fragments of the expected size from infected samples. The method will provide a valuable tool for rapid laboratory diagnosis of DEV infection. Thanks to its high-throughput format, the method can be useful for large epidemiological studies and elucidation of pathogenesis such as virus delay.
authors: Aravind, S.;Kamble, N. M.;Gaikad, S. S.;Shukla, S. K.;Khulpae, S. A.;Dey, S.;Mohan, C. M.

title: Molecular characteristics of influenza A (H1N1) pdm09 prevalent in Mexico during the 2012-2014 winter seasons.
abstract: Since the outbreak of the pandemic H1N1pdm09 virus in Mexico and California, a two-year increase in the number of cases has been detected in Mexico. Pandemic A/H1N1 09 virus, as seen in previous seasons, was detected in severe cases in the winter season of 2011-2012 and finally became the most common influenza virus in the winter season of 2013-2014. Molecular and phylogenetic analyzes of the entire viral genome are necessary to determine the antigenic and pathogenic characteristics of influenza viruses that cause serious consequences of the disease. This paper analyzed the evolution, antigenic and genetic drift of Mexican isolates from 2009 to 2014 at the start of the pandemic. According to different markers and previous reports of the virus from the 2011-2014 season in Mexico. In this study, we identified 13 novel substitutions with important biological implications, including virulence, MHC-presented T cell epitope and host specificity shift, and some other substitutions may have multiple biological functions. Systematic monitoring of mutations on the entire genome of the influenza A pH1N1 (2009) virus circulating at INER in Mexico City can provide valuable information for predicting the emergence of the new pathogenic influenza virus.
authors: Arellano-Llamas, R.;Alfaro-Ruiz, L.;Canon, C. A.;Rosshandler, II;Cruz-Lagunas, A.;Zuniga, J.;Vega, R. R.;Wong, C. W.;Maurer-Stroh, S.;Cordoba, S. R.;Liu, E. T.;Hidalgo-Miranda, A.;Vazquez-Perez, J. A.

title: Infectious diseases eradication strategies: African swine fever and swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS)
abstract: This publication provides a brief overview of two economically important diseases affecting swine species. Although they are caused by taxonomically distant, different symptomatology and disease-producing viruses, successful strategies have been used for their control and eradication. African swine fever (ASE) is on OIE's A-list and its importance in Europe is due to increased epidemics in sub-Saharan African countries in recent years and swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS). a disease that is not currently on the OIE list but is perhaps one of the biggest problems in international animal health today. In this article, the authors review both the diseases and current strategies used to eradicate ASFV and remove PRRS virus from endemic herds.
authors: Arias, M.;Romero, L.;Aguero, M.;Canals, A.;Zamora, M. J.;Sanchez-Vizcaino, J. M.

title: Common circulatory dynamics and persistence of newly introduced episodes of the 2012 West Nile Virus-associated outbreak in Texas 2012-2015
abstract: The second largest outbreak of West Nile encephalitis and West Nile fever ever recorded occurred in the United States (USA) in the summer of 2012. The outbreak was related to the widespread circulation of closely related branches or groups of West Nile virus (WNV). ) to multiple situations where they have not been before. Whether the invasive 2012 strains circulate and overwinter in states with their own endemic WNV population is unknown, and the impact of viral genetics on adaptation and persistence in a new ecological niche is uncertain. In this study, we sequenced 70 mosquito isolates from multiple counties of Texas between 2012 and 2015. We identified isolates representative of the previously identified 2012 WNV groups (Groups 8–10) and discovered a new group we named Group 11. ) were related to the invasive 2012 strains, of which Group 10 (45/68) predominated. We also observed differences in genotypes among 2012 WNV groups. Group 10 WNV in Texas, carrying two putative positive selected variants, had strong evidence of limited entries into Texas, extensive circulation, and continued persistence, perhaps indicative of overwintering. In contrast, Groups 8 and 11 had multiple entries into Texas, limited circulation, and limited persistence, without positively selected variants. Finally, we identified a potential transmission source in New York for Group 8 WNV arriving in Texas. Altogether, our study suggests that mutations in the WNV genome may affect the range and dynamics of WNV circulation and the ability of different strains to persist in new ecological niches.
authors: Aroh, C.;Liang, C.;Raj, P.;Wakeland, B.;Yan, N.;Wakeland, E.

title: Letter to the editor: Swine flu virus (H1N1) nucleoprotein gene drift causes respiratory disease in pigs
abstract: The nucleoprotein (NP) gene of the swine flu H1N1 variant, A/Sw/Quebec/5393/91 (SwQc91), was sequenced. Compared with other H1N1 strains, 12 amino acid (aa) changes were observed in the 101-484 aa region of the NP protein, including two aas, 345 and 430, which represent the unique lineage of porcine viruses. Phylogenetic analysis showed a shift in the NP gene.
authors: Arora, D. J. S.

title: Pig Astrovirus Type 3 in the Central Nervous System of Pig with Polioencephalomyelitis
abstract: Using next-generation sequencing, we identified and genetically characterized a porcine astrovirus type 3 strain present in tissues from the central nervous system of 1 piglet and 3 sows with neurological signs and non-suppurative polioencephalomyelitis. Further studies are needed to understand the potential for interspecies transmission and clinical effects.
authors: Arruda, B.;Arruda, P.;Hensch, M.;Chen, Q.;Zheng, Y.;Yang, C.;Gatto, I. R. H.;Ferreyra, F. M.;Gauger, P.;Schwartz, K.;Bradner, L.;Harmon, K.;Hause, B.;Li, G.

title: Identification of a Different Lineage Pig Pestivirus in Nursing Piglets with Congenital Tremor and Reproduction of Diseases Following Experimental Vaccination
abstract: Congenital tremors is a sporadic disease of neonatal pigs characterized by action-related recurrent myoclonus. Most outbreaks of congenital tremors have been attributed to an unidentified virus. The objectives of this project were to 1) detect potential pathogen(s) in samples from piglets with congenital tremor, and 2) develop a model of infection to propagate the disease. Using next-generation sequencing, a different strain pestivirus was detected in piglets with congenital tremors. The virus was originally most closely related to a bat pestivirus, but is now more closely related to a recently published new porcine pestivirus, tentatively referred to as atypical porcine pestivirus. A quantitative real-time PCR detected the virus in samples from newborn piglets with congenital tremors from two separate farms, but not in samples from unaffected piglets from the same farm. To achieve the latter objective, pregnant sows were inoculated with serum containing pestivirus or PBS (control) intravenously and intranasally simultaneously with direct inoculation of fetal amniotic vesicles by ultrasound-guided surgical technique. Vaccines were given on days 45 or 62 of pregnancy. Control piglets vaccinated with PBS were unaffected, while piglets vaccinated with the novel pestivirus were all affected by congenital tremors. Shivering severity for each piglet was scored from videos taken at 0, 1, and 2 days after calving. For most piglets, tremor severity remained relatively constant from 0 to 2 days post rearing. The prevalence of congenital shivering in pestivirus-vaccinated litter ranges from 57% (4 out of 7 affected piglets) to 100% (10 out of 10 affected piglets). The virus was consistently detected by PCR in tissues from piglets with congenital tremors, but not in control piglets. Specimens that were positive by PCR in over 90% of piglets sampled included brainstem (37 out of 41), mesenteric lymph node (37 out of 41), tracheobronchial lymph node (37 out of 41), and complete blood (19 out of 20) is found. . Although the first description of congenital tremors was in 1922, this is the first reported reproduction of congenital tremors following experimental vaccination with a different strain swine pestivirus. Studies investigating the disease mechanism, epidemiology, and diagnostic assay development are needed to better understand the pathophysiology of congenital tremors associated with this pestivirus.
authors: Arruda, B. L.;Arruda, P. H.;Magstadt, D. R.;Schwartz, K. J.;Dohlman, T.;Schleining, J. A.;Patterson, A. R.;Visek, C. A.;Victoria, J. G.

title: Genetic ancestor of external antigens of pandemic influenza A/H1N1 virus
abstract: The aim of this research is to discover the genetic relationships of the 2009 pandemic novel influenza A/H1N1 virus (NIV) external antigens Hemagglutinin (HA) and Neuraminidase (NA) with other influenza viruses by performing phylogenetic, comparative and statistical analyzes. Phylogenetic trees of these two antigens show that the sequences of NIV viruses are relatively homogeneous and that they are derived from several viruses circulating in the pig. The phylogenetic tree of HA shows that NIV has the closest relationship with North American pig lines, while NA is with European pig lines. In both segments, NIVs had the closest genetic relationship to swine flu virus strains. It strongly suggests that pigs are the most likely animal reservoir. Comparative analysis shows that among clade A, NIVs have high similarity as well as very low genetic diversity and also undergo strong purification selection, while neighboring clade B shows intermediate values when compared with CF branches. Indicates that the classical swine flu viruses found in part B may be the ancestor of the external antigens of NIVs. There has been a re-diversification process in the classic swine flu viruses. Specifically fixed mutation sites in the NIV of pig and human along with the vaccine strain provide an important recommendation for disease diagnosis and vaccine research.
authors: Arunachalam, R.;Paulkumar, K.;Annadurai, G.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the pandemic influenza A/H1N1 virus
abstract: The principle of this study was to determine the evolution of the pandemic novel influenza A/H1N1 2009 virus (NIV) by phylogenetic, comparative and statistical analysis. Phylogenetic trees of the eight genomic segments show that so far, the sequences of NIVs (outbreak group A) are relatively homogeneous and obtained by multiple genetic reclassifications of Eurasian and North American swine, avian and human viruses (group B). . This means that some group B influenza viruses have a higher potential for human-to-human transmission and development after animal-to-human interspecies transmission. The second analysis shows that NIV attempted minor evolutionary change among humans and had a long evolutionary history before meeting humans. Statistical analysis shows that viruses from both the epidemic and the closest group have homologous genes in their genomes, which may reflect the phylogenetic relationship of the strains, and also that the presence of unique mutations between AB groups may be associated with increased virulence of NIVs. Both phylogenetic and cluster analyzes confirm that gene exchange occurs between viruses originating from different species and that NIV with unpredictable pandemic potential can be generated. Therefore, we conclude that extensive work is required to recognize which reclassification groups are closely related to NIVs and to identify regions in NIV genes under the greatest or lowest selection pressure; this will ultimately be important in effective design. Vaccine and drugs for 'swine flu'.
authors: Arunachalam, R.;Paulkumar, K.;Annadurai, G.

title: Subgroup determination of group a rotaviruses from piglets in Nigeria
abstract: Subgroup analysis using subgroup-specific monoclonal ELISA revealed that subgroup 2-specific antigens of group A porcine rotaviruses were more predominant than subgroup 1. (39.8%) were determined to have subgroup 1 and 2 specificities, respectively. However, 37 (32.7%) test specimens could not be classified into any of the known subgroups of group A rotaviruses. These 'unclassifiable' samples likely lacked neither subgroup 1 nor 2 specificity in the ELISA, or may belong to a third subgroup that was not known or investigated in this study. Subgroup 1 and 2 specific antigens were common in all age groups studied. This was also observed after annual analysis of subgroup specificity; however, a higher prevalence of subgroup 2 specificity was observed in 1990 and 1991. Subgroup 1 rotaviruses were found in all 4 States sampled (Plateau, Benue, Oyo, and Cross River), while subgroup 2 rotaviruses were detected only in Plateau State. All rotaviruses obtained in this study had long genome electrophoretic migration patterns regardless of subgroup. Thus, the genomic diversity of group A rotaviruses does not necessarily reflect antigenic diversity, as there is no imperative correlation between the genome electropherotype pattern and subgroup specificity.
authors: Atii, D. J. I.;Ojeh, C. K.

title: Metagenomic virome analysis of Culex mosquitoes from Kenya and China

title: Integrated use of three machine learning techniques for influenza virus classification
authors: Attaluri, P. K.;Chen, Z.;Lu, G.

title: Effects of orally administered Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus on welfare and Salmonella colonization of young chicks
abstract: Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus is a bacterium that preys on and kills Gram-negative bacteria, including the zoonotic pathogens Escherichia coli and Salmonella. Bdellovibrio has potential as a biocontrol agent, but no reports of testing in live animals have been published and no data are available on whether Bdellovibrio can spread among animals. In this study, we attempted to fill this knowledge gap by using B. bacteriovorus HD100 doses in birds with normal gut microbiota or pre-dosed with a colonized Salmonella strain. In both cases, Bdellovibrio was given orally in combination with antacids. After administering a dose of Bdellovibrio to non-Salmonella-infected birds, we measured the birds' health and well-being and any changes in their intestinal pathology and culturable microbiota, but found that a dose of Bdellovibrio at 2 days of age changed the birds' overall diversity. The natural gut microbiota in 28-day-old birds showed no adverse effects on their growth and health. Drinking water and fecal matter in bird houses did not show any contamination by Bdellovibrio after dosing. Predatory Bdellovibrio administered orally to birds pre-dosed with a gut-colonizing strain of Salmonella enterica serovar Enteritidis phage type 4 (an important zoonotic pathogen) significantly reduced Salmonella numbers in the cecum content of the avian gut and reduced abnormal cecum morphology, indicating reduced cecum inflammation. dependent on the ceca of untreated controls or a non-predatory Î”pilA strain, suggesting that these effects are due to predatory action. This study is the first step towards applying Bdellovibrio therapeutically for other animal and possibly human infections. Â© 2011, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Atterbury, R. J.;Hobley, L.;Till, R.;Lambert, C.;Capeness, M. J.;Lerner, T. R.;Fenton, A. K.;Barrow, P.;Sockett, R. E.

title: Genetic characterization of foot-and-mouth disease viruses, Ethiopia, 1981-2007
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is native to sub-Saharan Africa. To better understand its complex epidemiology, which includes multiple virus serotypes and host species, we characterized viruses recovered from FMD epidemics in Ethiopia between 1981 and 2007. We detected 5 out of 7 FMDV serotypes (O, A, C, South African Soils [SAT] 1 and SAT 2). Serotype O was dominant, followed by serotype A; Type C was not recognized after 1983. Phylogenetic analysis of virus protein 1 sequences showed the emergence of a new topotype in the East African serotype 4. In 2007, serotype SAT 1 was detected in Ethiopia and formed a new distinct topotype (IX), and serotype SAT 2 re-emerged after a significant 16-year hiatus. The diversity of viruses highlights the role of this region as a reservoir for the FMD virus, and their continued emergence in Ethiopia will greatly influence the spread of the disease in this continent and the consequent control strategy.
authors: Ayelet, G.;Mahapatra, M.;Gelaye, E.;Egziabher, B. G.;Rufeal, T.;Sahle, M.;Ferris, N. P.;Wadsworth, J.;Hutchings, G. H.;Knowles, N. J.

title: Differentiation of Proteins and Viruses Using Pyrolysis Gas Chromatography Differential Mobility Spectrometry (PY/GC/DMS) and Pattern Recognition
abstract: It is extremely important to develop new analytical sensors for pathogen detection. Applications of such sensors range from providing environmental monitoring to providing human health diagnostic measures to early warning systems for bioterrorism. Some viruses and bacterial pathogens are of particular concern due to their ability to spread rapidly in human populations during a pandemic, and it is difficult to detect emerging variants of these pathogens. This article provides a reliable detection strategy to classify viruses from harmless proteins. Our new instrumentation is based on pyrolysis gas chromatography differential mobility spectrometry (PY/GC/DMS) and combines a microfabricated solid-state biosensor with a genetic algorithm-based machine learning method for pattern recognition. Together, this hardware and software combination allowed an extremely high classification accuracy (94%) among T4 bacteriophage from an unrelated protein, bovine serum albumin (BSA). This study suggests that this portable sensor can be used together with advanced data mining method as a fast, reliable and accurate tool for virus recognition.
authors: Ayer, S.;Zhao, W. X.;Davis, C. E.

title: Evaluation of oxidative stress with total antioxidant status, sialic acid, malondialdehyde and RT-PCR findings in sheep affected by bluetongue.
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Bluetongue (BT) is a non-contagious infectious disease of ruminants. The causative agent of the disease is the bluetongue virus (BTV), which is classified in the Reoviridae family Orbivirus. OBJECTIVE AND AIM: The aim of this study was to detect serum malondialdehyde (MDA), total antioxidant stress (TAS), total sialic acid (TSA), ceruloplasmin, triglyceride, alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST), gamma-bluetongue and blue mute sheep. glutamyltransferase (GGT), cholesterol, creatinine, albumin and total protein levels (BT). MATERIALS AND METHODS: The control group consisting of 13 Chios crossbred sheep and 10 healthy sheep aged 1-4 years and generally in the last stage of pregnancy were included in the study as the CT group. All sheep were clinically examined before blood samples were taken. Serum ALT, AST, cholesterol, triglyceride, albumin, GGT, total protein, creatinine and TAS levels were measured using commercially available kits according to the manufacturer's recommendations using a Biochemistry Auto Analyzer (Sinnowa D280, China). Serum lipid peroxidation was predicted by a method previously described where MDA reacts with thiobarbituric acid (TBA) to form a colored complex at a maximum absorbance of 535 nm. The TSA value was measured at 549 nm using the method described by Warren (1959): sialic acid was oxidized to formyl-pyruvic acid, which reacted with TBA to form a pink product. Ceruloplasmin concentration was measured according to Sunderman and Nomoto (1970): ceruloplasmin and p-phenylenediamine formed a colored oxidation product proportional to serum ceruloplasmin concentration. Real-time RT-PCR and conventional RT-PCR were performed as described by Shaw et al. (2007). RESULTS: Biochemistry analysis of serum showed that TSA, MDA, triglyceride, and ALT and AST were higher in the CT group, and ceruloplasmin and TAS were lower in the control group. Serum albumin, cholesterol, creatinine, total protein and GGT did not differ significantly between the two groups. CONCLUSION: Serum triglyceride, ceruloplasmin, TSA, MDA and TAS concentrations may be useful in diagnosis, prognosis and biochemical analysis of CT.
authors: Aytekin, I.;Aksit, H.;Sait, A.;Kaya, F.;Aksit, D.;Gokmen, M.;Baca, A. U.

title: Shift of Enterovirus species among children in Cameroon - identification of a new enterovirus, EV-A119
abstract: Background: Infections by human enteroviruses (EVs) are usually asymptomatic or mild, although they can cause more serious diseases such as meningitis and acute flaccid paralysis. EVs pose a threat to children globally, and outbreaks of aseptic meningitis and hand, foot, and mouth disease are frequently reported. OBJECTIVE: To identify EV strains circulating among healthy children in a small community of Limbe, Cameroon, two years apart. STUDY DESIGN: Species and EV types were obtained by partial 5'UTR-VP4 and VP1 sequencing of RNA from stool samples collected in October 2009 and September 2011 from 150 children in Cameroon. RESULTS: A total of 74 children (49%) were infected with 28 different types of EV. There were 29 (54%) infected children in 2009 and 45 (47%) children in 2011. In 2009, 15 (47%) children were infected with EV-A and 22 (71%) with EV-B in 2011 (p=0.0001). In 2009, a child was infected with a different EV, most similar to the EV-A90. Based on the full VP1 lineup, a new EV has been shown to be called the EV-A119. CONCLUSION: The present study demonstrates a high heterogeneity of circulating EV types among children in Limbe, Cameroon and a previously undescribed shift in dominant EV types.
authors: Ayukekbong, J.;Kabayiza, J. C.;Lindh, M.;Nkuo-Akenji, T.;Tah, F.;Bergstrom, T.;Norder, H.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of serotype Asia1 foot-and-mouth disease virus from Sulaymaniyah/Iraq using VP1 protein: heterogeneity with vaccine strain As1/Shamir/89
abstract: Foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV) serotypes O, A and Asia1 are responsible for a significant number of disease outbreaks in Iraq. The present study can be considered as the first molecular characterization of the Asia1 serotype in Iraq. Current research reports the detection of serotype FMDV Asia1 in local farms in the Sulaymaniyah regions during the 2012 and 2014 outbreaks. Phylogenetic analysis of the complete VP1 gene revealed that FMDV Asia1 domain isolates are covered by the genetic novel variant Sindh-08 (group VII), including strains PAK/iso/11 and TUR/13. The VP1 protein sequence of the circulating FMDV Asia1 genotype showed heterogeneity of nine amino acid substitutions within the GH cycle with the vaccine strain As1/Shamir/89 (JF739177) currently used in the vaccination program in Iraq. Our result indicated that differences in the VP1 protein in the GH cycle of the locally circulating FMDV serotype Asia1 strain may be a reason for the current vaccination failure.
authors: Baba Sheikh, M. O.;Rashid, P. M. A.;Marouf, A. S.;Raheem, Z. H.;Janga, S. C.

title: Origin of the 2009 Mexican influenza virus: a comparative phylogenetic analysis of major external antigens and matrix protein.
abstract: Triple reassortant swine flu A (H1) viruses containing genes from avian, human, and swine flu viruses emerged and became an epidemic among humans worldwide. More than 1,000 cases were detected in the first month, mainly in Mexico and the United States. Here, phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutin (HA), neuraminidase (NA), and matrix protein (MP) was performed. The analysis showed that H1 of this reasortant originated from American pigs, while NA and MP originated from European pigs. All 2009 isolates appear homogeneous and clustered together, although they differ from classical human A (H1N1) viruses.
authors: Babakir-Mina, M.;Dimonte, S.;Perno, C. F.;Ciotti, M.

title: Analysis of the leporid herpes virus 4 genome
abstract: The genome of a herpes virus highly pathogenic for rabbits, leporid herpes virus 4 (LHV-4), was analyzed using high-throughput DNA sequencing technology and primer walking. The assembled DNA sequences were further confirmed by restriction endonuclease digestion and Southern blot analyses. The total length of the LHV-4 genome was determined to be approximately 124 kb. The genes encoded in the LHV-4 genome are most closely related to herpesviruses of the Simplexvirus genus, including human herpesviruses (HHV-1 and HHV-2), cercopticine (CeHV-2 and CeHV-16), monkey herpesviruses including macacine (McHV-). are related. 1), bovine herpesvirus 2 (BHV-2) and wallaby (macropodid) herpesviruses (MaHV-1 and -2). Similar to other simplex virus genomes, LHV-4 has a high overall G+C content of 65-70% in unique regions and 75-77% in inverted repeat regions. The orthologs of ICP34.5 and US5 were not identified in the LHV-4 genome. This study demonstrates that LHV-4 has the smallest simplex virus genome characterized to date. © 2012 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Babra, B.;Watson, G.;Xu, W.;Jeffrey, B. M.;Xu, J. R.;Rockey, D. D.;Rohrmann, G. F.;Jin, L.

title: Genome Sequence of FMD Virus Serotype O Isolated from Morocco in 2015
abstract: The genome of a virus isolated from a foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) epidemic in Morocco in 2015 is described here. This virus is classified as serotype O, strain Ind-2001d in topotype ME-SA (Middle East-South Asia). This lineage is endemic to the Indian subcontinent, but has caused outbreaks in the Middle East and North Africa since 2013.
authors: Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;Wadsworth, J.;Gray, A.;Abouchoaib, N.;King, D. P.;Knowles, N. J.

title: Identification of a new hepacivirus in domestic cattle from Germany
abstract: The hepatitis C virus (HCV) continues to represent one of the most important threats to human health. In recent years, HCV-related sequences have been found in bats, rodents, horses and dogs, suggesting that hepaciviruses are widely distributed among animals. By applying unbiased high-throughput sequencing, a new virus of the genus Hepacivirus was discovered in a bovine serum sample. De novo assembly yielded an almost full-length genome encoding a 2,779 amino acid polyprotein. Phylogenetic analysis confirmed that the virus represents a new species within the genus Hepacivirus. Viral RNA screening determined that 1.6% (n = 5) of 320 individual animals in Germany and 3.2% (n = 5) of 158 cattle herds studied were positive for bovine hepacivirus. Repeated reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) analyzes of animals from a dairy herd proved that a significant percentage of cows were infected and some were viremic for more than 6 months. Clinical and post-mortem examination showed no signs of disease, including liver damage. Interestingly, quantitative RT-PCR from different organs and tissues combined with the presence of a miR-122 binding site in the viral genome strongly suggests a liver tropism for bovine hepacivirus, making this novel virus a promising animal model for HCV infections in humans. .
authors: Baechlein, C.;Fischer, N.;Grundhoff, A.;Alawi, M.;Indenbirken, D.;Postel, A.;Baron, A. L.;Offinger, J.;Becker, K.;Beineke, A.;Rehage, J.;Becher, P.

title: Pegivirus infection in domestic pigs, Germany
authors: Baechlein, C.;Grundhoff, A.;Fischer, N.;Alawi, M.;Hoeltig, D.;Waldmann, K. H.;Becher, P.

title: Surveillance and characterization of low pathogenic H5 avian influenza viruses isolated from wild migratory birds in Korea
abstract: Migratory waterfowl are the natural reservoir of influenza A viruses. However, interspecies transmission has occasionally caused outbreaks in various hosts, including humans. Phylogenetic analysis was performed to characterize the genetic origins of H5 avian influenza viruses isolated from migratory birds in South Korea. A total of 53 H5 viruses were isolated between October 2005 and November 2008. Full genetic characterization showed that most of these viruses belonged to the Eurasian-like avian lineage. However, portions of the AB/Korea/W235/07 and AB/Korea/W236/07 isolates clustered with viruses of the North American rather than Eurasian lineage, suggesting that reclassification has occurred between these two avian virus lineages. Phylogenetic analysis also showed that H5N2 and H5N3 virus isolates were in the low pathogenicity H5 phenotype. The H5 viruses appear to be antigenically similar, but can be distinguished from a recent HPAI H5N1 (EM/Korea/W149/06) virus by hemagglutinin inhibition (HI) assays. Experimental vaccination of representative viruses has shown that certain isolates, particularly AB/Korea/W163/07 (H5N2), can be detected in the trachea and lungs of chickens, but none are transmitted by direct contact. Furthermore, all viruses can be detected in the mouse lung without prior adaptation, indicative of their pathogenic potential in a mammalian host. Overall, our results highlight the important role that migratory birds play in the maintenance, transmission and reclassification of avian influenza viruses, highlighting the need for continued surveillance of influenza virus activity in these bird populations. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Baek, Y. H.;Pascua, P. N. Q.;Song, M. S.;Park, K. J.;Kwon, H. I.;Lee, J. H.;Kim, S. Y.;Moon, H. J.;Kim, C. J.;Choi, Y. K.

title: New Rath peptide for intracellular delivery of proteins and nucleic acids
abstract: In this study, a new cell penetrating peptide (CPP) named Rath from avian infectious bursal disease virus was identified. It has the potential to penetrate and migrate cargo molecules into cells regardless of temperature. In addition, it can deliver the oligonucleotide to chicken embryonic fibroblast primary cells within 30 minutes and intracellular antibodies within one hour. As an ideal delivery vehicle, it has the ability to protect cargo molecules in the presence of serum, nuclease, and has minimal or no cytotoxicity at the higher peptide concentrations studied. Biophysical characterizations have shown that Rath has a dominant Î² structure with a small Î± helix and has remarkable binding ability with protein and DNA. Therefore, characterization of the unique Rath peptide to deliver protein or nucleic acid to cells with non-covalent interactions can be used as an effective delivery method for a variety of cell-based experiments. Â© 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Bais, M. V.;Kumar, S.;Tiwari, A. K.;Kataria, R. S.;Nagaleekar, V. K.;Shrivastava, S.;Chindera, K.

title: Poxviruses in bats ... so what?
abstract: Poxviruses are important pathogens for humans and many domestic and wild animal species. Cross-species (including zoonotic) poxvirus infections can have serious consequences for the recipient host. Bats are a variety of mammals known to carry lethal viral zoonoses such as Rabies, Hendra, Nipah, and SARS. As a result, targeted studies reveal that bats are infected with a rich variety of novel viruses. Poxviruses were recently identified in bats, and their environments were significantly different. Here, we review the natural history of smallpox viruses in bats and highlight the viruses' interrelationship and context within the family Poxviridae. In addition to considering the zoonotic potential of these viruses, we also consider the broader implications of these findings. Specifically, the potential to explore and use this newly discovered relationship to study coevolution and interspecies transmission, along with key aspects of poxvirus host tropism as well as bat virology and immunology. Â© 2014 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Baker, K. S.;Murcia, P. R.

title: New, potentially zoonotic paramyxoviruses from the African straw-colored fruit bat Eidolon helvum
abstract: Bats carry a variety of paramyxoviruses that affect human and pet health when spread occurs. Recent studies have demonstrated a wide variety of paramyxoviruses in the urban roost population of straw-colored fruit bats in Ghana. Here, we further investigate this through virus isolation and identify two novel rubulaviruses: Achimota virus 1 (AchPV1) and Achimota virus 2 (AchPV2). The viruses form a phylogenetic cluster with each other and with other bat-derived rubulaviruses such as Tuhoko viruses, Menangle virus, and Tioman virus. We developed serological tests specific for AchPV1 and AchPV2 and found evidence of infection with both viruses in Eidolon helvum in sub-Saharan Africa and on islands in the Gulf of Guinea. Longitudinal sampling of E. helvum demonstrates persistence of the virus within fruit bat populations and suggests the spread of AchPVs by horizontal transmission. We also identified possible serological evidence of human infection with AchPV2 in Ghana and Tanzania. Where health surveillance and diagnosis is poor and HIV or Plasmodium sp. The clinically important zoonotic spread of chiropteran paramyxoviruses is likely to be overlooked in most of Africa, where comorbidities such as infection with Â© 2013, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Baker, K. S.;Todd, S.;Marsh, G. A.;Crameri, G.;Barr, J.;Kamins, A. O.;Peel, A. J.;Yu, M.;Hayman, D. T. S.;Nadjm, B.;Mtove, G.;Amos, B.;Reyburn, H.;Nyarko, E.;Suu-Ire, R.;Murcia, P. R.;Cunningham, A. A.;Wood, J. L. N.;Wang, L. F.

title: Peste des petits ruminant virus detected in tissues taken from the Asian lion (Panthera leo persico), IV.
abstract: In this study, peste des petits ruminant virus (PPRV) was detected in frozen pooled tissue samples from a dead Asian lion (Panthera leo persica). Samples were negative for canine distemper virus and positive for PPRV nucleic acids when tested by one-step RT-PCR using appropriate virus-specific primers. Subsequent amplification, cloning and sequencing of partial nucleocapsid, matrix and fusion genes confirmed the presence of PPRV nucleic acid.
