Comparative sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes of the structural genes of the isolated virus confirmed that the virus belongs to Asian lineage IV and is closely related to PPRV circulating in India. Â© 2012 Korean Veterinary Science Association.
authors: Balamurugan, V.;Sen, A.;Venkatesan, G.;Bhanot, V.;Yadav, V.;Bhanuprakash, V.;Singh, R. K.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analyzes of structural genes of virulent isolates and vaccine strains of peste des petits ruminant virus from India
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is an acute, highly contagious, notifiable and economically important transboundary viral disease of sheep and goats. In this study, sequence and phylogenetic analyzes of nucleocapsid (N), matrix (M), fusion (F) and hemagglutinin (H) coding sequences of virulent and vaccine strains of PPR virus (PPRV) were performed. was performed to identify genetic variations between field isolates and vaccine strains. The open reading frame (ORF) of these genes of the isolates/strains were amplified, cloned and sequenced by RT-PCR. The ORFs of the N, M, F and H genes were 1578, 1008, 1641 and 1830 nucleotides (nt) long and encode polypeptides of 525, 335, 546 and 609 amino acids (aa), respectively, as previously reported. Comparative sequence analyzes of these four genes of the isolates/strain were performed with published sequences. It revealed 97.7-100% and 97.7-99.8% identity among Asian lineage IV and 89.6-98.7 and 89.8-98.9% identity with other PPRV lineages at the nt and aa levels, respectively. Phylogenetic analyzes of these isolates based on aa sequences indicated that all viruses belong to lineage IV, along with other Asian isolates. This is in line with previous observations that only PPRV strain IV has been circulating in India since the disease was first reported. Furthermore, sequence analysis of the thermostable/thermo-adapted vaccine strains showed no significant changes in gene sequences encoding functional or structural surface protein. It is important to monitor the circulation of PPRV in susceptible animals with H gene-based sequence comparisons in addition to the F gene and N gene-based approaches to determine the distribution and spread of the virus in regular epidemics occurring in endemic countries. like India. ©2010 Blackwell Verlag GmbH.
authors: Balamurugan, V.;Sen, A.;Venkatesan, G.;Yadav, V.;Bhanot, V.;Riyesh, T.;Bhanuprakash, V.;Singh, R. K.

title: Transmissible bronchitis virus in different avian physiological systems - a field study in Brazilian poultry flocks
abstract: Avian infectious bronchitis is a highly contagious viral disease with economic implications for the poultry agribusiness. The disease presents with very systemic clinical manifestations (respiratory, renal, enteric and reproductive) and is caused by a coronavirus (infectious bronchitis virus, IBV). Infectious bronchitis virus is classified into different serotypes and genotypes (vaccine strains and field variants). This study aimed to evaluate the occurrence of IBV in commercial poultry flocks from 3 major production regions in Brazil and to determine the tropism of major circulating genotypes to 3 different avian physiological systems (respiration, digestive, urinary/reproductive). Clinical specimens suggestive of IBV infection were collected from 432 different commercial poultry flocks (1998 from broilers and 234 from breeders). The total number of biological samples consisted of organ pools from the above 3 physiological systems obtained from farms in 3 key production regions: midwest, northeast and south. Infectious bronchitis virus was detected by reverse transcription, real-time PCR of 5â€² untranslated regions. Results showed 179 IBV positive flocks (41.4% of flocks), 107 (24.8%) from broilers and 72 (16.8%) from breeders. Farms in different parts of the country had similar IBV-positive flocks, mostly broilers (average 54%) compared to breeders (average 30.8%). Reverse transcription was detected more frequently in the digestive tract of breeders (40%), in the digestive tract of chickens (43.5%) and respiratory systems (37.7%). Infectious bronchitis virus genotyping was performed by reverse transcription nested PCR and sequencing of the S1 gene selected from 79 IBV-positive flocks (45 broilers and 34 broilers). Most herds were infected with the Brazilian variant genotype rather than the Massachusetts vaccine genotype. These results indicate that the Brazilian variant (mainly in the enteric duct) predominates in commercial poultry flocks from 3 major production regions in Brazil. Â© 2014 Poultry Science Association Inc.
authors: Balestrin, E.;Fraga, A. P.;Ikuta, N.;Canal, C. W.;Fonseca, A. S. K.;Lunge, V. R.

title: Full-length genome sequence analysis of Hungarian swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus isolated from a pig with severe respiratory disease.
abstract: Here, we report the isolation of a type 1 porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) strain from a clinical outbreak of severe respiratory problems and high fever. Next-generation sequencing was used to determine the complete genome sequence of the isolate (9625/2012). The virus belongs to a new branch in subtype 1, branch D and shows the highest similarity to the PRRSV Olot/1991 and Amervac vaccine strain. Mutation analysis 9625/2012 showed no evidence of recombination, but high amino acid substitutions in putative neutralizing epitopes, suggesting an important role of selective immune pressure in the evolution of PRRSV 9625/2012.
authors: BÃ¡lint, Ã;Balka, G.;HorvÃ¡th, P.;KecskemÃ©ti, S.;DÃ¡n, Ã;Farsang, A.;Szeredi, L.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Bartha, D.;Olasz, F.;BelÃ¡k, S.;ZÃ¡dori, Z.

title: Whole genome sequence analysis of a wild, non-MLV-associated type 2 Hungarian PRRSV variant isolated in Europe
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) is a common swine pathogen that causes significant economic losses to the swine industry. The expanding diversity of PRRSV strains makes the diagnosis, control and eradication of the disease increasingly difficult. In this study, the authors report the complete genome sequencing of a type 2 PRRSV strain isolated from piglet carcasses in Hungary. Next-generation sequencing was used to determine the complete genome sequence of the isolate (PRRSV-2/Hungary/102/2012). Recombination analysis with available full-length genome sequences showed no evidence of such an event with other known PRRSV. Unique deletions and an insertion were found in the nsp2 region of PRRSV-2/Hungary/102/2012 compared to the highly virulent VR2332 and JXA-1 prototype strains. Most of the amino acid changes in GP4 and GP5 of the virus were in known antigenic regions, suggesting an important role for immunological pressure in the evolution of PRRSV-2/Hungary/102/2012. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that it belongs to 1 or 2 lineages of type 2 PRRSV. Given the lack of relevant PRRSV in Europe, the progenitor of PRRSV-2/Hungary/102/2012 was most likely transferred from North America, except for a partial sequence from Slovakia. Ingelvac is the first documented type 2 PRRSV isolated in Europe, not related to MLV.
authors: Balka, G.;Wang, X.;Olasz, F.;Balint, A.;Kiss, I.;Banyai, K.;Rusvai, M.;Stadejek, T.;Marthaler, D.;Murtaugh, M. P.;Zadori, Z.

title: Two amino acid changes at the N-terminus of the infectious gastroenteritis coronavirus spike protein cause loss of enteric tropism
abstract: To examine the molecular basis of TGEV tropism, a recombinant collection was created between the enteric- and respiratory tract-infecting infectious gastroenteritis coronavirus (TGEV) PUR46-MAD strain and the respiratory-only PTV strain. The frequency of recombinant isolation was about 10-9 recombinants per nucleotide and was 3.7 times higher at the 5'-end of the S gene than in other areas of the genome. Thirty recombinants were plaque purified and characterized phenotypically and genetically. All recombinant viruses had a single passage and inherited the 5'- and 3'-half of their genomes from enteric and respiratory parents, respectively. Recombinant viruses were divided into three groups named 1 to 3 according to the location of the crossover. Group 1 recombinants had crossover in the S gene, while Groups 2 and 3 had crossovers in ORF1b and ORF1a, respectively. The tropism of the recombinants was studied. Group 1 recombinants had enteric and respiratory tropism, while Group 2 recombinants infected the respiratory tract but not the enteric tract. The viruses of both groups differed by two nucleotide changes at positions 214 and 655. Both changes may in principle be responsible for the loss of enteric tropism, but only the change at nucleotide 655 was found specifically in respiratory isolates and most likely this single nucleotide change is due to loss of enteric tropism in closely related PUR46 isolates, leading to a substitution at amino acid 219 of the S protein. was responsible. Available data indicate the involvement of two different domains of the S protein, mapping between amino acids 522 and 744 and around amino acid 219, respectively, to infect enteric system cells with TGEV. The first domain binds to porcine aminopeptidase N, the cellular receptor for TGEV. In the other domain map, a second factor is mapped that has undefined structure but may be the binding site for a coreceptor required for enteric tropism of TGEV.
authors: Ballesteros, M. L.;SÃ¡nchez, C. M.;Enjuanes, L.

title: Investigation of foot and mouth disease outbreaks in Mbala and Kazungula districts of Zambia.
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is an acute, highly contagious viral infection of domestic and wild ungulates. It is known to be endemic in Zambia, with periodic outbreaks occurring in different geographical regions of the country. This study was conducted to investigate the presence of FMD virus (FMDV) in cases of suspected FMD reported in cattle from Kazungula and Mbala regions of Zambia. Sixty epithelial tissues or esophageal-pharyngeal (OP) scrapes (probang samples) were collected from Mbala (n = 51) and Kazungula (n = 9) and examined for FMDV. FMDV viral RNA and serotypes were examined by real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) and antigen Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA), respectively. Twenty-two samples (36.7%) were positive for the FMDV genome by qRT-PCR with Cycle threshold (Ct) values ranging from 13 to 31. FMDV-positive samples from epithelial tissues showed relatively higher Ct values compared to those from OP. scrapes regardless of geographic location. Forty percent (40%; n = 4) of epithelial tissues from Mbala were serotyped to the SAT 2 serotype by antigen ELISA. Kazungula samples were serotyped to SAT 1. These findings indicated that Mbala and Kazungula regions had at least FMD outbreaks in 2012 attributed to FMDV serotypes SAT 2 and SAT 1 field strains. Also, regular interaction between buffaloes from Mosi-o Tunya Park and domestic animals from surrounding areas may contribute to the emergence of regular FMD outbreaks in Kazungula, while uncontrolled animal movements along the borders between Mbala and Nsumbawanga may be responsible for disease outbreaks in Mbala. . In-depth molecular biological studies, including the sequencing and phylogeny of viruses, should be conducted to elucidate the complex epidemiology of FMD in Zambia, thereby providing valuable information needed for a rational control strategy of FMD in Zambia and neighboring countries.
authors: Banda, F.;Kasanga, C. J.;Sallu, R.;Sinkala, Y.;Sinkombe, T. W.;Mulumba, M.;Rweyemamu, M. M.;Wambura, P. N.

title: Isolation and Metagenomic Identification of Avian Leukosis Virus Associated with Mortality in Broilers
abstract: Avian leukosis virus (ALV) belongs to the Retroviridae family and causes significant economic losses in the poultry industry. Following an outbreak associated with high mortality in a broiler flock in northern Malaysia, kidney tissues from affected chickens were sent for virus isolation and identification in chicken embryonated eggs and MDCK cells. Evidence of virus growth was demonstrated by bleeding and embryo death in egg culture. Viral growth in cell culture has been demonstrated by the development of cytopathic effects. The isolated virus was purified by sucrose gradient and identified using negative staining transmission electron microscopy. Further validation was achieved through next-generation sequencing and nucleotide sequence homology search. Analysis of viral sequences using the NCBI BLAST tool revealed 99-100% sequence homology with the exogenous ALV viral envelope protein. Phylogenetic analysis based on partial envelope sequences showed that the Malaysian isolate clustered with ALV subgroup J, ALV subgroup E, and Taiwanese and Japanese ALV strains more closely related to recombinant A/E isolates. Based on these findings, it was concluded that ALV is associated with the current epidemic. Further studies on the molecular epidemiology and pathogenicity of the identified virus isolate were recommended.
authors: Bande, F.;Arshad, S. S.;Omar, A. R.

title: Unique genomic organization of a new Avipox virus detected in Turkey (Meleagris gallopavo)
abstract: Avipoxviruses are emerging pathogens that affect more than 200 bird species worldwide. Genetic characterization of avipoxviruses is performed by analysis of genomic regions encoding 4b and DNA polymerase. Whole genome sequence data are limited to a few avipoxvirus isolates. Based on the phylogenetic analysis, three main genetic branches are distinguished. In this study, a new avipoxvirus strain causing skin lesions in domestic turkey was reported. The virus was detected in a herd of turkeys vaccinated against avipoxvirus infection in Hungary in 2011. The genome of the isolated strain, TKPV-HU1124/2011, was uniquely short (~188.5 kbp) and expected to encode a reduced number of proteins. Phylogenetic analysis of genes encoding 4b and DNA polymerase distinguished TKPV-HU1124/2011 from other turkey-derived avipox viruses and classified it into a new genetic branch. This work allows for a new understanding of the genetic and genomic heterogeneity of avipoxviruses and fully highlights the importance of lineage diversity in vaccine efficacy.
authors: BÃ¡nyai, K.;Palya, V.;DÃ©nes, B.;GlÃ¡vits, R.;Ivanics, Ã‰;HorvÃ¡th, B.;Farkas, S. L.;Marton, S.;BÃ¡lint, Ã;Gyuranecz, M.;ErdÃ©lyi, K.;DÃ¡n, Ã

title: Evolutionary dynamics of the recent peste des petits ruminant virus outbreak in China between 2013 and 2014.
abstract: Peste des petits ruminant virus (PPRV) causes peste des petits ruminants (PPR), a highly contagious disease of sheep and goats that is considered a serious threat to the local economy in Africa and Asia. However, the in-depth evolutionary dynamics of PPRV during an epidemic are not well understood. We performed phylogenetic analysis on the genomic sequences of 25 PPRV strains from the Chinese 2013-2014 outbreaks. All these strains clustered in a new clade in lineage 4. Dating the most recent common ancestor of the PPRV China 2013-2014 strains to early August 2013, the evolutionary rate of 2.61 × 10âˆ'6 nucleotide substitutions per day per site was estimated. Transmission network analysis revealed that all virus sequences can be grouped into five infection clusters; This suggested that long-distance animal transmission played an important role in the spread of PPRV in China. These results expanded our knowledge of PPRV evolution to achieve effective control measures.
authors: Bao, J.;Wang, Q.;Li, L.;Liu, C.;Zhang, Z.;Li, J.;Wang, S.;Wu, X.;Wang, Z.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of peste des petits ruminant virus in free-living bharals (Pseudois nayaur) in Tibet, China.
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is an important viral disease of sheep and goats. The wildlife hosts of PPR, which may play an important role in the epidemiology of this disease, are not well defined. The research was conducted to examine the infection of the PPR virus (PPRV) in free-living bharals (Pseudois nayaur) in Tibet, China. In 2007, PPRV infection in two bharals in Rutog County, Tibet was confirmed based on clinical signs and detection of PPRV RNA in tissue samples. In 2008, PPRV infection in a bharal in Ge'gyai County, Tibet was found by competitive ELISA, reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction, and sequence analysis of the PPRV fusion protein (F) and nucleoprotein (N) gene segments. The PPRV variant identified in infected bharal was closely related to other circulating PPRV variants recently identified in sheep and goats from Tibet. This is the first report of PPRV infection in free-living bharals. © 2010.
authors: Bao, J.;Wang, Z.;Li, L.;Wu, X.;Sang, P.;Wu, G.;Ding, G.;Suo, L.;Liu, C.;Wang, J.;Zhao, W.;Li, J.;Qi, L.

title: Isolation and whole genome sequence of two reticuloendotheliosis virus strains from mixed infections with Marek's disease virus in China.
abstract: Classified as gammaretrovirus, reticuloendotheliosis virus (REV) has a variety of hosts, including chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys, and wild birds. REV causes immunosuppression of the host, which can lead to a number of pathological syndromes, in particular an increased susceptibility to other pathogens, thereby causing great harm to the poultry industry. Mixed infections of REV and Marek's disease virus (MDV) have been reported in many countries, including China. Previous reports have revealed that MDV vaccines are not effective and that even less virulent MDV strains will cause some losses due to mixed infections with REV. In addition, contaminants in the MDV vaccine may be the main source of REV. In this study, two clinical specimens were collected from two chicken flocks diagnosed with MDV. Two REV isolates were then obtained from clinical specimens. Isolates designated CY1111 and SY1209 were further confirmed by an indirect immunofluorescence assay and electron microscopy. Whole genome sequences of the two REV strains were determined to test the relationship between them and other REV strains. Phylogenetic trees showed that the two REV strains were closely related to most REV strains isolated from various hosts. Therefore, REVs can spread freely among these hosts under natural conditions. In addition, most REV strains in China were in the same branch. The present study provides some insights into REV in China.
authors: Bao, K. Y.;Zhang, Y. P.;Zheng, H. W.;Lv, H. C.;Gao, Y. L.;Wang, J. F.;Gao, H. L.;Qi, X. L.;Cui, H. Y.;Wang, Y. Q.;Ren, X. G.;Wang, X. M.;Liu, C. J.

title: Blood feeding, susceptibility to infection with Schmallenberg virus and phylogenetics of Culicoides (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) from the UK
abstract: Background: Culicoides biting midges (Diptera: Ceratopogonidae) are responsible for the biological transmission of internationally important arboviruses of livestock. In 2011, a new Orthobunyavirus was discovered that causes congenital malformations and miscarriages in ruminant animals in northern Europe. From field studies, Culicoides has been implicated in the transmission of this virus, later named Schmallenberg virus (SBV), but to date no assessment of the susceptibility of field populations to infection has been made under standard laboratory conditions. We evaluated the effect of membrane type (chick skin, collagen, Parafilm MÂ®) on field-collected Culicoides blood supply rates when presented with an artificial blood supply system (Hemotek, UK). Susceptibility to infection with SBV was then compared following blood feeding on an SBV-blood suspension delivered via (i) the Hemotek system or (ii) a saturated cotton wool padglet. Schmallenberg virus susceptibility was identified by RT-qPCR of RNA extractions of head homogenates and related haplotype identifications based on the DNA barcode region of Culicoides species and mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase 1 (cox1) gene. Results: Culicoides blood feeding rates were low across all membrane types tested (7.5% chick skin, 0.0% for collagen, 4.4% Parafilm MÂ®, 6029 female Culicoides total blood meal offered). For obsoletus complex, infection with SBV via membrane blood supply (8 out of 109 tested) and pledged blood supply (1 out of 94 tested) with both C. obsoletus (Meigen) and C. scoticus Downes & sensitivity has been demonstrated. Kettle susceptible to infection with SBV via oral feeding. Phylogenetic analyzes of cox1 DNA barcodes of 74 individuals evaluated from a single field site found potential evidence of cryptic species within UK populations for the Obsoletus complex. Conclusions: The methods described in this work provide tools for blood-feeding Palaearctic Culicoides for vector proficiency studies and colonization attempts. Susceptibility to SBV infection was 7.3% for membrane-fed members of the subgenus Avaritia and 1.1% for pledglet-fed members. Both C. obsoletus and C. scoticus were confirmed to be susceptible to infection with SBV, and potential evidence of cryptic species was found within samples of the UK Obsoletus complex, but the effects of cryptic diversity in the Obsoletus complex on arbovirus transmission are unknown.
authors: Barber, J.;Harrup, L. E.;Silk, R.;Veronesi, E.;Gubbins, S.;Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;Carpenter, S.

title: Persistence mechanisms in tick-borne diseases
abstract: The use of new, highly sensitive diagnostic methods has revealed that persistent infections are a common feature of different tick-borne diseases such as babesiosis, anaplasmosis and heart juice. Antigenic variation may contribute to disease persistence through the continued development of new surface structures, and we know in a few cases how this is achieved. Known or suspected persistence mechanisms in Babesia parasites include cytoadhesion and rapid variation of the adhesive ligand in Babesia bovis and different Babesia spp. In Anaplasma, wide diversity in the pfam01617 gene family accompanies cycling of organism levels in chronic infection. One conclusion from pioneering research at Onderstepoort is the identification of a related family of polymorphic genes likely involved in immunity to heart disease. We are beginning to understand the dimensions of the antigenic repertoires, and with the possibility of applying simultaneous high-throughput sequencing to 1000 small genome sequences, the full description is close. We may also consider for the first time modifying these genomes and looking at the effects on persistence and virulence. However, important biological questions remain unanswered; for example, why we see an emerging Anaplasma infection in humans and that infection of endothelial cells by Anaplasma is important for in vivo persistence.
authors: Barbet, A. F.

title: DNA sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of the protease gene of sheep adenovirus 3 indicate that sheep adenoviruses belong to two different genera.
abstract: So far, the only published ovine adenovirus DNA sequence was the complete genome of ovine adenovirus isolate 287 (OAV287), which has strikingly unique genomic organization compared to other mammalian adenoviruses and should be appropriately classified into a new adenovirus genus. The protease gene sequence of ovine adenovirus type 3 (OAdV-3) was determined and analyzed. The results of the phylogenetic analysis of the 205 residue long protein indicated that OAdV-3 belongs to the genus Mastadenovirus and is surprisingly closely related to bovine adenovirus type 2. Evolutionary distance between OAdV-3 and OAV287 despite common host origin. It proved to be wonderful suggesting that sheep, similar to cattle and poultry, can be infected by distantly related adenoviruses belonging to different genera. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Barbezange, C.;BenkÃ¶, M.;DÃ¡n, A.;Harrach, B.

title: Search for antigenic proteins of porcine circovirus type 2 by immunohistochemistry technique
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) is a virus classified in the family Circoviridae and is associated with postweaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS). Diagnosis should be at three main points: Presence of concordant clinical findings, histopathological lesions, and demonstration of nucleic acid and/or viral antigen within the lesions. The immunohistochemistry (IHC) method enables the display of viral antigens using specific antibodies and probes. In this study, two groups of samples were analyzed by IHC. Group I consists of 32 autopsied pigs with clinical signs of PMWS from commercial farms in the State of Minas Gerais. Group II consists of 109 tissues taken to the histopathology laboratory with lesions suggestive of PMWS. The first and second sampling showed 7.60% and 60.55% positivity for the presence of antigen PCV2, respectively. In both groups, viral antigens were more frequently expressed in lymph nodes and lungs, evidenced by intense immunoreactivity of histiocytes. Application of IHC allowed comparison between histopathological changes and distribution of viral antigen in tissue.
authors: Barbosa, C. N.;Freitas, T. R. P.

title: Investigation of antigens and antibodies against Porcine Circovirus Type-2 in pigs with and without post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome from commercial farms of Minas Gerais State.
abstract: Porcine Circovirus Type 2 (PCV-2) is a non-enveloped circular single-stranded DNA virus classified in the family Circoviridae related to postweaning multi-systemic wasting syndrome (PMWS) in piglets. Immune Histochemical (IHC) techniques are applied to the PCV-2 antigen detected in animal tissue injuries. However, pigs infected with asymptomatic or sub-clinical PCV-2 can spread the virus in the herd. Serological research on apparently healthy pigs may suggest a risk of virus transmission. In this study, antigens and antibodies to PCVS-2 were investigated in pigs from commercial farms in seven and eight mesor regions of Minas Gerais State (MG). Thirty-two pigs aged five to eleven weeks showing clinical signs of SMDS were autopsied. PCV-2 antigens were investigated by IHC from either sacrificed pigs (Group I) and diagnostic claim samples (Group II). 7.60% and more than 60% of the first and second groups, respectively, were positive for viral antigen. Intense labeling of macrophages and histiocytes in both, particularly in the lymph nodes and lung, proved antigens to CVS-2. In parallel, the Immunoperoxidase Monolayer Assay (IPMA) was applied to the antibody against PCV-2 screened in 955 pigs from 35 full-cycle commercial farms in the same mesorregions. All pig herds (100%) showed positive animals (confidence level 90 to 100%), and the frequency of pigs reacting varied by 96.6% (confidence level 94.7% to 98.6%). PCV-2 antibody titers ranged from 1:320 (moderate) to 1:10,240 (high). The results show that 2.66% and 9% of pigs from the Triangulo Mineiro and Zona da Mata regions, respectively, can develop clinical SMDS, reaching 3.35% in total serum.
authors: Barbosa, C. N.;Martins, N. R.;Esteves, E. G.;Freitas, T. R. P.

title: Cloning and sequence analysis of the matrix (M) protein gene of rinderpest virus and evidence for another bovine morbillivirus
abstract: We cloned and sequenced the entire M gene of the vaccine strain of Rinderpest virus and the M gene of the lethal Kabete 'O' strain from which it was derived. The sequences of these two genes were essentially identical (99% at the nucleotide level), but very different from a previously published Kabete OM gene sequence (M. Limo and T. Yilma, 1990, Virology 175, 323-327). Examination of the nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of known morbillivirus M genes showed that the earlier sequence was clearly from a morbillivirus, but neither from rinderpest virus nor from the pest des petits ruminant virus.
authors: Baron, M. D.;Goatley, L.;Barrett, T.

title: Isolation of multiple novel paramyxoviruses from pteropid bat urine
abstract: Bats have been found to harbor a number of emerging viruses with zoonotic potential, and great attention has been paid to identifying novel bat pathogens to determine the risk to human and animal health. Many groups have identified new viruses in bats through detection of viral nucleic acid; however, virus isolation is still a challenge and there are few reports of viral isolates from bats. In recent years, our group has developed optimized procedures for virus isolation from bat urine, including the use of primary bat cells. In our previous reports, we described the isolation of Hendra virus, Menangle virus and Cedar virus in Queensland, Australia. Here we report the isolation of four novel bat paramyxoviruses from urine collected from under pteropid tat (flying fox) colonies in Queensland and New South Wales between 2009 and 2011.
authors: Barr, J.;Smith, C.;Smith, I.;de Jong, C.;Todd, S.;Melville, D.;Broos, A.;Crameri, S.;Haining, J.;Marsh, G.;Crameri, G.;Field, H.;Wang, L. F.

title: Current perspectives on the phylogeny of Filoviridae
abstract: Sporadic outbreaks of deadly disease in humans and non-human primates caused by Ebola or Marburg viruses have driven research into the characterization of these viruses in hopes of identifying their host tropism and potential reservoirs. This understanding of the kinship of newly discovered filoviruses may help predict risk factors for outbreaks of hemorrhagic disease in humans and/or non-human primates. Recent discoveries such as three different genotypes of Reston ebolavirus unexpectedly discovered in domestic pigs in the Philippines; as well as a new species, Bundibugyo ebolavirus; the recent discovery of Lloviu virus as Cuevavirus, a potential new genus within the Filoviridae; and germline integrations of filovirus-like sequences in some animal species are providing new insights into the relevance, prevalence, and potential for human transmission of filoviruses. These new findings reveal that filoviruses are more diverse and may have a greater impact on animal evolution than previously thought. Here, we review these findings with implications for understanding the host range, prevalence, and transmission of Filoviridae. © 2011.
authors: Barrette, R. W.;Xu, L.;Rowland, J. M.;McIntosh, M. T.

title: Update of new 2nd generation vaccines against rotavirus allowed in Spain: Perspectives, challenges and opportunities
abstract: general review and update has been made on the importance of rotavirus and its effects as a source of gastroenteritis in the child. Comments are made on the structure, classification, pathogenicity, symptoms and treatment of the virus. The immunological response of the host in prevention from wild virus disease is reviewed and shows how re-infection becomes progressively less severe as severe diarrheal disease is prevented after initial infection. Briefly, the epidemiology and disease burden are described, showing that rotavirus is the cause of more than 600,000 deaths per year in underdeveloped countries, the high number of hospitalizations, outpatient visits and nosocomial infections, and the resulting high morbidity and mortality it represents. Public health. Hygienic conditions of health care, drinking water, access to oral rehydration, etc. The only possible intervention is preventive intervention, since the improvement achieved with the disease did not lead to a significant decrease in the incidence of the disease in both industrialized and developing countries. those. The most common rotavirus serotypes and genotypes known in the world and in our country are explained. Emphasis is placed on the immediate serotypes available. A comprehensive review of the major recent studies in the scientific literature on novel 2nd generation vaccines against rotavirus in the United States, authorized by the European Medicines Agency (EMEA), was also conducted. Although the two vaccines authorized in Spain come from different active ingredients, they have a common purpose, preventing severe diarrhea in the child due to rotavirus. Given the events with RotashieldÂ® (the first human-bovine reassortant rotavirus vaccine used in the United States and now withdrawn from the market) and its association with intestinal intussusception, large safety study designs involving more than 70,000 children were required. With both vaccines, RotarixÂ® and RotaTeqâ„¢, there is ample evidence that there is no increased risk of vaccination-related bowel intussusception. Efficacy, immunogenicity, adverse events, etc. related experiments were also reviewed. These are statistically significant and have been adequately tested within the allowable ranges in relation to placebos. A list of recent ACID (Advisory Board Immunization Practices) recommendations for RotaTeqâ„¢ is provided. Brief comments have been made on some of the pharmacoeconomic studies found in the literature, some of which are cost effective, but more advanced ones will be required once vaccines become operational and vaccination prices are determined for the public health system. Finally, the opportunities, challenges, and perspectives of current 2nd generation vaccines are discussed. In some of the future, the difficulties they will face are indicated. It was concluded on the importance of convincing pediatricians for the use of these new vaccines, raising awareness of parents, and including them in common routine vaccination practices by providing health education to both the regulatory authorities and them. This requires pharmacoeconomic studies that include current and real costs of the disease.
authors: Barrio Corrales, F.;Cuenca Burgos, M. J.;GarcÃ­a FernÃ¡ndez, M. A.;Trillo BelizÃ³n, C.

title: Molecular epidemiology of bluetongue virus in Portugal during the 2004-2006 epidemic.
abstract: After 44 years of epidemiological silence, the bluetongue virus (BTV) was reintroduced in Portugal in the fall of 2004. The first clinical cases of bluetongue (BT) were reported on sheep farms in the south of Portugal, close to the Spanish border. A total of six BTVs, five serotype 4 and one serotype 2 were isolated from sheep and cattle during the 2004-2006 epizootics. The nucleotide sequence of the L2, S7 and S10 gene segments of the BTV-4 prototype strain (BTV4/22045/PT04) from the first outbreak and BTV-2 (BTV2/26629/PT05) was precisely determined and compared with those of the others. parts of the world. Phylogenetic analysis showed that BTV4/22045/PT04 was associated with other BTV-4 strains circulating in the Mediterranean basin since 1998, with the highest identity (99%) with 2003 BTV-4 isolates from Sardinia and Corsica, BTV2/26629/ PT05 is virtually indistinguishable from the Onderstepoort BTV-2 live attenuated vaccine strain and the related field strain isolated in Italy. As the live-attenuated BTV-2 vaccine has never been used in Portugal, isolation of this strain may represent the natural circulation of the vaccine virus used in other countries in Mediterranean Europe. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Barros, S. C.;Ramos, F.;LuÃ­s, T. M.;Vaz, A.;Duarte, M.;Henriques, M.;Cruz, B.;Fevereiro, M.

title: Infection of macrophages with a lymphotropic herpes virus: a new tropism for Marek's disease virus.
abstract: Marek's disease virus (MDV) is classified as an oncogenic lymphotropic herpes virus of chickens. MDV infects B, Î±Î²T, and Î³Î´T lymphocytes productively and cytolytically and latently infects T helper lymphocytes. The aim of this study was to determine whether MDV infects macrophages in vivo and, if so, whether quantitative differences in macrophage infection are associated with MDV strain virulence. Chickens were infected with either lethal MDV (HPRS-16) or 'hypervirulent' MDV (C12/130). Flow cytometry with monoclonal antibodies recognizing MDV pp38 antigen and leukocyte antigens was used to identify MDV lytically infected cells. Macrophages from chickens infected with HPRS-16- and C12/130 were pp38+. Macrophages were shown to be pp38+, as assessed by confocal microscopy using antibodies that recognize MDV antigens of the three herpes virus kinetic classes: infected cell protein 4 (ICP4, immediate early), pp38 (early), and glycoprotein B (gB, late). Spleen macrophages from MDV-infected chickens were ICP4+, pp38+ and gB+, with nuclear localization in ICP4 indicating infection. Finally, MDV pp38+ macrophages had high natural death rates, confirming cytolytic MDV infection, although production of virus particles has not yet been detected. These results have two key implications for understanding the pathogenesis of MDV: (i) MDV has evolved to disrupt innate in addition to acquired immunity, and (ii) macrophages are excellent candidates for transporting MDV to primary lymphoid organs during the earliest stages of pathogenesis.
authors: Barrow, A. D.;Burgess, S. C.;Baigent, S. J.;Howes, K.;Nair, V. K.

title: Tick-borne viruses
abstract: Tick-borne viruses (TBVs) belong to the largest biological group known as arboviruses, which have a unique mode of transmission from blood-feeding arthropods (ticks, mosquitoes, sandflies, biting midges, etc.) to a susceptible vertebrate host. Taxonomically, they are a heterogeneous group of vertebrate viruses that exist in several viral families. With only one exception, African swine fever virus, all TBVs have an RNA genome. At least 160 tick-borne viruses are known to date, some of which pose a significant threat to human and animal health worldwide. Recently, a number of established TBVs have reemerged and spread to new geographic areas due to the impact of anthropogenic activities and few available vaccines. In addition, emerging tick-borne diseases are constantly being reported. Major advances in molecular biotechnologies have led to the discovery of new TBVs and further genetic characterization of unclassified viruses, leading to changes in the TBV classification established by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses. Although TBVs spend more than 95% of their lifecycles in tick vectors and the role of ticks as vectors has been known for over 100 years, our knowledge of TBVs and the molecular processes involved in virus-tick interactions is very scarce.
authors: BartÃ­kovÃ¡, P.;HolÃ­kovÃ¡, V.;KazimÃ­rovÃ¡, M.;Å tibrÃ¡niovÃ¡, I.

title: Comparative characteristics of the biological characteristics of small ruminant lentiviruses
abstract: Infections caused by small ruminant lentiviruses include diseases such as Maedi-Visna (MV) and goat arthritis-encephalitis (CAE). According to phylogenetic findings and common origin, small ruminant lentiviruses were divided into Groups A, B, C, D and E. Cultivation of lentiviruses demonstrated the cytopathic effect of 75 strains of CAE virus G-63 in primary culture of goats. synovial membrane cells with monolayer destruction and polynuclear cell formation; this was not characteristic for strains M-88, K-796 and Tverskoy. A high homology was found for Group B small ruminant lentiviruses and Tverskoy strain, and Group A with M-88 and K-796 strains.
authors: Baryshnikova, E. I.;Malogolovkin, A. S.;Kolbasova, O. L.;Tsybanov, S. Zh

title: Complete genome sequences of Roman West Nile virus strain 1a from human infection cases in northeastern Italy, 2011
abstract: During 2008-2009, several cases of human WNV disease caused by an endemic strain of strain 1 were reported in the areas surrounding the Po river in northeastern Italy. Since 2010, cases have been recorded in the nearby northern regions, and both lineages 1a and 2 were identified in 2011. Here, we describe two novel WNV whole genome sequences from cases of human WNV infection that occurred in 2011 in the Veneto Region. Phylogenetic analysis showed that both genome sequences belong to lineage 1a and are related to WNV strains of the Western Mediterranean subtype. The new WNV genomes had high nucleotide and amino acid sequence variation from each other and from the WNV strain circulated in Italy in 2008-2009. The existence of different strains of WNV in a relatively small geographical area is a new finding with an unpredictable impact on human diseases and requiring further investigation. Â© 2012 Authors. Clinical Microbiology and Infection Â© 2012 European Society of Clinical Microbiology and Infectious Diseases.
authors: Barzon, L.;Pacenti, M.;Franchin, E.;Squarzon, L.;Lavezzo, E.;Toppo, S.;Martello, T.;Cattai, M.;Cusinato, R.;PalÃ¹, G.

title: Swine flu viruses in North Vietnam in 2013-2014 article
abstract: Pigs are an important intermediate host for the emergence of pandemic influenza. Vietnam is the largest pork producer in South East Asia. Systematic virological and serological surveillance of swine flu viruses was conducted in North Vietnam from May 2013 to June 2014 with monthly pig sampling at local and large mass slaughterhouses and the live pig market. Seroprevalence of Influenza A in local abattoirs and large mass abattoirs was 48.7% and 29.1%, respectively. Seventy-seven influenza A viruses were isolated from the large mass slaughterhouse. Genetic analysis revealed six virus genotypes, including H1N1 2009 pandemic (H1N1pdm09) viruses, H1 human-induced H1N2, H3N2 and H1N1pdm09 reassortants, and triple reassortant H3N2 viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of porcine and human H1N1pdm09 viruses showed evidence of repeated transmission from humans to pigs rather than the long-term establishment of H1N1pdm09 as a long-term divergent lineage in pigs. Surveillance in the large slaughterhouse has proven to be the most efficient, cost-effective and sustainable method of surveillance for swine flu viruses in Vietnam.
authors: Baudon, E.;Chu, D. K. W.;Tung, D. D.;Thi Nga, P.;Vu Mai Phuong, H.;Le Khanh Hang, N.;Thanh, L. T.;Thuy, N. T.;Khanh, N. C.;Mai, L. Q.;Khong, N. V.;Cowling, B. J.;Peyre, M.;Peiris, M.

title: A new type of bovine papillomavirus in the genus Dyokappapapillomavirus
abstract: Papillomaviruses are a diverse group of viruses known to infect a wide variety of animal species. Bovine papillomaviruses (BPVs) are divided into at least 21 genotypes (BPV1 to BPV21); Â Most BPV isolates/strains identified to date belong to one of four genera, including Deltapapillomavirus, Xipapillomavirus, Epsilonpapillomavirus and Dyoxipapillomavirus. Here, we describe the identification and genetic characterization of a new type of BPV in the genus Dyokappapapillomavirus. A farm in New York state, USA, reported cases of chronic vulvovaginitis in Holstein cows in 2016. Biopsies and/or swab samples from the vaginal mucosa were subjected to diagnostic examination. Conventional diagnostic assays yielded negative results and vaginal swab samples were subjected to viral metagenomic sequencing. In particular, BLAST searches revealed a papillomavirus genome with a length of 7480 bp (67% nt sequence identity to BPV16). In addition, phylogenetic analysis of the L1 gene of the papillomavirus (tentatively designated BPV22) described herein revealed that it clusters with members of the Dyokappapapillomavirus genus. Interestingly, the recently identified BPV16 detected in fibropapilloma lesions in cattle also clusters within the Dyocappapillomavirus group. However, each virus forms a separate branch in the phylogenetic tree. These results indicate that putative BPV22 represents the second BPV within the genus Dyokappapapillomavirus.
authors: Bauermann, F. V.;Joshi, L. R.;Mohr, K. A.;Kutish, G. F.;Meier, P.;Chase, C.;Christopher-Hennings, J.;Diel, D. G.

title: Pig circovirus type 1 analysis detected in Rotarix vaccine
abstract: metagenomic analysis of live human vaccines recently demonstrated the presence of porcine circovirus type 1 (PCV1) DNA in the pediatric vaccine Rotarix, used for the prevention of acute gastroenteritis. Using real-time PCR for PCV1, several Rotarix series have found PCV1 DNA titers of the order of 6-7log10 copies per dose. Pretreatment of the reconstituted vaccine with the nuclease Benzonase followed by nucleic acid extraction and quantification of PCV1 DNA by real-time PCR revealed no loss of PCV1 DNA titer compared to untreated controls, suggesting that porcine viral DNA was present in the vaccine in an encapsulated form. PCV1 allowed PS cells, human HEK293 and Vero cells used for vaccine production were infected with Rotarix or PCV1, respectively, and subjected to immunofluorescence and RT-PCR. Viral genomes were present in cells incubated with Rotarix and also infected with PCV1, while viral transcription was seen only in cells infected with PCV1. Similarly, PCV1-specific protein expression was observed in PCV1-infected cells, but not in Rotarix-treated cells. Passage of the supernatant demonstrated productive infection in PCV1-infected PS cells, but not in HEK293 and Vero cells or any of the cell lines incubated with Rotarix. PCV1 DNA in Rotarix was protected from Benzonase digestion; however, PCV1 was not recognized by immune electron microscopy and was unable to infect PS, HEK293 or Vero cells, suggesting that the high amount of PCV1 DNA found in Rotarix does not reflect a corresponding proportion of biologically active virus particles. © 2010 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Baylis, S. A.;Finsterbusch, T.;Bannert, N.;BlÃ¼mel, J.;Mankertz, A.

title: Whole genome sequences of a cytopathic/non-cytopathic pair of bovine viral diarrhea virus subtype 1a viruses
abstract: Whole genome sequences of both biotypes of a pair of bovine viral diarrheal viruses isolated from a cattle affected by mucosal disease were determined by next-generation sequencing. The cytopathic virus had a 423-base insertion derived from bovine poly ubiquitin and a nucleotide change in the NS2/3 coding region. Both biotypes showed an additional glycosylation site at their N-terminus.
authors: Bazzucchi, M.;Bertolotti, L.;Giammarioli, M.;De Mia, G. M.

title: Identification and genetic characterization of bovine enterovirus by combination of two next-generation sequencing platforms
abstract: Rapid and accurate diagnosis is guaranteed for infectious diseases of pets that could have a significant impact on animal production or clinical practice. In this study, the identification and genetic characterization of bovine enterovirus (BEV) strain isolated from a calf with diarrhea is described. Two different next-generation sequencing platforms were used. Shotgun metagenomics performed by MinION sequencing (Oxford Nanopore Technologies) allowed the identification of BEV RNA from a cell culture isolate. BEV was then confirmed by a specific real-time RT-PCR assay. To obtain the entire genome of this isolate, sequence reads obtained by MinION were combined with those originating from NextSeq500 (Illumina). Genomic association and phylogeny with existing BEV strains have also been reported. Overall, this manuscript highlights the use of portable Minion array technology as a tool to support diagnostics in veterinary practice.
authors: Beato, M. S.;Marcacci, M.;Schiavon, E.;Bertocchi, L.;Di Domenico, M.;Peserico, A.;Mion, M.;Zaccaria, G.;Cavicchio, L.;Mangone, I.;Soranzo, E.;Patavino, C.;CammÃ , C.;Lorusso, A.

title: Genetic and antigenic characterization of novel pestivirus genotypes: Implications for classification
abstract: Currently, the Pestivirus genus consists of four confirmed strains of Bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 (BVDV-1), BVDV-2, Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) and Border disease virus (BDV) and a transient fifth strain represented by a single strain. (H138) was isolated from a giraffe in Kenya more than 30 years ago. To further address the heterogeneity of pestiviruses, we identified all Npro and E2 coding sequences for several novel pestivirus isolates. Interestingly, phylogenetic analysis revealed that a pestivirus isolated in Africa in the 1990s was closely related to strain H138. Moreover, several novel pestiviruses isolated from the sheep group differ significantly from all previously described pestiviruses, including a sheep pestivirus strain (Gifhorn), BDV, together with the previously described V60 strain (Reindeer-1) isolated from a reindeer. . We propose to call these mainly sheep-derived pestiviruses BDV-2 (V60-like isolates) and BDV-3 (Gifhorn); as a result, "classical" BDV isolates should be designated BDV-1. As an additional criterion for the separation of pestiviruses, the antigenic relationship of pestivirus isolates covering all the major genotypes observed was examined by cross-neutralization experiments. Analysis of antigenic similarities revealed the presence of seven major antigenic groups corresponding to BVDV-1, BVDV-2, CSFV, BDV-1, BDV-2, BDV-3 and "giraffe". We suggest that BDV-1, BDV-2 and BDV-3 should be considered as the main genotypes, given the absence of differences in host origin, disease course, and the results of our genetic and antigenic analyzes. species BDV. © 2003 Elsevier Science (USA). All rights reserved.
authors: Becher, P.;Ramirez, R. A.;Orlich, M.;Rosales, S. C.;KÃ¶nig, M.;Schweizer, M.;Stalder, H.;Schirrmeier, H.;Thiel, H. J.

title: Genetic typing of Croatian bovine viral diarrhea virus isolates
abstract: Between 2007 and 2011, a total of 1937 serum samples and five spleen samples from nine Croatian dairy herds were tested for bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) using virus isolation and immunoperoxidase testing. BVDV was detected in 13 persistently infected (PI) cattle with a non-cytopathogenic biotype, while isolates from spleen samples in five animals with fatal mucosal disease were of the cytopathogenic biotype. To reveal genetic typing of Croatian BVDV isolates, viral RNA was extracted from infected cell cultures and amplified by RT-PCR, primers targeting the 5'-UTR and Npro gene, followed by direct sequencing of purified PCR products. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the 5'-UTR genome region determined that all Croatian isolates belong to BVDV genotype 1; 11 isolates were grouped with BVDV-lb and 7 isolates with BVDV-If viruses. Phylogenetic tree extracted by Bayesian approach using combined 5'-UTR/Npro favored clustering of Croatian isolates into two subgroups. The deduced amino acid sequence of the Npro region revealed 5 regions unique to the four native BVDV-If isolates.
authors: Bedekovic, T.;Lojkic, I.;Lemo, N.;Cac, Z.;Cvetnic, Z.;Lojkic, M.;Madic, J.

title: Schmallenberg virus - a new orthobunyavirus emerging in Europe
abstract: SUMMARY In 2011, Schmallenberg virus (SBV), a novel orthobunia virus of the Simbu serogroup, was discovered using a metagenomic approach. SBV has caused a major epidemic in ruminant animals in Europe. It appears to be transmitted by biting midges, as is the case with related viruses such as the Akabane virus. Transplacental infection often results in the birth of defective calves, lambs and goats. Acute infections have been detected in adult ruminants or malformed SBV-positive offspring, and high seroprevalences in adult ruminants have been detected on more than 5000 farms in Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, Luxembourg, Denmark and Switzerland. seen. Core regions in the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium. This review covers the discovery of SBV, the spread of the epidemic, the role of vectors, the impact on livestock, public health issues, SBV diagnosis and precautions taken. The lessons to be learned from the Schmallenberg virus outbreak and the consequences of future outbreaks are discussed. Copyright © Cambridge University Press 2012.
authors: Beer, M.;Conraths, F. J.;Van Der Poel, W. H. M.

title: Multiple reclassified viruses as cause of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) virus outbreak, Netherlands, 2016
abstract: In 2016, an outbreak of the highly pathogenic avian influenza A virus subtype H5N8 in the Netherlands caused mass mortality among wild birds, and several commercial poultry farms and captive bird businesses were affected. We performed complete genome sequencing to examine the relationship between wild avian and avian viruses. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the viruses were related to H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses detected in Russia in May 2016, but contained 2 different variants of the novel polymerase basic 2 and nucleoprotein gene segments and polymerase acidic segment. Molecular dating suggests that reclassification events most likely occurred in wild birds from Russia or Mongolia. In addition, 2 genetically distinct H5N5 reassortant viruses were detected in wild birds in the Netherlands. Our study provides evidence for rapid and sustained reclassification of H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses that can lead to rapid changes in virus characteristics such as pathogenicity, infectivity, transmission, and zoonotic potential.
authors: Beerens, N.;Heutink, R.;Bergervoet, S. A.;Harders, F.;Bossers, A.;Koch, G.

title: Molecular analysis of swine hepatitis E virus from northern India
abstract: Background and targets: Hepatitis E is the main cause of enterically transmitted non-A, non-B hepatitis in developing countries. In developed countries such as the USA, Japan, and Taiwan, viruses that infect humans and pigs share the same genotype with high sequence similarity. Genotype 1 circulates in humans, while genotype 4 is found in pigs in India. This study was designed to investigate the presence of anti-HEV antibodies and HEV-RNA in the swine population from northern India, to investigate the genotype prevalent in this population, and to compare it with other swine and human HEV strains from India. Methods: A Indian A total of 67 serum samples were collected from aged (1-6 months) pigs from the Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI), Izatnagar, Bareily and subjected to anti-HEV IgG and HEV RNA detection. A phylogenetic tree was constructed using the neighbor-joining method and evaluated using the internal branch test method with MEGA 4 software. Results: Anti-HEV IgG and HEV RNA were found in 38.8 percent and 4.5 percent, respectively, of the porcine samples examined. The above samples were observed to be genotype 4e. The three new sequences had nucleotide similarity with other pig sequences in genotype 4 ranging from 80 to 98 percent. Interpretation and Conclusions: The three sequences observed in this study showed nucleotide similarity to other pig sequences from southern and western India. This study shows that genotype 4 'e' is common in northern India.
authors: Begum, N.;Polipalli, S. K.;Husain, S. A.;Kar, P.

title: Relationships and history of live Newcastle disease vaccine strains
abstract: NDV (Newcastle disease virus) strains used to be classified solely on the basis of virulence, but recently grouping based on genetic associations of strains is the preferred method. Live vaccine strains belong to the categories of mild (lentogenic) or moderately virulent (mesogenic), in contrast to the highly pathogenic epidemic viruses of the velogenic group. Insertion of vaccine strains into the 'NDV world' using their genetic traits and ancestry can be visualized as described below (Figure 1). 1. Lentogenic vaccine strains are found in two of the dozen or so NDV genotypes resident in chickens. One is American group 11 (includes vaccine strains B-1, LaSota, and F), and the other is genotype I (with strains Ulster 2C, V4/Queensland and NDV-6/10), also in wild waterfowl. 2. Mesogenic strains are also found in only two genotypes: group 11 (Roakin and Komarov strains) and Asian genogroup III (H and Mukteswar strains). 3. Vaccine strains of Groups I and 11 were of natural origin, while strains H, Mukteswar and Komarov were artificially attenuated, as claimed in reports in the 1940s. However, differences were seen between the true genetic identity and the putative origin of the mesogenic vaccine strains (Fig. 2). a) Since the mesogenic strain H is unrelated to its apparent parent, the virulent Herts'33, the reduced virulence of H cannot be attributed to egg-passing procedures performed in the UK, and its very existence is a puzzle. b) Strains H and Mukteswar with less than 0.3% nucleotide distance between them must be derived from the same isolate and thus cannot be the result of independent developments in the UK and India. c) The reduced virulence (mesogenic) of the H/Mukteswar strain cannot be associated with attenuation either; most likely a naturally occurring Indian field isolate. d) The mesogenic Komarov strain, which is said to be attenuated by intracerebral transmission of a local velogenic virus in ducklings in Palestine, is identical to Roakin, the American (genotype 11) vaccine strain for which no scientific explanation can be given.
authors: Bela, L.

title: New viruses detected by metagenomic approaches in veterinary medicine
abstract: In our world today, facing extraordinary environmental changes and dramatically intensifying globalization, we are facing challenges due to many new factors, including the emergence or re-emergence of hitherto "unknown" infectious diseases. Although we have a large arsenal of diagnostic methods at our disposal, most conventional diagnostic tests are highly virus-specific or target only a limited group of infectious agents. This specificity makes it difficult or even inhibits the detection of new or unexpected pathogens, such as new, emerging or re-emerging viruses or new viral variants. Recently developed viral metagenomic approaches provide an effective new way to screen samples and detect viruses without prior knowledge of the infectious agent, thus enabling better diagnosis and disease control in line with the principles of "One World, One Health" (www. oneworldonehealth). .organ). Using metagenomic approaches, we have recently identified a wide variety of novel viruses, such as novel bocaviruses, Torque Teno viruses, astroviruses, rotaviruses and cobuviruses, novel virus variants in honeybee populations, and a number of other infectious agents in swine disease syndromes. in other host species. These findings demonstrate that metagenomic detection of viral pathogens is now becoming a powerful, culture-independent and useful new diagnostic tool in veterinary diagnostic virology. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: BelÃ¡k, S.;Karlsson, O. E.;BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Berg, M.;Granberg, F.

title: Advances in viral disease diagnosis and molecular epidemiological technologies
abstract: The early and rapid detection and characterization of specific nucleic acids of medical-veterinary pathogens has proven invaluable for diagnostic purposes. The integration of amplification and signal detection systems, including online real-time instruments, has increased speed and sensitivity and greatly facilitated the quantification of target nucleic acids. They also allowed sequence characterization using melting or hybridization curves. Next-generation molecular diagnostic technologies offer hitherto unique detection and discrimination methodologies vital for the positive detection and identification of pathogenic agents, as well as the effects of pathogens on antibody production. The development phase of new technologies requires a thorough understanding of the accurate diagnosis and differentiation of existing and emerging diseases. The development of new technologies can only be successful if they are transferred and used in the field with a sustainable quality-assured practice to allow for optimal detection and effective control of diseases. The purpose of these new tools is to detect the presence of a pathogenic agent before disease begins. This manuscript mainly focuses on the experiences of two World Animal Health Organization collaborating centers in the context of molecular diagnosis and molecular epidemiology of transboundary and endemic animal diseases of viral origin, food safety and zoonoses. Â© 2009 Expert Reviews Ltd.
authors: BelÃ¡k, S.;ThorÃ©n, P.;LeBlanc, N.;Viljoen, G.

title: African swine fever virus and AIDS
authors: Beldekas, J.;Teas, J.;Hebert, J. R.

title: Propidium monoazide (PMA) and ethidium bromide monoazide (EMA) improve DNA sequencing and high-throughput sequencing of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus identification
abstract: Pan-viral DNA sequencing (PVDA) and high-throughput sequencing (HTS) are useful tools for identifying novel viruses of emerging diseases. However, both techniques have difficulties in identifying viruses in clinical samples due to the host genomic nucleic acid content (hg/cont). Both propidium monoazide (PMA) and ethidium bromide monoazide (EMA) have free DNA/RNA binding capacity, but the cell membrane is not permeable. Therefore, both are unable to bind conserved nucleic acids like viral genomes within intact virions. However, genetic material modified with EMA/PMA cannot be amplified by enzymes. To evaluate the potential of EMA/PMA to reduce the presence of amplifiable hg/cont in samples and improve virus detection, porcine reproductive and respiratory virus (PRRSV) was added to serum and lung tissue homogenates and treated with EMA/PMA. In addition, clinical samples positive for PRRSV RT-qPCR were also tested. EMA/PMA treatments significantly reduced amplified hg/cont and significantly increased the number of PVDA positive probes and their signal intensity compared to untreated spike lung samples. EMA/PMA treatments also increased the sensitivity of HTS by increasing the number of specific PRRSV readings and the percentage of PRRSV coverage. Interestingly, EMA/PMA treatments significantly increased the sensitivity of PVDA and HTS in two of the three clinical tissue samples. Therefore, EMA/PMA treatments offer a new approach to lower amplified hg/cont in clinical samples and increase the success of PVDA and HTS in identifying viruses.
authors: Bellehumeur, C.;Boyle, B.;Charette, S. J.;Harel, J.;L'Homme, Y.;Masson, L.;Gagnon, C. A.

title: High-throughput sequencing revealed the presence of an unpredictable strain of parvovirus in the Canadian pig: porcine partetravirus.
authors: Bellehumeur, C.;Boyle, B.;Mandeville, I.;Gagnon, C. A.

title: Atypical rotavirus in chickens in Argentina
abstract: The presence of rotavirus was investigated in a flock of chickens that experienced periodic episodes of diarrhea in the winter of 1986 in Argentina. All samples analyzed were negative by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). However, when the samples were examined by electron microscopy, particles indistinguishable from standard rotaviruses were detected in some samples. Of the 36 samples, 10 were positive after polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) analysis and all showed the same electropherotype. Based on these results, these viruses were classified as rotavirus-like or atypical rotaviruses.
authors: Bellinzoni, R.;Mattion, N.;Vallejos, L.;La Torre, J. L.;Scodeller, E. A.

title: Serological characterization of bovine rotaviruses isolated from dairy and cattle herds in Argentina.
abstract: Bovine rotaviruses isolated from cattle and dairy herds in Argentina, as previously described (G. Gerna, M. Battaglia, G. Milenesi, N. Passarani, E. Percivalle, and E. Cattaneo, Infect. Immun) immunoperoxidase focal reduction assay. was serotyped with. 43:722-729, 1984). Three strains from the cattle herds were associated with the UK and NCDV bovine rotavirus strains identified as serotype 6 (Y. Hoshino, TG Wyatt, HB Greenberg, J. Flores, and AZ Kapikian, J. Infect. Dis. 149:694-702, 1984). Two other strains from dairy herds were classified as bovine viruses related to the bovine strain B223 reported by Woode et al. (GN Woode, NE Kelso, TF Simpson, SK Gaul, LE Evans and L. Babiuk, J. Clin. Microbiol). 18:258-264, 1983) in the United States. To detect serotype 6 rotavirus using a serotype 6-specific monoclonal antibody, an enzyme-linked immunoassay that captures a serotyping antibody was developed and evaluated for strain characterization. Characterization of 72 group A rotavirus positive stool samples from cattle herds and 43 stool samples from dairy herds showed that serotype 6 rotavirus was predominant in cattle herds, but both serotype 6 and non-serotype 6 rotaviruses were dominant in dairy herds. Genomic double-stranded RNA analysis by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis showed that when outbreaks were caused by one serotype, only a single electropherotype was present in all samples.
authors: Bellinzoni, R. C.;Blackhall, J. O.;Mattion, N. M.;Estes, M. K.;Snodgrass, D. R.;LaTorre, J. L.;Scodeller, E. A.

title: Genotype Diversity of Newcastle Disease Virus in Nigeria: Disease Control Challenges and Looking Ahead
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the most important avian diseases threatening poultry productivity worldwide. The disease is associated with severe respiratory, gastrointestinal, and neurological lesions in chickens that lead to high mortality and some other production-related losses. The etiology of the disease is an avian paramyxovirus type-1 or Newcastle disease virus (NDV), whose isolates are serologically grouped into a single serotype, but genetically classified into a total of 19 genotypes due to the continued emergence and evolution of the virus. In Nigeria, molecular characterization of NDV is generally minimal and largely focuses on amplification of the partial F gene for genotype assignment. However, with the introduction of the most objective NDV genotyping criteria using whole fusion protein coding sequences in phylogenetic taxonomy, the enormous genetic diversity of the virus in Nigeria has become very remarkable. In this review, we examine the current ecological distribution of various NDV genotypes in Nigeria based on available complete fusion protein nucleotide sequences (1662 bp) in the NCBI database. Next, we will discuss the challenges of ND control as a result of the wide genetic distance between currently circulating NDV isolates and the most common vaccines used in the country to combat the disease. Finally, we propose future directions in the battle against economically devastating ND in Nigeria.
authors: Bello, M. B.;Yusoff, K. M.;Ideris, A.;Hair-Bejo, M.;Peeters, B. P. H.;Jibril, A. H.;Tambuwal, F. M.;Omar, A. R.

title: Novel polyphenol oxidase extracted from the metagenome expression library of bovine rumen: Biochemical properties, structural analysis and phylogenetic relationships
abstract: RL5, a gene encoding a novel polyphenol oxidase, was identified by activity screening of a metagenome expression library from bovine rumen microflora. Characterization of the recombinant protein produced in Escherichia coli revealed a multipotent capacity to oxidize a wide variety of substrates (syringaldazin > 2,6-dimethoxyphenol > veratryl alcohol > guaiacol > tetramethylbenzidine > 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol > 2.2â€²-azino-bis (3-ethylbenzthiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) (ABTS) – â‰« phenol red) over an unusually wide pH range from 3.5 to 9.0. For ABTS, syringaldazine and 2,6-dimethoxyphenol, the apparent Km and k cat values obtained from steady-state kinetic measurements at 40°C, pH 4.5 gave values of 26, 0.43 and 0.45 Î¼M and 18, 660 and 1175. s-1 respectively. Km values for syringaldazine and 2,6-dimethoxyphenol are up to 5 times lower than previously reported values for this enzyme class, and kcat values are up to 40 times higher. RL5 is a 4 copper oxidase with oxidation potential values of 745, 400 and 500 mV compared to the normal hydrogen electrode for the T1, T2 and T3 copper regions. A three-dimensional model of RL5 and site-directed mutants were generated to identify copper ligands. Bioinformatic analysis of the gene sequence and the sequences and contexts of neighboring genes suggested a tentative phylogenetic assignment to the genus Bacteroides. Kinetic, electrochemical, and EPR analyzes provide conclusive evidence that putative proteins from Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron and E. coli, which is closely related to the deduced protein encoded by the RL5 gene, are also multicopper proteins with polyphenol oxidase activity. This study demonstrates that these three newly characterized enzymes form a new family of functional multicopper oxidases with laccase activity related to conserved hypothetical proteins harboring the domain of unknown function DUF152, suggesting that some of these proteins may also be laccases. Â© 2006, American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.
authors: Beloqui, A.;Pita, M.;Polaina, J.;MartÃ­nez-Arias, A.;Golyshina, O. V.;ZumÃ¡rraga, M.;Yakimov, M. M.;GarcÃ­a-Arellano, H.;Alcalde, M.;FernÃ¡ndez, V. M.;Elborough, K.;Andreu, J. M.;Ballesteros, A.;Plou, F. J.;Timmis, K. N.;Ferrer, M.;Golyshin, P. N.

title: Molecular characterization of epizootic hemorrhagic disease virus associated with the Tunisian epidemic among cattle in 2006.
abstract: In 2006, outbreaks of epizootic hemorrhagic disease (EHD) among cattle were recorded in the Maghreb (Tunisia, Morocco and Algeria), which had serious repercussions on herds (head edema, necrotic lesions of the oral mucosa, hyperthermia of the teats, concomitant hyperthermia). anorexia and respiratory distress) and economic losses. This study provides new insights into the molecular characterization of the EHD virus (EHDV) circulating in Tunisia. Genome segments 2, 3, 6, 7 and 10 of EHDV, corresponding to the proteins VP2, VP3, VP5, VP7 and NS3/NS3A, respectively, were amplified and sequenced from the blood of an animal by RT-PCR. Nucleotide sequence comparisons of these five segments with sequences available in GenBank showed that an EHDV serotype 6 (EHDV-6) was present in Tunisia in 2006. The possible origin of this species is discussed.
authors: Ben Dhaou, S.;Sailleau, C.;Babay, B.;Viarouge, C.;Sghaier, S.;Zientara, S.;Hammami, S.;BrÃ©ard, E.

title: Prioritization of zoonotic viral diseases in wild pigs, domestic pigs and human interface
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Understanding the ecology of diseases requires an understanding of pathogens at the wildlife-animal interface. Wild pigs (Sus scrofa) are a health concern when countries try to prevent and control zoonotic diseases, as their populations raise environmental and health concerns due to infectious agents that can infect domestic pigs and other animal species, including humans. diseases at the interface of wild boars, domestic animals and humans. MATERIALS AND METHODS: The evidence-based semi-quantitative prioritization method included 27 criteria identified in recent publications. We classified them into five categories based on viral etiology: epidemiology (eight), prevention/control (three), economy/business (four), public health (nine), and society (three). Each criterion had a coefficient of 0 to 7 according to their evidence-based effects (maximum total of 189). Evidence for criteria for the nine viral diseases analyzed was obtained from a review of 81 sources published between 1977 and 2015. RESULTS: The top three diseases with the highest scores and zoonotic potential were swine flu (133), hepatitis E (123), and hantavirus infection (103) with the highest scores in the epidemiology and public health criteria. CONCLUSION: Semi-quantitative prioritization methods, evidence-based contributes impartially to decision making; however, they are rarely used in developing countries due to the lack of data from public health surveillance. Controlling common diseases requires the development of strategies to reduce the transmission of pathogens between wildlife, domestic animals and humans.
authors: Benavides-Arias, D.;Soler-Tovar, D.

title: Characterization of surface proteins of influenza A (H5N1) viruses isolated from humans in 1997-1998
abstract: Influenza A (H5N1) viruses infected people in Hong Kong between May and December 1997. Sixteen viruses were isolated during this epidemic, including 6 fatal cases. Molecular analysis of the surface proteins genes encoding hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) of these H5N1 isolates, a subtype not previously known to infect humans, is presented. The 16 human H5 HA sequences contain multiple basic amino acids adjacent to the cleavage site, a motif associated with highly pathogenic avian influenza A viruses. The phylogenetic relationship between both avian and human H5 hemagglutinins suggests that human isolates are directly related to isolates circulating among chickens in five poultry markets in Hong Kong before and during the outbreak in humans. HA sequences from human isolates and a novel chicken isolate represent a distinct clade in which two subsets can be distinguished antigenically and by the presence of a potential glycosylation site. Similarly, N1 neuraminidases of human H5 isolates represent a class that is evolutionarily distinct from previously characterized N1 neuraminidases. Recent human H5N1 virus NA genes are avian-like, indicating direct entry from an avian source rather than evolution of a human N1 NA. All 16 human NA genes encode a shortened stem due to a 19 amino acid deletion, also found in avian H5N1 isolates recently obtained from Hong Kong. Two unique amino acids were identified in the N1 NAs of recent human isolates; however, it is unknown whether these residues affect host range. Neither the HA nor the NA genes of human H5N1 virus isolates show evidence of adaptive changes during the epidemic. While analyzes of the surface protein genes of HSN1 viruses in this epidemic did not provide immediate answers to the molecular basis for virulence, the analyzes did provide clues to potentially important areas of the genes that are worth further investigation.
authors: Bender, C.;Hall, H.;Huang, J.;Klimov, A.;Cox, N.;Hay, A.;Gregory, V.;Cameron, K.;Lim, W.;Subbarao, K.

title: Analysis of Variability in Non-Coding Regions of Influenza A Viruses
abstract: The genomes of influenza A viruses (IAVs) contain eight negative-sense single-stranded RNA segments. In addition to the protein-coding region, each segment has 5' and 3' non-coding regions (NCR), which are important for transcription, replication and packaging. NCRs contain both conserved and segment-specific sequences, and the effects of variability in NCRs are not fully understood. Full NCRs have been identified from some viruses, but a detailed analysis of the potential variability in these regions between viruses from different host groups and locations has not been performed. To assess the degree of protection in NCRs among different viruses, we sequenced the NCRs of IAVs isolated from different wild avian host groups (ducks, gulls and seabirds). We then expanded our study to include NCRs available from the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) Influenza Virus Database, allowing us to analyze a wider variety of host species and more HA and NA subtypes. We found that the amount of variation within NCRs varied between segments, with the greatest variation being in HA and NA and the least in M and NS segments. Overall, variability in NCR sequences was correlated with coding region phylogeny, suggesting vertical coevolution of (coding sequence) CDS and NCR regions.
authors: Benkaroun, J.;Robertson, G. J.;Whitney, H.;Lang, A. S.

title: Molecular techniques: new opportunities in light of adenovirus research
abstract: Presenting their latest achievements in the field of adenovirus research, the author summarizes the new possibilities found in modern molecular techniques that are revolutionizing virus research and diagnostics. Among the new methods, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is of the greatest importance. Due to the large and growing number of known virus serotypes, the classical serological identification of new isolates has become extremely demanding today. In addition, reliable collections of reference strains and serums are rarely available in laboratories. PCR combined with sequencing offers a fast and efficient alternative. New viruses identified and classified by these methods are called types instead of serotypes. In different veterinary laboratories, the large number of strains of adenovirus isolated in different veterinary laboratories over the past few decades have not yet been characterized. Now these viruses can be typed and classified by sequence analysis of specific genes. Another major advantage of the method is that it allows molecular characterization of non-isolated viruses. This is particularly valuable for the study of adenoviruses from wild animals when isolation of the virus is often not a realistic option. The author's research group is the first in the world to determine the complete genomic sequence of an adenovirus solely through PCRs from infected organ samples of diseased and dead birds without successful isolation of the virus. Organ samples from different vertebrate animals found dead in zoos, pet stores, or the wild are continuously screened by PCR in the author's lab. Fecal samples are equally suitable for screening purposes. Besides birds and reptiles, a high rate of adenoviral infection has recently been demonstrated among domestic bats.
authors: Benko, M.

title: A proposal for a new (third) genus within the family Adenoviridae
abstract: This article presents a proposal for the establishment of a new adenovirus genus to host certain bovine, ovine and avian adenoviruses with special features that distinguish them from members of the existing genera Mastadenovirus and Aviadenovirus. This recommendation was developed from previous versions with the recommendation of the Adenovirus Working Group of the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV).
authors: BenkÃ¶, M.;Harrach, B.

title: Does common architecture spawn a viral lineage spanning all three domains of life?
abstract: Our discovery that the major coat protein of the bacteriophage PRD1 is similar to that of human adenovirus raised the unexpected possibility that viruses infecting bacteria may be evolutionarily related to those infecting animal hosts. We first review the evolution of this idea. Next, we describe how we used structure-based modeling to show that several other viruses with no detectable sequence similarity have coats made of similar proteins - the "double-barrelled trimer". There is evidence that the group includes several viruses that infect very different hosts in all three areas of life: Eukarya; bacterium; and Archaea, which split billions of years ago. The current classification of viruses hides such similarities. We propose that the appearance of a double-barrelled trimer coat protein in an icosahedral dsDNA virus with major aspects, regardless of its host, is a very strong indicator of membership in a viral lineage with a common ancestor.
authors: Benson, S. D.;Bamford, J. K. H.;Bamford, D. H.;Burnett, R. M.

title: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever: history, epidemiology, pathogenesis, clinical syndrome and genetic diversity
abstract: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is the most important tick-borne viral disease in humans, causing sporadic cases or outbreaks of serious disease in a wide geographical area from western China to the Middle East and Southeast Europe and most of Africa. CCHF is maintained in vertical and horizontal transmission cycles involving disease-free ixodid ticks and a variety of wild and domesticated vertebrates. The virus circulates in a number of tick genera, but Hyalomma ticks are the major source of human infection, possibly because both immature and adult forms actively seek hosts for the blood meals required at all stages of maturation. CCHF is most common among farm workers following the bite of an infected tick, and to a lesser extent among slaughterhouse workers who are exposed to the blood and tissues of infected farm animals and medical personnel through contact with bodily fluids of infected animals. CCHFV is the most genetically diverse of the arboviruses, with nucleotide sequence differences between isolates ranging from 20% for the viral S segment to 31% for the M segment. While viruses with different sequences can be found in the same geographic area, closely related viruses have been isolated in very distant regions, suggesting that CCHF has been widely spread from time to time in the past, possibly via migratory bird-borne ticks or international channels. animal trade.
