Reclassification between genome segments during co-infection of ticks or vertebrates appears to have played an important role in generating diversity and represents a potential future source of new viruses. In this article, we review the current knowledge of CCHF by first summarizing its molecular biology, maintenance and transmission, epidemiology, and geographic range. We also include a comprehensive discussion of CCHFV genetic diversity, including maps of the virus's range with overlaid phylogenetic trees. We then review the characteristics of CCHF, including the clinical syndrome, diagnosis, treatment, pathogenesis, vaccine development, and laboratory animal models of CCHF. The article ends with a discussion of the possible future geographic range of the virus. For the benefit of researchers, we include an Supplementary Table listing all published reports of CCHF cases and outbreaks in the English literature, as well as some key articles in other languages, with total case counts, case fatality rates, and all CCHF viruses in GenBank. Â© 2013 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Bente, D. A.;Forrester, N. L.;Watts, D. M.;McAuley, A. J.;Whitehouse, C. A.;Bray, M.

title: Genetic characterization and phylogenetic analysis of host range genes of Camelpox virus isolates from India
abstract: Camelpox virus (CMLV), a close variant of the Variola virus (VARV), infects camels worldwide. The zoonotic infections reported from India point to the need to study host-range genes responsible for host tropism. We report the sequence and phylogenetic analysis of five host-range genes: cytokine response modifier B (crmB), chemokine binding protein (ckbp), viral schlafen-like (v-slfn), myxomavirus T4-like (M-T4-like) and isolated from outbreaks in India. acquired b5r CMLV. Comparative analysis revealed that these genes are conserved among CMLVs and share 94.5%-100% identity at both the nucleotide (nt) and amino acid (aa) levels. All genes showed identity (59.3%-98.4%Â) with cowpox virus (CPXV), while three genes-crmB, ckbp and b5r showed similarity (92%-96.5%Â) with VARVs at both the nt and aa levels. . Interestingly, three consecutive serine residue insertions were observed in the CKBP protein of the CMLV-Delhi09 isolate, which was similar to CPXV-BR and VACVs, with five point mutations (K53Q, N67I, F84S, A127T, and E182G) similar to zoonotic OPXVs. Also, several inconsistent point mutations were observed in other gene(s) among Indian CMLVs. These suggest that different strains of CMLV are circulating in India and that these mutations may play an important role in the adaptation of CMLVs in humans. The phylogeny revealed co-clustering of all CMLVs except CMLV-Delhi09, which was grouped separately due to the presence of specific point mutations. However, the topology of the combined phylogeny showed the close evolutionary relationship of CMLV with VARV and TATV, followed by CPXV-RatGer09/1 from Germany. The availability of this genetic information will be useful in uncovering new strategies to control emerging zoonotic poxvirus infections.
authors: Bera, B. C.;Barua, S.;Shanmugasundaram, K.;Anand, T.;Riyesh, T.;Vaid, R. K.;Virmani, N.;Kundu, S.;Yadav, N. K.;Malik, P.;Singh, R. K.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of host range (E3L, K3L and C7L) and structural protein (B5R) genes of buffalopox virus isolates from buffalo, bovine and human in India.
abstract: Buffalopox virus (BPXV), a close variant of vaccinia virus (VACV), has emerged as a zoonotic pathogen. The host tropism of poxviruses is governed by host-range genes. Among the host range genes: E3L, K3L and C7L are essential for virus replication by preventing interferon resistance, whereas B5R is essential for virus spread and evade the host immune response as in VACV. We report the sequence analysis of host-range genes: E3L, K3L, C7L and membrane protein gene (B5R) of BPXVs from buffalo, bovine and human from recent outbreaks in India - their phylogenetic relationships with the reference strain (BP4) and other Orthopoxviruses. BPXVs revealed a range of homology with VACVs, including zoonotic Brazilian VACV-like viruses. The aa sequences of the E3L and K3L genes were 100% similar in buffalo, bovine and human isolates. However, only four important point mutations specific to the buffalo isolate (N12K and S36F in the C7L gene and D249G in the B5R gene) were observed. This indicates that different strains of BPXV were circulating during the outbreak. Mutations in C7L and B5R may play an important role in the adaptation of BPXV in humans and cattle, which needs further functional studies. BPXV strain isolated from buffalo may not be adopted in humans and cows. Various point mutations were observed in the host range genes of the reference strain (BPXV-BP4), which may be due to several virus passages in cell culture. The phylogeny constructed based on the assembled gene sequences revealed that BPXVs were not closely related to the vaccine strain (Lister and Lister-derived strain - LC16m8) as previously assumed, but rather more closely related to the reference strain (BPXV-BP4) and others. . Vaccine and vaccine-like viruses such as Passatempo and Aracatuba viruses. The availability of information on host tropism markers will enable us to understand the molecular mechanism of species tropism of poxviruses, which may be useful in uncovering new strategies to control zoonotic poxviral infections. © 2012 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Bera, B. Ch;Shanmugasundaram, K.;Barua, S.;Anand, T.;Riyesh, T.;Vaid, R. K.;Virmani, N.;Bansal, M.;Shukla, B. N.;Malik, P.;Singh, R. K.

title: Analysis of the fusion protein gene of porcine rubula virus LPMV: Comparative analysis of paramyxovirus F proteins.
abstract: Complementary DNA clones representing the fusion (F) protein gene of porcine rubula virus LPMV were isolated and sequenced. The F gene was found to be 1845 nucleotides long, containing a long open reading frame that can encode a protein of 541 amino acids. The cleavage motif for F0 into F1 and F2 is His-Arg-Lys-Lys-Arg. A sequence comparison and a phylogenetic analysis were performed to identify possible functional domains of paramyxovirus fusion proteins and also to classify porcine rubula virus. The F gene of LPMV is most closely related to the human mumps virus and simian virus type 5 F genes and is therefore classified into the rubulavirus genus. However, a coding region for a small hydrophobic protein was not found between the F and hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) genes, previously found in both SV5 and mumps.
authors: Berg, M.;Bergvall, A. C.;Svenda, M.;Sundqvist, A.;Moreno-LÃ³pez, J.;LinnÃ©, T.

title: Phage-bacteria relationships and CRISPR elements revealed by a metagenomic investigation of the rumen microbiome
abstract: Viruses are the most abundant biological entities on the planet and play an important role in balancing microbes within an ecosystem and facilitating horizontal gene transfer. Although bacteriophages are abundant in rumen environments, little is known about the types of viruses present or their interactions with the rumen microbiome. We undertook random pyrosequencing of virus-enriched metagenomes (viromes) isolated from bovine rumen fluid and analyzed the obtained data using comparative metagenomics. A high level of diversity was observed, with up to 28,000 different viral genotypes from each medium. The majority (~78%) of the sequences did not match the viruses previously described. Prophages, the most abundant bacteriophage and prophage types, outstripped lytic phages at a ratio of approximately 2:1, associated with members of the dominant rumen phylum (Firmicutes and Proteobacteria). Metabolic profiling based on SEED subsystems revealed enrichment of sequences with putative functional roles in DNA and protein metabolism, but a surprisingly low proportion of sequences assigned to carbohydrate and amino acid metabolism. We expanded our analysis to include the previously described metagenomic data and 14 reference genomes. Clustered regularly spaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR) were detected in most microbial genomes, suggesting previous interactions between viral and microbial communities. Â© 2011 Society for Applied Microbiology and Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Berg Miller, M. E.;Yeoman, C. J.;Chia, N.;Tringe, S. G.;Angly, F. E.;Edwards, R. A.;Flint, H. J.;Lamed, R.;Bayer, E. A.;White, B. A.

title: Using non-invasive metagenomics to characterize viral communities from wildlife
abstract: Microbial communities play an important role in organismal and ecosystem health. While high-throughput metabarcoding has revolutionized the study of bacterial communities, establishing comparable viral communities has proven difficult, especially in wildlife samples where virus diversity and limited amounts of viral nucleic acids present distinct challenges. Metagenomic sequencing is a promising solution for studying viral communities, but the lack of standardized methods currently hinders comparisons between host taxa or regions. Here, we developed a non-targeted shotgun metagenomic sequencing protocol to generate comparable viral communities from fecal and oropharyngeal swabs collected noninvasively. Using samples from common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus), a key species in transmission of the virus to humans and pets, we tested how different storage environments, nucleic acid extraction procedures, and enrichment steps affect viral community detection. Based on the finding of viral contamination in fetal bovine serum, we recommend storing swabs in RNAlater or other non-biological medium. We recommend extracting nucleic acid directly from swabs rather than supernatant or pelleted material with undetectable viral RNA levels. Results from a low-input RNA library preparation protocol show that ribosomal RNA depletion and mild DNase treatment reduce host and bacterial nucleic acid and improve virus detection. Finally, by applying our approach to twelve pooled samples from seven sites in Peru, we showed that saturated viral communities were detected at the resulting sequencing depth, allowing for unbiased comparisons of viral community composition. Future studies using the methods outlined here will elucidate determinants of viral communities across host species, environments, and time.
authors: Bergner, L. M.;Orton, R. J.;da Silva Filipe, A.;Shaw, A. E.;Becker, D. J.;Tello, C.;Biek, R.;Streicker, D. G.

title: Antigenic and genetic characterization of rabies viruses isolated from domestic and wild animals of Brazil identifies the hoary fox as a reservoir of rabies.
abstract: Fifty Brazilian rabies viruses collected from many different animal species and parts of the country were characterized by partial sequencing of the central, variable region of the P gene, a useful locus for sensitive molecular epidemiological studies. Phylogenetic analysis of the sequences, which included comparison with other rabies strains from all of the Americas, identified three major Brazilian virus groups, arbitrarily termed BRL-1 to BRL-3. BRL-1 was found in terrestrial carnivores and in clusters with other American strains of cosmopolitan ancestry. BRL-2 consisted of two separate isolates from two non-hematophagous bat species with evolutionary links to North American insectivorous bat-derived strains. BRL-3 consisted of isolates from vampire bats and possibly livestock infected by contact with vampire bats. The terrestrial group was further divided into three subtypes: BRL-1a was associated only with dogs and cats, while BRL-1b and BRL-1c were found only in gray foxes. These observations strongly support the role of the Brazilian hoary fox as a reservoir of rabies. Screening of representative Brazilian rabies viruses against a collection of anti-rabies monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) identified a small panel of mAbs that could be used to discriminate among all Brazilian subgroups identified by genetic classification in this study. © 2005 SGM.
authors: Bernardi, F.;Nadin-Davis, S. A.;Wandeler, A. I.;Armstrong, J.;Gomes, A. A. B.;Lima, F. S.;Nogueira, F. R. B.;Ito, F. H.

title: Human herpesvirus 7 is a T-lymphotropic virus and is related to, but significantly different from, human herpesvirus 6 and human cytomegalovirus.
abstract: An independent strain (JI) of human herpes virus 7 (HHV-7) was isolated from a patient with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS). No significant relationship could be established between HHV-7 and CFS with seroepidemiology. HHV-7 is a T-lymphotropic virus that infects CD4+ and CD8+ primary lymphocytes. HHV-7 can also infect an immature T cell line, SUP-T1, with varying success. Southern blot analysis with DNA probes screening 58.8% of the human herpes virus 6 (HHV-6) genome and hybridizing to all HHV-6 strains tested so far, homology to HHV-7 with only 37.4% of the total probe length showed. HHV-7, HHV-6 and Marek's disease contain the GGGTTA repetitive sequence, such as chicken herpes virus. DNA sequencing of a 186 base pair fragment of HHV-7(JI) revealed 57.5% and 36% identity with HHV-6 and human cytomegalovirus, respectively. Oligonucleotide primers (HV7/HV8, HV10/HV11) derived from this sequence only amplified HHV-7 DNA and did not amplify DNA from other human herpesviruses, including 12 different HHV-6 strains. Southern blot analysis with the p43L3 probe containing only the 186-base-pair HHV-7 DNA fragment hybridized to HHV-7 DNA. The molecular difference between human cytomegalovirus on the one hand and HHV-6 and HHV-7 on the other hand is greater than between HHV-6 and HHV-7, which is greater than between HHV-. 6 strains. This study supports the classification of HHV-7 as an additional member of human Î²-herpesviruses.
authors: Berneman, Z. N.;Ablashi, D. V.;Li, G.;Eger-Fletcher, M.;Reitz Jr, M. S.;Hung, C. L.;Brus, I.;Komaroff, A. L.;Gallo, R. C.

title: No evidence for viral sequences in five lepidic adenocarcinomas (formerly "BAC") with a high-throughput sequencing approach
abstract: BACKGROUND: In the past, the hypothesis of an infectious etiology of bronchiolo-alveolar carcinoma (BAC) has been controversial. We investigated tumor lung tissues of five patients with former BAC histology using high-throughput sequencing technologies to discover potential viruses found in this type of lung cancer. Approximately 180 million single 100 base reads were generated for each BAC sample. RESULTS: None of the reads showed significant similarity for Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus (JSRV) and no other viruses were found other than endogenous retroviruses. RESULTS: In conclusion, we demonstrated the absence of JSRV and other known human viruses in five well-characterized lepidic adenocarcinoma samples.
authors: Berthet, N.;Frangeul, L.;Olaussen, K. A.;Brambilla, E.;Dorvault, N.;Girard, P.;Validire, P.;Fadel, E.;Bouchier, C.;Gessain, A.;Soria, J. C.

title: No FMD virus transmission from Permanently Infected Cattle to Pure Cattle in Field Conditions in Vietnam
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD), caused by the foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV; Aphthovirus, Picornaviridae), is a highly contagious and economically important disease of ungulate pet and wildlife species worldwide. Following the clinical phase of FMD, the majority of FMDV-infected ruminants become persistently infected carriers, identified by detection of FMDV in oropharyngeal fluid (OPF) samples 28 days or more after infection. The aim of this prospective study was to characterize the FMD carrier status in cattle following natural infection under typical livestock practices in Vietnam. Ten permanently infected cattle on eight farms in Long An province in Southern Vietnam were followed by monthly screening of serum and oropharyngeal fluid samples for 12 months. To assess transmission from FMDV carriers, 16 pure cattle were deliberately brought into direct contact with permanently infected animals for 6 months and monitored by clinical and laboratory methods. The restricted mean duration of FMD carrier status was 27.7 months, and the rate of reduction in carrier animals was 0.03 per month. There was no evidence of transmission to naïve animals during the study period. In addition, there was no detection of FMDV infection or seroconversion in three calves born to carrier animals at the time of the study. The strength of infection for carrier-to-contact transmission was 0 per month, and the upper 95% confidence limit was 0.064 per month. Phylogenetic analysis of viral protein 1 (VP1) coding sequences from carriers showed that all viruses obtained in this study belong to the O/ME-SA/PanAsia lineage and are grouped with phylogenetically related viruses temporally and geographically. Analysis of the in-host evolution of FMDV based on full-length open reading frame sequences from consecutive samples from an animal showed that most nonsynonymous changes occurred in L<sub>pro</sub>, VP2 and VP2. VP3 protein coding regions. This study suggests that the duration of persistent FMDV infection in cattle may be longer than previously recognized, but the risk of transmission is low. Additional new information is provided on intra-host viral evolution under natural conditions in an endemic environment.
authors: Bertram, M. R.;Vu, L. T.;Pauszek, S. J.;Brito, B. P.;Hartwig, E. J.;Smoliga, G. R.;Hoang, B. H.;Phuong, N. T.;Stenfeldt, C.;Fish, I. H.;Hung, V. V.;Delgado, A.;VanderWaal, K.;Rodriguez, L. L.;Long, N. T.;Dung, D. H.;Arzt, J.

title: ORF serum allergy vascular
abstract: ORF is an infectious disease affecting sheep and goats caused by a parapoxvirus. It can be transmitted to humans and is considered an occupational hazard for those who handle sheep. The authors describe a case of ORF associated with allergic vasculitis, an evolution suggesting a pathogenic role of the virus. A 69-year-old woman presented erythematous plaques with a target-like appearance suggestive of ORF. Ten days after the first lesion appeared, both unbleached purpuric papules and necrotic purpura became evident on the legs, ankles, and dorsum of the feet. Histological evaluation showed leukocytoclastic vasculitis. These latter lesions disappeared within ten days without treatment. Also, ORF lesions resolved spontaneously three weeks after onset. After six months of follow-up, neither ORF lesions nor allergic vasculitis recurred. Viral infections are well known as etiological factors of vasculitis. Many factors led us to think that this case of allergic vasculitis was associated with ORF virus infection: time of onset, duration, resolution of the clinical course of ORF, no need for treatment for recovery, and six-month patient-free follow-up. repeats. This indicates the possibility of the ORF virus being classified within the group of viruses responsible for allergic vasculitis.
authors: Bettoli, V.;Trovato, C.;La Malfa, W.;Pazzaglia, M.

title: Dynamics of acute Montipora white syndrome: bacterial communities of healthy and diseased M. capitata colonies during and after a disease outbreak.
abstract: Coral diseases contribute to the decline of coral reefs globally and threaten the health and future of coral reef communities. Acute Montipora white syndrome (aMWS) is a tissue wasting disease that has killed hundreds of Montipora capitata colonies in Kaneohe Bay, Hawaii in recent years. This work describes the analysis of coral-associated bacterial communities using high-throughput sequencing generated by the PacBio RSII platform. Samples from the three health states of M. capitata (healthy, healthy-diseased, and diseased) were collected during an ongoing aMWS outbreak and a non-outbreak period, and bacterial communities were determined to determine if there was a change in community structure between the two. periods. The bacterial communities associated with the epidemic and non-outbreak samples were significantly different, and one of the main factors was Escherichia spp. in epidemic series. In silico bacterial source tracking suggested that this OTU was likely caused by sewage contamination of livestock and not of human origin. The most abundant coliform OTU was a culturable E. fergusonii isolate, strain OCN300, but did not induce disease symptoms on healthy M. capitata colonies when used in laboratory infection trials. In addition, screening of the sequencing output found that the most abundant OTUs corresponded to the previously described M. capitata pathogens. The synergistic combination of known coral pathogens, sewage pollutants, and other stressors such as fluctuating seawater temperatures and bacterial pathogens has the potential to increase the degradation of coral reef ecosystems.
authors: Beurmann, S.;Ushijima, B.;Videau, P.;Svoboda, C. M.;Chatterjee, A.;Aeby, G. S.;Callahan, S. M.

title: Capripox control and elimination prospects from the Indian subcontinent: A perspective.
abstract: Sheep pox and goat pox, two endemic capripox infections in India, pose a significant economic threat to the productivity of small ruminant animals in the subcontinent. Vaccination of all susceptible sheep and goats is a viable and sustainable method of control. The availability of effective live attenuated vaccines that are inherently thermostable and the development of advanced diagnostics provide opportunities to initiate effective control measures for capripox. All animals older than 4 months can be vaccinated with a single vaccine, either intradermally or subcutaneously, with available homologous vaccines. The success of the control program needs to be monitored with active surveillance, especially for the presence of virus, because sero-monitoring does not differentiate between infection and vaccination. Also, seroconversion following capripox vaccine cannot be adequately detected by available tools. Sustained control efforts require socio-economic and political stability, adequate infrastructure and logistical support to store and transport vaccines for delivery to remote end users. Availability of veterinary services, extension services developed to raise awareness among farmers contribute significantly to control campaigns. Poor vaccination coverage and inadequate infrastructure in large parts of the country are some of the main obstacles to the effective implementation of herd immunity through vaccination. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Bhanuprakash, V.;Hosamani, M.;Singh, R. K.

title: Current status of sheep pox
abstract: Sheep are the lively shores of shepherds and their economic contribution in terms of meat, wool and leather/skin is enormous. Various infectious diseases compromise optimum productivity; Among other economic losses, sheep pox is more important as the disease restricts the export of sheep and their products. Although clinical signs are indicative of disease, laboratory confirmation is required for definitive diagnosis and epidemiology study. The causative agent is antigenically and genetically closely related to sheep pox virus (SPV), goat pox virus (GPV) and tuberous skin disease virus (LSDV), which are other members of the capripox virus genus. In some countries, SPV and GPV are cross-infective for small ruminant animals, which poses a challenge in diagnosis and epidemiology. However, recent studies have shown that viruses are phylogenetically distinct and can be distinguished by molecular tools. Prophylaxis using attenuated vaccines is the choice of control measure since immunity is long lasting. Detailed information on isolation, identification, pathology, epidemiology, diagnosis and prophylaxis will not only help update scientific fraternity knowledge, but will also be useful to policy makers to formulate appropriate measures for the control and eradication of the disease. This synthesis is to provide the reader with a current review of the disease and its control to provide an overview of the problem. Â© 2006 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Bhanuprakash, V.;Indrani, B. K.;Hosamani, M.;Singh, R. K.

title: Fluorogenic RT-PCR test (TaqMan) for detection and classification of bovine viral diarrhea virus
abstract: one-tube fluorogenic RT-PCR based 'TaqMan' test has been developed for the detection and classification of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV). TaqMan-PCR was optimized to quantify BVD virus using the ABI PRISM 7700 array detection system and double-labeled fluorogenic probes. Two different gene-specific labeled fluorogenic probes for the 5â€² untranslated region (5â€² UTR) were used to differentiate between BVD type I and II. The sensitivity of the one-tube TaqMan assay was compared with the two-tube TaqMan assay and standard RT-PCR using 10-fold RNA dilutions. The one-tube TaqMan assay was 10-100 times more sensitive than the two-tube TaqMan assay and standardized one-tube RT-PCR. The specificity of the test was evaluated by testing different strains of BVD virus and other bovine viruses. A total of 106 BVD positive and negative pooled or single serum samples, field isolates and reference strains were tested. Quantification of cRNA from type I and II BVD virus was performed with a standard curve plotting cycle thresholds (CT) versus copy number. The one-tube TaqMan-PCR assay was sensitive, specific, and rapid for detection, quantification, and classification of BVD virus. Â© 2001 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Bhudevi, B.;Weinstock, D.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 Clade 2.3.2.1c virus in migratory birds, 2014-2015
abstract: new Clade 2.3.2.1c H5N1 reassortant virus caused several outbreaks in wild birds in parts of China from late 2014 to 2015. According to genetic and phylogenetic analysis, viruses have a stable gene sequence with Clade 2.3.2.1c HA. , one H9N2-derived PB2 gene and six other genes from Asian H5N1 origin. Clade 2.3.2.1c H5N1 reassortants showed a high genetic association with a human H5N1 strain (A/Alberta/01/2014). Further analysis showed that similar viruses were circulating in wild birds in China, Russia, Dubai (Western Asia), Bulgaria and Romania (Europe), as well as in domestic poultry in parts of Africa. Affected areas include Central Asia, East Asia-Australia, West Asia-East Africa and Black Sea/Mediterranean flight routes. These results suggest that novel Clade 2.3.2.1c reassortant viruses are circulating worldwide and may have gained a selective advantage in migratory birds, thus posing a serious threat to wild birds and potentially to humans. [Figure not available: see full text.]
authors: Bi, Y.;Chen, J.;Zhang, Z.;Li, M.;Cai, T.;Sharshov, K.;Susloparov, I.;Shestopalov, A.;Wong, G.;He, Y.;Xing, Z.;Sun, J.;Liu, D.;Liu, Y.;Liu, L.;Liu, W.;Lei, F.;Shi, W.;Gao, G. F.

title: Atypical bovine spongiform encephalopathies, France, 2001-2007
abstract: In France, through extensive active surveillance, â‰ˆ17.1 million adult cattle were tested for bovine spongiform encephalopathy from July 2001 to July 2007; â‰ˆ3.6 million were >8 years old. Our retrospective Western blot study, which included all 645 confirmed cases, found 7 to be H-type and 6 to L-type.
authors: Biacabe, A. G.;Morignat, E.;Vulin, J.;Calavas, D.;Baron, T. G. M.

title: Genetic analysis of full-length genomes and subgenomic sequences of TT virus-like minivirus human isolates
abstract: The phylogenetic relationship between the whole genomic sequences of ten Japanese and one French TT virus-like minivirus (TLMV) isolate was investigated. Analysis of the variability of nucleotide sequences and detection of signature patterns for overlapping genes indicated that ORF 1 and 2 were likely functional. However, this was not the case for a default third ORF, ORF3. Throughout the viral genome, several nucleotide or amino acid motifs conserved in circoviruses such as TT virus (TTV) and chicken anemia virus were identified. Phylogenetic analysis distinguished the three main TLMV groups and allowed the identification of putative recombination breakpoints in the untranslated region. TLMV genomes were detected by PCR in the plasma of 38/50 French blood donors tested and were also identified in peripheral blood mononuclear cells, stool and saliva. A phylogenetic study of 37 TLMV strains from France, Japan, and Brazil showed that the groupings were not related to geographic origin.
authors: Biagini, P.;Gallian, P.;Attoui, H.;Touinssi, M.;Cantaloube, J. F.;de Micco, P.;de Lamballerie, X.

title: History and biology of Marek's disease virus
authors: Biggs, P. M.

title: Polymerase errors accumulated during the natural evolution of the glycoprotein gene of vesicular stomatitis virus Indiana serotype isolates
abstract: We present the complete glycoprotein (G) gene nucleotide sequences of 26 vesicular stomatitis virus Indiana serotype (VSV IND) type 1 isolates from North and Central America. These sequences are also compared to the partial G gene sequences of VSV IND type 2 (Cocal) and type 3 (Alagoas) viruses and the full G gene sequences of the more distantly related VSV New Jersey (NJ) and Chandipura viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of G gene sequences with maximum sparing revealed four major lineages or subtypes within the classic VSV IND (type 1) viruses, each with a different geographic distribution. A high degree of VSV genetic diversity was found in Central America, and several virus subtypes of both the VSV IND and NJ serotypes were present in this primarily enzootic disease region. Nineteen percent sequence variation, but no deletions or insertions were evident in the 5' non-coding and coding regions of the VSV IND type 1 G genes. In addition to multiple base substitutions, the 3' noncoding regions of these viruses also contained multiple base insertions and deletions. This resulted in a striking variation in G gene sizes, with gene lengths ranging from 1,652 to 1,868 nucleotides. As the VSV IND type 1 subtypes diverged from the common ancestor with the NJ subtypes, their G mRNAs accumulated more 3' non-coding sequence inserts, ranging in length up to 303. They basically consist of an imprecise repetition of the UUUUUAA sequence generated by a unique polymerase stuttering error. Analysis of inferred amino acid sequence differences among VSV IND type 1 viruses revealed multiple substitutions within defined antigenic epitopes, suggesting that immune selection may play a role in the evolution of these viruses.
authors: Bilsel, P. A.;Nichol, S. T.

title: Physiological features and classification of Treponema sp strains. isolated from pigs in Poland
authors: Binek, M.;Szynkiewicz, Z. M.

title: Different genotypes of nephropathogenic infectious bronchitis viruses circulating together in the chicken population in China
abstract: Chicken nephropathogenic infectious bronchitis (IB) has been prevalent in most poultry farms in recent years, but the IB vaccination program has been widely implemented in China. To characterize the S1 protein of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) from China, five representative nephropathogenic IB viruses isolated from chickens from different provinces were genetically and phylogenetically analyzed. The results showed that the lengths of the S1 genes of the isolates were quite different (1,617, 1,620, 1,623, 1,629 and 1,632 nucleotides, respectively). The homology of nucleotides and amino acids among the five isolates was 76.7% vs. 92.1% and 73.9% vs. 89.5%, respectively, indicating a large variation in the S1 genes of the isolates. Variation in S1 genes can affect the antigenicity and pathogenicity of viruses. Genetically, point mutations, insertions and deletions in the S1 protein can be observed at many positions, particularly the first 150 amino acids in the N-terminus of the S1 protein. Two motif cleavage sites (RRXRR/S, HRRRR/S) were observed in the five stranded strains. Phylogenetic analysis suggested that they belonged to different lineages. These findings indicated that different genotypes of nephropathogenic IB viruses circulate together in the chicken population in China. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Bing, G. X.;Liu, X.;Pu, J.;Liu, Q. F.;Wu, Q. M.;Liu, J. H.

title: Enterovirus serotypes in patients with central nervous system and respiratory tract infections in Viet Nam 1997-2010.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Enteroviruses are the most common causative agents of human disease. Enteroviruses have recently been associated with regional and global epidemics, including severe disease (Enterovirus A71 and D68), and are of interest as emerging viruses. Here, we report Enterovirus AD (EV) from central nervous system (CNS) and respiratory tract infections in Vietnam. METHODS: Data and samples from prospective observational clinical studies conducted between 1997 and 2010 were used. Species and serotypes were determined using type-specific RT-PCR and viral protein 1 or 4 (VP1, VP4) sequencing. RESULTS: Samples from patients with CNS infection (51 children - 10 CSF and 41 respiratory/rectal swabs) and 28 adults (28 CSF) and respiratory tract infections (124 children - 124 respiratory swabs) were analyzed. Twenty-six different serotypes of four Enterovirus strains (AD), including EV-A71 and EV-D68, were identified. Enterovirus B has been associated with viral meningitis in children and adults. Enteroviruses A (EV-A71 and Coxsackievirus [CV] A10) associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease have been detected in children with encephalitis. Different serotypes of the four Enterovirus strains were found in respiratory samples, including 2 polio vaccine viruses, as well as 8 CV-A24 and 8 EV-D68. With the exception of EV-D68, the relevance of these viruses to respiratory infection is unknown. CONCLUSION: We described a diverse spectrum of enteroviruses from patients with CNS and respiratory tract infections in Viet Nam between 1997 and 2010. These data confirm the global circulation of Enterovirus genera and their associations and are important for clinical diagnosis, patient management and outbreak response.
authors: B'Krong, N.;Minh, N. N. Q.;Qui, P. T.;Chau, T. T. H.;Nghia, H. D. T.;Do, L. A. H.;Nhung, N. N.;Van Vinh Chau, N.;Thwaites, G.;Van Tan, L.;van Doorn, H. R.;Thanh, T. T.

title: Adenovirus respiratory infection in turkey poultry
abstract: virus with respiratory manifestations from turkey chicks was isolated in specific pathogen-free embryonated chicken eggs and subsequently adapted to chicken embryo fibroblast and turkey kidney cell cultures where round cell formation was observed. The cloned virus was ether resistant and contained triple thymidine. Intranuclear icosahedral virus particles of 80 nm were detected. These physicochemical properties place this isolate in the adenovirus virus group. The disease has been propagated experimentally by intratracheal vaccination of one-day-old turkey chicks. Snicking occurred in 100% of the birds and the mortality rate reached 50%. CELO (Phelps strain) antiserum neutralized uncloned and cloned CUA-2 in chicken embryos and uncloned virus in chicken embryo fibroblast cell cultures. Quail bronchitis virus antiserum neutralized the cloned CUA-2 in TK cells. Agar-gel precipitin identification lines were established using CELO antiserum and postinoculation sera from experimentally infected turkeys. Serologically, this virus should be classified as a type-1 adenovirus.
authors: Blalock, H. G.;Simmons, D. G.;Muse, K. E.;Gray, J. G.;Derieux, W. T.

title: Variable and constant regions in African swine fever virus DNA
abstract: An analysis of the SalI restriction pattern of African swine fever virus DNA showed that SalI recognition sites did not change after more than 100 virus passages in porcine macrophages. Virus strain BA71V obtained from virus isolate BA71 by adaptation to growth in VERO cells differed from unadapted virus in two deletions 2.5 and 7 kb long located close to the DNA ends. A restriction analysis of several virus clones from a naturally infected pig revealed length heterogeneity in both variable regions. A comparison of SalI restriction maps from 23 African swine fever virus isolates (8 African, 11 European and 4 American) showed that the virus genome consists of a fixed-length central region of approximately 125 kb and two closely spaced variable regions. The DNA ends are 38-47 kb long for the left DNA end and 13-16 kb for the right DNA end. The total length of ASF virus DNA ranged from 178 (BA71) to 189 (MOZ64) kb. 23 African swine fever virus isolates were classified into five groups according to the pattern of SalI regions in the central region. Four groups contained only African isolates, while all European and American isolates belonged to the same group. This distribution of isolates indicates that all virus field isolates outside Africa have a common origin.
authors: Blasco, R.;AgÃ¼ero, M.;Almendral, J. M.;ViÃ±uela, E.

title: Ledantevirus: A new genus proposed in Rhabdoviridae has a strong ecological relationship with bats.
abstract: The Le Dantec serogroup of rhabdoviruses consists of Le Dantec virus from a human with encephalitis and Keuriliba virus from rodents, each isolated in Senegal. The Kern Canyon serogroup consists of a loosely bound set of rhabdoviruses, most isolated from bats, including Kern Canyon virus from California, Nkolbisson virus from Cameroon, Central African Republic, and Kolente virus from Ivory Coast, Guinea, Mount Elgon bat. and Idea viruses from Kenya and Oita virus from Japan. Fukuoka virus isolated from mosquitoes, sandflies and cattle in Japan, Barur virus from a rodent in India, and Nishimuro virus from pigs in Japan have also been genetically or serologically linked to this group. Here, we analyze the genome sequences and phylogenetic relationships of this virus set. We show that they form three subgroups within a monophyletic group that we propose should produce the new genus Ledantevirus.
authors: Blasdell, K. R.;Guzman, H.;Widen, S. G.;Firth, C.;Wood, T. G.;Holmes, E. C.;Tesh, R. B.;Vasilakis, N.;Walker, P. J.

title: Koolpinyah and Yata viruses: two newly recognized ephemeroviruses from tropical regions of Australia and Africa
abstract: Koolpinyah virus (KOOLV) isolated from healthy Australian cattle and Yata virus (YATV) isolated from a Mansonia uniformis mosquito pool in the Central African Republic have been tentatively identified as rhabdoviruses. KOOLV was previously shown to be antigenically related to cotoncone virus, an ephemerovirus that causes a short-lived fever-like illness in cattle in Nigeria, but YATV did not react antigenically with any of the other viruses tested. Here we report the complete genome sequences of KOOLV (16,133 nt) and YATV (14,479 nt). Each has a complex genome organization with multiple genes, including a second nonstructural glycoprotein (GNS) gene and a viroporin (Î±1) gene between the G and L genes, characteristic of ephemeroviruses. Based on genome organization, sequence identity and cross-neutralization analysis, we show that both KOOLV and YATV should be classified as two new species in the genus Ephemerovirus.
authors: Blasdell, K. R.;Widen, S. G.;Diviney, S. M.;Firth, C.;Wood, T. G.;Guzman, H.;Holmes, E. C.;Tesh, R. B.;Vasilakis, N.;Walker, P. J.

title: Fatal ulcerative and hemorrhagic typhlocolitis in pregnant heifer associated with natural bovine enterovirus type-1 infection
abstract: two-year-old, 7.5-months pregnant Aberdeen Angus, apparently from a herd of 100 healthy cows, died 10 hours after being hospitalized. At necropsy, multiple foci of mucosal bleeding and ulceration were observed in the spiral colon and cecum. Virus isolation from intestinal lesions yielded a cytopathic virus, which by electron microscopy turned out to be a non-enveloped virus, approximately 27 nm. Further characterization by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), sequencing of the 5-UTR and partial VP1 coding region, and phylogenetic analysis classified the virus isolate as bovine enterovirus type 1 (BEV-1). No other significant pathogens were detected. This is the first report of BEV-1 isolated in the US from an animal with terminal enteric disease in more than 20 years. More research is needed to determine the prevalence of BEV in North America and to determine the clinical relevance of this little-studied virus.
authors: Blas-Machado, U.;Saliki, J. T.;Boileau, M. J.;Goens, S. D.;Caseltine, S. L.;Duffy, J. C.;Welsh, R. D.

title: Bovine viral diarrhea virus type 2 induced meningoencephalitis in a heifer
abstract: The brain of a 15-month-old, black female Angus with a 48-hour history of central nervous system disease was sent to the Oklahoma Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory. Microscopic findings consisted of acute, multifocal meningoencephalitis with neuronal degeneration and necrosis and gliosis. Viral isolation yielded non-cytopathic bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV). Virus genotyping classified the virus as BVDV type 2. Immunohistochemical labeling for BVDV antigens with the BVD MAb 3.12F1 clone was evident in the cytoplasm of neurons, glial cells, ependymal epithelium, perivascular macrophages and spindle cells, smooth muscle cells, and intravascular monocytes. brain and brain stem. Laboratory results support that tissue changes occur as a result of BVDV type 2 infection. In the absence of other clinical signs of BVDV infection and using the microscopic and laboratory evidence presented, we suggest that BVDV type 2 isolated from this case may represent a neurovirulent strain of the virus. To our knowledge, this is the first report of congenital or postnatal acquired brain lesions and neuronal viral antigen localization in BVDV genotype 2 viral infection.
authors: Blas-Machado, U.;Saliki, J. T.;Duffy, J. C.;Caseltine, S. L.

title: New circular DNA viruses in fecal samples of wild chimpanzees
abstract: Viral particles in fecal samples from wild chimpanzees were analyzed using random PCR amplification and sequencing. Sequences encoding proteins distantly related to the replicase protein of single-stranded circular DNA viruses were identified. Reverse PCR was used to amplify and sequence multiple small circular DNA viral genomes. Viral genomes were related to vertebrate circoviruses and plant geminiviruses in size and genome organization, but the rolling circle had a different location for the stem-loop structure involved in DNA replication. The replicase genes of these viruses were most closely related to those of the much smaller (similar to 1 kb) plant nanovirus circular DNA chromosomes. Because viruses have characteristics of both animal and plant viruses, we named them chimpanzee fecal-associated circular viruses (ChiSCV). Further metagenomic studies of animal samples will greatly increase our knowledge of viral diversity and evolution.
authors: Blinkova, O.;Victoria, J.;Li, Y. Y.;Keele, B. F.;Sanz, C.;Ndjango, J. B. N.;Peeters, M.;Travis, D.;Lonsdorf, E. V.;Wilson, M. L.;Pusey, A. E.;Hahn, B. H.;Delwart, E. L.

title: Epitope-blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays for the detection of serum antibodies to West Nile virus in multiple avian species
abstract: We report the development of epitope-blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) for the rapid detection of serum antibodies to West Nile virus (WNV) in taxonomically diverse North American avian species. A panel of flavivirus-specific monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) was tested in blocking experiments with serum samples from WNV-infected chickens and crows. Selected MAbs were further tested against serum samples from birds representing 16 species and 10 families. Serum samples were collected from birds infected with WNV or Saint Louis encephalitis virus (SLEV) and from uninfected control birds. Serum samples from SLEV-infected birds were included in these experiments because WNV and SLEV are antigenically closely related, maintained in similar transmission cycles, and have overlapping geographic distributions. ELISA using MAb 3.1112G potentially distinguished between WNV and SLEV infections, as all serum samples from WNV-infected birds and no serum samples from SLEV-infected birds were positive in this assay. Assays with MAbs 2B2 and 6B6C-1 readily detected serum antibodies in all WNV and SLEV-infected birds, respectively, and most other virus-infected birds. The other two MAbs partially differentiated between infections with these two viruses. Serum samples from most WNV-infected birds but not SLEV-infected birds were positive with MAb 3.67G, whereas almost all serum samples from SLEV-infected birds, but a few serum samples from WNV-infected birds, were positive with MAb 6B5A-5. . The inhibition assays reported here provide a fast, reliable and inexpensive diagnostic and surveillance technique for monitoring WNV activity in multiple avian species.
authors: Blitvich, B. J.;Marlenee, N. L.;Hall, R. A.;Calisher, C. H.;Bowen, R. A.;Roehrig, J. T.;Komar, N.;Langevin, S. A.;Beaty, B. J.

title: New Leaves on the Growing Tree of Pestiviruses
abstract: Pestiviruses are a group of viruses of veterinary importance that infect livestock such as pigs, cattle and sheep, as well as wild animals such as wild boar and different species of deer. For decades, only four classical strains (Classic swine fever virus, Bovine viral diarrhea virus types 1 and 2, Border disease virus) and a few so-called atypical pestiviruses (eg Giraffe virus, Pronghorn virus, HoBi virus) were known. A number of new pestiviruses have been identified in recent years (Bungowannah virus, Bat pestivirus, Norwegian rat pestivirus, Atypical porcine pestivirus, LINDA virus). Australian Bungowannah virus can be isolated and further characterized by classical sequencing, but all other novel new pestiviruses were identified by metagenomics using next-generation sequencing technologies. Here we describe these new viruses, their discovery and characterization. A distinction is made between the emergence of classical pestiviruses in new strains and new viruses or virus strains.
authors: Blome, S.;Beer, M.;Wernike, K.

title: Detection of a novel porcine boca-like virus in the background of postweaning multisystem wasting syndrome caused by porcine circovirus type 2
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV-2) has been found to be the causative agent of post-weaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS). However, PCV-2 is a ubiquitous virus in the pig population, and most pigs infected with PCV-2 do not develop the disease. Age, maintenance, genetics of PCV-2, other pathogens etc. It has been suggested that different factors such as the development of PMWS contribute to the development of PMWS. However, no proven link between any of these factors and disease development has so far been found. In this study, we investigated the possible presence of other hitherto unknown DNA containing infectious agents in lymph nodes collected from Swedish pigs with PMWS confirmed by random amplification and high-throughput sequencing. Although the vast majority of amplified genetic sequences belong to PCV-2, we also found genome sequences of Torque Teno virus (TTV) and a novel parvovirus. Detection of TTV like PCV-2 was expected, TTV was found to have a high prevalence in pigs worldwide. We were able to amplify a longer region of the parvovirus genome consisting of the entire NP1 and partial VP1/2. By comparative analysis of nucleotide sequences and phylogenetic studies, we propose that it is a novel porcine parvovirus with genetic relevance to bocaviruses. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;BelÃ¡k, S.;Fossum, C.;McKillen, J.;Allan, G.;Wallgren, P.;Berg, M.

title: Viral metagenomic analysis shows Co-infection status in healthy and PMWS-affected pigs
abstract: The development of high-throughput sequencing technologies has allowed the possibility to investigate and characterize the entire microbiome of individuals, providing a better understanding of the complex interaction between different microorganisms. This will help to understand how the microbiome influences the susceptibility of secondary agents and disease development. We applied viral metagenomics to investigate the virome of lymph nodes from Swedish pigs and healthy pigs suffering from postweaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS) multifactorial disease. The aim is to increase knowledge about potential viruses other than porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) involved in PMWS development and to increase knowledge about viroma of healthy individuals. A diverse viral flora was seen in healthy individuals, with several different viruses present at the same time. Most of the viruses identified are small linear and circular DNA viruses, such as the different circoviruses, anelloviruses and bocaviruses. In pigs suffering from PMWS, PCV2 sequences were highly detected, as expected, but other viruses were also detected in the background of PCV2. DNA viruses as well as RNA viruses have been identified, among them a porcine pestivirus with high similarity to the atypical porcine pestivirus that was recently (in 2015) discovered in the USA. Many of the viruses identified in the background of PCV2 in PMWS pigs can also be identified in healthy pigs. PCV2 sequences were also identified in healthy pigs, but at a much lower level than in PMWS-affected pigs. While the method used here is not quantitative, the very clear difference in the amount of PCV2 sequences in PMWS-affected pigs and healthy pigs likely reflects very strong replication of PCV2, which is known to be a feature of PMWS. Taken together, these findings suggest that pigs have an important viral flora consisting largely of small single-stranded and circular DNA viruses. Future research on such viruses will help to better understand the role of these ubiquitous viruses in the health and disease of pigs. We are also demonstrating the presence of a new swine pestivirus for the first time in Europe.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Fossum, C.;Wallgren, P.;Berg, M.

title: A metagenomic analysis shows the diverse microbial community of a vermicomposting system in Uganda.
abstract: Background: Vermicomposting is a mesophilic process in which earthworms are used to efficiently and cost-effectively process large volumes of organic waste. It has been suggested that it not only increases soil fertility, but also increases the biomass of beneficial bacteria while reducing harmful bacteria. The aim of this study was to establish a strategy to investigate and characterize the viral and bacterial composition of a vermicomposting system. Materials and methods: The vermicompost unit used in this study was placed at Makerere University Agricultural Research Institute Kabanyolo on the outskirts of Kampala, Uganda, and fed 80% cattle manure and 20% food waste. On Day 172 the compost was terminated and compost samples were collected from the three layers of the unit: top, middle and bottom layer. A metagenomic approach was then applied to characterize the viral and bacterial composition of the vermicompost system. Results and discussion: A high bacterial abundance and diversity was detected. Proteobacteria were the largest phyla in the compost (mainly Alpha-, Gamma- and Betaproteobacteria), accounting for almost 65% of the bacterial readings in the datasets. Salmonella spp., Escherichia coli, Enterobacter spp., Enterococcus spp. DNA samples from several potentially pathogenic bacteria, such as and Clostridium spp were detected in vermicompost, suggesting that harmful bacteria may still be present in vermicast. The main viral group consisted of phages; Apart from phages, mainly insect viruses were detected. The only animal or human virus identified was kobuvirus. In summary, metagenomic analysis has been shown to be an efficient technology to characterize the microbial composition of vermicast. Data from this study contributes to a better understanding of the microbes found in such composting systems and can help identify measures necessary for safe manure handling.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Lalander, C.;Komakech, A. J.;VinnerÃ¥s, B.;Boqvist, S.

title: Genome Sequence of a Bovine Rhinitis B Virus Identified in Cattle in Sweden
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Oma, V.;Khatri, M.;Hansen, H. H.

title: Viral metagenomic analysis of bush pigs (Potamochoerus larvatus) from Uganda identifies novel variants of Porcine parvovirus 4 and Torque teno sus virus 1 and 2.
abstract: Background: As a result of rapidly growing human populations, intensification of livestock production, and increased use of wildlife habitats for animal agriculture, the interface between wildlife, livestock and humans is expanding with potential impacts on both domestic animal and human health. Wild animals serve as reservoirs for many viruses that can occasionally cause new infections in domestic animals and/or the human population. Given this background, we used metagenomics to investigate the presence of viral pathogens in sera collected from bush pigs (Potamochoerus larvatus), a wild Suid species known to move between national parks and farmland in Uganda. Results: 454 pyrosequencing treatments showed the presence of Torque tenosus virus (TTSuV), porcine parvovirus 4 (PPV4), porcine endogenous retrovirus (PERV), a GB Hepatitis C-like virus, and a Sclerotinia hypovirulence-like virus in it. greenhouse from bush pigs. PCR assays for each specific virus coupled with Sanger sequencing revealed two TTSuV-1 variants, a TTSuV-2 variant, as well as PPV4 in serum samples, thus confirming the findings from 454 sequencing. Results: We performed the first analysis of viruses present in bushpig sera using a viral metagenomic approach and demonstrated for the first time the presence of PPV4 in a wild African Suid. In addition, we identified novel variants of TTSuV-1 and 2 in bush pigs. Â© 2012 Blomstrüm et al.; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;StÃ¥hl, K.;Masembe, C.;Okoth, E.;Okurut, A. R.;Atmnedi, P.;Kemp, S.;Bishop, R.;BelÃ¡k, S.;Berg, M.

title: Characterization of tonsils virome from conventional pigs and specific pathogen-free pigs.
abstract: Swine respiratory disease is a multifactorial disease that can be affected by a number of different microorganisms as well as non-infectious factors such as the management and environment of animals. It is generally believed that the interaction between different infectious agents plays an important role in respiratory diseases. Therefore, we used high-throughput sequencing combined with viral metagenomics to characterize the viral community of tonsil samples from pigs from a conventional herd with respiratory tract lesions at slaughter. In parallel, samples from specific pathogen-free pigs were also analyzed. This study showed a variable rate of co-infection in different pigs. Differences were seen in individual pigs, not group level. Some viruses, such as adenoviruses and certain picornaviruses, can be found in most pigs, while others, such as different parvoviruses and anelloviruses, have been identified in only a few pigs. In addition, the complete coding region of porcine parvovirus 7 and the complete genomes of two teschoviruses were obtained. The results of this study will help explain which viruses circulate in both healthy pigs and pigs associated with respiratory disease. This information is essential for future research into the role of viral-viral interactions in disease development.
authors: BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.;Ye, X.;Fossum, C.;Wallgren, P.;Berg, M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of partial S1 and N gene sequences of infectious bronchitis virus isolates from Italy revealed genetic diversity and recombination
abstract: total of ten infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) isolates collected from commercial chickens in Italy in 1999 were characterized by RT-PCR and sequencing of the S1 and N genes. Phylogenetic analysis based on partial S1 gene sequences shows five field viruses clustered together with 793/B strains with 91.3-98.5% nucleotide identity within the group and 624/ strains. These two IBV types were previously described in Italy. Three other variant isolates formed the new genotype that was recently detected in many countries of Western Europe. For Italy-02, one of these variant viruses, which later became the prototype strain, the entire S1 gene was sequenced to confirm its authenticity. In contrast, phylogenetic analysis of the more conserved partial N gene sequences containing 1-300 nucleotides revealed divergent clustering. Thus, the three variant IBVs of the new Italy-02 genotype, which had 96.7-99.2% S1 gene nucleotide identity with each other, belonged to three distinct subgroups based on N gene sequences. The 624/I-type isolate Italy-06 shared 97.7% and 99.3% identity with vaccine strain H120 in the N gene region, respectively, with Italy-03, which could not be detected using the S1 gene primers. Only one of the 793/B-type isolates, Italy-10, clustered with the 793/B strain, which shared 99.3% partial N gene identity, while the other four isolates were genetically distant from them (87.7-89.7% identity only) and occurred. separate homogeneous subgroup. The results showed that both mutations and recombination events could contribute to the genetic diversity of Italian isolates. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Bochkov, Y. A.;Tosi, G.;Massi, P.;Drygin, V. V.

title: Basic research on BSE transmission to humans
abstract: Prion diseases of animals and humans belong to neurological diseases with amyloidal deposition of related proteins. As for prion disease, cellular prionprotein, in its abnormal isoform(s), is an essential component of prionprotein aggregates found in the affected tissue. Unlike all neurodegenerative diseases such as Morbus Alzheimer's or Huntington's disease, prion diseases are contagious. Therefore, prion diseases were termed as Infectious Spongy Encephalopathies (TSE). The diseases have been well known for decades. Scrapie was first described around 1750, a case of BSE, most likely a misdiagnosis, was reported in 1850, and human Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) was described in 1920/1930. CJD, the transmission of Kuru, was suspected in the early 1950s and was erroneously classified as a slow viral disease. Transmission of CJD posed a problem for humans when transplants from CJD cases were used for treatment. Fortunately, these iatrogenic transfers were limited. But with the emergence of BSE and the emergence of variable cases of CJD in the UK and parts of Europe, scientists suspected that cattle-to-human transmission could occur. We know from animal models that there has been successful transmission by various means. Species barriers do not completely prevent transmission. Conversely, conduction barriers may exist that control individual susceptibility to prions. Transmission modes, transmission sensitivity, identification of receptor molecules, and molecular mechanisms of the transmission process are intensively investigated. The available information allows us to hypothesize that the invisible stages of prion infection (which do not exist) act as a species barrier. This obscure infection precedes overt disease and therefore most research focuses on the development of highly sensitive assay systems for the detection of very small amounts of pathological prionprotein in suspected cases. Invisibility should also warn us not to underestimate cases of BSE or human vCJD; currently 124 in Europe and one probable case in Hongkong (March 7, 2002). Whether BSE has spread to other parts of the world through animal feed ingredients or meat can neither be excluded nor confirmed at this time. Recent data on transmission and consequences of BSE for the human population are summarized in this review.
authors: Bodemer, W.;Kaup, F. J.

title: Comments on the current prevalence and epidemiology of BSE and prion diseases
abstract: Prion diseases of animals and humans are neurological diseases with amyloidal deposition of related proteins. As for prion disease, cellular prion protein, in its abnormal isoform(s), is an essential component of prion protein aggregates found in the affected tissue. Unlike all neurodegenerative diseases such as Morbus Alzheimer's or Huntington's disease, prion diseases are contagious. Therefore, prion diseases were termed as Infectious Spongy Encephalopathies (TSE). The diseases have been well known for decades. Scrapie was first described around 1750, a case of BSE was reported in the 1850s, most likely as a misdiagnosis, and human Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) was described in 1920/1930. The transmission of CJD, or Kuru, was suspected in the early 1950s and was mistakenly classified as a slow viral disease. Transmission of CJD posed a problem for humans when transplants from CJD cases were used for treatment. Fortunately, these iatrogenic transfers were limited. But with the emergence of BSE and the emergence of variable cases of CJD in the UK and parts of Europe, scientists suspected that cattle-to-human transmission could occur. We know from animal models that there has been successful transmission by various means. Species barriers do not completely prevent transmission. Instead, conduction barriers may exist that control individual susceptibility to prions. The modes of transmission, the susceptibility to transduction, the identification of receptor molecules, and the molecular mechanisms of the transduction process are being investigated with great intensity. Current information leads us to hypothesize that the invisible stages of prion infection incorrectly suggest a (non-existent) type barrier. This invisible infection precedes overt disease and therefore most research focuses on the development of highly sensitive assay systems for the detection of very small amounts of pathological prion protein in suspected cases. Invisibility should also warn us not to underestimate cases of BSE or human vCJD; Currently, there have been approximately 145 cases in Europe and one probable case in Hongkong (June 2003). Whether BSE has spread to other parts of the world through animal feed ingredients or meat can neither be excluded nor confirmed at this time. Recent data on transmission and consequences of BSE for the human population are summarized in this review. © Georg Thieme Verlag Stuttgart.
authors: Bodemer, W.;Kaup, F. J.

title: New viruses in birds: Need a rooftop or a cage? Review
abstract: Emerging viral diseases continue to have a major global impact on humans and animals. Rapid detection of the causative agent is a very important first step in order to take adequate precautions in the event of an outbreak of an emerging disease. This review discusses various aspects of virus discovery, with a particular focus on recently discovered viruses in birds. In recent years, new viruses with great potential have been discovered in domestic and wild bird species using various virus discovery methods. There are only a few studies reporting the detection of new viruses in endangered bird species, but increasing knowledge about viruses circulating in these species is important. Additional studies focusing on the full role of a novel virus in disease and the impact of a new virus on bird populations are often lacking. Intense collaboration between different disciplines is needed to gain useful insights into the role of these new viruses.
authors: Bodewes, R.

title: Viral metagenomic analysis of feces of wild small carnivores
abstract: Background: Recent studies have clearly demonstrated the enormous diversity of viruses that exist among wild animals. This exemplifies the necessary expansion of our knowledge of the diversity of viruses found in wildlife, as well as the potential transmission of these viruses to pets or humans. Methods In this study, we evaluated the viral diversity of fecal samples (n = 42) collected from 10 different species of wild small carnivores living in the northern part of Spain using random PCR combined with next-generation sequencing. Examples are American mink (Neovison vison), European mink (Mustela lutreola), European marten (Mustela putorius), European pine marten (Martes martes), stone marten (Martes foina), Eurasian otter (Lutra lutra), and Eurasian badger (Mustelidae family). meles meles); common genet of Viverridae family (Genetta genetta); Red fox (Vulpes vulpes) from the family Canidae and the European wildcat (Felis silvestris) from the family Felidae. Results: A series of possible novel viruses or virus variants were detected, including a theilovirus, phleboviruses, an amdovirus, a cobuvirus, and picobirnaviruses. Results: Using random PCR in combination with next-generation sequencing, sequences of various novel viruses or virus variants were detected in stool samples collected from Spanish carnivores. The new viruses detected highlight the viral diversity found in the fecal material of wild carnivores. Â© 2014 Bodewes et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Bodewes, R.;Ruiz-Gonzalez, A.;Schapendonk, C. M. E.;Van Den Brand, J. M. A.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.;Smits, S. L.

title: Identification of multiple novel viruses, including a parvovirus and a hepevirus, in red fox feces
abstract: Red foxes (Vulpes vulpes) are the most common members of the order Carnivora. Because they often live in (fairy)urban areas, they are a potential reservoir of viruses that can infect humans or pets from wildlife. Here we evaluated the fecal viral microbiome of 13 red foxes by random PCR combined with next-generation sequencing. Several novel viruses have been identified, including a parvovirus, bocavirus, adeno-associated virus, hepevirus, astroviruses, and picobirnaviruses.
authors: Bodewes, R.;van der Giessen, J.;Haagmans, B. L.;Osterhaus, A. D.;Smits, S. L.

title: Spatial Temporal Analysis of Genetic Diversity of Seal Influenza A(H10N7) Virus, Northwest Europe
abstract: UNLABELED: Influenza A viruses are major pathogens to humans, pets and wildlife, and these viruses occasionally cross the species barrier. In the spring of 2014, increased mortality rates of harbor seals (Phoca vitulina) were reported in Sweden and Denmark in connection with infection with an influenza A(H10N7) virus. Within a few months, the virus had spread to seals in the coastal waters of Germany and the Netherlands, killing thousands of animals. Genetic analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes of this seal influenza A(H10N7) virus revealed that it is most closely related to several avian influenza A(H10N7) viruses. The collection of samples from infected seals during the epidemic provided a unique opportunity to follow the adaptation of the avian virus to the new seal host. Sequence data for samples collected from 41 different seals from four different countries between April 2014 and January 2015 were obtained by Sanger sequencing and next-generation sequencing to describe the molecular epidemiology of seal influenza A(H10N7) virus. The majority of sequence variation occurred in the HA gene, and some mutations corresponded to amino acid changes not found in H10 viruses isolated from Eurasian birds. Also, the sequence variation in the HA gene was greater at the beginning than at the end of the epidemic, when a previously observed set of mutations was fixed. These results imply that when an avian influenza virus crosses the species barrier from birds to seals, amino acid changes in HA can occur rapidly and are important for the virus's adaptation to its new mammalian host. IMPORTANT: Influenza A viruses are major pathogens for humans, pets and wildlife. In addition to the continuous circulation of influenza A viruses between various host species, interspecies transmission of influenza A viruses occasionally occurs. Wild waterfowl and shorebirds are the main reservoir for most influenza A virus subspecies, and the spread of influenza A viruses from birds to humans or other mammalian species can cause major outbreaks. In this study, various sequencing methods were used to elucidate the genetic changes that occurred after the introduction and subsequent spread of an avian influenza A(H10N7) virus among northwestern European harbor seals using various samples collected during the outbreak. Such detailed knowledge of the genetic alterations required for the introduction and adaptation of avian influenza A viruses to mammalian hosts is important for a rapid risk assessment soon after such viruses have crossed the species barrier.
authors: Bodewes, R.;Zohari, S.;Krog, J. S.;Hall, M. D.;Harder, T. C.;Bestebroer, T. M.;van de Bildt, M. W. G.;Spronken, M. I.;Larsen, L. E.;Siebert, U.;Wohlsein, P.;Puff, C.;Seehusen, F.;Baumgartner, W.;Harkonen, T.;Smits, S. L.;Herfst, S.;Osterhaus, A.;Fouchier, R. A. M.;Koopmans, M. P.;Kuiken, T.

title: Newcastle disease outbreaks in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan in 1998, 2000, 2001, 2003, 2004 and 2005 were caused by viruses of the VIIb and VIId genotypes.
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) infects domestic and wild birds worldwide, and infections with virulent NDV strains continue to cause disease outbreaks in poultry and wild birds. To evaluate the evolutionary characteristics of 28 NDV strains isolated from chickens in Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan in 1998, 2000, 2001, 2003, 2004 and 2005, we investigated the phylogenetic relationships between these viruses and previously described viruses. For genotyping, fusion (F) gene phylogenetic analysis (nucleotide number 47-421) was performed using the sequences of Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan isolates and NDV strains selected from GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis showed that 14 strains newly characterized between 1998 and 2001 belonged to NDV genotype VIIb, whereas 14 strains isolated between 2003 and 2005 belonged to genotype VIId. All strains had a lethal fusion protein cleavage site (RRQR/KRF) and intracerebral pathogenicity indices in day-old chickens ranging from 1.05 to 1.87, both typical of NDV strains classified in the mesogenic or velogenic pathotype. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Bogoyavlenskiy, A.;Berezin, V.;Prilipov, A.;Usachev, E.;Lyapina, O.;Korotetskiy, I.;Zaitceva, I.;Asanova, S.;Kydyrmanov, A.;Daulbaeva, K.;Shakhvorostova, L.;Sayatov, M.;King, D.

title: Molecular characterization of virulent newcastle disease virus isolated from chickens during the 1998 NDV epidemic in Kazakhstan.
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) infects domestic and wild birds all over the world and is likely to cause epidemics in chicken flocks in the future. To evaluate the evolutionary characteristics of 10 NDV strains isolated from chickens in Kazakhstan in 1998, we investigated the phylogenetic relationships between these viruses and previously described viruses. For genotyping, fusion (F) gene phylogenetic analysis (nucleotide number 47-421) was performed using sequences of Kazakhstan isolates compared with sequences of NDV strains selected from GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all newly characterized strains belonged to the genetic group called VIIb. All strains had a virulent fusion cleavage site (RRQRR/F) of velogenic or mesogenic pathotypes, with intracerebral pathogenicity indices (ICPI) ranging from 1.05 to 1.87. © 2005 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Bogoyavlenskiy, A.;Berezin, V.;Prilipov, A.;Usachev, E.;Lyapina, O.;Levandovskaya, S.;Korotetskiy, I.;Tolmacheva, V.;Makhmudova, N.;Khudyakova, S.;Tustikbaeva, G.;Zaitseva, I.;Omirtaeva, E.;Ermakova, O.;Daulbaeva, K.;Asanova, S.;Kydyrmanov, A.;Sayatov, M.;King, D.

title: Phylogenetic analyzes show little variation among reticuloendotheliosis viruses that infect avian species, including the endangered Attwater's grouse.
abstract: Reticuloendotheliosis virus infection, which typically causes systemic lymphomas and high mortality in the endangered Attwater's prairie hen, has been identified as a major hurdle in the repopulation efforts of captive breeding facilities in Texas. Although antigenic relationships have been previously determined among reticuloendotheliosis virus (REV) strains, phylogenetic relationships have not been reported. Pol and env (SNV) of REV proviral DNA from prairie chickens (PC-R92 and PC-2404), poxvirus lesions in domestic chickens, prototype birds from REV-A and chick syncytial virus (CSV), and duck-borne spleen necrosis virus It was amplified and sequenced by PCR. 5032 bp of PC-R92 and REV-A, containing most of the pol and env genes, were 98% identical, and the nucleotide sequence identities of the smaller regions in pol and env from the REV strains studied ranged from 95% to 99%. and 93% to 99% respectively. The putative amino acid sequences were 97-99% identical in the polymerase and 90-98% in the envelope. Phylogenetic analyzes of nucleotide and amino acid sequences recently showed the closest relationship between poultry isolates, meadow chicken isolates, and prototype CSV, while only SNV appeared to be markedly different. While the origin of naturally occurring viruses is unknown, avian pox virus may be a critical component of the transmission of these ubiquitous oncogenic viruses. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Bohls, R. L.;Linares, J. A.;Gross, S. L.;Ferro, P. J.;Silvy, N. J.;Collisson, E. W.

title: Forécariah virus, a new representative of the Bhanja antigenic group, isolated in the Republic of Guinea
abstract: A new arbovirus named "Forécariah" has been isolated from ticks of Boophylus geigy in the Forecariah region of the Republic of Guinea (West Africa). This virus is classified into the Bhanja antigen group due to its physico-chemical, biological and antigenic properties.
authors: Boiro, I.;Lomonossov, N. N.;Malenko, G. V.;Balde, C.;Bah, A.

title: Shotgun Pyrosequencing Pig Capping and Metagenomic Analyzes of Dust from Grain Plants
abstract: Inhalation of agricultural dust causes inflammatory reactions and symptoms such as headache, fever and malaise that can progress to chronic airway inflammation and associated diseases such as asthma, chronic bronchitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and hypersensitivity pneumonia. Although feed particles are the main component of these dusts in many agricultural environments, the inflammatory responses they trigger are likely attributable to particle-associated bacteria, archaea, fungi and viruses. In this study, we performed shotgun pyrosequencing metagenomic analyzes of DNA from dust from swine confinement facilities or grain elevators, in comparison with dust from pet-free homes. DNA sequence alignment showed that 19% or 62% of the shotgun pyrosequencing metagenomic DNA sequence read from the pig facility or house dust was of porcine or human origin, respectively. In contrast, only 2% of such readings from cereal booster powder were of mammalian origin. These metagenomic shotgun reads of mammalian origin were excluded from our analyzes of agricultural dust microbiota. Compared to grain elevator or house dust in the pig farm, the ten most common bacterial taxa were determined to consist of 75%, 16% and 42% gram positive organisms, respectively. Of the top five swine plant dust species, four could be assigned (Clostridium, Lactobacillus, Ruminococcus and Eubacterium, in the 4% to 19% relative abundance range). The relative abundance of these four genera was lower in dust from grain silos or pet-free homes. These analyzes also highlighted the predominance of swine plant dust at the phylum-level Firmicutes (70%), Class-level Clostridia (44%), and Order-level Clostridiales (41%). In summary, shotgun pyrosequencing metagenomic analyzes of agricultural powders show that they differ qualitatively and quantitatively at the level of microbial taxa available, and bioinformatics analyzes used for such studies must be carefully designed to avoid the potential contribution of non-microbial DNA, e.g. from resident mammals.
authors: Boissy, R. J.;Romberger, D. J.;Roughead, W. A.;Weissenburger-Moser, L.;Poole, J. A.;LeVan, T. D.

title: Genetic characterization of bovine viral diarrheal viruses isolated from permanently infected calves and born in dams vaccinated against bovine viral diarrhea virus prior to breeding.
abstract: Objective - To collect and partially characterize strains of bovine viral diarrheal viruses (BVDVs) isolated from persistently infected (PI) calves born in vaccinated dams, to determine the genetic diversity of isolated viruses, and to determine the regional distribution of genetically similar virus subpopulations. Sample Population - 17 non-cytopathic (NCP) BVDVs from PI calves from 11 cattle or dairy herds. Procedures - Viral RNA was extracted from infected cell cultures and BVDV-specific PCR primers were used to amplify >1,000 bases of the viral genome. Derived sequences were used for molecular phylogenetic analyzes to determine viral genotype and viral genogroup and to evaluate genetic similarity between BVDVs. Results - Analysis of 17 NCP strains of BVDV failed to detect a viral genotype or viral genogroup not currently reported in the United States. One virus was classified as genotype 1, genogroup 1b, and 16 viruses were classified as genotype 2, genogroup 2a. Genotype 2 strains were genetically diverse, and genetic similarities were not evident between viruses from a small region from larger geographic regions. Results and Clinical Relevance - The viruses isolated from flocks to which genotype 1, genogroup 1a BVDV vaccine was administered before breeding were primarily genetically diverse genotype 2, genogroup 2a BVDVs. Vaccination with more than one BVDV genotype may be required to improve protection. The methods used in this study to obtain and analyze field strains are applicable to assessing the efficacy of current BVDV vaccines. Candidates for future vaccines are viruses that can evade the immune response of cattle vaccinated against BVDV with current vaccines.
authors: Bolin, S. R.;Lim, A.;Grotelueschen, D. M.;McBeth, W. W.;Cortese, V. S.

title: Prevalence of bovine viral diarrhea virus genotypes and antibodies to these viral genotypes in fetal bovine serum
abstract: One thousand lots of pooled fetal bovine serum (FBS) were tested for contamination with bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) and/or with neutralizing antibody to BVDV. Non-cytopathic or cytopathic BVDV was isolated from 203 lots of FBS. Analysis of viral isolates identified 115 type 1 and 65 type 2 BVDV isolates. Additional 23 virus isolates were mixtures of > or = 2 BVDV isolates and were not classified by viral genotype. Further characterization of type 1 viruses identified 51 subgenotype 1a and 64 subgenotype 1b BVDV isolates. Viral neutralizing antibody was detected in 113 FBS lots. Differential viral neutralization showed that type 1 BVDV induced antibody detected in 48 lots of FBS and type 2 BVDV induced antibody detected in 16 lots of FBS.
authors: Bolin, S. R.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: Unexpected diversity and expression of avian endogenous retroviruses
abstract: Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) were identified and characterized in three avian genomes to gain insight into early retroviral evolution. To detect relatively intact ERVs, we identified 500 ERVs in the chicken genome, 150 in the turkey genome, and 1,200 in the zebra finch genome using the RetroTector computer program. Previous studies have suggested that endogenous alpharetroviruses are present in chicken genomes. Few alpharetroviruses were seen in chicken and turkey genomes in this analysis; however, they were greatly outnumbered by beta-like, gamma-like, and alpha-like proviruses. While avian ERVs belonged to the same major groups as mammalian ERVs, they were more heterogeneous. In particular, beta-like viruses revealed an evolutionary continuum with the gradual gain and loss of betaretroviral markers and the transition from beta to alphabetic and then to alpharetroviruses. Thus, it seems that birds may have been like a melting pot for early ERV evolution. Most of the ERVs were integrated in clusters on the chromosomes, usually near the centromeres.
