About 25% of chicken ERVs were at or near cellular transcription units; this is almost random. Most of these integrations were in sensory orientation in introns. The integration number higher than the random number was >100 kb from the nearest gene. Deep sequencing studies of chicken embryo fibroblasts revealed that approximately 20% of 500 ERVs are transcribed and translated. A subset of these were also replicated in vivo in chickens, showing tissue-specific expression patterns. IMPORTANT Studies on avian endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) have given us an insight into an earlier retroviral world. Three different classes of ERVs were observed, with many features and some important differences of mammalian retroviruses. Many bird ERVs have been copied and translated.
authors: Bolisetty, M.;Blomberg, J.;Benachenhou, F.;Sperber, G.;Beemon, K.

title: Bird host spectrum of avipoxviruses
abstract: review of the occurrence of smallpox viruses in different bird species is given. The first publications appeared in Europe around 1850. At that time, smallpox as a definitive disease entity was diagnosed on the basis of clinical signs, later the detection of Bollinger's inclusion bodies (1877) with microscopically visible viral aggregates allowed an etiological diagnosis. Virus isolation and direct electron microscopy in embryonated chicken eggs gained importance as diagnostic tools in the 1950s. In addition, avipoxvirus taxonomy, virus characteristics, clinical manifestations, prevention modes and diagnostic procedures are also briefly explained. A natural infection of smallpox has been reported in about 232 species out of 23 orders out of about 9000 bird species. However, many more birds are likely to be susceptible to avipoxviruses.
authors: Bolte, A. L.;Meurer, J.;Kaleta, E. F.

title: Discovery of Swine Outbreak Diarrhea Virus and Recombinant Swine Enteric Coronavirus, Italy
abstract: The swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) has been detected sporadically in Italy since the 1990s. We report the phylogenetic relationship of porcine enteric coronaviruses collected in Italy between 2007-2014 and detect a severe shift in PEDV strain variability and a novel porcine enteric coronavirus created by recombination of the infectious gastroenteritis virus and PEDV.
authors: Boniotti, M. B.;Papetti, A.;Lavazza, A.;Alborali, G.;Sozzi, E.;Chiapponi, C.;Faccini, S.;Bonilauri, P.;Cordioli, P.;Marthaler, D.

title: Sequence comparison of the L2 and S10 genes of bluetongue viruses in the United States and the People's Republic of China
abstract: Bluetongue virus (BTV) infection of ruminants is endemic in most of the USA and China. Some of the S10 and L2 gene segments of the Chinese prototype strains of BTV serotypes 1, 2, 3, 4, 12, 15 and 16 were sequenced and compared with the same genes of the prototype and field strains of BTV from the USA. Phylogenetic analysis of the S10 gene separated Chinese viruses into a distinct monophyletic group from US viruses, while similar analysis of the L2 gene separated BTV strains by serotype, regardless of geographic origin. Copyright (C) 1999 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Bonneau, K. R.;Zhang, N.;Zhu, J.;Zhang, F.;Li, Z.;Zhang, K.;Xiao, L.;Xiang, W.;MacLachlan, N. J.

title: Identification and phylogenetic analysis of orf viruses isolated from goats outbreaks in the northeastern state of Assam, India.
abstract: Two outbreaks of orf virus (ORFV) (a parapoxvirus) infection in goats were investigated in Golaghat and Kamrup districts of Assam, northeast India. The disease was diagnosed by standard virological and molecular techniques. The entire protein-coding region of the B2L gene of the two isolates was cloned and sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis based on B2L amino acid sequences showed that the ORFVs identified in these outbreaks were closely related, and both were more closely related to the ORFV-Shahjahanpur 82/04 isolate from northern India. The current study revealed that precise characterization of the genomic region (B2L gene) can provide evidence for genetic variation and movement of ORFV strains circulating in India. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Bora, D. P.;Barman, N. N.;Das, S. K.;Bhanuprakash, V.;Yogisharadhya, R.;Venkatesan, G.;Kumar, A.;Rajbongshi, G.;Khatoon, E.;Chakraborty, A.;Bujarbaruah, K. M.

title: Isolation and molecular characterization of Orf virus from natural outbreaks in Assam goats.
abstract: Outbreaks of infectious ecthyma (caused by a Parapox virus) in goats were investigated in 6 districts of the northeastern Indian state of Assam. Diagnosis of the disease was made using both standard virological and molecular methods. Four representative isolates from different sites were selected for phylogenetic analysis. The main envelope protein (B2L) of the orf virus was targeted for molecular analysis. Sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of selected sequences at the nucleotide level revealed that the Orf virus isolates were closely related (97.6%-100%) with the highest similarity to Orf virus isolate 82/04 (98.4Â). Reported from Shahjahanpur, India. The data will give an idea of the transmission of the virus from the north to the northeast of the country.
authors: Bora, M.;Bora, D. P.;Barman, N. N.;Borah, B.;Bora, P. L.;Talukdar, A.;Tamuly, S.

title: Physicochemical and morphological relationships of some arthropod-derived viruses with bluetongue virus - a new taxonomic group. Physicochemical and serological studies
authors: Borden, E. C.;Shope, R. E.;Murphy, F. A.

title: Neuroinvasive Astrovirus Outbreaks Associated with Encephalomyelitis, Weakness and Paralysis in Weaned Pigs, Hungary
abstract: large, highly productive pig farm in Hungary had a 2-year history of neurological disease in newly weaned (25 to 35 days old) pigs with clinical signs of posterior paraplegia and a high mortality rate. Affected pigs autopsied had encephalomyelitis and neural necrosis. Porcine astrovirus type 3 was identified by reverse transcription PCR and in situ hybridization in brain and spinal cord samples from 6 animals from this farm. Among the tissues tested by quantitative RTPCR, the highest viral loads were detected in the brain stem and spinal cord. A similar swine astrovirus type 3 was detected in archived brain and spinal cord samples from 2 other geographically distant farms. Viral RNA was predominantly confined to neurons, particularly the brainstem, cerebellum (Purkinje cells), and cervical spinal cord. Astrovirus was generally undetectable in stool but was present in respiratory samples, suggesting a possible respiratory infection. Astrovirus can cause widespread, neuroinvasive epidemic disease.
authors: Boros, A.;Albert, M.;Pankovics, P.;Biro, H.;Pesavento, P. A.;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Identification and whole genome characterization of a novel picornavirus (Meleagris gallopavo) in Turkey
abstract: Members of the Picornaviridae family are important pathogens for humans and animals, although only a few (n=11) picornaviruses have been identified from avian sources compared to thousands of known bird species (>10 000). This study reports the metagenomic detection and whole genome characterization of a novel turkey picornavirus from fecal samples collected from eight turkey farms in Hungary. Using RT-PCR, commercial turkeys, both healthy (two-thirds) and affected (seven-eight) commercial turkeys with enteric and/or stunted syndrome were shown to spread virus in seven of eight farms (88%). The viral genome sequence (turkey/M176/2011/HUN; GenBank accession no. JQ691613) shows a high degree of amino acid sequence identity (96%) to the partial P3 genome region of a picornavirus recently reported in turkeys and chickens from the USA. and probably belong to the same species. In regions P1 and P2, turkey/M176/2011/HUN is most closely related to, but different from, cobuviruses and turdivirus 1. Whole genome analysis revealed the presence of characteristic picornaviral amino acid motifs, a potential type II-like 5α. €² UTR internal ribosome entry site (first identified among avian picornaviruses) and a conserved 48 nt-long "barbell-like" structure found in the 3â€² UTR of turkey/M176/2011/HUN and members of the picornavirus genus Avihepatovirus and Kobuvirus. The general presence of turkey picornavirus - a new strain of picornavirus - in stool samples from healthy and affected turkeys in Hungary and the USA indicates the worldwide occurrence and endemic circulation of this virus in turkey farms. Further studies are needed to investigate the etiological role and pathogenic potential of this picornavirus in food animals. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Boros, A.;Nemes, C.;Pankovics, P.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Genetic characterization of a novel picornavirus in turkeys (Meleagris gallopavo) distinct from turkey galliviruses and megriviruses and distantly related to members of the Avihepatovirus genus.
abstract: This study reports the metagenomic detection and whole genome characterization of a novel turkey picornavirus from stool samples of healthy (1/3) and affected (6/8) commercial turkeys with enteric and/or stunted syndrome in Hungary. The virus was detected in seven of the eight farms studied. The turkey/M176-TuASV/2011/HUN genome (KC465954) was genetically different from the currently known picornaviruses (megriviruses and galliviruses) from Turkey and showed distant phylogenetic association and common genomic features (eg polypeptides) hepatitis A virus (DHAV) of the avihepatovirus genus. duck. Whole genome analysis revealed numerous distinct genome features, such as the first aphthovirus 2A-like and DxExNPG/P 'ribosome-skipping' regions (76%, 23/30 amino acid identical) and the presence of two consecutive aphthovirus 2A-like sequence repeats. Sequence located at the end of the VP1 capsid protein (VP1/2A1 'ribosome skipping' region). Phylogenetic analyzes with DHAV, low sequence identity (33%, 32% and 36% amino acid identity in the P1, P2 and P3 regions) and type II-like internal ribosome entry site suggest that this turkey picornavirus is related but different from it. It is a genus of Avihepatovirus and may be a founding member of a new Avihepatovirus sister lineage. This is the third clade of picornavirus, taxonomically quite distinct, identified from turkeys exhibiting a variety of symptoms. © 2013 SGM.
authors: Boros, A.;Nemes, C.;Pankovics, P.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: A chicken with diarrhea co-infected with multiple picornaviruses simultaneously: Complete genome analysis of avian picornaviruses representing up to six genera.
abstract: In this study, all currently known chicken picornaviruses, including a novel one (chicken phacovirus 1, KT880670) in Hungary, were obtained from a single sample of a chicken with diarrhea suffering from a total of eight picornavirus co-infections in Hungary by viral metagenomic and RT-PCR methods. defined. . The complete genomes of six picornaviruses were determined and their genomic and phylogenetic features and UTR RNA structural patterns were analyzed in detail. Picornaviruses belonged to the genera Sicinivirus (first full genome), Gallivirus, Tremovirus, Avisivirus and "Orivirus" (two potential genotypes). In addition, unassigned phacoviruses were also detected in multiple chicken samples in the USA. Multiple co-infections promote and facilitate the recombination and evolution of picornaviruses and may ultimately contribute to the severity of diarrhea in chicken, one of the most important human food sources.
authors: Boros, Ã;Pankovics, P.;Adonyi, Ã;Fenyvesi, H.;Day, J. M.;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Genome characterization of a novel chicken picornavirus distantly related to members of the Avihepatovirus genus with a single 2A protein and a megrivirus-like 3' UTR.
abstract: Members of the genus Avihepatovirus and related picornaviruses of ducks, turkeys, and chickens ("Aalivius") have identical 2A peptide compositions, including three functionally unrelated 2A peptides, a genome feature characteristic of these monophyletic avian picornaviruses. The complete genome of a novel picornavirus, tentatively named Orivirus A1 (KM203656), was characterized from a cloacal specimen of a 4-week-old diarrheal chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) distantly related to members of the Avihepatovirus genus. The working strain contains a type II-like IRES, a single 2A protein of unknown function unrelated to the 2A proteins of avihepatoviruses, and multiple repetitive sequence motifs followed by an AUG-rich region and a long 3' untranslated region (UTR). The repeating sequences of the 3' UTR show substantial identity with phylogenetically distant "Unit A" sequences of megriviruses. The presence of a novel single 2A and megrivirus-like "Unit A" motifs suggests multiple recombination events in the evolution of this novel picornavirus.
authors: Boros, Ã;Pankovics, P.;Adonyi, Ã;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Comparative whole-genome analysis of chicken and Turkey megriviruses (family Picornaviridae): long 3' untranslated regions with a potential second open reading frame and evidence for possible recombination
abstract: UNLABELED: Members of the Picornaviridae family consist of small positive-sense single-stranded RNA (+ssRNA) viruses that can infect a variety of vertebrate species, including birds. One of the recently identified avian picornaviruses with a remarkably long (>9,040-nucleotide) but still not fully sequenced genome is turkey hepatitis virus 1 (THV-1; Melegrivirus A strain, Megrivirus), a virus associated with liver necrosis and enteritis. genus). in commercial turkeys (Meleagris gallopavo). This report presents the results of genetic analysis of three complete megrivirus genomes from fecal samples of chickens (chicken/B21-CHV/2012/HUN, GenBank accession no. KF961186 and chicken/CHK-IV-CHV/2013/HUN). GenBank accession no. KF961187) (Gallus gallus domesticus) and turkey (turkey/B407-THV/2011/HUN, GenBank accession no. KF961188) (Meleagris gallopavo) have the largest picornavirus genomes ever described (up to 9,739 nucleotides). The close phylogenetic association with THV-1 in the nonstructural protein-coding genome region and having the same internal ribosomal entry site type (IVB-like) suggest that the study strains belong to the genus Megrivirus. However, genome comparisons revealed many unique variations (for example, different numbers of potential 2A peptides, unusually long 3' genome segments with a potential second open reading frame of varying lengths, and multiple repetitive sequence motifs in the 3' untranslated region) and heterogeneity. Sequence relationships between structural and nonstructural genome regions. These differences suggest the classification of chicken megrivirus-like viruses as candidate new species in the genus Megrivirus. Based on the different phylogenetic positions of chicken megrivirus-like viruses in structural and nonstructural genome regions, the recombinant nature of these viruses is plausible. SIGNIFICANCE: Comparative genome analysis of turkey and novel chicken megriviruses, for example, unusually long 3' genome segments of various lengths containing up to four potential 2A peptides, a potential second open reading frame, multiple repetitive sequence motifs, and between structural and nonstructural genome regions. heterogeneous sequence relationships (possibly due to a recombination event). Our results may help us better understand the evolution and diversity (in terms of sequence and genome arrangement) of picornaviruses.
authors: Boros, A.;Pankovics, P.;Knowles, N. J.;Nemes, C.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Genomic analysis of a novel picornavirus from a migratory waterfowl, the greater white-fronted goose (Anser albifrons).
abstract: The complete genome of goose picornavirus 1 (GPV-1) strain goose/NLSZK2/HUN/2013 (MF358731) was determined by RT-PCR and next-generation sequencing from a cloacal sample of a migratory waterbird, the greater white-fronted goose (Anser). albifrons) in Hungary. The genome of GPV-1 shows a L-3-3-4 organization pattern with a 5'-terminal origin of replication (ORI) region, a type-IV IRES and an Hbox/NC-type 2A protein. This virus showed the highest overall sequence identity to members of the genus Kobuvirus, but the phylogenetic position of GPV-1 differs in the analyzed P1, 2C and 3CD phylogenetic trees, further increasing the diversity of known avian picornaviruses.
authors: Boros, Ã;Pankovics, P.;Simmonds, P.;Kiss, T.;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Multiple distinct picobirnaviruses with functional prokaryotic Shine-Dalgarno ribosome binding sites found in the cloaca specimen of a chicken with diarrhea
abstract: Picobirnaviruses (PBVs) of the Picobirnaviridae family have bisected (S1 and S2 segments), double-stranded RNA genomes. In this study, a total of N = 12 whole chicken PBV (ChPBV) segments (N = 5 of S1 and N = 7 of S2, Acc. No.: MH425579-90) using viral metagenomic and RT-PCR techniques. determined. single cloacal specimen of a chicken with diarrhea. The identified ChPBV segments are unrelated and far from all currently known PBVs. In silico sequence analyzes revealed the presence of conserved prokaryotic Shine-Dalgarno-like (SD-like) sequences upstream of the three putative open reading frames (ORFs) of S1 and a single putative ORF of S2 segments. According to the results of expression analyzes in E. coli using 6xHis-tagged recombinant ChPBV segment 1 construct and Western blot, these SD-like sequences are functional in vivo, indicating that S1 of study PBVs may contain three ORFs and support the bacteriophage structure of PBVs. . .
authors: Boros, Ã;PolgÃ¡r, B.;Pankovics, P.;Fenyvesi, H.;Engelmann, P.;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Characterization of neutralization sites on the circulating variant of swine vesicular disease virus (SVDV): a new site is shared by SVDV and the related coxsackie B5 virus.
abstract: Using a panel of novel monoclonal antibodies (mAbs), five neutralizing, conformation-dependent sites have been identified on the antigenic variant of the currently circulating porcine vesicular disease virus (SVDV). In studies of antigenic conservation of these regions, the four described antigenic/genetic SVDV groups showed distinguishable patterns confirming this classification. By sequencing mAb-resistant mutants, five regions were precisely mapped and localized in a three-dimensional model of the SVDV capsid. All of them were found to be oriented towards the outer surface of the capsid to a different extent. Three of the five regions found in VP1, VP2 and VP3 correspond to epitopes previously identified in historical isolates as sites 1, 2a and 3b, respectively. Another site mapped to position 258 of VP1, site IV, corresponds to a recently reported epitope and is described in this study as specific to isolates of the newest antigenic group of SVDV. A fifth region has been described for the first time and corresponds to the unique neutralizing region common to both SVDV and coxsackie B5 virus; It maps to positions 95 and 98 of VP1, but may also include nearby positions of VP1 belonging to site 1 in the BC loop, suggesting classification of site Ia. While novel conserved domain Ia-directed mAbs provide universal reagents for SVDV detection systems, these results may have useful diagnostic and epidemiological applications, as the site IV specificity of mAbs makes them unique markers for the newest strains of SVDV.
authors: Borrego, B.;Carra, E.;GarcÃ­a-Ranea, J. A.;Brocchi, E.

title: Role of viral population diversity in the adaptation of bovine coronavirus to new host environments
abstract: The high mutation rate of RNA viruses enables a diverse population of genetic viral genotypes to exist in a single infected host. Intra-host genetic diversity can better position the virus population to respond to and adapt to a variety of selective pressures, such as host switching events. Multiple novel coronaviruses, including SARS, have been detected in human samples in the past decade alone, demonstrating the potential of coronaviruses to be emerging human pathogens. Deep sequencing was used to characterize genomic changes in coronavirus half-species during simulated host switching. Three bovine nose samples infected with bovine coronavirus were used to infect human and bovine macrophage and lung cell lines. The virus replicated relatively well in macrophages, but lung cell lines were not infected efficiently enough to allow passage of non-lab-adapted samples. Approximately 12 kb of the genome was amplified before and after passage and sequenced at average coverages of approximately 950x(454 sequencing) and 38,000x(Illumina). The consensus sequence of most of the crossover samples had a 12 nucleotide insert in the consensus sequence of the spike gene, and multiple point mutations were associated with the presence of the insert. Deep sequencing revealed that the insert is present, but very rare in non-passaged samples, and can rapidly change to dominate the population when placed in a different environment. Attachment coding for the three arginine residues occurred at a site associated with fusion entry into host cells and may allow infection of new cell types through heparin sulfate binding. Analysis of the deep sequencing data showed that the two different genotypes circulated at different frequency levels in each sample, supporting the hypothesis that the mutations found in the passaged strains were "selected" from a pre-existing pool rather than de novo mutation and subsequent population. fixing.
authors: Borucki, M. K.;Allen, J. E.;Chen-Harris, H.;Zemla, A.;Vanier, G.;Mabery, S.;Torres, C.;Hullinger, P.;Slezak, T.

title: Capripoxvirus vectored vaccines against livestock diseases in Africa
abstract: Five different viral diseases in livestock, tuberous skin disease (LSD), sheep pox (SPP), goat pox (GTP), Rift Valley fever (RVF) and ruminant animals (PPR) are circulating in the same parts of Africa and making it formidable. imposes a huge burden on economic activity and public health. While commercial vaccines against these viruses are available, the cost of regular multi-disease vaccination regimens is too high for most African farmers. Therefore, a single, affordable multivalent vaccine that simultaneously protects against all 5 diseases would be of significant benefit to the livestock industry in Africa. It can also serve as a platform for the development of new vaccines, which is important to other developing countries around the world. In this article, we provide an overview of the economic importance of farm animals in Africa, the pathogens responsible for RVF, PPR, SPP, GTP and LSD, and the vaccination strategies currently used to combat them. Next, we review experience with the development of attenuated capripox viruses as vaccines against LSD, SPP, and GTP, and recombinant capripoxvirus vectored vaccines against RVF and PPR. We conclude the article by presenting the rationale for a single, multivalent capripoxvirus vectored vaccine to protect against 5 livestock diseases and explaining the approach taken by a consortium of Canadian and South African researchers to develop such a vaccine. Crown Copyright © 2013 Published by Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Boshra, H.;Truong, T.;Nfon, C.;Gerdts, V.;Tikoo, S.;Babiuk, L. A.;Kara, P.;Mather, A.;Wallace, D.;Babiuk, S.

title: Molecular genetic analyzes of clinical isolates of Varicella-zoster (VZV)
abstract: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is classified in the alpha-herpes virus subfamily. The VZV genome is highly conserved. Molecular genetics brings more information about the evolutionary processes of VZV, the mechanisms of the infectious processes of VZV, as well as the pathogenesis of VZV. VZV causes chickenpox (chickenpox) in childhood and can be reactivated in the same person later in life, causing shingles (herpes zoster). Both diseases are the same type of virus. In recent years, molecular genetic analysis methods (whole genome sequencing, microarray techniques) have been helping to gather more detailed information about the VZV genome, including information about genetic recombination.
authors: BoÅ¡tÃ­kovÃ¡, V.;BoÅ¡tÃ­k, P.

title: Indicator of Interspecies Spread of Astrovirus Associated with Sheep and Cattle Encephalitis
abstract: We report the identification of a neurotropic astrovirus associated with encephalitis in a sheep. This virus is genetically nearly identical to an astrovirus recently identified in neurologically diseased cattle. The similarity indicates that astroviruses of the same genotype can cause different types of encephalitis.
authors: Boujon, C. L.;Koch, M. C.;Wuthrich, D.;Werder, S.;Jakupovic, D.;Bruggmann, R.;Seuberlich, T.

title: Genetic characterization of full-length Hepatitis E virus sequences and shedding new light on codon usage bias, genotypic distribution, host restriction, and genome evolution
abstract: The hepatitis E virus (HEV) exists in different species and ecological niches. It is divided into 4 main mammalian genotypes. In this study, 3 novel full-length pig HEV genomes were sequenced and the results did not reveal any specific host determinants when compared with human isolates of the same genotype. Nucleotide composition and codon usage bias were determined to characterize HEV host restriction and genome evolution. Specific nucleotide bias was observed for nucleotides A and C in all HEV genotypes. No nucleotide bias was observed between the 3 codon positions, except for the ORF1 hypervariable region and the ORF2/3 overlapping region. CpG dinucleotides have also been shown to be underrepresented in HEV, as in most RNA viruses. The number of effective codons used in the HEV genome was high, indicating the absence of codon bias. Correspondence analysis of relative synonymous codon usage was performed and showed that HEV evolution is not driven by geographic or host factors, but represents HEV phylogeny. These results confirm that HEV genome evolution is mainly based on mutational repression. Natural selection may also play a role in shaping the HEV genome, particularly in the ORF1 hypervariable region and the ORF2/3 overlapping region, involving, for example, fine-tuning of translation kinetics and escape from the host immune system. These regions can be included in the host restriction. Finally, this study revealed the need to reevaluate possible subtyping classification. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Bouquet, J.;Cherel, P.;Pavio, N.

title: Identical consensus sequence and conserved genomic polymorphism of hepatitis E virus during controlled interspecies transmission
abstract: High-throughput sequencing of bile and faeces of two pigs experimentally infected with human hepatitis E virus (HEV) of the 3f genotype revealed the same full-length consensus sequence as in the human sample. Twenty-nine percent of the polymorphic regions found in HEV from the human sample were preserved throughout infection of the heterologous host. Interspecies transmission of HEV half-species is the result of genomic negative selection pressure on random mutations that can be detrimental to the viral population. HEV intrahost nucleotide diversity was found to be in the lower range of other human RNA viruses but correlated with values found for zoonotic viruses. HEV transmission between humans and pigs is not modulated by host-specific mutations, suggesting that adaptation is mainly regulated by ecological drivers. Â© 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Bouquet, J.;Cheval, J.;RogÃ©e, S.;Pavio, N.;Eloit, M.

title: Whole genome of evolution of a duck influenza A virus in pig cells, deep pyrosequencing analysis
abstract: We examined the subpopulation level evolution of a duck influenza A virus isolate during passage from porcine tracheal cells. The complete genomes of strain A/mallard/Netherlands/10-Nmkt/1999 and its porcine cell passaged strain were analyzed by 454 pyrosequencing with depth of coverage ranging from several hundred to several thousand reads at any point. This allowed characterization of identified minority subpopulations of gene segments 2, 3, 4, 5, 7 and 8 found in the original isolate. These minority subpopulations ranged from 9.5% (for section 2) to 46% (for section 4) of the relevant gene segments in the parent stock. These were probably contributed by one or more viruses circulating in the same region, at the same time, and in the same or sympathetic host species. Minority subpopulations of sections 3, 4 and 5 became extinct upon viral transmission in porcine cells, whereas minority subpopulations of sections 2, 7 and 8 replaced their majority counterparts. The porcine passaged virus was therefore a three-segment reassortant and also harbored point mutations in segments 3 and 4. The passaged virus was more homogeneous than the parent stock and there were only 17 minority single nucleotide polymorphisms above the overall frequency above 5%. genetic code. While limited here to a single sample, this deep sequencing approach highlights the evolutionary versatility of influenza viruses, in which they take advantage of their genetic diversity, propensity for mixed infection, and re-diversification to adapt to a new host environmental niche.
authors: Bourret, V.;Croville, G.;Mariette, J.;Klopp, C.;Bouchez, O.;Tiley, L.;Guerin, J. L.

title: Whole genome-based molecular characterization of encephalitis-associated bovine astroviruses
abstract: New strains of astroviruses have recently been identified in association with neurological diseases in cattle. These viruses include bovine astrovirus CH13 (BoAstV CH13), which was identified in Switzerland in a cow with encephalitis. Molecular tests with a combination of reverse transcription (RT-) PCR and in situ hybridization (ISH) have shown that astrovirus infection is responsible for about a quarter of viral encephalitis cases of unknown etiology in cattle. Still, whether these animals were infected by BoAstV CH13 or other strains of astrovirus remained to be investigated. In this study, we sequenced the entire astrovirus genome in brain tissues of eight RT-PCR and/or ISH positive cattle. Phylogenetic comparison of genomic RNA and encoded nonstructural and structural proteins revealed that all these astrovirus strains are very similar to BoAstV CH13 and a bovine encephalitis strain (BoAstV NeuroS1) reported from the USA, and clearly different from others previously. reported astroviruses. The conserved 5' and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs) have been predicted to exhibit distinct secondary RNA structures, possibly involved in viral RNA replication and/or protein translation. Based on these data, we propose that BoAstV CH13/NeuroS1 represents a novel genotype species within the Mammastrovirus genus. The high degree of similarity between strains and their relative distance from other genotypes suggests that during evolution, some astroviruses specifically acquired factors that contribute to neuroinvasion. (C) 2016 Authors. Posted by Elsevier BV
authors: Bouzalas, I. G.;Wuthrich, D.;Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Drogemuller, C.;Bruggmann, R.;Seuberlich, T.

title: Neurotropic astrovirus in cattle with nonsuppurative encephalitis in Europe
abstract: Encephalitis is a frequently diagnosed condition in cattle with neurological diseases. Many affected animals show a non-suppurative pattern of inflammatory reactions in the brain. While this pattern supports a viral etiology, the causative pathogen is unknown in the majority of cases. Using viral metagenomics, we identified an astrovirus (bovine astrovirus [BoAstV]-CH13) in the brain of a cow with nonsuppurative encephalitis. In addition, BoAstV RNA was detected by reverse transcription-PCR and in situ hybridization in about a quarter (5/22 animals) of cattle with non-suppurative encephalitis of unknown etiology. Viral RNA was found primarily in neurons and at the pathology site. These findings support the idea that BoAstV infection is a common cause of encephalitis in cattle. Phylogenetically, BoAstV-CH13 is closely related to rare isolates of astrovirus from encephalitis cases in animals and a human patient. Future research needs to address the pathogenic mechanisms, epidemiology and potential interspecies transmission of these neurotropic astroviruses. Copyright © 2014, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Bouzalas, I. G.;WÃ¼thrich, D.;Walland, J.;DrÃ¶gemÃ¼ller, C.;Zurbriggen, A.;Vandevelde, M.;Oevermann, A.;Bruggmann, R.;Seuberlich, T.

title: A viral metagenomic approach in a non-metagenomic experiment: Mining of next-generation sequencing datasets from pig DNA identified several pigs.
authors: Bovo, S.;Mazzoni, G.;Ribani, A.;Utzeri, V. J.;Bertolini, F.

title: viral metagenomic approach in a non-metagenomic experiment: mining next-generation sequencing datasets from pig DNA identified several porcine parvoviruses for retrospective evaluation of viral infections.
abstract: Shot-gun next-generation sequencing (NGS) on all DNA extracted from samples collected from mammals often produces reads that are not mapped (ie, unmapped reads) in the host reference genome and are often discarded as by-products of experiments. In this study, we extracted Ion Torrent reads obtained by sequencing DNA isolated from archived blood samples collected from 100 performance-tested Italian Great White pigs. Two libraries of reduced representation were prepared from two DNA pools, each formed from 50 equimolar DNA samples. Bioinformatics analyzes were performed to extract unpaired reads on the reference pig genome from the two NGS datasets. In silico analyzes included read mapping and sequence splicing approaches for a viral metagenomic analysis using the NCBI Viral Genome Resource. Our approach identified sequences that matched several viruses from the Parvoviridae family: porcine parvovirus 2 (PPV2), PPV4, PPV5 and PPV6, and porcine bocavirus 1-H18 isolate (PBoV1-H18). The presence of these viruses was confirmed by PCR and Sanger sequencing of individual DNA samples. PPV2, PPV4, PPV5, PPV6 and PBoV1-H18 were identified in samples collected in 1998-2007, 1998-2000, 1997-2000, 1998-2004 and 2003, respectively. For most of these viruses (PPV4, PPV5, PPV6, and PBoV1-H18), previous studies reported their first occurrence much later (5 to 10 years) than our identification period and in different geographic regions. Our study provided a retrospective evaluation of apparently asymptomatic parvovirus-infected pigs, providing information that may be important for describing the emergence and prevalence of different parvoviruses in Southern Europe. This study demonstrated the potential of mining NGS datasets that were not originally derived by metagenomic experiments for viral metagenomic analyzes in a livestock species.
authors: Bovo, S.;Mazzoni, G.;Ribani, A.;Utzeri, V. J.;Bertolini, F.;Schiavo, G.;Fontanesi, L.

title: Molecular characterization of menangle virus, a novel paramyxovirus infecting pigs, fruit bats and humans.
abstract: Menangle virus (MenV), isolated after a piglet reproductive disease outbreak in New South Wales in August 1997, is the second previously unclassified member of the Paramyxoviridae family and has been described in Australia since 1994. Similar to Hendra virus (HeV), MenV appears to be a virus of fruit bats (flying foxes) from the genus Pteropus. No serological cross-reactivity was detected between MenV and other known paramyxoviruses, and a cDNA extraction method was used to obtain viral-specific cDNA from MenV-infected cells to facilitate virus classification. Cloning and sequencing of the products allowed the identification of all sequences of the NP, P/V, M, F and HN genes. Comparison of nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences for each gene with members of the Paramyxoviridae family, determination of the P gene mRNA editing strategy, and phylogenetic analyzes confirmed that MenV is a new member of the genus Rubulavirus. However, the deduced protein sequence of MenV HN exhibited only limited sequence homology compared to the binding proteins of other paramyxoviruses. Key differences in amino acid residues, which are considered important determinants of neuraminidase activity, suggest that MenV HN is unlikely to have the same degree of neuraminidase activity that is characteristic of other rubulavirus and respirovirus HN proteins. Â© 2001 Academic Press.
authors: Bowden, T. R.;Westenberg, M.;Wang, L. F.;Eaton, B. T.;Boyle, D. B.

title: Mechanism of Action of A238L: Immune Avoidance Protein of African Swine Fever Virus
authors: Bowick, G.

title: Analysis of different host cell nuclear proteome caused by attenuated and lethal hemorrhagic arenavirus infection
abstract: Arenaviruses are important emerging pathogens and include a number of hemorrhagic fever viruses classified as NIAID category A priority pathogens and CDC potential biological threat agents. Infection of guinea pigs with the New World arena virus Pichindé virus (PICV) was used as a biosafety level 2 model for Lassa virus. Despite ongoing research, little is known about the molecular basis of pathogenesis and this has hindered the design of new antiviral therapeutics. Modulation of the host response is a potential strategy for the treatment of infectious diseases. We have previously investigated the global host response to attenuated and lethal arenavirus infections using high-throughput immunoblotting and kinomic approaches. In this report, we describe the different nuclear proteomes of a murine cell line induced by mock infection and infection with attenuated and lethal variants of PICV, investigated using two-dimensional gel electrophoresis. Spot identification using tandem mass spectrometry revealed the involvement of a number of proteins and several heterogeneous nuclear ribonuclear proteins that regulate inflammation through potential modulation of NF-κB activity. Pathway analysis revealed a potential role for the transcription factor XBP-1, a transcription factor involved in major histocompatibility complex II (MHC-II) expression; differential DNA-binding activity was revealed by the electrophoretic mobility shift assay, and differences in surface MHC-II expression were seen following PICV infection. These data are consistent with the results of several previous studies and highlight potential differences between transcriptional and translational regulation. This study provides a set of differentially expressed targets for further investigation and suggests that important events in pathogenesis may be set early in infection. Copyright © 2009, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Bowick, G. C.;Spratt, H. M.;Hogg, A. E.;Endsley, J. J.;Wiktorowicz, J. E.;Kurosky, A.;Luxon, B. A.;Gorenstein, D. G.;Herzog, N. K.

title: Genomic sequences of Australian bluetongue virus prototype serotypes reveal global associations and possible entry routes to Australia
abstract: Bluetongue virus (BTV) is transmitted by biting midges (Culicoides spp.). It mainly causes disease in sheep and sometimes cattle and other species. BTV spread to northern Europe, causing disease in sheep and cattle. The introduction of new serotypes, changes in vector species, and climate change have contributed to these changes. Ten BTV serotypes have been isolated in Australia without significant associated disease. Simplified methods and template preparation for the preferential isolation of double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) enabled high-throughput sequencing of 10 genome segments of all Australian BTV prototype serotypes. The phylogenetic analysis strengthened the Western and Eastern topotypes that were previously characterized but revealing unique features of several Australian BTVs. Most of the Australian BTV genome segments (Seg-) were closely related, clustering together within Eastern topotypes. A new Australian topotype has been identified for Seg-5 (NS1) and taxa have spread to several serotypes and over time. Seg-1, -2, -3, -4, -6, -7, -9 and -10 of BTV_2_AUS_2008 were closely related to cognate segments of viruses from Taiwan and Asia, but not to other Australian viruses. supports. BTV_2 has recently entered Australia. The Australian BTV_15_AUS_1982 prototype turned out to be unusual among Australian BTV isolates, with Seg-3 and -8 distantly related to other BTV sequences from all serotypes. Â© 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Boyle, D. B.;Bulach, D. M.;Amos-Ritchie, R.;Adams, M. M.;Walker, P. J.;Weir, R.

title: The evolution of human influenza A viruses from 1999 to 2006: A complete genome study.
abstract: Background: Information on the complete genome sequencing of seasonal influenza A viruses from different countries is valuable for monitoring and understanding the evolution and migration of strains. Few complete genome sequences of influenza A viruses from Europe are currently available to the public, and several longitudinal genome studies of human influenza A viruses have been performed. We examined the evolution of circulating human H3N2, H1N1 and H1N2 influenza A viruses from 1999 to 2006, analyzed 234 Danish human influenza A viruses and characterized 24 complete genomes. Results: H3N2 was the most common strain in Denmark during the study period, but H1N1 dominated the 2000-2001 season. H1N2 viruses were first observed in Denmark in 2002-2003. After years of minor genetic variation in H1N1 viruses, the 2005-2006 season brought more variability to H1N1 than before. This indicates that H1N1 viruses are evolving and that H1N1 will soon become the prevalent strain again. Overall, influenza A hemagglutinin (HA) of H3N2 viruses formed seasonal phylogenetic clusters. Different lineages were also observed circulating together in the same season. Evolution has been stochastic, influenced by small "jumps" in genetic distance rather than constant drift, particularly with the advent of Fujian-like viruses in 2002-2003. Periods of evolutionary stasis were also observed, which may indicate that the viruses adapt well. The evolution of H3N2 viruses has also been influenced by gene reclassifications between lineages in different seasons. None of the influenza genes were affected by strong positive selection pressure. Antigenic region B in H3N2 HA was the preferred region for genetic change during the study period, possibly because region A was masked by glycosylations. Substitutions were observed in CTL epitopes in genes encoding neuraminidase (NA), polymerase acidic protein (PA), matrix protein 1 (M1), non-structural protein 1 (NS1) and specifically nucleoprotein (NP). The N-linked glycosylation pattern varied over the study period, and H3N2 isolates from 2004 to 2006 were highly glycosylated, with ten secons predicted in HA, the highest amount of glycosylation observed in this study period. Conclusion: This study is the first to our knowledge characterizing the evolution of the complete genomes of influenza A H3N2, H1N1 and H1N2 isolates from Europe over a seven-year period from 1999 to 2006. More precise information about circulating strains is inferred for prediction of next season strains and thus better matching of vaccine composition.
authors: Bragstad, K.;Nielsen, L. P.;Fomsgaard, A.

title: Genomic evolution of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) isolates revealed by deep sequencing.
abstract: Most studies of PRRSV evolution have been restricted to a particular region of the viral genome. A comprehensive genome-wide understanding of the impact of different mechanisms on shaping PRRSV genetic diversity is still lacking. To this end, deep sequencing was used to obtain the genomic sequences of a diverse set of 16 isolates from a region of Hong Kong with a complex PRRSV epidemiological record. Genome assemblies and phylogenetic typing showed co-circulation of strains of both genotypes (type 1 and type 2) with varying patterns of Nsp2 deletion and different evolutionary lineages ("High Fever"-like and local endemic type). Recombination analyzes revealed genomic breakpoints in the structural and nonstructural regions of the genomes of both genotypes, with evidence of many recombination events originating from common ancestors. In addition, the high coating fold per nucleotide allowed the characterization of minor variants originating from half-species of each strain. Overall, 0.56-2.83% of the sites were found to be polymorphic to cognate consensus genomes. The distribution of small variants in each genome was not uniform, indicating the effect of selective forces. The proportion of variants capable of causing an amino acid change in their respective codons ranged from 25-67%, and many were estimated to be non-destructive. As noted in previous reports, low-frequency deletion variants were also detected, providing a possible mechanism for their abrupt emergence.
authors: Brar, M. S.;Shi, M.;Hui, R. K.;Leung, F. C.

title: border disease in cattle
abstract: Within the family Flaviviridae, viruses in the genus Pestivirus such as Border disease virus of sheep (BDV) can cause great economic losses to livestock. Initially, taxonomic classification of pestiviruses was based on the host species from which they were isolated, but it is now known that many pestiviruses exhibit broad species tropism. This review provides an overview of BDV infection in cattle. The clinical, haematological and pathological-anatomical findings in cattle temporarily or permanently infected with BDV are broadly similar to those in cattle infected with the closely related pestivirus bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV). Accordingly, diagnosis of BDV infection can be difficult as it must be differentiated from various pestiviruses in cattle. Second, it is crucial in countries with control programs to eradicate BVDV in Bovidae because pestivirus infections in sheep, which in most cases serve as reservoirs for BDV, are not included in the eradication scheme. Interspecies transmission of BDV between sheep and cattle occurs regularly, but the overall relevance of BDV in cattle appears to be minimal. However, on-farm or local-level BDV outbreaks can be very costly.
authors: Braun, U.;Hilbe, M.;Peterhans, E.;Schweizer, M.

title: Swine Flu Virus (H1N2) Characterization and Transmission in Ferrets, Chile
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of the influenza hemagglutinin gene (HA) suggested that commercial pigs in Chile harbor unique human seasonal H1-like influenza viruses, but further information, including characterization of these viruses, was not available. We isolated influenza virus (H1N2) from a pig in a backyard breeding farm in central Chile and showed that the HA gene was the same as in a previous report. The HA and neuraminidase genes were most similar to human H1 and N2 viruses of the early 1990s, and the inner segments were similar to influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. The virus multiplied efficiently in vitro and in vivo and was transmitted by respiratory droplets in ferrets. It was antigenically different from other swine viruses. Hemagglutination inhibition analysis showed decreased antibody titers to the swine Chile H1N2 virus in persons born after 1990. Besides the potential risk to humans, further work is needed to characterize the ecology of influenza in pigs in South America.
authors: Bravo-Vasquez, N.;Karlsson, E. A.;Jimenez-Bluhm, P.;Meliopoulos, V.;Kaplan, B.;Marvin, S.;Cortez, V.;Freiden, P.;Beck, M. A.;Hamilton-West, C.;Schultz-Cherry, S.

title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Circoviridae
abstract: The Circoviridae family includes viruses with small, circular, single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) genomes, including the smallest known animal viruses. Members of this family are classified into two genera, Circovirus and Cyclovirus, which are distinguished by the location of the source of replication with respect to their coding region and the length of the intergenic regions. Within each genus, the species restriction threshold is 80% genome-wide nucleotide sequence identity. This is a summary of the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV) Report on the taxonomy of Circoviridae available at www.ictv.global/report/circoviridae.
authors: Breitbart, M.;Delwart, E.;Rosario, K.;Segales, J.;Varsani, A.

title: Shotgun metagenomics of biostains using ultra-deep DNA sequencing
abstract: Detailed molecular analysis of blood or other biological stains at a crime scene is often hampered by the low quantity and quality of extractable DNA. However, determining the origin and composition of a stain is in most cases a prerequisite for the final clarification of a criminal case. Standard methodologies, for example microsatellite typing or mitochondrial DNA sequencing following DNA amplification, are often not sensitive enough to result in sufficient and precise data. We performed ultra-deep DNA sequencing using 454 pyrosequencing technology on a whole genome amplified (WGA) environmental biostain that was unsuccessfully analyzed by standard methodologies following WGA. However, with the combination of WGA and 454 pyrosequencing, we were able to generate 7242 single sequences with an average length of 195 bp. A total of 1,441,971 bp of DNA sequences were generated and compared to public DNA sequence databases. Using ReMask and basic logical alignment search tool (BLAST) searches against known microbial and mammalian genomes, it was possible to determine the metagenomic composition of the blot, i.e. 4.2% bacterial DNA, 0.3% viral DNA, 2.7% fungal DNA, 10.3% mammalian repetitive DNA. , 0.9% pig DNA, 0.13% human DNA, and 81.5% DNA of unknown origin. Our data suggest that 454 pyrosequencing has the potential to be a powerful tool not only in basic research but also in metagenomic analysis of biological trace materials for forensic genetics. Â© 2009 Elsevier Ireland Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Brenig, B.;Beck, J.;SchÃ¼tz, E.

title: A common nomenclature proposal for the viral branches that make up the Varicella-zoster virus strains: Summary of the VZV Nomenclature Meeting 2008, Barts and the London School of Medicine and Dentistry, 24-25 July 2008
abstract: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), the causative agent of chickenpox and zoster, was the first fully sequenced human herpes virus for which vaccines were licensed and widely used. Three groups have published genotyping schemes based on single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and have identified five different phylogenetic segments among them, with two additional possible segments. Sequencing of over 23 complete VZV genomes from around the world further refined the phylogenetic distinctions between SNP genotypes. The widespread surveillance in countries where the varicella vaccine is currently in use, and the challenges posed by three unique genotyping approaches, led to an international meeting where an agreement was reached on a common nomenclature based on phylogenetic branches. In this article, we review the original genotyping schemes and discuss the basis for a new common nomenclature for VZV strains. We propose a minimum set of SNPs that we recommend to be used to genotype these viruses. Finally, we propose criteria by which new branches can be recognized.
authors: Breuer, J.;Grose, C.;Norberg, P.;Tipples, G.;Schmid, D. S.

title: Sequencing of the nucleocapsid protein gene of the swine epidemic diarrhea virus confirms that this virus is a coronavirus related to human coronavirus 229E and porcine gastroenteritis virus.
abstract: The nucleotide sequence of the 1.7 kbp cDNA containing the region closest to the 3' end of the swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) genome was determined independently for the two European PEDV isolates. Almost identical results were obtained for the two isolates from PEDV infection cases in Belgium and England in 1977 and 1987, respectively. The sequences contained a 1323 nucleotide (nt) open reading frame (ORF) with moderate identity to the nucleocapsid (N) gene of other coronaviruses. The greatest similarity in both nucleic acid and protein levels was with human coronavirus 229E. However, the PEDV N gene was significantly larger than that of human 229E and porcine gastroenteritis viruses. This reflects the presence of a putative insertion of approximately 135 nt located towards the middle of the N gene. A second 336 nt ORF was found in the PEDV N gene that could encode a leucine-rich protein similar to, but shorter than, the bovine coronavirus internal protein. Several RNA motifs specific to coronaviruses were also observed. These results confirm the previous tentative classification of PEDV as a coronavirus.
authors: Bridgen, A.;Duarte, M.;Tobler, K.;Laude, H.;Ackermann, M.

title: WHO expert consultation on rabies
authors: Briggs, D.;Bourhy, H.;Cleaveland, S.;Cliquet, F.;Ertl, H.;Fayaz, A.;Fooks, A.;Hemachudha, T.;Ichhpujani, R. L.;Kaboyo, W. R.;Koprowski, H.;Madhusudana, S. I.;Wilde, H.;Cliquet, F.;Spinola, F.;Belotto, A.;Bhatia, R.;Endo, H.;Ganter, B.;Gibert, R.;Grachev, V.;Knezevic, I.;Mc Adams, D.;Meslin, F. X.;Miranda, E.;Morgeaux, S.;Roungou, J. B.

title: Outbreaks appear to be exacerbated during the period from 2007 to 2014.
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) virus affects livestock worldwide. There are seven different serotypes, each with various topotypes, genetic lineages, and strains. Some lineages have distinct traits that may contribute to sporadic spread beyond their recognized endemic areas. The aim of this study is to review the most important FMD epidemiological events that occurred worldwide between 2007 and 2014. Severe outbreaks were caused by FMD virus (FMDV) strain O/Asia/Mya-98 in Japan and South Korea in 2010. previously disease free. In India, where FMD is endemic, the most significant event was the reemergence of the O/ME-SA/Ind-2001 lineage in 2008. Notably, this lineage, normally confined to India, Bangladesh, Nepal and Bhutan, was also found. It caused various outbreaks in Saudi Arabia and Libya in 2013 and in Tunisia and Algeria in 2014-2015. In January 2011, FMDV-positive wild boars were found in Bulgaria, where the disease last occurred in 1996, followed by 12 outbreaks in FMDV O/ME-SA/PanAsia2-infected animals. In 2012, FMDV SAT2 caused outbreaks in Egypt and the Palestinian Autonomous Territories. Another important event was the emergence of FMDV Asia1 Sindh-08 in the Middle East. In South America, an outbreak of FMDV serotype O, topotype Euro-SA was reported in Paraguay in 2011 and was considered alum-free with the vaccine at that time. Lessons learned from past events point to the need for an integrated strategy for FMDV control and surveillance, consisting of coordinated global and regional efforts. The specific local characteristics of the host, environment, and virus that condition the occurrence of FMD should be carefully evaluated and incorporated to adapt appropriate strategies to local plans. In this review, we have compiled relevant epidemiological FMD events to provide an overview of the current situation. We have further discussed the current challenges that exist in different FMD areas.
authors: Brito, B. P.;Rodriguez, L. L.;Hammond, J. M.;Pinto, J.;Perez, A. M.

title: Enteric virome in inflammatory bowel disease
authors: Brooks, J.;Watson, A.

title: Non-maternal transmission is the major mode of ovine lentivirus transmission in a flock of sheep: A molecular epidemiology study.
abstract: Transmission of ovine progressive pneumonia virus (OPPV), a sheep lentivirus, occurs by both maternal and non-maternal routes. At present, the contribution of each pathway to the overall herd OPPV prevalence is not fully understood, as previous serological epidemiological studies lacked the ability to accurately track transmission routes within an infected flock. In this study, the amount of maternal OPP transmission in a naturally infected flock of sheep was evaluated by applying molecular analyzes to proviral sequences derived from peripheral blood leukocytes of OPP positive mother-daughter pairs (N=40). Both proviral envelope (env) and long terminal repeat (LTR) sequences, separately and combined, were used in the following 2 sequence analysis methods: phylogenetic analysis and binary distance calculations. Actual maternal transmission events were defined as concordance in 2 of the 2 sequence analysis methods. Using this criterion, proviral env sequences resulted in a maternal transmission frequency of 14.3% and proviral LTR sequences resulted in a maternal transmission frequency of 10%. Both rates of maternal transmission differed significantly from the equation (P<0.0001). This indicates that the remaining 85.7-90% of girls are infected by non-maternal transmission. This is also the first study to calculate the OPP proviral rate of change for the env gene and LTR promoter. Accurate identification of OPPV transmission pathways provides critical epidemiological data to support management to reduce herd transmission and viral dose. © 2010.
authors: Broughton-Neiswanger, L. E.;White, S. N.;Knowles, D. P.;Mousel, M. R.;Lewis, G. S.;Herndon, D. R.;Herrmann-Hoesing, L. M.

title: Antigenic and genetic analyzes of H1N1 influenza A viruses from European pigs
abstract: H1N1 influenza A viruses isolated from pigs in Europe since 1981 have been studied both antigenically and genetically and compared with H1N1 viruses from other sources. H1N1 viruses from pigs and birds can be divided into three groups: avian, classical porcine and 'bird-like' swine viruses. Low or no reactivity of 'bird-like' swine viruses in HI tests with raised monoclonal antibodies against classical porcine viruses was associated with amino acid substitutions in the antigenic regions of hemagglutinin (HA). Phylogenetic analysis of the HA gene revealed that classical swine viruses from European pigs were most closely related and closely related to North American swine strains, while 'bird-like' swine viruses clustered with avian viruses. 'Bird-like' viruses, introduced to pigs in the UK in 1992, apparently originated directly from strains in pigs in continental Europe at the time. The HA genes of the porcine viruses studied had limited variation in antigenic regions and also contained fewer potential glycosylation sites compared to human H1N1 viruses. HA exhibited antigenic shift, which was more pronounced in 'bird-like' porcine viruses rather than classical porcine strains. Genetic analyzes of two recent "bird-like" swine viruses showed that all RNA segments were most closely related to those of avian influenza A viruses.
authors: Brown, I. H.;Ludwig, S.;Olsen, C. W.;Hannoun, C.;Scholtissek, C.;Hinshaw, V. S.;Harris, P. A.;McCauley, J. W.;Strong, I.;Alexander, D. J.

title: Molecular comparisons of full-length metapneumovirus (MPV) genomes, including newly identified french AMPV-C and -D isolates, further support possible subclassification within the MPV genus.
abstract: Four avian metapneumovirus (AMPV) subgroups (AD) have been reported previously based on genetic and antigenic differences. However, until now, full-length sequences of the only known isolates of European subgroup C and subgroup D viruses (duck and turkey origin, respectively) were not available. These full-length sequences were identified and compared with other previously reported full-length AMPV and human metapneumoviruses (HMPV) sequences using phylogenetic, nucleic and amino acid sequence comparisons and a codon usage bias study. The results confirmed that subgroup C viruses were more closely related to HMPV than the other AMPV subgroups in the study. This was consistent with previous findings using partial genome sequences. Closer relationships between AMPV-A, B, and D were also evident in most of the results. Three metapneumovirus "clusters" HMPV, AMPV-C and AMPV-A, B and D were further supported by codon bias and phylogenetics. Data also presented here, along with data from previous studies describing antigenic relationships between AMPV-A, B, and D, and between AMPV-C and HMPV, may require a metapneumovirus subclassification similar to that used for avian paramyxoviruses with grouping AMPV-A, B. and D as type I metapneumoviruses and AMPV-C and HMPV as type II. Â© 2014 Brown et al.
authors: Brown, P. A.;Lemaitre, E.;Briand, F. X.;Courtillon, C.;Guionie, O.;AllÃ©e, C.;Toquin, D.;Bayon-Auboyer, M. H.;Jestin, V.;Eterradossi, N.

title: Bovine virus diarrhea virus - Strategic decisions for diagnosis and control
abstract: In the 15 years since the last In Practice article on bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV), there has been an explosion in understanding of the molecular mechanisms of viral replication and mutation, particularly those related to biotypic variation. The importance of BVDV as the primary pathogen of cattle, particularly as a cause of reproductive loss, is better understood hand in hand. The BVDV vaccine is currently available in the UK, providing better prospects for protection against infection. However, strategic decisions regarding diagnosis, control and vaccination continue to pose difficult dilemmas for the veterinarian, and it is these issues that this article focuses on.
authors: Brownlie, J.;Thompson, I.;Curwen, A.

title: Epidemics of viral meningitis and single, novel, recombinant and anthroponotic origin of swine vesicular disease virus
abstract: Background and targets: Porcine vesicular disease virus (SVDV) is a close relative of the human Enterovirus B serotype coxsackievirus B5. As the etiologic agent of an important veterinary emergency, few studies have attempted to explain its origin. However, several key questions remain, including the virus's exact biological ancestor and its geographic and temporal origin. Methodology: We sequenced the nearly complete genomes of 27 SVDV and 13 coxsackievirus B5 samples, all originally isolated between 1966 and 2006, and analyzed them with available sequences and historical information. Results: Analyzes containing 24 additional nearly complete SVDV genomic sequences show clear signs of intra-SVDV recombination, while all 51 SVDV isolates remain monophyletic. This supports the hypothesis of a single anthroponotic origin of transfer. Analysis of individual coding and non-coding regions supports a recombinant origin of SVDV between coxsackievirus B5 and another Enterovirus B serotype, most likely coxsackievirus A9. Comprehensive Bayesian sequence-based analysis of the time of the most recent common ancestor of all sequences analyzed shows this in a few years around 1961. Epidemiological evidence suggests that China is an origin, but there are no existing specimens to definitively test this. Conclusions and implications: Historical research and clinical aspects of the relevant Enterovirus B serotypes make the present results consistent with a hypothesis stating that SVDV arose through coinfection, recombination, and a single anthroponotic event during the major viral meningitis outbreaks around 1960. 1961 includes ancestral serotypes. The exact geographic origin of SVDV may not be tested due to historical aspects.
authors: Bruhn, C. A. W.;Abel Nielsen, S. C.;Samaniego, J. A.;Wadsworth, J.;Knowles, N. J.;Gilbert, M. T. P.

title: Role of Schmallenberg virus infection in congenital malformations in ruminant animals in Scotland in spring 2017
abstract: Scotland's Rural College (SRUC) in conjunction with the Moredun Research Institute conducts surveillance for Schmallenberg virus (SBV) infection in cattle and sheep. This article reports the findings regarding the diagnosis of fetopathy associated with SBV infection and other congenital malformations in these species between 1 January and 5 May 2017.
authors: BrÃ¼lisauer, F.;Scholes, S.;Caldow, G. L.;Rocchi, M.;Dagleish, M. P.;Chianini, F.

title: A genetic study of the interaction of Piry virus with drosophila. II. Classification and some preliminary characterizations of viral agD mutants
abstract: The pyry virus mutants selected for their varying growth characteristics in Drosophila melanogaster were previously termed agD mutants. This article presents a classification scheme for grouping some of these mutants and also presents the characteristics of some members of each group. For each agD clone, analysis of the mean incubation time at 20°C versus time at 28°C (tÌ„20, tÌ„28) allowed us to identify compared to a similar data range for wild-type virus. 4 classes of agD mutants: (1) mutants equally affected at both temperatures, (2) cold-sensitive mutants in drosophila (csD), (3) heat-sensitive mutants in drosophila (tsD), and (4) with average incubation time mutants could not be predicted at 20 or 28°C. All agD mutants are listed. Most of these were also ts in chicken embryo cells (CEC) and some were classified as complementation groups. Some correlations were noted. For example, agD mutants with ts+ in CEC were frequently (7 out of 12) weak cold sensitive in drosophila. All of these tsD mutants, which also had ts in CEC, belonged to complement group I (protein L). The true csD mutants, whose differentiation of incubation time increased regularly with wt and again ts in CEC, all belonged to group I, except those belonging to group V (G protein). The three mutants fell into a separate subclass of csD mutants characterized by a defect in CO2 sensitivity symptom expression below a certain temperature. One of these, which is more characterized, was shown to be in complement group V. Some mutants of the fourth class were studied for their ability to infest flies. It was found to be more or less strongly affected. Among these mutants, mutations to the L, N, and G proteins were assigned independently of this phenomenon, suggesting the involvement of different physiological defects. A comparison was made between the phenotypes of some of the agD mutants in drosophila and other members of the vesiculovirus family. Analogy of sigma rhabdovirus with tsD mutants has also been reported.
authors: Brun, G.

title: Rotavirus 993/83, isolated from calf feces, is very similar to an avian rotavirus.
abstract: Polypeptides from purified virions of calf rotavirus (RV) isolate 993/83 and those from pigeon RV isolate PO-13 migrated on SDS-polyacrylamide gels. Two polypeptides, 45K and 47K, were detected at the VP6 position. Both proteins behaved like real VP6 protein by EDTA and heat treatment. RV 993/83 and PO-13 showed the same one-dimensional peptide maps for VP2 and proteins 45K and 47K. More than 70% of serum from German cattle older than 1 year neutralized serum antibodies to RV 993/83 and RV PO-13.
authors: Brussow, H.;Nakagomi, O.;Minamoto, N.;Eichhorn, W.

title: Bovine herpesvirus 4 genome: Cloning, mapping and strain variation analysis
abstract: The restriction map of the bovine herpes virus 4 (BHV-4) genome (test strain V) was generated by analysis of clones from a lambda library (Sau3AI partial digestion) and a plasmid library (Sau3AI partial digestion) for the restriction enzymes EcoRI, BamHI and HindIII (EcoRI). pieces). A genome unit was defined as the length of the unique central portion flanked at both ends by one of the terminal tandem repeats called polyrepetitive DNA (prDNA) and estimated to be 113 ± 2 kbp. V. A restriction map of the prDNA of the test strain showed internal 200 bp tandem repeats of the different sequences. This region in prDNA was highly polymorphic among BHV-4 strains even in a viral DNA preparation from a plaque-purified strain. The right linkage between the repeated and unique sequence of the genome occurred in a nearly constant region, but the left linkage contained a modified prDNA and was variable between BHV-4 strains. The unique central part of the genome was very similar in the four strains in question, with few variations dependent on the presence or absence of a restriction site and four length variations located at positions 0.006 to 0.034 (left end), 0.211. 0.225, 0.864 to 0.881 and 0.962 to 0.984 (right end). The total length variation of 1 genome unit does not exceed 1 kbp.
authors: Bublot, M.;Van Bressem, M. F.;Thiry, E.;Dubuisson, J.;Pastoret, P. P.

title: The Ancient Evolutionary History of Polyomaviruses
abstract: Polyomaviruses are a family of DNA tumor viruses known to infect mammals and birds. To investigate the family's deeper evolutionary history, we used a combination of viral metagenomic, bioinformatics and structural modeling approaches to identify and characterize fish and arthropod-associated polyomavirus sequences. Analyzes based on different new sequences show that polyomaviruses have been slowly co-evolving with their animal hosts for at least half a billion years. Phylogenetic analyzes of individual polyomavirus genes suggest that some modern polyomavirus strains arose after ancient recombination events involving distantly related polyomavirus lineages. The enhanced evolutionary model provides a useful platform for developing a more accurate taxonomic classification system for the viral family Polyomaviridae.
authors: Buck, C. B.;Van Doorslaer, K.;Peretti, A.;Geoghegan, E. M.;Tisza, M. J.;An, P.;Katz, J. P.;Pipas, J. M.;McBride, A. A.;Camus, A. C.;McDermott, A. J.;Dill, J. A.;Delwart, E.;Ng, T. F.;Farkas, K.;Austin, C.;Kraberger, S.;Davison, W.;Pastrana, D. V.;Varsani, A.

title: Inflammation of the udders of cows due to a virus from the Pox group
abstract: Clinical and laboratory studies have been conducted on enzootic inflammation of cow udders. The isolated virus was classified as the Pox group according to its physicochemical and biological properties. It looks like poxvirus officinale. Treating the nipples with a 3.0% alcohol water pyoctanin solution as well as milking (catheterization) led to improvement.
authors: Buczek, J.;Krzyzanowski, J.;Majer, B.;Malinowski, E.

title: Seroprevalence of Rift Valley fever and abortion frequency among livestock in Kisoro county, South West Uganda (2016): a prerequisite for zoonotic infection.
abstract: Background: Rift Valley fever (RVF) is classified as viral hemorrhagic fever and is endemic in East and West Africa. RVF is caused by an arthropod-borne virus (RVFV); The disease is zoonotic and affects human and animal health and international trade. While causing abortions in livestock, human infection occurs through close contact with infected animals or animal products. Methods: A quantitative observational study was conducted using stratified sampling in the western region of Uganda. Blood samples and abortion events were collected and recorded from 1000 animals (goats, sheep, and cattle). Serum was analyzed for RVFV IgG reacting antibodies using competitive ELISA assay. Results: The overall RVFV seroprevalence was 10.4% (104/1000). Cattle (7%) had the highest seroprevalence, followed by Sheep (2.2%), followed by goats (1.2%). Species-specific RVFV seroprevalence was highest in cattle (20.5%), followed by sheep (6.8%), followed by goats (3.6%). Seroprevalence of RVFV (21.8%) in mountainous areas in the north was significantly higher than in lowland areas in the south (3.7%) (p < 0.001). The overall prevalence of abortion was (17.4%), sheep with the highest prevalence of abortion (7.8%), followed by goats (6.3%), followed by cattle (3.3%). Species-specific low prevalence was highest in sheep (24.1%), followed by goats (18.8%), followed by cattle 9.7%. Conclusion: RVFV is endemic in Kisoro county and animals in the highland areas are more likely to be exposed to RVFV infection compared to the lowland areas in the south. Outbreaks in livestock will most likely lead to zoonotic infection in the Kisoro area.
authors: Budasha, N. H.;Gonzalez, J. P.;Sebhatu, T. T.;Arnold, E.

title: Molecular analysis of H7 avian influenza viruses from Australia and New Zealand: genetic diversity and associations from 1976 to 2007.
abstract: Whole genome sequencing of 11 Australian and 1 New Zealand avian influenza A virus isolates (all H7 subtype) allowed the sequences of each of the genome segments to be compared with those of other subtype H7 avian influenza A viruses. The inference of phylogenetic relationships for each segment was used to develop a model of the natural history of these viruses in Australia. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin segment indicates that Australian H7 isolates form a monophyletic branch. This pattern is consistent with the long-term, independent evolution associated with geographic regions in this example. On the basis of analysis of other H7 hemagglutinin sequences, three other geographic regions where similar monophyletic branches were observed were confirmed. These regions are Eurasia plus Africa, North America and South America. Analysis of neuraminidase sequences from the H7N1, H7N3 and H7N7 genomes revealed the same site-based associations. This model of independent evolution of Australian isolates is supported by the results of the analysis of each of the six remaining genomic segments. These results suggest that the maintenance host(s) is almost exclusively associated with Australia, associated with the emergence of five different combinations of neuraminidase subtypes (H7N2, H7N3, H7N4, H7N6, H7N7) among the 11 Australian isolates. Despite the emergence of multiple neuraminidase types, the single lineage of Australian H7 hemagglutinin sequences suggests the existence of a genetic pool from which several reassortants emerged rather than the presence of a small number of stable viral clones. This evolutionary pattern is likely to occur in each of the above-mentioned regions.
authors: Bulach, D.;Halpin, R.;Spiro, D.;Pomeroy, L.;Janies, D.;Boyle, D. B.

title: Effect of hepatitis C virus 3–²-untranslated region on IRES-dependent and cap-dependent translation initiation
abstract: Translation of hepatitis C virus (HCV) genomic RNA is driven by an internal ribosome entry site (IRES) in the 5â€²-untranslated region (5â€²-UTR), and HCV 3â€²-UTR increases IRES activity. Since HCV 3â€²-UTR has a unique structure among 3â€²-UTRs, we checked for possible communication between the 5â€²- and 3â€²-UTR of HCV during translation using chimeric reporter RNAs. We show that HCV IRES and the HCV-like IRES of porcine teschovirus (PTV) or EMCV IRES-driven translation, which belongs to a very different family of viruses (picornaviruses), are also enhanced by HCV 3â€²-UTR. or with a poly(A)-tail in different cell types. Â© 2010 European Federation of Biochemical Societies.
authors: Bung, C.;Bochkaeva, Z.;Terenin, I.;Zinovkin, R.;Shatsky, I. N.;Niepmann, M.

title: Estimating population diversity with unreliable low frequency counts
abstract: We consider the classical population diversity estimation scenario based on frequency count data (once, twice in the sample, number of classes or taxa represented, etc.), but with the condition that the lowest frequency counts, especially singletons, may not be reliable. observed. This is particularly evident in data derived from modern high-throughput DNA sequencing, where errors can cause sequences to be misassigned to new taxa rather than matching them to existing, observed taxa. We look at a number of methods to address this issue, with particular focus on fitting a parametric mix model and deleting the most diverse component; we also consider the data to be left censored and effectively combine two or more low frequency counts. We have found that these purely statistical "downstream" corrections will depend strongly on their underlying assumptions, but such methods can still be useful.
authors: Bunge, J.;BÃ¶hning, D.;Allen, H.;Foster, J. A.

title: Clinical and Pathological Characterization of a Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza H7N8 Outbreak in Commercial Turkeys in Southern Indiana
abstract: Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) is a systemic fatal disease in poultry caused by various subtypes of the influenza A virus and classified on the basis of serological reactions to the surface glycoproteins hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. In January 2016, a new subtype of HPAI-H7N8- was identified in a herd of commercial turkeys (Meleagris gallopavo) in southern Indiana. Clinical signs and history included increased mortality, shortness of breath, head tremors, supine lying, and napping or unaware birds. Post-mortem examination of six recently deceased birds revealed red-colored mucus and marked pulmonary edema in the choana and trachea. Histological lesions in the brain included severe, multifocal lymphohistiocytic meningoencephalitis with foci of malacia, neuronal necrosis, and neuronophagia. Although histological changes in the cerebellum are considered mild, all anatomical locations of the brain are affected. Other histological lesions include pulmonary congestion and edema, splenic obstruction and lymphoid depletion, fibrinoid necrosis of vessels within the spleen, and multifocal pancreatic acinar necrosis. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) was weakly positive for influenza A in the brain; IHC was negative in other tissues tested. The clinical and pathological features of this case matched previously published material on HPAI and were added to examples of known or suspected mutations of a low pathogenic virus to a highly pathogenic virus.
authors: Burcham, G. N.;Ramos-Vara, J. A.;Murphy, D. A.

title: Isolation of a Latent Adenolike Virus from Chicken Kidney Cell Cultures
authors: Burke, C. N.;Luginbuhl, R. E.;Helmboldt, C. F.

title: Etiologically classifiable viral infections in pets: case 1970
authors: BÃ¼rki, F.

title: Herpesvirus strigis: a new avian herpes virus. I. Biological features
abstract: virus isolated from dead owls exhibiting a syndrome called Hepato splenitis infectiosa strigum (HSIS) killed chicken embryos following vaccination by various means. Miliary necrotic foci and type A nuclear inclusion bodies were observed in the CAM and embryonic liver and spleen. Syncytia, giant cells and type A nuclear bodies appeared in chicken embryo fibroblast tissue cultures. These features, along with the biochemical and biophysical properties described in another article, allowed the HSIS virus to be classified as a herpes virus. No serological cross-reactions were observed between HSIS virus on the one hand and infectious laryngotracheitis virus, Marek virus and 5 non-avian herpes viruses on the other. The HSIS virus is therefore considered a new avian herpes virus. Herpesvirus strigis is suggested as a suitable name because owls of the order strigiformes are its natural host.
authors: Burki, F.;Burtscher, H.;Sibalin, M.

title: Bovine adenoviruses. III. Subclassification into two subgroups via immunodiffusion tests
abstract: Bovine subgroup II adenoviruses, represented by officially recognized serotypes 4 to 8, have soluble antigens that do not cross-react with either classical mastadenovirus (human or bovine subgroup I) nor aviadenovirus antigens or their respective antibodies in immunodiffusion tests. Small amounts of classical mastadenovirus group reactive antigen were previously demonstrated in bovine subgroup II adenoviruses by cross-complementary fixation. However, no bovine subgroup II-specific adenovirus antigen has been demonstrated in classical mastadenoviruses. To date, serodiagnosis of bovine adenoviral infections has been severely hampered by ignorance of these facts, leading to a massive underestimation of the frequency of such infections. We propose a third genus, paramastadenovirus, within the family Adenoviridae, including currently known and future strains that mainly contain the novel group-reactive soluble antigen shown here.
authors: Burki, F.;Hinaidy, B.;Bockmann, J.

title: Classification of 53/69 isolate as a separate equine herpes virus from equine coital exanthema
abstract: On the occasion of an outbreak of equine coital exanthema (ECE), a virus strain designated ECE 53/69 was isolated from a vaginal swab.
