It induced plaques, polykaryotic giant cells and Cowdry type A nuclear inclusion bodies in horse cell cultures. Replication of ECE 53/69 is completely inhibited by IUDR. Proven sensitive to ether, trypsin, heat and low pH. All these features and electron microscopic data described elsewhere allowed the strain to be classified as a herpes virus. It has been confirmed to be an equine herpes virus by natural and experimental infections in equines and by replication occurring only in equine cell cultures. Equine cytomegaloviruses also replicate only in equine cells. But they do this at a much slower rate and remain attached to the cell. ECE 53/69, by contrast, causes very fast cpe and is released to the tc environment at high titer. Equine rhinopneumonitis virus differs from ECE by replication in a broad spectrum of heterologous cells as well as lack of cross-neutralization, cross-complement fixation, and different clinical manifestations. ECE 53/69 is therefore a separate strain of equine herpes virus.
authors: Burki, F.;Pichler, L.;Sibalin, M.

title: Virus classification and nomenclature
authors: Burnet, S. M.

title: Inactivation of viruses by aziridines
abstract: Ethyleneimine (EI) and N-acetylethyleneimine (AEI) have been shown to inactivate viruses belonging to most of the families identified by the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy. The mechanism by which they inactivate viruses has not been established. This article describes experiments with foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) and polio virus, showing that the inactivating lesion is on RNA.
authors: Burrage, T.;Kramer, E.;Brown, F.

title: Hepatitis E Virus in Petting Farm Rabbits, Wild Rabbits and Farm Rabbits in the Netherlands
abstract: It has been suggested that rabbits are a source of zoonotic Hepatitis E virus. Phylogenetic analysis of HEV isolates (23.0% and 60%, respectively) from farmed, wild and domestic rabbits in the Netherlands showed that they were grouped among published rabbit HEV lines and differed from most human isolates. Dutch rabbits are unlikely to be a zoonotic resource.
authors: Burt, S. A.;Veltman, J.;Hakze-van der Honing, R.;Schmitt, H.;van der Poel, W. H. M.

title: Influenza A virus subtypes in wild birds in North-Eastern Spain (Catalonia)
abstract: Since the spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 in 2005, several surveillance programs have been initiated in poultry and wild birds worldwide. This study describes for the first time the detection of different subtypes of avian influenza viruses (AIV) in wild birds in the western Mediterranean region (Catalonia, North-Eastern Spain). Over a 3-year period (mid-2006 to mid-2009), 1374 birds from 16 different families were examined and a total of 62 AIVs were detected via a real-time reverse transcriptase PCR assay. AIV was detected more frequently in the families Anatidae, Phoenicopteridae, Rallidae and Laridae. Of the 62 positive samples, 28 AIVs could be isolated in embryonated eggs. All isolates were subtyped by hemagglutinin and neuraminidase inhibition techniques, and 10 different hemagglutinin (HA) and 7 neuraminidase (NA) were found in 13 different subtype combinations. The most common combinations were H4N6 (22.2%) and H1N1 (18.5%). HA and NA gene sequences of different AIV subtypes were compared and aligned with existing AIV strains obtained from genome databases. Our studies of AIV phylogenetic analysis revealed that all AIV genes sequenced from wild birds in North-Eastern Spain cluster within Eurasian avian branches, including the H8, N4 and N5 gene sequences analyzed for the first time in Europe. The results contribute to the understanding of AIV in the Mediterranean region and Europe. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Busquets, N.;Alba, A.;Napp, S.;SÃ¡nchez, A.;Serrano, E.;Rivas, R.;NÃºÃ±ez, J. I.;MajÃ³, N.

title: Studies on sialidase and esterase of influenza viruses
abstract: The main contributions of the author and collaborators on sialidase of influenza virus types A and B (EC 3.2.1.18) and O-acetylesterase of type C (EC 3.1.1.53) are summarized. After a short introduction to the subject, the author's negative results on inhibitors are interpreted. Next, the characteristics of the three procedures tested based on the determination of NADH as a measure for silaidase activity are discussed. Spectrofluorimetric measurement of NADH concentration is a more sensitive and useful procedure than spectrophotometry, although less sensitive than that based on bioluminescence. Sialidase activity is generally higher in influenza virus type A than in type B; however, some differences were found between the three subtypes A studied. Also, the thermal stability and stability to changes in pH values are higher for influenza virus from ducks, then humans and finally pigs. O-acetyletherase of influenza virus type C shows broad specificity; It is effective on compounds containing O-acetyl, which may not be sialic acid. This enzyme appears to contribute to facilitating the sialidase action of influenza virus types A and B. The characteristics of influenza virus type C suggest its inclusion as a new genus in the future classification of viruses.
authors: Cabezas, J. A.

title: Circulation of rabies virus in non-hematophagous bats in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, from 2001-2010
abstract: Introduction: Rabies is one of the most known deadly zoonoses responsible for 55,000 deaths annually. It is transmitted to humans mainly by the bite of infected domestic or wild animals. This article demonstrates the circulation of this virus in non-hematophagous bats in Rio de Janeiro City, Brazil. Methods: A survey was conducted on the number of rabies-positive bats sent for diagnosis by the Instituto Municipal de Medicina VeterinÃ¡ria Jorge Vaitsman's SeÃ§o de Virologia. Positive animals were identified and the isolated viruses were submitted for antigenic typing by indirect immunofluorescence. Results were compared with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention antigenic panel. Results: Between 2001-2010, 555 non-hematophagous bats were recruited to the laboratory for rabies diagnosis, of which 198 (35.7%) were recruited from the City of Rio de Janeiro. A total of 11 (5.5%) animals were positive for this disease. Antigenic typing revealed a predominance of variant 3 in 9 (81.8%) of the isolated viruses; 1 virus was classified as variant 4 and 1 variant separated by viruses in insectivorous bats was identified. Conclusions: Data from this study demonstrated the presence of rabies virus in synanthropic populations of non-hematophagous bats in the City of Rio de Janeiro. Circulation of this agent in these animals poses a serious risk to human and animal health and requires attention and control measures by the authorities.
authors: Cabral, C. C.;de Morais, A. C. N.;Dias, A. V. A. B.;AraÃºjo, M. G.;Moreira, W. C.;Mattos, G. L. M.

title: Molecular epidemiology of enterovirus and parecovirus infections by patient age over a 4-year period in Spain.
abstract: The epidemiology and clinical relevance and type distribution by age of enterovirus (EV) and parechovirus (HPeV) infections were determined during a 4-year study period in Spain. During 2010-2013, a total of 21,832 clinical specimens were screened for EV, with a detection frequency of 6.5% (1,430). Of the total EV-negative samples, only 1,873 samples were available for HPeV testing from 2011 to 2013. HPeV was detected in 42 (2%) of them. Positive samples were genotyped using PCR and sequencing. EV infections occurred in all patient groups: neonates (17%), children 28 days to 2 years (29%), children 2-14 years (40%), and adults (14%). Thirty-four different EV types were identified. HPeV infections were detected only in infants <8 m (70% neonate, P < 0.05). All but one HPeV were HPeV-3. Differences in type frequency determination were found according to age and clinical signs. Coxsackievirus (CV)-B4 (61%), CV-B5 (83%) and HPeV-3 (64%) were more common in newborns than in elderly patients (P < 0.05). Echovirus (E)-3 (60%), E-18 (47%), E-25 (62%), CV-A6 (61%), CV-A16 (72%), and EV-71 (75%) ) were detected mainly in children aged 28 days to 2 years (P < 0.05), whereas E-6 (79%), E-20 (88%), and E-30 (85%) were predominant in children older than 2 years. and adults (P < 0.05). Clinically, meningitis was associated with EV (P < 0.01), whereas encephalitis was more common in HPeV-infected patients. CV-B types were associated with myocarditis (90%; P < 0.05) and EV types A with hand-foot-mouth disease/atypical exanthema (88%; P < 0.05). J.Med. Viral. 89:435-442, 2017. © 2016 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
authors: Cabrerizo, M.;Diaz-Cerio, M.;Munoz-Almagro, C.;Rabella, N.;Tarrago, D.;Romero, M. P.;Pena, M. J.;Calvo, C.;Rey-Cao, S.;Moreno-Docon, A.;Martinez-Rienda, I.;Otero, A.;Trallero, G.

title: Molecular evolution of H1N1 swine flu in Guangdong, China, 2016-2017
abstract: Pigs are the main host of the H1N1 swine flu virus (SIV), but H1N1 can also infect humans and sometimes cause serious respiratory illness. We conducted an epidemic survey during 2016-2017 to monitor the evolution of SIV in Guangdong, China. Nine H1N1 influenza viruses were isolated from porcine nasal swabs. Antigenic analysis revealed that these viruses belong to two different antigenic groups represented by A/Swine/Guangdong/101/2016 and A/Swine/Guangdong/52/2017. In addition, three genotypes known as GD52/17 like, GD493/17 like and GD101/16 like were identified by phylogenetic analysis. More importantly, genotypes with internal genes from at least 4 pdm/09 origins have become widespread in China in recent years. A total of 2966 porcine serum samples were used to perform the hemagglutination inhibition (HI) tests, and the results showed that the seroprevalence values of SW/GD/101/16 were significantly higher (32.2% in 2016, 32.1% in 2017). . SW/GD/52/17 seroprevalence values (18% in 2016, 16.7% in 2017). Our study showed that three reasortant genotypes of H1N1 SIV currently circulating in China are stable, but H1N1pdm09 poses challenges for human health with the inclusion of internal genes in these reasortant genotypes. Strengthening SIV surveillance is therefore critical to SIV control and minimizing its potential threat to public health.
authors: Cai, M.;Huang, J.;Bu, D.;Yu, Z.;Fu, X.;Ji, C.;Zhou, P.;Zhang, G.

title: Genetic characterization and evolutionary analysis of 4 Newcastle disease virus isolates complete genomes from waterfowl in Southern China between 2003-2007
abstract: The complete genomes of four Newcastle disease virus (NDV) strains isolated from ducks and wild birds in Guangdong province, China between 2003 and 2007 were sequenced and analyzed in this study. Pathogenicity tests in chicken embryos and chickens indicate that D3 and R8 are lentogenic and W4 and P4 are mesogenic strains. Phylogenetic analysis using all six genes provides a high-resolution profile for genotype determination as genotype I for strains D3 and R8 and genotype VI for strains W4 and P4. In addition, molecular dating based on different genes shows that D3 and R8 diverged from their common ancestor around 1998; W4 and P4 split from their common ancestor around 1999. Subsequent selective pressure analysis showed specific features of gene evolution in all 4 strains since their divergence from the last common ancestor. Furthermore, the geographical origin of the 4 strains was concluded from Europe through two independent introduction events by phylogeographic analysis. This provides insights into the potential impact of waterfowl migration on NDV epidemiology. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Cai, S.;Li, J.;Wong, M. T.;Jiao, P.;Fan, H.;Liu, D.;Liao, M.;Jiang, J.;Shi, M.;Lam, T. T. Y.;Ren, T.;Leung, F. C. C.

title: Identification and analysis of differentially expressed microRNAs in PK-15 cells infected with Japanese encephalitis virus by deep sequencing.
abstract: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), a mosquito-borne Flavivirus, causes acute viral encephalitis with high morbidity and mortality in humans and animals. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small non-coding RNAs that are important modulators of complex host-pathogen interaction networks. However, our knowledge of changes in miRNAs in host cells after JEV infection is still limited. To understand the molecular pathogenesis of JEV at the post-transcriptional regulation level, we used Illumina deep sequencing to sequence two small RNA libraries prepared from PK-15 cells before and after JEV infection. We identified 522 and 427 miRNAs in infected and uninfected cells, respectively. Overall, 132 miRNAs were significantly differentially expressed after challenge with JEV: 78 were up-regulated and 54 down-regulated. Sequencing results for selected miRNAs were confirmed by RT-qPCR. GO analysis of host target genes revealed that these dysregulated miRNAs are involved in complex cellular pathways, including the metabolic pathway, inflammatory response, and immune response. To our knowledge, this is the first report of comparative expression of miRNAs in PK-15 cells after JEV infection. Our findings will support further studies of the roles of miRNAs in JEV replication and identify potential candidates for antiviral therapies against JEV.
authors: Cai, Y.;Zhu, L.;Zhou, Y.;Liu, X.;Liu, X.;Li, X.;Lang, Q.;Qiao, X.;Xu, Z.

title: Small but mighty: The role of tripe microbes in livestock
authors: Cammack, K. M.;Austin, K. J.;Lamberson, W. R.

title: RUMINNAT NUTRITION SYMPOSIUM: Small but mighty: Role of rumen microbes in livestock
abstract: Microbes living in the rumen convert low-quality, fibrous plant material into usable energy for the host ruminant animal. The rumen microbiome, made up of bacteria, protozoa, fungi, archaea, and viruses, forms a complex web of symbiosis essential for host ruminant care, immune function, and overall reproductive efficiency. Robert Hungate laid the foundation for rumen microbiome research. This area of research has expanded immensely with advances in methodology and technology that have not only developed the ability to describe microbes in taxonomic and density terms, but also characterize microbe populations, their functions and interactions with each other and with the host. The interaction between the rumen microbiome and the host contributes to variation in many phenotypic traits expressed by the host animal. A better understanding of how the rumen microbiome affects host health and performance could lead to new strategies and treatments for trait improvement. Furthermore, elucidating maternal, genetic, and environmental factors that influence rumen microbiome formation and development may provide new insights into possible mechanisms for manipulating rumen microbial composition to improve long-term host health and performance. The potential for these small but mighty tripe microbes to play a role in improving livestock production is appreciated, although relatively uncertain.
authors: Cammack, K. M.;Austin, K. J.;Lamberson, W. R.;Conant, G. C.;Cunningham, H. C.

title: Complete Genome Sequence of Pig Parvovirus 2 from Pig Greenhouse
abstract: A complete genomic sequence of porcine parvovirus 2 (PPV-2) was detected by viral metagenome analysis on pig serum. Phylogenetic analysis of this genome reveals that it is highly similar to previously reported North American PPV-2 genomes. The complete PPV-2 sequence is 5,426 nucleotides long.
authors: Campos, F. S.;Kluge, M.;Franco, A. C.;Giongo, A.;Valdez, F. P.;Saddi, T. M.;Brito, W. M.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Initial detection and molecular characterization of Nebovirus in Brazil
abstract: Nebovirus is a new virus genus of the Caliciviridae family that has recently been characterized in cattle and is associated with gastrointestinal disorders such as diarrhea, anorexia, and intestinal lesions, particularly in calves. The aim of this study is to investigate the prevalence of neboviruses in Brazilian cattle and to analyze the detected virus strains phylogenetically. A prevalence of 4Â·8% of neboviruses was detected in stool samples from 62 cattle from different states of Brazil. All positive animals were <20 days old and had diarrhea. Phylogenetic analysis grouped the virus sequences in the Newbury1 clade. In this study, there was >96%Â·% nt (100% aa) sequence identity between virus sequences and >88%Â·8 nt (>94Â·4% aa) identity with Newbury1/UK. Our results show for the first time that neboviruses originated in Brazil and South America, and the first Newbury1-like nebovirus found outside the UK.
authors: Candido, M.;Alencar, A. L. F.;Almeida-Queiroz, S. R.;Buzinaro, M. G.;Munin, F. S.;Godoy, S. H. S.;Livonesi, M. C.;Fernandes, A. M.;Sousa, R. L. M.

title: Lambda display phage as a mucosal vaccine delivery vehicle for peptide antigens
abstract: The bacteriophage is structurally stable in the gastrointestinal tract and has favorable safety, stability, ease of manufacture, and immunogenicity properties. These properties make them potential candidates as vehicles for oral vaccine delivery, but little is known about their capacity to induce mucosal immune responses in the small intestine. Whole-body imaging validated lambda bacteriophage (LP) of mice was distributed throughout the gastrointestinal tract 24 hours after oral delivery. In newborn calves, targeted delivery of confirmed LP to the small intestine was immunogenic in a dose-dependent manner and was uptake by Peyer's patches. LP-specific IgA responses were induced in both Peyer patches and draining mesenteric lymph nodes. A lambda display phage (LDP) was constructed to present three immunogenic disease-specific epitopes (DSE) from the cervid prion protein (amino acids 130-140 [YML]; 163-170 [YRR] and 171-178[YRR]). phage capsid head protein D (LDP-DSE). Targeted delivery of purified LDP-DSE to intestinal segments induced IgA responses to all three peptide epitopes. Moreover, administration of bacteria expressing soluble D-DSE also induced epitope-specific IgA responses within targeted Peyer patches. These are the first studies to report the use of LDP to induce epitope-specific IgA responses in the small intestine and to confirm the function of Peyer's patches as a site for LP recruitment. Also, IgA responses to peptide epitopes on LDP were observed in the absence of a mucosal adjuvant. These observations confirm that LDP has the capacity to function as a mucosal delivery vehicle with protein D as an effective carrier for peptide epitopes. (C) 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Cano, P. G.;Gamage, L. N. A.;Marciniuk, K.;Hayes, C.;Napper, S.;Hayes, S.;Griebel, P. J.

title: Two novel parvoviruses in fruiting new and old world bats
abstract: Bats, a globally distributed group of mammals of high ecological importance, are increasingly recognized as natural reservoir hosts for viral agents important to human and animal health. In this study, we evaluated pools of blood samples from two phylogenetically distant bat families, specifically flying foxes (Pteropodidae), West African Eidolon helvum, and two New World leaf-nosed fruit bat species (Phyllostomidae). Artibeus jamaicensis and Artibeus lituratus in Central America. An array-independent virus discovery technique (VIDISCA) combined with high-throughput sequencing was used to detect two novel parvoviruses: a PARV4-like virus named Eh-BtPV-1 in Eidolon helvum from Ghana and the first member of a putative new genus in Turkey. Artibeus jamaicensis (Aj-BtPV-1) from Panama. These viruses were circulating in 7-8% of the corresponding bat colony. Aj-BtPV-1 was also found in Artibeus lituratus (5.5%). Both viruses were detected in high concentrations in the blood of infected animals: up to 10E8 and 10E10 copies/ml for Aj-BtPV-1 and Eh-BtPV-1, respectively. Eh-BtPV-1 was also detected in all organs (brain, lungs, liver, spleen, kidneys, and intestine) collected from bats, and the spleen and kidneys were identified as the most likely sites for viral replication to occur. Our study shows that bat parvoviruses share common ancestors with known human and livestock parvoviruses. We also provide evidence that a variety of Parvovirinae can cause active infection in bats and that they are widely distributed in these animals of different geographic origins, ecology and climatic ranges. Â© 2011 Canuti et al.
authors: Canuti, M.;Eis-Huebinger, A. M.;Deijs, M.;de Vries, M.;Drexler, J. F.;Oppong, S. K.;MÃ¼ller, M. A.;Klose, S. M.;Wellinghausen, N.;Cottontail, V. M.;Kalko, E. K. V.;Drosten, C.;van der Hoek, L.

title: Swine flu epidemic in Argentina revealed a non-contemporary human H3N2 virus that is highly contagious among pigs
abstract: Sporadic outbreaks of human H3N2 influenza A virus (IAV) infections in swine populations have been reported since 1970 in Asia, Europe, and North America. Serological studies in pigs in South America indicate that IAVs of the H3 and H1 subtypes are currently in circulation; however, neither virus isolation nor characterization has been reported. In November 2008, an outbreak of respiratory disease consistent with swine flu virus (SIV) infection in pigs was detected in Argentina. The present study describes the clinical epidemiology, pathology, and molecular and biological features of the virus. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the virus isolated 96-98% common nucleotide identities with H3N2 IAVs circulating in humans from 2000 to 2003. Antigenically, sera from experimentally vaccinated animals cross-reacted mainly with H3N2 influenza viruses of non-contemporary human origin. In an experimental infection in a commercial pig breed, the virus had low virulence but effectively transmitted to pigs in contact, causing severe disease when an infected animal contracted a secondary bacterial infection. This is the first report of fully human H3N2 IAV associated with clinical disease in pigs from South America. These studies highlight the importance of bidirectional transmission of IAVs and SIVs between pigs and humans and call for improved surveillance of influenza in the pig population worldwide. © 2011 SGM.
authors: Cappuccio, J. A.;Pena, L.;DibÃ¡rbora, M.;Rimondi, A.;PiÃ±eyro, P.;Insarralde, L.;Quiroga, M. A.;Machuca, M.;Craig, M. I.;Olivera, V.;Chockalingam, A.;Perfumo, C. J.;Perez, D. R.;Pereda, A.

title: Newcastle disease outbreaks in Italy in 2000
abstract: Among the consequences of the highly pathogenic avian flu epidemic that affected Italy between 1999 and 2000 was an outbreak of Newcastle disease in northern and central Italy. It affected industrially raised poultry, dealer flocks and backyard flocks, with a total of 254 outbreaks reported up to 31 December 2000. Virological studies have yielded virulent isolates of Newcastle disease virus producing intracerebral pathogenicity indices ranging from 1-6 to 2-0. and which can be classified as belonging to group C1 according to their monoclonal antibody binding patterns. Clinical, gross, and microscopic findings were specific to Newcastle disease, and different bird species were susceptible to varying degrees. Chickens and guinea fowl emerged as the most susceptible, followed by pheasants, turkeys and ostriches. The epidemiological research highlighted the important role of the broiler hatchery in initiating the epidemic and the dealers in sustaining the epidemic. Control measures imposed by Directive 92/66/EEC are discussed with reference to outbreaks in backyard flocks.
authors: Capua, I.;Dalla Pozza, M.;Mutinelli, F.;Marangon, S.;Terregino, C.

title: Isolation of an avian paramyxovirus type 9 from migratory waterfowl in Italy [3]
authors: Capua, I.;De Nardi, R.;Beato, M. S.;Terregino, C.;Scremin, M.;Guberti, V.

title: Neurovirulence of pseudorabies virus
abstract: Virulence is defined as the relative capacity of a microorganism to overcome the defense mechanisms of the host organism and thereby cause disease. Virally induced virulence is usually measured by measuring the mean time to death or appearance of symptoms following viral vaccination. In this review, we make a distinction between general virulence and neurovirulence. We define neurovirulence as the degree of pathogenesis in the nervous system, but we intend it to be more extensive than the ability of the virus to grow in the central nervous system (CNS). This distinction is made possible by recent advances that allow an integrated assessment of the degree of pathology, reactive gliosis, and inflammatory response to infection in the intact organism with specific antisera and molecular probes.
authors: Card, J. P.;Enquist, L. W.

title: Deadly Outbreak in Tonkean Macaques, Possibly Caused by Novel Orthopox Virus, Italy, January 2015 <sup>1</sup>
abstract: In January 2015, 12 Tonkean macaques died in a shelter in Italy over a 3-week period. An orthopoxvirus infection was suspected due to negative staining electron microscopy results. Diagnosis was confirmed by histology, virus isolation and molecular analysis performed in different organs from all animals. An epidemiological study was unable to identify the source of infection in the environment. Trapped rodents were negative by virological testing, but specific IgG was detected in 27.27% of small rodents and 14.28% of rats. The susceptible monkey population received attenuated live vaccine and no adverse reactions were observed; a detectable humoral immune response was induced in most vaccinated animals. We performed molecular characterization of orthopoxvirus isolate by next generation sequencing. According to a phylogenetic analysis of 9 conserved genes, the virus may be part of a new clade stretching between cowpox and ecromelia viruses.
authors: Cardeti, G.;Gruber, C. E. M.;Eleni, C.;Carletti, F.;Castilletti, C.;Manna, G.;Rosone, F.;Giombini, E.;Selleri, M.;Lapa, D.;Puro, V.;Di Caro, A.;Lorenzetti, R.;Scicluna, M. T.;Grifoni, G.;Rizzoli, A.;Tagliapietra, V.;De Marco, L.;Capobianchi, M. R.;Autorino, G. L.

title: Virological and phylogenetic characterization of attenuated small ruminant lentivirus isolates escaping effective serological detection.
abstract: Three field isolates of small ruminant lentiviruses (SRLVs) were derived from a mixed herd of goats and sheep that had been certified free of goat arthritis encephalitis virus (CAEV) for many years. Phylogenetic analysis of pol sequences allowed to classify these isolates as subtype A4. None of the animals showed clinical signs of SRLV infection, confirming previous observations suggesting that this particular subtype is highly attenuated, at least for goats. A quantitative real-time PCR strategy based on primers and probes derived from a highly variable env region allowed us to classify animals as uninfected, single or double infected. The performance of different serological instruments based on this classification revealed their profound inability to monitor animals infected with this particular SRLV subtype. In vitro, the isolates showed differences in their cytopathicity and tended to replicate more efficiently in goat, particularly goat macrophages, than in sheep cells. In contrast, in vivo, these viruses achieved significantly higher viral loads in sheep than in goats. Both env subtypes infected goats and sheep with equal yield. But one of them achieved significantly higher viral loads in both species. In conclusion, we characterized three isolates of SRLV subtype A4 that circulated efficiently in a mixed herd of goats and sheep despite their marked attenuation and a strict physical separation between goats and sheep. The poor performance of applied serological tools indicates that it is imperative to develop new, subtype-specific tools to support an SRLV eradication campaign. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Cardinaux, L.;Zahno, M. L.;Deubelbeiss, M.;Zanoni, R.;Vogt, H. R.;Bertoni, G.

title: Pseudocowpox outbreak in fattening calves in southern Brazil
abstract: Pseudokowpox virus is a parapoxvirus often associated with papulovesicular and scabies lesions in the udders and udders of milking cows and is frequently transmitted to humans. Describes an unusual skin disease outbreak in fattening calves in southern Brazil. Of 17 male cattle aged 6-48 months fed on pastures, 14 (82%) were affected. The animals developed papules, vesicles, and scabies proliferative lesions on the muzzle with a clinical course of approximately 10-15 days. Scabies lesions often present with exudation and bleeding. Histological examination of mucocutaneous tissue in the detached crusts revealed acanthosis with thickening of the corneal layer and early keratinization (parakeratotic hyperkeratosis). There were multifocal lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates in the dermis. Electron microscopic examination of the shell samples revealed typical parapoxvirus particles: oval-shaped (260 nm × 160 nm), enveloped and covered with a helical layer. Polymerase chain reaction using a set of pan-parapoxvirus primers for the B2L gene amplified a 590-bp product from DNA extracted from the shells. The nucleotide sequence of amplicons revealed a 97% nucleotide homology with Pseudocowpox virus and lower homology with other parapoxviruses: Bovine papular stomatitis virus (84%) and Orf virus (94%). A phylogenetic tree was constructed based on the B2L sequence, showing that the virus clustered with Pseudocowpox virus isolates. Â© 2012 American Association of Veterinary Laboratory Diagnostic Specialists.
authors: Cargnelutti, J. F.;Flores, M. M.;Teixeira, F. R. M.;Weiblen, R.;Flores, E. F.

title: Diagnosis and Control of LPAI H5N8 Outbreak in a Commercial Flock of Japanese Quail (Coturnix coturnix japonica) in the Central Valley of California
abstract: In April 2014, an outbreak of the low pathogenic avian influenza H5N8 North American genetic strain was diagnosed in a commercial quail operation in Stanislaus County, California. The spike in mortality resulted in 20 Japanese quail chickens (Coturnix c. japonica) being sent to the California Animal Health and Food Safety Laboratory, Turlock Branch. Oropharyngeal and cloacal swabs tested positive for influenza A virus H5N8 by real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction. The virus was later isolated. In vivo assay and sequencing of the protein cleavage site of hemagglutinin classified the virus as a North American genetic strain with low pathogenicity for chickens. Following the diagnosis, a rapid and coordinated response took place to contain the outbreak. The affected building was evacuated, cleaned and disinfected. For commercial bird flu testing, three areas - a 3 kilometer (km) radius (High Risk Area), a 3-10 km area (Buffer Zone) and a 10-20 km (Surveillance Area) - were created from the affected building. and non-commercial poultry operations. Surveillance tests and rapid control measures were successful in controlling and eradicating the epidemic, and the spread of the virus from the index swarm was not revealed. This report describes the history, diagnosis, surveillance and control measures implemented to manage this outbreak.
authors: Carnaccini, S.;Crossley, B.;Breitmeyer, R.;Charlton, B. R.;Bland, M.;Fowler, K.;De La Torre, F.;Torchetti, M. K.;Wong, S. S.;Wilson, D.;Jones, A.;SentÃ­es-CuÃ©, C. G.

title: High-throughput sequencing and comparative genomics of the foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: Despite a basic understanding of many aspects of FMD biology, much information regarding FMDV virulence, host range, and virus transmission is poorly understood. Here, we present how the use of high-throughput sequencing for whole-genome sequences of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) has led to a number of new insights, including viral genome sequence conservation and variability, genetic diversity in nature, and phylogenetic classification of isolates. First complete sequences of South African Territories type 1 and 3 (SAT1 and SAT3) genomes. Comparative genomic analysis of full-length sequences of FMDV isolates enabled: (i) identification of novel viral genomic motifs of possible biological relevance, as well as highly conserved regulatory or coding regions critical to aspects of virus biology; (ii) characterization of the first complete sequences of the SAT1 and SAT3 genomes; (iii) identification of a new strain of SAT virus genetically distinct from other SAT and Euro-Asian strains; (iv) precise identification of worldwide circulating strains for epidemiological and forensic attribution; (v) consideration of mutation and recombination processes as mechanisms equally involved in evolution; (vi) mutation rates, tolerance, and constraints of genes and proteins during the evolution of FMD viruses during in vivo replication; and (vi) support for a new evolutionary model hypothesis.
authors: Carrillo, C.;Tulman, E. R.;Delhon, G.;Lu, Z.;Carreno, A.;Vagnozzi, A.;Kutish, G. F.;Rock, D. L.

title: global virome project
authors: Carroll, D.;Daszak, P.;Wolfe, N. D.;Gao, G. F.

title: Tracing Jenner's vaccine: Revisiting the Cowpox virus classification
abstract: Cowpox virus (CPXV) is identified as the source of the first vaccine used to prevent the onset and spread of an infectious disease. It is one of the earliest identified members of the genus Orthopoxvirus, which includes viruses that cause human smallpox and monkeypox. Both historical and current literature define "cattle pox" as a disease with a single etiological agent. The genotypic data presented here suggest that CPXV is not a single species, but a combination of several (up to 5) species capable of infecting cows, humans, and other animals. The practice of naming agents after the host from which the resulting disease arises obscures the true taxonomic relationships of "cattlepox" isolates. These data support the rise of as many as four new strains within the traditional "cattlepox" group and suggest that both wild and modern vaccine strains of Vaccinia virus are most closely related to CPXV in continental Europe rather than its homeland of the United Kingdom. vaccine.
authors: Carroll, D. S.;Emerson, G. L.;Li, Y.;Sammons, S.;Olson, V.;Frace, M.;Nakazawa, Y.;Czerny, C. P.;Tryland, M.;Kolodziejek, J.;Nowotny, N.;Olsen-Rasmussen, M.;Khristova, M.;Govil, D.;Karem, K.;Damon, I. K.;Meyer, H.

title: Vaccinia and other viruses with vaccines available show a marked similarity to the HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein: the possibility of using existing vaccines to stop the AIDS pandemic
abstract: Cross-reactive immunity occurs when infection or vaccination with a virus provides protection against another related family member. A search for homologues of the HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein revealed that it consists of thousands of intercalated and overlapping viral pairings, or longer-range consensus, of the pentapeptide, belonging to more than 70% of the currently sequenced virome, infecting all kingdoms from bacteria to humans. Other proteins (nef/tat/gag/pol) were similar to proteins from equine infectious anemia virus and HTLV-2/HTLV-3 viruses, while also highly homologous to proteins from Visna/Maedi and other ovine viruses. This phenomenon suggests that horizontal gene transfer from co-infecting RNA and DNA viruses to retroviruses is extensive and provides a pathway for subsequent insertion of non-retroviral genes into human and other genomes via retroviral integration. This homology includes all viruses whose vaccines are currently available. Cross-reactive immunity may be effective in AIDS, as the Vaccinia vaccine for the tropic form of CCR5 reduces viral replication in cells of HIV-1 infected patients. Measles, Dengue virus, or GB virus C infections also reduce HIV-1 viral load. Vaccinia/smallpox vaccine reintroduction can be expected to have a significant impact on the AIDS pandemic, and careful examination of potential uses of other available viral and bacterial vaccines deserves close attention. This phenomenon may also apply to other persistent viruses, bacteria and parasites for which there is no vaccine, and the arsenal of current vaccines may play a role in diseases other than those for which they were designed. Â© 2012 Informa Healthcare USA, Inc.
authors: Carter, C. J. C.

title: Hepatitis E Virus: A Cross-sectional Serological and Virological Study in Pigs and Humans at Zoonotic Risk in the Field of High-Density Pig Breeding
abstract: An increase in autochthonous hepatitis E virus (HEV) infections has been noted in Italy, which is suspected of being zoonotically transmitted from pigs; This study was conducted to determine the seroprevalence and risk factors associated with hepatitis HEV exposure in both pigs and humans working on pig farms located in a high-density pig farming area in the Piedmont region of northwest Italy. The presence of viral RNA in human and pig samples was also evaluated and phylogenetic analysis was performed on HEV positive samples. Forty-two pig farms were sampled; 142 workers were recruited and divided into two groups: (i) 69 workers who had occupational contact with pigs on 42 sample farms (including veterinarians and farmers); (ii) without occupational contact with 73 pigs. Of the 42 swine farms, 41 (97%) tested positive for the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for HEV antibodies (Abs). The overall seroprevalence in pigs was 50% (441/879), and the seropositivity rate was higher in pigs (333/469, 71%). In stool samples, HEV RNA was detected in animals on 13 (31%) of the 42 farms tested, resulting in a higher positivity in weaning (40/246, 16.3%). Phylogenetic analysis classified all HEV isolates into genotype 3 (subtypes 3f, 3e, 3c). All humans were negative for the HEV viral genome in the blood. Five of the 142 sera were positive for IgG anti-HEV, with an overall prevalence of 3.52%, and there was no statistically significant difference in prevalence rates between workers at zoonotic risk and the control group (5.7% vs. 1.3%). In contrast, a significant difference (OR 10.1) was observed within the subgroup, suggesting a correlation between duration of exposure and the probability of HEV infection, compared with short-term subjects (veterinarians) and long-term workers (farmers). Notification of HEV infection is not mandatory in Italy, but continuous epidemiological surveillance should be provided to clarify the epidemiology of this disease.
authors: Caruso, C.;Peletto, S.;Rosamilia, A.;Modesto, P.;Chiavacci, L.;Sona, B.;Balsamelli, F.;Ghisetti, V.;Acutis, P. L.;Pezzoni, G.;Brocchi, E.;Vitale, N.;Masoero, L.

title: Bovine papillomavirus in Brazil: detection of coinfection of unusual types by a PCR-RFLP method
abstract: Bovine papillomavirus (BPV) is recognized as a causative agent of benign and malignant tumors in cattle. Thirteen types of BPV are currently characterized and classified into three different genera associated with different pathological outcomes. The described BPV strains and other putative ones have been demonstrated by molecular biology methods, in particular using degenerated PCR primers. Specifically, differences in the nucleotide sequence of the L1 gene are useful for the identification and classification of new papillomavirus types. In the current study, a method based on the PCR-RFLP technique and DNA sequencing was evaluated as a screening tool and allowed the detection of two chronically relatively rare types of BPV in lesion samples from a six-year-old Holstein dairy cow. affected by cutaneous papillomatosis. These findings point to the spread of BPVs of uncertain pathogenic potential, as two relatively rare, newly identified types of BPV, first characterized in Japan, were also detected in Brazil. Â© 2013 RF Carvalho et al.
authors: Carvalho, R. F.;Sakata, S. T.;Giovanni, D. N. S.;Mori, E.;BrandÃ£o, P. E.;Richtzenhain, L. J.;Pozzi, C. R.;Arcaro, J. R. P.;Miranda, M. S.;Mazzuchelli-De-Souza, J.;Melo, T. C.;Comenale, G.;Assaf, S. L. M. R.;BeÃ§ak, W.;Stocco, R. C.

title: Two novel circo-like viruses detected in human feces: whole genome sequencing and electron microscopy analysis
abstract: Application of viral metagenomic techniques and a series of PCRs in a human stool sample enabled the detection of two novel circular unise DNA viral genomes with 92% nucleotide identity. The viruses have been tentatively named the approximately similar virus-Brazilian (CLV-BR) strains hs1 and hs2 and have genome lengths of 2526 and 2533 nucleotides, respectively. Four major open reading frames (ORFs) were identified in each of the genomes, and differences between the two genomes were primarily observed in ORF 2. low identity (36%). Our phylogenetic analysis based on the rep protein showed that CLV-BRs do not cluster with members of the Circoviridae, Nanoviridae, or Geminiviridae families, and are more closely related to circo-like genomes previously identified in reclaimed water and a wild rodent excrement. and a bat. CLV-BRs are members of a putative new family of circular Rep-encoding ssDNA viruses. Electron microscopy revealed icosahedral (similar to 23 nm) structures and rod-shaped viral particles (similar to 65-460 × 21 × 10 nm in length, diameter, and axial channel, respectively), possibly reflecting novel viruses. Circus-like viruses have been detected in stool samples from humans and other mammals (bats, rodents, chimpanzees, and cattle), cerebrospinal fluid and serum from humans, as well as in samples from many other sources, such as insects, meat, and the environment. Further studies are needed to classify all new circular DNA viruses and to elucidate their hosts, pathogenicity and evolutionary history. (C) 2013 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Castrignano, S. B.;Nagasse-Sugahara, T. K.;Kisielius, J. J.;Ueda-Ito, M.;Brandao, P. E.;Curti, S. P.

title: Research by PCR N22 Region in Tork Tenovirus (TTV) and Chicken Plasma (Gallus gallus domesticus) in Serum and Total Blood of Brazilian Non-Human Primates
abstract: Torque teno virus (TTV) is a recently discovered DNA virus originally isolated from a Japanese patient (initials, TT) with post-transfusion hepatitis of unknown etiology. TTV is a circular DNA virus that has recently been classified, together with the related Torque teno minivirus, into a new genus called Anellovirus. Infection TTV has been detected in a number of non-human primates as well as domestic animals. The aim of this study was to search for TTV in serum and total blood of Brazilian monkeys and plasma of domestic chickens by seminested PCR of the coding region (N22), followed by a genomic sequence and phylogenetic analysis. No serum samples were amplified. TTV DNA was detected in total blood in 3 (4%) of 75 brown capuchins (Cebus apella) and 1 (25%) of 4 golden-headed lion tamarinds (Leontopithecus chrysomelas). Phylogenetic analysis revealed that one sample showed similarities with a sequence of cotton upper tamarin (Saguinus oedipus) (So-TTV2) and douroucoulis (Aotes trivirgatus) (At-TTV3). The two samples were similar to a human Torque Teno Mini Virus (TLMV). The other sample clustered with a chimpanzee strain (Pt-TTV6) and human TTV strain TA278. All of the plasma chicken samples tested were negative. The amino acid sequences reported in this study are the first amino acid sequences obtained from the total blood of non-human primates naturally infected with TTV in Brazil.
authors: Catroxo, M. H. B.;Nishiya, A.;Sabino, E.;Teixeira, P. S.;Petrella, S.;Milanelo, L.;Vieira, J. C. F.;Diaz, R. S.

title: Human hepatitis E virus circulation in Bulgaria: Deep Bayesian phylogenetic analysis for viral spread control in the country.
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection in Bulgaria is endemic as indicated by the seroprevalence of antibody to the virus in the general population and the high prevalence of registered clinical cases. In this study, a deep Bayesian phylogenetic analysis was performed to provide information on the genetic diversity and distribution of HEV genotypes in Bulgaria. Three different datasets of HEV virus were created for genotyping with maximum likelihood method, evolutionary rate estimated by Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo approach, demographic history research and selective pressure analysis. The evolution rate for genotype 3e was 351 × 10aˆ'3 substitutions/place/year (95% peak posterior density [95% HPD]: 145 × 10 âˆ'3-575 × 10 âˆ'3). The root of the time to the last common ancestor of the Bayesian maximum clade confidence tree of the HEV 3e genotype corresponded to 1965 (HPD 95% 1949-1994). Bulgar sequences are mainly clustered in the main branch (wing A). The monophyletic branch contained all Bulgarian genotype 3e sequences. The demographic history showed slight growth from 1995 to 2000, followed by some kind of bottleneck in the 2010s, a peak in 2011, and new growth through 2015. Selection pressure analysis did not show sites under positive pressure, but showed 64 statistically significant sites under negative selection. . Molecular epidemiological surveillance by the Bayesian phylogeny of HEV virus may contribute to tracing the pathway of human infection after direct contact with pork source or improving public health control after meat is heated.
authors: Cella, E.;Golkocheva-Markova, E.;Sagnelli, C.;Scolamacchia, V.;Bruni, R.;Villano, U.;Ciccaglione, A. R.;Equestre, M.;Sagnelli, E.;Angeletti, S.;Ciccozzi, M.

title: First report of Cowpea mild mottle virus in Chia (Salvia hispanica)
abstract: Chia (Salvia hispanica), a herbaceous plant of the Lamiaceae family, has gained popularity due to its high concentrations of health-promoting Omega-3 fatty acids. Plants with different virus-like symptoms were observed in major chia producing areas in Argentina. Some plants exhibited yellowing, variegated and blistered leaves, while others exhibited shortened internodes and leaf and stem deformation. The aim of this study was to identify the viruses that infect this crop. Forty symptomatic chia plants were collected from nine production sites in northeastern Argentina. Samples were tested by DAS-ELISA for Alfalfa mosaic virus (AMV), Cowpea mild mottle virus (CPMMV), Cucumber mosaic virus (CMV), Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV) and Tospovirus group (I, II and III). by PTA-ELISA for genus Potyvirus and by PCR for Begomovirus. CPMMV was detected in three plants with different types of symptoms. In these plants, feather-like inclusions formed by virions were observed by transmission electron microscopy. ORF2 to ORF6 (2462 nucleotides) from the CPMMV viral genome was amplified by RT-PCR. The nucleotide (nt) sequence of the coat protein gene (CP - ORF5) of the Chia virus isolate was obtained and compared to the 31 CPMMV sequence reported in GenBank. The results showed that nt identity ranged from 75.5 to 99.0% above the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy criteria for Carlavirus species differentiation. Phylogenetic analysis with CP gene nt sequences revealed that the CPMMV chia isolate grouped with other CPMMV isolates from Brazil, Ghana, India, Puerto Rico, Taiwan and other plant species in the USA, but separated from the other four individuals from India. This is the world's first report of the presence of CPMMV in chia. Although other viruses were not detected in this study, because CPMMV is found in chia plants with different symptoms, it is possible that the different symptoms observed were produced by a mixture of viruses. (C) 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Celli, M. G.;Perotto, M. C.;Merino, M. C.;Nome, C. F. D.;Flores, C. R.;Conci, V. C.

title: Taxon sequencing in phylogenetic trees through evolutionary algorithms
abstract: BACKGROUND: In a typical "left to right" phylogenetic tree, the vertical order of taxa is meaningless because only the branch path between them reflects their degree of similarity. To make unresolved trees more informative, we propose here an innovative Evolutionary Algorithm (EA) method to search for the best graphic representation of unresolved trees to give biological meaning to the vertical arrangement of taxa. METHODS: Starting from a West Nile virus phylogenetic tree, in a (1+1)-EA, we developed it by randomly rotating the internal nodes and selecting the tree with better fit at each generation. The fitness is the sum of the genetic distances between the considered taxon and the next taxon r (radius). After adjusting the radius for best performance, we developed the trees with (lambda + mu)-EAs to examine the effect of population on the algorithm. RESULTS: (1+1)-EA consistently outperformed a random search and better results were obtained by setting the radius to 8. (lambda + mu)-EAs performed as well as (1+1) except for the larger population. (1000 + 1000). RESULTS: Trees after evolution showed an improvement in both fitness (based on genetic distance matrix, then close taxa are actually genetically close) and biological interpretation. Samples collected in the same state or year converged, making the tree easier to interpret. Biological relationships between samples are also easier to observe.
authors: Cerutti, F.;Bertolotti, L.;Goldberg, T. L.;Giacobini, M.

title: Phylogenetic characterization of classic swine fever viruses isolated in Korea between 1988 and 2003.
abstract: Twenty-four classical swine fever (CSF) virus isolates from CSF outbreaks in the Republic of Korea in 1988 and 2003 were genetically characterized for the partial E2 gene (190 nucleotides) and compared with CSF viruses reported by other countries. Phylogenetic analyzes classified Korean field isolates into subgroup 3.2 between 1988 and 1999, forming an independent division from CSF viruses identified in other countries. In contrast, viruses isolated during the 2002-2003 CSF outbreaks were classified in a different subgroup (2.1). 2.1 viruses showed a close genetic association (92.1-100% nucleotide similarity) with CSF viruses reported from China and Taiwan in 1998-2001. As no evidence of CSF virus infection was detected in the Korean boar (Sus scrofa coreanus) population, molecular characterization results strongly suggest that the CSF epidemic outbreaks in Korean pig populations between 2002 and 2003 are attributed to the introduction of a new virus. possibly the strain or strains from neighboring countries. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Cha, S. H.;Choi, E. J.;Park, J. H.;Yoon, S. R.;Kwon, J. H.;Yoon, K. J.;Song, J. Y.

title: Molecular characterization of bovine transient fever virus in Thailand between 2013 and 2017.
abstract: Bovine ephemeral fever (BEF), in the negative sense, is an arthropod-borne disease caused by the bovine ephemeral fever virus (BEFV), a single-stranded RNA virus. BEFV is endemic in tropical and subtropical regions, including Thailand, a country in mainland Southeast Asia. However, there are few studies on BEFV in Thailand and no information is available on the molecular properties of BEFV. Therefore, the aim of this study was to genetically characterize Thai BEFVs and reveal their evolution by phylogenetic analysis of G gene ectodomain sequences. From 2013 to 2017, blood samples were collected from cattle matching the BEF case definition from three regions of Thailand. Thai BEFV G genes and the whole genome of one isolate were sequenced and characterized East Asia/TH/LRI0045/2016. In addition, their phylogeny was established. This is the first report on the genetics of BEFV in Southeast Asia. The G ectodomain coding region of Thai BEFV found in 2013-2017 is closely related to the second and third subclades of the East Asian lineage. In addition, we observed mutations in the putative P'ORF of all Thai BEFVs that formed an early stop codon. Thai G gene sequences are closely related to sequences from mainland Chinese and Taiwanese isolates. All genomic sequences of Thai BEFV and East Asian/Chinese/JT02 L/2002 share features suggesting a common evolutionary relationship between East and Southeast Asian strains. Further research on the relationship between animal translocation, BEFV circulation in the Greater Mekong subregion, and acquisition of more G gene sequences could improve understanding of BEFV epidemiology in mainland Southeast Asia.
authors: Chaisirirat, T.;Sangthong, P.;Arunvipas, P.;Petcharat, N.;Thangthamniyom, N.;Chumsing, W.;Lekcharoensuk, P.

title: Metagenomic analysis of antibiotic resistance genes in dairy cow feces following therapeutic administration of third generation cephalosporin.
abstract: Although dairy manure is widely applied to the field, it is relatively less studied compared to other farm animals as a potential source of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) to the environment and ultimately to human pathogens. Ceftiofur, the most widely used antibiotic in US dairy cows, is a 3rd generation cephalosporin, a class of antibiotics critical to human health. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of typical ceftiofur antibiotic treatment on the prevalence of ARGs in the fecal microbiome of dairy cows using a metagenomic approach. Î²-lactam ARGs were found to be elevated in the faeces of Holstein cows (n = 3) treated with ceftiofur compared to control cows (n = 3). However, the total number of ARGs in all classes was not measurably affected by ceftiofur treatment, possibly due to the predominance of unaffected tetracycline ARGs in their metagenomic libraries. Functional analysis via MG-RAST further revealed that ceftiofur treatment resulted in increases in gene sequences associated with "phages, prophages, transposable elements and plasmids", revealing that this treatment also enriched the ability to transfer ARGs horizontally. Measurable taxonomic shifts (increase) were noted with ceftiofur treatment, along with additional functional shifts (for example, increase in genes associated with stress, chemotaxis, and resistance to toxic compounds; metabolism of aromatic compounds and decrease in cell division and cell cycle-related genes). reduction in Bacterioidia and Actinobacteria). This study demonstrates that ceftiofur has a broad, measurable and immediate effect on the cow fecal metagenome. Given the importance of 3rd generation cephalospirins in human medicine, their continued use in dairy cattle should be carefully considered, and waste treatment strategies should be explored to slow the spread of ARG from dairy cattle manure. Copyright:
authors: Chambers, L.;Yang, Y.;Littier, H.;Ray, P.;Zhang, T.;Pruden, A.;Strickland, M.;Knowlton, K.

title: Interspecies transmission from birds and emergence of new viruses
abstract: Birds, the only living members of the dinosaur lineage, are warm-blooded vertebrates that display high species biodiversity, perching and migratory behavior, and a unique adaptive immune system. Birds provide natural reservoirs for numerous viral species and thus provide a source of genes for the evolution, emergence and spread of new viruses. Human entry into the natural habitats of wild birds, domestication of wild birds as pets or racing birds, and increased poultry consumption by humans have made it easier for avian viruses to cross species barriers to cause zoonosis. Recently, a new adenovirus was found only in birds, causing an outbreak of Chlamydophila psittaci infection among birds and humans. Rather than jumping directly from bird to human and becoming the primary cause of an epidemic, a new avian virus may be the potentiator of another epidemic-causing zoonotic agent. A comprehensive avian virome will improve our understanding of the evolutionary dynamics of birds.
authors: Chan, J. F. W.;To, K. K. W.;Chen, H.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: Identification and phylogenetic analysis of orf virus from goats in Taiwan
abstract: An outbreak of infectious ecthyma in goats in central Taiwan was investigated. The disease was diagnosed by physical and histopathological examinations, and the etiology of the disease was determined by electron microscopy and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) as the sequence of orf virus and major envelope protein (B2L) gene. The entire protein-coding region of the B2L gene was cloned and sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis of the B2L amino acid sequences showed that the orf virus identified in this outbreak was more closely related to the Indian ORFV-Mukteswar 59/05 isolate. This is the first report on the molecular characterization of orf virus in Taiwan. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Chan, K. W.;Lin, J. W.;Lee, S. H.;Liao, C. J.;Tsai, M. C.;Hsu, W. L.;Wong, M. L.;Shih, H. C.

title: Analysis of the genomic sequences of 95 papillomavirus types: combining typing, phylogeny and taxonomy
abstract: Our aim was to examine the phylogenetic relationships of all known papillomaviruses (PVs) and the possibility of constructing a supratype taxonomic classification based on this information. Of the many detectable homologous segments found in PV genomes, a 291-bp segment of the L1 gene is notable because it is surrounded by the MY09 and MY11 consensus primers and contains highly conserved amino acid residues that simplify sequence alignment. We determined the sequences of human PV type 20 (HPV-20), HPV-21, HPV-22, HPV-23, HPV-24, HPV-36, HPV-37, HPV-38, HPV-48, MY09-MY11, HPV- 50, HPV-60, HPV-70, HPV-72, HPV-73, ovine (sheep) PV, bovine PV type 3 (BPV-3), BPV-5 and BPV-6 and now a database has been created. It covers HPV-1 to HPV-70, HPV-72, HPV-73, seven HPV genomes yet to be typed, and 15 animal PV types. Three additional animal PVs were analyzed based on other sequence data. We constructed phylogenies based on partial L1 and E6 gene sequences and distinguished five major divisions, which we call supergroups. One of them combines 54 types of genital PV, which can be divided into eleven groups. The second supergroup has 24 types and combines most PVs typically found in patients with epidermodysplasia verruciformis, but also includes several types typical of other cutaneous lesions such as HPV-4. The third supergroup combines the six known ungulate fibropapillomaviruses, the fourth includes the cutaneous hoofed PVs BPV-3, BPV-4 and BPV-6, and the fifth includes HPV-1, HPV-41, HPV-63, canine oral PV . , and the cottontail rabbit PV. The finch PV and two rodent PVs, Micromys minutus PV and Mastomys natalensis PV, are left ungrouped due to the relative isolation of each of their progeny. Within most supergroups, groups formed on the basis of cladistic principles combine phenotypically similar PV types. We discuss the basis of our classification, the concept of PV type, speciation, PV-host evolution, and estimates of their evolution rates.
authors: Chan, S. Y.;Delius, H.;Halpern, A. L.;Bernard, H. U.

title: Whole genome sequencing of bluetongue virus-1 isolate MKD20/08/Ind from goats in India
abstract: This communication reports the complete genome sequencing for MKD20/08/Ind bluetongue virus-1 (BTV-1) isolated from goat in northern India. The total BTV-1 genome size was found to be 19,190bp. A comparison study between the Indian isolate and other global isolates revealed that it belongs to the 'Eastern' BTV topotype. The complete genome sequence of BTV-1 will provide vital information about its geographic origin and will also prove useful for comparing the Indian isolate with global isolates from other host species.
authors: Chand, K.;Biswas, S. K.;Sharma, G.;Saxena, A.;Tewari, N.;Mahajan, S.;Pandey, A. B.

title: Genome sequence comparison of two United States live attenuated vaccines of infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV)
abstract: This study focused on two US chicken embryo-derived (CEO) vaccines designated as vaccine 1 [LT Blen (GenBank accession: JQ083493); Laryngo-Vac® (GenBank accessed: JQ083494), an Australian Serva vaccine reference ILTV genome sequence [Gallid herpes virus 1 (GaHV-1); GenBank accession number: HQ630064]. The genomes of the two vaccine ILTV strains were sequenced using the Illumina Genome Analyzer 2X of 36 cycles of single-ended reads. The results revealed that there were several nucleotide differences (23 in vaccine 1; 31 in vaccine 2) and showed that the US CEO strains were practically identical to the Australian Serva CEO strain, a vaccine of European origin. Sequence differences indicated the spectrum of variability between vaccine strains. Only eight amino acid differences were found in vaccine 1 in ILTV proteins, including UL54, UL27, UL28, UL20, UL1, ICP4, and US8. Similarly, UL54, UL27, UL28, UL36, UL1, ICP4, US10, and US8 in vaccine 2. Further comparison of US CEO vaccines with several ILTV genome sequences revealed that US CEO vaccines are genetically close to both the Serva vaccine and 63140/C/08/BR (GenBank access: HM188407) and differ from the two Australian-origin CEO vaccines. SA2 (Gen-Bank entry: JN596962) and A20 (GenBank entry: JN596963), which closely resemble each other. These data demonstrate the potential of high-throughput sequencing technology to provide insight into the sequence variation of different ILTV strains. This information can be used to distinguish between vaccine ILTV strains and also to identify emerging mutant strains of field isolates. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Chandra, Y. G.;Lee, J.;Kong, B. W.

title: Isolation and molecular epidemiology of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) virus from an outbreak in free-range wild birds, India 2016
abstract: We report the molecular epidemiology of the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus implicated in an epidemic that caused death in free-range wild birds in Mysore, Karnataka state, India. The virus was typified as HPAI A(H5N8) by conventional and TaqMan probe-based real-time PCR experiments. Six isolates of HPAI virus were obtained in 9-day embryonated chicken eggs. The hemagglutinin gene-based phylogeny of virus isolates showed >99.9% nucleotide sequence identity with HPAI A(H5N8) isolates from migratory birds and domestic poultry from China and Korea, suggesting that these wild birds direct their migration through Korea and/or eastern China, or indicates passing through regions. dead birds must have come into direct or indirect contact with wild birds migrating from eastern China and/or Korea. The study highlights the role of migratory wild birds in the worldwide spread of HPAI.
authors: Chandranaik, B. M.;Byregowda, S. M.;Venkatesha, M. D.;Ramesha, K. R.;Nandini, P.;Reddy, P.;Bindu, K. V. T.;Shivashankar, B. P.;Shankar, B. P.;Rani, M. S.

title: Lessons from Taiwan's Largest Avian Flu Virus Outbreak, 2015
abstract: The largest avian flu (AI) outbreak in history attacked poultry and wild birds in Taiwan starting January 6, 2015. This study analyzes surveillance results, epidemiological characteristics, and viral sequences using government-published information to minimize future pandemic influenza. H5 section 2.3.4.4 highly pathogenic AI viruses (HPAIVs) were not detected in Taiwan before 2015. During this outbreak, four types of etiologic agents were identified: three new subtypes H5N2, H5N8 and H5N3 strains 2.3.4.4 HPAIVs and an endemic chicken H5N2 subtype (Mexican-like lineage) of low pathogenic AI viruses. Co-circulation of H5N2 clade 2.3.4.4 HPAIVs H5N8 and H5N3 subtypes or mixed subtypes accompanied by legacy H5N2 viruses also occurred in the same farm. More than 90% of domestic geese died from this AI epidemic; In the first outbreaks, geese were most affected. The outbreak peaked in mid-January for all three new H5 subtypes. Spatial epidemiology found that the most affected areas were located in the southwestern coastal areas. Different geographic distributions of AI virus subspecies were detected in terrestrial poultry (mainly chickens), Changhwa (P = 0.03) and Yunlin (P = 0.007) counties, with hotspots of H5N2 guideline 2.3.4.4 vs. past endemic legacy H5N2 viruses. , respectively, central Taiwan. Phylogenetic and sequence analyzes of all the early 10 Taiwan H5 wing 2.3.4.4 isolates covering the three subtypes showed that they were very different from HA of past native H5 viruses from domestic ducks (75%-80%) and chickens (70%). -75%). However, they had the highest percentages of sequence identity (99.53-100%) with HA of A/crane/Kagoshima/KU13/2014(H5N8) isolated on December 7, 2014 in Japan, and recently in Japan, America and Korea. H5 HPAIVs [A/Northern pintail/Washington/40964/2014 (H5N2) and A/gyrfalcon/Washington/41088-6/2014 (H5N8): 99.002-99.54% and A/Baikal teal/Korea /Donglim3/2014 ( H5N8): 98.61%-99.08%], this implies a possible common ancestor of H5 guideline 2.3.4.4 viruses. H5 clade 2.3.4.4 Multiple subtypes of HPAIVs imply high viral reclassification. We propose as a vitally important step the establishment of an integrated surveillance system that includes clinical, virological and serological surveillance in poultry and wild birds, pigs and other mammals common in multi-animal mixed farms, and in high-risk human populations. Minimize future pandemic influenza.
authors: Chang, C. F.;King, C. C.;Wan, C. H.;Chang, Y. C.;Chan, T. C.;David Lee, C. C.;Chou, P. H. B.;Li, Z. R. T.;Li, Y. T.;Tseng, T. J.;Lee, P. F.;Chang, C. H.

title: Dual infection of bovine strains of group a and porcine-like group C rotaviruses with gnotobiotic calves influences the pathogenesis of group C rotavirus
abstract: There is serological evidence of the existence of bovine group C rotaviruses in the United States, but no reports of their isolation. Ninety stool samples from calves with diarrhea, 81 samples from adult cows with diarrhea (winter dysentery), and 20 stool samples from healthy adult cows were tested for group C rotaviruses by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, immune electron microscopy, and reverse transcription-PCR (RT). -PCR). Three samples from adult cow diarrhea cases were positive by RT-PCR alone, and a group of rotavirus C was isolated from a positive sample in monkey kidney (MA104) cells (WD534tc/C). Genetically and serologically, the WD534tc/C strain was more closely related to the Cowden pig group C strain than the Shintoku bovine strain. Since the original cow feces also contained a group A rotavirus (detected after passing through cell culture), we hypothesized that such bilateral rotavirus infections might play a role in the pathogenesis of rotaviruses and in host adaptation. Therefore, we examined the pathogenesis of WD534tc/C alone or in combination with virulent (IND/A) or attenuated (NCDV/A) bovine group A rotaviruses in gnotobiotic calves. WD534tc/C alone induced diarrhea without (or limited to) virus transmission in vaccinated calves (n = 3). In contrast, all calves coinfected with WD534tc/C and IND/A (n = 2) developed diarrhea and shed both viruses, whereas calves co-infected with WD534tc/C and NCDV/A (n = 3) developed diarrhea, but each neither virus spilled. . Infection with WD534tc/C or NCDV/A alone caused only mild villous atrophy (jejunum and/or ileum), while dual infection with both viruses caused lesions in the small intestine. Although IND/A alone caused villous atrophy, more extensive small bowel lesions occurred in calves co-infected with WD534tc/C and IND/A. In conclusion, coinfection of calves with group A rotaviruses increased the fecal excretion of a bovine group C rotavirus and the extent of histopathological lesions in the small intestines. Our findings therefore suggest a potential new hypothesis for the adaptation of heterologous rotaviruses to new host species involving binary infections.
authors: Chang, K. O.;Nielsen, P. R.;Ward, L. A.;Saif, L. J.

title: Nipah virus: phylogeny and replication
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of Nipah virus isolates from Malaysia, Bangladesh, and Cambodia revealed the existence of at least two different sets of NiV strains. Based on the major glycoprotein (G) gene, the Nipah virus-Tambun isolate clustered with Nipah virus isolates from Cambodia and Bangladesh, while the remaining isolates from Malaysia clustered in a separate cluster. Sequence heterogeneity was noted among Nipah virus isolates from Malaysia, but the overall genomic sequence aberration value was small, suggesting that the virus originated recently. Nipah virus replicated well in stable kidney cells in pigs and in human lung fibroblast cells. Human monocytes were infected with Nipah virus, but the cells did not support productive infection. Similarly, infection of human neuron cells did not result in the release of a high yield of infectious virus. Monocytes can serve to spread Nipah virus from the site of infection, including the blood-brain barrier. And in the brain, Nipah virus probably spreads by cell-to-cell diffusion mechanism.
authors: Chang, L. Y.;AbuBakar, S.

title: Torque Teno Minivirus Infection in Chronic Cervicitis and Cervical Tumors in Isfahan, Iran
abstract: Objectives: Tork teno mini virus (TTMV) is classified as Betatorquevirus genus of Anelloviridoe. Little is known about the prevalence of TTMV in humans. Worldwide, cervical cancer is the second most common cancer affecting women. In this study, we aimed to estimate the frequency of TTMV infection and the possible role of this virus in its etiology in cases of cervicitis and cervical tumors such as intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and adenocarcinoma in an Isfahan population. Methods: 79 cases of cervicitis and 42 tumors were collected from the histopathological files of Al-Zahra Hospital in Isfahan, Iran. DNA was extracted and subjected to nested polymerase chain reaction. Results: A total of 62% of samples tested were positive for TTMV. It was positive in 52.4% of adenocarcinomas, 68.4% of CINs, and 100% of SCC cases. In cervicitis, 48% of cases were positive. In the phylogenetic structure, two of the cervical tumor isolates and two of the cervicitis isolates were placed in the same cluster as previously reported isolates from Japan (EF538880 and AB041962). Additionally, three of the isolated cervical tumors (JQ734980, JQ734981, and JQ734982) were placed in another cluster. Conclusion: The presence of the virus in cervical tissues indicates possible sexual transmission of the virus. Copyright (C) 2013 S. Karger AG, Basel
authors: Changani, L.;Bouzari, M.;Talebi, A.

title: Isolation and characterization of a feline syncytial virus
abstract: syncytium-forming virus was isolated by trypsinization cultivation and serial passage of tissue kidney of an apparently normal kitten. A full study of the growth and biological properties of the virus was performed in the Crandell feline kidney cell line. The morphogenesis and morphology of this feline syncytial virus were studied by electron microscopy. The characteristics of the virus demonstrated in this study warrant further effort to classify it definitively. It was concluded that feline syncytial virus, bovine syncytial virus and simian foamy agent all belong to the same virus group.
authors: Chappuis, G.;Tektoff, J.

title: Host specificity, pathogen exposure, and superinfections influence the distribution of Anaplasma phagocytophilum genotypes in ticks, roe deer, and livestock in a fragmented agricultural environment.
abstract: Anaplasma phagocytophilum is a bacterial pathogen primarily transmitted in Europe by Ixodes ricinus ticks. It infects wild mammals, farm animals and sometimes humans. Roe deer are considered the main reservoir, but the genotypes they carry are different from those found in livestock and humans. Here, we investigated whether roe deer was the main source of circulating A. phagocytophilum genotypes in the study of I. ricinus nymphs on a fragmented farmland in France. We first evaluated the prevalence of the pathogen in 1837 I. ricinus nymphs (sampled throughout georeferenced sections) and 79 roe deer. The prevalence was significantly different between ticks and roe deer: 1.9% versus 76%, respectively. Second, using high-throughput amplicon sequencing, we characterized the diversity of A. phagocytophilum genotypes found in 22 infected ticks and 60 infected roe deer; The aim was to determine the frequency of coinfections. Only 22.7% of infected ticks carried genotypes associated with roe deer. This finding is in line with other findings suggesting that cattle density is the main factor explaining the infected tick density. To explore epidemiological scenarios that might explain these patterns, we constructed segmental models that focused on how exposure to A. phagocytophilum and the dynamics of infection affect pathogen prevalence in roe deer. At exposure levels estimated by the results of this study and the literature, the high prevalence in roe deer was seen only in the model where superinfections can occur in all infection phases and where the probability of infection after exposure is greater than 0.43. We then interpreted these results in terms of animal husbandry and human health.
authors: Chastagner, A.;Pion, A.;Verheyden, H.;Lourtet, B.;Cargnelutti, B.;Picot, D.;Poux, V.;Bard, E.;Plantard, O.;McCoy, K. D.;Leblond, A.;Vourc'h, G.;Bailly, X.

title: Reassortant Avian Influenza A(H9N2) viruses in chickens in retail poultry stores, Pakistan, 2009-2010
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of influenza viruses collected from chickens in live poultry retail stores in Lahore, Pakistan during the period December 2009 to February 2010 showed that influenza A(H9N2) lineage polymerase and non-structural genes are formed via inter- and intrasubtypic reclassifications. Many of the observed amino acid signatures were characteristic of human isolates; therefore, their circulation may increase inter-subtype or inter-subtype reclassification.
authors: Chaudhry, M.;Angot, A.;Rashid, H. B.;Cattoli, G.;Hussain, M.;Trovo, G.;Drago, A.;Valastro, V.;Thrusfield, M.;Welburn, S.;Eisler, M. C.;Capua, I.

title: Variations in lentiviral gene expression in monocyte-derived macrophages from naturally infected sheep
abstract: Seventy-nine 1-year-old lambs from three different farms and one feeder were examined for natural lentivirus infection. We used three different methods to detect infection in blood-borne macrophages and to stage the ovine lentivirus life cycle. The cytopathic infectious virus was obtained from 14/14 Border Leicester animals obtained from a naturally infected herd. Neither virus particles, virus proteins, virus-specific antibodies, nor viral DNA were detected in samples from 34 lambs from two farms in southern Kansas City. However, we identified 11 infected animals from 31 feeder lambs. Specific viral proteins were immunoprecipitated from macrophages of an animal, but no infectious cytopathic virus was isolated from these cells. Cells from ten other animals contained viral DNA, but neither viral particles nor proteins could be detected by our techniques. Thus, in these naturally infected animals, the virus life cycle either continued to be completed due to differentiation of infected precursor cells in the blood or was stopped at the DNA stage despite the maturation of monocytes into macrophages. Sequence analysis of the env gene of viral genomes from two of the ten fattening sheep showed sequences different from those of known ovine and goat lentiviruses. Surprisingly, these sequences have a higher identity (nucleotide and derived amino acid sequences) than the sheep prototype, the maedi-visna virus. These data suggest that ovine and goat lentiviruses found in North American sheep may have a common ancestral genotype closely related to goat virus.
authors: Chebloune, Y.;Karr, B.;Sheffer, D.;Leung, K.;Narayan, O.

title: Extracting the Clonal Structure of Viral Populations from Time Series Ranking
abstract: RNA virus populations will go through mutation and selection processes that result in a mixed population of viral particles. High-throughput sequencing of a viral population then contains a mixed signal of the underlying clones. We want to identify the underlying evolutionary structures. We use two sources of information to try this out; intrasegment connectivity information and mutation prevalence. We show that although the solutions are not unique even for complete information sets, clone haplotypes, their prevalence, and maximally sparing reticulated evolutionary structures can be identified. This applies to a chain of influenza infections, where we extract evolutionary structures, including reclassification, and demonstrate some interpretation difficulties from deep sequencing due to artifacts such as template switching during PCR amplification.
authors: Chedom, D. F.;Murcia, P. R.;Greenman, C. D.

title: Transfer of Viral Communities Between Humans During Fecal Microbiota Transplantation
abstract: Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is a highly effective treatment for resistant Clostridium difficile infections. However, concerns remain regarding the undesired co-transfer of pathogenic microbes such as viruses. Here, we examined FMT from a single healthy human donor to three pediatric ulcerative colitis patients, each receiving 22 to 30 FMT treatments. Viral particles were purified and sequenced from donor and recipient stool samples; The reads were then assembled into contigs corresponding to viral genomes or partial genomes. Transfer of selected viruses was confirmed by quantitative PCR. Viral contigs present in the donor are easily detectable in recipients, with up to 32 different donor viral contigs appearing in the recipient sample. Reassuringly, none of these were viruses known to replicate in human cells. Instead, viral contigs were either scored as bacteriophages or could not be taxonomically attributed, suggesting unstudied phage. The two most frequently transferred gene types were associated with temperate phage replication. In addition, members of Siphoviridae, the typically temperate group of phages containing phage lambda, were found to be transferred with significantly greater efficiency than other groups. Based on these findings, we propose that the temperate phage replication style may promote efficient phage transfer between human individuals. In summary, we documented the transfer of multiple viral lineages between human individuals via FMT, but in this case series, none were from viral groups known to infect human cells. IMPORTANT Human-to-human transfer of entire virus communities has seldom been studied, but is likely of medical significance. Here, we examined fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT), a highly successful treatment for recurrent Clostridium difficile infection and potentially other gastrointestinal (GI) diseases. We investigated the transfer of viral communities during FMT and documented the transfer of multiple viral lineages between humans. None of these were viruses that replicated in animal cells or were known to be pathogenic. We found that temperate bacteriophage that form stable relationships with their hosts are significantly more likely to be transferred during FMT. This supports a model in which the viral temperate replication style may have evolved in part to support efficient viral transmission between environments.
authors: Chehoud, C.;Dryga, A.;Hwang, Y.;Nagy-Szakal, D.;Hollister, E. B.;Luna, R. A.;Versalovic, J.;Kellermayer, R.;Bushman, F. D.

title: Complete genome sequence of Newcastle disease virus mesogenic vaccine strain R2B from India
abstract: Mesogenic vaccine strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) are widely used in many countries of Asia and Africa to control Newcastle disease in poultry. In India, the mesogenic strain R2B was introduced in 1945; It protects adult chickens pre-vaccinated with the lentogenic vaccine virus and provides long-term immunity. In this article, we report the complete genome sequence of the hitherto unsequenced Indian vaccinia virus strain R2B. The viral genome is 15,186 nucleotides long and contains the polybasic amino acid motif at the fusion protein cleavage site, indicating that this vaccine strain evolved from a virulent virus. Phylogenetic analysis of this mesogenic vaccinia virus classified it with viruses belonging to genotype III of class cluster II of NDV. Â© 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Chellappa, M. M.;Dey, S.;Gaikwad, S.;Kataria, J. M.;Vakharia, V. N.
