title: Minimal core genome sequence typing of bacterial pathogens: a combined approach for clinical and public health microbiology.
abstract: Bacterial pathogens pose a heavy health burden worldwide. In the new era of high-throughput sequencing and online bioinformatics, real-time genome typing of infectious agents, and particularly those with serious clinical implications, promises to guide clinical care to limit the detrimental effects of infections and prevent potential local diseases. or global epidemics. Here, we sequenced and compared 85 isolates of Streptococcus suis, a zoonotic human and swine pathogen; Here we analyzed 32 recognized serotypes and 75 sequence types representing species diversity and human clinical isolates of high public health importance. We found that 1,077 of the 2,469 genes were shared by all isolates. Excluding 201 common but motile genes, 876 genes were defined as the minimum core genome (MCG) of the species. Of the 190,894 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) identified, 58,501 were located in the MCG genes and were termed MCG SNPs. A population structure analysis of these MCG SNPs classified 85 isolates into seven MCG groups, of which MCG group 1 included all isolates from human infections and outbreaks. Our MCG typing system for S. suis provided a clear separation of groups containing isolates associated with humans from groups containing isolates associated with animals. It also separated the group, which included epidemic isolates, including those causing life-threatening streptococcal toxic shock-like syndrome, from isolates of sporadic or less severe meningitis or bacteremia only. The typing system facilitates the application of genome data to the fields of clinical medicine and epidemiology and to the surveillance of S. suis. MCG groups can also be used as taxonomic units of S. suis to identify bacterial subpopulations with the potential to cause serious clinical infections and large-scale epidemics.
authors: Chen, C.;Zhang, W.;Zheng, H.;Lan, R.;Wang, H.;Du, P.;Bai, X.;Ji, S.;Meng, Q.;Jin, D.;Liu, K.;Jing, H.;Ye, C.;Gao, G. F.;Wang, L.;Gottschalk, M.;Xu, J.

title: Genetic analysis of virulence and antimicrobial resistant plasmid pOU7519 in Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis
abstract: Background: Zoonotic Salmonella enterica serovar Choleraesuis (S. Choleraesuis) causes paratyphoid in pigs and bacteremia in humans, usually carrying or congregating a virulence plasmid and sometimes a separate antimicrobial resistant plasmid. This study aimed to analyze the possible mechanism of how to construct a virulence resistant chimera of the plasmid in S. choleraesuis. Methods: The entire plasmid sequence of pOU7519 in S. choleraesuis strain OU7519 was determined using shotgun cloning and sequencing. Sequence annotation and comparison were performed to identify the sequence responsible for the formation of a chimeric virulence resistance pOU7519. Other chimeric plasmids among the collected S. choleraesuis strains were also confirmed. Results: The 127,212 bp long sequence pOU719 was determined to be a chimera of the virulence plasmid pSCV50 and a multidrug-resistant plasmid pSC138 found in S. choleraesuis strain SC-B67. pOU7519 is a conjugative plasmid carrying a variety of mobile DNAs, including prophages, insertion sequences, integrons and transposons, particularly a Tn. 6088-like transposon. By truncating the pSCV50-pSC138 chimera junction in pOU7519, defective sequences were found in the integrase gene scv50 (int) and attachment site (att), resulting in a stable chimera plasmid, possibly due to failure of excision. pSCV50-pSC138 chimera. Similar structure of chimera was also found in other large plasmids. Conclusion: Deletion of both int and att sties could possibly block chimera excision and result in an irreversible, stable pSCV50-pSC138 chimera. The emergence of conjugative virulence and antimicrobial-resistant plasmids in S. choleraesuis may pose a threat to public health.
authors: Chen, C. L.;Su, L. H.;Janapatla, R. P.;Lin, C. Y.;Chiu, C. H.

title: Ordered shotgun sequencing of 135 kb Xq25 YAC containing four putative genes, including three confirmed by ANT2 and EST matches
abstract: Ordered shotgun sequencing (OSS) was successfully accomplished with an Xq25 YAC substrate. yWXD703 DNA was subcloned into lambda phage and sequences of insertion ends of lambda subclones were used to generate a map to select the minimal laying path of clones to be fully sequenced. The 135 038 nt sequence contains the entire ANT2 cDNA, as well as four other candidates suggested by computer-assisted analyses. One of the putative genes is homologous to a gene involved in Graves' disease, and this is confirmed by pairings of ANT2 and the other two EST. The results show that OSS can be applied to YACs in agreement with previous simulations and also that the YAC sequence accurately reflects the sequence of uncloned human DNA.
authors: Chen, C. N.;Su, Y.;Baybayan, P.;Siruno, A.;Nagaraja, R.;Mazzarella, R.;Schlessinger, D.;Chen, E.

title: Whole genome characterization of a rotavirus B (RVB) strain identified in ibex children with enteritis reveals interspecies crossing with RVB cattle strains.
abstract: Rotavirus B (RVB) has been associated with intestinal disease in many animal species. An RVB strain was identified in pooled gut samples from Alpine goat pups (2 to 3 days old) with high (>90%) morbidity and a complete goat RVB genome was characterized. Histology revealed villus atrophy, samples tested positive for RVB by real-time RT-PCR, and metagenomic next-generation sequencing identified only RVB and orf virus. In the VP4 gene segment, the goat RVB strain had a higher percentage of nucleotide identity to the Indian bovine RVB strains than the Japanese bovine RVB strains, but the VP7, VP6, VP2, NSP5 gene segments strain of the American goat RVB strain, Japanese bovine RVB strains was genetically related. The results demonstrate the lack of RVB sequences to understand the reclassification or evolutionary relevance of RVB strains from cattle and goats.
authors: Chen, F.;Knutson, T. P.;Ciarlet, M.;Sturos, M.;Marthaler, D. G.

title: Evolutionary relationships between large double-stranded DNA viruses infecting microalgae and other organisms as inferred from DNA polymerase genes
abstract: To examine genetic relatedness between viruses infecting microalgae, DNA polymerase gene (DNA pol) fragments were amplified and sequenced from 13 virus clones infecting three distantly related microalgae (Chlorella strains NC64A and Pbi, Micromonas pusilla and Chrysochromulina spp.). . Phylogenetic trees on DNA pol sequences and hybridization of total genomic DNA showed similar branching patterns. Genetic relatedness calculated from hybridization and sequencing data showed good agreement (r = 0.90), indicating that DNA pol sequences can be used to determine genetic relatedness and infer phylogenetic relationships between these viruses. The phylogenetic tree extracted from DNA pol amino acid sequences from 24 dsDNA viruses, including Phycodnaviruses, herpesviruses, poxviruses, baculoviruses, and African swine fever virus, is in good agreement with groupings based on the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses. Microalgal viruses are more closely related to each other than other dsDNA viruses and form a separate phyletic group, suggesting that they share a common ancestor and belong to the Phycodnaviridae. Also, Phycodnaviridae is more closely related to Herpesviridae than to other virus families in which DNA pol sequences are present.
authors: Chen, F.;Suttle, C. A.

title: Identification of fluctuating key genes caused by avian leukemia virus (ALV-J) infection in chicken cells
abstract: Avian leukemia subgroup J (ALV-J) is one of the most harmful neoplastic diseases in poultry production. However, the differences between post-infection somatic cells and immune cells are poorly understood. The aim of our study was to detect different responses to infection with ALV-J in different cell lines in chicken. In this study, we detected transcriptome expression changes during infection with ALV-J in chicken embryo fibroblast (CEF) and HD11 cell lines. RNA-Seq was used to determine the expression levels of mRNA transcripts from the two cell types after infection with ALV-J at 1, 4 and 7Â dpi, and gene ontology analyzes were used to cluster differentially expressed genes in pathways. Quantitative real-time PCR confirmed the expression of 336 and 269 differentially expressed genes related to innate immunity (OASL, CCL4), adaptive immunity (LYZ, CD72), apoptosis and autophagy (WISP2, COMP) in the CEF and HD11 lines, respectively. inflammation (JSC, IL8) and tumorigenesis (PCNA, GPX3). Notable signal transduction pathways included the PPAR signaling pathway and ECM-receptor interactions in CEF, and the Toll-like receptor, NOD-like receptor, and RIG-I-like receptor signaling pathways in HD11. To our knowledge, this is the first study to use high-throughput sequencing methods to investigate viral infection in different cell types. The results of the current study provide a basis for developing potential biomarkers for viral infection.
authors: Chen, G.;Li, Z.;Su, S.;Chang, G.;Qiu, L.;Zhu, P.;Zhang, Y.;Xu, Q.

title: Identification and Research of a Novel Avian Coronavirus in Ducks
abstract: The rapid discovery of new viruses using next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies, including DNA-Seq and RNA-Seq, has greatly expanded our understanding of viral diversity in recent years. Timely identification of new viruses using NGS technologies is also important for us to control emerging infectious diseases caused by new viruses. In this study, we identified a novel duck coronavirus (CoV) distinct from chicken infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) using RNA-Seq. The new duck-specific CoV was a potential new strain within the genus Gammacoronavirus, as indicated by the sequences of three regions in the viral 1b gene. We also conducted a study of CoVs in domestic poultry in China using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) targeting the viral nucleocapsid (N) gene. A total of 102 CoV positives were detected through the questionnaire. Phylogenetic analysis of viral N sequences suggested that CoVs in domestic birds are divided into several site-specific or host-specific clades or sub-clades around the world and that IBVs can infect ducks, geese and pigeons, although circulating mainly in chickens. Furthermore, this study provided new data supporting the idea that some host-specific CoVs other than IBVs circulate in ducks, geese, and pigeons, and showed that the novel duck-specific CoV identified in this study via RNA-Seq is genetically closer to some CoVs. . circulating in wild waterfowl. Taken together, this study provided new insights into the diversity, distribution, evolution and control of avian CoVs. © 2013 Chen et al.
authors: Chen, G. Q.;Zhuang, Q. Y.;Wang, K. C.;Liu, S.;Shao, J. Z.;Jiang, W. M.;Hou, G. Y.;Li, J. P.;Yu, J. M.;Li, Y. P.;Chen, J. M.

title: The complete matrix of the H3N8 equine influenza virus and the evolution of the matrix1, matrix2 gene
abstract: In our study, phylogenetic analysis of M, M1 and M2 genes of H3N8 equine influenza virus (EIV) was performed. Furthermore, the aa sequences of the M1 and M2 proteins were aligned and mapped. The result showed that the M, M1 and M2 gene of all recent EIV strains of Florida-2 strain isolated after 2007 were under differential evolution. It evolved into a different clade called the Aisan clade, which was distinguished from the EIV strains of the Florida-2 clan isolated before 2007 and more closely resembled the European clade. This was also revealed by a sequence analysis of the M1 and M2 protein. In addition, the phylogenetic tree of the M2 gene showed that it evolved in a different pattern than the full M and M1 gene. The M1 and M2 genes of two equine-derived influenza viruses of A/Swine/Chibi/01/2005 and A/Swine/Anhui/01/2006 were validated here under frozen evolution. Our studies will enrich our knowledge of the M, M1 and M2 genes of the H3N8 EIV and will form the basis of further research on this subject.
authors: Chen, J.;Guo, X.

title: Genetic variation of Chinese PRRSV strains based on the ORF5 sequence
abstract: Thirteen isolates of swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) from different provinces of China were analyzed and compared with several PRRSV isolates from other countries. Phylogenetic analysis indicates that all Chinese PRRSV isolates in this study belong to the American genotype, except for one strain B13, which clustered as a European genotype. Sequence analysis revealed that Chinese isolates of the American genotype PRRSV are highly similar in ORF5 sequence and can be classified into two subspecies. One contains PRRSV isolates more closely related to the American vaccine strain MLV Resp and its parent strain VR-2332, and the other includes those only distantly related. Slight genetic variation has occurred within the Chinese isolates, and some strains may be directly caused by the vaccinia virus. Â© 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Chen, J.;Liu, T.;Zhu, C. G.;Jin, Y. F.;Zhang, Y. Z.

title: Molecular epidemiology of swine epidemic diarrhea virus in China
abstract: Since the beginning of 2006, the swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) has been re-emerging in vaccinated pig herds. Open reading frame 3 (ORF3) is the only accessory gene in the PEDV genome. All ORF3 genes of 12 PEDV domain strains and one vaccine strain were sequenced. The ORF3 genes of Chinese PEDV domain strains (except CH/GSJIII/07) contain a single 672- or 675-nucleotide (nt) ORF encoding a 223- or 224-aa long peptide. However, vaccine strain CV777 and CH/GSJIII/07 contain a 276-nt ORF due to a 49-nt deletion at nt 245-293. Chinese PEDV domain strains and PEDV reference strains are divided into three groups based on the phylogenetic relationship of ORF3 genes. Chinese PEDV field strains (except CH/GSJIII/07) have a close phylogenetic relationship to Korean strains and are genetically different from PEDV vaccine strains. However, CH/GSJIII/07 has a close phylogenetic relationship to the two vaccine strains, suggesting that it may have evolved from a live vaccine strain. Chinese PEDV field strains (except CH/GSJIII/07) can be distinguished from PEDV vaccine strains by a nested RT-PCR method. © 2010 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Chen, J.;Wang, C.;Shi, H.;Qiu, H.;Liu, S.;Chen, X.;Zhang, Z.;Feng, L.

title: Origin and future distribution of the novel A(H1N1) influenza virus that emerged in North America in 2009
abstract: The origin of the novel A(H1N1) influenza virus, which has recently emerged in North America, is an important and controversial issue in disease control and risk assessment. While some experts claimed it was an unusually hybridized mix of human, avian and swine flu viruses, others concluded that it was a purely simple reclassification hybrid of two swine flu viruses. Here, the phylogenetic diversity of the viral PB1, PA and PB2 gene sequences using online web servers and the results show that all 8 genetic segments of the new virus are probably descended from two swine flu virus strains, and one of the strains is a lineage of human, avian and swine flu viruses that emerged in the world about 10 years ago. hybridized mix. Given the recent epidemiological trends of the new virus, we believe it will spread more widely around the world and remain in human populations for a long time. It can also spread among pig populations. Widespread spread of the new virus in the future may coincide with the disappearance of a subtype of the previous human influenza A virus.
authors: Chen, J. M.;Sun, Y. X.;Liu, S.;Jiang, W. M.;Chen, J.;Hou, G. Y.;Li, J. P.

title: Reassortant Clade of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N6) Virus 2.3.4.4, Taiwan, 2017
abstract: A highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N6) virus of class 2.3.4.4 was detected in a domestic duck found dead in Taiwan in February 2017. The endemic status and continued evolution of several reassortant highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses in Taiwan raises concern for further reclassification and is the fifth wave of intercontinental spread.
authors: Chen, L. H.;Lee, D. H.;Liu, Y. P.;Li, W. C.;Swayne, D. E.;Chang, J. C.;Chen, Y. P.;Lee, F.;Tu, W. J.;Lin, Y. J.

title: Isolation, genome sequencing and functional analysis of two T7-like coliphages of avian pathogenic Escherichia coli.
abstract: Avian pathogenic Escherichia coli (APEC) causes colibacillosis, which causes significant economic losses to the poultry industry worldwide. Due to drug residues and increasing antibiotic resistance caused by antibiotic use, bacteriophages and other alternative therapeutic agents are expected to control APEC infection in poultry. Two APEC phages, P483 and P694, were isolated from feces from the farmer's market in China. We then examined their biological characteristics and performed high-throughput genome sequencing and homology analyzes of these phages. The compilation results of high-throughput sequencing showed that the structures of both the P483 and P694 genomes consisted of linear and double-stranded DNA. Electron microscopy and homology analysis results revealed that both P483 and P694 belong to T7-like virus, a member of the Podoviridae family of the order Caudovirales. Comparative genomic analysis showed that most of the predicted proteins of these two phages showed the strongest sequence. Similarity with Enterobacteria phages BA14 and 285P, Erwinia phage FE44 and Kluyvera phage Kvp1; however, some proteins, such as gp0.6a, gp1.7 and gp17, showed lower similarity (< 85%) to homologues of other phages in the T7 subgroup. We also found some unique features of P483 and P694, such as the two gene types of P694 and the lack of lytic activity of P694 against host bacteria in liquid medium. Our results serve to advance our understanding of the phage evolution of T7-like coliphages and provide the potential application of phages as therapeutic agents for the treatment of diseases.
authors: Chen, M.;Xu, J.;Yao, H.;Lu, C.;Zhang, W.

title: Deep Sequencing, Details of a Crossover Map of Chimeric Genes in Two Pig Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus Infectious Clones
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recombination is a major contributor to the genetic diversity of most viruses. A reverse genetics system using infectious clones expressing green fluorescent protein (GFP) and enhanced GFP (EGFP) was developed to study recombination requirements. However, it is still unclear what kind of crossover events occur to produce viable offspring. OBJECTIVE: We used 454 sequencing to extract recombination events in this system. METHODS: Two porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) infectious clones, P129-EGFP-97C and P129-GFPm-d (2-6) were co-transfected into HEK-293T cells. P129-EGFP-97C is a fully functional virus containing a non-fluorescent EGFP. P129-GFPm-d (2-6) is a defective virus but contains a fluorescent GFPm. Successful recombination was evident with the emergence of fully functional progeny virus expressing fluorescence. Total RNA was extracted from fluorescent-expressing infected cells and the entire fluorescent gene was amplified to prepare an amplicon library for 454 sequencing. RESULTS: Deep sequencing, nucleotide identities varied from ~37% (21nt to 165nt variable region) to 20% (T<sub>289</sub>C) to ~38% (456-651nt) showed. 100% (672-696nt) compared to EGFP. The results showed that crossover events occurred in three conserved regions (166-288nt, 290-455nt, 652-671nt), also supported by sequence alignments. Remarkably, the short conserved region (652-671nt) showed a crossover hotspot. In addition, four crossover models (two single and two double crossovers) can be used to generate viable recombinants. CONCLUSION: The reverse genetics system, which includes the use of high-throughput sequencing, provides a genetic platform to study the genesis of live recombinant viruses.
authors: Chen, N.;Chand, R. J.;Rowland, R. R. R.

title: Pig reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus replication and half-species evolution in non-adaptive-immune pigs.
abstract: Replication of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) was studied in a swine line with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Real-time RT-PCR revealed a unique course of infection for the SCID group. During the course of the infection, viremia was initially significantly lower than in normal puppies, but rose significantly by day 21. Deep sequencing of viral structural genes at days 11 and 21 identified seven amino acid substitutions in both normal and SCID pigs. The most significant change was a W99R substitution in GP2 that was present in the vaccine at a frequency of 35% but eventually disappeared in all pigs regardless of immune status. Thus, the amino acid substitutions that occur during acute infection are likely the result of adaptation of the virus to replication in pigs and not of immune selection.
authors: Chen, N.;Dekkers, J. C.;Ewen, C. L.;Rowland, R. R.

title: Metagenomic analysis of the RNA fraction of the fecal virome shows high diversity in pigs infected with swine endemic diarrhea virus in the United States.
abstract: Background: The emergence and re-emergence of the swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) in North America, Asia, and Europe has caused severe economic losses to the global swine industry. However, the effect on virome and disease severity of PEDV-infected pigs is unknown. Advances in sequencing technology have made it possible to characterize the entire microbiome of different body regions for any given host. Methods: The aim of this study was to characterize the RNA virome in PEDV positive pigs using a hypothesis-free metagenomic approach based on next-generation sequencing. Specifically, 217 PEDV-positive pig faecal swab samples collected from diarrheal piglets from 17 US states between 2015 and 2016 were analyzed. Results: A bioinformatics analysis based on the Kraken algorithm revealed the presence of 9 different RNA strains outside of PEDV (Alphacoronavirus genus), including Mamastrovirus (52%, 113/217), Enterovirus (39, 85/217), Sapelovirus (31). %, 67/217), Posavirus (30%, 66/217), Kobuvirus (23%, 49/217), Sapovirus (13%, 28/217), Teschovirus (10%, 22/217), Pasivirus (9 %, 20/217) and Deltacoronavirus (3%, 6/217). Of the 217 piglets, 58 (27%) had PEDV infection alone, while the remaining 159 (73%) shed up to 2 9 different viruses. Conclusion: These findings showed that PEDV-infected diarrheal pigs have a large RNA viral flora consisting of four different families: Astroviridae, Picornaviridae, Caliciviridae and Coronaviridae.
authors: Chen, Q.;Wang, L.;Zheng, Y.;Zhang, J.;Guo, B.;Yoon, K. J.;Gauger, P. C.;Harmon, K. M.;Main, R. G.;Li, G.

title: A new strain of astrovirus in the gut of diarrheal yaks on the Qinghai-Tibet plateau, 2013
abstract: The yak (Bos grunniens) is an iconic symbol in the high-altitude region of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. Diarrhea is a common disease in the area and causes great economic losses. To investigate the diversity of viral strains, we reported the metagenomic-derived virome in a pooled stool sample of 20 diarrheal yaks. Nine viruses found in pooled diarrheal samples in order of abundance of nucleic acid sequence, influenza A virus, bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV), rotavirus, ungulate tetraparvovirus 1 (bovine hocovirus), astrovirus (AstV), bovine enterovirus, hepatitis E virus, kobuvirus, and mountain rat hepatitis virus. Compared with healthy yaks, AstV alone had a significantly higher prevalence rate in diarrheal samples, indicating a correlation with clinical symptoms of diarrhea in the closets. To further investigate the molecular characterization of Yak AstV, a nearly complete genome was obtained from a diarrheal sample. It was 6243 bp in length and shared 46.4%-66.2% similarity in faeces to other related bovine AstVs. Phylogenetic analysis of the genome showed that yak AstV fell into the cluster of bovine AstVs, but in a unique lineage, suggesting that a new species of AstV had been identified in the yaks. Interestingly, the ORF2 region of yak AstV had closer similarity and genetic association with deer AstV strain CcAstV-2 than with bovine AstVs. Further analysis indicated that a possible interspecies recombination event occurred in ORF2. In summary, this study expanded our understanding of the viral communities of diarrheal yaks and identified a new AstV associated with diarrhea in yaks.
authors: Chen, X.;Zhang, B.;Yue, H.;Wang, Y.;Zhou, F.;Zhang, Q.;Tang, C.

title: Cloning and molecular characterization of the ORF5 gene from a PRRSV-SN strain from southwestern China.
abstract: To monitor the genetic variation of PRRSV, the ORF5 gene of the PRRSV-SN strain located in Suining City, Sichuan Province was cloned and sequenced. The results showed that strain PRRSV-SN is a highly pathogenic PRRSV (HP-PRRSV) variant strain with the North American (NA) genotype. Homology analysis showed that the ORF5 gene of the PRRSV-SN isolate shares 89.4% (86.5%) nucleotide (amino acid) sequence similarity with the North American strain VR-2332, and 98.8% (96%) identity with JXA1 ( Europe The similarity with the representative strain Lelystad virus of the type 57.7%. Phylogenetic analysis showed that PRRSV-SN belongs to the NA genotype and has the same subtype as other highly pathogenic PRRSV strains. Amino acid sequence analysis showed that, compared with strain VR2332, PRRSV-SN has varying degrees of variation in signal peptide, transmembrane domain (TM), primary neutralizing epitope (PNE), non-neutral epitopes, and N-glycosylation sites. Antigenicity analysis showed that PRRSV-SN ORF5 gene products and JXA1 have similar antigenic properties, and the antigenic epitopes are mainly located in the regions aa30-39, aa50-60, aa128-141, aa146-155 and aa161-183. In contrast, the antigenic properties of PRRSV-SN are quite different from that of the VR2332 strain. The main differences were that the PRRSV-SN strain was significantly narrower in the aa30-39 and aa50-60 regions than the VR2332 strain, but was significantly wider in the aa136-141 region. The results of this study showed that the epidemic strains that caused PRRSV outbreaks in the farm were still mainly JXA1 variants, but the genes of the PRRSV epidemic strain still showed constant diversity due to the more frequent use of live vaccine immunizations. Vaccination with live PRRSV should be reduced and surveillance of PRRSV strains increased.
authors: Chen, X. W.;Li, L.;Yin, M.;Wang, Q.;Luo, W. T.;Ma, Y.;Pu, Z. H.;Zhou, J. L.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of human/swine/avian gene reassortant H1N2 influenza A virus isolated from a pig in China.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Our aim in this study was to determine the genetic characterization and possible origin of H1N2 swine flu virus (A/Swine/Guangxi/13/2006) (Sw/GX/13/06) from lung tissue of a pig in Guangxi. Province, China. METHODS: Eight Sw/GX/13/06 genes were cloned and genetically analyzed. RESULTS: The hemagglutinin (HA), nucleoprotein (NP), matrix (M), and non-structural (NS) genes of Sw/GX/13/06 were most closely related to the classic porcine H1N1 influenza virus strain genes. The neuraminidase (NA) and PB1 genes were most closely related to the corresponding genes from the human influenza H3N2 virus strain. The remaining two genes, PA and PB2 polymerase genes, were most closely related to avian influenza virus descendant genes. CONCLUSION: Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that Sw/GX/13/06 is a human/swine/avian H1N2 virus and is closely related to H1N2 viruses isolated from pigs in the United States (1999-2001) and Korea (2002). To our knowledge, Sw/GX/13/06 was the first triple-reasortant H1N2 influenza A virus isolated from a pig in China. Whether sw/GX/13/06 poses a potential threat to breeding farm and human health will be further investigated.
authors: Chen, Y.;Meng, X.;Liu, Q.;Huang, X.;Huang, S.;Liu, C.;Shi, K.;Guo, J.;Chen, F.;Hu, L.

title: Gene expression profile after activation of RIG-I in 5'ppp-dsRNA-challenged DF1
abstract: Retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I) can recognize influenza viruses and evoke the innate immune response. RIG-I is absent in the chicken genome but is conserved in the ducks genome. RIG-I deficiency makes chickens more susceptible to avian influenza infection, and clinical symptoms are more pronounced than in other poultry. It is unknown whether delivery of duck RIG-I to chicken cells induces immunity as seen in ducks and the role of RIG-I in resident immunity. In this study, a chicken cell strain with stable duRIG-I expression by lentiviral infection was established by donating DF1/LV5-RIG-I and a control strain DF1/LV5 was established in parallel. To confirm stable, high-level duRIG-I expression in DF1 cells, duRIG-I mRNA and protein levels were determined by real-time RT-PCR and Western blot, respectively. Also, 5'triphosphate double-stranded RNA (5'ppp-dsRNA) was used to mimic an RNA virus infection and infected DF1/LV5-RIG-I and DF1/LV5 cells were subjected to high-throughput RNA sequencing; 193.46M reading and 39.07G base. A total of 278 differentially expressed genes (DEGs), namely duRIG-I-mediated responding genes, were identified by RNA-seq. Among 278 genes, 120 DEGs were annotated in the KEGG database, and the most reliable KEGG pathways are likely to be the signaling pathways of RIG-I-like receptors. Functional analysis by gene ontology (GO) indicates that the functions of these DEGs are mainly related to Type I interferon (IFN) signaling, IFN-Î²-mediated cellular responses, and upregulation of the RIG-I signaling pathway. Based on the genes shared between the different pathways, a network representing crosstalk between RIG-I and other signaling pathways was constructed using the Cytoscape software. The network suggests that the RIG-mediated pathway may cross-talk with the Jak-STAT signaling pathway, Toll-like receptor signaling pathway, Wnt signaling pathway, ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis, and MAPK signaling pathway during transmission of antiviral signals. After screening, a group of key responsive genes in RIG-I-mediated signaling pathways such as ISG12-2, Mx1, IFIT5, TRIM25, USP18, STAT1, STAT2, IRF1, IRF7 and IRF8 were tested for differential expression by true. time RT-PCR. In summary, by combining our results and the available literature, we propose a RIG-I-mediated signaling network in chickens.
authors: Chen, Y.;Xu, Q.;Li, Y.;Liu, R.;Huang, Z.;Wang, B.;Chen, G.

title: Characterization of a newly identified bacteriophage infecting Bordetella bronchiseptica in pigs.
abstract: novel lethal bacteriophage infecting Bordetella bronchiseptica, vB_BbrM_PHB04, was isolated from wastewater collected from a pig farm in China. The phage vB_BbrM_PHB04 exhibited growth over a wide range of temperature and pH conditions, and showed different coat values and lytic spectrum activity within the same strains at 25Â°C and 37Â°C. High-throughput sequencing revealed that vB_BbrM_PHB04 has a linear double-stranded DNA genome with 124 putative open reading frames. Overall, the vB_BbrM_PHB04 genome showed very low similarity (highest nucleotide identity 82%, 1% coverage) to other phage sequences in the GenBank database. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that vB_BbrM_PHB04 is a new member of the Myoviridae family. In addition, polymerase chain reaction-based detection of phage genes in phage-resistant B. bronchiseptica variants revealed no evidence of lysogenic activity of the vB_BbrM_PHB04 phage.
authors: Chen, Y.;Yang, L.;Sun, E.;Song, J.;Wu, B.

title: Co-circulation of pandemic 2009 H1N1, classic swine H1N1 and bird-like swine H1N1 influenza viruses in pigs in China
abstract: Pandemic A/H1N1 influenza viruses emerged in March 2009 in both Mexico and the United States and were efficiently transmitted in the human population. They occasionally infect other mammals, including pigs, dogs, and cats, from humans. In this study, we report the isolation and genetic analysis of novel viruses in pigs in China. These viruses were phylogenetically related to the pandemic 2009 H1N1 influenza viruses isolated from humans and pigs, suggesting that the pandemic virus is currently circulating in pig populations, and this hypothesis was further supported by serological surveillance of pig sera collected over the same period. We also isolated two more H1N1 viruses belonging to the strains of classical porcine H1N1 virus and avian-like porcine H1N1 virus, respectively. Multiple genetic strains of H1N1 viruses circulate together in the swine population, highlighting the importance of intensive surveillance for swine flu in China. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Chen, Y.;Zhang, J.;Qiao, C.;Yang, H.;Zhang, Y.;Xin, X.;Chen, H.

title: Japanese encephalitis virus genotype variation, Taiwan, 2009-2010
abstract: Genotype I of the Japanese encephalitis virus first appeared in Taiwan in 2008. Phylogenetic analysis of 37 viruses from pig farms in 2009-2010 classified these viruses into 2 unique genotype I virus subsets and suggested multiple entries and rapid replacement of genotype III by genotype I virus. in Taiwan.
authors: Chen, Y. Y.;Fan, Y. C.;Tu, W. C.;Chang, R. Y.;Shih, C. C.;Lu, I. H.;Chien, M. S.;Lee, W. C.;Chen, T. H.;Chang, G. J.;Chiou, S. S.

title: Genetic variation in envelope genes of contemporary US swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus strains influences viral antigenicity.
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) is one of the most economically important diseases in pigs caused by the porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV). Genome sequences of sixty-six PRRSV strains were obtained using metagenomic sequencing of serum samples collected in the USA in 2014 to investigate contemporary genetic diversity. Phylogenetic analysis of genes encoding envelope proteins identified four to eight distinct lineages with >87% intraclade identity. To investigate the effect of observed genetic variation on antigenicity, genome regions encoding GP2a-GP3-GP4 or GP5-M in strain SD95-21 were replaced with alleles from each of eight different PRRSV strains using reverse genetics. The GP2a-GP3-GP4 region from only four of the eight strains yielded live recombinant virus. When appropriate, both GP2a-GP3-GP4 and GP5-M variably affected antigenicity. A significant strain-related loss in cross-reactivity was variably observed with indirect immunofluorescence assays using antisera from pigs vaccinated with commercially modified live vaccines following replacement of GP2a-GP3-GP4 or GP5-M. Significantly reduced neutralization titers were similarly measured using antisera from pigs naturally exposed to PRRSV. These results demonstrate the need to consider genomic regions as well as GP5 for PRRSV epidemiology and vaccination.
authors: Chen, Z.;Collin, E.;Peddireddi, L.;Clement, T.;Gauger, P.;Hause, B. M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of Indian rabies virus isolates targeting the whole glycoprotein gene
abstract: Rabies is a deadly viral zoonosis endemic in India. There are no reports of phylogenetic studies of Indian rabies virus isolates based on the whole G gene. In this study, a total of 25 rabies positive brain samples collected from six different host species from North India (UP, MP, Delhi, Rajasthan), South India (Kerala and Karnataka) and Gujarat between 2001-2014 were tested. G gene amplification by RT-PCR as three overlapping fragments of 881.bp, 991.bp and 618.bp. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that all Indian rabies virus isolates were genetically closely related to Arctic-like 1a strain viruses. However, two distinct clusters were identified, namely India South and India North. All Indian rabies isolates had 95.5-100% homology with respect to geography, but did not host the species. Amino acids deduced in comparison revealed two amino acid changes, aa 356 in ECTO; N. â†' K and aa 458; M. â†' I was found to differentiate between Indian Southern and Indian Northern isolates.
authors: Cherian, S.;Singh, R.;Singh, K. P.;Manjunatha Reddy, G. B.;Anjaneya;Ravi Kumar, G. V. P. P. S.;Sumithra, T. G.;Singh, R. P.

title: Evolution of Bovine viral diarrhea virus in Canada from 1997 to 2013
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is a rapidly evolving, single-stranded RNA virus and is a pathogen that limits the production of cattle worldwide. 79 viral isolates collected between 1997 and 2013 in Canada were subjected to next-generation sequencing. Bayesian phylogenetics was used to evaluate the evolution of this virus. A mean replacement rate of 1.4×10âˆ'3 replacements/places/year was found in both BVDV1 and BVDV2. The evolution rates in the E2 gene were slightly faster than in other regions. We also identified population structures below the subgenotype level, possibly with phenotypic effects. Two distinct clusters exist within BVDV2a and can be distinguished in part by a tyrosine to isoleucine mutation at position 963 in the E2 protein, a position related to the antigenicity of BVDV1 isolates. Significant clustering within all subgenotypes, particularly BVDV2a, is evident and may lead to new levels of genotypic classification. Therefore, continuous monitoring of emerging variants is necessary.
authors: Chernick, A.;van der Meer, F.

title: Identification of several segments of novel single-stranded circular DNA viruses with preserved root loop structures in pig dung
abstract: Metagenomic analysis of fecal samples collected from swine with diarrhea detected sequences encoding a replication initiator protein (Rep). The genomes of ten novel single-stranded DNA viruses were identified and exhibited a similar genome organization. The two putative open reading frames (ORFs) encoding the Rep and capsid protein are duplicated bidirectionally and separated by two intergenic regions. Root-loop structure(s) specific to genomes undergoing the rolling circle DNA replication mechanism were observed. Phylogenetically, these ten genomes are in a monophyletic sequence with the previously described porcine fecal-associated virus (PoSCV), but different enough to be further classified into six different virus sequences.
authors: Cheung, A. K.;Ng, T. F.;Lager, K. M.;Alt, D. P.;Delwart, E.;Pogranichniy, R. M.

title: Unique circovirus-like genome detected in pig feces
abstract: Using a metagenomic approach and molecular cloning methods, we identified, cloned and sequenced the complete genome of a novel circular DNA virus, porcine fecal-associated virus (PoSCV4) from pig feces. Phylogenetic analysis of the inferred replication initiator protein showed that PoSCV4 was most associated with the circular DNA virus associated with fur seal droppings.
authors: Cheung, A. K.;Ng, T. F.;Lager, K. M.;Alt, D. P.;Delwart, E. L.;Pogranichniy, R. M.

title: distinct fraction of circular single-stranded DNA viruses from pig dung
abstract: Using metagenomic and molecular cloning methods, we characterized five novel small, circular viral genomes from pig feces that are distantly related to chimpanzee and pig feces-associated circular viruses (ChiSCV and PoSCV1). Phylogenetic analysis has placed these viruses in a rather different part of this rapidly growing new viral family. This new strain of virus, tentatively termed pig feces-associated circular viruses 2 and 3 (PoSCV2 and PoSCV3), encodes a stem-loop structure (possibly the origin of DNA replication) and a widely found replication initiator protein in the small intergenic region. other biological systems that replicate their genomes via the rolling circle mechanism. Moreover, these viruses also display three additional overlapping open reading frames in the large intergenic region between the capsid and replication initiation protein genes. Â© 2013 Springer-Verlag Wien (outside the USA).
authors: Cheung, A. K.;Ng, T. F.;Lager, K. M.;Bayles, D. O.;Alt, D. P.;Delwart, E. L.;Pogranichniy, R. M.;Kehrli Jr, M. E.

title: Biology of influenza a virus
abstract: Outbreaks of avian influenza A virus in poultry and humans in the last decade have posed a pandemic threat to man. Here we discuss the basic classification and structure of influenza A virus. The viral genome contains eight viral segments of RNA and the functions of the viral proteins encoded by this genome are described. Also, RNA transcription and replication of this virus is reviewed. Â© 2007 New York Academy of Sciences.
authors: Cheung, T. K. W.;Poon, L. L. M.

title: Genome analysis of orf virus isolates from goats in Fujian Province, southern China.
abstract: Orf virus (ORFV), a species of the Parapoxvirus genus of the family Poxviridae, causes a non-systemic, highly contagious and rash disease in sheep, goats and other wild and domestic ruminants. Our previous work shows that orf is ubiquitous in Fujian Province, China, an area of significant heterogeneity among ORFVs. In this study, we sequenced the complete genomes of four Fujian goat ORFV strains (OV-GO, OV-YX, OV-NP, and OV-SJ1). The four strains were 132-139 kb in length, each containing 124-132 genes and approximately 64% G+C content. The most notable differences between the four strains were found near the genome termini. Compared with other ORFVs, seven genes were absent in OV-NP and three genes near the right terminal in OV-SJ1. We also investigated the skin virulence of four Fujian ORFVs in goats. ORFVs with gene deletions showed low virulence, while ORFVs without gene deletions showed high virulence in goats, suggesting that gene deletion probably led to attenuation of ORFVs. Gen 134 was disrupted in the OV-NP genome due to the absence of the start code. The phylogenetic tree based on the complete Parapoxviruse genomes showed that sheep-derived and goat-derived ORFVs formed distinctly separate branches with 100% bootstrap. Based on the single gene phylogenetic tree of 132 genes of ORFVs, it can be easily distinguished that 47 genes originate from sheep or goats. To further reveal the genetic diversity presented in goat ORFVs and sheep ORFVs, we analyzed the inferred amino acid sequences of gene 008, multiple alignments of amino acid sequences of gene 008 from five goat ORFVs and four sheep ORFVs. revealed 33 unique aminos. acids that differentiate it as a host, either sheep or goat. The availability of genomic sequences of four Fujian goat ORFVs may help us understand the diversity of orf virus isolates in this region and distinguish between orf strains originating from sheep and goats.
authors: Chi, X.;Zeng, X.;Li, W.;Hao, W.;Li, M.;Huang, X.;Huang, Y.;Rock, D. L.;Luo, S.;Wang, S.

title: Diagnosis and phylogenetic analysis of multifocal cutaneous orf virus, an epidemic of mixed bacterial infection in goats in Fujian province, China.
abstract: Orf virus outbreaks are common on goat farms in China. In this study, we investigated a severe multifocal cutaneous orf virus outbreak lasting up to 6 months with correlated mixed bacterial infection with high morbidity (93.7%) and mortality (15%) among children in a crossbred herd. Goats in the Fujian province of China. The disease was diagnosed as an orf virus (ORFV XD strain) infection associated with Streptococcus pluranimalium and Staphylococcus, identified using standard virological and bacteriological techniques. Multiple sequence alignments and phylogenetic analyzes of all ORFV 011 (B2L), 059 (F1L), 032, and 080 genes revealed that although virus phylogeny was clustered in branches of traditional orf virus strains, it still showed high diversity within this subset. . Furthermore, sequences from the ORFV 080 gene allowed us to distinguish different strains at a higher resolution, and these observations gave us a comparative view of the ORFV 080 gene. This is the first report describing a severe multifocal cutaneous orf virus outbreak with associated bacterial infection in China.
authors: Chi, X.;Zeng, X.;Luo, S.

title: Classification and putative origins of Brazilian swine circovirus 2 obtained by phylogenetic and phylogeographic approaches.
abstract: Porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2) is the major causative agent of post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome (PMWS) and is associated with different syndromes affecting pigs. The PCV2 genome has three main open reading frames (ORFs), among which ORF2 encodes the capsid protein. In this study, the ORF2 nucleotide sequences of 30 Brazilian isolates were analyzed. Sequences were compared with other GenBank sequences using phylogenetic and phylogeographic approaches. Our results show high sequence variability in Brazil, as Brazilian isolates in this study were classified in subgroups 1AB, 2D, and 2, suggesting that the virus was introduced multiple times in Brazil. On the other hand, most Brazilian isolates appear to be derived from only one entry. Multiple introductions of the virus have likely occurred through the importation of animals with the asymptomatic form of the virus or the importation of contaminated semen, according to data from the Pig Breeders' Association. The results indicate the need to implement programs aimed at selecting sows to prevent importation of Group 1 PCV2 infected animals. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Chiarelli-Neto, O.;Yotoko, K. S. C.;Vidigal, P. M. P.;Silva, F. M. F.;Castro, L. A.;Fietto, J. L. R.;Silva Jr, A.;Almeida, M. R.

title: Ranaviruses and other members of the Iridoviridae family: their place in the virosphere
abstract: Members of the Iridoviridae family, collectively called iridovirides, are large, double-stranded DNA-containing viruses that infect invertebrates and cold-blooded (ectothermic) vertebrates. In the former, infections often lead to massive viral replication, resulting in iridescence and eventual death of the infected animal. Among the latter, infections target various organs and can cause high levels of morbidity and mortality among commercially and ecologically important fish and amphibian species. The viral replication strategy was primarily elucidated through the frog virus 3 (FV3) study with additional input from other iridovirides of ecological or commercial importance. Replication occurs in both nuclear and cytoplasmic compartments and includes genome length and concatemeric DNA synthesis, extensive methylation of the viral genome (only among vertebrate viruses), coordinated expression of three classes of viral gene products, and formation of icosahedral virions within the cytoplasmic viral assembly. Sites. Phylogenetic analyzes identify five genera within the family and suggest that members of the families Iridoviridae, Ascoviridae, and Marseilleviridae compromise a monophyletic lineage, with ascoviruses most closely related to invertebrate iridoviruses.
authors: Chinchar, V. G.;Waltzek, T. B.;Subramaniam, K.

title: Genetic diversity of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus strains from Iran
abstract: Background: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFV) is a member of the Bunyaviridae family and the Nairovirus genus. It has a negative-sense, single-stranded RNA genome of approximately 19.2 kb, containing Small, Medium, and Large segments. CCHFVs are relatively different in their genome sequences and are grouped in seven separate sequences based on S-segment sequence analysis and six compartments based on M-segment sequences. Our aim was to obtain new information about the molecular epidemiology of CCHF in Iran. Methods: We analyzed the partial and complete nucleotide sequences of the S and M segments from 50 Iranian patients. Extracted RNA was amplified using one-step RT-PCR and subsequently sequenced. Sequences were analyzed using Mega5 software. Results: Phylogenetic analysis of partial S segment sequences, clade IV-(Asia 1), clade IV-(Asia 2) and clade V-(Europe) accounted for 80%, 4% and 14% of circulating genomic variants of CCHFV. has shown. respectively in Iran. However, one of the Iranian strains (Iran-Kerman/22) was not associated with any of the other sequences and formed a new sequence (VII). Phylogenetic analysis of complete S-segment nucleotide sequences from selected Iranian CCHFV strains, complemented by representative strains from GenBank, revealed similar topology with eight major clusters as partial sequences. A partial M-segment phylogeny would make Iranian strains either III. Conclusion: Phylogenetic analysis revealed subtle links between distant geographic locations, which we suggest may arise from the international livestock trade or long-distance transmission of CCHF by infected ticks through bird migration.
authors: Chinikar, S.;Bouzari, S.;Shokrgozar, M. A.;Mostafavi, E.;Jalali, T.;Khakifirouz, S.;Nowotny, N.;Fooks, A. R.;Shah-Hossein, N.

title: Genetic diversity of swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus in Korea
abstract: The high genetic diversity of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) has been an obstacle to developing an effective vaccine for porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS). This study was conducted to assess the degree of genetic variation among PRRSVs in Korean pig farms where wasting and respiratory syndrome were observed from 2005 to 2009. Samples from 786 farms were tested for the presence of PRRSV using the reverse transcription PCR protocol. A total of 117 farms were positive for type 1 PRRSV, and 198 farms were positive for type 2. Nucleotide sequences encoding open reading frame (ORF) 5 were analyzed and compared to several published PRRSV isolates obtained worldwide. The sequence identity of ORF 5 in isolates was 81.6%Ìƒ100% for type 1 viruses and 81.4%Ìƒ100% for type 2 viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of ORF 5 sequences showed that type 1 and 2 PRRSVs from Korea were mainly classified into three and four clusters, respectively. The analyzed isolates were distributed across clusters regardless of the year of isolation or geographic origin. In conclusion, our results showed that the genetic diversity of PRRSVs from Korean pig farms was high and increased over time. Â© 2013 Korean Veterinary Science Association.
authors: Choi, E. J.;Lee, C. H.;Song, J. Y.;Song, H. J.;Park, C. K.;Kim, B.;Shin, Y. K.

title: Sequence analysis of old and novel swine circovirus strains associated with congenital tremor in pigs and their comparison with strains associated with post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome.
abstract: The whole genomes of 7 porcine circovirus (PCV) isolates from pigs with congenital tremor (CT), type A2, or post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome (PMWS) were cloned and sequenced. One isolate (CT-PCV-P7) was obtained from a neonatal pig with CT, type A2, in the late 1960s. Two recent PCV isolates (CT-PCV-P5, CT-PCV-P6) were from 2 affected neonatal pigs from different farms with unrelated CT outbreaks; Type A2. Four isolates (PMWS-PCV-P1, PMWS-PCV-P2, PMWS-PCV-P3, PMWS-PCV-P4) obtained from pigs with PMWS from 4 different farms. A comparative analysis of these PMWS and PCV isolates showed 99% sequence identity with each other and over 96% sequence identity with pre-sequenced PCV2 isolates. However, CT-PCV-P5 and CT-PCV-P6 isolates shared 99% of the same identity with each other and interestingly with PMWS PCV isolates. There were no consistent genomic differences between PMWS and final CT isolates. CT-PCV-P7 showed 98% identity similarity to PCV1 derived from PK-15 and only 72% identity similarity to CT-PCV-P5 or CT-PCV-P6. Phylogenetic analysis of old isolate (CT-PCV-P7) and new isolates (CT-PCV-P5, CT-PCV-P6, PMWS-PCV-PI, PMWS-PCV-P2, PMWS-PCV-P3, PMWS-PCV- P4) was correctly classified as PCVI and PCV2, respectively.
authors: Choi, J.;Stevenson, G. W.;Kiupel, M.;Harrach, B.;Anothayanontha, L.;Kanitz, C. L.;Mittal, S. K.

title: Molecular epidemiological investigation of lentogenic newcastle disease virus from domestic birds at live bird markets in Korea.
abstract: Newcastle disease surveillance program was conducted in live bird markets in Korea to expand our epidemiological understanding of the disease in Korea. During the surveillance programme, 10 lentogenic Newcastle disease viruses (NDV) were isolated and identified from apparently healthy chickens and ducks in live bird markets. Lentogenic viruses had sequence motifs of either 112GKQGRL117 (n = 8) or 112GRQGRL117 (n = 2) at the F0 cleavage site. Sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes of NDV isolates based on the hypervariable region of the F protein revealed two distinct genotypes: genotype I (n = 8) and II (n = 2). Genotype I viruses were most closely related to strain NDV V4 (n = 7) or strain NDV Ulster 2C (n = 1). In contrast, genotype II viruses clustered with NDV vaccine strains (LaSota and VG/GA), which are commonly used as live vaccines in Korea. The epidemiological significance of NDV in live bird markets in Korea is debated. Â© 2012 American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Choi, K. S.;Lee, E. K.;Jeon, W. J.;Kwon, J. H.;Lee, J. H.;Sung, H. W.

title: Epidemiological observations of bovine viral diarrhea virus in Korean domestic calves.
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is a major disease worldwide in the livestock industry. To date, little research has been done on BVDV circulating in the Republic of Korea (ROK). The cases summarized in our study resulted from rectal swabs taken from 80-day-old calves. Of 99 Korean domestic calves with diarrhea, 22 were identified as BVDV positive and 3 different 50-untranslated region (UTR) sequences were identified. The results showed that BVDV infections in ROK were mostly found during winter and when calves are younger than 20 days. Phylogenetic analysis based on 50-UTR revealed that our cases from Korean domestic calves belonged to BVDV-2a. Therefore, the outcome of this study will be useful to understand the epidemiology and allow producers at ROK to better protect their animals. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2010.
authors: Choi, K. S.;Song, M. C.

title: Avian influenza viruses and their pathogenic potential in Korean live poultry markets
abstract: In 2003, we surveyed live poultry markets in Korea and isolated 9 H9N2, 6 H3N2 and 1 H6N1 influenza viruses. Antigenic and phylogenetic analyzes showed that all 9 H9N2 isolates were of A/Chicken/Korea/25232-96006/96-like lineage (caused disease in chickens in Korea in 1996) but differed from H9N2 viruses in southeast China. They had at least 4 genotypes and reproduced in chickens but not mice. The H3N2 and H6N1 viruses were new to Korea and were likely reassortants of avian influenza viruses from southeast China and the more recent Korean H9N2 viruses. All 8 segments of the H3N2 viruses formed a single phylogenetic cluster with 99.1% to 100% homology. H3N2 viruses proliferated in chickens and mice without preadaptation, but H6N1 virus did not. Our results show an increasingly diverse pool of avian influenza viruses that are potential pandemic influenza agents in Korea. Â© 2004 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Choi, Y. K.;Heui Seo, S.;Kim, J. A.;Webby, R. J.;Webster, R. G.

title: Viral metagenomics reveals presence of highly divergent quaranjavirus in Rhipicephalus ticks from Mozambique
abstract: Background: Ticks are the primary vectors for many well-known disease-causing agents that affect human and animal populations globally, such as tick-borne encephalitis, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, and African swine fever. In this study, viral metagenomics was used to determine which viruses were present in Rhipicephalus spp. Ticks collected in Mozambique's Zambezi Valley. Methods: RNA was amplified by sequence-independent single primer amplification (SISPA) and high-throughput sequencing was performed on the Ion Torrent platform. The produced sequences were subjected to quality control and classified by BLAST. CodonCode aligner and SeqMan were used to assemble the sequences. Results: Although viruses similar to Parvoviridae and Coronaviridae were also identified, most of the viral sequences showed the closest sequence identity to the Orthomyxoviridae family. Nearly complete sequences of the five orthomyxoviral segments (HA, NP, PB1, PB2 and PA) were obtained, showing an amino acid identity of 32%-52% against known quaranjaviruses. The sequences were most closely associated with the Wellfleet Bay virus and were detected and isolated from common plumage during a fatality event in the United States. Conclusions: In summary, this study identified a highly distinctive virus in the family Orthomyxoviridae associated with Rhipicephalus ticks from Mozambique. Further genetic and biological studies are needed to explore the potential pathogenesis of the identified orthomyxovirus.
authors: Cholleti, H.;Hayer, J.;Mulandane, F. C.;Falk, K.;Fafetine, J.;Berg, M.;BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.

title: Characterization of fecal virus of captive and wild Tasmanian devils using virus-like particles metagenomics and meta-transcriptomics.
authors: Chong, R.;Shi, M.;Grueber, C. E.;Holmes, E. C.;Hogg, C.

title: Effect of seasonal vaccination on selection of influenza A/H3N2 epidemic variants
abstract: The effect of vaccination on the dynamics of influenza virus variants is largely unknown in humans, unlike in poultry. In this study, we compared influenza hemagglutinin (HA) gene sequences isolated from vaccinated and unvaccinated populations with annual vaccine strains. In total, 181 influenza A/H3N2 virus samples isolated from 82 vaccinated and 99 unvaccinated patients (2011-15, four Japanese influenza seasons) were genetically analyzed using a next-generation sequencer. Amino acid (AA) differences from the corresponding vaccine strains were found in 74 of the 329 HA1 sites. There was a maximum of four AA differences within epitopes in the previous three seasons (2011-14) and fifteen AA differences in the following season (2014-15). A greater number of deviations to AA differences were found to be more significant in isolates obtained from vaccinated patients compared to unvaccinated patients (P=0.0005 in 2011-14; P=0.0096 in 2014-15). Differences in AA within epitopes were also higher in isolates from vaccinated patients than in unvaccinated patients (2.64% vs. 2.14% for 2011-14, P=0.033; 7.78% vs. 6.59% for 2014-15, P=0.058). AA differences at seven sites (48I-278K, 128A-142G, 145S, 158K and 193S) became dominant in subsequent seasons. In all of these regions, dominance was maintained during incompatibility of isolates with vaccine strains and was lost after vaccine mating. Our data suggest that vaccination-induced immune pressure in humans works to select influenza variants that are genetically distant from vaccine strains.
authors: Chong, Y.;Ikematsu, H.

title: Effect of viral and bacterial community diversity on prevalence of pathogenic E. coli in preharvest cattle.
authors: Chopyk, J.

title: Pathogenicity, sequence and phylogenetic analysis of Malaysian Chicken anemia virus obtained after low and high passages in MSB-1 cells
abstract: Specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens inoculated with low-transition Chicken anemia virus (CAV), SMSC-1 and 3-1 isolates produced lesions suggestive of CAV infection. Repeated passages of isolates up to passage 60 (P60) and passage 123 in cell culture produced viruses with significantly lower pathogenicity in SPF chickens compared to low passage isolates. Sequence comparison showed that only nucleotide changes in the coding region of P60 transition isolates were thought to contribute to virus attenuation. Phylogenetic analysis showed that SMSC-1 and 3-1 are highly different, but their P60 transitional derivatives share significant homology with a Japanese isolate A2.
authors: Chowdhury, S. M. Z. H.;Omar, A. R.;Aini, I.;Hair-Bejo, M.;Jamaluddin, A. A.;Md-Zain, B. M.;Kono, Y.

title: Characterization of H9N2 avian influenza viruses from the Middle East shows heterogeneity at amino acid position 226 in hemagglutinin and potential for transmission to mammals.
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies are a valuable tool for tracking changes in viral genomes and determining the genetic heterogeneity of viruses. In this study, NGS was applied to clinical poultry samples from Jordan to detect eleven H9N2 low pathogenic avian influenza viruses (LPAIV). All of the tested viruses belonged to the Middle East A genetic group of the G1 strain. Deep sequencing showed a high degree of heterogeneity of glutamine and leucine residues at position 226 in the hemagglutinin (HA) gene, increasing specificity for avian or mammalian type receptors. Additionally, additional amino acid changes were detected in PB1, PA, M1, M2, and NS1 among the viruses tested. Compared with single gene amplification, the application of NGS for the surveillance and characterization of H9N2 LPAIV provides a complete genetic profile of emerging isolates and a better understanding of the potential for zoonotic transmission to mammals.
authors: Chrzastek, K.;Lee, D. H.;Gharaibeh, S.;Zsak, A.;Kapczynski, D. R.

title: Use of Sequence-Independent, Single Primer Amplification (SISPA) for rapid detection, identification and characterization of avian RNA viruses
abstract: Existing technologies with next-generation sequencing have revolutionized the metagenomic analysis of clinical samples. To achieve non-selective amplification and recovery of low-abundance genetic sequences, a simplified Sequence-Independent, Single-Primary Amplification (SISPA) technique was applied in combination with the MiSeq platform to target negative and positive-sense single-stranded RNA viral sequences. . This method allowed successful sequence assembly of the viral genome of full- or full-length avian influenza virus (AIV), infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), and Newcastle disease virus (NDV). In addition, SISPA analysis applied to unknown cases of clinical mixed viral infection produced genome assemblages consisting of 98% NDV and 99% IBV genomes. Complete or nearly complete virus genome sequence was obtained with titers of 10<sup>4.5</sup> EID<sub>50</sub>/ml (50% embryo infection dose) or above, and virus identification was detectable with titers 10<sup>3 </sup> EID<sub>50</sub>/ml or more. Taken together, these studies demonstrate a simple template enrichment protocol for rapid detection and accurate characterization of avian RNA viruses.
authors: Chrzastek, K.;Lee, D. H.;Smith, D.;Sharma, P.;Suarez, D. L.;Pantin-Jackwood, M.;Kapczynski, D. R.

title: Characterization of a novel gyrovirus in human feces and chicken meat
abstract: Background: Sequence-independent amplification of clinical samples may lead to the identification of new pathogens. Objectives: To identify novel viruses in human stool samples from patients with diarrhea and to investigate the ecology and clinical significance of such viruses. Study design: Nucleic acid extracted from stool samples from patients with diarrhea of unknown etiology was subjected to random PCR amplification and Roche/454 pyrosequencing. The new viruses identified were characterized genetically and epidemiologically. Results: Four gyroviruses, chicken anemia virus (CAV), human gyrovirus (HGV)/avian gyrovirus 2 (AGV2), gyrovirus 3 (GyV3), and a new gyrovirus (provisionally designated gyrovirus 4 (GyV4)) were identified in human stool samples. . GyV4 was also detected in chicken skin and meats for human consumption, as well as CAV and AGV2/HGV. Results: A new gyrovirus (GyV4) was identified in human feces and in chicken meat sold for human consumption. This virus was phylogenetically different from previously reported gyroviruses in chicken and humans (chicken anemia virus, human gyrovirus, avian gyrovirus 2 and recently reported gyrovirus 3). The epidemiology and pathogenesis of this virus in humans and chickens need further investigation. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Chu, D. K. W.;Poon, L. L. M.;Chiu, S. S. S.;Chan, K. H.;Ng, E. M.;Bauer, I.;Cheung, T. K.;Ng, I. H. Y.;Guan, Y.;Wang, D.;Peiris, J. S. M.

title: Locust pox virus, orf virus, and mycoplasma capricolum subsp. capripneumoniae in goats
abstract: The current study has shown that Goatpox virus (GTPV), Orf virus (ORFV) and Mycoplasma capricolum subsp. Capripneumoniae (MCCP) from a Chinese goat farm with a case fatality rate of 60.2%. The clinical signs observed were ecthyma and increased respiratory rate with frequent coughing. Specific fragments of the p32 gene of GTPV, the B2L gene of ORFV and the 16S ribosomal RNA gene of MCCP were simultaneously amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) from tissues of 12 dead goats. PCR products were cloned in GenBank, sequenced and aligned with their respective reference sequences for further identification of pathogens. This study reports a mixed infection with GTPV, ORFV and MCCP in goats. Â© 2011 Author(s).
authors: Chu, Y.;Yan, X.;Gao, P.;Zhao, P.;He, Y.;Liu, J.;Lu, Z.

title: Pathotyping and Phylogenetic Characterization of Newcastle Disease Viruses Isolated in Peru: Identification of Two New Subgenotypes within Genotype XII
abstract: Infections of poultry with virulent strains of avian paramyxovirus 1 (APMV-1), also known as Newcastle disease viruses (NDVs), cause Newcastle disease (ND). This highly contagious disease affects poultry and many other bird species worldwide. In countries where the disease is common, continuous monitoring and characterization of isolates causing epidemics is necessary. In this study, we report the results of pathogenicity testing and phylogenetic analyzes of seven NDVs isolated from various regions of Peru between 2004 and 2015. The intracerebral pathogenicity indices (ICPIs) of the six viruses range from 1.75 to 1.88, corresponding to a velogenic pathotype. The remaining virus had an ICPI of 0.00, corresponding to a lentogenic pathotype. These results were consistent with amino acid sequences in the fusion protein (F) cleavage site. All velogenic isolates had the polybasic amino acid sequence 112RRQKRâ†“F117 at the F cleavage site. Phylogenetic analyzes of the complete F gene sequences showed that all isolates were classified in class II of APMV-1. Velogenic viruses are classified in genotype XII, while lentogenic virus is classified in genotype II, which is closely related to the LaSota vaccine strain. Furthermore, the tree topology, bootstrapping values and genetic distances observed in the XII genotype resulted in the identification of new XIIa subgenotypes (in South America) and XIIb (in China), and possibly two clades in the XIIa genotype. All velogenic Peruvian viruses belonged to subgenotype XIIa. Overall, our results confirm the existence of the XII genotype in Peru and show that it is the common genotype currently circulating in our country. Phylogenetic characterization of these isolates helps characterize the evolution of NDV and may aid in the development of vaccines specific to our regional needs.
authors: Chumbe, A.;Izquierdo-Lara, R.;Tataje, L.;Gonzalez, R.;Cribillero, G.;GonzÃ¡lez, A. E.;FernÃ¡ndez-DÃ­az, M.;Icochea, E.

title: Introduction to the ecology of arboviruses (in Russian)
abstract: Arboviruses make up the largest group of viruses of vertebrates. By 1972, about 400 arboviruses had been registered in the world, of which about 260 were divided into 41 groups according to their antigenic properties; 130 viruses have not yet been grouped. In the Universal Classification System of Viruses, arboviruses are included in 6 genes: Alphavirus, Flavivirus, Rhabdovirus, Reovirus, Arenavirus, and Enterovirus. Members of these genera differ markedly in biology, morphology, and biochemical and antigenic characteristics, indicating the heterogeneous character of the arboviruses group. The heterogeneity of this group suggests that transmission of viruses by arthropods as modes of propagation arose independently from systematically distant different types of viruses. All known arboviruses are pathogenic only to vertebrates. They also multiply in arthropod tissue (in vivo and in vitro) but show no pathogenic effects on them. It is noteworthy that certain viruses of arthropods do not reproduce in the tissues of vertebrates. Arbovirus circulation cycles are mainly determined by the trophic relationships of hematophagous arthropods with vertebrates. These associations are most abundant with the group of approximately parasitized mammals. 2500 species of mosquitoes, sandflies, sandflies and Ixodid, Argasid and Gamasid ticks. The trophic associations of arbovirus vectors with birds are considerably lower than with mammals. Apparently, the more than 500 types of hematophages in this category are not related to birds. The most numerous affinities with this group of vertebrates are found in mosquitoes and Argasid ticks. Close trophic relationships are indicated by reptilia reptilla, mosquitoes of the genus Deinocerite, some sandflies of the genus Sergentomyia, and all Ixodid ticks of the genus Aponoma. The total number of species of arbovirus vectors parasitizing on reptiles does not exceed 50. Ecologically, 212 arboviruses can be named mammalian viruses, 39 avian viruses, and 3 reptile arboviruses. There is a close positive correlation (coefficient 0.90) between the number of vectors trophically associated with one or another land vertebrate group and the number of arboviruses specific to that group. Most arboviruses originate on one continent, but spread over two to three continents if they have mainland connections (North and South America, Africa, and Eurasia). Arboviruses occurring in the Western and Eastern hemispheres are ecologically related to humans (Dang 2 and 3, yellow fever), domestic animals (bluetongue of the sheep, Wad Medani) or migratory birds and their narrowly specific parasites (Tyuleniy virus). (453 references.)
authors: Chunikhin, S. P.

title: Genetic characterization of rabies virus isolates detected in the Russian Federation during 2008-2011.
abstract: 63 gene N fragments of rabies virus field isolates detected in different regions of the Russian Federation during 2008-2011 were sequenced. Comparison with previously tested isolates and strains showed that newly isolated isolates could be placed into five previously identified phylogenetic groups: Arctic group, Central Russian group, Eurasian group, Northern European group, and Caucasian group. The Arctic group isolates detected in the Komi republic were identical to the previously described rabies virus strain from Yakutia. This is the first reliable case to detect Arctic group rabies virus in the European part of Russia.
authors: Chupin, S. A.;Chernyshova, E. V.;Metlin, A. E.

title: Genetic characterization of H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 swine flu virus in Thailand
abstract: Pigs are known to be a suitable host for influenza A virus. Phylogenetic analysis has not yet been attempted on swine flu virus (SIV) in Thailand. This report presents the molecular and phylogenetic analysis performed on SIV in Thailand. In this study, the molecular genetics of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase were elucidated by subtyping 12 SIV isolates from central and eastern Thailand. Three subtypes have been defined as H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2. Phylogenetic analysis of the SIV hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes shows individual clusters containing swine, human, or avian influenza virus at various global locations. Also, amino acid substitutions were detected at the receptor binding site or antigenic regions of the hemagglutinin gene. © 2008 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Chutinimitkul, S.;Thippamom, N.;Damrongwatanapokin, S.;Payungporn, S.;Thanawongnuwech, R.;Amonsin, A.;Boonsuk, P.;Sreta, D.;Bunpong, N.;Tantilertcharoen, R.;Chamnanpood, P.;Parchariyanon, S.;Theamboonlers, A.;Poovorawan, Y.

title: Ungulate copiparvovirus 1 (bovine parvovirus 2): characterization of a new genotype and associated viremia in different cattle age groups
abstract: new bovine parvovirus 2 (BPV2) genotype containing 5394Â nt was identified by next-generation sequencing from the sera of healthy cattle of different age groups reared in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. The genome organization of the novel BPV2 genotype preserves two ORFs unique to Parvovirinae members with 86.4% of their overall nucleotide sequence identities compared to other members of the subfamily. Phylogenetic analysis revealed similar clustering with two previously described bovine BPV2 within the Copiparvovirus genus. No significant differences (PÂ â‰¥Â 0.05) were detected in the distribution of BPV2 infection in different age groups in cattle. This is the third complete or nearly complete genome sequence of BPV2 reported to date and may contribute to a better understanding of the biology of copiparvoviruses and their interactions with the host.
authors: Cibulski, S. P.;Teixeira, T. F.;dos Santos, H. F.;de Sales Lima, F. E.;Scheffer, C. M.;Varela, A. P. M.;de Lima, D. A.;Schmidt, C.;Silveira, F.;de Almeida, L. L.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Phylogenesis and Clinical Aspects of Pandemic 2009 Influenza A (H1N1) Virus Infection
abstract: In the spring of 2009, a new swine-borne influenza A (H1N1) virus emerged and spread worldwide, causing a pandemic influenza. Here, 329 naso-pharyngeal swabs collected from patients with flu-like symptoms were analyzed by real-time PCR for the presence of the H1N1 2009 pandemic virus. Twenty-five samples collected from immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients contained the H1N1 pandemic virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes showed no significant differences in similarity and/or homology between sequences identified in immunocompetent individuals and sequences from immunocompromised patients. Pre-existing clinical conditions may affect the outcome of H1N1 disease.
authors: Ciccozzi, M.;Babakir-Mina, M.;Lo Presti, A.;Marcuccilli, F.;Perno, C. F.;Ciotti, M.

title: Metasecretome-selective phage display approach to explore the functional potential of a rumen microbial community
abstract: BACKGROUND: In silico, secretome proteins can be predicted from fully sequenced genomes using a variety of existing algorithms that identify membrane targeting sequences. For the metasecretome (collection of surface, secreted, and transmembrane proteins from environmental microbial communities), this approach is impractical given that metasecretome open reading frames (ORFs) make up only 10% to 30% of the total metagenome and are underrepresented in the dataset. generally low coverage of the metagenomic gene pool, even in large-scale projects. RESULTS: By combining secretome selective phage display and next-generation sequencing, we focused sequencing analysis of the complex rumen microbial community on the metasecretome component of the metagenome. This approach resulted in a high enrichment (29-fold) of fibrolytic enzymes secreted from the plant-bound microbial community of the bovine rumen. In particular, we have so far identified hundreds of rare modules of cellulosomes, specialized cell-surface complexes for plant fiber recognition and degradation. CONCLUSIONS: As a method, metasecretome phage display combined with next-generation sequencing has the power to sample the diversity of low-abundance surface and secreted proteins that would otherwise require extraordinarily large metagenomic sequencing projects. As a resource, the metasecretome display library, powered by the dataset obtained by next-generation sequencing, is readily available for i) affinity selection by standard phage display methodology and ii) easy purification of displayed proteins as part of the virion for individual functional analysis.
authors: Ciric, M.;Moon, C. D.;Leahy, S. C.;Creevey, C. J.;Altermann, E.;Attwood, G. T.;Rakonjac, J.;Gagic, D.

title: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrhea virus: evidence of an increasing number of variants in Italy
abstract: Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) is responsible for serious economic losses on cattle farms worldwide. BVDV is a high genome variability RNA virus with practical implications for epidemiology, diagnosis, and disease control. Genetic monitoring has been recommended as the first step in BVDV control. Thirty-seven Bovine Viral Diarrhea Viruses have been identified and genetically characterized in persistently infected cattle, animals affected by mucosal disease, and in bulk milk. The 5–²UTR region was amplified and sequenced, and a phylogenetic analysis was performed comparing all Italian BVDV sequences available from the Genbank database. An unusual number of persistently infected animals proved to be present on multiple farms. Phylogenetic analysis linked all of our viruses to BVDV type I and distinguished four different subgroups within this genotype. Analysis of old and new viruses revealed the circulation of viruses classified in subgroups BVDV Ia and Ij, which were never reported in Italy.
authors: Ciulli, S.;Galletti, E.;Battilani, M.;Scagliarini, A.;Gentile, A.;Morganti, L.;Prosperi, S.

title: Evidence for the Presence of Tunisian-Like Pestiviruses in Small Ruminants in Italy since 2007
abstract: The genus Pestivirus, which belongs to the family Flaviviridae, contains ssRNA+ viruses responsible for infectious diseases in pigs, cattle, sheep, goats and other domestic and wild ruminant animals. Like most RNA viruses, pestivirus has high genome variability with practical implications for disease epidemiology, diagnosis and control. In addition to the officially recognized strains of the pestivirus genus such as BVDV-1, BVDV-2, BDV and CSFV, other pestiviruses have been identified. In addition, most ruminant pestiviruses show the low or absent species specificity observed in serological tests and can infect more than one species. Small ruminants, in particular, are the recipient hosts of the most heterogeneous group of pestiviruses. The aim of this study is to perform the molecular characterization of pestiviruses isolated from sheep and goats in Sicily, Italy. Phylogenetic analysis of two viral genomic regions (part of 5'-UTR and all Npro regions) revealed the presence of different pestivirus genotypes in the analyzed goat and sheep herds. Two of the five viral isolates clustered with BVDV-1d viruses, a strain common in Italy but never reported in Sicily. The other three isolates formed a separate cluster with high similarity to Tunisian isolates, which were recently proposed as a new pestivirus strain. This represents the first evidence for the presence of Tunisian-like pestivirus in small ruminant animals in Italy. Also, one of the isolates was collected from a goat and represents the first isolation of this species of Tunisian-like pestivirus.
authors: Ciulli, S.;Purpari, G.;Agnello, S.;Di Marco, P.;Di Bella, S.;Volpe, E.;Mira, F.;de Aguiar Saldanha Pinheiro, A. C.;Vullo, S.;Guercio, A.

title: Association between protection against human rotavirus disease and factors influencing protection in low-income settings
abstract: Rotaviruses (RV) are the leading cause of gastroenteritis in infants and children worldwide and are predominantly associated with high mortality in low-income settings. The virus is classified into G and P serotypes as well as P genotypes based on differences in the surface-exposed proteins VP7 and VP4, respectively. Infection results in a variable level of protection from subsequent re-infection and disease. This protection is predominantly homotypic in some settings, while broader heterotypic protection is reported in other cohorts. Two antigenically different oral RV vaccines are licensed and available widely, including in under-resourced settings, with funding from the GAVI alliance. The first is a monovalent vaccine derived from a live attenuated human RV strain, and the second is a pentavalent bovine-human reclassification vaccine. Both vaccines are highly effective in high-income settings, but greatly reduced levels of protection are reported in low-income countries.
