Here we discuss the current challenges faced by mucosal immunologists and vaccineists seeking to identify immunological correlates and understand the varying levels of protection these vaccines confer in humans. Such understanding is critical to maximizing the public health impact of existing vaccines, as well as developing the next generation of RV vaccines needed.
authors: Clarke, E.;Desselberger, U.

title: Structural analysis of electrophoretic variation in genome profiles of rotavirus domain isolates
abstract: Detailed structural studies were performed on five bovine rotavirus isolates with varying migration patterns of genome segments on electrophoresis on polyacrylamide gels. Individual genome segments of each isolate were characterized by partial digestion of terminally radiolabelled RNA with a base-specific nuclease. This analysis showed that although mobility variations are always associated with detectable changes in the nucleotide sequence, sequence changes that are at least as large as those found in segments that show electrophoretic mobility variations are also detected in segments that do not show mobility variations. Evidence that genome segment reclassification has occurred among viruses in the field came from analysis of 11 RNA species from these five isolates. The overall conclusion from these results is that great care should be taken in interpreting simple genome profiling analyzes of different isolates for epidemiological purposes and that classification of these viruses on the basis of genome electropherotype alone can be misleading.
authors: Clarke, I. N.;McCrae, M. M. A.

title: Identification and analysis of the first 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza virus from US wild pigs
authors: Clavijo, A.;Nikooienejad, A.;Esfahani, M. S.

title: Physical and chemical inactivation of the hemagglutinins of type A influenza viruses: aiding in classification
abstract: Effects of temperature and treatment with sodium dodecyl sulfate, Tween 20, dithiothreitol, trypsin, or guanidine on the hemagglutination capacity of six type A influenza viruses (A(0)/PR8/34, A(1)/CAME/46) , A(2) /J305/57, A(2)/Bethesda/63, A(2)/HK/Aichi/68 and A(2)/HK/80/68, a strain of swine virus (A /Swine/76/?) and a horse strain (A/Equi-2/63) was determined. The two Hong Kong strains are easily distinguishable from previous A(2) strains by the resistance of their hemagglutinins to trypsin treatment and by their failure to restore hemagglutination capacity after removal of dithiothreitol from the treated virus preparations. In these respects, the horse strain was most similar to the Hong Kong variants. The pattern of hemagglutination inactivation also differentiated porcine, PR8 and CAME strains from each other as well as from the other five strains. The results suggest that grouping type A viruses according to the pattern of inactivation of their hemagglutinins may be a valuable aid to standard serology for a more precise classification of these viruses.
authors: Cleeland, R.;Grunberg, E.;Prince, H. N.

title: A complex mosaic of enteroviruses shapes the transmission and evolution of community-acquired hand, foot, and mouth disease in a single hospital
abstract: Human enteroviruses (EV) pose a major risk to public health. This is particularly so in the Asia-Pacific region, where increasing numbers of cases of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) and major outbreaks of serious neurological disease associated with EV-A71 are occurring. Despite their importance, key aspects of the emergence, epidemiology, and evolution of EVs remain unclear, and most studies of EV evolution have focused on a limited number of genes. Here, we describe the genomic-scale evolution of EV-A viruses over an 18-month period sampled from mildly diseased pediatric patients admitted to a single hospital in Western Sydney, Australia. This analysis revealed the presence of eight viral serotypes—Coxsackievirus (CV) A2, A4, A5, A6, A8, A10, A16, and EV-A71—up to four different serotypes circulating at any given 1 month. Despite the absence of large-scale outbreaks, a high level of geographic and temporal mixing of serotypes was detected. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that multiple strains of the same serotype were present in the community and that this diversity was shaped by multiple entries into the Sydney population with only a single CV-A6 lineage exhibiting in situ transmission over the entire study period. Genomic-scale analyzes also revealed the existence of novel and historic EV recombinants. Notably, our analysis did not reveal any association between viral phylogeny, including serotype, and patient age, sex, or disease severity (for uncomplicated disease). This study highlights the contribution of EV-A viruses other than EV-A71 to mild EV disease, including HFMD, in Australia, and highlights the need for greater surveillance of these viruses to develop strategies for outbreak preparedness and vaccine design.
authors: Cobbin, J. C. A.;Britton, P. N.;Burrell, R.;Thosar, D.;Selvakumar, K.;Eden, J. S.;Jones, C. A.;Holmes, E. C.

title: Enhanced arbovirus surveillance by deep sequencing: identification of novel rhabdoviruses and bunyaviruses in Australian mosquitoes.
abstract: Viral metagenomics characterizes known viruses and identifies unknown viruses based on sequence similarities with previously sequenced viral genomes. A metagenomic approach was used to identify virus sequences that cause cytopathic effects in cultures of mammalian cells inoculated in Australian mosquitoes. Sequence comparisons reveal strains of Liao Ning virus (Reovirus, Seadornavirus) previously detected only in China, Stretch Lagoon virus (Reovirus, Orbivirus) that infect livestock, two new dimarhabdoviruses, Beaumont and North Creek viruses, and two new orthobunyaviruses, Murrumbidgee. took it out. and Salt Ash viruses. The new virus proteomes segregated by -50% from their previously genetically characterized closest viral relatives. Deep sequencing also produced the genomes of Warrego and Wallal viruses, the orbiviruses associated with kangaroo blindness, whose genomes have not been fully defined. This study highlights viral metagenomics in concert with conventional arbovirus surveillance to characterize known and novel arboviruses in field-collected mosquitoes. Follow-up epidemiological studies are necessary to determine whether new viruses infect humans. © 2013 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Coffey, L. L.;Page, B. L.;Greninger, A. L.;Herring, B. L.;Russell, R. C.;Doggett, S. L.;Haniotis, J.;Wang, C.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E. L.

title: Characterization of ncRNAs in Human Pathogenic Protists Using High-throughput Sequencing Technology
abstract: ncRNAs are key genes in many human diseases, including cancer and viral infection, and they also provide critical functions in pathogenic organisms such as fungi, bacteria, viruses and protists. Until now, identification and characterization of disease-associated ncRNAs has been slow or inaccurate, requiring many years of testing to understand complex RNA and protein gene relationships. High-throughput sequencing now offers the opportunity to characterize miRNAs, siRNAs, small nucleolar RNAs (snoRNAs) and long ncRNAs on a genomic scale, making it faster and easier to clarify how these ncRNAs contribute to the disease state. brings. However, this technology is still relatively new and ncRNA discovery is not a high priority application for modern bioinformatics. Here, we summarize the background concepts and practical approaches for ncRNA analysis using high-throughput sequencing and its relevance to understanding human diseases. As a case study, we focus on the parasitic protists Giardia lamblia and Trichomonas vaginalis, where great evolutionary distance means difficulties in comparing ncRNAs with those from model eukaryotes. A combination of biological, computational and sequencing approaches allowed easier classification of classes of ncRNAs such as snoRNAs, but also helped identify new classes. It is hoped that greater understanding of ncRNA expression and interaction may aid in the development of less drastic treatment for protist-based diseases.
authors: Collins, L. J.

title: The recently identified flavivirus Bamaga virus is horizontally transmitted by Culex mosquitoes and interferes with in vitro replication and in vivo transmission of West Nile virus.
abstract: Arthropod-derived flaviviruses such as yellow fever (YFV), Zika and dengue viruses continue to cause significant human diseases globally. These viruses are transmitted by mosquitoes when a female sucks an infected blood meal from a viremic vertebrate host and secretes the virus into a subsequent host. Bamaga virus (BgV) is a recently discovered flavivirus in Culex sitiens subgroup mosquitoes collected from the Cape York Peninsula of Australia. This virus phylogenetically clusters with the YFV group, but is potentially restricted in most vertebrates. However, a high level of replication in an opossum cell line (OC) indicates a potential relationship with marsupials. Vector competence of two members of Cx to determine whether BgV can be transmitted horizontally by mosquitoes. sitiens subgroup, Cx. annulirostris and Cx. sitiens was investigated for BgV. Eleven to thirteen days after ingesting an infectious blood meal, infection rates were 11.3% and 18.8% for Cx. annulirostris and Cx. sites respectively. The client transmitted the annulirostris virus at low levels (5.6% had overall BgV-positive saliva); The customer sitiens did not transmit the virus. When mosquitoes were intratoracially injected with BgV, the infection and transmission rates for both species were 100% and 82%, respectively. These results provided the first evidence that BgV can be transmitted horizontally by Cx. annulirostris, the primary vector of pathogenic zoonotic flaviviruses in Australia. We also evaluated whether BgV could interfere with in vitro replication and in vivo infection and transmission of superinfecting pathogenic Culex-associated flaviviruses. BgV significantly reduced the in vitro growth of Murray Valley encephalitis and West Nile (WNV) viruses. Prior infection with BgV by injection did not prevent WNV superinfection of Cx. annulirostris, significantly fewer BgV-infected mosquitoes can transmit WNV than mosquitoes injected with mock-injections. Overall, these data contribute to our understanding of flavivirus ecology, modes of transmission by Australian mosquitoes, and mechanisms of superinfection response.
authors: Colmant, A. M. G.;Hall-Mendelin, S.;Ritchie, S. A.;Bielefeldt-Ohmann, H.;Harrison, J. J.;Newton, N. D.;Oâ€™Brien, C. A.;Cazier, C.;Johansen, C. A.;Hobson-Peters, J.;Hall, R. A.;van den Hurk, A. F.

title: Viromes as genetic reservoirs for microbial communities in aquatic environments: A focus on antimicrobial resistance genes
abstract: Although studies of viromes isolated from aquatic environments are becoming more frequent, most are limited to the characterization of viral taxonomy. Bacterial readouts are abundant in viromes, but how much role this genetic material plays in aquatic microbiology ecology remains unclear. To this end, we have developed a useful approach for the characterization of viral and microbial communities of aquatic environments, focusing specifically on the identification of microbial genes harbored in viromes. Virus-like particles were isolated from water samples collected along the Lambro River from the spring to the highly urbanized area of Milan. Derived viromes were analyzed by shotgun metagenomic sequencing, looking for the presence, relative abundance of bacterial genes, focusing specifically on genes involved in antimicrobial resistance mechanisms. Antibiotic and heavy metal resistance genes were identified in all virome samples, with a high amount of reads assigned to cellular processes and signaling. Compared with those identified in the microbiome isolated from the same sample, virome data revealed differences in functional categories and their relative abundance. To confirm the role of the aquatic viral population in bacterial gene transfer, water-based mesocosms were disrupted or undisturbed by low dose tetracycline. Results from qPCR experiments revealed variation in abundance of tet genes in the virome and microbiome, highlighting the relevant role of viral populations in microbial gene mobilization.
authors: Colombo, S.;Arioli, S.;Neri, E.;Della Scala, G.;Gargari, G.;Mora, D.

title: Beyond the gut bacterial microbiota: The gut viroma
authors: Columpsi, P.;Sacchi, P.;Zuccaro, V.

title: Identification of an enterovirus recombinant by insertion of a torovirus-like gene during an outbreak of diarrhea in fattening pigs.
abstract: Diarrhea outbreaks on swine farms have caused great concern in Europe and the USA, as they could lead to dramatic swine losses. During a suspected outbreak of swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) in Belgium, we performed viral metagenomics to evaluate other potential viral pathogens. Although PEDV was detected, its low abundance indicated that other viruses were involved in the outbreak. Interestingly, one porcine bocavirus and several enteroviruses were most abundant in the sample. We also observed the presence of a gene-spliced porcine enterovirus genome, similar to a C28 peptidase gene found in toroviruses, which was confirmed using resequencing, bioinformatics and proteomic approaches. Moreover, the cleavage sites predicted for insertion indicate that this gene is expressed as a single protein rather than a fused protein. Recombination in enteroviruses has been reported as an important mechanism for generating genetic diversity, but gene insertions are extremely rare in viral families. While such intrafamilial recombinations are rare, our finding suggests that these events may contribute significantly to viral evolution.
authors: Conceicao-Neto, N.;Theuns, S.;Cui, T.;Zeller, M.;Yinda, C. K.;Christiaens, I.;Heylen, E.;Van Ranst, M.;Carpentier, S.;Nauwynck, H. J.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Modular approach to customize sample preparation procedures for viral metagenomics: a reproducible protocol for virome analysis.

title: Hepatitis E virus is prevalent in the swine population of the Lao People's Democratic Republic, and there is evidence of homogeneity with Chinese Genotype 4 human isolates.
abstract: The aim of this study was to determine the prevalence and genotypic range of Hepatitis E virus (HEV) in the pig population of the northern Lao People's Democratic Republic (PDR). We collected 181 fecal samples from 6-month-old domestic-breed pigs, and feces were stored in RNA stabilization buffer due to cold chain and transport limitations. Twenty-one (11.6%) pigs had detectable HEV RNA and 43.5% of backyard pig herds were infected. Based on a 240 base pair nucleotide sequence surrounding the junction of open reading frames 1, 2 and 3 (ORF1, ORF2 and ORF3), isolates were phylogenetically classified into genotype 4. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed distinct genetic groups of Lao HEV isolates and the two isolates. Clustered groups with human and porcine HEV isolates from China. This was the first study to show genotype 4 HEV in Lao PDR, indicating that pigs are a potential reservoir for human HEV infection. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Conlan, J. V.;Jarman, R. G.;Vongxay, K.;Chinnawirotpisan, P.;Melendrez, M. C.;Fenwick, S.;Thompson, R. C. A.;Blacksell, S. D.

title: Hepaciviruses quite different from African cattle
abstract: The hepatitis C virus (HCV; Hepacivirus genus) is a highly relevant human pathogen. Unique hepaciviruses (HV) have recently been discovered in animal hosts. No direct ancestor of HCV has been found, but the genetically closest animal HVs are found in horses. To investigate whether other peridomestic animals also carry HVs, we analyzed serum from Ghanaian cattle for HVs by reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR). Nine of 106 samples from different sampling sites contained HV RNA (8.5%) at median viral loads of 1.6×105 copies/ml. Infection seemed unrelated to cattle age and sex. Nearly complete genome sequencing of five representative viruses confirmed the taxonomic classifications. Bovine HVs formed two distinct phylogenetic lineages that differed up to 17.7% at the nucleotide level in the polyprotein-coding region, suggesting co-occurrence of different virus subtypes. A conserved microRNA122-binding site at the 5' internal ribosomal entry site suggested liver tropism of bovine HVs. Phylogenetic analyzes suggested the circulation of HVs in cattle for several centuries. Bovine HVs were genetically quite different from all other HVs, including HCV. HVs from genetically related equine and bovine hosts were not monophyletic, confirming host changes during evolution of the Hepacivirus genus. Similar to equine HVs, the genetic diversity of bovine HVs was low compared to HCV genotypes. This demonstrates the impact of the human-modified ecology of peridomestic animals on virus diversity. Further studies should explore the occurrence of cattle HVs in other geographic areas and breeds, virus pathogenicity in cattle, and potential exposure of human risk groups such as farmers, butchers and slaughterhouse workers.
authors: Corman, V. M.;Grundhoff, A.;Baechlein, C.;Fischer, N.;Gmyl, A.;Wollny, R.;Dei, D.;Ritz, D.;Binger, T.;Adankwah, E.;Marfo, K. S.;Annison, L.;Annan, A.;Adu-Sarkodie, Y.;Oppong, S.;Becher, P.;Drosten, C.;Drexler, J. F.

title: Next-generation sequencing as a tool for the study of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) macro and micro molecular epidemiology
authors: Cortey, M.;Diaz, I.;Martin-Valls, G. E.;Mateu, E.

title: Heterosubtypic neutralizing antibodies are produced by people vaccinated with the seasonal flu vaccine.
abstract: The target of neutralizing antibodies that protect against influenza virus infection is the viral protein HA. Genetic and antigenic variation in HA has been used to classify influenza viruses into subtypes (H1-H16). The neutralizing antibody response to influenza virus is thought to be specific for several antigenically related isolates of a given subtype. However, although heterosubtypic antibodies capable of neutralizing multiple influenza virus subtypes have been recently isolated from phage display libraries, it is unknown whether such antibodies are produced during an immune response to influenza virus infection or vaccine. We report here that following vaccination with seasonal influenza vaccine containing H1 and H3 influenza virus subtypes, some individuals produce antibodies that cross-react with H5 HA. By immortalizing IgG-expressing B cells from 4 individuals, we isolated 20 heterosubtypic mAbs that bind and neutralize viruses belonging to various HA subtypes (H1, H2, H5, H6 and H9), including pandemic A/California/07/09 H1N1. isolate. mAbs used different VH genes and carried a high frequency of somatic mutations. Except for one mAb that binds to the HA spherical head, all heterosubtypic mAbs bind to acid-sensitive epitopes in the HA root region. Four mAbs were evaluated in vivo and protected mice from challenge with influenza viruses representing different subtypes. These findings suggest that seasonal influenza vaccine can induce polyclonal heterosubtypic neutralizing antibodies that cross-react with swine-derived pandemic H1N1 influenza virus and highly pathogenic H5N1 virus.
authors: Corti, D.;Suguitan Jr, A. L.;Pinna, D.;Silacci, C.;Fernandez-Rodriguez, B. M.;Vanzetta, F.;Santos, C.;Luke, C. J.;Torres-Velez, F. J.;Temperton, N. J.;Weiss, R. A.;Sallusto, F.;Subbarao, K.;Lanzavecchia, A.

title: Evaluation of virulence of some strains of peste-des-petits-ruminant virus (PPRV) in experimentally infected West African dwarf goats.
abstract: Different isolates of peste-des-petits-ruminant virus (PPRV) from outbreaks in Africa and India were investigated for virulence in West African dwarf goats in Ivory Coast. Six groups of five animals received a lethal suspension of various virus strains at a concentration of 103 TCID50/mL, and goats were observed for 15 days after infection. Ivory Coast 89 (CI89), Guinea Conakry and Bissau Guinea PPRV strains caused a peracute disease; The India-Calcutta strain caused acute illness; The Sudan-Sennar strain produced acute to mild illness, while the Nigeria 75/1 wild-type strain induced mild illness and the animals recovered. The viruses examined contained PPRV samples from certain lineages based on the nucleoprotein PPRV genes. This experiment demonstrated that virulence characteristics can be a useful marker to aid in the classification of PPRV isolates. Â© 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Couacy-Hymann, E.;Bodjo, C.;Danho, T.;Libeau, G.;Diallo, A.

title: Genetic and antigenic variability in bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) isolates from Belgium
abstract: This report describes the genetic and antigenic variability of bovine viral diarrhea virus strains isolated in Belgium. A portion of the 5"² untranslated region and the 5" end of the gp53 (E2) coding sequence were amplified and sequenced by PCR. Phylogenetic analysis showed that most of the field isolates were separated into Ib or II genotypes. Of the 28 field isolates, only one belonged to genotype Ia. Interestingly, some type I strains were equally different from type Ia and Ib strains and clustered into additional subtypes within genotype I. Immune sera from young calves experimentally inoculated with field isolates first identified on the basis of their sequence were used in two-way neutralization experiments. . The results clearly differentiated type I from type II strains, although some degree of cross-neutralization was observed. Within type I, the new clusters were not antigenically distinguishable from the more common type Ib strains or type Ia NADL strains, suggesting that the BVDV genotype I is antigenically homogeneous. The isolation of BVDV type I and II strains from cell lines and a bovine vaccine demonstrates that molecular epidemiology surveillance for BVDV is warranted. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Couvreur, B.;Letellier, C.;Collard, A.;Quenon, P.;Dehan, P.;Hamers, C.;Pastoret, P. P.;Kerkhofs, P.

title: Animal genomics in natural reservoirs of infectious diseases
abstract: Natural reservoirs of viruses, such as wild bats, birds, rodents, and non-human primates, are often non-model organisms and, until recently, offer limited opportunities for in-depth study. Next-generation sequencing provides a way to partially circumvent this limitation, as the methods required for data collection and analysis are largely species-independent. Comparative genomics and other "omics" provide new opportunities to study the structure and function of diverse biological systems of wild species that would otherwise be inaccessible. The genomes of natural reservoir hosts can help identify dominant pathways of virus-host interaction and reveal differences between susceptible and resistant organisms, populations, and species. This is of great scientific interest and may also provide a resource for the rational design of treatments for viral diseases in humans and livestock. In this way, we will 'learn from nature' and one day apply this knowledge to create disease-resistant livestock or to develop new treatment and prevention strategies. Reservoir host genomics will also open up the possibilities for developing new vaccines for wildlife, helping to develop new diagnostic platforms, and having broad implications for developmental and evolutionary biology. In this review, the authors focus on the natural reservoir hosts of viral pathogens, although most of the discussion points are equally applicable to natural reservoirs of pathogenic bacteria, fungi or other parasites.
authors: Cowled, C.;Wang, L. F.

title: pseudovirus infection in Oklahoma beagle dogs
abstract: Pseudorabies are caused by Suid herpesvirus 1, a member of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily. Although pigs are the natural host of Pseudorabies virus (PRV), the virus has a wide host range and can cause fatal encephalitis in many species. The United States achieved PRV-free status in 2004 after the virus was eradicated from domestic pig herders, but the virus is still present in wild pig populations. The present report describes PRV infection in 3 dogs used to hunt wild boars. The dogs developed clinical signs including facial abrasions, shortness of breath, vomiting, diarrhoea, ataxia, muscle stiffness and facial itching with death. Two were euthanized and one died approximately 48 hours after the onset of clinical signs. Significant histological changes consisted of neutrophilic trigeminal ganglioneuritis with neurophagia and suspicious intranuclear inclusion bodies. Pseudorabies virus was isolated from fresh tissues from 2 dogs, and immunohistochemistry detected the virus in the third dog. Virus sequencing and phylogeny based on available GenBank sequences revealed that the virus is a field strain, possibly closely related to a cluster of PRV strains previously identified in Illinois. Despite being eradicated from domestic pigs in the United States, PRV is present in wild pig populations and therefore should continue to be considered a possible cause of disease in dogs and other pets with compatible clinical histories and signs. Constant surveillance is necessary to prevent reinfection of PRV to domestic pigs. Â© 2011 American Association of Veterinary Laboratory Diagnostics.
authors: Cramer, S. D.;Campbell, G. A.;Njaa, B. L.;Morgan, S. E.;Smith, Ii S. K.;McLin, Iv W. R.;Brodersen, B. W.;Wise, A. G.;Scherba, G.;Langohr, I. M.;Maes, R. K.

title: Chronic arthritis in goats caused by a retrovirus
abstract: A virus was isolated from an adult goat with chronic arthritis and demonstrated to belong to the retrovirus group by electron microscopy and biochemical methods. Inoculation of the virus to the offspring of specific pathogen-free goats from cesarean section produced arthritic lesions similar to those in spontaneous disease. Virus was re-isolated from experimentally induced lesions.
authors: Crawford, T. B.;Adams, D. S.;Cheevers, W. P.;Cork, L. C.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza a(h5n1) viruses at the animal-human interface in Vietnam, 2003-2010
abstract: Mutation and reclassification of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses at the animal-human interface remains a major concern for the emergence of viruses with pandemic potential. To understand the relationship between H5N1 viruses circulating in poultry and viruses isolated from humans, extensive phylogenetic and molecular analyzes of viruses collected from both hosts in Vietnam between 2003 and 2010 were performed. We examined the temporal and spatial distribution of human cases relative to H5N1 poultry outbreaks and characterized amino acid substitutions in each gene segment identified in humans relative to closely related viruses from avian hosts. Six emagglutinin sequences and 8 genotypes were identified in humans, and all were originally identified in poultry. Various amino acid mutations have been identified throughout the genomes of viruses isolated from humans; this points to the potential of avian viruses infecting humans to rapidly acquire molecular markers associated with mammalian adaptation and antiviral resistance.
authors: Creanga, A.;Hang, N. L. K.;Cuong, V. D.;Nguyen, H. T.;Phuong, H. V. M.;Thanh, L. T.;Thach, N. C.;Hien, P. T.;Tung, N.;Jang, Y.;Balish, A.;Dang, N. H.;Duong, M. T.;Huong, N. T.;Hoa, D. N.;Tho, N. D.;Klimov, A.;Kapella, B. K.;Gubareva, L.;Kile, J. C.;Hien, N. T.;Mai, L. Q.;Davis, C. T.

title: Multiple guideline 2.3.2.1 Emergence of influenza A (H5N1) virus subgroups and detection of new reassortants in Vietnam
abstract: Phylogenetic analyzes of 169 influenza A(H5N1) virus genomes were performed for samples collected through active surveillance and outbreak responses in Vietnam between September 2010 and September 2012. Section 1.1 viruses persisted in the southern regions, while section 2.3.2.1 had three genetically distinct subsets. It is found in northern and central Vietnam. The identification of each subgroup corresponded to the detection of new reassortants, probably due to their overlapping nationwide circulation. While the previously identified genotypes 1.1 and A/Hubei/1/2010-like 2.3.2.1 remained the dominant viruses detected, A/Hubei/1/2010-like (HA, NA, PB2, PB1, PA, NP) and A/duck-like /Vietnam/NCVD-885/2010-like (M, NS) viruses and a virus determined to have A/duck/Vietnam/NCVD-885/2010-like HA, NA, A/Hubei/1/2010-like PB2 and PA having the genes PB1 and NP. In addition, viruses like 2.3.2.1 item A/Hong Kong/6841/2010, first detected in mid-2012, PB2 and PA like A/Hubei/1/2010 and PB1 like A/duck/Vietnam/NCVD-885/2010 NP, NA, M, NS genes. © 2013.
authors: Creanga, A.;Thi Nguyen, D.;Gerloff, N.;Thi Do, H.;Balish, A.;Dang Nguyen, H.;Jang, Y.;Thi Dam, V.;Thor, S.;Jones, J.;Simpson, N.;Shu, B.;Emery, S.;Berman, L.;Nguyen, H. T.;Bryant, J. E.;Lindstrom, S.;Klimov, A.;Donis, R. O.;Davis, C. T.;Nguyen, T.

title: Major molecular aspects of human coronaviruses and their homology with animal coronavirus strains
abstract: After the discovery of several new human respiratory pathogens in 1965, a group of viruses known since 1937 but not called coronaviruses began to emerge. It has been noted that some newly identified human respiratory viruses, designated avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), mouse hepatitis virus (MHV), and OC43 and 229E, have similar appearances. These viruses exhibited a characteristic fringe of large, distinctive, petal-shaped peplomers or spikes resembling a crown. They were named 'coronavirus' after this feature. Shortly thereafter, several new viruses were added to the group of coronaviruses that cause disease in pigs, rats, turkeys, dogs, cats, and cattle. The diversity of infected animal species and the multitude of organ systems involved have made Coronaviridae one of the most important viral families in veterinary medicine. The two human coronaviruses (HCV), HCV-OC43 and HCV-229E, belong to different antigenic groups. HCV-OC43 shares antigenic correlation with neonatal calf diarrhea coronavirus (NCDCV), porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus (HEV), and MHV. HCV-229E is antigenically associated with porcine infectious gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) and canine coronavirus (CCV). As a group, coronaviruses contain a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA genome of 27 to 31 kb with an estimated molecular weight of 6 x 106 to 8 x 106 daltons. In infected cells, the viral RNA genome is first transcribed into a full-length negative-strand RNA, which is transcribed into a positive-sense genomic RNA and six to eight subgenomic mRNAs by a leader-prime transcription mechanism.
authors: Cristallo, A.;Gambaro, F.;Battaglia, M.;Cereda, P. M.

title: Two loci controlling genetic cellular resistance to avian leukosis-sarcoma viruses
abstract: Female chickens known to be heterozygous for resistance to subgroups A and B of avian leukosis-sarcoma viruses were mated with males known to be homozygously resistant to both. The strain was tested for resistance to representative viruses of subgroups A, B and transiently identified C both on the chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) and in tissue culture. The divergence rates of resistance to subgroup A and B viruses were consistent with the previously proposed hypothesis that single autosomal recessive genes control resistance to each subgroup. Mixed infection on CAM and replicated plate infection in tissue culture with subgroups A and B viruses showed that resistance to subgroups A and B was independently inherited. Tests with viruses provisionally classified as subgroup C showed that they consisted largely of a mixture of subgroup A and B viruses, or particles with both host range specificity. However, virus stocks of subgroup C category, as well as some stocks classified as subgroup B, produced few pocks or foci on individuals known to be resistant to subgroup A and B viruses. These stocks of Rous sarcoma virus are claimed to carry 1% to 10% of a true subgroup C virus.
authors: Crittenden, L. B.;Stone, H. A.;Reamer, R. H.;Okazaki, W.

title: Phylogenetic analysis and pathogenicity of H3 subtype avian influenza viruses isolated from live poultry markets in China.
abstract: H3 subtype influenza A virus is one of the main subtypes threatening both public and animal health. However, the evolution and pathogenicity of the H3 avian influenza virus (AIV) circulating in domestic birds in China remains largely unclear. In this study, seven H3 AIVs (four H3N2 and three H3N8) were isolated from poultry in the live poultry market (LPM) in China. Phylogenetic analyzes of the whole genomes showed that all viruses clustered in the Eurasian lineage, except that the N8 genes of the two H3N8 isolates fell into the North American lineage. Surprisingly, the N8 gene of one H3N8 and two H3N2 isolates PB2, PB1, NP and NS has close association with that of the highly pathogenic H5N8 viruses circulating in Korea and the United States, contributing to the internal genes of H3-like AIV. thinks it can be found. highly pathogenic H5N8 viruses. The phylogenetic tree and antigenic cross-reactivity results of the HA gene indicated that two antigenically different H3 viruses were circulating in LPM in China. Most H3 viruses were replicated in mouse lung and nasal turbinate without prior adaptation, and representative H3 viruses infect chickens without causing clinical signs. Reclassification of H3 subtype influenza viruses warrants continued surveillance at LPM in China.
authors: Cui, H.;Shi, Y.;Ruan, T.;Li, X.;Teng, Q.;Chen, H.;Yang, J.;Liu, Q.;Li, Z.

title: Phylogeny, Pathogenicity and Transmission of H5N1 Avian Influenza Viruses in Chickens
abstract: We analyzed five H5N1 avian influenza viruses (AIVs) isolated from different birds in China in 2012. Based on the whole genome sequences, we divided the viruses into four genotypes. The DKE26, GSE43 and DKE53 viruses belonged to Genotypes 1–3, respectively. CKE93 and CKE96 viruses were classified into Genotype 4. Genotype 1–3 corresponds to viruses containing the HA gene of section 2.3.2 and Genotype 4 is the virus carrying the HA gene of section 7.2. To better understand the pathogenicity and transmission of viruses, we infected chickens with 103 EID50 /0.1 ml GSE43 (clan 2.3.2) or CKE93 (c. 7.2) virus. Our results revealed that 6 of 7 specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens inoculated with GSE43 virus died 7 days before infection, but all SPF chickens inoculated with CKE93 virus survived infection. Both GSE43 and CKE93 viruses proliferated systemically in chickens. Virus titers of GSE43 virus in the tested organs were clearly higher than those of CKE93 virus. Our results revealed that the pathogenicity and replication of GSE43 in chickens was much higher than that of CKE93. GSE43 virus can be transmitted between chickens, but CKE93 cannot be transmitted between chickens by pure contact. Thus, different H5N1 AIV strains had variable pathogenicity and transmission abilities among chickens. Our study adds to the knowledge of the pathogenic variations of common H5N1 viruses.
authors: Cui, J.;Qu, N.;Guo, Y.;Cao, L.;Wu, S.;Mei, K.;Sun, H.;Lu, Y.;Qin, Z.;Jiao, P.;Liao, M.

title: Identification and genetic characterization of a novel circular single-stranded DNA virus in a human upper respiratory tract sample.
abstract: Metagenomic analysis by high-throughput sequencing is a tool for detecting both known and novel viruses. Using this technique, a novel circular single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) virus genome was discovered in the respiratory secretions of a fever traveller. The virus, designated human respiratory-associated PSCV-5-like virus (HRAPLV), has a genome containing 3,018 bases, with two main putative ORFs that reversibly encode capsid (Cap) and replicase (Rep) protein and are separated by two intergenic regions. A root loop structure was predicted in the larger intergenic region (LIR). The predicted amino acid sequences of the Cap and Rep proteins of HRAPLV showed the highest identity to those of the pig feces-associated circular virus 5 isolate CP3 (PoSCV 5) (53.0% and 48.9%, respectively). The host tropism of the virus is unknown, and further studies are warranted to determine whether this novel virus is associated with human disease.
authors: Cui, L.;Wu, B.;Zhu, X.;Guo, X.;Ge, Y.;Zhao, K.;Qi, X.;Shi, Z.;Zhu, F.;Sun, L.;Zhou, M.

title: Analysis of microRNA expression profiles in DEF cells infected with Duck Tembusu virus
abstract: Duck Tembusu virus (DTMUV), belonging to the Flaviviridae family, is a single-stranded positive sense RNA virus. Since April 2010, the DTMUV epidemic in southeastern provinces of China has caused great economic losses. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play important regulatory roles in viral infection through binding to host target genes or viral genomes. To better understand the molecular mechanisms of virus-host interaction, we here describe miRNA expression profiles in DTMUV-infected and uninfected DEF cells by high-throughput sequencing. A total of 287 known and 63 new miRNAs were identified. 48 miRNAs, including 26 known miRNAs and 22 novel miRNAs, were differentially expressed in response to DTMUV infection. Among these miRNAs, 37 miRNAs were up-regulated and 11 miRNAs were down-regulated. 9 miRNAs were randomly selected for validation by qRT-PCR experiment. The results of the qRT-PCR experiment were consistent with the sequencing data. GO enrichment showed that the predicted targets of these differentially expressed miRNAs are mainly involved in the regulation of the immune system, cellular process and metabolic process. KEGG pathways analysis revealed that predicted target genes are involved in various signaling pathways, such as the Wnt signaling pathway, TGF-beta signaling pathway, mTOR signaling pathway, and FoxO signaling pathway. This is the first study to evaluate changes in miRNA expression in DEF cells upon DTMUV infection. Our findings provide important clues to better understand DTMUV-host interaction.
authors: Cui, M.;Jia, R.;Huang, J.;Wu, X.;Hu, Z.;Zhang, X.;Wang, M.;Zhu, D.;Chen, S.;Liu, M.;Zhao, X.;Wu, Y.;Yang, Q.;Zhang, S.;Liu, Y.;Zhang, L.;Yin, Z.;Jing, B.;Cheng, A.

title: Sensitive surveillance for viral respiratory pathogens: virome capture sequencing for detection and genomic characterization of severe acute respiratory infections.
authors: Cummings, M. J.;Tokarz, R.;Bakamutumaho, B.

title: Sensitive surveillance for viral respiratory pathogens: virome capture sequencing for detection and genomic characterization of severe acute respiratory infection in Uganda.
abstract: Background: Vulnerable public health is a new set of methods for targeting disease prevention and mitigation interventions to high-risk subpopulations. We implemented a syndromic surveillance-sensitive public health strategy for severe acute respiratory infection (SARI) in Uganda, combining spatio-temporal analytics with genomic sequencing to detect and characterize potentially epidemic viral respiratory pathogens. Methods: Using a national surveillance network, we identified patients with unexplained, influenza-negative SARI between 2010 and 2015. Spatio-temporal analyzes were performed retrospectively to identify unexplained SARI clusters. Within clusters, respiratory viruses were detected and characterized in naso and oropharyngeal swab samples using a novel oligonucleotide probe capture (VirCapSeq-VERT) and high-throughput sequencing platform. The linkage with conventional epidemiological strategies further characterized the transmission dynamics of the pathogens identified. Results: Of the 2,901 unexplained SARI cases, 9 were identified, constituting 301 (10.4%) cases. Clusters were more likely to occur in urban areas and during the biennial rainy season. Within the detected clusters, we identified an unrecognized outbreak of measles-related SARI; sequence analysis included co-circulation of endemic genotype B3 and genotype D4, possibly imported from England. We also identified a possible cluster of hospital SARIs associated with a novel picobirnavirus most closely related to swine and dromedary viruses. Conclusions: Using a sensitive approach to public health surveillance, we detected and characterized the genomics of vaccine-preventable and zoonotic respiratory viruses associated with clusters of severe respiratory infections in Uganda. Future studies are needed to evaluate the feasibility, scalability, and impact of implementing similar approaches during real-time public health surveillance in low-income settings.
authors: Cummings, M. J.;Tokarz, R.;Bakamutumaho, B.;Kayiwa, J.;Byaruhanga, T.;Owor, N.;Namagambo, B.;Wolf, A.;Mathema, B.;Lutwama, J. J.;Schluger, N. W.;Lipkin, W. I.;O'Donnell, M. R.

title: Single-choice type: Integrating human and animal medicine into a revolutionary paradigm
abstract: One health is a concept since early civilizations that supports the view that there is no great distinction between animal and human medicine. This shared vision was almost completely forgotten in the early 20th century, although it continued throughout the 19th century. It is now experiencing a renaissance to coincide with the awakening of the role evolutionary biology plays in human and animal health, including sexually transmitted infections (STIs). A number of STIs in humans have similar infections in animals; likewise, both humans and animals have STIs specific to each mammalian camp. These similarities and differences offer opportunities for basic medical and public health studies, including evolutionary insights that can be gleaned from ongoing interdisciplinary research, particularly with current molecular analytical tools, in an era that may turn into a golden age of mutually helpful discovery. Â© 2011 New York Academy of Sciences.
authors: Currier, R. W.;Steele, J. H.

title: Preliminary characterization of D'Aguilar virus and three Palyam group viruses new in Australia
abstract: Between 1974 and 1980, 424 viruses were isolated from insects or the blood of sentry cattle at CSIRO's Long Pocket Laboratories, Division of Animal Health, of which 165 cross-reacted with D'Aguilar virus (an Australian). Palyam group virus) in a complement fixation test. Neutralization tests were used to classify these viruses into four serotypes, with isolates D'Aguilar B8112, CSIRO 11, CSIRO 58 and CSIRO 82 as type strains. The last three were new to Australia. Like other orbiviruses, these four serotypes were partially susceptible to treatment with chloroform or chloroform. Neutralizing antibodies to D'Aguilar, CSIRO 11 and CSIRO 58 viruses were detected in sera from cattle, buffalo, deer and sheep, but not in sera from humans, horses, pigs or marsupials. Antibodies to the CSIRO 82 virus were detected in 85% of the 26 tested buffaloes and 0.4% of the 495 cattle serum tested. In Australia, antibody distribution for the D'Aguilar, CSIRO 11 and CSIRO 58 viruses remained within the distribution range of Culicoides brevitarsis, the insect from which these viruses are most commonly rescued. The antibody distribution for CSIRO 82 virus isolated from a pool containing C. schultzei and C. peregrinus remained within the much more restricted distribution ranges of these strains. None of these viruses have been associated with the disease.
authors: Cybinski, D. H.;St George, T. D.

title: Third genome size category of avian paramyxovirus serotype 1 (Newcastle disease virus) and its evolutionary implications
abstract: The aim of the study was to determine whether there is a relationship between molecular models and virus evolution. Therefore, the whole genome sequence of two different apathogenic Newcastle disease virus (NDV) strains was determined and a third category of genome size was recognized, comprising 15,198 nucleotides. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that two major divisions have occurred throughout the history of NDV, resulting in three genome size categories. An ancient split in the primitive reservoir (wild waterfowl species) gave rise to two basal sister clades, class I and II, with genomes of 15,198 (due to the 12-nucleotide insert in the phosphoprotein gene) and 15,186 nucleotides, respectively. Only the ancestors of class II viruses colonized chicken populations and later evolved into virulent forms. These occurred multiple times, resulting in an early lineage [including genotypes I-IV and H33(W)] with a genome size of 15,186 nucleotides. A second division occurred in the secondary (chicken) host in the 20th century. This resulted in the branching of a branch (including the last genotypes V-VIII, consisting of pathogenic viruses only) with the simultaneous insertion of six nucleotides into the 5'2 non-coding region of the nucleoprotein gene, thereby further increasing the genome size. 15,192 nucleotides. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: CzeglÃ©di, A.;UjvÃ¡ri, D.;Somogyi, E.;Wehmann, E.;Werner, O.;Lomniczi, B.

title: Characterization of cowpox-like orthopox virus causing a fatal infection in man
abstract: In August 1990, an orthopox virus (OPV) was isolated from a severe case of generalized infection with a fatal outcome in an 18-year-old immunocompromised man. In this communication, we provide a detailed characterization of the type of virus causing it. Based on the different epitope configurations detected by the various monoclonal antibodies, the isolate can be distinguished from other OPV strains and is classified as a cowpox virus (CP). This classification was validated by constructing a species-specific PCR assay and physical maps for the restriction enzymes HindIII and XhoI. Based on serological data from neutralization experiments, blocking-ELISAs and Western blot analysis evidence provided that the infection was acquired from a stray cat.
authors: Czerny, C. P.;Zeller-Lue, C.;Eis-HÃ¼binger, A. M.;Kaaden, O. R.;Meyer, H.

title: Outbreaks of zoonotic vaccinia virus in Brazil
abstract: Vaccinia virus (VACV) was used as a live vaccine during the WHO-led smallpox eradication campaign in the second half of the 20th century. The program ended with the eradication of the disease, one of the most important achievements of modern medicine. Interestingly, one of the key factors in the successful vaccination campaign - VACV itself - is poorly understood regarding its natural reservoirs, evolutionary history and origins, often considered extinct as a naturally occurring virus. However, orthopox viruses other than variola virus are known to have been circulating in Brazil since the early 1960s. More specifically, VACV has been associated with naturally acquired infections in humans, cattle, and possibly other reservoirs since 1999, when cattle vaccine outbreaks began to be identified consistently from year to year. In this article, we list and discuss the most important VACV outbreaks that have occurred in Brazil over the past 20 years. Phylogenetic issues are considered, as recent studies have indicated large genetic variance among isolates. Both published and recent clinical and epidemiological data are presented. Â© 2011 Future Medicine Ltd.
authors: Da Fonseca, F. G.;Kroon, E. G.;Nogueira, M. L.;De Souza Trindade, G.

title: Novel bovine papillomavirus type discovered by rolling circle amplification combined with next-generation sequencing
abstract: Fifteen bovine papillomavirus (BPV) types have now been identified and classified into four genera: Deltapapillomavirus, Epsilonpapillomavirus, Dyoxipapillomavirus, and Xipapillomavirus. Here we report the complete genome sequence of a novel type of BPV (BPV 04AC14) derived from a papillomatous lesion. The genome is 7,282 bp long and exhibits the classical genetic organization and motifs of Papillomaviridae members. Maximum likelihood phylogenetic analyzes revealed that BPV 04AC14 clustered with members of the genus Xipapillomavirus. The nucleotide sequence of the L1 capsid protein of the novel BPV is closely related to its counterpart, BPV3, with which it shares 79% homology. These findings suggest that this virus is a new type of BPV of the genus Xipapillomavirus.
authors: Da Silva, F. R. C.;Cibulski, S. P.;Daudt, C.;Weber, M. N.;GuimarÃ£es, L. L. B.;Streck, A. F.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.;Canal, C. W.

title: Zika virus: What do we know about viral nature, transmission mechanisms and neurological consequences?
abstract: The Zika virus epidemic, which started in Brazil in 2014, has spread to more than 30 countries and regions in Latin America, leading to a rapid increase in the incidence of newborns with microcephaly and adults with neurological complications. At the start of the epidemic, little was known about the morphology of Zika virus, its genome structure, its routes of transmission, and its potential to cause neurological malformations and disorders. With the advancement of basic science, discoveries of the mechanisms of strain variability, viral transfer to the fetus, and neurovirulence have been published. These will certainly lead to the development of strategies to block vertical viral transmission, neuronal invasion and pathogenesis in the near future. This article reviews the current literature on Zika virus infections to provide a holistic view of its etiology and pathogenesis. We discuss the history and epidemiology of Zika virus in Brazil, viral structure and taxonomy, old and newly described modes of transmission, and neurological consequences of infection.
authors: Da Silva, L. R. C.;De Souza, A. M.

title: A Case of Fatal Augmentation Disease in a Dog: Immunolocalization of the Virus and Complete Genome Sequencing
abstract: Louping-ill (LI), caused by the Louping-ill virus (LIV), causes an often fatal encephalitis, affecting mainly sheep and red grouse (Lagopus lagopus scotica), but is also seen in other species. An adult male Border collie dog was definitively diagnosed with lethal LI, and the lesion profile, LIV antigen distribution, and the complete genome sequence of the responsible LIV were investigated to determine whether it differed significantly from sheep-derived LIV. No gross lesion was present. Histological lesions were limited to the central nervous system and consisted of lymphocytic perivascular cuffs, glial foci, neuronal necrosis, and neuronophagia. Immunlocalization of the viral antigen showed that it is present only in small amounts in neurons. These histological and immunohistochemical findings were similar to those reported in affected sheep. Compared with published whole genome sequences of sheep-derived LIV, only minor differences were present and phylogenetically, the virus clustered individually between a subsection containing Scottish strains, LIV 369/T2 and G, and another subsection containing a British isolate LIV A. . shares a common progenitor with LIV A from the dog. These findings indicate that there is no dog-specific LIV strain, dogs are susceptible to sheep-associated LI strains, and there is an increased prevalence of ticks and thus exposure to LIV is safe. Dogs may require effective vaccination.
authors: Dagleish, M. P.;Clark, J. J.;Robson, C.;Tucker, M.;Orton, R. J.;Rocchi, M. S.

title: Evolutionary analysis of Tembusu virus: Evidence for emergence of a dominant genotype
abstract: We recently identified Tembusu virus (TMUV) as the causative agent of the duck contagious disease that has spread in China since 2010. A recent study has shown a potential case of human infection by TMUV, citing the evolution of TMUV in particular. Since no information is available regarding the evolution of TMUV, we performed extensive phylogenetic analyzes using TMUV's largest collection of full open reading frame (ORF) sequences. Our results showed that two virus strains were associated with the 2010 outbreak in China, and lineage II, specifically sublineage II-c, emerged as the dominant lineage currently circulating. We conclude that the most recent common ancestor (MRCA) of this TMUV emerged around 1996. Evidence of natural recombination was also detected in TMUV. Molecular adaptation analyzes revealed that strong negative selection shaped the evolution of TMUV, while a set of codons exposed to positive pressure were also identified. Our work has revealed, for the first time, the evolutionary history and character of TMUV and will be helpful for vaccine and diagnostic development.
authors: Dai, L.;Li, Z.;Tao, P.

title: Next-generation sequencing strategies to characterize the turkey genome
abstract: The Hindi genome sequencing project was launched in 2008 and was mainly based on next generation sequencing (NGS) technologies. In our initial studies, we used a synergistic combination of 2 NGS platforms (Roche/454 and Illumina GAII), detailed bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) maps, and unique assembly tools to sequence and assemble the genome of the domesticated turkey, Meleagris gallopavo. Since the initial release in 2010, efforts have continued to improve genome assembly, gene annotation, and genomic analysis. The first assembly construct (2.01) represented approximately 89% of the genome sequence with 17X depth of coverage (931 Mb). Sequence contigs were assigned to 30 of 40 chromosomes and approximately 10% of the assembled sequence corresponded to unassigned chromosomes (ChrUn). The array has been refined through both genome-wide and domain-focused sequencing, including shotgun and double-ended sequencing, and targeted sequencing of chromosomal regions with low or missing coverage. These additional efforts improved the sequence assembly and resulted in 2 sequential genome constructs with higher genome coverage (25X/Build3.0 and 30X/Build4.0) with a total available sequence of 1,010 Mb. Also, BAC with end sequences assigned to Z/W and MG18 (MHC) chromosomes, ChrUn, or not inserted into the previous construct were isolated, deeply sequenced (Hi-Seq) and included in the final construct (5.0). A comprehensive set of RNA samples was collected from female and male turkeys at various developmental stages to aid in the explanation and to construct a gene expression atlas of major tissues. Transcriptome sequencing data (using Illumina Hi-Seq) will provide information to improve the final assembly and ultimately improve sequence annotation. The most recent sequence covers more than 95% of the turkey genome and should provide a much more advanced gene level annotation, making it a valuable resource for studying genetic variation underlying economically important traits in poultry.
authors: Dalloul, R. A.;Zimin, A. V.;Settlage, R. E.;Kim, S.;Reed, K. M.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolates from outbreak cases in commercial chickens and wild pigeons in Ethiopia.
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND), caused by virulent avian paramyxovirus type 1, is one of the most important diseases responsible for devastating epidemics in poultry flocks in Ethiopia. However, little is known about the genetic characteristics of Newcastle disease viruses (NDVs) circulating in commercial chickens and wild birds. In this study, we characterized isolates from poultry farms (n = 8) and wild pigeons (n = 4) from outbreaks suspected of ND between 2012 and 2014. NDVs isolated from pathological specimens by grafting into embryonated chicken eggs were biologically characterized by conventional intracerebral pathogenicity indices (ICPI) and genetically based on Phylogenetic analysis of partial F-gene sequences (260 bp) spanning the cleavage site. The ICPI values of isolates obtained from chickens ranged from 0.9 to 1.8; whereas the ICPI of pigeon isolates was 1.4. All isolates contained multiple basic amino acids in the inferred cleavage site of the fusion protein, which is typical of virulent viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the partial cleavage region of the F-gene (260 bp) showed that all virus sequences from pigeons were identical and clustered in the VIh genotype, while virus sequences from chickens clustered together in the VIf genotype. The similarity between viruses obtained from chickens and viruses obtained from pigeons varies between 82.5% and 85.6%. This indicates that different subgenotypes of genotype VI are circulating in the chicken and wild pigeon population in Ethiopia. This warrants further work to understand the role of wild birds in NDV epidemiology in Ethiopia and highlights the importance of continued surveillance in both wild poultry and domestic poultry.
authors: Damena, D.;Fusaro, A.;Sombo, M.;Belaineh, R.;Heidari, A.;Kebede, A.;Kidane, M.;Chaka, H.

title: Characterization of Hungarian porcine circovirus 2 genomes associated with PMWS and PDNS cases
abstract: The authors report data from the first survey on the incidence of postweaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS) and swine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome (PDNS) in Hungary. A specific PCR method was developed for the detection of Porcine circovirus 2 (PCV-2) and this method has proven to be suitable for diagnostic purposes. PCR scanning of organ samples from pigs suspected of being affected by PMWS or PDNS revealed the presence of PCV-2 in 80% of cases. Six PCV-2 genomes from Hungarian isolates were fully sequenced. Phylogenetic comparison with all available PCV-2 sequences showed that swine circoviruses circulating in Hungary are more variable than in many other European countries. The two Hungarian strains clustered together with the Spanish strains forming a separate group; the other two fell into a common group with the French, UK and Dutch strains, while the other two strains showed the closest association with two of the three known German PCV-2 sequences.
authors: DÃ¡n, Ã;MolnÃ¡r, T.;Biksi, I.;GlÃ¡vits, R.;Shaheim, M.;Harrach, B.

title: Application of SureSelect target enrichment system for next-generation sequencing to obtain the complete genome sequence of bovine leukemia virus
abstract: In this study, the SureSelect target enrichment system for Illumina Multiplexed Sequencing was applied to proviral DNA sequencing of bovine leukemia virus (BLV). Whole genomic DNA sequences of four Vietnamese BLV strains were successfully obtained in less than one week with high read depth values and 100% genome coverage in all sequenced samples. This work provides the first complete Vietnamese BLV genome sequences. Their genetic variability and phylogenetic relationships were also analyzed and compared with that of 28 complete BLV genome sequences from different parts of the world. The results obtained provided new insights into the genetic diversity of the BLV tax gene and also allowed us to identify nucleotide mutations in the gene that may not have been detected with the currently available commercial detection kit.
authors: Dao, T. D.;Bui, V. N.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Mizutani, T.;Ogawa, H.;Imai, K.

title: A new research and development paradigm for rift valley fever and zoonotic disease control
abstract: Although Rift Valley fever is a disease that, with its broader societal effects, disproportionately affects vulnerable populations who are vulnerable to economic and environmental challenges, the Rift Valley fever virus has been neglected by major global donors and disease control programs since its discovery in 1931. We describe recent outbreaks affecting humans and animals and discuss the severe socioeconomic impacts on affected populations and the slow pace of development of new vaccines. We also discuss the mixed global response, greatly fueled by the virus's classification as a potential bioterrorism agent and its potential to move beyond traditional east African borders. We advocate a refocus on strategy with increased global collaboration and a greater sense of urgency and investment that focuses on an equity-based approach that is prioritized by need for funding and research inspired by the principles of equity and social justice.
authors: Dar, O.;McIntyre, S.;Hogarth, S.;Heymann, D.

title: Development and validation of a highly sensitive real-time PCR assay for rapid detection of parapoxviruses
abstract: Parapoxviruses (PaPVs) cause widespread infections in ruminant animals worldwide. All PaPVs are zoonotic and can infect humans after direct or indirect contact with infected animals. Here we report the development and validation of a highly sensitive real-time PCR assay for rapid detection of PaPVs. The new assay (referred to as the RVSS assay) was specific for PaPVs only and had no cross-reactivity to other pox viruses. Using a recombinant plasmid as a positive control, the analytical sensitivity of the assay was determined as 16 genome PaPV copies per assay. Amplification efficiency estimate (91-99%), inter-assay and inter-assay variability estimation (standard deviation [SD]: 0.28-1.06 and 0.01-0.14, respectively), and operator variability estimate (SD: 0.78 between labs and 0.28 between operators in a lab) ) was within the acceptable range. Diagnostic specificity was evaluated on 100 samples from healthy normal animals, and all but 1 tested negative (99%). Diagnostic susceptibility (DSe) was evaluated in 77 clinical specimens (skin/shell) from infected sheep, goats and cattle and all tested positive (100%). The assay was multiplexed with beta-actin as an internal positive control and the multiplex assay displayed the same DSe as the single assay. Further characterization of PaPV samples by nucleotide sequencing of PCR products following species-specific real-time PCR and conventional PCR revealed the presence of Orf virus not only in sheep and goats, but also in 1 bovine animal. Validated RVSS testing demonstrated high specificity, sensitivity, reproducibility, and robustness, which are critical for laboratory detection of PaPVs.
authors: Das, A.;Ward, G.;Lowe, A.;Xu, L.;Moran, K.;Renshaw, R.;Dubovi, E.;Reising, M.;Jia, W.

title: Characterization of bovine enteric caliceal-like virus, Newbury agent 1
abstract: The bovine enteric calicivirus-like virus, Newbury agent 1 (NA1), was characterized to determine whether it is a member of the Caliciviridae and to establish its antigenic relationship with the established bovine enteric calicivirus Newbury agent 2 (NA2). Solid-phase immune electron microscopy (SPIEM) allowed the quantification of NA1 virions and identification of stool samples with optimal virus levels. The NA1 particles were 36.6 nm in diameter, had an indistinct surface structure resembling human small round viruses (SRSVs) and a buoyancy density of 1.34 g ml-1. A single capsid protein of 49.4 kDa was detected by Western blotting in purified NA1 preparations prepared from post-infection but not pre-infection stool samples and post-infection but not pre-infection sera. NA1 was antigenically unrelated to bovine enteric calicivirus NA2 produced by SPIEM. These features were consistent with the NA1 classification within the Caliciviridae, but showed heterogeneity in the capsid composition of bovine enteric caliciviruses. Copyright (C) 2000 European Federation of Microbiology Societies.
authors: Dastjerdi, A. M.;Snodgrass, D. R.;Bridger, J. C.

title: How many types of papillomavirus may not be detected in papilloma lesions?
abstract: coinfection of at least seven papillomavirus (PV) types was detected by next-generation sequencing (NGS) of randomly prepared rolling circle amplification (RCA) products of a bovine (Bos taurus) papilloma lesion from the Brazilian Amazon region. Six possible new PV types that could not be detected by widely used PCR protocols were identified. Overall L1 nucleotide identities were less than 90% compared to the PV strains and strains described. L1 nucleotide BLAST sequence hits indicated that each new strain was associated with Beta, Gamma, Dyokappa, Dyoeta and Xipapillomavirus, as well as two possible new unclassified genera. Our results show that the use of NGS is relevant for the detection and characterization of distantly related PV and is of great importance in coinfection studies. This information will help us understand the biology and pathogenesis of PV and will also contribute to disease control. We can also conclude that there are many unknown circulating PVs.
authors: Daudt, C.;da Silva, F. R.;Streck, A. F.;Weber, M. N.;Mayer, F. Q.;Cibulski, S. P.;Canal, C. W.

title: Borna disease: up-to-date information and virus detection in France
abstract: For over two centuries, Borna's disease (BD) has been described as an infectious meningoencephalomyelitis that occurs sporadically in Central Europe, affecting horses and sheep. Over the past decade, the epidemiology of BD has been debated. First, its geographic distribution appears larger than previously thought. Second, the disease can affect a large number of warm-blooded animal species, including humans. The etiologic agent is Borna disease virus (BDV), an enveloped, non-segmented negative-stranded RNA virus classified in the novel virus family Bornaviridae (order Mononegavirales). It can cause severe clinical signs of encephalitis with striking behavioral disturbances and cause death. The BDV genome has recently been detected in the blood and brain of several animal species (horses, cattle, foxes) in France.
authors: Dauphin, G.;Legay, V.;Pitel, P. H.;Zientara, S.

title: Diagnostic phylogenetics reveals a novel Porcine circovirus 2 cluster
abstract: Porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2) was common in pigs in the United States before PCV2-related disease (PCVAD) emerged in 2006. Limited nucleotide sequence of open reading frame 2 (ORF2) encoding the capsid, the single structural protein, two genotypes, PCV2a and PCV2b. Later, PCV2c and mutant PCV2b or PCV2d were also identified. However, extensive PCV2 ORF2 sequence databases in veterinary diagnostic laboratories have not been systematically analyzed to determine the genetic diversity of field isolates. Here, we interrogated >1100 PCV2 ORF2 nucleotide sequences to assess population diversity and genetic variation. We identified a novel PCV2 genotype that differs significantly from all known PCV2 mainly in ORF2. Notably, ORF2 contains a unique carboxyl terminal amino acid addition resulting in an ORF2 of 238 amino acids. All other PCV2 ORF2 proteins are 233 or 234 aa long. Phylogenetic analysis shows it to be older than other PCV2 genotypes. The findings demonstrate the value of analyzing routine diagnostic laboratory sequence databases in population genetic analyzes of animal pathogens.
authors: Davies, B.;Wang, X.;Dvorak, C. M. T.;Marthaler, D.;Murtaugh, M. P.

title: Dilemma of rare events: swine epidemic diarrhea virus in North America
abstract: The swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) has been recognized as a swine pathogen for 40 years, but was not detected in the Western Hemisphere until 2013. Initially causing a relatively mild and sporadic illness, PEDV has more recently been associated with outbreaks of severe diarrheal disease in Asia and subsequently in North America. PEDV shares some important features with two major pandemic viruses (swine reproductive and respiratory virus; porcine circovirus type 2) that have high mutation rates and high host specificity and appear to have been present in the porcine virome for decades before its emergence. cause serious clinical illness. A unique feature of PEDV in North America has been the implication of feed as a means of transmission, particularly with concerns about porcine-derived ingredients. The importance of relatively rare events contributing to both the emergence and transmission of PEDV is discussed in relation to approaches to the management of associated risks.
authors: Davies, P. R.

title: The shotgun experience sequencing the 134 kilobase-pair DNA molecule
abstract: So far, large DNA sequences have been obtained by cloning fragments of the target molecule into plasmid, cosmid or bacteriophage lambda vectors. The 134 kbp DNA sequence of channel catfish virus was determined with relative ease by shotgun cloning of random pieces of genomic DNA directly into a bacteriophage M13 vector, sequencing with dideoxynucleotide chain termination, and compiling the data using Staden's database manipulation programs. Experience gained during this effort shows that sequences substantially larger than 134 kbp can be obtained using this approach.
authors: Davison, A. J.

title: DNA sequence of frog adenovirus
abstract: The frog adenovirus (FrAdV-1) genome was sequenced and found to be the smallest of all known adenovirus genomes. The resulting sequence is 26163 bp in size and contains a significant direct repeat near the right terminal; this implies that it was derived by recombination from a parent genome of only 25517 bp. The closest relative of FrAdV-1 was proven to be turkey adenovirus 3, a previously unknown avian adenovirus with a close relative. Sequence comparisons showed that the two viruses had equivalent gene complements, including a gene whose product was associated with sialidases. Phylogenetic analyzes supported the establishment of a fourth adenovirus genus containing these two viruses, in addition to the established Mastadenovirus and Aviadenovirus genus and the proposed Atadenovirus genus. Sixteen genes were found to be conserved among these four lineages, possibly inherited from an ancestral adenovirus.
authors: Davison, A. J.;Wright, K. M.;Harrach, B.

title: Metagenomic analysis of the turkey gut RNA virus community
abstract: Viral enteric disease is an ongoing economic burden for poultry producers worldwide, and despite significant research, no single virus has emerged as a possible causative agent and target of prevention and control efforts. Historically, electron microscopy has been used to identify suspected viruses, with many small, round viruses escaping classification based on morphology alone. National and regional studies using molecular diagnostics have revealed that suspected viruses are constantly circulating in United States poultry, with many viruses occurring simultaneously and in healthy birds. High-throughput nucleic acid pyrosequencing is a powerful diagnostic technology capable of identifying the complete genomic repertoire contained in a complex environmental sample. We used the Roche/454 Life Sciences GS-FLX platform to compile an RNA virus metagenome from turkey flocks experiencing intestinal disease. This approach yielded a large number of sequences homologous to viruses in the BLAST nr protein database, many of which have not been described in turkeys. Our analysis of this turkey gut RNA metagenome focuses specifically on turkey-derived members of the Picornavirales, Caliciviridae, and turkey Picobirnaviruses. Â© 2010 Dayet licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Day, J. M.;Ballard, L. L.;Duke, M. V.;Scheffler, B. E.;Zsak, L.

title: Comparative analysis of gut bacterial and RNA viral communities from sentinels housed in selected broiler farms
abstract: There is great interest in characterizing the complex microbial communities in poultry guts and understanding the effects of these dynamic communities on microbes of importance to poultry performance, disease status, animal welfare and human health. Research characterizing avian enteric virus has identified novel avian viruses, but the roles these viruses play in disease and performance problems are not yet fully defined. The complex bacterial community in the poultry gut influences gut development, immune status and animal health, each of which can be an indicator of overall performance. Current metagenomic research was conducted to provide insight into the colonization of specific pathogen-free chickens by enteric microorganisms under field conditions and to compare the pre-contact gut microbiome with the altered microbiome following contact with field-raised poultry. Analysis of intestinal virus from contact birds ("series") placed on farms revealed colonization by members of the Picornaviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Reoviridae and Astroviridae absent or in proportionally lower numbers in pre-contact birds. Analysis of the sentinel gut bacterial community revealed an altered community in post-contact birds, particularly by members of the Lachnospiracea/Clostridium and Lactobacillus families and genera. Members of the avian enteric Reoviridae and Astroviridae are well characterized and have historically been implicated in poultry enteric disease; Members of Picobirnaviridae and Picornaviridae have been described in birds and the avian gut only relatively recently, and their role in recognized disease syndromes and bird performance in general has not been established. This metagenomic analysis provided insight into the colonization of the poultry gut by enteric microbes circulating in commercial broiler flocks and identified enteric viruses and virus communities warranting further study to understand their role in avian gut health and disease.
authors: Day, J. M.;Oakley, B. B.;Seal, B. S.;Zsak, L.

title: Molecular and phylogenetic analysis of a novel Picobirnavirus originating from Turkey.
abstract: previous metagenomic analysis of the turkey gut RNA virus community identified novel enteric viruses that may be involved in poultry enteric diseases or performance problems noted in the field. As part of the molecular characterization of these novel enteric viruses, a reverse transcriptase-PCR diagnostic assay was developed targeting a novel turkey-derived picobirnavirus (PBV) that was originally identified in a pooled gut sample from North Carolina turkey flocks. Little detailed molecular information is available on the Picobirnaviridae family, particularly PBVs identified in avian species. This diagnostic assay targets the turkey PBV RNA-dependent RNA polymerase gene and produces an 1135 bp amplicon. This assay was validated using in vitro transcribed RNA and tested using archived enteric samples collected from turkey flocks in the southeastern United States. Furthermore, a phylogenetic analysis suggests that turkey PBV is unique because it is not closely grouped with the well-known PBV genogroups circulating in mammalian hosts. Â© American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Day, J. M.;Zsak, L.

title: Investigation of Turkey Enteric Picornavirus and Its Relationship with Enteric Disease in Poultry
abstract: Previous investigations of the viral community in the avian gastrointestinal tract had revealed a number of new and partially identified enteric viruses. It is clear that the avian gut viral community is minimally characterized and not fully understood. Research on the microbiome of the avian gut has provided some insight into the geographic distribution and rapidly evolving taxonomy of avian enteric picornaviruses. The present research was undertaken to produce a comparative metagenomic analysis of intestinal virus from a healthy flock of turkeys from a field placed flock. This research revealed a series of enteric picornaviruses found in commercial birds in the field that are not completely absent in the healthy flock. A novel molecular diagnostic assay was used to monitor shedding of field strains of turkey enteric picornavirus in commercial flocks inoculated with picornavirus-positive intestinal homogenates prepared from turkeys with moderate enteric disease. The spread of this new enteric picornavirus in commercial poultry resulted in a significant reduction in weight gain, suggesting that this common resident in the turkey intestine may cause performance problems or intestinal disease in the field.
authors: Day, J. M.;Zsak, L.

title: Archived Molecular Characterization of Enteric Picornaviruses in Turkey and Chicken Samples from the United States
abstract: Recent metagenomic analyzes of enteric viromes in turkeys and chickens have revealed complex viral communities consisting of multiple viral families. New avian picobirnaviruses (family Picobirnaviridae), multiple-tailed phage species (family Siphoviridae) and unspecified avian enteric picornaviruses (family Picobirnaviridae) are particularly important. These metagenomic analyzes have revealed the existence of well-known groups of enteric viruses, such as chicken and turkey astroviruses (Astroviridae family) and avian rotaviruses, in addition to the largely unidentified and thus relatively poorly understood avian enteric viral families. reoviruses (family Reoviridae). The order Picornavirales is a group of viruses in flux, particularly among avian picornaviruses, as several new genera have been recently identified based on community analysis of enteric viromes from poultry and other avian species worldwide. Our previous research on turkey enteric picornaviruses suggests that avian enteric picornaviruses may contribute to the enteric disease syndromes and performance problems commonly observed in turkeys in the Southeastern United States. This report describes the final phylogenetic analysis of turkey and chicken enteric samples archived from 2004 to the present at the Southeastern Poultry Research Laboratory, and is the first step to place these new avian picornaviruses within the larger Picornaviridae family.
authors: Day, J. M.;Zsak, L.

title: High global cyclovirus diversity among dragonflies
abstract: Members of the family Circoviridae, particularly the genus Circovirus, were thought to infect only vertebrates; however, members of a sister group under the same family, the proposed genus Cyclovirus, have recently been detected in insects. To explore the diversity of cycloviruses and to better understand the evolution of these novel ssDNA viruses, we present here five cycloviruses isolated from three dragonfly species (Orthetrum sabina, Xanthocnemis zealandica and Rhionaeschna multicolor) collected in Australia, New Zealand and the USA. respectively. The genomes of these five viruses share similar genome structure with other cycloviruses, with a circular ~1.7 kb genome and two main bidirectionally transcribed ORFs. Genomic sequence data collected during this study were combined with all cyclovirus genomes available in public databases to identify conserved motifs and regulatory elements in intergenetic regions, as well as to identify diversity and recombinant regions within their genomes. The genomes reported here represent four different strains of cyclovirus, three of which are novel. Our results confirm that cycloviruses circulate widely in winged insect populations; Of the eight different cyclovirus species detected in dragonflies to date, some show a wide geographic distribution. Recombination analysis revealed both interspecies and interspecies recombination events among cycloviruses, including genomes from different sources (eg goat meat and human feces). Similar to other well-characterized circular ssDNA viruses, recombination may play an important role in cyclovirus evolution. © 2013 SGM.
authors: Dayaram, A.;Potter, K. A.;Moline, A. B.;Rosenstein, D. D.;Marinov, M.;Thomas, J. E.;Breitbart, M.;Rosario, K.;ArgÃ¼ello-Astorga, G. R.;Varsani, A.

title: Detection of hepatitis E virus in liver, mesenteric lymph node, serum, bile and feces of naturally infected pigs affected by different pathological conditions
abstract: The aim of this study is to detect hepatitis E virus (HEV) in different samples from naturally infected pigs and to genetically characterize the detected strains. Serum, bile, liver, lymph nodes, and feces were collected from 69 animals, 1 week to 4 months old, with different pathological conditions. Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was performed to detect the histopathology of HEV and tissues. Positive RT-PCR samples were sequenced and phylogenetically analyzed. HEV was detected in at least one sample in 26 (37.7%) of 69 animals. Bile was the most common positive sample, followed by mesenteric lymph nodes, liver, faeces, and serum. HEV was detected in 1 (n = 7), 2 (n = 8) and 3 (n = 11) month old pigs.
