A total of 22 (31.9%) of 69 pigs had mild to moderate hepatitis, and 15 of these were HEV RT-PCR positive in at least one of the samples tested. live pigs such as liver, mesenteric lymph node and bile. Phylogenetic analyzes confirmed that all identified Spanish swine HEV strains belonged to genotype III. Therefore, genotype III strains are present in a relatively high proportion of pigs 1 to 3 months old. Through this study, it cannot be ruled out whether concomitant infections will affect HEV distribution in infected pigs. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: de Deus, N.;Seminati, C.;Pina, S.;Mateu, E.;MartÃ­n, M.;SegalÃ©s, J.

title: Recently, antigenic and molecular heterogeneity in swine flu A(H1N1) virus isolates, with possible implications for vaccination policy.
abstract: To investigate the occurrence of antigenic drift in swine flu A(H1N1) viruses and the coupling between epidemic and vaccine strains, 26 virus isolates and previous outbreaks from respiratory disease outbreaks among training pigs in the Netherlands in the 1995/1996 season were studied using serological and molecular methods. In contrast to porcine H3N2 viruses, no significant antigenic shift was observed in porcine H1N1 viruses isolated from the late 1980s to 1996. However, a marked antigenic and genetic heterogeneity was recently detected among the 26 porcine H1N1 virus strains in hemagglutination inhibition tests and nucleotide sequence analyses. Interestingly, the observed antigenic and molecular variants were not randomly distributed between farms. This finding indicates the independent introduction of different swine H1N1 virus variants in the various farms of the study and points to a marked difference in the epidemiologies of human and swine flu viruses. The observed heterogeneity may hinder the control of swine flu by vaccination and indicates that the efficacy of existing swine flu vaccines should be reassessed and the antigenic reactivity of swine flu viruses should be monitored regularly. Â© 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: De Jong, J. C.;Heinen, P. P.;Loeffen, W. L. A.;Van Nieuwstadt, A. P.;Claas, E. C. J.;Bestebroer, T. M.;Bijlsma, K.;Verweij, C.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.;Rimmelzwaan, G. F.;Fouchier, R. A. M.;Kimman, T. G.

title: Evolutionary origin of 2A-like sequences in Totiviridae genomes
abstract: In recent years, there has been a significant increase in the number of new species potentially belonging to the Totiviridae family. Many of these new viruses are not yet covered by the Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) official classification. In this study, a phylogenetic analysis involving novel sequences of Totiviridae candidates revealed a clade containing Giardiavirus and a wide variety of novel totiviruses infecting arthropods, protozoa and mollusks. This extended Giardiavirus lineup includes two monophyletic groups, one containing the Giardia lamblia virus (GLV) (GLV-like group) grouped with viruses that infect arthropods and vertebrates, and the other the previously proposed Artivirus group (IMNV-like group). Screening members of the GLV-like group to search for genomic elements already identified in the IMNV-like group revealed the presence of regions with a high affinity for 2 A-like oligopeptides, mainly in a particular subset of arthropod viruses. that these viruses retain their ancestral characteristics. The presence of these "pseudo2 A-sites" associated with phylogenetic reconfiguration indicates that these sequences emerged at a decisive stage for viral evolution. If they are changed to functional 2A-like sequences, an irreversible pathway will be initiated to increase genome complexity.
authors: de Lima, J. G. S.;Teixeira, D. G.;Freitas, T. T.;Lima, J. P. M. S.;Lanza, D. C. F.

title: Akabane, Aino and Schmallenberg virus – where and what do we know about the role of domestic ruminant hosts and Culicoides vectors in virus transmission and overwintering?
abstract: Akabane, Aino, and Schmallenberg virus belong to the Simbu serogroup of Orthobunyaviruses and depend on Culicoides vectors for spread among ruminant hosts. While infections of adults are mostly asymptomatic or associated with only mild symptoms, transplacental transmission of these viruses to the developing fetus can have significant teratogenic effects. Research focusing mainly on congenital malformations has established a relationship between the developmental stage at which a fetus is infected and the outcome of an Akabane virus infection. Available data suggest that a similar correlation holds for Schmallenberg virus infections, but is not yet completely conclusive. Experimental and field data also show that Akabane virus is definitely more effective in inducing congenital malformations in cattle than Aino and Schmallenberg virus. The mechanism by which these Simbu viruses pass annual periods of very low vector abundance in temperate climatic regions has not been defined. Annual windblown reintroduction of infected sandflies with year-round vector activity from tropical endemic areas has been proposed, as has overwintering in adult perennial sandflies. However, experimental and field data indicate that the role of vertical virus transmission in the ruminant host cannot be excluded as a wintering mechanism at this time. Further studies are needed on the biology of Culicoides and specific groups of transplacentally infected newborn ruminants without gross malformations to elucidate this issue.
authors: De Regge, N.

title: Zoonotic genotype 3 Recommendation for a new subtype of hepatitis E virus: HEV-3l
abstract: Nearly complete genomic sequences of two hepatitis E virus (HEV) strains detected from feces of infected pigs were obtained. Phylogenetic analysis of complete coding regions and p-spacing comparisons showed close association with the French pig strain FR-SHEV3c, which was detected in 2006 (p-distance value 0.101), belonging to HEV-3 but not assigned to any known subtype. The three HEV sequences showed relatively high nucleotide distances (p-distance > 0.129) compared to other identified HEV subtype references and unclassified strains. The HEV classification criteria and high sequence similarity suggest that these strains can be assigned to a putative new subtype of genotype 3, HEV-3l.
authors: De Sabato, L.;Lemey, P.;Vrancken, B.;Bonfanti, L.;Ceglie, L.;Vaccari, G.;Di Bartolo, I.

title: Bovine papular stomatitis affecting dairy cows and milkers in midwestern Brazil
abstract: Bovine papular stomatitis virus (BPSV) is a parapoxvirus associated with papular and erosive lesions in the mouth, lip and oral mucosa of cattle. The udders of milked cows are sometimes affected and the infection is often transmitted to humans. This report describes an outbreak of BPSV infection affecting cows and including humans in midwestern Brazil. The disease was observed in neighboring small hand-milking farms and affected 20 milking cows. Symptoms included painful reddish papules, ulcers, and scabies proliferative lesions on the nipples with a clinical course of 7-12 days. Affected cows showed severe local pain that did not allow milking to be completed. Histologically, parakeratotic hyperkeratosis with acanthosis, spongiosis and adjacent focal widespread ulcers and multifocal inflammatory infiltrate was observed in the epidermis. Eosinophilic inclusion bodies were noted in the cytoplasm of epithelial cells. Staff milking affected cows developed lesions on the hands, painful papules that progressed to ulcerative and scabies lesions within 4-7 days. A polymerase chain reaction using a series of pan-parapoxvirus primers for the B2L gene performed on DNA extracted from scabs amplified a 590-bp product that, when sequenced, revealed 99%, 85%, and 84% similarities to BPSV, Pseudocowpox virus, and Orf virus respectively. A phylogenetic tree was constructed based on the B2L sequence showing that the virus clustered with BPSV isolates. Although clinical cases consistent with BSPV infection have frequently been described in Brazil, this report describes the agent associated with bovine and human disease in the country. Â© 2012 American Association of Veterinary Laboratory Diagnostic Specialists.
authors: de Sant'Ana, F. J. F.;Rabelo, R. E.;Vulcani, V. A. S.;Cargnelutti, J. F.;Flores, E. F.

title: Laboratory decision making during the 1997-1998 classic swine fever epidemic in the Netherlands
abstract: The National Reference Laboratory for classical swine fever (CSF) virus in the Netherlands examined more than two million samples for CSF virus or serum antibody during the 1997-1998 CSF epizootic. The enormous sample size and prevalence of border disease (BD) virus and bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) virus infections in Dutch pig herds required the laboratory to focus diagnostic efforts on generating CSF-specific test results throughout the eradication campaign. Detection of 82% of the 429 outbreaks was achieved using direct immunofluorescence and peroxidase testing (FAT/IPA) in combination with samples (tonsils) from clinically suspected pigs. This suggests that in most outbreaks, pigs have clinical signs recognized by farmers and/or veterinarians that indicate the presence of CSF virus in a herd of pigs. A positive diagnosis of 74% of all tissue samples (tonsils) collected from infected pig farms was made by FAT. More than 140,000 heparinized blood samples were analyzed with virus isolation resulting in the detection of 4.5% of infected flocks. CSF virus was isolated in approximately 29% of all blood samples collected from pigs from infected or suspected farms. Various serological studies, each conducted in a different framework, led to the detection of 13.5% of the total number of epidemics. Detection of CSF virus antibody in serum was performed by semi-automatic blocking ELISA. Approximately 28.5% of the sera that reacted in the ELISA were classified as positive for CSF virus neutralizing antibody and 26.5% were classified as positive for other pestiviruses following virus neutralization test (VNT). We concluded that the two identified CSF laboratory diagnostic methods were decisive in the eradication campaign: the first was FAT for screening diseased pigs; and second, ELISA and VNT when millions of predominantly healthy pigs need to be screened for the presence of CSF serum antibody. However, when examining samples from swine herds with a high prevalence of non-CSF pestiviruses, decision-making can be severely hampered based on the results generated by both methods.
authors: De Smit, A. J.;Eble, P. L.;De Kluijver, E. P.;Bloemraad, M.;Bouma, A.

title: Araçatuba virus: A vaccine-like virus associated with infection in humans and cattle
abstract: We describe the Araratuba virus, a vaccine-like virus associated with a cowpox-like outbreak in a dairy herd, and a related case of human infection. Diagnosis was based on virus growth characteristics, electron microscopy, and molecular biology techniques. Molecular characterization of the virus was performed using polymerase chain reaction amplification, cloning and DNA sequencing of conserved orthopoxvirus genes such as vaccine growth factor (VGF), thymidine kinase (TK), and hemagglutinin. We used the VGF-homologous and TK gene nucleotide sequences to construct a phylogenetic tree for comparison with other smallpox viruses. The gene sequences showed 99% homology with the vaccinia virus genes and clustered together with the virus isolated in the phylogenetic tree. Aracatuba virus is very similar to Cantagalo virus, showing the same signature deletion in the gene. Aracatuba virus may be a novel vaccine-like virus or may represent the spread of Cantagalo virus.
authors: De Souza Trindade, G.;Da Fonseca, F. G.;Marques, J. T.;Nogueira, M. L.;Mendes, L. C. N.;Borges, A. S.;PeirÃ³, J. R.;Pituco, E. M.;Bonjardim, C. A.;Ferreira, P. C. P.;Kroon, E. G.

title: New parvoviruses from wild and domestic animals in Brazil provide new insights into parvovirus distribution and diversity
abstract: Parvoviruses (family Parvoviridae) are small, single-stranded DNA viruses. Many parvoviral pathogens of medical, veterinary and ecological importance have been identified. In this study, we used high-throughput sequencing (HTS) to investigate the diversity of parvoviruses infecting wild and domestic animals in Brazil. We identified 21 parvovirus sequences (including twelve nearly complete genomes and nine partial genomes) in samples derived from rodents, bats, opossums, birds, and cattle in the states of Pernambuco, São Paulo, Paraná, and Rio Grande do Sul. These sequences were investigated using phylogenetic and distance-based approaches, thereby classifying them into eight parvovirus species (six of which had not been previously described) representing six different genera in the Parvovirinae subfamily. Our findings expand the known biogeographic range of previously characterized parvovirus species and the known host range of three known parvovirus genera (Dependovirus, Aveparvovirus and Tetraparvovirus). Furthermore, our research provides a window into the ecological dynamics of parvovirus infections in vertebrates and reveals that many parvovirus genera contain well-defined sublineages that circulate widely throughout the world within certain taxonomic host groups.
authors: De Souza, W. M.;Dennis, T.;Fumagalli, M. J.;Araujo, J.;Sabino-Santos, G.;Maia, F. G. M.;Acrani, G. O.;Carrasco, A. O. T.;Romeiro, M. F.;Modha, S.;Vieira, L. C.;Ometto, T.;Queiroz, L. H.;Durigon, E. L.;Nunes, M. R. T.;Figueiredo, L. T. M.;Gifford, R. J.

title: Neurological Clinical Symptoms in Cattle with Astrovirus-Associated Encephalitis
authors: Deiss, R.;Selimovicâ€Hamza, S.

title: Neurological Clinical Symptoms in Cattle with Astrovirus-Associated Encephalitis
abstract: Background: Evidence for neurotropic astroviruses has been established using new genetic methods in cattle suffering from a previously unknown viral encephalitis. Objective: To describe the clinical manifestations observed in cattle with astrovirus-associated encephalitis. Animals: Eight cattle (4 cows, 3 heifers and 1 bull from 4 different breeds) admitted to the Ruminant Clinic due to neurological disease and 1 cow examined in the field. Methods: Cases were selected on the basis of neuropathological diagnosis of nonsuppurative encephalitis, positive in situ hybridization result for astrovirus, and availability of physical and neurological evaluation results. If available, laboratory results were evaluated. Results: The most common clinical symptoms were decreased environmental awareness (7), cranial nerve dysfunction (5), and lying on the back (5). The cow seen in the field was the only animal with serious behavioral changes. The number of cells in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) increased in 4 animals and the protein concentration increased in 3 of the 5 samples. In 1 case, the presence of astrovirus in a CSF sample could be identified by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction. Other laboratory abnormalities were nonspecific. Conclusions and Clinical Significance: Astrovirus infection may be an important differential diagnosis in cattle with clinical signs of brain disease and should be considered after other causes have been excluded. The clinical and epidemiological significance of encephalitis associated with astrovirus infection should be further investigated.
authors: Deiss, R.;Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Seuberlich, T.;Meylan, M.

title: Swine vesicle disease: characteristics of the virus strain France 1/73
abstract: France 1/73 swine vesicular disease strain has the biological and physicochemical characteristics of an Enterovirus. Single cycle growth in the IBR'S2 cell can be detected in as little as 2 hours 30 minutes and the maximum is reached in 5 hours. Replication takes place in the cytoplasm of the cell. A specific green fluorescence in the cytoplasm can be demonstrated within four hours of infection by fluorescent immunofluorescence. The virions obtained by this cell system were concentrated with PEG and analyzed by ultracentrifugation on a sucrose gradient. Thus, the two particle populations are separated. The first one has a sedimentation coefficient of 150S and the other 75S. After isopicnic centrifugation, a density of 1.34 g/cm3 is attributed to the heavier particles and 1.30 g/cm3 to the lighter particles. Electron microscopic examination shows that the particles have a diameter between 30 and 32 nm. The stain penetrates all particles with a density of 1.30 g/cm3 and corresponds to empty capsids. An effective specific antiserum has been prepared in pigs with these viral antigens. It can be used for all serological reactions. Therefore, it is used for differential diagnosis with complement fixation tests (classical reaction at 37°C) using vesicular fluid from sick pigs. An inactivated oil adjuvant vaccine was also prepared. The rate of protection of vaccinated animals is between 75% and 100% with a probability of 95%.
authors: Delagneau, J. F.;Guerche, J.;Adamowicz Ph. andPrunet, P.

title: Characteristics of Bovine Parvovirus (strain 86/Alger). Type of nucleic acid stability and one step growth
authors: Delagneau, J. F.;Vincent, J.

title: Sparkling viruses - A world apart
abstract: Foamy viruses (FVs) or spumaviruses were first described in cell cultures from monkey kidneys in the early 1950s. Subsequently, FVs were isolated in various mammalian species such as cats, cattle and horses. It is quite common in non-human primates and does not occur naturally in humans, although a few cases of monkey-to-human transmission have been described. Interestingly, the replication strategy of FVs differs in many ways from that of other retroviruses, presenting features closely related to pararetroviruses exemplified by hepatitis B virus (HBV), but also closely related to yeast retrotransposons. These features led to the creation of a separate viral subfamily by the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy in 2002; spumaretrovirinae. Â© 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Delelis, O.;Lehmann-Che, J.;SaÃ¯b, A.

title: Microbial diversity of a full-scale UASB reactor applied to poultry abattoir wastewater treatment: integration of 16S rRNA gene amplicon and shotgun.
authors: Delforno, T. P.;JÃºnior, G. V. Lacerda;Noronha, M. F.

title: Microbial diversity of a full-scale UASB reactor applied to poultry slaughterhouse wastewater treatment: integration of the 16S rRNA gene amplicon and shotgun metagenomic sequencing.
abstract: The 16S rRNA gene amplicon and whole-genome shotgun metagenomic (WGSM) sequencing approaches were used to investigate broad-spectrum profiles of microbial composition and metabolic diversity from a full-scale UASB reactor applied to poultry abattoir wastewater treatment. Data were generated using the MiSeq 2Â Ã—Â 250Â bp and HiSeq 2Â Ã—Â 150Â bp Illumina sequencing platforms for 16S amplicon and WGSM sequencing, respectively. Each approach revealed a distinct microbial community profile, with Pseudomonas and Psychrobacter as the dominant genera for the WGSM dataset and Clostridium and Methanosaeta for the 16S rRNA gene amplicon dataset. Virome characterization revealed the existence of two viral families with Bacteria and Archaea, Myoviridae and Siphoviridae as hosts. A wide functional diversity was found, with a predominance of genes involved in acetone, butanol, and ethanol synthesis; and one-carbon metabolism (eg, methanogenesis). Genes related to acetotropic methanogenesis pathways were more abundant than methylotrophic and hydrogenotrophic, confirming the taxonomic results showing the prevalence of the acetotropic genus Methanosaeta. Furthermore, the dataset showed several metabolic genes involved in the sulfur, nitrogen, iron and phosphorus cycles, and that many species can act on all cycles. BLAST analysis against the Antibiotic Resistance Genes Database (ARDB) revealed that the microbial community contained 43 different types of antibiotic resistance genes, some of which were associated with chicken growth promotion (eg, bacitracin, tetracycline, and polymyxin).
authors: Delforno, T. P.;Lacerda JÃºnior, G. V.;Noronha, M. F.;Sakamoto, I. K.;Varesche, M. B. A.;Oliveira, V. M.

title: Physico-chemical characterization of bovine transient fever virus as a member of the Rhabdoviridae family
abstract: This study of the physico-chemical properties of bovine ephemeral fever virus was initiated to determine whether it could be classified as a rhabdovirus. In contrast to the normal bullet-shaped morphology of some rhabdoviruses, virus particles are usually cone-shaped or lighter variants than bullet-shaped. Virion contains six proteins with single-stranded RNA and moles that precipitate at 42S. wt. 164, 101, 64, 53, 43 and 29 x 103. Protein P101 is located on the surface of the virus and is glycosylated. It is removed by treatment of virus particles with trypsin. The nucleoprotein, protein P64, has been found to be a phosphoprotein like N protein of rabies virus, whereas NS in vesicular stomatitis virus is phosphorylated protein. The virus harvest contains imperfect interfering particles. The particles are cone-shaped forms as short as about one-third the length of the infectious virion and resemble imperfectly interfering particles of vesicular stomatitis virus in morphology. These particles interfere with the replication of bovine transient fever virus, but not the serotype of Indiana vesicular stomatitis virus. They contain single-stranded RNA that collapses at 18 to 20S. The particles appear to have the same protein composition as that found in the virus particle. The physico-chemical properties of the bovine transient fever virus justify its inclusion in the Rhabdoviridae family. The protein composition differs in detail from that found for vesicular stomatitis and rabies viruses, but is similar to that found for Obodhiang and kotonkan, two rabies serogroup viruses isolated from insects in Africa.
authors: Della-Porta, A. J.;Brown, F.

title: ICTV virus classification profile: Birnaviridae
abstract: Birnaviridae is a family of viruses with bipartite dsRNA genomes of approximately 6 kbp forming icosahedral, non-enveloped virions. The family includes four genera, three of which (Aquabirnavirus, Avibirnavirus, and Blosnavirus) infect vertebrates (except mammals), while members of the fourth genus (Entomobirnavirus) infect insects. Each genus contains 1-3 species. Infectious pancreatic necrosis virus of salmonids and infectious bursal disease virus of poultry are two economically important viruses. This is a summary of the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV) Report on the Birnaviridae taxonomy available at www.ictv.global/report/birnaviridae.
authors: Delmas, B.;Attoui, H.;Ghosh, S.;Malik, Y. S.;Mundt, E.;Vakharia, V. N.;Lefkowitz, E. J.;Davison, A. J.;Siddell, S. G.;Simmonds, P.;Sabanadzovic, S.;Smith, D. B.;Orton, R. J.;Kuhn, J. H.

title: Animal virus discovery: opportunities for improving animal health, understanding zoonoses, and vaccine development
abstract: Characterization of viral genomes has accelerated due to advances in DNA sequencing technology. Sources and molecular methods of animal samples for the identification of novel viral pathogens and steps to determine their pathogenicity are listed. The difficulties of predicting future interspecies transitions are highlighted by the wide diversity of known viral zoonoses. Recent virus studies in wild and domestic animals have characterized a large number of viruses, including some closely related to those that infect humans. The detection of multiple genetic lineages within viral families that infect a single host species, interspersed phylogenetically with viruses from other host species, reflects past interspecies crossings. From a better understanding of animal viromes, numerous opportunities will arise for the production of new vaccines. Â© 2012 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Delwart, E.

title: Monitoring the immune response to vaccination with an inactivated vaccine associated with bovine neonatal pancytopenia by deep sequencing transcriptome analysis in cattle.
abstract: Bovine neonatal pancytopenia (BNP) is a novel fatal, alloimmune/alloantibody-mediated disease of newborn calves induced by ingestion of colostrum from cows vaccinated with a specific vaccine against Bovine Virus Diarrhea Virus (BVDV). The hypothesis of pathogenic MHC class I molecules in the vaccine has been put forward, but no formal proof of specific causal MHC class I alleles has yet been provided. However, the unique properties of the vaccine result in extremely high titers of specific antibodies in vaccinated animals, but are also found in other molecules that apparently induce BNP. Therefore, a comprehensive picture of the immune response to the vaccine is so important. Applying the new approach of next-generation RNA sequencing (RNAseq), our study provides a new holistic, comprehensive analysis of blood transcriptome regulation after vaccination with the specific BVDV vaccine. Our RNAseq approach identified a novel cytokine-like gene in the bovine genome that was greatly upregulated after vaccination. This gene has not been previously identified in any other species and may be specific to the immune response of ruminants. Furthermore, our data elicited a multi-coordinated immune response against double-stranded (ds) RNA or a dsRNA analog after vaccination with an inactivated single-stranded (ss) RNA vaccine. This suggests either significant contamination of the vaccine with dsRNA from host cells after virus culture, or a dsRNA analog administered to the vaccine. The first option will highlight the potential risks associated with virus culture on homologous cells during vaccine production; The second option will highlight the potential risks associated with immunostimulating adjuvants used in vaccine production.
authors: Demasius, W.;Weikard, R.;Hadlich, F.;Muller, K. E.;Kuhn, C.

title: The chicken skin virome analyzed by high-throughput sequencing shows a very different composition from human skin.
abstract: Recent studies show that the human skin in homeostasis is a complex ecosystem that includes virome circular DNA viruses, particularly papillomaviruses and polyomaviruses. To determine the chicken skin virome in comparison with the human skin virome, a chicken swab sample from fifteen healthy indoor chickens with five genetic backgrounds was examined for the presence of DNA viruses by high-throughput sequencing (HTS). The results show a predominance of herpes viruses of the genus Mardivirus, either from vaccine-induced or possibly asymptomatic infection. Despite the high sensitivity of the HTS method used here to detect small circular DNA viruses, we did not detect any papillomavirus, polyomavirus or circovirus, indicating that these viruses may not be resident in chicken skin. The results show that the turkey herpes virus is localized in the skin of the vaccinated chickens. This study demonstrates the major differences between skin viruses of chickens and humans. The source of this difference remains to be further studied in relation to skin physiology, environment or virus population dynamics.
authors: Denesvre, C.;Dumarest, M.;RÃ©my, S.;Gourichon, D.;Eloit, M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of classic swine fever virus isolated from Taiwan
abstract: Three virus populations with different genotypes were identified, including one historical (subgroup 3.4) and two exotic (subgroup 2.1) strains, by analyzing the E2 sequences of classical swine fever virus from field outbreaks in Taiwan in 1993-2001. The first subgroup 2.1 virus was isolated in 1994, and further sporadic outbreaks have occurred after 1996. Phylogenetic analysis using the E2 region divided Taiwanese 2.1 virus strains into two distinct genotypes (designated 2.1a and 2.1b). 2.1b viruses were isolated only in 2001 and shared approximately 94.8% nucleotide identity to 2.1a viruses in total genomic sequences. The results show that viruses 2.1a and 2.1b can be introduced from different origins. Â© 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Deng, M. C.;Huang, C. C.;Huang, T. S.;Chang, C. Y.;Lin, Y. J.;Chien, M. S.;Jong, M. H.

title: Phylogenetic and genetic characterization of a 2017 clinical isolate of H7N9 virus in Guangzhou, China, during the fifth epidemic wave.
abstract: Pathogenic H7N9 influenza viruses continue to pose a public health problem. The H7N9 virus has caused five waves of epidemics in China since 2013. In this study, a novel H7N9 strain (A/Guangdong/8H324/2017) was isolated from a female patient with severe respiratory disease during the fifth wave of the disease. 2017 H7N9 epidemic. Phylogenetic analysis showed that H7N9 viruses collected during the fifth wave belonged to two distinct lineages: the Pearl River Delta lineage and the Yangtze River Delta lineage. The new isolate is closely related to Pearl River Delta H7N9 viruses isolated from patients in Guangdong Province. The new H7N9 isolate has the addition of three essential amino acids to the hemagglutinin (HA) cleavage site, which can increase virulence in poultry. The 2017 isolate also has an R292K substitution in the neuraminidase (NA) protein that confers oseltamivir resistance. This study highlights the pandemic potential of the novel H7N9 virus in mammals; therefore, future characterization and surveillance is warranted.
authors: Deng, Y.;Li, C.;Han, J.;Wen, Y.;Wang, J.;Hong, W.;Li, X.;Liu, Z.;Ye, Q.;Li, J.;Zhou, C.;Yu, L.;Qin, C.;Zhang, F.;Jiang, T.

title: High prevalence of bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 in Chinese pig herds
abstract: Nested RT-PCR was used to investigate bovine viral diarrhea virus in 511 samples collected from Chinese pigs showing clinical symptoms between 2007 and 2010. Of these, 137 were BVDV-positive and the prevalence rate of BVDV was 23.1% (9/39). 2007, 27.7% (44/159) in 2008, 33.6% (34/101) in 2009 and 23.6% (50/212) in 2010. -UTR. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that they were BVDV-1 and subdivided into BVDV-1a, BVDV-1b, BVDV-1m, BVDV-1o and an unknown subgenotype. This study showed that BVDVs are quite common in Chinese pig herds and appropriate measures should be taken to control the prevalence of BVDV in pig herds. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Deng, Y.;Sun, C. Q.;Cao, S. J.;Lin, T.;Yuan, S. S.;Zhang, H. B.;Zhai, S. L.;Huang, L.;Shan, T. L.;Zheng, H.;Wen, X. T.;Tong, G. Z.

title: Transmission of influenza A(H1N1) 2009 pandemic viruses in Australian pigs
abstract: Background Pigs have receptors for both human and avian influenza viruses and are a natural host for influenza A viruses. The 2009 influenza A(H1N1) pandemic (H1N1pdm) virus, derived from avian, human and swine flu viruses, has infected pigs in several countries. Objectives To investigate the relationship between H1N1pdm viruses isolated from swine outbreaks in Australia and human samples associated with one of the outbreaks by phylogenetic analysis and to determine whether any reclassification events occurred during human-swine interspecies transmission. Methods Real-time RT-PCR and whole genome sequencing were performed on RNA isolated from nasal swabs and/or virus cultures. Phylogenetic analysis was performed using the Geneious package. Outcomes Influenza H1N1pdm outbreaks were detected in three pig farms in three different states in Australia. Further analysis of the Queensland outbreak led to the identification of two different types of viruses in pigs. Two staff members working on the same pig farm were also infected with the same two strains found in pigs. Whole genome sequence analysis on viruses isolated from pigs and humans did not identify reclassifications of these H1N1pdm viruses to seasonal or avian influenza A viruses. Conclusions This is the first report of infected with swine flu in Australia and marks the end of the flu-free era for the Australian swine industry. Although no reclassifications were detected in these cases, the ability of these viruses to pass between pigs and humans highlights the importance of monitoring the pig for new influenza infections. Â© 2012 Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Deng, Y. M.;Iannello, P.;Smith, I.;Watson, J.;Barr, I. G.;Daniels, P.;Komadina, N.;Harrower, B.;Wong, F. Y. K.

title: Porcine virome and xenotransplantation
abstract: The composition of swine virus includes viruses that infect pig cells, ancient virus-derived elements, including endogenous retroviruses inserted into pig chromosomes, and bacteriophages that infect a wide array of bacteria living in pigs. Viruses that infect pigs, among them viruses that also infect human cells, as well as porcine endogenous retroviruses (PERVs), are important when assessing the viral safety of xenotransplantation. Bacteriophages mainly associated with bacteria found in the gut are not important in this context. Xenotransplantation using pig cells, tissues or organs is being developed to alleviate human transplant distress. Here, published data describing viromes in different pigs and their relevance to the virus safety of xenotransplantation are analyzed for the first time. Consequently, analysis of porcine virus has resulted in the identification of a large number of new viruses, although their effects on xenotransplantation are unclear. Most importantly, viruses with known or suspected zoonotic potential were generally not detected by next-generation sequencing, but were uncovered by more sensitive methods.
authors: Denner, J.

title: Identification of 6 new strains of Ghanaian G8P human-bovine reassortant rotavirus by next-generation sequencing
abstract: Group of rotaviruses (RVA) is the most important etiologic agent of acute gastroenteritis in children <5 years of age worldwide. The monovalent rotavirus vaccine Rotarix was included in the National Extended Immunization Program (EPI) in Ghana in May 2012. However, there is little genetic and phylogenetic data in pre-vaccine publicity on the complete genomes of circulating human RVAs. The common bovine rotavirus VP7 genotype G8 has been detected sporadically in Ghanaian children, usually in combination with VP4 genotype P[6]. To investigate the genomic constellations and phylogeny of circulating RVA strains prior to vaccine administration, the complete genomes of two unusual G8P[6] strains detected during burden of disease surveillance, GH018-08 and GH019-08, were characterized by Illumina MiSeq sequencing. . Ghanaian isolates, GH018-08 and GH019-08, displayed the unusual, previously unreported genotype constellation G8-P[6]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A2-N2-T2-E2-H3. Phylogenetic analyzes confirmed that 10 out of 11 genes of GH018-08 and GH019-08 were identical/nearly identical, significant variation detected only in VP1 genes, and clearly established that multiple independent interspecies transmission and reclassification events occurred between partners. circulating bovine/sheep/goat rotaviruses and human DS-1-like RVA strains. These findings highlight the contribution of reclassification and interspecies transmission events to the high rotavirus diversity in this region of Africa and confirm the need for simultaneous monitoring of animal and human rotavirus strains.
authors: Dennis, F. E.;Fujii, Y.;Haga, K.;Damanka, S.;Lartey, B.;Agbemabiese, C. A.;Ohta, N.;Armah, G. E.;Katayama, K.

title: Insights on circovirus host range from the genomic fossil record
abstract: In samples from humans and domestic animals, various DNA sequences derived from circoviruses (Circoviridae family) have been identified, often in association with pathological conditions. However, in the majority of cases, little is known about the natural biology of the viruses from which these sequences are derived. Endogenous cirroviral elements (CVe) are DNA sequences derived from circoviruses that occur in animal genomes and provide a useful source of information about circovirus-host relationships. In this study, we screened the genome assemblies of 675 animal species and identified a large number of circovirus-related sequences, including the first CVe samples derived from cycloviruses. We confirmed the presence of this CVe in the breeding line of the long twig (Pseudomyrmex gracilis), thereby determining that cycloviruses infect insects. We examined the evolutionary relationships between CVe and contemporary circoviruses, showing that CVe from ants and mites is a relatively close group with cycloviruses in phylogeny. Furthermore, the relatively random scattering of cyclovirus sequences from vertebrate samples and CVe from insect genomes suggested that contamination may be an important consideration in studies reporting these viruses. Our study demonstrates how endogenous viral sequences can inform metagenomic-based virus discovery. Additionally, it casts doubt on the role of cycloviruses as pathogens of humans and other vertebrates.
authors: Dennis, T. P. W.;Flynn, P. J.;de Souza, W. M.;Singer, J. B.;Moreau, C. S.;Wilson, S. J.;Gifford, R. J.

title: Deep sequencing of viral genomes provides insights into the evolution and pathogenesis of the varicella zoster virus and vaccine in humans.
abstract: Vaccination with the vOka vaccine prevents varicella (chickenpox) in children and susceptible adults. The vOka vaccine strain contains a mix of genotypes and causes rashes in a small number of recipients despite attenuation. Like the wild-type virus, the vaccine delays neuronal tissue and can then be reactivated to cause Herpes zoster (shingles). We purified and sequenced vOka directly from skin lesions using hybridization-based methodologies. We demonstrated that vaccine alleles can be recovered from lesions and that there is a serious bottleneck between vaccination and lesion formation. Genotypes in any given lesion appear to come from one to three vaccine genotypes with a low frequency of new mutations. A single vOka haplotype and new mutations are not consistently present in the rashes; this indicates that neither new mutations nor recombination with wild-type were critical for the evolution of vOka eruptions. Instead, alleles resulting from attenuation (ie not derived from free-living virus) are present at lower frequencies in rash genotypes. We identified 11 loci in which the ancestral allele was selected in vOka rash occurrence and showed that the genotypes in rashes that were reactivated without delay were indistinguishable from rashes that occurred immediately after vaccination. We conclude that, although the VOka vaccine is heterogeneous, it did not evolve to form rashes by positive selection in the half-species mode, but rather allows selection in human subjects for alleles that were essentially neutral at the time of vaccine production, allowing us to identify them. key loci for rash formation.
authors: Depledge, D. P.;Kundu, S.;Jensen, N. J.;Gray, E. R.;Jones, M.;Steinberg, S.;Gershon, A.;Kinchington, P. R.;Schmid, D. S.;Balloux, F.;Nichols, R. A.;Breuer, J.

title: Molecular Aspects of Varicella-Zoster Virus Delay Review
abstract: Primary varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection causes varicella (chickenpox) and a lifelong latent infection of ganglionic neurons. VZV is reactivated in approximately one-third of infected individuals, causing herpes zoster, often accompanied by neurological complications. The restricted host range of VZV and the lack of suitable in vitro models until recently have severely hindered molecular studies of VZV latency. However, recent technological advances have facilitated a number of exciting studies culminating in the discovery of a VZV delay-associated transcript (VLT) and provide new insights into our understanding of VZV delay and the factors that can initiate reactivation. Extracting the functions of the VLT and related molecular mechanisms should now be considered a priority to improve our understanding of the factors governing VZV delay and reactivation. In this review, we summarize the implications of recent discoveries in the field of VZV latency from both the virus and host perspective and provide a roadmap for future work.
authors: Depledge, D. P.;Sadaoka, T.;Ouwendijk, W. J. D.

title: Deep Sequencing of Distinctive Preparations of Live Attenuated Varicella-Zoster Virus Vaccine Reveals a Conserved Core Attenuating Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms
abstract: UNLABELED: The continued success of the live attenuated varicella-zoster virus vaccine in preventing varicella-zoster and herpes zoster, and many of the mutations that contribute to attenuation of the vOka virus for replication in the skin, are well documented. At least three different vOka preparations are marketed. Here, we demonstrate 137 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) using deep sequencing of seven batches of vOka vaccines (including ZostaVax, VariVax, VarilRix, and Oka/Biken working seed) from three different manufacturers (VariVax, GSK, and Biken). mutations are present in all vaccine series. This includes six regions where the vaccine allele, which we think may be important for attenuation, is fixed or close to fixation. We also show that, despite differences in vaccine populations between preparations, batch-to-batch variation is minimal, as is the number and frequency of individual batch-specific mutations. This demonstrates that vaccine production processes do not introduce new mutations and that despite the mix of variants available, VZV live vaccines are extremely stable. IMPORTANT: The continued success of vaccines to prevent chickenpox and shingles, together with the extremely low incidence of adverse reactions, demonstrates the quality of these vaccines. The vaccine itself consists of a heterogeneous population of live attenuated viruses and thus requires deep sequencing technologies to investigate differences and similarities in virus populations between different preparations and vaccine lines. Our data show minimal variation between groups, an important safety feature, and provide new insights into the extent of mutations found in this attenuated virus.
authors: Depledge, D. P.;Yamanishi, K.;Gomi, Y.;Gershon, A. A.;Breuer, J.

title: Classification of rotaviruses: World Health Organization/Food and Agriculture Organization Comparative Virology Program Report
abstract: The Reoviridae study team was established in 1975 as part of the World Health Organization/Food and Agriculture Organization Comparative Virology Program. Reovirus-like agents associated with diarrhea in humans and animals, and the generic name rotavirus for the Nebraska calf diarrhea virus strain has been adopted. bovine rotavirus was selected as the candidate reference virus. Stocks of this virus and gnotobiotic calf antiserum have been prepared. Antigenic differences between rotaviruses isolated from different species were detected on the basis of virus neutralization tests; A possible correlation was noticed between antigen specificity and variation in RNA segments and structural proteins of rotaviruses.
authors: Derbyshire, J. B.;Woode, G. N.

title: Isolation of bovine viral diarrheal viruses from bison
authors: Deregt, D.;Tessaro, S. V.;Baxi, M. K.;Berezowski, J.;Ellis, J. A.;Wu, J. T. Y.;Gilbert, S. A.

title: [New classification of porcine enteroviruses: serological and molecular genetic aspects]
abstract: Performed genetic and serological reclassification of 36 industrial, typical and laboratory strains porcine enteroviruses isolated in Ukraine, due to changes in the modern classification and nomenclature family Picornaviridae by the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy. Results of molecular genetic studies of 34 strains assigned to Picornaviridae family, Teschovirus genus, Porcine teschovirus species, 2 virus strains did not undergo polymerase chain reaction with species-specific primer. In the neutralization reaction of the virus, 1 serotype Porcine teschovirus, 4 strains -PTV-3, 1-to PTV-6, 1 strain - 23 strains of Porcine sapelovirus, typical antigenic properties among the three strains, and 4 strains - antigenically different from reference strains Porcine teschovirus, Enterovirus G and Porcine sapelovirus.
authors: Derev'ianko, S. V.

title: 5'-UTR-based phylogenetic analysis of Classical swine fever virus isolates from India
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF), caused by the classic swine fever virus (CSFV), is an important worldwide disease of pigs. Genetic typing of CSFV isolates can help to understand the epidemiology of the disease and to trace the source of the outbreak. 5'-UTR sequence analysis and subsequent genetic classification of nine CSFV field isolates from India showed that 3 isolates belonged to genotype 2.1 and were closely related to European CSFV strains. The remaining 6 isolates belonged to genotype 1, which includes old and new strains. However, the genotype 2.1 group consisted of only the last field isolates. The study showed the circulation of both genotypes 1 and 2.1 in the northeastern part of India.
authors: Desai, G. S.;Sharma, A.;Kataria, R. S.;Barman, N. N.;Tiwari, A. K.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of Newcastle disease virus isolates occurring in India between 1989 and 2013.
abstract: The study details the characterization of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates from commercial poultry flocks (chicken) and wild birds (crane) in India over the period from 1989 to 2013. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that most of the NDV isolates belonged to class II. , genotype XIIIa, and a chicken isolate (108/BAREILLY/AD-IVRI/91) was genotype VI with 3Â% variation from other viruses of the same genotype. Another chicken isolate (75/RAMPUR/AD-IVRI/89) was grouped into genotype III and showed 4Â% diversity with genotype III viruses. Crane-derived NDV was identified as genotype II, corresponding to the vaccine virus. This appears to be the first report of the existence of the XIIIa genotype, and its ancestral viruses have been circulating in different bird species in India for the past two decades. In addition, genetically distinct viruses belonging to genotypes II, III and VI are also circulating in India.
authors: Desingu, P. A.;Singh, S. D.;Dhama, K.;Karthik, K.;Vinodh Kumar, O. R.;Malik, Y. S.

title: Transcript of the UL28 homolog of bovine herpes virus 1 and expression kinetics of its product
abstract: We report that bovine herpesvirus 1 (BHV1) UL28 ORF, a homologue of the herpes simplex virus (HSV) UL28 gene, represents a functional gene encoding a viral-specific protein. Located at positions 53 058 - 55 538 of the viral genome, the BHV1 UL28 ORF encodes a 3.4 kb viral-specific transcript detected 6 h post infection (pi), after which its levels accumulated up to 12 h and remained stable up to 24 h pi thereafter. Transcription of BHV1 UL28 was determined to initiate 95 bases upstream from the initiation codon of the ORF, corresponding to 33 nucleotides downstream from a putative TATA box. A BHV1 UL28 specific antiserum produced against a T7-Tag/UL28 fusion protein expressed in E. coli specifically reacted with a 100 kDa protein in Western blots of BHV1 infected protein cell lysates. The expression kinetics of the protein was delayed by 6 hours relative to its transcript, suggesting that the gene is regulated at the translational level. Unlike the HSV and pseudorabies virus UL28 genes, which belong to the viral genes of the early (Î²) class, that of BHV1 is clearly classified as an Î³2 gene. Further studies will be required to determine whether these kinetic differences have any functional significance. Â© 2001 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Desloges, N.;Simard, C.

title: Metagenomic comparison of endemic viruses from broilers with runting-stunting syndrome and normal birds
abstract: Worker stunting syndrome (RSS) in broilers is an enteric disease that causes significant economic losses to poultry producers worldwide due to increased feed efficiency, reduced body weight during growth and excessive culling. Of particular interest are RSS-associated viral agents that have been difficult to characterize fully to date. Past research into the etiology of RSS has implicated a wide variety of RNA and DNA viruses, but to date, no single virus has been identified as the main agent of RSS, and the current view is that it may originate from a collection of viruses, collectively known as virome. This article attempts to characterize viral pathogens associated with 2-3 week old RSS affected and unaffected broilers using next generation sequencing and comparative metagenomics. Analysis of viromes identified a total of 20 DNA and RNA viral families, with 2 unidentified categories consisting of 31 different viral genera and 7 unclassified genera. The most abundant viral families identified in this study were Astroviridae, Caliciviridae, Picornaviridae, Parvoviridae, Coronaviridae, Siphoviridae, and Myoviridae. This study identified historically important viruses associated with diseases such as chicken astrovirus, avian nephritis virus, chicken parvovirus and chicken calicivirus, as well as relatively new viruses such as chicken megrivirus and sicinivirus 1, and will help expand knowledge on enteric disease in broiler chickens. chickens provide information on the viral components of a healthy avian gut and identify various enteric viruses and viral communities suitable for further study.
authors: Devaney, R.;Trudgett, J.;Trudgett, A.;Meharg, C.;Smyth, V.

title: Enrichment of Viral Nucleic Acids with Sex-Specific Oligonucleotides by Solution Hybrid Selection
abstract: Despite recent advances, our knowledge of potential and rare human pathogens is far from comprehensive. Current molecular diagnostic tools rely mainly on specific amplification of marker sequences and may miss infections caused by unknown and rare pathogens. Using high-throughput sequencing (HTS) can solve this problem; however, due to the extremely low fraction of pathogenic genetic material in clinical specimens, its application is only cost effective in special rather than routine cases. In this work, we present a method for semi-specific enrichment of viral conservative sequences in an HTS library by hybridization in solution with strain-specific degenerate biotinylated oligonucleotides. Nucleic acids of test viruses (yellow fever virus and Japanese encephalitis virus) were enriched by solution hybrid selection using pan-flavivirus oligonucleotides. In addition, enterovirus (family: Picornaviridae, genus: Enterovirus) sequences were successfully enriched using the foot-and-mouth disease virus (family: Picornaviridae, genus: Aphthovirus) oligonucleotide. The enrichment factor relative to background nucleic acid was approximately 1,000-fold. Because hybridization has less stringent oligonucleotide coupling requirements than PCR, a few oligonucleotides are sufficient to cover potential sequence variation across the entire genus and may even enrich nucleic acids of viruses of other related genera. The efficient enrichment of viral sequences makes their use in diagnostics cost-effective.
authors: Deviatkin, A. A.;Lukashev, A. N.;Markelov, M. M.;Gmyl, L. V.;Shipulin, G. A.

title: Megaphages infect Prevotella and variants are common in gut microbiomes
abstract: Bacteriophages (phages) significantly shape microbial community composition, redistribute nutrients through host fragmentation, and drive evolution through horizontal gene transfer. Despite their importance, there is still much to learn about phages in the human microbiome. We investigated the gut microbiomes of humans from Bangladesh and Tanzania, two African baboon social groups, and Danish pigs; Most of these microbiomes contain phages belonging to a clade with genomes >540 kilobases long, which is the largest ever reported in the human microbiome and close to the maximum size ever reported for phages. We call these Lacquer phages. CRISPR differential targeting indicates Lac phages infect bacteria of the genus Prevotella. We manually curated to complete 15 different Lak phage genomes from metagenomes. The genomes show many interesting features, including the use of an alternative genetic code, large highly expressed intergenic regions, and up to 35 putative transfer RNAs, some of which contain enigmatic introns. Different individuals have different phage genotypes, and shifts in variable frequencies on consecutive sampling days reflect changes in the relative abundance of phage subpopulations. Recent homologous recombination resulted in extensive genome mixing of nine baboon Lak phage populations. We conclude that lac phages are common in intestinal communities containing Prevotella species, and megaphages with fascinating and underexplored biology may be common, but largely overlooked components of the human and animal gut microbiomes.
authors: Devoto, A. E.;Santini, J. M.;Olm, M. R.;Anantharaman, K.;Munk, P.;Tung, J.;Archie, E. A.;Turnbaugh, P. J.;Seed, K. D.;Blekhman, R.;Aarestrup, F. M.;Thomas, B. C.;Banfield, J. F.

title: Molecular and Antigenic Characterization of Piscine orthoreovirus (PRV) from Rainbow Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss)
abstract: Piscine orthoreovirus (PRV-1) causes heart and skeletal muscle inflammation (HSMI) in farmed Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar). Recently, a new PRV (formerly PRV-Om, here PRV-3) was found in rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) with HSMI-like disease. PRV is considered an emerging pathogen in farmed salmonids. In this study, molecular and antigenic characterization of PRV-3 was performed. Erythrocytes are the main target cells for PRV and blood samples collected from experimentally challenged fish were used as a source of virus. Virus particles were purified by gradient ultracentrifugation and the complete coding sequences of PRV-3 were obtained by Illumina sequencing. Compared to PRV-1, the nucleotide identity of the coding regions was 80.1%, and the amino acid identities of the predicted PRV-3 proteins ranged from 96.7% (lambda1) to 79.1% (sigma3). Phylogenetic analysis showed that PRV-3 belonged to a separate cluster. The region coding for Sigma3 was sequenced from PRV-3 isolates collected from rainbow trout in Europe. These sequences were pooled together, but far from PRV-3 isolated from rainbow trout in Norway. Bioinformatic analyzes of PRV-3 proteins revealed that predicted secondary structures and functional domains are conserved between PRV-3 and PRV-1. Rabbit antisera raised from PRV-1 to purified virus or various recombinant virus proteins all cross-reacted with PRV-3. Our findings show that various genetic, antigenic and structural features are conserved between PRV-1 and-3, despite the different species preferences of PRV subtypes.
authors: Dhamotharan, K.;Vendramin, N.;Markussen, T.;Wessel, O.;Cuenca, A.;Nyman, I. B.;Olsen, A. B.;Tengs, T.;Krudtaa Dahle, M.;Rimstad, E.

title: Recent epidemiology of Peste des petits ruminant virus (PPRV)
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is an economically important viral disease of goats and sheep, first described in West Africa in the 1940s. Although the first description of the virus in India dates back to 1987, the virus has been circulating in parts of sub-Saharan Africa for several decades and in the Middle East and South Asia since 1993. To examine the genetic relationship between isolates of different geographic origin, a selected region of the fusion (F) protein gene of viruses was amplified using RT/PCR and the resulting DNA product was sequenced for phylogenetic analysis. Viruses from 27 outbreaks reported between 1993 and 2000 in Asian and Middle Eastern countries and two recent outbreaks from the African continent were compared with the prototype African strain. Of the four known strains of the PPR virus, strains 1 and 2 viruses have only been found in West Africa. Originating from an outbreak in Burkina Faso in 1999, the virus fell into strain 1. Viruses of strain 3 have been found in East Africa, where there was an outbreak of this type in Ethiopia in 1996, as well as in Arabia and southern India. However, there has been no further isolation of strain 3 virus from India since it was reported from Tamil Nadu in 1992. A virus from this strain was circulated in Yemen in 2001. In the past 8 years, only the fourth strain virus has spread to the Middle East and Asian subcontinent, reaching as far east as Nepal and Bangladesh. This strain of the virus was also reported from Kuwait in 1999. The geographic origin of the novel 4 virus is unknown, although it is most closely related to African ancestry 1. , a related bovine virus, is considered unlikely. Â© 2002 Published by Elsevier Science BV
authors: Dhar, P.;Sreenivasa, B. P.;Barrett, T.;Corteyn, M.;Singh, R. P.;Bandyopadhyay, S. K.

title: Chapter 2.3.2.1 Genetic characterization of avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, Indonesia, 2012
abstract: Influenza A(H5N1) viruses were detected and characterized in September 2012, after unusually high mortality rates were reported among farmed ducks on the Indonesian island of Java. Sequence analyzes revealed all genes clustered with contemporary sequence 2.3.2.1 viruses rather than enzootic sequence 2.1.3 viruses, indicating the entry of an exotic H5N1 clade into Indonesia.
authors: Dharmayanti, N. L.;Hartawan, R.;Pudjiatmoko;Wibawa, H.;Hardiman;Balish, A.;Donis, R.;Davis, C. T.;Samaan, G.

title: Temperate coliphages: classification and correlation with habitats
abstract: Temperate coliphages were obtained from sewage, mammalian feces, and lysogenic strains of Escherichia coli. A total of 32 phages of independent origin were divided into six groups using the criteria of host range, antigenic homology, and ultraviolet inducibility of prophage. In some cases, demonstration of genetic interactions confirmed the classification scheme. Nine phages were assigned to the P2 family and 19 to the lambda family. The remaining four isolates may represent some new phylogenetic species. Phages from lysogenic strains of E. coli were all found to be P2-related, whereas the majority of phages recovered as cell-free plaque-forming units could be assigned to the lambda family. It is suggested that the biological properties of phages belonging to the two main families are reflected in the observed distribution patterns. The virions of the HK256 phage display multiple tail fibers and may therefore represent a 'new' form of virions among temperate cophages.
authors: Dhillon, E. K. S.;Dhillon, T. S.;Lam, Y. Y.;Tsang, A. H. C.

title: Evidence of recombination in neboviruses
abstract: Neboviruses are bovine enteric caliciviruses (Nebovirus genus) associated with enteric diseases in calves. By screening the feces of calves collected from Italian herds using primers targeting a conserved strain in calicivirus RNA-dependent RNA-polymerase (RdRp), nebovirus RNA was detected in enteritised calves (13.1%), but not in clearly healthy animals. Upon sequence analysis of the RdRp fragment, the Italian viruses formed a tightly conserved group and closely resembled the nebovirus prototype Nebraska/80/US. It's a 2.2 string. The kb ORF1 fragment spanning the 3' end of the RdRp and the full-length capsid coding region of the two nebovirus strains was identified, revealing significant genetic heterogeneity in the capsid protein as the two Italian viruses were classified in two different capsid lineages, and a recombination downstream of the highly conserved shell (S) domain. propose the event. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Di Martino, B.;Di Profio, F.;Martella, V.;Ceci, C.;Marsilio, F.

title: Genome plasticity of triple reassortant H1N1 influenza A virus during infection of vaccinated pigs.
abstract: To gain insight into the evolution of influenza A viruses (IAVs) during infection of vaccinated pigs, we experimentally infected a 3-week-old naive pig with triple reassortant H1N1 IAV and directly contacted the sowing pig with a group of age-olds. -paired vaccinated pigs (n510), We indexed the genetic diversity and evolution of the virus at the intra-host level by directly deep sequencing the entire genome from nasal swabs collected in two separate samples at the time of infection, we obtained 13 IAV metagenomes from 13 samples of the virus vaccine and six pigs that tested positive for IAV during the study. containing two samples from each, Infection produced a heterogeneous population of alleles (sequence variants) that were dynamic over time. Overall, 794 polymorphisms were identified among all. Samples yielding 327 alleles, 214 of which are unique sequences, were translated into a total of 43 different hemagglutinin proteins, two of which were observed in more than one pig. where neuraminidase (NA) was preserved and only one dominant NA was found throughout the study, the genetic diversity of IAVs changed dynamically within and between pigs, However, most of the substitutions observed in internal gene segments were synonymous, Our results showed remarkable diversity of IAV and vaccinated pigs The complex, rapid and dynamic evolution of IAV during infection can only be appreciated by repeated sampling and deep sequence analysis of individual animals.
authors: Diaz, A.;Enomoto, S.;Romagosa, A.;Sreevatsan, S.;Nelson, M.;Culhane, M.;Torremorell, M.

title: Molecular features of Nipah virus glycoproteins
abstract: Nipah virus (NiV) is a highly pathogenic paramyxovirus that emerged from fruit bats in Malaysia in 1998, causing an outbreak of severe respiratory disease in pigs and fatal encephalitis in humans with high mortality rates. Unlike most paramyxoviruses, NiV can infect a wide variety of mammalian species. Due to this wide host range, zoonotic potential, high pathogenicity to humans, and the lack of effective vaccines or therapeutics, NiV was classified as a biosafety level 4 pathogen. This article provides an overview of the molecular properties of NiV, focusing on the structure, functions, and unique biological properties of two NiV surface glycoproteins, the receptor-binding G protein and the fusion protein F. Since viral glycoproteins are major determinants for the cell, detailed knowledge of these proteins in terms of tropism and virus spread can help to understand the molecular basis of viral pathogenicity. Â© 2007 New York Academy of Sciences.
authors: Diederich, S.;Maisner, A.

title: Genetic analysis of avian paramyxovirus-1 (Newcastle disease virus) isolates from pig populations in China with respect to commonly used commercial vaccine strains.
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is thought to infect bird species only. However, at least eight NDV strains were isolated from pig populations in China during 1999-2006, and four of these were genetically and phylogenetically characterized. Genetic analysis revealed that JL106 and SP13 had a 112G-RQGR-L117 motif at the cleavage site of protein F, while JL01 and MP01 had a 112G-KQGR-L117 motif, suggesting that they are all typical for low virulence viruses. Phylogenetic analysis based on full-length F gene sequences indicated that JL106 and SP13 belong to genotype II, similar to the commercial La Sota vaccine strain widely used in China. While JL01 and MP01 cluster within genotype I, they are genetically identical to the V4 vaccine strain. Animal experiments showed that JL106 can effectively infect chickens. The present results indicated that the use of live La Sota and V4 vaccines and close contact between bird and pigs can result in interspecies infection, therefore further surveillance of swine NDV epidemiology is warranted. © 2010 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Ding, Z.;Cong, Y. L.;Chang, S.;Wang, G. M.;Wang, Z.;Zhang, Q. P.;Wu, H.;Sun, Y. Z.

title: Modulation of microRNAs in two genetically different chicken lines predisposed to different necrotic enteritis disease
abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNA) play a critical role in post-transcriptional regulation by affecting the 3'-UTR of target genes. We used small RNA high-throughput sequencing (HTS) to investigate whether miRNAs are differentially expressed in these two chicken lines after induction, using inbred White Leghorn chicken lines, line 6.3 and line 7.2, which show the disease resistant and susceptible phenotypes of Marek, respectively. . necrotic enteritis (NE). 12 miRNAs selected from the most down-regulated or up-regulated miRNAs following NE induction were confirmed by their expression in real-time PCR. Among these miRNAs, miR-215, miR-217, miR-194, miR-200a, miR-200b, miR-216a, miR-216b and miR-429 are highly expressed in the gut derived from line 7.2, while miR- 1782 and miR-499 were downregulated. In the spleen, miR-34b and miR-1684 were the most up-regulated miRNAs at line 6.3. Notably, five of the six target genes, CXCR5, BCL2, GJA1, TCF12 and TAB3, were differentially expressed between line 6.3 and line 7.2 and showed suppression in the MD-susceptible chicken line. Their expression levels were inversely proportional to those of miRNA from both HTS and quantitative real-time PCR. These results suggest that some miRNAs are differentially altered in response to NE and modulate the expression of their target genes in the two inbred lines. Collectively, HTS analysis of gut miRNAs from NE-affected inbred chickens showing different disease phenotypes led to the identification of miRNA-regulated host immunity genes. Future studies of the function of these miRNAs and their target genes in the host will lead to a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms that control host-pathogen interaction in NE. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Dinh, H.;Hong, Y. H.;Lillehoj, H. S.

title: Studies on Myxovirus Yucaipa: Classification as a Member of the Paramyxovirus Group
authors: Dinter, Z.;Hermodsson, S.;Hermodsson, L.

title: Characteristics and Classification of Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus
abstract: Examination of strains C24V (Oregon) and MAC A (Ontario) of bovine viral diarrhea viruses showed that they are viruses with compound helical symmetry, containing ribonucleic acid, essential lipid, and the helix diameter is around 180 Å. Because of these features, it is recommended that the virus be accepted as a member of the Myxovirus group. Porcine cholera virus is associated with bovine viral diarrhea virus via a "soluble" antigen and also has essential lipid. Therefore, it is suggested that the swine cholera virus represents yet another veterinary myxovirus.
authors: Ditchfield, J.;Doane, F. W.

title: Metagenomic analysis of RNA viruses in a freshwater lake
abstract: Freshwater lakes and ponds offer an ecological interface between humans and various host organisms. They are a habitat for the larval stage of many insects and can serve as a medium for intraspecific and interspecific transmission of viruses such as avian influenza A virus. Also, freshwater bodies are already known reservoirs for disease-causing viruses such as Norwalk Virus, Coxsackievirus, Echovirus, and Adenovirus. Although RNA virus populations have been studied in marine environments, very limited analysis of the freshwater viral community has been made to date. Here we present a study of RNA viruses in Needwood Lake, a freshwater lake in Maryland, USA. Our results show that, as with studies in other aquatic environments, most of the nucleic acid sequences obtained show no significant similarity to known sequences. The remaining sequences are mainly from viral types with significant similarity to about 30 viral families. We speculate that these new viruses could infect a variety of hosts, including plants, insects, fish, pets and humans. Among these viruses, we discovered a previously unknown dsRNA virus closely related to Banna Virus, which is responsible for a febrile illness and is native to Southeast Asia. We also found multiple viral sequences distantly related to Israel Acute Paralysis virus, which plays a role in honeybee colony collapse disorder. Our data suggest that, due to their direct contact with humans, domestic and wild animals, freshwater ecosystems can serve as reservoirs for a wide variety of viruses (both pathogenic and non-pathogenic) and possibly play a role in the spread of emerging and pandemic diseases. Â© 2009 Djikeng et al.
authors: Djikeng, A.;Kuzmickas, R.;Anderson, N. G.;Spiro, D. J.

title: Genetic analysis of human rotavirus C: the appearance of the Indo-Bangladeshi strain in Far East Asian countries.
abstract: Rotaviruses C (RVCs) circulate worldwide as an enteric pathogen in both humans and animals. Most studies of their genetic diversity focus on the VP7 and VP4 genes, but the complete genomes of 18 human RVCs have been identified in independent studies. The genetic background of Far East Asian RVCs is different from other human RVCs found in India and Bangladesh. Recently, an RVC detected in South Korea in 2010 had a similar genetic background to India-Bangladeshi RVCs. This study was conducted to identify the entire genome of eight Japanese RVCs detected in 2005-2012 and compare them with other human and animal global RVCs to better understand the genetic background of contemporary Far East Asian RVC. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that human RVCs differ from animal RVCs. Among human RVCs, three lineage constellations had long circulation. The genetic background of Far East Asian RVC was distinguished from Indo-Bangladeshi RVC as previously reported. However, in 2012 we found one Japanese RVC carrying the genetic background of Indo-Bangladeshi RVC, while the remaining seven Japanese RVCs carried the typical genetic background of Far East Asian RVC. This is the India-Bangladesh RVC's first report in Japan. With this observation and the reclassification of human RVCs in Hungary, our study demonstrates the spread of RVCs from one region to another.
authors: Doan, Y. H.;Haga, K.;Fujimoto, A.;Fujii, Y.;Takai-Todaka, R.;Oka, T.;Kimura, H.;Yoshizumi, S.;Shigemoto, N.;Okamoto-Nakagawa, R.;Shirabe, K.;Shinomiya, H.;Sakon, N.;Katayama, K.

title: Zoonotic hepatitis E virus: Classification, animal reservoirs and transmission routes
authors: Doceul, V.;Bagdassarian, E.;Demange, A.;Pavio, N.

title: Sequence analysis of a porcine enterovirus serotype 1 isolate: Relationships to other picornaviruses.
abstract: The majority of the genomic sequence of a porcine enterovirus serotype 1 (PEV-1) isolate was determined. The genome was found to contain a large open reading frame encoding a leader protein before the capsid protein region. This showed no sequence identity to other picornavirus leader regions and sequence data suggested that it lacks proteolytic activity. The 2A protease was small and showed a remarkable sequence identity to aftoviruses and at rhinovirus serotype 2. The 2A/2B junction had the typical cleavage site (NPG/P) exhibited by these viruses. Other proteins shared less than 40% sequence identity with equivalent proteins from other picornavirus genera. Phylogenetic analyzes of the P1 and 3D sequences showed that this virus forms a separate branch of the Picornaviridae family. Based on the results presented in this manuscript, PEV-1 has been assigned to a new genus of picornavirus. The phylogeny of the virus relative to other picornaviruses is discussed.
authors: Doherty, M.;Todd, D.;McFerran, N.;Hoey, E. M.

title: Functional characterization of a monoclonal antibody epitope using a lambda phage display depth sequencing platform
abstract: We recently described a method called PROFILER for the identification of antigenic regions that are preferentially targeted by polyclonal antibody responses after vaccination. To test the technique's ability to provide insight into the functional properties of monoclonal antibody (mAb) epitopes, we used here a well-characterized meningococcal factor H-binding protein (fHbp) epitope recognized by mAb 12C1. A fHbp library engineered on a lambda phage vector enabling surface expression of polypeptides of very different lengths was subjected to massive parallel sequencing of phage inserts after affinity selection with 12C1 mAb. We identified dozens of unique antibody-selected sequences, the most enriched of which (termed FrC) can largely recapitulate the ability of fHbp to bind mAb 12C1. Computational analysis of the cumulative enrichment of single amino acids in fragments selected by the antibody identified two overrepresented residue sequences (H248-K254 and S140-G154), whose presence was subsequently found to be required for FrC binding to mAb 12C1. Collectively, these results demonstrate that PROFILER technology can quickly and reliably identify discrete "hotspots" that have a crucial role in antigen-antibody interactions in the context of complex conformational epitopes, thus providing useful clues for the functional characterization of the epitope.
authors: Domina, M.;Lanza Cariccio, V.;Benfatto, S.;Venza, M.;Venza, I.;Borgogni, E.;Castellino, F.;Midiri, A.;Galbo, R.;Romeo, L.;Biondo, C.;Masignani, V.;Teti, G.;Felici, F.;Beninati, C.

title: Wide host range and genetic diversity of mammalian and avian astroviruses
abstract: Astroviruses are a diverse family of viruses that infect a wide variety of mammalian and avian hosts. Here, we explain the phylogenetic diversity of astroviruses based on the ORF1b and ORF2 genes and the current classification methodology, emphasizing the propensity of astroviruses to undergo interspecies transmission and genetic recombination, complicating attempts towards a unified and comprehensive classification strategy that greatly increases diversity.
authors: Donato, C.;Vijaykrishna, D.

title: Identification of Peste des Petits Ruminants Virus, Georgia, 2016
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of samples from peste des petits ruminant virus (PPRV) outbreaks reported in Georgia revealed a closer association with viruses from northern and eastern Africa than with viruses from countries close to Georgia. This finding has crucial implications for the control of PPRV in the region.
authors: Donduashvili, M.;Goginashvili, K.;Toklikishvili, N.;Tigilauri, T.;Gelashvili, L.;Avaliani, L.;Khartskhia, N.;Loitsch, A.;Bataille, A.;Libeau, G.;Diallo, A.;Dundon, W. G.

title: Detecting transmission and reclassification events for influenza A viruses by genotype profiling
abstract: Evolutionary transmission and reclassification events for influenza A viruses have traditionally been detected by phylogenetic analysis for eight gene segments of influenza viruses. Because phylogenetic analysis can be complex, we developed the genotype profiling method, which bundles phylogenetic algorithms to analyze combination patterns of gene segments and integrated epidemiology information. With the method, reclassification and contamination analysis becomes a simple and reliable process combining genotypes that are identical for the biological process of the virus. An application called IVEE that implements the method is available for all academic users to implement the method http://snptransformer.sourceforge.net. We also found that a previous summary of reclassification events in swine flu A viruses may be inaccurate. Â© 2011 Dong et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Dong, C.;Ying, L.;Yuan, D.

title: Phylogenetic diversity and genotypic complexity of H9N2 influenza A viruses revealed by genomic sequence analysis
abstract: H9N2 influenza A viruses have become resident in terrestrial poultry and wild birds worldwide and occasionally infect mammals, including humans and pigs. To comprehensively elucidate the genetic and evolutionary characteristics of H9N2 influenza viruses, we performed a large-scale sequence analysis of 571 viral genomes from the NCBI Influenza Virus Resource Database, representing the spectrum of H9N2 influenza viruses isolated from 1966 to 2009. Panoramic framework to better understand the genesis and evolution of H9N2 influenza viruses and to explain the history of H9N2 viruses circulating in various hosts. Panorama phylogenetic analysis of eight viral gene segments revealed the complexity and diversity of H9N2 influenza viruses. The 571 H9N2 viral genomes were classified into 74 distinct lineages with marked host and geographic differences in phylogeny. Panorama genotypic analysis also revealed that H9N2 viruses contained at least 98 genotypes, which were divided into seven series (AG) according to HA lineages. Phylogenetic analysis of internal genes showed that H9N2 viruses are closely related to H3, H4, H5, H7, H10 and H14 subtype influenza viruses. Our results show that H9N2 viruses undergo extensive reclassification to generate multiple reassortants and genotypes; this suggests that the continued circulation of multiple genotypic H9N2 viruses in various hosts worldwide has the potential to cause future influenza outbreaks in poultry and epidemics in humans. To facilitate international communication about the evolution, ecology and epidemiology of H9N2 influenza viruses, we propose a nomenclature system to describe and unify all strains and genotypes of H9N2 influenza viruses. Â© 2011 Dong et al.
authors: Dong, G.;Luo, J.;Zhang, H.;Wang, C.;Duan, M.;Deliberto, T. J.;Nolte, D. L.;Ji, G.;He, H.

title: Reassortant H9N2 influenza viruses containing H5N1-like PB1 genes isolated from black-billed magpies in southern China.
abstract: H9N2 influenza A viruses have become endemic to different terrestrial poultry and wild birds in Asia and occasionally infect humans and pigs. To evaluate the role of black-billed magpies (Pica pica) in the evolution of influenza A virus, we conducted two outbreak studies on avian influenza viruses in wild black-billed magpies in 2005 in Guangxi, China, and characterized three isolated black-billed magpies. H9N2 viruses (BbM viruses). Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the three BbM viruses were nearly identical in all their genomes with 99.7% to 100% nucleotide homology, and the genes for BJ94-like (Ck/BJ/1/94), HA, NA, M and NS, SH/F/98-like (Ck/SH) /F/98) PB2, PA and NP genes and H5N1-like (Ck/YN/1252/03, clade 1) PB1 genes. Genetic analysis showed that BbM viruses were most likely the result of multiple reclassifications between co-circulating H9N2-like and H5N1-like viruses and were genetically different from other H9N2 viruses due to the presence of H5N1-like PB1 genes. Genotypic analysis revealed that BbM viruses evolved from a variety of sources and belonged to a new genotype (B46) discovered in our recent study. Molecular analysis showed that BbM viruses are likely to be low pathogenic reagents. However, the results of our pathogenicity study showed that BbM viruses reproduce efficiently in chickens and a mammalian mouse model, but not lethal to infected chickens and mice. Antigenic analysis showed that the BbM viruses were antigenic heterologous with the H9N2 vaccine strain. Our study is probably the first report to document and characterize H9N2 influenza viruses isolated from black-billed magpies in southern China. Our results indicate that black-billed magpies are susceptible to H9N2 influenza viruses, raising concerns about possible transmission of reassortant H9N2 viruses among poultry and wild birds. Â© 2011 Dong et al.
authors: Dong, G.;Xu, C.;Wang, C.;Wu, B.;Luo, J.;Zhang, H.;Nolte, D. L.;Deliberto, T. J.;Duan, M.;Ji, G.;He, H.

title: Characteristics of influenza H13N8 subtype virus first isolated from Qinghai Lake District, China
abstract: Background: As the highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza killed thousands of wild birds in this region in 2005, Lake Qinghai in China has become a hotspot for research on the impact of avian flu on migratory wild birds. However, the ecology and evolution of the low pathogenic avian influenza virus in this region is limited. This project-based bird flu surveillance in the Qinghai Lake area was initiated in 2012. Method: Wild bird droppings and lake surface water samples were collected in Qinghai Lake in 2012. Virus isolation was performed on embryonated chicken eggs.
