Influenza A virus was detected by rRT-PCR. Virus sequences were obtained by deep sequencing. Phylogenetic correlation and molecular characteristics of viruses were analyzed. Virus growth and infection characteristics, receptor binding preference and pathogenicity were studied in vitro. Results: Two H13N8 subtype influenza viruses were isolated. Viruses phylogenetically belong to the Eurasian lineage. Most of the genes are associated with the gull-borne influenza virus, with the exception of the PB1 gene, which is most likely derived from the Anseriformes virus. Evidence of interspecies reclassification is presented. The two viruses have limited growth capacity in MDCK and A549 cells, but grow well in embryonated eggs. The dual receptor binding properties of the two viruses were revealed. Low pathogenic properties were determined by the trypsin-dependent plaque formation assay. Results: Two H13N8 subtypes of influenza viruses were highly associated with gull origin. The interspecies reclassification of the H13 subtype virus among wild birds of Anseriforme litter Charadriiformes highlights the importance of strengthening bird flu surveillance in this region. This work helps to understand the ecology, evolution and transmission pattern of the H13 subtype influenza virus globally.
authors: Dong, J.;Bo, H.;Zhang, Y.;Dong, L.;Zou, S.;Huang, W.;Liu, J.;Wang, D.;Shu, Y.

title: Polymorphisms affecting the gE and gI proteins contribute in part to the virulence of an emerging, highly virulent Chinese pseudorabies virus.
abstract: An outbreak of a highly virulent pseudorabies virus strain ZJ01 occurred in pigs vaccinated with PRV in China in 2011. In this study, the Chinese prototypical PRV strain LA caused mild respiratory disorders, while ZJ01 caused fatal diseases. The whole genome sequencing results show that the two viruses can be classified into two subsets, unlike the traditional European and US strains. To examine the potential role of the gE and gI proteins in ZJ01 virulence, we generated several recombinant viruses. In two chimeric viruses (rZJ01-LA/gEI and rLA-ZJ01/gEI), the gE and gI genes were replaced using the corresponding genes from ZJ01 and LA. rZJ01-LA/gEI and parent virus rZJ01 retained high virulence in piglets, although the survival time of piglets infected with rZJ01-LA/gEI was clearly prolonged. In contrast, rLA-ZJ01/gEI exhibited higher virulence than the parent virus rLA. We conclude that changes in gE and gI proteins contribute in part to the increased virulence of strain ZJ01.
authors: Dong, J.;Gu, Z.;Jin, L.;Lv, L.;Wang, J.;Sun, T.;Bai, J.;Sun, H.;Wang, X.;Jiang, P.

title: A novel recombinant swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus virulent strain in China
abstract: Pig reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) is one of the most important swine diseases worldwide. In this study, GDsg, a novel virulent strain of PRRS virus (PRRSV), was isolated in Guangdong province of China and caused high fever, high morbidity and high mortality in pigs and piglets. The genome of this new strain was 15,413 nucleotides (nt) long, and comparative analysis revealed that GDsg shared 82.4% to 94% identity with type 2 PRRSV strains, but only 61.5% identity with type 1 PRRSV Lelystad virus strain. Phylogenetic analysis showed that type 2 PRRSV isolates contained five subgenotypes (I, II, III, IV and V), represented by NADC30, VR-2332, GM2, CH-1a and HuN4, respectively. Moreover, GDsg belongs to the nascent type 2 PRRSV subgenotype III. More interestingly, the newly isolated GDsg strain has multiple discontinuous nt deletions, 131 (19 + 18 + 94) at location 1404-1540 and a 107 nt insertion in the NSP2 region. Most importantly, strain GDsg was identified as a virus that was recombined between the low pathogenic field strain QYYZ and the vaccine strain JXA1-P80. As a result, a new independent subgenotype and recombinant PRRSV strain has emerged in China and may be a new threat to China's swine industry.
authors: Dong, J. G.;Yu, L. Y.;Wang, P. P.;Zhang, L. Y.;Liu, Y. L.;Liang, P. S.;Song, C. X.

title: Dynamic coevolution and interaction of avian leukosis virus genetic variants and host immune responses
abstract: The subgroup Javian leukosis virus (ALV-J), a typical retrovirus, is characterized by the presence of a cloud of several variants and significant genetic diversity. Previous studies describing the evolutionary dynamics of ALV-J genetic variants focused mainly on the early infection period or on a few randomly selected clones. Here, we vaccinated 30 specific pathogen-free chickens with the same constitutive ALV-J stock with known genetic background. Six (three antibody positive and three antibody negative) chickens were selected from among 15 viremia chickens. Viruses were serially isolated at 36 weeks and then sequenced using the MiSeq high-throughput sequencing platform. This produced the largest ALV-J dataset to date, consisting of over three million clean reads. Our results showed that host humoral immunity can greatly increase the genetic diversity of ALV-J genetic variants. Notably, selection pressures favored a dynamically proportional changes in ALV-J genetic variant frequency. The cross-neutralization assay showed that with the change of the dominant variant, the antibody titers specific to the infectious clones corresponding to the most dominant variants at weeks 12 and 28 also changed significantly in sera collected at weeks 16 and 32. Dominant variant shift was observed in antibody negative chickens. We also identified a new hypervariable region in the gp85 gene. Our study reveals the interaction between ALV-J and the host that could facilitate the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs.
authors: Dong, X.;Meng, F.;Hu, T.;Ju, S.;Li, Y.;Sun, P.;Wang, Y.;Chen, W.;Zhang, F.;Su, H.;Li, S.;Cui, H.;Chen, J.;Xu, S.;Fang, L.;Luan, H.;Zhang, Z.;Chang, S.;Li, J.;Wang, L.;Zhao, P.;Shi, W.;Cui, Z.

title: First report of Porcine teschovirus (PTV), Porcine sapelovirus (PSV), and Enterovirus G (EV-G) in Brazilian pig herds
authors: Donin, D. G.;Leme, R. de Arruda;Alfieri, A. F.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of rotavirus A NSP2 gene sequences and evidence of intragenic recombination
abstract: Rotavirus nonstructural protein NSP2 is one of the earliest and most abundant viral proteins produced during infection. This protein has many essential roles in RNA binding, viroplasm formation, replication cycle involving helicase and can hydrolyze β-phosphate of RNA and NTPs, acting as an RTPase and NTPase. Analysis of sequences from rotavirus strains isolated in Australia between 1984 and 2009 revealed that the NSP2 gene was highly conserved and clustered with NSP2 genotypes N1 and N2, which were defined according to the whole genome-based rotavirus classification system. Phylogenetic analysis showed that NSP2 gene sequences isolated from Australian rotavirus strains formed four distinct lineages. Temporal variation was observed in several clusters over the 26-year period, with ancestry D and A detected only since 1999 during the entire study period. Phylogenetic analysis and dendrograms identified NSP2 genes that exhibited reclassification between different virus VP7 genotypes. Sequence from a human strain closely grouped with the NSP2 genes of bovine rotavirus strains. This study also identified a cross-lineage sequence that exhibits evidence of recombination in which intergenic recombination has been detected for the first time in an NSP2 gene sequence. This work increases the understanding of the evolutionary mechanisms of NSP2 in terms of improved vaccine design. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Donker, N. C.;Boniface, K.;Kirkwood, C. D.

title: Identification of fungi in shotgun metagenomic datasets
abstract: Metagenomics uses nucleic acid sequencing to characterize species diversity in different niches, such as environmental biomes or the human microbiome. Most studies have used 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing to identify bacteria. However, the decreasing sequencing cost has resulted in a gradual shift away from amplicon analyzes and towards shotgun metagenomic sequencing. Shotgun metagenomic data can be used to identify a wide variety of species, but has rarely been applied to fungal identification. Here, we develop a set of classification pipeline called FindFungi and use it to identify fungal sequences in publicly available metagenome datasets. We focus primarily on animal metagenomes, particularly those from the pig and mouse microbiomes. We identified fungi in 39 of the 70 datasets of 71 fungal species. At least 11 pathogenic species with zoonotic potential have been identified, including Candida tropicalis. We identified Pseudogymnoascus species from 13 Antarctic soil samples that were initially analyzed for the presence of bacteria capable of degrading diesel oil. We also show that Candida tropicalis and Candida loboi are probably the same species. Additionally, we identified several instances where contaminating DNA was erroneously incorporated into fungal genome assemblies.
authors: Donovan, P. D.;Gonzalez, G.;Higgins, D. G.;Butler, G.;Ito, K.

title: The art of culture: Developing cell lines
authors: Dove, A.

title: Assessing the Diversity of Rodent-Transmitted Viruses: High-throughput Sequencing and Discovery of Classical Amplification/Sequencing Approaches
abstract: Rodents are distributed worldwide and interact with humans in many ways. They provide vital ecosystem services, some species are useful models in biomedical research, and some are kept as pets. However, many rodent species can have adverse effects, such as damage to crops and stored products, and are a health concern due to the transmission of pathogens to humans and animals. The first rodent viruses were discovered through isolation approaches, resulting in groundbreaking information in immunology, molecular and cell biology, and cancer research. In addition to rodent-specific viruses, rodent-borne viruses cause numerous zoonotic diseases. The most prominent examples are the reoccurring outbreaks of human hemorrhagic fever disease caused by arena and hantaviruses. In addition, rodents, tick-borne encephalitis virus and Borrelia spp. They are reservoirs for vector-borne pathogens such as Today, next-generation sequencing or high-throughput sequencing (HTS) is revolutionizing the rate at which new viruses are discovered, but other molecular approaches, such as generic RT-PCR/PCR and rolling circle amplification techniques, are contributing significantly. fast-paced process. However, when comparing known human viruses to those known for rodents, the mammalian taxon with the largest species number, the available information still represents only the tip of the iceberg. The diagnostic potential of HTS-based metagenomic approaches is demonstrated by their use in whole genome determination and discovery of novel borne- and adenoviruses as causative disease agents in squirrels. As a result, HTS combined with traditional RT-PCR/PCR-based approaches resulted in a significantly increased knowledge of the diversity of rodent viruses. Future improvements of the workflows used, including bioinformatics analysis, will further increase our knowledge and preparedness should new viruses emerge. Classical virological and additional molecular approaches are needed for genome annotation, functional characterization, and evaluation of their zoonotic potential of novel viruses discovered by these technologies.
authors: Drewes, S.;StrakovÃ¡, P.;Drexler, J. F.;Jacob, J.;Ulrich, R. G.

title: Bats host major mammalian paramyxoviruses
abstract: The large virus family Paramyxoviridae includes some of the most important human and animal viruses such as measles-, distemper-, mumps-, parainfluenza-, Newcastle disease-, respiratory syncytial virus and metapneumoviruses. Here, we detect an estimated 66 novel paramyxoviruses in a sample of 119 bat and rodent species (9,278 individuals) worldwide. Major discoveries include evidence of the origin of Hendra- and Nipah virus in Africa, identification of a bat virus specific to human mumps virus, detection of close relatives of respiratory syncytial virus, direct evidence of mouse pneumonia and canine distemper virus in bats, as well as Sendai virus in rodents. Phylogenetic reconfiguration of host associations suggests that host transitions from bats to other mammals and birds predominate. Hypothesis tests in the maximum likelihood framework allow for the phylogenetic placement of bats as temporary hosts in the ancestral nodes of both major Paramyxoviridae subfamilies (Paramyxovirinae and Pneumovirinae). Future attempts to predict the emergence of new paramyxoviruses in humans and animals will have to rely mainly on these data. Â© 2012 Macmillan Publishers Limited. All rights reserved.
authors: Drexler, J. F.;Corman, V. M.;MÃ¼ller, M. A.;Maganga, G. D.;Vallo, P.;Binger, T.;Gloza-Rausch, F.;Rasche, A.;Yordanov, S.;Seebens, A.;Oppong, S.;Sarkodie, Y. A.;Pongombo, C.;Lukashev, A. N.;Schmidt-Chanasit, J.;StÃ¶cker, A.;Carneiro, A. J. B.;Erbar, S.;Maisner, A.;Fronhoffs, F.;Buettner, R.;Kalko, E. K. V.;Kruppa, T.;Franke, C. R.;Kallies, R.;Yandoko, E. R. N.;Herrler, G.;Reusken, C.;Hassanin, A.;KrÃ¼ger, D. H.;Matthee, S.;Ulrich, R. G.;Leroy, E. M.;Drosten, C.

title: Bats worldwide carry viruses related to the hepatitis E virus, forming a putative new genus within the family Hepeviridae.
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is one of the most common causes of acute hepatitis in tropical and temperate climates. Tropical genotypes 1 and 2 are associated with foodborne and waterborne transmission. Zoonotic reservoirs (mainly pigs, wild boar and deer) are considered for genotypes 3 and 4 found in temperate climates. Considering the association of several zoonotic viruses with bats, we analyzed 3,869 bat samples from 85 different species and five continents for hepevirus RNA. HEVs have been detected in African, Central American and European bats, forming a new phylogenetic branch in the Hepeviridae family. Bat hepeviruses were highly diverse and comparable to human HEV in sequence variation. No evidence of human transmission of bat hepeviruses was found in more than 90,000 human blood donations and in individual patient sera. Whole genome analysis of a representative virus confirmed the official classification within the family Hepeviridae. Sequence and distance-based taxonomic considerations suggested that bat hepeviruses form a separate genus within the family Hepeviridae, and that at least three other genera can be identified, comprising human, rodent, and avian hepeviruses. This could mean that hepeviruses have recently invaded mammalian hosts and undergo speciation according to host constraints. Human HEV-related viruses in livestock and peridomestic animals may represent secondary acquisitions of human viruses rather than animal precursors causally involved in human HEV evolution. Â© 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Drexler, J. F.;Seelen, A.;Corman, V. M.;Tateno, A. F.;Cottontail, V.;Zerbinati, R. M.;Gloza-Rausch, F.;Klose, S. M.;Adu-Sarkodie, Y.;Oppong, S. K.;Kalko, E. K. V.;Osterman, A.;Rasche, A.;Adam, A.;MÃ¼ller, M. A.;Ulrich, R. G.;Leroy, E. M.;Lukashev, A. N.;Drosten, C.

title: Next-generation sequencing demonstrates West Nile virus half-species diversity after a single pass in an in vivo infection model in a carrion crow (Corvus corone).
abstract: West Nile virus (WNV) occurs as a population of genetic variants (quasispecies) that infect a single animal. Previous low-resolution estimates of viral genetic diversity in sampled wild birds and mosquitoes and in multiple passage adaptation studies in vivo or in cell culture suggest that WNV genetic diversity is mostly limited to the mosquito vector. This study investigated the genetic variation of WNV in avian hosts during a single passage using next-generation sequencing. Wild-caught carrion crows were subcutaneously infected using a clonal Middle Eastern WNV. Blood samples were taken 2 and 4 days after infection. A reverse transcription (RT)-PCR approach was used to amplify the WNV genome directly from serum samples prior to next-generation sequencing, yielding at least 700 x average depth in each sample. Appropriate controls were sequenced to distinguish biologically relevant low-frequency variants from experimentally revealed errors. WNV populations in wild crows showed considerable diversity, far from the vaccinia virus semispecies structure. In contrast, WNV populations in intracerebrally infected day-old chickens were not different from those of the inoculum. Where previous studies have concluded that WNV genetic diversity is only experimentally demonstrated in permitted insect vector species, we have experimentally demonstrated that WNV populations vary significantly in a wild bird reservoir species.
authors: Dridi, M.;Rosseel, T.;Orton, R.;Johnson, P.;Lecollinet, S.;Muylkens, B.;Lambrecht, B.;Van Borm, S.

title: Complete nucleotide sequence of vaccine strain of Chinese serotype Asia1 of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: The full-length nucleotide sequence of the Chinese vaccine strain Asia1/YNBS/58 of the foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) was determined. The results showed that the complete genome of YNBS/58 is 8,164 nucleotides (nt) long, including 1,061-nt 5â€² untranslated region (UTR), 6,990-nt open reading frame (ORF), and 113-nt 3â. €² UTR. Genome sequences of Asia1/YNBS/58 and other known FMDV strains were compared. Homology analysis showed that non-structural proteins were more conserved than structural proteins in FMDV, and the 5â€² UTR was more conserved than the 3â€² UTR. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that Asia1/YNBS/58 clustered in the Asia1 serotype and was associated with three other isolates, Asia1/IND/63/72, Asia1/3chymron/63 and Asia1/2ISRL/63, suggesting that they are closely related. genetic relationship. VP1-, VP2-, and VP3-based phylogenetic trees were divided into different clusters according to different serotypes, while other gene-based phylogenetic trees exhibited some degree of crossover between serotypes. According to the nucleotide similarities between Asia1/YNBS/58 and two new Chinese Asia1 isolates, Asia1/HKN/05 and Asia1/JS/05, each constitutes a distinct genotype. This study is the first annotation of the full-length genomic sequence of the FMDV Chinese serotype Asia1. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Du, J.;Chang, H.;Cong, G.;Shao, J.;Lin, T.;Shang, Y.;Liu, Z.;Liu, X.;Cai, X.;Xie, Q.

title: MicroRNA expression profile of primary sheep testicular cells in response to bluetongue virus infection
abstract: Bluetongue virus (BTV) is a member of the Orbivirus genus in the family Reoviridae and causes a non-contagious, insect-borne disease in domestic and wild ruminant animals, primarily sheep, and sometimes cattle and some deer species. Virus infection can trigger changes in the cellular microRNA (miRNA) expression profile, which plays important post-transcriptional regulatory roles in gene expression and can greatly influence viral replication and pathogenesis. Here, we used deep sequencing technology to determine which cellular miRNAs are differentially expressed in primary sheep testicular (ST) cells infected with BTV. A total of 25 known miRNAs and 240 new miRNA candidates differentially expressed in BTV-infected and uninfected ST cells were identified, and 251 and 8428 predicted target genes were annotated, respectively. Nine differentially expressed miRNAs and their mRNA targets were confirmed by quantitative reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction. Target prediction and functional analysis of these regulated miRNAs revealed significant enrichment for a variety of signaling pathways, including MAPK, PI3K-Akt, endocytosis, Hippo, NF-kB, viral carcinogenesis, FoxO, and JAK-STAT signaling pathways. This study provides a valuable basis for further research into the roles of miRNAs in BTV replication and pathogenesis.
authors: Du, J.;Gao, S.;Tian, Z.;Xing, S.;Huang, D.;Zhang, G.;Zheng, Y.;Liu, G.;Luo, J.;Chang, H.;Yin, H.

title: Distribution and characteristics of rodent picornaviruses in China
abstract: Rodents are important reservoir hosts of many important zoonotic viruses. The Picornaviridae family contains clinically important pathogens that infect humans and animals, and an increasing number of rodent picornaviruses have recently been associated with zoonoses. From October 2013 to July 2015, we collected 574 pharyngeal and anal swab samples from 287 rodents from 10 different species from eight representative regions of China. Seven representative sequences identified from six rodent species were amplified as complete genomes and classified into four lineages. The three lineage 1 viruses belonged to a novel picornavirus genus and were more closely related to Hepatovirus than to other picornaviruses based on aa homology. Lineage 2, lineage 3 and lineage 4 viruses belong to the genera Rosavirus, Hunnivirus and Enterovirus, which represent the new species, respectively. Based on both phylogenetic and identity analyses, Lineage 2 viruses were closely related to rosavirus 2 obtained from the feces of a child in The Gambia, and Lineage 3 viruses were closely related to pet Hunnivirus. Lineage 4 viruses provide the first evidence of these enteroviruses and their evolution in rodent hosts in China.
authors: Du, J.;Lu, L.;Liu, F.;Su, H. X.;Dong, J.;Sun, L. L.;Zhu, Y. F.;Ren, X. W.;Yang, F.;Guo, F.;Liu, Q. Y.;Wu, Z. Q.;Jin, Q.

title: Molecular evolution and emergence of the H5N6 avian influenza virus in central China.
abstract: The H5N6 avian influenza virus (AIV) has posed a potential threat to public health since its emergence in China in 2013. To understand the evolution and emergence of H5N6 AIV in the avian population, we conducted molecular surveillance of live poultry markets (LPMs) in Wugang. Province of Hunan Province in central China in 2014 and 2015. Wugang Province is located on the East Asia-Australia migratory bird crossing route and one human death was reported in the province on 21 November 2016 due to an H5N6 virus. In total, we sampled and sequenced the complete genomes of 175 H5N6 AIVs. Notably, our analysis revealed that H5N6 AIVs contain at least six genotypes resulting from segment reclassification, including a rare variant with an HA gene derived from the H5N1 clade 2.3.2 and a novel NP gene whose origins are H7N3 viruses. In addition, phylogenetic analysis revealed that genetically similar H5N6 AIVs tended to cluster according to geographic regions of origin. These results help reveal the evolutionary behavior of influenza viruses before they appeared in humans.
authors: Du, Y.;Chen, M.;Yang, J.;Jia, Y.;Han, S.;Holmes, E. C.;Cui, J.

title: Identification, phylogenetic evolutionary analysis of GDQY orf virus isolated from Qingyuan City, Guangdong Province, southern China.
abstract: Infection with Orf virus (ORFV) leads to infectious ecthyma, also called infectious pustular dermatitis, which often affects sheep, goats and other small ruminants. It has a large worldwide distribution and has also been reported to infect humans. Although many strains have been isolated from different parts of mainland China, rarely any strains have been reported from the southern provinces of China. We reviewed a case of orf virus infection that occurred in Qingyuan City, Guangdong Province in southern China. An orf virus strain, GDQY, was successfully isolated and identified by cell culture techniques and transmission electron microscopy. The complete genes of ORFV011, ORFV059, ORFV106 and ORFV107 were amplified for sequence analysis based on nucleotide or amino acid levels. To discuss genetic variation, precise sequences were used to compare with other reference strains isolated from different regions or countries. Phylogenetic trees were constructed based on these species and evolutionary distances were calculated based on the alignment of their exact sequences. The typical structure of Orf virus was observed in cell culture suspensions inoculated with GDQY, and the full length of the four genes were amplified and sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis showed that GDQY is homologous to FJ-DS and CQ/WZ on ORFV011 nucleotides. ORFV059 may be more variable than ORFV011 based on comparison between GDQY and other isolates. Genetic studies of ORFV106 and 107 were reported for the first time in the presented study.
authors: Duan, C.;Liao, M.;Wang, H.;Luo, X.;Shao, J.;Xu, Y.;Li, W.;Hao, W.;Luo, S.

title: Isolation and characterization of influenza A virus (subtype H5N1) causing the first highly pathogenic avian influenza outbreak in chickens in Bhutan.
abstract: In 2010, we identified the Influenza A/H5N1 virus that caused the first outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in chickens in Bhutan. The virus was highly virulent for chicken and killed them within two days of experimental vaccination with an intravenous pathogenicity index (IVPI) of 2.88. Full genome sequencing of 4 viral isolates was performed for genetic and phylogenetic analyses. The isolates revealed multiple basic amino acids at the cleavage sites of hemagglutinin (HA), similar to other "Qinghai-like" H5N1 isolates. The receptor binding site of the HA molecule contained bird-like amino acids (222Q and 224G). The isolates also contained amino acid residue K at position 627 of the PB2 protein and other markers in the NS 1 and PB1 proteins, emphasizing the risk to mammals. However, the isolates were susceptible to currently commercially available influenza drugs. Sequence analysis showed that Bhutanese viruses shared 99.1-100% nucleotide homology in all eight genes among themselves, and a 2010 chicken isolate from Bangladesh (A/chicken/Bangladesh/1151-11/2010) showed the common progenitor virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the Bhutanese isolates belonged to subdivision 2.2.3 (EMA 3) and shared a common progenitor virus with the 2010 Bangladesh virus. Based on the evidence of phylogeny and molecular markers, it can be concluded that the outbreaks in Bhutan and Bangladesh in 2010 were caused by the independent introduction of the virus, possibly through migratory birds. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Dubey, S. C.;Dahal, N.;Nagarajan, S.;Tosh, C.;Murugkar, H. V.;Rinzin, K.;Sharma, B.;Jain, R.;Katare, M.;Patil, S.;Khandia, R.;Syed, Z.;Tripathi, S.;Behera, P.;Kumar, M.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Krishna, L.

title: Identification of a novel coronavirus from guinea fowl using metagenomics
abstract: Although classical virology techniques, such as virus culture, electron microscopy, or classical PCR, have failed to identify the causative agent of guinea fowl flare disease, we have identified a novel disease-associated avian gammacoronavirus using metagenomics. Next-generation sequencing is an unbiased approach that allows sequencing almost all the genetic material present in a given sample.
authors: Ducatez, M. F.;Guerin, J. L.

title: Characterization of a novel genotype and serotype of infectious bronchitis virus in West Africa.
abstract: Between 2002 and 2007, more than 1,000 chickens from commercial farms, live bird markets and backyard farms in Nigeria and Niger were tested for the presence of the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) genome. Phylogenetic analysis of the full-length sequences of the Spike 1 (S1) gene revealed a new IBV genotype, which we have named 'IBADAN'. The minimum genetic distance to the nearest 'non-IBADAN' strains (UK/7/93 at nucleotide level; H120 and M41 at amino acid level) reached 24% and 32% at nucleotide and amino acid levels, respectively. The complete genome of the IBADAN reference strain (NGA/A116E7/2006) had a genetic distance of 9.7-16.4% at the nucleotide level with all available fully sequenced strains. Since IBV S1 plays an important role in antigenicity, the antigenic relevance of NGA/A116E7/2006 was compared with strains of other serotypes. NGA/A116E7/2006 did not cross-react with antisera against strains IT02, M41, D274, Connecticut or 793/B in virus neutralization experiments. NGA/A116E7/2006 cross-reacted with the QX-like ITA/90254/2005 strain, but only at a low level (33% antigenic association), suggesting that IBADAN also represents a new serotype. Comparison of S1 sequences identified several amino acids that may play a role in IBV antigenicity. Despite the absence of obvious clinical signs in birds infected with IBADAN strains, it is important to test for cross-protection of current vaccine strains. © 2009 SGM.
authors: Ducatez, M. F.;Martin, A. M.;Owoade, A. A.;Olatoye, I. O.;Alkali, B. R.;Maikano, I.;Snoeck, C. J.;Sausy, A.;Cordioli, P.;Muller, C. P.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of low pathogenicity H5N1 and H7N3 influenza A virus isolates from sentry, free-flying, wild mallards at a study site in 2006.
abstract: Between August and October 11, 2006, low pathogenicity (LP) North American strains H5N1 and H7N3 avian influenza A viruses (AIV) and other subtype clusters were obtained from free-flying, resident wild mallards, one of which was used as a sentry. domain. The antigenic subtypes, pathogenicity potentials and Sanger sequencing of the identified isolates of H5N1 and H7N3 isolates were obtained only from samples collected on 8/2/2006 and 9/8/2006, respectively. However, subsequent efforts using next-generation sequencing (NGS) and additional Sanger sequencing found partial H7 segments in other HA-NA virus combinations on 8/2/2006, 9/8/2006, and 10/11/2006. It is well known that AIVs form temporal genomic constellations over wider geographic areas and over the years; these sequential sampling data revealed that dynamics of AIVs may be active within a short period of time and that newer sequencing platforms are increasing recognition of mixed infections. Both findings provide further insight into the natural history of AIVs in natural reservoirs. © 2011 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Dugan, V. G.;Dunham, E. J.;Jin, G.;Sheng, Z. M.;Kaser, E.;Nolting, J. M.;Alexander, H. L.;Slemons, R. D.;Taubenberger, J. K.

title: Viral diversity in porcine intestinal mucus used for heparin production as analyzed by high-throughput sequencing
abstract: Heparin is one of the main pharmaceutical products made from raw animal ingredients. To identify the viral load associated with this raw material, we performed high-throughput sequencing (HTS) on mucus samples for heparin production collected from European pigs. We identified the Circoviridae and Parvoviridae members as the most common contaminating viruses, along with viruses from the Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Reoviridae, Caliciviridae, Adenoviridae, Birnaviridae and Anelloviridae families. New putative viral strains were also identified. The burden of several known or novel small non-enveloped viruses that are particularly difficult to inactivate or eliminate during heparin processing was measured by qPCR. Analysis of combined HTS and specific qPCR results will influence the refinement and validation of inactivation procedures and also aid in risk analysis of viral heparin contamination.
authors: Dumarest, M.;Muth, E.;Cheval, J.;Gratigny, M.;HÃ©bert, C.;Gagnieur, L.;Eloit, M.

title: Effects of house environment on poultry litter bacterial community composition
abstract: Viral and bacterial pathogens are a major economic concern for the US broiler industry, and the ecological epicenter of poultry pathogens is the mix of poultry litter bedding, chicken droppings and feathers. This study used high-throughput sequencing to assess the richness and diversity of poultry litter bacterial communities and to explore links between these communities and a poultry's environmental characteristics, including its history of gangrenous dermatitis (GD). Cluster analysis of 16S rRNA gene sequences revealed differences in the distribution of bacterial phylotypes between Wet and Dry litter samples and houses. The wet litter contained more diversity, with 90% of the total bacterial abundance occurring in the first 214 OTU clusters. In contrast, only 50 clusters accounted for 90% of Dry litter bacterial abundance. Arcobacter sp., an emerging human pathogen that occurs only in Wet litter samples of a house with a modern evaporative cooling system. Sixth largest cluster of OTUs among all samples classified as Ironically, the primary pathogenic clostridial and staphylococcal species associated with GD were not found in any household; however, there were thirteen 16S rRNA gene phylotypes, mostly Gram-positive phyla, specific to GD-affected homes and occurring primarily in Wet litter samples. Overall, the poultry environment has been shown to significantly affect the composition of litter bacterial communities and may play an important role in the emergence of foodborne pathogens. Â© 2011 Dumas et al.
authors: Dumas, M. D.;Polson, S. W.;Ritter, D.;Ravel, J.;Gelb Jr, J.;Morgan, R.;Wommack, K. E.

title: Molecular and microscopic evidence of viruses in marine copepods
abstract: As dominant members of marine mesozooplankton communities, copepods play critical roles in oceanic food webs and in the biogeochemical cycle. Despite the ecological importance of copepods, little is known about the causes of copepod deaths, and up to 35% of total copepod deaths cannot be explained by predation alone. Viruses have been established as ecologically important infectious agents in the oceans; however, viral infection in mesozooplankton communities has not been investigated. Here, we used molecular and microscopic techniques to document viral infection in natural populations of the calanoid copepods Acartia tonsa (Calve) and Labidocera aestiva (Wheeler) in Tampa Bay, FL. Viral metagenomics has revealed previously undocumented viruses of all species called Acartia tonsa copepod circo-like virus (AtCopCV) and Labidocera aestiva copepod circo-like virus (LaCopCV). LaCopCV was found to be extremely common and abundant in L. aestiva populations, with prevalence of up to 100% in some samples and mean viral loads per capita of 1.13 x 10(5) copies. LaCopCV transcription was also detected in most of the L. aestiva individuals showing viral activity. AtCopCV was detected sporadically in A. tonsa populations throughout the year, suggesting temporal variability in viral infection dynamics. Finally, unknown virus-like particles were observed in the connective tissues of A. tonsa and L. aestiva by transmission electron microscopy; this showed that the viruses were actively replicating in copepod connective tissue rather than infecting intestinal contents, parasites or symbionts. Taken together, these results provide strong independent evidence for active viral infection in dominant copepod species, showing that viruses can significantly affect mesozooplankton ecology.
authors: Dunlap, D. S.;Ng, T. F. F.;Rosario, K.;Barbosa, J. G.;Greco, A. M.;Breitbart, M.;Hewson, I.

title: Bovine enteroviruses in the calf: An attempt at serological, biological and pathological classification.
abstract: Bovine enteroviruses have been classified into 8 serotypes to provide a basis for pathogenicity studies. Oral and subcutaneous inoculation of the virus in 1-day to 8-week-old calves generally resulted in leukopenia and fever. Of the 6 colostrum-deprived calves vaccinated before receiving their first milk, 3 died; however, a comparable proportion (9/17) of unvaccinated colostrum-deprived calves also died. Calves 4 to 8 weeks old that were exposed to the virus developed fever and leukopenia, but less than half of the calves developed diarrhea and few died. None of the unvaccinated calves fed colostrum died. In utero infection of the fetus appeared to be a common occurrence, as judged by the presence of antibodies to one or more bovine enteroviruses in fetuses who aborted at 4 months or more of pregnancy. The antibodies were believed to be of fetal origin. It has been hypothesized that intrauterine infection may contribute to the premature death of the newborn calf or the lack of resistance to bacterial infection.
authors: Dunne, H. W.;Huang, C. M.;Lin, W. J.

title: Characterization of novel Bovine Leukemia Virus (BLV) antisense transcripts by deep sequencing reveals constitutive expression and transcriptional interaction with viral microRNAs in tumors.
abstract: Background: Bovine Leukemia Virus (BLV) is a deltaretrovirus closely related to Human T cell leukemia virus-1 (HTLV-1). Cattle are the natural host of BLV, where it integrates into B-cells and produces a lifelong infection. Most infected animals remain asymptomatic, but after a long latency approximately 5% develop an aggressive leukemia/lymphoma, reflecting the disease course of HTLV-1. The mechanisms by which these viruses trigger cellular transformation remain unclear. In both viruses, little or no transcription is observed in tumors from the 5'LTR, but proviruses are not transcriptionally silent. In the case of BLV, an RNA polymerase III transcribed microRNA cluster is highly expressed, while the HTLV-1 antisense transcript HBZ is consistently present in all tumors examined. Results: Here, we show, using RNA-seq, that the BLV provirus constitutively expresses antisense transcripts in all leukemic and asymptomatic samples also examined. The first transcript (AS1) can be alternately polyadenylated and produce ~600bp (AS1-S) transcript and less abundant ~2200bp (AS1-L) transcript. Alternative splicing creates a second transcript of ~400bp (AS2). The coding potential of AS1-S/L is unclear, with a small open reading frame of 264bp, but the transcripts are mainly retained in the nucleus, implying a lncRNA-like role. The AS1-L transcript overlaps with BLV microRNAs, and using high-throughput sequencing of the RNA-ligas-mediated (RLM) 5'RACE, we show that the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC) cleaves AS1-L. Furthermore, experiments using BLV proviruses modified with deleted or reversed microRNAs point to additional transcriptional interaction between the two viral RNA species. Conclusions: The identification of novel viral antisense transcripts suggests that the BLV provirus is far from silent in tumors. Moreover, the consistent expression of these transcripts in both leukemic and non-malignant clones points to a vital role in the virus's life cycle and tumorigenic potential. In addition, cleavage of AS1-L transcript by BLV-encoded microRNAs and transcriptional interference between the two viral RNA species suggest a shared role in the regulation of BLV.
authors: Durkin, K.;Rosewick, N.;Artesi, M.;Hahaut, V.;Griebel, P.;Arsic, N.;Burny, A.;Georges, M.;Van den Broeke, A.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of beak and feather disease virus across a host ring type complex
abstract: Pathogens have been hypothesized to play an important role in host diversity and speciation. Susceptibility of hybrid hosts to pathogens is thought to be a common phenomenon that may promote host population divergence and subsequent speciation. However, when testing common diversity of pathogens in the hybridizing host complex, few studies have been tested for pathogen infection in animal hybrid sites. For over 8 years, we have studied natural infection by the rapidly evolving single-stranded DNA virus, beak and feather disease virus (BFDV), which infects parrots using a host-ring species complex (Platycercus elegans) in Australia. We found that host subspecies and hybrids varied dramatically in both prevalence and burden of BFDV: intermediate subspecies, both hybrid and phenotypical, had lower prevalence and burden compared to the main subspecies, while host age, sex, longitude, and latitude, as well as temporal effects, were controlled by the control subspecies. is done. . We sequenced viral isolates across the range for the first time to our knowledge in any host-pathogen system, revealing patterns of genomic variation similar to Mayr's ring-species hypothesis. Viral phylogeny, geographic location, intraspecies host density, and parrot community diversity and composition did not explain differences in BFDV prevalence or burden among subpopulations. Overall, our analyzes suggest that functional host responses to infection, or strength of infection, differ between subspecies and hybrids. Our findings highlight the role of host hybridization and lines in altering host-pathogen interactions, dynamics that may have important implications for gene flow and speciation patterns, and provide insights into how pathogens can adapt to different host populations.
authors: Eastwood, J. R.;Berg, M. L.;Ribot, R. F.;Raidal, S. R.;Buchanan, K. L.;Walder, K. R.;Bennett, A. T.

title: Novel Atlantic bottlenose dolphin parainfluenza virus TtPIV-1 clusters with bovine PIV-3 genotype B strains
abstract: Parainfluenza virus 3 (PIV-3) is a common viral infection not only in humans but also in many other species. Serological evidence indicates that approximately 100% of children in the United States are infected with PIV-3 by age 5 years. Similarly, in cattle, PIV-3 is commonly associated with the bovine respiratory disease complex. A new dolphin PIV-3 (TtPIV-1) has been described by Nollens et al. From a dolphin diagnosed with an unknown respiratory disease in 2008. At that time, TtPIV-1 was found to be most similar to, but different from, bovine PIV-3 (BPIV-3). In this study, similar viral growth kinetics and production of proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1Î², IL-6 and CXCL8) were observed between BPIV-3 and TtPIV-1 in BEAS-2B, MDBK and Vero cell lines. The initial terminology of TtPIV-1 was based on the partial sequence of the fusion and RNA polymerase genes. Based on the similarities we saw with the in vitro study, it was important to examine the TtPIV-1 genome in more detail. Whole genome sequencing and subsequent phylogenetic analysis revealed that all six viral genes of TtPIV-1 clustered within the recently described BPIV-3 genotype B strains, and reclassification of TtPIV-1 with BPIV-3 genotype B strains was proposed.
authors: Eberle, K. C.;Neill, J. D.;Venn-Watson, S. K.;McGill, J. L.;Sacco, R. E.

title: Characterization of structural proteins of swine epizootic diarrhea virus, strain CV777
abstract: Porcine epizootic diarrhea virus cannot be grown in cell culture; Intestinal perfusate material from a pig infected with strain CV777 should be used for characterization. A peak of virus-specific ELISA activity was detected in isopic sucrose gradients at a density of 1.17 g/ml. Using sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis after immunoprecipitation of radioiodinated-purified virus material, 3 low molecular weight (20,000 to 32,000 daltons [D]) proteins were found; After staining the glycoprotein expression with nitrocellulose and concanavalin A and horseradish peroxidase, 1 of the proteins (23,000 D) gave a signal. Another protein of 58,000 D was encountered, the only protein that binds an RNA probe. Finally, a protein of 85,000 D associated with small bands of approximately 110,000 and 135,000 D was seen in most experiments. The same bands were visualized using the Concanavalin A-blot technique. The demonstration of a polydisperse protein cluster consisting of 20,000 to 32,000 D (at least 1 of which is glycosylated), 85,000 to 135,000 D glycosylated proteins, and an RNA-binding protein of 58,000 D is taken as structural evidence of porcine epizootics. diarrhea virus should be classified with Coronaviridae regardless of the apparent antigenic association with other members of that family.
authors: Egberink, H. F.;Ederveen, J.;Callebaut, P.;Horzinek, M. C.

title: Detection and Molecular Characterization of Foot and Mouth Disease Viruses from Outbreaks in Some States of Northern Nigeria 2013-2015
abstract: Control measures for foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) have not been implemented in Nigeria due to the lack of locally produced vaccines and risk-based analyzes due to insufficient data on circulating FMD virus (FMDV) serotypes/strains. Blood and epithelial samples were collected from FMD outbreaks reported in four states in northern Nigeria (Kaduna, Kwara, Plateau and Bauchi) in 2013-2015. FMDV nonstructural protein (NSP) seroprevalence for outbreaks was estimated at 80% (90/72) and 70% (188) post-outbreak. Antibodies to FMDV serotypes O, A, SAT1, SAT2, and SAT3 were detected across states using solid-phase competitive ELISA. The FMDV genome was detected in 99% (73 out of 74) samples from animals affected by FMD using rRT-PCR, and the cytopathic effect in cell culture was found in 59% (44 out of 74) of these samples. Three FMDV serotypes O, A and SAT2 were isolated and characterized. Phylogenetic evaluations of virus isolates indicated that two topotypes of FMDV serotype O, East Africa-3 (EA-3) and West African (WA) as well as FMDV strains of African genotype (G-IV) were in circulation. serotype A and FMDV SAT2 topotype VII strains. The serotype O (EA-3) strains from Nigeria are most closely related to a 1999 virus strain from Sudan, while the WA strain from Nigeria shares genetic association with three 1988 viruses from Niger. FMDV serotype A strains were closely related to a known virus from Cameroon, and SAT2 strains were most closely related to virus subtypes from Libya. This study provides evidence of co-occurrence of FMDV serotypes and topotypes in West, Central, East and North Africa and is relevant for control. The findings help fill the knowledge gap of FMDV dynamics in Nigeria and the West African subregion to support local and regional development of vaccine-based control plans and international risk assessment.
authors: Ehizibolo, D. O.;Haegeman, A.;De Vleeschauwer, A. R.;Umoh, J. U.;Kazeem, H. M.;Okolocha, E. C.;Van Borm, S.;De Clercq, K.

title: Bovine herpesvirus type 2 is closely related to primate alphaherpes viruses.
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus type 2 (BoHV-2), also known as bovine mammillitis virus, is classified, together with herpes simplex virus types 1 and 2 (HSV-1 and HSV-2), in Family Herpesviridae, Subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae, and Genus Simplexvirus us and its 15 kb U (L) Other primate simplex viruses based on similarities in 4 genes within cluster 23-29. This can be explained by either a global similarity or a recombination event that introduces primate herpesviral sequences into a bovine virus. Our sequences confirm for DNA polymerase (U(L)30), a large gene adjacent to the previously identified conserved cluster, and glycoprotein G (U(S)4), a gene as far away from the cluster as possible on the circularized genome. He claims a close relationship between BoHV-2 and primate simplex viruses and a global similarity and possibly a close evolutionary relationship. Therefore, it can be predicted that BoHV-2 may pose a greater danger to humans than previously appreciated.
authors: Ehlers, B.;Goltz, M.;Ejercito, M. P.;Dasika, G. K.;Letchworth, G. J.

title: Initial outbreaks and phylogenetic analyzes of avian influenza H9N2 viruses isolated from poultry flocks in Morocco
abstract: Background: H9N2 avian influenza viruses continue to spread worldwide in poultry and wild birds. Morocco faced the first H9N2 influenza virus outbreaks affecting different poultry production in early 2016. After the virus was released, it spread very quickly across the country. Methods: Samples were collected from 11 chicken flocks with high morbidity and mortality rates. Four viruses from broilers and one virus from broiler breeders were successfully isolated and fully sequenced. Results: Phylogenetic and molecular marker analyzes indicated that Fas viruses belonged to the G1 lineage and probably originated from the Middle East. Fasanisolates, as is known for H9N2 viruses, have several genetic markers that increase virulence in poultry and transmission to humans. Conclusion: This study demonstrated that under field conditions H9N2 can have a devastating effect on egg production and mortality, highlighting the lack of pathogen-related surveillance data in the region.
authors: El Houadfi, M.;Fellahi, S.;Nassik, S.;GuÃ©rin, J. L.;Ducatez, M. F.

title: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza H5N1 Clade 2.3.2.1c Virus in Lebanon, 2016
abstract: We report the phylogenetic analysis of the first H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza virus outbreak detected in poultry in Lebanon in April 2016. Our whole genome sequencing analysis revealed that the Lebanese H5N1 virus belongs to genetic branch 2.3.2.1c and is located in Europe and West Africa.
authors: El Romeh, A.;Zecchin, B.;Fusaro, A.;Ibrahim, E.;El Bazzal, B.;El Hage, J.;Milani, A.;Zamperin, G.;Monne, I.

title: Detection of the first G6P[14] human rotavirus strain from a child with diarrhea in Egypt
abstract: We report the first detection of a G6P[14] rotavirus strain in the stool of a child who participated in a hospital-based diarrhea surveillance study conducted in Egypt during 2004. Rotavirus infection was initially detected using a rotavirus group A VP6 enzyme immunoassay; P (VP4) and G (VP7) genotypes of the strain were determined by RT-PCR. We sequenced the VP7 gene and the VP8* portion of the VP4 gene, and the strain VP7 [>94% nucleotides (nt), >97% amino acids (aa)] and VP4 (>93% nt, >98% aa) was found in Italy in the winter of 1987. Sequences of PA169, a novel strain of G6P[14] isolated for the first time from juvenile. Additional sequencing and analysis of the remaining structural (VP1-VP3, VP6) and non-structural (VP1-VP3, VP6) proteins (NSP1-NSP5) support this animal-to-human reclassification theory. According to the whole genome classification system, strain G6P[14] (EGY3399) was assigned to the genotypes G6-P[14]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A11-N2-T6-E2-H3. The greatest similarity of EGY3399 NSP4 and NSP5 gene sequences was with those of sheep and monkey origin, respectively. Combined with other observations, our results support other studies showing that G6P[14] isolates rarely cause severe diarrhea in Egyptian children and that animal rotavirus contributes to the genetic diversity of rotavirus detected from humans through interspecies crossover and single- or multi-segment reclassification. © 2011.
authors: El Sherif, M.;Esona, M. D.;Wang, Y.;Gentsch, J. R.;Jiang, B.;Glass, R. I.;Baker, S. A.;Klena, J. D.

title: Avian flu: Virology, diagnosis and surveillance
abstract: Avian influenza virus (AIV) is the causative agent of a zoonotic disease that affects populations worldwide, often with devastating economic and health consequences. Most AIV subtypes cause little or no disease in waterfowl, but outbreaks in poultry may be associated with high mortality. Although transmission of AIV to humans is rare and is strain-dependent, the virus has the ability to mutate or re-transform into a form that triggers a life-threatening infection. The continued emergence of new influenza strains makes it particularly difficult to predict behavior, spread, virulence, or potential for human-to-human transmission. It is difficult to prepare for this event, as it is difficult to predict which viral strain or which location will initiate the next pandemic. However, rigorous implementation of biosecurity, vaccination and education programs can minimize the threat of AIV. Global surveillance programs help record and identify emerging and potentially pandemic strains hosted by the reservoir host. Â© 2013 Future Medicine Ltd.
authors: El Zowalaty, M. E.;Bustin, S. A.;Husseiny, M. I.;Ashour, H. M.

title: Sheep respiratory syncytial virus F gene sequence and its diagnostic application
abstract: Ruminant respiratory syncytial viruses (RSVs) are divided into 2 subgroups, ovine RSV and bovine RSV. Although sheep RSV infects cattle, its contribution to bovine respiratory disease, an important issue for vaccine development in cattle, has not been determined. Diagnosis by virus isolation or serology has low or variable sensitivity and/or specificity, and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) has been proposed as a rapid and sensitive technique for RSV detection. A simple procedure has been developed to detect and identify bovine and ovine RSVs. First, the nucleotide sequence of the sheep RSV fusion (F) gene was determined and compared with representative strains of bovine RSV and human RSV subgroups A and B. The sheep RSV F gene has 85% and 72-73% nucleotide identity with those of cattle. RSV and human RSV, respectively. The predicted amino acid sequence of the sheep RSV F gene has 94% and 83-84% amino acid identity with those of bovine RSV and human RSV, respectively. Next, PCR primers targeting a specific F gene fragment of bovine and ovine RSV were designed. Primers represented the sequence complementary to bases 85-103 and bases 510-493 of the sheep RSV F gene. A similar PCR product (426 bp) was obtained by agarose gel electrophoresis from bovine RSV and ovine RSV. However, the products were specific to the parent virus and could be distinguished by EcoRI or MspI restriction endonuclease cleavage. EcoRI separated the ovine product into 2 bands (285 and 141 bp), but did not affect the bovine RSV PCR product. However, MspI separated the bovine product into 2 bands (229 and 197 bp) but had no effect on the ovine product. In addition, this assay did not amplify any PCR products with human RSV. Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) followed by restriction enzyme digestion is a useful and practical approach for the detection and differentiation of ruminant respiratory syncytial viruses.
authors: Eleraky, N. Z.;Kania, S. A.;Potgieter, L. N.

title: Accurate classification and amino acid signatures of hemagglutinin for influenza A virus host-origin association and subtyping
abstract: Host-origin classification and signatures of influenza A viruses were searched based on the HA protein for HA host tracking. Hidden Markov models (HMMs), decision trees, and associative classification for each influenza A virus subtype and major hosts (human, avian, pig) were constructed. Features of HA protein signatures that are specific to the host and subtype were sought. Host-associated signatures revealed in different subtypes of the virus were identified. Support and confidence ratings were performed for evaluation of classification models based on ROC curves and amino acid class association rules. Host classification based on HA subtype achieved accuracy between 91.2% and 100% using decision trees after feature selection. Host-specific class association rules for avian-host origins gave better ratings of support and confidence, followed by human and finally porcine origin. This finding indicated lower specificity of the pig host, perhaps pointing to the ability to mix different strains. © 2013 Elsevier Inc.
authors: ElHefnawi, M.;Sherif, F. F.

title: Close linkage of genes encoding receptors for A and C subgroups of avian sarcoma/leukosis virus on chicken chromosome 28
abstract: Avian sarcoma and leucosis viruses (ASLV) are classified into six major subgroups (A to E to J) based on the properties of viral envelope proteins and the use of cellular receptors for virus entry. Subgroup A and B receptors are molecularly identified and their genomic locations TVA and TVB mapped. Subgroup C receptor unknown, its genomic locus TVC is reported to be genetically linked to TVA located on chicken chromosome 28. In this study, we used two chicken strains in themselves carrying different allelic encodings for resistance (TVCR) and susceptibility (TFCS) against infection by subgroup C viruses. A backross population of these lines was tested for susceptibility to subgroup C infection and genotyped for markers from chicken chromosome 28. We confirmed the close link between the TVA and TVC loci. We also defined the position of TVC on chromosome 28 relative to markers in the consensus map of the chicken genome.
authors: Elleder, D.;PlachÃ½, J.;Hejnar, J.;Geryk, J.;Svoboda, J.

title: Identification and genetic characterization of rabies virus from Egyptian buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) bitten by a fox
abstract: Rabies is caused by a negative-stranded RNA virus classified in the genus Lyssavirus of the family Rhabdoviridae of the order Mononegavirales. The aim of this study was to determine and analyze the nucleotide sequence of the nucleoprotein (N) gene of the rabies virus (RABV) from two buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) bites in Egypt in 2013. The diseased buffaloes showed nervous symptoms. with fire. Samples were collected from the brains of buffaloes suspected of rabies. RABV in collected samples was identified using direct fluorescent antibody (dFA) technique, histopathological examination, and reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Also, the nucleotide sequence of the partially amplified nucleoprotein (N) gene was compared with other RABV wild strains available in GenBank. The results revealed that RABV antigen was identified by dFA technique in diseased buffalo brains and characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusions (Negri bodies) and RABV nucleic acid were detected by histopathology and RT-PCR, respectively. The identified virus showed close genetic association with previously identified stray strains from dogs in different Governorates in Egypt and strains identified in Israel and Jordan, indicating transmission of the virus between Egyptian Governorates and potential transmission from and/or neighboring countries.
authors: El-Tholoth, M.;El-Beskawy, M.;Hamed, M. F.

title: Phages rarely encode antibiotic resistance genes: a cautionary tale for virome assays
authors: Enault, F.;Briet, A.;Bouteille, L.;Roux, S.;Sullivan, M. B.

title: Genome of bovine herpes virus 1 (BHV-1) strains that exhibit neuropathogenic potential compared to known BHV-1 strains via restriction site mapping and cross hybridization
authors: Engels, M.;Giuliani, C.;Wild, P.

title: Genetic and virulence characterization of classic swine fever viruses isolated in Mongolia from 2007 to 2015.
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF), a highly contagious viral disease affecting domestic and wild pigs in many developing countries, is considered endemic in Mongolia with 14 recent outbreaks in 2007, 2008, 2011, 2012, 2014 and 2015. For the first CSF viruses isolated from these 14 outbreaks were analyzed in pigs to evaluate their molecular epidemiology and pathogenicity. Based on the nucleotide sequences of the 5–² untranslated regions, the isolates were phylogenetically classified as 2.1b or 2.2 subgenotypes, and the 2014 and 2015 isolates classified as 2.1b were closely related to the Chinese and Chinese isolates. Korea. Also, at least three different viruses classified as 2.1b circulate in Mongolia. Experimental infection of the representative isolate in 2014 showed moderate pathogenicity with relatively mild clinical manifestations in pigs at 4 weeks of age. Understanding the diversity of circulating CSF viruses provides insight into disease dynamics and evolution and can inform the design of effective CSF control strategies in Mongolia.
authors: Enkhbold, B.;Shatar, M.;Wakamori, S.;Tamura, T.;Hiono, T.;Matsuno, K.;Okamatsu, M.;Umemura, T.;Damdinjav, B.;Sakoda, Y.

title: Virology in the 21st century
authors: Enquist, L. W.

title: Structural similarities of swine cholera virus with togaviruses
authors: Enzmann, P. J.;Weiland, F.

title: Viral discovery as a tool for pandemic preparedness
abstract: Emerging diseases are often caused by new or previously unrecognized zoonotic viral pathogens, and they tend to originate and emerge from wildlife. When human or animal cases are first identified, specific molecular or serological diagnostic tests are not yet available, resulting in a delay in determining the etiologic agent and source of an outbreak. Preparing for the next virus emergence is a major public health concern due to poor understanding of the diversity of potential candidates found in wildlife reservoirs. Characterizing the diversity of viruses in key wildlife species will help reduce the time between detection and response in the event of an epidemic and inform public health strategies that reduce the risk of spread from animal reservoirs. Pathogen discovery techniques such as consensus polymerase chain reaction (cPCR) and next-generation sequencing (NGS) have been used to identify known and novel viruses in animals and humans, but have not been widely used in surveillance programs. Metagenomic studies have identified new viruses, new strains of known viruses, and characterized host microbiomes. While NGS represents an unbiased approach to viral sequence detection, it is limited to lower sensitivity than conventional PCR, requires significant bioinformatics capabilities, and is low cost and therefore not commonly found in the regions of the world most vulnerable to zoonotic disease formation. In contrast, consensus PCR uses standard and widely available technologies, has greater sensitivity than NGS, and has also been used to identify novel viruses in wildlife, livestock, and humans, although it is limited to detecting conserved target genetic sequences among known virus groups. The use of cPCR, if possible in combination with NGS and serology, can offer a powerful approach to the rapid identification of etiologic agents in an epidemic and to characterize the important wildlife virome known to carry zoonotic viruses. Here, the authors review the pathogen discovery techniques currently used in human and animal surveillance programs and the challenges of using viral discovery to identify novel zoonotic pathogens.
authors: Epstein, J. H.;Anthony, S. J.

title: Major transitions in human evolution revisited: A tribute to ancient DNA
abstract: The origin and diversity of modern humans has been characterized by major evolutionary transitions and demographic changes. Patterns of genetic variation in modern populations could help reconstruct something akin to 200,000 years of population history. However, by combining this information with genomic data from ancient remains, we can now have direct access to our evolutionary history and reveal our population history in much greater detail. This review summarizes major recent achievements in ancient DNA research and shows how the field has moved from polymerase chain reaction (PCR) amplification of short mitochondrial fragments to whole genome sequencing, thus revisiting our own history. Ancient DNA studies have revealed the paths our ancestors took while colonizing the planet, who they mixed with, how they domesticated plant and animal species, how they genetically responded to changes in lifestyle, and also which pathogens destroyed their populations. These approaches promise to soon resolve many of the pending debates about our own origins that cannot be resolved from modern patterns of genetic variation alone, and therefore provide an extremely powerful toolkit for the next generation of molecular anthropologists. (c) 2014 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Ermini, L.;Sarkissian, C. D.;Willerslev, E.;Orlando, L.

title: Viral Communities Between Sympathetic Vampire Bats and Cattle
abstract: Vampire bats are the only mammal known to feed exclusively on blood from other animals, usually domestic cattle. We tested the hypothesis that adaptation of vampire bats to hematophagy would result in shared viral communities between vampire bats and cattle as a direct result of historical spillover events due to hematophagy. We analyzed the presence of different viruses in sample populations of sympathetic bat and prey populations and looked for viruses shared between taxa. A limited number of DNA viral groups were detected within each species. However, there was no evidence of a common viral community between the vampire bat and cattle populations tested.
authors: Escalera-Zamudio, M.;Taboada, B.;Rojas-Anaya, E.;LÃ¶ber, U.;Loza-Rubio, E.;Arias, C. F.;Greenwood, A. D.

title: Large deletions in the 5'-untranslated region of the foot-and-mouth disease virus of serotype C
abstract: The nucleotide sequences of the 5'-untranslated region (5'-UTR) on the 3' side of the Poly C pathway were compared for 21 isolates of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) of serotype C from Europe. , South America and the Philippines. Compared to most American isolates, European isolates have a 43 nucleotide deletion. A larger deletion of 86 nucleotides is present in some viruses from South America and the Philippines. These deletions include the loss of one or two predicted pseudoknot structures in this region of the 5'-UTR. In addition, multiple point mutations allowed the derivation of a phylogenetic tree that defined a group of isolates very similar to that derived from the capsid gene sequences of the same viruses. The study provides evidence that deletion (or insertion) events must have been very frequent during the evolution of FMDV type C, because phylogenetically very closely related (belonging to the same tree branch) viruses may differ in the presence or absence of these deletions. Implications for FMDV evolution are discussed.
authors: Escarmis, C.;Dopazo, J.;Davila, M.;Palma, E. L.;Domingo, E.

title: Effect of antigenic and genetic drift on serological surveillance of H5N2 avian influenza viruses
abstract: Serological surveillance of Avian Influenza (AI) viruses is performed by the hemagglutination inhibition (HI) test using reference reagents. This method is recommended by animal health organizations as a standard test to detect antigenic differences (subspecies) between circulating influenza virus, vaccine, and/or reference strains. However, significant differences were observed between reference antisera and field isolates during sero surveillance of influenza A viruses in pig and poultry farms. The aim of this study was to examine the effects of influenza virus genetics and antigenic drift on serological tests using standard HI tests and reference reagents. Low pathogenic AI H5N2 viruses isolated in Mexico between 1994 and 2008 were used for phylogenetic analysis of AI hemagglutinin genes and for serological testing using antisera produced with year-specific AI virus isolates. Phylogenetic analysis revealed a significant difference between early LPAI H5N2 viruses (1994 - 1998) and newer virus domain isolates (2002 - 2008). The results of the HI assay were significantly influenced by the choice of AI H5N2 virus (year of isolation) used as the reference antigen for the assay. These analyzes show that LPAI H5N2 viruses in Mexico consistently undergo genetic drift, and the sero-surveillance of AI viruses is significantly affected by the antigen or antiserum used for HI testing. To keep pace with AI antigenic shift, reference viral antigens and/or antisera must be constantly changed during surveillance of AI viruses. This strategy should improve the estimation of antigenic differences between circulating AI viruses and selection of appropriate vaccine strains.
authors: Escorcia, M.;Carrillo-SÃ¡nchez, K.;March-Mifsut, S.;Chapa, J.;Lucio, E.;Nava, G. M.

title: Identification of novel Newcastle disease virus subgenotype VII-(j) based on fusion protein
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is believed to be the cause of fatal poultry diseases worldwide. The fusion (F) protein plays an important role in virus pathogenesis and is also used for Newcastle disease virus classification. In this study, we determined the complete coding sequence of the F gene in novel velogenic NDV isolates with an intravenous pathogenicity index (IVPI) of 1.8 and a mean time to death (MDT) of 72 or 48Â hours. The complete sequences of the F genes of the new Iranian isolates were amplified and sequenced in both directions. These isolates were compared to 195 nucleotide sequences obtained from GenBank (available as of 07/17/2016). A phylogenetic tree for the F gene was constructed using MEGA6 software with statistical analysis based on 500 bootstrap copies. Evolutionary distances revealed that the new virulent isolates from Iran belonged to genotype VII in a new distinct subgenotype named VII-(j). This new subgenotype deviated 3% from genotype VIId. Recombination analysis showed that these new isolates were not recombinant NDVs.
authors: Esmaelizad, M.;Mayahi, V.;Pashaei, M.;Goudarzi, H.

title: Echination (horsepox vaccine): an early alternative to vaccination (cattlepox vaccine) and potential role of equinepox virus in the origin of smallpox vaccine
abstract: Nearly 150 years after Edward Jenner published "The Investigation" in 1798, it was generally assumed that cowpox virus was the vaccine against smallpox. It wasn't until 1939 that vaccinia, the smallpox vaccine virus, was serologically related but different from cowpox virus. In the absence of a known natural host, the vaccine was considered to be a laboratory virus that may have resulted from mutational or recombinational events involving cowpox virus, variola viruses, or some unknown ancestral Orthopox viruses. A favorite candidate for a vaccine progenitor has been the horsepox virus. Edward Jenner suspected that cowpox was derived from horsepox, and also believed that the "substance" from both diseases could be used as a preventative for smallpox. In the 19th century, horsepox vaccine (echination) was used together with cowpox vaccine (vaccination) in Europe to prevent smallpox. Vaccine production practices in the 19th century may have resulted in the use of virus mixtures, resulting in different genetic modifications that resulted in today's vaccine strains. Horsepox, a disease previously reported only in Europe, began disappearing on this continent since the turn of the 20th century and now appears to be extinct, but the virus perhaps continues to lurk in an unknown reservoir. Genomic sequencing of a horsepox virus isolated in Mongolia in 1976 showed that although closely related to the vaccine, this equinepox virus contains additional, potentially ancestral sequences not found in vaccines. Recent genetic analyzes of current vaccine viruses have revealed that some strains contain ancestral equinepox virus genes or are phylogenetically related to equinepox virus. We recently reported that a commercially produced smallpox vaccine produced in the United States in 1902 is genetically remarkably similar to the horsepox virus, forming a missing link in this 200-year-old mystery.
authors: Esparza, J.;Schrick, L.;Damaso, C. R.;Nitsche, A.

title: Orthopoxvirus DNA: Strain differentiation by electrophoresis of restriction endonuclease-cleaved virion DNA
abstract: Procedures were developed to purify intact intracytoplasmic poxvirus particles from infected cells and isolate DNA from virions by equilibrium centrifugation in sodium diatrizoate density gradients. The supernatant density of twelve closely related orthopoxviruses purified in these gradients was determined as 1.25 g/ml and that of isolated virion DNAs as 1.1 g/ml. Virion DNA from each of the 12 selected prototype and wild-type viruses was partitioned with three distinct site-specific restriction endonucleases, Hind III, Sal I, and Bam HI, and fragments (molecular weights 0.5 × 10 to 20 × 106). separated by agarose gel electrophoresis. The characteristic DNA fragment migration patterns observed in the gels allowed the viruses to be classified. By comparing the profiles of Hind III fragmented DNAs, we were able to classify viruses into 4 types: cowpox, vaccine, monkeypox (2 isolates) and variola (8 isolates). Viruses resulting from infection with variola major can be distinguished from viruses from infection with variola minor. Isolates within the species (strains) were also distinguished mainly by comparing the gel electrophoresis profiles of Sal I-digested DNA from viruses.
authors: Esposito, J. J.;Obijeski, J. F.;Nakano, J. H.

title: zoonotic smallpox viruses
abstract: Poxviruses endanger a long-known group of important pathogens, including some zoonotic members that affect living animals and humans. While whole genome sequence analysis has begun to shed light on the molecular mechanisms underlying host cell infection, viral replication and virulence, our understanding of poxvirus maintenance in nature and their transmission to humans is still poor. In the last two decades, reports of human monkeypox outbreaks in Africa and North America, increased numbers of cowpox virus infections in cats, exotic animals and humans, and human vaccine virus infections in South America and India remind us – alongside eradicated smallpox disease virus - there are other smallpox viruses that can harm men. We are beginning to learn that the host range of some pox viruses is much larger than originally thought, and that mainly rodents serve as virus reservoirs. The following review aims to provide an up-to-date overview of the epidemiology of zoonotic poxviruses and to highlight orthopox viruses. By outlining the available information on poxvirus transmission, we hope to raise awareness about the transmission routes of infections and their correct diagnosis. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Essbauer, S.;Pfeffer, M.;Meyer, H.

title: Antigenic and genetic associations between European highly virulent infectious bursal disease viruses and an early West African isolate.
abstract: Antigenic and genetic relationships between multi-virulent (vv) infectious bursal disease viruses (IBDV) from different countries were investigated. Antigenic characterization was performed using an antigen capture ELISA based on a panel of seven neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (Mabs) that search for at least three VP2-located antigenic domains. All these domains are reactive for European classical serotype 1 IBDV in the Faragher 52/70 (F52/70) reference strain, Genomic characterization was obtained by reverse transcription, amplification and direct sequencing of a genome fragment encoding the VP2 variable domain. Eleven vv isolates from France were compared with UK661, DV86 and 849VB viruses from the British, Dutch and Belgian and an early vv isolate from Ivory Coast in 1988. All viruses were antigenic characterized by non-binding of Mab 3 and 4. The lack of binding of Mabs 3 and 4 could therefore be helpful to distinguish between classical and vvIBDVs, none of the non-French strains resembled French isolates 91168 and 94432 that did not bind Mabs 6, 7 or 8, Genetic analysis revealed close associations Among all European viruses that differ from each other by no more than 12 nucleotides and 3 amino acids. The African isolate was markedly different from all European viruses, including the F52/70 virus, with at least 22 nucleotides and six amino acid differences. Phylogenetic analysis based on neighbor-joining and parsimony methods suggests that the African virus may belong to a genetically distinct lineage of the highly pathogenic IBDVs.
authors: Eterradossi, N.;Arnauld, C.;Tekaia, F.;Toquin, D.;Le Coq, H.;Rivallan, G.;Guittet, M.;Domenech, J.;van den Berg, T. P.;Skinner, M. A.

title: Tracing the origin and common phylogeny of caliciviruses
abstract: Caliciviruses infect a wide variety of mammalian hosts and include the genus Norovirus, which is the primary cause of foodborne viral gastroenteritis in humans. Using publicly available sequence data and phylogenetic analysis tools, the origins and virus-host shared phylogeny of these viruses were investigated. Here, evidence is presented that supports host switching by caliciviruses, but that zoonotic transfer has not occurred in the past of these viruses. The age or demographics of caliciviruses cannot yet be estimated with any firm support, but as new dated sequences become available, further studies of this family may provide important insights into the emergence of foodborne diseases that are important to human health. disease.
authors: Etherington, G. J.;Ring, S. M.;Charleston, M. A.;Dicks, J.;Rayward-Smith, V. J.;Roberts, I. N.

title: Antigenic characterization of inclusion body hepatitis virus
abstract: Evidence that inclusion body hepatitis (IBHC) in chickens is caused by a virus (IBHV) was established in 1973. Characterization of IBHV was performed using standard criteria for virus classification. The results showed that IBHV is a member of the avian adenovirus group. However, no antigenic associations were found between IBHV and the other two avian adenovirus isolates (CELO and Indiana C), as observed by hemagglutination (HA) and virus serum neutralization tests. Another adenovirus isolate was found to be serologically different from IBHV (Tipton strain), but promoted typical IBHV. This antigen was able to give a specific precipitate reaction with sera from chickens previously exposed to IBHV. Repeated embryo transfer of IBHV reduced its pathogenicity for susceptible chickens. Protection of chickens against IBHV challenge has been achieved by vaccination with high embryo transfer IBHV (Tipton strain). It was also found that subcutaneous administration of vaccine virus induced a better immune response than the instillation route, as observed by the resulting virus serum neutralization index.
authors: Fadly, A. M.;Winterfield, R. W.

title: Re-emergence of Peste des Petits Ruminants virus in Morocco in 2015: molecular characterization and experimental infection in Alpine goats.
abstract: Peste des Petits Ruminants (PPR) is a transboundary viral disease of small ruminant animals that causes great economic losses in Africa, the Middle East and Asia. In Morocco, the first PPR outbreak was reported in 2008. Since then, no cases have been reported for seven years, probably due to three consecutive vaccination campaigns in 2008-2011 and close surveillance in border areas. In June 2015, the disease resurfaced in Morocco, raising questions about the origin of the virus. PPR virus was confirmed by qRT-PCR and the virus was isolated from clinical samples on VeroNectin-4 cells. The disease was propagated experimentally in Alpine goats using epidemic isolates from both sheep and goats. Molecular characterization of the 2015 Fas PPR isolate confirmed the identity of the virus as strain IV, closely related to the 2012 Algerian (KP793696) and 2012 Tunisian (KM068121) isolates, and significantly different from the previous PPRV Fas 2008 strain (HQ131927). This study therefore confirms a new attack of the PPR virus in Morocco in 2015 and highlights the urgency of implementing a joint control strategy to combat PPR in the Maghreb region in North Africa.
authors: Fakri, F.;Embarki, T.;Parida, S.;Bamouh, Z.;Jazouli, M.;Mahapatra, M.;Tadlaoui, K.;Fassi-Fihri, O.;Richardson, C. D.;Elharrak, M.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of bovine viral diarrhea virus in Italy
abstract: The genetic characteristics of 38 bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) isolates collected in 1999 from sick or healthy and permanently infected cattle of dairy farms in northern Italy were investigated. The partial 5'²-untranslated region (5'²-UTR) sequence of each isolate was determined and phylogenetic analysis was performed. All isolates were classified as belonging to the BVDV-1 genotype and can be assigned to different BVDV-1 groups, namely BVDV-1b (n = 20), BVDV-1d (n = 6) and BVDV-1e (n = 10). ). The remaining two isolates can be classified as BVDV-1f and BVDV-1h, respectively. These results provided evidence for genetic heterogeneity of BVDV in Italy and contributed to a better knowledge of the circulation of BVDV strains and their classification.
authors: Falcone, E.;Cordioli, P.;Tarantino, M.;Muscillo, M.;La Rosa, G.;Tollis, M.

title: Frequency and health outcome of bovine viral diarrhea virus detected in subpopulations of peripheral blood mononuclear cells in permanently infected animals
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDV) cause acute and persistent infections. Acute infection results in generalized immunosuppression characterized by a reduction in circulating lymphocytes as a result of depletion of CD4+ and CD8+ T cell populations. Persistent infection with BVDV is the result of immune tolerance and is not usually associated with lymphocytopenia.
