The health outcomes of permanently infected (PI) calves vary widely; some die from mucous disease, some succumb to bad attitudes, and others appear normal and survive to adulthood. Detection of BVDV at the single lymphoid cell level is important for examining subpopulations of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) during BVDV infections, but there are several methods that can be used to detect and quantify BVDV at this level. To overcome this challenge, a new flow cytometry-based PrimeFlow RNA assay was developed using in situ detection of BVDV. This assay was used to evaluate differences in viral distribution within subpopulations of PBMC over time in PI calves carrying one of two different types of BVDV (type 1 and type 2). Samples were taken from the calves at 3 different time points, approximately one month apart. During the course of the study, a subset of the calves died from maltreatment. Mucosal disease was not noted in any of the deaths. BVDV RNA was detected in all clinically healthy-appearing PI PBMCs using RNA probes specific for the BVDV N<sup>pro</sup>-E<sup>rns</sup> coding regions for each virus of interest. Calves succumbing to bad thrift were found to have little or no virus in their T cells. Clearance of the virus from T cells suggests a compromised immune tolerance in these calves. This is the first report of an observed pattern in viral load in T-cell subpopulations and survival in PI calves.
authors: Falkenberg, S. M.;Dassanayake, R. P.;Walz, P.;Casas, E.;Neill, J. D.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis of pseudorabies virus variants isolated from Guangdong province, southern China during 2013-2014.
abstract: False rabies (PR) outbreaks have occurred in Southern China since late 2011, resulting in significant economic impacts on the swine industry. To identify the cause of PR outbreaks specifically among vaccinated pigs, 11 pseudorabies virus (PRV) field strains were isolated from Guangdong province during 2013-2014. Major viral genes (gE, TK, gI, PK, gD, 11K and 28K) were analyzed in this study. Insertions or deletions were observed in the gD, gE, gI and PK genes compared with other PRV isolates from all over the world. Furthermore, sequence alignment showed that insertions in gD and gE were unique molecular features of the new common PRV strains in China. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that our isolates clustered on an independent branch with other strains isolated from China in recent years and showed a closer genetic relationship with earlier isolates from Asia. Our results suggest that these isolates are novel PRV variants with unique molecular signatures.
authors: Fan, J.;Zeng, X.;Zhang, G.;Wu, Q.;Niu, J.;Sun, B.;Xie, Q.;Ma, J.

title: Identification and characterization of swine cobuvirus variant isolated from suckling piglet in Gansu province, China.
authors: Fan, S.;Sun, H.;Ying, Y.;Gao, X.;Wang, Z.;Yu, Y.;Li, Y.

title: Analysis of Egg-adapted Mutations in Influenza A H1N1pdm09 Viruses in Hubei Province, China, 2013-2014
abstract: Influenza A H1N1pdm09 Virus; chicken embryo; Phylogenetic tree; Egg adaptation; Antigenic site; drug resistance zone; Summary: To investigate egg-adapted mutation in influenza A H1N1pdm09 viruses isolated from the Hubei influenza surveillance network, a comparative analysis of three influenza A H1N1pdm09 viruses isolated in chicken embryo and their corresponding MDCK cell-derived viruses was performed. Analyzes included examining the phylogenetic tree, evolution rates, amino acid substitutions, egg-adapted mutation, and homology modeling. We found differences between egg-adapted viruses and MDCK cell-derived viruses based on phylogenetic trees and evolutionary rates; viruses tended to "NA>HA>MP". Four amino acid substitutions (Q223R, V527 I, M19I and H275Y) were found in three egg-adapted viruses. Q223 Rand V527I was found in hemagglutinin protein, while M19I and H275Y were detected in neuraminidase. The Q223R mutation changed the structure of the antigenic regions between Sb and Ca2. H275Y is a classic neuraminidase resistance mutation. The results show that egg-adapted mutations occur when influenza viruses are isolated in chicken embryos from the Hubei influenza surveillance network. These mutations may affect the selection of vaccine candidates and vaccine efficacy; therefore, monitoring for egg-adapted mutations in the influenza surveillance network should be strengthened.
authors: Fang, B.;Liu, L.;Ye, G.;Li, X.;Yu, X.;Jiang, Y.

title: Influenza A virus neuraminidase: protein regions potentially involved in virus-host interactions
abstract: Phylogenetically informative amino acid positions (PIPs) were identified in influenza A neuraminidases of N1 and N2 subtypes. Neuraminidase evolves in a lineage-specific manner as the virus adapts to a new host or changes to escape the host's immune system. Therefore, many PIPs define positions that are undoubtedly involved in virus-host interactions. Phylogenetically significant regions (PIRs) are defined as several PIPs close together. There are 15 PIRs in N1 and 12 in N2, seven of which are shared between the two subtypes. Many PIRs overlap with antigenic or glycosylation sites. Other PIRs may represent additional antigenic regions or be relevant to other aspects of virus host biology.
authors: Fanning, T. G.;Reid, A. H.;Taubenberger, J. K.

title: Selection of vaccine strains of foot and mouth disease virus for use in South Africa
abstract: The SAT 1, SAT 2 and SAT 3 (SAT: South African Territories) strains of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus are most widely represented in Southern African countries, particularly the SAT 2 virus. Since 1982, 139 isolates of these virus types have been examined. O and other type A viruses have been detected in the north of this region. Typing and subtyping of viruses by complement fixation (CF) testing can be enhanced using monoclonal antibody panels (MAbs) that provide an accurate antigenic profile of a new strain. A total of 33 strains of SAT 2 were investigated using MAbs and the results allow classification of viruses into groups presenting the same profile. The author presents comparisons using conventional serotyping methods (CF and virus neutralization (VN) tests) of isolates and vaccine viruses, as well as profiling of isolates using MAbs. Both analysis methods provide information about the relationships between viruses. The CF and VN tests provide details on how animals respond to a particular isolate and how that antibody response will recognize another isolate; from this, serological relationships can be proposed regarding how different isolates may induce a humoral immune response. With MAb profiling, details of antigenic relationships between isolates are obtained, allowing the identification of individual epitopic variations. These analyzes may provide the potential to place different isolates into 'antigenic' groups. Compared with the vaccine viruses, the vaccine virus with the closest profile to the isolate group can be tried to be detected. Immunological analysis (for example, using the CF tests used in this paper) can provide more information about the association between a particular vaccine and MAb profiling and an identified antigenic group. Of course, this MAb profile can provide essential information in a very short time, which is particularly useful in an emergency. Confirmation of results from profiling will then be provided by serological analysis. Such pooled assays provide a more comprehensive description of the antigenic and immunogenic relationships between FMD virus isolates and between isolates and vaccine viruses.
authors: Fargeaud, D.

title: Intra-epidemic genome variation in the highly pathogenic African swine fever virus (ASFV) from the country of Georgia
abstract: BACKGROUND: African swine fever virus (ASFV) causes acute hemorrhagic infection of clothing, with a mortality rate of up to 100%. No vaccine is available and the potential for catastrophic disease remains high in Europe due to the ongoing ASF epidemic in Russia and the Baltic states. To date, no intra-epidemic complete genome variation has been reported for ASFV. To provide a more comprehensive basis for genetic variation early in the ASF epidemic, we sequenced two Georgian ASFV samples, G-2008/1 and G-2008/2, derived from domestic pig blood collected in 2008. METHODS: Genomic DNA was directly extracted from low volume ASFV PCR positive pig blood samples and subjected to next-generation sequencing on the Illumina Miseq platform. De novo and mapped sequence assemblies were performed using CLCBio software. Genomic plots, sequence alignments, and assembly patterns were created using Geneious v10.2.4. Sequence repeat architecture was analyzed using DNASTAR GeneQuest 14.1.0. RESULTS: The G-2008/1 and G-2008/2 genomes were distinguished from each other by encoding changes in seven genes, including MGF 110-1 L, X69R, MGF 505-10R, EP364R, H233R, E199L and MGF 360. -21R, in addition to eight homopolymer pathway variations. The 2008/2 genome had a novel allele status at a previously unidentified intergenic repeat locus between the C315R and C147L genes. The C315R/C147L locus represents the earliest observed variable repeat sequence polymorphism reported among those isolated from this outbreak. No sequence variation was observed in conventional ASFV subtyping markers. The two genomes exhibited complete linearity and identical gene content with the Georgia 2007/1 reference genome. Approximately 56 unique homopolymer A/T pathway variations unique to the Georgia 2007/1 genome were identified. In both 2008 genomes, within-sample sequence read heterogeneity was evident in six homopolymeric G/C pathways restricted to the known hypervariable ~7 kb region in the left terminal region of the genome. CONCLUSIONS: This is the first reported intra-epidemic comparative genomic analysis for ASFV and provides insight into the intra-epidemic microevolution of ASFV. The genomes reported here, in addition to the G-2007/1 genome, provide an early basis for future genome-level comparisons and epidemiological monitoring efforts.
authors: Farlow, J.;Donduashvili, M.;Kokhreidze, M.;Kotorashvili, A.;Vepkhvadze, N. G.;Kotaria, N.;Gulbani, A.

title: Foreign matter detection in vaccines - Review of technical aspects
abstract: The quality and safety of commercial vaccines is of paramount importance. Contrary to all precautions and efforts, the use of biological material in vaccine development and manufacture can lead to potential contamination of vaccines with known and unknown foreign agents (EAs). In the veterinary field, official lists of EAs have been compiled as a legal framework. potential agents that need to be tested during the manufacture of vaccines. However, the detection of known and unknown contaminants in vaccines is a common task for manufacturers and authorities in both the veterinary and human fields, who share the similar needs of specific technical approaches. State-of-the-art molecular methods such as large parallel sequencing (MPS) or randomized PCR coupled with microarrays can open new perspectives in foreign matter testing. The robustness and efficacy of this technical approach in vaccine control was clearly demonstrated in a human vaccine sample when swine circovirus type 1 (PCV1) contamination occurred in Rotarix, a human rotavirus vaccine. The results and implications are reviewed here from the perspective of veterinary regulation. Â© 2012 International Alliance for Biological Standardization.
authors: Farsang, A.;KulcsÃ¡r, G.

title: Xenosurveillance reflects traditional sampling techniques for the identification of human pathogens: a comparative study in West Africa.
abstract: Background New surveillance strategies are needed to detect the rapid and sustained emergence of infectious disease agents. Ideally, the application of new sampling strategies should be simple, technologically uncomplicated, and applicable to areas where emergence events are known to occur. To this end, xenosurveillance is a technique that utilizes blood collected by hematophagus arthropods to track and identify vertebrate pathogens. Mosquitoes are largely ubiquitous animals, often found in large populations. Also, many species of domestic or peridomestic mosquitoes will preferentially get their food by sucking blood from humans, making them a unique and largely unused reservoir for collecting human blood. Methodology/Basic findings By systematically collecting blood-fed mosquitoes during a field trip in northern Liberia, we sought to exploit this phenomenon to determine whether the pathogen sequences from bloodstained mosquitoes accurately reflect those obtained directly from humans. Specifically, blood was collected from humans by fingertip and aspirating blood-feeding mosquitoes from inside the homes. Shotgun metagenomic sequencing of RNA and DNA derived from these samples was performed to detect pathogen sequences. Samples from the xenosurveillance and fingerprint blood draw produced a similar number and quality of reads relative to the two human viruses, GB virus C and hepatitis B virus. Conclusions/Significance This study presents the first systematic comparison between alien surveillance and more traditional sampling methodologies, while also demonstrating the feasibility of alien surveillance as a tool for sampling human blood for circulating pathogens.
authors: Fauver, J. R.;Weger-Lucarelli, J.;Fakoli, L. S.;Bolay, K.;Bolay, F. K.;Diclaro, J. W.;Brackney, D. E.;Foy, B. D.;Stenglein, M. D.;Ebel, G. D.

title: Duck gut viral metagenome analysis captures snapshot of viral diversity
abstract: BACKGROUND: Ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) are an economically important waterfowl for meat, eggs and feathers; it is also a natural reservoir for influenza A viruses. The emergence of new viruses is attributed to the coexistence of multiple virus species and subtypes in their reservoir hosts. An in-depth understanding of virome status in major reservoir species is essential for effective prediction of future viral outbreak or pandemic. METHODS: To obtain an unbiased measure of viral diversity in the enteric pathway of ducks by the viral metagenomic approach, we deeply sequenced viral nucleic acid extracted from cloacal swabs collected from a flock of 23 ducks that share water bodies with wild migratory birds. RESULT: A total of 7,455,180 reads were produced at an average length of 146 bases, of which 7,354,300 reads were de novo merged into 24,945 contigs with an average length of 220 bases, and the remaining 100,880 reads were singular. The duck viroma was identified by sequence similarity comparisons of contigs and singletons (BLASTx E score, <10(-3)) against the viral reference database. Numerous sequences of duck viromes were homologous to animal virus of the family Papillomaviridae; and phages of the Caudovirales, Inoviridae, Tectiviridae, Microviridae families and unclassified phages. In addition, several sequences of duck viromes were homologous to insect viruses of the families Poxviridae, Alphatetraviridae, Baculoviridae, Densovirinae, Iflaviridae, and Dicistroviridae; and plant viruses of the families Secoviridae, Virgaviridae, Tombusviridae and Partitiviridae, reflecting the diet and placement of ducks. CONCLUSION: This study increases our understanding of viral diversity and expands knowledge about the spectrum of viruses that reside in the enteric duct of ducks.
authors: Fawaz, M.;Vijayakumar, P.;Mishra, A.;Gandhale, P. N.;Dutta, R.;Kamble, N. M.;Sudhakar, S. B.;Roychoudhary, P.;Kumar, H.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Raut, A. A.

title: Inactivation of viruses from different taxonomic groups by copper sulfate
abstract: The study results of the inactivated effects of copper sulfate on viruses belonging to different taxonomy groups are summarized in the article. Copper sulfate is a simple and reliable agent for the inactivation of classical swine fever, Aujeszky's disease and bovine infectious rhinotracheitis viruses. Its inactivation action is based on its ability to reduce the viral genome to the low molecular fragment. Apart from inactivation of virus material, a decrease in the level of protective antibody determinants is observed when copper sulfate is used in case of sheep fever.
authors: Fedorov, D. G.;Balysheva, V. I.;Zhesterev, V. I.;Tsybanov, S. Z.;Zakutskii, N. I.;Slivko, V. V.

title: Role of mosquitoes Culex pipienis f. pipiens and Cx. pipes f. Molestus (Diptera, Culicidae) in the spread of West Nile virus in southern Russia
abstract: Client pipiens is one of the major vectors of West Nile virus in southern Russia and is represented by the autogenic form, molestus, and the non-autogenic form, pipiens. The spatial distribution of their larvae and food preferences of females were investigated to assess the potential role of each form in the spread of the virus. The taxonomic status of mosquitoes was determined from their autogenicity capacity (543 samples) and mitochondrial DNA type (348 samples). Mosquitoes of the Pipiens form have been shown to thrive in open urban and rural reservoirs and females are non-autogenic. Client pipiens form molestus has also been found only in urban biotopes, particularly in flooded basements and open reservoirs, where in some years it has formed a mixed population with Cx. pipiens forms pipiens. Among females with the mole mitotype, both autogenic (85-95.2%) and non-autogenic samples were detected. Genetic analysis of Cx. Pipiens females gathered under the Berezantsev bell and in a trap with a bird showed that both forms were attracted to man and bird. The findings suggest it's Cx. pipiens form pipiens can transmit West Nile virus to both town and suburban people and Cx. pipiens can only form molestus in urban areas.
authors: Fedorova, M. V.;ShaÄ­kevich, E. V.

title: Molecular detection and characterization of human gyroviruses identified in ferret fecal virome
abstract: New gyroviruses recently disclosed can infect chickens and/or humans; however, their pathogenic potential is unknown. In our metagenomic investigation, we detected several of the novel gyroviruses in fecal viromes of ferrets with lymph node and organ enlargement. The complete genomic sequences of the selected gyrovirus strains showed 90.7-99.4% similarity to the homologous reference gyrovirus strains. This study showed no association between gyrovirus shedding from ferrets and the observed background disease; however, it provides evidence for genetic diversity among gyroviruses and increases the likelihood that the domestic ferret can transmit gyroviruses to heterologous hosts, eg humans.
authors: FehÃ©r, E.;PazÃ¡r, P.;KovÃ¡cs, E.;Farkas, S. L.;Lengyel, G.;Jakab, F.;Martella, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Genome sequence analysis of a distinctive Italian infectious bursal disease virus
abstract: recent study identified an infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) genotype (ITA) occurring in IBDV-live vaccinated chickens without clinical manifestations of infectious bursal disease (IBD). VP2 sequence analysis showed that strains of the ITA genotype clustered separately from vaccine strains and other IBDV reference strains, either classically or highly virulent. To obtain a more comprehensive molecular characterization of the IBDV ITA genotype and to speculate about its origin, the domain isolate IBDV/Italy/1829/2011 previously assigned to the ITA genotype was sequenced and the resulting sequences were compared. to the corresponding arrays currently available. In addition, phylogenetic and recombination analyzes were performed. Interestingly, multiple amino acid (AA) sequence alignments revealed that strain IBDV/Italy/1829/2011 shares several AA residues as well as some virulence markers with the very lethal IBDV strains, particularly in the VP1 protein. However, sequence analysis showed the presence of several IBDV strains-specific residues with a low degree of virulence in strain IBDV/Italy/1829/2011. Although homologous recombination and reassortant phenomena can occur naturally between different IBDV strains, no evidence of these events was found in the genome of the IBDV/Italy/1829/2011 strain confirmed to be a genetically different IBDV genotype.
authors: Felice, V.;Franzo, G.;Catelli, E.;Di Francesco, A.;Bonci, M.;Cecchinato, M.;Mescolini, G.;Giovanardi, D.;Pesente, P.;Lupini, C.

title: Initial evaluation of the classic swine fever marker vaccine candidate CP7_E2alf for oral vaccination of wild boar under field conditions
abstract: Oral vaccination against classical swine fever (CSF) is a powerful tool to control disease outbreaks in wild boars. So far, vaccination campaigns have been conducted using live attenuated vaccines that do not allow serological differentiation of infected from vaccinated animals (DIVA). Although this disadvantage is acceptable for wild boar, the use of marker vaccines will facilitate studies on disease and vaccination dynamics. Recently, the CSF marker vaccine candidate CP7_E2alf was evaluated for oral immunization under laboratory conditions. The promising results led to efforts to study the vaccine candidate in field conditions and feed formulation. In this context, two oral vaccination campaigns were carried out with CP7_E2alf feed vaccines in two areas called 'faunistic hunting farms' in the Umbria region of Italy. One campaign was run using a single vaccination, the second with a routinely applied double vaccination strategy. Both campaigns were conducted without concerted hunting actions. Feed intake, vaccine virus detection, and antibody responses were evaluated along with reviews on bowel cleansing. As a comparator, seven wild boars were hand-fed with feed under laboratory conditions. In the field, feed intake ranged from 63.7% to 98.7%, with antibody prevalence reaching only 33.3-35.1%. Marker serology showed that sample quality had a strong influence on the test result, with a total of 85% correct classification of samples. The vaccine virus could not be detected. Under hand-feeding conditions, six out of seven wild boars received at least one feed, and five of these showed detectable antibody levels seven weeks post-vaccination. These results were supported by stability tests. Appropriate stability of the vaccine virus has been demonstrated in both field and laboratory conditions. In total, most results were in line with our expectations. However, optimization of the DIVA test should be attempted in the future. © 2014.
authors: Feliziani, F.;Blome, S.;Petrini, S.;Giammarioli, M.;Iscaro, C.;Severi, G.;Convito, L.;Pietschmann, J.;Beer, M.;De Mia, G. M.

title: Co-localization and interaction of duck enteritis virus glycoprotein H and L
abstract: Background: Duck Enteritis Virus (DEV), belonging to the Î±-herpesvirus subfamily, is a linear double-stranded DNA virus. Glycoproteins H and L (gH and gL) encoded by UL22 and UL1 are conserved in the family of herpes viruses. They play important roles as gH/gL dimers during viral entry into host cells via cell-cell fusion. The interaction between gH and gL has been confirmed in various human herpes viruses such as Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), and Human Cytomegalovirus (HCMV). In this article, we examined the interaction between DEV gH and gL. Results: Recombinant plasmids pEGFP-N-gH and pDsRED-N-gL were successfully generated. Expressions of both DEV gH and gL were observed after 12 h of incubation of COS-7 cells transfected with plasmids pEGFP-N-gH and pDsRED-N-gL, respectively. Furthermore, co-localization of a ratio of gH and gL was detected in the cytoplasm of COS-7 cells after co-transfection for 24 h. Recombinant plasmids pCMV-Flag-gL and pCMV-Myc-gH were then generated and co-transfected into COS-7 cells. Both gH and gL were shown to be tested with positive results by co-immunoprecipitation and Western blotting. Results: Our results demonstrated not only the co-localization of DEV gH and gL in COS-7 cells, but also the interaction between them. It will provide insight for further studies in terms of protein-protein interaction in DEV.
authors: Feng, D.;Cui, M.;Jia, R.;Liu, S.;Wang, M.;Zhu, D.;Chen, S.;Liu, M.;Zhao, X.;Wu, Y.;Yang, Q.;Yin, Z.;Cheng, A.

title: Analysis of the S1 gene of avian infectious bronchitis virus isolated in southern China between 2011 and 2012.
abstract: Sixty-two strains of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) strains were isolated from infected chickens from different farms in southern China between 2011 and 2012, and 66.1% of the isolated strains were associated with typical nephritis. Analysis of S1 gene sequences amplified from 62 isolated strains along with 40 reference strains published in Genbank showed nucleotide homologies ranging from 63.5% to 99.9% and amino acid homologies ranging from 57.9% to 100%. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that all Chinese IBV strains clustered in six different genetic groups (I-VI). Most of the isolated strains belonged to group I and isolation of group V strains increased compared to a previous surveillance period. The current vaccine strains (H120, H52, W93, and Ma5) used in China formed the Mass group, which is evolutionarily distant from the Chinese isolates. Alignment of S1 amino acid sequences revealed polymorphic and diverse substitutions, insertions and deletions, and the S1 protein of the major pandemic strains contained 540 amino acids with a cleavage site sequence of HRRRR or RRF(L/S)RR. Further analysis showed that recombination events formed a new subgroup. Taken together, these findings suggest that various IBV variants circulated and genetically evolved together in Southern China during the observation period. Therefore, long-term continuous surveillance is very important for the prevention and control of IBV infection. Â© 2014 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Feng, K.;Xue, Y.;Wang, F.;Chen, F.;Shu, D.;Xie, Q.

title: Induction and suppression of innate antiviral responses by picornaviruses
abstract: The Picornaviridae family consists of small, non-enveloped, positive-stranded RNA viruses and enteroviruses (eg, oral disease virus. Picornavirus infections activate a cytosolic RNA sensor, MDA5, which in turn induces a type I interferon response, a crucial component of antiviral immunity. Furthermore, picornaviruses activate the formation of stress granules (SGs), large preassembled mRNP clusters (messenger ribonucleoprotein particles) to temporarily store these molecules upon cellular stress.Meanwhile, picornaviruses actively suppress these antiviral responses to enable efficient replication. In this review, we provide an overview of the MDA5-mediated induction and suppression of the IFN-Î±/Î² response and the cellular stress pathway by picornaviruses.
authors: Feng, Q.;Langereis, M. A.;van Kuppeveld, F. J. M.

title: Contribution of a novel recombinant strain to the outbreak of coxsackievirus A6-related hand, foot, and mouth disease in Shanghai, China, 2012-2013
abstract: Since late 2012, coxsackievirus A6 (CVA6) has gradually become the predominant pathogen responsible for hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) in several provinces of China. A total of 626 patients diagnosed with HFMD in Shanghai, China from January 2012 to September 2013 were included in this study. Of these, 292 CVA6-infected cases were subjected to clinical analysis. Whole genome sequencing, recombination and phylogenetic analyzes were also performed. A recombinant CVA6 monophyletic strain was found during a CVA6-related HFMD outbreak in Shanghai, China in November 2012 and comprised 21.9% (64/292) of CVA6 strains over the study period. Recombination analyzes showed that the 2C gene of the novel CVA6 virus was probably derived from a circulating coxsackievirus A4 (CVA4) strain in the population. Clinical observation has shown that this recombinant CVA6 virus causes a more generalized rash than non-recombinant CVA6 virus. This nascent CVA6 strain was associated with significant HFMD cases in Shanghai from 2012 to 2013 and poses a potential threat to public health.
authors: Feng, X.;Guan, W.;Guo, Y.;Yu, H.;Zhang, X.;Cheng, R.;Wang, Z.;Zhang, Z.;Zhang, J.;Li, H.;Zhuang, Y.;Zhang, H.;Lu, Z.;Li, M.;Yu, H.;Bao, Y.;Hu, Y.;Yao, Z.

title: Disease outbreaks caused by steppe-type rabies viruses in China
abstract: Although rabies is a major public health problem in China, the epidemiology of animal rabies in the northern and northwestern border provinces is unknown. From February 2013 to March 2014, seven outbreaks of pet rabies caused by wild carnivores were reported in the Xinjiang (XJ) and Inner Mongolia (IM) Autonomous Regions of China and were diagnosed in brain samples of infected animals by fluorescent antibody testing (FAT). and RT-PCR. Ten fields of rabies virus were obtained. Sequence comparison and phylogenetic analysis based on the complete N gene (1353 bp) amplified directly from the original brain tissues showed that these ten strains were steppe-type viruses closely related to strains reported in Russia and Mongolia. None had been previously described in China. Viruses from XJ and IM clustered separately in the two lineages, showing their distinct geographic distribution. This study highlights the importance of wildlife surveillance and interdepartmental cooperation in controlling cross-border rabies transmission.
authors: Feng, Y.;Wang, W.;Guo, J.;Alatengheli;Li, Y.;Yang, G.;Su, N.;Zhang, L.;Xu, W.;Sheng, Z.;Ma, L.;Gui, J.;Dejide;Lin, H.;Tu, C.

title: Next-generation sequencing of five novel avian paramyxoviruses of 8 isolates from Kazakhstan indicates a low rate of genetic evolution in four decades
abstract: During a study that followed wild birds in Kazakhstan in 2013, five avian paramyxoviruses of serotype 8 (APMV-8) were isolated and each was further characterized. Viruses were isolated from three White-fronted geese (Anser albifrons), a Whooper swan (Cygnus cygnus) and a Lesser fly (Calidris minuta). Prior to our study, only two complete APMV-8 sequences had been reported worldwide since their discovery in the US and Japan in the 1970s. We report the complete genome sequences of newly detected viruses and analyze the four decades of genetic evolution of APMV-8 viruses.
authors: Fereidouni, S.;Jenckel, M.;Seidalina, A.;Karamendin, K.;Beer, M.;Starick, E.;Asanova, S.;Kasymbekov, E.;Sayatov, M.;Kydyrmanov, A.

title: Pathogenesis of Influenza D Virus in Cattle
abstract: NOT LABELED: Cattle has been proposed as the natural reservoir for a new member of the Orthomyxoviridae virus family tentatively classified as influenza D virus (IDV). Although isolated from sick animals, it is unclear whether IDV causes any clinical disease in cattle. To address this aspect of Koch's assumptions, three dairy calves (treatment animals) kept in separate pens were intranasally inoculated with IDV strain D/bovine/Mississippi/C00046N/2014. 1 day after inoculation, one seronegative calf (contact animal) was added to each of the treated animal houses. The virus was detected in seroconverted and respiratory tracts in cattle in both the treatment and contact groups. Histologically, there was a significant increase in neutrophil tracking in the tracheal epithelium of treatment calves compared to control animals. While infected and contact animals showed various symptoms of respiratory infection, they were mild and the calves in the treatment group did not differ from controls in heart rate, respiratory rate or rectal temperature. To mimic zoonotic transmission, two ferrets were exposed to a plastic toy fomite soaked with infected nasal discharge from treated calves. This ferret did not shed the virus or the seroconverter. In summary, this study shows that IDV causes a mild respiratory illness upon experimental infection of cattle and can be effectively transmitted between cattle by in-pente contact, but cannot be transferred from cattle to ferrets via fomite exposure. These findings support the hypothesis that cattle are a natural reservoir for the virus. IMPORTANT: A new influenza virus has been identified in swine, cattle, sheep and goats that has been tentatively classified as influenza D virus (IDV). Among these hosts, cattle have been proposed as natural reservoirs. In this study, we show that bovines experimentally infected with IDV can shed the virus and transmit it to other cattle by direct contact, but not via fomite routes to ferrets. IDV induced minor clinical signs in infected cattle, fulfilling another Koch's assumption for this new agent, but other objective clinical endpoints did not differ from those of control animals. Although the disease observed was mild, IDV induced neutrophil tracking and epithelial attenuation in the bovine trachea, which may facilitate coinfection with other pathogens and in doing so predispose animals to bovine respiratory disease.
authors: Ferguson, L.;Olivier, A. K.;Genova, S.;Epperson, W. B.;Smith, D. R.;Schneider, L.;Barton, K.;McCuan, K.;Webby, R. J.;Wan, X. F.

title: Molecular and phylogenetic characterization based on the complete genome of the pathotype of a virulent Newcastle disease virus isolated in Brazil in the 1970s.
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is caused by avian paramyxovirus type 1 (APMV-1) or Newcastle disease virus (NDV), which includes a diverse group of viruses with a single-stranded, negative-sense RNA genome. ND is one of the most important diseases of chickens as it seriously affects poultry production worldwide. In the 1970s, virulent ND outbreaks were recorded in Brazil and strain APMV-1/Chicken/Brazil/SJM/75 (SJM) of NDV was isolated. This strain was characterized as highly pathogenic for chickens but not pathogenic for other avian species. Here, we present the complete genome of the NDV strain SJM and explore the phylogenetic relationships of this virus with other NDV strains in terms of genome and protein composition, as well as characterizing the evolutionary process. NDV strain SJM is categorized as a velogenic virus, and the complete genome is 15,192 nucleotides long, consisting of six genes in the order 3'-NP-PMF-HN-L-5'. The presence of the major pathogenic determinant of NDV strains (112R-RQK-Râ†“F117) was identified in the Fusion protein of NDV strain SJM. In addition, phylogenetic analysis classified the NDV lineage SJM as a member of class II, genotype V, showing that this virus helps us understand the evolutionary process of strains belonging to this genotype. This work adds to the growing interest in involving the characterization of NDV isolates to improve our current understanding of the epidemiology, surveillance and evolution of pathogenic strains. Â© 2014 Authors.
authors: Fernandes, C. C.;Varani, A. M.;Lemos, E. G. M.;de Miranda, V. F. O.;Silva, K. R.;Fernando, F. S.;Montassier, M. F. S.;Montassier, H. J.

title: Molecular detection of bovine Noroviruses in Argentine dairy calves: Circulation of a tentative new genotype.
abstract: Bovine noroviruses are enteric pathogens detected in fecal samples of both diarrheal and nondiarrheal calves from various countries around the world. However, epidemiological information on bovine noroviruses is still lacking for many major cattle producing countries from South America. In this study, three bovine norovirus genogroup III sequences were determined by conventional RT-PCR and Sanger sequencing in feces from diarrheal dairy calves (B4836, B4848 and B4881, all collected in 2012). Phylogenetic studies of these three samples based on a partial coding region for RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp, 503 nucleotides) suggested that two of them (B4836 and B4881) belong to genotype 2 (GIII.2) and the third (B4848). ) was more closely related to genotype 1 (GIII.1) strains. By deep sequencing, the capsid region of two of these strains could be determined. This confirmed the circulation of genotype 1 (B4848) by the availability of another sequence (B4881), which shares the highest genetic association with genotype 1 but is far enough away to establish a new genotype. This latter strain was shown in silico to be a recombinant: phylogenetic divergence was detected between the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase coding sequence (genotype GIII.2) and the capsid protein-coding sequence (genotype GIII.1 or a potential norovirus genotype). Based on these data, this strain may be the second genotype GIII.2_GIII.1 bovine norovirus recombinant described in the worldwide literature. Further analysis even suggested that this strain could be a potential norovirus GIII genotype, tentatively designated GIII.4. The data provide important epidemiological and evolutionary information on bovine noroviruses circulating in South America.
authors: Ferragut, F.;Vega, C. G.;Mauroy, A.;Conceicao-Neto, N.;Zeller, M.;Heylen, E.;Uriarte, E. L.;Bilbao, G.;Bok, M.;Matthijnssens, J.;Thiry, E.;Badaracco, A.;Parreno, V.

title: Oligonucleotide microchip for subtyping influenza A virus
abstract: BACKGROUND: Influenza A viruses are divided into subtypes based on the antigenic properties of two outer glycoproteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA). Sixteen subtypes of HA and nine species of NA are known. Recently, circulations of some subtypes (H7N7, H5N1) have been closely monitored because of the epidemiological threat they present. OBJECTIVES: This study evaluates the potential of using gel-based microchip technology for rapid and sensitive molecular subtyping of influenza A virus. METHODS: The method uses a microchip consisting of 3D gel-based elements with immobilized probes. Segments of the HA and NA genes are amplified using multiplex RT-PCR and then microchip hybridized. RESULTS: The developed microchip was validated using a panel of 21 known reference strains of influenza virus. The selected strains represented different HA and NA subtypes derived from avian, porcine and human hosts. The entire procedure takes 10 hours and allows one to identify 15 HA subtypes and two NA subtypes. Forty-one clinical specimens (Russia, 2005) isolated during poultry decline in Novosibirsk were successfully identified using the proposed technique. The sensitivity and specificity of the method were 76% and 100%, respectively, when compared to the 'gold standard' techniques (virus isolation with the following characterization by immunoassay). CONCLUSIONS: We conclude that subtyping using gel-based microchips is a promising approach for rapid detection and identification of influenza A and can greatly improve its monitoring.
authors: Fesenko, E. E.;Kireyev, D. E.;Gryadunov, D. A.;Mikhailovich, V. M.;Grebennikova, T. V.;L'Vov D, K.;Zasedatelev, A. S.

title: Epidemiological investigation and analysis of protein variability of the NS5B gene and non-primate hepacivirus in several equine cohorts from the state of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
abstract: Among the recently disclosed hepacivirus strains, non-primate hepacivirus/hepacivirus A in horses and donkeys is closely related to human hepatitis C virus (HCV). Therefore, the horse is an attractive surrogate large animal model for HCV therapy, pathogenesis and prophylaxis studies. Despite global efforts, epidemiological and genetic studies have not been able to elucidate the risk factors, virus distribution, or genetic variability of hepacivirus A, which is also important for equine welfare. Very little information about this background scene is available in Brazil. The aim of this study was to investigate the potential risk factors associated with hepacivirus A infection among different horse cohorts in the state of Rio de Janeiro and to evaluate the diversity of the viral NS5B gene and protein. Hepacivirus A RNA was detected in equine cohorts from all geographic mesoregions, regardless of horse activity or breed investigated. The statewide prevalence ranges from 4.0% to 27.5%. Potential risk factors such as geographic location and age of female horses were significantly associated with the presence of virus RNA. Phylogenetic analysis revealed the circulation of subtype 2 in all meso-regions. NS5B gene sequences clustered by geographic origin, whereas NS5B fragments did not allow for discriminant analysis. The predicted NS5B protein showed significant protection, particularly in the thumb area. In conclusion, the higher frequency of hepacivirus A RNA detection in breeding horses and young females suggests a direct link between reproductive practices and spread of the virus. Additional studies are required to understand the distribution of this genetically conserved hepacivirus.
authors: Figueiredo, A. S.;Lampe, E.;de Albuquerque, Pplf;Chalhoub, F. L. V.;de Filippis, A. M. B.;Villar, L. M.;Cruz, O. G.;Pinto, M. A.;de Oliveira, J. M.

title: Bat astroviruses: Toward understanding the transmission dynamics of a neglected virus family
abstract: Bats belong to the order Chiroptera, which represents the second largest order of mammals with over 1,200 species and an almost global distribution. Environmental changes and deforestation have severely affected many ecosystems, intensifying contact between wildlife and humans. In recent years, bats have been found to harbor a number of different viruses with zoonotic potential, as well as a wide variety of astroviruses, for which the question of zoonotic potential remains unanswered to this day. Human astroviruses have been identified as the causative agent of diarrhea in children and immunocompromised patients. For a long time, astroviruses were thought to be strictly species-specific. However, a large genetic diversity has recently been discovered between animal and human astroviruses, which may indicate the potential for these viruses to overcome species barriers. Furthermore, our knowledge of the tissue tropism of astroviruses has been extended to some neurotropic strains recently shown to be responsible for encephalitis in humans and animals. This review provides an overview of what is known about astroviruses in bats, humans and livestock, particularly cattle and pigs. Future research activities are recommended to unravel astrovirus infection dynamics in bat populations to further evaluate the zoonotic potential of these viruses.
authors: Fischer, K.;dos Reis, V. P.;Balkema-Buschmann, A.

title: A mutation 'Hot Spot' in Schmallenberg virus M-segment
abstract: In autumn 2011, Schmallenberg virus (SBV), a novel orthobunia virus of the Simbu serogroup, was identified by metagenomic analysis in Germany. SBV has since been detected in ruminant animals all over Europe and research has been conducted on phylogenetic relationships, clinical manifestations and epidemiology. However, until now, only comparative sequence analysis of SBV genome segments with other strains of the Simbu serogroup has been performed, and detailed data on S and M segments related to virus-host-cell interaction have been lacking. In this study, we investigated S- and M-segment sequences from 24 SBV positive field samples from sheep, cattle and goats collected from all over Germany. The results showed that the overall genome variability of SBV is neither regional nor dependent on host species. However, we have characterized for the first time a region with high sequence variability (a mutation 'hot spot') within the glycoprotein Gc encoded by the M segment. © 2013 SGM.
authors: Fischer, M.;Hoffmann, B.;Goller, K. V.;HÃ¶per, D.;Wernike, K.;Beer, M.

title: Rapid metagenomic diagnosis for epidemic suspected of severe pneumonia
authors: Fischer, N.;Rohde, H.;Indenbirken, D.;GÃ¼nther, T.;Reumann, K.;LÃ¼tgehetmann, M.;Meyer, T.;Kluge, S.;Aepfelbacher, M.;Alawi, M.;Grundhoff, A.

title: A55 Foot and mouth disease virus undergoes abundant viral genomic changes at different stages of cattle infection
authors: Fish, I.;Stenfeldt, C.;Pauszek, S. J.;Brito, B. P.

title: Rift Valley fever virus
abstract: Rift Valley fever is considered one of the most important viral zoonoses in Africa. In 2000, the Rift valley fever virus spread to the Arabian Peninsula, causing two simultaneous outbreaks in Yemen and Saudi Arabia. It is transmitted to ruminants and humans through mosquitoes. The viral agent is an arbovirus belonging to the genus Phlebovirus in the Bunyaviridae family. This virus family consists of more than 300 members divided into five genera: Orthobunyavirus, Phlebovirus, Hantavirus, Nairovirus, and Tospovirus. Several members of the Bunyaviridae family are responsible for fatal hemorrhagic fevers: Rift Valley fever virus (Phlebovirus), Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (Nairovirus), Hantaan, Sin Nombre and related viruses (Hantavirus), and recently Garissa virus (Orthobunyavirus), now identified as Ngari. Here, we focus on recent data on recent developments in the Rift Valley fever virus, its epidemiology, molecular biology, and interactions between viral and cellular proteins that help to understand the molecular mechanisms the virus uses to circumvent the host cellular response. © 2005 Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.
authors: Flick, R.;Bouloy, M.

title: Letter to the Editor, by Ralf Dürrwald, Jolanta Kolodziejek, Aemero Muluneh, Sibylle Herzog, and Norbert Nowotny, "The epidemiological model of classical Borna disease and the regional genetic clustering of Borna disease viruses suggest the existence of hitherto unknown endemic reservoir host populations". Germs and Infection 8 (2006) 917-929
authors: Flower, R.;Kamhieh, S.

title: Torquetenovirus: human virome from bench to bedside
authors: Focosi, D.;Antonelli, G.;Pistello, M.;Maggi, F.

title: pike hepatitis herpes viruses
abstract: Comparative studies were conducted on crane herpes viruses from two different enzootics in Austria and France. The viruses studied appear to be the same in terms of their physico-chemical properties, morphology and biological reactions in the egg. Crane viruses are tentatively classified as beta-herpes viruses. Crane herpesvirus antisera produced in rabbits reacted with each other and with herpesvirus obtained from bobwhite quails in cross-neutralization tests. No reactivity was observed with other avian herpes viruses and human herpes simplex virus types 1 and 2.
authors: Foerster, S.;Chastel, C.;Kaleta, E. F.

title: Primate immunodeficiency virus classification and nomenclature
authors: Foley, B. T.;Leitner, T.;Paraskevis, D.;Peeters, M.

title: Influenza D in Italy: for a better understanding of viral infection in pigs
authors: Foni, E.;Chiapponi, C.;Baioni, L.;Zanni, I.;Merenda, M.

title: Pseudorabies virus can be classified into five genotypes using partial sequences of UL44.
abstract: Suid herpesvirus 1 (SuHV-1) is the causative agent of pseudorabies (PR), a disease of great importance due to the huge losses it causes in the pig industry. The aim of this study was to identify a method for genotyping SuHV-1 based on the partial sequences of the gene encoding the gene for glycoprotein C (gC) and to elucidate possible reasons for the variability of this region. A total of 109 g of sequences collected from GenBank were divided into five main groups after reconstruction of a phylogenetic tree by Bayesian inference. Analysis showed that a portion of the gC (approximately 671 bp) was under selective pressure at various points coinciding with sites of protein defect. It was also possible to divide SuHV-1 into five genotypes that evolved under different selective pressures. These genotypes are not country or continent specific, perhaps due to multiple entry events related to pig imports.
authors: Fonseca, A. A., Jr.;Camargos, M. F.;Sales, M. L.;Heinemann, M. B.;Leite, R. C.;Reis, J. K.

title: Genomic analysis of the multi-host pathogen Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae reveals extensive recombination as well as the existence of three generalist branches with wide geographic distribution.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Knowledge of how bacterial populations are structured is an important prerequisite for studying their ecology and evolutionary history, facilitating research on host specificity, pathogenicity, geographic distribution, and molecular epidemiology. Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is an opportunistic pathogen currently re-emerging in both the swine and poultry industries globally. This bacterium causes occasional deaths in captive marine mammals and has recently been implicated in large-scale wildlife killings. However, despite its economic importance and wide geographic and host distribution, including zoonotic potential, the global diversity, recombination rates, and population structure of this bacterium are poorly characterized. In this study, we performed a large-scale genomic comparison of E. rhusipathiae based on a diverse collection of isolates to address these information gaps. RESULTS: Eighty-three E. rhusipathiae isolates from a range of host species and geographic origins isolated between 1958 and 2014 were sequenced and combined using both reference-based mapping and de novo splicing. We found that a large portion (58%) of the core genome undergoes recombination. Therefore, we used three independent methods resistant to the presence of recombination to define the population structure of this species: a phylogenetic tree and network analysis based on a set of conserved protein sequences in silico chromosome staining. All three methods were broadly compatible and supported the existence of three different clades within the E. rhusiopathiae species. Although we found some evidence of host and geographic clustering, each clan contained isolates from a variety of host species and from multiple continents. RESULTS: Using whole genome sequence data, we validated recent suggestions that E. rhusipathiae is a weakly clonal species that has been extensively shaped by homologous recombination. Despite frequent recombination, we can reliably identify three distinct classes that are not clearly separated by host species or geographic origin. Our results provide a fundamental basis for future molecular epidemiological, ecological, and evolutionary studies of E. rhusiopathiae and facilitate comparisons with other recombinogenic, multi-host bacteria.
authors: Forde, T.;Biek, R.;Zadoks, R.;Workentine, M. L.;De Buck, J.;Kutz, S.;Opriessnig, T.;Trewby, H.;van der Meer, F.;Orsel, K.

title: Genetic diversity among pandemic 2009 influenza viruses isolated from a transmission chain
abstract: BACKGROUND: Influenza viruses such as swine influenza A(H1N1) virus (A(H1N1)pdm09) generate genetic variation due to the high error rate of their RNA polymerases, often resulting in mixed genotype populations (intra-host variants) within a cell. single infection. This variation helps influenza respond rapidly to selection pressures such as those imposed by the immunological host response and antiviral therapy. We performed deep sequencing to characterize influenza intra-host variation in a transmission chain consisting of three cases due to oseltamivir-susceptible viruses and one derived oseltamivir-resistant case. METHODS: Following detection of A(H1N1)pdm09 infections, we performed in-depth sequencing of the complete NA gene from two of the oseltamivir-susceptible virus-infected cases and all eight gene segments of the viruses causing the remaining two cases. CONCLUSIONS: No evidence of a resistance-causing mutation (resulting in NA H275Y substitution) was observed in oseltamivir-susceptible subjects. Furthermore, deep sequencing revealed a subpopulation of oseltamivir-susceptible viruses in the case carrying resistant viruses. We detected a higher level of intra-host variation in the case with oseltamivir-resistant viruses than in those infected with oseltamivir-susceptible viruses. CONCLUSIONS: Oseltamivir resistance was detected only after prophylaxis with oseltamivir, suggesting that the mutation was selected as a result of antiviral intervention. The persistent oseltamivir-susceptible virus population in the case carrying resistant viruses suggests that either a small proportion survive the treatment or that the oseltamivir-susceptible virus quickly re-establishes itself in the virus population after the bottleneck. Moreover, the increased intra-host variation in the oseltamivir resistant case is consistent with the hypothesis that population diversity of an RNA virus may increase rapidly after a population bottleneck.
authors: Fordyce, S. L.;Bragstad, K.;Pedersen, S. S.;Jensen, T. G.;Gahrn-Hansen, B.;Daniels, R.;Hay, A.;Kampmann, M. L.;Bruhn, C. A.;Moreno-Mayar, J. V.;Avila-Arcos, M. C.;Gilbert, M. T.;Nielsen, L. P.

title: Detection of hepatitis E virus in samples of animal origin collected in Hungary
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is an enterically transmitted human pathogen. HEV infections are mainly associated with acute, self-limiting, icteric hepatitis with a mean mortality of 1%. Animal reservoirs are thought to play an important role in the protection of the virus and the spread of HEV to humans. HEV-induced seroconversion has been described in several species, but clinical hepatitis has not been observed in animals to date. The fact that HEV strains derived from animals are genetically closely related to human HEV isolates supports the notion of zoonotic transmission of the virus. In this comprehensive study, HEV formation was investigated in Hungarian wild and domestic animal samples. HEV RNA was detected by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction in liver samples of wild boar, roe deer and deer. Studies of domestic pig samples detected HEV in 39% of Hungarian pig farms surveyed. Concurrent research revealed no definite difference in the frequency of HEV positivity between liver and fecal samples of domestic pigs. The highest (36%) incidence of HEV infection was found among 11-16 week old pigs. Samples from domestic cattle and rodents collected from pig farms, forests and meadows tested negative for HEV RNA. Phylogenetic analysis of partial sequences amplified in the ORF1 and ORF2 regions of the selected strains revealed that the viruses detected belonged to three subgroups of the third gengroup. HEV is closely related to human and porcine HEV strains detected in different countries. Studies have revealed the widespread distribution of HEV in Hungarian wild ungulate and domestic pig populations with significant genetic variation across strains. © 2009 Elsevier BV
authors: ForgÃ¡ch, P.;Nowotny, N.;ErdÃ©lyi, K.;Boncz, A.;Zentai, J.;Szucs, G.;Reuter, G.;Bakonyi, T.

title: Real-Time Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction for Differentiation of Massachusetts Vaccine and Brazilian Field Genotypes of Avian Infectious Bronchitis Virus
abstract: Avian infectious bronchitis virus is classified according to serotypes or genotypes (or both) in different poultry producing countries of the world. In Brazil, the Massachusetts type (Mass) and local field Brazilian variants (genotypes; BR) used as live vaccines predominate in commercial poultry flocks. This work describes the development and validation of two real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reactions (RT-qPCR) for the specific detection of Mass and BR genotypes in allantoic fluids and clinical specimens. Genotype-specific primers combined with a generic probe targeting the S1 gene constituted Mass RT-qPCR and BR RT-qPCR-specific assays. The analytical sensitivity and linearity of these assays were determined in comparison to an IBV generic real-time RT-PCR based on the 5' untranslated region (5'UTR RT-qPCR). Mass RT-qPCR detected five Mass field isolates, three vaccine samples and one co-infected sample (BR and Mass), while BR RT-qPCR detected 16 BR field isolates. Both assays were linear (R(2) > 0.98), reproducible, and as sensitive as the conventional 5'UTR RT-qPCR used to detect IBV. In the analysis of 141 IBV clinical specimens, 8 were positive for Mass RT-qPCR, 76 for BR RT-qPCR, and 2 for both tests. Of the remaining 55 samples, 25 were positive for the 5'UTR RT-qPCR only and 30 were negative for the three assays. As a result, both analyzes were able to detect Mass and BR genotypes, allowing fast and easy IBV molecular typing from allantoic fluids and clinical samples.
authors: Fraga, A. P.;Ikuta, N.;Fonseca, A. S.;Spilki, F. R.;Balestrin, E.;Rodrigues, C. D.;Canal, C. W.;Lunge, V. R.

title: Discovery of parvovirus-related sequences in an unexpectedly wide range of animals
abstract: Our knowledge of the genetic diversity and host ranges of viruses is piecemeal. This is especially true for the Parvoviridae family. Genetic diversity studies of single-stranded DNA viruses within this family have largely focused on species that infect arthropods and vertebrates that cause diseases of humans and our pets: a focus that distorts our perception of parvovirus diversity. While metagenomic approaches can help correct this bias, so can transcriptomic studies. Large amounts of transcriptomic data are available for a wide variety of animal species and may contain detectable viral transcripts when this data is erroneously collected from infected individuals. Therefore, we conducted a systematic search for parvovirus-related sequences (PRSs) in publicly available databases of transcripts, genomes, and proteins, and eleven new transcriptome datasets. This revealed 463 PRSs in transcript databases from 118 animals. At least 41 of these PRSs are likely integrated into animal genomes, as they are also found in genomic sequence databases. In addition to elucidating the ubiquity of parvoviruses, the number of parvoviral sequences discovered in public databases has revealed numerous previously unknown parvovirus-host combinations; especially in invertebrates. Our findings suggest that the host range of current parvoviruses may encompass the entire animal kingdom.
authors: FranÃ§ois, S.;Filloux, D.;Roumagnac, P.;Bigot, D.;Gayral, P.;Martin, D. P.;Froissart, R.;Ogliastro, M.

title: Classification of cowpox viruses into several branches and identification of a new strain
abstract: Cowpox virus (CPXV) was considered as a uniform species within the genus Orthopoxvirus (OPV). Previous phylogenetic analysis showed that CPXV is polyphyletic and isolates can cluster in distinct clades, where two of these clades show genetic similarities to variola (VARV) or vaccinia viruses (VACV). Further analyzes were initiated to assess both the genetic diversity and the evolutionary background of circulating CPXVs. Here we report full-length sequences of 20 CPXV strains isolated from different animal species and humans in Germany. Phylogenetic analysis of a total of 83 full-length OPV genomes confirmed the polyphyletic character of the CPXV strain and suggested at least four distinct segments. The German isolates from this study clustered mainly in two CPXV-like branches and no VARV- and VACV-like strains were observed. A single strain isolated from a cottony tamarind clustered away from all other CPXVs and may represent a new and unique evolutionary lineage. Classification of CPXV strains into clades roughly followed their geographical origins, with the highest clan diversity ever observed for Germany. We also found evidence for recombination between OPV strands without significant disruption in clustering observed. In conclusion, this analysis significantly expands the number of CPXV full-length sequences available and confirms the co-circulation of several CPXV clades in Germany and provides the first data on a new evolutionary CPXV lineage.
authors: Franke, A.;Pfaff, F.;Jenckel, M.;Hoffmann, B.;HÃ¶per, D.;Antwerpen, M.;Meyer, H.;Beer, M.;Hoffmann, D.

title: Exploratory metagenomic analyzes of pigs affected by periweaning failure-development syndrome
abstract: Modern pig farming is characterized by the emergence of several syndromes of unclear etiology or multifactorial origin, including periweaning fail-to-thrive syndrome (PFTS). In fact, its specific etiology remains unclear, although several causes have been investigated over time. This study aimed to investigate the potential role of viral agents in PFTS-affected and healthy animals by evaluating the virome composition of different organs using a metagenomic approach. This analysis allowed the demonstration of a higher abundance of Porcine parvovirus 6 (PPV6) in healthy subjects, while increased Ungulate bocaparvovirus 2 (BoPV2), Ungulate protoparvovirus 1 (PPV), and Porcine circovirus 3 (PCV-3) in pigs with PFTS. No abundance of different RNA viruses was found between PFTS-affected and control pigs. Remarkably, this is the first molecular characterization of PPV6 and BoPV2 in Spain and one of the few worldwide, supporting their apparent widespread circulation. Interestingly, PCV-3 has been recently identified in several clinical-pathological conditions, as well as in healthy pigs, whereas the pathogenic potential of BoPV2 is unknown. Although the results obtained should be taken as preliminary, it opens the door to further studies on the potential role of these viruses or their combinations as predisposing factor/s for the formation of PFTS.
authors: Franzo, G.;Kekarainen, T.;Llorens, A.;Correa-Fiz, F.;SegalÃ©s, J.

title: Subpopulations in aMPV vaccines are unlikely to be the sole cause of virulence.
abstract: Avian metapneumovirus (aMPV) frequently infects the respiratory and reproductive tracts of domestic birds with secondary infections and causes serious economic losses in many parts of the world. While the disease in general is effectively controlled with live vaccines, virulence of these vaccines has been demonstrated several times. Consensus sequence mutations involved in the process have been identified on more than one occasion. In a previous subtype A aMPV candidate vaccine study, small subpopulations were included. In the current study, the presence of subpopulations in a subtype B vaccine was investigated by deep sequencing. Of the 19 positions where the vaccine (strain VCO3/50) and progenitor (strain VCO3/60616) consensus sequences differed, subpopulations were found to have sequence-matching progenitor sequences at 4 positions. However, none of these mutations occurred in a virulent return of that vaccine, thus demonstrating that the majority of the progenitor virus population did not survive the weakening process and thus were clearly not involved in any virulence reversion. However, a single nucleotide variation was found in the vaccine that agreed with the consensus sequence of a derived virulent revertant virus, so this and other undetected, potentially virulent subpopulations may be involved in the reversal. Much deeper sequencing of progenitor, vaccine, and revertant may clarify whether problematic virulent subpopulations are present and therefore need to be routinely removed during aMPV vaccine preparation prior to registration and release.
authors: Franzo, G.;Naylor, C. J.;Drigo, M.;Croville, G.;Ducatez, M. F.;Catelli, E.;Laconi, A.;Cecchinato, M.

title: Actinic keratosis viroma: can we prevent squamous cell carcinoma with a vaccine?
authors: Frazer, I. H.

title: charlatan leptin
abstract: Background: A LEP transcript upregulated in the lungs of ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) infected with avian influenza A virus was recently identified in the Nature Genetics manuscript reporting the duck genome. In vertebrates, the LEP gene symbol is reserved for leptin, a key regulator of energy balance in mammals. Results: Expanding this search by initiating a comprehensive search for this gene in genome data made available to public databases with the duck genome manuscript All avian genomes in the whole genome shotgun sequencing database, we were able to report the first identification of coding sequences capable of encoding the complete leptin protein precursor in wild birds. Gene structure, synthesis and sequence similarity (up to 54% identity and 68% identity) to reptilian leptin in hawks (Falco peregrinus and cherrug), udders (Pseudopodoces humilis), finches (Taeniopygia guttata) and pigeons (Columba livia) confirmed avian leptin was a true ortholog of the mammalian form. However, in the duck, as in other domestic poultry, the LEP gene could not be identified. Conclusion: The lack of LEP gene in poultry suggests that birds that have lost it are particularly suitable for domestication. The identification of an intact avian gene for leptin in wild birds may partially explain the evolutionary conservation of its receptor in leptin-free poultry. Â© 2014 Friedman-Einat and Seroussi; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Friedman-Einat, M.;Seroussi, E.

title: Implications for the crystal structure and host adaptation of porcine vesicular disease virus
abstract: Porcine vesicular disease virus (SVDV) is an Enterovirus of the Picornaviridae family that causes symptoms indistinguishable from foot-and-mouth disease virus. Phylogenetic studies have shown that it is a recently evolved genetic subset of the important human pathogen coxsackievirus B5 (CBV5) and, in agreement with this, uses the coxsackie and adenovirus receptor (CAR) for cell entry. The 3.0-a… crystal structure (highly virulent) of strain UK/27/72 SVDV reveals the expected similarity in core structure to that of other picornaviruses and shows the closest existing structure to CBV5, most similar to that of coxsackievirus B3 (CBV3). . Properties that help assemble and solidify protein subunits are expanding in this virus, perhaps explaining its extreme tolerance to environmental factors. Using the multiple capsid sequences available for both SVDV and CBV5, we mapped amino acid substitutions that may have occurred during the putative adaptation of SVDV to a new host on the structure of SVDV and a model of the SVDV/CAR complex produced. Referring to the complex of CBV3 and CAR visualized by cryo-electron microscopy. The alterations are divided into three clusters as follows: one row of five-fold pore, the second pairs with the CAR-binding site and partially overlaps with the degradation accelerating factor (DAF) site to bind to echovirus 7 (ECHO7), and the third lies close to where the low-density lipoprotein receptor binds to the minor rhinovirus group. to the five-fold axis. Subsequent changes in SVDV (post 1971) map to the first two clusters and may have improved the adaptation of the virus to pigs by optimizing the recognition of a porcine CAR and/or DAF homologue.
authors: Fry, E. E.;Knowles, N. J.;Newman, J. W. I.;Wilsden, G.;Rao, Z.;King, A. M. Q.;Stuart, D. I.

title: Molecular detection and typing of duck hepatitis A virus directly from clinical specimens
abstract: To develop a new approach for detection and typing of duck hepatitis A virus (DHAV), a pair of non-degenerate primers were designed to amplify a âˆ¼250-bp genomic region at 5â€²UTR. 3 reference strains and 6 duck embryo-derived isolates containing 2 serotypes from various regions of China were successfully amplified with the primer set. The molecular typing method was developed by determining the nucleotide sequence of the amplicon. Nucleotide identity was 94% with homologous serotype and 73% with heterologous serotype when isolate sequences were compared with DHAV 5-UTR sequences found in public databases. Phylogenetic analysis revealed monophyletic clustering of 5-UTR sequences of a homologous serotype and confirmed the new classification of DHAV (two new serotypes recently described in Taiwan and South Korea, respectively) to three identified genotypes (A, B, and C). Analysis of the results by capsid coding region showed that the primer pair should aid in the detection of DHAV and the amplicon sequence contains type-specific information and can be used for efficient and rapid molecular typing. Molecular methods have proven their usefulness through the detection and typing of DHAV directly from 28 liver samples collected from dead ducklings during duck viral hepatitis epidemics in different parts of China between 2001 and 2007. The results confirmed the presence of DHAV in all 28 samples. and A (13/28) and C (15/28) genotypes of DHAV circulated together in China. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Fu, Y.;Pan, M.;Wang, X.;Xu, Y.;Yang, H.;Zhang, D.

title: Comparative transcriptome analyzes show enhanced cellular protection against FMDV in PK15 cells pretreated with IFN-Î³.
abstract: Interferon gamma (IFN-Î³) can induce a host antiviral response against foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV) in vivo and in vitro. To elucidate the mechanism of IFN-Î³ anti-FMDV infection in host cells, high-throughput RNA sequencing was analyzed for systemic changes in gene expression profiles in FMDV-infected PK15 cells with or without IFN-Î³ pretreatment. More than 25 million reads covering 1.2–1.5 Gb were analyzed from each experimental panel. FMDV challenge altered the transcription of genes that positively and negatively regulate cell death or apoptosis; however, the expected immunosuppression response was not clear. IFN-Î³ pretreatment normalized the increase in apoptosis with FMDV infection. Moreover, transcription factors required for IFN-Î³ functioning, STAT1 and IRF1 were upregulated by IFN-Î³ pretreatment and stimulated downstream IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). These induced ISGs are mainly responsible for antigen processing, antigen presentation or antiviral defense. Interestingly, a synergistic effect was observed on some ISGs, including OAS1, OAS2, MX1, MX2, RIG-I, and IFIT1, in combination therapy compared to IFN-Î³ therapy alone. The proposed effects identified by RNA sequencing were consistent with the cellular morphology changes and were confirmed by the respective protein markers. This is the first report to investigate transcriptome changes caused by FMDV infection with or without IFN-Î³ pretreatment. Identified key host genes controlling cell survival in vitro expand our comprehensive understanding of how IFN-Î³ inhibits FMDV infection and may shed light on the development of improved FMD control approaches.
authors: Fu, Y.;Zhu, Z.;Chang, H.;Liu, Z.;Liu, J.;Chen, H.

title: Molecular characterization of novel P[14], G8 bovine group A rotavirus, Sun9 isolated in Japan
abstract: In this study, a novel bovine group A rotavirus (RV-A) isolated from calf diarrhea in Tochigi Prefecture, Japan was genetically characterized by sequence analysis of genome segments encoding Sun9, VP4 and VP7. Nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of genome segments encoding VP4 and VP7 of Sun9, P[14] human and lapin RV-A (80.2-88.7% and 90.9-94.8%) and G8 bovine and revealed high homology with human RV-As. (83.1-95.5% and 92.3%-98.2%). Sun9 was also classified as P[14] and G8 in the phylogenetic analysis of the nucleotide sequences of the genome segments encoding VP4 and VP7. Although previous reports have suggested that the P[14],G8 human RV-A isolated so far is derived from reclassification between human and bovine RV-A or from interspecies transmission of bovine RV-A to human, P[ 14] none, G8 bovine RV-A has not yet been reported. Sun9 may be the first direct proof of the above hypothesis. Â© 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Fukai, K.;Saito, T.;Inoue, K.;Sato, M.

title: Bovine herpesvirus-1: comparison and differentiation of vaccine and field strains based on genomic sequence variation
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus-1 (BoHV-1) causes major diseases in cattle, including respiratory, fetal diseases and reproductive tract infections. Control programs often include vaccination with a modified live viral (MLV) vaccine. Sometimes BoHV-1 strains are isolated from infected animals or fetuses after vaccination. Currently there are no markers to distinguish MLV strains from field strains of BoHV-1. In this study, several BoHV-1 strains were sequenced using whole genome sequencing technologies, and the data were analyzed to identify single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). The strains sequenced included the reference BoHV-1 Cooper strain (GenBank Accession JX898220), eight commercial MLV vaccine strains, and 14 field strains from the cases submitted for diagnosis. Based on SNP analyses, viruses can be classified into groups with similar SNP patterns. Eight MLV strains can be distinguished, although some are closely related. A number of field strains isolated from animals with a history of prior vaccination had SNP patterns similar to specific MLV viruses, while other field isolates were very different from all vaccine strains. The results suggest that some BoHV-1 isolates from clinically sick cattle/fetus may be associated with a previous MLV vaccination history, but more information is needed on the rate of BoHV-1 genome sequence alteration before irrefutable associations can be established. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Fulton, R. W.;d'Offay, J. M.;Eberle, R.

title: Evolutionary analyzes on the HA gene of epidemic H1N1/09: early findings
abstract: The HA protein is responsible for influenza virus attachment and subsequent fusion of viral and cellular membranes. Antigenic drift is driven by the accumulation of point mutations in HA. And the receptor binding specificity of HA is responsible for the host range restriction of the virus. In April 2009, large new outbreaks of H1N1 influenza were reported in the human population from North America. The pandemic H1N1 virus was caused by the swine flu virus. The evolutionary process after the introduction of the pandemic virus into the human population has not been clarified. We performed phylogenetic analyzes that construct and calculate a phylogenetic tree for site-based selective pressures in the HA gene. The phylogenetic tree showed that pandemic viruses were not clearly clustered in the phylogenetic tree based on their geographic location or isolation time. The virus is circulating the world extensively, with multiple entries in most geographic areas. We found 3 positively selected regions in the HA gene for the pandemic H1N1 virus. Among them, position 206 is located in an antigenic region. We did not find significant negative selection at any of the receptor binding sites. The virus thrives under unique selective pressure.
authors: Furuse, Y.;Suzuki, A.;Oshitani, H.

title: Gene segment reclassification between Eurasian and American avian influenza viruses in Italy.
abstract: All genes of avian influenza A viruses are phylogenetically divided into two large clades, American and Eurasian. Reclassifications between gene segments of influenza viruses belonging to two different clades are rare events and have never been previously described in poultry in Europe and Asia. This study presents the genetic characterization of two influenza viruses isolated from domestic mallards in Italy in 2004 and 2005. Phylogenetic analysis of the whole genome showed that these viruses contain mixed gene segments belonging to the American and Eurasian branches. © Springer-Verlag 2009.
authors: Fusaro, A.;Monne, I.;Cattoli, G.;de Nardi, R.;Salviato, A.;Martin, A. M.;Capua, I.;Terregino, C.

title: Genetic Diversity of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N8/H5N5) Viruses in Italy, 2016-17
abstract: In the winter of 2016-17, highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) and A(H5N5) viruses of clan 2.3.4.4 were identified in wild and domestic birds in Italy. We report the occurrence of multiple entries and describe the identification in Europe of 2 new genotypes generated through multiple reclassification events.
authors: Fusaro, A.;Monne, I.;Mulatti, P.;Zecchin, B.;Bonfanti, L.;Ormelli, S.;Milani, A.;Cecchettin, K.;Lemey, P.;Moreno, A.;Massi, P.;Dorotea, T.;Marangon, S.;Terregino, C.

title: Unexpected Dynamics of Inter-farm Transmission During a High-Pathogenic Avian Influenza Outbreak
abstract: UNLABELED: Next-generation sequencing technology is now increasingly applied to study the intra-host and inter-host population dynamics of viruses. However, information about the evolution of the avian influenza virus and transmission during a naturally occurring epidemic is still limited. Here, we use deep sequencing data from clinical samples collected from five industrial enterprises and a backyard farm infected during the 2013 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H7N7 outbreak in Italy to reveal (i) epidemic virus population diversity, (ii) . evolution of virus pathogenicity and (iii) viral transmission routes between different farms and shelters. We show high genetic diversity of HPAI H7N7 viruses in a single farm as a result of separate bottlenecks and founder effects. Specifically, we identified co-circulation in the index case of two viral strains showing a different insertion at the hemagglutinin cleavage site, as well as nine nucleotide differences and 92 minority variants at the consensus level. To assess inter-farm transmission, we combined epidemiological and genetic data and identified the index case as the main source of the virus, suggesting that different viral haplotypes spread from the index farm to other industrial enterprises, possibly at different time points. Our results revealed the dynamics of inter-farm transmission, showing that epidemiological data cannot be resolved alone, and showed that delay in disease detection and eradication is the main reason for the emergence and spread of the HPAI strain. IMPORTANT: The intra- and inter-host evolutionary dynamics of a highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) strain during a naturally occurring epidemic are currently poorly understood. Here, we perform for the first time an in-depth series analysis of all samples collected during an HPAI epidemic, and demonstrate the importance of complementing epidemic research with genetic data to reconstruct the transmission dynamics of viruses and to evaluate between and within. -farm genetic diversity of the viral population. We show that the evolutionary transition from the low pathogenic form to the highly pathogenic form occurred in the first infected herd, where we identified haplotypes with different lengths of hemagglutinin cleavage sites. We also identify the index case as the main source of virus, indicating that rapid implementation of population reduction measures is necessary to limit the spread of the virus to other farms.
authors: Fusaro, A.;Tassoni, L.;Milani, A.;Hughes, J.;Salviato, A.;Murcia, P. R.;Massi, P.;Zamperin, G.;Bonfanti, L.;Marangon, S.;Cattoli, G.;Monne, I.

title: Development of a pyrosequence test for typing alphaherpes viruses
abstract: Identification of the herpes virus in biological material is usually accomplished by real-time PCR. In order to classify the identified virus strain, real-time PCR must be supplemented with capillary electrophoresis sequencing analysis, which is often time consuming. Here, we present a protocol for the rapid and reliable identification of 5 closely related herpes viruses by the PyroMark Q24 sequencing system. PyroMark performs DNA sequencing analysis using pyrosequencing, a technology based on the detection of pyrophosphate released during DNA elongation [1]. PyroMark is designed to detect changes in specified variable positions of DNA. It can efficiently detect single nucleotide differences in sequences [2]. In this paper, we describe a protocol to pyrosequence a small polymorphic segment of the US8 gene. Based on the differences identified in the nucleotide sequence, we can easily classify the herpes virus as Bovine herpesvirus 1.1, Bovine herpesvirus 1.2, Bovine herpesvirus 5, Bubaline herpesvirus 1 or Caprine herpesvirus. Protocol setup offers several advantages over commonly used techniques: it requires less than one business day to move; allows to analyze up to 24 samples at a time at reasonable costs; and the aforementioned herpes viruses, to detect genetically strongly related organisms with great reliability and specificity. The procedure is readily applicable to other virus families with appropriate modifications.
authors: Fusco, G.;Amoroso, M. G.;Gesualdi Montesano, N.;Viscardi, M.

title: Temperature sensitive mutants of Chandipura virus. II. Phenotypic characteristics of six complementary groups
