abstract: Fifty mutants of the rhabdovirus Chandipura virus temperature sensitive (ts) were classified into six complementation groups, designated ChI to ChVI. Group ChI contains 44 mutants, group ChII contains 2 mutants, and the remaining groups each contain 1 mutant. Mutants in the ChI, ChIII, ChIV, and ChVI groups had RNA-negative phenotypes in experiments measuring amplification of RNA synthesis at the restriction temperature. Two mutants in the ChII group had RNA-positive phenotypes and the virions were thermostable. The mutant ts Ch851 of the ChV group was also RNA positive, and the M polypeptide of this mutant appeared unstable in cells incubated at the restriction temperature. Thus, the ChII and ChV complementation groups are likely to represent genes encoding two viral proteins of the virion envelope. A precise assignment cannot be made in the case of the four RNA-negative groups, as all studied mutants showed some polymerase activity in vitro at the limiting temperature. An attempt to obtain polymerase mutants by screening for susceptibility to rifampin was unsuccessful. The six temperature-dependent host-range mutants (tdCE phenotype) of Chandipura virus failed to replicate in chicken embryo cells at the limiting temperature, but otherwise they differed from similar vesicular stomatitis viruses in host-spacing characteristics.
authors: Gadkari, D. A.;Pringle, C. R.

title: Analysis by high-throughput sequencing of Specific Pathogen-Free eggs
abstract: Specific Pathogen Free (SPF) embryonated eggs are used in the manufacture of many veterinary and human vaccines. We used High Throughput Sequencing to screen allantoic fluids and embryos for the presence of encapsulated viral genomes and viral transcripts, respectively. SPF eggs from two different manufacturers were tested. We have proven sequences corresponding to known endogenous retroviruses and Avian Leukosis Virus sequences, but no sequences that could suggest a productive infection of eggs with a virus even distant from known viruses. Our results strongly suggest that SPF eggs, such as those used for this study, represent a safe substrate for vaccine production. (C) 2014 International Alliance for Biological Standardization. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Gagnieur, L.;Cheval, J.;Cochet, M.;Breard, E.;Gratigny, M.;Hebert, C.;Muth, E.;Viarouge, C.;Dumarest, M.;Coulpier, M.;Eloit, M.

title: Unbiased analysis of viral diversity in fetal bovine serum and trypsin used in cell culture by high-throughput sequencing
abstract: Fetal bovine serum (FBS) and trypsin are reagents used in cell culture and have been a source of viral contamination of pharmaceutical products. We performed high-throughput sequencing (HTS) for two commercial pools of FBS batches and three commercial trypsin batches. Taxonomies were determined by comparing contig and singleton sequences with all NCBI nucleic acid and protein databases. The same major viral strains were demonstrated across batches of a given reagent, but the proportion of viral reads among total reads varied significantly between samples (from 0.002% to 22.7%). The sequences found in FBS were mainly derived from bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) 1 to 3 and bovine parvovirus 3 (BPV3). The BVDV sequences derived from FBS showed only minor differences with the primers generally used to screen for BVDV. The viral sequences in trypsin were mainly from porcine circovirus type 2. Other known viral sequences and potential new viral strains (bovine parvovirus and bovine pegivirus) were demonstrated at lower read counts. The burden of some known and novel viruses detected by HTS can be measured by qPCR. The results of the HTS provide a framework for evaluating the appropriateness of control measures, including the design of PCRs, bioassays, and inactivation procedures. Â© 2014 International Alliance for Biological Standardization.
authors: Gagnieur, L.;Cheval, J.;Gratigny, M.;HÃ©bert, C.;Muth, E.;Dumarest, M.;Eloit, M.

title: Genetic characterization and evolutionary analysis of Newcastle disease virus isolated from domestic duck in South Korea.
abstract: Domestic ducks are considered a potential reservoir of the Newcastle disease virus. The study characterized a Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated from a domestic duck during surveillance in South Korea. The complete genome of the NDV isolate was sequenced and the phylogenetic relationship with reference strains was investigated. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the strain clustered in genotype I of Class II ND viruses had highly phylogenetic similarity to NDV strains isolated from waterfowl in China, but far from viruses isolated in chickens and vaccine strains used in South Korea. Pathogenicity assay in chickens revealed that it is a lentogenic virus. The deduced amino acid sequence of the cleavage site of the fusion (F) protein confirmed that the isolate contained the avirulent motif 112GKQGRL117 at the cleavage site and did not cause significant disease in chickens and ducks. By fusion gene-based phylogeographic analysis, we predict the origin of an ancestral virus of the isolate and its sister strain found in China around 1998. It highlights the need for continued surveillance to improve current understanding of molecular epidemiology and the evolution of pathogenic strains. .
authors: Gaikwad, S.;Kim, J. Y.;Lee, H. J.;Jung, S. C.;Choi, K. S.

title: Antiviral activity of tetrahydro-2(1H)-pyrimidinones and related compounds
abstract: 24 tetrahydro-2(1H)-pyrimidinone derivatives and related compounds were tested in vitro for antiviral activity against representatives of six viral taxonomic groups. Screening was performed with a two-step procedure, including the agar diffusion plaque inhibition test and a one-step growth cycle setup. Tetrahydro-2(1H)-pyrimidinone (THP), 1,3-bis(piperidinomethyl)-THP, a significant activity (THPT) of the three mono- and bis-morpholinomethyl derivatives of the 1-morpholinomethyl derivative of tetrahydro-2(1H)-pyrimidinthione and established against the corresponding N,N'-bis(morpholinomethyl)-urea poultry plague virus. In the one-step growth cycle setup, these compounds inhibited 87.5-99.6% of the infectious virus yield. Two of the compounds, the 1-morpholinomethyl derivatives of THP and THPT, also showed a strong inhibitory effect on the reproduction of Semliki Forest virus, exceeding 99.9% in the one-step growth cycle test. A borderline effect was observed in some derivatives against Vaccinia virus and Newcastle disease virus. The structure-activity relationship of this group of compounds is discussed.
authors: Galabov, A. S.;Velichkova, E.;Karparov, A.

title: Genotyping of African swine fever virus (ASFV) isolates associated with disease outbreaks in Uganda in 2007.
abstract: Samples from infected domestic pigs associated with the African swine fever (ASF) outbreak at three sites in central Uganda in 2007 were confirmed to be infected with African swine fever virus (ASFV) using P72 gene-based polymerase chain reaction amplification (PCR). assay combined with restriction analysis. None of the sera collected from pigs with clinical symptoms were positive using the tests prescribed by the OIE serological. However, seven hemadsorbing viruses were isolated in macrophage culture and genotyped with partial p72 and full-length p54-gene sequences. Four of these viruses were isolated directly from serum samples. All viruses were classified into the domestic pig cycle-related p72 and p54 genotype IX, including viruses responsible for ASF outbreaks in Kenya in 2006 and 2007 and Uganda in 2003. To identify virus associations at higher resolution, typing was performed by tetrameric analysis. Amino acid repeat regions within the central variable region (CVR) of the B602L gene. Uganda isolate sequences showed 100% identity to viruses isolated from outbreaks in Kenya in 2007. The ID was greater than any virus recovered from an earlier outbreak in Kenya in 2006. This provides further evidence that the genetically similar ASFV virus within p72 Genotype IX may be circulating. between Kenya and Uganda. Â© 2011 Academic Journals.
authors: Gallardo, C.;Ademun, A. R.;Nieto, R.;Nantima, N.;Arias, M.;MartÃ­n, E.;Pelayo, V.;Bishop, R. P.

title: The nanovirus-alphasatellite complex identified in Vicia cracca in the Rhone delta region of France
abstract: Nanoviruses are multicomponent, single-stranded DNA viruses that infect plants. Using a viral metagenomically informed approach, a novel nanovirus and two associated alpha satellite molecules were identified in an uncultivated asymptomatic Vicia cracca plant in the Rhne region of France. This new nanovirus genome contains eight genomic components (called DNA-R, DNA-S, DNA-M, DNA-C, DNA-N, DNA-U1, DNA-U2, and DNA-U4) and all components < Other nanovirus 66% binary sequence identity with their genome. Two related alphasatellites share 62% identity with each other and <81% identity would be all other nanovirus-associated alphasatellites.
authors: Gallet, R.;Kraberger, S.;Filloux, D.;Galzi, S.;Fontes, H.;Martin, D. P.;Varsani, A.;Roumagnac, P.

title: Genetic information and anti-tuberculosis potential of DNAIII mycobacteriophages
abstract: Objective: To understand the genetic information of Mycobacteriophage DNAIII and to explore its anti-tuberculosis potential. Methods: Mycobacteriophage DNAIII DNA was isolated and purified using the lambda DNA extraction protocol. Shotgun sequences were assembled with Phred and PhraD and edited with Consed, then gaps were filled by sequencing the PCR fragments. General features of the genome were analyzed using the EditSeq software of the DNAStar software package. The genome was screened for open reading frames using Glimmer 3.0. The genetic information of the mycobacteriophage DNAIII genome was further investigated by co-linearity analysis and phylogenetic tree construction. The ability of DNAIII to cleave M. tuberculosis was investigated in vitro and the effects of temperature, alcohol, and pH values on DNAIII survival were determined. Results: The DNAIII genome had a size of 39,520 bp and was linear double-stranded DNA, with a G+C content of 66.83%. DNAIII contained 60 predicted protein-coding genes and did not encode any tRNA. There was no tandem repeat sequence in the DNAIII genome. The DNAIII gene encoded 32 integrases and also no gene encoding a repressor. DNAIII was quite similar to Angel and BPs and was in line at the nucleotide acid level. At three different time points (1 day, 2 days and 3 days), M. tuberculosis numbers in the DNAIII group were significantly smaller than those in the control group (P<0.05). DNAIII was unstable to temperature, alcohol, and pH. Conclusion: DNAIII belonging to the G cluster is a mycobacteriophage capable of degrading M. tuberculosis.
authors: Gan, Y. L.;Liu, P.;Wu, T. T.;Guo, S. L.

title: Newcastle disease virus: current status and understanding Review
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the highly pathogenic viral diseases of avian species. ND is economically important because of the large mortality and morbidity associated with it. The disease is endemic in many third world countries where agriculture serves as the primary source of national income. Newcastle disease virus (NDV) belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family and is a well-characterized member among the avian paramyxovirus serotypes. In recent years, NDV has attracted virologists not only for its pathogenic potential, but also for its oncolytic activity and use as a vaccine vector for both humans and animals. The NDV-based recombinant vaccine offers a viable choice for live attenuated vaccine construction due to the modular nature of transcription, minimal recombination frequency, and absence of DNA phase during replication. Our current understanding of NDV biology is expanding rapidly due to the availability of modern molecular biology tools and high-throughput whole genome sequencing.
authors: Ganar, K.;Das, M.;Sinha, S.;Kumar, S.

title: A REVIEW OF SIGNAL INFLUENZA VIRUS A (S-OIV) INFECTION
authors: Ganguly, S.;Giri, S.;Aseri, G. K.;Yadav, P.;Khare, N. K.

title: Alternative splicing analysis in chicken embryo fibroblasts in response to reticuloendotheliosis virus infection
abstract: Alternative splicing (AS) plays an important role in regulating genomic expression at the transcriptional level and is involved in many important biological functions of cells, so a gene can be spliced into different transcript variants and subsequently translated into many different types of proteins. Reticuloendotheliosis virus (REV) is a type of retrovirus that can infect multiple bird species and lead to runting syndrome, immunosuppression, and oncogenesis. In this study, we analyzed AS in REV-infected chicken embryo fibroblasts (CEFs) grafted with second-generation REV (group VB) and compared with normal CEFs (group C) by high-throughput RNA sequencing technology. A total of 6,939 alternatively spliced genes were detected, among which the most common pattern was the skipped exon (SE). In addition, 5,607 AS genes were found to be differentially expressed; Compared with group C, group VB contains 2,825 genes that are significantly up-regulated and 2,782 genes that are significantly down-regulated. These 5,607 differentially expressed AS genes are involved in many important biological processes. Many are involved in apoptosis and tumorigenesis. We also proved by agarose gel electrophoresis that the AS events predicted by our study are real and that AS is closely associated with apoptosis and tumorigenesis in REV-infected CEFs. Our study provides the best analysis to date of the potential link between AS and CEFs in response to REV infection. Research highlights transcriptomic analysis of REV-infected CEFs using high-throughput sequencing. Potential link between alternative splicing and CEFs in response to REV infection. The skipped exon is the most common spliced pattern in REV-infected CEFs. Differentially expressed genes mainly involved in apoptosis and tumorigenesis.
authors: Gao, C.;Zhai, J.;Dang, S.;Zheng, S.

title: Classification of a new member of the TBE flavivirus subgroup according to its immunological, pathogenetic and molecular characteristics: Identification of subgroup-specific pentapeptides.
abstract: The antigenic, pathogenic and molecular properties of Turkish sheep encephalitis (TSE) virus, TTE80 strain, were compared with other members of the tick-borne encephalitis (TBE) virus complex. Monoclonal antibodies with defined specificity for the flavivirus envelope glycoprotein differentiated TSE virus from loping disease (LI), western or far eastern TBE, Langat and Powassan virus in indirect immunofluorescence, hemagglutination-inhibition and neutralization tests. TSE virus, which causes LI-like disease in sheep, was similar to LI virus in mouse neurovirulence tests. Molecular homology data of all structural genes of TSE virus compared to other tick-borne flaviviruses indicated that TSE virus is a separate member of the TBE virus subgroup. The data are consistent with the conclusion that TSE virus evolved in a separate evolutionary pathway compared to close antigenic relatives, western European, far eastern TBE viruses and LI virus. By aligning amino acids encoded in the viral envelope glycoprotein of mosquito and tick-borne flaviviruses, we also identified subgroup-specific pentapeptide motifs for tick-borne encephalitis, Japanese encephalitis and dengue subgroup viruses of the Flavivirus genus. These pentapeptides have important implications for the evolution, classification and diagnosis of flaviviruses.
authors: Gao, G. F.;Hussain, M. H.;Reid, H. W.;Gould, E. A.

title: Viral genome and antiviral drug susceptibility analysis of two patients from a family cluster caused by influenza A(H7N9) virus in Zhejiang, China, 2013
abstract: Goals: In the winter of 2013, people were at risk of human-to-human transmission of the re-emerging influenza A(H7N9) virus. Here, we report on the clinical features, genomic sequences of the host viruses, and antiviral drug susceptibility of two patients infected with this virus from the same family. Methods: Clinical and epidemiological data of two patients from the same family were collected and analyzed. Sequencing was performed for viruses isolated from these two patients and an epidemiologically related chicken, and the sequences of eight gene segments of the viruses were analyzed phylogenetically. The susceptibility of viruses to antiviral drug therapy was determined by the neuraminidase inhibitor susceptibility test. Results: Two patients in a family cluster shared the same symptoms but had different outcomes and had a strong epidemiological link. Three strains were isolated, two from these two patients and one from chicken. Analyzes of genome sequencing and phylogenetic trees showed that the two viruses were nearly identical. We noted the presence of two new mutations in the NA gene and six new mutations in the PB2 gene, in addition to the PB2 E627K amino acid substitution that was not present in the first-wave isolates. Drug susceptibility testing showed that the new isolates were resistant to oseltamivir but susceptible to peramivir. Results: Two patients in a family cluster were cases of probable human-to-human transmission. The new isolates were susceptible to peramivir but reduced susceptibility to oseltamivir.
authors: Gao, H. N.;Yao, H. P.;Liang, W. F.;Wu, X. X.;Wu, H. B.;Wu, N. P.;Yang, S. G.;Zhang, Q.;Su, K. K.;Guo, J.;Zheng, S. F.;Zhu, Y. X.;Chen, H. L.;Yuen, K. Y.;Li, L. J.

title: Integrated analysis of microRNA-mRNA expression in A549 cells infected with influenza A viruses (IAVs) from different host species
abstract: Although several miRNAs have been shown to be involved in the influenza virus replication cycle, the identification of miRNAs and mRNAs expressed in A549 cells infected with influenza A viruses (IAVs) from different host species has remained poorly studied. To investigate the molecular mechanisms associated with differential expression of miRNAs during influenza A virus infection, we profiled global miRNA and mRNA expression in A549 cells infected with human seasonal influenza A virus H3N2 (Human_Br07), porcine influenza A virus H1N1. (SW_3861) or avian influenza A virus H3N2 (AVI_9990). MiRNA and mRNA expression profiles were obtained by microarray and high-throughput sequencing analyses, respectively. Integrated analysis of differentially expressed miRNAs (DEMs) and differentially expressed genes (DEGs) was performed using bioinformatics tools, and expression of miRNAs and mRNAs was determined by real-time quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR). ) was confirmed with We identified 20 miRNAs (6 up-regulated and 14 down-regulated) and 1286 mRNAs (935 up-regulated and 351 down-regulated) that exhibited the same differential expression trends in three groups of infected cells compared to an uninfected control. An integrated analysis of these expression profiles identified 79 miRNA-mRNA pairs associated with the influenza A reference pathway, and 107 miRNA-mRNA interactions were associated with the defense of the virus. In addition, the results obtained showed that 8 differentially expressed miRNAs (hsa-miR-210-3p, hsa-miR-296-5p, hsa-miR-371a-5p, hsa-miR-762, hsa) Supported by qPCR analysis. -miR-937-5p, hsa-miR-1915-3p, hsa-miR-3665 and hsa-miR-1290) and 13 differentially expressed mRNAs (IFNL1, CXCL10, RSAD2, MX1, OAS2, IFIT2, IFI44 L, MX2 , XAF1, NDRG1, FGA, EGLN3, and TFRC). Our findings suggest that dysregulated miRNA expression plays a crucial role in infection by IAVs originating from different species and provides a basis for further investigation of the molecular regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs involved in influenza A virus infection.
authors: Gao, J.;Gao, L.;Li, R.;Lai, Z.;Zhang, Z.;Fan, X.

title: De novo assembly and functional annotations of the Metorchis orientalis (trematode: Opisthorchiidae) transcriptome
abstract: Metorchis orientalis is a neglected zoonotic parasite that lives in the gallbladder and bile duct of humans as well as poultry and some mammals. Despite its economic and medical importance, the known information about the transcriptome and genome of M. orientalis is limited. In this study, we performed de novo sequencing, transcriptome assembly, and functional annotations of adult M. orientalis, from which approximately 77.4 million high-quality clean reads were obtained, among which the length of transcript contigs ranged from 100 to 11,249 nt, with an average length. 373 nt and N50 length 919 nt. Next, we pooled 31,943 unigenes, of which 20,009 (62.6%) were annotated by BLASTn and BLASTx searches against the existing database. Of these unigenes, 19,795 (62.0%), 3407 (10.7%), 10,620 (33.2%) showed significant similarity in the NR, NT and Swiss-Prot databases, respectively; 5744 (18.0%) and 4678 (14.6%) unigens were assigned to GO and COG, respectively; and 9099 (28.5%) unigenes were identified and mapped to 256 paths in the KEGG Pathway database. We also found that 98 (1.08%) unigenes were associated with bile secretion and 5 (0.05%) unigenes were associated with the primary bile acid biosynthesis pathways category. Characterization of these transcriptomic data has implications for a better understanding of the biology of M. orientalis and will facilitate the development of intervention agents for this and other pathogenic butterflies of human and animal health importance.
authors: Gao, J. F.;Gao, Y.;Qiu, J. H.;Chang, Q. C.;Zhang, Y.;Fang, M.;Wang, C. R.

title: Biological heterogeneity of H5N1 influenza A virus isolates from humans in Hong Kong, including systemic replication in mice.
abstract: In 1997, an H5N1 avian influenza A virus infected humans in Hong Kong. Although the virus causes systemic infection and is highly lethal in chickens due to the sensitivity of hemagglutinin to furin and PC6 proteases, it is unknown whether it also causes systemic infection. infection in humans. Clinical outcomes of infection in Hong Kong residents ranged from mild respiratory illness to multiple organ failure leading to death. Therefore, to understand the pathogenesis of influenza due to these H5N1 isolates, we investigated their virulence in mice. The results identified two different groups of viruses: group 1, where the lethal dose (MLD50) for 50% of mice was between 0.3 and 11 PFU, and group 2, where the MLD50 was greater than 103 PFU, after intranasal vaccination of mice with 100 PFU group 1 virus. One day later, the virus titer in the Lungs was 107 PFU/g, or 3 log units higher than that of group 2 viruses. Both virus strains proliferated to high titers (> 106 PFU/g) in the lungs on day 3 and maintained these titers through day 6. More importantly, only group 1 viruses caused systemic infection and multiplied in non-respiratory organs, including the brain. Immunohistochemical analysis showed replication of group 1 virus in brain neurons and glial cells and cardiac myofibers. Phylogenetic analysis of all viral genes showed that both groups of Hong Kong H5N1 viruses formed a distinct lineage from that of other viruses, and that genetic reclassification did not occur between H5N1 and H1 or H3 human viruses. Since mice and humans harbor both furin and PC6 proteases, we propose that the virulence mechanism responsible for the lethality of influenza viruses in birds also works in mammalian hosts. The failure of some H5N1 viruses to produce systemic infection in our model suggests that many still unidentified factors contribute to the severity of H5N1 infection in mammals. In addition, the ability of these viruses to produce systemic infection in mice and the clear differences in pathogenicity between the isolates studied here suggest that this system provides a useful model for the study of the pathogenesis of avian influenza virus infection in mammals.
authors: Gao, P.;Watanabe, S.;Ito, T.;Goto, H.;Wells, K.;McGregor, M.;James Cooley, A.;Kawaoka, Y.

title: Deep Sequencing Analysis of DF-1 Cell Transcriptome Response to Infection with Duck Newcastle Disease Virus
abstract: Newcastle Disease (ND) is caused by Newcastle Disease Virus (NDV), with respiratory and digestive mucosal bleeding for typical symptoms. It is an acute highly contact disease. NDV can proliferate in DF-1 cells. NDV from waterfowl is different from older NDV from chicken, it causes death of waterfowl. However, the molecular mechanisms of NDV-infected waterfowl are still not fully understood. In this study, researchers used the illumina genome analyzer platform to perform genome-wide Digital Gene Expression (DGE), a tag-based high-throughput transcriptome sequencing method analysis of NDV-YC-infected DF-1 cells. The researchers were able to achieve a sequencing depth of 5.0-6.1 million tags per library and found >8000 genes that would be differentially expressed during NDV-YC infection processes. NDV-YC specifically identified genes involving the I-kappaB kinase/NF-kappaB and TGF-beta signaling pathway. Further analysis cell part, binding and bioregulation terms used in Gene Ontology (GO) analysis are the main clauses, respectively. The data are useful to better understand the molecular mechanism of infected NDV-YC and provide a basis for further in vivo studies and clinical trials.
authors: Gao, S. M.;Sun, M. H.;Wang, Z. X.;Li, X. W.;Fan, H. Y.;Ren, T.

title: Whole genome shotgun sequencing revealed highly polymorphic genome regions and genes in Escherichia coli O157:H7 isolates collected from a single feeding site.
abstract: Escherichia coli serotype O157:H7 continues to pose a serious health threat to humans. Bovines, the main reservoir of the pathogen, harbor E. coli O157:H7 in their gastrointestinal tract and shed variable concentrations of E. coli O157:H7 into the environment. Genetic characterization of cattle barn E. coli O157 strains is of interest to the livestock industry, food industry, and public health community. This study applied whole genome shotgun sequencing (WGS) and single nucleotide variant (SNV) to characterize 279 cattle barn E. coli O157:H7 strains isolated from a single medium in the southwestern USA. More than 4,000 SNVs were identified among the strains, and the resulting phylogenomic tree revealed three main groups. Using the Sakai strain genome as a reference, more than 2,000 SNVs were annotated and a detailed SNV map was created. The results clearly revealed highly polymorphic loci throughout the E. coli O157:H7 genome aligned with prophage regions and highly variable genes involved in processing bacterial genetic information. WGS data was further profiled against an extensive virulence factor database (VFDB) for virulence gene identification. Out of a total of 285 virulence genes identified, only 132 were present in all strains. There were six virulence genes specific to single isolates. Our findings suggested that genome variations of E. coli O157:H7 are mainly attributable to the dynamics of certain phages and that bacterial strains have variable virulence gene profiles despite originating from a single bovine population; pathogenicity, host prevalence, and transmissibility with E. coli O157:H7.
authors: Gao, X.;Yang, X.;Noll, L.;Shi, X.;Worley, J.;Allard, M.;Brown, E.;Nagaraja, T. G.;Meng, J.

title: Koolpinyah: a virus related to kotonkan from cattle in northern Australia
abstract: Two closely related viruses were isolated from the blood of cattle near Darwin, Northern Territory, Australia. Serological studies were performed when virus morphology studies showed these to be rhabdoviruses. These isolates are closely related or identical and related to, but distinct from, rabies-associated cotoncan virus. Other serological studies have shown that these are two isolates of a newly recognized virus for which the name Koolpinyah virus has been suggested.
authors: Gard, G. P.;Melville, L. F.;Calisher, C. H.;Karabatsos, N.

title: Genomic characterization of vinegar crest virus, an Australian nairovirus isolated from Argas robertsi ticks collected from cattle herons in 1983.
abstract: This report describes the nearly complete genomic sequence and subsequent analysis of Vinegar Hill virus (VINHV; transient member of the genus Orthonairovirus, family Nairoviridae, order Bunyavirales). VINHV is the second nairovirus reported to be isolated from mainland Australia and the first to be sequenced and analyzed. Our genetic analysis indicates that VINHV belongs to the Dera Ghazi Khan genogroup, a group of viruses previously isolated from other parts of the world, including Asia, South Africa and the USA. We discuss possible routes of entry of nairoviruses into Australia and the need to understand the viroma of Australian ticks in the context of new and emerging disease.
authors: Gauci, P. J.;McAllister, J.;Mitchell, I. R.;Cybinski, D.;St George, T.;Gubala, A. J.

title: Whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of Bluetongue virus serotype 2 strains isolated in the United States, including a novel strain from the western United States.
abstract: Bluetongue is a potentially fatal arboviral disease of domestic and wild ruminant animals characterized by diffuse edema and tissue necrosis. Bluetongue virus (BTV) serotypes 10, 11, 13, and 17 are seen in most of the United States, while serotype 2 (BTV-2) has previously only been detected in the southeastern United States. Since 1998, 10 other BTV serotypes have also been isolated from ruminant animals in the southeastern United States. In 2010, BTV-2 was first identified in California, and preliminary sequence analysis showed that the virus isolate was closely related to BTV strains circulating in the southeastern United States. In the current study, the whole genome sequence of the California strain of BTV-2 was compared with that of other BTV-2 strains from the Americas. The results of the analysis suggest that genetically distinct viruses circulate together in the southeastern United States, and that the 2010 western isolate is also closely related to the southeastern BTV strains. While it remains unclear how this new virus was transported to California, the current study's findings highlight the need for continued surveillance of this economically important livestock disease.
authors: Gaudreault, N. N.;Mayo, C. E.;Jasperson, D. C.;Crossley, B. M.;Breitmeyer, R. E.;Johnson, D. J.;Ostlund, E. N.;MacLachlan, N. J.;Wilson, W. C.

title: Antigenic relationships among some animal rotaviruses: In vitro virus neutralization and cross-protection in piglets.
abstract: The serotype, RNA electropherotype and cross-protection properties of rotaviruses isolated from dog, monkey pig and human species were compared. Bovine strain B:USA:78:1A and dog strain C:USA:81:2 were adapted to cell culture and cloned in this study. Other viruses, namely monkey strain S:USA:79:2, porcine Ohio State University strain P:USA:77:1, and human strain WA, have already been adapted to cell culture, although they have been further cloned for this task. Serum neutralization test was used to classify viruses into serotype groups. Viruses that differed 20-fold or more in neutralization titer were divided into different serotype groups. Four main serotype groups were found in this study and these groups were represented by cattle, human, pig and dog-monkey strains. From cross-protection studies, these serotype groups were found to differ significantly. Except for the swine strain, none of the viruses used as the vaccine protected the gnotobiotic piglets from challenge with the virulent swine Ohio State University rotavirus strain. Also, the canine virus protected the piglets from fighting the monkey virus. RNA electropherotype confirmed that the dog and monkey strains differed in the eight RNA segments, eliminating the possibility that they were the same virus. From these findings, it was concluded that only viruses belonging to the same serotype group can be expected to provide cross protection, and therefore, vaccination should be done with serotypes that the animal is likely to be exposed to.
authors: Gaul, A. K.;Simpson, T. F.;Woode, G. N.;Fulton, R. W.

title: Hematological parameters in blood of sheep infected and uninfected with Maedi-visna virus
abstract: Classified as a lentivirus of the Retroviridae family, maedi-visna virus (MVV) causes a very widespread economically important disease in sheep in many parts of the world. The presence of infection in Turkey has been demonstrated by previous studies. In this study, whole blood samples were analyzed by ELISA and PCR to detect MVV antibody and antigen responses, respectively. Hematological findings were observed and comparisons were made between antibody and antigen positive naturally infected (n=5), antibody positive and antigen negative (n=20), antibody and antigen negative (n=20) sheep. When infected sheep were compared with control sheep, Hgb and MPV parameters were shown to be statistically different (P <= 0.001). These findings suggest that MVV infections should be considered as an important health risk for the flock of sheep and Hgb and MPV blood parameters may be helpful in the diagnosis of MVV.
authors: Gazyagci, S.;Azkur, A. K.;Aslan, M. E.

title: Overview of influenza A virus receptors
abstract: Influenza A viruses are spherical particles that attach to cells through bonds between hemagglutinin and specific cellular receptors. Numerous recent studies have revealed that Sialic acid (SA) is a crucial component of influenza A virus receptors. This short review summarizes recent advances in our understanding of influenza A virus receptors. The introduction describes the classification of influenza A virus receptors and the review continues with a study of the distribution of SA in different tissues and hosts. This is followed by the research applications of influenza A virus receptors and an explanation of why worldwide receptor studies are so important. Â© 2011 Informa Healthcare USA, Inc.
authors: Ge, S.;Wang, Z.

title: Genetic diversity of novel circular ssDNA viruses in bats in China
abstract: New circular ssDNA genomes have been recently identified in animals and the environment using metagenomic and high-throughput sequencing approaches. In this study, five full-length circular ssDNA genomes were obtained from bat fecal samples using reverse PCR with sequences designed based on circovirus-related sequences from Solexa sequencing data derived from a random amplification method. These five sequences shared a genomic organization similar to circovirus or the recently proposed cyclovirus of the Circoviridae family. The newly obtained circovirus/cyclovirus-like genomes ranged from 1 741 to 21 77 bp and consisted of two major ORFs, ORF1 and ORF2, each encoding the putative replicase (Rep) and capsid (Cap) proteins, respectively. The potential root loop region was predicted in all five genomes, and three of them had the typical conserved non-nucleotide motif of cycloviruses. A set of primers targeting the conserved Rep region was designed and used to detect the prevalence of circovirus/cyclovirus sequences in individual bats. Of the 199 samples tested, 47 (23.6%) were positive for the cyclovirus genome and two (1.0%) were positive for the cyclovirus genome. A total of 48 partial Rep sequences plus five full-length genomes were obtained in this study. Detailed analysis showed that these sequences are distantly related to known circovirus/cyclovirus genomes and may represent 22 new species belonging to the family Circoviridae.
authors: Ge, X. Y.;Li, J. L.;Peng, C.;Wu, L. J.;Yang, X. L.;Wu, Y. Q.;Zhang, Y. Z.;Shi, Z. L.

title: An outbreak of wild-borne H1NX avian influenza viruses in Anhui, China
abstract: Background: As natural hosts of avian influenza viruses (AIVs), aquatic and migratory birds form temporary "genome constellations" by providing a gene pool for genetic transfer to and between species. This study describes the phylogenetic dynamics of H1NX based on the full molecular characterization of eight virus genes collected in Anhui Province, China from 2014 to 2015. Methods: Hemagglutination and hemagglutination inhibition tests were used to determine the hemagglutination (HA) activity of HA subtypes. The entire genomes of viruses were sequenced on an ABI PRISM 3500xl DNA Analyzer. Sequences were genetically analyzed using DNASTAR and MEGA 6 to study their genetic evolution. Pathogenic effects of viruses were evaluated using mouse infection models. Results: Seven strains of the H1 subtype avian influenza virus were isolated. Phylogenetic analysis showed natural recombination of H1 influenza viruses between Eurasian ancestry and North American ancestry. Some genes had high sequence identity with A/bean goose/Korea/220/2011(H9N2); this is a typical case involving viral reclassification between Eurasian ancestry and North American ancestry. The results of infection experiments in mice showed that viruses can acquire the ability to replicate in the respiratory organs of mice without adaptation. Conclusions: These findings suggest that continuous surveillance of wild birds, especially migratory birds, is important for understanding the ecology of the virus and providing early warning of possible H1 influenza outbreaks.
authors: Ge, Y.;Yao, Q. C.;Wang, X. F.;Fan, Z. Q.;Deng, G. H.;Chai, H. L.;Chen, H. L.;Hua, Y. P.

title: Genetically diverse low pathogenic avian influenza A virus subtypes circulate together in poultry in Bangladesh
abstract: Influenza virus surveillance, poultry epidemic research and genomic sequencing were evaluated from 2007 to 2013 in Bangladesh to understand the ecology and evolution of low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) A viruses. We analyzed 506 bird samples collected from poultry in live bird markets and backyard flocks. To identify influenza A viruses. Virus isolation positive samples (n = 50) were divided into subtypes and their genomes completing the coding were sequenced. The most frequently identified subtypes among LPAI isolates are H9N2, H11N3, H4N6 and H1N1. Less frequently detected subtypes included H1N3, H2N4, H3N2, H3N6, H3N8, H4N2, H5N2, H6N1, H6N7, and H7N9. Gene sequences were compared to publicly available sequences using phylogenetic inference approaches. Among the 14 identified subtypes, most of the viral gene segments were most closely related to poultry or wild avian viruses commonly found in Southeast Asia, Europe and/or North Africa. LPAI subtypes were distributed in various geographic regions in Bangladesh, and the surface and inner protein gene segments were phylogenetically clustered with a diverse number of viral subtypes, suggesting an extensive reclassification among these LPAI viruses. H9N2 subtype viruses differed from other LPAI subtypes in that genes from these viruses consistently clustered together, indicating that this subtype is enzootic in Bangladesh. The H9N2 strains identified in Bangladesh were phylogenetically and antigenically related to previous human-derived H9N2 viruses detected in Bangladesh, representing a potential source for human infection. In contrast, circulating LPAI H5N2 and H7N9 viruses were both phylogenetically and antigenically unrelated to H5 viruses previously identified in humans in Bangladesh and H7N9 strains isolated from humans in China. Domestic poultry sold at live bird markets in Bangladesh carried a wide variety of LPAI virus subtypes and a high diversity of genotypes. Together with the seven-year sampling time frame, these findings demonstrate the continued circulation of these viruses in the country.
authors: Gerloff, N. A.;Khan, S. U.;Zanders, N.;Balish, A.;Haider, N.;Islam, A.;Chowdhury, S.;Rahman, M. Z.;Haque, A.;Hosseini, P.;Gurley, E. S.;Luby, S. P.;Wentworth, D. E.;Donis, R. O.;Sturm-Ramirez, K.;Davis, C. T.

title: Microarray resources for genetic and genomic studies in chicken: A review.
abstract: The advent of microarray technologies has allowed massively parallel analysis of thousands of genomic regions, revolutionizing the nature and scope of genetic and genomic research in humans and other species. It has been used for various purposes such as transcriptome analysis, CNV detection, SNP and CNV genotyping, examination of DNA-protein interaction, and detection of genome methylation. Microarrays have also made invaluable contributions to research for the chicken, as well as other avian species, as an important model organism for the study of embryology, immunology, oncology, virology, evolution, genetics and genomics. Despite their major contributions to life science research, the future of microarrays is being questioned with the advent of massively parallel next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies that promise to overcome some of the limitations of microarray platforms. In this article, we review the various sources of microarrays developed for chicken and their potential past and future applications. We also discuss about the future of microarrays in the NGS era, particularly in the context of livestock genetics. We argue that although NGS promises some important advantages, and in particular offers the opportunity to explore new elements in genome microarrays, it will remain the main tools for research and application in the field of farm animal genetics/genomics due to its affordability and high price. throughput nature, mature embedded technologies and ease of implementation. Also, with the emergence of new microarray technologies such as capture arrays, NGS and microarrays are expected to complement each other in future research in the life sciences. Â© 2013 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
authors: Gheyas, A. A.;Burt, D. W.

title: Transforming animal genomics with next-generation sequencing technologies: decade-long challenges and their impact on genetic architecture
abstract: For more than a quarter of a century, sequencing technologies, from Sanger's method to next-generation high-throughput techniques, have provided fascinating opportunities in the life sciences. The continued upward trajectory of sequencing technologies will improve livestock research and accelerate the development of a variety of new genomic and technological studies with livestock. The use of high-throughput technologies in livestock research has increased interest in metagenomics, epigenetics, genome-wide association studies, and the identification of single-nucleotide polymorphisms and copy number variations. Such studies are beginning to provide revolutionary insights into biological and evolutionary processes. Farm animals such as cattle, pigs and horses have played a dual role as economically and agriculturally important animals as well as biomedical research models. The first part of this study explores the state of current sequencing methods, many of which are used in animal genomic studies, and the second part summarizes the state of bovine, pig, equine and chicken genome sequencing and illustrates the achievements during the last study. A few years. Finally, we describe several high-throughput sequencing approaches for improved detection of known, unknown and emerging infectious agents, leading to better diagnosis of infectious diseases. The insights from viral metagenomics and the advancement of next-generation sequencing will strongly support specific and efficient vaccine development and provide strategies for controlling infectious disease transmission between animal populations and/or between animals and humans. However, prospective sequencing technologies will require more research and in-field testing before they reach the market.
authors: Ghosh, M.;Sharma, N.;Singh, A. K.;Gera, M.;Pulicherla, K. K.;Jeong, D. K.

title: Genetic detection and characterization of HoBi-like viruses emerging in archival fetal bovine serum series
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDV) are members of the genus Pestivirus within the family Flaviviridae. Based on their antigenic and nucleotide differences, BVDV is classified into two recognized strains, BVDV-1 and BVDV-2. More recently, a new putative pestivirus strain tentatively termed "HoBi-like" has been associated with bovine viral diarrhea. HoBi-like viruses were first identified in fetal bovine serum (FBS) imported from Brazil. Subsequently, a number of HoBi-like viruses were detected as contaminants in FBS or cell culture and in live ruminants. To further investigate possible pestivirus contamination in commercially available FBS batches, 26 FBS batches with various countries of origin were tested in this study for the presence of bovine pestiviruses. All 26 groups were positive by RT-PCR for at least one strain of bovine pestivirus. HoBi-like viruses were detected in 15 groups. Analysis of the 5'UTR and Npro sequences of 15 newly identified HoBi-like viruses combined with analysis of additional sequences from GenBank identified 4 genetic groups tentatively termed 3a-3d. The current study confirmed the presence of HoBi-like viruses that occur in FBS products labeled with different geographic origins. This finding has obvious implications for the safety of biological products such as cell lines and vaccines.
authors: Giammarioli, M.;Ridpath, J. F.;Rossi, E.;Bazzucchi, M.;Casciari, C.;De Mia, G. M.

title: Current taxonomy of bovine viral diarrhea virus type 1 according to the method of palindromic nucleotide substitutions
abstract: The pestivirus bovine viral diarrheal virus type 1 strain is responsible for cosmopolitan diseases affecting cattle and other ruminants and presents a wide variety of clinical manifestations with a corresponding impact on zootechnical production. Understanding genomic features and virus taxonomy is essential to maintain control and prophylactic programs. Considering the recent various studies reporting a relatively high number of new strains, especially from Asian countries, four hundred and eighty-two genomic sequences were evaluated in this study by applying the palindromic nucleotide substitutions method for genotyping. Based on secondary structure alignment and calculation of genetic distance between strains in the 5–² untranslated region of pestivirus RNA, the current taxonomy of the species was reviewed. Twenty-two genotypes were identified by applying a nomenclature based on difference in genus.
authors: Giangaspero, M.;Apicella, C.

title: Classification of peste des petits ruminant virus as the fourth member of the Morbillivirus genus.
abstract: Peste des petits ruminant (PPR) is a viral disease of sheep and goats in West Africa. When first identified, the virus was considered a variant of the rinderpest virus. The biological and physicochemical characteristics of the virus indicate that it is closely related to the measles, rinderpest and canine distemper viruses. These three viruses make up the Morbillivirus genus of Paramyxoviridae. The PPR virus is sufficiently different from these 3 viruses to justify its consideration as the fourth member of the Morbillivirus genus.
authors: Gibbs, E. P. J.;Taylor, W. P.;Lawman, M. J. P.;Bryant, J.

title: Whole genome sequencing in epidemic analysis
abstract: In addition to the ever-present concern of medical professionals about epidemics of infectious diseases, the relative ease of access and low cost of acquiring, producing and disseminating pathogenic organisms or biological toxins mean that bioterrorist activity must also be considered when faced with a disease outbreak. . The use of whole-genome sequencing (WGS) in epidemic analysis facilitates rapid and accurate identification of pathogen virulence factors and can be used to identify disease transmission pathways within a population and provide information about the likely source. Molecular tools such as WGS are being developed and developed rapidly to provide robust and higher resolution methods for identifying, comparing and classifying pathogenic organisms. If these pathogen characterization methods are applied appropriately, they will provide an enhanced public health response, whether an outbreak of disease is initiated by natural events or by accidental or deliberate human activities. The current application of next-generation sequencing (NGS) technology in microbial WGS and microbial forensics is reviewed.
authors: Gilchrist, C. A.;Turner, S. D.;Riley, M. F.;Petri, W. A.;Hewlett, E. L.

title: Massive Extinction of Bovine Leukemia Virus Proviral Clones Located at Genomic Transcriptionally Active Sites During Primary Infection
abstract: Deltaretroviruses, such as human T-lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1) and bovine leukemia virus (BLV), cause a persistent infection that usually remains asymptomatic but can also lead to leukemia or lymphoma. These viruses reproduce by infecting new lymphocytes (i.e. infectious cycle) or by clonal expansion of infected cells (mitotic cycle). The relative importance of these two cycles in viral replication changes during infection. Most infected clones are formed before the onset of an effective immune response. Next, the major replication pathway is the mitotic expansion of pre-existing infected clones. Due to the scarcity of available samples and ethical reasons, only limited data are available on early infection by HTLV-1. Therefore, we addressed this question in a comparative BLV model. We used high-throughput sequencing to map and quantify the insertion sites of the provirus to monitor the clonality (i.e., the number of distinct clones and the abundance of each clone) of the BLV-infected cell population. We found that BLV spread shifted from cell neoinfection to clonal proliferation approximately 2 months after inoculation. Initially, BLV proviral integration significantly favors transcribed regions of the genome. Negative selection subsequently removes 97% of detected clones in seroconversion and dislikes BLV-infected cells carrying a provirus located close to a promoter or a gene. However, clone abundance among surviving proviruses is positively correlated with the proximity of the provirus to a replicating site. Thus, during primary infection, two opposing forces operate and determine the fate of long-term clonal composition: (1) initial integration within genes or promoters, and (2) negative selection favoring proviruses located near replicated regions. The result of this initial response will contribute to the proviral load setpoint value as clonal abundance will benefit from carrying a provirus in replicated regions. Â© 2013 Gillet et al.
authors: Gillet, N. A.;GutiÃ©rrez, G.;Rodriguez, S. M.;de Brogniez, A.;Renotte, N.;Alvarez, I.;Trono, K.;Willems, L.

title: Bovine Leukemia Virus Small Non-coding RNAs Are Functional Elements Regulating Replication and Contributing to In Vivo Oncogenesis
abstract: Retroviruses are not expected to encode miRNAs because of the potential problem of self-cleavage of their genomic RNAs. This assumption has recently been challenged by experiments showing that bovine leukemia virus (BLV) encodes miRNAs from intragenomic Pol III promoters. BLV miRNAs are abundantly expressed in B-cell tumors in the absence of significant levels of genomic and subgenomic viral RNAs. Using deep RNA sequencing and functional reporter assays, we demonstrated that miRNAs mediate the expression of genes involved in cell signaling, cancer, and immunity. We also demonstrate that BLV miRNAs are required to induce B-cell tumors in an experimental model and promote efficient viral replication in the natural host.
authors: Gillet, N. A.;Hamaidia, M.;de Brogniez, A.;Gutierrez, G.;Renotte, N.;Reichert, M.;Trono, K.;Willems, L.

title: Sequence analysis of alpha trans-inducing factor of bovine herpesvirus type 5 (BHV-5)
abstract: Bovine herpes virus (BHV), a member of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily, is classified into neurovirulent and non-neurovirulent subtypes according to different neuropathogenicity. Transcription of viral immediate early (IE) genes during alphaherpesvirus gene expression is mediated by a multicomponent immediate early complex (IEC) integrated by a host cell protein, the viral tegument protein alpha trans-inducing factor (Î±-tif). HCF) and a host Octamer protein (Oct). In this article, we present a series analysis of Î±-tif of the encephalitic BHV subtype bovine herpesvirus type 5 (BHV-5). Bovine herpesvirus type 1 (BHV-1) and BHV-5 Î±-tifs share 98% amino acid sequence homology. However, BHV-5 Î±-tif is 23 residues shorter at the amino end than BHV-1 Î±-tif. Amino acid alignment of the Î±-tifs of BHV-1 and BHV-5 with other alphaherpes viruses shows conserved motif domains as well as significant differences mainly located at the amino and carboxyl termini.
authors: Gillette, K.;Misra, V.;Bratanich, A.

title: Neuropathotyping: a new system for classifying Marek's disease virus
abstract: statistical approach was used to construct a new classification system based on neurological responses of Marek's disease virus (MDV). To improve the system, neurological response data from 15x7 chickens inoculated with 30 serotype 1 MDV strains were statistically analyzed by a cluster analysis. The aim was to determine a statistical system that would confirm whether the three neurovirulence groups were correlated with the three previously described pathotypes. The system was also validated in two additional specific pathogen-free (SPF) chicken strains, SPAFAS and line SC (Hy-Vac). The proposed system is based on the analysis of three variables: 1) frequency of birds showing transient paralysis (dpi) 9 to 11 days after vaccination, (2) mortality before 15 dpi, and (3) frequency of birds showing persistent neurological disease between 21 and 23 dpi. Using this system, an MDV can be classified into one of three groups, namely neuropathotypes A, B, and C, which roughly correspond to lethal, very lethal and very lethal plus pathotypes, respectively. However, the correlation between neuropathotype and pathotype was not absolute and neuropathotyping is a complement rather than a replacement for the existing pathotyping system. Our results showed that neuropathotyping studies can be conducted in two types of commercial SPF chickens using the same variants, although the system must first be standardized using prototype viruses. Neuropathotypes can also be predicted with reasonable accuracy by our statistical analysis. Using this analysis, we determined that MDV strains within the very virulent pathotype could be divided into neuropathotypes B and C, thereby establishing a previously unrecognized pathotypical classification. This finding demonstrates how neuropathotyping can expand important information not identified by conventional pathotyping.
authors: Gimeno, I. M.;Witter, R. L.;Neumann, U.

title: Natural transmission and comparative analysis of small ruminant lentiviruses in Norwegian sheep and goat populations.
abstract: Serological studies of small ruminant lentivirus (SRLV) infections have revealed seropositive sheep in several mixed herds in which sheep were kept with seropositive goats. Here, we examined genetic associations in LTR, pol and env surface unit (SU) of SRLV isolates from both mixed and monospecies herds and their growth patterns in goat (GSM) and sheep (FOS) synovial membrane cell cultures. Phylogenetic analyzes of pol and env SU revealed that Norwegian SRLVs from both goats and sheep in mixed herds were distributed in group C, while isolates from unmixed sheep herds clustered in group A with maedi-visna-like representatives of the A1 subtype. . In this study, it has been suggested that the transmission direction of group C virus is from goat to sheep. The replication efficiency in GSM and FOS cultures and the cytopathic phenotype induced by SRLV isolates did not indicate any species-specific traits. No specific nucleotide sequences of the LTR-U3 region or env SU were identified that could be associated with the cytopathic phenotype. This study shows that sheep in Norway harbor SRLVs belonging to phylogenetic groups A and C, providing further evidence that interspecies infection is a regular feature of SRLVs that may represent an important source for viral persistence. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Gjerset, B.;Jonassen, C. M.;Rimstad, E.

title: Characterization of microRNAs encoded by the bovine herpesvirus 1 genome
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus 1 (BoHV-1) is a worldwide ubiquitous and important bovine pathogen. This study reports the identification of 10 microRNA (miRNA) genes, Bhv1-mir-B1-Bhv1-mir-B10, encoded by the BoHV-1 genome that has been processed into 12 detectable mature miRNAs, as determined by ultra-high-throughput sequencing bioinformatics analyses. small RNA libraries and expression studies. We found that four of the miRNA genes were present in the BoHV-1 genome in duplicate, resulting in a total of 14 miRNA coding loci. The unique features of BoHV-1 miRNAs include evidence of bidirectional transcription and the close association of two miRNA genes with origin of replication, including a miRNA encoded in the origin of replication. The miRNA gene Bhv1-mir-B5 is encoded in the opposite DNA strand of the delay-associated transcript, potentially giving rise to antisense transcripts originating from this locus. The association of herpesvirus miRNAs with latency appears to be a common feature in alphaherpesviruses. Analyzes of the BoHV-5 genome for putative miRNA gene orthologs identified a high degree of evolutionary conservation for nine of the BoHV-1 miRNA genes. The possible roles of BoHV-1 miRNAs in the regulation of known BoHV-1 transcription units and the genetics of BoHV-1 genotypes are also discussed. Â© 2010 The State of Queensland operates through the Department for Employment, Economic Development and Innovation.
authors: Glazov, E. A.;Horwood, P. F.;Assavalapsakul, W.;Kongsuwan, K.;Mitchell, R. W.;Mitter, N.;Mahony, T. J.

title: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza H5N8 clan in a German Zoo 2.3.4.4 Epidemiological and Molecular Analysis of the Outbreak: Effective Disease Control with Minimal Drugs
abstract: Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A virus (HPAIV) subtype H5N8, agent 2.3.4.4 were first reported from South Korea in January 2014. These viruses spread rapidly to Europe and North America in the fall of 2014, causing five outbreaks in poultry businesses in Germany by February 2015. Birds kept in a zoo in northeastern Germany were also affected. Only a few individual white storks (Ciconia ciconia) showed clinical symptoms and eventually died during infection, but subsequent in-depth diagnostic investigations showed that other birds kept in the same composition of white storks were acutely positive or passed. Asymptomatic infection with HPAIV H5N8. The authority granted an exception to the culling of all 500 remaining zoo birds. Restraint measures included grouping zoo birds into eight epidemiological units, in which 60 birds from each unit repeatedly tested negative for H5N8. Epidemiological and phylogenetic studies revealed that the most likely source of entry was direct or indirect contact with infected wild birds, as white storks had access to a small pond frequented by wild mallards and other aquatic wild birds for 10 days in December 2014. Median network analysis showed that zoo bird viruses segregated into a distinct 2.3.4.4 sequence with closest links to H5N8 isolates obtained from mute swans (Cygnus olor) in Sweden in April 2015. Avifaunistic collections after HPAIV attacks.
authors: Globig, A.;Starick, E.;Homeier, T.;Pohlmann, A.;Grund, C.;Wolf, P.;Zimmermann, A.;Wolf, C.;Heim, D.;SchlÃ¶ÃŸer, H.;Zander, S.;Beer, M.;Conraths, F. J.;Harder, T. C.

title: Subtyping of swine flu viruses using a high-throughput real-time PCR platform.
abstract: Influenza A viruses (IAVs) are important human and animal pathogens with a high impact on human and animal health. In Denmark, a passive surveillance program for IAV in pigs has been implemented since 2011, where screening tests and subsequent subtyping are performed by reverse transcription quantitative real-time PCR (RT-qPCR). A disadvantage of the current subtyping system is that several assays are required to cover a wide variety of circulating subtypes, making the system expensive and time consuming. Therefore, the aim of this study was to develop a high-throughput method that could improve surveillance of swine flu viruses (swIAVs) and reduce virus subtyping costs. Twelve qPCR assays specific to various swIAV-related hemagglutinin and neuraminidase gene lines and six assays specific to IAV's internal genes have been developed and optimized for the high-throughput qPCR platform BioMark (Fluidigm). qPCR assays were validated and optimized to run under the same reaction conditions using 48.48 dynamic array (48.48DA). Sensitivity and specificity were evaluated by testing field samples with virus isolates and known subtypes. The results revealed a similar performance of swIAV 48.48DA to traditional real-time analysis, and also the specificity of swIAV 48.48DA was very high and there were no cross-reactions between tests. This high-throughput system provides a cost-effective alternative for subtyping swIAVs.
authors: Goecke, N. B.;Krog, J. S.;Hjulsager, C. K.;Skovgaard, K.;Harder, T. C.;Breum, S. Ã˜;Larsen, L. E.

title: Potential for co-infection of mosquito-specific flavivirus, nhumirim virus to prevent transmission of west nile virus in mosquitoes
abstract: Nhumirim virus (NHUV) is an insect-specific virus that is phylogenetically linked with dual host mosquito-borne flaviviruses. Previous in vitro co-infection experiments have shown that prior or concomitant infection of Aedes albopictus C6/36 mosquito cells with NHUV results in a 10,000-fold reduction in viral production of West Nile virus (WNV). This interference between WNV and NHUV was observed here in an additional Ae. albopictus mosquito cell line, C7-10. A mutant of WNV 2K peptide (V9M) capable of superinfecting with a predetermined WNV infection showed comparable interference from NHUV as the parent WNV strain in C6/36 and C7-10 cells. Culex quinquefasciatus and Culex pipiens mosquitoes were inoculated intrathoracically with NHUV and WNV or, as a control only, with WNV, allowed to incubate viruses exogenously for up to nine and 14 days, respectively, and transmissibility and replication of WNV were determined. Cx rate. WNV-transmitting quinquefasciatus mosquitoes were significantly lower for the WNV/NHUV group at seven and nine days post-vaccination (dpi) than for the WNV control, while no differences in Cx were observed. pipiens vaccine group. At nine dpi, a 40% reduction in infectivity was observed in mosquitoes from the dual vaccination group compared to the WNV-only control. These data demonstrate the potential for infection of some Culex species. Vectors with NHUV can act as a barrier for efficient transmissibility of flaviviruses associated with human disease.
authors: Goenaga, S.;Kenney, J. L.;Duggal, N. K.;Delorey, M.;Ebel, G. D.;Zhang, B.;Levis, S. C.;Enria, D. A.;Brault, A. C.

title: Interaction between MDV and HVT influences viral miRNA expression
abstract: It is well known that herpes viruses encode a large number of microRNAs (miRNAs) and that these virally encoded small RNAs play multiple roles in infection. This study was conducted to determine how co-infection of a pathogenic MDV serotype 1 (MDV1) strain (MD5) and a vaccine strain (turkey herpes virus [HVT]) alters viral miRNA expression in vivo. We first used small RNA deep sequencing to identify MDV1-encoded miRNAs expressed in tumorigenic spleens of MDV1-infected birds. The expression patterns of these miRNAs were then further evaluated at an early time point (7 days after infection [dpi]) and a late time point (42 dpi) in birds with and without HVT vaccination using real-time PCR (RT-PCR). In addition, the effect of MDV1 co-infection on HVT-encoded miRNAs was determined using RT-PCR. A diverse miRNA population was expressed at 42 dpi in MDV-induced tumorigenic spleens, and 18 of the 26 known mature miRNAs were represented. Of these, both mdv1-miR-M4-5p and mdv1-miR-M2-3p were the most highly expressed miRNAs. RT-PCR analysis also revealed that nine MDV miRNAs were differentially expressed between 7 dpi and 42 dpi infected spleen. At 7 dpi, three miRNAs were differentially expressed between the spleens of HVT and MD5 co-infected birds compared to MD5-infected birds alone, while at 42 dpi nine miRNAs were differentially expressed. At 7 dpi, expression of seven HVT-encoded miRNAs was affected in the spleens of co-infected birds compared to birds receiving HVT vaccine alone. At 42 dpi, the six HVT-encoded miRNAs were differentially expressed between the two groups. Target prediction analysis demonstrates that these differentially expressed viral miRNAs are involved in the regulation of various cellular processes, including cell proliferation and adaptive immune response. Â© American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Goher, M.;Hicks, J. A.;Liu, H. C.

title: Application of phylogeny reconstruction and character evolution analysis to infer directional microbial transmission patterns
abstract: used phylogenetic analyzes to reconstruct directional interspecies transmission patterns during a pseudorabies virus outbreak in Illinois, USA, in 1989. It was isolated from five species: cattle, sheep, goat, pig, and raccoon (Procyon lotor). I generated DNA sequences for 16 isolates of pseudorabies virus in the glycoprotein C gene from which I generated phylogenetic trees. I then used these trees in conjunction with parsimony-based analyzes of character evolution to infer the frequency and direction of interspecies transmission events. Comparison of inferred frequencies and transmission directions based on 10,000 random trees with null expectations showed a significant excess of transmission events from pigs to pigs and a corresponding lack of transmission events from non-swine species. These results are in line with the known biology and natural history of pseudorabies virus and suggest that retrospective phylogeny reconstitution and character evolution analyzes can be used to investigate the transmission ecology of pathogens. Â© 2003 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Goldberg, T. L.

title: Bluetongue virus serotype 24 (BTV-24) in Israel: phylogenetic characterization and clinical manifestation of the disease
abstract: Bluetongue (BT), a viral disease of ruminants transmitted by arthropods, affects sheep more severely than other domestic animals. Bluetongue virus serotype 24 (BTV-24) is one of the 26 known Bluetongue virus (BTV) serotypes. In this paper, we present phylogenetic analysis data of 9 viral genes (Seg1, Seg2, Seg3, Seg4, Seg5, Seg6, Seg8, Seg9 and Seg10) from 8 Israeli BTV-24 isolates and correlate the genotype of BTV-24. isolates according to phenotypes according to clinical signs. A high level of genetic identity (>99.6%) between Seg2, Seg4 and Seg5 in all 8 BTV-24 isolates indicated that these segments shared the same viral ancestor. Phylogenetic analysis of Seg1, Seg3, Seg5, Seg8, Seg9 and Seg10 revealed that Israeli BTV-24 strains contained 4 variants. Five of the viruses revealed high identity between all 9 segments and represented variant 1. A second variant (BTV24/3027/6/10), isolated in 2010, in 3 gene segments (VP-1, VP-3 and NS-3 genes). A third variant (BTV24/3027/1/10) showed significant variation from variant 1 in 6 segments (VP-1, VP-3, VP-6 and NS-1, NS-2 and NS-3 genes), while the fourth one variant (BTV24/2214/1/10) showed significant variation from variant 1 in 4 segments (VP-1, NS-1, NS-2 and NS-3 genes). These marked differences in sequence identity suggest that high levels of genetic reclassification have occurred among BTV strains circulating together in Israel.
authors: Golender, N.;Panshin, A.;Brenner, J.;Rotenberg, D.;Oura, C.;Khinich, E.;Bumbarov, V.

title: Biological and molecular aspects of bovine herpesvirus 4 (BHV-4)
abstract: This review summarizes the latest information on bovine cytomegalovirus BHV-4. The virus is not associated with clearly defined clinical entities in cattle. It can be easily isolated in tissue culture and has a wide host range. BHV-4 strains are quite similar in restriction enzyme analysis of their DNA, but the size of their pr DNA is different. The genome represents an Î³-herpes virus. Due to its uniqueness, BHV-4 is discussed as a suitable vector.
authors: Goltz, M.;Ludwig, H.

title: Review viral enteritis in calves review article
abstract: complex community of bacteria, viruses, fungi, protists and other microorganisms inhabit the gastrointestinal tract of calves and play important roles in gut health and disease. The viral component of the microbiome (virome) is receiving increasing attention for its role in neonatal calf diarrhea (NCD). Rotavirus and coronavirus have long been associated with noncommunicable diseases, and commercial vaccines have been produced against these agents. Recently, other viruses that may play a role in diarrhea have been discovered in calf stool samples, mostly by sequence-based methods. These viruses include torovirus, norovirus, nebovirus, astrovirus, kobuvirus, and enterovirus. Most studies included epidemiological studies attempting to show association with diarrhea for each virus, alone or in combination with potential pathogens. However, the contribution of these viruses to calf diarrhea has been difficult to determine, and many uncertainties remain regarding their role as primary pathogens, coinfecting agents, or commensals.
authors: Gomez, D. E.;Weese, J. S.

title: Genetic diversity of bovine viral diarrhea virus in cattle from Mexico
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) infects cattle populations worldwide, causing significant economic losses despite its impact on animal health. Previous studies have reported the prevalence of BVDV species and subgenotypes in cattle from the United States and Canada. We investigated the genetic diversity of BVDV strains detected in bovine serum samples from 6 different Mexican regions. Sixty-two BVDV isolates from Mexico were genetically typed based on comparison of sequences from 5â€² untranslated regions (5â€²-UTR) of the viral genome. Phylogenetic reconstruction showed that 60 of the samples belonged to the BVDV-1 genotype and 2 to the BVDV-2 genotype. Comparison of partial sequences of 5â€²-UTR clustered 49 samples in BVDV-1c, 8 samples in BVDV-1a, 3 samples in BVDV-1b and 2 samples with subgenotypes BVDV-2a. Our work, combined with previously published information on BVDV field type diversity in the United States and Canada, benefits the development of effective detection assays, vaccines and control programs for North America.
authors: GÃ³mez-Romero, N.;Basurto-AlcÃ¡ntara, F. J.;Verdugo-RodrÃ­guez, A.;Bauermann, F. V.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: Detection of border disease virus in Mexican cattle
abstract: The genus Pestivirus within the Flaviviridae consists of four recognized species: bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 (BVDV-1), bovine viral diarrhea virus 2 (BVDV-2), borderline disease virus (BDV), and classic swine fever virus (CSFV). . BDV primarily infects sheep and goats, but has also been reported in cattle and wild animals. Sheep and goat infections cause economic losses due to the birth of permanently infected animals with low production and low life expectancy. In this study, we report the detection of BDV in bovine serum collected as part of a pestivirus surveillance program from six regions of Mexico, where 67.1% of BVDV seroprevalence was previously calculated. Phylogenetic analyzes based on comparison of the 5-UTR region identified Mexican strains as BDV-1. Border disease (BD) is listed as an exotic disease in Mexico and the origin of BDV in these cattle is unclear. This is the first BDV identification in Mexican cattle.
authors: GÃ³mez-Romero, N.;Basurto-AlcÃ¡ntara, F. J.;Verdugo-RodrÃ­guez, A.;Lagunes-Quintanilla, R.;Bauermann, F. V.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: A pathological study of the perisinusoidal unit of the liver in acute African swine fever.
abstract: African swine fever is an acute hemorrhagic disease of pigs that can serve as a model for the study of the pathogenesis of other viral hemorrhagic fevers. This article describes an ultrastructural study of the array of lesions produced in the perisinusoidal functional unit of the liver of pigs vaccinated with Malawi '83 African swine fever virus, which is classified as hemadsorbing and highly lethal. Virus replication was observed in Kupffer cells and monocytes three days after inoculation, in hepatocytes and fat-storing cells five and seven days after inoculation, and in sinusoidal endothelial cells seven days after inoculation. Other observations included intravascular coagulation, which peaked five days post-vaccination, and fibroblast and myofibroblast transformation of fat-storing cells seven days post-vaccination. These results suggest that activated cells of the mononuclear phagocyte system may play an important role in this lesion sequence, and the possible role of cytokines that may be released by these cells is discussed.
authors: GÃ³mez-Villamandos, J. C.;HervÃ¡s, J.;MÃ©ndez, A.;Carrasco, L.;Villeda, C. J.;Sierra, M. A.;Wilkonson, P. J.

title: Molecular investigation of bovine viral diarrhea virus infection in yaks (Bos gruniens) from Qinghai, China.
abstract: Background: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is a pestivirus that infects both domestic animals and wildlife species worldwide. In China, cattle are often infected with BVDV of different genotypes, but there is very limited information about BVDV infection and genetic diversity of the virus in the vicinity of China. The objectives of this study were to detect viral infection in the vicinity of Qinghai, China, and the 5" untranslated region (5"UTR) and N-terminal protease (N <sup>pro</ s>) region. Results: Between 2010 and 2012, 407 blood samples were collected from clinical or non-clinical closes in six counties of Qinghai Province. Ninety-eight samples (24%) were found to be positive by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) targeting a conserved region of BVDV-1 and BVDV-2. The nucleotide sequences of the 5â€²UTR and the complete N<sup>pro</sup> region were determined for 16 positive samples. Phylogenetic reconstructions showed that all 16 samples belonged to subgenotypes BVDV-1b, BVDV-1d and BVDV-1q. Conclusions: This study provides, for the first time, molecular evidence for BVDV infection involving multiple subgenotypes of BVDV-1 in the vicinity of Qinghai. This could have occurred under three possible scenarios: interspecies transmission, natural infection, and use of BVDV-contaminated vaccines. The results have important implications for yak production and management in China, particularly showing the need to stop unscientific vaccine practices and increase biosecurity. Â© 2014 Gong et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Gong, X.;Liu, L.;Zheng, F.;Chen, Q.;Li, Z.;Cao, X.;Yin, H.;Zhou, J.;Cai, X.

title: Insect retro elements provide new insights into origin of hepatitis B viruses
abstract: The origin of the hepadnaviruses (Hepadnaviridae), a group of reverse-transcriptional DNA viruses that infect vertebrates, remains a mystery. All known retrotransposons are only distantly related to hepadnaviruses. Here we report the discovery of two novel lineages of retroelements that we have identified as the hepadnavirus-like retroelement (HEART1 and HEART2) within insect genomes through screening of 1,095 eukaryotic genomes. Both phylogenetic and similarity analyzes show that HEART retroelements represent the closest non-viral relatives of hepadnaviruses so far. The discovery of HEART retroelements narrows the evolutionary gap between hepadnaviruses and retrotransposons and can thus provide unique insights into the origin and evolution of hepadnaviruses.
authors: Gong, Z.;Han, G. Z.

title: Global spread of hemorrhagic fever viruses: predicting pandemics
abstract: As successive outbreaks swept the world, the scientific community quickly learned from them about the emergence and transmission of infectious diseases. Outbreaks often occur when healthcare systems are unprepared. During an unexpected epidemic, health officials come under damage control, fear is mobilized, and the desire to understand the threat is greatest. As humanity recovers, policymakers seek scientific expertise to improve their "preparation" to face future events. The global spread of the disease is exemplified by the spread of yellow fever from Africa to the Americas, the spread of dengue fever through the transcontinental migration of mosquitoes, the relentless outbreaks of flu virus, and most recently the unexpected emergence of the Ebola virus. spread by motorcycles and long-distance carriers. Other pathogens notable for their epidemic spread include arenavirus hemorrhagic fevers and hantavirus diseases, which are carried by rodents over great geographic distances, and arthropod-borne viruses (West Nile, chikungunya, and Zika) activated by ecology and vector adaptations. Have we learned from past epidemics? Are we ready for the worst? The ultimate goal is to develop a resilient global health infrastructure. In addition to acquiring treatments, vaccines and other preventative drugs, biosurveillance is critical to preventing disease from occurring and preventing its spread. So far, only the western hemisphere has a large and built-in monitoring system; however, diseases continue to emerge sporadically, particularly in Southeast Asia and South America, highlighting the flaws of our surveillance. Outbreaks destabilize fragile governments, devastate the most vulnerable populations, and threaten global society. Pandemic risk calculations use new technologies such as computational maintenance of geographic and historical datasets, Geographic Information Systems (GIS), Next Generation sequencing, and Metagenomics to monitor molecular changes during the emergence of pathogens, and mathematical models to assess risk. Forecasts help identify emerging hotspots, populations at risk, and pathogens under genetic evolution. Preparedness anticipates the international partnerships needed to manage risks, the needs of the population, infrastructure capacities, sources of emergency financing, and finally, before a disaster occurs. Currently, the world is in an intermediate phase of trying to reduce health inequalities despite massive environmental changes due to exponential population growth, political conflicts, migration, global trade, urbanization and global warming. On behalf of humanity, we must focus on building the necessary capacities for health surveillance, preparedness and pandemic response.
authors: Gonzalez, J. P.;Souris, M.;Valdivia-Granda, W.

title: Origin, distribution and potential risk factors associated with influenza A virus in pigs in two production systems in Guatemala
abstract: Background: Guatemala is the country with the largest pork production in Central America; however, evidence of influenza A virus (IAV) in pigs is not clearly defined. Objectives: In this study, we analyzed the presence and spatial distribution of IAV in commercial and backyard pig populations. Methods: Samples from two nationwide surveys conducted in 2010 and 2011 were tested using virological (rRT-PCR and virus isolation) and serological (ELISA and hemagglutination inhibition) assays to detect IAV. Results: Influenza A virus was detected in 15.7% (30.6% of herds) of pigs sampled in 2010 and 11.7% (24.2% of herds) in 2011. Percentage of seropositive pigs 10.6% (16.1% of herds) and 1.4% (3.1% of herds) per year, respectively. Three pandemic H1N1 and one seasonal human-like H3N2 virus were isolated.
