Antibodies against viruses from different genetic clusters were detected. No reassortant strains were detected with swine viruses. Unlike the most recent seasonal human vaccine strains, the H3N2 virus was closely related to human viruses circulating in Central America in 2010. Spatial clusters of rRT-PCR positive swarms were detected annually by screening statistics. Conclusions: Our results show IAV circulation across Guatemala and identify commercial farms, animal health status and age as potential risk factors associated with IAV infection and exposure. Detection of human-borne viruses in pigs suggests a role for humans in the molecular epidemiology of IAV in pigs in Guatemala and attests to gaps in local animal and human surveillance.
authors: Gonzalez-Reiche, A. S.;RamÃ­rez, A. L.;MÃ¼ller, M. L.;Orellana, D.;Sosa, S. M.;Ola, P.;Paniagua, J.;OrtÃ­z, L.;Hernandez, J.;CordÃ³n-Rosales, C.;Perez, D. R.

title: Marseille virus, blood safety and human virome
authors: Goodman, J. L.

title: Similarity of outer capsid protein VP4 of Gottfried strain of porcine rotavirus to that of asymptomatic human rotavirus strains
abstract: Genomic segment 4 of the porcine Gottfried strain (serotype 4) of porcine rotavirus encoding the outer capsid protein VP4 was sequenced and its deduced amino acid sequence analyzed. Amino acid homology to the corresponding protein of asymptomatic or symptomatic human rotaviruses representing serotypes 1 to 4 of porcine rotavirus VP4 ranged from 87.1% to 88.1% for asymptomatic strains and 77.5% to 77.8% for symptomatic strains. Amino acid homology of Gottfried strain to monkey rhesus rotavirus, monkey SA11 virus, bovine Nebraska calf diarrhea virus and porcine OSU strains ranged from 71.5% to 74.3%. Antigenic similarities of VP4 epitopes between Gottfried strain and human rotaviruses were detected by a plaque reduction neutralization assay with hyperimmune antisera produced against Gottfried strain or a Gottfried (10 genes) x human DS-1 rotavirus (VP7 gene) reassortant exhibiting serotype 2. neutralization specificity. In addition, a panel of six anti-VP4 monoclonal antibodies capable of neutralizing human rotaviruses of serotype 1, 3 or 4 was able to neutralize the Gottfried strain. These observations suggest that the VP4 outer capsid protein of Gottfried rotavirus is more closely related to human rotaviruses than to animal rotaviruses.
authors: Gorziglia, M.;Nishikawa, K.;Hoshino, Y.;Taniguchi, K.

title: Molecular phylogenetics of Newcastle disease viruses isolated from vaccinated flocks during epidemics in southern India reveals the circulation of a new subgenotype.
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is an economically important contagious poultry viral disease reported worldwide. ND is endemic in India and episodes of ND outbreaks are not uncommon despite strict vaccinations. We isolated and characterized seven ND viruses from commercial poultry farms inoculated during severe disease outbreaks in Tamil Nadu, southern India, between April 2015 and June 2016. All seven isolates were categorized as virulent according to the mean time to death (48-54 hours). in embryonated chicken eggs. In addition, their sequences bore the virulence signature of multi-basic amino acid residues in the fusion protein cleavage sites (RRQ/RR/KRF). Phylogenetic and evolutionary distance analyzes revealed the circulation of a new subgenotype of the XIII genotype, class II ND viruses proposed here as sub-genotype XIIIe. The genetic difference between circulating virulent strains and vaccine strains could possibly explain the disease outbreak in vaccinated herds. In addition, our study points to the need to implement routine epidemiological surveillance and review the current vaccination program.
authors: Gowthaman, V.;Ganesan, V.;Gopala Krishna Murthy, T. R.;Nair, S.;Yegavinti, N.;Saraswathy, P. V.;Suresh Kumar, G.;Udhayavel, S.;Senthilvel, K.;Subbiah, M.

title: Update on information about the hepatitis E virus
abstract: From its first definition, hepatitis E infection has been considered as a disease with an epidemiological pattern related to the consumption of wastewater and contaminated food, similar to hepatitis A infection. The prevalence of hepatitis E is higher in areas with poor hygiene conditions. The use of molecular techniques has contributed to gaining valuable information on the epidemiology of hepatitis E in developed countries. In these regions, hepatitis E virus infection shows a different pattern and is associated with contact with domestic animals, particularly pigs. The role of hepatitis E as a possible zoonosis in industrialized countries provides a new and interesting approach to this disease. This review summarizes the available information on the biology, structure and transmission of the virus and diagnosis of infection. In addition, this review describes the current status of HE infection in areas with low incidence of acute hepatitis E and the role of animals as potential reservoirs for HEV.
authors: Gracia, M. T. P.

title: Detection and genome characterization of bovine polyomaviruses in beef muscle and minced meat samples from Germany
abstract: Polyomaviruses are small, non-enveloped, circular double-stranded DNA viruses. Some polyomaviruses can induce tumors and cancer under certain conditions. Bovine polyomaviruses (BPyV) 1-3 have so far been little analyzed. It has been hypothesized that consumption of beef containing polyomavirus may contribute to the development of cancer in humans. To assess the distribution of the BPyV genome in meats from Germany, 101 beef muscle samples and 10 minced meat samples were analyzed here. A custom sample preparation method coupled with or without rotating circle amplification (RCA) and BPyV-specific PCRs was developed and implemented. BPyV-1 DNA was detected in 1/101 (1%) samples from beef and 2/10 (20%) minced meat samples. While BPyV-2 DNA was detected in 3/10 (30%) ground beef samples, BPyV-3 was not detected in the samples. RCA application did not increase the detection rate in beef samples. Sequence analysis of PCR products showed the presence of BPyV-1, BPyV-2a and BPyV-2b. The entire genome of a BPyV-1 strain from ground beef showed 97.8% sequence identity to the BPyV-1 reference strain, and the genome of a BPyV-2a strain from ground beef showed 99.9% sequence identity to strain 2aS11. It can be concluded that BPyV genomes can often be detected in minced meat samples, but higher sample numbers should be investigated in the future to confirm this finding. To assess the risk of cancer induction through consumption of BPyVs found in beef products, further studies should focus on the infectivity, tumorigenicity and heat resistance of the viruses contained. (C) 2016 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Grafe, D.;Ehlers, B.;Made, D.;Ellerbroek, L.;Seidler, T.;Johne, R.

title: Advances in antiviral vaccine development
abstract: Antiviral vaccines have been the most successful biomedical intervention to prevent epidemic viral disease. Vaccination for smallpox in humans and rinderpest in cattle was the basis for disease eradication, and recent advances in polio eradication are promising. While early vaccines were developed experimentally by passing them on from live animals or eggs, newer vaccines have been developed due to the advent of new technologies, particularly cell culture and molecular biology. Recent technological advances in gene delivery and expression, nanoparticles, protein production, and adjuvants have created the potential for new vaccine platforms that could provide solutions for vaccines against viral pathogens for which there is currently no intervention. In addition, the technological convergence of human monoclonal antibody isolation, structural biology, and high-throughput sequencing provides new opportunities for atomic-level immunogen design. Selection of human monoclonal antibodies can identify immunodominant antigenic regions associated with neutralization and provide reagents to stabilize and resolve the structure of viral surface proteins. Understanding the structural basis for neutralization can guide the selection of vaccine targets. Deep sequencing of the antibody repertoire and identification of the ontogeny of desired antibody responses may reveal splice recombination and somatic mutation requirements for B cell recognition and affinity maturation. Collectively, this knowledge will provide new strategic approaches for selecting vaccine antigens, formulations and regimens. It also creates the potential for rational vaccine design and creating a catalog of vaccine technology platforms that will be effective against any family or class of viral pathogens and improve our preparedness for emerging viral threats. Published in 2013. This article is a US Government work and is in the US public domain.
authors: Graham, B. S.

title: Genital Zoster Infection: The Big Rogue
abstract: Herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1), herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) are taxonomically closely related viruses that produce clinically distinct diseases but share common features of infection. HSV-1 and HSV-2 both produce cutaneous and mucocutaneous primary infections followed by reactivation disease in the same or a nearby anatomical site. Primary VZV infection, also known as chickenpox, is a childhood disease that usually produces smallpox-like cutaneous lesions that are scattered throughout the body. Reactivation VZV infection, often referred to as herpes zoster, usually occurs later in life, but unlike HSV disease, it typically produces smallpox-like lesions in a different anatomical location throughout the dermatomes. Therefore, the clinical differential diagnosis of reactivation HSV infection and zoster is usually based on the anatomical location and appearance of the lesion(s). The recent availability of molecular tests has resulted in the unexpected diagnosis of zoster infections in male and female patients presenting with genital lesions. The purpose of this article is to provide a brief overview of HSV and VZV infections and to relate a laboratory experience that resulted in the diagnosis of zoster infections using a molecular assay in which almost 10% of the 282 positive VZV specimens were from the genitals.
authors: Granato, P. A.

title: Metagenomic Detection of Viral Pathogens in Spanish Honey Bees: Co-infection with Aphid Fatal Paralysis, Israel Acute Paralysis, and Sinai Lake Viruses
abstract: The situation with honey bees in Europe has deteriorated in recent years with steady declines in populations and/or catastrophic winter losses. This has been largely attributed to the emergence of a variety of known and "unknown" emerging new diseases. Previous studies have shown that colonies can often harbor more than one pathogen, making it difficult to identify etiologic agents by classical methods. Using an unbiased metagenomic approach, which allows the detection of both unexpected and previously unknown infectious agents, three viruses, Aphid Lethal Paralysis Virus (ALPV), Israel Acute Paralysis Virus (IAPV) and Lake Sinai Virus (LSV), has been reported in honey bees. The existence of a subgroup of ALPV with the ability to infect bees has only recently been reported, and this is the first such strain to be described in Europe. Similarly, LSV appears to be a group of as yet unclassified viruses with uncertain impact on colony health and these viruses have not been previously identified outside of the United States. Our study also reveals that these bees carry Turnip Ringspot Virus (TuRSV), a plant virus that serves as potentially important vector organisms. Taken together, these results illustrate new possibilities opened up by high-throughput sequencing and metagenomic analysis to study emerging diseases in domestic and wild animal populations, including honey bees. Â© 2013 Granberg et al.
authors: Granberg, F.;Vicente-Rubiano, M.;Rubio-Guerri, C.;Karlsson, O. E.;Kukielka, D.;BelÃ¡k, S.;SÃ¡nchez-VizcaÃ­no, J. M.

title: Whole genome sequence comparison of vtx2 transforming phages from Enteroaggregative Hemorrhagic Escherichia coli strains
abstract: BACKGROUND: Enteroaggregative Hemorrhagic E. coli (EAHEC) is a novel group of pathogenic E. coli characterized by the presence of a vtx2-phage integrated into the genomic backbone of Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAggEC). So far, four different serotypes of EAHEC have been identified, causing a minor outbreak and six sporadic cases of HUS during the 1992-2012 period, in addition to the major infection outbreak in Germany in 2011. In the present study, we determined the whole genome sequence of the vtx2-phage, designated Phi-191, found in the first described EAHEC O111:H2 isolated in France in 1992, and compared the sequences with those of the vtx-phages available. RESULTS: The whole genome sequence of the Phi-191 phage was identical to that of vtx2-phage P13374 found in the EAHEC O104:H4 strain isolated 20 years later during the German epidemic. Also, the EAHEC O104:H4 strains described so far were almost identical to those of other vtx2-phages. Conversely, the Phi-191 phage looked different from the vtx2-phage carried by EAHEC O111:H21 isolated in Northern Ireland in 2012. typical Verositotoxin-producing strains of E. coli showed the presence of a 900 bp sequence uniquely associated with EAHEC phages and encoding a tail fiber. RESULTS: At least two different vtx2-phages, both characterized by the presence of a specific tail fiber encoding gene, interfered with the emergence of EAHEC. Despite the high variability described for vtx-phages, the finding of an identical vtx2-phage in two EAggEC strains isolated after 20 years is unexpected, suggesting that such vtx2-phages are under strong selective pressure. Observation of different EAHEC infections has been traced back to countries where EAggEC infections are endemic and human sewage treatment is generally ineffective, suggesting that such countries may represent the cradle for the emergence of the EAHEC pathotype. In these regions, human-induced EAggEC can extensively contaminate the environment where they may encounter free vtx-phages emitted by the feces of ruminants.
authors: Grande, L.;Michelacci, V.;Tozzoli, R.;Ranieri, P.;Maugliani, A.;Caprioli, A.;Morabito, S.

title: Genetic characterization of tick-borne flaviviruses: New insights into evolution, pathogenetic markers and taxonomy.
abstract: Here, we analyze the complete coding sequences of all recognized tick-borne flavivirus strains, including previously uncharacterized isolates of Gadgets Gully, Royal Farm and Karshi virus, seabird-associated flaviviruses, Kadam virus and Kyasanur Forest disease virus, and Omsk hemorrhagic fever virus. Significant taxonomic improvements have been proposed, for example the identification of three main groups (mammalian, seabird and Kadam tick-borne flavivirus groups), establishment of a new strain (Karshi virus), and assignment of Tick-borne encephalitis and Louping patient viruses to one species. unique strains (Tick-borne encephalitis virus), including four viral types (i.e. Western Tick-borne encephalitis virus, Eastern Tick-borne encephalitis virus, Turkish sheep Tick-borne encephalitis virus and Louping sick Tick-borne encephalitis virus). The analyzes also reveal a complex relationship between viruses that infect birds and those that infect mammals. Ticks that feed on both categories of vertebrates could form the evolutionary bridge between the three distinct lineages described. Â© 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Grard, G.;Moureau, G.;Charrel, R. N.;Lemasson, J. J.;Gonzalez, J. P.;Gallian, P.;Gritsun, T. S.;Holmes, E. C.;Gould, E. A.;de Lamballerie, X.

title: Taxonomy of caliciviruses
abstract: The International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV) has recently approved several proposals submitted by the existing Caliciviridae working group. These recommendations include division of the family into 4 new genera named Lagovirus, Vesivirus, 'Norwalk-like viruses' (NLVs) and 'Sapporo-like viruses' (SLVs); The last 2 genera were given tentative names until names acceptable to the scientific community were determined. The genus is further divided into the following species: Feline calicivirus and swine virus (Vesivirus genus), rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus and European brown rabbit syndrome virus (Lagovirus genus), Norwalk virus (NLV genus) and Sapporo virus (genus) vesicular exanthema (SLV genus). In addition, ICTV approved the proposal to remove the hepatitis E virus from Caliciviridae to an 'unassigned' classification status.
authors: Green, K. Y.;Ando, T.;Balayan, M. S.;Berke, T.;Clarke, I. N.;Estes, M. K.;Matson, D. O.;Nakata, S.;Neill, J. D.;Studdert, M. J.;Thiel, H. J.

title: Next-generation sequencing analysis of the RFHVMn genome, a macaque homolog of Kaposi's sarcoma (KS)-associated herpes virus, from a KS-like tumor of a pig-tailed macaque.
abstract: The complete sequence of the retroperitoneal fibromatosis-associated herpes virus Macaca nemestrina (RFHVMn), the porcine-tailed macaque homolog of Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpes virus (KSHV), was determined by next-generation sequence analysis of a Kaposi sarcoma (KS)-like macaque tumor. . Co-linearity of the genes with the KSHV genome was observed, and the core herpes virus genes had strong sequence homology to the corresponding KSHV genes. RFHVMn lacked homologues of open reading frame 11 (ORF11) and KSHV ORFs K5 and K6; this appears to have been created by duplication of ORFs K3 and K4 after KSHV and RFHV split. RFHVMn contained positional homologues of all other unique KSHV genes, although some showed limited sequence similarity. RFHVMn contained a set of candidate microRNA genes. Although there was little sequence similarity to KSHV microRNAs, it contained the same seed sequence, kshv-miR-K12-10a, as a candidate positional homologue, indicating functional overlap. RNA transcript splicing was highly conserved between RFHVMn and KSHV, and strong sequence conservation was noted at specific promoters and putative origins of replication, predicting substantial functional similarities. Sequence comparisons showed that RFHVMn and KSHV evolved in long-term synchronization with the evolution of their hosts, and both viruses are phylogenetically grouped in the RV1 lineage of Old World primate rhadinoviruses. RFHVMn is the closest KSHV homolog to be fully sequenced and the first sequenced RV1 rhadinovirus homologue of KSHV from a non-human Old World primate. The strong genetic and sequence similarity between RFHVMn and KSHV, combined with similarities in biology and pathology, suggest that RFHVMn infection in macaques offers an important and relevant model for the study of KSHV in humans. Â© 2013, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Gregory Bruce, A.;Ryan, J. T.;Thomas, M. J.;Peng, X.;Grundhoff, A.;Tsai, C. C.;Rose, T. M.

title: A metagenomic analysis of pandemic influenza a (2009 H1N1) infection in patients from North America.
abstract: Although metagenomics has previously been used for pathogen discovery, its cost and complexity have prevented it from being used as a practical front-line diagnosis for unknown infectious diseases. Here, we demonstrate the utility of two metagenomic-based strategies, a pan-viral microarray (Virochip) and deep sequencing, for the identification and characterization of the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza A virus. Using nasopharyngeal swabs collected in the early stages of the pandemic in Mexico, Canada and the United States (n = 17), Virochip was able to detect a new virus most closely related to swine flu viruses without prior knowledge. Deep sequencing yielded reads corresponding to 2009 H1N1 influenza in each sample (percentage of aligned sequences corresponding to 2009 H1N1 ranging from 0.0011 to 10.9%), covering up to 97% of the influenza genome in one sample. Detection of 2009 H1N1 by deep sequencing was possible even at titers close to the detection limits for specific RT-PCR, and the percentage of sequence reads was linearly correlated with virus titer. Deep sequencing also provided information on upper respiratory microbiota and host gene expression in response to 2009 H1N1 infection. An unbiased analysis combining sequence data from all 17 outbreak samples revealed that 90% of the 2009 H1N1 genome could be assembled de novo without the use of any reference sequences, including joining several full-length genomic segments. These results suggest that a modern metagenomic detection strategy could potentially replace the multiple traditional diagnostic tests required to search for an outbreak of a new pathogen and provide a blueprint for comprehensive diagnosis of unexplained acute diseases or epidemics in clinical and public health settings. Â© 2010 Greninger et al.
authors: Greninger, A. L.;Chen, E. C.;Sittler, T.;Scheinerman, A.;Roubinian, N.;Yu, G.;Kim, E.;Pillai, D. R.;Guyard, C.;Mazzulli, T.;Isa, P.;Arias, C. F.;Hackett Jr, J.;Schochetman, G.;Miller, S.;Tang, P.;Chiu, C. Y.

title: Complete genome of klassevirus - a new picornavirus in pediatric stool
abstract: Background: Diarrhea kills 2 million children worldwide each year, but in approximately 30-50% of cases no etiologic agent is found. Picornaviral genera such as enterovirus, cobuvirus, cosavirus, parechovirus, hepatovirus, teschovirus and cardiovirus have all been found in human and animal diarrhea. Modern technologies, particularly deep sequencing, allow rapid, high-throughput screening of clinical samples such as feces for novel infectious agents associated with human disease. Results: A pool of 141 pediatric gastroenteritis samples previously found to be negative for known diarrheal viruses was subjected to pyro-sequencing. From a total of 937,935 sequence reads, a collection of 849 reads distantly related to Aichi virus was collected and found to constitute 75% of a novel picornavirus genome. The whole genome was then cloned and found to share 52.3% nucleotide double identity and 38.9% amino acid identity to Aichi virus. The low level of sequence identity suggests a new genus of picornavirus, which we refer to as classevirus. Blind screening of 751 stool samples from both symptomatic and asymptomatic individuals revealed a second positive case of classevirus infection, which was later found to be from the index case's 11-month-old twin. Conclusion: We report the discovery of human classevirus 1, a member of a novel picornavirus genus, in the stool of two infants from Northern California. Further characterization and epidemiological studies will be required to determine whether classeviruses are important causes of human infection.
authors: Greninger, A. L.;Runckel, C.;Chiu, C. Y.;Haggerty, T.;Parsonnet, J.;Ganem, D.;DeRisi, J. L.

title: Isolation of a virus strain from Argas persicus ticks
abstract: A previously unidentified virus was isolated from Argas persicus ticks collected on sentry chickens in western Slovakia. The strain was lethal to lactating mice only after intracerebral vaccination. No symptoms were induced in adult mice. The virus strain was insensitive to sodium deoxycholate and resistant to ether treatment. An antigen prepared from the virus did not agglutinate goose or human erythrocytes. The single strain obtained in 1976 appeared unrelated to many known arboviruses when tested with the complement fixation reaction.
authors: Gresikova, M.;Nosek, J.;Sekeyova, M.

title: Molecular characterization of H3N2 influenza A viruses isolated from Ontario pigs in 2011 and 2012.
abstract: Background: Data on the molecular diversity of commonly circulating type A influenza viruses in Ontario pigs are scarce. Still, this information is essential for animal and public health surveillance, vaccine updates, and understanding the evolution and wide-spread spread of the virus. Methods: The study population consisted of 21 herds of pigs with clinical problems due to respiratory disease. Nasal swabs from individual pigs were collected and tested by virus isolation and rtRT-PCR in MDCK cells. All eight segments of 10 H3N2 viruses were sequenced and molecularly characterized using high-throughput sequencing. Results: The prevalence within herd ranges from 2% to 100%. Structurally, Ontario H3N2 viruses can be classified into three different groups. Group 1 was most similar to the original trH3N2 virus from 2005. Group 2 was most similar to Ontario turkey H3N2 isolates, with PB1 and NS genes from trH3N2 virus and M, PB2, PA and NP genes from A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. All Group 3 internal genes were genetically related to A(H1N1)pdm09. Analysis of the HA1 antigenic regions showed that Group 1 had 8 aa changes within the 4 antigenic regions, A(1), B(3), C(2) and E(2). Group 2 viruses have 8 aa changes in 3 antigenic sites A(3), B(3) and C(2), while Group 3 viruses have 3 antigenic sites, B(1), D(1) and E(2), cluster IV. Compared to H3N2 virus [A/swine/Ontario/33853/2005/(H3N2)]. Results: Characterization of Ontario H3N2 viruses clearly demonstrates reclassification of gene segments from cluster IV between North American pig trH3N2 to A(H1N1)pdm09 virus.
authors: GrgiÄ‡, H.;Costa, M.;Friendship, R. M.;Carman, S.;Nagy, Ã‰;Wideman, G.;Weese, S.;Poljak, Z.

title: Prevalence of Hepatitis E Virus Infection at Slaughter in Pigs, United Kingdom, 2013
abstract: Since 2010, reports of infection with hepatitis E virus (HEV) have increased in England and Wales. Despite growing evidence of the zoonotic potential of swine HEV, limited data are available on its prevalence in pigs in the UK. We investigated antibody prevalence, active infection and virus variation in serum and cecal content samples from 629 pigs at slaughter. The prevalence of antibodies to HEV was 92.8% (584/629) and HEV RNA was found in 15% (93/629) of cecal content, 3% (22/629) of plasma samples and 2% of both ( 14/14) detected. 629). However, although HEV is common in UK pigs and enters the food chain of viremic pigs, most (22/23) viral sequences clustered separately from the predominant type seen in humans. Therefore, pigs raised in the UK are unlikely to be the main source of human HEV infections in the UK. More research is needed to determine the source of these infections.
authors: Grierson, S.;Heaney, J.;Cheney, T.;Morgan, D.;Wyllie, S.;Powell, L.;Smith, D.;Ijaz, S.;Steinbach, F.;Choudhury, B.;Tedder, R. S.

title: Molecular and in vitro characterization of hepatitis E virus from UK pigs
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection is common in the global pig population. Although clinically uncertain in pigs, hepatitis E in humans is caused by HEV infection and transmission through the food chain has been identified. Following a 2013 study investigating the prevalence of HEV infection in slaughter-age pig samples in the UK, the one showing the highest viral load was selected for further characterization. High-throughput sequencing was used to obtain the complete coding sequence from the five samples. An in-frame insertion was observed within the HEV hypervariable region in two samples. To investigate whether this mutation causes high levels of viremia and excretion, virus isolation and culture was performed in sampled pigs. Based on viral growth kinetics, there was no evidence that these additions affect replication efficiency in vitro, suggesting that as yet undetermined host factors may influence the course of infection and, consequently, the risk of foodborne transmission.
authors: Grierson, S. S.;McGowan, S.;Cook, C.;Steinbach, F.;Choudhury, B.

title: Genomic epidemiology of methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus throughout colonization and skin and soft tissue infection.
abstract: OBJECTIVES: Staphylococcus aureus skin and soft tissue infection (Sa-SSTI) places a significant burden on healthcare systems. There is a high incidence of Sa-SSTI in New Zealand, where most morbidity is caused by the polyclonal methicillin-susceptible (MSSA) bacterial population. However, MSSA also colonizes the cornified epithelium of approximately 20% of the population asymptomatically, and their distinction between commensalism and pathogenicity is not fully understood. We aimed to see if MSSA differed genetically between colonization and SSTI; and whether strains isolated from domestic animals differ from human strains given the close interactions between humans and pets. METHODS: We compared the genomes of concurrent colonization and clinical MSSA isolates from humans and domestic animals in New Zealand. RESULTS: Core and accessory genome comparisons revealed a homogeneous bacterial population between colonization, disease, humans and domestic animals. MSSA colonization rate in dogs was relatively low (5.4%). CONCLUSIONS: In New Zealand, most Sa-SSTI morbidity results from a random sample of the MSSA population colonizing, consistent with the opportunistic infection pattern rather than the paradigm that separates strains by pathogenicity. Therefore, investigating the factors that determine colonization and immune escape may be more beneficial than comparative virulence studies. Contact with pet pets may pose a low zoonotic risk.
authors: Grinberg, A.;Biggs, P. J.;Zhang, J.;Ritchie, S.;Oneroa, Z.;O'Neill, C.;Karkaba, A.;Velathanthiri, N. S.;Coombs, G. W.

title: Identification of vanilla-infecting potyviruses by direct sequencing of a short RT-PCR amplicon
abstract: simple one-tube one-step RT-PCR assay with degenerate primers followed by direct sequencing of a 327 bp coat protein gene fragment was used to identify vanilla-infecting potyviruses. With this technique, precise species assignment was achieved for 34 potyvirus-infected vanilla samples collected in the Indian Ocean and Pacific regions between 1997 and 2005. Virus identification was based on BLAST homology and nucleotide identities of 162 to 327 nt fragments with known potyvirus sequences. Species assignment was confirmed by neighbor splicing of 149 nts common to 32 vanilla sequences and 51 known potyviruses. Subject to further definition, these data revealed four additional Potyvirus strains that can infect vanilla: Bean yellow mosaic virus, Cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus, Ornithogalum mosaic virus, and Wisteria vein mosaic virus. The procedure was fast, cost-effective, easy to use and showed good taxonomic discriminant value. It also made it possible to identify potyviruses in neighboring weeds and should therefore aid in the understanding of potyvirus outbreaks occurring in a variety of epidemiological conditions.
authors: Grisoni, M.;Moles, M.;Farreyrol, K.;Rassaby, L.;Davis, R.;Pearson, M.

title: Ootheca bennigseni Weise, O-mutabilis (Schonherr) and O-meridiana sp n. (Chrysomelidae : Galerucinae), bean and cowpea pests in the Afrotropic Region
abstract: Ootheca mutabilis (Schonherr) and O. bennigseni Weise are considered to be two prominent pests on beans (Phaseolus vulgaris (L.), Fabaceae) in Central and East Africa. These insects destroy root tissue and seedlings, skeletonize the leaves of plants and feed on inflorescences, causing severe crop losses. Both species feed on cowpea (Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp. (Fabaceae). As new combinations to: O. bifrons (Laboissiere), O. bourquii (Laboissiere), O. caerulea (Jacoby), O. fulvipes (Jacoby), O. chapuisi (Jacoby), O. minuta (Laboissi re), O. nigrilabris (Laboissiere), O. podagrica (Laboissiere), O. proteus (Chapuis), O. semicaerulea (Jacoby), O. variabilis (Laboissiere), and O. vittata (Laboissiere). proposed as a replacement name Ootheca meridiana sp.n. is described as a new pest species of bea ns from South Africa and cowpea.
authors: Grobbelaar, E.

title: Varicella-Zoster virus-specific gp140: A highly immunogenic and disulfide-linked structural glycoprotein
abstract: 140,000-dalton disulfide-linked glycoprotein (gp140) expressed by varicella-zoster virus (VZV) was identified in infected cultured cells and was precipitated by two murine monoclonal antibodies (VZ-151 and VZ-158). When analyzed under reduction conditions by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, gp140 was predominantly partitioned into a 66,000 low molecular weight product (gp66). Because metrisamide was observed in the polypeptide profile of gradient-purified enveloped virions, this protein was classified as a viral structural component. By immunofluorescence analyzes with a monoclonal antibody probe, it has been documented that gp140 expression is highly conserved both in cultured cells inoculated with homologous (VZV-Oka) and heterologous (VZV-32) strains and in infected human tissues from chickenpox and zoster patients. The highly immunogenicity of the glycoprotein was confirmed by the presence of high titer of anti-gp140 antibody in the sera of both hyperimmunized laboratory animals and naturally infected humans. Transiently, the humoral response to gp140 following primary VZV infection preceded that to other viral glycoproteins. These studies therefore describe an immunogenic, disulfide-linked viral structural glycoprotein that must lie between the five other fucosylated species – gp118, gp98, gp88, gp62 and gp45 – specific to VZV previously described.
authors: Grose, C.;Edwards, D. P.;Weigle, K. A.

title: Epidemic delayed abortion in pigs - research case
abstract: This article briefly describes PRRS (Pig Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome), which emerged in Germany and other European countries in the winter of 1990. Data were collected from the literature and from their own experience. In the clinical picture of this new disease, which causes significant economic losses, the shortening of the gestational period or the prolongation of the pregnancy period with delayed abortion before the 1. 110th day; 2. increase in stillborn piglets; 3. A larger scale of pre-weaning mortality with a higher frequency of secondary infections. Pathological findings in piglets are observed subcutaneous edema, fluid accumulation in body cavities, and sometimes interstitial pneumonia. Sows from affected farms examined prior to birth have mononuclear placenta. Currently, an unclassified virus isolated by Dutch researchers is suggested to be the causative agent and is called the Lelystad virus.
authors: grosse Beilage, E.;Stockhofe-Zurwieden, N.;SchÃ¶ttker-Wegner, H. H.

title: Next-Gen Sequencing Approach Reveals Viral Transcripts Found in Poxvirus Virions
abstract: Transcripts are known to be incorporated into particles of DNA viruses belonging to the Herpesviridae and Mimiviridae families, but the presence of transcripts in other DNA viruses such as poxviruses has not yet been analyzed. Therefore, we first created a next-generation sequencing (NGS)-based protocol that enables unbiased identification of transcripts in virus particles. Next, we applied our protocol to analyze RNA in Cowpox virus, an emerging zoonotic member of the Poxviridae family. Our results revealed that 19 viral transcripts were included, while host identifications were limited to ribosomal and mitochondrial RNA. Most viral transcripts had an unknown and immunomodulatory function, suggesting that transcript participation may be beneficial for poxvirus immune evasion. Notably, the most abundant transcript originates from the D5L/I1R gene, which encodes a viral inhibitor of the host cytoplasmic DNA sensing mechanism.
authors: Grossegesse, M.;Doellinger, J.;Haldemann, B.;Schaade, L.;Nitsche, A.

title: Combined Proteomics/Genomics Approach Reveals Proteomic Alterations of Mature Virions as a Novel Poxvirus Adaptation Mechanism
abstract: Like poxviruses, DNA viruses have a highly stable genome, suggesting that the adaptation of virus particles to specific cell types is not limited to genomic changes. Cowpox viruses are zoonotic pox viruses with an extraordinarily wide host range that demonstrate their adaptive potential in vivo. To elucidate the adaptation mechanisms of poxviruses, we isolated cowpox virus particles from a rat and passaged them five times in a human and a rat cell line. We then analyzed the proteome and genome of the non-passaged virions and each passage. While the overall viral genome sequence was stable during migration, proteomics revealed many changes in virion composition. Interestingly, an increased viral fitness was observed in human cells in the presence of increased amounts of immunomodulatory proteins. Protein amounts were likely regulated at the transcriptional level, as the only small variant with increased frequency during crossover was located in a viral RNA polymerase subunit, and also because most small variants were found in transcription-associated genes. This study is the first comparative proteome analysis of virus particles before and after cell culture propagation, revealing proteomic alterations as a novel poxvirus adaptation mechanism.
authors: Grossegesse, M.;Doellinger, J.;Tyshaieva, A.;Schaade, L.;Nitsche, A.

title: Bacteriophage strain typing by rapid single molecule analysis
abstract: Rapid characterization of unknown biological samples is the focus of many current studies. Here, we report a method for screening biological samples by optical mapping of their DNA. We use a novel, one-step chemo-enzymatic reaction to covalently attach fluorophores to DNA at the four-base recognition sites of a DNA methyltransferase. Due to the diffraction limit of the light, the intense scattering of the tags results in a continuous fluorescent signal throughout the DNA. Amplitude modulations (AM) of fluorescence intensity along stretched DNA molecules exhibit a unique molecular fingerprint that can be used for identification. We show that this labeling scheme is highly informative and allows for accurate genotyping. We demonstrate the method by labeling the genomes of lambda and T7 bacteriophages, which results in a consistent, unique AM profile for each genome. These profiles are also successfully used for identification of phages from a background phage library. Our method may provide an easy way to screen and typify a variety of organisms and has potential applications in metagenomic studies of diverse ecosystems.
authors: Grunwald, A.;Dahan, M.;Giesbertz, A.;Nilsson, A.;Nyberg, L. K.;Weinhold, E.;Ambjornsson, T.;Westerlund, F.;Ebenstein, Y.

title: Epidemiological investigation of pseudorabies in Shandong Province from 2013 to 2016
abstract: In late 2011, a variant pseudorabies virus (vPRV) emerged in swine herds vaccinated with Bartha-K61, resulting in high morbidity and mortality of piglets in China. Since 2013, autopsy lesions, histological studies, virus isolation, phylogenetic analysis, and selection pressure analysis of the gE gene of vPRV have been recorded for 395 clinical cases, and 5,033 pig serum samples have been detected by the PRV gE-coated enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. The main clinical symptoms were miscarriage in pregnant sows, fatal neurological signs in piglets, and respiratory disease in growing pigs. Histopathological examination revealed necrotic splenitis, hepatitis and lymphadenitis, hemorrhagic nephritis and non-suppurative encephalitis. Typical eosinophilic inclusion bodies were found in the nuclei of liver cells. Using PCR, 110 samples from 395 clinical cases were tested to be positive for the gE gene. Fifteen vPRV strains were isolated and confirmed by sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of the gE gene. The strains shared 97.1%-99.9% nucleotide (nt) and 96.6%-99.5% amino acid (aa) homology with the PRV reference strains. Selection pressure analysis showed that a site in the codons of glycoprotein E was under positive selection. Of the 5,033 serum samples, 2,909 were positive by ELISA for a positive rate of 57.8%. These results showed that vPRV is still prevalent in Shandong Province and there is severe PRV infectious pressure. The preparation of new vaccines against PRV is extremely urgent.
authors: Gu, J.;Hu, D.;Peng, T.;Wang, Y.;Ma, Z.;Liu, Z.;Meng, F.;Shang, Y.;Liu, S.;Xiao, Y.

title: Genome sequencing and genetic analysis of a natural reassortant H5N1 subtype avian influenza virus with H9N2 internal genes
abstract: Summary: An H5N1 subtype avian influenza virus, A/duck/Shandong/009/2008 (Dk/SD/009/08), was isolated from apparently healthy domestic ducks in some live bird market in eastern China during our epidemiological surveillance. To investigate the genetic composition, Dk/SD/009/08 was subjected to genome sequencing. The amino acid motif of the cleavage site was "PLRERRRK-R/GL", which is consistent with the characterization of HPAIV. Classified in Dk/SD/ 009/08, Clade 2.3.4, according to the newest unified nomenclature of H5N1. BLAST results show that four gene segments (HA, NA, NP, and NS) have the highest nucleotide identities with H5N1 subtype AIVs, while the remaining four (PB2, PB1, PA, and M) show the closest association with H9N2 subtype. showed. Therefore, Dk/SD/009/08 may be a natural reassortant virus. Phylogenetic analysis also showed that G1-like H9N2 subtype AIVs, mainly common in Southern Chinese quail, could confer internal genes for Dk/SD/009/08.
authors: Gu, M.;Liu, W. B.;Cao, J. P.;Cao, Y. Z.;Zhang, X. R.;Peng, D. X.;Liu, X. F.

title: Chapter 2.3.4 Novel variants of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses, China
abstract: Between 2009 and 2012, we identified 7 highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses isolated from poultry in China, of which 2.3.4. Antigenic drift in subtype H5N1 variants may reduce the efficacy of vaccines designed to control these viruses in poultry.
authors: Gu, M.;Zhao, G.;Zhao, K.;Zhong, L.;Huang, J.;Wan, H.;Wang, X.;Liu, W.;Liu, H.;Peng, D.;Liu, X.

title: Identification and Phylogenetic Analysis of Orf Virus Isolated from Outbreak in Boer Goat in Shanxi Province
abstract: To identify and analyze Orf virus in Shanxi Province, China, a strain of Orf virus was successfully isolated by passage from lamb testis (LT) from shell materials of boer goat with clinically painful mouth symptom from a goat farm in Shanxi Province. Orf virus was identified by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) testing, recurrent infection testing, transmission electron microscopy, and PCR. The nucleotide and amino acid sequences of two genes of Orf virus were analyzed. The results showed that under electron microscopy the virus has the presence of typical parapoxvirus virions and many eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions observed by hematoxylin-eosin (H&E) staining. In the ELISA test, the optical density (OD) readings of the sample showed a positive result, and virus-infected rabbits typically appeared infected with Orf virus. All these findings proved to be an Orf virus, for example. Phylogenetic studies of the Orf B2L and Orf F1L genes showed that the virus clustered in different branches and was more closely related to the Orf virus Nantou (DQ904351) and OV-SA00 isolates (AY386264). Moreover, the above results can provide some insight into the genotype of the etiologic agent responsible for the Orf epidemic in Shanxi Province and also provide a comparative view of the B2L and F1L genes of parapoxvirus.
authors: Gu, S. P.;Shi, X. T.;Shi, Z. Y.;Wang, Z. B.;Zheng, M. X.

title: Metagenomic analysis of Sichuan takin fecal sample viromes reveals novel enterovirus and astrovirus
abstract: The Sichuan takin inhabit the bamboo forests of the Eastern Himalayas and is considered China's national treasure, with the highest legal protection and conservation status considered vulnerable according to the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. In this study, fecal samples of 71 Sichuan takin were pooled and deep sequenced. Of the 103,553 viral sequences, 21,961 were assigned to mammalian viruses. The de novo review revealed the genomes of an enterovirus and an astrovirus, and contigs of circoviruses and genogroup I picobirnaviruses. Whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis showed that Sichuan takin enterovirus is a novel serotype/genotype of Enterovirus G strain with evidence of recombination. Sichuan takin astrovirus is a new subtype of bovine astrovirus, possibly belonging to a new genogroup in the Mamastrovirus genus. Further studies will reveal whether these viruses can also be found in Mishmi takin and Shaanxi takin and their pathogenic potential.
authors: Guan, T. P.;Teng, J. L. L.;Yeong, K. Y.;You, Z. Q.;Liu, H.;Wong, S. S. Y.;Lau, S. K. P.;Woo, P. C. Y.

title: Expression of pseudorabies virus-encoded long non-coding RNAs in epithelial cells and neurons
abstract: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) play important roles in regulating eukaryotic genome replication and gene expression in a variety of biological systems. Here, we identified lncRNAs transcribed from PK-15 cells infected with pseudorabies virus (PRV). Based on high-throughput sequencing data, we obtained 87,263,926 and 93,947,628 clean reads from mock-infected and PRV-infected PK-15 cells, respectively. Through a normalized analytical protocol, we identified three novel viral lncRNAs. According to the differential expression analysis between mock-infected and PRV-infected cells, 4151 host lncRNAs were significantly upregulated and 2327 host lncRNAs were significantly downregulated in the last group. Viral lncRNAs and several host lncRNAs were confirmed by northern blotting and real-time PCR. The findings showed that the viral lncRNA LDI could regulate the expression of IE180, a potent transcriptional activator of viral genes. We also characterized the expression of viral lncRNAs in a culture of infected primary chicken dorsal root ganglia (DRG). Collectively, the data obtained indicate that PRV produces lncRNAs in both epithelial cells and chicken DRG neurons.
authors: Guan, X.;Liu, J.;Jiang, H.;Wu, C. X.;Chen, H. C.;Liu, Z. F.

title: Genetic characterization of an H2N2 influenza virus isolated from a muskrat in Western Siberia.
abstract: Thirty-two muskrats (Ondatra zibethicus) were captured for surveillance of avian influenza virus in wild waterfowl and mammals near Lake Chany, Russia, West Siberia. A/miskrat/Russia/63/2014 (H2N2) was isolated from an apparently healthy muskrat using chicken embryos. Based on phylogenetic analysis, the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of this isolate were classified in the Eurasian avian-like influenza virus classification and were closely related to low pathogenic avian influenza viruses (LPAIVs) isolated from wild waterfowl in Italy and Sweden, respectively. Other internal genes were also closely associated with LPAIVs isolated from Eurasian wild waterfowl. The results show that interspecies transmission of LPAIVs from wild waterfowl to semi-aquatic mammals has occurred, facilitating the spread and evolution of LPAIVs in the wetlands of West Siberia.
authors: Gulyaeva, M.;Sharshov, K.;Suzuki, M.;Sobolev, I.;Sakoda, Y.;Alekseev, A.;Sivay, M.;Shestopalova, L.;Shchelkanov, M.;Shestopalov, A.

title: Detection and characterization of novel bocavirus (genus Bocaparvovirus) and gastroenteritis viruses from asymptomatic pigs in Ireland
abstract: BACKGROUND: Farm animals have been the putative source of several human outbreaks in recent years, for example influenza H1N1, rotavirus G8/G9 and MERS-CoV. Monitoring of new viruses in animals is essential to assess the risk to human and animal health and to identify any economic effects, such as growth retardation. There are few data on the detection and characterization of gastroenteritis viruses, particularly novel viruses, in pigs in Ireland. Recently, a number of small novel porcine DNA viruses have emerged globally, for example, torque tenosus virus, porcine bocavirus, and parvoviruses 2 and 4, and little is known about the biology and potential pathogenicity of these viruses. Bocaparvovirus is a genetically distinct group of viruses recently detected in humans and animals. METHODS: This study investigated the presence of gastroenteritis viruses (rotavirus A, porcine circovirus, adenovirus and porcine bocavirus) in archived stool samples from asymptomatic piglets from a commercial farm in Ireland. A total of 104 samples were pooled and screened using conventional molecular techniques (PCR and RT-PCR), followed by a subset of samples (n=44) individually examined. Viral diversity was then investigated using statistical and phylogenetic techniques. RESULTS: The initial scan showed a high prevalence of PBoV in this farm with the formation of three distinct groups in the phylogenetic analysis. Other viruses were also investigated in this study, with the first report of PCV, PAdV and strain I G5 RVA in Ireland. Some samples contained >1 virus and statistical analysis showed a strong correlation for mixed infections of PBoV and PAdV in this farm. CONCLUSION: Investigating the diversity of enteric viruses circulating in Irish pig farms is important to improve current prophylactic tools and facilitate early detection of changes in circulating viruses.
authors: Gunn, L.;Collins, P. J.;Fanning, S.;McKillen, J.;Morgan, J.;Staines, A.;O'Shea, H.

title: H1N1 influenza virus epitopes classified by monoclonal antibodies
abstract: Epitopes play an important role in influenza infection. It may be useful to screen for universal influenza virus vaccines by analyzing epitopes of multiple subtypes of the hemagglutinin (HA) protein. Previously, a total of 40 monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) from influenza virus HA antigens (the development and characterization of 40 mAbs generated using H1N1 influenza virus split vaccines have been published previously) were used to detect mAbs and classify them into different influenza virus subcategories. ELISA method. Following this, common continuous amino acid sequences were identified by multiple sequence alignment analysis with the GenBank database and DNAMAN software for use in the prediction of epitopes of the HA protein. Synthesized peptides of these common sequences were prepared and used to confirm and identify linear epitopes predicted through localization and distribution analyses. These methods identified nine HA linear epitopes distributed among different strains of influenza virus, three from influenza A, four from 2009 H1N1 and seasonal influenza, and two from H1. The current study demonstrated that, considering a combination of antigen-antibody reaction specificity, variation in influenza virus HA protein and linear epitopes could offer a useful approach for designing effective multi-epitope vaccines. Furthermore, the study aimed to elucidate the cause and pathogenic mechanism of influenza caused by the influenza virus HA, and offers a new insight to identify epitopes of other pathogenic microorganisms.
authors: Guo, C. Y.;Zhang, H. X.;Xie, X.;Liu, Y.;Sun, L. J.;Li, H. J.;Yu, P. B.;Hu, H. Y.;Sun, J. Y.;Li, Y.;Feng, Q.;Zhao, X. R.;Liang, D. Y.;Wang, Z.;Hu, J.

title: Highly Pathogenic Influenza A(H5Nx) Viruses with Altered H5 Receptor-Binding Specificity
abstract: The emergence and intercontinental spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5Nx) virus 2.3.4.4 is unprecedented. H5N8 and H5N2 viruses have caused major economic losses to the poultry industry in Europe and North America, and fatal human infections with the H5N6 virus have occurred in Asia. Information is urgently needed on the evolution of the receptor-binding specificity of these viruses, which may affect the host range. We report that the emergence of these viruses is accompanied by a change in receptor binding specificity. In contrast to the ancestral sequence 2.3.4 H5 proteins, the new generation 2.3.4.4 H5 proteins bind to fucosylated sialosides due to the K222Q and S227R substitutions unique to the highly pathogenic influenza virus H5 proteins. The North American sequence 2.3.4.4 virus isolates only retained the K222Q substitution, but still binds fucosylated sialosides. Altered receptor binding specificity of virus clade 2.3.4.4 H5 proteins may have contributed to the emergence and spread of H5Nx viruses.
authors: Guo, H.;de Vries, E.;McBride, R.;Dekkers, J.;Peng, W.;Bouwman, K. M.;Nycholat, C.;Verheije, M. H.;Paulson, J. C.;van Kuppeveld, F. J.;de Haan, C. A.

title: Target discovery for precision medicine using high-throughput genome engineering
abstract: In the past few years, programmable RNA-guided nucleases such as the CRISPR/Cas9 system have ushered in a new era of precision genome editing in various model systems and human cells. Functional screens using large libraries of RNA guides can interrogate a large field of hypotheses to detect specific genes and genetic elements involved in key biological processes and disease-related phenotypes. Here, we review recent high-throughput CRISPR screens (eg, loss-of-function, gain-of-function, and targeting non-coding elements) and highlight their potential to uncover new therapeutic targets, such as those related to cancer resistance to small molecular drugs. and immunotherapies, tumor growth, infectious disease, congenital genetic disorders, and other therapeutic challenges.
authors: Guo, X.;Chitale, P.;Sanjana, N. E.

title: Identification and genomic characterization of a novel CRESS DNA virus from a calf with severe hemorrhagic enteritis in China.
abstract: In this study, a novel circular replication-associated protein (Rep)-encoding single-stranded (CRESS) DNA virus was discovered in a diarrheal sample of a calf with severe hemorrhagic enteritis. The so-called Bo-Circo-like virus CH has a circular genome of 3909 nucleotides (nt). Six putative open reading frames (ORFs) were identified, including Rep, capsid (Cap), and four proteins of unknown function. Both genome size and number and organization of encoded ORFs are most closely related to Bo-Circo-like virus CH, Po-Circo-like virus 21 detected in pig feces. A preliminary study using primers specific for the Rep region showed that 5.3% (4/75) of the diarrheal samples were positive for Bo-Circo-like virus and all 42 healthy samples were negative. In conclusion, our results suggest that the Bo-Circo-like virus CH may represent a novel virus in cattle. More research is needed to determine the relationship between virus infection and diarrhea.
authors: Guo, Z.;He, Q.;Tang, C.;Zhang, B.;Yue, H.

title: Detection and molecular characteristics of neboviruses in dairy cows in China
abstract: In this study, 98 diarrheal and 70 non-diarrheal samples were collected from 13 dairy farms located in 5 provinces in China from April 2017 to May 2018. According to RT-PCR results, approximately 41.8% (41/98) and 5.7% (4/70) of the diarrhea specimens were found to be nebovirus positive in the non-diarrheal specimens, and some diarrheal specimens were found to be bovine rotavirus (73.2%), bovine coronavirus (36.6%). and/or bovine viral diarrhea virus (31.7%). Phylogenetic analysis of 23 nebovirus RdRp fragments showed that these strains were closely related to Nebraska-like (NB-like) strains, but all contained in a unique large branch. Furthermore, phylogenetic analysis of 18 complete VP1 sequences from this study revealed 14 strains of lineage 1 and 4 strains of lineage 3. domain name. The complete genome of a nebovirus strain, Bo/YLA-2/17/CH, which has a recombination event within the P1A domain of its VP1, was successfully sequenced and found to be 7453 nt in length, which may represent a novelty. nebovirus strain based on phylogenetic analysis of the whole genome sequence. In conclusion, this study reveals that neboviruses circulate widely in dairy cows in China and exhibit a unique RdRp evolution. To our knowledge, this is the first reported recombination event located within the P1A domain of nebovirus VP1.
authors: Guo, Z.;He, Q.;Zhang, B.;Yue, H.;Tang, C.

title: Sequence analysis of the Meq oncogene among Indian isolates of Marek's disease herpes virus
abstract: Marek's disease (MD), caused by Marek's disease virus (MDV), is a highly contagious neoplastic disease of chickens that can be prevented by vaccination. However, many cases of vaccine failure have been reported worldwide in recent years, as chickens develop symptoms of MD despite proper vaccination. Significant polymorphisms and point mutations in the Meq gene of MDV have been reported to be associated with virulence and oncogenicity. This study was conducted to isolate and characterize MDV domain isolates based on the Meq gene. Twenty-five specimens from suspected MD cases were collected and processed for virus isolation in duck embryo fibroblast (DEF) primary culture; where 28% (7 out of 25) samples showed the characteristic cytopathic effects of MDV in the form of plaques and syncytia. Additional evidence for the presence of MDV in these samples was confirmed by PCR. To analyze the diversity in all seven isolates of MDV, a polymorphism study was performed by cloning and sequencing the full-length Meq gene (1020 bp). Sequence homology of 23 reference strains and 7 isolates showed 98.10%-99.40% identity in nucleotide and 95.90-98.50% identity in amino acid sequences. Six isolates revealed 5 repeats of 4 proline (PPPP), while one isolate revealed only 4 repeats. In the phylogenetic analysis, these isolates formed a distinct cluster with close association with the Chinese isolates. The study points to a high mutation rate in field isolates of MDV, which may be a possible cause of vaccination failure.
authors: Gupta, M.;Deka, D.;Ramneek

title: Restriction enzyme analysis of bovine herpesvirus-1 DNA from an Indian isolate
abstract: An Indian BHV-1 isolate was analyzed using several restriction endonucleases. The restriction pattern of BHV-1 DNA with HindIII, BamHI and EcoRI was found to be similar to other restriction endonuclease patterns reported for respiratory isolates of BHV-1. Therefore, this isolate can be grouped under BHV-1.1 (respiratory form of BHV-1). Several restriction endonucleases yielded the distinct restriction profile of BHV-1 DNA. The total molecular size of BHV-1 DNA for the studied isolate was also estimated to be between 136 kb and 138 kb.
authors: Gupta, P. K.;Rai, A.

title: Genetic variation in the VP1 gene of the foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype Asia 1
abstract: The full nucleotide sequence of the 1D (VP1-encoding) gene of 61 foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) serotype Asian I virus isolates from different outbreaks in India between 1985 and 1999 was determined, including two currently used vaccine strains. The sequences were compared with each other and with those from other Asian countries. On the basis of phylogenetic analysis viruses can be grouped into four genotypes (genotypes I-IV). All 61 isolates from India belong to a single genotype (genotype-II), which is subdivided into three lineages (B1, B2 and B3) under the same genotype. Viruses of the B1 and B3 lineage were found to be more common before 1996, while viruses of the B2 lineage appeared to be new variants responsible for most of the recent outbreaks. Most isolates of the B1 lineage lack an amino acid in the VP1 protein (position 44), whereas most isolates of the B2 and B3 lineage contain it, indicating the possibility that these lineages evolved independently. The evolution rate of FMDV Asia 1 virus was also estimated and found 2.7 x 10(-2) synonym substitutions per nucleotide per year.
authors: Gurumurthy, C. B.;Sanyal, A.;Venkataramanan, R.;Tosh, C.;George, M.;Hemadri, D.

title: Turkish coronavirus is more closely related to avian infectious bronchitis virus than mammalian coronaviruses: a review
abstract: Turkey coronavirus (TCoV) is the cause of an acute, highly contagious enteric disease of turkeys. In recent years, TCoV has been increasingly recognized as an important pathogen of young turkeys in North America, causing economic losses due to growth disruption and inadequate feed conversion. Although the epidemiology and pathogenesis of TCoV has been extensively studied, TCoV remains one of the least characterized of known coronaviruses. Avian and mammalian coronaviruses are divided into different antigenic/genotypic groups; however, the classification of TCoV is controversial. Previous studies have shown TCoV to be closely related to bovine coronavirus and other group 2 mammalian coronaviruses, but more recent antigenic and genome sequence analyzes contradict these findings and instead provide evidence that TCoV is closely related to avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV). provides. In addition, experimental studies have shown that the host TCoV range once thought to be limited to turkeys also includes chickens. These studies have raised additional questions regarding the classification of TCoV; in particular, whether IBV and TCoV are taxonomically different viruses or whether TCoV is merely a variant of IBV. Because these studies show that TCoV and IBV are so closely related, sequence analyzes of TCoV have given credence to the idea that TCoV is a variant of IBV. However, these studies were limited to only three TCoV strains and relatively small portions of the TCoV genome. TCoV is easily distinguished from IBV based on antigenic and biological differences, suggesting that TCoV should be considered as a separate virus strain. Additional studies will be needed to better define the relationship between TCoV and IBV and to resolve this taxonomic question. Based on our current understanding, it seems prudent to consider TCoV and IBV as distinct virus strains that share a close phylogenetic relationship and together form group 3 of the coronavirus major antigenic groups.
authors: Guy, J. S.

title: Constructs of H5 avian and H9 swine flu virus hemagglutinin: possible origin of influenza subtypes
abstract: Influenza A virus (H1-H15) has 15 subtypes, all of which are found in avian species. It has caused three pandemics in the last century: H1 in 1918 (and 1977), H2 in 1957, and H3 in 1968. An H5 avian virus in 1997 and an H9 virus in 1999 caused respiratory disease outbreaks in Hong Kong. We determined the three-dimensional structures of hemagglutinins (HAs) from H5 avian and H9 porcine viruses closely related to viruses isolated from humans in Hong Kong. We compared them with known structures of H3 HA from the virus causing the 1968 H3 pandemic and the HA-esterase-fusion (HEF) glycoprotein from an influenza C virus. Structure and sequence comparisons suggest that HA subtypes may have arisen from the diversification of properties that affect the metastability of HAs required for membrane fusion activities in viral infection.
authors: Ha, Y.;Stevens, D. J.;Skehel, J. J.;Wiley, D. C.

title: Application of genomics to emerging zoonotic viral diseases Review
abstract: Interspecies transmission of pathogens can lead to the emergence of new infectious diseases in humans as well as in domestic and wild animals. Genomic tools such as high-throughput sequencing, mRNA expression profiling, and microarray-based analysis of single-nucleotide polymorphisms provide unprecedented ways to analyze the diversity of genomes of emerging pathogens and the molecular basis of host response to them. By comparing and contrasting the consequences of an emerging infection with those of closely related pathogens in different but related host species, we can further delineate the various host pathways that determine the outcome of zoonotic transmission and adaptation to newly invaded species. The ultimate challenge is to relate pathogen and host genomic data to the biological consequences of zoonotic transmission and transform the integrated data into novel intervention strategies that will eventually allow for effective control of emerging infectious diseases. [References: 29]
authors: Haagmans, B. L.;Andeweg, A. C.;Osterhaus, A. D.

title: Application of genomics to emerging zoonotic viral diseases
abstract: Interspecies transmission of pathogens can lead to the emergence of new infectious diseases in humans as well as in domestic and wild animals. Genomic tools such as high-throughput sequencing, mRNA expression profiling, and microarray-based analysis of single-nucleotide polymorphisms provide unprecedented ways to analyze the diversity of genomes of emerging pathogens and the molecular basis of host response to them. By comparing and contrasting the consequences of an emerging infection with those of closely related pathogens in different but related host species, we can further delineate the various host pathways that determine the outcome of zoonotic transmission and adaptation to newly invaded species. The ultimate challenge is to relate pathogen and host genomic data to the biological consequences of zoonotic transmission and transform the integrated data into novel intervention strategies that will eventually allow for effective control of emerging infectious diseases. Â© 2009 Haagmans et al.
authors: Haagmans, B. L.;Andeweg, A. C.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.

title: Possible sources and routes of transmission of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus subtype H5N1 infections in poultry and wild birds in Central Europe in 2007 were obtained through likelihood analysis.
abstract: Recurrent outbreaks of H5N1 HPAIV occurred in several Central European countries in 2007. In-depth phylogenetic analyzes including full-length genomic sequences of related viruses were performed to elucidate the possible origins and transmission routes of the outbreaks. Tree reconstructions and host-slide and ancestral field inferences were performed within the framework of maximum likelihood. All viruses belonged to a separate subgroup (named "EMA-3") within section 2.2 and therefore differed from the two HPAIV H5N1 virus strains (called "EMA-1" and "EMA-2") contained in the same virus. geographic area in 2006. Analysis of the concatenated coding regions of all eight genome segments significantly improved the resolution and robustness of the reconstructed phylogenies compared to single gene analyzes. At the same time, methodological limits to the retrospective establishment of transmission networks spanning a relatively small geographic area and for a short period of time emerged when only a few supporting area epidemiological data were available. Uncertainties persisted about the origin of EMA-3 viruses from a region encompassing Southeast Germany and the Czech Republic, and the ways in which they spread to other European countries. AIV monitoring programs for wild birds and poultry in these countries did not reveal the presence of these viruses in either population. Host transitions between domestic poultry and wild bird populations have occurred several times. Analysis of outbreaks in Northeast Germany and nearby northern Poland in December 2007 showed that the geographic or even temporal environment of the outbreaks did not necessarily indicate a common source of invasion. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Haase, M.;Starick, E.;Fereidouni, S.;Strebelow, G.;Grund, C.;Seeland, A.;Scheuner, C.;Cieslik, D.;Smietanka, K.;Minta, Z.;Zorman-Rojs, O.;Mojzis, M.;Goletic, T.;Jestin, V.;Schulenburg, B.;Pybus, O.;Mettenleiter, T.;Beer, M.;Harder, T.

title: In vitro isolation, dissemination and characterization of duck hepatitis virus type III
abstract: In vitro isolation, dissemination and characterization of duck hepatitis virus Type III (DHV-III) are described. Serologically different from classical (Type I) DHV, this virus was grown in liver and kidney cell cultures of duck origin. Replication was limited in chicken and quail kidney and duck embryo fibroblast cultures. It did not grow in various other cell cultures of avian or mammalian origin. The virus was successfully grown in the embryonic eggs of ducks, not chickens. DHV-III passed through a 50 nm membrane filter, was stable at pH 3.0, and resisted treatment with 5% chloroform. Virus growth was not inhibited by treatment with 5-iodo-2-deoxyuridine. Electron-microscope examination revealed crystalline arrays in the cytoplasm; The virus particles had cubic symmetry and were about 30 nm in diameter. According to these features, this virus can be classified as a member of the picornavirus group.
authors: Haider, S. A.;Calnek, B. W.

title: Newly discovered mosquito viruses help control vector-borne viral diseases
abstract: Many mosquito-borne viruses, such as dengue, Zika, West Nile, chikungunya, and Ross River viruses, can infect vertebrates associated with diseases in humans or animals. However, the use of deep sequencing and other open-minded approaches to detect viruses in mosquitoes has revealed many new RNA viruses, most of which do not infect vertebrates. The discovery of these 'insect-specific' viruses (ISVs) redefined the mosquito virus and led to the redrawing of viral taxonomic classification lines1,2. Despite their benign phenotype, ISVs have become a hot research topic with recent studies showing they have important applications for biotechnology.
authors: Hall, R. A.;Jody, H. P.

title: Metagenomic Detection of Viruses in Aerosol Samples from Animal Slaughterhouse Workers
abstract: Published studies have shown that those working in animal slaughterhouses have a higher risk of lung cancer compared to the general population. No specific causative agent has been identified and exposure to various chemicals has been studied and found to be unrelated. Evidence suggests a biological etiology, as the risk is highest for workers exposed to live animals or biological substances containing animal feces, urine or blood. To investigate possible biological exposures in animal slaughterhouses, we used a metagenomic approach to characterize the profile of organisms present in an aerosol sample. An assessment of aerosol exposure for individual workers was made by collecting personal samples representing the respirable fraction of dust/bioaerosol in workplace air in both cattle and sheep slaughterhouses. Two sets of nine personal aerosol samples were pooled for the cattle processing and sheep processing areas, with a total of 332,677,346 sequence reads each and 250,144,492 sequence reads at 85 bp length, respectively. Eukaryotic genome sequences were found at both sampling locations, and cattle, sheep, and human sequences were common. Sequences from WU polyomavirus and human papillomavirus 120 were detected in the metagenomic dataset from the cattle processing area, and these sequences were confirmed to be present in the original personal aerosol samples. This work presents the first metagenomic description of personal aerosol exposure and this methodology can be applied to a variety of settings. Furthermore, the detection of two candidate viruses warrants further research in determining occupational exposures in animal slaughterhouses. Â© 2013 Hall et al.
authors: Hall, R. J.;Leblanc-Maridor, M.;Wang, J.;Ren, X.;Moore, N. E.;Brooks, C. R.;Peacey, M.;Douwes, J.;McLean, D. J.

title: Detection of arboviruses and other microorganisms in experimentally infected mosquitoes using massively parallel sequencing
abstract: The incidence of human disease attributed to arbovirus infection is increasing worldwide with effective control interventions limited to sustainability, insecticide resistance, and lack of effective vaccines. Several promising control strategies are currently under development, such as the release of mosquitoes trans-infected with virus-blocking Wolbachia bacteria. The implementation of any control program depends on effective virus surveillance and a thorough understanding of virus-vector interactions. Massively parallel sequencing has enormous potential to provide comprehensive genomic information that can be used to evaluate many aspects of arbovirus ecology and to evaluate new control strategies. To demonstrate the proof of principle, we analyzed Aedes aegypti or Aedes albopictus experimentally infected with dengue, yellow fever or chikungunya viruses. Random amplification was used to prepare sufficient templates for sequencing in the Personal Genome Machine. Viral sequences were present in all infected mosquitoes. Additionally, in most cases, we were also able to identify mosquito species and mosquito microorganisms, including the bacterial endosymbiont Wolbachia. Importantly, naturally occurring Wolbachia strains can be distinguished from strains trans-infected to mosquitoes. The method allowed us to assemble full-length viral genomes and detect other microorganisms in a single reaction without prior sequencing knowledge. This is a step towards implementing massively parallel sequencing as an arbovirus surveillance tool. It has the potential to provide information on virus transmission dynamics and has applicability to post-release monitoring of Wolbachia in mosquito populations.
authors: Hall-Mendelin, S.;Allcock, R.;Kresoje, N.;van den Hurk, A. F.;Warrilow, D.

title: Metabarcoding analysis of the eukaryotic microbiota in the gut of HIV-infected patients
abstract: Research on the relationship between changes in the gut microbiota and human diseases, including AIDS, is a growing area. However, studies on the eukaryotic component of the gut microbiota in HIV-infected patients have just begun and have not yet been conducted. Furthermore, eukaryotic community profiling is influenced by the use of different methodologies at each step of culture-independent techniques. Here, four DNA extraction protocols were compared to initially test the effectiveness of each method in recovering eukaryotic DNA from stool samples. Our results revealed that the recovery of eukaryotic components from stool samples differed significantly between DNA extraction methods. Next, the composition of the gut eukaryotic microbiota was evaluated through clone sequencing, high-throughput sequencing of nuclear ribosomal internally transcribed spacers 1 (ITS1) and 2 (ITS2) amplicons, and real-time PCRs in HIV-infected patients and healthy volunteers. Our results revealed that not only richness (Chao-1 index) and alpha diversity (Shannon diversity) differed between HIV-infected patients and healthy volunteers depending on the molecular strategy used, but also global eukaryotic community composition with little overlapping taxa. among the techniques. Furthermore, our results based on the cloning libraries and ITS1/ITS2 metabarcoding sequencing showed significant differences in fungal composition between HIV-infected patients and healthy volunteers, but without obvious clusters separating the two groups. According to cloning libraries, Malassezia restriction was significantly more common in stool samples from HIV-infected patients, while operational taxonomic units (OTUs) of Candida albicans and Candida tropicalis were significantly higher in stool samples from HIV-infected patients compared to healthy subjects. in both ITS subregions. Finally, real-time PCR showed the presence of different proportions of Microsporidia, Giardia lamblia, Blastocystis and Hymenolepis diminuta in stool samples from HIV patients compared to healthy individuals. Our study revealed that the use of different sequencing approaches can influence the results of perceived eukaryotic diversity of the human gut. We also provide a more comprehensive look at the eukaryotic community in the gut of HIV-infected patients through the complementarity of the different molecular techniques used. Combining these diverse methodologies could provide a gold standard for a more complete characterization of the eukaryotic microbiome in future studies.
authors: Hamad, I.;Abou Abdallah, R.;Ravaux, I.;Mokhtari, S.;Tissot-Dupont, H.;Michelle, C.;Stein, A.;Lagier, J. C.;Raoult, D.;Bittar, F.

title: Using Bayesian network modeling to resolve farm management risk factors for bovine viral diarrhea virus infection
abstract: Understanding the risk factors for bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) transmission is important for planning national disease control programs. However, traditional statistical approaches may miss important aspects of BVD epidemiology due to the highly correlated nature of many farm-level risk factors. In this cross-sectional study, we used data collected from 304 cattle herds in New Zealand during the 2015/2016 period to compare the results of Bayesian network (BN) analysis and multivariate logistic regression. Blood samples from 15 heifers from each farm were pooled and analyzed by an antibody ELISA test to classify BVD virus exposure. Farmers were surveyed about general management practices, their knowledge of BVD and risk factors for disease transmission, including on and off-farm movements, on-farm contacts, and whether they implemented BVD control measures for service bulls. Multiple assignment was used to remove missing values from the dataset before statistical analysis. The results showed that 57/116 (49.1%) fattening holdings and 95/188 (50.5%) dairy holdings were most likely to be actively infected with the BVD virus. Around 60% of the farms had heifers/cows moving to the premises and 13.8% of the farmers reported contact with cattle from other farms. The results of the multivariate logistic regression showed that farms that had heifers/cows transported to facilities for all or most of the last five years had a higher risk of being BVD seropositive than farms without these movements (OR 2.21, 95% CI 1.29). â€“4.24). Farms where cattle had occasional or occasional contact with cattle from other farms were at higher risk than farms without any inter-farm animal contact (OR 2.63, 95% CI 1.33–5.41), although this association was not frequency dependent. Only close animal contacts between farms were directly associated with BVD status in the BN model, but this approach further resolved other complex relationships between associated management factors and provided additional important insights into BVD epidemiology. Compared to other countries with intensive production systems, contact over the fence appeared to play a more important role in New Zealand pastoral-based production systems and should be considered when developing strategies for a national BVD control program.
authors: Han, J. H.;Holter, J.;Moffat, J.;Weston, J. F.;Heuer, C.;Gates, M. C.

title: Genetic recombination between two genotypes of Genogroup III bovine noroviruses (BoNVs) and capsid sequence diversity between BoNVs and Nebraska-like bovine enteric caliciviruses
abstract: To determine the genogroups and genotypes of circulating bovine enteric caliciviruses (BECVs) in calves, we identified the complete capsid gene sequences of 21 BECVs. Nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences were phylogenetically compared with those of known human and animal enteric caliciviruses. Based on these analyses, 15 BECV belonged to Norovirus genogroup III and genotype 2 (GIII/2) and were genetically different from human Norovirus GI and GII. Six BECVs had capsid gene sequences similar to those of the unclassified Nebraska (NB)-like BECV. 15 bovine noroviruses (BoNVs) were more closely related to Bo/NLV/Newbury-2/76/UK (GIII/2) and other known genotype 2 BoNVs than genotype 1 Bo/NLV/Jena/80/DE . BoNV Bo/CV521-OH/02/US shows high nucleotide and amino acid identities (84% and 94%, respectively) with the Bo/NLV/Newbury-2/76/UK capsid gene, while the nucleotide and amino acid sequences are the percentage of the RNA polymerase gene. was more closely related to those of Bo/NLV/Jena/80/DE (77% and 87% identity, respectively) than Bo/NLV/Newbury-2/76/UK (69% vs. 69%). identities), suggesting that Bo/CV521-OH/02/US is a genotype 1-2 recombinant. Gene conversion analysis by the recombinant identification program and SimPlot also predicted that Bo/CV521-OH/02/US is a recombinant. Six NB-like BECVs shared 88% to 92% nucleotide and 94% to 99.5% amino acid identity with NB BECV in the capsid gene. The results of this study demonstrate the genetic diversity in the capsid genes of circulating BECVs in Ohio calf calves, provide new data for coinfections with different BECV genotypes or genogroups, and identify the first natural BoNV genotype 1-2 recombinant similar to human previously reported. norovirus recombinants.
authors: Han, M. G.;Smiley, J. R.;Thomas, C.;Saif, L. J.
