title: [Metagenomic-based detection of swine viruses]
abstract: There are extreme types of viruses in the environment and animals, some of which are unknown. However, many unknown viruses are barely detected through conventional virus isolation and PCR assay. Developing a technology platform to detect unknown viruses. We have established technology based on viral metagenomics in combination with new molecular diagnostics. The technology consists of host nucleic acid extraction, random PCR amplification, large-scale sequencing, and bioinformatics. The technology was applied to detect cells infected with classical swine fever virus (CSFV) and a tissue sample of a pig infected with porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2). We amplified 13.7% of the CSFV genome and 47.2% of the PCV2 genome sequences, respectively. We also amplified 16.4% sequences of the monkey parainfluenza virus type 5 genome from an unknown virus cell culture using the developed method. In addition, using the method developed in conjunction with high-throughput sequencing, we detected 1.1% virus sequences from 7, including CSFV, PCV2, torque tenosus virus (TTSuV), porcine bocavirus (PBoV), and human adenovirus type 6 (Ad6). clinical swine samples of unknown causative agents. The developed metagenomics-based method showed good sensitivity for the detection of both DNA and RNA viruses from various porcine samples and has potential for universal detection of known and unknown viruses. It can facilitate the diagnosis of emerging viral diseases.
authors: Han, W.;Luo, Y.;Zhao, B.;Sun, Y.;Li, S.;Qiu, H.

title: Mycoplasma ovipneumoniae – primary cause of epizootics of severe pneumonia in the Norwegian Muskox (Ovibos moschatus) population
abstract: The Norwegian musk ox (Ovibos moschatus) population inhabits the high mountain plateau of Dovre and originates from animals brought from Greenland. In the late summers of 2006 and 2012, severe pneumonia outbreaks occurred, with mortality rates of 25-30%. During the 2012 epidemic, high-quality specimens were obtained from culled sick animals for microbiological and pathological studies. High-throughput sequencing (pyrosequencing) of pneumonic lung tissue resulted in high concentrations of Mycoplasma ovipneumoniae and Pasteurella multocida subsp. multocida was found in four animals, while no viral sequence could be identified. Mycoplasma ovipneumoniae and P. multocida multocida were also isolated by culture. Using real-time PCR on lung swabs, M. ovipneumoniae was detected in all 19 pneumonic lungs examined. Gross pathological examination revealed severe consolidations primarily in the cranial portions of the lungs and also identified a case of otitis media. Histologically, the lung lesions were characterized as acute to subacute mixed exudative and moderately proliferative bronchoalveolar pneumonia. Immunohistochemical (IHC) examination revealed high levels of M. ovipneumoniae antigens in lung lesions and intense staining, especially in neutrophils. Similar IHC finding was observed in archived blocks of lung tissue from animals studied during the 2006 outbreak. Specific to M. ovipneumoniae, biobanked musk ox serums from stray musk oxen killed and culled sick musk oxen, as well as from wild reindeer (Rangifer tarandus tarandus) in Dovre, and musk oxen in Greenland. ELISA was applied. During the epidemic in 2012, serology and mycoplasma culture were also performed on sheep in the pasture in the musk ox region. Our findings demonstrated separate entries of M. ovipneumoniae infection from infected grazing sheep in 2006 and 2012. Salt licks shared by the two species were a possible route of infection.
authors: Handeland, K.;Tengs, T.;Kokotovic, B.;Vikoren, T.;Ayling, R. D.;Bergsjo, B.;Sigurardottir, O. G.;Bretten, T.

title: Mycoplasma ovipneumoniae - primary cause of epizootics of severe pneumonia in the Norwegian musk cattle (Ovibos moschatus) population
abstract: The Norwegian musk ox (Ovibos moschatus) population inhabits the high mountain plateau of Dovre and originates from animals brought from Greenland. In the late summers of 2006 and 2012, severe pneumonia outbreaks occurred, with mortality rates of 25-30%. During the 2012 epidemic, high-quality specimens were obtained from culled sick animals for microbiological and pathological studies. ELISA was applied. During the epidemic in 2012, serology and mycoplasma culture were also performed on sheep in the pasture in the musk ox region. authors: Handeland, K.;Tengs, T.;Kokotovic, B.;Vikoren, T.;Ayling, R. D.;Bergsjo, B.;SigurÃ°ardÃ³ttir Ã“, G.;Bretten, T.

title: Pathogenic simian immunodeficiency virus infection is associated with expansion of the enteric virome
authors: Handley, S. A.;Thackray, L. B.;Zhao, G.;Presti, R.;Miller, A. D.

title: Swine epidemic diarrhea in Europe: Detailed analyzes of disease dynamics and molecular epidemiology
abstract: Pig epidemic diarrhea (PED) is an acute and highly contagious intestinal disease caused by the no-name virus (PEDV), which belongs to the Alphacoronavirus genus in the Coronaviridae virus family. PEDV has also been detected in Europe, following disastrous outbreaks in Asia and the United States. To better understand the general condition, molecular epidemiology and factors that may influence the most variable disease impact; Forty samples of pig feces from different PED outbreaks in Germany and other European countries were collected and sequenced using next-generation sequencing. A total of 38 new PEDV full encoding sequences were generated. Compared on a global scale, all sequences examined from Central and South-Eastern Europe formed a highly homogeneous PEDV S INDEL cluster, suggesting recent re-entry. However, detailed analyzes revealed two new clusters and putative ancestral strains. Based on available background data, correlations between clusters and location, farm type, or clinical presentation could not be established. In addition, the effect of secondary infections was investigated using metagenomic datasets. While few coinfections were observed, no correlation with disease course was found. However, in addition to the PEDV genomes, ten complete viral coding sequences were reconstructed from nine different datasets, each representing new virus strains. In detail, three strains of passivirus A, two astroviruses, a porcine sapelovirus, a cobuvirus, a porcine torovirus, a posavirus and an enterobacter phage were almost completely sequenced.
authors: Hanke, D.;Pohlmann, A.;Sauter-Louis, C.;HÃ¶per, D.;Stadler, J.;Ritzmann, M.;Steinrigl, A.;Schwarz, B. A.;Akimkin, V.;Fux, R.;Blome, S.;Beer, M.

title: High picornavirus diversity in rats from different continents revealed by deep sequencing
abstract: Outbreaks of zoonotic diseases in humans and livestock are not uncommon, and an important component in controlling such emerging viral diseases is rapid and reliable diagnosis. Such methods are generally PCR-based and therefore require the availability of sequence data from the pathogen. Rattus norvegicus (R. norvegicus) is a known reservoir for important zoonotic pathogens. Transmission may be by direct contact with the animal, for example by exposure to fecal matter, or indirectly by arthropod vectors. Here, we investigated the viral content in rat fecal matter (n=29) collected from two continents by analyzing 2.2 billion next-generation sequencing reads derived from both DNA and RNA. Among other virus families, we found that sequences from members of Picornaviridae were abundant in the microbiome of all samples. Here we describe the diversity of picornavirus-like contigs, including full-length genomes closely related to Boone cardiovirus and Theiler encephalomyelitis virus. From this study, we conclude that picornaviruses in R. norvegicus are more diverse than previously recognized. The R. norvegicus viroma should be investigated further to evaluate its full potential for zoonotic virus transmission.
authors: Hansen, T. A.;Mollerup, S.;Nguyen, N. P.;White, N. E.;Coghlan, M.;Alquezar-Planas, D. E.;Joshi, T.;Jensen, R. H.;Fridholm, H.;KjartansdÃ³ttir, K. R.;Mourier, T.;Warnow, T.;Belsham, G. J.;Bunce, M.;Willerslev, E.;Nielsen, L. P.;Vinner, L.;Hansen, A. J.

title: Human sapoviruses: genetic diversity, recombination and classification
abstract: The Caliciviridae family includes four genera Sapovirus, Norovirus, Lagovirus and Vesivirus, including Sapporo virus (SaV), Norwalk virus (NoV), Rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus (RHDV), and Feline calicivirus (FCV), respectively. SaV is an agent that causes gastroenteritis in children and adults. SaV can be divided into five genogroups (GI-GV), among which GI, GII, GIV and GV are known to infect humans, while SaV GIII infects swine species. Detection methods include ELISA, RT-PCR, and real-time RT-PCR. Because few SaV studies have been conducted, it is difficult to draw correlations or conclusions between incidence, detection, and overall prevalence rates. However, most studies agree that SaV infection is more common in young children than adults, and that infection in children almost always occurs by age 5 years. In addition, children in day care centers and institutions are at greatest risk for SAV-related infection and transmission. Recently, a number of important findings regarding human SaV have been discovered. SaV strains were detected in water samples including untreated wastewater samples, treated wastewater samples and river samples. SaV strains have also been detected in shellfish samples intended for human consumption, and recombinant SaV strains have been detected in several different countries. The purpose of this review was to highlight the available information about human SaV, which appears to be an increasingly important virus that causes gastroenteritis in humans. Copyright © 2007 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
authors: Hansman, G. S.;Oka, T.;Katayama, K.;Takeda, N.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of a novel parvovirus distantly related to human bufavirus in domestic pigs.
abstract: In this study, a novel parvovirus (strain pig/Zsana3/2013/HUN, KT965075) was detected in domestic pigs and genetically characterized by viral metagenomic and PCR methods. The novel parvovirus was distantly related to human bufaviruses and was detected in 21 (90.5%) and five (33.3%) of 15 stool samples collected from five animals with and without posterior paraplegia of unknown etiology. Affected farms and a control farm in Hungary, respectively. Pig/Zsana3/2013/HUN is very common in domestic pigs and potentially represents a new parvovirus species in the subfamily Parvovirinae.
authors: Hargitai, R.;Pankovics, P.;KertÃ©sz, A. M.;BÃ­rÃ³, H.;Boros, Ã;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Close phylogenetic relationship between egg laying syndrome virus, bovine adenovirus serotype 7 and ovine adenovirus strain 287
abstract: cloned egg laying syndrome (EDS) virus genomic DNA fragment containing the protease gene was identified, and the full nucleotide sequence of the protease and the partial nucleotide sequence of the hexon genes were determined. Phylogenetic analysis of the protease gene revealed that the EDS virus is more closely related genetically to bovine adenovirus type 7 (BAV-7) and ovine adenovirus isolate 287 (OAV287) than to other members of the Mastadenovirus or EDS genus. The virus belongs to another member of the Aviadenovirus genus. The three viruses share other similarities in that they are characterized by having a high content of AT in their genomes and having more compact genomes than other adenoviruses. The protease gene from all three viruses contained active site residues (H55-D72-C122 triad) and C104 (which provides a disulfide bond to the pVIc cofactor). However, P137, which is thought to be trafficked in all other members of the Mastadenovirus genus, was deficient in the protease of the EDS virus, BAV-7 and OAV287. These results suggest that EDS virus should be classified in a separate taxon together with BAV-7 and OAV287.
authors: Harrach, B.;Meehan, B. M.;BenkÃ¶, M.;Adair, B. M.;Todd, D.

title: The Strange, Expanding World of Animal Hepaciviruses
abstract: Hepaciviruses and pegiviruses form two closely related sister genera of the family Flaviviridae. In the last five years, the known phylogenetic diversity of the hepacivirus genus has certainly exploded. What was once an isolated infection in humans (and possibly other primates) has now expanded to include horses, rodents, bats, colobus monkeys, cows, and more recently cat sharks, shedding new light on the genetic diversity and host range of hepaciviruses. Interestingly, despite the identification of these many animal and primate hepaciviruses, equine hepaciviruses remain the closest genetic relatives of human hepaciviruses, providing an interesting clue as to the zoonotic origin of hepatitis C virus. This review summarizes the importance of these studies and discusses current thinking about the origin and evolution of animal hepaciviruses and their potential use as surrogate models for hepatitis C virus study.
authors: Hartlage, A. S.;Cullen, J. M.;Kapoor, A.

title: Comparative analysis of selected genes from Diachasmimorpha longicaudata entomopoxvirus and other poxviruses
abstract: Diachasmimorpha longicaudata entomopoxvirus (DlEPV) is the first symbiotic EPV identified from a parasitic wasp. DlEPV is introduced into the tefritid fruit fly larva host along with the wasp egg during spawning. We sequenced a shotgun genomic library of dlEPV DNA and analyzed and compared the predicted protein sequences of eight ORFs with that of selected pox viruses and other organisms. BlastP studies showed that five of these were homologous to poxvirus putative proteins such as metalloprotease, a putative membrane protein, late transcription factor-3, virion surface protein, and poly(A) polymerase (PAP) regulatory small subunit. Three of these are similar to those of other organisms, such as gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT) of Arabidopsis thaliana, eukaryotic initiation factor 4A (eIF4A) of Caenorhabditis briggsae, and lambda phage integrase (Î»-Int) of Enterococcus faecium. Transcription motifs for conserved early (TGA, A/T, XXXXA) or late (TAAAAT, TAAT or TAAAT) gene expression in poxviruses were identified with these ORFs. Phylogenetic analysis of multiple alignments and aggregation of five ORFs and 20 poxvirus homologous sequences shows that DlEPV likely split from the ancestral node between poultry pox virus and B, lepidopteran, and orthopteran EPVs, and Amsacta moorei and Melanoplus sanguinipes belonged to these species. He claimed he was leaving. EPV belongs respectively. The dlEPV putative GGT, eIF4A and Î»-Int contained many conserved domains typifying these proteins. These homologs may be involved either in viral pathogenicity or enhancement of parasitism via compensation and gamma-glutamyl cycling in the parasitized fly, or through integration of a portion of the viral genome into the wasp and/or parasitized fly. Â© 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Hashimoto, Y.;Lawrence, P. O.

title: Genetic diversity of chicken anemia virus following cell culture passage in MSB-1 cells
abstract: Compared to CAV isolates that have undergone 60 passages in MSB-1 cells (SMSC-1/P60, 3-1/P60), chicken anemia virus (CAV) isolates received 33-66 nucleotide substitutions in the coding region and were passaged only 5 times in 13-MSB-1 cells. 16 amino acid changes (SMSC-1 and 3-1) compared to 16 (Chowdhury et al., Arch. Virol. 148, 2437-2448, 2003). In this study, we found that a low CAV (BL-5) and a high CAV transition (BL-5/P90) differed by only 15 nucleotide substitutions, resulting in 11 amino acid changes. VP1-based phylogenetic analysis also revealed that both isolates were close to each other but not to other CAV isolates from Malaysia, namely SMSC-1 and 3-1.
authors: Hasmah, M. S.;Omar, A. R.;Wan, K. F.;Hair-Bejo, M.;Aini, I.

title: Newcastle disease outbreaks in Sudan from 2003 to 2006 were caused by viruses of the 5d genotype.
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is a serious neurological and respiratory disease in poultry that affects all bird species but does not cause symptoms in wild waterfowl that are traditionally their natural hosts. In the late 1990s, a new genotype, ie. Pathogenic to all bird species, including waterfowl, 5d originated in China and has since spread from East Asia to parts of Europe, the Middle East and Africa. We performed a phylogenetic analysis of the fusion protein gene of isolates from ND outbreaks in Sudan and found that all contemporary strains isolated between 2003 and 2006 were genotype 5d containing the virulent fusion protein cleavage site (F0) motif 112RRQKRF117. Entry through a Middle East trading partner is likely to be a source of infection, as the phylogenetic analysis excludes the possibility of entry from western and southern Africa. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Hassan, W.;Khair, S. A. M.;Mochotlhoane, B.;Abolnik, C.

title: Transmission patterns of human enterovirus 71 to and from European countries, 2003 to 2013
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV-71) is implicated in epidemics of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) and has been reported to occur in east and southeast Asia with serious neurological complications. In other geographic areas, transmission of this virus is poorly understood. We used large array datasets (viral protein 1 belongs to the gene encoding VP1) and a Bayesian phylogenetic approach to compare the molecular epidemiology and geographic spread patterns of EV-71 subgenogroups B4, B5, C1, C2 and C4 in Europe. other parts of the world. The European countries considered for the study were Member States of the European Union (EU) and Iceland, Norway and Switzerland. Viruses of subgenogroups B4, B5 and C4 circulate mainly in eastern and southeastern Asia. Sporadic entries of these subgenogroups are observed in Europe, but C1 and C2 viruses predominate. The phylogenies showed evidence of multiple spreading events involving C1 and C2 viruses in Europe since the mid-1990s. Two sporadic waves of C2 infections also occurred in 2010 and 2013. The 2007 Dutch epidemic caused by C2 and the emergence of B5 and C4 infections in the EU between 2004 and 2013 occurred when circulation of C1 viruses was low. A chain of transmission involving a C4 virus was traced from Japan to the EU and later to Canada between 2001 and 2006. Recent events in which the spread of viruses from, to, and within Europe have occurred appear to be relevant to the long-term survival of EV. -71 highlights the need for enhanced surveillance of this virus.
authors: Hassel, C.;Mirand, A.;Lukashev, A.;Terletskaia Ladwig, E.;Farkas, A.;Schuffenecker, I.;Diedrich, S.;Huemer, H. P.;Archimbaud, C.;Peigue-Lafeuille, H.;Henquell, C.;Bailly, J.

title: Borna's disease
abstract: Borna disease virus, a newly classified non-segmented negative-stranded RNA virus with international distribution, infects a wide variety of warm-blooded animals from birds to primates. Infection causes movement and behavioral disorders reminiscent of some neuropsychiatric syndromes. The virus is not clearly linked to any human disease; however, an association between viral infection and selected neuropsychiatric disorders has been suggested. We review recent advances in Borna disease virus research, focusing on evidence of infection in humans.
authors: Hatalski, C. G.;Lewis, A. J.;Lipkin, W. I.

title: Detection of Campylobacter jejuni in rectal swab samples from Rousettus amplexicaudatus in the Philippines
abstract: Bats are the second diversity species of mammals and are widely found throughout the world. They are thought to be reservoirs and vectors of zoonotic pathogens. However, there are few reports of evidence of pathogenic bacteria retained in bats. Precise knowledge of pathogenic bacteria in the bat microbiota is important for zoonotic control. Therefore, metagenomic analysis targeting the V3-V4 region of the 16S rRNA of the rectal microbiota in Rousettus amplexicaudatus was performed using high-throughput sequencing. The results revealed that 103 genera of bacteria were detected, including Camplyobacter. Campylobacter was the second dominant genus, and Campylobacter coli and Campylobacter jejuni were identified in the microbiome of R. amplexicaudatus. Campylobacteriosis is one of the serious bacterial diarrheal diseases in humans, and C. jejuni is the most frequently accused species as the causative agent of campylobacteriosis. Therefore, we investigated the prevalence of C. jejuni in 91 wild bats by PCR. As a result of targeted PCR testing on the 16S-23S intergenic spacer, the partial genome of C. jejuni was detected in only five R. amplexicaudatus. This is the first report of C. jejuni being detected in bat rectal swab samples. C. jejuni is the most common cause of campylobacteriosis in humans, transmitted through contact with water and livestock. This result showed that R. amplexicaudatus could be a carrier of C. jejuni.
authors: Hatta, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Katayama, Y.;Taniguchi, S.;Masangkay, J. S.;Puentespina, R.;Eres, E.;Cosico, E.;Une, Y.;Yoshikawa, Y.;Maeda, K.;Kyuwa, S.;Mizutani, T.

title: Use of reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction for detection of vaccine contamination by avian leukosis virus
abstract: reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for avian leukosis virus (ALV) has been developed for the detection of contamination of vaccines produced in embryonated egg and cell cultures from chickens. ALV is highly pathogenic and induces a broad spectrum of disease in infected animals. ALV can be divided into five subgroups (AE). The envelope glycoprotein (env gp85) is the main antigen determinant and is responsible for subgroup classification. Viral RNA of all subgroups (AE) was isolated and amplified using three sets of primers. Subsequently, restriction endonuclease analysis confirmed product identity and differentiated between subgroups. In specific pathogen-free (SPF) eggs experimentally inoculated with ALV, viral RNA was found in allantoic fluids, as well as in vaccines supplemented with different subsets of ALV. No incidental virus was detected in commercially available preparations. This system provides a rapid and specific in vitro method for the detection of ALV RNA as a foreign agent and can be applied for quality control of avian vaccines.
authors: HÃ¤uptli, D.;Bruckner, L.;Ottiger, H. P.

title: Virus detection using metagenomic sequencing of porcine nasal and rectal swabs
abstract: Advances in DNA sequencing have increased our ability to generate large amounts of sequence data at lower costs. These advances have made possible direct microbial detection and characterization from clinical samples, known as metagenomic sequencing. Viral metagenomic sequencing was performed in five snout and five faecal swab pools collected from each of two primary and two secondary market slaughterhouses and a cull pig purchasing station in the southeastern United States. Sequences were assembled de novo and analyzed by BLASTN to identify viruses present in the samples. Twenty-seven different viruses were detected. Reads similar to the diverse family of single-stranded circular DNA viruses were identified in nearly every sample (50/47). Other viruses identified in all five sampling sites and in more than half of the samples were bocavirus, torovirus, posavirus, torque teno virus, IAS virus, picobirnavirus, and teschovirus. Viruses identified at more than one site in more than 20% of the samples included enterovirus, parvovirus, influenza A virus, sapelovirus, and Senecavirus A. Other important swine viruses detected less frequently include swine circovirus type 2, swine epidemic diarrhea virus and swine deltacoronavirus. Together, these results demonstrate that metagenomic sequencing is a powerful tool for virus detection and characterization.
authors: Hause, B.;Duff, J. W.;Scheidt, A.;Anderson, G.

title: Bovine rhinitis viruses are common in US cattle with bovine respiratory disease
abstract: Bovine rhinitis viruses (BRV) are established etiological agents of the bovine respiratory disease complex, but little research has been published on their epidemiology and ecology for several decades. Only bovine rhinitis A virus 1 (BRAV1) has been identified in the USA, while bovine rhinitis A virus 2 (BRAV2) and bovine rhinitis B virus (BRBV) have been previously identified only in the UK and Japan, respectively. Metagenomic sequencing of a nasal swab from a bovine respiratory disease (BRD) diagnostic presentation from Kansas identified contigs with approximately 90% nucleotide identity to BRAV2 and BRBV. A combination of de novo and template assemblies using reference genomes yielded nearly complete BRAV2 and BRBV genomes. The nearly complete genome of bovine rhinitis A virus 1 (BRAV1) was also determined from a historical isolate to allow for further molecular epidemiological studies. A 5'-nuclease reverse transcription PCR assay targeting the 3D polymerase gene was designed and used to screen 204 archived BRD clinical samples. Thirteen (6.4%) were positive. Metagenomic sequencing of six positive samples identified mixed BRAV1/BRAV2, BRAV1/BRBV and BRAV2/BRBV infections for five samples. One specimen showed infection with BRAV1 only. Seroprevalence studies using a cell culture-adapted BRBV found that antibodies reactive to immunofluorescence testing were common in the flocks analyzed. Altogether, these results suggest that BRV infections are common in cattle with respiratory disease and that BRAV1, BRAV2 and BRBV circulate together in US cattle and show high similarity to viruses isolated from various sites more than 30 years ago.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Collin, E. A.;Anderson, J.;Hesse, R. A.;Anderson, G.

title: Characterization of a new influenza virus in cattle and pigs: a proposal for a new genus in the family Orthomyxoviridae.
abstract: We recently reported the isolation of a novel virus, tentatively named C/swine/Oklahoma/1334/2011 (C/OK), with 50% overall homology to human influenza C viruses (ICV) from an Oklahoma pig. Deep RNA sequencing of C/OK virus found a different matrix 1 (M1) protein expression strategy from that of ICV. The novelty of the C/OK virus prompted us to investigate whether the C/OK virus could be found in a non-swine species. Significantly, we found that C/OK virus was prevalent in US cattle herds, as demonstrated by reverse transcription (RT)-PCR and serological assays. Genome sequencing of three cattle viruses isolated from two herds in different states further confirmed these findings. To determine whether porcine/bovine C/OK viruses can be reclassified with human ICV and to clarify the taxonomic status of C/OK, in vitro reclassification and serological typing by agar gel immunodiffusion (AGID) were performed. In vitro reclassification using two human ICVs and two porcine and bovine C/OK viruses showed that human ICV and C/OK viruses were unable to reclassify and produce viable progeny. No cross-recognition of detergent cleaved virions was observed in AGID between human and non-human viruses using polyclonal antibodies that are antigenically reactive to cognate antigens. Taken together, these results suggest that C/OK virus is genetically and antigenically different from ICV. It is suggested that the new virus be classified in a separate genus of the Orthomyxoviridae family. The presence of C/OK virus in swine and cattle indicates that this new virus can spread and infect other mammals, including humans. Â© 2014 Hause et al.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Collin, E. A.;Liu, R.;Huang, B.;Sheng, Z.;Lu, W.;Wang, D.;Nelson, E. A.;Li, F.

title: Discovery of a new putative atypical porcine pestivirus in pigs in the USA
abstract: Pestiviruses are some of the most important pathogens affecting ruminants and pigs. Here, we assemble a contiguous 11 276 bp encoding the 3635 aa polyprotein predicted from pig serum with 68% double identity with a recently partially characterized Rhinolophus affinis pestivirus (RaPV) and approximately 25-28% double identity to those of other pestiviruses. , Virus tentatively named atypical porcine pestivirus (APPV), Metagenomic sequencing of 182 serum samples identified four additional APPV positive samples, Positive samples were from five states and ELISAs using recombinant APPV Erns, cross-reactive in 94% of a collection of pig serum samples found antibodies, suggesting that APPV is widely distributed in the US pig herd. .
authors: Hause, B. M.;Collin, E. A.;Peddireddi, L.;Yuan, F.;Chen, Z.;Hesse, R. A.;Gauger, P. C.;Clement, T.;Fang, Y.;Anderson, G.

title: Identification of a novel Picornavirales virus distantly related to posavirus in pig feces.
abstract: De novo assembly of metagenomic sequencing reads from feces of a clinically normal pig identified two contigs of approximately 9 kb each consisting of a single large open reading frame. One contig encodes a predicted 2990 amino acid protein with 83% identity to the recently disclosed posavirus 1, while the other contig encodes a predicted 2942 amino acid protein with only 25% identity limited to the genomic region encoding RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp). coded it. ) of posavirus 2. Besides RdRp, searching the conserved domain database identified domains associated with picornavirus capsid proteins, but failed to identify domains of picornaviral helicase and proteinase. In addition, a domain representing a family of Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma immunoglobulin-blocking virulence proteins was identified near the 5â€²-terminal. Phylogenetic analysis found a distant relationship between this new virus, provisionally termed posavirus 3, and the unclassified posaviruses and fisaviruses, which are proposed to represent different genera in a new family of Picornavirales.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Hesse, R. A.;Anderson, G. A.

title: An inactivated influenza D virus vaccine partially protects cattle from respiratory disease caused by homologous challenge
authors: Hause, B. M.;Huntimer, L.;Falkenberg, S.

title: Senecavirus A in Pigs, United States, 2015
authors: Hause, B. M.;Myers, O.;Duff, J.;Hesse, R. A.

title: The wild pig viroma is dominated by single-stranded DNA viruses and contains a novel Orthopneumovirus that circulates in both wild and domestic pigs.
abstract: Wild pigs are known reservoirs for a variety of pathogens that can adversely affect pets. Metagenomic sequencing was performed on 100 pooled nasal swabs to assess the viral ecology of wild pig in the USA. Virome was dominated by small, ssDNA viruses belonging to the families Circoviridae, Anelloviridae and Parvovirinae. Only four RNA viruses have been identified: porcine cobuvirus, porcine sapelovirus, atypical porcine pestivirus, and a novel Orthopneumovirus provisionally termed porcine orthopneumovirus (SOV). SOV shared ~90% nucleotide identity with murine pneumonia virus (MPV) and canine pneumovirus. A modified commercially available ELISA for MPV found that approximately 30% of both wild and domestic pig sera were positive for antibodies cross-reactive with MPV. Quantitative reverse transcription-PCR identified two (2%) and four (5.0%) positive nasal swab pools from wild and domestic pigs, respectively, and confirmed that SOV was circulating in both herds.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Padmanabhan, A.;Pedersen, K.;Gidlewski, T.

title: A wide variety of posaviruses in pig feces are of aquatic origin.
abstract: Posaviruses are a very different group of viruses identified in pig feces that are distantly related to other members of the order Picornavirales. Eighteen posavirus genomes were assembled from 10 of 25 (40%) faecal swab pools collected from healthy adult pigs. Phylogenetic analysis of the conserved RNA-bound RNA polymerase (Pol) domain found that posaviruses form a large, highly diverse, monophyletic segment containing similar viruses identified in human (husavirus) and fish (fisavirus) feces or intestinal contents, respectively. Quantitative reverse transcription PCR analysis of water samples collected from commercial pig barns, four out of 19 samples (21%) were positive using a 5-nuclease assay targeting the Pol region of posavirus 1. Serological evidence of posavirus infection found only one positive sample, suggesting that posaviruses do not commonly infect pigs, and together these results suggest a possible aquatic host.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Palinski, R.;Hesse, R.;Anderson, G.

title: Complete genome sequence of a porcine polyomavirus from nasal swabs of pigs with respiratory disease
abstract: Metagenomic sequencing of pooled nasal swabs from pigs with unexplained respiratory disease identified multiple reads mapped to a previously uncharacterized porcine polyoma virus. Sus scrofa polyomavirus 2 was most closely related to betapolyomaviruses, which is frequently detected in mammalian respiratory specimens.
authors: Hause, B. M.;Smith, C.;Bishop, B.;Stewart, C.;Simonson, R.

title: Pseudocowpoxvirus genome: comparison of a reindeer isolate and a reference strain
abstract: Parapoxviruses (PPV) from the family Poxviridae cause pustular cutaneous disease in sheep and goats (orf virus, ORFV) and cattle (pseudocowpoxvirus, PCPV and bovine papular stomatitis virus, BPSV). Here we present the first genomic sequence of the reference strain PCPV (VR634) together with the genomic sequence of a PPV (F00.120R) isolated from reindeer (Rangifer tarandus tarandus) in Finland. The F00.120R and VR634 genomes are 135 and 145 kb in length and contain 131 and 134 putative genes, respectively, whose genome organization is similar to that of other PPVs. While the predicted proteins of F00.120R and VR634 have an average amino acid sequence identity of over 95%, they share only 88% and 73% amino acid identity with the ORFV and BPSV proteomes, respectively. The most notable differences were found near the genome termini. Six genes are absent in F00.120R and three in VR634 seen near the right terminal of other PPVs. The four genes at the left end of F00.120R and one in the middle of both genomes appear to be fragmented paralogs of other genes within the genome. VR634 has larger-than-expected inverted terminal repeats, possibly as a result of genomic rearrangements. The high G+C content (64%) of these two viruses, together with amino acid sequence comparisons and whole genome phylogenetic analyzes, confirms the classification of PCPV as a separate species within the genus Parapoxvirus and confirms that the virus is responsible for the epidemic of infectious stomatitis. In the winter of 1999-2000, reindeer can be classified as PCPV. © 2010 SGM.
authors: Hautaniemi, M.;Ueda, N.;Tuimala, J.;Mercer, A. A.;LahdenperÃ¤, J.;McInnes, C. J.

title: History of prions and transmission of protein misfolding
abstract: The nature of the causative agents of these "slow virus diseases" remains a mystery, as J. Cuillé and PL Chelle successfully transmitted scrapie among sheep to chimpanzee by experimental vaccination in 1936 and DC Gajdusek kuru and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in 1966 and 1968, respectively. In 1982, S. Prusiner named them "PRIONs" (for "Protein-containing Infectious particles") because they appear to lack nucleic acids to classify them as viruses. Most rare human PRION diseases appeared "sporadic", although infectious or genetic mechanisms were rarely found. They shared many clinical and neuropathological features with human neurodegenerative diseases (slow development, marked nervous system involvement, amyloid deposits, poor immune response), the mechanism of which is not generally considered infectious. In 1991, H. Braak demonstrated the low spread of neuropathological tau-related lesions along anatomical pathways in the Alzheimer's disease brain. They appear long before clinical signs. The abnormally misfolded protein features of many neurodegenerative diseases are thought to be picked up after initial seeding. This leads to their cell-to-cell transmission and propagation through neuronal and extra-neuronal pathways, which is unexpectedly under investigation. Whether insemination is contagious or not is controversial. This new paradigm should open the door to a new therapeutic approach to understand their natural histories and phenotypic diversity, which has already led to an assessment of the diagnostic value of skin biopsy.
authors: Hauw, J. J.;Haik, S.;Brandel, J. P.

title: Evidence of microevolution of Salmonella Typhimurium during a series of egg-related epidemics linked to a single poultry farm
abstract: BACKGROUND: The bacterium Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium (S. Typhimurium) is one of the most common causes of foodborne gastroenteritis outbreaks. A series of S. Typhimurium outbreaks occurred in Tasmania, Australia between 2005 and 2008, all traced back to eggs originating from a single poultry farm. To investigate the microevolution of a pathogenic S. Typhimurium clone in a natural, spatio-temporal constrained population, we sequenced the genomes of 12 isolates associated with these outbreaks. RESULTS: Isolates sharing a DT135-like phage type, known locally as 135@ or 135a, formed a segment within the S. Typhimurium population that closely resembled the reference genome SL1334 (160 single-nucleotide polymorphisms or SNPs). Ten of the isolates belonged to a single clone (<23 SNPs between pairs of isolates), possibly representative of the poultry circulating S. Typhimurium population; the other two were sporadic cases and were genetically different from this clone. Divergence dating showed that all 12 isolates diverged from a common ancestor in the mid-1990s, and the clone began diversifying in 2003-2004. This clone spread to the human population several times between 2005 and 2008; over this time period, SNPs continued to accumulate at a constant rate of 3-5 SNPs per year, or 1x10-6 substitution site-1 year-1, faster than the longer one. -S. Predicted futures (~50 years) rates for Typhimurium. Our data show that roughly half of the nonsynonymous substitutions are rapidly removed from the S. Typhimurium population, after which the purification selection is no longer important and the remaining substitutions are fixed in the population. S. Typhimurium 135® isolates were nearly identical to SL1344 in gene content and virulence plasmids. Their phage contents were close to SL1344 except that they carried a different variant of Gifsy-1, lacked the P2 residue found in SL1344, and replaced the P2 phage SopEphi of SL1344 with a new P2 phage, P2-Hawk. The DT135 lacks the P2 prophage. Two additional plasmids were identified in S. Typhimurium 135® isolates, pSTM2 and pSTM7. Both plasmids were IncI1, but phylogenetic analysis of the plasmids and their bacterial hosts suggest that these plasmids are genetically distinct and result from independent plasmid acquisition events. CONCLUSIONS: This study provides high-resolution insight into the short-term microevolution of the important human pathogen S. Typhimurium. It shows that purifying selection occurs rapidly in this population (<= 6 years) and then declines, providing an estimate for the short-term rate of substitution. The latter is likely to be more suitable for foodborne outbreak research than previous estimates based on longer timescales.
authors: Hawkey, J.;Edwards, D. J.;Dimovski, K.;Hiley, L.;Billman-Jacobe, H.;Hogg, G.;Holt, K. E.

title: Diversity in VP3, NSP3 and NSP4 of rotavirus B detected from Japanese cattle
abstract: Bovine rotavirus B (RVB) is the etiologic agent of diarrhea mostly seen in adult cattle. Currently, several viral protein (VP)1, 2, 4, 6, and 7 and non-structural proteins (NSP)1, 2, and 5 bovine RVB sequences are available in the DDBJ/EMBL/GenBank databases, and none are reported for VP3, NSP3, and NSP4. has been done. To fill this gap in the genetic characterization of bovine RVB strains, we used a metagenomic approach and sequenced and analyzed the complete coding sequences (CDS) of the VP3, NSP3 and NSP4 genes and partial or complete CDS of others. RVB genes detected from Japanese cattle. VP3, NSP3 and NSP4 of bovine RVBs, murine, human, and porcine RVBs suggest that bovine RVBs belong to a new genotype. In addition, significantly lower amino acid sequence identities were observed for NSP4 (36.1%-39.3%) between bovine RVBs and RVBs of other species. In contrast, hydrophobic plot analysis of NSP4 revealed profiles similar to RVBs of other species and strains of rotavirus A (RVA). Phylogenetic analyzes of all gene segments revealed that the bovine RVB strains formed a branching cluster away from other RVBs. These results suggest that bovine RVBs evolved independently from other RVBs, but in a similar fashion to other rotaviruses. These findings provide insight into the evolution and diversity of RVB strains.
authors: Hayashi-Miyamoto, M.;Murakami, T.;Minami-Fukuda, F.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Kishimoto, M.;Sano, K.;Naoi, Y.;Asano, K.;Ichimaru, T.;Haga, K.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Aoki, H.;Shirai, J.;Ishida, M.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Single-stranded genomic RNA from turkey enterovirus-like virus
abstract: We have previously described a disease syndrome in young turkeys caused by an enterovirus-like virus. The virus was named an enterovirus-like virus based on size, morphology, and intracytoplasmic crystal virus sequences. In this study, further characterization of the virus was performed to determine its classification. The virus has a floating density of 1.33 g/ml in CsCl and a single-stranded RNA genome of about 7.5 kilobases. These combined features indicate that this agent is an enterovirus.
authors: Hayhow, C. S.;Parwani, A. V.;Saif, Y. M.

title: Analysis of HIV-1 subtype B third variable region peptide motifs for induction of neutralizing antibodies against HIV-1 primary isolates
abstract: The HIV-1 gp120 V3 cycle is a potent inducer of neutralizing antibodies for T-cell line-adapted HIV-1, but less potent for primary isolates. We hypothesized that peptides representing the diversity of native HIV-1 V3 loop variants could capture elements of conserved higher-order structures, thereby stimulating broadly reactive neutralizing antibodies. We designed a panel of 29 subtype B V3 sequences that are assumed to reflect the range of V3 diversity. These peptides were used to immunize guinea pigs. The most potent peptide (62.19) induced antibodies that clustered around the subtype B consensus sequence and reproducibly neutralized 31% of subtype B HIV-1 primary isolates evaluated, but exhibited limited cross-neutralization of non-subtype B HIV-1 strains. Taken together, these data indicated that the limited neutralization profile of antibodies induced by optimal subtype B V3 motifs likely represents the maximum neutralization width of subtype B HIV-1 primary isolates achievable by anti-V3 peptide antibodies. Â© 2005 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Haynes, B. F.;Ma, B.;Montefiori, D. C.;Wrin, T.;Petropoulos, C. J.;Sutherland, L. L.;Scearce, R. M.;Denton, C.;Xia, S. M.;Korber, B. T.;Liao, H. X.

title: Group A Rotaviruses in Chinese Bats: Genetic Composition, Serology, and Evidence for Bat-to-Human Transmission and Reclassification
abstract: Bats are natural reservoirs for many pathogenic viruses, and growing evidence supports the idea that bats may harbor group A rotaviruses (RVA), which is an important cause of diarrhea in children and young animals. Currently, 8 RVA strains with entirely new genotype constellations or genotypes possibly originating from other mammals have been identified from African and Chinese bats. However, all data are mainly based on the detection of RVA RNA, which is only present during acute infections and does not allow assessment of the actual exposure of a bat population to RVA. To systematically investigate the genetic diversity of RVAs, 547 bat anal swabs or intestinal samples and 448 bat serums were collected from five provinces of southern China. Specific reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) screening found four RVA strains. Lineage GLRL1 had an entirely new constellation of genotypes, while the other three had a constellation consistent with the MSLH14-like genotype, a newly characterized virus group widely prevalent in Chinese insectivorous bats. Among the latter, strain LZHP2 provided strong evidence of cross-species transmission of RVAs from bats to humans, while strains YSSK5 and BSTM70 likely reconnected between typical MSLH14-like RVAs and human RVAs. RVA-specific antibodies were detected in 10.7% (48/448) of bat serum by an indirect immunofluorescence assay (IIFA). Bats in Guangxi and Yunnan had a higher prevalence of RVA-specific antibodies than bats in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces. These observations provide evidence for interspecies transmission of MSLH14-like bat RVAs to humans, highlighting the public health impact of bats as a reservoir of RVA. IMPORTANT Bat viruses such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), Ebola, Hendra and Nipah viruses are important pathogens causing outbreaks of emerging serious infectious diseases. However, little is known about bat viruses that can cause gastroenteritis in humans, although 8 group A viruses (RVA) have been identified from bats so far. In this study, 4 additional RVA strains were identified, one of which provides strong evidence for zoonotic transmission from bats to humans. Serological studies have also shown that RVA infection in bats is much more common than expected based on detection of viral RNA.
authors: He, B.;Huang, X. H.;Zhang, F. Q.;Tan, W. L.;Matthijnssens, J.;Qin, S. M.;Xu, L.;Zhao, Z. H.;Yang, L. E.;Wang, Q. X.;Hu, T. S.;Bao, X. L.;Wu, J. M.;Tu, C. C.

title: Virome profile of bats from Myanmar by metagenomic analysis of tissue samples reveals newer mammalian viruses
authors: He, B.;Li, Z.;Yang, F.;Zheng, J.;Feng, Y.;Guo, H.;Li, Y.

title: Characterization of a novel G3P[3] rotavirus isolated from a smaller horseshoe bat: a distant relative of feline/dog rotaviruses.
abstract: Bats are considered important animal reservoirs for many viruses that are pathogenic to humans. A viral metagenomics-based approach was used to examine gut samples from 78 insectivorous bats in Yunnan Province, China. Seventy-four reads were found to be associated with group A rotavirus (RVA). Further reverse transcription-PCR screening and viral isolation in cell cultures confirmed the presence of a new RVA strain, RVA/Bat-tc/MSLH14/2012/G3P[3], in 1 (6%) of 16 small horseshoe bats. Whole genomic sequencing analyzes show that MSLH14 is of feline/canine origin. Phylogenetic analysis showed that VP7 was most closely related to bovine RVA strains from India, whereas VP4 was most closely related to an unusual human RVA strain CMH222 with animal traits isolated from Thailand. The remaining gene segments were only distantly related to a number of animal RVA strains, most of which were believed to be associated with cat/dog RVAs. Experimental infection demonstrated that bat RVA strain MSLH14 was highly pathogenic to lactating mice, causing 100% mortality when inoculated orally with a titer as low as 5×-102 50% tissue culture infective doses. Because this virus is not closely related to any known RVA strains, it is tempting to think that it is a true strain of bat RVA rather than an interspecies-transmitted virus. However, further screening of bat populations, preferably young animals, will be crucial in determining whether this virus is widely distributed in the bat population.
authors: He, B.;Yang, F.;Yang, W.;Zhang, Y.;Feng, Y.;Zhou, J.;Xie, J.;Feng, Y.;Bao, X.;Guo, H.;Li, Y.;Xia, L.;Li, N.;Matthijnssens, J.;Zhang, H.;Tu, C.

title: Genome-wide mapping of DNase I hypersensitive regions and association analysis with gene expression in MSB1 cells
abstract: DNase I hypersensitive regions (DHSs) mark various classes of cis regulatory regions such as promoters and enhancers. MSB-1, derived from chicken Marek's disease (MD) lymphomas, is an MDV-transformed CD4+ T cell line for the MD study. Previously, DNase IHS sites have been studied in human cell types mainly for mammals. To capture regulatory elements specific to MSB1 cells and explore the molecular mechanisms of MDV-induced T-cell transformation in MD, we generated a high-quality DHS map and gene expression profiling for functional analysis in the MSB1 cell line. A total of 21,724 significant DHS peaks were detected from approximately 40 million short reads. DHS distribution differed between chromosomes and they preferred to enrich gene-rich chromosomes. More interestingly, DHS enrichments were found to be scarce in regions that were abundant in CpG islands. Furthermore, we integrated DHSs into gene expression data and found that while DHSs tended to enrich on highly expressed genes across all gene regions, DHSs did not show significant changes for low and silently expressed genes. Furthermore, the correlation of DHSs with expression of lincRNAs was also calculated, implying that enhancer-associated lincRNAs likely originate from enhancer-like regions of DHSs. Together, our results showed that DNase I HS regions were highly correlated with active gene expression in MSB1 cells, suggesting that DHSs could be considered as markers to identify cis regulatory elements associated with chicken Marek's disease. Â© 2014 He, Carrillo, Luo, Ding, Tian and Song.
authors: He, Y.;Carrillo, J. A.;Luo, J.;Ding, Y.;Tian, F.;Song, J.

title: Whole genome sequencing of genotype VI Newcastle disease viruses from formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissues from wild pigeons reveals continued evolution and previously unrecognized genetic diversity in the USA.
abstract: Background: Newcastle disease viruses (NDV) are highly contagious and cause disease in both wild birds and poultry. A pigeon-adapted variant of genotype VI NDV, commonly referred to as pigeon paramyxovirus 1, is widely isolated from columbia in the United States and worldwide. Full genomic characterization of these genotype VI viruses circulating in wild colombias in the United States is limited, and failure of rapid diagnostic detection has been reported due to the genetic variability of the virus. Therefore, in this study, formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) samples were subjected to next-generation sequencing (NGS) to identify and characterize these circulating viruses, providing valuable genetic information. NGS enables deep sequencing of multiple samples in parallel. When used on FFPE samples, this methodology allows for retrospective studies of infectious organisms. Methods: FFPE wild pigeon tissue samples (kidney, liver and spleen) from 10 deaths in the USA between 2010 and 2016 were analyzed using NGS to detect and sequence NDV genomes from randomly amplified total RNA. Results were compared with previously published immunohistochemistry (IHC) results conducted on the same samples. In addition, phylogenetic analyzes were performed on the complete and partial fusion gene and whole genome coding sequences. Results: Twenty-three of the 29 IHC-positive FFPE pigeon samples were identified as positive for NDV by NGS. Positive samples produced an average genome coverage of 99.6% and an average median depth of 199. In the USA from 2010 to 2016. Wild bird-derived FFPE samples. There are at least two distinct US genotype VI NDV strains conserved in wild pigeons, independently evolving continuously, and without obvious epidemiological links to viruses circulating abroad. These findings support the hypothesis that Columbuses served as a reservoir of lethal NDV in the United States.
authors: He, Y.;Taylor, T. L.;Dimitrov, K. M.;Butt, S. L.;Stanton, J. B.;Goraichuk, I. V.;Fenton, H.;Poulson, R.;Zhang, J.;Brown, C. C.;Ip, H. S.;Isidoro-Ayza, M.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Electrostatic Variation of Haemagglutinin as a Distinguishing Mark of the Evolution of Avian Influenza Viruses
abstract: Avian influenza virus is a zoonotic agent that significantly affects public health and the poultry industry. Monitoring viral evolution and spread is crucial for surveillance and monitoring programs currently based on serological or DNA sequencing-phylogenetic analysis. However, virus-host interactions, antigenic drift, and spread of viral strands are strongly dependent on variation in the surface properties of capsid proteins. Here we report that in silico comparative structural analysis of hemagglutinin can reveal relevant evolutionary fingerprints, especially when integrated with sequence-based analyses. Phylogenetic analyzes of H9 viral strains from wild birds and poultry by different methods led to reliable clustering of viruses into five main groups. Subsequent comparison of structural features showed concordance between such aggregation and surface electrostatic fingerprints. These latter fingerprints associate group-specific variations in electrostatic charges and isocontours with well-known hemagglutinin regions involved in modulation of immune escape and host specificity. This work suggests that the integration of structural and sequence comparisons could enhance the investigation of trends and related mechanisms in viral evolution.
authors: Heidari, A.;Righetto, I.;Filippini, F.

title: MChip, a low-density microarray, distinguishes between seasonal human H1N1, North American pig H1N1 and 2009 pandemic H1N1.
abstract: Please cite this article as: Heil et al. (2010) MChip, a low-density microarray, differentiates between seasonal human H1N1, North American pig H1N1 and 2009 pandemic H1N1. Influenza and Other Respiratory Viruses 4(6), 411-416. Background MChip uses data from the hybridization of amplified viral RNA to 15 different oligonucleotides targeting the influenza A matrix (M) gene segment. An artificial neural network (ANN) automates the interpretation of subtle differences in fluorescent intensity patterns from the microarray. The entire process from clinical sample to identification, including amplification of viral RNA, can be completed in <8 hours for under $10. Objectives The work presented here represents an effort to expand and test the capabilities of MChip to discriminate against influenza A/H1N1 from various strains. Methods MChip ANN is trained to recognize fluorescent display patterns of a variety of known influenza A viruses, including human H1N1, human H3N2, swine H1N1, 2009 pandemic influenza A H1N1 and samples of a wide variety of avian, equine, canine, and a wide variety of influenza A viruses. swine flu viruses. The robustness of the MChip ANN was evaluated using 296 blind isolates. Results ANN training was extended by the addition of 71 well-characterized influenza A isolates, providing relatively high accuracy (minor misclassification) in distinguishing unique H1N1 strains: nine human A/H1N1 (88%Â·9% correct), 35 human A/H3N2 (% 97Â·1% correct), 31 North American pig A/H1N1 (80Â·6 correct), 14 2009 pandemic A/H1N1 (87Â·7% correct), and 23 negative samples (91Â·3% correct). Genetic variation among porcine H1N1 isolates may have contributed to the lower success rate for these viruses. Conclusions The present study demonstrates that MChip has the ability to distinguish genetic variations between influenza viruses with appropriate ANN training. Further selective enrichment of ANN will improve its ability to rapidly and reliably characterize influenza viruses of unknown origin. © 2010 Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Heil, G. L.;McCarthy, T.;Yoon, K. J.;Liu, S.;Saad, M. D.;Smith, C. B.;Houck, J. A.;Dawson, E. D.;Rowlen, K. L.;Gray, G. C.

title: Molecular characterization of avian reovirus isolates in Tunisia
abstract: Background: Genotype analyzes of avian reoviruses isolated from organ samples from chickens with suspected clinical symptoms between 1997 and 2008 were based on sequences for both the ÏƒC and ÏƒB genes, enabling studies to be conducted, in agreement with those published in Genbank. molecular classification and relationships. Methods The full length of the known variable protein ÏƒC and some of the genes encoding ÏƒB were amplified by RT-PCR using conserved primers. PCR products were sequenced and sequences analyzed and aligned with avian reovirus sequences from the Genbank database. Results: Sequences of ÏƒC-encoding genes of all isolated strains showed their close association with American, Chinese and Indian strains. Taking the American strain S1133 as reference, two Tunisian isolates 97.1 and 97.2 showed some nucleotide substitutions. For isolate 97.1, the substitution was silent, whereas for strain 97.2, the mutation was at the first position of the corresponding codon and induced substitution of the encoded amino acid. For the gene encoding ÏƒB, the sequences of the Tunisian strains showed mutations at positions two or three of the corresponding codons, inducing substitutions of amino acids at these positions. Phylogenetic trees based on genes encoding ÏƒC and ÏƒB showed a closer association of genotype I between isolates from Tunisia, America, and Taiwan. Conclusion: Our study identifies the genotype of avian reoviruses that are not yet genetically well characterized. The characterization and classification of these viruses may be important for understanding the epidemiology of malabsorption syndrome and viral arthritis and improving our knowledge of the genotype of strains circulating in Tunisian herds. In addition, examining their variable pathogenicity can be extremely important in selecting the appropriate vaccine strain to control the disease. Â© 2013 Hellal Kort et al.; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Hellal Kort, Y.;BourogÃ¢a, H.;Gribaa, L.;Scott-Algara, D.;Ghram, A.

title: Serotype C foot-and-mouth disease virus isolates from India belong to a separate hitherto unidentified strain group.
abstract: Full 1D gene sequences of 13 Indian foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) type C domain isolates and one vaccine strain (C-Bombay/64) were determined. All field isolates showed greater genetic homogeneity (95-100%) among themselves and were 19.7-21.2% different from the vaccine strain. In phylogenetic analysis, Indian field isolates formed a distinct lineage (lineage VII) distinct from the six previously identified lineages (lineage I-VI) in type C FMDV [J. Viral. 66 (1992) 3557]. The vaccine strain is grouped with European ancestry (strain II). Comparison of the deduced amino acid sequences of the antigenic regions A and C of the domain isolates showed no significant change from the vaccine strain. The unidirectional serological association determined in ELISA indicated the antigenic affinity of the field isolates with C-Bombay/64. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Hemadri, D.;Sanyal, A.;Tosh, C.;Venkataramanan, R.;Pattnaik, B.

title: Emergence of a new type O foot-and-mouth disease virus: phylogenetic and evolutionary relationship to the PanAsia pandemic strain.
abstract: Foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV) serotype O has been associated with over 75% of outbreaks in India. Previous studies with this serotype have shown that viruses circulating in India belong to a single genotype. Recent (February 2001) foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks in Europe have focused global attention on the source of the virus and have been traced to the PanAsia (serotype O) strain found in India since 1990. In this study, we sequenced the complete VP1-encoding (1D) gene for 71 FMDV serotype O isolates from India, belonging to the PanAsian strain, that were recovered from field outbreaks in the past 4 years (1962-2001) to further characterize the isolates. All isolates in the tree were classified in three main branches (determined as A, B and C); Branch C is further divided into four groups (I-IV), of which IV. belongs to the group PanAsia strain. We also show that the PanAsia strain has been endemic circulating since 1982 (not in 1990, as previously reported) and has been the most dominant epidemic strain in recent years, with distribution in at least 17 states in the country. During 2001, another new virus group (group III) with 5.4-11.1% genetic deviation at the nucleotide level from the PanAsia strain was found to circulate endemic together and gradually replace it. At the amino acid level, this strain differed from the PanAsia strain at the five amino acid positions in VP1. Although these strains differed at the nucleotide level, they maintained a good antigenic relationship with one of the vaccine strains widely used in the country (IND R2/75). Given the ability of the PanAsia virus to persist, spread and outpace other strains, the current trend could be of serious concern as the newly emerged virus has replaced it. If this is true, there is another equally different species, PanAsia, which could pose a serious threat to the global dairy and meat industries.
authors: Hemadri, D.;Tosh, C.;Sanyal, A.;Venkataramanan, R.

title: Genetic analysis of foot and mouth virus type O isolates responsible for field outbreaks in India between 1993 and 1999
abstract: The partial nucleotide sequence at the 3â€² end of the 1D (VP1-encoding) gene of 90 foot-and-mouth disease virus type O isolates obtained from field outbreaks in India between 1993-9 was determined. Sequences were compared with each other and with reference viruses. Published sequences of 15 type O isolates from different parts of Asia and one isolate from Europe (O1BFS) and one isolate from Egypt (O1/Sharquia/Egypt/72) were also included in the analysis for comparison. On the basis of phylogenetic analysis, viruses can be grouped into four different genotypes (genotypes I-IV). All 90 isolates from India were genotype-I, as were the reference isolates from Bangladesh, China, Egypt, Iran, Saudi Arabia, Syria and Turkey. Genotype-I isolates were further subdivided into 16 subgenotypes. The Indian isolates were found to be extremely heterogeneous in nature and clustered into 12 different genetic groups. The nucleotide sequence difference between isolates in genotype-I is 0-11.6%, while it is 0-8.8% in Indian isolates. Viruses of similar genetic groups circulate in India, Bangladesh, and Middle Eastern countries. Genotypes-II and -III are represented by Lebanese (O1/South Lebanon) and European (O1-BFS) isolates, respectively. Genotype-IV consists of isolates from China, Hong Kong and Taiwan. This study reveals the emergence of viruses belonging to more than one genetic group in a short time and the persistence of a single genetic group for several years in the same geographical area. This is consistent with the endemic nature of the disease in the country.
authors: Hemadri, D.;Tosh, C.;Venkataramanan, R.;Sanyal, A.;Samuel, A. R.;Knowles, N. J.;Kitching, R. P.

title: MERS coronavirus in dromedary herd, Saudi Arabia
abstract: prospective study of a herd of dromedary camels during the 2013-14 calving season showed Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus infection in calves and adults. The virus was isolated from the nose and feces, but more often from the nose. The pre-existing neutralizing antibody did not protect against infection.
authors: Hemida, M. G.;Chu, D. K.;Poon, L. L.;Perera, R. A.;Alhammadi, M. A.;Ng, H. Y.;Siu, L. Y.;Guan, Y.;Alnaeem, A.;Peiris, M.

title: st. Comparison of biological features of Louis encephalitis and Rio Bravo viruses
abstract: st. Louis encephalitis (SLE) virus, an arbovirus and Rio Bravo (RB) virus, a non-arthropod virus, and flaviviruses that cross-reacted in neutralization tests. Many of their biological properties were compared. Viral growth curves revealed that >99% of infectious SLE (Paton) virus remained cell-associated in Vero cells, but was gradually released into the medium of infected BHK-21 cells. In contrast, RB (M-64) virus was released into the fluids of Vero and BHK-21 cell cultures after maturation. Forty times more SLE virus than RB virus adsorbed on monolayer cultures of Aedes dorsalis cells. SLE, but not RB virus, replicated and reached high titers (108 pfu/ml) in Ae. Dorsalis cell cultures maintained in medium expected to enhance recovery of RB virus. Also, RB virus, not SLE virus, replicated in cultured bat epithelial cells and primary duck embryo cells incubated at 42°C. Clearly, the prototype strains of RN and SLE viruses are different viruses. Both the classification of RB virus in the flavivirus genus and the antigenic relationship between RB and SLE viruses require further clarification.
authors: Hendricks, D. A.;Hardy, J. L.;Reeves, W. C.

title: Human biliary glycoproteins serve as receptors for interspecies transfer of mouse hepatitis virus.
abstract: The Mouse Hepatitis virus (MHV) variant, designated MHV-H2, was isolated by serial passage in mixed cultures of permissive DBT cells and nonpermissive Syrian Hamster Kidney (BHK) cells. MHV-H2 was efficiently replicated in hamster, mouse, primate kidney (Vero, Cos 1, Cos 7) and human adenocarcinoma (HRT) cell lines, but not in pig testicular (ST), feline kidney (CRFK), and canine kidney (MDCK) cells. To understand the molecular basis of coronavirus cross-species transfer into human cell lines, the replication of MHV-H2 was studied in hepatocellular carcinoma (HepG2) cells expressing the high human homolog of the normal murine receptor, biliary glycoprotein (Bgp). . MHV-H2 was replicated in human HepG2 cells, breast carcinoma (MCF7) cells at low levels, and human colon adenocarcinoma (LS 174T) cell lines expressing high levels of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) at low levels. These data suggested that MHV-H2 might use the human Bgp homolog as a receptor for entry into HepG2 cells. To further examine MHV-H2 receptor utilization in human cell lines, blockade experiments were performed with a panel of different monoclonal or polyclonal antisera directed against human CEA genes. Pretreatment of HepG2 cells with a polyclonal antiserum for all CEA family members or with Kat4c (cd66abde), a monoclonal antibody directed against Bgp1, CGM6, CGM1a, NCA and CEA, inhibits virus replication and MHV-H2 infects HepG2 cells. Use of another monoclonal panel with more restricted cross-reactivity between human CEAs, Col-4 and Col-14, but not MHV-H2 infection in B6.2, B1.13, Col-1, Col-6 and Col-12. blocked it. HepG2 cells. These antibodies did not block sindbis virus (SB) replication in HepG2 cells, nor did they block SB, MHV-A59, or MHV-H2 replication in DBT cells. Monoclonal antibodies Col-4, Col-14 and Kat4c (cd66abde) reacted strongly with human Bgp and CEA, but showed variable binding patterns with other CEA genes. Following expression of human Bgp in normally nonpermissive porcine testis (ST) and feline kidney (CRFK) cells, the cells became susceptible to MHV-H2 infection. These data suggested that phylogenetic homologs of virus receptors represent natural channels for virus xenotropism and interspecies transfer.
authors: Hensley, L. E.;Baric, R. S.

title: Metagenomic identification, seasonal dynamics and potential transmission mechanisms of Daphnia-associated single-stranded DNA virus in two temperate lakes.
abstract: We used a metagenomic approach to identify viruses that may be involved in the ecology of Daphnia spp. Oneida and Cayuga lakes (upper New York state). We identified highly represented putative eukaryotic, circular, single-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) viral genomes. Among them, we discovered a genotype similar in both sequence and genomic architecture to a previously reported virus from a hyperthermal lake that shares features of both single-stranded ribonucleic acid (RNA) and single-stranded DNA viruses. We used quantitative polymerase chain reactions to examine the prevalence of both positive and negative chains and viral load of the hybrid virus (DMClaHV) associated with Daphnia mendotae (Cladocera) during a summer season in Lakes Oneida and Cayuga. DMClaHV had high prevalence within Daphnia populations where the viral load and the proportion of virus positive individuals were higher prior to the host population decline. DMClaHV viral load was different between the two Daphnia species (D. mendotae and D. retrocurva), and dynamics between viruses and their hosts varied between the two lakes. We detected DMClaHV in eggs (ephippia) from Lake Oneida sediments with an estimated age of 30 years. Using transmission electron microscopy, we observed small (20 nm in diameter) virus-like particles in Daphnia that are quite distant from intestinal tissues and are not associated with intracellular parasites. Because daphnia plays a critical role in many lake ecosystems, DMClaHV can have significant effects on herbivores and hence carbon flow throughout the lake ecosystem.
authors: Hewson, I.;Ng, G.;Li, W. F.;LaBarre, B. A.;Aguirre, I.;Barbosa, J. G.;Breitbart, M.;Greco, A. W.;Kearns, C. M.;Looi, A.;Schaffner, L. R.;Thompson, P. D.;Hairston, N. G.

title: Application of high resolution melting curve analysis for classification of infectious bronchitis viruses in field samples
abstract: Aim: A real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR)/high resolution melting (HRM) curve analysis protocol was developed in our laboratory to differentiate infectious bronchitis (IB) virus reference strains. In the current study, this method was used to detect and classify IB viruses in field submissions. Procedure: Samples were taken from 40 suspected cases of IB virus over an 11-month period, and 17 applicants were positive for IB virus via polymerase chain reaction. HRM curve analysis classified each strain as subgroup 1, 2, or 3 strains (12 references) or an unclassifiable strain (5 references). The 3' untranslated region (UTR) and partial S1 gene nucleotide sequences were determined for the 17 IB virus strains and their identity was compared with that of the relative reference strains to validate the classifications established using HRM curve analysis. Results: The 3'UTR and S1 gene nucleotide sequences from 12 IB domain viruses classified as subgroup 1, 2 or 3 using HRM curve analysis had -99% identity with the corresponding subgroup reference strain. Analysis of the 3' UTR and S1 gene nucleotide sequences for the five unclassifiable IB virus strains showed that four belonged to one of the subgroups and one was a potential recombinant strain (between subgroups 2 and 3 strains). A new recombinant strain was also identified. Conclusion: HRM curve analysis can rapidly assign most IB viruses found in field presentations to known subgroups. Importantly, HRM curve analysis also identified variant genotypes requiring further investigation. Â© 2010 Authors. Australian Veterinary Journal Â© 2010 Australian Veterinary Association.
authors: Hewson, K. A.;Browning, G. F.;Devlin, J. M.;Ignjatovic, J.;Noormohammadi, A. H.

title: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus: Sequence analysis of small RNA segments from a worldwide virus collection.
abstract: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHFv) is a member of the Nairovirus genus in the Bunyaviridae family. It has a triple, single-stranded RNA genome with negative polarity consisting of large (L), medium (M), and small (S) segments. CCHF virus is enzootic in lifeguard and wild animals in many parts of the Middle East, Asia and Africa and is also recognized in Southeastern Europe. Severe disease, manifested by hemorrhagic fever and high mortality rates (up to 50%), is recognized only in humans. We determined the complete sequence of the small genomic RNA segment from various strains of CCHF viruses originating from the outbreaks in Pakistan 2000, Baghdad 1976 and Uzbekistan 1967. Phylogenetic analysis of three sequence data from the small genomic RNA segment available from a number of strains shows that they can be divided into seven subtypes. Superimposed on this model, connections between distant geographic locations indicate the existence of a global reservoir of CCHFv. In some cases, these links may result from long-distance transport of the virus or infected ticks during pet trade and bird migration. Â© 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Hewson, R.;Chamberlain, J.;Mioulet, V.;Lloyd, G.;Jamil, B.;Hasan, R.;Gmyl, A.;Gmyl, L.;Smirnova, S. E.;Lukashev, A.;Karganova, G.;Clegg, C.

title: Guinea pig model of infectious disease-viral infections
authors: Hickey, A. J.

title: Sequences of the coat protein gene of five pistachio stripe virus (PStV) strains from Thailand and their evolutionary relationship to other bean common mosaic virus sequences.
abstract: The coat protein gene and part of the 3' non-coding region of five pistachio stripe viruses (PStV) from Thailand were cloned and sequenced. Phylogenetic comparisons of these strains and related sequences, known as T1, T3, T5, T6 and T7, showed that these strains were indeed PStV strains. Moreover, PStV strains appear to be related to each other according to their geographical origins. That is, despite the diversity of symptoms caused by these strains and the overlap of symptom types between strains from different locations, Thai strains are more closely related than strains from the USA or Indonesia. Like other PStV strains, PStV-Thai bean can be considered as strains of common mosaic virus (BCMV), but can be distinguished from bean-infecting strains of BCMV and blackeye cowpea mosaic virus (B1CMV) by sequence and host range. Unlike PStV-Ib, no evidence was found that PStV-Thai strains are recombinants of PStV and B1CMV, although strain T3 may be a recombinant of different PStV sequences. Phylogenetic analyzes of BCMV group viruses suggest that the acquisition of the ability to infect peanuts may have occurred only once.
authors: Higgins, C. M.;Cassidy, B. G.;Teycheney, P. Y.;Wongkaew, S.;Dietzgen, R. G.

title: High-throughput sequencing methods for microbiome profiling: application to food animal systems Review
abstract: Analysis of microbial communities using high-throughput sequencing methods began in the mid-2000s, allowing for 1000 to 10,000 sequence reads per sample and megabase data generation per sequence run. This unprecedented sequencing depth has allowed the discovery of the 'rare biosphere' in environmental samples for the first time. The technology was quickly applied to studies in a variety of human subjects. Perhaps these early studies reminded us that although microbes living in mammals are known to outnumber host cells, many of them are unknown members of our second genome, or microbiome (as invented by Joshua Lederberg). because we cannot culture them. High-throughput methods for microbial 16S ribosomal RNA gene and whole genome shotgun (WGS) sequencing have begun to reveal the composition and identity of archaeal, bacterial, and viral communities at many sites in and on the human body. Research into the microbiota of food production animals has been published over the past few years, and future studies should benefit from protocols and tools developed from large-scale human microbiome studies. However, animal-related production resources such as advanced host genome assemblies and an increasing diversity of host-specific microbial reference genome sequences will be needed to allow for meaningful and robust analysis of 16S rDNA and WGS sequence data.
authors: Highlander, S. K.

title: Influenza transmission reflects seasonality of wild birds throughout the annual cycle
abstract: Influenza A Viruses (IAV) in nature must overcome the changing barriers of transmission caused by the mobility of their primary hosts, migratory wild birds, that change over the annual cycle. Using a phylogenetic network of viral sequences from North American wild birds (2008–2011), we show a transition from intraspecies transmission to interspecies transmission that, together with reclassification, allows IAV to reach viral flux in successive seasons from summer to winter. Our study supports amplification of IAV during summer propagation by the locally persisted and introduced virus from a wide range of latitudes. As birds migrate from their breeding grounds to lower latitudes, they become involved in transmission networks that are more closely linked to other bird species, and transmission of interspecies reassortant viruses peaks during the winter months. We propose that altering migration dynamics could be a critical strategy for pathogens infecting mobile hosts living in regions with strong seasonality.
authors: Hill, N. J.;Ma, E. J.;Meixell, B. W.;Lindberg, M. S.;Boyce, W. M.;Runstadler, J. A.

title: Microbial Ecology Along the Gastrointestinal System
abstract: The ecosystem of the human gastrointestinal (GI) system undergoes a range of environmental, chemical and physical conditions as it moves from the oral cavity to the anus. These differences in conditions, along with food or other ingested substrates, influence the composition and density of the microbiota, as well as their functional roles, by choosing the most suitable for that environment. Although the number of studies on Archaea, Eukarya and Viruses is limited despite their important roles in this ecosystem, previous studies mostly focused on Bacteria. Also, many studies focusing on the composition of microbiomes are still exploratory, due to the difficulties associated with collecting samples directly from inside humans. Therefore, mechanistic studies are carried out to investigate functions using animal models. However, differences in physiology and microbiomes need to be clarified to help translate animal model findings into human context. This review will highlight Bacteria, Archaea, Fungi, and Viruses, discuss differences along the GI tract of healthy humans, and make comparisons to three common animal models: rats, mice, and pigs.
authors: Hillman, E. T.;Lu, H.;Yao, T.;Nakatsu, C. H.

title: TTV, a novel human virus with a single-stranded circular DNA genome
abstract: TT virus (TTV) was found in 1997 from a hepatitis patient without virus markers. However, the true impact of TTV on liver diseases remains unclear to date. Due to the lack of suitable cell systems to support the growth of TTV, the biology of TTV is still unclear. This review attempts to summarize the current state of TTV outside of TTV's taxonomic diversity. TTV was the first human virus with a single-stranded circular DNA genome. TTV has been considered a member of the Circoviridae, although others have suggested it fits into a new family. TTV differs from ambisense viruses in the Circovirus genus because the former genome is negative-chain. The genome structure of TTV is more closely related to chicken anemia virus in the genus Gyrovirus, but sequence similarity is minimal except for a brief stretch at 3816-3851 of TA278. Currently, the working group proposes the full name of TTV as TorqueTenoVirus and the TTV-like mini-virus TorqueTenoMiniVirus (TTMV) in a new strain of Anellovirus (ring). TTVs are common in non-human primates, and human TTV can cross-infect chimpanzees. In addition, TTV sequences have been detected in chickens, pigs, cows and sheep. TTV can be transmitted from mother to child through infection. However, within one year of birth, the prevalence reaches the same level in infants born to both TTV-positive and TTV-negative mothers, even without breastfeeding. The non-coding region surrounding a short 113 nt GC-rich stretch and occupying approximately one-third of the genome is considered to contain the putative origin of replication. Three mRNAs, TTV, 3.0 and 1.2 and 1.0 kb are expressed by the species. A protein translated from 3.0 kb mRNA is considered the main capsid protein as well as replicase. The nature of the proteins translated by the other two mRNAs is still hypothetical. Copyright © 2002 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
authors: Hino, S.

title: Torque teno virus (TTV): Current status
abstract: Torque tenovirus (TTV), currently classified in the family Anellovirus genus Circoviridae, was first found in a patient with non-AE hepatitis.
