TTV has a single-stranded circular DNA of âˆ¼3.8 kb. TTVs are extraordinarily diverse, spanning five groups, including the SANBAN and SEN viruses. Torque teno mini virus (TTMV) with a genome of âˆ¼2.9 kb also has wide variants. Recently, two related 2.2 and 2.6 kb species have joined this community. Recombinations between variants are frequent. This extensive TTV variety cannot be explained; It is unclear how TTVs might be viable and why they need such genetic variation. A definitive culture system still does not exist. TTVs are ubiquitous in >90% of adults worldwide, but the human pathogenicity of TTV has not been fully established. Epidemiological studies should identify variants and clinical targets studied and calibrate the sensitivity of the assay used. Potentially interesting observations include higher viral load in patients with severe idiopathic inflammatory myopathies, cancer, and lupus. Active replication was also found in infants with acute respiratory diseases. TTV/TTMV-related viruses have been found in chimpanzees, monkeys, African monkeys and tupaia, as well as in chickens, pigs, cows, sheep and dogs. Experimentally, rhesus monkeys were permanently infected by TTV, but only 1/53 chimpanzees. TTV transcribes three types of mRNA, 3.0-, 1.2-, and 1.0-kb in a 60:5:35 ratio. Recently, at least three mRNAs have been demonstrated in chicken anemia virus. The genomic region -154/-76 contains a critical promoter. TTV seems to have at least three proteins; however, the precise functions of these proteins await further research studies. Copyright © 2006 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
authors: Hino, S.;Miyata, H.

title: Association of torque teno virus with chicken anemia virus
abstract: This chapter examines the relationship between Torque teno virus (TTV) and chicken anemia virus (CAV). Each has a circular single-stranded (ss)DNA genome with each of the known open reading frames (ORF) in its antigenomic chain. This structure is different from the structures of circoviruses. TTV and CAV have different genomic sizes, 3.8 kb and 2.3 kb, respectively. The spectrum of the TTV genome is extremely diverse, while the spectrum of the CAV genome is extremely narrow. Although a 36-nt stretch near the origin of replication of TA278 TTV has more than 80% similarity to that of CAV, the sequence of other genomic regions does not show significant similarity. However, the relative allocation of ORFs on each frame in these viruses mimics each other. Three or more messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are produced by transcription in both. A structural protein with a replicase domain is encoded by frame 1 in every virus, and a non-structural protein with a phosphatase domain is encoded by frame 2. In each virus, a protein on framework 3 induces apoptosis in transformed cells. Recently, we confirmed that apoptin is required for CAV replication. TTV proposed to form a new family, Anelloviridae. Given these similarities and differences between CAV and TTV, it seems more plausible to place CAV, the only member of the Gyrovirus genus, together with TTV into Anelloviridae or a new independent family. © 2009 Springer.
authors: Hino, S.;Prasetyo, A. A.

title: Conservation of L and 3C proteinase activities in distantly related aftoviruses
abstract: Foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV) leader (L) proteinase is an important virulence determinant in FMDV infections. It has two distinct catalytic activities: (i) C-terminal processing at the L/VP4 junction; and (ii) inducing cleavage of the translation initiation factor eIF4G, an event that inhibits cap-dependent translation in infected cells. The only other member of the Aphthovirus genus, equine rhinitis A virus (ERAV), also encodes an L protein, but it shares only 32% amino acid identity with its FMDV counterpart. Another more distantly related picornavirus, equine rhinitis B virus (ERBV), which is not classified as an aftovirus, also encodes an L protein. Using in vitro transcription and translation analysis, we demonstrated that both ERAV and ERBV L proteins have C-terminal processing activity. Moreover, expression of ERAV L, but not ERBV L, in BHK-21 cells resulted in effective inhibition of cap-dependent translation in these cells. We show that EBAV and FMDV L proteinases induce eIF4GI cleavage at very similar or identical positions. Interestingly, ERAV 3C also induces eIF4GI cleavage and produces different products that also migrate together with those induced by FMDV 3C. ERBV L proteinase does not induce eIF4GI cleavage, consistent with its inability to turn off cap-dependent translation. We also show that another unique feature of FMDV L, stimulation of enterovirus internal ribosome entry site (IRES) activity, is also shared by ERAV L proteinase, but not by ERBV L. Functional preservation of different ERAV and FMDV proteinases indicates the possibility that these enzymes may have a similar and important role in the pathogenesis of infections by these distantly related aftoviruses.
authors: Hinton, T. M.;Ross-Smith, N.;Warner, S.;Belsham, G. J.;Crabb, B. S.

title: Epidemiology of vampire bat-transmitted rabies virus in Goias, Central Brazil: reassessment based on the GL intergenic region.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Vampire bat-related rabies wreaks havoc on both the livestock industry and the public health sector in central Brazil. The geographic distributions of rabies virus variants transmitted from the vampire bat are restricted to mountain chains. These findings were explained by analyzing a highly conserved nucleoprotein gene. This study aims to elucidate the detailed epidemiological characters of rabies virus transmitted from the vampire bat by phylogenetic methods based on the 619-nt sequence containing the unconserved GL intergenic region. RESULTS: Vampire bat transmitted rabies virus isolates separated into 8 phylogenetic lineages in the previous nucleoprotein gene analysis were separated into 10 phylogenetic lineages with significant bootstrapping values. It has been reconfirmed that the distribution of most variants is restricted by mountain chains. Also, variants in undulating areas have narrow distributions and are apparently separated by mountain ridges. CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates that the 619-nt sequence containing the GL intergenic region is more useful than the partial nucleoprotein gene for state-level phylogenetic analysis of rabies virus, while also showing that the distribution of vampire bat-transmitted RABV variants tends to diverge. not only by mountain chains but also by mountain ridges, thus suggesting that the diversity of vampire bat-transmitted RABV variants is constrained by geographic fluctuations.
authors: Hirano, S.;Itou, T.;Carvalho, A. A.;Ito, F. H.;Sakai, T.

title: Whole genome analysis of a novel neurotropic bovine astrovirus detected in a Japanese black cattle with non-suppurative encephalomyelitis in Japan
abstract: Although neurotropic bovine astroviruses (BoAstVs) have been described in North America and Europe, their presence has never been reported in Asia. In this study, we detected BoAstV in the brain of a calf with neurological symptoms. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the identified virus belonged to the Virginia/Human-Mink-Ovine Glade, which contains most of the neurotropic astroviruses, including the neurotropic BoAstVs. Similarity plot analysis showed that the virus was closely related to the American BoAstV NeuroS1 strain by ORF regions and the European BoAstV CH13 strain in the 3' untranslated region, suggesting that intra-genotypic recombination events occurred.
authors: Hirashima, Y.;Okada, D.;Shibata, S.;Yoshida, S.;Fujisono, S.;Omatsu, T.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Phylogeny and natural history of primate lentiviruses, SIV and HIV
abstract: Studies of primate lentivirus phylogeny over the past decade have established at least five groups of related but genetically distinct simian immunodeficiency viruses (SIVs), each originating from a different African primate species. The hypothesis that HIV-2 (and SIVmac) arose by interspecies transmission from sooty mangabeys (Cercocebus atys) was strengthened by further characterization of the SIVsm/SIVmac/HIV-2 virus group. SIV from all four subspecies of African green monkeys (SIVagm) was characterized by a distinctive chimeric genome structure of SIVagm from West African green monkeys. Although these naturally infected primates remain healthy, cross-species transmission to other primate species can result in immunodeficiency caused by SIVsm infection of macaque monkeys (Macaca sp.) and recently SIVagm infection of pig-tailed macaques (M. nemestrina). Studies of variation in infected individuals have been facilitated by adapting heteroduplex analysis techniques and single-stranded conformational polymorphism of PCR-generated fragments.
authors: Hirsch, V. M.;Dapolito, G.;Goeken, R.;Campbell, B. J.

title: Association of receptors of a new virus strain with those of the mumps-NDV-influenza group
abstract: The relationships of cellular receptors and hemagglutinin inhibitors of a new virus strain (1233) with members of the mumps-Newcastle disease-flu group were investigated. It was found to be difficult. 1233 does not destroy the receptors or inhibitors of the other group, and the latter does not destroy the 1233 receptors or inhibitor. The only exception to this statement was the moderate destruction of the 1233 inhibitor in egg white by the Newcastle disease virus. Classification of the 1233 lineages was discussed in the light of this evidence, which tended to place the 1233 lineage in a different category from any other strain of the MNI group.
authors: Hirst, G. K.

title: Establishment of the concept of prion diseases
abstract: The history of prion diseases is derived from descriptions of scrapies of sheep and goats in the eighteenth century. In 1920, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease was reported as the first case of human prion diseases recognized as subacute spongiform encephalopathy, one of the neurodegenerative diseases. Subsequently, many conduction experiments were conducted, which led to the establishment of the basic concept of infectious spongiform encephalopathy (TSE). The infectious agent was supposed to be a new virus, so TSE was classified as a slow virus infection. In 1982, Prusiner investigated the infectious fraction of scrapie-infected brain homogenate, identified the infectious agent as proteinaceous infectious particles that resist inactivation by nucleic acid-altering procedures, and renamed prion after virion in viral infection.
authors: Hizume, M.;Mizusawa, H.

title: Book Review: Poultry Diseases
authors: Hoerr, F. J.

title: New orthobunyavirus in cattle, Europe, 2011
abstract: An unidentified disease in cattle was reported in Germany and the Netherlands in 2011. Clinical signs included fever, decreased milk production, and diarrhea. Metagenomic analysis identified a novel orthobunyavirus that was subsequently isolated from the blood of affected animals. Surveillance was initiated to test newborns with defects in the affected area.
authors: Hoffmann, B.;Scheuch, M.;HÃ¶per, D.;Jungblut, R.;Holsteg, M.;Schirrmeier, H.;Eschbaumer, M.;Goller, K. V.;Wernike, K.;Fischer, M.;Breithaupt, A.;Mettenleiter, T. C.;Beer, M.

title: Differences in virus receptor for type I and type II feline infectious peritonitis virus
abstract: Feline infectious peritonitis viruses (FIPVs) are divided into type I and type II serogroups. Here we report that feline aminopeptidase N (APN), a cell surface metalloprotease in intestinal, lung and kidney epithelial cells, is a receptor for type II FIPV but not type I FIPV. A monoclonal antibody (MAb) RG-4 that blocks infection of Felis catus whole fetus (fcwf-4) cells by type II FIPV was obtained by immunizing mice with fcwf-4 cells that are highly susceptible to FIPV. This MAb also blocked infection of fcwf-4 cells by type II feline enteric coronavirus (FECV), canine coronavirus (CCV), and infectious gastroenteritis virus (TGEV). On the other hand, it did not prevent infection by type I FIPVs. MAb RG-4 recognized a polypeptide with a relative molecular mass of 120-130 kDa in feline intestinal brush-bordered membrane (BBM) proteins. The polypeptide had aminopeptidase activity and the first 15 N-terminal amino acid sequence was the same as that of the feline APN. Reacting with feline intestinal BBM proteins and MAb RG-4 (feline APN), the polypeptide inhibited the infectivity of type II FIPV, type II FECV, CCV and TGEV to fcwf-4 cells, but not type I FIPVs.
authors: Hohdatsu, T.;Izumiya, Y.;Yokoyama, Y.;Kida, K.;Koyama, H.

title: Characterization of monoclonal antibodies to feline infectious peritonitis virus type II and antigenic relationship between feline, swine and canine coronaviruses
abstract: Seven monoclonal antibodies (MAb) with neutralizing activity against feline infectious peritonitis virus (FIPV) strain 79-1149 (type II) were prepared. When the polypeptide specificity recognized by these monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) was investigated by Western immunoblotting, all of the MAbs reacted with the peplomer glycoprotein (S) of the virus. By competitive binding assay, these MAbs were found to recognize at least 3 different epitopes. Reactivity of these MAbs with 6 viruses classified as FIPV type I (UCD-1, UCD-2, UCD-3, UCD-4, NW-1 and Black), feline enteric coronavirus (FECV) type II strain 79-1683, canine coronavirus (CCV) strain 1-71 and transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) strains were investigated by TO-163 and SH neutralization tests. All MAbs neutralized FECV strain 79-1683, CCV strain 1-71, and TGEV strains TO-163 and SH, while 6 did not neutralize FIPV type I viruses. Also, MAb against TGEV strain TO-163, which has potent neutralizing activity against 7 TGEV viruses, neutralized CCV strain 1-71, FECV strain 79-1683 and FIPv strain 79-1146, but 6 FIPV type I' i did not neutralize viruses. These results indicated that there are at least 3 epitopes involved in the neutralization of FIPV type II strain 79-1146 and that these epitopes are absent in FIPV type I viruses but present in FECV strain 79-1683, which does not induce feline infection. peritonitis, TGEV strains TO-163 and SH and CCV strain 1-71. These results demonstrate the existence of 2 FIPV serotypes that are clearly distinguishable by neutralization testing using MAbs.
authors: Hohdatsu, T.;Okada, S.;Koyama, H.

title: Nipah virus classification via fractal size and shannon entropy
authors: Holden, T.;Gadura, N.;Cheung, E.

title: Exploring the phylodynamics of RNA viruses
authors: Holmes, E. C.;Grenfell, B. T.

title: Tembusu-like flavivirus (Perak virus) as a cause of neurological disease outbreaks in young Peking ducks
abstract: neurological disease of young Pekin ducks characterized by ataxia, lameness and paralysis was observed in several duck farms in Malaysia in 2012. Gross pathological lesions were absent or inconsistent in the majority of cases, but severe and consistent microscopic lesions were found in the brain. and spinal cord characterized by non-purulent panencephalomyelitis. Several virus isolates were obtained in cell cultures (Vero and DF-1) inoculated with brain homogenates of affected ducks and in embryonated duck eggs. After exclusion of other viruses, isolates were identified as flavivirus by flavivirus-specific reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) experiments. Subcutaneous or intramuscular vaccination of 2-week-old Pekin ducks with a flavivirus isolate resulted in typical clinical signs and histological lesions in the brain and spinal cord. Inoculated virus was detected by RT-PCR from organ samples of ducks with clinical signs and histological lesions. With a delay of several days, disease was also observed in intermingled contact control birds. Phylogenetic analysis of the NS5 and E gene sequences proved that the isolates are representatives of a new phylogenetic group within the XI (Ntaya virus group) of the Flavivirus genus. This Malaysian Duck Tempus Virus (DTMUV), named Perak virus, has moderate genomic RNA sequence similarity to a related DTMUV identified in China. In our experiment, the Malaysian DTMUV strain can be transmitted in the absence of mosquito vectors. These findings may have implications for the control and prevention of this emerging group of flaviviruses.
authors: Homonnay, Z. G.;KovÃ¡cs, E. W.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Albert, M.;FehÃ©r, E.;MatÃ³, T.;TatÃ¡r-Kis, T.;Palya, V.

title: The high genetic variation of viruses of the Nairovirus genus reflects the diversity of dominant tick hosts.
abstract: The genus Nairovirus (family Bunyaviridae) contains seven serogroups of 34 predominantly tick-borne viruses, including several associated with severe human and livestock diseases [for example, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) and Nairobi sheep disease (NSD), respectively]. Prior to this report, no comparative genetic studies or molecular detection assays have been developed for this virus genus. To characterize at least one representative from each of the seven serogroups, reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) primers targeting the L polymerase-encoding region of the RNA genome of these viruses were successfully designed based on the conserved amino acid motifs contained within. predicted catalytic core region. Sequence analysis revealed that nairoviruses are a highly diverse group, exhibiting nucleotide and amino acid identity differences of up to 39.4% and 46.0%, respectively. Virus genetic associations correlated well with serological groupings and tick host associations. The hosts of these viruses include both hard (family Ixodidae) and soft (family Argasidae) ticks. Virus phylogenetic analysis reveals two major monophyletic groups: hard tick and soft tick vector viruses. In addition, viruses vectored by ticks of the genus Ornithodoros, Carios, and Argas also form three separate monophyletic lineages. The striking similarities between tick and nairovirus phylogenies are consistent with the possible co-evolution of viruses and tick hosts. Fossil and phylogenetic data, placing the hard tick-soft tick divergence between 120 and 92 million years ago, point to an ancient origin for viruses of the Nairovirus genus. Â© 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Honig, J. E.;Osborne, J. C.;Nichol, S. T.

title: Rapid detection, characterization and enumeration of foodborne pathogens
abstract: As food safety management develops further, microbiological testing will continue to play an important role in assessing whether the Food Safety Goals are being met. However, traditional microbiological culture-based methods are limited, particularly in their ability to provide timely data. This review discusses the reasons for the increasing interest in rapid methods, current developments in the field, research needs and future trends. The advent of biotechnology introduced new technologies that led to rapid diagnostic methods and changing food testing practices. Rapid methods consist of many different detection technologies, from simple differential coating media to the use of complex instruments, including specialized enzyme substrates, antibodies and DNA. The use of non-invasive sampling techniques for live animals came into focus especially with the 1990s epidemic of bovine spongiform encephalopathy associated with the Creutzfeldt Jakob Disease epidemic in humans. Serology is still an important tool in preventing foodborne pathogens from entering human food through meat and milk from animals. One of the primary uses of rapid methods is rapid screening of large numbers of samples, most of which are expected to test negative, resulting in faster product availability. This has been the main strength of rapid methods such as real-time Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR). Enrichment PCR, where the primary culture broth is tested in PCR, is the most common approach in rapid testing. Recent reports show that it is possible to both enrich a sample and enumerate with pathogen-specific real-time PCR if the enrichment time is short. This can be particularly useful where food manufacturers are asking about the pathogen level in a contaminated product. Another important issue is automation; key factors here are miniaturization and multiple testing; this means that not only is one device flexible enough to test many pathogens, but many pathogens can be detected with a single test. The review is mainly based on the author's scientific work contributing to the field with the following new developments: (i) serological testing for large-scale screening, surveillance, or eradication programs, (ii) detection of Salmonella otherwise on the same day (iii) pathogen following a short log-phase enrichment counting, (iv) detection of foodborne pathogens in air samples, and finally (v) biological monitoring of pathogens based on mathematical modeling even in the absence of isolates. Rapid methods are discussed in a broad global health perspective, in the international food supply, and for improving quantitative microbial risk assessments. The need for quantitative sample preparation techniques, culture-independent, metagenomic-based detection, online monitoring, a global validation infrastructure was emphasized. The cost and ease of use of rapid analysis remain formidable hurdles to overcome. Â© 2011 Author. APMIS © 2011 APMIS.
authors: Hoorfar, J.

title: Biological and biochemical characterization of sheep scrapies in Japan
abstract: Due to the apparent absence of an agent-specific nucleic acid genome, scrapie strains cannot be classified by the genome characterization commonly used for classification of many viruses. However, scrapie strains can be distinguished to some extent by biological features such as infectivity to experimental animals and distribution of neuropathological lesions, and by biochemical features such as molecular mass and relative protease resistance of the disease-specific prion protein isoform (PrPSc). . To pre-characterize the scrapie strains common in Japan, we analyzed the transmissibility of sheep scrapie isolates to mice and the relative proteinase K (PK) resistance of the corresponding PrPSc. The results show that Japanese scrapie strains can be divided into at least three groups based on biological and biochemical characteristics. The first group includes isolates with PrPSc that cause disease in mice with an incubation period of âˆ¼400 days and have relatively high PK resistance. The isolates of the second group contain PrPSc, which is highly resistant to PK digestion but poorly transmitted to mice. The last group consists of PrPSc-associated isolates that cause disease in mice with an incubation period of less than 300 days and have reduced PK resistance. There have been sporadic cases of sheep stripping in Japan since 1982, with only âˆ¼60 officially reported so far. However, the diversity of scrapi strains in the field suggested by our data raises concern that a scrapi strain similar to the parent agent of bovine spongiform encephalopathy may exist or arise in Japan. Therefore, continuous surveillance of the scrapie will be required to prevent further spread of the scrapie not only among the sheep population but to other species and to eliminate any potential sheep scrapie risk to public health.
authors: Horiuchi, M.;Nemoto, T.;Ishiguro, N.;Furuoka, H.;Mohri, S.;Shinagawa, M.

title: Rabies in Iraq: Trends in Human Cases 2001-2010 and Characterization of Animal Rabies Strains in Baghdad
abstract: Rabies control requires the consistent supply of reliable sources, constructive cooperation between veterinary and public health authorities, and systematic surveillance. These are challenging in all circumstances, but especially during combat. Here, we describe current human rabies surveillance data in Iraq, the results of renewed sampling for rabies in animals, and the initial genetic characterization of circulating rabies strains from Iraq. Human rabies can be reported, with cases reported since 2003 and a marked increase in Baghdad between 2009 and 2010. These changes coincide with the increasing number of dog bites reported. There is no laboratory confirmation of any disease or virus characterization and no systematic surveillance for rabies in animals. To address these issues, brain samples were collected from pets in the Baghdad area and tested for rabies. Three of the 40 brain samples were positive for fluorescent antibody testing and for rabies virus (RABV) using semi-nested RT-PCR. Bayesian phylogenetic analysis using partial nucleoprotein gene sequences derived from the samples showed that the viruses belonged to a single virus variant and shared a common ancestor with viruses from neighboring countries 22 years ago (95% HPD 14-32). These include countries in the west, north and east of Iraq, some with other virus variants circulating simultaneously. These results suggest possible multiple entries of rabies into the Middle East and regular cross-border movement of the disease. 4000 years after the original description of the disease consistent with rabies, animals and humans still die from this preventable and neglected zoonosis. Â© 2013 Horton et al.
authors: Horton, D. L.;Ismail, M. Z.;Siryan, E. S.;Wali, A. R. A.;Ab-dulla, H. E.;Wise, E.;Voller, K.;Harkess, G.;Marston, D. A.;McElhinney, L. M.;Abbas, S. F.;Fooks, A. R.

title: A new family of vertebrate viruses: Toroviridae
abstract: The proposed Toroviridae family is characterized by enveloped, peplomer-bearing particles containing an elongated tubular nucleocapsid with helical symmetry. The capsid can be bent into an open torus, giving the virion a biconcave disc or kidney-shaped morphology (largest diameter 120-140 nm), or the capsid can be flat, resulting in a rod-shaped particle (35 x 170 nm). Morphogenesis occurs by budding of preformed nucleocapsids, mainly from the membranes of the Golgi system and the rough endoplasmic reticulum. The proposed Berne virus as the family prototype contains a single polyadenylated helix of infectious positive sense RNA, M(r) approximately 6.5 x 10 6 . The RNA is surrounded by a major nucleocapsid phosphoprotein (M(r) approximately 20,000), which is surrounded by a membrane containing a major protein (M(r) 22,000) and a phosphoprotein (M(r) 37,000). Viral peplomers about 20 nm long carry markers for neutralization and hemagglutination; They are formed by a polydisperse N-glycosylated protein (M(r) 75,000-100,000). In infected cells, four major subgenomic polyadenylated RNAs were identified with 3.0, 0.71, 0.46 and 0.26 x 106 M(r)s. Torovirus replication is inhibited by actinomycin D, alpha-amanitin and UV pre-irradiation of the host cell. light. All toroviruses identified so far cause enteric infections and are probably transmitted by the fecal-oral route. Serological relationships between equine, bovine and human toroviruses have been demonstrated.
authors: Horzinek, M. C.;Flewett, T. H.;Saif, L. J.

title: Prevalence of bovine viral diarrhea virus in dairy cattle herds in eastern China
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is a worldwide spread pestivirus that infects cattle and other ruminants; however, there are few reports of epidemiological investigation of BVDV in eastern China. In this study, bulk tank milk from 36 dairy herds in eastern China was subjected to serological studies, 77.8% of herds were positive for BVDV antibody. The individual animal status in the two herds was further investigated by collecting blood samples, with a positive rate of 49.74% and 24.64%, and the mean positive rate of calves, heifers and lactating cows was 15.94%, 40.16% and 41.7%, respectively. In addition, a clinical survey was conducted on 8170 dairy cattle from 36 herds for diarrhea syndrome, respiratory problems and reproductive failure, and the pathogens of all clinical cattle were further investigated. The results showed that BVDV is one of the main pathogens that infects animals by combining them with various other viruses. Nine BVDV strains were subsequently isolated; Phylogenetic analysis showed that the BVDV subtypes currently circulating in eastern China are BVDV 1a and BVDV 1c. In addition, 1.86% of the 377 cows tested tested positive for the BVDV antigen. This study provided the basis for further studies on vaccination and control strategies for BVDV in eastern China.
authors: Hou, P.;Zhao, G.;Wang, H.;He, H.

title: Transcriptome Analysis of Rabbit Spleen Infected with Porcine Cholera Lapinizing Virus Based on High-throughput Sequencing Technology
abstract: In the current study, rabbit spleen was analyzed 12 hours, 24 hours, 30 hours, 36 hours and 48 hours after infection with porcine cholera lapinized virus (strain C) using high-throughput sequencing. The rabbit genome was used as a reference to identify differentially expressed genes (DEGs) at different time points post-infection. The top 10 DEGs were filtered by importance and we searched for their biological functions through the Uniprot and NCBI databases. At the first three time points, there are 10 co-expressing genes, many of which are associated with immunity and inflammation. The last two time points for the first 10° are the same and B2 M, RLA-DR-ALPHA, CD74 and IGJ are involved in the antiviral immune response. The GO functional annotation revealed that in biological processes, at all time points except 24 hours after infection, the immune response had the most terms, followed by metabolism and regulation. According to the KEGG database, DEGs for 24 hpost infection were enriched for the RIG-I-like receptor signaling pathway, and DEGs for 30 hpost infection were found to have a focal adhesion and ECM-receptor interaction pathway. Moreover, DEGs for 36 el 48hpost infection have seven identical pathways that are directly or indirectly related to the antiviral response. These pathways include the proteasome, lysosome, ribosome, chemokine signaling pathways, B cell receptor signaling pathway, antigen processing and presentation pathway, and Fc gamma R-mediated phagocytosis pathway. These results provide new insights into gene expression in rabbit spleens. - Provides a theoretical basis for further understanding of infection with strain C and the molecular mechanisms by which rabbits adapt to infection with strain C.
authors: Hou, Y.;Zhao, D.;Liu, G.;He, F.;Liu, B.;Fu, S.;Hao, Y.;Zhang, W.

title: Molecular and phylogenetic analyzes of a novel Amphotropic murine leukemia virus (MuLV-1313)
abstract: Background: Amphotropic murine leukemia viruses (MuLV-As) are naturally occurring, exogenously acquired gammaretroviruses endemic to Southern California wild mice. These viruses replicate in vitro in a wide variety of cell types, including human cells, and can cause both hematological and neurological disorders in both wild animals and inbred laboratory mice. Because MuLV-As also exhibit distinct interference and neutralization properties, the envelope proteins of these viruses have been extremely useful for studying virus-host cell interactions and as tools for the transfer of foreign genes into a variety of hosts, including human cells. However, the genomic structure of any of the few known MuLV-A has not been established, and the evolutionary relationship of amphotropic retroviruses to numerous exogenous or endogenous MuLV strains remains unclear. Here, we present the complete genetic makeup of a novel amphotropic virus, designated MuLV-1313, and show that this retrovirus, together with other MuLV-As, belongs to a distinct molecular, biological, and phylogenetic class among MuLV strains isolated from numerous laboratory environments. or wild rats. Results: The host range of MuLV-1313 is similar to previously isolated MuLV-A, except that this virus replicates efficiently in chicken cells as well as in mammals. Compared with the ENV proteins of other MuLV-As (4070A, 1504A and 10A-1), the gp70 protein of MuLV-1313 differs in signal peptides and proline-rich hinge regions. However, the MuLV-1313 envelope protein is completely unrelated to what is present in a globally diverse self and a wide variety of murine retroviruses isolated from wild mice. Genetic analysis of the entire MuLV-1313 genome with dot plot analyzes comparing each nucleotide of one genome with the corresponding nucleotide of the other revealed that the genome of this virus, with the exception of the env gene, was more closely related to the virus. Biologically distinct wild mouse ecotropic retrovirus (Cas-Br-E) isolated from another area of Southern California was isolated according to any of the 15 MuLV strains whose full-length sequences are available in GenBank. This finding was supported by phylogenetic analyzes and hierarchical clustering of the entire genomic sequence of MuLV-1313; this also placed all MULV-A in a genetically distinct category among the large family of retroviruses isolated from a large number of mouse species globally. Similarly, constructing individual dendrograms for each of the Gag, Pol, and Env proteins of MuLV-1313 indicated that amphotropic retroviruses belong to a phylogenetically specific group of gammaretroviruses compared to all known MuLV strains. Conclusion: The molecular, biological, and phylogenetic features of amphotropic retroviruses, including MuLV-1313, are different from a large family of exogenously or endogenously transmitted ecotropic, polytropic, and xenotropic MuLV strains from laboratory and wild mice. Furthermore, both a naturally occurring amphotropic and a biologically distinct ecotropic retrovirus of Southern California hyrax are more closely related to each other in the evolutionary tree than any other mammalian gammaretrovirus that shows a common origin of these viruses. This is the first report of a complete genomic analysis of a unique phylogenetically distinct group of amphotropic viruses. © 2006 Howard et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Howard, T. M.;Sheng, Z.;Wang, M.;Wu, Y.;Rasheed, S.

title: Avian hepatitis E virus in chickens, Taiwan, 2013
abstract: A previously unidentified strain of avian hepatitis E virus (aHEV) is now endemic among chickens in Taiwan. The analysis showed that the virus was 81.5%-86.5% similar to other aHEVs. In Taiwan, aHEV infection has been reported in chickens not exposed to aHEV, suggesting transmission from asymptomatic cases or repeated administration through an unknown common source(s).
authors: Hsu, I. W.;Tsai, H. J.

title: Detection of various novel astroviruses from small mammals in China
abstract: Astroviruses infect humans and many animal species, causing gastroenteritis. To gain a comprehensive understanding of the distribution and genetic diversity of the astrovirus in small mammals, we tested 968 anal swabs from 39 animal species, most of them bats and rodents. We detected several astroviruses in 10 bat species, including known bat astroviruses and numerous new viruses. Meanwhile, new groups of astroviruses were identified in three wild rodent species, and a remarkably high genetic diversity of astroviruses appeared in Eothenomys cachinus. We detected astroviruses in captive-bred hedgehogs, and an almost full-length genome sequence was determined for one strain. Phylogenetic analysis of the entire ORF2 sequence suggested that this strain may have a common ancestor with porcine astrovirus type 2. Also, to the best of our knowledge, this study reports the first discovery of astroviruses in shrews and pikas. Our results provide new insights into understanding these small mammals as the natural reservoir of astroviruses.
authors: Hu, B.;Chmura, A. A.;Li, J. L.;Zhu, G. J.;Desmond, J. S.;Zhang, Y. Z.;Zhang, W.;Epstein, J. H.;Daszak, P.;Shi, Z. L.

title: Surveillance of Avian influenza virus and Newcastle disease virus (NDV) and characterization of Class I NDV isolates in commercial breeding farm in China
abstract: To determine the true prevalence of avian influenza virus (AIV) and Newcastle disease virus (NDV) in ducks in Shandong province, China, extensive surveillance studies were conducted from July 2007 to September 2008 in breeding ducks of a busy farm. Cloacal and tracheal swabs were obtained from 30 randomly selected birds that appeared healthy each month. While all swabs were negative for recovery of influenza A virus, 87.5% of tracheal swabs and 100% of cloacal swabs collected in September 2007 were positive for Newcastle disease virus isolation. Several NDV isolates were obtained from tracheal and cloacal swabs of apparently healthy ducks. All isolates were apathogenic as determined by MDT and ICPI. The HN gene and the variable region of the F gene (nt 47-420) of four randomly selected isolates were sequenced. A 374 bp region of the F gene and the full length of the HN gene were used for phylogenetic analysis. Four isolates were identified as the same isolate based on their 99.2-100% nucleotide sequence identities, showing a closer phylogenetic relationship to lentogenic Class I viruses. While there was a 1.9-9.9% nucleotide difference between isolates and other Class I viruses in the variable region of the F gene (nt 47-420), there was a 38.5-41.2% nucleotide difference between isolates and Class II viruses. The amino acid sequences of the F protein cleavage sites in these isolates were 112-ERQERL-117. The full length of the HN gene of these isolates was 1851 bp, which encodes 585 amino acids. Homology analysis of the nucleotide sequence of the HN gene showed that there were 2.0-4.2% nucleotide differences between isolates and other Class I viruses, and 29.5-40.9% differences between isolates and Class II viruses. The results show that these isolates are not phylogenetically related to the vaccine strain (LaSota). This work adds to the understanding of the ecology of influenza viruses and Newcastle disease viruses in ducks and highlights the need for continued surveillance at times of an ongoing and expanding AIV and NDV epidemic. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Hu, B.;Huang, Y.;He, Y.;Xu, C.;Lu, X.;Zhang, W.;Meng, B.;Yan, S.;Zhang, X.

title: Genetic diversity and positive selection analysis of the classical swine fever virus envelope protein gene E2 under C-strain vaccination in eastern China.
abstract: Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) causes an economically important and highly contagious swine disease worldwide. C-strain vaccination is one of the most effective ways to control this disease. Since 2014, sporadic outbreaks of CSF have occurred in some C-strain vaccinated provinces of China. To decipher the disease etiology, 25 CSFV E2 genes from 169 clinical samples were cloned and sequenced. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that all 25 isolates belonged to subgenotype 2.1. Twenty-three of the 25 isolates clustered in a newly identified subgenotype, 2.1d, and shared some consistent molecular features. To determine whether the entire E2 gene is under positive selection pressure, we used a site-by-site analysis to identify specific codons that underwent evolutionary selection, and seven positively selected codons were found. Three positively selected regions (amino acids 17, 34 and 72) were identified in the antigenicity-related B/C domains of the amino terminal half of the E2 protein. In addition, another positively selected region (amino acid 200) exhibited a polarity change from hydrophilic to hydrophobic, which may alter the antigenicity and virulence of CSFV. The results show that CSFV strains circulating in Shandong province mostly clustered in subgenotype 2.1d. Furthermore, identification of these positively selected regions may help reveal molecular determinants of virulence or pathogenesis and clarify the driving force of CSFV evolution in eastern China.
authors: Hu, D.;Lv, L.;Gu, J.;Chen, T.;Xiao, Y.;Liu, S.

title: Virome analysis for identification of novel mammalian viruses in bats from southeastern China
authors: Hu, D.;Zhu, C.;Wang, Y.;Ai, L.;Yang, L.;Ye, F.;Ding, C.

title: Deep sequencing of the mouse lung transcriptome reveals prominent expression of long noncoding RNA associated with high virulence of H5N1 avian influenza virus in mice.
abstract: Long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) play numerous key regulatory roles in a variety of biological processes. However, their functions in influenza A virus (IAV) pathogenicity remain largely unexplored. Here, we systematically compared the complete transcriptome response of mouse lung infected with highly pathogenic (A/Chicken/Jiangsu/k0402/2010, CK10) or non-pathogenic (A/Goose/Jiangsu/k0403/) using next-generation sequencing. 2010, GS10) H5N1 virus. A total of 126 significantly differentially expressed (SDE) lncRNAs from three copies were determined to be associated with high virulence of CK10, while 94 SDE lncRNAs were determined to be associated with GS10. Functional category analysis suggested that mRNAs co-expressed with CK10-regulated SDE lncRNAs were highly associated with abnormal and uncontrolled inflammatory responses. Further canonical pathway analysis also confirmed that these targets are highly rich for inflammatory pathways. Moreover, mRNA co-expressed with 9 lncRNAs and 17 lncRNAs associated with multiple targeted genes was successfully validated by qRT-PCR. A targeted lncRNA (NONMMUT011061) that was markedly activated and correlated with multiple mRNAs was selected for further analysis, including prediction of transcription factors, potential interacting proteins, genomic location, coding ability, and secondary structure construction. More importantly, NONMMUT011061 was markedly induced during highly pathogenic H5N8 virus infection in mice, suggesting a potential universal role of NONMMUT011061 in the pathogenesis of different H5 IAV. Altogether, these results provide a subset of lncRNAs that may play important roles in the pathogenesis of influenza virus and add lncRNAs to the broad repertoire of host factors used by IAV for infection and persistence.
authors: Hu, J.;Hu, Z.;Wang, X.;Gu, M.;Gao, Z.;Liang, Y.;Ma, C.;Liu, X.;Hu, S.;Chen, S.;Peng, D.;Jiao, X.;Liu, X.

title: Cloning and sequence analysis of Duck hepatitis B virus genome from Hubei brown ducks
abstract: Seventy serum samples were collected from adult brown ducks in Hubei to elucidate native Duck hepatitis B virus (DHBV) infection in DHBV and to characterize the genome structure of DHBV. The complete genome of the DHBV strain was amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and cloned into T vector and sequenced. The results showed that the natural infection rate of DHBV in Hubei was 10%. The PCR isolated DHBV genome (GenBank accession number DQ276978) had 3 024 nucleotides with three overlapping reading frames encoding surface, core and polymerase proteins, respectively. Comparison of the genome sequences of this strain with 17 DHBV strains from GenBank revealed an identity between 89.3% and 93.5% at the nucleotide level. The amino acid sequences of the S protein, the core protein, and the functional domain of the Pol protein were highly segregated among all these DHBV strains. This Hubei strain was found to share more signature amino acids in the polymerase genes with the "Chinese" DHBV strains than with those of the "Western" country strains. This finding was also supported by a phylogenetic tree analysis. Therefore, this Hubei DHBV strain should be classified as a subtype of Chinese strains.
authors: Hu, Q.;Lei, Y. C.;Zhang, Z. Z.;Tian, Y. J.;Zhang, Z. M.;Li, L.;Xia, J. B.;Lu, M. J.;Yang, D. L.

title: Computational study of the interdependence between hemagglutinin and neuraminidase of the pandemic 2009 H1N1
abstract: Influenza type A viruses are divided into subtypes on the basis of two surface proteins, hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA). The HA protein facilitates viral attachment and entry into a host cell, and the NA protein aids in the release of viral progeny from the infected cell. The complementary roles of HA and NA require cooperation with important implications for viral replication and fitness. HA protein from early strains of the pig-borne pandemic 2009 H1N1 binds preferentially to human-type receptors, with weak binding to avian-type receptors. This virus caused several human deaths in Texas, USA in December 2013, which motivated us to investigate changes in genetic traits that could contribute to the virus's increased virulence. Our time-series analysis on strains of this virus collected from 2009 to 2013 implied that the HA binding preference of this virus in the US, Europe and Asia is characteristic of the porcine H1N1 virus since 2009. However, the trait of seasonal human H1N1 and binding avidity for avian-type receptors were on a steady rise, with a clear increase in 2013 with American strains having the sharpest fluctuation. The first change could improve viral transmission and replication in humans, and the second might increase its ability to cause deep infection in the lungs, which could explain the recent human deaths in Texas. In light of HA and NA co-adaptation and evolutionary interactions, we also investigated the NA activity of this virus to reveal the functional balance between HA and NA during virus evolution. Finally, we identified amino acid substitutions critical to the evolution observed in the HA and NA of the virus.
authors: Hu, W.

title: Multiplex PCR for Simultaneous Detection of Three Zoonotic Parasites Ancylostoma ceylanicum, A. caninum and Giardia lamblia Assemblage A
abstract: Ancylostoma ceylanicum, A. caninum, and Giardia lamblia community A are common intestinal parasites of dogs and cats; they can also infect humans and cause parasitic zoonoses. In this study, a multiplex PCR method was developed for the simultaneous identification and detection of these three zoonotic parasites. Three pairs of specific primers were designed based on the ITS sequence of A. ceylanicum and A. caninum and the TPI gene of G. lamblia found in GenBank. A multiplex PCR reaction system was established by optimizing the reaction condition, and also a series of tests regarding sensitivity, specificity and clinical application were performed.
authors: Hu, W.;Wu, S.;Yu, X.;Abullahi, A. Y.;Song, M.;Tan, L.;Wang, Z.;Jiang, B.;Li, G.

title: Rapid genome sequencing and characterization of novel avian influenza A H7N9 virus directly from clinical specimen by semiconductor sequencing.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Recent outbreaks of severe pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome have attracted great public attention. Rapid and accurate diagnosis of the causative agent is the key to an adequate response to suspected outbreaks. OBJECTIVES: We present a case highlighting the potential of semiconductor sequencing to rapidly identify novel virus genome sequences. STUDY DESIGN: We developed a method for rapid de novo assembly of novel influenza A H7N9 virus genome directly from a patient's tracheal aspirate using semiconductor sequencer without culture and pre-sequence information. Also, characteristic amino acids were analyzed and phylogenetic analysis was performed for key genes of influenza A virus. RESULTS: Deep sequencing yielded 435,239 reads assigned to H7N9 viruses with an average length of 172 bp, accounting for 18.6% of the total reads (2,339,680). The complete genome of the virus was obtained by de novo splicing within 2 days. The genomic average depth of coverage of Ion Torrent PGM was up to 5679 times. Selected characteristic amino acids were observed, and phylogenetic analyzes showed that the novel H7 virus was genetically close to the 2011 duck H7N3 viruses in Zhejiang. The new N9 sequences were closely related to the gene sequences of N9 derived from H11N9 ducks in Jiangxi in 2011 and H2N9 sequences from Hong Kong in China in 2010 and may therefore have a common ancestry. CONCLUSIONS: Array-independent semiconductor sequencing is a powerful tool for investigating the spread of a new pathogen.
authors: Hu, Y.;Ren, X.;Li, L.;Xiao, Y.;Dong, J.;Sun, L.;Zhu, Y.;Yang, F.;Zhang, X.;Jin, Q.

title: Different microRNA alterations contribute to various outcomes following EV71 and CA16 infections: Information from high-throughput sequencing in rhesus monkey peripheral blood mononuclear cells
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) are the predominant pathogens of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). Although these viruses show genetic homology, there are some differences between the clinical manifestations caused by the two viruses. Furthermore, the underlying mechanisms leading to these differences remain unclear. microRNAs (miRNAs) are involved in numerous biological or pathological processes, including host responses to viral infections. Here, we focused on differences in miRNA expression patterns in rhesus monkey peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) infected with EV71 and CA16 at various time points using high-throughput sequencing. The results showed that 106 known and 13 novel miRNAs differed significantly, among which 32 key miRNAs for target prediction presented opposite trends in samples infected with EV71 and CA16. GO and pathway analysis of predicted targets showed enrichment in 14 biological processes, 10 molecular functions, 8 cellular components and 104 pathways. Next, regulatory networks of miRNA-transcription factors, miRNA-predicted targets, miRNA-GOs and miRNA-pathways were constructed to reveal the complex regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs during the infection phase. Ultimately, we analyzed hierarchical GO categories of predicted targets involved in immune system processes, showing that innate and adaptive immunity can be quite different following EV71 and CA16 infections. In conclusion, this report is the first to describe miRNA expression profiles in EV71 and CA16-infected PBMCs using high-throughput sequencing. Our findings may provide a valuable basis for further studies on the regulatory roles of miRNAs related to different immune responses induced by EV71 and CA16 infections.
authors: Hu, Y.;Song, J.;Liu, L.;Li, J.;Tang, B.;Wang, J.;Zhang, X.;Zhang, Y.;Wang, L.;Liao, Y.;He, Z.;Li, Q.

title: Comparative analysis of microRNAs in response to EV71 and CA16 infection in human bronchial epithelial cells by high-throughput sequencing to reveal different infection mechanisms.
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), mainly caused by Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) infections, exhibited significantly different clinical manifestations. However, the factors underlying these differences remain unclear. Recently, the functions of microRNAs (miRNAs) in pathogen-host interactions have been highlighted. Here, we have performed comprehensive miRNA profiling at multiple time points using high-throughput sequencing in human bronchial epithelial (16HBE) cells infected with EV71 and CA16. The results showed that 154 known and 47 novel miRNAs exhibited remarkable differences in expression. Of these, 65 miRNAs, including 58 known and 7 novel miRNAs, showed opposite trends in samples infected with EV71 and CA16. Next, we searched further for target prediction, focusing mainly on 56 known differentially expressed miRNAs. GO and pathway analysis of these targets showed enrichment of 18 biological processes, 7 molecular functions, 1 cellular component and 123 pathways. Among these pathways, Cadherin signaling pathway, Wnt signaling pathway and angiogenesis showed significant changes. The regulatory networks of these miRNAs with predicted targets, GOs, pathways and transcription factors were identified, suggesting that miRNAs exhibit complex regulatory mechanisms during the infection phase. In conclusion, we specifically analyzed hierarchical GO categories of adhesion-related predicted targets. The results showed that the differential changes induced by EV71 and CA16 infection may be partially related to airway epithelial barrier function. Taken together, our data provide useful information that helps elucidate different host-pathogen interactions following EV71 and CA16 infection and may offer new therapeutic targets for these infections.
authors: Hu, Y.;Song, J.;Liu, L.;Li, J.;Tang, B.;Zhang, Y.;Wang, J.;Wang, L.;Fan, S.;Feng, M.;Li, Q.

title: Characterization of genes encoding complete US10, SORF3 and US2 proteins from duck enteritis virus
abstract: Based on the understanding that analysis on the unique short (US) region of duck enteritis virus (DEV) can contribute to the recognition of molecular characterization and evolution of DEV, the study includes a 5,121-bp fragment US10, which contains three genes encoding the entire unique short region. open reading frame (SORF) 3 and US2 proteins were amplified from the DEV (C-KCE) genome. The transcriptional orientation of US10 and SORF3 was tail-to-tail, and SORF3 and US2 were the same. Potential core promoters and polyadenylation (poly(A)) sites were predicted for US10, SORF3 and US2, and also confirmed by polymerase chain reaction. Phylogenetic analysis for the three complete coding sequences showed that DEV is more closely related to avian herpesviruses, particularly Mardivirus, and should be classified into a separate genus of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Hu, Y.;Zhou, H.;Yu, Z.;Chen, H.;Jin, M.

title: MicroRNA Expression Profiles of Swine Kidney 15 Cell Lines Infected with Swine Outbreak Diahorrhea Virus
abstract: To investigate the effect of swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) on microRNA expression profiles of porcine kidney 15 cells (PK-15), total RNA was isolated from PK-15 cells with or without PEDV infection. We then obtained the miRNAs using solexa sequencing technology and analyzed these differentially expressed miRNAs. Heatmap cluster analysis and GO (ontology, GO) (Gene function, MF, Molecular) analysis were performed on key differences in miRNA expression, and 10 key differences in miRNA expression were selected by RT-qPCR. The result showed that the expression level of 214 kinds of microRNAs (miRNAs) was significantly different in PEDV-infected cells compared with normal PK-15 cells. Among them, 175 kinds of miRNAs were significantly up-regulated, while 39 kinds of miRNAs were significantly down-regulated. Moreover, the qPCR results of expression trends of miRNA were similar to those of solexa sequencing. Heatmap cluster analysis showed that the vast majority of viral groups were differentially expressed in miRNA compared to the control group, Go analysis showed miRNAs combination, binding protein, protein kinase activity, transfer enzyme activity, phosphorus-containing radical transfer, phosphotransferase enzyme activity and other biological effects. The miRNA-confirmed expression trends of RT-qPCR were consistent with the high-throughput sequencing results. The results showed that swine epidemic diarrhea virus infection had a significant effect on the level of miRNA expression in PK-15 cells, thus providing a new insight for further study of miRNA preparation for PEDV therapy.
authors: Huang, J.;Lang, Q.;Li, X.;Xu, Z.;Zhu, L.;Zhou, Y.

title: Mock viral replication is inhibited by a novel miR-21 target
abstract: Pseudorabies virus (PRV) is a porcine virus classified as a member of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily of Herpesviridae. Recent studies have confirmed that viruses regulate gene expression in host cells. Genes commonly affected include oxidative stress response genes, genes involved in the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase/Protein Kinase B (PI3K/Akt) signaling pathway, and genes related to interferon and interleukin. However, post-transcriptional regulation of host genes following PRV infection has so far been unclear. In this study, we used miRNA microarray approaches to evaluate miRNA expression in PRV-infected porcine kidney 15 cell lines (PK-15) and observed that miR-21 was highly expressed 12 hours after cells were infected with PRV. We also identified chemokine (CXC motif) ligand 10 (CXCL10), also called interferon-Î³-inducible protein-10 (IP-10), as a novel target gene of miR-21. IP-10 was downregulated 4 h after PRV infection. PRV replication was significantly inhibited by IP-10 overexpression. © 2014 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Huang, J.;Ma, G.;Fu, L.;Jia, H.;Zhu, M.;Li, X.;Zhao, S.

title: Detection of a novel pig parvovirus, PPV4, in Chinese pig herds
abstract: To determine whether the novel porcine parvovirus type 4 (PPV4) recently reported in America is prevalent in China, a set of specific primers were designed for molecular investigation of PPV4 among clinical samples collected from various provinces of China between 2006 and 2010. and used. The results showed that PPV4 was found in 2.09% (12/573) among clinical samples studied in Chinese pig herds and 0.76% (1/132) among samples from healthy animals. We also note that PPV4 was not detected in samples taken before 2009. Analysis of the coding sequences showed that the Chinese and American PPV4 genome sequences were closely related with greater than 99% nucleotide sequence identity. Similar to a previous study, viral genomes were detected in head-to-head configuration of various lengths of the noncoding region. Our findings confirmed that PPV4 is a unique virus recently discovered in pigs. Phylogenetically, PPV4 is most closely related to bovine parvovirus 2 (BPV2, which is not Bocavirus and not assigned to any Parvovirinae genus), and shares restricted ORF1 (33.6%) and ORF2 (24.5%) amino acid identity. Regarding genome structure and organization, PPV4 encodes an ORF3 resembling the genus Bocavirus in the middle of the viral genome. However, the PPV4 ORF3-encoded protein shares minimal amino acid identity with the ORF3-encoded proteins of the Bocavirus genus. © 2010 Huang et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Huang, L.;Zhai, S. L.;Cheung, A. K.;Zhang, H. B.;Long, J. X.;Yuan, S. S.

title: Differences in gut microbiota between piglets and piglets not infected with swine epidemic diarrhea virus
abstract: Pig epidemic diarrhea, which is a catastrophic gastrointestinal disease, causes great financial losses due to its high infectivity, morbidity and mortality in lactating piglets, despite the development and implementation of various vaccines. In this study, high-throughput sequencing was used to investigate differences in gut microbiota between uninfected piglets and piglets infected with swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV). The results revealed that the small intestinal microbiota of PEDV-infected lactating piglets showed low diversity and was dominated by Proteobacteria (49.1%). In addition, the composition of the small intestinal microbiota of PEDV-infected suckling piglets differed markedly from that of uninfected piglets. Some of the taxa, which differed abundantly between uninfected piglets and PEDV-infected piglets, were associated with amino acid metabolism as determined by cellular transport and catabolism, energy metabolism, biosynthesis of other secondary metabolites, and estimation of microbial function based on bacteria. 16S rRNA gene. Therefore, tuning of the gut microbiota may be a promising method for the prevention or treatment of PEDV.
authors: Huang, M. Z.;Wang, S. Y.;Wang, H.;Cui, D. A.;Yang, Y. J.;Liu, X. W.;Kong, X. J.;Li, J. Y.

title: A Selective Bottleneck Shapes the Evolutionary Mutant Spectrum of Enterovirus A71 during Human Viral Spread
abstract: RNA viruses accumulate mutations to adapt rapidly to environmental changes. Enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) causes a variety of clinical manifestations, sometimes with serious neurological complications. However, the mechanism by which EV-A71 develops in the human body is unclear. Using deep sequencing and haplotype analyzes of viruses from various tissues of an autopsy patient, we sought to define the evolutionary pathway by which enterovirus A71 evolved its suitability to invade the central nervous system in humans. A broad spectrum of mutants with different mutations was observed at the initial sites of infection in the respiratory and digestive systems. After viral invasion, we identified a haplotype switch and dominant haplotype, with glycine at VP1 residue 31 (VP1-31G) in viral particles spread to the integumentary and central nervous systems. In vitro viral growth and fitness assays showed that VP1-31G confers growth and fitness advantage in human neuron cells, whereas VP1-31D confers enhanced replication in human colorectal cells. A higher rate of VP1-31G was also found among fatal cases, suggesting that it may facilitate central nervous system infection in humans. Our data provide a first look at EV-A71-like species from oral tissues to the central nervous system in humans, with broad implications for the surveillance and pathogenesis of this reemerging viral pathogen.IMPORTANCE EV-A71 remains. a worldwide burden for public health. Although EV-A71 is the main etiologic agent of hand, foot and mouth disease, it can cause neurological pulmonary edema, encephalitis and even death, especially in children. Understanding the selection processes that drive dispersal and accurately predicting EV-A71 diversity during invasion in humans is critical for applications in viral pathogenesis and vaccine research. Here we describe a bottleneck of choice that arises in respiratory and digestive tissues. The glycine substitution at VP1 residue 31 helps viruses overcome the bottleneck and invade the central nervous system. This substitution is also advantageous for replication in neuronal cells in vitro. Considering that fatal cases involve increased glycine substitution in VP1-31, we propose that increased prevalence of VP1-31G may alter viral tropism and aid central nervous system invasion. Our findings provide new insights into a dynamic mutant spectral switch that is active during acute viral infection with emerging viral pathogens.
authors: Huang, S. W.;Huang, Y. H.;Tsai, H. P.;Kuo, P. H.;Wang, S. M.;Liu, C. C.;Wang, J. R.

title: Double ATPase and GTPase activity of replication-associated protein (Rep) of beak and feather disease virus
abstract: Background: Psittacine beak and feather disease affects parrots and causes an immunosuppressive disease that is usually characterized by an abnormal shape and growth of the animal's beak, feathers, and paws. Beak and feather disease virus (BFDV) is a single-stranded circular DNA virus and is classified as a member of the Circoviridae family. Two main open reading frames (ORFs) are known to encode a replication-associated (Rep) protein and a capsid-associated (Cap) protein. Methods: The Rep and Cap genes of BFDV were fused with tags and subsequently expressed and purified, respectively. Both ATPase and GTPase activities of the recombinant Rep protein are measured. Substrate and ion preference, optimal conditions, the effects of ATPase and GTPase inhibitors, and the presence of Cap protein on Rep protein's ATPase and GTPase activity are examined. Finally, the effects of the Walker A motif, the Walker B motif and a new GYDG motif of the Rep protein on the ATPase and GTPase activities were investigated by various mutants. Results: Recombinant Rep protein may show ATPase activity and GTPase activity. The rep protein was able to hydrolyze both deoxyribonucleotides and ribonucleotides. The order of substrate preference between nucleoside triphosphates and deoxynucleoside triphosphates was found to be ATP > GTP > CTP >= UTP and dATP > dGTP > dTTP > dCTP, respectively. Both ATPase and GTPase activity of the BFDV Rep protein required magnesium ions, and the presence of calcium ions significantly inhibited the ATPase and GTPase activity of the Rep protein. The optimal temperatures for ATPase activity and GTPase activity were both 56 degrees C, while the optimal pH values were both pH 7.5. Both the ATPase activity and GTPase activity of the BFDV Rep protein were significantly downregulated by the polynucleotides and 36 bp (located at the origin of replication) dsDNA of the BFDV genome. ATPase activity of BFDV Rep protein was found to be more sensitive to sodium azide than sodium orthovanadate and N-ethylmaleimide. Linoleic acid inhibited GTPase activity of Rep protein more potently than dynasore. This suggested that the Rep protein of BFDV should be classified as an F-type ATPase and a polyunsaturated fatty acid sensitive GTPase. In the presence of 10 ng of Cap protein, the ATPase activity and GTPase activity of the BFDV Rep protein were significantly increased. In addition, the BFDV Rep protein contains the Walker A motif, the Walker B motif, and a new GYDG motif. Various deletion and site-directed mutants of the Rep protein affecting these motifs had both ATPase activity and GTPase activity significantly reduced, suggesting that all three motifs contribute to ATPase and GTPase activities; especially. In addition, the ATPase activity and GTPase activity of the deletion mutants of the Rep protein were reversed in the presence of the Cap protein. This is the first example of dual ATPase and GTPase activity reported in the Rep protein of BFDV. (C) 2015 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Huang, S. W.;Liu, H. P.;Chen, J. K.;Shien, Y. W.;Wong, M. L.;Wang, C. Y.

title: Co-infection with multiple strains of bovine papular stomatitis virus
abstract: Bovine papular stomatitis virus (BPSV) infects cattle and occupationally humans. Common subclinical infections, frequent recurrent infections, and persistence of the virus in healthy animals constitute a poorly understood, but possibly complex, scenario of maintenance and transmission of BPSV in nature. Here we report the isolation of multiple BPSV strains co-infecting a single animal. Whole-genome analysis of isolated BPSV strains revealed genomic variability that likely influences virus virulence and infectivity. Also, incompatible phylogenetic relationships between viruses suggested genomic recombination. These results have important implications for parapoxvirus infection biology and virus evolution in nature.
authors: Huang, T.;Tulman, E. R.;Diel, D. G.;Khatiwada, S.;Sims, W.;Edwards, J. F.;Wen, X.;Kutish, G. F.;Rock, D. L.;Delhon, G.

title: Maintenance and reclassification of gull influenza A viruses in Atlantic North America.
abstract: Gulls are important hosts of avian influenza A viruses (AIVs), and gull AIVs often contain gene segments of mixed geographic and host lineage origins. In this study, the prevalence of AIV in Canada, Newfoundland gulls between 2008 and 2011 was analyzed. The overall prevalence was low (30/1645, 1.8%), but there was a significant peak of infection in the fall. Newfoundland gulls had a high seroprevalence of AIV, and 50% of the gulls sampled showed evidence of previous infection. To shed light on the transmission, reclassification and persistence dynamics of gull AIVs in Atlantic North America, the sequences of 16 gull AIVs were identified and analyzed. Reclassification of transcontinental and waterfowl lineages was common. One wholly Eurasian origin AIV and another with transcontinental reassortant waterfowl lineage virus were particularly noteworthy. These geographic and inter-host group transmission patterns highlight the importance of characterization of gull AIVs as part of attempts to understand global AIV dynamics.
authors: Huang, Y.;Wille, M.;Benkaroun, J.;Munro, H.;Bond, A. L.;Fifield, D. A.;Robertson, G. J.;Ojkic, D.;Whitney, H.;Lang, A. S.

title: A 4-year study of avian influenza virus prevalence and subtype diversity in Newfoundland ducks, Canada.
abstract: The Canadian island of Newfoundland is at the eastern tip of North America and has migratory bird links across the North Atlantic Ocean as well as the continental mainland. Here, Newfoundland's St. We report a 4-year epidemiological study of avian influenza virus (AIV) in ducks from the St. The overall prevalence of AIV detection in ducks during this study was 7.2%, with American Black Ducks contributing to the vast majority of samples collected and AIV positives. Baby ducks showed a significantly higher detection rate of AIV (10.6%) compared to adults (3.4%). Seasonally, AIV prevalence rates were higher in the fall (8.4%), but positives were still detected in the winter (4.6%). Preliminary serology tests showed a high incidence of prior AIV infection (20/38, 52.6%). A total of 43 viruses were characterized for HA-NA or HA subtypes; this revealed a wide variety of AIV subtypes and very few subtype recurrences from year to year. Investigation of the movement patterns of ducks in this region showed that this is a largely non-migratory duck population, and this may contribute to the observed pattern of high AIV subtype turnover. Phylogenetic analysis of 4 H1N1 and one H5N4 AIVs showed that these viruses were highly similar to other low pathogenic AIV sequences from North American waterfowl and assigned all gene segments to the American-avian lineage. Notably, H1N1 viruses identified in successive years had homologous genomes. Detection of such homologous AIV genomes over the years has been rare, but demonstrates the role of the environmental reservoir in viral perpetuation.
authors: Huang, Y.;Wille, M.;Dobbin, A.;Robertson, G. J.;Ryan, P.;Ojkic, D.;Whitney, H.;Lang, A. S.

title: Genetic, pathogenic and antigenic diversity of Newcastle disease viruses in Shandong Province, China
abstract: Thirty-one Newcastle disease viruses (NDVs) isolated from domestic and wild birds in Shandong Province, China (2006-2014) were genetically, pathogenic and antigenic characterized. Phylogenetic analysis classified the viruses into a single genotype under Class I and four genotypes under Class II. Nineteen viruses classified in genotype VII of Class II were velogenic, while other viruses were either mesogenic or lentogenic for chickens. Some NDV isolates (17/23) did not show neutralizing reactivity with a monoclonal antibody raised against the HN protein of the LaSota strain, reflecting the mutation in the relevant antigenic epitope. When challenged with two genotype VII NDV isolates, disease development of LaSota-vaccinated SPF chickens was prevented, but virus transmission was detected for at least 5 days after challenge. Circulation of the same NDV isolate for up to 13 years revealed the role of an environmental reservoir in maintaining NDV, reinforcing the importance of strict biosecurity measures in addition to vaccination for disease control.
authors: Huang, Y.;Yang, S.;Hu, B.;Xu, C.;Gao, D.;Zhu, M.;Huang, Q.;Zhang, L.;Wu, J.;Zhang, X.;Khan, M. I.

title: Molecular characterization of a highly pathogenic pig: reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus variant in Hubei, China.
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) has been recognized worldwide as one of the most important pathogens of pigs. In 2006, more than 10 provinces of China experienced an epidemic of epizootic swine disease characterized by high fever, flushed skin, and high morbidity and mortality. From June 2006 to April 2007, we searched some clinical samples in Hubei province by RT-PCR and cloned several major genes shown in this study, the N, GP5 and NSP2 genes. Phylogenetic analysis of these genes revealed that the highly pathogenic PRRSV variant ZB was responsible for the 2006 outbreak of swine disease in Hubei province, similar to variants isolated from other provinces in China, and belonged to the NA-type PRRSV. . In the PRRSV variants, N and GP5 cut approximately 90% identity (sharing only 65% identity with ATCC VR-2332) with some typical NA-type Chinese isolates except the prototypical ATCC VR-2332 and the 2850bp NSP2 gene. All, however, show greater than 97% identity and 97% identity with other highly pathogenic Chinese PRRSV strains. In addition, there are extensive amino acid (aa) mutations in the GP5 protein and 2 deletions in the Nsp2 protein compared with previous isolates. Most of the variants found in the epizootic epidemic of swine diseases in China in 2006 were variants furthest from the typical NA-type PRRSV in the phylogenetic range, and these variations may be responsible for the differences in pathogenicity observed between these variants and the original Chinese PRRSV strains. . Â© Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer-Verlag GmbH 2009.
authors: Huang, Y.;Zhang, B.;Fu, Z. F.;Rayner, S.;Zheng, F. L.;Liang, W. W.;Yang, K. L.;Xu, D. P.;Wang, H. Z.

title: Clinical features and phylogenetic analysis of Coxsackievirus A9 in Northern Taiwan in 2011
abstract: Background: Coxsackievirus A9 (CA9) was one of the most common serotypes of enteroviral infections in Taiwan in 2011. Few studies have focused on the clinical manifestations of CA9 infections, after several patient series were reported in the 1960s and 1970s. Our work explores and deepens current understanding of CA9. Methods: We analyzed clinical presentations of 100 culture-proven CA9-infected patients in 2011 by reviewing their medical records and delineated the CA9 phylogenetic tree. Proven CA9 infections, mean (SD) age 4.6 (3.4) years and male/female ratio 1.9. For clinical manifestations, 96 patients (96%) had fever and the mean (SD) duration of fever was 5.9 (3.4) days. Sixty-one patients (61%) developed a skin rash, and the predominant pattern was a generalized, nonpruritic maculopapular rash without vesicular changes. While most patients showed injected throat, only 19 cases (19%) found oral ulcers, of which 6 were diagnosed with herpangina. Complex cases included: aseptic meningitis (n=8), bronchopneumonia (n=6), acute cerebellitis (n=1), and polio-like syndrome (n=1). Phylogenetic analysis for the current strains of CA9 is closest to the CA9 isolate 27-YN-2008 from the border region of mainland China and Myanmar. Conclusions: During the 2011 outbreak in Taiwan, the most common feature of CA9 was generalized febrile exanthema rather than herpangina or hand. , foot and mouth disease. Considering the possibility of prolonged fever and some complications, caution should be exercised in the evaluation of patients and in estimating the clinical course. Â© 2013 Huang et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Huang, Y. C.;Chu, Y. H.;Yen, T. Y.;Huang, W. C.;Huang, L. M.;Cheng, A. L.;Wang, H. Y.;Chang, L. Y.

title: Multiple infection of porcine Torque teno virus in a single pig and characterization of full-length genomic sequences of four US prototype PTTV strains: inference for genotyping of PTTV.
abstract: Porcine Torque teno virus (PTTV) has recently been shown to contribute in part to the experimental induction of swine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome and post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome in pigs in the United States. Here we report the identification of four different full-length genomic sequences of PTTV strains from a single swine in Virginia. Detailed analyzes of the genomic organization, degree of variability, and features of conserved nucleotide and amino acid motifs of PTTV were performed. The results showed that these four prototype US PTTV strains identified from the same pig represent different genotypes or subtypes, and a revised classification system was subsequently proposed for PPTV. This is the first study to document multiple PTTV infections with different genotypes or subtypes in a single pig. The identification of new PTTV strains from pigs in the United States also paves the way for future disease characterization and genotyping of PTTV. Â© 2009 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Huang, Y. W.;Ni, Y. Y.;Dryman, B. A.;Meng, X. J.

title: Hemagglutinin-Neuraminidase Protein of Newcastle Disease Virus Determines Tropism and Virulence
abstract: The hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) protein of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) plays a crucial role in the infection process. However, the precise contribution of the HN gene to the pathogenesis of NDV is unknown. In this study, the role of the HN gene in NDV virulence was investigated. Using reverse genetic procedures, the HN genes of a virulent recombinant NDV strain, rBeaudette C (rBC) and an avirulent recombinant NDV strain, rLaSota, were altered. The hemadsorption and neuraminidase activities of the chimeric viruses differed significantly from the parent strains, but the heterotypic F and HN pairs were equally effective in promoting fusion. The tissue tropism of viruses was shown to depend on the source of the HN protein. The chimeric virus with the HN protein, derived from the virulent virus, exhibited a tissue preference similar to that of the virulent virus and vice versa. Chimeric viruses with reciprocal HN proteins gained or lost virulence as determined by a standard test of the intracerebral pathogenicity index of chickens and the mean time to death in chicken embryos (a measure designed to classify these viruses); this indicates that it is a function of virulence. Amino acid differences in HN protein. These results are consistent with the hypothesis that the virulence of NDV is multigenic and that F protein cleavage alone does not determine the virulence of a strain.
authors: Huang, Z.;Panda, A.;Elankumaran, S.;Govindarajan, D.;Rockemann, D. D.;Samal, S. K.

title: Comparison of Microbiomes Among Red-winged Mite Populations (Dermanyssus gallinae): Dominance of Bartonella-Like Bacteria
abstract: Blood-feeding red poultry mites (RPM) serve as vectors of pathogenic bacteria and viruses among vertebrate hosts, including wild birds, poultry chickens, mammals, and humans. The microbiome of RPM has not yet been studied with high-throughput sequencing. RPM eggs, larvae and occluded adult/nymph samples from four houses in Czechia were used for microbiome analyzes by Illumina amplicon sequencing of the 16S ribosomal RNA (rRNA) gene V4 region. A laboratory RPM population was used as a positive control for transcriptome analysis by pyro-sequencing with identification of sequences originating from bacteria. Samples of occluded adult/nymph stages had 100 times more copies of 16S rRNA gene copies than egg and larval samples. Microbiome composition differed between the four houses and between observed growth stadiums. In the adult microbiome, the 10 OTUs comprised 90 to 99% of all sequences. Bartonella-like bacteria comprised between 30 and 70% of the sequences in the RPM microbiome and 25% of the bacterial sequences in the transcriptome. Phylogenetic analyzes of 16S rRNA gene sequences revealed two distinct groups of Bartonella-like bacteria forming sister groups: (i) symbiotes of ants; (ii) Bartonella genus. Cardinium, Wolbachia and Rickettsiella sp. found in the microbiomes of all stadiums tested, while Spiroplasma eriocheiris and Wolbachia were identified in the laboratory RPM transcriptome. Microbiomes from eggs, larvae, and engorged adults/nymphs were different. Bartonella-like symbionts were found in all stadiums and sampling sites. Bartonella-like bacteria were the most diversified group within the RPM microbiome. While the presence of identified putative pathogenic bacteria is relevant to human and animal health issues, identification of symbiotic bacteria could lead to new control methods aimed at destabilizing the arthropod host.
authors: Hubert, J.;Erban, T.;Kopecky, J.;Sopko, B.;Nesvorna, M.;Lichovnikova, M.;Schicht, S.;Strube, C.;Sparagano, O.

title: ISOLATION AND CLASSIFICATION OF CATTLE VIRUSES DURING HEALTH HEALTH
authors: Huck, R. A.;Cartwright, S. F.

title: Documentation and classification of oncogenic viruses
authors: Huebner, R. J.

title: Cowpox virus isolate, lethal in humans, shows attenuated phenotype in mice
abstract: We cultured Cowpox virus (CPXV) from skin lesion material of a human patient from Austria. Phylogenetic comparison of the HA-gene revealed a highly homogeneous cluster with other local isolates in recent years, with the A36R-gene mostly related to strains from elephant origin from Germany. Despite causing human disease, the AT/Carinthia/788/07 isolate surprisingly showed a very low virulence in BALB/c mice compared to vaccinia virus upon intranasal inoculation, even at high titers.
