This is in contrast to previous reports on other CPXV isolates. Using shotgun DNA sequencing, several insertions and deletions were found in genes likely involved in host range, immune regulation and established virulence factors. These preliminary data may indicate that CPXV strains with proven pathogenicity for humans may have reduced virulence in mice and vice versa. In addition, low virulence strains may have the advantage of persisting in less dense rodent populations. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Huemer, H. P.;Lassnig, C.;Nowotny, N.

title: Oral fluids as a live animal sample source to evaluate cross-reactivity and cross-protection following intranasal influenza a virus vaccine in pigs.
abstract: There are many antigenically distinct H1 influenza A virus (IAV) variants currently circulating in North American pigs, complicating vaccine development due to the inability to formulate a vaccine with broad cross-protection. Experimentally, live attenuated influenza virus (LAIV) vaccines show increased cross-protection compared to inactivated vaccines. However, there is no standardized assay to predict cross protection following LAIV vaccination. The hemagglutination inhibiting (HI) antibody in serum is the gold standard correlation of protection following IAV vaccine. LAIV vaccine does not induce an intact serum HI antibody titer; however, a local mucosal antibody response occurs. Therefore, there is a need for a source of live animal samples that can be used to evaluate LAIV immunogenicity and cross-protection. Here, we evaluated the use of oral fluids (OF) and nasal wash (NW) collected after IAV vaccination as a live animal sample source in an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) to predict cross-protection compared to conventional serology. Both live virus exposure and LAIV vaccine provided heterologous protection, but protection was the greatest protection against phylogenetically more closely related viruses. IAV-specific IgA was detected in NWand OF samples and was cross-reactive to representative IAV from each H1 cluster. Endpoint titers of cross-reactive IgA in OF from pigs exposed to live virus were associated with heterologous protection. LAIV vaccination provided significant protection, while LAIV immunogenicity was reduced compared to live virus exposure. These data suggest that OF from pigs inoculated with wild-type IAV with surface genes matching the LAIV seed strain can be used in an ELISA to assess the cross-protection and antigenic association of circulating and emerging IAV in the pig.
authors: Hughes, H. R.;Vincent, A. L.;Brockmeier, S. L.;Gauger, P. C.;Pena, L.;Santos, J.;Braucher, D. R.;Perez, D. R.;Loving, C. L.

title: The capsid protein characteristics of cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus and cowpea cowpea mosaic virus confirm the existence of two main subgroups of aphid-borne, legume-infecting potyviruses.
abstract: study on the capsid proteins of different potyviruses infecting legumes using specific monoclonal antibodies on immunoblots of crude extracts from infected plants, the coat protein M(r) of cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CAMV) and cowpea cowpea mosaic virus (BlCMV). revealed that he has 32K and 35K values respectively. Immunoblot comparisons of blCMV, peanut strip mosaic virus (PStV), bean common mosaic virus (BCMV), and azuki bean mosaic virus (AzMV) revealed equal reactivity of 35K coat proteins. Similar comparisons between CAMV and necrotic BCMV strain (NL3 isolate) showed a serological association between 32K coat proteins, the results providing the first evidence of a possible similarity between CAMV and BCMV NL3. Peptides from trypsin digests of coat proteins of many of these legume-infecting potyviruses were analyzed by HPLC. Comparison of peptide profiles confirmed the serological results in distinguishing the two subgroups. The peptide profiles of the coat protein from BICMV, PStV, AzMV and BCMV were almost identical, suggesting that these could be considered strains of a virus. In contrast, the peptide profiles of the various CAMV serotypes and BCMV NL3 differed from the first group and showed limited similarities with each other.
authors: Huguenot, C.;Furneaux, M. T.;Hamilton, R. I.

title: Evidence that cowpea aphid mosaic and cowpea cowpea mosaic viruses are two different potyviruses
abstract: The immunoreactivity of a panel of polyclonal antibodies and monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) against African isolates of potyviruses from cowpea and African yam bean was examined in ELISAs. A serological study involving reference isolates, followed by further characterization in different hosts, resulted in the separation of potyviruses into two different serogroups, one containing blackeye cowpea mosaic virus (B1CMV) and the other cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CAMV). Using biotin-labeled MAbs, B1CMV isolates were further divided into two serotypes and CAMV isolates into five serotypes. Since both B1CMV and CAMV induce a very similar mosaic disease in cowpea, different ELISA procedures using mixed MAbs were evaluated and a single protocol was developed that allows reliable diagnosis of both viruses.
authors: Huguenot, C.;Furneaux, M. T.;Thottappilly, G.;Rossel, H. W.;Hamilton, R. I.

title: Pacific Ocean Virus (POV): a marine viral metagenomic dataset and associated protein clusters for quantitative viral ecology
authors: Hurwitz, B. L.;Sullivan, M. B.

title: Addressing global ruminant agriculture issues by understanding the Romanian microbiome: past, present and future
abstract: The rumen is a complex ecosystem of anaerobic bacteria, protozoa, fungi, methanogenic archaea and phages. These microbes interact closely to break down plant material indigestible by humans while providing metabolic energy to the host and producing methane in the case of archaea. As a result, ruminant animals produce meat and milk rich in high-quality protein, vitamins and minerals and therefore contribute to food security. As the world population is estimated to reach approximately 9.7 billion by 2050, an increase in ruminant production is necessary to meet global protein demand despite limited land availability, while minimizing environmental impact. While challenging, these goals are achievable but depend on our understanding of the rumen microbiome. Attempts to manipulate the rumen microbiome to take advantage of global agricultural challenges have continued for decades with limited success, mostly due to a lack of detailed understanding of this microbiome and our limited ability to culture many of these microbes outside the rumen. The potential to manipulate the rumen microbiome and meet global livestock challenges through the introduction of animal husbandry and dietary interventions in early life have recently emerged as promising new technologies. Our inability to phenotype ruminants in a high-throughput manner has also hampered progress, but the recent increase in "omics" data may allow further development of mathematical models and rumen microbial gene biomarkers as proxies. Advances in computational tools, high-throughput sequencing technologies, and cultivation-independent "omics" approaches continue to revolutionize our understanding of the rumen microbiome. This will ultimately provide the knowledge framework needed to address current and future ruminant livestock problems.
authors: Huws, S. A.;Creevey, C. J.;Oyama, L. B.;Mizrahi, I.;Denman, S. E.;Popova, M.;MuÃ±oz-Tamayo, R.;Forano, E.;Waters, S. M.;Hess, M.;Tapio, I.;Smidt, H.;Krizsan, S. J.;YÃ¡Ã±ez-Ruiz, D. R.;Belanche, A.;Guan, L.;Gruninger, R. J.;McAllister, T. A.;Newbold, C. J.;Roehe, R.;Dewhurst, R. J.;Snelling, T. J.;Watson, M.;Suen, G.;Hart, E. H.;Kingston-Smith, A. H.;Scollan, N. D.;Do Prado, R. M.;Pilau, E. J.;Mantovani, H. C.;Attwood, G. T.;Edwards, J. E.;McEwan, N. R.;Morrisson, S.;Mayorga, O. L.;Elliott, C.;Morgavi, D. P.

title: Sample size calculations for Bayesian estimation of bovine viral-diarrhea-virus infection in cattle herds
abstract: When the prevalence of persistently infected animals in such herds is very small (eg < 1%), we used a Bayesian classification approach to estimate the bovine viral-diarrhea-virus infection status of a herd. An example of the approach is presented using data on cattle herds in Wyoming, USA. The approach uses historical covariate information (serum neutralization titers collected on animals in 16 herds) in a predictive model to classify a future observable herd. Simulations to estimate misclassification probabilities for different misclassification costs and prevalences of infected flocks can be used as a guide for the sample size needed for classification of a future flock. Â© 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Huzurbazar, S.;Van Campen, H.;McLean, M. B.

title: High diversity and potential translocation of DNA viruses in ballast water
abstract: Ballast water is a common vector for the transport of invasive species into new marine and aquatic environments. We used a metagenomic approach to study the composition and diversity of viral communities in ballast water from vessels originating in Mexico, Saudi Arabia, New York and Panama, and in water from ports of destination in Busan, Korea. Myoviridae was the most abundant virus family in ballast water, followed by Podoviridae and Siphoviridae. We have also identified viruses that infect invertebrates, amoebae and algae in ballast water and Busan port water. Interestingly, samples from New York and Panama had several viruses that infect humans or other animals (Swinepox virus, Raccoonpox virus, Suid herpes virus, and Human endogenous retrovirus). There were also giant viruses in all ballast water samples, particularly Megavirus chilensis identified in New York and Panama, and Pandoravirus salinus in Mexico and Saudi Arabia. These results provide detailed descriptions of the properties of viruses present in ballast water, document significant viral diversity, and demonstrate potential migration of viruses through ballast water.
authors: Hwang, J.;Park, S. Y.;Lee, S.;Lee, T. K.

title: Molecular identification of three novel herpes viruses found in Australian bred saltwater crocodiles (Crocodylus porosus) and captive Australian freshwater crocodiles (Crocodylus johnstoni)
abstract: Part of a larger study of three emerging disease syndromes highlighted by conjunctivitis and pharyngitis, systemic lymphoid proliferation and encephalitis and lymphodular skin infiltrates in farmed saltwater crocodiles (Crocodylus porosus) and a systemic lymphoid proliferation syndrome in captive freshwater crocodiles (Crocodylus) ), cytopathic effects (CPE), including syncytial cell formation, were observed in primary crocodile cell lines exposed to clarified tissue homogenates from affected crocodiles. Ten cell cultures with CPE were then screened for herpes viruses using two broad reactive herpes virus PCRs. Amplicons were obtained from 9 out of 10 cell cultures and sequenced. Three new herpes viruses were discovered, and phylogenetic analysis of these viruses showed a 63% posterior probability value supporting these viruses to cluster with the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily, and a 100% posterior probability of clustering with a lineage containing Alphaherpesvirinae and other unassigned reptilian herpes viruses. It is suggested that they be named Crocodyline herpesvirus (CrHV) 1, 2 and 3. CrHV1 and 2 were isolated from saltwater crocodiles only, and CrHV3 was isolated from freshwater crocodiles only. A duplex PCR was designed that could detect these herpes viruses in formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissues; this is a sample type in which none of the broadly reactive PCRs can detect these herpes viruses. This work describes isolation, molecular detection and phylogeny. Some of these new herpes viruses, but their association with emerging disease syndromes, require further investigation.
authors: Hyndman, T. H.;Shilton, C. M.;Wellehan, J. F., Jr.;Davis, S.;Isberg, S. R.;Phalen, D.;Melville, L.

title: Indigenous Hepatitis E in England and Wales from 2003 to 2012: Evidence of an Emerging New Virus Phylotype
abstract: Background. Enhanced surveillance and molecular characterization studies of hepatitis E virus (HEV) have been conducted in England and Wales since 2003. The dynamics of hepatitis E has changed with the recent increase in the number of indigenous cases and the observed viral shift. Methods HEV antibody and RNA data were analyzed to detect annual number of acute infections, HEV genotype trend, and viral phylogeny. These data were analyzed in the context of collected travel history and demographic data. Results. In total, 2713 cases of acute hepatitis E were diagnosed, of which 1376 were domestic infections. Travel-related cases remained stable and were mainly associated with Genotype 1 infections. In contrast, large fluctuations were recorded in domestic litigation, with a dramatic increase from year to year in the period 2010-2012. Molecular characterization has shown that native infections have split into two distinct phylogenetic groups, with the emergence of a new group of Genotype 3 viruses coinciding with the recent increase in cases. Results. HEV infection rates are dynamic in England and Wales and are affected by changing trends in cases of local origin. The recent increase in native cases and the emergence of native viruses that were not widely circulated before 2010 suggest that the risk of acquiring HEV is changing.
authors: Ijaz, S.;Said, B.;Boxall, E.;Smit, E.;Morgan, D.;Tedder, R. S.

title: Identification of bovine enteric Caliciviruses (BEC) from cattle in Baden-Württemberg
abstract: Caliciviruses are known to cause different diseases in many animal species. Bovine enteric caliciviruses (BEC) are associated with diarrhea in cattle. These viruses are classified in the genus Norovirus and are closely related to human noroviruses, the leading cause of gastroenteritis in humans. This raised questions about zoonotic transmission and an animal reservoir for human viruses. Of the 41 stool samples collected for diagnostic purposes from cattle with diarrhea in Aulendorf, Germany, two samples tested positive for BEC. Samples were amplified with newly degenerate BEC-specific primers that amplify a 263 bp portion of the RNA polymerase domain. Analysis of nucleotide sequences showed that these viruses were most closely related to Norovirus genogroup III/2 (Bo/NLV/Newbury-2/76/UK) viruses.
authors: Ike, A. C.;Roth, B. N.;BÃ¶hm, R.;Pfitzner, A. J.;Marschang, R. E.

title: Herd immunity and fatal flu cases among the poultry and wild bird exposure population in Russian Asia in 2013-2014
abstract: In October 2013, a total of 1,525 blood serum samples were collected from people living in areas at high risk for the outbreak of pandemic-potential influenza viruses in Russian Asia. The presence of antibodies to influenza viruses in the serum was tested in the hemagglutination inhibition test. None of the samples gave positive results with A/H5 and A/H7 antigens. Twelve strains of influenza A(H1N1pdm09) virus were isolated from people who probably died of influenza during the 2013-2014 epidemic season. All strains were similar to vaccine strain A/California/07/09 in antigenic properties and susceptibility to anti-neuraminidase drugs (oseltamivir and zanamivir). Genetic analysis revealed that all strains belonged to group 6, subgroup 6B of influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. HA1: Substitutions in S164F, as well as E235K in NA, as well as E47G, A86V, K331R, N386K, N397K and K131E in NS1, N29S in N29S and NEP divide R34Q into two groups: 1st group-A/ Chita/1114 /2014, A/Chita/1115/2014, A/Chita/853/2014, A/Barnaul/269/2014 and 2nd group-A/Chita/655/2014, A/Chita/656/2014, A/Chita/ 709/2014, A/Chita/873/2014. The D222G mutation in HA1, often associated with high morbidity of the disease, was present in strain A/Novosibirsk/114/2014. N386K substitution in NA removes a potential N-glycosylation site in A/Chita/1114/2014, A/Chita/1115/2014, A/Chita/853/2014, A/Barnaul/269/2014, A/Novosibirsk/ neuraminidases . 114/2014 and A/Blagoveshensk/252/2014.
authors: Ilyicheva, T.;Abdurashitov, M.;Durymanov, A.;Susloparov, I.;Goncharova, N.;Kolosova, N.;Mikheev, V.;Ryzhikov, A.

title: Molecular identification of enteroviruses from cattle and goat feces and media in Thailand.
authors: Income, N.;Kosoltanapiwat, N.;Taksinoros, S.

title: Variations in the major envelope glycoprotein GP5 of Czech strains of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus
abstract: Major envelope glycoprotein genes (ORF5) of seven Czech isolates of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) were amplified and their nucleotide sequences determined. ORF5 exhibited nucleotide and amino acid identities of 87%Â·5-100% and 87Â·6-100%, respectively, among isolates. In a phylogenetic tree, all European isolates are grouped in a different genotype from the reference American strains (VR-2332, IAF-Klop). Two different clades were identified among the European isolates. Two Czech isolates (V-501 and V-503) and Italian strain PRRSV 2156 were collected on a single branch. The remaining European lineages constituted the second clan. Surprisingly, two separate clustered strains (V-501 and V-516) were isolated from the same flock. In addition, the possible effect of in vitro cultivation on the nucleotide sequence was analyzed. Nine point mutations in the ORF5 region resulted from 152 in vitro passage of V-502 isolate in MARC-145 cells.
authors: Indik, S.;Valicek, L.;Klein, D.;Klanova, J.

title: Bats Are an Unused System for Understanding Microbiome Evolution in Mammals
abstract: Mammals evolved in a microbial world, and as a result, microbial symbionts played a role in their evolution. An exciting new sub-discipline of metagenomics addresses how microbes, particularly those found in the gut, facilitate the ecological and phylogenetic radiation of mammals. However, the vast majority of such studies focus on pets, laboratory models, or charismatic megafauna (for example, pandas and chimpanzees). The result is a large number of studies covering several taxa in the mammalian tree of life, leaving broad patterns of microbiome function and evolution unclear. Wildlife microbiome research urgently needs a model system to test hypotheses about metagenomic involvement in host ecology and evolution. We propose that bats (Order: Chiroptera) represent an ideal model system for comparative microbiome studies and provide opportunities to study host phyla, diet, and other natural history features related to the evolution of the gut microbiome.
authors: Ingala, M. R.;Simmons, N. B.;Perkins, S. L.

title: Genetic heterogeneity between parapoxviruses (Capricornis Cristus) isolated from sheep, cattle and Japanese serovs.
abstract: Standard strains of four parapoxviruses isolated from sheep, cattle and wild Japanese serows (Capricornis Crispus) and seven unclassified Japanese strains were molecularly compared. Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis of viral DNA, indirect immunofluorescence experiments using monoclonal antibodies, partial nucleotide sequencing of the envelope gene, phylogenetic analysis and PCR-RFLP were performed. These analyzes revealed that parapoxviruses were divided into four groups, and the region sequenced in this study was highly conserved within each group. Each of the Japanese isolates was classified into one of these groups. These findings also indicated that parapoxvirus infections among wild Japanese serows were caused by at least two different parapoxviruses, bovine papular stomatitis virus and orf virus. The methods presented here are useful for the genetic characterization and classification of parapoxviruses.
authors: Inoshima, Y.;Murakami, K.;Yokoyama, T.;Sentsui, H.

title: Identification and characterization of Highlands J virus from a Mississippi dune crane using unbiased next-generation sequencing.
abstract: Advances in massively parallel DNA sequencing platforms, commonly referred to as next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies, have greatly reduced the time, labor, and cost associated with DNA sequencing. Thus, NGS has become a routine tool for new viral pathogen discovery and will likely become the standard for routine laboratory diagnosis of infectious diseases in the near future. This study demonstrated the application of NGS for rapid identification and characterization of a virus isolated from the brain of an endangered Mississippi dune crane. This bird was part of the population restoration study and was found emaciated in 2012, just days after Hurricane Isaac passed through the Mississippi refuge. Postmortem examination identified trichostrongyliasis as the probable cause of death, but an arboviral etiology was strongly suspected when a togavirus was isolated from the Bird's brain due to a virus with morphology. Because individual molecular analyzes were negative for the few known arboviruses, unbiased NGS of Illumina MiSeq was used to definitively identify and characterize the causative viral agent. Whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis revealed that the viral isolate was Highlands J virus, a known avian pathogen. This study demonstrates the use of neutral NGS for rapid detection and characterization of an unidentified viral pathogen and the application of this technology to wildlife disease diagnosis and conservation medicine.
authors: Ip, H. S.;Wiley, M. R.;Long, R.;Palacios, G.;Shearn-Bochsler, V.;Whitehouse, C. A.

title: Virus pathotype and deep sequencing of the HA gene of the low pathogenic H7N1 avian influenza virus causing death in Turkey.
abstract: Low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) viruses of the H7 subtype usually cause mild illness in poultry. However, the evolution of an LPAI virus into a highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus results in the production of a virus that can cause serious illness and death. The classification of these two pathotypes is based, in part, on signs of disease and death in chickens, as assessed in an intravenous pathogenicity test, but the impact of LPAI viruses in turkeys is less well understood. During investigation of LPAI virus infection in turkeys, three week old groups of birds vaccinated with A/chicken/Italy/1279/99 (H7N1) showed signs of severe illness and died or were euthanized within seven days of infection. The virus was detected in many internal tissues and organs from the birds whose medicine was culled. To examine the possible evolution of the infecting virus into a highly pathogenic form in these turkeys, sequencing of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene cleavage site was performed by analyzing multiple cDNA amplicons from swabs and tissue sample extracts using Sanger and Next Generation Sequencing. . In addition, an RT-PCR test has been developed to detect the HPAI virus. There was no evidence of the presence of HPAI virus either in the virus used as the vaccine or in swab from infected birds. However, a small proportion (<0.5%) of virus carried in individual tracheal or liver samples contained a HPAI virus-specific molecular signature at the HA cleavage site. All signature sequences were identical and resembled the HPAI viruses collected during the Italian epizootic in 1999/2000. We hypothesize that the detection of HPAI virus in tissue samples following infection with A/chicken/Italy/1279/99 reflects amplification of a virus present at very low levels in the mixed inoculum, but strikingly, we did not observe any new HPAI virus signatures. amplified DNA analyzed by deep sequencing.
authors: Iqbal, M.;Reddy, K. B.;Brookes, S. M.;Essen, S. C.;Brown, I. H.;McCauley, J. W.

title: Pig's gut microbiome
authors: Isaacson, R.;Kim, H. B.

title: Genetic analysis of ORF5 in swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus in Japan.
abstract: In recent years, no reports on genetic information focusing on Japan have been published on the porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV). To clarify the effect of time on PRRSV genomic evolution, we sequenced open reading frame 5 (600 or 603 bases) from Japanese PRRSV isolates over three periods (1992-1993, 2000-2001 and 2007-2008) and compared their phylogenetics. relationships. Evaluation of the mean binary homology of nucleotide sequences of PRRSV isolates showed a trend towards increasing heterogeneity over time. In addition, we detected a virus classified in cluster IV, indicative of increased genetic variation of PRRSV in Japan. Â© 2011 The Societies and Blackwell Publishing Asia Pty Ltd.
authors: Iseki, H.;Takagi, M.;Miyazaki, A.;Katsuda, K.;Mikami, O.;Tsunemitsu, H.

title: Genome segment B of the highly virulent infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) encoding the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase protein VP1 is phylogenetically distinct from all other IBDV strains.
abstract: full-length cDNA clone of the very virulent infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) BD 3/99 strain B segment was constructed and the full-length nucleotide sequence was constructed. The nucleotide sequence encoding VP1, an RNA-dependent RNA polymerase of BD 3/99, is aligned with 17 other strains of IBDV, including six highly virulent, three classically virulent, five classically attenuated, one antigenic variant and two serotype 2 strains. . The VP1 genes of all highly virulent strains were 97.5% to 99.8% identical. Except for an atypical Australian strain, 002-73, all classical virulent or attenuated and antigenic variant strains were 97.5% to 100% identical. Serotype 2 strains deviated only 4-6% from serotype 1 classically virulent or attenuated strains; however, in contrast, highly virulent strains differed from serotype 2 strains by 10.5% to 12.5%, as well as classical virulent or attenuated strains. Analysis of the inferred amino acid sequence of VP1 revealed 17 commonalities, including 8 unique amino acid substitutions in multi-lethal strains. In the phylogenetic tree, highly virulent strains formed a separate cluster, and all other strains were grouped together, including classical virulent, attenuated, and antigenic variant strains, and even serotype 2 strains. It is suggested that VP1 of the very virulent IBDV is phylogenetically distinct from all other IBDV strains and likely originates from a hitherto unidentified source.
authors: Islam, M. R.;Zierenberg, K.;Muller, H.

title: Whole genome analysis of porcine astroviruses detected in Japanese pigs reveals genetic diversity and possible intra-genotypic recombination.
abstract: Porcine astroviruses (PoAstVs) are the ubiquitous enteric virus of pigs distributed in various countries around the world. The clinical significance of the infection is unknown, as PoAstVs have been detected in healthy-appearing pigs. However, AstVs have recently been associated with a serious neurological disorder in animals, including humans, and zoonotic potential has been suggested. To date, little is known about the epidemiology of PoAstVs among the pig population in Japan. In this report, we present an analysis of the nearly complete genome of 36 PoAstVs detected by a metagenomic approach in feces of Japanese pigs. Based on a phylogenetic analysis and pairwise sequence comparison, 10, 5, 15 and 6 sequences were classified as PoAstV2, PoAstV3, PoAstV4 and PoAstV5, respectively. Co-infection with two or three strains was found in individual stool samples from eight pigs. ORF1a, ORF1b and ORF2 phylogenetic trees of PoAstV2 and PoAstV4 showed differences in their topology. PoAstV3 and PoAstV5 strains shared high sequence identities within each genotype at all ORFs; however, one PoAstV3 strain and one PoAstV5 strain showed significant sequence variation in ORF2 from other PoAstV3 and PoAstV5 strains, respectively. Recombination analysis using whole genomes revealed evidence of multiple possible intra-genotype recombination events in PoAstV2 and PoAstV4; this suggested that recombination may have contributed to genetic diversity and played an important role in the evolution of Japanese PoAstVs.
authors: Ito, M.;Kuroda, M.;Masuda, T.;Akagami, M.;Haga, K.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Kishimoto, M.;Naoi, Y.;Sano, K.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Aoki, H.;Ichimaru, T.;Mukono, I.;Ouchi, Y.;Yamasato, H.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Whole genome analysis of Japanese bovine toroviruses reveals natural recombination between porcine and bovine toroviruses
abstract: Bovine toroviruses (BToVs) belong to the subfamily Toroviridae within the family Coronaviridae and are pathogens that cause enteric disease in cattle. In Japan, BToVs are distributed throughout the country and cause gastrointestinal infection in calves and cows. In this study, complete genome sequences of two Japanese BToVs and partial genome sequences of two Japanese BToVs and one porcine torovirus (PToV) from remote regions of Japan were determined and genetic analyzes were performed. Pairwise nucleotide comparison and phylogenetic analyzes revealed that Japanese BToVs share high identity with each other and show high similarity with strain BToV Breda1 in S, M, and HE coding regions. Japanese BToVs showed high similarities with porcine toroviruses in the ORF1a, ORF1b and N coding regions and in the 5' and 3' untranslated regions, suggesting a natural recombination event. Recombination analyzes mapped putative recombinant breakpoints to the 3' ends of the ORF1b and HE regions. These findings demonstrate that the interspecies recombinant nature of Japanese BToVs results in a closer association between BToV Breda1 and PToVs.
authors: Ito, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Naoi, Y.;Otomaru, K.;Sato, M.;Masuda, T.;Haga, K.;Oka, T.;Yamasato, H.;Omatsu, T.;Sugimura, S.;Aoki, H.;Furuya, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Potyvirus associated with the spotted fruit of Passiflora edulis in Kagoshima prefecture, Japan, is the third strain of the proposed new strain East Asian Passiflora virus (EAPV) phylogenetically separated from strains of Passion fruit woodland virus.
abstract: potyvirus (isolate IB) that causes mottled or wilted fruit and leaf mosaic symptoms of purple passion fruit has been found in the botanical garden of Kagoshima University in Japan. This isolate - differed in host range from Passion fruit woodland virus (PWV)-AO isolates previously reported to cause 'lignification' in Japan. Isolates IB and AO had 83% amino acid identity in coat proteins (CPs). In phylogenetic analysis, East Asian isolates IB, AO, and PWV-Taiwan clustered together and differentiated from Australian PWV and Brazilian Cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus isolates, which cause passion fruit 'woody'. We propose the name "East Asian Passiflora virus (EAPV)" for the new potyvirus strains. © Springer-Verlag 2005.
authors: Iwai, H.;Yamashita, Y.;Nishi, N.;Nakamura, M.

title: New bioinformatics strategies for prediction of directional sequence changes in influenza virus genomes and surveillance of potentially dangerous strains
abstract: Background: With the significant increase in microbial and viral sequence data from high-throughput DNA sequencers, new tools are needed for comprehensive analysis of large sequence data. We have developed a "Bulk Learning Self-Organizing Map (BLSOM)" that can characterize large numbers, even millions, of genomic sequences in a single plane. Influenza virus is one of the zoonotic viruses and shows clear host tropism. Important topics for bioinformatics studies of influenza viruses are prediction of genomic sequence changes in the near future and surveillance of potentially dangerous strains. Methods: To characterize sequence changes in influenza virus genomes after invasion from other animal hosts to humans, mono-, di-, tri-, and tetranucleotide compositions were found in the whole genome sequences of influenza A and B viruses, with a clear host-dependent clustering (self-organization) of sequences. found. Results: Viruses isolated from humans and birds differed from each other in mononucleotide composition. In addition, host-dependent oligonucleotide compositions that could not be explained by the host-bound mononucleotide composition were revealed by oligonucleotide BLSOMs. Retrospective time-dependent direction changes of mono- and oligonucleotide compositions visualized for human strains on BLSOMs can provide predictive information about sequence changes in newly invaded viruses from other animal hosts (for example, pig-derived pandemic H1N1/09). : Based on the host-dependent oligonucleotide composition, we propose a strategy for the prediction of direction changes in virus sequences and for surveillance of potentially dangerous strains when introduced into human populations from non-human sources. Because of their medical and social significance, millions of genomic sequences from infectious microbes and viruses have become available, and BLSOM can characterize big data and support efficient knowledge discovery. Â© 2013 Iwasaki et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Iwasaki, Y.;Abe, T.;Wada, Y.;Wada, K.;Ikemura, T.

title: Arboviruses: Inclusion in a general virus classification system
authors: J, Casals

title: Molecular characteristics of infectious bursal disease viruses from asymptomatic broiler flocks in Europe
abstract: Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) exists in several different antigenic and pathogenic forms. The immunosuppression caused by this virus in young chickens is not always associated with clinical signs of disease. Antigenic variant viruses originally identified in the United States typically do not cause clinical signs of disease, but can cause significant immunosuppression through destruction of B lymphocytes. Using a reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, we conducted a study of asymptomatic broiler chicken flocks for IBDV in Europe. Restriction fragment length polymorphisms in the viral protein 2 (VP2) gene of four isolates from Spain and four from France indicated that they may differ from the classical and highly virulent (vv) IBDV strains found in Europe. Nucleotide sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the hypervariable region of the VP2 gene showed that all eight viruses were more similar to US variant viruses than to classical viruses. In two viruses, one from France and the other from Spain, threonine was observed at amino acid position 222 and serine at position 254. These two substitution mutations are characteristic of Delaware variant viruses. In addition, all eight viruses had mutated amino acid position 318 from glycine to aspartic acid, another substitution mutation commonly found in US variant viruses. Although import restrictions prevent us from directly testing the antigenicity of these viruses, their nucleotides and predicted amino acid sequences suggest that they may be antigenically distinctive compared to classical and vvIBDV commonly found in Europe. Confirmation of the existence of antigenic variant IBDV strains in Europe requires additional immunological studies to elucidate the exact nature of viral epitopes. Our data support the need for these immunological studies.
authors: Jackwood, D. J.;Cookson, K. C.;Sommer-Wagner, S. E.;Le Galludec, H.;De Wit, J. J.

title: Diversity of genome segment B from infectious bursal disease viruses in the United States.
abstract: Several phylogenetic lineages of the infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) genome segment B have been described. Although this genome segment has been shown to contribute to virulence, little is known about the genetic lineages that exist in the United States. The nucleotide genome segment B sequences of 67 IBDV strains collected from 2002 to 2011 in the United States were examined. The majority (47) of these viruses were from California, although they were from nine different states. A 722-base pair region near the 5' end of genome segment B, starting at 168 nucleotides and ending at 889, was analyzed and compared to sequences available in GenBank. Nucleotide sequence alignment revealed that mutations were frequently observed and evenly distributed throughout the region. Amino acids at positions 145, 146, and 147 were found to change frequently when the predicted amino acids were aligned. Six different amino acid triads were observed, and the very lethal (vv) IBDV strains (based on the presence of the vvIBDV genome segment A sequence) all had the T145, D146 and N147 triad. None of the non-vvIBDV strains had this TDN triplet. Phylogenetic analysis of the 67 nucleotide sequences revealed four important genome segment B lineages among US viruses. One contained genome segment B sequences typically found in vvIBDV and three contained genome segment B sequences without vvIBDV. When available sequences in GenBank were added to the analysis, two additional strains without US viruses were observed; one contained viruses from China and the other contained viruses from Ivory Coast. Although the samples tested were not representative of all poultry producing regions in the United States, all serotype 1 viruses from states other than California belonged to a genome segment B lineage. Three other strains observed in the United States were populated only with viruses found in California, except for the serotype 2 strain, where the type strain was a serotype 2 virus from Ohio. The data provide further evidence for the importance of genome segment B identification during routine molecular diagnosis of all IBDV strains. Â© 2012 American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Jackwood, D. J.;Crossley, B. M.;Stoute, S. T.;Sommer-Wagner, S.;Woolcock, P. R.;Charlton, B. R.

title: Different evolutionary trajectories of vaccine-controlled and uncontrolled avian infectious bronchitis viruses in commercial poultry.
abstract: To determine the genetic and epidemiological relevance of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) isolates from commercial poultry to attenuated live IBV vaccines, we performed a phylogenetic network analysis on the full-length S1 sequence for Arkansas (Ark), Massachusetts (Mass), and Delmarva/1639. (DMV/1639) type viruses were isolated from clinical cases by 3 different diagnostic laboratories in 2015. Phylogenetic network analysis of archaeal isolates showed two dominant groups associated with 2 mutations, consistent with subpopulations found in commercial vaccines for this type of IBV. In addition, a series of satellite groups were observed for the Ark-type virus surrounding the two dominant populations; this is probably due to the fact that mutations associated with the nature of this vaccine remain in the herd. Phylogenetic network analysis of mass-type viruses shows two groupings corresponding to vaccine sequences from different manufacturers. No satellite groups were observed for Masstype viruses, which is consistent with the persistence of this vaccine type in the field. At the time of collection, no vaccine was used for DMV/1639 type viruses and phylogenetic network analysis showed a diffuse network suggesting no clear change in genetic distribution. Selection pressure analysis showed that DMV/1639 and Mass-type strains thrived under negative selection, while Ark-type viruses thrived under positive selection. These data support the hypothesis that live attenuated vaccine use plays a role in the genetic profile of similar IB viruses in the field and that phylogenetic network analysis can be used to identify vaccine and vaccine-derived isolates; this is important for us to understand the role of the creature. vaccines play in the evolutionary trajectory of these viruses.
authors: Jackwood, M. W.;Lee, D. H.

title: Delta hepatitis cause: 'Viral hepatitis, type D'
abstract: The α'-agent has been sufficiently characterized to deserve its designation as a virus and standardization of its nomenclature. Therefore, as recommended by Rizzetto et al., the following conventions are accepted: The Î´-agent will be called hepatitis D virus (HDV), its antigen, hepatitis D antigen (HDAg), and the infection-associated disease, viral hepatitis. , type D.
authors: Jacobson, I. M.;Dienstag, J. L.

title: Genetic analysis of avian influenza A viruses isolated from domestic waterfowl at live bird markets in Hanoi, Vietnam, prior to fatal H5N1 human infections in 2004.
abstract: The first known cases of human infection with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 viruses occurred in Vietnam in late 2003. However, HPAI H5N1 and low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) H5N2 and H9N3 viruses were isolated from domestic waterfowl during live birds. Market (LBM) surveillance in Vietnam in 2001 and 2003. To understand the possible role of these early viruses in the generation of H5N1 strains that infect humans, we performed sequencing and molecular characterization. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the hemagglutinin (HA) genes of the two goose HPAI H5N1 strains belong to item 3, and the surface glycoprotein and replication complex genes are most closely related (98.5-99.7% homologous) to A/duck/Guangxi/22/01. revealed. The (H5N1) virus was detected contemporary in southern China, while the M and NS genes were derived from a virus like A/duck/Hong Kong/2986.1/00 (H5N1). The H5 HA gene of the duck HPAI H5N1 strain belonged to item 5 and belonged to A/quail/Shantou/3846/02 (H5N1), A/teal/China/2978.1/02 (H5N1) and A/ partridge/ Shantou/2286/03 (H5N1). )-like viruses. Phylogenetic analysis also showed that all eight gene segments of goose and duck HPAI H5N1 and LPAI H5N2 viruses differ from H5N1 clade-1 viruses known to cause fatal human infections in Vietnam since late 2003. aquatic avian influenza viruses and their H9 HA belonged to Korean ancestry. The PB2 gene of A/duck/Vietnam/340/01 (H9N3) virus had lysine at position 627. Based on molecular characterization of specific amino acid residues on the surface and relevant internal protein-coding genes, Vietnamese H5N1 and H9N3 virus isolates showed specificity to the avian cell surface receptor and sensitivity to currently licensed anti-influenza A virus chemotherapeutics. Our findings suggest that the H5N1 and H5N2 viruses circulating among geese and ducks at LBMs in Hanoi, Vietnam in 2001 and 2003 are not close ancestors of clade-1 viruses associated with deadly human infections in Vietnam. Clade-1 HPAI H5N1 viruses were introduced to Vietnam independently.
authors: Jadhao, S. J.;Nguyen, D. C.;Uyeki, T. M.;Shaw, M.;Maines, T.;Rowe, T.;Smith, C.;Huynh, L. P.;Nghiem, H. K.;Nguyen, D. H.;Nguyen, H. K.;Nguyen, H. H.;Hoang, L. T.;Nguyen, T.;Phuong, L. S.;Klimov, A.;Tumpey, T. M.;Cox, N. J.;Donis, R. O.;Matsuoka, Y.;Katz, J. M.

title: Genetic analysis of avian influenza viruses: co-circulation of avian influenza viruses with allele A and B nonstructural gene in Northern Pintail (Anas acuta) ducks wintering in Japan.
abstract: The 1918 (H1N1), 1957 (H2N2), 1968 (H3N2), and 2009 (H1N1) pandemic influenza virus strains have genes related to avian influenza viruses (AIVs). The nonstructural (NS) gene of AIVs plays an important role in host-viral interaction. However, little is known about the degree of diversity of this gene in Northern pintail (Anas acuta) ducks overwintering in Japan. This study describes the characteristics of pintail-derived H1N1, H1N2, H1N3, H5N2, H5N3, H5N9 and H7N7 viruses. It turned out that most of the viruses are avian strains and are not associated with pandemic and seasonal flu strains. However, NP genes of 62.5% (5/8) viruses were found to be closely associated with an A/swine/Korea/C12/08, indicating genetic material exchange and continued mammalian associated evolution of AIVs. In addition, all viruses except Aomori/422/07 H1N1 contain the PSIQSRGLF motif, which is commonly found in avian, porcine, and human H1 strains. Aomori/422/07 H1N1 has a PSVQSRGLF motif that is identical to a North American strain. These findings are linked to an important transcontinental, Asia-America biogeographic interface. Phylogenetically, all viruses are clustered in the Eurasian lineage. Co-circulation of allele A and B (NS gene) viruses was evident in the study, implying the presence of a large reservoir of influenza A virus in pintail wintering in Japan. Â© 2012 Alam Jahangir et al.
authors: Jahangir, A.;Ruenphet, S.;Sultana, N.;Shoham, D.;Takehara, K.

title: Isolation and characterization of H9N2 influenza virus isolates from avian respiratory disease outbreak
abstract: This study reports the isolation and characterization of the H9N2 virus responsible for the disease characterized by symptoms such as respiratory distress, head swelling, runny nose, decreased feed intake, cyanotic comb, decreased egg production, and death. Virus isolation from allantoic fluid inoculated with tracheal aspirates and whole genome sequencing of the two isolates were performed on an Ion-Torrent sequencer. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the two H9N2 isolates were reasortant viruses showing a G1-like lineage for HA, NA and NP, a Hok/49/98-like lineage for PB1 and PA, and a PK/UDL-01/05-like lineage for PB2. . , an IL/90658/00-like strain for NS and an unknown strain for the M gene. Analyzes of the HA cleavage site showed a series of (333PARSSRGL340) indicating that these isolates have low pathogenicity. Isolate 2 has leucine at amino acid position 226, a substitution associated with mammalian adaptation of avian influenza virus. Isolate 1 has the S31N substitution in the M2 gene associated with drug resistance, as well as the R57Q and C241Y mutations in the NP gene associated with human adaptation. The result reported here provides in-depth information on H9N2 viruses circulating in domestic poultry of India and supports a policy of active effort to control and manage H9N2 infections in Indian poultry.
authors: Jakhesara, S. J.;Bhatt, V. D.;Patel, N. V.;Prajapati, K. S.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Emergence of a genotype I variant of the avian infectious bronchitis virus in the northern part of India
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is one of the leading causes of a persistent economic burden for poultry industries worldwide. IBV belongs to the genus Gammacoronavirus in the family Coronaviridae. IBV infection causes respiratory and nephrogenic symptoms in broilers. In addition, its infection causes a decrease in fertility and hatchability in laying birds. Using next-generation sequencing, we have identified the first complete genome sequence of a variant IBV from an outbreak in the northern Indian state of Haryana. In the phylogenetic analysis of the IBV isolate, genotype I clustered with strain 1 (GI-1). The deduced amino acid sequence of the S gene of the IBV isolates showed a high level of identity with the strains isolated from Tamil Nadu and the reference vaccine strains. Our result suggests that the IBV virus isolated from unvaccinated chicken flocks in northern India may be a returning strain originally evolved from the live attenuated vaccine strains used in the region. Full genome sequencing of additional IBV isolates from India is essential to understanding the epidemiology of IBV in India.
authors: Jakhesara, S. J.;Nath, B.;Pal, J. K.;Joshi, C. G.;Kumar, S.

title: Pathotypical and Sequence Characterization of Newcastle Disease Viruses from Vaccinated Chickens Showing Genotypes II, IV and XIII and Circulation in India
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) causes a highly contagious disease that continually plagues the global poultry industry. The nature and molecular epidemiology of NDVs prevalent in recent outbreaks in India are poorly understood. This study aimed to characterize NDVs prevalent in vaccinated herds in India using whole genome sequencing and biological pathotyping. Twelve site isolates were collected from outbreaks occurring in different regions of India and characterized as velogenic according to the intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) and amino acid sequence in the F protein cleavage region. Twelve of the field isolates and five commonly used vaccine strains were selected for whole genome sequencing using Ion Torrent PGM technology, providing complete genome sequences for ten field isolates and all vaccine types. The genome of all isolates was found to be 15×192 nt in length and there was a high level of conservation between APMV-I viruses and multiple genomic features. Phylogenetic analysis and evolutionary distance calculations placed the isolates into genotypes II, IV, and XIII. A review of other recently reported strains provided preliminary evidence of VI, VII and XVIII genotypes circulating in India. Comparison between field and vaccine virus sequences revealed unique genomic and amino acid differences in key antigenic regions of the F and hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) genes, and these substitutions can be targeted for site-directed mutagenesis to assess the impact on virus pathogenicity. This study highlights the need to evaluate available vaccines through systematic protection experiments to determine protection efficacy against field isolates.
authors: Jakhesara, S. J.;Prasad, V. V.;Pal, J. K.;Jhala, M. K.;Prajapati, K. S.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Swine Deltacoronavirus, Thailand, 2015
authors: Janetanakit, T.;Lumyai, M.;Bunpapong, N.;Boonyapisitsopa, S.;Chaiyawong, S.;Nonthabenjawan, N.;Kesdaengsakonwut, S.;Amonsin, A.

title: Sequence analysis of the S1 glycoprotein gene of infectious bronchitis viruses: identification of a new phylogenetic group in Korea.
abstract: Twelve Korean infectious bronchitis viruses (IBV) were isolated in the field from chickens suspected of being carriers of infectious bronchitis between 2001 and 2003. The S1 glycoprotein genes of these IBV isolates were amplified by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and analyzed by restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis. These Korean IBV isolates were divided into three groups according to the RFLP patterns obtained using the HaeIII restriction enzyme. Half of the twelve isolates were similar to the KM91 RFLP model, a common model in Korea. Three more isolates were associated with the Arkansas strain pattern, but there were some unique variations. The other three viruses showed variable RFLP patterns. For a comparison with published sequences for non-Korean IBV strains, amplified PCR products from twelve isolates were cloned and sequenced. The isolates that received Korean IBV had 71.2-99.7% nucleotide sequence homology among themselves and 45.9-80.7% nucleotide sequence homology with non-Korean IBV strains. Regarding the deduced amino acid sequence, Korean IBV isolates had 71.5%-99.3% similarity to each other and 44.9%-80.3% similarity to non-Korean IBV strains. Phylogenetic tree analysis revealed that some IBV isolates appeared to belong to a new group, distinct from non-Korean IBV strains or previously isolated Korean IBV strains. Specifically, the new Korean IBV isolates K10217-03, K3-3 and K1255-03 represented a distinct group. These findings suggest that Korean IBVs are constantly evolving.
authors: Jang, J. H.;Sung, H. W.;Song, C. S.;Kwon, H. M.

title: Antigenic and genetic analyzes of foot and mouth disease virus type A isolates for selection of the candidate vaccine strain reveal the emergence of a variant virus responsible for the most recent outbreaks in India.
abstract: Recent reports have shown the existence of two antigenic and genetic groups (genotypes VI and VII) of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) type A in India, which differ from vaccine strains. To select the appropriate field isolate as the candidate vaccine strain, antisera are tested in a neutralization assay against representative isolates from both the genotypes and the two vaccine strains in use. Two candidate vaccine strains from both genotypes are selected by close antigenic match to field isolates. In conclusion, IND 81/00 (genotype VII) had better antigenic coverage (antigenic association (r)-value > 0.40 with 79% of 2002-2003 isolates) than IND 258/99 (genotype VI). ) is obviously given; r-value > 0.40) with 42% of 2002-2003 isolates. Phylogenetic analysis based on the P1 genomic region placed all new isolates (2001–2003) in genotype VII and marked a major evolution, with the emergence of a novel variant virus (VIIb-VP359del) with an amino acid deletion at an antigenically critical residue (VP359). . skipping, possibly due to immune selection. Although very limited in scope, these data indicate a marked predominance of genotype VII over genotype VI and underscore the need to continue further molecular epidemiological research to confirm this finding. Â© 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Jangra, R. K.;Tosh, C.;Sanyal, A.;Hemadri, D.;Bandyopadhyay, S. K.

title: Statoviruses, a new taxon of RNA viruses found in the gastrointestinal tract of various mammals
abstract: Next-generation sequencing has expanded our understanding of the viral populations that make up the mammalian virome. For Stool-associated Tombus-like viruses found in multiple metagenomic datasets, we describe a new virus taxon named Statoviruses. These viruses define a new division phylogenetically related to the Tombusviridae and Flaviviridae RNA virus families. Five different types of statovirus have been identified in human, macaque, mouse, and bovine gastrointestinal tract samples. The prototype genome, statovirus A, was frequently identified in macaque fecal samples from many geographically diverse cohorts. Another genome, statovirus C1, was discovered in a stool sample from a human child with a fever, cough, and rash. Further experimental data will clarify whether these viruses are infectious to mammals or originate from another source in the mammalian gastrointestinal tract.
authors: Janowski, A. B.;Krishnamurthy, S. R.;Lim, E. S.;Zhao, G.;Brenchley, J. M.;Barouch, D. H.;Thakwalakwa, C.;Manary, M. J.;Holtz, L. R.;Wang, D.

title: Epidemiological investigation of an outbreak of goose parvovirus infection in Sweden
abstract: An outbreak of goose parvovirus (GPV) infection on a Swedish goose farm in the spring of 2004 increased mortality rates from 2% in unaffected first broods to 90% and 99% respectively in two broods and 40% in geese following introduction of the virus. It hatched later in the same breeding season. This article describes clinical observations, diagnostic procedures, and epidemiological research conducted to elucidate the source of infection. Diagnosis was confirmed by serology, virus isolation, and sequence analysis of a 493-bp long fragment of the VP1 gene. The phylogenetically causative virus was closely related to pathogenic GPV strains isolated from Poland and the United Kingdom in 2003 and 2004, respectively. The Swedish isolate showed less homology with the pathogenic strains and attenuated vaccine strains from Hungary and Asia. Epidemiological research showed that the virus was first introduced to a contract farm (farm A) and then transferred to the farm (index farm) that sent the newly hatched goslings and birds for autopsy. The exact time and source of entry of the virus into farm A could not be determined with certainty. Possible sources of infection include backyard goose eggs subcontracted to farm A for hatching, wild geese infested with pasture-breeding goose on farm A, and a group of Canadian goose eggs (Branta canadensis). hatched in the same machine as eggs produced by wild geese and produced by farm A.
authors: Jansson, D. S.;Feinstein, R.;Kardi, V.;MatÃ³, T.;Palya, V.

title: A new bovine papillomavirus (BPV-6) causing true epithelial papillomas of mammary gland skin: A member of a proposed new subgroup of BPV
abstract: papillomavirus has been isolated from leaf epithelial papillomas of the bovine udder. It is clearly distinguishable from all other bovine papillomaviruses (BPVs) based on its DNA sequence homology and antigenic properties and is therefore characterized as a novel entity termed BPV-6. BPV-6 has no nonspecific papillomavirus antigen, its genomic DNA is smaller (7.2 kb), and it does not show any sequence homology to BPV-1, BPV-2 or BPV-5, whereas it is approximately the same length. as BPV-3 or BPV-4, with which it shares some sequence homology. Bovine papillomaviruses are divided into two subgroups: subgroup A, which consists of BPV-1, BPV-2, and BPV-5, which all induce fibropapillomas, and subgroup B, which consists of BPV-3, BPV-4, and BPV- 6, all true causes epithelial papillomas.
authors: Jarrett, W. F. H.;Campo, M. S.;O'Neil, B. W.

title: ViQuaS: an enhanced line of reconstruction for viral half-species spectra produced by next-generation sequencing
abstract: MOTIVATION: The combined effect of high replication rate and low fidelity of viral polymerase in most RNA viruses and some DNA viruses results in the formation of a viral half-species. Uncovering information about half-species populations greatly benefits the study of disease progression, antiviral drug design, vaccine design, and viral pathogenesis. We present a new line of analysis called ViQuaS for viral half-species spectrum reconstruction using short next-generation sequencing reads. ViQuaS is based on a new reference-supported de novo assembly algorithm for generating local haplotypes. A significantly extended version of an existing global strain reconstruction algorithm is also used. RESULTS: Benchmark results showed that ViQuaS outperformed the other three previously published methods ShoRAH, QuRe and PredictHaplo with at least 3.1-53.9% improvements in recall, 0-12.1% in precision, and 0-38.2% improvements in F-score. at least 0.006-0.143 improvements in KL-divergence and 0.001-0.035 in root mean square error in terms of strain frequency estimation over the next best algorithm under strain sequence assembly and various simulation settings. We also applied ViQuaS to a real read set derived from an in vitro human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-1 population, two independent FMD virus datasets derived from the same biological sample, and a real HIV-1 dataset, and it showed better results than other available methods. .
authors: Jayasundara, D.;Saeed, I.;Maheswararajah, S.;Chang, B. C.;Tang, S. L.;Halgamuge, S. K.

title: Mixed triad: allied viruses in unique final isolates of highly virulent type 2 bovine viral diarrhea virus detected by deep sequencing
abstract: UNLABELED: In February 2013, very severe acute clinical symptoms were observed in calves, heifers and dairy cattle on several farms in North Rhine-Westphalia and Lower Saxony, Germany. Deep sequencing revealed the coexistence of three distinct genome variants within the highly virulent bovine viral diarrhea virus type 2 (BVDV-2) isolates. While the majority of the population (about 95%) harbored one copy of a 222-nucleotide (nt) segment within the p7-NS2 coding region, the minority reflected the standard structure of a BVDV-2 genome. In addition, unusual mutations were found in both variants within the highly conserved p7 protein and near the p7-NS2 cleavage site. Using a reverse genetic system with a BVDV-2a strain harboring a similar duplication, it can be shown that during replication, non-duplication genomes are generated de novo from duplicating genomes. The major variant with duplication is necessarily accompanied by the minor variant without duplication. RNA secondary structure prediction allowed analysis of the unique but stable mix of three BVDV variants and also provided explanation for their production. Finally, our results suggest that the duplicated variant plays a major role in the highly lethal phenotype. IMPORTANCE: This study highlights the importance of whole-genome deep sequencing combined with manual in-depth data analysis for the search for viruses in basic research and diagnosis. Here, we investigated highly virulent isolates of bovine viral diarrheal virus from a series of outbreaks in 2013. We discovered a unique special feature of the viral genome, an unstable duplication of 222 nucleotides that was eventually deleted by viral polymerase activity, resulting in an unexpectedly mixed population of viral genomes for all investigated isolates. Our work is of great importance for the field because we show that these insertion/deletion events allow for another genome plasticity of plus-strand RNA viruses, in addition to the well-known polymerase-induced single-nucleotide variations that are generally considered major. basis for viral adaptation and evolution.
authors: Jenckel, M.;Hoper, D.;Schirrmeier, H.;Reimann, I.;Goller, K. V.;Hoffmann, B.;Beer, M.

title: Identification of two novel reassortant avian influenza a (H5N6) viruses in songbirds in Korea, 2016
abstract: Background: On November 20, 2016, two new strains of H5N6 highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIVs) were isolated from three song swans (Cygnus cygnus) in Gangjin Bay, South Jeolla province, South Korea. Identification of HPAIVs in wild birds is important as there is a potential risk of transmission of these viruses to poultry and humans. Results: Phylogenetic analysis revealed that Gangjin H5N6 viruses were classified in the Asian H5 line 2.3.4.4 lineage and were distinguishable from H5N8 and H5N1 HPAIVs previously isolated in Korea. Except for the polymerase acidic (PA) gene, viruses were most closely associated with A/duck/Guangdong/01.01SZSGXJK005-Y/2016 (H5N6) (98.90 ~ 99.74%). The PA genes of the two novel Gangjin H5N6 viruses were most closely related to AIV isolates previously characterized from Korea, A/hooded crane/Korea/1176/2016 (H1N1) (99.16%) and A/environment/Korea/W133/2006 (H7N7). ) (98.65%). The absence of newer viruses for A/environment/Korea/W133/2006 (H7N7) indicates the need for analysis of new wild avian AIVs isolated in Korea as they may provide further clues as to the origin of these new reassortant H5N6 viruses. Conclusions: Although research continues on the origins and epidemiology of these infections, the most likely route of infection for songbirds has been through direct or indirect contact with reassortant viruses spread by migratory wild birds in Korea. Continuous monitoring of AIVs in wild birds will help reduce this risk, as H5N6 HPAIVs can potentially infect poultry and humans.
authors: Jeong, J.;Woo, C.;Ip, H. S.;An, I.;Kim, Y.;Lee, K.;Jo, S. D.;Son, K.;Lee, S.;Oem, J. K.;Wang, S. J.;Kim, Y.;Shin, J.;Sleeman, J.;Jheong, W.

title: Genetic characterization of H1 avian influenza viruses isolated from migratory birds and domestic ducks in Korea.
abstract: H1 avian influenza viruses (AIVs) isolated from migratory birds and domestic ducks from 2003 to 2007 were analyzed to determine their genetic relationships. Phylogenetic analysis with nucleotide sequences of all eight gene segments showed that 13 H1 AIVs from migratory birds and domestic ducks belong to Eurasian avian lineages and are closely related to each other. There was no evidence of reclassification among human, porcine, and avian hosts compared with swine or human-derived H1 influenza viruses in Korea. Our results show that H1 AIVs isolated in Korea from 2003 to 2007 are genetically stable. However, given the role of migratory birds and the domestic duck as sources of AIVs, constant surveillance is necessary. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2010.
authors: Jeong, O. M.;Kim, Y. J.;Choi, J. G.;Kang, H. M.;Kim, M. C.;Kwon, J. H.;Lee, Y. J.

title: Detection of Newcastle disease virus in a commercial laying hen flock and its effect on post-vaccination immunity development.
abstract: The aim of this study was to monitor the concentration of antibodies against Newcastle disease after vaccination of laying hens at the beginning and end of the laying period. The study was conducted on a commercial layer flock in Opatovice, Czech Republic, in 2008-2010. A total of 280 blood serum samples were obtained from laying hens from four hens. Serum was tested with the hemagglutination inhibition test according to the OIE Guidelines. As a result of atypical results of serological tests, virological tests were performed. Newcastle disease virus RNA was demonstrated by RT-nested PCR in pooled tissue samples of 5 chickens, ileocecal tonsillar intestinal samples, trachea, as well as a swab sample from a poultry environment. Based on sequencing analysis and subsequent phylogenetic analysis, the virus was identified as a low pathogenic paramyxovirus strain (PMV-1). This low pathogenic strain had no effect on the health of laying hens.
authors: Jerabkova, J.;Juranova, R.;Rosenbergova, K.;Kulikova, L.;Hera, A.;Lany, P.;Kubicek, O.;Kolacek, J.

title: Prototype of a novel IIS/IIC/IIG endonuclease-methyltransferase TsoI recognizing the 5'-TARCCA(N11/9)-3' sequences from Thermophile Thermus scotoductus
abstract: Thermus sp. The IIS/IIG/IIC family of enzymes includes the thermostable, bifunctional fused restriction endonuclease (REase)-methyltransferases (MTase): TaqII, Tth111II/TthHB27I, TspGWI, TspDTI, and TsoI. Enzymes are large proteins (about 120 kDa), their enzymatic activity is affected by S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), they recognize similar asymmetric cognate regions and are fragmented at 11/9 nucleotide (nt) distances. Enzymes exhibit similarities in amino acid (aa) sequences and DNA catalytic motifs. Thermos sp. The enzymes are an example of functional aa sequence homologies between REases that recognize different but related DNA sequences. The family consists of the TspGWI- and TspDTI- subfamilies. TsoI appears to be a non-identical 'triple' associated with TspDTI and Tth111II/TthHB27I. The discovery of TsoI purified from Thermus scotoductus is described. This prototype TsoI-digested bacteriophage lambda (α) exhibited a novel specificity as determined by (i) cleavage of a reference plasmid and bacteriophage DNA, (ii) cleavage of specific PCR DNA substrates, (iii) flow sequencing of cleavage products, and (iv) shotgun. ») Cloning and sequencing of its DNA. The enzyme recognizes a degenerate 5'-TARCCA-3' sequence, whereas DNA strands are cut 11/9 nt downstream. The discovery of the TsoI prototype is of practical importance in biotechnology as it expands the palette of cleavage specificities for gene cloning.
authors: Jezewska-Frackowiak, J.;Lubys, A.;Vitkute, J.;Zakareviciene, L.;Zebrowska, J.;Krefft, D.;Skowron, M. A.;Zylicz-Stachula, A.;Skowron, P. M.

title: Characterization of the hemagglutinin gene of H9 subtype avian influenza viruses isolated in 2007-2009 in China.
abstract: The H9 subtype avian influenza viruses (AIVs) circulating in China have raised concerns about their effects on poultry and their risk to public health. In this report, three studies on viruses were reported and the hemagglutinin gene of 55 virus strains isolated in China in 2007-2009 were sequenced and analyzed. The results showed that the prevalence of viruses in China is increasing and most of the H9 AIVs circulating in China in the last decade belong to the h9.4.2 subset. Viruses isolated in China in 2007-2009 differed slightly from previous strains (genetic distances >7.1%). Meanwhile, a possibly dominant segment of viruses circulating in China in 2007-2009 was detected. Mutation analysis has suggested that viruses pose greater risks to public health in recent years. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Ji, K.;Jiang, W. M.;Liu, S.;Chen, J. M.;Chen, J.;Hou, G. Y.;Li, J. P.;Huang, B. X.

title: Transcriptome analysis of sheep oral mucosal response to Orf virus infection
abstract: Infectious ecthyma is a highly contagious disease with worldwide distribution, caused by the Orf virus (ORFV) of the Parapoxvirus. To examine the transcriptional level change of host gene expression in response to ORFV infection, several young small-tailed Han sheep were inoculated with ORFV and oral mucosa tissue samples (T0, T3, T7 and T15) were collected at day 0. RNA-seq showing that 1928, 3219 and 2646 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified between T3 versus T0, T7 versus T0 and T15 versus T0, respectively. transcriptome comparisons were made. Gene Ontology (GO) analyzes of DEGs from these comparisons revealed that ORFV can trigger potent immune response of host cells during the early stage of infection. Moreover, GO and network analysis demonstrated that positive and negative regulatory mechanisms of apoptosis are integrated into host cells, by up- or down-regulating the expression level of DEGs involved in apoptotic pathways, to achieve a homeostasis of oral mucosa tissues during exposure. Against ORFV infection. In conclusion, our study describes for the first time the direct effects of ORFV on its host's global host gene expression using high-throughput RNA sequencing, which provides a resource for future characterization of the interaction mechanism between mammalian host and ORFV.
authors: Jia, H.;Zhan, L.;Wang, X.;He, X.;Chen, G.;Zhang, Y.;Feng, Y.;Wei, Y.;Zhang, Y.;Jing, Z.

title: Phylogenetic analysis using the E2 gene of the classic swine fever virus reveals a new subgenotype in China
abstract: Classic swine fever (CSF) epidemics have had serious economic consequences in China. Phylogenetic analysis based on full-length E2 gene sequences showed that five classical swine fever virus (CSFV) isolates collected from Hunan province in 2011 and 2012 may coexist with seven other isolates from neighboring provinces Guangdong (5) and Guangxi (2). A new subgenotype that may be endemic to southern China for at least fourteen years can be classified as 2.1c. Subgenotype 2.1c isolates showed 90.2-94.9 and 89.9-93.8% nucleotide sequence similarity, respectively, with lower nucleotide identities between subgenotypes 2.1a and 2.1b in the E2 gene. shares (91.1-95.7%). ). Further analysis based on a partial E2 gene sequence (216th nt) showed that subgenotype 2.1c isolates are also circulating in Thailand. Alignment of the E2 amino acid sequences indicated that subgenotype 2.1c isolates exhibited a SPA. a†'. TPV substitution at positions 777 and 779 compared with subgenotypes 2.1a and 2.1b. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Jiang, D. L.;Gong, W. J.;Li, R. C.;Liu, G. H.;Hu, Y. F.;Ge, M.;Wang, S. Q.;Yu, X. L.;Tu, C.

title: [Genotyping and molecular evolution of the varicella-zoster virus]
abstract: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV, Human herpes virus 3) is a member of the Herpesviridae family and is classified, together with HSV-1 and HSV-2, as the alpha subfamily. VZV is most often the causative agent of chickenpox (varicella) in children and then produces latency in the sensory ganglia and then causes shingles (zoster) with the potential to be reactivated. In recent years, increasing molecular epidemiological studies have been conducted to monitor mutations in the VZV genome, to distinguish vaccinia virus from wild-type virus, to examine the phylogeny of VZV strains worldwide, and to understand the evolution of different VZV clades. Progress has a major impact in the fields of epidemiology, virology and bioinformatics. This review discusses the available data on the geographic distribution and molecular evolution of VZV clades.
authors: Jiang, L. F.;Gan, L.;Chen, J. X.;Wang, M. L.

title: Integrative analysis of differentially expressed microRNAs of pulmonary alveolar macrophages from piglets during H1N1 swine flu A virus infection.
abstract: H1N1 swine flu A virus (H1N1 SwIV) is an important subtype of influenza viruses with pandemic potential. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are endogenous small RNA molecules that regulate gene expression. MiRNAs related to H1N1 SwIV have been rarely reported. To understand the biological functions of miRNAs during H1N1 SwIV infection, this study profiled differentially expressed (DE) miRNAs in pulmonary alveolar macrophages from piglets during H1N1 SwIV infection using a deep sequencing approach validated by quantitative real-time PCR. Compared with the control group, 70 and 16 DE miRNAs were identified at post-infection day (PID) 4 and PID 7, respectively. 56 DE miRNAs were identified between PID 4 and PID 7. While defending H1N1 SwIV infection during the acute phase of swine flu, expression levels gradually return to normal during the recovery phase to prevent very severe swine lung injury from occurring. In addition, the targets of DE miRNAs for bioinformatics analysis were also obtained. Our results will be useful for investigating the functions and regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs in human influenza, as the pig serves as an excellent animal model for studying the pathogenesis of human influenza.
authors: Jiang, P.;Zhou, N.;Chen, X.;Zhao, X.;Li, D.;Wang, F.;Bi, L.;Zhang, D.

title: Transcriptome analysis reveals dynamic changes in coxsackievirus A16-infected HEK 293T cells
abstract: BACKGROUND: Coxsackievirus A16 (CVA16) and enterovirus 71 (EV71) are two of the major causes of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) worldwide. Although many studies have focused on infection and pathogenic mechanisms, the transcriptome profile of the host cell on CVA16 infection is still largely unknown. RESULTS: In this study, we compared the mRNA and miRNA expression profiles of human embryonic kidney 293T cells infected with and not CVA16. We highlight that the transcription of SCARB2, a cellular receptor for both CVA16 and EV71, is upregulated approximately 10-fold in infected cells compared to uninfected cells. Upregulation of SCARB2 transcription induced by CVA16 may increase the likelihood of subsequent CVA16/EV71 infection, resulting in co-infection with two viruses in a single cell. This explanation would partially explain the co-circulation and genetic recombination of multiple EV71 and CVA16 viruses. Based on the correlation analysis of miRNAs and genes, we speculated that the high expression of SCARB2 is modulated by downregulation of the miRNA has-miR-3605-5p. We also found that differentially expressed miRNA target genes are mainly reflected in extracellular membrane (ECM)-receptor interaction and circadian rhythm pathways; these may be associated with clinical symptoms of patients infected with CVA16, such as aphthous ulcers, cough. , myocarditis, somnolence and potentially meningoencephalitis. The miRNAs hsa-miR-149-3p and hsa-miR-5001-5p may result in upregulation of genes in these morbid pathways related to CVA16 and may also cause clinical symptoms. CONCLUSIONS: This study illuminated the changes in 293T cells upon CVA16 infection at the transcriptome level, including highly upregulated SCARB2 and ECM-receptor interaction and genes in the circadian rhythm pathways and key miRNAs in gene expression regulation. These results provided new insights into the pathogenesis of HFMD caused by CVA16 infection.
authors: Jin, J.;Li, R.;Jiang, C.;Zhang, R.;Ge, X.;Liang, F.;Sheng, X.;Dai, W.;Chen, M.;Wu, J.;Xiao, J.;Su, W.

title: Genetic characterization of a new astrovirus in gout afflicted geese
abstract: Since the beginning of 2016, the Chinese goose industry has experienced severe gout outbreaks; however, the etiologic factor of the disease is still unclear. Here we investigated the possible involvement of viral infection in the disease. Using sequence-independent PCR amplification, astrovirus sequences were generated from a case of gout. Full-length genomic sequencing and sequence analysis of three strains of goose astrovirus (GoAstV) revealed that they belonged to a novel avastrovirus most closely related to viruses classified within the Avastrovirus 3 strain. GoAstV was detected in 16/16 gout cases collected from two provinces, supporting a pathogenic role for the novel avastrovirus.
authors: Jin, M.;Wang, X.;Ning, K.;Liu, N.;Zhang, D.

title: Genome sequencing and characterization analysis of a Beiffing isolate of chicken coronavirus infectious bronchitis virus
abstract: Avian infectious bronchitis virus (AIBV) is classified as a member of the coronavirus genus in the family coronaviridae. The enveloped virus has a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA genome of approximately 28 kilobases with a 5' cap structure and a 3' polyadenylation pathway. The complete genome sequence of the Beijing isolate, infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), was determined by cloning sequencing and primary walking. The entire genome is 27733 nucleotides long and has ten open reading frames: 5'-orf1a-orf1ab-s-3a-3b-em-6a-6b-n-3'. Alignment of the genome sequence of the IBV Beijing isolate with that of two AIBV strains and one SARS coronavirus, respectively, was performed. The genome sequence of the IBV Beijing isolate was 91.2% similar to that of the IBV strain LX4 (incomplete, 1940 bp size). However, the full-length genome sequence of the IBV Beijing isolate was 85.2% identity to IBV Strain Beaudette and only 50.8% homology to that of the SARS coronavirus. The results showed that the IBV genome has a remarkable variation. And the IBV Beijing isolate is not closely related to the SARS coronavirus. Phylogenetic analyzes based on whole genome sequence, S protein, M protein and N protein also showed that AIBV Beijing isolate was the only virus in group III and was free from SARS coronavirus. In conclusion, this study will contribute to IBV-related diagnostic and disease control studies in China.
authors: Jin, W. W.;Chen, C.;Zhang, Y.;Zhao, Y. Q.;Feng, J. D.;Chen, F. Y.;Wu, Q. M.;Yang, H. C.;Wang, M.;Yu, J. L.;Li, N.;Gong, Y. S.;Sun, Q. X.;Chen, Z. L.

title: Detection and molecular characterization of enteric viruses in breeding turkeys
abstract: This study was conducted to detect and characterize enteric viruses (rotavirus, astrovirus, reovirus and coronavirus) in breeding houses. Five turkey brood herds were selected. Fecal samples were collected from all flocks at 1 week and then biweekly until the birds were 9 weeks old. Stool samples were collected in groups of five. Of the 193 pools ("samples") tested by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction, 47.2%, 30.6%, and 10.4% samples were positive for astrovirus, rotavirus, and reovirus, respectively. No coronavirus was detected in any of the samples. Overall, 118 (61.1%) samples were positive for one or more enteric viruses. Of the 118 samples, 70 (59.3%) were positive for a single virus and 48 (40.7%) were positive for a combination of viruses. Phylogenetic analysis based on the polymerase gene showed that astroviruses clustered into two groups with sequence similarity ranging from 85.6 to 100% at the nucleotide level. Based on the NSP4 gene sequences, the rotaviruses clustered in a group and had 96.3% to 99.9% sequence similarity at the nucleotide level. Based on the S4 gene sequences, reoviruses clustered in a single group with sequence similarity of 96.9% to 100%. The different amino acid sequences of all three viruses may affect the antigenicity and/or pathogenicity of these viruses and may merit further study. The presence of two or three different viruses in combination can affect turkey health and disease dynamics. © 2010 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Jindal, N.;Patnayak, D. P.;Chander, Y.;Ziegler, A. F.;Goyal, S. M.

title: Molecular characterization of foot and mouth disease virus in Hong Kong from 2001-2002
abstract: Most molecular epidemiological studies of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) are based on comparisons of the VP1 gene sequence. In this report, the nucleotide sequences of the VP1 coding region of O/HKN/3/01, O/HKN/5/01, O/HKN/12/01, O/HKN/7/02 and O FMDV type O strains were analyzed between 2001 and 2002. /HKN/10/02 isolated from the disease outbreak in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China (Hong Kong SAR) was detected and compared with the sequences of other FMDVs. The results revealed that the VP1 gene of the five isolates had identical nucleotide (nt) sequences (639 nt) encoding 213 amino acids and no changes were found in critical amino acid regions 144 (Val), 148 (Leu). It is found in the VP1 protein epitope (amino acids 140-160, 200-213) or at amino acids 145-147, which includes the arginine-glycine-aspartic acid (RGD) sequence), 154 (Lys) and 208 (Pro). It takes part in the adsorption of the virus into the host cell.
