Analysis of the VP1 gene nucleotide sequence revealed that the five isolates studied were most closely related to FMDVs found in Hong Kong from 1991 to 1999 and Taiwan in 1997. Moreover, critical amino acids on the antigen epitope of common Hong Kong isolates and serotype O1/Manisa/Turkey/69 vaccine strain showed relative conservatism, they were genetically distantly related, suggesting variation between common Hong Kong FMDV strains and vaccine strain. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 2006.
authors: Jinding, C.;Mingqiu, Z.;Hui, K. H.;Leung, F. C.

title: One-Way Traffic of Viral Motor Channel for Double Stranded DNA Translocation
abstract: Linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) viruses package their genomes in a procapsid using an ATP-driven nanomotor. Here we report that the bacteriophage phi29 DNA packaging engine exerts a one-way traffic feature for dsDNA translocation from N-terminal input to C-terminal output via a valve mechanism in DNA packaging, as demonstrated by voltage ramp, electrode polarity switching and sedimentation force. evaluation. Without the use of gate control found in other biological channels, the observed unidirectional dsDNA transport provides a novel system with a natural valve to control dsDNA loading and gene delivery in bioreactors, liposomes or high-throughput DNA sequencing apparatus.
authors: Jing, P.;Haque, F.;Shu, D.;Montemagno, C.;Guo, P. X.

title: Molecular analysis of hepatitis E virus from farm rabbits in Inner Mongolia, China and successful spread in A549 and PLC/PRF/5 cells.
abstract: Rabbit hepatitis E virus (HEV) strains have recently been isolated in various parts of China, the USA and France. However, the host range, distribution, and zoonotic potential of these HEV strains are unknown, and their spread in cultured cells has not yet been reported. A total of 211 4-month-old rabbits reared on a farm in Inner Mongolia were tested for the presence of anti-HEV antibodies and HEV RNA. Overall, 121 rabbits (57.3%) tested positive for anti-HEV antibodies and 151 (71.6%) had detectable HEV RNA. The 174 HEV strains from these viremic rabbits, including two different strains from 23 rabbits each, differed from each other by up to 13.6% in the sequence of 412 nucleotides (nt) in ORF2 and were 89.3-95.9% identical to that reported. Rabbit HEV strains in other provinces of China. Three representative Inner Mongolian strains, one from each of the three phylogenetic clusters whose whole genomic sequences were determined, shared 79.6-96.7% identity with the rabbit HEV strains reported in the entire or 242-1349-nt partial genomic sequence. Rabbit HEV strains derived from liver tissues of rabbits with high HEV load propagate efficiently in human cell lines (A549 and PLC/PRF/5 cells), suggesting the potential zoonotic risk of rabbit HEV. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Jirintai, S.;Jinshan;Tanggis;Manglai, D.;Mulyanto;Takahashi, M.;Nagashima, S.;Kobayashi, T.;Nishizawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Characterization of Fitzroy river virus and serological evidence of human and animal infection
abstract: In 2011 and 2012 in North Western Australia, surveillance detected a new arbovirus in mosquitoes. Genetic and phenotypic analyzes confirmed that the new flavivirus, designated Fitzroy River virus, is related to the yellow fever virus group Sepik virus and Wesselsbron virus. Most of the isolates (81%) came from Aedes normanensis mosquitoes, providing circumstantial evidence of a possible vector. In cell culture, Fitzroy River virus replicated in mosquito (C6/36), mammalian (Vero, PSEK and BSR) and avian (DF-1) cells. It also infected intraperitoneally vaccinated weaning mice and caused mild clinical disease in 3 intracranially vaccinated mice. Specific neutralizer in sentinel horses (12.6%), cattle (6.6%) and chickens (0.5%) from the Northern Territory of Australia and a subgroup of humans (0.8%) from northern Western Australia antibodies were detected.
authors: Johansen, C. A.;Williams, S. H.;Melville, L. F.;Nicholson, J.;Hall, R. A.;Bielefeldt-Ohmann, H.;Prow, N. A.;Chidlow, G. R.;Wong, S.;Sinha, R.;Williams, D. T.;Lipkin, W. I.;Smith, D. W.

title: Rat hepatitis E virus: geographic cluster within Germany and serological detection in wild Norway rats (Rattus norvegicus)
abstract: Zoonotic hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection in industrialized countries is thought to result from transmission from wild boar, domestic pig and deer as reservoir hosts. Detection of HEV-specific antibodies in rats and other rodents suggested that these animals may represent an additional source for human HEV transmission. Recently, a new HEV (ratHEV) was detected in Norwegian rats from Hamburg, Germany, showing the typical genome organization but a high nucleotide and amino acid sequence variation relative to other mammalian and avian HEV strains. Here we describe the multiple detection of ratHEV RNA and HEV-specific antibodies in Norway rats from additional cities in northeastern and southwestern Germany. Whole genome analysis of two new strains from Berlin and Stuttgart confirmed the association of ratHEV with Norwegian rats. Available data showed continued presence of this virus in rat populations in Berlin and Hamburg. Phylogenetic analysis of a short segment of the open reading frame 1 confirmed a geographic clustering of corresponding sequences. Serological studies using recombinant ratHEV and genotype 3 capsid protein derivatives showed antigenic differences that could be due to high amino acid sequence variation in the immunodominant region. The high number of animals showing only ratHEV RNA or anti-ratHEV antibodies suggested a non-persistent infection in the Norway rat. Future studies must prove the transmission routes and zoonotic potential of the virus in rat populations. The recombinant ratHEV antigen produced here will allow future seroepidemiological studies to differentiate between ratHEV and genotype 3 infections in humans and animals. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Johne, R.;Dremsek, P.;Kindler, E.;Schielke, A.;Plenge-BÃ¶nig, A.;Gregersen, H.;Wessels, U.;Schmidt, K.;Rietschel, W.;Groschup, M. H.;Guenther, S.;Heckel, G.;Ulrich, R. G.

title: Hepeviridae: an expanding family of vertebrate viruses
abstract: The hepatitis E virus (HEV) was first described in 1990, but hepatitis E-like diseases in humans have been recorded for a long time, dating back to the 18th century. HEV genotypes 1-4 were subsequently identified in human hepatitis E cases with different geographical distribution and different modes of transmission. In pigs, wild boars and other animal species, genotypes 3 and 4 were identified in parallel and their zoonotic potential was confirmed. Until 2010, these genotypes were the only known representatives of the Hepeviridae family, along with avian HEV strains that infect chickens. Subsequently, additional HEV-related viruses were detected in wild boars, different HEV-like viruses were identified in rats, rabbits, ferrets, mink, fox, bats and deer, and a distantly related agent was identified from closely related salmon. This review summarizes the characteristics, phylogenetic relationships, host association, and proposed involvement in diseases of HEV-like viruses known so far. Based on the information reviewed, a proposal is presented for a new taxonomic grouping scheme of viruses within the family Hepeviridae.
authors: Johne, R.;Dremsek, P.;Reetz, J.;Heckel, G.;Hess, M.;Ulrich, R. G.

title: Sequence analysis of the VP6-encoding genome segment of avian group F and G rotaviruses.
abstract: Rotavirus groups A to E are primarily defined by antibody reactivity against the capsid protein VP6. In addition, two putative groups of rotaviruses (F and G) have been identified in birds. Here, the first nucleotide sequences of the VP6-encoding genome segment of group F (strain 03V0568) and group G (strain 03V0567) rotaviruses, both derived from chickens, are presented. Group F rotavirus is most closely related to avian group A and D rotaviruses, with 49.9-52.3% nucleotide and 36.5-39.0% amino acid sequence identity. Group G rotavirus is most closely related to mammalian group B rotaviruses with 55.3-57.5% nucleotide and 48.2-49-9% amino acid sequence identity. The terminal sequences of the genome segment were similar in groups A, D, and F, and in groups B and G. The findings show the long-term evolution of rotavirus groups in two distinct branches and support the development of a sequence-based classification system. for rotavirus groups. © 2011 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Johne, R.;Otto, P.;Roth, B.;LÃ¶hren, U.;Belnap, D.;Reetz, J.;Trojnar, E.

title: Rabies epidemiology in southeastern Europe
abstract: Rabies is endemic in a number of countries in Southeast Europe, including Romania, Bulgaria and Turkey. With the possible eastward enlargement of the European Union, rabies elimination programs are likely to be increased in new member states to reduce the disease burden. A clear understanding of the epidemiology of the virus in this part of Europe is vital before such programs are implemented. With the exception of Turkey, the red fox (Vulpes vulpes) is the major disease reservoir in Southeast Europe. However, cases of rabies in the dog (Canis familyis) are regularly reported. Unlike northern Europe, the raccoon dog (Nyctereutes procyonoides) does not appear to be a vector in the south. This study summarizes the current rabies situation in Southeast Europe and demonstrates phylogenetic relationships between viruses in many countries in the region. Rabies virus RNA was extracted from the original samples and a fragment of the nucleoprotein gene amplified by reverse transcriptase PCR. Automated sequencing was used to derive nucleoprotein gene sequences and these were used to prepare a molecular phylogeny of rabies viruses in southeastern Europe. In Bulgaria, the dog is the main vector for rabies in contact with humans and livestock. However, other species may also act as reservoirs for the disease, complicating the development of elimination strategies. The fox is the main reservoir species for rabies in Romania, although cases are regularly reported in dogs. Despite a gradual decline in canine rabies, urban pockets of the disease persist in many regions of Turkey. There is also some evidence that the fox is an important vector for rabies and may be responsible for increases in cattle rabies in the Aegean region of the country. Throughout the region, there is evidence of cross-border movement of rabies by both wildlife and dog vectors.
authors: Johnson, N.;Freuling, C.;Vos, A.;Un, H.;Valtchovski, R.;Turcitu, M.;Dumistrescu, F.;Vuta, V.;Velic, R.;Sandrac, V.;Aylan, O.;MÃ¼ller, T.;Fooks, A. R.

title: The fed antibiotic carbadox induces phage gene transcription in the pig gut microbiome.
abstract: Carbadox is a quinoxaline-di-N-oxide antibiotic fed to more than 40% of young pigs in the United States and shown to induce phage DNA transduction in vitro; however, the effects of carbadox on porcine microbiome functions are poorly understood. We investigated the longitudinal effects of Carbadox on porcine gut microbial gene expression (fecal metatranscriptome) and phage population dynamics (fecal dsDNA viromes) in vivo. Microbial metagenome, transcriptome and virome sequences have been annotated for taxonomic inference and gene function using the FIGfam (isofunctional homologous sequences) and SEED subsystems databases. When beta diversity of microbial FIGfam annotations were compared, control and carbadox communities were different 2 days after carbadox introduction. This effect was driven by carbadox-related low expression of FIGfams (n = 66) related to microbial respiration, carbohydrate utilization and RNA metabolism (q < 0.1), suggesting bacteriostatic or bactericidal effects in certain populations. Interestingly, carbadox treatment resulted in increased expression of FIGfams related to all stages of the phage lytic cycle 2 days after the addition of carbadox (q â‰¤0.07), suggesting carbadox-mediated induction of prophages and phage DNA recombination. These effects were reduced with 7 days of continuous carbadox in the bait, suggesting an acute effect. In addition, viromes contained several genes encoding resistance to tetracycline, aminoglycoside, and beta-lactam antibiotics, but these did not change in frequency with time or treatment. The results show reduced bacterial growth and metabolism, prophage induction, and potential transduction of bacterial fitness genes in porcine gut bacterial communities as a result of carbadox administration. SIGNIFICANCE FDA regulations for agricultural antibiotic use have focused on antibiotics important to human medicine. Carbadox is an antibiotic that is not used in humans but is frequently used in US pig farms. It is important to examine the possible side effects of Carbadox use because it has been shown to promote bacterial evolution, which may indirectly affect antibiotic resistance in bacteria of clinical importance. Interestingly, this study shows greater prophage gene expression in the faeces of carbadox-fed animals 2 days after initiation of in-feed carbadox treatment compared to the faeces of unmedicated animals. Importantly, the phage genetic material isolated in this study contained genes that could confer resistance to antibiotics important in human medicine; this suggests that human antibiotic resistance genes are mobile between bacteria via phages. This study underlines the side effects of antibiotics and shows that the effects of various antibiotics should be considered when antibiotics are used or new regulations are considered.
authors: Johnson, T. A.;Looft, T.;Severin, A. J.;Bayles, D. O.;Nasko, D. J.;Wommack, K. E.;Howe, A.;Allen, H. K.

title: Illumina MiSeq 16S amplicon array analysis of bovine respiratory disease-associated bacteria in lung and mediastinal lymph node tissue
abstract: Background: Bovine respiratory disease (BRD) is caused by the growth of single or multiple pathogenic bacterial species in lung tissue following stress and/or viral infection. Next-generation sequencing of 16S ribosomal RNA gene PCR amplicons (NGS 16S amplicon analysis) is a powerful culture-independent open reference method recently used to increase understanding of BRD-associated bacteria in the upper respiratory tract of BRD cattle. However, it has not yet been used to study the microbiome of the bovine lower respiratory tract. The aim of this study was to use NGS 16S amplicon analysis to identify bacteria in postmortem lung and lymph node tissue samples collected from fatal BRD cases and clinically healthy animals. Cranial lobe and associated mediastinal lymph node postmortem tissue samples were collected from calves diagnosed with BRD and clinically healthy calves by veterinary laboratory pathologists. NGS 16S amplicon libraries targeting the V3-V4 region of the bacterial 16S rRNA gene were prepared and sequenced on an Illumina MiSeq. Quantitative insights into microbial ecology (QIIME) were used to identify operational taxonomic units (OTUs) corresponding to 16S rRNA gene sequences. Results: Leptotrichiaceae, Mycoplasma, Pasteurellaceae, and Fusobacterium were the OTUs most detected in the lungs and lymph nodes of calves that died from BRD. Leptotrichiaceae, Fusobacterium, Mycoplasma, Trueperella, and Bacteroides had greater relative abundance in postmortem lung samples from fatal BRD cases in dairy calves compared with clinically healthy calves without lung lesions. Leptotrichiaceae, Mycoplasma and Pasteurellaceae showed higher relative abundance in postmortem lymph node samples collected from fatal BRD cases in dairy calves compared with clinically healthy calves without lung lesions. Two contigs of the Leptotrichiaceae sequence were then joined from the shotgun sequences enriched with bacterial DNA. Results: Microbiomes of the cranial lung lobe and mediastinal lymph node from calves deceased from BRD and clinically healthy HF calves were characterized. Contigs corresponding to the abundant Leptotrichiaceae OTU were sequenced and found not to be identical to any known bacterial genera. This suggests that we have identified a new strain of bacteria associated with BRD.
authors: Johnston, D.;Earley, B.;Cormican, P.;Murray, G.;Kenny, D. A.;Waters, S. M.;McGee, M.;Kelly, A. K.;McCabe, M. S.

title: Identification of avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 in poultry farms in Indonesia.
abstract: Avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 (AIV-H9N2) has been established in domestic poultry in Asia and Africa. AIV-H9N2 has not been previously reported in Indonesia. Here we describe the presence of AIV-H9N2 in poultry farms in Indonesia. Ninety-nine cases have been observed in various provinces of Indonesia. Clinical signs, pathological lesions and egg production were recorded. Validation was performed using virus isolation, reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR), and sequencing. Secondary data of Eurasian lineages were downloaded from GenBank to establish the hemagglutinin (HA) phylogeny. For neuraminidase, the five sequences with the highest similarity to each sequence found in this study were downloaded. The phylogeny was extracted using the Neighbor-Joining method in the MEGA6 package. Forty-nine AIV-H9N2-positive cases were observed, of which 35 tested positive for AIV-H9N2 only. The age of the infected chickens was 43.17 Â± 16.56 weeks and their egg production was 35.85% Â± 17.80% lower than before the epidemic. The BLAST search revealed that the nucleotide sequence of the HA-encoding gene identified in this study shares 98% sequence identity with A/Muscovy duck/Vietnam/LBM719/2014(H9N2), while the neuraminidase-encoding gene sequences share 94%. 98% and 100% identity with three different influenza viruses. The phylogeny indicates that the HA of AIV-H9N2 found in this study forms a distinct cluster with sequence data from some Vietnam and China. NA sequence data form three separate clusters. We conclude that AIV-H9N2 is prevalent in many provinces in Indonesia. Herd biosecurity and vaccination against this virus subtype must be implemented rapidly to reduce economic losses in the poultry industry. Comprehensive and strict AIV surveillance is essential to prevent the veterinary and public health consequences of the circulation of this virus in Indonesia.
authors: Jonas, M.;Sahesti, A.;Murwijati, T.;Lestariningsih, C. L.;Irine, I.;Ayesda, C. S.;Prihartini, W.;Mahardika, G. N.

title: Molecular identification and characterization of novel coronaviruses infecting graylag geese (Anser anser), wild pigeons (Columbia livia), and mallards (Anas platyrhynchos)
abstract: In light of the finding of a previously unknown coronavirus as the etiology of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), it is likely that coronaviruses other than those recognized to date are circulating in animal populations. Here are the results of a coronavirus screening using a universal coronavirus RT-PCR for the avian greylag goose (Anser anser), wild pigeon (Columbia livia), and mallard (Anas platyrhynchos). Coronaviruses were found in cloaca swab samples from all three bird species. In the graylag goose, 40 out of 163 birds sampled were positive for the coronavirus, while two out of 100 pigeons sampled and one in five mallards sampled tested positive. Infected graylag geese showed lower body weights compared to virus negative birds, demonstrating the clinical significance of the infection. Phylogenetic analyzes of the replicase gene and nucleocapsid protein sequences showed that all of the novel coronaviruses described in this study diverged from group III coronaviruses. All novel avian coronaviruses harbored the conserved s2m RNA structure in their 3â€² untranslated regions, such as the other previously described group III coronaviruses and the SARS coronavirus. Sequencing of the complete nucleocapsid gene and downstream regions of the goose and pigeon coronaviruses proved the presence of two additional open reading frames, one for the encoded proteins and one for the transmembrane domains predicted, but lacking sequence similarity to known proteins for the goose coronavirus. - additional open reading frame for pigeon coronavirus with a predicted transmembrane domain downstream of the nucleocapsid gene. © 2005 SGM.
authors: Jonassen, C. M.;Kofstad, T.;Larsen, I. L.;LÃ¸vland, A.;Handeland, K.;Follestad, A.;Lillehaug, A.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of bovine pestiviruses: testing the evolution of clinical symptoms
abstract: This study presents the phylogenetic analysis of 115 bovine pestiviruses. Sequence data placed in front of the 5' untranslated genomic region were analyzed with maximum stinginess, bootstrapping and stinginess. We tested the proposed classifications of the group and analyzed the development of symptoms associated with Pestivirus infections in cattle. Based on the historical framework provided by our phylogenetic trees, we also determined the extent and significance of contamination by the virus in biologicals. Our phylogenetic analyzes showed that the previously identified genotypes were monophyletic. except genotype 1a. Based on our cladograms, we suggest the presence of more than 12 monophyletic groups within the BVDV 1 strain. Mapping of clinical symptoms suggests that the emergence of some genotypes may have resulted from a change in the pathogenic process. Enteric Problems appear to be ancestral, while Reproductive and Respiratory Problems 1b, 1d, and the genotype Arg 1 proposed here appear. that a contaminated product may be a vehicle for virus spread. Implications for virus evolution, virus taxonomy, veterinary medicine, and biotechnology are discussed. (C) Willi Hennig Society 2004.
authors: Jones, L. R.;Cigliano, M. M.;Zandomeni, R. O.;Weber, E. L.

title: Homologous recombination in bovine pestiviruses - Phylogenetic and statistical evidence
abstract: Bovine pestiviruses (Bovine Viral Diarrea Virus 1 (BVDV 1) and Bovine Viral Diaarrea Virus 2 (BVDV 2)) belong to the Pestivirus (Flaviviridae) genus, which consists of positive-stranded RNA viruses that cause significant economic losses worldwide. To further investigate the evolutionary mechanisms responsible for variation in the virus, we used phylogenetic and bootstrap analyzes to systematically screen for alignments of previously sequenced genomes. Previously published data suggested that homologous crossover may be one of the mechanisms responsible for the genomic rearrangements observed in cytopathic (cp) strains of bovine pestiviruses. However, homologous recombination involves not only homologous crossovers but also the replacement of a homologous region of the acceptor RNA. Furthermore, cytopathic strains represent evolutionary dead paths as they are only isolated from fatal cases of mucosal disease. Here we report evidence of homologous inter-genotype recombination in the genome of a non-cytopathic (ncp) strain of Bovine Viral Diarrea Virus 1, type strains of the Pestivirus genus. We also show that intra-genotype homologous recombination can be a common phenomenon in both Pestivirus strains. This evidence indicates that homologous recombination contributes to the diversification of bovine pestiviruses in nature. Implications for virus evolution, taxonomy and phylogenetics are discussed. Â© 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Jones, L. R.;Weber, E. L.

title: Emergence of the virulence-related PB2 E627K substitution in a fatal human case of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus A(H7N7) infection, as determined by Illumina ultra-deep sequencing.
abstract: Bird flu viruses can cross the species barrier and infect humans. While evidence of human-to-human transmission of avian influenza viruses to date has been limited, the evolution of variants towards more efficient human-to-human transmission could result in a new influenza virus pandemic. In both avian influenza A(H5N1) and recently emerged avian influenza A(H7N9) viruses, the polymerase basic 2 protein (PB2) E627K mutation appears to be key to human adaptation. During a major influenza A(H7N7) virus outbreak in the Netherlands in 2003, the A(H7N7) virus isolated from a fatal human case contained the PB2 E627K mutation as well as the hemagglutinin (HA) K416R mutation. In this study, we aimed to investigate whether these mutations occur in bird or human host by sequencing Illumina Ultra-Deep of three previously unexplored clinical samples obtained from the fatal case. We also examined three chicken samples, two of which were from the source farm.
authors: Jonges, M.;Welkers, M. R.;Jeeninga, R. E.;Meijer, A.;Schneeberger, P.;Fouchier, R. A.;de Jong, M. D.;Koopmans, M.

title: Bat-related virus infection: summary of reports from Thailand
abstract: The bat is an interesting mammal that can fly. There is a very interesting but limited reference to the bat-related disease of mankind. There are many viral infections that can be transmitted to humans through bats. These virus infections are often serious and difficult to manage. In this mini-review, the authors summarize and discuss the bat-borne virus infection mentioned in previous publications in Thailand, a tropical country in Southeast Asia.
authors: Joob, B.;Wiwanitkit, V.

title: Detection of Fowlpox virus carrying different genome segments of reticuloendotheliosis virus
abstract: Fowlpox virus (FWPV), the type species of the genus Poxviridae of the Avipoxvirus family, is a large double-stranded DNA virus that causes avian pox in chickens and turkeys. In particular, sequences of the avian retrovirus reticuloendotheliosis virus (REV) are frequently found integrated into the FWPV genome. Some FWPV strains carry remnants of REV long terminal repeats (LTRs), while other strains have been shown to contain inserts of nearly full-length REV provirus in their genomes. In this study, we detected heterogeneous FWPV populations carrying the REV LTR or full-length REV provirus genome in a Merriam's wild turkey (Meleagris gallopavo merriami). The bird presented papules scattered on the hairless areas of the head. Avipoxvirus-like virions were observed in lesions by transmission electron microscopy and the presence of FWPV was confirmed by DNA sequencing. Metagenomic sequencing performed on nucleic acid extracted from skin lesions revealed two populations of FWPV genomes carrying a 197-nt residue of the REV LTR or a 7939-nt-long fragment corresponding to the full-length REV provirus. Specifically, PCR amplification using primers targeting FWPV sequences flanking the REV insertion site confirmed the natural occurrence of heterogeneous FWPV genome populations in an additional clinical sample from another fowl disease-affected turkey. In addition, sequencing of a historical FWPV isolate from chickens in the USA in 2000 also revealed the existence of two FWPV-REV genome populations. The results here show distinct FWPV populations containing variable segments of the REV genome integrated into their genomes. These different genome populations are likely the result of homologous recombination events that occur during FWPV replication.
authors: Joshi, L. R.;Bauermann, F. V.;Hain, K. S.;Kutish, G. F.;ArmiÃ©n, A. G.;Lehman, C. P.;Neiger, R.;Afonso, C. L.;Tripathy, D. N.;Diel, D. G.

title: West Nile virus strain 2 infection in a blood donor from Vienna, Austria, August 2014
abstract: Eastern Austria is neighboring areas with ongoing West Nile virus (WNV) transmissions. Three human WNV infections have been diagnosed in Austria in the last decade. The Austrian Red Cross Blood Service (ARC-BS) launched the first voluntary WNV screening with the Nucleic Acid Test (NAT) in blood donors from Eastern Austria in June 2014. It is also the most comprehensive WNV surveillance program in humans to date in Austria. . In August 2014, an autochthonous WNV infection was detected in a blood donor from Vienna. So far, one out of 67,800 whole blood donations has been found to be positive for WNV RNA.
authors: Jungbauer, C.;Hourfar, M. K.;Stiasny, K.;Aberle, S. W.;Cadar, D.;Schmidt-Chanasit, J.;Mayr, W. R.

title: Production of henipavirus nucleocapsid proteins in yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae
abstract: Hendra and Nipah viruses are newly emerged, zoonotic viruses and their genomes have nucleotide and predicted amino acid homologies that place them in the Paramyxoviridae family. Currently, these viruses are classified in the new genus Henipavirus within the subfamily Paramyxovirinae, family Paramyxoviridae. The genes encoding the HeV and NiV nucleocapsid proteins were cloned into the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae expression vector pFGG3 under the control of the GAL7 promoter. High expression of these proteins (18-20 mg l-1 yeast culture) was obtained. Mass spectrometric analysis confirmed the primary structure of both proteins with 92% sequence coverage obtained using MS/MS analysis. Electron microscopy showed the association of typical herringbone structures of purified recombinant nucleocapsid proteins characteristic of other paramyxoviruses. The nucleocapsid proteins showed stability in yeast and can be easily purified by cesium chloride gradient ultracentrifugation. HeV nucleocapsid protein was detected with sera from fruit bats, humans, HeV-infected horses, and NiV nucleocapsid protein was immunodetected with sera from fruit bats, humans, and pigs. The development of an efficient and cost-effective system for the production of henipavirus nucleocapsid proteins could aid in the development of reagents for the diagnosis of viruses. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Juozapaitis, M.;Serva, A.;Zvirbliene, A.;Slibinskas, R.;Staniulis, J.;Sasnauskas, K.;Shiell, B. J.;Wang, L. F.;Michalski, W. P.

title: The MET gene is a common integration target in chicken hemangiomas induced by avian leukosis virus subgroup j.
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) is a simple retrovirus that can cause hemangiomas and myeloid tumors in chickens and is currently a major economic problem in Asia. Here, we characterize ALV-J strain PDRC-59831, a newly studied US isolate of ALV-J. Five-day-old chicken embryos were infected with this virus, and chickens developed myeloid leukosis and hemangioma within 2 months of hatching. To investigate the pathogenesis mechanism, we used high-throughput sequencing to analyze the proviral integration sites in these tumors. We found expanded clones with integrations in the MET gene in two of the five hemangiomas studied. This integration locus was not seen in the previous study characterizing ALV-J-induced myeloid leukosis. MET is a known proto-oncogene that acts through various signaling pathways and is implicated in many neoplasms. We show that tumors harboring MET integrations exhibit strong overexpression of MET mRNA.
authors: Justice, J.;Malhotra, S.;Ruano, M.;Li, Y.;Zavala, G.;Lee, N.;Morgan, R.;Beemon, K.

title: Common sites of viral integration identified in B-cell lymphomas caused by avian leukosis virus
abstract: Avian leukosis virus (ALV) induces B-cell lymphoma and other neoplasms in chickens by integrating in or near cancer genes and disrupting their expression. Four genes (MYC, MYB, Mir-155, and TERT) were previously identified as co-integration sites in these virus-induced lymphomas and are thought to play a causal role in tumorigenesis. In this study, we use high-throughput sequencing to identify additional genes that trigger tumorigenesis in ALV-induced B-cell lymphomas. In addition to the four previously included genes, we identify other genes as co-integration sites, including TNFRSF1A, MEF2C, CTDSPL, TAB2, RUNX1, MLL5, CXorf57 and BACH2. We also analyze the genome-wide ALV integration environment in vivo and find increased frequency of ALV integration near transcriptional start sites and within transcripts. Previous work has shown that ALV prefers a weak consensus sequence for integration in cultured human cells. We validate this consensus sequence for in vivo ALV integration in the chicken genome. IMPORTANT Avian leukosis virus induces B-cell lymphomas in chickens. Previous studies have shown that ALV can induce tumors through insertional mutagenesis and that several genes are involved in the development of these tumors. In this study, we use high-throughput sequencing to reveal the genome-wide landscape of ALV integration in ALV-derived B-cell lymphomas. We find high levels of ALV integration near transcription start sites and use co-integration site analysis to greatly increase the number of genes involved in the development of these tumors. Interestingly, we identify several genes targeted by viral insertions that have not previously been shown to be involved in cancer.
authors: Justice, J. F.;Morgan, R. W.;Beemon, K. L.

title: Detection of hepatitis E virus in archived German wild boar serum samples
abstract: Hepatitis E is a rare human disease commonly imported from endemic areas in Central Europe. A zoonotic transmission from swine, deer and wild boar is assumed for domestic infections. Using three different RT-PCR protocols, hepatitis E virus (HEV) RNA was detected in 10 (5.3%) of 189 serum samples collected in 1995/1996 from wild boars in Germany. Sequence analysis shows close association with genotype 3 isolates of pigs and humans from the Netherlands and Japan. The results show that HEV has existed in Germany for more than 10 years and that wild boar can serve as a reservoir for HEV. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kaci, S.;NÃ¶ckler, K.;Johne, R.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) isolates from Turkey: identification of a new subgroup in BVDV-1.
abstract: The genetic heterogeneity of Turkish ruminant pestiviruses was investigated by phylogenetic analysis of the nucleotide sequences encoding complete Npro. A total of 30 virus isolates obtained from 15 provinces across the country between 1997-2005 were included in the phylogenetic analysis. Virus isolates mostly originate from cattle, and one isolate from sheep. All bovine isolates belonged to BVDV-1, sheep isolates belonged to BVDV-2. Fifteen isolates formed a new subgroup within BVDV-1, provisionally termed BVDV-1l. The remaining bovine isolates were typed as BVDV-1a (n = 4), BVDV-1b (n = 4), BVDV-1d (n = 3), BVDV-1f (n = 2) and BVDV-1h (n = 1). ). The isolates assigned to BVDV-1l originated from various geographic regions in different years. There was no correlation between genetic grouping and the locations where the isolates were obtained. In most cases viruses originating from a farm belonged to the same subgroup (n = 5). This study shows that the newly detected BVDV-1l subgroup is dominant and widespread in Turkey. In addition, an ovine virus isolate was identified as the first BVDV-2 member reported in Turkey. A serological study using samples from western Turkey showed that BVDV-2 was also found in cattle. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kadir, Y.;Christine, F.;Barbara, B. W.;Zeki, Y.;Feray, A.;Aykut, O.;Ibrahim, B.;Sibilina Cedillo, R.;Heinz-JÃ¼rgen, T.;Matthias, K.

title: Virus shedding in a porcine monocyte cell line
abstract: The spread of seventeen virus strains classified into five virus families in a porcine monocyte cell line (SW/K99) was studied at the point of infective progeny production. The viruses studied were adapted for growth in a porcine epithelial cell line (KSEK6) and were previously proven to show clear CPE. These viruses were repeatedly passaged in monocyte cultures independent of CPE formation. Passage level 3 cultures were titrated for infectivity using KSEK6 cells. Of the viruses studied, only Aujeszky's disease virus (ADV) was able to replicate in monocytes. Four ADV strains, two virulent and two attenuated strains were compared for their growth in the two cell lines. The final amount of infective progeny measured at 72 hours of incubation at 36.5 degrees C was in almost similar order between the 2 cell lines. However, the amount of infective progeny produced at 24 h incubation was higher in SW/K99 cells than in KSEK6 cells. CPE formation was also more pronounced in SW/K99 cells at an early incubation. The data show that the viral susceptibility of monocytes to ADV is higher than that of epithelium. Other viruses were abortive in monocytes.
authors: Kadoi, K.

title: Full-length infectious clone of an Iranian chicken anemia virus isolate
abstract: An Iranian strain of chicken anemia virus (CAV), designated IR CAV, was isolated for the first time in culture of the Marek's disease virus-transformed lymphoblastoid cell line MDCC-MSB1 (MSB1). The full-length CAV DNA of this strain was cloned into the bacterial plasmid pTZ57R/T to generate the pTZ-CAV molecular clone. The nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of viral proteins of IR CAV were compared with those of representative CAV sequences, including reference and commercial vaccine strains. IR CAV was not associated with vaccine strains and was also found to contain glutamine at positions 139 and 144, confirming previous studies that such mutations are associated with slow virus propagation rate in cell culture. pTZ-CAV was digested with PstI to release IR CAV DNA and then transfected into MSB1 cell by electroporation. Transfected cells showed cytopathic effect similar to virion-initiated infection. One-day-old specific pathogen-free chicks were vaccinated with regenerated virus from transfected MSB1 cells and compared to chicks vaccinated with IR CAV. Gross lesions in birds vaccinated with regenerated virus demonstrated the infectious nature of virus regenerated from cloned IR CAV DNA.
authors: Kaffashi, A.;Eshratabadi, F.;Shoushtari, A.

title: Partial sequence of the DNA-dependent DNA polymerase gene of avian adenoviruses: a reference panel for general diagnostic PCR in poultry.
abstract: Adenoviruses are common infectious agents in different poultry species. The traditional, serological typing of new isolates with virus neutralization tests is now in transition to be replaced by PCR and sequencing. The first proposed PCRs for the detection of adenoviruses were designed to target the hexon gene, the main capsid protein. In birds, members of three different genera of the family Adenoviridae can be found. Accordingly, three specific hexon PCRs had to be prepared for the detection of adenoviruses in poultry. A significantly more sensitive PCR targeting the viral DNA-dependent DNA polymerase gene has recently been described. This method has proven to be an effective alternative for the general detection of adenoviruses regardless of their genus affiliation. Poultry adenoviruses (FAdVs) isolated from chicken to date contain twelve serotypes classified into five virus types (FAdV-A to E). The polymerase gene sequence has yet to be determined from only three FAdV species, which represent three species. In the current study, the panel of polymerase gene sequences was complemented by those of the remaining FAdVs. The newly identified sequences will facilitate the identification of new FAdV isolates as an existing species or as a putative new FAdV. Once the polymerase sequence is known, more specific PCRs for amplification of hexon and other genes can be designed and performed based on preliminary species classification.
authors: KajÃ¡n, G.;Sameti, S.;Benko, M.

title: Japanese encephalitis in a 114-month-old cow: pathological investigation of the affected cow and genetic characterization of the Japanese encephalitis virus isolate.
abstract: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is classified in the genus Flavivirus in the family Flaviviridae. JEV can cause febrile illness and encephalitis mainly in humans and horses and occasionally cattle. In late September 2010, a 114-month-old cow showed neurological symptoms similar to those observed in previous cases of Japanese encephalitis (JE) in cattle; therefore, we performed virological and pathological tests on cows. As a result, JEV was isolated from the brain of the affected cow. We determined the complete genome sequence of the JEV isolate, which we named JEV/Bo/Aichi/1/2010, including the envelope (E) gene region and the 3' untranslated region (3'UTR). Our phylogenetic analyzes of the E region and the whole genome indicated that the isolate belongs to JEV genotype 1 (G1). The isolate, JEV/Bo/Aichi/1/2010, was most closely related to several JEV G1 isolates from Toyama Prefecture, Japan in 2007-2009 by phylogenetic analysis of the E region. In addition, nucleotide alignment revealed that the deletion in the 3'UTR was identical between JEV/Bo/Aichi/1/2010 and several other JEV G1 isolates identified in Toyama Prefecture in 2008-2009. A hemagglutination inhibition (HI) test was performed for the detection of anti-JEV antibodies in the affected cow, and the test detected 2-mercaptoethanol (2-ME)-sensitive HI antibodies against JEV in the serum of the affected cow. Histopathological examination revealed non-suppurative encephalomyelitis in the affected cow, and immunohistochemical assay detected JEV antigen in the brain. Based on the findings of nonsuppurative encephalomyelitis observed in the central nervous system, JEV antigen detected in the brain, JEV isolated from the brain and HI antibodies sensitive to 2-ME against JEV detected in the serum, we diagnosed the case with cow JE. . This is the first reported case of JE in a cow over 24 months old.
authors: Kako, N.;Suzuki, S.;Sugie, N.;Kato, T.;Yanase, T.;Yamakawa, M.;Shirafuji, H.

title: Genetic reclassification of porcine enteroviruses.
abstract: The genetic diversity of porcine teschoviruses (PTVs; previously designated porcine enterovirus 1) and most serotypes of porcine enteroviruses (PEVs) were studied. Following the determination of the majority of the genomic sequence of the PTV reference strain Talfan, the nucleotide and derived amino acid sequences of the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) region, the capsid VP2 region and the 3–2 untranslated region (3–²-NTR) PTVs and It was compared among clubfoot and with other picornaviruses. Sequences were obtained by RT-PCR and 3â€²-RACE with primers based on Talfan sequences and available PEV strains. Phylogenetic analysis of RdRp/VP2 and analysis of the predicted RNA secondary structure of 3â€²-NTR indicated that PEVs should be genetically reclassified into at least three groups, one of which should be assigned to PTVs and two PEV subtypes. 8 V 13 and strain PEV-9 UKG4 10/73.
authors: Kaku, Y.;Sarai, A.;Murakami, Y.

title: Flu Vaccine Review
abstract: Influenza viruses belong to the Orthomyxoviridae RNA virus family and are classified into three different types based on their major antigenic differences; Influenza A, Influenza B, and Influenza C. Influenza viruses cause annual human epidemics, both seasonal and pandemic. Seasonal flu epidemics caused by influenza A and B viruses result in 3-5 million serious cases and thousands of deaths worldwide each year. Influenza pandemics caused by the influenza A virus occur at unpredictable intervals. Influenza A virus will cause epidemics and pandemics as it spreads from migratory birds, pigs, horses and humans. Fomites can be transmitted from person to person through coughing and sneezing. Pandemics are responsible for increased morbidity and mortality compared to seasonal influenza. In the last century, four such pandemics have occurred in 1918, 1957, 1968 and 2009. Influenza B causes only human-to-human spread, with particular emphasis on the fact that no other hosts are involved, thus not included in pandemics. Influenza C is a mild illness.[1] It causes seasonal flu attacks, such as Northern infections from September to March, while Southern infections occur from May to September. Due to the diversity in viruses responsible for infections in these two seasons; He needs two different sets of vaccines. Influenza usually has an incubation period of 2 days, ranging from 1 to 4 days.
authors: Kalarikkal, S. M.;Jaishankar, G. B.

title: Co-circulation of three clusters of 793/B-like avian infectious bronchitis virus genotypes in Iranian chicken flocks
abstract: Avian infectious bronchitis (IB) is an acute and highly contagious viral disease that causes serious economic losses to the poultry industry. 793/B IB virus is an important genotype of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) currently circulating in many countries, including Iran. One hundred confirmed IBV specimens (between 2014 and 2015; from 15 provinces in Iran) were selected for genotyping based on S1 sequence. As a result of the phylogenetic analysis, it was determined that 30% of the IBV isolates belonged to the 793/B genotype. The results showed that Iranian 793/B-like IBV isolates could be divided into three clusters: 4/91-like (50%), 1/96-like (40%) and IB88-like (10%). Sequence similarity between Iranian 793/B-like IBV isolates is 87.69-100%. The highest identity is between 4/91 and IB88 clusters (96.38%), while the lowest similarity is between 1/96 and IB88 clusters (87.62%). This study presents a comprehensive analysis of 793/B-type IBV in Iran and characterization of the molecular epidemiology of IBV in the country.
authors: Kalokhoran, A. Y.;Ghalyanchilangeroudi, A.;Hosseini, H.;Madadgar, O.;Karimi, V.;Hashemzadeh, M.;Hesari, P.;Zabihi Petroudi, M. T.;Najafi, H.

title: Avian influenza as a zoonotic agent (highly pathogenic)
abstract: The zoonotic agents that challenge the world every year are influenza A viruses. In the past, human pandemics caused by influenza A viruses occurred periodically. Wild waterfowl are carriers of all variants of influenza virus A subtypes and therefore most likely form the natural reservoir of all influenza A viruses. While avian influenza viruses in natural avian reservoirs generally have low pathogenicity (LPAIV), some have gained virulence by mutation after transmission and adaptation to susceptible biliary poultry. So-called highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIV) cause mass mortality in susceptible birds and cause enormous economic losses when poultry is affected. Besides a number of avian influenza virus subtypes with sporadically infected mammals, HPAIV H5N1 Asia shows strong zoonotic features and has been transmitted from birds to different mammalian species, including humans. Theoretically, pandemic viruses may originate directly from avian influenza viruses or may arise after genetic reclassification between avian and mammalian viruses. So far, HPAIV H5N1 already meets two conditions for a pandemic virus: as a new subtype it has never been seen in the human population and has infected at least 438 people and caused serious illness and high lethality in 262 people to date (August). 2009). Achieving effective human-to-human transmission would complete the emergence of a new pandemic virus. Therefore, fighting H5N1 at its source is a prerequisite for reducing the pandemic risks posed by this virus. Other influenza viruses considered pandemic candidates are descended from the H2, H7, and H9 subtypes, all of which have infected humans in the past. Here we provide a comprehensive overview of avian influenza viruses regarding their zoonotic potential. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kalthoff, D.;Globig, A.;Beer, M.

title: Serological classification of feline caliciviruses by plaque reduction neutralization and immunodiffusion
abstract: Serological classification of 14 feline calicivirus isolates was performed using plaque reduction neutralization tests. Sixty to 200 plaque-forming units of virus were used against 20 antibody units of hyperimmune goat antisera prepared on individual isolates. The results revealed that these viruses are related to varying degrees, but no two are the same. Arrangements in order of greatest intergroup reaction yielded essentially 1 serotype, except for 1 virus that showed unidirectional neutralization reactions with heterologous isolates. Geographical origin, site of viral isolation, or plaque size had no association with neutralization pattern. The F9 isolate, which showed the greatest intergroup reactions, was proposed as a possible reference virus. Viruses were indistinguishable using gel diffusion analysis versus feline antisera.
authors: Kalunda, M.;Lee, K. M.;Holmes, D. F.;Gillespie, J. H.

title: Evidence that enteric viruses circulate together in sewers and the population of Greater Cairo
abstract: Objectives: To characterize the major enteric viruses (enterovirus, rotavirus, norovirus, astrovirus and adenovirus) in the sewers of Greater Cairo and compare the results with clinical data collected over the same period. Methods and Results: Seventy-two sewage samples were collected from two wastewater treatment plants from April 2006 to February 2007. Enteroviruses, noroviruses (NoVs) and rotaviruses (RVs) were detected by RT-PCR at a rate of 22%, 18% and 8Â·. 3% of the samples, respectively. Adenovirus and astrovirus were not detected. G2P[8], G9P[8], G1P[8], G2P[4] and rare G12 RV isolates were detected in the setting alongside a bovine RV. Environmental NoV strains mostly belonged to genogroup I (84%). Rotaviruses and some NoVs were also similar to those found in clinical specimens. Conclusions: Comparison of environmental and clinical data shows that similar RV and NoV isolates were circulating in the environment and population during the same period. Significance and Impact of the Study: Few studies have investigated the prevalence and epidemiology of RVs and NoVs in Cairo. This study is the first to establish an association between viral gastroenteritis and the simultaneous presence of enteric viruses in the environment for Greater Cairo, where combined environmental and clinical studies should help prevent infections by these major pathogens. Â© 2009 Society for Applied Microbiology.
authors: Kamel, A. H.;Ali, M. A.;El-Nady, H. G.;Aho, S.;Pothier, P.;Belliot, G.

title: A simple method for parallel deep sequencing of complete influenza A genomes
abstract: Given the grave threat of influenza A to human and animal health and its ability to evolve rapidly through mutation and reclassification, tools that enable its timely characterization are necessary to help track its evolution and spread. To this end, deep sorting can be an invaluable tool. This study reports a comprehensive method that enables in-depth sequencing of complete genomes of influenza A subtypes using the Illumina Genome Analyzer IIx (GAIIx). Using this method, the complete genomes of nine viruses representing the 2009 pandemic H1N1 virus, human H5N1 virus, and porcine H1N1 virus were sequenced in parallel to an average depth of 122 times in a single lane of a GAIIx flow cell. . This technique can be applied to cultivated and uncultivated virus. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Kampmann, M. L.;Fordyce, S. L.;Ãvila-Arcos, M. C.;Rasmussen, M.;Willerslev, E.;Nielsen, L. P.;Gilbert, M. T. P.

title: Nucleotide sequence of avian carcinoma virus MH2: Two potential onc genes, one related to avian virus MC29 and the other to murine sarcoma virus 3611.
abstract: The 5.2-kilobase (kb) RNA genome of avian carcinoma virus MH2 has 5'-Î”gag (0.2 kg)-mhg (1.2 kg)-myc (1.4kb)-c (0.4 kg)-poly)A genetic structure. ) (0.2 kb)-3'. Î”gag is a partial retroviral core protein gene, mht and myc are cell-derived MH2-specific sequences, and c is the 3'-terminal retroviral vector sequence. Here we present the 3.5 kb nucleotide sequence from the 3' end of Î´gag to the 3' end of proviral MH2 DNA molecularly cloned to elucidate the genetic makeup of the virus and other mht- and myc-containing oncogenic virus as well as with the chicken proto-myc gene. The following results were obtained: (i) Î´gag-mht generates a hybrid gene with a contiguous reading frame of 2682 nucleotides ending with a stop codon near the 3' end of mht. The 3' 969 nucleotides of mht up to the stop codon are 80% sequenced with the onc-specific raf sequence (94% homologous at the amino acid level removed) of murine sarcoma virus 3611. (ii) The myc sequence is preceded by an RNA splice acceptor region shared with the cellular proto-myc gene, beyond which it is in line with the avian retrovirus MC29 and chicken myc sequences to the 3'-termination codon and 40 noncoding nucleotides. proto-myc. Thus myc forms a second MH2-specific gene together with a 5' retroviral exon. (iii) myc is followed by the 3'-terminal c region of about 400 nucleotides, which is in line with that of Rous sarcoma virus except for a displacement near the 5' end of the long terminal repeat. It was concluded that MH2 contains two genes with oncogenic potential, the Î”gag-mht gene, which is closely related to the Î”gag-raf transforming gene of MSV 3611, and the myc gene, which is closely related to the transforming gene of MSV 3611. MC29. It can also be concluded that cellular proto-onc genes that become viral onc genes in sequence transduction are a small group, as 5 out of 19 known onc sequences are shared by different taxonomic virus groups of mht/raf. homology is the closest ever determined.
authors: Kan, N. C.;Flordellis, C. S.;Mark, G. E.

title: Impact of emergence of Coxsackievirus A6 in Osaka City, Japan on hand, foot, and mouth disease epidemic
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute febrile illness characterized by fever; throat ache; and vesicular eruptions on the mucous membranes of the hands, feet, and mouth. Until 2010, HFMD was predominantly associated with enterovirus (EV) A71 and coxsackievirus (CV) A16 in Japan. In 2011, CV-A6 emerged as the primary causative agent causing the largest HFMD outbreak in Japan since 1981. Since then, CV-A6 has caused major HFMD outbreaks every 2 years. Phylogenetic analysis of Whole Viral Protein 1 (VP1) sequences revealed that most CV-A6 strains detected from 2011 to 2015 in Osaka City were classified in a different branch compared to CV-A6 strains detected from 1999 to 2009. put it. The A6 strain detected in 2011 and most CV-A6 strains detected from 2013 to 2015 were mainly divided into two different genetic groups. Each epidemic strain carried unique amino acid substitutions in the putative DE, EF, and GH loops of the VP1 protein exposed on the virion surface. The appearance of substitutions on the virion surface and the accumulation of a susceptible population are likely to be important factors in recent HFMD outbreaks.
authors: Kanbayashi, D.;Kaida, A.;Yamamoto, S. P.;Hirai, Y.;Kubo, H.;Fujimori, R.;Hakui, N.;Hirokawa, H.;Iritani, N.

title: Genetic characterization of highly pathogenic avian influenza A H5N8 viruses isolated from wild birds in Egypt.
abstract: In December 2016, a newly emerged H5N8 influenza virus was isolated from green-winged teal in Egypt. In this study, we present a detailed characterization of the complete genomes of Egyptian H5N8 viruses and some virological features. Genetic analysis has shown that Egyptian H5N8 viruses are highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the genome of Egyptian H5N8 viruses is related to recently characterized reassortant 2.3.4.4 clan H5N8 viruses isolated from different Eurasian countries. Numerous peculiar mutations have been characterized in maize H5N8 viruses, possibly allowing these viruses to transmit and virulence in mammals. Egyptian H5N8 viruses preferentially bind to bird-like receptors rather than human-like receptors. Also, Egyptian H5N8 viruses were fully sensitive to amantadine and neuraminidase inhibitors. Chicken sera grown against commercial inactivated avian influenza-H5 vaccines showed no or very low reactivity with currently characterized H5N8 viruses, consistent with genetic variation. Surveillance of avian influenza in waterfowl provides early warning of certain threats to poultry and human health and should therefore be continued.
authors: Kandeil, A.;Kayed, A.;Moatasim, Y.;Webby, R. J.;McKenzie, P. P.;Kayali, G.;Ali, M. A.

title: Reassortant swine flu viruses isolated in Japan contain pandemic A(H1N1) 2009 genes
abstract: In 2013, three reasortant swine flu viruses (SIV) (two H1N2 and one H3N2) were isolated from symptomatic pigs in Japan; each contained genes from the pandemic A(H1N1) 2009 virus and endemic SIVs. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that two H1N2 viruses, A/swine/Gunma/1/2013 and A/swine/Ibaraki/1/2013, are reasortants containing genes from three different lineages: (i) H1 and nucleoprotein (NP) Japanese Genes derived from a classic porcine H1 HA lineage uniquely circulating among its SIVs; (ii) neuraminidase (NA) genes from human-like H1N2 porcine viruses; and (iii) other genes from pandemic A(H1N1) 2009 viruses. The H3N2 virus, A/swine/Miyazaki/2/2013, consisted of genes from two sources: (i) hemagglutinin (HA) and NA genes derived from human and human-like H3N2 porcine viruses, and (ii) pandemic A(H1N1) 2009 viruses. Phylogenetic analysis also showed that each reassortant may have arisen independently in Japanese pigs. A/swine/Miyazaki/2/2013 has strong antigenic reactivity with antisera produced for some seasonal human strain viruses isolated during or before 2003, whereas A/swine/Miyazaki/2/2013 has antisera reactivity against viruses isolated after 2004. found. was clearly weaker. In addition, antisera against some strains of seasonal human lineage H1 viruses did not react with A/swine/Gunma/1/2013 or A/swine/Ibaraki/1/2013. These findings suggest that the emergence and spread of these reassortant SIVs is a potential public health risk. Â© 2014 The Societies and Wiley Publishing Asia Pty Ltd.
authors: Kanehira, K.;Takemae, N.;Uchida, Y.;Hikono, H.;Saito, T.

title: Genetic analyzes of avian influenza viruses in Mongolia between 2007 and 2009 and their association with Korean isolates from domestic poultry and wild birds.
abstract: This study was conducted to monitor wild birds based on concern that they could spread the avian influenza virus (AIV) between Mongolia and Korea, which share the same migration route. From the 1,528 stool samples analyzed, 21 low-pathogenic AIVs were isolated from 2007 to 2009. Nineteen AIV positive stool samples were identified as Anseriformes by DNA barcode. The most commonly isolated subtype was H3 (61.9%) and the most common hemagglutinin/neuraminidase combination was H3N8 (52.4%). Phylogenetic analysis was performed to assess their genetic relationship to domestic poultry and wild birds in Korea. The H3 and H7 surface genes belonged to the Eurasian ancestry and were grouped together with Korean wild birds and poultry. While most N8 genes phylogenetically clustered with viruses isolated in Eurasia, 1 of the Mongolian viruses and some Korean viruses belonged to the North American ancestry. The polymerase acidic protein of the internal gene was indistinguishable from the highly pathogenic AIV of the goose/guangdong/1/1996 (gs/ gd)-like virus H5N1. Our study shows that Mongolian AIV isolates genetically evolve with multiple genotypes and are closely related to AIV in poultry and Korean wild birds. Â© 2011 Poultry Science Association A.Ş.
authors: Kang, H.;Kim, M.;Choi, J.;Batchuluun, D.;Erdene-Ochir, T.;Paek, M.;Sodnomdarjaa, R.;Kwon, J.;Lee, Y.

title: Isolation of reassortant H13N2 virus from a mallard stool sample in South Korea
abstract: Background: Virus subtype H13N2, A/mallhead/Kr/SH38-45/2010 (H13N2), was first isolated from a mallard fecal sample in South Korea. Results: Phylogenetic analysis of all eight viral genes revealed that this virus arose through genetic mixing between the Eurasian and North American gene pools, and possibly between wild ducks and gulls. The H13 and N2 surface genes clustered in a group with Eurasian isolates from gulls and wild birds, respectively. The PB2, PA, NP, M, and NS segments belong to the Eurasian lineage, while the PB1 gene is clustered in the North American lineage. They also showed an avian-related pattern in the phylogenetic analysis: the M gene was similar to subtype H13 viruses in gulls, while other segments were similar to avian influenza viruses of other subtypes from wild ducks. Conclusions: The data suggest that the novel reassortant H13N2 virus isolated in South Korea may have arisen by genetic reclassification between intercontinental and interspecies transmission in wild birds. Â© 2012 Kang et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Kang, H. M.;Choi, J. G.;Kim, M. C.;Kim, H. R.;Oem, J. K.;Bae, Y. C.;Paek, M. R.;Kwon, J. H.;Lee, Y. J.

title: Isolation of avian influenza virus (H9N2) from emu in China
abstract: This is the first reported isolation of avian influenza virus (AIV) from emu in China. An outbreak of AIV infection has occurred on an emu farm housing 40 four-month-old birds. Various degrees of hemorrhages were discovered in the affected emus tissues. Microscopically, cell degeneration and necrosis were observed. Electron microscopy revealed round or oval virions with a diameter of 80 nm to 120 nm surrounded by a pointed envelope. The virus was classified as low pathogenic AIV (LPAIV) according to OIE standards. It was named A/Emu/HeNen/14/2004(H9N2)(Emu/HN/2004). The HA gene (168315p) was amplified by RT-PCR and compared to other animal H9N2 AIV sequences in the US National Institutes of Health genetic sequence database GenBank. The results indicated that Emu/HN/2004 may have come from an avian influenza virus (H9N2) from Southern China.
authors: Kang, W. H.;Pang, W. Y.;Hao, J. F.;Zhao, D. M.

title: Phylogenetic relationships and pathogenicity variation of two Newcastle disease viruses isolated from domestic ducks in southern China.
abstract: Background: Newcastle disease (ND) is an OIE listed disease caused by virulent avian paramyxovirus type 1 (APMV-1) strains, which are enzootic and cause great economic losses in the poultry industry. Genotype VII and genotype IX NDV viruses were the dominant genotype circulating in China and may possibly be responsible for disease outbreaks in chicken flocks in recent years. While ducks and geese often exhibit invisible infections. Methods In this study, we investigate the whole genome sequencing, clinicopathological characterization and transmission of two virulent Newcastle disease viruses, SS-10 and NH-10, isolated from domestic ducks in Southern China in 2010. Results: Sequences based on F and whole gene phylogenetic analysis showed that SS-10 (genotype VII) and NH-10 (genotype IX) belong to class II. The deduced amino acid sequence was <sup>(112)</sup>RRQK/RRF<sup>(117)</sup> at the fusion protein cleavage site. Animal experiment results showed that SS-10 virus isolated from ducks was highly pathogenic for chickens and geese, but low pathogenic for ducks. It can be detected from spleen, lung, kidney, trachea, small intestine, bursa fabric, thymus, pancreas and cecal tonsils, oropharyngeal and cloacal swabs and can be transmitted to naive contact birds. It can also infect chickens, ducks and geese by pure contact. However, the NH-10 virus isolated from ducks can infect some chickens, ducks and geese, but only cause the chickens to die. In addition, it can infect pure contact chickens, ducks and geese. Conclusion: Two NDV isolates showed different biological properties in terms of pathogenicity and transmission in chickens, ducks and geese. Therefore, there is no species preference for chicken, duck or goose viruses, and more attention should be paid to the interspecies transmission of VII NDVs between ducks, geese and chickens for the control and eradication of ND.
authors: Kang, Y.;Li, Y.;Yuan, R.;Li, X.;Sun, M.;Wang, Z.;Feng, M.;Jiao, P.;Ren, T.

title: Phylogenetic and pathotypical characterization of Newcastle disease viruses circulating in southern China and transmission in different birds.
abstract: Although the highly pathogenic Newcastle disease virus (NDV) has been frequently isolated from poultry in China since 1948, the mode of transmission among avian species is largely unknown. Given that various wild bird species play a role as sources of transmission, in this study we genotypically and pathotypically characterized 23 NDV isolates collected from chickens, ducks and pigeons at live bird markets (LBMs) in Southern China as part of an H7N9 surveillance program. To simulate the natural transmission of different animal species in LBMs, we selected three representative NDVs (GM, YF18 and GZ289) isolated from different birds to assess the pathogenicity and transmission of the indicated viruses. chickens, ducks and pigeons. Furthermore, to investigate the replication and shedding of NDV in poultry, we inoculated chickens, ducks and pigeons with an EID50 of 106 of each virus by intraocular and intranasal routes. Eight hours after infection, naive contact groups were housed with those vaccinated with each of the viruses as a means to monitor contact transmission. Our results showed that genetically diverse viruses circulate in LBMs in Guangdong Province, South China, and that NDV from different birds has different tissue tropisms and host ranges when transmitted in different birds. Therefore, we recommend continuous epidemiological surveillance of LBMs to support the prevention of the spread of these viruses in different birds, particularly chickens, and highlight the need for studies of virus-host association.
authors: Kang, Y.;Xiang, B.;Yuan, R.;Zhao, X.;Feng, M.;Gao, P.;Li, Y.;Li, Y.;Ning, Z.;Ren, T.

title: Isolation and characterization of a parapoxvirus from sheep with papular stomatitis
abstract: An outbreak of papular stomatitis occurred in a flock of sheep in Hokkaido, Japan. Histological examination, immunohistochemistry, electron microscopic observation and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) were performed. The lesions were characterized by epithelial hyperplasia, acanthosis, ballooning degeneration of the spinous layer, and stratum granulosum. A parapoxvirus was isolated from the skin lesions of affected sheep and characterized genetically and antigenically. Restriction endonuclease analysis of the PCR product showed a pattern specific to orf virus (ORFV) and the isolate reacted with monoclonal antibodies against ORFV. The partially deduced amino acid sequence of the viral envelope gene was principally the same as that of Japanese ORFVs. These results showed that the epidemic was caused by parapoxvirus infection. The isolated virus could be classified as ORFV and was closely related mainly to Japanese ORFVs but not foreign ORFVs or other parapoxviruses.
authors: Kanou, Y.;Inoshima, Y.;Shibahara, T.;Ishikawa, Y.;Kadota, K.;Ohashi, S.;Morioka, K.;Yoshida, K.;Yamada, S.

title: Classification of Dutch and German avian reoviruses by sequencing the ÏƒC protein
abstract: We amplified, cloned and sequenced (part of) the open reading frame of the S1 segment encoding the ÏƒC protein of avian reoviruses isolated from chickens with different disease conditions in Germany and the Netherlands from 1980 to 2000. These avian reoviruses were analyzed. phylogenetically and compared with sequences of avian reoviruses in the Genbank database. Avian reoviruses can be grouped into 5 different genotyping clusters, and this classification was the same when the sequences were compared to the 5â€² end, 3â€² end of protein C or the entire open reading frame. Therefore, sequencing of any part of the gene encoding the ÏƒC protein appears reliable for classification. We could not detect a correlation between the ÏƒC sequences of avian reoviruses and the disease state from which they were isolated. The sequences found in the Netherlands and Germany, such as those in Taiwan, are more diffuse than the known avian reovirus ÏƒC sequences in the USA and Australia. We did not establish temporal or geographic differences in the avian reoviruses studied.
authors: Kant, A.;Balk, F.;Born, L.;Van Roozelaar, D.;Heijmans, J.;Gielkens, A.;Ter Huurne, A.

title: Characterization of isolated partial genomic sequences of Hepatitis E virus and genotype 3 HEV in young pigs from Finland.
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infections occur in pigs worldwide. Swine infection is usually subclinical, but HEV genotypes 3 and 4 are zoonotic agents that cause sporadic, native cases of human hepatitis E. The aim of this study was to investigate the occurrence and dynamics of total HEV infections in young pigs. 273 faecal samples collected from six farms to genetically characterize the resulting HEV isolates and to examine the phylogenetic relationships of HEV isolates occurring in different pig farms in Finland. Fecal shedding of HEV of individual piglets was monitored in two farms selected from five farms identified as HEV RNA positive. HEV excretion was detected in 87.5% of piglets during the study. Piglets contracted primary HEV infection 3-8 weeks after weaning and when transferred to breeding farms, nearly all (96.6%) of pigs with an available sample on this occasion were still shedding the virus. According to the phylogenetic analysis, all HEV isolates obtained belonged to HEV genotype 3, subtype e, and the separate, farm-specific isolate originating from 10 out of 11 farms studied. The results of our study show that HEV infections in young pigs are quite common and HEV RNA-positive pigs pose a possible risk of infection for pig breeders by enabling HEV transmission from farms to fattening farms, and there are genetic variations in HEVs from different origins. farms are formed.
authors: Kantala, T.;Heinonen, M.;Oristo, S.;Von Bonsdorff, C. H.;Maunula, L.

title: Supersize me: How whole genome sequencing and big data are transforming epidemiology
abstract: In epidemiology, identifying 'who infects whom' allows us to measure key features such as incubation times, heterogeneity in transmission rates, duration of contagiousness, and presence of high-risk groups. Although invaluable, the existence of many plausible routes of infection complicates this and makes epidemiological contact tracing uncertain, logistically prohibitive, or both. The recent emergence of next-generation sequencing technology is transforming our ability to understand high-resolution disease transmission, sometimes even from host to host scale, by allowing the identification of traceable differences in the pathogen genome. We review recent examples of the use of pathogen whole genome sequencing for forensic monitoring of transmission routes and focus on specific issues that evolutionary dynamics need to be supported by epidemiological information about the most likely timing of events and possible transmission routes. . We also discuss the potential pitfalls in over-interpreting these data and highlight that combining this technology with complex mathematical and statistical approaches has the potential to produce a paradigm shift in our understanding of infectious disease transmission and control. © 2014 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Kao, R. R.;Haydon, D. T.;Lycett, S. J.;Murcia, P. R.

title: Next-generation sequencing technologies: tool to study avian virus diversity
abstract: Increasing globalization, climate changes and the wildlife-livestock interface have resulted in the emergence of new viral pathogens or zoonoses that have become a serious concern for bird, animal and human health. High biodiversity and bird migration facilitate the spread of the pathogen and provide reservoirs for emerging infectious diseases. Current classical diagnostic methods, which aim to be limited to the group of virus-specific or viral agents, preclude the identification of new viruses or viral variants. Recently developed next-generation sequencing (NGS) approaches provide better diagnosis and disease control by providing culture-independent methods useful for understanding viral diversity and discovery of novel virus. This review discusses the different possible steps of an NGS study using sequence-independent amplification, high-throughput sequencing and bioinformatics approaches to identify novel avian viruses and their diversity. NGS leads to the identification of a wide variety of novel viruses, such as picobirnavirus, picornavirus, orthoreovirus, and avian gamma coronavirus associated with guinea fowl, and is also used to characterize viral diversity among avian species. The review also briefly discusses the areas of viral-host interaction and disease-associated causation with newly identified avian viruses.
authors: Kapgate, S. S.;Barbuddhe, S. B.;Kumanan, K.

title: Avian parvovirus: classification, phylogeny, pathogenesis and diagnosis
abstract: Defined in the early 1980s, avian parvoviruses are found worldwide in the intestines of healthy birds as well as young birds with enteric disease syndrome. Chicken parvovirus (ChPV) and turkey parvovirus (TuPV) belong to the genus Aveparvovirus within the Parvovirinae subfamily. Poultry parvoviruses are small, non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA viruses consisting of three open reading frames; 1 (VP1), the first two encoding nonstructural protein (NS) and nuclear phosphoprotein (NP), and the third encoding viral capsid proteins. and VP2). Unlike other parvoviruses, the VP1-specific region does not contain the phospholipase A2 sequence motif. Recent experimental studies have suggested that parvoviruses are candidate pathogens in cases of enteric disease syndrome. Current diagnostic methods for detection of avian parvovirus include PCR, real-time PCR, enzyme-linked immunosorbent testing using recombinant VP2 or VP1 capsid proteins. Moreover, sequence-independent amplification techniques combined with next-generation sequencing platforms have allowed rapid and simultaneous detection of parvovirus from affected and healthy birds. There is no commercial vaccine; therefore, the development of an effective vaccine to control the spread of infection should be of primary importance. This review presents up-to-date information on avian parvoviruses with an emphasis on taxonomy, phylogenetic association, genomic analysis, epidemiology, pathogenesis, and diagnostic methods.
authors: Kapgate, S. S.;Kumanan, K.;Vijayarani, K.;Barbuddhe, S. B.

title: Multiple new strains of astroviruses in human feces
abstract: Diarrhea continues to be an important cause of morbidity and mortality in developing countries, where a large number of cases remain without a defined etiology. Astroviruses are a recently identified cause of animal gastroenteritis, which includes two species currently suspected to cause human diarrhea. Using pan-astrovirus RT-PCR, we analyzed human fecal samples from different continents for astrovirus-related RNA sequences. Based on variants of the two known human astrovirus species and genetic distance criteria, we identified three new astrovirus species, all distantly related to mink and ovine astroviruses, and tentatively named them HMOAstV strain AC. The complete genome of strain A displayed all the conserved features of mammalian astroviruses. Each of the three groups of astroviruses (HAstV, AstV-MLB, and HMOAstV) currently found in human feces were more closely related to animal astroviruses, suggesting that human astroviruses can emerge periodically from zoonotic transmissions. Based on the pathogenicity of its closest phylogenetic relatives in animals, further investigation into the role of HMOAstV in human gastroenteritis, which has been detected so far in Nigeria, Nepal and Pakistan, is warranted. © 2009 SGM.
authors: Kapoor, A.;Li, L.;Victoria, J.;Oderinde, B.;Mason, C.;Pandey, P.;Zaidi, S. Z.;Delwart, E.

title: A Newly Identified Bocavirus Species in Human Feces
abstract: Viral metagenomic analysis was used to identify "HBoV2", a previously uncharacterized parvovirus strain whose closest phylogenetic relative is human bocavirus (HBoV). HBoV2 has an identical genomic organization to HBoV, but only 78%, 67% and 80% identity with the latter's NS1, NP1 and VP1/VP2 proteins, respectively. The study used polymerase chain reaction to detect HBoV2 sequences in 5 of 98 stool samples from Pakistani children and in 3 of 699 stool samples from Edinburgh. Almost full-length genome sequencing revealed the presence of 3 HBoV2 genotypes and evidence of recombination between genotypes. Further studies are required to identify the anatomical sites of HBoV2 replication and potential associations with clinical symptoms or disease.
authors: Kapoor, A.;Slikas, E.;Simmonds, P.;Chieochansin, T.;Naeem, A.;Shaukat, S.;Alam, M. M.;Sharif, S.;Angez, M.;Zaidi, S.;Delwart, E.

title: Detection of non-polio enteroviruses and molecular epidemiology of enterovirus 71, coxsackievirus A16 and echovirus 30 in Hungary 2000-2008.
abstract: Human enteroviruses are associated with a variety of clinical syndromes, from minor febrile illness to serious, potentially fatal conditions such as aseptic meningitis, stroke, myocarditis, and neonatal enteroviral sepsis. Between June 2000 and August 2008, echovirus (E) types 2, 4, 6, 7, 9, 11, 13, 25, 30, coxsackievirus (CV) -A16, -A19, -B5 and enterovirus 71 (EV71) were reported in Hungary. In this study, 29 previously positive enterovirus samples from 28 patients diagnosed with hand, foot and mouth disease, meningitis and encephalitis were molecularly typed. The genetic associations of the identified serotypes CV-A16, EV71 and E30 were assessed by direct sequencing of the genomic region encoding the capsid protein VP1. Sequences were compared with each other and with sequences from other geographic areas located in Genbank. Phylogenetic analysis of CV-A16 revealed that viruses are mostly of Far Eastern or Asia-Pacific origin. Typing of EV71 showed that one virus from 2000 belonged to genotype C1, and five viruses observed in 2004 and 2005 were identified as genotype C4. 11 strains of echovirus 30 showed homology with those of neighboring European countries. Molecular analysis of E30 revealed that three distinct strains were circulating in Hungary in 2000, 2001 and 2004-2006. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2009.
authors: Kapusinszky, B.;Szomor, K. N.;Farkas, A.;TakÃ¡cs, M.;Berencsi, G.

title: Supplement to the international catalog of arboviruses, including several other vertebrate viruses
abstract: The first edition was published in 1967 and represented the working Catalog in February 1967, when it contained information about 204 registered viruses. Thirty-seven additional viruses registered until June 1970 were published in an appendix in November 1970. A second update patch with 14 newly registered viruses was released in November 1971. The second edition of the catalog was published in 1975 and contained information about 359. Viruses registered in the catalog running as of December 1974. This current report includes the first supplement of the second published Catalog edition and includes 30 additional virus records. With the retraction of Samford virus, which was determined to be a type of Aino virus, the number of registered viruses reached 388. Of the 30 new records in this appendix, 17 viruses isolated from arthropods, 2 viruses isolated from humans, and 11 isolated from other vertebrates. Two human viruses (ROC, EBO) have been associated with serious human disease. One of the arthropod isolates (ORU) and a virus isolated from a mule (VSA) have also been implicated in human disease, and SSH virus from a rabbit has been noted to cause subclinical infections in man. Three viruses (BEF, IBA, VSA) isolated from cattle and mules cause widespread disease in domestic animals. ACAV's Arthropod-Borne Status (SEAS) Evaluation Subcommittee rated only one of these newly recorded viruses (SSH) as a proven arbovirus, based on experimental demonstration of transmission by mosquitoes. Another (ORU) was rated as a possible arbovirus; the third (EBO) is probably not an arbovirus; and the remainder as possible arboviruses awaiting more definitive information on arthropod infection and transmission.
authors: Karabatsos, N.

title: A novel method for multiplexed target enrichment of MinION next-generation sequencing libraries using PCR-generated baits.
