abstract: Enrichment of targeted regions within complex next-generation sequencing libraries commonly uses biotinylated baits to capture desired sequences. This method provides high read coverage over targets and their flanking regions. Oxford Nanopore Technologies has recently released the Minion, a sequencer with a USB3.0 interface. To date, no particular method for enriching Minion libraries has been standardized. Here, we describe a simple and efficient way for multifold enrichment of MinION libraries, using biotinylated PCR-generated baits in a novel approach, overcoming technical limitations regarding the chemistry of sequencing-adapters and the length of DNA fragments. Using Phage Lambda and Escherichia coli as models, we selectively enrich for specific targets, significantly increasing the corresponding read coverage, eliminating unwanted regions. We show that by capturing genomic fragments containing target sequences, we recover reads that expand targeted regions so that they can be used to identify potentially unknown flanking sequences. We demonstrate the efficiency of this method in multiplexed form by pooling enriched libraries derived from two different E. coli strains and analyzing them in parallel. We evaluated the optimal bait size for large fragment libraries and for the first time defined a standardized method for target enrichment on the Minion platform.
authors: Karamitros, T.;Magiorkinis, G.

title: Genetic characterization of H3N2 influenza viruses isolated from pigs in North America, 1977-1999: Evidence for fully human and reassortant virus genotypes.
abstract: Since 1998, H3N2 viruses have caused epizootics of respiratory disease in pigs in major US pork production areas. We sequenced the full-length protein-coding regions of all eight RNA segments from four H3N2 viruses that we isolated from pigs in the Midwestern United States between March 1998 and March 1999, as well as from H3N2 viruses recovered from a piglet in Canada in January 1997 and from a pig in Colorado in 1977. taken. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that the 1977 Colorado and 1997 Ontario isolates were fully human influenza viruses. However, viruses isolated from pigs in the Midwestern USA since 1998 are reassortant viruses containing hemagglutinin, neuraminidase, and PB1 polymerase genes from human influenza viruses, matrix, nonstructural, and nucleoprotein genes from classical porcine viruses, and PA and PB2 polymerase genes from birds. viruses. The HA proteins of Midwestern reassortant porcine viruses can be distinguished from the 1995 human H3 virus strain by the 12 amino acid mutation in HA1. In contrast, the Sw/ONT/97 virus, which does not spread from pig to pig, lacks 11 of these changes. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Karasin, A. I.;Schutten, M. M.;Cooper, L. A.;Smith, C. B.;Subbarao, K.;Anderson, G. A.;Carman, S.;Olsen, C. W.

title: Characterization of avian H3N3 and H1N1 influenza A viruses isolated from pigs in Canada
abstract: H3N3 and H1N1 influenza A viruses were isolated from Canadian pigs in 2001 and 2002. These viruses are phylogenetically related to waterfowl viruses and antigenically different from reference swine influenza viruses. The isolation of these viruses re-emphasizes the potential for interspecies transmission of influenza viruses from waterfowl to pigs in North America.
authors: Karasin, A. I.;West, K.;Carman, S.;Olsen, C. W.

title: Intestinal eukaryotic virome in healthy and diarrheal neonatal piglets
abstract: Neonatal swine diarrhea of uncertain etiology has been reported in some European countries. The aim of this study was to use viral metagenomics to examine possible viral involvement in this diarrheal and to identify the intestinal virome with a focus on eukaryotic viruses. Samples from the distal jejunum of 50 diarrheal and 19 healthy piglets from 10 affected flocks were analyzed. The viral fraction of the samples was isolated and the nucleic acids (RNA and DNA fractions) were subjected to sequence-independent amplification. Samples from diarrheal piglets from the same herds were pooled, while samples from healthy piglets were analyzed separately. A total of 29 clinical samples, plus two negative controls and a positive control of mock metagenome, were sequenced using the Ion Torrent platform. The obtained sequence data were subjected to taxonomic classification using Kraken, Diamond and HMMER. Eight different mammalian virus families (Adenoviridae, Anelloviridae, Astroviridae, Caliciviridae, Circoviridae, Parvoviridae, Picornaviridae, and Reoviridae) were detected in healthy samples, while four were detected in pooled diarrheal samples (Anelloviridae, Circoviridae, Picornaviridae, and Reoviridae). It was not possible to associate a particular virus family with the diarrhea investigated. In conclusion, this study does not support the hypothesis that the diarrhea under investigation is caused by known mammalian viruses. The results, however, indicate that known mammalian viruses are present in the gut as early as 24-48 hours after birth, suggesting immediate postnatal infection or possibly transplacental infection.
authors: Karlsson, O. E.;Larsson, J.;Hayer, J.;Berg, M.;Jacobson, M.

title: A severe pediatric infection with a new strain of enterovirus A71, Thuringia, Germany
abstract: Infection with enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) is a major cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). Outbreaks involving severe cases with neurological and cardiopulmonary complications have been reported, particularly from Southeast Asia. The epidemiology of EV-A71 in Europe is not well understood. In the summer of 2015, a two-year-old girl from Thuringia, Germany, presented with rhombencephalitis/brainstem encephalitis associated with severe neurological and cardiopulmonary complications. EV-A71 was detected in stool and nearly the entire viral genome was amplified and sequenced. The region encoding the capsid protein VP1 belongs to the EV-A71 subgenogroup C1, while the region encoding the 3D polymerase represents a unique lineage. Therefore, the data suggest that the Thuringian EV-A71 sequence likely represents a recombinant. The case highlights the importance of intensified EV-A71 surveillance in Germany and Europe, including analysis of whole genome data.
authors: Karrasch, M.;Fischer, E.;Scholten, M.;Sauerbrei, A.;Henke, A.;Renz, D. M.;Mentzel, H. J.;Boer, K.;Bottcher, S.;Diedrich, S.;Krumbholz, A.;Zell, R.

title: Understanding the evolutionary relationship of hemagglutinin protein from influenza viruses using phylogenetic and molecular modeling studies.
abstract: The current H1N1 (2009) swine flu is epidemic in nature and is responsible for global economic losses and deaths. Among the eight gene segments of H1N1, hemagglutinin (HA) plays an important role in the attachment of the virus to the host cell surface, and entry of viral RNA into the host cell leads to infection. In this study, the 1952 sequences of H1N1 (2009) HA from Mexico City and the sequence and phylogenetic analysis of different subtypes of the pandemic influenza A virus were studied, and the results showed the closest association with the H1N1 (2009) Mexico strain. H1N1 (2007) Norwegian Mallard strain. Analysis of the predicted secondary structures from the protein sequence revealed that reduction of alpha helices was observed in many areas of the sequences between 2005 and 2010. Conversely, structural level analysis is required to critically assess functional significance. Therefore, a structural level search was performed for the above mentioned proteins by establishing the 3D structure of these proteins through homology modeling. Models were validated and structural-level similarities were evaluated by overlapping. Next, docking studies were performed to find the mode of binding of sialic acid (SA) with influenza HA. Molecular dynamics simulations were conducted to examine the interactions of SA molecule with HA. Energy analysis reveals that the van der Waal interaction is more favorable for HA binding with SA of the entire influenza virus. Binding pocket analysis shows that the density of H-bond donor and acceptor is greater in H1N1 (2009). Â© 2013 Â© 2013 Taylor & Francis.
authors: Karthikeyan, M.;Kirubakaran, P.;Singh, K. D.;Sampath, B.;Krishnasamy, G.

title: Possible risks posed by single-stranded DNA viruses of pigs associated with xenotransplantation
abstract: Routine large-scale xenotransplantation from pigs to humans is approaching clinical reality thanks to several cutting-edge technologies, particularly the ability to rapidly engineer genetically defined pigs. However, the use of pig organs in humans carries risks, such as the undesired interspecies transfer of viruses and the adaptation of these porcine viruses to the human organ recipient. Recent advances in virology have led to the identification of large numbers of viruses in many niches, including the emergence of metagenomic techniques to characterize whole viromes. Single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) viruses are the largest group common in mammalian virome studies. Specifically, ssDNA viral genomes are characterized by a high rate of nucleotide substitution, which confers a tendency to adapt to new hosts and interspecies barriers. Pig-associated ssDNA viruses include torque tenosus viruses (TTSuV) in the family Anelloviridae, porcine parvoviruses (PPV) and porcine bocaviruses (PBoV), both in the family Parvoviridae, and porcine circoviruses (PCV) in the family Circoviridae. confirmed to be pathogenic to pigs. The risks of these viruses to the human recipient during xenotransplantation procedures are relatively unknown. Based on the scant information available on the prevalence, preference and pathogenicity of porcine-associated ssDNA viruses, careful screening and monitoring is required. In the case of positive identification, risk assessments and strategies to eliminate these viruses in xenotransplantation pig stock may be needed.
authors: Karuppannan, A. K.;Opriessnig, T.

title: Phylogenetic relationships of the G gene sequence of bovine transient fever virus isolated in Japan, Taiwan and Australia.
abstract: The G gene encoding the neutralization antigen of bovine ephemeral fever virus (BEFV) was characterized to describe the molecular epidemiology of the virus in Japan and genetic relationships among Japanese, Taiwanese and Australian isolates. The nucleotide and amino acid sequences of the gene are highly conserved among Japanese strains regardless of the year of isolation and are closely related to Taiwanese strains. By phylogenetic analysis, Japanese and Taiwanese strains were clearly classified into three chronological clusters: 1966, 1984-1989, and 1996-2004, indicating that outbreaks of cattle transient fever can occur almost simultaneously by the same genotype in both countries. On the other hand, the Australian strains were distantly related to these East Asian strains and were placed in the independent fourth cluster of the phylogenetic tree. Three amino acid substitutions at residues 224, 271 and 499 in the neutralizing epitopes are suggested to be responsible for the antigenic variations of bovine ephemeral fever virus, two of which form novel glycosylation sequences. The cross-neutralization test using bovine transient fever virus isolated in Japan showed that the vaccine developed based on the oldest Japanese strain, YHL, is still effective in controlling bovine transient fever in Japan. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kato, T.;Aizawa, M.;Takayoshi, K.;Kokuba, T.;Yanase, T.;Shirafuji, H.;Tsuda, T.;Yamakawa, M.

title: Carp (Cyprinus carpio) infection with Cyprinid Herpesvirus 3 (CyHV-3) - an update
abstract: Infection of carp (Cyprinus carpio) with Cyprinid Herpesvirus 3 (CyHV-3) - an update Carp and koi (Cyprinus carpio) are extensively bred worldwide with an ever-growing circle of enthusiasts as both livestock and pet fish. Since the late 90s of the last century, the species has been threatened by a new virus, recently classified as a herpes virus. The virus, now known as Cyprinid Herpesvirus 3 (CyHV-3) or Koi Herpesvirus (KHV), causes huge losses in both industries every year. This review aims to provide an overview of current information on the disease and pathogen, as well as to explain why CyHV-3 remains a serious problem in both carp and koi aquaculture, 14 years after its discovery.
authors: Kattlun, J.;Gotesman, M.;Bergmann, S. M.;El-Matbouli, M.

title: Analysis of codon usage pattern evolution in avian rotaviruses and their preferred host.
abstract: Rotavirus infection is a worldwide problem with the emergence of quite different viruses classified into 8 species (AH). Here we report the evolutionary evaluation of codon usage patterns in the virus-host system in avian rotavirus (AvRV) of the RVA, RVD, RVF and RVG strains (preferably affecting birds). Nucleotide contents, codon usage bias (CUB), relative synonym codon usage (RSCU), and effective codon number (ENCs) values were investigated by targeting the major inner capsid viral protein (VP6) of these AvRV strains to overexpress. The results confirm that evolutionary traits influence rotavirus (RV) genetic diversity and the effect of host natural selection on AvRV codons. Synonym codon usage patterns were evaluated by following multivariate statistical procedures on all available AvRV encoding gene sequences. RSCU trees housed all AvRV species and preferred host sequences in a single topology, confirming greater affinity of AvRVs with host chicken cell genes. Similarly, codon adaptation index (CAI) results also showed higher adaptation of AvRVs to the chicken host. Codon preference analysis of RVs revealed that the VP6 gene is more proficiently expressed in the yeast system, whereas codon optimization may be required for efficient expression in Escherichia coli and Homo sapiens. The findings provide fundamental evidence of the dynamics of AvRV evolution and host adaptation that can be used for additional research on avian species in the future.
authors: Kattoor, J. J.;Malik, Y. S.;Sasidharan, A.;Rajan, V. M.;Dhama, K.;Ghosh, S.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Kobayashi, N.;Singh, R. K.

title: CRISPRs of Enterococcus faecalis and E. hirae isolates from pig feces have species-specific repeats but share some common discriminant sequences.
abstract: Clustered regularly spaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR) are currently a topic of interest in microbiology due to their role as a prokaryotic immune system. While research of CRISPR distribution and characterization to date has focused on pathogenic bacteria, less is known about CRISPR in commensal bacteria, where it may have an important role in the ecology of the microbiota of humans and other animals and act as a recorder of interactions. between bacteria and viruses. A combination of PCR and sequencing was used to determine the prevalence and distribution of CRISPR sequences in Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus hirae isolates from faeces of healthy pigs. Both type II CRISPR-Cas and Orphan CRISPR (without Cas genes) were detected in 195 isolates examined. CRISPR-Cas was detected in 52 (46/88) and 42% (45/107) isolates of E. faecalis and E. hirae, respectively. The prevalence of Orphan CRISPR sequences was higher in E. faecalis isolates (95%, 84/88) compared to E. hirae isolates (49, 53/107). Species-specific repeat sequences were identified in Orphan CRISPR sequences, and 42 unique spacer sequences were identified. Only two spacers matched previously characterized porcine virome sequences, and many were apparently derived from chromosomal sequences of enterococci. Surprisingly, 17 (40%) of the spacers were detected in both species. Shared spacer sequences are evidence of a lack of species specificity in the agents and mechanisms responsible for the integration of spacers, and the abundance of spacer sequences corresponding to bacterial chromosomal sequences reflects specific interspecific interactions in the gut microbiota.
authors: Katyal, I.;Chaban, B.;Ng, B.;Hill, J. E.

title: Insights on bovine rumen plasmidoma
abstract: Plasmids are self-replicating genetic elements that can mobilize between different hosts. Plasmids often serve as mediators of lateral gene transfer, a process that has been recognized as a powerful and shaping evolutionary force in microbial environments. Our aim was to characterize the overall plasmid population in bovine rumen environment, which harbors a complex and dense microbiota of paramount importance to humans. We developed a procedure for the isolation of total rumen plasmid DNA, termed rumen plasmid, and subjected it to deep sequencing by analyzing it using the Illumina paired-end protocol and public and custom-built bioinformatics tools. The large number of plasmid contigs aligned with plasmids of rumen bacteria isolated from different locations and at various time points suggest that not only bacterial taxa but also their plasmids are defined by ecological niche. The bacterial phylum distribution of the plasmid was different from that of the rumen bacterial taxa. However, both shared the dominance of the phyla Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, and Proteobacteria. Clearly, the rumen plasmidoma has a highly mosaic structure that can cross phyla. Interestingly, when we compared the functional profile of the rumen plasmid with two plasmid databases and two recently published rumen metagenomes, it was revealed that the rumen plasmid encodes functions that are enriched in the rumen ecological niche and may provide advantages to its hosts. suggests that the functional profiles of mobile genetic elements are related to their environment, as previously implied for viruses.
authors: Kav, A. B.;Sasson, G.;Jami, E.;Doron-Faigenboim, A.;Benhar, I.;Mizrahi, I.

title: Circulation of reassortant influenza A(H7N9) viruses in poultry and humans, Guangdong Province, China, 2013
abstract: Influenza A(H7N9) virus emerged in eastern China in February 2013 and continues to circulate in this region, but its ecology is not fully understood. In April 2013, the Guangdong Province Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) implemented environmental and human syndromic surveillance for the virus. Environmental samples from poultry markets at 21 city CDCs (n=8,942) and respiratory samples from individuals with flu-like illness or pneumonia (n=32,342) were tested; Viruses isolated from 6 environmental samples and 16 patients were sequenced. Sequence analysis showed co-circulation of 4 influenza A(H7N9) virus strains reclassified with avian influenza A(H9N2) viruses circulating in this region. In addition, the increase in human cases that began in late 2013 coincided with the increase in influenza A H7 virus isolates detected by environmental surveillance. The co-circulation of multiple avian influenza viruses capable of infecting humans highlights the need for increased surveillance of poultry and potential environmental resources.
authors: Ke, C.;Lu, J.;Wu, J.;Guan, D.;Zou, L.;Song, T.;Yi, L.;Zeng, X.;Liang, L.;Ni, H.;Kang, M.;Zhang, X.;Zhong, H.;He, J.;Lin, J.;Smith, D.;Burke, D.;Fouchier, R. A.;Koopmans, M.;Zhang, Y.

title: Characterization of emerging Newcastle disease viruses isolated in Taiwan between 2002-2008
abstract: To elucidate the epidemiological relationships between ND outbreaks and genetic lineages, a portion of the F gene (535 bp) and the full-length HN gene (1922 bp) of recent Taiwanese NDVs isolated in 2002-2008 were amplified by reverse transcription (RT). -polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and sequenced. Only some of the above amplified PCR products of the F and HN genes (374 and 1713 bp) and their deduced amino acid residues were compared with 60 other NDVs from GenBank. Most recent Taiwan isolates (29/30) clustered in subgenotype VIIe, while only one isolate was classified as subgenotype VIIc. All 29 isolates of subgenotype VIIe were further subclassified and tentatively designated sub-genotypes VIIe2 (13 isolates), VIIe3 (5 isolates), and VIIe4 (11 isolates). Subgenotype VIIe2 isolates with the 112R-RQKR-F117 motif and amino acid residue substitutions at positions 23 (L to F) and 90 (T to A) were collected over the period 2002-2005. Subgenotype VIIe3 isolates with the 112R-RKKR-F117 motif and amino acid residue substitutions were found at positions 74 (E to G) and 75 (A to G) within the epitopes and at positions 114 (Q to K) within the cleavage region of the F protein. It was collected between 2003-2006. Subgenotype VIIe4 isolates with the 112R-RQKR-F117 motif and amino acid residue substitutions at positions 23 (L to F), 26 (I to T), and 90 (T to A) were collected during 2007-2008. All NDV isolates in this study exhibited a high intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI), all classified as velogenic-type NDVs. Subgenotypes VIIe2 and VIIe4 viruses currently predominate and play a role in many of the recent ND outbreaks in Taiwan. Phylogenetic analysis of these isolates revealed that they may have evolved from previously reported local strains (VIIe1). This finding is essential for improving disease control strategies and developing vaccines for ND. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Ke, G. M.;Yu, S. W.;Ho, C. H.;Chu, P. Y.;Ke, L. Y.;Lin, K. H.;Tsai, Y. C.;Liu, H. J.;Lin, M. Y.

title: Baculovirus infection of caterpillar (Lepidoptera: Noctuidae) feeding on leaf blades of spiny or smooth-edged grass (Festuca spp.)
abstract: Susceptibility of the armyworm, Mythimna unipuncta (Haworth), to infection by a baculovirus (NPV) isolated from a Kentucky caterpillar population, in two suspected progenitors of longgrass, Festuca mairei and Festuca arundinacea subsp. phenas with intact or removed spiny leaf margins to test whether leaf spines erode or puncture the peritrophic matrix (PM) and facilitate the migration of virions to sites of infection in midgut tissue. PCR amplification and sequencing of selected genes from the virus and phylogenetic inference from aligned sequences were performed to identify and classify the virus. Edge spines had no effect on percent infection or days of death of newly moulted 5th stages fed with spiny or smooth-edged F. mairei leaf blades 24 hours before and after droplet feeding doses of 10(8) or 10(9) OBs ml. (one). Fifth instar, fed with spiny or smooth-edged grass blades, had similarly undamaged PMs when viewed with a scanning electron microscope. The fourth stage, virus-treated F. arundinacea subsp. phenas leaf blades did not differ in rates of days to death, prickly edges intact or removed, infected or dead. The food bolus moves in a liquid medium within the PM, and frass dissections showed that the margin spines were contained within a food bolus separated from the PM by non-thorny plant material rather than adjacent to the PM; therefore, the friction of the edge spines with the PM may be low. These results suggest that caterpillars will not be less susceptible to baculovirus infection when feeding on tall fescue varieties with straight leaf edges planted for better livestock performance compared to those fed standard barbed-edged varieties. We believe this is the first study to investigate the effects of a natural physical structure on PM degradation and infection by a baculovirus. (C) 2012 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Keathley, C. P.;Harrison, R. L.;Potter, D. A.

title: Genetic variability of swine circovirus 2 in vaccinated and unvaccinated commercial farms
abstract: Vaccines against swine circovirus 2 (PCV2) are now widely used to control diseases caused by the virus. Although vaccines protect pigs against disease, they do not induce sterility immunity and therefore infections with PCV2 persist on farms. Due to its high evolutionary rate, PCV2 is expected to adapt rapidly to environmental pressures such as vaccination. The aim of this study was to elucidate the molecular variation of PCV2 in relation to vaccination. PCV2 variability was investigated in infected pig samples from five farms where vaccination was never administered and two farms where pigs had been vaccinated for at least 2 years. For genetic analysis, complete PCV2 genomes were amplified and subsequently pooled with vaccination status from the serum of eight vaccinated, infected pigs and 16 unvaccinated, infected pigs. The variability of viral populations was quantified using next-generation sequencing followed by bioinformatics analysis. The number of cleavage sites was similar in the uninoculated (n=109) and inoculated pools (n=96), but the distribution of these regions across the genome was different. Most importantly, in the capsid gene, the number of cleaved regions was only observed in the unvaccinated population. Based on structural analysis, some low-frequency amino acids are expected to result in viruses with low biological compatibility. In contrast, D294 in the replicase represents a new amino acid that is dominant and unique in the grafted pool. This study showed that variable populations of PCV2 circulate on commercial farms and that this variability is different in samples from vaccinated and unvaccinated farms.
authors: Kekarainen, T.;Gonzalez, A.;Llorens, A.;Segales, J.

title: Sequencing and molecular modeling identify candidate members of the Caliciviridae family in bats.
abstract: Emerging viral diseases represent an ongoing challenge for the globalized world, and bats constitute an enormous, partially discovered reservoir of potentially zoonotic viruses. Caliciviruses are important human and animal pathogens and can affect human health on a global scale, as observed with human noroviruses. By scanning stool samples from bats in Hungary, calicivirus RNA was detected in samples of Myotis daubentonii and Eptesicus serotinus bats. To characterize bat caliciviruses in more detail, large portions of the viruses' genome sequence were determined. Phylogenetic analyzes and molecular modeling definitively identified the two viruses as candidate members within the family Caliciviridae; one calicivirus strain resembles members of the Sapovirus genus, and the other bat calicivirus is more closely related to the porcine caliciviruses of the proposed Valovirus genus. These data serve an effort to identify reservoir hosts for potential emerging viruses and recognize important evolutionary relationships.
authors: Kemenesi, G.;GellÃ©rt, Ã;Dallos, B.;GÃ¶rfÃ¶l, T.;Boldogh, S.;EstÃ³k, P.;Marton, S.;Oldal, M.;Martella, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Jakab, F.

title: The microbiome of the pig's soft palate
authors: Kernaghan, S.;Bujold, A. R.;MacInnes, J. I.

title: Genetic characterization of Indian peste des petits ruminant animal virus (PPRV) by sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of fusion protein and nucleoprotein gene segments.
abstract: Peste des petits ruminant (PPR) is an important viral disease of sheep and goats endemic in India. The study was undertaken to characterize local PPRV by sequencing fusion (F) protein and nucleoprotein (N) gene segments and phylogenetic analyzes to focus on genetic variation in field viruses. Selected regions of the PPRV genome were amplified by RT-PCR from clinical samples collected from 32 sheep and goats, and the resulting amplicons were sequenced for phylogenetic analysis. Phylogenetic tree based on the 322 bp F gene sequences of PPRV from five different locations clustered them into lineage 4 along with other Asian isolates. While the 425 bp N gene sequences revealed a different branching pattern, three different clusters were obtained for the Nigerian, Turkish and Indian isolates. Thus, it turned out that the classification of PPRV into lineages based on N gene sequences gives a better picture of the molecular epidemiology for PPRV. Â© 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Kerur, N.;Jhala, M. K.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Comparison of Schmallenberg virus sequences isolated from mammalian host and arthropod vector
abstract: Schmallenberg virus (SBV) is a member of the Peribunyaviridae family, which includes pathogens important to human and veterinary medicine. The virus is transmitted only between animals and mainly by biting the mid-ends of the genus Culicoides. This study was conducted to determine SBV genetic diversity and to elucidate host-vector adaptation. All three viral segments were analyzed for sequence variability and phylogenetic relationships. Polish SBV strains from acute infections of cattle, congenital cases in sheep and Culicoides midges were sequenced using Sanger and next-generation sequencing (NGS) methods. The resulting sequences were genetically similar (99.2-100% identity) to the BH80/11-4 strain first identified from German cattle. The sampling year and origin of the Polish sequences had no effect on the molecular diversity of SBV. Considering all the Polish and European sequences analyzed, the ovine-derived sequences were the most variable, while the sandfly ones were more conserved and included unique substitutions found primarily in the nonstructural protein S. The SBV sequences isolated from Culicoides are the first to be submitted and reported to GenBank. .
authors: Kesik-Maliszewska, J.;Antos, A.;Rola, J.;Larska, M.

title: Cygnet river virus, a new orthomyxovirus from Ducks, Australia
abstract: A new virus, called Cygnet River virus (CyRV), has been isolated in embryonated eggs of Muscovy ducks in South Australia. CyRV is morphologically similar to arenaviruses; however, sequencing identified CyRV as an orthomyxovirus. The high mortality rate among ducks co-infected with Salmonella suggests that CyRV alone or in combination with other infections may be pathogenic.
authors: Kessell, A.;Hyatt, A.;Lehmann, D.;Shan, S.;Crameri, S.;Holmes, C.;Marsh, G.;Williams, C.;Tachedjian, M.;Yu, M.;Bingham, J.;Payne, J.;Lowther, S.;Wang, J.;Wang, L. F.;Smith, I.

title: Epidemiology of human and animal cobuviruses
abstract: Kobuviruses are members of the Picornaviridae family. Initially, members of the genus Kobuvirus were named according to their host species. Viruses found in humans are called “Aichi virus”, those from cattle are called “bovine cobuvirus”, and viruses isolated from pigs are called “porcine cobuvirus”. Currently, the taxonomy of cobuviruses has been proposed and the virus species renamed. Changed "Aichi virus" to "Aichivirus A", "bovine cobuvirus", "Aichivirus B" and "porcine cobuvirus" to "Aichivirus C". Among Aichivirus A, three different members have been identified, including Aichi virus 1 (human Aichivirus), canine cobuvirus 1, and murine cobuvirus 1. Aichi virus is globally distributed in 1 human and has been described at a low incidence (0-3%) in sporadic cases of acute gastroenteritis. Aichi virus 1 has been reported to be associated with various types of clinical disease, including diarrhea, vomiting, fever, purulent conjunctivitis, and respiratory symptoms. Studies from Japan, Spain, Germany, and Tunisia have shown a high prevalence of antibodies to Aichi virus 1 in populations. Aichivirus B, or formerly known as bovine cobuvirus, was first reported in 2003. Since then, Aichivirus B has been reported from various countries around the world. The overall prevalence of Aichivirus B ranges from 1% to 34.5%, with the highest prevalence found in cattle with diarrhea in Korea. Aichivirus C or swine cobuvirus is commonly found in pigs. Aichivirus C has been found in both diarrhea and healthy pigs, and the positive rate for this virus ranges from 3.9% to 100%. Aichivirus C has been reported to have a high prevalence in wild boars in Hungary. The accumulated data of biological, pathological and epidemiological studies of kobuviruses are still limited. Comprehensive global studies of prevalence and diversity are required and will help to provide more information on pathogenicity, genetic heterogeneity, interspecies transmission and the global distribution of cobuviruses.
authors: Khamrin, P.;Maneekarn, N.;Okitsu, S.;Ushijima, H.

title: Novel nonstructural protein 4 genetic group in swine rotavirus
authors: Khamrin, P.;Okitsu, S.;Ushijima, H.;Maneekarn, N.

title: A Multicenter Study to Evaluate Performance of High-throughput Sequencing for Virus Detection
abstract: Its high-throughput sequencing (HTS) capability for detection of known and unknown viruses makes it a powerful tool for broad microbial research, such as the evaluation of new cell substrates that can be used for the development of new biological products. However, like any new assay, regulatory applications of HTS need method standardization. Therefore, our three laboratories initiated a study to evaluate the performance of HTS for potential detection of viral incidental agents by adding model viruses in different cellular matrices to mimic putative materials for biomaterial production. Based on different physical and biochemical properties and commercial availability, four model viruses were selected: human respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), feline leukemia virus (FeLV), and human reovirus (REO). Additionally, porcine circovirus (PCV) has been tested by a laboratory. For HTS, it was prepared for HTS by adding intact viruses or extracted viral nucleic acids to different HeLa cell matrices (resuspended whole cells, cell lysate or total cellular RNA) individually or by mixing. Data were acquired using different sequencing platforms (Roche 454, Illumina HiSeq1500 or HiSeq2500). Bioinformatic analyzes were performed independently by each laboratory using available tools, pipelines and databases. The results showed that comparable virus detection was achieved in the three laboratories regardless of sample processing, library preparation, sequencing platform, and bioinformatics analysis: 0.1 to 3 viral genome copies were detected per cell for all model viruses used. This work highlights the potential of using HTS for the sensitive detection of incidental viruses in complex biological samples containing cellular backgrounds. IMPORTANCE Recent high-throughput sequencing (HTS) studies have resulted in unexpected discoveries of known and novel viruses in a variety of sample types, including research materials, clinical materials, and biological products. Therefore, HTS can be a powerful tool to supplement existing methods for demonstrating the absence of incidental or unwanted viruses in biological products, especially when using a new cell line. However, HTS is a complex technology with different platforms that require standardization for the evaluation of biologics. This collaborative study was conducted to investigate the detection of different virus strains using two different HTS platforms. Results from independently conducted studies demonstrated a similar sensitivity of virus detection regardless of the different sample preparation and processing procedures and bioinformatics analyzes performed in the three laboratories. Comparable HTS detection of different virus strains supports the development of reference virus materials in the future for standardization and validation of different HTS platforms.
authors: Khan, A. S.;Ng, S. H. S.;Vandeputte, O.;Aljanahi, A.;Deyati, A.;Cassart, J. P.;Charlebois, R. L.;Taliaferro, L. P.

title: Sequence data to determine the taxonomic location of bean common mosaic virus and cowpea mosaic virus isolates.
abstract: The nucleotide sequences and 3' untranslated regions (3'-NTRs) of coat protein genes of three bean common mosaic virus isolates (NL1, NL3, and NY15) and one cowpea mosaic virus (W) isolate were determined. Comparison of these sequences revealed that the coat proteins of NL1, NY15 and W were identical in size (287 amino acids) and exhibited an overall sequence similarity (94 to 97%) and 84 to 98% in their N-terminal regions. Also, their 3'-NTRs were very similar in length [253 to 256 nucleotides (nt)] and sequence (93% to 96% identity). In contrast, the coat protein of NL3 had only 261 amino acids and showed 87% to 89% identity with NL1, NY15 and W, while its N-terminal region showed only 46% to 61% identity. The 3'-NTR of NL3 also showed notable differences in both length (240 nt) and sequence (56% to 63% similarity). These results, together with previous serological findings, confirm the conclusion that NL1, NY15 and W should be considered strains of the same virus, namely the bean common mosaic virus, and NL3 is a strain of a different potyvirus for which the name 'bean' is used. black root virus' has been suggested.
authors: Khan, J. A.;Lohuis, D.;Goldbach, R.;Dijkstra, J.

title: Separation of Strains of Bean Common Mosaic-Virus and Blackeye Cowpea Mosaic-Virus Using Antibodies Against N-Terminal and C-Terminal or N-Terminal Peptide Domains of Coating Proteins
abstract: Previous attempts to serologically isolate strains of bean common mosaic virus (BCMV) NL1, NL3 and NY15 and cowpea mosaic virus (B1CMV) W strain had failed. Antibodies to the N- and C- or N-terminal peptide regions of coat proteins of the above strains enabled discrimination between B1CMV-W, BCMV-NY15 and BCMV-NL3 in electroblot immunoassay and ELISA. Discrimination was better with antibodies directed to the N-terminus than to the N- and C-terminus. The NL1 strain of BCMV cross-reacted with both B1CMV-W and BCMV-NY15, but not with BCMV-NL3. The taxonomic implications of these findings are discussed.
authors: Khan, J. A.;Lohuis, H.;Goldbach, R. W.;Dijkstra, J.

title: Molecular characterization of classic swine fever virus isolated from India during 2012–14
abstract: Classical swine fever is a highly contagious and economically important viral disease of pigs. Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) outbreaks were recorded at different locations in the Kamrup region of Assam, India between 2012 and 2014. The nucleotide sequences of 10 CSFV isolates were analyzed based on the partial nucleotide sequences of the E2, 5' NTR and NS5B genes. Phylogenetic analysis showed the predominance of subgroup 2.2 with 2.1 strains in the northeastern part of India. The variation in the nucleotide sequences of the E2, 5'NTR and 3'NS5B genes of CSFV allows monitoring of changes in the virus population over time. The study will provide useful epidemiological information for evaluating circulating CSFV genogroups in India.
authors: Khatoon, E.;Barman, N. N.;Deka, M.;Rajbongshi, G.;Baruah, K.;Deka, N.;Bora, D. P.;Kumar, S.

title: Viral diversity and clonal evolution from stepless genomic data
abstract: Background: Clonal expansion is a process by which a single organism reproduces asexually, giving rise to a diversifying population. It is pervasive in nature, from in-host pathogen evolution to emerging infectious disease outbreaks. Standard phylogenetic tools are based on full-length genomes or population consensus sequences (phased genotypes) of individual pathogens. Although high-throughput sequencing technologies can sample population diversity, short sequence reads unique to them preclude evaluating whether two reads originate from the same clone (phase-free genotypes). This obstacle severely limits the application of phylogenetic methods and the investigation of intra-host dynamics of acute infections using this rich data source. Methods: We present two measures of diversity to study the evolution of clonal populations using phase-free genomic data, eliminating the need to construct full-length genomes. Our method follows a maximum likelihood approach to predict evolution rates and times to the most recent common ancestor, based on a comfortable molecular clock model; independent of the growth model. Deviations from neutral evolution indicate the presence of selection and bottleneck events. Conclusions: We evaluated our methods in silico and then compared them with current approaches to the well-characterized 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemic. We then applied our method to high-throughput genomic data from marburgvirus-infected non-human primates and extracted the time of infection and the rate of intra-host evolution and determined purifying selection in viral populations. Conclusions: Our method has the power to use minor variants found in less than 1% of the population and capture genomic diversity within days of infection, making it an ideal tool for the study of acute RNA viral infection dynamics.
authors: Khiabanian, H.;Carpenter, Z.;Kugelman, J.;Chan, J.;Trifonov, V.;Nagle, E.;Warren, T.;Iversen, P.;Bavari, S.;Palacios, G.;Rabadan, R.

title: Genetic characterization and pathogenicity assessment of Newcastle disease virus isolated from wild peacock.
abstract: The continued spread and emergence of the Newcastle disease virus (NDV) poses a potential threat to the domestic poultry industry worldwide. Mainly, wild bird species have always been associated with the natural reservoir of the virus and the spread of the disease. In this study, we report the isolation of Newcastle disease virus (NDV/Peacock/India/2012) in autopsy brain tissue sample of wild peacock from North India. The complete genome of the virus was found to be 15,186 nucleotides (nts) with six genes in the order 3â€²-Nâ€“PMF-HN-L-5â€², restricted to a 55-nts leader region at 3â€. A sequence of 114 nts fragments at the ² end and 5â€² end. Sequence analysis of the fusion protein revealed the dibasic amino acid cleavage site <sup>112</sup>RRQKRF<sup>117</sup>, which is a characteristic motif of the virulent virus. Phylogenetic analysis placed the isolate in genotype II of Newcastle disease virus and showed the lowest mean percentage of divergence (6%Â) with other genotype II counterparts. The isolate was characterized as mesogenic (intermediate pathotype) based on mean time to death in embryonated chicken eggs (63Â h) and intracerebral pathogenicity index in day-old chicks (1.40). The report highlights the dynamic ecology of NDV strains circulating in a wild avian host during the 2012 North Indian outbreak. In addition, genotypic and pathotypic characterizations of the isolate may aid in the development of a homologous vaccine against the circulating NDV strain in the avian population.
authors: Khulape, S. A.;Gaikwad, S. S.;Chellappa, M. M.;Mishra, B. P.;Dey, S.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the fusion protein cleavage region of isolates that acquired Newcastle disease virus from Iran.
abstract: Nine Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates from Newcastle disease (ND) outbreaks in different regions of Iran were characterized at the molecular level. Sequence analysis revealed that the isolates share two pairs of arginine and one phenylalanine at the N-terminus of the fusion (F) protein cleavage site, similar to other velogenic isolates of NDV previously characterized. Eight of the nine isolates had the same amino acid sequence as VOL95, a 1995 Russian NDV isolate. However, one isolate, MK13, showed 5 amino acid substitutions, of which 3 were reported for other velogenic NDV isolates. These results show that the source of ND outbreaks in different regions of Iran in 1995-1998 was VOL95.
authors: Kianizadeh, M.;Aini, I.;Omar, A. R.;Yusoff, K.;Sahrabadi, M.;Kargar, R.

title: Classification of avian paramyxoviruses by immunodiffusion on the basis of antigenic specificity of M protein antigens.
abstract: Seventeen avian paramyxoviruses, consisting of ten reference strains and seven novel isolates, were classified into six species by immunodiffusion on the basis of antigenic specificity of M protein (MP) antigens. Species were represented by the following viruses. (1) Newcastle disease virus, (2) Chicken/California/Yucaipa/56, (3) Turkey/Wisconsin/68, (4) Duck/Mississippi/75, (5) Pigeon/Otaru/76, and (6) Budgerigar / Kunitachi/1/74. Differences in HN antigens between viruses classified as the same species on the basis of the antigenic specificity of MP antigens may provide a basis for classifying them into types.
authors: Kida, H.;Yanagawa, R.

title: Complete Genome Sequence of Mannheimia haemolytica Strain Mh10517 Isolated from Sheep in South Africa
abstract: Respiratory disease caused by Mannheimia haemolytica is a major concern in the cattle and small animal industry worldwide. This issue arises due to the interaction of multiple contributing factors, including the physical stresses associated with weaning, shipping, harsh weather conditions, and overcrowding with viral and bacterial infections. The entire genome of M. haemolytica strain Mh10517 was analyzed using an Illumina MiSeq high-throughput sequencing platform. The genome size is 2.67 Mb with an estimated 2,879 gene sequences. The availability of this genome sequence will advance work on various aspects of the biology of M. haemolytica in Africa and the world in general.
authors: Kidanemariam Gelaw, A.;Bihon, W.;Faranani, R.;Mafofo, J.;Rees, J.;Madoroba, E.

title: Genetic variability in hepatitis B viruses
abstract: In 1988, it was reported that the complete nucleotide sequences of 18 hepatitis B virus (HBV) strains were clustered into four genetic groups (A to D), with more than 8% difference between groups. This classification of strains in terms of genome sequence has since proven to be an important tool in understanding the epidemiology and evolution of HBV and has been expanded to include three more genotypes. Parallel to the HBV genotypes identified in humans, HBV strains isolated from different primates and hepadnaviruses found in groundhogs, ground squirrels, ducks and herons were studied. Sequence differences between HBV genotypes can lead to structural differences at the pregenome level and also to dramatic differences at the translational level when specific and commonly occurring mutations occur. There is increasing evidence that the clinical picture, response to treatment, and long-term prognosis may vary depending on which genotype infects the patient. Therefore, evaluation of traditional serological patterns in a patient should take into account the genotype of the infecting strain. Nucleotide variability among HBV strains has been used in many studies to monitor transmission routes, and as it has become increasingly clear that differences between HBV genotypes are important, the need for reliable and easy methods to distinguish HBV genotypes has emerged. This review summarizes information on HBV genotypes in relation to their genetic, structural and clinically relevant differences and their origin and evolution in the context of hepadnaviruses in general.
authors: Kidd-Ljunggren, K.;Miyakawa, Y.;Kidd, A. H.

title: Identification of plant protein kinases in response to abiotic and biotic stresses using SuperSAGE.
abstract: Plants are sessile organisms that are exposed to many environmental adversities. In order to survive, they must effectively sense and respond to biotic and abiotic stresses. During this process, protein kinases are essential in sensing environmental stimuli and trigger signaling cascades. Kinases are among the largest and most important gene families for biotechnological purposes and present many challenges to bioinformaticians due to the combination of various regions as well as conserved domains. Cowpea [Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp.] is an important legume that has adapted to different agro-climatic conditions including drought, humidity and varying temperatures. For this product, combining the SuperSAGE method with high-throughput sequencing technology will generate reliable transcriptome profiles with millions of tags counted and statistically analyzed. One approach to assessing biotic and abiotic stresses was accomplished by generating more than 13 million cowpea SuperSAGE tags, which can be obtained from the leaves/roots of plants under abiotic (mechanical damage and salinity) or biotic (CABMV, Cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus) stresses. Annotation and identification of tags binding to previously well-defined ESTs by BlastN allowed for back-identification of kinases. Annotation efficiency depended on the database used, and KEGG was seen as a good resource for annotated ESTs, especially when complemented with an independent Gene Ontology category, as well as Gene Index using selected species. Using different approaches allowed the identification of 1,350 kinase candidates considering biotic libraries and 2,268 related to abiotic libraries based on a combination of both adequate descriptions and GO terms. Additional searches in kinase-specific databases allowed the identification of a relatively low number of additional kinases, revealing the lack of kinase databases for non-model organisms, particularly plants. Regarding the kinase families, a total of 713 potential kinases were classified into 13 families of the CMGC and STE groups. Regarding differentially expressed kinases, 169 of 713 potential kinases were identified (p < 0.05), 100 up-regulated and 69 down-regulated when comparing different libraries, resulting in a comprehensive panel of differentially expressed kinases under biotic and abiotic stresses. allowed. non-model plant such as cowpea. Â© 2011 Bentham Science Publishers.
authors: Kido, E. A.;de AraÃºjo Barbosa, P. K.;Neto, J. R. C. F.;Pandolfi, V.;Houllou-Kido, L. M.;Crovella, S.;Molina, C.;Kahl, G.;Benko-Iseppon, A. M.

title: Estimating the global spread of H5N1 avian flu
abstract: The spread of the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza in Asia, Europe and Africa has had enormous effects on the poultry industry and poses a significant threat to human health. The ways in which the virus spreads and will spread between countries have been discussed extensively, but have not yet been analyzed comprehensively and quantitatively. We integrated data on phylogenetic relationships of virus isolates, migratory bird movements, and trade in poultry and wild birds to determine the pathway of 52 individual entry events into countries and predict future spread. We show that 9 out of 21 entries of H5N1 into countries in Asia are most likely via poultry and 3 out of 21 via migratory birds. In contrast, spread to most (20/23) countries in Europe was most likely via migratory birds. In Africa, the spread was probably partly by poultry (2/8 introduction) and partly by migratory birds (3/8). Our analyzes estimate that H5N1 is more likely to be transmitted to the Western Hemisphere via infected poultry and to the United States mainland by subsequent movement of migratory birds from neighboring countries rather than eastern Siberia. These results highlight the potential synergy between trade and wildlife movement in the emergence and pandemic spread of pathogens and demonstrate the value of predictive models for disease control. Â© 2006 by the US National Academy of Sciences.
authors: Kilpatrick, A. M.;Chmura, A. A.;Gibbons, D. W.;Fleischer, R. C.;Marra, P. P.;Daszak, P.

title: Characterization of the complete genome of circular single-stranded DNA virus from pig faeces in Korea.
abstract: Porcine circular single-stranded DNA viruses have been newly identified from pig feces in Korea. This virus was referred to as bovine feces-associated circular DNA virus (BoSCV)-like virus discovered in pig feces. However, extensive features of the virus have not been described. Therefore, this research focuses on finding a complete genome sequence and analyzing the genetic characteristics of the virus. The virus, now called pig feces-associated circular DNA virus (PoSCV Kor) in Korea, consists of 2,589 bases that form a circular structure. Between the 5' ends and 3' ends of the two putative ORFs, each stem-loop structure has two main ORFs that reversely encode the replicase and capsid protein. This feature is the same as PoSCV in New Zealand, but different from chimpanzee fecal-associated circular virus (ChiSCVs) and BoSCV, which have a stem-loop structure. It is therefore certain that PoSCV Kor is genetically very similar to PoSCV; same number of nucleotide bases and amino acid identity of replicase and capsid protein (96% and 93%, respectively). This fact can be confirmed by the finding that PoSCV Core and PoSCV are in the same cluster by phylogenetic analysis based on comparison with the full sequences of other circular ssDNA viruses.
authors: Kim, A. R.;Chung, H. C.;Kim, H. K.;Kim, E. O.;Nguyen, V. G.;Choi, M. G.;Yang, H. J.;Kim, J. A.;Park, B. K.

title: Detection of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome-like, Middle East Respiratory Syndrome-like Bat Coronaviruses and Group H Rotavirus in the Feces of Korean Bats
abstract: Bat species worldwide have recently been recognized as major reservoirs of various zoonotic viruses such as severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV), Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), Nipah virus and Hendra virus. In this study, consensus primer-based reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reactions (RT-PCRs) and high-throughput sequencing were performed to investigate viruses in bat fecal samples collected from 11 native bat habitats in Korea between July and December 2015. Various coronaviruses, including alphacoronaviruses, SARS-CoV-like, and MERS-CoV-like betacoronaviruses, were first detected in Korean bat feces. In addition, we detected a new bat rotavirus belonging to group H rotavirus, which has only been identified in humans and pigs to date. Therefore, our results indicate the need for ongoing surveillance and additional virological studies in the domestic bat.
authors: Kim, H. K.;Yoon, S. W.;Kim, D. J.;Koo, B. S.;Noh, J. Y.;Kim, J. H.;Choi, Y. G.;Na, W.;Chang, K. T.;Song, D.;Jeong, D. G.

title: H5N1 subtype highly pathogenic avian influenza virus isolated from healthy mallard caught in South Korea
abstract: On December 7, 2010, the H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza virus was isolated from a healthy mallard caught in the Mankyung River in South Korea. Phylogenetic analysis showed that this virus was classified in section 2.3.2 and was closely related to H5N1 viruses isolated from wild birds in Mongolia, Russia and China in 2009 and 2010. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Kim, H. R.;Kim, B. S.;Bae, Y. C.;Moon, O. K.;Oem, J. K.;Kang, H. M.;Choi, J. G.;Lee, O. S.;Lee, Y. J.

title: Molecular characterization of chicken infectious anemia viruses detected in breeders and broilers in South Korea.
abstract: In South Korea, 32 chicken infectious anemia virus (CIAV) strains from various breeder and commercial chicken flocks have been genetically characterized for the first time. Phylogenetic analysis of the viral protein 1 gene, including the hypervariable region of the CIAV genome, showed that the Korean CIAV strains were divided into groups II, IIIa and IIIb. Strains have been commonly identified in commercial poultry farms as well as in great-grandparent and grandparent rearing farms. In the field, CIAV strains from breeder farms had no clinical effect, but commercial farm strains were associated with depression, growth retardation, and anemia, regardless of the strain originating group. In addition, we identified 7 CIAV genomes similar to vaccine strains from vaccinated and unvaccinated breeder flocks. These data indicate the need for further studies on pathogenicity and vaccine efficacy against different groups of CIAV, together with continuous CIAV surveillance and genetic analysis in breeder farms. Â© 2010 Poultry Science Association A.Ş.
authors: Kim, H. R.;Kwon, Y. K.;Bae, Y. C.;Oem, J. K.;Lee, O. S.

title: Characterization of Avian Encephalomyelitis Outbreaks in South Korea from 2006 to 2013
abstract: This study was conducted to characterize avian encephalomyelitis (AE) viruses from various breeder and commercial chicken flocks in South Korea. Young chicken less than 4 weeks old showed neurological signs as typical AE infection between 2006 and 2011. In 2013, idiopathic AE occurred in unvaccinated 79-day-old chickens with clinical signs of ataxia and paralysis. Phylogenetic analysis of viral protein 2 genes of AE viruses showed that all tested AE viruses were genetically similar to the vaccine strain [Calnek 1143]. In the embryo inoculation test through the yolk sac, only one field strain and one commercial vaccine were adapted to the embryo. The results showed that AE outbreaks in South Korea were caused by strains genetically similar to the vaccine strain, indicating the possibility of vaccine disruption or persistence in the chicken population.
authors: Kim, H. R.;Kwon, Y. K.;Lee, H. S.

title: Ostrich (Struthio camelus) Infected with H5N8 High Pathogenicity Avian Influenza Virus in South Korea in 2014
abstract: The highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus of the H5N8 subtype was isolated from a young ostrich in South Korea in March 2014. Clinical manifestations characterized by signs of anorexia, depression and irritability were observed. Isolated A/ostrich/Korea/H829/2014 (H5N8) virus had a cleavage site motif containing multiple basic amino acids typical of HPAI virus. The phylogenetic tree of the hemagglutinin gene of the H5 HPAI virus showed that this ostrich H5N8 virus belonged to viruses 2.3.4.4 along with the H5N8 strains isolated from ducks and wild birds in South Korea in 2014. Pathologically, redness, enlargement and bleeding in the pancreas, spleen, brain brittleness and hydropericardium were prominent. Histological legions were observed in the pancreas, spleen, liver, lung, heart, and brain, and influenza A nucleoproteins were detected in the same organs by immunohistochemistry. Other ostriches bred together in open camps were not infected with the HPAI virus according to serological and virological tests. The findings show that ostriches are susceptible to the H5N8 HPAI virus, but this virus does not spread efficiently among rats.
authors: Kim, H. R.;Kwon, Y. K.;Lee, Y. J.;Kang, H. M.;Lee, E. K.;Song, B. M.;Jung, S. C.;Lee, K. H.;Lee, H. K.;Baek, K. H.;Bae, Y. C.

title: Identification of a picornavirus from chickens with infectious viral proventriculitis using metagenomic analysis
abstract: Infectious viral proventriculitis (TVP), a contagious disease in chickens, is responsible for economic losses in the commercial poultry industry. However, the main etiologic agent is unknown. Using metagenomics, we compared the diversity of viruses found in proventriculus samples from South Korean flocks diagnosed with TVP between 2003 and 2012 with that of healthy flocks in South Korea. An average of 21,538,726 sequence reads of each sample was generated by high-throughput sequencing. 160 nt long. Enrichment in viral sequences indicated that at least three viruses were present in each TVP sample. Although we could not identify a TVP pathogen matching the known morphology, picornavirus sequences were present in all five disease samples, suggesting an association with TVP. Five samples yielded 1,045-1,720 bp contigs with 81-84% nt sequence identity to turkey hepatitis virus (accession number: HM751199). Whole genome analysis showed that the new picornavirus strain QIA01 was similar to turkey hepatitis virus in the P2 and P3 regions (82.7% nt and 95.5% aa sequence identity), but differed in the structural region and partial 2A peptides (56.2%). . nt and 23.9% aa array ID). In addition, the QIA01 virus was similar to chicken megrivirus (87.0 nt and 95.6% aa sequence identity) recently detected in chickens with malabsorption syndrome in Hungary. Our results are useful for understanding the genetic diversity of avian picornaviruses and for classifying chicken megrivirus as a pathogen affecting the gastrointestinal tract of chickens.
authors: Kim, H. R.;Yoon, S. J.;Lee, H. S.;Kwon, Y. K.

title: Characterization and phylogenetic analysis of Varicella-zoster virus strains isolated from Korean patients
abstract: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a causative agent of chickenpox in primary infection and shingles after undelayed reactivation. Complete or nearly complete genomic DNA sequences have been reported for various VZV strains. Recently, clinical VZV strains were isolated from Korean patients whose genome was sequenced using high-throughput sequencing technology. In this study, we analyzed the single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) of VZV strains to genetically characterize Korean clinical isolates. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that three Korean strains YC01, YC02 and YC03 were linked to clade 2. Comprehensive SNP analysis identified 86 sites specific to 5 VZV wings. VZV strains isolated from Korea did not form a phylogenetic cluster. Instead, YC02 and YC03 clustered strongly in cluster 2, more specifically cluster 2a, with Chinese strain 84-7. Signature sequences for cluster 2a were identified and found to play an important role in distinguishing cluster 2a strains from other clade 2 strains, as demonstrated in substitution studies. Further genetic analysis with additional strains isolated from Japan, China and other Asian countries will provide new understanding of the importance of the two different subdivisions within chapter 2.
authors: Kim, M. H.;Jeon, J. S.;Kim, I. K.;Park, J. S.;Park, H.;Shin, O. S.;Lee, C. H.

title: Effective selection of antibodies reactive to homologous epitopes on human and mouse hepatocyte growth factors by next-generation sequencing-based analysis of the B cell repertoire.
abstract: YYB-101 is a humanized rabbit anti-human hepatocyte growth factor (HGF)-neutralizing antibody currently in clinical trial. To test the effect of antibody neutralization of HGF on anti-cancer T cell immunity, we generated surrogate antibodies reactive to the mouse homologue of the epitope targeted by YYB-101. First, we inoculated a chicken with human HGF and monitored changes in the B cell repertoire with next-generation sequencing (NGS). We then extracted the VH gene repertoire from the NGS data, segmented it according to sequence homology, and classified the components according to the change in the number of unique VH sequences within each component and the frequencies of the VH sequences following immunization. These changes must be accompanied by preferential proliferation and somatic hypermutation or gene conversion of B cells encoding HGF-reactive antibodies. One component showed significant increases in the number and frequency of hosted genes encoding unique VH sequences and antibodies that are reactive to human HGF and compete with YYB-101 for HGF binding. Some of the antibodies also responded to mouse HGF. The selected VH sequences shared 98.3% identity and 98.9% amino acid identity. Therefore, the antibodies encoded by them are all likely to respond to the epitope targeted by YYB-101.
authors: Kim, S.;Lee, H.;Noh, J.;Lee, Y.;Han, H.;Yoo, D. K.;Kim, H.;Kwon, S.;Chung, J.

title: Prevalence and genetic characteristics of porcine circovirus types 2 and 3 in Korea
abstract: BACKGROUND: Porcine circovirus-associated diseases (PCVAD), caused by porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2), threaten the swine industry worldwide. Five PCV2 genotypes have recently been identified: PCV2a, PCV2b, PCV2c, PCV2d, and PCV2e. In addition, a novel porcine circovirus was identified from a pig case with dermatitis, nephropathy syndrome and reproductive failure based on metagenomic analysis and classified as porcine circovirus type 3 (PCV3). Therefore, the present study was conducted to determine the prevalence and genetic characteristics of PCV2 and PCV3 in clinical samples. RESULTS: A total of 471 samples (161 lung and lymph node tissue samples from 34 farms and 310 serum samples from 47 farms) were tested for PCV2. Among these, 171 samples from 59 farms positive for PCV2 were genotyped. Another 690 samples (296 lung and lymph node tissue samples from 91 farms, 108 aborted fetus samples from 26 farms, and 286 serum samples from 47 farms) were tested for PCV3. Based on the PCV2 genotyping results, PCV2d was the most common genotype (10 of 171 samples), and coinfections with combinations of PCV2a, 2b, and 2d were identified in 48 samples from 17 farms. A total of 14 samples from 11 farms were positive for both PCV2 and PCV3. 57 samples (9.8%) from 32 farms (23.2%) were positive for PCV3. Among 108 aborted fetuses from 26 farms, only 2 samples were positive for PCV3. Based on sequence comparisons, PCV2d shares 89.6-91.0% and 93.2-94.3% homology with PCV2a and PCV2b, respectively; 98.6-100% homology is shared between PCV2d strains. The PCV3 strains identified in this study share 98.0-99.5% homology. CONCLUSIONS: Our study concluded that PCV2d became the most dominant genotype in Korea. PCV3 has also been identified in clinical specimens, although no significant association with clinical symptoms was observed in PCV3-positive cases.
authors: Kim, S. C.;Nazki, S.;Kwon, S.;Juhng, J. H.;Mun, K. H.;Jeon, D. Y.;Jeong, C. G.;Khatun, A.;Kang, S. J.;Kim, W. I.

title: Complete genome sequence of a new Newcastle disease virus: strain isolated from a chicken in West Africa.
abstract: The complete genome sequence of an African Newcastle disease virus (NDV) strain isolated from a chicken in Togo in 2009 was determined. The genome is 15,198 nucleotides (nt) long and is classified at genotype VII in the class II cluster. Compared to common vaccine strains, the African strain contains a previously identified 6-nt insert in the N gene untranslated region and a novel 6-nt insert in the HN-L intergenic region. Genome length differences are indicative of the natural history of NDV. This is the first identification of a class II NDV strain with a 15,198 nt genome and 6-nt insert in the HN-L intergenic region. Sequence variation relative to vaccine strains was significant, possibly contributing to epidemics and demonstrating the continued evolution of new NDV strains in West Africa. Â© 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Kim, S. H.;Nayak, S.;Paldurai, A.;Nayak, B.;Samuel, A.;Aplogan, G. L.;Awoume, K. A.;Webby, R. J.;Ducatez, M. F.;Collins, P. L.;Samal, S. K.

title: Genetic diversity and pathogenic potential of low pathogenic H7 avian influenza viruses isolated from wild migratory birds in Korea
abstract: To detect the circulation of H7 avian influenza viruses, we characterized H7 viruses found in South Korea's migratory bird and live poultry markets from 2005 to 2014. Phylogenetic analysis showed that although all viruses clustered in the Eurasian H7 lineage of avian viruses, at least 12 different genotypes were represented. Most H7 viruses contained at least one gene segment from the highly pathogenic A/Sck/Hong Kong/YU100/02(H5N1)-like avian virus, which could be divided into at least two antigenic groups. Although we did not detect genetically identical strains, the HI assay showed close cross-reactivity of some isolates with H7N9 viruses from China. Animal studies revealed that most genotypes can reproduce in the lungs of mice and chickens without prior adaptation, and some, particularly the H7N4 and H7N7 subtypes, cause death in mice. These results reinforce the recent growing pandemic concerns regarding H7 viruses and highlight the importance of continued surveillance of avian influenza viruses in the wild.
authors: Kim, Y. I.;Kim, S. W.;Si, Y. J.;Kwon, H. I.;Park, S. J.;Kim, E. H.;Kim, S. M.;Lee, I. W.;Song, M. S.;Choi, Y. K.

title: Genetic and phylogenetic characterizations of a novel genotype of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 viruses in 2016/2017 in South Korea.
abstract: During outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N6 viruses in South Korea in 2016, new H5N8 viruses were also isolated from migratory birds. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the HA gene of these H5N8 viruses belongs to item 2.3.4.4, similar to recent H5Nx viruses, and is descended from A/Brk/Korea/Gochang1/14(H5N8), a minor strain of H5N8 that emerged in 2014. and then disappeared. At least four reclassification events with different subtypes (H5N8, H7N7, H3N8 and H10N7) occurred, and a chicken challenge study revealed that they were classified as HPAI viruses according to OIE criteria.
authors: Kim, Y. I.;Park, S. J.;Kwon, H. I.;Kim, E. H.;Si, Y. J.;Jeong, J. H.;Lee, I. W.;Nguyen, H. D.;Kwon, J. J.;Choi, W. S.;Song, M. S.;Kim, C. J.;Choi, Y. K.

title: Foot and mouth disease virus: a review
abstract: Foot and mouth disease has long been a major plague on animal health, but it is now close to being a disease of the past, at least in Europe. Effective but expensive and not entirely safe vaccination was discontinued in all European Union countries in 1991. However, research on this virus, which is one of the most studied viruses in both basic virology and animal health, continues to bring new data on still poorly known aspects of its biology, such as cell penetration, RNA translation, replication and capsid assembly. These different aspects are reviewed. The development of biotechnology has allowed the emergence of new, if not more efficient, at least completely safe vaccines. The intrinsic mutational characteristics of this virus are still a major challenge for its complete eradication.
authors: Kim, Y. J.;Remond, M.

title: Analysis of rotavirus species diversity and evolution, including newly identified full-length genome sequences of rotavirus F and G.
abstract: Rotaviruses are the leading cause of viral acute gastroenteritis in humans and animals. Eight different strains of rotavirus (AH) have been identified based on the antigenicity of the VP6 gene and their nucleotide sequence identity. Here we describe the first complete genome sequences of rotavirus F (strain 03V0568) and G (strain 03V0567) with a length of 18,341 and 18,186 bp, respectively. Both viruses have open reading frames for the rotavirus proteins VP1 to VP7 and NSP1 to NSP5 located in 11 genome segments. Nucleotide sequence identities to other rotaviruses ranged from 29.8% (NSP1 gene) to 61.7% (VPI gene) for rotavirus F and 29.3% (NSP1-2 gene) to 65.9% (NSP2 gene) for rotavirus G, thus confirming their classification. different types of viruses. The encoded proteins revealed remarkable sequence differences between rotavirus strains. In contrast, non-coding 5'-terminal sequences of genome segments were highly conserved across all rotavirus strains. Different 3'-terminal consensus sequences exist between rotavirus A/D/F, rotavirus C, and rotavirus B/G/H. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that rotaviruses split into two main branches, namely rotavirus A/C/D/F and rotavirus B/G/H. Within these clades, rotavirus F was mainly clustered with rotavirus D and rotavirus B and rotavirus G. In addition, differentiation between mammalian and avian rotavirus A strains, the host-specific evolution of rotavirus B and C, as well as an ancient reclassification event between avian rotavirus A and D, is illustrated by phylogenetic data. These results underscore the high diversity of rotaviruses as a result of a complex evolutionary history. (C) 2012 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kindler, E.;Trojnar, E.;Heckel, G.;Otto, P. H.;Johne, R.

title: Investigation of in-host and in-herd sequence diversity of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: Due to the low fidelity of enzymes involved in RNA genome replication, foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus samples consist of unique polymorphic populations. This study used deep sequencing to characterize the diversity of FMD virus (FMDV) populations in 6 infected cattle on a single farm during a series of outbreaks in the UK in 2007. A 7.6Â kb nucleotide fragment spanning the polyprotein coding region of the FMDV genome. Illumina sequencing of each sample identified fine polymorphic structures at each nucleotide position, from consensus level changes to variants found at a frequency of 0.24%. These data were used to explore the population dynamics of FMDV at both herd and host level, to evaluate the effect of the host on viral herd structure, and to identify transmission links with viruses recovered from other farms in the same outbreak series. In 7 samples from 6 different animals, a total of 5 consensus level variants were identified, in addition to 104 subconsensus variants, 22 of which were shared among 2 or more animals. Further analysis revealed differences in herd structures from samples obtained from the same animal, suggesting the existence of different viral populations that evolved independently at different lesion sites within the same infected animal.
authors: King, D. J.;Freimanis, G. L.;Orton, R. J.;Waters, R. A.;Haydon, D. T.;King, D. P.

title: Rapid serotyping of infectious bronchitis virus isolates by hemagglutination-inhibition test
abstract: The hemagglutination-inhibition (HI) test has recently been evaluated as a method for typing suspected infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) isolates. Hemagglutination (HA) antigen was prepared from each isolate by phospholipase C treatment of virus concentrated from the allanto-amniotic fluids of infected chicken embryos. An HI test was performed with the HA antigen of each isolate against a battery of 17 antisera prepared against different strains of IBV classified by virus neutralization (VN). The HI test identified Ark 99 and Holland isolates similar to strains previously classified by VN. The two isolates included in this study were not inhibited by any reference antiserum and therefore appeared antigenically different. The isolates were also evaluated by the VN and the results of the VN and HI methods were accepted. The results therefore suggest that the HI test may be useful for a rapid, hypothetical identification of new IBV isolates.
authors: King, D. J.;Hopkins, S. R.

title: Advanced bioinformatics profiling of VIDISCA libraries for virus detection and discovery
abstract: VIDISCA is a next-generation sequencing (NGS) library preparation method designed to enrich viral nucleic acids from samples prior to highly multiplexed low-depth sequencing. Reliable detection of known viruses and discovery of new distinct viruses from NGS data require specialized analysis tools that are both sensitive and accurate. Existing software was used to design a new bioinformatics workflow for high-throughput detection and discovery of viruses from VIDISCA data. The workflow leverages the molecular biology of VIDISCA library preparation, particularly the use of the Mse1 restriction enzyme, which generates biological copy library inserts from the same genomes. The workflow performs total metagenomic analysis for classification of non-viral sequences, including parasites and host, as well as virus-specific analysis. To increase the downstream analysis speed, the ribosomal RNA is sequenced and the remaining reads are clustered at 100% identity. Known and new viruses are precisely detected by alignment to a virus-only protein database, and false positives are removed. A new cluster profiling assay takes advantage of viral biological replicates produced by Mse1 digestion using read clustering to flag the presence of short genomes in very high copy numbers. Importantly, this analysis enables the identification of highly repetitive sequences even if no homology is detected, as demonstrated here by the detection of a novel gokushovirus genome from human fecal matter. The workflow was validated using readout data from serum and stool samples from HIV-1 positive adults and serum samples from pigs infected with atypical porcine pestivirus.
authors: Kinsella, C. M.;Deijs, M.;van der Hoek, L.

title: The genome structure of a new chicken virus identifies it as a parvovirus.
abstract: The nucleic acid of chicken parvovirus-like particles showed sensitivity to DNase and S1 nuclease treatment and resistance to digestion by RNase. Viral DNA in vitro served as a template for self-priming transformation into a double-stranded form of approximately 5200 base pairs. There was no evidence of encapsulation of polar opposite threads. These findings confirm the taxonomic classification of chicken parvovirus-like particles as poultry parvovirus type 1 within the Parvovirus genus of Parvoviridae.
authors: Kisary, J.;Avalosse, B.;Miller-Faures, A.;Rommelaere, J.

title: Latest information on bovine virus diarrhea virus review article
abstract: Pestivirus genus is one of the most intensively studied animal virus groups. Detailed studies of pestiviruses also necessitate reclassification of the genus. The last study summarized the latest information on bovine diarrhea virus (BVDV). Actual taxonomic questions have also been addressed, such as the two genotypes of BVDV, as well as the new, non-host-specific classification of pestiviruses. Morphological and physical characterization of the virus has not been addressed. Genome structure (Figure 1), genome organization, proteins responsible for cytopathogenic effect are discussed according to our current knowledge. The differences between the two biotypes of BVDV – cytopathogenic (cp, Figure 2) and non-cytopathogenic (ncp) viruses – are also discussed, classifying them according to the recombinative events to which the virus genome is subjected. For now, based on the results of recent studies, it appears that recombinative events of the amino-terminus of the nonstructural p80 enzyme protein (Figure 3) of BVDV are mainly responsible for the transformation of ncp BVDV - mainly nature - to cp BVDV and thus to the development of mucosal disease. , MD.
authors: Kiss, I.;Kecskemeti, S.

title: Rescue of different avian boraviruses from proventricular dilatation disease cases: identification of a candidate etiologic agent.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Proventricular dilatation disease (PDD) is a deadly disease that threatens domesticated and wild psittacine birds worldwide. It is characterized by lymphoplasmacytic infiltration of the ganglia of the central and peripheral nervous system, leading to disorders of the central nervous system as well as irregular enteric motility and consequent wasting. For nearly 40 years, a viral etiology for PDD has been suspected, but to date no candidate etiologic agent has been reproducibly associated with the disease. RESULTS: Analysis of 2 PDD case-control series independently collected on different continents using pan-viral microarray revealed a boravirus hybridization signature in 62.5% (5/8) of PDD cases and none (0/8) in controls. Ultra-high-throughput sequencing was used to recover the complete viral genome sequence from one of the virus-positive PDD cases. This revealed a boravirus-like genome organization for this agent with a high degree of sequence variation from all previous boravirus isolates. We propose the name avian bornavirus (ABV) for this agent. More specific ABV PCR analysis of an additional set of independently collected PDD cases and controls yielded a significant difference in ABV detection rate among PDD cases (71, n = 7%) compared to controls (0%, n = 14); Fisher's Exact Test). Partial sequence analysis of a total of 16 ABV isolates that we have now rescued from them and an additional case set reveal at least 5 different ABV genetic subsets. CONCLUSION: These studies clearly demonstrate the existence of an avian reservoir of remarkably diverse boraviruses and present a compelling candidate for the search for the etiologic agent of PDD.
authors: Kistler, A. L.;Gancz, A.;Clubb, S.;Skewes-Cox, P.;Fischer, K.;Sorber, K.;Chiu, C. Y.;Lublin, A.;Mechani, S.;Farnoushi, Y.;Greninger, A.;Wen, C. C.;Karlene, S. B.;Ganem, D.;DeRisi, J. L.

title: Continuous circulation of African swine fever virus in Tanzania, 2010-2012
authors: Kitambi, A.;Council, K. D.

title: Current Information on Porcine circovirus 3 (PCV-3): A New Virus with As-yet Unknown Impact on Porcine Industry Review
abstract: Porcine circovirus 3 (PCV-3) is a recently identified virus belonging to the Circoviridae family. It represents the third member of the Circovirus genus capable of infecting pigs, along with PCV-1, which is considered non-pathogenic, and PCV-2, one of the most economically relevant viruses for the swine industry worldwide. PCV-3 was first found in 2015 by metagenomic analyzes in tissues of pigs suffering from swine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome, reproductive failure, myocarditis, and multisystemic inflammation.
