The absence of other common pathogens as potential infectious agents of these conditions has raised the suspicion that PCV-3 may play an etiological role in disease occurrence. Subsequently, the viral genome was detected in apparently healthy pigs, and retrospective studies showed that PCV-3 was already present in pigs by the early 1990s. In fact, available evidence indicates that PCV-3 is a fairly common virus worldwide. Recently, virus DNA has also been found in wild boar, expanding the scope of infection susceptibility among the Suidae family; furthermore, the potential reservoir role of this species for domestic pig has been proposed. Phylogenetic studies with PCV-3 partial and full sequences available from around the world revealed high nucleotide identity (>96%), although two main groups and several subsets were also identified. It has also been suggested that the most dated to about 50 years ago belonged to a common ancestor. Considering the economic importance and known effects of PCV-2 on the swine industry, a new member of the same family as PCV-3 should not be neglected. Studies on epidemiology, pathogenesis, immunity and diagnosis are warranted in the next few years. Therefore, the current review will update current knowledge and future research trends on PCV-3.
authors: Klaumann, F.;Correa-Fiz, F.;Franzo, G.;Sibila, M.;Nunez, J. I.;Segales, J.

title: Occurrence and phylogenetic analysis of bovine respiratory syncytial virus in respiratory disease outbreaks in Norway.
abstract: Bovine respiratory syncytial virus (BRSV) is one of the major pathogens involved in the bovine respiratory disease (BRD) complex. The seroprevalence of BRSV in Norwegian cattle herds is high, but its role in respiratory disease outbreaks is unclear. The aim of the study was to investigate the etiological role of BRSV and other respiratory viruses in BRD outbreaks and to conduct a phylogenetic analysis of Norwegian BRSV strains. BRSV infection was detected serologically and/or virologically in 18 of 21 (86%) outbreaks and as a single viral agent in most cases. When serology showed the presence of bovine coronavirus and/or bovine parainfluenza virus 3, the number of BRSV positive animals in the herd was always higher, supporting the view that BRSV is the main pathogen. Sequencing of the G gene of BRSV-positive samples indicated that existing circulating Norwegian BRSVs, along with other Northern European isolates, belonged to genetic subgroup II. An isolate from an outbreak that occurred in Norway in 1976 was also investigated. This strain formed a distinct clade in subgroup II, clearly distinct from the existing Scandinavian sequences. Currently circulating BRSV can be split into two different strains co-existing in the same geographic area. Sequence variations between the two strains were in an antigenic important part of the G protein. The results showed that BRSV is the most important etiologic agent of BRD outbreaks in Norway and often acts as the sole viral agent. Phylogenetic analysis of Norwegian BRSV strains and several previously published isolates supported the geographic and temporal clustering theory of BRSV.
authors: Klem, T. B.;Rimstad, E.;Stokstad, M.

title: Reliable classification and recombination analysis of porcine endogenous retroviruses
abstract: Prevention of interspecific infection with porcine endogenous retroviruses (PERV) is crucial for xenotransplantation. Previous studies have identified the potential risk of infection for the PERV Î³1 subfamily A, B, and C. Replication competent PERV Î³1 proviruses assigned to a particular subfamily and hybrid viruses resulting from retroviral recombination events between subfamilies were observed. Future porcine genome sequencing projects will reveal large numbers of new PERV proviruses from additional breeds and animals. Evaluation of these viral genomes should be done to assess the potential risk of retroviral interspecies infection. In this study, we tested common sequence comparison methods for classification of PERV sequences and detection of hybrid clones. Examination of polymorphic nucleotide positions was found to be the most appropriate procedure. We describe a quick and simple method using bioinformatics software tools that can also be applied to similar analyzes of other viral genomes. © 2005 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Klymiuk, N.;Aigner, B.

title: Impact of Enteroviruses and Parechoviruses on public health
abstract: Enteroviruses (EV) include viruses that were originally classified into several groups based on their cell culture replication patterns and clinical manifestations: poliovirus, coxsachivirus A, coxsachivirus B, and ECHOvirus. The closely related genus Parechovirus has more recently been associated with human disease. EVs are common commensals in the human gut, usually found without adverse effects on the individual, but are also associated with a wide variety of diseases and syndromes, including nonspecific rash diseases, hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), conjunctivitis. meningitis and encephalitis, myocarditis and polio. This results in a significant worldwide burden of disease, often due to a particular EV genotype. An estimated 1 billion people are infected with EVs each year.
authors: Knippenberg, B.;Ferson, M. J.

title: Serological classification of bovine enteroviruses
abstract: Cross-virus neutralization (VN), complement fixation (CF) and immunoprecipitation (IP) tests tested seven currently recognized bovine enterovirus (BEV) serotypes with seven serologically distinct strains previously isolated in Great Britain and two other BEVs from the United Kingdom. was used for comparison. . Based on the criteria used to distinguish between other human and animal picornavirus serotypes, it was discovered that BEV types 1, 4, 5 and 6 are related to each other and can be included in a single serotype. Types 3 and 7 were found to be the same and associated with serotype 2. All nine other BEVs were included in serotype 1 or 2. Not all strains in each serotype were the same and antigenic variants were designated as subtypes. Antigenic associations not revealed by VN were shown in the CF and IP tests. Bovine enterovirus strains, whose antisera have the widest intratypical reactivity, were proposed as prototypes. The two proposed BEV serotypes can also be distinguished by their ability to agglutinate erythrocytes. Guinea pig erythrocytes were agglutinated by both serotypes, while sheep red cells only reacted with serotype 1.
authors: Knowles, N. J.;Barnett, I. T. R.

title: Classification of porcine enteroviruses by antigenic analysis and cytopathic effects in tissue culture: definition of 3 new serotypes
abstract: Porcine enteroviruses isolated in the UK between 1972 and 1976 were compared with 8 previously described serotypes and with human coxsackie B virus types 1 to 6 for their ability to grow in different cell lines. This allowed all strains to be classified into 3 broad groups according to the type of cytopathic effect in IBRS-2 cells and further subdivided on the basis of cytopathic effect production in BHK 21, HeLa and VERO cells. None of the porcine enterovirus strains were neutralized with antisera to human enteroviruses (Lim Benyesh-Melnick Pools), except for porcine vesicular disease virus, which was neutralized with coxsackie B5 antiserum. Antisera against 8 porcine enterovirus serotypes prepared in gnotobiotic pigs or guinea pigs failed to neutralize 9 isolates that could be classified into the 3 proposed new serotypes 9, 10 and 11. Guinea pig sera can be used as an alternative to gnotobiotic pig serums for type differentiation.
authors: Knowles, N. J.;Buckley, L. S.;Pereira, H. G.

title: Investigation of antigenic variants of foot and mouth disease virus by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis of structural polypeptides
abstract: Twenty-nine foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) type A virus strains, previously classified as serologically distinct subtypes, were analyzed by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE) to determine the degree of variation in the pattern of structural polypeptides and to evaluate the technique. as an aid to existing subtyping techniques. The majority of the subtypes studied had different polypeptide patterns, but some variation also occurred between strains within a subtype. The location of VP2(1B) and VP3(1C) generally did not change over long periods in different strains within a subtype and between geographically related subtypes. Changes in the position of VP1(1D) were also observed within a subtype. The technique was considered of value for screening isolates prior to traditional serological procedures and for tracing the possible origin of FMD outbreaks.
authors: Knowles, N. J.;Hedger, R. S.

title: VP1 sequencing protocol for foot-and-mouth disease virus molecular epidemiology
abstract: The nucleotide sequences of field strains of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) contribute to our understanding of the distribution and evolution of viral strains circulating in different parts of the world. This article summarizes a practical reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and sequencing strategy that can be used to generate RNA sequences encoding the VP1 (1D) region of FMDV. The protocol includes a selectable PCR panel and sequencing primers to characterize genetically diverse isolates representing all seven FMDV serotypes. A sequence list containing prototype sequences for all proposed FMDV topotypes is also described to provide a framework for phylogenetic analysis. The technical details and prototype sequences provided in this paper can be used by FMD Reference Laboratories and others to harmonize the molecular epidemiology of FMDV.
authors: Knowles, N. J.;Wadsworth, J.;Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;King, D. P.

title: A porcine enterovirus G associated with enteric disease contains a novel papain-like cysteine protease
abstract: Identification of unknown pathogens in pigs with enteric disease is difficult due to the wide variety of bacterial and viral species found in stool samples. Current methods generally require testing only a limited number of known species using bacterial or viral isolation or quantitative PCR analysis. Here, the feces of two 25-day-old piglets with diarrhea from Texas, USA were analyzed by metagenomic next-generation sequencing to quickly identify possible pathogens. Our analysis included a bioinformatics pipeline consisting of rapid short-read classification and de novo genome assembly that resulted in the identification of a porcine enterovirus G (EV-G), a complete genome with significant nucleotide differences (>30%) among the available sequences, and Torovirus papain-like A new nonstructural protein sequentially similar to cysteine protease (PLpro). This discovery led to the identification and circulation of an EV-G with a new PLpro that had not been previously reported in the US.
authors: Knutson, T. P.;Velayudhan, B. T.;Marthaler, D. G.

title: Gentian mosaic virus: A New Species in the genus Fabavirus
abstract: SUMMARY A viral isolate named N-1 obtained from a gentian (Gentiana scabra) plant showing mosaic symptoms mechanically infected nine plant species in six families. These plants are known as hosts of fabaviruses. The N-1 isolate consisted of isometric particles with a diameter of 30 nm and contained two RNA molecules of approximately 6.0 and 3.6 kb in length, as estimated by agarose gel electrophoresis. RNAs are individually encapsulated in two of the three particle types. Each particle contained two different proteins with Mr values of 39.3 x 10(3) and 26.6 x 10(3) as determined by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Analysis of the complete nucleotide sequences of the RNAs revealed that each encodes a single large polyprotein, where the putative functional proteins are arranged in a similar fashion to those in Legume wilt virus 1 (BBWV-1) and Legume wilt virus 2 (BBWV-). 2) They are members of the genus Fabavirus (Comoviridae family). Analysis of the inferred amino acid sequences of the proteins showed that those of isolated N-1 shared 38% to 66% identity with those of BBWV-1 and BBWV-2, but only 16 to 42% identity with a comovirus, Cowpea mosaic virus. . Phylogenetic analysis based on the amino acid sequences of the RNA polymerase placed isolate N-1 in a separate lineage from BBWV-1 and BBWV-2. In the indirect enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, the N-1 isolate BBWV-1 showed distant serological association with BBWV-2 and another fabavirus, Lamium mild mosaic virus. Our results show that N-1 represents a new Fabavirus strain. We propose the name Gentian mosaic virus for this new strain.
authors: Kobayashi, Y. O.;Kobayashi, A.;Hagiwara, K.;Uga, H.;Mikoshiba, Y.;Naito, T.;Honda, Y.;Omura, T.

title: The Cattle Virus Virus: A Schedule
abstract: Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus (BVDV) is a bovine pathogen, a member of the Flaviviridae family, a genus of pestivirus that also includes Classical Swine Fever Virus (CSFV or swine cholera virus) and Border Disease Virus of sheep (BDV). It causes significant economic losses mainly associated with reproductive failure. Pestiviruses are small enveloped viruses about 40 nm in diameter. The nucleocapsid is probably icosahedral. The genome consists of a single-stranded positive RNA encoding approximately 430 kD of protein product. Genetic expression consists of the synthesis of a polyprotein that is processed together and post-translationally. Two biotypes can be distinguished based on its "in vitro" behavior: non-cytopathic (ncp) and cytopathic (cp), most likely derived from ncp by mutations and/or recombination. BVDV can cross the placenta and infect the fetus, causing problems ranging from fetal death to the birth of a permanently infected (P) calf, depending on the fetal age at the time of infection. PI animals are immuno-tolerant to the virus and spread it in all secretions. Only the ncp biotype was isolated from PI animals. Superinfection of a PI animal with a cp strain causes mucosal disease, which is always fatal. Since 1993, outbreaks of serious, sometimes hemorrhagic disease caused by ncp BVDV have occurred in Canada and the USA. Genomic and serological differences between "traditional" strains and viruses isolated from these outbreaks, including subtypes I and II of BVDV, both cp and ncp strains. Analyzes of the non-coding 5'-UTR region of the genome of pestiviruses from different species (bovine, ovine, porcine) indicate that there are at least 3 genotypes within the genus. A new classification of these viruses based on genomic sequence rather than type of origin has been proposed. Genomic heterogeneity exists in the BVDV genome, which presents 3 hypervariable regions, 2 of which are in the major neutralizing protein. The prevalence of BVDV antibodies in the cattle population in Argentina is 70% and the prevalence of persistent infections is around 1%.
authors: Kobrak, A.;Weber, E. L.

title: Influenza A viruses isolated from migratory ducks in Oklahoma
abstract: Nine type A influenza viruses were isolated from ducks migrating and wintering in Oklahoma in 1976-77. The antigenic classification of the isolated viruses revealed three distinct subtypes: Hav1 Nav2, Hws N1 and Hav6 N2. No transmission of influenza viruses from wild ducks to sentinels (McGraw mallards) was detected in the same lakes.
authors: Kocan, A. A.;Hinshaw, V. S.;Daubney, G. A.

title: Genomic comparison of bovine papillomavirus 1 isolates from bovine, equine and acini lesioned tissue samples
abstract: Several attempts have been made to classify equidistant and bovine isolates of bovine papillomavirus 1 (BPV1) based on sequence tags. This study includes newly determined sequence information from 33 equine, acini and bovine BPV1 isolates and explores host species-dependent sequence bias. Twenty of the viral genomes were sequenced along their entire length, and thirteen, including the flanking sequences, were sequenced at two specific sites, the LCR and E5 ORF. Alignment and analysis of the sequences did not reveal statistically significant site differences between the bovine and equine sequences. None of the proposed divergence sites cited by other authors showed significant species-specific features. Our results demonstrate that BPV1 is shared between equine, acini and bovine host species and that viral transfer between cattle and horses is a recurrent and ongoing phenomenon.
authors: Koch, C.;Ramsauer, A. S.;Drogemuller, M.;Ackermann, M.;Gerber, V.;Tobler, K.

title: Metagenomics-driven virome: existing procedures and new additions
authors: Kohl, C.;Nitsche, A.;Kurth, A.

title: Using RNALaterÂ® protection for Virome sequencing in outbreak settings
authors: Kohl, C.;Wegener, M.;Nitsche, A.;Kurth, A.

title: Phylogenetic and recombination analysis of the herpesvirus genus varicellovirus
abstract: BACKGROUND: Varicelloviruses include a genus within the alphaherpesvirus subfamily and infect both humans and other mammals. Recently, next-generation sequencing has been used to generate genomic sequences of several members of the Varicellovirus genus. Here, currently available varicellovirus genomic sequences were used for phylogenetic, recombination and genetic distance analysis. CONCLUSIONS: A phylogenetic network containing the genomic sequences of individual species was constructed and suggested a potential constraint between ungulate and non-hoofed viruses. Intraspecies genetic distances were found in hoof viruses (pseudorabies virus (SuHV-1) 1.65%, bovine herpes virus type 1 (BHV-1) 0.81%, equine herpes virus type 1 (EHV-1) 0.79%), equine herpes virus type) was higher. 4 (EHV-4) 0.16%), non-hoofed viruses (feline herpes virus type 1 (FHV-1) 0.0089%, canine herpes virus type 1 (CHV-1) 0.005%, varicella-zoster virus (VZV) ) 0.136% ) ). The G + C content of ungulate viruses was also higher compared to non-hoofed viruses (FHV-1 45.8%) (SuHV-1 73.6%, BHV-1 72.6%, EHV-1 56.6%, EHV-4 50.5% , CHV-1 31.6%, VZV 45.8%), suggesting a possible link between G + C content and intraspecies genetic diversity. Varicellovirus clade terminology is variable between different species, and we propose a standardization based on genomic genetic distance. A recent study reported no recombination among the sequenced FHV-1 strains, but both splitstree and bootstrap screening and PHI analysis in the current study showed recombination. We also found that the recently sequenced Brazilian CHV-1 strain BTU-1 may contain a genetic signal from an unknown varicellovirus in the UL50 gene. CONCLUSION: Together, the data contribute to a better understanding of varicellovirus genomics, and we also propose a new clade nomenclature scheme based on genetic distances.
authors: Kolb, A. W.;Lewin, A. C.;Moeller Trane, R.;McLellan, G. J.;Brandt, C. R.

title: African swine fever virus, Siberia, Russia, 2017
abstract: African swine fever (ASF) is arguably the most dangerous and emerging swine disease worldwide. ASF is a serious problem for the swine industry. The first case of ASF in Russia was reported in 2007. We report an outbreak of ASF in Siberia, Russia, in 2017.
authors: Kolbasov, D.;Titov, I.;Tsybanov, S.;Gogin, A.;Malogolovkin, A.

title: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrhea virus from Austrian field samples
abstract: Twenty-five bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) positive field samples were typed to 5'-UTR by sequencing PCR products amplified using universal 324/326 pestivirus primers. All viruses were classified as BVDV-1, no BVDV-2 isolates were identified. Fourteen viruses were typed as BVDV-1f, six viruses as BVDV-1b, four viruses as BVDV-1h, and one virus fell into the BVDV-1g group. Comparison of the data presented in this study with data for other BVDV isolates from Austria shows that the BVDV-1f subgenotype is predominant in Austrian cattle populations.
authors: Kolesarova, M.;Franz, S.;Jackova, A.;Vilcek, S.;Mostl, K.;Benetka, V.;Schopf, K.;Schoder, G.;Hofer, J.;Baumgartner, W.

title: Genetic clustering of Borna disease virus natural animal isolates, laboratory and vaccine strains strongly reflects their regional geographic origins.
abstract: The aim of this study was to obtain more detailed information about the genetic evolution and variability of the Borna disease virus (BDV). Phylogenetic analyzes were performed on field viruses originating from naturally infected animals, the BDV vaccine strain 'Dessau', four commonly used laboratory strains and the new BDV subtype No/98. Four regions of the BDV genome were analyzed: the complete p40, p10 and p24 genes and the 5'-untranslated region of the X/P transcript. BDV isolates from the same geographic region clearly showed a higher degree of identity to each other than BDV isolates from other regions, regardless of host species and year of isolation. Five different clusters can be formed within endemic areas, corresponding to the geographic regions from which the viruses originate: (i) a Swiss, Austrian and Liechtenstein Rhine valley group geographically closely related to the neighboring Baden-Wurttemberg and Bavaria II group (ii) in the western part of Germany; (iii) a third group, the so-called Bavarian I group, whose formation is limited to Bavaria; (iv) bordering on the territory of these federal states in the eastern part of Germany, with the southern Saxony-Anhalt and northern Saxony group; and (v) a mixed group of samples from different regions of Germany; but they were mainly from the federal states of Thuringia and Lower Saxony. Laboratory strains and vaccine strain are clustered within these groups according to their geographical origin. With all field and laboratory strains, the vaccine strain was clearly differentiated from the recently described and highly distinct BDV strain No/98, originating in an area in Austria where Borna disease is not endemic.
authors: Kolodziejek, J.;Durrwald, R.;Herzog, S.;Ehrensperger, F.;Lussy, H.;Nowotny, N.

title: West Nile virus positive blood donation and subsequent entomological investigation, Austria, 2014
abstract: West Nile virus (WNV) nucleic acid is reportedly detected in a blood donation from Vienna, Austria, as well as in Culex pipiens pupae and egg rafts sampled near the donor's residence. Complete genomic sequences of human and mosquito-derived viruses were generated, genetically compared and phylogenetically analyzed. The viruses were not identical, but closely related to each other and to recent Czech and Italian isolates, suggesting that related WNV strains circulate together within a limited geographic area. The detection of WNV in a blood donation originating from a region with a low prevalence of WNV in humans (only three cases with a serological diagnosis between 2008 and 2014) is surprising and highlights the importance of WNV nucleic acid testing even in such regions. active mosquito surveillance programs.
authors: Kolodziejek, J.;Seidel, B.;Jungbauer, C.;Dimmel, K.;Kolodziejek, M.;Rudolf, I.;HubÃ¡lek, Z.;Allerberger, F.;Nowotny, N.

title: Whole genomic analysis of human and bovine G8P 1 rotavirus strains isolated in Nigeria provides evidence for direct interspecies transmission from cattle to humans
abstract: Bovine group A rotavirus (RVA) G8P[1] strains have been rarely detected in humans. Two Nigerian strains of G8P[1], HMG035 (RVA/Human-tc/NGA/HMG035/1999/G8P[1]) and NGRBg8 (RVA/Cow-tc/NGA/NGRBg8/1998/G8P[1]), previously It has been suggested that it has bovine VP7, VP4 and NSP1 genes. To obtain precise information about the origin and evolution of these G8P[1] strains, the complete nucleotide sequences of the entire genomes of HMG035 and NGRBg8 strains were determined and analyzed in this study. In whole genomic analysis, strains HMG035 and NGRBg8 were found to be closely related to each other in all 11 segments and have a bovine RVA-like genotype constellation (G8-P[1]-I2-R2-C2). -M2-A11-N2-T6-E2-H3). In addition, phylogenetic analysis revealed that each of the 11 genes of HMG035 and NGRBg8 strains was of bovine origin. Therefore, it has been suggested that the HMG035 and NGRBg8 strains are derived from a common origin, and the NGRBg8 strain was hypothesized to represent a sample of bovine RVA strains transmitted to humans. Our findings provide clear evidence for direct cattle-to-human interspecies transmission of RVA strains.
authors: Komoto, S.;Adah, M. I.;Ide, T.;Yoshikawa, T.;Taniguchi, K.

title: Reclassification of Human and Animal Rotavirus Gene Segments in Emerging DS-1-Like G1P 8 Rotavirus Strains
abstract: The emergence and rapid spread of novel DS-1-like G1P[8] human rotaviruses in Japan has recently been reported. More recently, such intergenogroup reassortant strains have been identified in Thailand, implying the continued spread of unusual rotavirus strains in Asia. During surveillance of rotavirus in Thailand, three DS-1-likes with G3P[8] (RVA/Human-wt/THA/SKT-281/2013/G3P[8] and RVA/Human-wt/THA/SKT-) intergenogroup reasortant strain) 289/2013/G3P[8]) and G2P[8] (RVA/Human-wt/THA/LS-04/2013/G2P[8]) genotypes were identified in stool samples from hospitalized children with acute gastroenteritis. In this study, we sequenced and characterized the complete genomes of SKT-281, SKT-289 and LS-04 strains. In full genomic analysis, all three strains displayed unique genotype constellations containing both genogroup 1 and 2 genes: G3-P[8]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A2-N2-T2-E2-H2 for strains SKT-281. and G2-P[8]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A2-N2-T2-E2-H2 for strain SKT-289 and LS-04. Apart from the G genotype, the unique genotype constellation of the three strains (P[8]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A2-N2-T2-E2-H2) is usually shared with the DS-1-like G1P[8. ] strains. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that nine out of 11 genes of SKT-281 and SKT-289 strains (VP4, VP6, VP1-3, NSP1-3 and NSP5) originated from DS-1-like G1P[8] strains, with the remaining VP7 and NSP4 genes in equine and bovine, respectively. was found to originate. Therefore, strains SKT-281 and SKT-289, DS-1-like G1P[8], appeared as reasortant strains to animal-derived human and/or animal rotaviruses. On the other hand, seven of the 11 genes of the LS-04 lineage (VP7, VP6, VP1, VP3, and NSP3-5) appear to originate from locally circulating DS-1-like G2P[4] human rotaviruses, while three of their genes (VP4, VP2, and NSP1) are DS- It is assumed to be derived from 1 like G1P[8] strains. Notably, the remaining NSP2 gene of the LS-04 strain appeared to be of bovine origin. Therefore, the LS-04 strain was hypothesized to be a multiple reclassification strain relative to DS-1-like G1P[8], locally circulating DS-1-like G2P[4], bovine-like human and/or bovine rotaviruses. Overall, the great genomic diversity among DS-1-like G1P[8] strains seemed to have been established by reclassification involving human and animal strains. To our knowledge, this is the first report on whole genome-based characterization of DS-1-like intergenogroup reassortant strains with genotypes G3P[8] and G2P[8] that originated in Thailand. Our observations will provide important insights into the evolutionary dynamics of emerging DS-1-like G1P[8] strains and related reassortants.
authors: Komoto, S.;Tacharoenmuang, R.;Guntapong, R.;Ide, T.;Tsuji, T.;Yoshikawa, T.;Tharmaphornpilas, P.;Sangkitporn, S.;Taniguchi, K.

title: Isolation and Phylogenetic Analysis of H9N2 Swine Flu Virus from Sick Pigs in Southern China in 2010
abstract: Before pigs became infected with foot and mouth disease in Guangdong in January 2011, some pigs developed flu-like symptoms; cough, sneezing, runny nose and fever. Researchers collected nasopharyngeal swabs of all sick pigs whenever possible. An H9N2 influenza virus was isolated from the pig population. The complete genome of an isolate designated A/Swine/Guangdong/L1/2010(H9N2) was sequenced and compared with sequences available in GenBank. The results of the analyzes showed that the A/Swine/Guangdong/L1/2010(H9N2) sequence was similar to that of several avian influenza viruses. Based on phylogenetic analysis of complete gene sequences, A/Swine/Guangdong/L1/2010(H9N2) likely resulted from reclassification of avian influenza viruses.
authors: Kong, W. L.;Huang, L. Z.;Cao, N.;Qi, H. T.;Zhao, M. M.;Guan, S. S.;Wang, W. H.;Zao, F. R.;Qi, W. B.;Jiao, P. R.;Zhang, G. H.

title: Varicella-zoster virus induces apoptosis in subpopulations of primary human peripheral blood mononuclear cells in vitro
abstract: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), a member of the subfamily Herpesviridae, Î±-Herpesvirinae, is pathogenic only in humans. Chickenpox is the result of primary infection by VZV. During the viremic phase, VZV infects peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) and spreads to the environment. It causes typical lesions in skin cells. Apoptosis has been demonstrated in different cell types by other Î±-herpesviruses. VZV-infected T lymphocytes, B lymphocytes, and monocytes, respectively, were examined in this in vitro study by flow cytometry, immunofluorescence, and electron microscopy. All infected cell types showed signs of apoptosis: a lower DNA content, DNA fragmentation, loss of membrane integrity, and an altered nuclear morphology. The observed results led to the suggestion that VZV could induce apoptosis during in vivo infection in PBMC subpopulations. © 2003 scientifiques et médicales Elsevier SAS. All rights reserved.
authors: KÃ¶nig, A.;HÃ¶mme, C.;HaurÃ¶der, B.;Dietrich, A.;Wolff, M. H.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of foot and mouth disease viruses isolated in Argentina
abstract: By analyzing the complete or partial VPI sequences of 31 foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) viruses belonging to serotypes A, O, and C, we determined the genetic relevance of field strains of FMD virus (FMDV) circulating in Argentina between 1961 and Argentina. 1994. Phylogenetic analysis, including 15 previously published Argentine sequences and six reference strains, revealed that (i) FMD type A strains show the highest genetic heterogeneity and can be divided into five lineages with a sequence difference of 0.9-18.5% between strains. (ii) Most of the FMD type O viruses grouped in two clusters (within 0.2% to 6.0% cluster sequence difference) circulating in Argentina since the early 1960s, and (iii) FMD type C viruses grouped in two clusters. 13.4% nucleotide sequence difference between each cluster. The availability of sequence data for many more field isolates from the region will enable us to understand the genetic relationships between FMDV strains and quickly track the source of an FMD outbreak for epidemiological surveillance.
authors: KÃ¶nig, G.;Blanco, C.;Knowles, N. J.;Palma, E. L.;Maradei, E.;Piccone, M. E.

title: Molecular epidemiology of foot and mouth virus types A and O isolated in Argentina during the 2000-2002 epizootic.
abstract: Between 2000 and 2002, an epizootic disease of foot and mouth disease (FMD) affected Argentina and spread throughout the country, causing more than 2,500 epidemics. To study the evolution of FMD viruses (FMDV) and aid disease control measures, genetic characterization and phylogenetic analysis of 43 epizootic-representing domain isolates were performed. The nucleotide sequence of the VP1 coding region was determined for viruses and used in this study. Two serotype A strains, A/Arg/00 and A/Arg/01 (preload value 1000/1000), and two different serotype strains O/Arg/00 (848/1000 bootstrap value) were identified. Phylogenetic analysis indicates that A/Arg/01 and O/Arg/00 viruses may be related to ancient South American isolates, while the origin of A Argentina 2000 viruses remains unclear. Comparison of amino acid sequences with vaccine reference strains revealed differences in critical antigenic regions for the resulting strains A/Arg/00 and A/Arg/01, resulting in a change in the current vaccine formulation. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: KÃ¶nig, G. A.;Palma, E. L.;Maradei, E.;Piccone, M. E.

title: The heterogeneity of ruminant pestiviruses: Academic interest or an important basis for the development of vaccines and diagnostics?
abstract: Pestiviruses cause economically important diseases of livestock. Members of pestiviruses are bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 (BVDV-1), BVDV-2, classical swine fever virus (CSFV) and borderline disease virus (BDV). Phylogenetic analyzes based on the entire nucleic acid sequence encoding Npro provide statistically significant separation of established species and subgroups within species. BVDV-1 strains isolated in Germany can be associated with at least five different subgroups. In contrast, all BVDV-2 isolates detected so far in Germany are closely related and belong to a subgroup. A group of virus isolates from sheep and zoo animals is clearly different from the established pestivirus strains and may be termed BDV-2. The antigenic relationship of pestiviruses was investigated using virus isolates and antisera identified in cross-neutralization experiments. Six antigenic groups were distinguished, corresponding to the genetic clusters BVDV-1, BVDV-2, CSFV, BDV-1, BDV-2 and Giraffe-1. A significant antigenic difference was also observed between members of subgroups 1a and 1b of BVDV-1. Studies on the genetic and antigenic heterogeneity of pestiviruses are important for the development of new vaccines, diagnostic tests and eradication programs.
authors: KÃ¶nig, M.;Cedillo Rosales, S.;Becher, P.;Thiel, H. J.

title: Characterization and identification of Oya virus, a Simbu serogroup virus of the genus Bunyavirus, isolated from a pig with suspected Nipah virus infection.
abstract: virus called Oya virus was isolated in Vero cell cultures from the lungs of a pig with suspected Nipah virus infection. The virus emerged as a spherical enveloped RNA virus with a diameter of 79 nm. RT-PCR was performed for the detection of Oya virus. A common primer set for the S-RNA of the Simbu serogroup of the Bunyavirus genus was able to amplify a cDNA from the Oya virus RNA. Sequence data of the product revealed that the partial gene of the Oya virus S-RNA segment has 65-70% homology with the published cDNA sequences of Simbu serogroup viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the data showed that Oya virus grouped in the Simbu serogroup, but was genetically different from the molecularly analyzed serogroup viruses. Serological studies revealed that the virus is spreading widely and intensely in Malaysia.
authors: Kono, Y.;Yusnita, Y.;Mohd Ali, A. R.;Maizan, M.;Sharifah, S. H.;Fauzia, O.;Kubo, M.;Aziz, A. J.

title: Virological and pathological characterization of an avian H1N1 influenza A virus
abstract: Gene segments from avian H1N1 influenza A viruses have been remapped with other influenza viruses to create pandemic strains over the past century. However, little effort has been made to understand the characteristics of avian H1N1 influenza viruses. Here, we present the genome sequence and molecular and virological characterization of an avian influenza A virus, A/wildbird/Korea/SK14/2014 (A/SK14, H1N1), isolated from migratory birds during the winter in South Korea. 2014-2015. Whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis revealed that the virus belongs to the Eurasian avian lineage. Although the A/SK14 virus retained its avian-receptor binding preference, it also exhibited detectable human-like receptor binding and was able to replicate in differentiated primary normal human bronchial epithelial cells. In animal models, A/SK14 virus was moderately pathogenic in mice and the virus was detected in nasal washes of vaccinated guinea pigs, but not in direct contact guinea pigs. Although A/SK14 shows moderate pathogenicity in a mammalian model and has no evidence of transmission, our results suggest that the dual receptor specificity of the A/SK14-like virus may allow a faster adaptation to mammals and further continuous surveillance and risk assessment activities.
authors: Koo, B. S.;Kim, H. K.;Song, D.;Na, W.;Song, M. S.;Kwon, J. J.;Wong, S. S.;Noh, J. Y.;Ahn, M. J.;Kim, D. J.;Webby, R. J.;Yoon, S. W.;Jeong, D. G.

title: Evolution of thymidine and thymidylate kinases: the possibility of independent capture of TK genes by different virus groups
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of viral and cellular thymidine and thymidylate kinases was performed using computer assisted methods. Multiple alignments and temporal phylogenetic trees were generated for two families of these enzymes, including a) mammalian thymidine kinases (TK), smallpox viruses, African swine fever virus, E. coli, and bacteriophage T4; and b) thymidylate kinases (ThyK) of yeast and poxviruses and distantly related herpes virus proteins with both enzymatic activities. Analysis of the alignment of TKs of the first family highlighted three strongly conserved divisions. Two of these corresponded to motifs A and B of the purine NTP-binding pattern. The third, C-terminal segment, showing the highest protection, contained a modified Zn finger motif. It is speculated that this motif may be involved in TK oligomerization. Phylogenetic trees constructed by three different methods suggested that cellular TK genes could be captured independently by T4 bacteriophage, African swine fever virus, avian pox virus, and other smallpox virus. The observed tree topologies seem to contradict popular virus-host coevolutionary schemes and imply that different subdivisions of smallpox viruses diverged from their hosts at earlier stages in evolution. The deoxynucleoside monophosphate kinase of bacteriophage T4 has been shown to be related to the ThyK family. Phylogenetic analysis suggested that ThyK genes were probably acquired independently by phage T4, smallpox viruses and herpes viruses.
authors: Koonin, E. V.;Senkevich, T. G.

title: Characterization of Ovine herpesvirus 1 RKZ isolate
abstract: The cytopathic effect (CPE), mainly characterized by round cell foci, was observed in cultures of primary plexus choroid cells from healthy lambs following cryopreservation. It was possible to transmit the infectious agent to other primary cells of sheep origin by co-cultivation with infected cells. High percentage of sheep (65-80% in 3 different herds from Slovakia) were found to be infected with this infectious agent by indirect immunofluorescence microscopy. Electron microscopy of cells with CPE revealed the presence of herpes virus particles. Viral DNA was isolated from infected cells using pulsed gel electrophoresis and also used as probe in Southern blot analysis. The probe specifically reacted only with DNA from cells infected with Ovine herpesvirus 1 (OvHV-1), but not with DNA from other ruminant herpesviruses. Some of the HindIII restriction fragments of DNA of RKZ, named OvHV-1 isolate, were cloned. A portion of the H9 clone was sequenced, identifying a gene encoding a polypeptide homologous to the conserved herpes virus VP23 structural protein. Comparing the sequence of this clone with the VP23 sequences of other herpes viruses, it was concluded that OvHV-1 can be classified within the genus Rhhadinovirus of the subfamily Gammaherpesvirinae. Sequencing the DNA of the RKZ isolate to the H9 clone enabled the establishment of a sensitive and highly specific polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay for the detection of OvHV-1.

title: Molecular genetic features of velogenic strains of Newcastle disease virus isolated in Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan.
abstract: The F gene fragment of 79 strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated from domestic and synanthropic birds in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Ukraine and Russia between 1993 and 2007 were analyzed comparatively. Phylogenetic analysis of test isolates and reference NDV strains obtained from GenBank was performed by polymerase chain reaction with subsequent sequencing and comparative analysis of 154-bp nucleotide sequences in the main functional region of the F gene. All newly characterized isolates belong to three NDV genotype VII subgroups: Vila, VIIb, VIId. The results suggest that monitoring of NDV strains isolated in CIS countries is necessary, as the spread of NDV among migratory and synanthropic birds (pigeons, crows and jackdaws) poses a serious threat to the commercial poultry industry.
authors: Korotetsky, I. S.;Bogoyavlensky, A. P.;Prilipov, A. G.;Usachev, E. V.;Usacheva, O. V.;Turmagambetova, A. S.;Zaitseva, I. A.;Kydyrmanov, A.;Shakhvorostova, L. I.;Kh Sayatov, M.;Borisov, V. V.;Pchelkina, I. P.;Gerilovich, A. P.;Berezin, V. E.

title: Differentiation of classical swine fever virus (CSFV) strains using monoclonal antibodies against structural glycoproteins
abstract: Two panels of monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) against the classic swine fever virus (CSFV) envelope glycoproteins E2 (12 mAb) and EO (11 mAb) were constructed and tested with the immunoperoxidase binding assay against 135 pestivirus strains and isolates. Variability of the binding pattern has been demonstrated for CSFV as well as bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) strains and isolates. The mAb panels against E2 and EO resulted in very different reactivity patterns. Certain mAbs against E2 reacted with (i) all CSFV isolates, (ii) only 4 out of 126 CSFV isolates, or (in) approximately 90% of CSFV isolates tested and 78% of ruminant pestivirus isolates . Anti-CSFV EO mAbs allowed detection of greater variability between CSFV strains and isolates than anti-E2 mAbs. None of the 11 anti EO mAbs recognized a conserved epitope for CSFV or showed cross-reactivity with ruminant pestiviruses. Using both panels of mAbs against the two CSFV structural glycoproteins resulted in the differentiation of 21 antigenic types of CSFV strains and isolates. The panels described can be used to trace the origin of CSFV after disease outbreaks.
authors: Kosmidou, A.;Ahl, R.;Thiel, H. J.;Weiland, E.

title: Phylogenetic correlation of Greek and Italian orf virus isolates based on the VIR gene
abstract: Thirteen orf virus isolates obtained from crusty scab lesions of nine sheep and four goats with suspected infectious ecthyma infection from different geographical regions of Greece and Italy between 1995 and 2004 were analyzed. The DNA of all isolates was successfully PCR amplified with primers 045F-045R, identifying them as parapox virus. Partial DNA sequence of the Orf virus interferon resistance (VIR) gene, phylogenetic analysis of available isolates, and amino acid comparison of the interferon resistance protein encoded by this genomic region were performed. Based on the results of the present report, a precise characterization of the studied genomic region may provide evidence for genetic variation and movement of circulating orf virus strains. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kottaridi, C.;Nomikou, K.;Teodori, L.;Savini, G.;Lelli, R.;Markoulatos, P.;Mangana, O.

title: Phylogenetic evolution of the swine human influenza virus: a pandemic H1N1 2009
abstract: Genome constellation information from different countries and different hosts in the pandemic influenza A virus H1N1 2009 is valuable for monitoring and understanding the evolution and migration of these strains. The complete genome sequences of selected influenza A viruses distributed worldwide are publicly available, and several longitudinal genome studies of human, avian, and porcine influenza A viruses have been performed. All downloadable sequences of influenza A viruses available on the GISAID Platform (Global Initiative for Sharing Global Influenza Data) were first analyzed through the web servers of the Influenza Virus Resource at NCBI. Phylogenetic study of the circulating human pandemic H1N1 virus showed that the new variant has a distinctive evolutionary feature. There is no single way for pandemic H1N1 to acquire new genes from other distinguishable viruses recently circulating in local human, pig or domestic poultry populations from various geographic regions. The wide genetic diversity among all segments found in the pandemic H1N1 genome indicates that multiple entry of the virus occurred during 1999-2009. Initial interspecies transmission may have occurred in the long-term past, and subsequent rearrangement steps give rise to three lineages: classical SIV common in North America, avian-like SIV in Europe, and related bird-like SIV in Asia. This analysis adds to the evidence that pigs are not the only hosts to play the 'mixing bowl' role that has been suggested for many years.
authors: Kowalczyk, A.;Markowska-Daniel, I.

title: Biological and molecular characterization of chicken anemia virus isolates from Slovenia
abstract: The presence of chicken anemia virus (CAV) in Slovenia was confirmed by vaccination of 1-day-old chickens without antibodies to CAV and isolation of the virus in the Marek disease chicken cell-MSB1 line and polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Experimental vaccination of 1-day-old chickens resulted in lower hematocrit values, thymus atrophy, and bone marrow atrophy. CAV was confirmed by PCR in the thymus, bone marrow, Fabricius bursa, liver, spleen, ileocecal tonsils, duodenum, and proventriculus. The nucleotide sequence of the entire viral protein (VP)1 gene was determined by direct sequencing. Alignment of the VP1 nucleotide sequences of Slovenian CAV isolates (CAV-69/00, CAV-469/01 and CAV-130/03) showed 99.4% to 99.9% homology. The VP1 nucleotide sequence alignment of the Slovenian isolates with the other 19 CAV strains showed 94.4% to 99.4% homology. The Slovenian isolates shared the highest homology with the BD-3 isolate from Bangladesh. Alignment of the inferred VP1 amino acids showed that the Slovenian isolates share 100% homology and have an amino acid sequence most similar to the BD-3 strain (99.6%) from Bangladesh and 99–1% similar to the G6 strain from Japan and the United States. L-028 strain from USA. Slovenian isolates were at least (96.6%) similar to strain 82-2 from Japan. A phylogenetic analysis based on the alignment of VP1 amino acids showed that the CAV isolates used in the study formed three groups, indicating the possible presence of genetic groups among the CAV strains. CAV isolates are grouped together regardless of their geographic origin and pathogenicity.
authors: KrapeÅ¾, U.;BarliÄ-Maganja, D.;Toplak, I.;Hostnik, P.;Rojs, O. Z.

title: Circulation of infectious bronchitis virus strains from Italy 02 and QX genotypes in Slovenia between 2007 and 2009
abstract: Fourteen infectious bronchitis viruses (IBV) detected in broiler, broiler and layer flocks in Slovenia between 2007 and 2009 were molecularly analyzed by reverse transcription-PCR and direct sequencing of the S1 gene. Phylogenetic analyzes based on partial S1 gene sequences revealed that seven strains were classified as Italy 02 genotype, an IBV genetic group not previously detected in Slovenia. The other seven strains were classified as the QX genotype. The results of phylogenetic analyzes and epidemiological studies revealed that genetic classification is related to the geographical origins of IBV strains. Slovene strains from Italy 02 genotype detected between 2007 and 2009 showed greater genetic variability (maximum nucleotide and amino acid differences were 4.8% and 9.9%, respectively) than strains isolated from the QX genotype (1.2%) isolated in 2008 and 2009. and 1.3%, respectively). Slovenian strains classified as the Italy 02 genotype form a distinct genetic cluster. These strains shared five specific amino acid substitutions that were fixed during the surveillance period. Strains from the QX genotype that share a particular amino acid substitution also form a separate genetic cluster. Â© 2011 American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: KrapeÅ¾, U.;Slavec, B.;Rojs, O. Z.

title: The importance of structure in the classification of avian viruses
authors: Krauss, H.

title: Metagenomics - a new approach to study our microbial neighbors
abstract: Background: In our age, information society is a part of every aspect of life, including computer-based technologies, data analytical procedures. Bioinformatics provides approaches to information gathering and updating that were unimaginable two decades ago. Metagenomics is the field of bioinformatics that helps improve our knowledge of the composition of microbial species in production or in domestic animals, humans or the environment. Objectives: This study describes the main steps of a metagenomic analysis. Metagenomic research of swine dysentery as an important animal disease is cited as an example. Materials and methods: Intestinal contents from three clinically diseased fattening pigs were sampled from three different parts of the intestine (ie, cecum, colon, and rectum). All DNA was extracted from the samples, then sequenced with next-generation sequencing technology. The 1,782,466 reads produced were collected and analyzed. Reads were adjusted by the Kraken bioinformatics tool against archaeal, bacterial and virus genome databases. The results of the alignments were visualized with the Krona tool. Results and Discussion: The presented case study helps the reader understand how metagenomic studies work and provides new professional insights into the microbiome of selected organs in different organisms. The ratios of different taxa provide insight into the gut microbial communities in diseased animals. In addition, a short review is presented to show the application possibilities of metagenomics in the field of animal health. Bioinformatics is an emerging field, and knowledge of the methods, possible implications, and limitations is essential for clinicians and researchers alike. This work provides a simple introduction to metagenomics in the language of veterinarians.
authors: Kriko, E.;Farkas, R.;Adorjan, A.;Makrai, L.;Solymosi, N.

title: Deep sequencing analysis reveals transient microbiota changes associated with the development of bovine digital dermatitis.
abstract: Bovine digital dermatitis (DD) is the leading cause of lameness in dairy cattle worldwide. Despite 35 years of research, the exact etiologic agent associated with the disease process is still unknown. Previous studies have shown that multiple bacterial species are associated with the lesions, with spirochetes being the most reliably identified organism. This study details the deep sequencing metagenomic evaluation of 48 step DD biopsy specimens collected during a 3-year longitudinal study of disease progression. More than 175 million sequences were evaluated using both shotgun and 16S metagenomic techniques. According to the shotgun sequencing results, there was no evidence of fungal or DNA viral etiology. The bacterial microbiota of biopsy specimens progresses through a systematic series of changes associated with the new morphological lesion scoring system developed as part of this project. This scoring system was validated as the microbiota of each stage was statistically significantly different from the other stages (P<0.001). The microbiota of control biopsy specimens was very diverse and became less diverse as lesions developed. Although Treponema spp. predominant in advanced lesions, they were relatively low in newly identified early lesions associated with the onset of the disease process. Treponema spp consortium. The lesions change significantly as they progress through the identified morphological stages. The results of this study support the hypothesis that DD is a polybacterial disease process and provide unique insights into temporal changes in bacterial populations throughout lesion development. Â© 2014, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Krull, A. C.;Shearer, J. K.;Gorden, P. J.;Cooper, V. L.;Phillips, G. J.;Plummera, P. J.

title: Molecular classification of enteroviruses not identified by neutralization tests
abstract: We isolated six viruses from patients diagnosed with aseptic meningitis or hand, foot, and mouth disease. The cytopathic effect of these viruses on cultured cells was similar to that of enteroviruses. However, viral neutralization tests against standard antisera were negative. Phylogenetic analysis with the complete VP4 nucleotide sequences of these 6 viruses and 29 enterovirus serotypes classified 3 of the viruses as serotype ecovirus type 18 (EV18) and 3 as serotype human enterovirus 71 (HEV71). These results were confirmed by re-microneutralization tests with HEV-monospecific antisera or an additional phylogenetic analysis with complete VP4 nucleotide sequences. Phylogenetic analysis with complete VP4 genes is more useful in identifying enterovirus serotypes than neutralization tests with enterovirus serotype-specific antisera.
authors: Kubo, H.;Iritani, N.;Seto, Y.

title: New flu viruses in bats and cattle: "Forcing the Envelope" of Influenza Infection
authors: Kuchipudi, S.;Nissly, R.

title: Whole genome characterization of a chelonian orthoreovirus strain identifies significant genetic diversity and can classify reptilian orthoreoviruses into different species
abstract: In this study, we report the sequence and phylogenetic characterization of the CH1197/96 orthreovirus strain isolated from a spur turtle (Testudo graeca) on chicken embryo fibroblast cells. The 23,957 bp long genome sequence was obtained using a combination of semiconductor and capillary sequencing. Nucleotide (48.4-70.3%) and amino acid (39.2%) -80.7%) sequence identity, although genomic characterization showed that the virus was most similar to bush viper reovirus strain 47/02 and that the two strains formed a monophyletic group in phylogenies performed with all segments. values were intermediate between the two reptilian reoviruses. Based on our results and current classification criteria for the genus Orthoreovirus, the turtle reovirus strain CH1197/96 may be the first representative of a new genus of reptilian Orthoreovirus.
authors: Kugler, R.;Marschang, R. E.;IhÃ¡sz, K.;Lengyel, G.;Jakab, F.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Farkas, S. L.

title: Next-generation sequencing (NGS): testing fecal samples from diarrheal pigs
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies are a major breakthrough in the field of infectious disease diagnosis as they allow new pathogen detection without prior sequencing information and enable simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens, whole genome studies, and metagenome studies. The aim of this study was to determine the value of NGS in the detection of pathogens in clinical specimens, ie porcine stool specimens with diarrhea. Fecal samples from four pigs with severe diarrhea were analyzed. NGS libraries were prepared from sample suspensions and used for Ion Torrent sequencing. In total, 396,486 reads were combined into 1,537 contigs. Taxonomy units were assigned to 786 contigs, while 751 contigs remained unassigned. All four samples were positive for swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PED). In two samples, viruses from Picobirnavirus and porcine astrovirus were also detected, while in one sample, viruses from the Torovirus strain were found positive. In addition to viral sequences, sequences from bacteria, archaea, nematode, Protista and amoeba were also detected in the samples examined. Based on these results, we can conclude that NGS technology is a powerful tool for infectious disease diagnosis, enabling simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens in complex samples.
authors: Kuhar, U.;Kusar, D.;Papic, B.;Toplak, I.

title: Virus terminology below the species level: a standard terminology for strains and virus variants adapted to laboratory animals assigned to the Filoviridae family
abstract: The International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) regulates the classification of viruses by taxa, but is not responsible for nomenclature for taxon members. International expert groups, such as the ICTV Working Groups, recommend classifying and naming viruses and their strains, varieties and isolates. The ICTV Filoviridae Working Group has recently presented an updated classification and nomenclature for filoviruses. Later, and in collaboration with many other filovirus experts, a consistent nomenclature for native genetic variants and isolates was developed, aimed at simplifying the retrieval of sequence data from electronic databases. This is the first important step towards a viral genome annotation standard sought by the US National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI). Here, this work has been extended to include in vitro-obtained filoviruses by artificial selection by passing them through laboratory hosts. Pre-developed template for native filovirus genetic variant naming (<virus name> <isolation host-suffix>/<country of sampling>/<sampling year>/<genetic variant assignment>-<isolate assignment>) is preserved, but variants adapted to laboratory animals for adapting the type of information added to each field. For example, the full-length description of an Ebola virus Mayinga variant adapted from "Vector" at the State Virology and Biotechnology Research Center would be similar to "Ebola virus VECTOR/C.porcellus-lab" to cause disease in guinea pigs after seven passages. /COD/1976/Mayinga-GPA-P7". We recommend using the full-length designation in databases and in the method section of publications, as recommended for names of native filovirus variants. Abbreviated notations ("EBOV VECTOR/C.por/COD/76/May-GPA- P7") and abbreviations (like "EBOV/May-GPA-P7") can be used throughout the rest of the text. how critical it is to convey the information contained in the full-length name. If only one EBOV strain/variant/isolate is considered, "EBOV" will suffice Â© 2013 Springer-Verlag Wien (outside the USA).

title: Nyamiviridae: A new family in the Mononegavirales setting
abstract: Nyamanini virus (NYMV) and Midway virus (MIDWV) are unclassified tick-borne agents that infect landbirds and seabirds, respectively. Recent molecular characterization of both viruses confirmed their already known close serological relationship and their association with members of the order Mononegavirales (bornaviruses, filoviruses, paramyxoviruses and rhabdoviruses). A third agent, soybean cyst nematode virus 1 (SbCNV-1, previously called soybean cyst nematode nyavirus), was recently found to be an additional member of this new virus group. Here we review the available information on all three viruses and propose classifying them as members of a new mononegaviral family, Nyamiviridae. Â© 2013 Springer-Verlag Wien (outside the USA).
authors: Kuhn, J. H.;Bekal, S.;CaÃ¬, Y.;Clawson, A. N.;Domier, L. L.;Herrel, M.;Jahrling, P. B.;Kondo, H.;Lambert, K. N.;Mihindukulasuriya, K. A.;Nowotny, N.;Radoshitzky, S. R.;Schneider, U.;Staeheli, P.;Suzuki, N.;Tesh, R. B.;Wang, D.;Wang, L. F.;Dietzgen, R. G.

title: Taxonomic rearrangement of the family Bornaviridae
abstract: Knowledge about bornaviruses has expanded significantly over the past decade. A possible reservoir of mammalian Borna disease virus has been identified, different boraviruses have been detected in birds and reptiles, and endogenous boravirus-like elements have been discovered in the genomes of vertebrates of various species. Previous sequence comparisons and alignments have shown that members of the current Bornaviridae family are phylogenetically diverse and are not adequately classified in the current boravirus taxonomy supported by the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV). We provide an update of these analyzes and describe their impact on classification. We propose to keep the family name Bornaviridae and the genus Bornavirus, but reorganize the species classification. PAirwise Sequence Comparison (PASC) of bornavirus genomes and Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) comparison of genomic and protein sequences indicates that this genus should contain at least five species, in combination with other currently published phylogenetic analyzes and known biological characteristics of bornaviruses. : Mammalian 1 bornavirus (classical Borna disease virus and divergent Borna disease virus isolate No/98), Psittaciform 1 bornavirus (avian/psittacine bornaviruses 1, 2, 3, 4, 7), Passeriform 1 bornavirus (avian/canarybornaviruses C1, C2) , C3, LS), Passeriform 2 bornavirus (estrildid finch bornavirus EF) and Waterbird 1 bornavirus (avian bornavirus 062CG). This classification is also compatible with the biological characteristics of these viruses and their vertebrate hosts. A snake boravirus proposed to be designated Loveridge's garter snake virus 1 should be classified as a member of an additional species (Elapid 1 boravirus) not assigned to a genus in the family Bornaviridae. Avian bornaviruses 5, 6, MALL and another "reptile bornavirus" ("Gaboon viper virus") should not be classified until further information is available. Finally, we propose new virus names and abbreviations as needed to achieve clear distinction and unique identification.
authors: Kuhn, J. H.;DÃ¼rrwald, R.;BÃ o, Y.;Briese, T.;Carbone, K.;Clawson, A. N.;deRisi, J. L.;Garten, W.;Jahrling, P. B.;Kolodziejek, J.;Rubbenstroth, D.;Schwemmle, M.;Stenglein, M.;Tomonaga, K.;WeissenbÃ¶ck, H.;Nowotny, N.

title: Reorganization and expansion of the nidoviral family Arteriviridae
abstract: The Arteriviridae family currently includes a single Arterivirus genus. This genus includes four species as taxonomic homes for equine arthritis virus (EAV), lactate dehydrogenase-raising virus (LDV), porcine respiratory and reproductive syndrome virus (PRRSV), and simian hemorrhagic fever virus (SHFV), respectively. A revision of this classification is urgently needed to accommodate the latest description of eleven highly different simian arteriviruses in various African non-human primates, a novel arterivirus in an African forest giant opossum, and a new arterivirus in common brushtails in New Zealand. In addition, the current arterivirus terminology does not conform to the latest version of the International Code for Classification and Nomenclature of Viruses. Here we outline an updated, modified and improved arterivirus taxonomy based on current data. Taxon-specific sequence truncations are generated based on a newly constructed open reading frame 1b phylogeny and pairwise sequence comparison (PASC) of coding-whole arterivirus genomes. As a result, the current Arterivirus genus has been replaced by five genera: Equartevirus (for EAV), Rodartevirus (LDVÂ +Â PRRSV), Simartevirus (SHFVÂ +Â simian arteriviruses), Nesartevirus (for arterivirus from forest giant opossums) and Dipartevirus (common brushtail) arterivirus). The current strain Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus has been split into two strains to accommodate clear differences between the European and American PRRSV "types", both of which have now received virus status. The current strain Simian hemorrhagic fever virus has been subdivided into nine strains to accommodate the twelve known simian arteriviruses. Non-Latinized binomial species names were introduced to replace all existing species names to clearly distinguish them from virus names that remained largely unchanged.

O.;Coffey, L. L.;Wolfe, N. D.;Delwart, E.;Clawson, A. N.;Postnikova, E.;Bollinger, L.;Lackemeyer, M. G.;Radoshitzky, S. R.;Palacios, G.;Wada, J.;Shevtsova, Z. V.;Jahrling, P. B.;Lapin, B. title: Genomic characterization of the genus Nairovirus (Family Bunyaviridae)
abstract: Nairovirus, one of the five bunyaviral genera, includes seven species. Genomic sequence information is limited for members of the Dera Ghazi Khan, Hughes, Qalyub, Sakhalin and Thiafora nairovirus species. To further characterize these species, we used next-generation sequencing and historical virus culture samples to identify 14 complete and nine coding-complete nairoviral genome sequences. Viruses not previously sequenced include the Abu Mina, Clo Mor, Great Saltee, Hughes, Raza, Sakhalin, Soldado, and Tillamook viruses. In addition, we present genomic sequence information on additional isolates of previously sequenced Avalon, Dugbe, Sapphire II and Zirqa viruses. Finally, we identified Tunisian virus, previously thought to be a phlebovirus, as an isolate of Abu Hammad virus. Phylogenetic analyzes indicate that Sapphire II virus should be reassigned to Dera Ghazi Khan nairovirus and Hazara, Tofla and Nairobi sheep disease viruses should be reassigned to new strains. We also propose new strains for the Kasokero group (Kasokero, Leopards Hill, Yogue viruses), the Ketarah group (Gossas, Issyk-kul, Keterah/soft tick viruses), and the Burana group (WÄ“nzhÅ u tick virus, HuàngpÃ). tick virus 1, TÇŽchéng tick virus 1). Our analyzes highlight the sibling relationship of nairoviruses and arenaviruses and show that several nairo-like viruses (ShÄ yong spider virus 1, XänzhÅ u spider virus, SänxiÃ¡ su strider virus 1, South Bay virus, WÇ”hÃ). n centipede virus 2) requires establishment of new genera in a larger nairovirus-arenavirus supergroup.
authors: Kuhn, J. H.;Wiley, M. R.;Rodriguez, S. E.;BÃ o, Y.;Prieto, K.;Travassos da Rosa, A. P. A.;Guzman, H.;Savji, N.;Ladner, J. T.;Tesh, R. B.;Wada, J.;Jahrling, P. B.;Bente, D. A.;Palacios, G.

title: Incidence of endogenous viral genes and susceptibility or resistance to Marek's disease in two strains of white leghorn chickens selected for egg production
abstract: Endogenous viral (ev) genes related to avian leukosis virus were classified in two differently selected Leghorn strains to investigate whether such genes affect production properties. The K strain was selected for resistance to Marek's disease (MD) and high egg production and egg weight, while the S strain was selected only for MD susceptibility. Except that the founders of the K strain included a few commercial birds, both strains were derived from a common genetic basis. DNA restriction fragment length analyzes of strain 110 K and strain 94 S revealed the presence of 8 different ev genes, 6 of which were identical to predefined loci. This result was confirmed by assays for group-specific antigen (gs-antigen), the product of the gag region of ev-genes. The gs-antigen levels in birds closely followed that estimated from data from the ev-genes described previously. Both strains had a similar average number of ev-genes per bird (3.5 and 3.2 for S and K strains, respectively). However, strain K carried only five different house genes while strain S carried seven. Four of these loci were present in both strains. Ev genes absent or less frequently occurring in strain K included those encoding either infectious endogenous virus (ev-10 and possibly ev-19) or internal viral plug proteins (ev-3). Only ev genes that are transcriptionally silent or encode the viral envelope gene were present with increasing frequency in the K lineage. The results show that selection for egg traits and/or resistance to Marek's disease reduces the frequency of endogenous producing house genes. virus or viral plug proteins.
authors: Kuhnlein, U.;Gavora, J. S.;Spencer, J. L.;Bernon, D. E.;Sabour, M.

title: Natural peste des petits ruminant virus infection: New pathological findings resembling other morbillivirus infections.
abstract: In this study, pathological and virological findings were defined in 15 sheep and 6 goats who died from natural peste des petits ruminant virus infection in Turkey. Pathological findings included erosive ulcerative stomatitis, fibrino-necrotic tracheitis, bronchointerstitial pneumonia, multifocal coagulation necroses in the liver, and severe lymphocytolysis in lymphoid tissues. Syncytial cells were particularly prominent in the oral mucosa, pulmonary alveoli, liver, and lymphoid tissues. In addition to the typical tissue distribution, eosinophilic intracytoplasmic and/or intranuclear inclusions were observed in epithelial cells lining the renal pelvis and abomasal mucosa. Immunolabeling of the viral antigen was observed in myocytes of the kidney, brain, rumen, abomasum, heart, and tongue, as well as in its more typical locations. In this study, the first peste des petits ruminants, which are endemic in Kırıkkale, Turkey's Central Anatolia Region, are reported and explained in detail. In conclusion, these previously unreported pathological findings in natural peste des petits ruminant virus infection provide a basis for similarity to other morbillivirus infections such as canine disease and disease of marine mammals. Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction analyzes showed that the 448-bp genome fragment was amplified in 18 cases (18/21, 85.7%). Phylogenetic analysis indicated that the viruses belonged to lineage 4 in the peste des petits ruminant virus common phylogenetic tree.
authors: Kul, O.;Kabakci, N.;Atmaca, H. T.;Ã–zkul, A.

title: Emergence of new reassortant H6N2 avian influenza viruses in ducks in India
abstract: Recent reports of human infection by H6 subtype avian influenza viruses (AIV), common in terrestrial poultry, indicate that the virus has evolved into a possible pandemic strain. Here we report the antigenic and genetic characterization of two H6N2 viruses isolated from apparently healthy domestic ducks in Kerala and Assam, India in 2014 and 2015, respectively. The hemagglutination inhibition assay revealed antigenic divergence between the two isolates, supported by amino acid differences at 55 positions (15.98%) between hemagglutinin (HA). is pathogenic to poultry and susceptible to oseltamivir. However, Kerala14 had the V27I mutation marker for amantadine resistance in M2. Assam15 virus had an additional N-linked glycosylation on HA2 (position 557) compared to Kerala14 virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA gene revealed that both viruses belonged to different lineages (Eurasian and Asian II). The phylogeny of neuraminidase and internal gene segments revealed that both viruses are novel reassortants and genetically distinct with different gene constellations. The results suggest the independent entry of two H6N2 viruses into India and migratory wild birds of the Central Asian transit route may be the source of H6N2 viruses in ducks in India. Therefore, continuous AIV surveillance in poultry and wild birds is essential for the early detection of the emergence of new strains with pandemic potential and the control of their spread.
authors: Kumar, M.;Nagarajan, S.;Murugkar, H. V.;Saikia, B.;Singh, B.;Mishra, A.;Tripathi, S. K.;Agarwal, S.;Shukla, S.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Singh, V. P.;Tosh, C.

title: Isolation and phylogenetic analysis of an orf virus from sheep in Makhdoom, India.
abstract: Orf (infectious ecthyma) is an exanthematic disease caused by a parapoxvirus and primarily occurs in sheep and goats with zoonotic effects. The current research investigated an orf outbreak in the Muzzaffarnagari flock of sheep at the Central Institute for Research on Goats (CIRG) in Makhdoom, Mathura, Uttar Pradesh, India. Primary goat testis cell culture was used for the first time for the isolation of Orf virus (ORFV). The identity of the virus was confirmed by amplification and sequence analysis of the major envelope glycoprotein (B2L) gene and was designated ORFV/sheep/India/2012/CIRG. Phylogenetic analysis of the B2L protein gene clustered with ORFV strains from China, suggesting that different ORFV strains are circulating in India. In comparison of nucleotide and inferred amino acid sequence analysis (n = 63), a unique 126S residue was observed in ORFV/sheep/India/2012/CIRG. In further sequence analysis (B2L) of different ORFV strains (n = 63), some conserved amino acid residues were identified and summarized as host-specific (sheep, human, camel, tachin and musk ox). Â© 2013 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Kumar, N.;Wadhwa, A.;Chaubey, K. K.;Singh, S. V.;Gupta, S.;Sharma, S.;Sharma, D. K.;Singh, M. K.;Mishra, A. K.

title: Hepatitis E virus: current scenario
abstract: Hepatitis E infection caused by the hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a common cause of acute hepatitis in developing countries with poor sanitation and hygiene. The virus is classified into one serotype and four genotypes (1-4). Genotypes 1 and 2 only infect humans, while genotypes 3 and 4 infect other animals, especially pigs. In endemic areas, large outbreaks of acute hepatitis caused by genotype 1 or 2 viruses often occur due to fecal-oral transmission, usually through contamination of drinking water. The disease is particularly severe (20-30% death) among pregnant women, with a high attack rate in young adults (ages 15-45). HEV appears to be a zoonotic disease by transmission from pigs, wild boars and deer or by foodborne transmission. Chronic infections are rare, except in immunocompromised individuals, such as organ transplant recipients. A subunit vaccine has been shown to be effective in preventing clinical disease, but is not yet commercially available. Our understanding of HEV has undergone major changes in recent years, and in this article we review the available knowledge regarding the molecular biology, pathobiology, and epidemiology of HEV infection. We also review current therapeutic interventions and strategies used to control HEV infection, with emphasis on possible approaches that could be used to develop an effective vaccine against HEV. Â© 2012 International Society of Infectious Diseases.
authors: Kumar, S.;Subhadra, S.;Singh, B.;Panda, B. K.

title: Full-length sequencing and genomic characterization of Bagaza, Kedougou, and Zika viruses
abstract: Many members of the Flavivirus genus are the causative agents of major diseases of humans, livestock and wildlife. Currently, a complete genome sequence is not available for the three African viruses, Bagaza, Zika and Kedougou viruses, each representing a separate virus subgroup according to the latest virus classification. In this study, we obtained a complete genome sequence of each of these three viruses and characterized their open reading frames (ORFs) according to gene sizes, cleavage sites, potential glycosylation sites, distribution of cysteine residues, and unique motifs. Sequences of the three viruses were then screened across the entire length of the ORF against existing sequences of other African flaviviruses and reference viruses selected for genetic association. Collectively, the data showed that Kedougou virus was close to, but still different from, dengue viruses, with Bagaza virus sharing genetic kinship with West Nile virus in several genomic regions. In non-coding regions, a particular pattern of organization of sequences conserved in 37asal; The terminal region is usually associated with the current virus grouping. © 2007 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Kuno, G.;Chang, G. J. J.

title: Muscovy duck reovirus ÏƒC protein is atypically encoded by the smallest genome segment
abstract: Although musk duck reovirus (DRV) shares characteristics with chicken isolated reovirus, commonly called avian reovirus (ARV), the two virus strains are antigenically different. Similar to the previously identified DRV ÏƒB-encoded gene (1201 bp in length), three other double-stranded RNA small genome segments of DRV were cloned and sequenced. They were 1325, 1191, and 1124 bp in length, respectively, and contained conserved terminal sequences common to ARVs. They coded for single expression products except the smallest (S4), which contained two overlapping open reading frames (ORF1 and ORF2). BLAST analyzes revealed that proteins encoded by the 1325 and 1191 bp genes share high levels of identity with ARV ÏƒA and ÏƒNS, respectively, and to a lesser extent with their other orthreovirus counterparts. No homology was found for the p10 protein encoded by S4 ORF1. The 29.4 kDa product encoded by S4 ORF2 appeared to be 25% identical to ÏƒC encoded by ARV S1 ORF3, a cell attachment oligomer that induces type-specific neutralizing antibodies. The addition of large gaps in the N-terminal portion of the DRV protein was necessary to improve DRV and ARV ÏƒC amino acid sequence alignments. However, a leucine zipper motif was preserved and secondary structure analyzes predicted a three-stranded α-helix helix feature at this amino portion. Thus, despite extensive sequence variation, DRV ÏƒC has been suggested to be structurally and possibly functionally related to ARV ÏƒC. This study provides evidence for the diversity of polycistronic S class genes of reoviruses isolated from birds and raises the question of the relative classification of DRV in the Orthoreovirus genus.
authors: Kuntz-Simon, G.;Le Gall-ReculÃ©, G.;de BoissÃ©son, C.;Jestin, V.

title: Comparative Metagenomic Profile of Symbiotic Bacterial Communities Associated with Ixodes persulcatus, Ixodes pavlovskyi, and Dermacentor reticulatus Ticks
abstract: Ticks Ixodes persulcatus, Ixodes pavlovskyi and Dermacentor reticulatus living in Western Siberia are responsible for the transmission of a number of etiological agents that cause tick-borne diseases in humans and animals. Data on the microbiomes of these organisms are needed, as these ticks are abundant in the slums of major cities, agricultural areas, and popular tourist areas and frequently attack humans and animals. Using the metagenomic 16S profile, we evaluate bacterial communities associated with I. persulcatus, I. pavlovskyi and D. reticulatus ticks collected from the Novosibirsk region of Russia. A total of 1214 ticks were used for this study. DNA from ticks was pooled according to tick species and sex. Sequencing of the V3-V5 domains of 16S rRNA genes was performed using the Illumina Miseq platform. The following bacterial genera were common in the populations studied: Acinetobacter (all three tick species), Rickettsia (I. persulcatus and D. reticulatus), and Francisella (D. reticulatus). B. burgdorferi sensu lato and B. miyamotoi sequences were detected in I. persulcatus and I. pavlovskyi, but not in D. reticulatus ticks. Pooled samples of all studied tick species contained bacteria from the Anaplasmataceae family, although their occurrence was low. DNA from A. phagocytophilum and Candidatus Neoehrlichia mikurensis was first observed in I. pavlovskyi ticks. Significant interspecies differences were observed in the number of bacterial taxa and in-species diversity due to tick sex. Bacterial communities associated with I. pavlovskyi ticks showed a higher biodiversity compared to I. persulcatus and D. reticulatus ticks. Bacterial community structure was also diverse among tick species studied, as demonstrated by permutational analysis of variance using the Bray-Curtis difference metric (p = 0.002). Inter-sex variation was confirmed by the PERMANOVA test in I. persulcatus (p = 0.042) and I. pavlovskyi (p = 0.042) ticks. Our study demonstrated that 16S metagenomic profiling can be used for rapid assessment of the occurrence of medically important bacteria in tick populations living in different natural biotopes and hence the epidemic hazard of studied foci.
authors: Kurilshikov, A.;Livanova, N. N.;Fomenko, N. V.;Tupikin, A. E.;Rar, V. A.;Kabilov, M. R.;Livanov, S. G.;Tikunova, N. V.

title: Genetic diversity and inter-genogroup recombination events of sapoviruses detected from pig feces in Japan
abstract: Sapoviruses (SaV) are enteric viruses that infect humans and animals. SaVs are highly diverse and are divided into multiple genogroups based on their structural protein (VP1) sequences. SaVs detected from pigs belong to eight genogroups (GIII, GV, GVI, GVII, GVIII, GIX, GX and GXI), but little is known about the SaV genogroup distribution in the Japanese pig population. In this study, 26 nearly complete genomes (> 6000 nucleotides: nt) and three partial sequences (2429 nt, 4364 nt and 4419 nt length, including the entire VP1 coding region) of SaV were obtained from one diarrheal and 15 non-diarrheic cells. - Porcine feces with diarrhea using a metagenomic approach in Japan. Phylogenetic analysis of the complete VP1 amino acid sequence (aa) revealed that 29 pig SaVs were classified into seven genogroups; GIII (11 strains), GV (1 strain), GVI (3 strains), GVII (6 strains), GVIII (1 strain), GX (3 strains) and GXI (4 strains).
