This manuscript presents the first nearly complete genome sequences of GX and GXI and demonstrates novel inter-genogroup recombination events.
authors: Kuroda, M.;Masuda, T.;Ito, M.;Naoi, Y.;Doan, Y. H.;Haga, K.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Kishimoto, M.;Sano, K.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Aoki, H.;Ichimaru, T.;Sunaga, F.;Mukono, I.;Yamasato, H.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Oka, T.;Nagai, M.

title: A rapid and robust method for whole genome sequencing of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) Type 1 and Type 2
abstract: PRRSV is a positive-sense RNA virus with a high degree of genetic variability among isolates. Monitoring PRRSV genetic diversity is essential for diagnostic susceptibility and vaccine design. However, only a few complete genome sequences of PRRSV isolates have been made public to date. In this study, rapid and robust methods for long-range RT-PCR amplification and next-generation sequencing (NGS) were developed and validated on nine Type 1 and nine Type 2 PRRSV viruses. The methods produced robust and reliable sequences on both primary material and viruses adapted to cell culture, and the protocols performed well on all three NGS platforms tested (Roche 454 FLX, Illumina HiSeq2000, and Ion Torrent PGMTM Sequencer). These methods will greatly facilitate the generation of more complete genome PRRSV sequences globally.
authors: Kvisgaard, L. K.;Hjulsager, C. K.;Fahnoe, U.;Breum, S. O.;Ait-Ali, T.;Larsen, L. E.

title: Molecular epidemiology of Newcastle disease in the Republic of Korea.
abstract: Twenty-three strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated in the Republic of Korea between 1988 and 1999 were studied by partial nucleotide sequence of the fusion (F) gene and phylogenetic analysis. Most of the Korean strains formed a distinctive cluster in genotype VI and were genetically distant (4.0-8.7%) from other subtypes (a, b, c, d and e) and tentatively termed VIf. Some Korean strains isolated in 1995 have been grouped as genotype VIIa and are more closely related to Taiwanese than Western European strains. The results show that genotype VIf strains have been conserved by enzootic infections over the past decade, while genotype VIIa appears to have been introduced more recently in the Republic of Korea. Â© 2003 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Kwon, H. J.;Cho, S. H.;Ahn, Y. J.;Seo, S. H.;Choi, K. S.;Kim, S. J.

title: Molecular epizootiology of recurrent low pathogenic avian influenza with H9N2 subtype virus in Korea.
abstract: The first outbreak of low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI), H9N2 virus subtype, in 1996 led to an eradication response, but LPAI returned to Korea in 1999. The relationship between initial and recurrent viruses is unclear. To determine the molecular epizootiology of recurrent LPAI, we performed phylogenetic analysis with partial nucleotide sequences of four gene segments (HA, NA, NP and PB2) from eight chicken-derived H9N2 viruses. Recurrent H9N2 viruses showed higher nucleotide similarity to 1996 Korean isolates in the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes than other Eurasian viruses and formed a separate cluster with early Korean isolates and some isolates from migratory and domesticated ducks in Japan and China. Phylogenetic analysis with internal genes showed that some Korean isolates form a cluster in China and Taiwan with other subtypes such as H5N1, H6N1 and H6N2. These results suggest that recurrent viruses are lineages of early Korean H9N2 isolates, but further work is needed to elucidate their phylogenetic relationship to viruses in China. © 2006 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Kwon, H. J.;Cho, S. H.;Kim, M. C.;Ahn, Y. J.;Kim, S. J.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza a(H5N8) viruses were reintroduced to South Korea by migratory waterfowl, 2014-2015
abstract: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) viruses were isolated from migratory waterfowl in South Korea during the 2014 autumn-winter 2015 period, recurrently after initial introduction in winter 2014. These reemerging viruses were phylogenetically different from isolates circulating in poultry farms in South Korea.
authors: Kwon, J. H.;Lee, D. H.;Swayne, D. E.;Noh, J. Y.;Yuk, S. S.;Erdene-Ochir, T. O.;Hong, W. T.;Jeong, J. H.;Jeong, S.;Gwon, G. B.;Song, C. S.

title: Prevalence of novel swine circovirus 3 in Korean pig populations
abstract: Porcine circovirus 3 (PCV3) is a novel porcine circovirus characterized by swine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome, reproductive failure, and multisystemic inflammation in pigs. However, the distribution and genetic characteristics of PCV3, which originated in Korea, remain unclear. In this study, we determined the nationwide prevalence and genetic characteristics of PCV3 using pen-based oral fluid samples. The overall prevalence of PCV3 in individual samples and farm level was 44.2% (159/360) and 72.6% (53/73) respectively. Korean PCV3 99.2Â Â±Â 0.2% (98.9–99.8%) and 98.6% Â± 0.5% (97.9–99.%) in the whole genome and ORF2, respectively 8) shared nucleotide identity. US strains. These data suggested that PCV3 is widely distributed throughout Korean pig populations.
authors: Kwon, T.;Yoo, S. J.;Park, C. K.;Lyoo, Y. S.

title: Different vaccination routes affect infectivity and pathogenesis of H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza virus infection in chickens and domestic ducks.
abstract: H5N1 type A influenza viruses, classified as Qinghai-like virus (section 2.2), are a unique strain of type A influenza viruses with the capacity to produce significant morbidity and mortality in gallinaceous and anseriform birds, including domestic and wild ducks. The aim of this study was to determine the pathogenesis and susceptibility of chickens and domestic ducks to the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus A/Whooper Swan/Mongolia/224/05 (H5N1) when administered via the respiratory or gastrointestinal tract. Chickens and ducks were more susceptible to H5N1 HPAI virus when exposed intranasally compared to ingestion routes (intragastric or orally fed infected chicken meat), as evidenced by low infectious and lethal viral doses. In the ingestion exposure pathogenesis study, pathological changes associated with virus detection included hemorrhage, necrosis, and inflammation. These changes were generally observed in most of the internal organs of chickens 2 to 4 days after inoculation (DPI) and are similar to the lesions and virus localization seen in birds in natural cases or in experimental studies performed intranasally. Dietary exposure to the virus caused systemic infection in ducks characterized by moderate lymphocytic encephalitis, necrotizing hepatitis and pancreatitis, and a corresponding virus was demonstrated in the lesions. In ingested chickens and ducks, lesions, virus or both were first demonstrated in the upper digestive tract at 1 DPI, suggesting that the digestive tract is the first site affected by the consumption of infected meat or gavage of the virus in liquid medium. . However, as demonstrated in the infectivity study in chickens, nutritional infection required higher exposure doses to establish infection in chickens compared to intranasal exposure. These data suggest that upper respiratory exposure to H5N1 HPAI virus in birds results in viral infection and transmission more than consumption of infected meat unless it contains high doses of virus, as in cannibalized infected carcasses. Â© American Society of Bird Pathologists 2010.
authors: Kwon, Y. K.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Virological Surveillance and Pre-Antigenic Characterization of Influenza Viruses in Pigs in Five European Countries from 2006 to 2008
abstract: This study presents the results of virological surveillance for swine flu viruses (SIVs) in Belgium, United Kingdom, Italy, France and Spain from 2006 to 2008. Our main aims were to clarify the emergence of the three SIV subtypes - H1N1, H3N2 and H1N2. - at regional levels, to identify novel reassortant viruses and antigenically compare SIVs with human H1N1 and H3N2 influenza viruses. Lung tissue and/or nasal swabs from acute respiratory disease outbreaks in pigs were investigated by virus isolation. Hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) subtypes were determined using standard methods. Of a total of 169 viruses, 81 were classified as 'bird-like' H1N1, 36 as human-like H3N2 and 47 as human-like H1N2. Only five new reasortant viruses were identified: two H1N1 viruses had a human-like HA and three H1N2 viruses had a bird-like HA. All three SIV subtypes were detected in Belgium, Italy and Spain, while only H1N1 and H1N2 viruses were found in England and Northwest France. Cross-hemagglutination inhibition (HI) tests against selected ancient and novel human influenza viruses with hyperimmune sera showed a strong antigenic association between human H1N1 and H3N2 viruses from the 1980s and H1N2 and H3N2 human-like SIVs, confirming their common origin. However, antisera to human viruses isolated in the last decade have not reacted with currently circulating H1 or H3 SIVs, suggesting that especially young people may be susceptible to some degree of SIV infections. © 2009 Blackwell Verlag GmbH.
authors: Kyriakis, C. S.;Brown, I. H.;Foni, E.;Kuntz-Simon, G.;Maldonado, J.;Madec, F.;Essen, S. C.;Chiapponi, C.;Van Reeth, K.

title: Deep Sequencing for Evaluation of Genetic Stability of Influenza A/California/07/2009 (H1N1) Vaccine Viruses
abstract: Virus growth during influenza vaccine production can lead to mutations that change the antigenic properties of the virus and therefore affect the protective potency of the vaccine. Different reassortants of the pandemic "swine" H1N1 influenza A vaccine (121XP, X-179A and X-181) viruses, as well as wild-type A/California/07/2009(H1N1) and A/PR/8/34 strains, embryonated eggs and DNA/ RNA is used for Illumina HiSeq and MiSeq sequencing. The RNA sequences of these viruses, published in NCBI, were used as reference for alignment of sequencing reads generated in this study. The consensus sequences of these viruses differed from the NCBI-accumulated sequences at a few nucleotides. The 121XP stock obtained by reverse genetics was more heterogeneous than the X-179A and X-181 stocks prepared by conventional reassortant technology. Passaged 121XP virus contained four non-synonymous mutations in the HA gene. One of these mutations (Lys226Glu) was located in the Ca antigenic region of HA (18% of the population). Two non-synonymous mutations were present in the HA of X-179A-derived viruses: Pro314Gln (18%) and Asn146Asp (78%). The last mutation in the Sa antigenic site was also detected at a low level (11%) in wild-type A/California/07/2009(H1N1) virus and was present as a complete substitution in derived X-181 viruses. From the X-179A virus. In the inherited X-181 viruses, two mutations occurred in HA: a silent mutation A1398G (31%) in one group and G756T (Glu252Asp, 47%) in another group. The last mutation was located in the conservative region of the antigenic region Ca. The RNA sequencing protocol was found to be robust, reproducible, and suitable for monitoring the genetic consistency of influenza vaccine seed stocks.
authors: Laassri, M.;Zagorodnyaya, T.;Plant, E. P.;Petrovskaya, S.;Bidzhieva, B.;Ye, Z.;Simonyan, V.;Chumakov, K.

title: Genomic and phylogenetic characterization of viruses in the Manzanilla and Oropouche species complexes of the Bunyaviridae family Orthobunyavirus genus.
abstract: comprehensive characterization of the genetic diversity of viruses found in vector and vertebrate host populations is essential for the early detection and response of emerging pathogenic viruses, but genetic characterization of many important viral groups remains incomplete. The Simbu serogroup of the Orthobunyavirus genus, the Bunyaviridae family is an example. The Simbu serogroup currently consists of a highly diverse group of related arboviruses that infect both humans and economically important animal species. Here, we report the complete genome sequences for 11 viruses in this group, focusing on the large and poorly characterized Manzanilla and Oropouche species complexes. Phylogenetic and binary divergence analyzes demonstrated the presence of high levels of genetic diversity within these two species complexes, at the same level as seen among the other five species complexes in the Simbu serogroup. Based on previously reported divergence thresholds between species, the data suggested that these two complexes should in fact be divided into at least five species. Together these five species formed a distinct phylogenetic branch apart from the rest of the Simbu serogroup. Pairwise sequence differences between viruses of this clade and viruses in other Simbu serogroup species complexes were similar to levels of difference between other orthobunyavirus serogroups. The genetic data also suggested relatively high levels of natural reclassification, with three potential reclassification events, including two well-supported events involving viruses known to infect humans.
authors: Ladner, J. T.;Savji, N.;Lofts, L.;da Rosa, A. T.;Wiley, M. R.;Gestole, M. C.;Rosen, G. E.;Guzman, H.;Vasconcelos, P. F. C.;Nunes, M. R. T.;Kochel, T. J.;Ian Lipkin, W.;Tesh, R. B.;Palacios, G.

title: Virus diversity detected by deep sequencing in pigs from a common background
abstract: While advances in nucleic acid sequencing have made possible the discovery of many infectious agents, challenges remain for scientists and veterinary diagnosticians attempting to design animal studies with minimal variables and interpret laboratory results. To evaluate pyrosequencing technology as a potential screening method for predicting viroma in pigs, faecal samples were collected from 4 pigs from a group of 175 co-raised since birth. A number of viruses have been detected, demonstrating the application of this technology to determine background "noise" in pigs. However, pyrosequencing also demonstrated the diversity of viruses in a group of animals and how this could confuse experimental design and hinder a definitive diagnosis. Â© 2012 Author(s).
authors: Lager, K. M.;Ng, T. F.;Bayles, D. O.;Alt, D. P.;Delwart, E. L.;Cheung, A. K.

title: Characterization of High Pathogenic Avian Influenza H5N1 Viruses Isolated from Domestic Poultry in China
abstract: The highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 virus has caused several outbreaks in domestic poultry. Despite great efforts to contain the spread of this virus, it continues to thrive and poses a significant threat to public health due to its high mortality rate. In this study, we sequenced the entire genomes of eight H5N1 avian influenza viruses isolated from domestic poultry in eastern China and compared them with typical influenza virus strains. Phylogenetic analyzes of all eight genomes, the two main branches circulating in China, 2.3.2.1. and 7.2. showed that it belonged to The viruses clustered in section 2.3.2.1 shared a high degree of homology with H5N1 isolates found in East Asia. The isolates clustered in section 7.2 were found to circulate in China with an east to west density gradient. Pathogenicity studies in mice showed that these isolates proliferated in the lungs and that clan viruses 2.3.2.1 exhibited a significantly higher degree of virulence compared to 7.2 viruses. Our results contribute to elucidating the biological characterization and pathogenicity of HPAI H5N1 viruses.
authors: Lai, C. C.;Wang, K. Y.;Chen, R.;Zhang, A. J.;Gu, H. J.;Yin, Y. B.;Wang, D. D.;Liu, L. L.;Xing, L.;Tong, Y. G.;Ma, Z. J.;Yang, P. H.;Wang, X. L.

title: Serological characterization of Buffalopox virus
abstract: Buffalopox virus has been classified as a member of the variola vaccinia subgroup of poxviruses on the basis of a range of biological characteristics and serological tests. A recent study demonstrated differences in electrophoretic behavior between buffalopox and vaccinia virus antigens. This study was conducted to extend previous findings regarding the close association of buffalopox, vaccinia, and cowpox viruses using gel diffusion, immunoelectrophoresis, and complement fixation tests. All these observations suggest that buffalopox virus is a separate entity closely related to vaccine and cowpox viruses and supports inclusion of buffalopox virus in subgroup I of poxviruses.
authors: Lal, S. M.;Singh, I. P.

title: Real-time PCR method for simultaneous detection, quantification and differentiation of Capripox viruses
abstract: The genus Capripoxvirus (CaPV) consists of three members, namely sheep pox virus (SPPV.), goat pox virus (GTPV), and tuberous skin disease virus (LSDV), which affects sheep, goats and cattle, respectively. CaPV infections produce similar symptoms in sheep and goats, and the three viruses are serologically indistinguishable. As there are conflicting views on the host specificity of CaPVs, particularly for goat pox and sheep pox viruses, the development of rapid genotyping tools will facilitate more accurate disease diagnosis and surveillance for better management of capripox outbreaks. This article describes the species-specific, real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) based on unique molecular markers found in the G-protein-coupled chemokine receptor (GPCR) gene sequences of CaPVs and simultaneously uses dual hybridization probes. detection, quantification and genotyping. The assay can distinguish between CaPV strains based on differences in melting point temperature (Tm) obtained after fluorescence melting curve analysis (FMCA). It is highly sensitive and offers low within-run and inter-run variation. This real-time PCR test will allow rapid genotyping and gene-based classification of viral strains and precise identification of isolates, making an important contribution to CaPV diagnosis and a better understanding of the epidemiology of CaPVs. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Lamien, C. E.;Lelenta, M.;Goger, W.;Silber, R.;Tuppurainen, E.;Matijevic, M.;Luckins, A. G.;Diallo, A.

title: Circulation of multiple subtypes of bovine viral diarrhea virus type 1 in cattle herds of southern Italy with no evidence for HoBi-like pestivirus
abstract: Bovine pestiviruses include bovine viral diarrhea 1 (BVDV-1) and 2 (BVDV-2) plus an emerging group called HoBi-like pestiviruses. This article presents the results of an epidemiological investigation for pestiviruses circulating in cattle in southern Italy. Molecular analyzes performed on a total of 924 bovine samples identified 74 BVDV strains, including 73 BVDV-1 and 1 BVDV-2 virus. Phylogenetic analysis performed on partial 5-UTR and Npro sequences revealed the presence of 6 different BVDV-1 subtypes and a single BVDV-2c strain. BVDV-1 exhibited high levels of genetic heterogeneity, which could have both prophylactic and diagnostic implications. In addition, the detection of BVDV-2c highlights the need for continued surveillance for the emergence of new pestivirus strains in cattle farms in southern Italy.
authors: Lanave, G.;Decaro, N.;Lucente, M. S.;Guercio, A.;Cavaliere, N.;Purpari, G.;Padalino, I.;Larocca, V.;Antoci, F.;Marino, P. A.;Buonavoglia, C.;Elia, G.

title: New Orthopoxvirus and Deadly Disease in Cat, Italy
abstract: We report the detection and whole genome characterization of a novel orthopox virus (OPXV) responsible for a fatal infection in a cat. Skin lesions caused by the virus are histologically characterized by leukocyte infiltration and eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions. Different PCR approaches failed to assign the virus to an identified OPXV strain. Large amounts of typical brick-shaped virions were observed by electron microscopy, morphologically related to OPXV. This OPXV strain (Italy_09/17) was isolated on cell cultures and embryonated eggs. Phylogenetic analysis of the 9 combined genes showed that this virus was distantly related to cowpox virus, more closely to ecromelia virus, and belonged to the same OPXV cluster that was recently isolated from captive macaques in Italy. Comprehensive epidemiological surveillance in cats and rodents will assess whether cats are accidental hosts and whether rodents are the main reservoir of the virus. The zoonotic potential of this new virus also deserves further investigation.
authors: Lanave, G.;Dowgier, G.;Decaro, N.;Albanese, F.;Brogi, E.;Parisi, A.;Losurdo, M.;Lavazza, A.;Martella, V.;Buonavoglia, C.;Elia, G.

title: Tavşanlarda yeni bocaparvovirüsler
abstract: Bocaparvovirus is a newly established genus within the family Parvoviridae and has been identified as a possible cause of enteric, respiratory, reproductive/neonatal and neurological diseases in humans and various animal species. In this study, metagenomic analysis was used to identify and characterize a novel bocaparvovirus in the feces of rabbits with enteric disease. To assess the prevalence of the new virus, rectal swabs and stool samples from rabbits with and without diarrhea were screened with a specific PCR assay. The complete genome sequence of the new parvovirus has been reconstructed. The virus was distantly related to other bocaparvoviruses; The three ORFs shared 53%, 53% and 50% nucleotide identity to homologous genes of porcine bocaparvoviruses, respectively. The virus was detected in 8/29 (28%) and 16/95 (17%) samples of rabbits with and without diarrhea, respectively. Sequencing of the capsid protein fragment targeted by diagnostic PCR identified two distinct bocaparvovirus populations/subtypes with 91.7-94.5% nucleotide identity to each other. The inclusion of these novel parvoviruses in diagnostic algorithms of rabbit diseases may help inform about their potential pathogenic roles and effects on rabbit production and virological profiles of laboratory rabbits.
authors: Lanave, G.;Martella, V.;Farkas, S. L.;Marton, S.;FehÃ©r, E.;Bodnar, L.;Lavazza, A.;Decaro, N.;Buonavoglia, C.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Bird flu - Commercial poultry elimination still not visible
abstract: Avian influenza viruses are highly contagious microorganisms that primarily affect birds. However, it has also been isolated from a number of mammals, including humans. Avian influenza virus can cause great economic losses in the poultry industry due to its high mortality. Although there are pathogenic variants that are low virulence and usually cause only mild clinical symptoms, the H5 and H7 subtypes can mutate into a low to highly virulent (pathogenic) virus and should be considered in eradication strategies. The primary source of infection for commercial poultry is direct and indirect contact with waterfowl and wild birds, which form a natural reservoir of the virus. Live poultry markets, exotic birds and ostriches also play an important role in the epidemiology of avian influenza. Secondary transmission of avian influenza virus (i.e. between poultry farms) is primarily attributed to fomites and humans. Airborne transmission is also important, and the virus can spread in humans via aerosol. Diagnostic tests detect viral proteins and genes. Virus-specific antibodies can be monitored by serological testing, where virus isolation and identification are complementary procedures. The number of bird flu outbreaks seems to be increasing - outbreaks have been reported in Italy, Hong Kong, Chile, Netherlands, South Korea, Vietnam, Japan, Thailand, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, China, Pakistan in the last 5 years, United States, Canada, Southern Africa and Malaysia. In addition, increasing numbers of human, in some cases fatal, avian flu cases have paralleled outbreaks in commercial poultry. There are great concerns about the possibility of a new virus subtype with pandemic potential emerging from these outbreaks. For human health, eradication of the virus from poultry is essential; however, the large number of small poultry holdings, the lack of control experience and resources, and the international scale of transmission and infection make rapid control and long-term prevention of relapses extremely difficult. In the western world, renewed interest in free-range housing poses a threat to future epidemics. Increasing ethical objections to the massive slaughter of birds require a different approach to bird flu eradication.
authors: Landman, W. J. M.;Schrier, C. C.

title: Three new canine papillomaviruses promote taxonomic cord formation
abstract: More than 100 human papillomaviruses (HPV) have been identified and their entire genomes sequenced. Most of these HPVs can be classified into three different genera: alpha-, beta-, and gamma-papilloma viruses (PVs). It should be noted that only one or few PVs have been identified for each animal species. However, four canine PVs (CPV) (COPV, CPV2, CPV3, and CPV4) have been identified and their entire genomic sequences published. Based on their sequence similarities, they belong to three different clades. In this study, circular viral DNA was amplified from three dogs showing signs of pigmented plaques, endophytic papilloma or squamous cell carcinoma in situ. Analysis of DNA sequences revealed that these are three novel viruses (CPV5, CPV6 and CPV7) whose genomes contain all conserved sequence elements of known PVs. The genomes of these seven CPVs were compared to classify them appropriately. Interestingly, binary sequence alignments of putative amino acid sequences as well as phylogenetic analyzes revealed that CPV5 grouped well with CPV3 and CPV4, while CPV7 grouped with CPV2, but neither group matched with other classified PVs. However, CPV6 is grouped with COPV, a lambda-PV. Based on this evidence, the division of CPVs into three distinct categories can therefore be supported. Thus, similar to HPVs, it may be that known and currently unknown CPVs are related and form only a few branches or genera. © 2009 SGM.
authors: Lange, C. E.;Tobler, K.;Ackermann, M.;Panakova, L.;Thoday, K. L.;Favrot, C.

title: Tick-borne viruses: A review in terms of therapeutic approaches
abstract: Many important human diseases worldwide are caused by tick-borne viruses. These diseases have become important public health problems in recent years. Tick-borne viruses that cause diseases in humans belong to three families: Bunyaviridae, Flaviviridae and Reoviridae. In this review, we focus on therapeutic approaches to several of the more important tick-borne viruses from these 3 families. These viruses are the newly discovered tick-borne phleboviruses known as Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus (CCHF) and thrombocytopenia syndrome virus (SFTSV), Heartland virus and Bhanja virus from the Bunyaviridae family, tick-borne encephalitis virus (TBEV), Powassan virus. (POWV), Louping-ill virus (LIV), Omsk hemorrhagic fever virus (OHFV), Kyasanur Forest disease virus (KFDV), and Alkhurma hemorrhagic fever virus (AHFV) from the Flaviviridae family. To date, no effective antiviral medication is available against most of these tick-borne viruses. Although there is widespread use of antiviral drugs such as ribavirin for the treatment of CCHF in some countries, there are concerns that ribavirin may not be as effective against CCHF as once thought. Here we also discuss the availability of vaccines for the control of these viral infections. The lack of treatment and prevention approaches for these viruses is highlighted, and we hope this review can raise public health awareness of the threat posed by this group of viruses. © 2014 Elsevier GmbH.
authors: Lani, R.;Moghaddam, E.;Haghani, A.;Chang, L. Y.;AbuBakar, S.;Zandi, K.

title: Lifestyle and Genome Structure of Marine Pseudoalteromonas Siphovirus B8b Isolated from the Northwest Mediterranean
abstract: Marine viruses (phages) alter bacterial diversity and evolution through effects on marine biogeochemical cycles, and yet the few well-developed model systems limit opportunities for hypothesis testing. Here, Pseudoalteromonas sp. We isolate phage B8b from the Mediterranean using Use the QC-44 as a host and characterize it using numerous techniques. Morphologically, the phage B8b was classified as a member of the Siphoviridae family. Single-stage growth analyzes showed that this cyfovirus had a latent period of 70 minutes and released 172 new viral particles per cell. Host spacing analysis against 89 bacterial host strains showed that phage B8b was isolated from Alteromonas sp. (37 strains from 6 genera were tested), which helps to connect the phylogenetic distance possible in a phage-mediated horizontal gene transfer event. Pseudoalteromonas phage B8b genome size was 42.7 kb, the first with clear structural and replication modules was identified using virion structural proteomics, exploiting the identification of 16 structural genes, of which only 4 have any similarity to known structural proteins. In nature, this phage was common in coastal marine environments in both photic and aphotic layers (found in 26.5% of viral metagenomes present), but not abundant in any sample (average per sample abundance was 0.65% of reads). Together these data improve our understanding of cyphoviruses in nature and provide the basis for a new 'rare virosphere' phage-host model system.
authors: Lara, E.;Holmfeldt, K.;Solonenko, N.;Sa, E. L.;Ignacio-Espinoza, J. C.;Cornejo-Castillo, F. M.;Verberkmoes, N. C.;Vaque, D.;Sullivan, M. B.;Acinas, S. G.

title: Blood transcriptomes reveal new parasite zoonoses circulating in Madagascar's lemurs
abstract: Zoonotic diseases are a looming threat to global populations, and about 75% of emerging infectious diseases can spread among wildlife, pets and humans. The 'One World, One Health' perspective provides us with an ideal framework for understanding and potentially reducing the spread of zoonoses, and the island of Madagascar serves as a natural laboratory for conducting these studies. Rapid habitat degradation and climate change on the island contribute to more frequent contact between humans, livestock and wildlife, increasing the potential for pathogen spread events. Madagascar's long geographic isolation, combined with the recent and repeated introduction of agriculture and invasive species, is likely to remain uncharacterized by a number of circulating pathogens in lemur populations. Therefore, the application of new approaches for de novo pathogen discovery is imperative. To this end, we used non-targeted deep sequencing of blood transcriptomes from two critically endangered wild lemur species (Indri indri and Propithecus diadema) to characterize blood-borne pathogens. Our results demonstrate several unidentified vector-borne parasites circulating in lemurs, some of which can cause disease in wildlife, livestock and humans. We anticipate that advanced methods for de novo identification of unknown pathogens will have broad utility for characterizing other complex disease transmission systems.
authors: Larsen, P. A.;Hayes, C. E.;Williams, C. V.;Junge, R. E.;Razafindramanana, J.;Mass, V.;Rakotondrainibe, H.;Yoder, A. D.

title: Characterization of a novel potyvirus that naturally infects chickpea
abstract: During the growing season 1999-2001, symptoms of mosaic, stunting, yellowing, wilting, internode shortening and phloem discoloration were observed in chickpea (Cicer arietinum) grown in the Chuquisaca Department of southern Bolivia. In some fields, about 10% of the plants exhibited virus-like symptoms and seed yield was greatly reduced. Lentils (Lens culinaris) were also observed to be infected, but not peas (Pisum sativum) or broad beans (Vicia faba) growing in nearby fields. Infected chickpea tissue responded positively to the potyvirus group-specific monoclonal antibody (MAb), but there were no serological reactions with antisera against potyviruses. Bean common mosaic virus or Bean common mosaic necrosis virus. Western blots of total protein extracts probed with the Potyvirus MAb revealed a single band of ca. 32 kDa. Comparative sequence analysis of cDNA clones produced from the putative coat protein gene consisted of 282 amino acids (31.9 kDa) and showed intermediate identities of 67%, 66,163, 63 and 61% with coat proteins of potyviruses Pepper severe mosaic virus, Pepper yellow mosaic potato virus Y, Plum pox virus and Pepper mottle virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the coat protein amino acid sequence revealed that this virus is a unique member of the Potyviridae family and is phylogenetically closely related to a group of potyviruses infecting Solanaceae rather than potyviruses infecting other legumes. The proposed name for the new causative agent is Chickpea yellow mosaic virus.
authors: Larsen, R. C.;Kaiser, W. J.;Wyatt, S. D.;Buxton-Druffel, K. L.;Berger, P. H.

title: Recent advances in research involving BHV-4
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus type 4 is common in cattle populations worldwide. Although the virus is not a direct pathogen, it is an important factor for research purposes and its role in secondary infections. The article summarizes the results of foreign and domestic laboratories over the past five years. The most important results of foreign research groups were the identification of a protein involved in virus-cell interaction, a detailed study of viral DNA, which provided some data on the replication cycle and new evidence for the classification of this virus as Gammaherpesvirinae. subfamily. Since the first BHV-4 strain was isolated in Hungary (BARTHA, 1963), this virus has always been one of the main targets of research activities. In animal experiments, they studied the spread, distribution, viremia, delay of the virus by various methods such as polymerase chain reaction, immunohistochemistry and virus isolation. The virus has some characteristics of Beta and Gammaherpes viruses. During infection, the virus mostly binds to the respiratory and immune system, remains in leukocytes for a very long time, periodically appears in the blood serum and creates neural and permanent infection. immune tissues. The virus may play a role in inhibiting some immune functions by reducing the in vitro mitotic activity of leukocytes.
authors: Laszlo, E.

title: Bats host a variety of parvoviruses as a possible origin of mammalian dependent parvoviruses and a source of bat-pig interspecies transmission.
authors: Lau, S. K. P.;Ahmed, S. S.;Tsoi, H. W.

title: Discovery and Sequence Analysis of Four Deltacoronaviruses from Birds in the Middle East Reveals Interspecies Jumping by Recombination as a Potential Mechanism for Bird-to-Bird and Bird-to-Mammalian Transmission
abstract: The emergence of the Middle East respiratory syndrome has once again demonstrated that animal coronaviruses (CoVs) are a potential source for human outbreaks. To investigate the diversity of deltacoronavirus in animals in the Middle East, we tested fecal samples from 1,356 mammals and birds in Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Four new deltacoronaviruses from eight birds from four species were detected by reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR): FalCoV UAE-HKU27 from a falcon, HouCoV UAE-HKU28 from a wild boar, PiCoV UAE-HKU29 from a pigeon, and QuaCoV UAE -HKU30 from five quails . Complete genome sequencing showed that FalCoV UAE-HKU27, HouCoV UAE-HKU28 and PiCoV UAE-HKU29 belong to the same CoV species, suggesting recent interspecies crossing, possibly along the food chain, between hawks and their prey, rose hips and pigeons. Western blot detected specific anti-FalCoV UAE-HKU27 antibodies in 33 (75%) of 44 hawk serum samples, supporting true infection in hawks after virus acquisition. QuaCoV UAE-HKU30 belongs to the same CoV species as the swine coronavirus HKU15 (PorCoV HKU15) and the sparrow coronavirus HKU17 (SpCoV HKU17), previously discovered in pigs and tree sparrows, and supports bird-to-swine transmission. Recombination involving spike protein is common among deltacoronaviruses, which can facilitate interspecies transmission. FalCoV UAE-HKU27, HouCoV UAE-HKU28, and PiCoV UAE-HKU29 originated from recombination between white eye coronavirus HKU16 (WECoV HKU16) and magpie robin coronavirus HKU18 (MRCoV HKU18), QuaCoV UAE-HKU30, PorCoV HKU15/SpCoV HKU17. and munia coronavirus HKU13 (MunCoV HKU13) and PorCoV HKU15 from the recombination between SpCoV HKU17 and bulbul coronavirus HKU11 (BuCoV HKU11). Birds in the Middle East are host to a variety of deltacoronaviruses with potential for interspecies transmission.IMPORTANCE In an attempt to explore the diversity of deltacoronavirus among mammals and birds in Dubai, four novel deltacoronaviruses were detected in stool samples from eight of them. four different species of birds: FalCoV UAE-HKU27 from a falcon, HouCoV UAE-HKU28 from a wild boar, PiCoV UAE-HKU29 from a pigeon, and QuaCoV UAE-HKU30 from five quails. Genome analysis has revealed evidence of recent interspecies crossing between hawks and their prey, rosehips and pigeons, possibly along the food chain, as well as transmission from birds to pigs. Recombination, known to occur frequently in some coronaviruses, was also common among these deltacoronaviruses and occurred predominantly in the spike region. Such recombination involving receptor binding protein may contribute to the emergence of new viruses that can infect new hosts. Birds in the Middle East are home to a variety of deltacoronaviruses with potential for interspecies transmission.
authors: Lau, S. K. P.;Wong, E. Y. M.;Tsang, C. C.;Ahmed, S. S.;Au-Yeung, R. K. H.;Yuen, K. Y.;Wernery, U.;Woo, P. C. Y.

title: Chickens harbor a variety of picornaviruses resulting from potential interspecies transmission by recombination
abstract: While chickens are an important reservoir for emerging pathogens such as avian influenza viruses, little is known about the diversity of picornaviruses in poultry. We discovered a previously unknown variety of picornaviruses in chickens in Hong Kong. Picornaviruses were detected by reverse transcription-PCR in 87 cloacal and 7 tracheal samples from 93 of 900 chickens, and their partial 3Dpol gene sequences formed five different clades (I to V) among known picornaviruses. Analysis of eight genomes from different clades, including six new picornavirus strains (ChPV1, ChPV2 and ChPV3 from clade II, ChPV4 and ChPV5 from clade III, ChGV1 from clade IV) and one extant strain (Avian encephalomyelitis virus). revealed seven different picornaviruses. from clade V). The six novel chicken picornavirus genomes display distinct phylogenetic positions and genome features from related picornaviruses, supporting their classification as separate species. Furthermore, ChPV1 could potentially belong to a new genus with low sequence homologies to related picornaviruses, particularly in the P1 and P2 regions, including the predicted L and 2A proteins. However, these new picornaviruses were most closely related to picornaviruses of other avian species (Paserivirus A-associated ChPV1, ChPV2 and ChPV3, Avisivirus A and Duck hepatitis A virus, ChPV4 and ChPV5, Melegrivirus A, ChGV1 to Gallivirus A). Also, ChPV5 represented a potential recombinant picornavirus with P2 and P3 regions, possibly originating from Melegrivirus A. Chickens are an important reservoir for a variety of picornaviruses that can cross the barriers of avian species through mutation or recombination. Â© 2014 Authors.
authors: Lau, S. K. P.;Woo, P. C. Y.;Yip, C. C. Y.;Li, K. S. M.;Fan, R. Y. Y.;Bai, R.;Huang, Y.;Chan, K. H.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of a new porcine astrovirus: relationship to other astroviruses
abstract: Emerging viruses pose a constant threat to human health and livestock, as the epidemics of influenza, henipavirus and SARS have proven many times over. Knowledge of the diversity of viromes found in reservoir species could lead to a better understanding of the origin of emerging pathogens. In this study, we expand knowledge of astrovirus diversity in pigs by reporting the genetic characterization of an unknown astrovirus lineage. Phylogenetic analyzes provided evidence that this porcine astrovirus lineage is unique and does not share a recent common ancestor with any known mamastrovirus. The data reported in this study brings the number of porcine astrovirus strains to a total of five, all likely representing different species with different origins. Â© 2011 Her Majesty The Queen is at Canada's Right as represented by the Minister for the Environment.
authors: Laurin, M. A.;Dastor, M.;L'Homme, Y.

title: Molecular variation in the porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) nucleoprotein gene (ORF7)
abstract: The nucleoprotein gene (ORF7) of 15 European isolates of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) was sequenced and compared with the corresponding sequences of other PRRSV isolates (2 European and 13 American) and one isolate other arteriviruses (lactate dehydrogenase elevation). virus (LDV), simian hemorrhagic fever virus (SHFV), and equine arthritis virus (EAV). Phylogenetic relationships were established using neighbor aggregation and thrift methods. Four lineages (PRRSV, LDV, SHFV and EAV) were distinguished. Two more PRRSV genotypes, European and American, can be identified. The European genotype of PRRSV is highly conserved. Analysis of nucleotide and amino acid substitutions in PRRSV ORF7 revealed four stable regions that are conserved, likely due to requirements for nucleocapsid function and/or structure. No fixed accumulation of mutations in ORF7 could be pinpointed when studying synonymous or nonsynonymous mutations. In vivo passage of European PRRSV had little effect on the ORF7 sequence: only a small number of synonymous substitutions could be detected in ORF7, confirming its low variability. Copyright (C) 1998 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Le Gall, A.;Legeay, O.;Bourhy, H.;Arnauld, C.;Albina, E.;Jestin, A.

title: Biochemical and genomic characterization of musk duck parvovirus
abstract: duck parvovirus (DPV) isolated from musk ducks during the epizootic in France in 1989 was purified and characterized from inoculated allanto-amniotic fluids by CsCl density gradient centrifugation. Banding with a diameter of 22 to 23 nm was observed at densities of 1.39 to 1.42 and 1.38 of filled and empty non-enveloped icosahedral viral particles, respectively. Viral proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and the estimated molecular weights of the 3 major proteins were 91, 78 and 58 kDa. The nucleic acid was shown to be a single-stranded DNA of about 5300 bases with terminal palindromic hairpins. These results indicate that the virus was detected by Jestin et al. confirms its previous classification in the Parvoviridae family created by [14] on a morphological and serological basis. DPV DNA was reannealed, showing that complementary DNA strands were encapsulated. A partial restriction endonuclease map was also generated. This study constitutes the first biochemical and genomic description of a musk duck parvovirus.
authors: Le Gall-Recule, G.;Jestin, V.

title: Molecular characterization of serotype A foot and mouth disease viruses circulating in Vietnam in 2009.
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is the main cause of endemic outbreaks in Vietnam in recent years. In this study, six serotype A foot-and-mouth disease viruses (FMDV) collected from endemic outbreaks in four different provinces of Vietnam in January and February 2009 were genetically characterized for their whole genome sequences. Genetic analysis based on the complete viral genome sequence showed that they are closely related and share 99.0-99.8% amino acid (aa) identity. Genetic and inferred aa analysis of the capsid-encoding gene VP1 showed that all six Vietnamese strains were classified in genotype IX out of a total of 10 major genotypes worldwide and shared 98.1-100% aa identity with each other. They were closely related to type A strains most recently isolated in Laos (A/LAO/36/2003, A/LAO/1/2006, A/LAO/6/2006, A/LAO/7/2006 and A/LAO). /8/2006), Thailand (A/TAI/2/1997 and A/TAI/118/1987) and Malaysia (A/MAY/2/2002) share 88.3-95.5% nucleotide (nt) identities. In contrast, Vietnamese type A strains showed low nt identities of 77.3% to 80%, with two old type A FMDVs isolated in Thailand in 1960 (a15thailand iso43) and in 1975 in the Philippines (aphilippines iso50). It showed IDs ranging from 9. A multiple alignment based on the deduced amino acid sequences of the gene encoding Type A FMDV capsid VP1 revealed three amino acid substitutions between strains of Vietnam and strains from other Southeast Asian countries (Laos, Thailand, Malaysia, and the Philippines). Alanine was replaced with valine at residue 24, asparagine with arginine at residue 85, and threonine with serine at residue 196. Moreover, all recently isolated FMDV strains of type A in Vietnam, Laos, Thailand, and Malaysia have an amino acid deletion at residue 140. Proportion of capsid VP1 protein compared with two former type A FMDV strains from Thailand and the Philippines and most other type A representatives worldwide. This article is the first to report comprehensive genetic characterization of FMDV type A circulating in Vietnam. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Le, V. P.;Nguyen, T.;Lee, K. N.;Ko, Y. J.;Lee, H. S.;Nguyen, V. C.;Mai, T. D.;Do, T. H.;Kim, S. M.;Cho, I. S.;Park, J. H.

title: Heterogeneity and genetic variation of serotypes O and Asia 1 isolated in Vietnam.
abstract: Six field foot and mouth disease viruses (FMDVs), including four serotype O and two serotype Asia 1 strains, were collected from endemic outbreaks in 2005, 2006 and 2007 from four different provinces in Vietnam. Viruses were isolated and genetically characterized for their complete genomic sequences. Genetic analysis based on whole genomic coding sequences revealed that the four serotype O FMDVs are related, sharing 95.2% nucleotide (nt) identity and 97.5-97.6% amino acid (aa) identity. Genetic analysis and a phylogenetic tree based on the VP1 gene of FMDV showed that the four extant Vietnamese serotype O strains had a high level of identity with other serotype O representatives of the Mya-98 lineage of the Southeast Asian (SEA) topotype. All four viruses clustered in the Mya-98 lineage of the SEA topotype, sharing 92.3-95.6% nt and 93.4-96.7% aa identity. This finding of the Mya-98 lineage differed from previous reports that Vietnamese serotype O strains belonged to the Cam-94 strain of SEA topotype and two other topotypes, Middle East-South Asian (ME-SA) and Cathay. For the two serotypes Asia 1 FMDV, genetic analysis based on the complete genomic coding sequences as well as the VP1 gene revealed that they belonged to two genogroups, IV and V. Genogroup V, isolated in 2007, was very closely related to the pandemic Asia 1 strain that caused FMD outbreaks in 2005 in China (Asia1/WHN/CHA/06, FJ906802) and Mongolia (Asia1/MOG/05, EF614458). and shared 99.0. -99.3% nt and 99.5-100% aa identity. In contrast, the second strain As1/VN/LC04/2005 of genogroup IV isolated in 2005, all referenced Vietnam serotype Asia 1 strains found in GenBank databases, sharing 86.4-100% nt and 90.9-100% aa. was closely associated with identity with each. This study is the first description of the full-length genomic sequence of Vietnamese FMDV serotypes O and Asia 1 and may provide evidence of the simultaneous circulation of different FMDV serotypes and subtypes in Vietnam in recent years. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Le, V. P.;Nguyen, T.;Park, J. H.;Kim, S. M.;Ko, Y. J.;Lee, H. S.;Nguyen, V. C.;Mai, T. D.;Do, T. H.;Cho, I. S.;Lee, K. N.

title: The human virome: new tools and concepts
authors: Lecuit, M.;Eloit, M.

title: Sequence analysis of the hemagglutinin gene of H9N2 Korean avian influenza viruses and evaluation of the pathogenic potential of isolate MS96.
abstract: Sequence analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene of five Korean isolates of H9N2 avian influenza virus (AIV) showed that these viruses were closely related and likely originated from the same source. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA1 subunit of H9 subtype isolates revealed that Korean AIV isolates differ from isolates in the Hong Kong poultry markets in 1997. None of the Korean AIVs had multiple basic amino acids at the HA cleavage site that conferred high pathogenicity on some of them. H5 and H7 AIVs. Phylogenetic analysis of the nucleoprotein and matrix gene showed that Korean isolates clustered with AIVs of Eurasian origin. The pathogenic potential of one of the isolates (MS96) was evaluated after several passages in 14-day-old embryonated chicken eggs (ECE). The fourteen-day ECE derivatives of MS96 showed increased HA titer in eggs and embryo mortality; this was evident after the third pass in the 14-day ECE. Sequence analysis of the cleavage site of MS96 after passages three and ten in the 14-day ECE showed no changes in the amino acid sequence. Pathogenicity of MS96 after the tenth passage in 14-day-old eggs (MS96p10(ECE14)) was tested with 4-week-old specific pathogen-free chickens. The 14-day derivative MS96p10(ECE14) showed greater tissue tropism than the parent virus and caused more severe clinical manifestations. In addition, after intranasal vaccination of 86-week broiler breeders and 30-week layers, the MS96p10(ECE14) derivative caused more severe depression symptoms than the parent virus and a temporary decrease in egg production.
authors: Lee, C. W.;Song, C. S.;Lee, Y. J.;Mo, I. P.;Garcia, M.;Suarez, D. L.;Kim, S. J.

title: High Pathogenic Avian Influenza Viruses and Production of New Reassortants, United States, 2014-2015
abstract: Asian highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) viruses spread to North America during the autumn bird migration in 2014. Complete genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of 32 H5 viruses identified novel H5N1, H5N2 and H5N8 viruses that emerged in late 2014 by reclassification with North American low pathogenicity avian influenza viruses.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Bahl, J.;Torchetti, M. K.;Killian, M. L.;Ip, H. S.;DeLiberto, T. J.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Characterization of low pathogenicity H5 and H7 Korean avian influenza viruses in chickens
abstract: To date, all isolated highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) viruses that cause systemic infection with high mortality in poultry species are known to belong to either the H5 or H7 subtypes. HPAI viruses may arise due to the addition of multiple basic amino acids to the cleavage site of the hemagglutinin protein after administration of low pathogenic H5 and H7 viruses to poultry. In this study, we investigated the phylogenetic characteristics of H5 (n = 4) and H7 (n = 3) low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) viruses isolated from wild birds in Korea using the nucleotide sequences of all 8 gene segments. viral genome. We also evaluated the infectivity, contagiousness and pathogenic potential of these viruses in chickens. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all viruses used in the study clustered in the Eurasian lineage and were similar to viruses isolated in Asian countries sharing the East Asian-Australian migratory bird flight path. Our H5N2 isolates cannot be reproduced and transmitted in chickens, but H7N8 isolates can be reproduced efficiently and transmitted to exposed chickens. Furthermore, as our H7N8 isolates cause watery diarrhea in chickens, these viruses not only serve as progenitors of new strains of HPAI but also potentially cause clinical disease in poultry. Although there have been no reports of LPAI mutations in HPAI in these regions, wild bird surveillance studies should focus on monitoring the introduction and transmission of HPAI H5N1 and LPAI H5 and H7 viruses. Â© 2012 Poultry Science Association A.Ş.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Kwon, J. H.;Park, J. K.;Lee, Y. N.;Yuk, S. S.;Lee, J. B.;Park, S. Y.;Choi, I. S.;Song, C. S.

title: Roman Reassortant Clade 2.3.4.4 Avian Influenza A(H5N8) Virus in Wild Waterfowl, Russia, 2016
abstract: The emergence of new avian influenza viruses in migratory birds is of concern because of the potential for the virus to spread during autumn migration. We report the identification of new highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses of the H5N8 subtype, section 2.3.4.4, in waterfowl and shorebirds of Siberia and their reclassification with other avian influenza viruses.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Sharshov, K.;Swayne, D. E.;Kurskaya, O.;Sobolev, I.;Kabilov, M.;Alekseev, A.;Irza, V.;Shestopalov, A.

title: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H7N9) Virus, Tennessee, USA, March 2017
abstract: In March 2017, highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H7N9) was detected on 2 poultry farms in Tennessee, USA. Surveillance data and genetic analyzes demonstrated multiple introductions of low pathogenic avian influenza virus prior to mutation to high pathogenicity and inter-farm transmission. Poultry surveillance should continue as low pathogenic viruses are circulating and spreading to commercial poultry.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Torchetti, M. K.;Killian, M. L.;Berhane, Y.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Reoccurrence of Avian Influenza A(H5N2) Virus Clade 2.3.4.4 in Wild Birds, Alaska, USA, 2016
abstract: We report a re-emergence of the highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N2) virus guideline 2.3.4.4 in a wild wild duck in August 2016 in Alaska, USA. Identification of this virus in a migratory species, low-frequency persistence in North America, and potential re-distribution of the virus during 2016 fall migration.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Torchetti, M. K.;Killian, M. L.;DeLiberto, T. J.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Deep sequencing of H7N8 avian influenza viruses from the surveillance zone supports that H7N8 highly pathogenic avian influenza was confined to a single outbreak farm in Indiana in 2016
abstract: In mid-January 2016, an outbreak of H7N8 highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) in commercial turkeys occurred in Indiana. Surveillance within the 10 km control zone detected H7N8 low pathogenic avian influenza virus (LPAIV) in nine surrounding turkey flocks, but no other facilities affected by HPAIV. We sequenced four of the H7N8 HPAIVs isolated from a single farm and nine LPAIVs identified during control zone surveillance. The assessment included phylogenetic network analysis showing a close association between HPAIV and LPAIV and the spread of the progenitor H7N8 LPAIV among affected turkey farms in Indiana, followed by spontaneous mutation to HPAIV in a single precursor via acquisition of three essential amino acids in hemagglutinin cleavage. domain. Deep sequencing of available viruses failed to identify subpopulations in HPAIV or LPAIV, suggesting that the HPAIV mutation likely occurred in a single farm and that HPAIV did not spread to epidemiologically linked LPAIV-affected farms.
authors: Lee, D. H.;Torchetti, M. K.;Killian, M. L.;Swayne, D. E.

title: Molecular epidemiological investigation of Newcastle disease virus from domestic ducks in Korea
abstract: To expand the epidemiological understanding of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) in domestic ducks in Korea, 14 NDV isolates from apparently healthy domestic ducks were biologically and genetically characterized. Thirteen and 1 isolates of NDV were categorized as lentogenic and velogenic viruses, respectively, based on in vivo pathogenicity tests. Twelve lentogenic viruses showed HA activity to equine RBCs, while 1 lentogenic virus and velogenic virus were negative. Lentogenic viruses (n=13) had sequence motifs 112ERQERL117 (n=1) or 112GRQGRL117 (n=12) at the F0 cleavage site, while velogenic virus (n=1) had sequence motifs 112RRQKRF117 in the same region. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that at least three different genotypes can be found in Korean domestic ducks; one class I genotype (genotype 2) and two class II (genotypes I and VII) genotypes. Class I virus was most closely related to genotype 2 strains isolated in birds from the USA, Germany and Denmark. Twelve lentogenic class II viruses were grouped together in genotype I and subsequently divided into at least three clusters: Aomori-like, Ulster2C-like, and V4-like. Velogenic class II virus has been assigned to genotype VII, which represents viruses responsible for recent outbreaks in many Asian countries, including Korea. The epidemiological significance of native duck isolates of NDV in Korea is discussed. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Lee, E. K.;Jeon, W. J.;Kwon, J. H.;Yang, C. B.;Choi, K. S.

title: Genetic diversity of avian infectious bronchitis virus isolates in Korea between 2003 and 2006
abstract: Thirty-three field isolates of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were recovered from commercial chicken flocks in Korea between 2003 and 2006 and were phylogenetically characterized by nucleotide sequence analysis of the IBV S1 gene hypervariable region. Our phylogenetic analysis revealed that the final field isolates of IBV formed at least three distinct phylogenetic types, including KI, K-II, and K-III. KI type IBV consisted of 13 native isolates of IBV, which evolved from strain Kr-EJ/95 and subsequently split into K-Ia-type and K-Ib-type strains. K-II type IBV isolates (n = 19) were closely related to nephropathogenic IBV variants from China and Japan. The K-III type isolate (Kr/D064/05), first identified by this study, was closely associated with enteric IBV variants from Chinese strains causing proventriculitis. Sequence comparisons showed >27.5% amino acid differences between IBV types. The molecular epidemiological features of IBV field isolates are briefly discussed.
authors: Lee, E. K.;Jeon, W. J.;Lee, Y. J.;Jeong, O. M.;Choi, J. G.;Kwon, J. H.;Choi, K. S.

title: Genome sequence of the pitchfork-like disease virus, a yatapoxvirus
abstract: The genome sequence of Yaba-like disease virus (YLDV), an unclassified member of the Yabaxvirus genus, has been determined. Excluding terminal hairpin rings, the YLDV genome is 144,575 bp long and contains 1883 bp of inverted terminal repeats (ITRs). Within 20 nucleotides of the terminal is a sequence conserved in other poxviruses that is required for resolution of concatemeric replicative DNA intermediates. The nucleotide composition of the genome is 73% A+T, but ITRs are only 63% A+T. The genome contains 151 tightly packed open reading frames (ORFs) that are 180 nucleotides in length or conserved in other smallpox viruses. ORFs within 23 kb of each end are transcribed towards the terminals, while ORFs in the central region of the genome are encoded in both DNA strands. In the central region, ORFs have a conserved position, orientation and sequence compared to vaccinia virus ORFs and encode many enzymes, transcription factors or structural proteins. In contrast, ORFs near the termini are more distinct and have no counterpart in other smallpox viruses in seven cases. The YLDV genome encodes several predicted immunomodulators; Examples include two proteins with affinity to CC chemokine receptors and predicted secreted proteins with affinity to MHC class I antigen, OX-2, interleukin-10/mda-7, poxvirus growth factor, serpins, and a type I interferon-binding protein. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that YLDV is very closely related to wild monkey tumor virus, but apart from the yatapoxvirus genus, YLDV is more closely related to swine pox virus and leporipoxviruses than other cordopoxviruses. Â© 2001 Academic Press.
authors: Lee, H. J.;Essani, K.;Smith, G. L.

title: Production of reassortant influenza viruses in the non-industrial poultry system
abstract: We compared the genetic and biological characteristics of 35 influenza viruses with different epidemiological histories, including the H3N2 canine influenza virus (CIV) in Korea. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that chicken-adapted H9N2 viruses (A/chicken/Korea/96006/96 [CK/Kor/96006-like]) acquired aquatic avian gene segments by reclassification, and that these reclassified H9N2 viruses were detected more frequently in small poultry species. put it. more than industrial poultry. Conversely, gene segments from viruses such as CK/Kor/96006 were also detected in most viruses from domestic ducks. Interestingly, domestic ducks rather than wild waterfowl harbored close relatives of all eight gene segments of the H3N2 CIV that prefer to bind to bird receptors. Therefore, it is assumed that bi-directional viral transmission events occur between terrestrial and aquatic poultry, particularly within the non-industrial poultry system. These events contributed to the production of a new reassortant, H3N2 CIV. Gene movements must be clarified and managed in non-industrial poultry systems to avoid the production of other interspecies reassortants. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Lee, H. J.;Lee, D. H.;Lee, Y. N.;Kwon, J. S.;Lee, Y. J.;Lee, J. B.;Park, S. Y.;Choi, I. S.;Song, C. S.

title: Survival of prototype strains of somatic coliphage families in environmental waters and when exposed to UV low-pressure monochromatic radiation or heat
abstract: The potential use of specific somatic coliphage taxonomic groups as viral markers based on their aquatic persistence and prevalence was investigated. Representative type strains of the 4 major somatic coliphage taxonomic groups were seeded in reactive water and an ambient surface water drinking water source, and the survival of the added phages was measured for 90 days at temperatures of 23-25 and 4 Â°C. The viruses Microviridae (type strain PhiX174), Siphoviridae (type strain Lambda) and Myoviridae (type strain T4) are most persistent in water at the temperatures tested. Microviridae (type strain PhiX174) and Siphoviridae (type strain Lambda) were the most resistant to UV radiation, and Myoviridae (type strain T4) and Microviridae (type strain PhiX174) were the most heat resistant. Due to their greater persistence in water over time and their relative resistance to heat and/or UV radiation, Myoviridae (type T4 strain), Microviridae (type strain PhiX174) and Siphoviridae (type strain Lambda) were preferred somatic candidates. As aquatic fecal indicator viruses, coliphages are generally most resistant to these conditions, with Microviridae (type strain PhiX174). © 2011 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Lee, H. S.;Sobsey, M. D.

title: Genome-wide analysis of influenza viral RNA and nucleoprotein association
abstract: Influenza A virus (IAV) genomes consist of eight single-stranded RNA segments coated with viral nucleoprotein (NP) molecules. Classically, the interaction between NP and viral RNA (vRNA) is depicted as a uniform 'beads on a string' pattern. Using high-throughput sequencing of RNA isolated by cross-linking immunoprecipitation (HITS-CLIP), we determined the vRNA binding profiles of NP for two H1N1 IAV strains in virions. Contrary to the current vRNA packaging model, NP does not bind vRNA uniformly in strains A/WSN/1933 and A/California/07/2009, instead each vRNA segment exhibits a unique binding profile that includes enriched or weak sites. In the NP association. Surprisingly, both H1N1 strains have similar but different NP binding profiles despite extensive sequence conservation. The peaks identified by HITS-CLIP were confirmed as true NP binding sites based on insensitivity to DNA antisense oligonucleotide-mediated RNase H digestion. Furthermore, nucleotide content analysis of NP peaks revealed that these regions are relatively G-rich and U-poor compared to genome-wide nucleotide content, indicating a yet unidentified sequence bias for NP association in vivo. Taken together, our study of genome-wide NP-vRNA interaction has implications for understanding influenza vRNA architecture and genome packaging.
authors: Lee, N.;Le Sage, V.;Nanni, A. V.;Snyder, D. J.;Cooper, V. S.;Lakdawala, S. S.

title: First detection of novel enterovirus G recombining a torovirus papain-like protease gene associated with diarrhea in swine in South Korea
authors: Lee, S.;Lee, C.

title: Attenuated vaccines can recombine to form virulent domain viruses
abstract: Recombination between herpes viruses has been observed under experimental conditions in vitro and in vivo. This has raised safety concerns about the use of attenuated herpes virus vaccines in human and veterinary medicine, and other known concerns associated with their use, including reversion to virulence and disease from recurrent reactivation of a life-long chronic infection. We used high-throughput sequencing to investigate associations between emerging field strains of infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV, gallid herpesvirus 1) and vaccine strains. We show that independent recombination events between different attenuated vaccine strains result in virulent recombinant viruses that have become the dominant strains responsible for widespread disease in Australian commercial poultry flocks. These findings highlight the risks of using multiple different attenuated herpes virus vaccines or vectors in the same populations.
authors: Lee, S. W.;Markham, P. F.;Coppo, M. J.;Legione, A. R.;Markham, J. F.;Noormohammadi, A. H.;Browning, G. F.;Ficorilli, N.;Hartley, C. A.;Devlin, J. M.

title: First complete genome sequence of infectious laryngotracheitis virus
abstract: Background: Infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV) is an alphaherpes virus that causes acute respiratory disease in chickens worldwide. To date, only one complete genomic sequence of ILTV has been reported. This series was created by combining partial series from six different ILTV genres. Therefore, the complete genomic sequence of a single (individual) ILTV strain has not been previously determined. This study aimed to use high-throughput sequencing technology to determine the complete genomic sequence of the live attenuated vaccine strain of ILTV. Results: The complete genomic sequence of the Serva vaccine strain of ILTV was determined, annotated and compared with the combined ILTV reference sequence. The genome size of the Serva strain was 152,628 bp with a G+C content of 48%. A total of 80 predicted open reading frames were identified. The Serva strain had 96.5% DNA sequence identity with the assembled ILTV sequence. Notably, the assembled ILTV sequence was found to lack four major sequence regions, including two copies of a 1,563 bp sequence in the 528 bp and 594 bp sequences and repeat regions in the UL29 and UL36 genes, respectively. Significant differences in the size of the predicted translation products of 4 other genes (UL54, UL30, UL37 and UL38) were also identified. More than 530 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) have been identified. Most SNPs were located within three genomic regions corresponding to the sequence from the SA-2 ILTV vaccine strain in the ordered ILTV sequence. Results: This is the first complete genomic sequence of a single ILTV lineage. This sequence will facilitate future comparative genomic studies of ILTV by providing a suitable reference sequence for sequence analysis of other ILTV strains. © 2011 Lee et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Lee, S. W.;Markham, P. F.;Markham, J. F.;Petermann, I.;Noormohammadi, A. H.;Browning, G. F.;Ficorilli, N. P.;Hartley, C. A.;Devlin, J. M.

title: Dicer-2- and Piwi-mediated RNA interference in mosquito cells infected with Rift Valley fever virus
abstract: Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV) is a Phlebovirus (family Bunyaviridae) transmitted by mosquitoes. It infects humans and ruminants, causing dramatic epidemics and epizootics in Africa, Yemen and Saudi Arabia. Although recent studies have demonstrated the importance of non-structural protein NSs as a major component of virulence in vertebrates, little is known about the infection of mosquito vectors. Here, we examined RVFV infection in three different mosquito cell lines: Aag2 cells from Aedes aegypti and U4.4 and C6/36 cells from Aedes albopictus. In contrast to mammalian cells, where NSs form nuclear filaments, U4.4 and Aag2 cells downregulated NSs expression such that NSs filaments never formed in the nucleus of U4.4 cells and were lost early post-infection in the case of Aag2 cells. In contrast, in C6/36 cells, nuclear filaments of NSs were visible for the entire duration of infection. Analysis of virus-derived small interfering RNAs (viRNAs) by deep sequencing showed very low viRNA production in C6/36 cells known to be Dicer-2 deficient but expressing some viRNAs presenting a Piwi signature. In contrast, Aag2 and U4.4 cells produced large amounts of viRNA that predominantly matched the S segment and showed signatures of Dicer-2 and Piwi. While 21-nucleotide (nt) Dicer-2 viRNAs were prominent during early infection, the population of 24- to 27-nt Piwi RNAs (piRNAs) gradually increased and later became predominant during acute infection and persistence. In Aag2 and U4.4 cells, the combined actions of the Dicer-2 and Piwi pathways triggered an effective antiviral response, which, among other actions, allowed the suppression of filament formation of NSs and the establishment of persistence. In C6/36 cells, Piwi-mediated RNA interference (RNAi) appeared sufficient to elicit an antiviral response against a secondary infection with a super-infecting virus. This study provides new insights into the role of Dicer and Piwi in mosquito antiviral defense and the development of the antiviral response in mosquitoes.
authors: Leger, P.;Lara, E.;Jagla, B.;Sismeiro, O.;Mansuroglu, Z.;Coppee, J. Y.;Bonnefoy, E.;Bouloy, M.

title: To investigate the contribution of bacteriophages to antibiotic resistance
abstract: Bacteriophages (phages) are the most abundant and diverse biological entities on our planet. They infect susceptible bacterial hosts in which they reproduce or persist. In the latter case, phages can give new functions to their hosts as a result of gene transfer, thus contributing to their adaptation (short-term) and evolution (long-term). In this context, the role of phages in the spread of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) among bacterial hosts in natural environments has not yet been clearly resolved. Here we conduct a comprehensive analysis of thirty-three viromes from different habitats to investigate whether phages harbor ARGs. Our results show that human-associated viromes do not or rarely carry ARGs, suggesting that viromes from non-human sources (e.g. pig feces, raw sewage, and freshwater and marine environments) contain a large reservoir of ARGs, thus suggesting that phages can play. part of the spread of antibiotic resistance. Given this, the role of phages should not be underestimated and should be taken into account when designing strategies to tackle the global crisis of antibiotic resistance.
authors: Lekunberri, I.;Subirats, J.;Borrego, C. M.;BalcÃ¡zar, J. L.

title: First identification of mammalian orthreovirus type 3 in swine with diarrhea in Europe
abstract: Mammalian Orthoreoviruses 3 (MRV3) has been identified in diarrheal pigs from the USA and Asia. We first detected MRV3 in piglets with severe diarrhea due to Swine Epidemic Diarrhea in Europe (Italy). The virus was phylogenetically related to the human and bat-derived European reoviruses and the US and Chinese pig MRV3.
authors: Lelli, D.;Beato, M. S.;Cavicchio, L.;Lavazza, A.;Chiapponi, C.;Leopardi, S.;Baioni, L.;De Benedictis, P.;Moreno, A.

title: Nucleotide sequence analysis and expression from recombinant vectors indicate that the binding protein G of bovine respiratory syncytial virus differs from that of human respiratory syncytial virus.
abstract: Bovine respiratory syncytial (BRS) virus causes a severe lower respiratory tract disease in calves, similar to the disease in children caused by human respiratory syncytial (HRS) virus. Although there is antigenic cross-reactivity among other major viral structural proteins, the major glycoprotein G of BRS virus and that of HRS virus are antigenically different. G glycoprotein has been implicated as the binding protein for the HRS virus. We performed a molecular comparison of the glycoprotein G of the BRS virus with its HRS virus counterparts. CDNA clones corresponding to BRS virus G glycoprotein mRNA were isolated and analyzed by dideoxynucleotide sequencing. BRS virus G mRNA contained 838 nucleotides excluding poly(A) and had a large open reading frame encoding a polypeptide of 257 amino acid residues. The deduced amino acid sequence of the BRS virus G polypeptide showed only 29-30% amino acids with either subgroup A or B HRS virus G protein. However, despite this low level of identity, there were strong similarities in the predicted hydropathy profiles of the BRS virus and HRS virus G proteins. A cDNA molecule containing the complete BRS virus G major open reading frame was inserted into the thymidine kinase gene of the vaccine virus by homologous recombination, and a recombinant virus containing the BRS virus G protein gene was isolated. This recombinant virus expressed BRS virus G protein as demonstrated by Western immunoblot analysis and immunofluorescence of infected cells. BRS virus G protein expressed from the recombinant vector was transplanted and expressed on the surface of infected cells. Antiserum of BRS virus G protein made using recombinant vector to immunize animals recognized BRS virus binding protein but not HRS virus G protein and vice versa, confirming the absence of antigenic cross-reactivity between BRS and HRS virus binding proteins. Based on the data presented here, we conclude that BRS virus should be classified within the genus Pneumovirus in a separate group from HRS virus and that it is not more closely related to HRS virus subgroup A than HRS virus subgroup B.
authors: Lerch, R. A.;Anderson, K.;Wertz, G. W.

title: Real-time PCR for simultaneous detection and genotyping of bovine viral diarrhea virus
abstract: Since Belgian herds have two genotypes of bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDV), their differentiation is important for disease surveillance. A quantitative real-time PCR assay has been developed to detect and classify bovine viral diarrheal viruses of genotypes I and II. A pair of primers and two TaqMan probes specific to the highly conserved regions of the 5â€²UTR were designed. The FAM and VIC labeled probe sequences differed by three nucleotides, allowing differentiation between genotypes I and II. The assay detectability of the genotype I and II real-time PCR assay was 1000 and 100 replicates, respectively. Highly reproducible data were obtained as the coefficients of variation of the threshold cycle values between studies were less than 2.2%. Accurate classification of genotypes I and II viruses was evaluated using reference strains of both genotypes and characterized field isolates. Application to clinical diagnosis was evaluated on pooled blood samples by post-study measurement of fluorescence associated with FAM and VIC. 100% agreement with the traditional RT-PCR method confirmed that this new technique can be used for routine detection of permanently infected immuno-tolerant animals. Â© 2003 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Letellier, C.;Kerkhofs, P.

title: Detection and genotyping of bovine diarrhea virus by reverse transcription-polymerase chain amplification of the 5' untranslated region
abstract: reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was developed to distinguish bovine diarrhea virus (BVDV) from other pestiviruses and to determine the genotype of BVDV isolates. For this purpose, primer pairs were selected in the 5' untranslated region (5'UTR). Primers B(E) and B2 were located in highly conserved regions and were pestivirus specific. Two primer pairs, B3B4 and B5B6, were specific for BVDV genotypes I and II, respectively. With this technique, an amplification product of the expected size was obtained with primer pairs B3B4 or B5B6 for the 107 BVDV isolates tested, but not for BDV or CSFV. For some isolates grouped into genotype II, sequence analysis of PCR fragments confirmed that they were classified according to this genotype.
authors: Letellier, C.;Kerkhofs, P.;Wellemans, G.;Vanopdenbosch, E.

title: Avian Influenza Virus Surveillance in Wild Birds in Georgia: 2009-2011
abstract: Located on the border of Europe and Asia, the Caucasus is important for the migration and overwintering of wild waterfowl. Three flight paths, Central Asia, East Africa-West Asia and Mediterranean/Black Sea flight paths, converge in the Caucasus region. Therefore, the Caucasus region can act as a migration bridge for influenza virus transmission when it collects in high concentrations during post-breeding, migration and wintering periods of birds. Since August 2009, we have established a surveillance network for influenza viruses in wild birds using five sample sites geographically spread across suitable habitats in both eastern and western Georgia. We obtained paired tracheal and cloacal swabs and fresh stool samples. We collected 8343 swabs from 76 species belonging to 17 families in 11 bird orders, 84 of which were real-time RT-PCR positive for avian influenza virus (AIV). No highly pathogenic AIV (HPAIV) H5 or H7 viruses were detected. The overall prevalence of AIV was 1.6%. We observed the highest prevalence (5.3-9.8%) in great gulls during autumn migration, and the highest prevalence (4.2-13%) in Black-Headed Gulls in spring. In ducks, we observed an increased prevalence of AIV in autumn post-molt aggregations and in the cessation period (6.3%), but at lower levels than in other post-molt regions further north in Eurasia. We observed another prevalence peak during the wintering period (0.14-5.9%). Serological and virological monitoring of the breeding colony of Armenian Gulls showed that adult birds were seropositive upon arrival at the breeding colony, but remained negative for AIV serologically and virologically, unlike other geographic gull AIV data, during the time the brood spent in the breeding grounds. regions. We show that close phylogenetic relatives of viruses isolated in Georgia originate from a wide geographic area throughout Western and Central Eurasia, and likely from areas represented by multiple distinct migration pathways linking different host subpopulations. © 2013 Lewis et al.
authors: Lewis, N. S.;Javakhishvili, Z.;Russell, C. A.;Machablishvili, A.;Lexmond, P.;Verhagen, J. H.;Vuong, O.;Onashvili, T.;Donduashvili, M.;Smith, D. J.;Fouchier, R. A. M.

title: Evolution of the foot-and-mouth disease virus: effects of recombination and selection
abstract: Foot and mouth disease virus is an economically important animal virus that exhibits extensive genetic and antigenic heterogeneity. In order to examine the evolutionary forces affecting the population dynamics of the foot-and-mouth disease virus, individual genes and coding genomes for Eurasian (Asia1, A, C and O) serotypes were examined in terms of phylogenetic relationships, recombination, genetic diversity. and choice. Our analyzes suggest that paraphyletic relationships between serotypes are not as common as previously suggested and that convergent evolution may obscure phylogenetic relationships. We provide evidence that the identification of recombinant sequences and recombination breakpoint patterns between and within serotypes is highly dependent on the level of genetic diversity and convergent characters found in a given dataset, as well as the methods used to detect recombination. Here, we also investigate the effect of adaptive positive selection on capsid proteins and nonstructural 2B, 2C, 3A and 3Cpro genes to identify regions of the genome involved in genetic diversity and antigenic diversity. Two different categories of positive selection at the amino acid level were examined; conservative (stabilizing) selection that preserves certain phenotypic properties of an amino acid residue and radical (stabilizer), and selection that significantly alters the phenotype and potentially the functional and/or structural properties of the protein. Approximately 29% of the residues in the capsid proteins were under positive selection. Of these, 64% were under the influence of destabilizing selection, 80% were under the influence of stabilizing selection, and 44% had phenotypic traits affected by both types of selection.
