Most of the residues under selection (74%) were located outside of known antigenic regions; suggestive of additional uncharacterized epitopes and genomic regions related to antigenic drift. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Lewis-Rogers, N.;McClellan, D. A.;Crandall, K. A.

title: Close association between 2009 H1N1 virus and South Dakota AIV strains
abstract: Although previous publications have suggested that the 2009 pandemic influenza A (H1N1) virus was reclassified from swine viruses in North America and Eurasia, its close ancestry still remains unclear due to the large evolutionary distance between the 2009 H1N1 virus and previously isolated strains. Since the emergence of 2009 H1N1 influenza, there has been great interest in influenza, with the result that large numbers of influenza virus sequences have been deposited in public sequence databases. Explosion analysis showed that the recently presented 2007 South Dakota avian influenza virus strains and other North American avian strains contain genetic segments very closely related to the 2009 H1N1 virus; this suggests that these avian influenza viruses are very close relatives of the 2009 H1N1 virus. Phylogenetic analyzes also show that 2009 H1N1 viruses are related to both avian and swine flu viruses circulating in North America. Because migrating wild birds are preferred to pigs as carriers for spreading influenza viruses over great distances, it is very likely that birds played an important role in the intercontinental evolution of the 2009 H1N1 virus. Understanding the evolutionary path of the emerging influenza virus is essential to find a way to prevent emerging cases. This study reveals the close relationship between the 2009 pandemic virus and North American avian viruses and highlights the increased surveillance of influenza in birds to understand the evolution of 2009 pandemic influenza. Â© 2011 Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Li, C.;An, X. P.;Mi, Z. Q.;Liu, D. B.;Jiang, H. H.;Pan, B.;Wang, S.;Chen, B.;Tong, Y. G.

title: The rumen microbiome associated with feed efficiency and host genetics in beef cattle.
authors: Li, F.

title: Origin, Genetic Diversity and Evolutionary Dynamics of the Novel Pig Circovirus 3
abstract: Porcine circovirus 3 (PCV3) is a novel virus associated with acute PDNS (swine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome)-like clinical manifestations identified by metagenomic sequencing from porcine. Its high occurrence could pose a potential threat to the swine industry worldwide. The processes that result in the emergence and spread of PCV3 are poorly understood. Here, the possible origin, genotypes and evolutionary dynamics of PCV3 are determined based on available genomic sequences. The closest ancestor of PCV3 was found to be within 1 bat CVs. Using different phylogenetic methods, two main genotypes were identified, PCV3a and PCV3b. The effective population size of PCV3 was found to increase rapidly from late 2013 to early 2014, and this was associated with the diversification of PCV3a and PCV3b. A relatively high effective reproduction number (Re) and higher evolution rate were found compared to other single-stranded DNA viruses, and positive selection was identified on codons 122 and 320 (24 of ORF2). It is hypothesized that this, together with the prediction of a potential change of an antigenic epitope at position 320, may have allowed PCV3 to evade the host immune response. Overall, this study has important implications for understanding ongoing PCV3 cases worldwide and will guide future efforts to develop effective preventive and control measures.
authors: Li, G.;He, W.;Zhu, H.;Bi, Y.;Wang, R.;Xing, G.;Zhang, C.;Zhou, J.;Yuen, K. Y.;Gao, G. F.;Su, S.

title: Comparative analysis of the UL1 to UL7 genes of duck enteritis virus and other herpesviruses of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily
abstract: The nucleotide sequences of eight open reading frames (ORFs) located at the 5â€² end of the unique long region of the duck enteritis virus (DEV) Clone-03 strain were determined. The identified genes were named UL1, UL2, UL3, UL4, UL5, UL6 and UL7 homologues of herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1). DEV UL3.5, located between UL3 and UL4, had no homologue in HSV-1. The regulation and transcriptional orientation of the eight genes were in line with their homologues in HSV-1. Phylogenetic trees were constructed based on the alignment of the deduced amino acids of the eight proteins with their homologues in 12 alpha-herpesviruses. In the UL1, UL3, UL3.5, UL5 and UL7 protein trees, branches were more closely related to the Mardivirus genus. However, phylogenetic trees of UL2, UL4 and UL6 proteins showed a great distance from Mardivirus; this indicates that DEV evolved differently from other viruses in the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily and formed a single branch within this subfamily. Copyright © 2009, Sociedade Brasileira de Genética.
authors: Li, H.;Liu, S.;Han, Z.;Shao, Y.;Chen, S.;Kong, X.

title: Characterization of genes encoding UL24, TK and gH proteins from duck enteritis virus (DEV): an evidence for DEV classification
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) has been classified in the family Herpesviridae, but has not been grouped in any genus so far. The four overlapping fragments were amplified from the DEV genome by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). The combined length of the four fragments was 6202 bp, containing genes encoding uniquely long (UL) 24, thymidine kinase (TK) and glycoprotein H (gH) proteins. UL24 overlapped with TK by 64 nucleotides (nt) in a head-to-head transcription orientation, and TK and gH had the same transcription orientation. Comparison of the amino acid sequences of these 3 derived DEV proteins with 12 other alphaherpes viruses showed 5 highly conserved sites in UL24 as well as 5 consensus sites in TK and 4 consensus sites in gH. RNA polymerase II transcriptional control elements were identified in all UL24, TK and gHs of DEV. These elements included core promoters, TATA motifs and polyadenylation sites. Phylogenetic analysis was calculated for the genetic classification of DEV in the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae along with 12 other alphaherpes viruses. The result showed that DEV was more closely associated with avian herpes viruses other than infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV) than with other alphaherpes viruses. In conclusion, according to the phylogeny-based analysis and homology comparison of the functional domains of UL24, TK and gH, DEV should be classified into a separate genus of the Alphaherpesvirinae subfamily in the family Herpesviridae. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Li, H.;Liu, S.;Kong, X.

title: Avian Influenza Virus Subtype H9N2 Affects Intestinal Microbiota, Barrier Structure Damage, and Inflammatory Bowel Disease in Chicken Ileum
abstract: Avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 (H9N2 AIV) has caused significant losses to the poultry industry due to high mortality associated with secondary infections attributable to E. coli. This study attempts to address the underlying secondary mechanisms after H9N2 AIV infection. Initially, nine-day-old specific pathogen-free chickens were divided into control (uninfected) and H9N2-infected groups, respectively. Using Illumina sequencing, histological examination, and quantitative real-time PCR, H9N2 AIV was found to cause intestinal microbiota disruption, injury, and inflammatory damage to the intestinal mucosa. Escherichia genus in particular, especially E. coli, increased significantly (p < 0.01) five days after infection (dpi), while Lactobacillus, Enterococcus and other probiotic organisms decreased significantly (p < 0.01). Simultaneously, mRNA expression of tight junction proteins (ZO-1, claudin 3 and occludin), TFF2 and Muc2, was significantly decreased (p < 0.01), indicating destruction of intestinal epithelial cell tight junctions and damage to the mucin layer. build. Moreover, mRNA expression of the proinflammatory cytokines IFN-gamma, IL-22, IFN-alpha and IL-17A in intestinal epithelial cells was significantly upregulated, resulting in inflammatory response and intestinal damage. Our findings may provide a theoretical basis for diarrhea and gastroenteritis-like symptoms observed following H9N2 AIV infection, such as secondary E. coli infection.
authors: Li, H.;Liu, X.;Chen, F.;Zuo, K.;Wu, C.;Yan, Y.;Chen, W.;Lin, W.;Xie, Q.

title: Poultry adenovirus type C serotype 4 is attributed to the occurrence of hepatitis-hydropericardium syndrome in chickens in China.
abstract: Since July 2015, an emerging infectious disease of Hepatitis-Hydropericardium syndrome (HHS) has been prevalent in chicken flocks in China. To confirm the causative agent and investigate the epidemiology of the disease, a total of 38 chicken flocks were collected and identified, including 187 samples from Jilin, Liaoning, Heilongjiang, Henan, Anhui, Hubei, Jiangxi, Xinjiang, Shandong and Hunan provinces in China. PCR detection, sequencing, phylogenetic analysis and virus isolation. By PCR method, 81 samples (positive sample rate, 81/187, 43.3%) were positive for poultry adenovirus (FAdV) in 33 chicken flocks (positive chicken flock ratio, 33/38, 86.8%). 30 FAdV strains C, 41 strain D, 9 strain E and 1 were uncertain for viral strains by phylogenetic analysis, indicating that at least three strains of FAdVs (C, D and E) are common in China. and strains C and D were predominantly common viral strains. Interestingly, our results showed that two types of FAdV (C and D) coexist in a flock, resulting in a complex situation for the prevalence of the disease. In addition, 13 viral FAdV-C strains were isolated from different geographic areas and one of the isolates, designated strain HN/151025 from Henan Province, was inoculated intramuscularly or orally into 40-day-old specific pathogen-free chickens. pathogenicity. It was found that 90% (9/10) chickens died in the post-threat intramuscular injection group and 30% (3/10) chickens in the oral infection group. Histopathological examination revealed that the pathology was limited to the liver, kidney, spleen and heart. These results showed that the virus was a highly virulent strain.
authors: Li, H.;Wang, J.;Qiu, L.;Han, Z.;Liu, S.

title: Diagnosis of Peste des Petits Ruminants in Wild and Domestic Animals in Xinjiang, China, 2013-2016
abstract: Peste des petits ruminant viruses (PPRVs) re-emerged in China in late 2013 and subsequently spread rapidly through the movement of live goats and sheep. In this study, 96 pet samples and 13 wildlife samples were analyzed for the presence of PPRV infection by ELISA or RT-PCR. While 91 of 96 samples from sheep and goats were positive for PPRV, all 13 samples from three wild species Capra ibex (Capra ibex sibirica), argali (Ovis ammon) and Goiter gazelle (Gazella subgutturosa) were positive. . Five wildlife isolates from the above examples were identified as lineage IV by multiple alignments of partial sequences in the N gene.
authors: Li, J.;Li, L.;Wu, X.;Liu, F.;Zou, Y.;Wang, Q.;Liu, C.;Bao, J.;Wang, W.;Ma, W.;Lin, H.;Huang, J.;Zheng, X.;Wang, Z.

title: Analysis of microRNA expression profiles in Madin-Darby bovine kidney cells infected with Caprine parainfluenza virus type 3
abstract: Caprine parainfluenza virus type 3 (CPIV3) is an emerging pathogenic respiratory agent that infects both young and adult goats and was identified in eastern China in 2013. Cellular microRNAs (miRNAs) have been reported to be important modulators of the complex virus-host. interactions. To elucidate the role of miRNAs in madin-darby bovine kidney (MDBK) cells during CPIV3 infection. In this study, we performed high-throughput sequencing technology to analyze small RNA libraries in CPIV3-infected and mock-infected MDBK cells. The results showed that a total of 249 known and 152 novel candidate miRNAs were differentially expressed in MDBK cells after CPIV3 infection, and 22,981 and 22,572 target genes were predicted, respectively. In addition, RT-qPCR testing was used to further validate the expression patterns of 13 of these differentially expressed miRNAs and their mRNA targets. Functional annotation analysis revealed that these up- and down-regulated target genes are mainly involved in the MAPK signaling pathway, Jak-STAT signaling pathway, Toll-like receptor signaling pathway, p53 signaling pathway, focal adhesion, NF-kappa B signaling pathway, and apoptosis. get. To our knowledge, this is the first report of comparative expression of miRNAs in MDBK cells after CPIV3 infection. Our finding provides insight into the expression profile of miRNAs in response to CPIV3 infection and offers clues to identify potential candidates for antiviral therapies against CPIV3.
authors: Li, J.;Mao, L.;Li, W.;Hao, F.;Zhong, C.;Zhu, X.;Ji, X.;Yang, L.;Zhang, W.;Liu, M.;Jiang, J.

title: Metagenomic identification, genetic characterization and genotyping of porcine sapoviruses
abstract: Sapoviruses (SaVs), belonging to the Sapovirus genus of the Caliciviridae family, were known as enteric pathogens that cause acute gastroenteritis. SaVs have been detected in humans and many animals, including pigs, and some porcine SaVs have shown close sequence association with human strains, suggesting the possibility of interspecies transmission. Here, we sequenced the genomes of two porcine SaVs (with the pedigrees p38 and SH1703) using metagenomic analyzes and conventional RT-PCR methods. Phylogenetic trees were constructed based on the full genome, full-length VP 1 nucleotide and amino acid sequences to group these two strains. The two porcine SaV strains p38 and SH1703 detected in this study were classified as genogroup III and genogroup VII, respectively. These two strains showed similar genomic organization as that of other SaVs. We first segmented SaVs into 51 genotypes within 19 genogroups. Our data are useful for the genetic characterization and classification of newly detected SaVs worldwide.
authors: Li, J.;Zhang, W.;Cui, L.;Shen, Q.;Hua, X.

title: Fecal shedding of rotavirus vaccine in Chinese children after vaccination with Lanzhou lamb rotavirus vaccine
abstract: Lanzhou lamb rotavirus vaccine (LLR) is an oral live attenuated vaccine that was first licensed in China in 2000. To date, >60 million doses of LLR have been distributed to children. However, little is known about fecal shedding of LLR in children. Therefore, stool samples (nâ€‰=â€‰1.184) were collected from 114 children during the period of September-November 2011/2012 for 15 days after vaccination. Fecal shedding and viral loads were determined by an enzyme immunoassay kit (EIA) and real-time RT-PCR. The whole genome was sequenced and the vaccine strain isolated by culture in MA104 cells. Approximately 14.0% (16/114) of children had rotavirus positive samples by EIA at least 1 day after vaccination. Viral loads in EIA-positive samples ranged from "103" to 1.9" copies/g. Fecal shedding occurred as early as day 2 post-vaccination and as late as day 13 post-vaccination, peaking at day 5-10 post-vaccination. A strain of LLR was isolated by culture in cells of MA104. Sequence analysis showed 99% identity to the prototype strain of LLR. Fecal shedding of LLR in stool within 15 days after LLR vaccination is common, indicating that vaccine strains can multiply in human enteric tissues.
authors: Li, J. S.;Cao, B.;Gao, H. C.;Li, D.;Lin, L.;Li, L. L.;Liu, N.;Duan, Z. J.

title: Partial nucleotide sequence of hepatitis E viruses detected in the sera of patients with hepatitis E from 14 cities in China.
abstract: Aim. To investigate the genotypes of hepatitis E viruses (HEV) detected in the sera of patients from different regions of China. Methods The partial genome of open reading frame 2 (ORF2) of 45 HEV strains identified from 14 cities of China (nt6461-6860, nt5994-6294) was amplified and sequenced using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and direct sequencing. Results. Of the 45 strains, 41 (91%) share the same genotype as the HEV Burmese strain (B), with nucleotide identities greater than 98% with the representative HEV Chinese strain. Only 4 HEV strains differ significantly from 3 prototype strains of HEV; nucleotide identities 77% - 80% with HEV Burmese/Chinese strain, 74% - 76% with Mexican strain, and 74% - 77% with newly discovered HEV USA/swine strain, respectively. Phylogenetic analysis suggests that these 4 strains may represent 2 distinct subtypes of a novel HEV genotype that differ significantly from the prototype Mexican, Burmese and USA/swine strains. Solution. Most patients with hepatitis E in China are infected with the Chinese prototype HEV, and only a small proportion are infected with the new genotype HEV.
authors: Li, K.;Zhuang, H.;Zhu, W.

title: Identification and genomic analysis of two strains of duck-derived Tembusu virus in southern China.
abstract: Egg-laying duck flocks in southern China's Guangdong province have been suffering from a widely spread infectious disease, with sudden egg drops and deaths since the winter of 2010. However, the causative pathogen was unknown. We obtained two independent virus isolates, FS and JM, from diseased duck flocks and sequenced the entire length of open reading frames (ORFs) and identified them as duck-borne Tembusu virus by PCR detection. Two isolates FS and JM shared high sequence similarity to isolates of duckorigin Tembusu virus that first emerged in eastern China in April 2010. Burst analysis shows that FS and JM have the highest similarity ([99%) of all ORF sequences. BYD-1 (first reported duck-derived Tembusu virus) and JS804 (first reported goose Tembusu virus) show that full-length genomes are highly conserved in waterfowl Tembusu viruses. This study shows that duck-derived Tembusu viruses spread rapidly from eastern China to southern China, causing widespread infections. The high conservation of duck-derived Tembusu virus strains provides a genomic basis for selecting strains for vaccine preparation to better protect against this novel virus infection. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Li, L.;An, H.;Sun, M.;Dong, J.;Yuan, J.;Hu, Q.

title: Virome analysis of HIV patients treated with antiretroviral shows no correlation between T cell activation and anellovirus levels
authors: Li, L.;Deng, X.;Costa, A. C. Da;Bruhn, R.;Deeks, S. G.

title: Divergent astrovirus associated with neurological disease in cattle
abstract: Using viral metagenomics of brain tissue from a young adult crossbred bovine with acute neurological disease onset, we sequenced the complete genome of a novel astrovirus (BoAstV-NeuroS1) phylogenetically related to a sheep astrovirus. In a retrospective analysis of 32 bovine encephalitis of unknown etiology, 3 other infected animals were identified using PCR and in situ hybridization for viral RNA. Viral RNA was limited to the nervous system and was detected in the cytoplasm of affected neurons in the spinal cord, brainstem, and cerebellum. Microscopically, the lesions were diffuse neuronal necrosis, microgliosis, and perivascular cuffing preferentially distributed in gray matter, most severe in the cerebellum and brainstem with increasing density caudally in the spinal cord. These results suggest that infection with BoAstV-NeuroS1 is a potential cause of neurological disease in cattle.
authors: Li, L.;Diab, S.;McGraw, S.;Barr, B.;Traslavina, R.;Higgins, R.;Talbot, T.;Blanchard, P.;Rimoldi, G.;Fahsbender, E.;Page, B.;Phan, T. G.;Wang, C.;Deng, X.;Pesavento, P.;Delwart, E.

title: A wide variety of circoviruses infect livestock and are commonly found in human and chimpanzee faeces.
abstract: Circoviruses are known to infect birds and pigs and cause a wide variety of severe symptoms with significant economic implications. Using viral metagenomics, we identified circovirus-like DNA sequences and identified 15 circular viral DNA genomes in stool samples from humans and wild chimpanzees from Pakistan, Nigeria, Tunisia, and the United States. Distinctive genomic features and phylogenetic analyzes indicate that some viral genomes are part of a previously unrecognized genus in the family Circoviridae, which we tentatively refer to as "Cyclovirus", whose genetic diversity is comparable to that of all known species in the genus Circovirus. Detection of Circoviridae in feces of US adults was limited to porcine circoviruses, which are also present in most US pork products. To determine whether the different cycloviruses found in human faeces outside the US are of dietary origin, we genetically compared them to cycloviruses in muscle tissue samples from farm animals commonly eaten in Pakistan and Nigeria. Limited genetic overlap between cycloviruses in human fecal samples and local cow, goat, sheep, camel and chicken meat samples indicated that the majority of the 25 Cyclovirus species identified may be human viruses. We show that the genetic diversity of small circular DNA viral genomes in various mammals, including humans, is significantly greater than previously recognized, and that frequent exposure through meat consumption and contact with animal or human feces provides ample opportunities for cyclovirus transmission. Determining the role of cycloviruses in both human and animal diseases, found in 7 to 17% of non-US human feces and 3% to 55% of non-US meat samples tested, is now facilitated by knowledge of their genomes. Copyright © 2010, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Li, L.;Kapoor, A.;Slikas, B.;Bamidele, O. S.;Wang, C.;Shaukat, S.;Masroor, M. A.;Wilson, M. L.;Ndjango, J. B. N.;Peeters, M.;Gross-Camp, N. D.;Muller, M. N.;Hahn, B. H.;Wolfe, N. D.;Triki, H.;Bartkus, J.;Zaidi, S. Z.;Delwart, E.

title: A gyrovirus infecting a seabird
abstract: We characterized the genome of a highly differentiated gyrovirus (GyV8) in the spleen and uropygial gland tissues of a diseased northern fulmar (Fulmarus glacialis), a pelagic stranded bird in San Francisco, California. No other exogenous viral sequences could be identified using viral metagenomics. The small circular DNA genome did not share significant nucleotide sequence identity in VP1 with any of the previously identified gyroviruses and only shared 38-42% amino acid sequence identity in VP1. GyV8 is the first member of the third major phylogenetic clade of this viral genus and the first gyrovirus detected in an avian species other than chicken.
authors: Li, L.;Pesavento, P. A.;Gaynor, A. M.;Duerr, R. S.;Phan, T. G.;Zhang, W.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: Bat guano viroma: Dominance of dietary viruses from insects and plants plus new mammalian viruses
authors: Li, L.;Victoria, J. G.;Wang, C.;Jones, M.;Fellers, G. M.

title: Isolation and genetic analysis revealed that there were no dominant new strains of avian infectious bronchitis virus circulating in Southern China during 2004-2008.
abstract: Between 2004 and 2008, twenty-seven strains of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were isolated from dead or diseased chickens from different poultry farms in Southern China and the S1 gene was sequenced from them. Phylogenetic analysis of S1 gene sequences of 27 isolated strains along with 29 strains published in Genbank revealed that all but one isolated and published IBV strains clustered in six different I-VI genotypes. 26 isolated strains belong to genotypes I, II and III and form a large phylogenetic branch without new dominant strains, while all five vaccine strains belong to genotype V, which is evolutionarily distant from genotypes I, II and III. Study of the protease cleavage motif within the S1 protein found 12 distinct cleavage motifs, 2 motifs specific to isolated strains and 7 motifs specific to published strains, in which 3 motifs are shared by both isolated and published strains, and this motif is absent from the new dominant strain. Alignment analysis of the S1 amino acid sequences showed that amino acid substitutions, insertions and deletions were polymorphic and diverse, showing no evidence of dominant genetic variation among isolated strains. Taken together, there were no dominant new strains circulating in Southern China during 2004-2008. However, circulating IBV strains are constantly evolving with genetic compositions far from vaccine strains; this explains why there were persistent but infrequent outbreaks in commercial herds in Southern China during 2004-2008. In addition, continued surveillance of IBV strains circulating in the field is extremely important to guard against the sudden emergence of new dominant strains. © 2009 Elsevier BV
authors: Li, L.;Xue, C.;Chen, F.;Qin, J.;Xie, Q.;Bi, Y.;Cao, Y.

title: Discovering the virus of sick horses
abstract: Metagenomics was used to characterize viral genomes in clinical samples of equine with various organ-specific diseases of unknown etiology. A novel parvovirus was detected in the cerebrospinal fluid of horses with neurological signs, alongside a previously described hepacivirus closely related to human hepatitis C virus and equid herpesvirus 2. Four co-infecting picobirnaviruses were found in the plasma of two febrile horses, including an unusual genome with fused RNA segments and a different anellovirus. A novel cyclovirus genome has been characterized from the nasal secretions of another febrile animal. Finally, a small circular DNA genome with the Rep gene belonging to a virus we call kircovirus was detected in the liver and spleen of a horse with fatal idiopathic hepatopathy. This work increases the number of viruses found in equine and characterizes their genomes to aid future epidemiological studies of their transmission and potential association with various equine diseases.
authors: Li, L. L.;Giannitti, F.;Low, J.;Keyes, C.;Ullmann, L. S.;Deng, X. T.;Aleman, M.;Pesavento, P. A.;Pusterla, N.;Delwart, E.

title: A new bocavirus in canine liver
abstract: Background: Bocaviruses are classified as a genus within the family Parvoviridae of single-stranded DNA viruses and are pathogenic in some mammalian species. Small canine virus (MVC), which has been associated with neonatal diseases and fertility disorders, with two previously reported strains in dogs; and the respiratory disease-associated Canine bocavirus (CBoV). Results: In this study, using deep sequencing of viral particles enriched from the liver of a dog with severe hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, necrotizing vasculitis, granulomatous lymphadenitis and anuric renal failure, we identified and characterized a new bocavirus we named Canine bocavirus 3 (CnBoV3). The three major ORFs of CnBoV3 (NS1, NP1, and VP1) shared less than 60% identity with those of other bocaviruses, characterizing it as a novel strain based on ICTV criteria. Reverse PCR showed the presence of concatemerized or circular forms of the genome in the liver. Results: We genetically characterized a bocavirus that was quite different from previous canine bocaviruses found in respiratory and fecal samples in a dog liver. Its role in the complex disease of this animal has not yet been determined.
authors: Li, L. L.;Pesavento, P. A.;Leutenegger, C. M.;Estrada, M.;Coffey, L. L.;Naccache, S. N.;Samayoa, E.;Chiu, C.;Qiu, J. M.;Wang, C. L.;Deng, X. T.;Delwart, E.

title: Viruses in dogs with diarrhea include the novel cobuviruses and sapoviruses.
abstract: Dogs' close interactions with humans and surrounding wildlife often provide opportunities for interspecific virus transmission. To initiate an unbiased characterization of eukaryotic viruses in the gut of dogs, deep sequencing of partially purified viral capsid-protected nucleic acids from the feces of 18 diarrheal dogs was used in this study. Known canine parvoviruses, coronaviruses, and rotaviruses were identified and the genomes of the first reported canine cobuvirus and sapovirus were characterized. First-sequence canine picornavirus and canine cobuvirus, the closest genetic relative of the diarrhea-causing human Aichi virus, were detected at high frequency in the stool of both healthy and diarrhoeic dogs. Canine sapovirus has formed a new genogroup within the genus Sapovirus, which is also a group of viruses associated with human and animal diarrheal diarrhea. These results highlight the high frequency of new virus detection possible even in animal species that have been extensively studied using metagenomic approaches and provide viral genomes for further disease-association studies.
authors: Li, L. L.;Pesavento, P. A.;Shan, T. L.;Leutenegger, C. M.;Wang, C. L.;Delwart, E.

title: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N8) Virus in Wild Migratory Birds, Qinghai Lake, China
abstract: In May 2016, a highly pathogenic strain of avian influenza A(H5N8) virus caused deaths among 3 wild migratory bird species in China's Qinghai Lake. Genetic analysis showed that the novel reassortant virus belonged to group B H5N8 viruses, and reclassification events most likely occurred in early 2016.
authors: Li, M.;Liu, H.;Bi, Y.;Sun, J.;Wong, G.;Liu, D.;Li, L.;Liu, J.;Chen, Q.;Wang, H.;He, Y.;Shi, W.;Gao, G. F.;Chen, J.

title: Genetic characterization of continuously evolving highly pathogenic H5N6 influenza viruses in China, 2012-2016
abstract: H5N6 is a highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) and zoonotic disease causing recurrent endemics in East Asia. At least 155 H5N6 outbreaks, including 15 human infections, have been reported in China. These repeated outbreaks have raised concern that the H5N6 virus could be transmitted to humans and cause a pandemic. In February 2016, peacocks on a breeding farm exhibited a highly contagious disease. Post-mortem investigations, including RT-PCR and virus isolation, confirmed that the highly pathogenic H5N6 influenza virus was the causative agent and the strain was named A/Pavo Cristatus/Jiangxi/JA1/2016. In animal experiments it exhibited high pathogenicity in chickens and an estimated median lethal dose of ~104.3 TCID50 in mice. A phylogenetic analysis showed that JA1/2016 clustered in H5 section 2.3.4.4. The FG594-like H5N6 virus from Guangdong Province was the possible precursor of JA1/2016, with an estimated time of divergence of June 2014. We also found that H5N6 influenza viruses can be classified into the following two groups: Group 1 and Group 2. Group 2 influenza viruses have not been detected since the end of 2014, whereas Group 1 influenza viruses have continuously evolved and reintroduced with the "gene pool" circulating in southern China. classified and this has resulted in the rise of new subtypes of the influenza virus. The increase in the number of identified hosts, the widening of the distribution range, and the continued development of H5N6 AIVs increase the risk of an H5N6 virus spreading to other continents and causing a pandemic.
authors: Li, M.;Zhao, N.;Luo, J.;Li, Y.;Chen, L.;Ma, J.;Zhao, L.;Yuan, G.;Wang, C.;Wang, Y.;Liu, Y.;He, H.

title: Isolation and characterization of the novel goose parvovirus-related virus reveals the evolution of waterfowl parvovirus.
abstract: Short beak and dwarfism syndrome (SBDS) has been occurring consistently in China since 2015. It is caused by a new goose parvovirus-associated virus (NGPV) and can severely restrict the growth of ducks. In this study, seven NGPV dyes were isolated from different regions in China between 2015 and 2016. To better understand the correlation between NGPV and goose parvovirus (GPV), we performed whole genome sequencing and a comprehensive analysis of the NGPV genome. Phylogenetic and alignment analysis showed that NGPV is an offshoot of GPV and shares 92.2%-97.1% nucleotide identity with GPV. Compared with classical GPV, five consensus nucleotide mutations in all seven NGPV isolates and two 14 nucleotide pair deletions in six NGPV isolates were found in opposite terminal repeats, twelve and eight synchronous amino acid changes were found in the replication protein and capsid Viral gene regulation, humoral immune responses, and NGPV protein, respectively, which may be important for host transfer. In particular, SDLY1602 was shown to be a recombinant strain with potential major GPV vaccine strain 82-0321v and minor GPV wild strain GDaGPV. This is the first report to show that recombination between two classical GPV strains creates a circulating NGPV strain. This work will improve our understanding of NGPV molecular biology and make it easier to explain the evolutionary properties of GPV.
authors: Li, P.;Lin, S.;Zhang, R.;Chen, J.;Sun, D.;Lan, J.;Song, S.;Xie, Z.;Jiang, S.

title: A range of UV-inducible autolytic vectors for high-throughput screening
abstract: high-throughput screening scheme is often a prerequisite for directed evolution of enzymes or metagenomic analysis of DNA samples. To test the intracellular enzymes of interest (for example, when Escherichia coli is used), in many cases chemical or enzymatic cell lysis is required, which can be tedious and costly. In this study, a series of UV-inducible autolytic vectors were created to offer a simpler method of cell lysis that does not require the use of additional fluid. The SRRz lysis gene cassette from bacteriophage Lambda was cloned downstream of a UV-inducible promoter, recA promoter or umuDC promoter and was also inserted into the backbone of pUC18 and transformed into E. coli BL21 cells. SRRz expression and cell lysis were induced by UV irradiation. For both the recA and umuDC promoters, the lysis efficiency at 30 Â°C was found to be consistent and over 60% when measured using Î²-galactosidase as the reporter. However, at 37 °C the lysis profiles were found to be irregular. UV lysis in 96-well plates also produced consistent lysis results comparable to those obtained with lysozyme treatment, demonstrating the utility of these autolytic vectors in high-throughput screening. This set of artificial SRRz autolysis units should be transferrable to other vectors. Surprisingly, E. coli BL21(DE3) was also found to partially degrade under UV irradiation, with a lysis efficiency of 44.5% at 30 Â°C and 22.5% at 37 Â°C. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Li, S.;Xu, L.;Hua, H.;Ren, C.;Lin, Z.

title: Virus Genome Terminology Examination by High-throughput Sequencing
abstract: Analysis of genomic terminal sequences has been an important step forward in studies of viral DNA replication and packaging mechanisms. However, traditional methods for studying genome termini are challenging due to time-consuming protocols and their inefficiencies where critical details are easily lost. Recent advances in next-generation sequencing (NGS) have made it a powerful tool for studying genome termini. In this study, we sequenced one iridovirus genome and twenty phage genomes using NGS and confirmed for the first time that the high-frequency sequences (HFSs) found in NGS reads are indeed terminal sequences of viral genomes. We also established a criterion to distinguish between termini type and viral packaging mode. We also obtained additional terminal details such as terminal repeats, multiple terminals, asymmetric terminals. With this approach, we were able to simultaneously detect genome termini details as well as obtain the complete sequence of bacteriophage genomes. Theoretically, this application could be further extended to analyze larger and more complex genomes of plant and animal viruses. This work proposed a new and effective method for research on viral replication, packaging, terminase activity, transcription regulation and host cell metabolism.
authors: Li, S. S.;Fan, H.;An, X. P.;Fan, H. H.;Jiang, H. H.;Chen, Y. B.;Tong, Y. G.

title: Genome comparison of a novel classical swine fever virus isolated in China in 2004 with other CSFV strains
abstract: The SWH/CA/2004 genome of a novel classical swine fever virus (CSFV) isolated from a pig pen in Henan Province in central China is 12296 nucleotides (nt) long. The 373-nt 5â€² terminal untranslated region (NTR) consists of a 11697-nt open reading frame (ORF) and a 226-nt 3â€²- encoding a 3898 amino acid (aa) polyprotein. NTR. Genome comparison of the SWH/CA/2004 isolate (GenBank Access: DQ127910) with other known CSFV isolates was performed and analyzed. Corresponding segments from SWH/CA/2004 and other reported strains shared 80.4-99.8% identity at the nucleotide level and 89.5-99.8% identity at the amino acid level. From an evolutionary perspective, isolate SWH/CA/2004 is closely related to the highly lethal isolate cF114/CA/2001 with a binary distance of 0.013; and is distantly related to moderately lethal isolated GXWZ02/CA/2003 by a binary distance of 0.170. Phylogenetic trees of the full-length genome and the following region Erns, E1, E2, and NS5B-based neighbor-joining (NJ) method were constructed and divided into approximately different genetic groups in terms of avirulence, intermediate virulence, and high virulence, while other region-based NJ trees were sequenced between these groups. showed. The four genomic regions may constitute important criteria for genetic typing of various CSFV isolates. Based on these analyses, it was concluded that SWH/CA/2004 isolate belongs to the highly virulent isolate group. However, SWH/CA/2004 also contains a 14-U deletion in the 3–²-NTR that is characteristic of avirulent isolates. These analyzes constitute a comprehensive study of CSF phylogenetics based on different regions of the genome and may provide the basis for future molecular epidemiology research to identify virulent strain outbreaks and trigger the application of appropriate control measures. © 2006 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Li, X.;Xu, Z.;He, Y.;Yao, Q.;Zhang, K.;Jin, M.;Chen, H.;Qian, P.

title: Differential expression of microns in porcine cell line infected with porcine parvovirus
abstract: Background: Porcine parvovirus (PPV), a member of the Parvoviridae family, causes great economic losses to the pig industry worldwide. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of non-protein-coding genes that play many different and complex roles in viral infections. Finding: Aiming to determine the effect of PPV infections on the cellular miRNAome, we used high-throughput sequencing to sequence two miRNA libraries prepared from porcine kidney 15 (PK-15) cells under normal conditions and during PPV infection. There was differential miRNA expression between uninfected and infected cells: 65 miRNAs were upregulated and 128 miRNAs were downregulated. We detected expression of miR-10b, miR-20a, miR-19b, miR-181a, miR-146b, miR-18a and other previously identified immune-related miRNAs. Gene Ontology analysis of host target genes and KEGG function annotations suggested that miRNAs are involved in complex cellular pathways, including cellular metabolic processes, immune system processes, and gene expression. Results: These data show that a large set of miRNAs are expressed in PK-15 cells and some miRNAs are changed in PPV-infected PK-15 cells. A number of microRNAs play an important role in the regulation of immune-related gene expression. Our findings should aid the development of new control strategies to prevent or treat PPV infections in pigs.
authors: Li, X.;Zhu, L.;Liu, X.;Sun, X.;Zhou, Y.;Lang, Q.;Li, P.;Cai, Y.;Qiao, X.;Xu, Z.

title: Genetic analysis of two swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses of different virulence isolated in China
abstract: S1 and SY0608 strains of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) were isolated separately in 1997 and 2006 and had different pathogenicity in pigs. To understand their genomic features, the full-length genome of S1 and SY0608 isolates was sequenced and analyzed. The results showed that their genome compositions differed significantly and shared only 88.5% nucleotide identity with each other. Genetic diversity and amino acid substitutions are not randomly distributed in the genome and are mainly focused on ORF1a, ORF3 and ORF5. The highly pathogenic strain SY0608 had 30 amino acid deletions at amino acid positions 480 and 532-560 compared to strain S1. Alignment of the Nsp1-Nsp8, GP2-GP5, M, and N amino acid sequence of S1 and SY0608 with other PRRSV isolates indicated that variation is mainly found in Nsp2, GP3, and GP5 proteins. Compared with strain S1, strain SY0608 showed some potential glycosylation site mutations at amino acid positions 26 and 39 in GP5 that may be associated with viral antigenicity. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the two strains belonged to two different clades with no differences in pathogenicity. Interestingly, deletion species recently isolated in China formed a new minor branch that reveals the same evolutionary trend. © 2008 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Li, Y.;Wang, X.;Jiang, P.;Chen, W.;Wang, X.

title: From discovery to spread: Evolution and phylogeny of the Getah virus
abstract: Getah virus (GETV) was first isolated in 1955 in Malaysia. Since then, epidemics of GETV in horses and pigs have caused great economic losses. Currently, GETV has spread to Eurasia and Southeast Asia, including mainland China, Korea, Japan, Mongolia, and Russia. The data show that the Most Recent Common Ancestor (MRCA) of GETV existed about 145 years ago (95% HPD: 75–244) and gradually evolved into four distinct evolutionary populations: Groups I-IV. MRCA (19°K to 60°K) of GETVs in Group III, which includes all GETVs isolated from mosquitoes, pigs, horses and other animals since the 1960s, existed approximately 51 years ago (95% HPD) : 51â€). "72. Group III is responsible for most viral outbreaks among domestic animals. An analysis of the GETV E2 protein sequence and structure revealed seven common amino acid mutation sites. These sites are structural and electrostatic detected between common Group III isolates and the MM2021 prototype strain. These differences may explain the recent geographic radiation of the virus. Considering the economic importance of GETV infection in pigs and horses, we recommend the implementation of stringent viral screening and monitoring programs.
authors: Li, Y. Y.;Liu, H.;Fu, S. H.;Li, X. L.;Guo, X. F.;Li, M. H.;Feng, Y.;Chen, W. X.;Wang, L. H.;Lei, W. W.;Gao, X. Y.;Lv, Z.;He, Y.;Wang, H. Y.;Zhou, H. N.;Wang, G. Q.;Liang, G. D.

title: MicroRNA-23b Promotes Avian Leukosis Virus Subgroup J (ALV-J) Replication by Targeting IRF1
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) can cause several different leukemia-like proliferative diseases in the hemopoietic system of chickens. Here, we investigated the transcriptome profiles and miRNA expression profiles of ALV-J-infected and uninfected chicken spleens to identify genes and miRNAs involved in ALV-J invasion. In total, 252 genes and 167 miRNAs were differentially expressed in ALV-J-infected spleens compared to control uninfected spleens. miR-23b expression was up-regulated in ALV-J-infected spleens compared to control spleens, and transcriptome analysis revealed that interferon regulatory factor 1 (IRF1) expression was down-regulated in ALV-J-infected spleens compared to uninfected. spleen. A dual luciferase reporter assay demonstrated that IRF1 is a direct target of miR-23b. miR-23b overexpression (P = 0.0022) significantly reduced IRF1 mRNA levels and suppressed IRF1-3'-UTR reporter activity. In vitro experiments revealed that miR-23b overexpression potentiates ALV-J replication, whereas miR-23b loss of function inhibits ALV-J replication. IRF1 overexpression inhibited ALV-J replication and IRF1 knockdown increased ALV-J replication. Also, IRF1 overexpression significantly (P = 0.0014) increased IFN-Î² expression. In conclusion, these results suggested that miR-23b may play an important role in ALV-J replication by targeting IRF1.
authors: Li, Z.;Chen, B.;Feng, M.;Ouyang, H.;Zheng, M.;Ye, Q.;Nie, Q.;Zhang, X.

title: Evidence of non-suppurative encephalitis caused by swine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus as the cause of death in piglets
abstract: An outbreak of acute swine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus (PHEV) infection has occurred in piglets, characterized by neurological symptoms, vomiting, diarrhea, and malaise. Coronavirus-like particles were observed in homogenized tissue suspensions of the brain of dead piglets by electron microscopy, and a wild strain of PHEV was isolated, characterized and named PHEV-CC14. Histopathological examinations of dead piglets showed features of non-suppurative encephalitis and some neurons in the cerebral cortex were degenerated and necrotic and had neuronophagia. Similarly, mice vaccinated with PHEV-CC14 were found to have symptoms of depression, arched waists, central nervous system (CNS) dysfunction in standing and swinging front paws. Furthermore, PHEV-positive labeling of neurons in the cortices of dead piglets and infected mice promoted viral infections of the nervous system. Next, the major structural genes of PHEV-CC14 were sequenced and phylogenetically analyzed, and the strain shared 95%-99.2% nt identity with other PHEV strains available in GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis clearly demonstrated that the wild strain clustered into a subclass with a HEV-JT06 strain. These findings suggested that the virus has a strong tropism for the CNS, thereby inducing nonsuppurative encephalitis as the cause of death in piglets. At the same time, the estimated risk of widespread transmission showed a certain variation among the PHEV strains currently circulating around the world. First of all, the information presented in this study not only provides a good reference for the experimental diagnosis of PHEV infection for pig breeding, but also promotes the development of new effective vaccines.
authors: Li, Z.;He, W.;Lan, Y.;Zhao, K.;Lv, X.;Lu, H.;Ding, N.;Zhang, J.;Shi, J.;Shan, C.;Gao, F.

title: MicroRNAs in immune organs of chickens and ducks indicate differential immunity to H5N1 avian influenza.
abstract: Chickens are susceptible to the highly pathogenic H5N1 strain of the avian influenza virus (HPAIV), while ducks are not. Here, we used high-throughput sequencing to analyze microRNA expression in the spleen, thymus, and bursa of Fabricius of H5N1-HPAIV-infected and uninfected chickens and ducks. We described the genomic locations of duck microRNAs and compared the microRNA repertoires of chickens and ducks. Our results showed that the microRNA expression patterns in homologous immune organs of specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens and ducks differed significantly. Also, there was a greater difference in microRNA expression patterns in immune organs of HPAIV-infected chickens than HPAIV-infected ducks. Together, our results may help explain the roles of microRNAs in differential immunity of chickens and ducks to H5N1 HPAIV.
authors: Li, Z.;Zhang, J.;Su, J.;Liu, Y.;Guo, J.;Zhang, Y.;Lu, C.;Xing, S.;Guan, Y.;Li, Y.;Sun, B.;Zhao, Z.

title: Novel avian coronavirus and flared disease in Guinea Chicken, France
abstract: For decades, French guinea fowl have been affected by fulminant enteritis of uncertain origin. Using metagenomics, we have identified a novel avian gammacoronavirus associated with this disease, distantly related to turkey coronaviruses. Deadly respiratory diseases in humans have recently been caused by coronaviruses of animal origin.
authors: Liais, E.;Croville, G.;Mariette, J.;Delverdier, M.;Lucas, M. N.;Klopp, C.;Lluch, J.;Donnadieu, C.;Guy, J. S.;Corrand, L.;Ducatez, M. F.;GuÃ©rin, J. L.

title: A systematic analysis of the miRNA transcriptome in lymphoma caused by Marek's disease virus reveals novel and differentially expressed miRNAs.
abstract: Marek's disease is a lymphoproliferative neoplastic disease of chicken that poses a serious threat to poultry health. T-cell lymphoma caused by Marek's disease virus (MDV) is also an excellent biomedical model for neoplasia research. Recently, miRNAs have been shown to play important roles in mediating neoplastic transformation. To investigate the host miRNA expression profiles during the tumor transformation stage of MDV infection, we performed deep sequencing in two MDV-infected samples (spleen with tumor and MD lymphoma from the liver) and two uninfected controls (non-infected spleen and lymphocytes). In total, 187 and 16 known miRNAs were identified in chicken and MDV, respectively, and 17 new chicken miRNAs were further confirmed by qPCR. We identified 28 down-regulated miRNAs and 11 up-regulated miRNAs in MDV-infected samples by bioinformatic analysis. Of the nine further tested by qPCR, seven were confirmed. gga-miR-181a, gga-miR-26a, gga-miR-221, gga-miR-222, gga-miR-199*, and gga-miR-140* were down-regulated and gga-miR-146c in MDV-infected tumors was upregulated in spleens and MD lymphomas. In addition, 189 putative target genes were predicted for the seven differentially expressed miRNAs. Luciferase reporter gene assay showed interactions of gga-miR-181a with MYBL1, gga-miR-181a with IGF2BP3 and gga-miR-26a with EIF3A. Differential expression of miRNAs and predicted targets strongly suggest that they contribute to MDV-induced lymphogenesis.
authors: Lian, L.;Qu, L.;Chen, Y.;Lamont, S. J.;Yang, N.

title: Cloning, sequencing and polymorphism analysis of novel classical MHC class I alleles in northern pig-tailed macaques (Macaca leonina)
abstract: The northern pig-tailed macaque (Macaca leonina) has been confirmed to be an independent species from the Old World monkey's pig-tailed macaque group. We previously reported that northern pig-tailed macaques are also susceptible to HIV-1. Here, we sought to evaluate the role of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I-limited immune responses to HIV-1 infection, to make this animal a potential model of HIV/AIDS and to explore its virus control mechanism. viral replication and disease progression. As a first step, we first cloned and characterized the classic MHC class I gene of northern pig-tailed macaques. In this study, we identified 39 MHC class I alleles, including 17 MHC-A and 22 MHC-B alleles. Of these identified alleles, 30 were novel and 9 were identical to alleles previously reported from other macaque species. The MHC-A and MHC-B loci were both duplicative in rhesus macaques and southern pig-tailed macaques. In addition, we also detected patterns of positive selection in northern pig-tailed macaques, revealing the presence of equilibrium selection with 20 positive selection sites at the peptide binding site. Analysis of B and F peptide binding pockets in northern and southern pig-tailed macaques and rhesus macaques revealed that they would likely share several common peptides. Therefore, this study provides important MHC immunogenetic information and adds value to northern pig-tailed macaques as a promising HIV/AIDS model.
authors: Lian, X. D.;Zhang, X. H.;Dai, Z. X.;Zheng, Y. T.

title: Arboviruses and their associated infections in China: A comprehensive field and laboratory investigation over the past 30 years
abstract: Since the 1980s, extensive field and laboratory research has been conducted throughout China, and a total of 29 virus species belonging to 7 families and 13 genera have been identified by whole-genome sequencing and molecular methods, as well as virological, morphological and immunological methods. genetic analysis. Most of the virus isolates belong to 9 genera in the families Flaviviridae, Bunyaviridae, Togaviridae and Reoviridae. Of these, 4 genera (Orthobunyavirus, Bunyavirus, Phlebovirus and Nairovirus) belong to the Bunyaviridae family and 3 genera (Seadonavirus, Orbivirus and Cypovirus) belong to the Reoviridae family. Analyzes of associations between viruses and human/animal diseases have shown that Japanese encephalitis virus, dengue virus, severe fever virus with thrombocytopenia syndrome, tick-borne encephalitis virus, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus, West Nile virus, and Tahina virus can cause human disease. and animal infections and disease outbreaks in China. This review systematically introduces the current state of the diversity and geographic distribution of arboviruses and vectors in China. In addition, our results provide strong technical support for the prevention and control of arboviral diseases, the treatment of epidemics, and the early warning and prediction of diseases and are therefore important for the control and prevention of arboviral diseases in and around Asia. World.
authors: Liang, G.;Li, X.;Gao, X.;Fu, S.;Wang, H.;Li, M.;Lu, Z.;Zhu, W.;Lu, X.;Wang, L.;Cao, Y.;He, Y.;Lei, W.

title: Newcastle disease outbreaks in western China were caused by genotypes VIIa and VIII.
abstract: Twelve strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) were isolated from chickens involved in Newcastle disease (ND) outbreaks in western China (Shaanxi, Gansu, Xinjiang, Qinghai and Guangxi provinces) between 1979 and 1999. All strains were determined to be velogenic with plaque. formation, mean time to death (MDT) of embryonated eggs, and intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI). Acid guanidinium-thiocyanate method was used for the preparation of virus RNA. A 908bp nucleotide fragment was amplified by RT-PCR starting from the N-terminus of the F gene, and the PCR segments were cloned and sequenced into the PGEM-T vector. The similarities of the nucleotide sequences (1-519bp) of the F gene (1-125) and the predicted amino acid sequences were analyzed by comparing 12 NDV isolates with the NDV vaccine strains Lasota, B1, H1 and V4 as well as classical NDV strains. and recent epizootic strains. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all strains were from two new genotypes; The NDV strains that caused the ND epidemic in western China between 1998 and 1999 were genotype VIIa, while the strains from Qinghai province (1979-1985) were genotype VIII found predominantly in South Africa. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liang, R.;Cao, D. J.;Li, J. Q.;Chen, J.;Guo, X.;Zhuang, F. F.;Duan, M. X.

title: Provirus variants of bovine leukemia virus in naturally infected cattle from Argentina and Japan
abstract: serological subset of bovine leukemia virus (BLV) has not been identified, whereas genetic variation among BLVs has been reported by polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP). To investigate the distribution of BLV provirus variants, 42 isolates from Argentina and Japan were screened for a segment of the env gene by nested PCR followed by DNA sequencing. The nucleotide sequences were compared with other previously characterized BLV variants from different geographic regions (Belgium, France, Italy, North America, Australia, Japan and Argentina). Most of the analyzed segments had a tendency for nucleotide substitution without changing the amino acid. The generated phylogenetic tree showed the relationships and differences between proviruses and within each. Most of the samples in Argentina formed a cluster. All but one specimens from Japan also formed a cluster, and some showed high homology with isolates from Australia and the USA. Considering sequence analysis of env PCR products of all Japanese and Argentine samples and comparison with other previously isolated sequences, variation was up to 3.5% and was characterized geographically in each area. Â© 2003 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Licursi, M.;Inoshima, Y.;Wu, D.;Yokoyama, T.;GonzÃ¡lez, E. T.;Sentsui, H.

title: Taxonomy of viruses with etiological association with human, bovine and swine gastroenteritis
authors: Liebermann, H.

title: Phylogenetic characterization of Newcastle disease viruses isolated in Taiwan between 2003-2006
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates from chicken cases were obtained from various sites in Taiwan between 2003 and 2006 and were genotypically analyzed using reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) with primers specific to the viral fusion (F) protein gene. (534 basis points). A portion of the amplified F protein DNA product (nucleotide sequence 47-418) and deduced amino acid sequences were phylogenetically compared with those from strains previously reported in Taiwan and other geographic regions. Our results showed that all Taiwan isolates (n = 20) collected between 2003 and 2006 belong to the VIId genotype according to the phylogenetic tree. In addition, all six Taiwanese isolates obtained in 2003 carry the motif 112R-RQK-R116 and have amino acid L23 replaced by F23 (assigned Group 1). On the other hand, 12 of 14 Taiwanese isolates obtained between 2004-2006 have the motif 112R-RKK-R116 and have amino acid G74 instead of E74 (assigned as Group 2). To our knowledge, these are the first reported VIId isolates to have the sequences G74/112R-RKK-R116 within the F0 protein. These isolates obtained between 2003 and 2006 are considered the velogenic type, as NDV-infected chickens have high mortality, severe clinical manifestations, typical postmortem lesions, and a high intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI). Group 2 viruses have become dominant and responsible for the majority of Taiwanese outbreaks in recent years. Based on our phylogenetic analysis, it can be hypothesized that these isolates evolved from previously reported local strains, with the Group 2 family appearing last in genotype VIId. Knowledge is essential to improve the efficiency of control strategies and vaccine development for NDV. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Lien, Y. Y.;Lee, J. W.;Su, H. Y.;Tsai, H. J.;Tsai, M. C.;Hsieh, C. Y.;Tsai, S. S.

title: Live attenuated nephropathogenic infectious bronchitis virus vaccine provides broad cross-protection against novel variant strains
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) infections cause huge economic losses to the poultry industry worldwide, and the emergence of new variant strains complicates disease control. This study investigated the genetic and protective properties of emerging Korean IBV strains. A phylogenetic analysis showed that several new isolates formed 2 distinct clusters (new cluster 1 and 2) that differed from other pre-existing clusters. The new cluster 1 IBV strains represented recombinants between the Korean nephropathogenic strain KM91 and strain QXIBV. The new cluster 2 IBV strains showed lower amino acid homology (<58.7%) compared to previous isolates. We evaluated the protective efficacy of commercial IBV vaccines (strain H120 and K2) against these new isolates. In cross-protection studies, strain H120 did not provide adequate protection against these variants. However, the highly attenuated nephropathogenic IBV vaccine, strain K2, provided significantly higher levels of protection against variants (P < 0.05 or better) compared to chickens vaccinated with H120. These results suggest that the K2 vaccine may be helpful in reducing the economic losses caused by emerging IBV recombinants (new cluster 1) and variants (new cluster 2). Â© 2012 Poultry Science Association A.Ş.
authors: Lim, T. H.;Kim, M. S.;Jang, J. H.;Lee, D. H.;Park, J. K.;Youn, H. N.;Lee, J. B.;Park, S. Y.;Choi, I. S.;Song, C. S.

title: The fecal virome of healthy chickens reveals a great diversity of the eukaryotic viral community, including novel circular ssDNA viruses.
abstract: This study focused on the identification of the fecal virus of healthy chickens raised on high-density, export-based poultry farms in Brazil. After high-throughput sequencing, a total of 7743 de novo-assembled contigs were generated and compared with known nucleotide/amino acid sequences from the GenBank database. Analysis with BLASTx revealed that 279 contigs (4%) were associated with eukaryotic virus sequences. Viral genome sequences (total or partial) showing members of recognized viral families including Adenoviridae, Caliciviridae, Circoviridae, Parvoviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Picornaviridae and Reoviridae have been identified, some of which represent novel genotypes. In addition, a set of circular replication-associated proteins encoding DNA viruses were also identified. The characterization of the fecal virus of healthy chickens described here not only provides a description of viruses encountered in such niches, but should also serve as a basis for future studies comparing viral populations in flocks of healthy and diseased chickens. It may also apply to human health, as chickens represent a significant portion of the animal protein consumed worldwide.
authors: Lima, D. A.;Cibulski, S. P.;Finkler, F.;Teixeira, T. F.;Varela, A. P. M.;Cerva, C.;Loiko, M. R.;Scheffer, C. M.;Dos Santos, H. F.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Intestinal viroma of broilers affected and unaffected by malabsorption syndrome via shotgun metagenomics
abstract: Malabsorption syndrome (MAS) is an economically important disease of commercially reared young broilers, characterized by growth retardation, defective feather development, and diarrheal stools. Several viruses have been temporarily associated with this syndrome. Here, fecal viromes of 70 fecal samples collected from diseased (n = 35) and healthy (n = 35) chickens from seven flocks were characterized and compared to examine potential associations between enteric viruses and MAS. After high-throughput sequencing, a total of 8,347,319 paired postreads were generated with an average of 231 nt. By analysis of de novo-assembled contigs, 144 contigs > 1000 nt hitting eukaryotic viral sequences were identified as determined by the GenBank database. A number of known and unknown representatives of Adenoviridae, Anelloviridae, Astroviridae, Caliciviridae, Circoviridae, Parvoviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Picornaviridae and Reoviridae, as well as novel uncharacterized CRESS-DNA viruses were identified. However, the distribution of sequence reads of viral genomes identified in diseased or healthy birds did not differ statistically significantly. These findings indicate that there is no relationship between MAS formation and enteric viruses. The viral genomes reported in this study, including several novel viruses, appear to be part of the normal gut microbiota of chickens.
authors: Lima, D. A.;Cibulski, S. P.;Tochetto, C.;Varela, A. P. M.;Finkler, F.;Teixeira, T. F.;Loiko, M. R.;Cerva, C.;Junqueira, D. M.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Ocular Vaccine Infection in Dairy Worker, Brazil
abstract: We reviewed a clinical case of vaccinia virus causing an ocular manifestation in a dairy worker in Brazil. Biological and molecular analyzes identified a co-infection with 2 isolates from different Brazilian vaccinia virus phylogenetic groups.
authors: Lima, M. T.;Oliveira, G. P.;Assis, F. L.;Bretas de Oliveira, D.;Vaz, S. M.;Trindade, G. S.;Abrahao, J. S.;Kroon, E. G.

title: Nucleotide Sequence of Genes Encoding Canine Herpesvirus Gb, Gc, and Gd Homologs
abstract: The nucleotide sequence of the genes encoding the canine herpes virus (CHV) gB, gC and gD homologues was determined. These genes are estimated to encode polypeptides of 879, 459 and 345 amino acids, respectively. Comparison of the predicted amino acid sequences of CHV gB, gC and go with homologous sequences from other herpes viruses indicates that CHV is an alphaherpes virus, a result consistent with the previous classification of this virus based on biological characteristics. Alignment of homologous gB, gC, and gD amino acid sequences shows that most of the cysteine residues are conserved, indicating that these glycoproteins have similar tertiary structures. The nucleotide sequence of the open reading frame downstream from the CHV gC gene was also determined. The predicted amino acid sequence of this putative polypeptide appears to be homologous to a family of proteins encoded downstream from the gC gene in most, but not all, alphaherpes viruses.
authors: Limbach, K. J.;Limbach, M. P.;Conte, D.;Paoletti, E.

title: High prevalence of hepatitis e virus in Swedish deer - a phylogenetic characterization and comparison of virus from different regions
abstract: BACKGROUND: The hepatitis E virus (HEV) infects a number of species, including humans, pigs, wild boars and deer. Zoonotic transmission may contribute to the high HEV seroprevalence in the human population of many countries. A new distinct HEV from the Swedish deer (Alces alces) was recently identified by partial genome sequencing. Because only one strain was found, its classification within the HEV family, prevalence of deer, and zoonotic potential were uncertain. Therefore, we searched samples from 231 deer in seven Swedish counties for HEV and sequenced a nearly complete deer HEV genome. Phylogenetic analysis was performed to classify this virus within the Hepeviridae family and to search for potential host-specific determinants. METHODS AND RESULTS: Deer's HEV prevalence was determined by PCR (active infection marker) and serological assays (past infection marker) of serum and 51 fecal samples from 231 Swedish deer. Active and past infection markers were found in 67 (29%) animals, with 34 (15%) positive for HEV RNA, 43 (19%) seropositive for anti-HEV antibodies, and 10 (4%) both markers. . The number of young individuals positive for HEV RNA was greater than that of older individuals, and the number of individuals positive for anti-HEV antibody increased with age. The high-throughput sequenced deer HEV genome was 35-60% identical to existing HEVs. Partial sequences of ORF1 from 13 deer strains showed high similarity between them, forming a distinct monophyletic lineage with a common ancestor to the HEV genotypes 1-6, containing members known for zoonotic transmission. CONCLUSIONS: This study shows a high frequency of HEV in Swedish deer, with 30% of animals showing current and past infection markers. Deer are therefore an important animal repository of HEV. The phylogenetic relationship indicated that deer HEV belonged to genotype 1-6 group, which includes strains that also infect humans, thus indicating a potential for zoonotic transmission of this HEV.
authors: Lin, J.;Karlsson, M.;Olofson, A. S.;Belak, S.;Malmsten, J.;Dalin, A. M.;Widen, F.;Norder, H.

title: High prevalence of hepatitis E virus in Swedish deer - A phylogenetic characterization and comparison of virus from different regions
abstract: Background: The hepatitis E virus (HEV) infects a number of species, including humans, pigs, wild boars and deer. Zoonotic transmission may contribute to the high HEV seroprevalence in the human population of many countries. A new distinct HEV from the Swedish deer (Alces alces) was recently identified by partial genome sequencing. Because only one strain was found, its classification within the HEV family, prevalence of deer, and zoonotic potential were uncertain. Therefore, we searched samples from 231 deer in seven Swedish counties for HEV and sequenced a nearly complete deer HEV genome. Phylogenetic analysis was performed to classify this virus within the Hepeviridae family and to search for potential host-specific determinants. Methods and Results: The prevalence of HEV in deer was determined by PCR (active infection marker) and serological assays (past infection marker) of serum and 51 fecal samples from 231 Swedish deer. Active and past infection markers were found in 67 (29%) animals, with 34 (15%) positive for HEV RNA, 43 (19%) seropositive for anti-HEV antibodies, and 10 (4%) both markers. . The number of young individuals positive for HEV RNA was greater than that of older individuals, and the number of individuals positive for anti-HEV antibody increased with age. The high-throughput sequenced deer HEV genome was 35-60% identical to existing HEVs. Partial sequences of ORF1 from 13 deer strains showed high similarity between them, forming a distinct monophyletic lineage with a common ancestor to the HEV genotypes 1-6, containing members known for zoonotic transmission. Conclusions: This study shows a high frequency of HEV in Swedish deer, and 30% of the animals showed current and past infection markers. Deer are therefore an important animal repository of HEV. The phylogenetic relationship indicated that deer HEV belonged to genotype 1-6 group, which includes strains that also infect humans, thus indicating a potential for zoonotic transmission of this HEV.
authors: Lin, J.;Karlsson, M.;Olofson, A. S.;BelÃ¡k, S.;Malmsten, J.;Dalin, A. M.;WidÃ©n, F.;Norder, H.

title: Evidence from nature: interspecies spread of heron hepatitis B viruses
abstract: Heron hepatitis B viruses (HHBVs) in three subspecies of free-living great blue herons (Ardea herodias) from Florida, USA were identified and characterized. Eight of the 13 samples were positive in all assays used, while sera from egrets, which are also members of the Ardeidae family, were negative in the same assays. Comparative phylogenetic analysis of viral DNA sequences from the preS/S region of previously reported new HHBV strains isolated from captive gray herons (Germany) and free-range great blue herons (USA) revealed strong conservation (95% sequence similarity). ) with two distinct clusters implying a common ancestor of all strains. Our data show for the first time that different subspecies of herons have been infected with HHBV and that these infections have been found in non-captive birds. Phylogenetic analysis and the fact that different heron species are geographically isolated populations suggest that lateral transmission, virus adaptation and environmental factors all play a role in HHBV spread and evolution.
authors: Lin, L.;Prassolov, A.;Funk, A.;Quinn, L.;Hohenberg, H.;Frolich, K.;Newbold, J.;Ludwig, A.;Will, H.;Sirma, H.;Steinbach, F.

title: Influenza A(H9N2) Virus, Myanmar, 2014-2015
abstract: Between 2014 and 2015, routine surveillance of influenza A virus was carried out in Myanmar. Influenza A(H9N2) virus was isolated in Shan State, upper Myanmar. Whole genome sequencing showed that the H9N2 virus from Myanmar was closely related to the H9N2 virus of the 4.2.5 clan from China.
authors: Lin, T. N.;Nonthabenjawan, N.;Chaiyawong, S.;Bunpapong, N.;Boonyapisitsopa, S.;Janetanakit, T.;Mon, P. P.;Mon, H. H.;Oo, K. N.;Oo, S. M.;Mar Win, M.;Amonsin, A.

title: Molecular epidemiology of J-subgroup avian leukosis virus isolated from meat-type chickens in southern China between 2013 and 2014.
abstract: Members of the avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) cause a variety of diseases associated with tumorigenesis and reduced fertility, causing major economic losses to the poultry industry worldwide. The molecular epidemiology of ALV-J strains was investigated to assess the status of ALV-J infection in broiler chickens in southern China. In this study, a total of 265 clinical specimens collected from southern China between 2013 and 2014 were searched for the presence of ALV-J resulting in 12 virus isolates. Phylogenetic analysis showed that 91.7% (11/12) of ALV-J isolates had high homology to Chinese strata isolates and belonged to a subgroup. One of the ALV isolates (designated GD1411-1) is relatively closely related to the ALV-J broiler isolates, indicating that GD1411-1 isolate may be a transitional strain. Several unique nucleotide substitutions were detected in the gp85 and U3 region in all 12 ALV-J isolates. This study provides some interesting insights into the molecular characterization of ALV-J isolates. These findings will be useful for understanding the pathogenic mechanism of ALV-J infection.
authors: Lin, W.;Li, X.;Dai, Z.;Zhang, X.;Chang, S.;Zhao, P.;Zhang, H.;Chen, F.;Xie, Q.

title: Genetic and pathobiological characterization of H3N2 canine influenza viruses isolated in Jiangsu Province, China in 2009-2010.
abstract: The newly emerged canine influenza virus (CIV) poses significant concerns for both veterinary and public health. During 2009-2010, six strains of H3N2 influenza virus were isolated from dogs in Jiangsu Province, China. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of eight gene segments revealed that six viruses were most similar to a recent canine-derived subtype H3N2 influenza virus, originating from the avian strain, which was isolated from cats in South Korea. By comparing the deduced amino acid sequences of the hemagglutinin 1 (HA1) and neuraminidase (NA) genes of six Jiangsu isolates with those of most similar avian species, we found that all isolates had several common mutations, potential glycosylation, at the receptor binding sites. Regions and cleavage site in HA1 and antigenic regions in both HA1 and NA segments. Significantly, a unique two-amino acid addition to the NA stem was found. Experimental infection of BALB/c mice revealed that viral RNA could be detected in major rodent organs such as brain, heart, spleen, kidney, liver, and intestine, as well as in the lung. All organs from infected mice showed significant lesions and viral antigen staining. This study highlights the potential of domesticated animals as a reservoir for influenza virus and the need for surveillance programs to detect interspecies transmission. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Lin, Y.;Zhao, Y.;Zeng, X.;Lu, C.;Liu, Y.

title: Detection and characterization of viruses that cause hand, foot, and mouth disease from children in Seri Kembangan, Malaysia.
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral infection among infants and children. The main causative agents of HFMD are enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CVA16). Coxsackievirus A6 (CVA6) infections have recently been reported in neighboring countries. Infected infants and children may present with fever, mouth/throat ulcers, redness of the hands and feet, and vesicles. In addition, EV71 infections can cause fatal neurological complications. Since 1997, EV71 has caused fatalities in Sarawak and Peninsular Malaysia. The aim of this study was to identify and classify viruses detected from patients presenting clinical signs and symptoms of HFMD in Seri Kembangan, Malaysia. From December 2012 to July 2013, a total of 28 samples were collected from patients with clinical case definitions of HFMD. HFMD viruses were detected using semi-nested reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (snRT-PCR). Positive snRT-PCR products were sequenced and phylogenetic analyzes of viruses were performed. Of the 28 samples, 12 (42.9%) were positive on snRT-PCR, seven were CVA6 (58.3%), two were CVA16 (16.7%), and three were EV71 (25%). Based on phylogenetic analysis studies, EV71 strains were identified as subgenotype B5; CVA16 strains classified as sub-genotypes B2b and B2c; CVA6 strains are closely related to strains from Taiwan and Japan. In this study, HFMD in Serial Kembangan was caused by different Enterovirus types, EV71, CVA6 and CVA16.
authors: Ling, B. P.;Jalilian, F. A.;Harmal, N. S.;Yubbu, P.;Sekawi, Z.

title: Hypothesis on source, transmission and characteristics of infection by avian influenza A (H7N9) virus - based on field epidemiological research analysis and gene sequence analysis
abstract: Summary: On March 31, 2013, the National Health and Family Planning Commission announced that human infections with influenza A (H7N9) virus have occurred in Shanghai and Anhui provinces of China. H7N9 cases were later detected in Jiangsu and Zhejiang provinces. It is estimated that the virus first spread to the north along the route followed by migratory birds, and then spread to neighboring provinces with the sale of poultry. Epidemiological studies have been carried out on samples taken from the external environment of infected cases, routes of transmission, farmers' markets and live poultry markets. Phylogenetic study of viral sequences from human and avian infections in Zhejiang showed that those from Shanghai and Jiangsu provinces along Taihu Lake were highly homologous with those from the external environment. This suggests that avian viruses carried by waterfowl combine with virus carried by migratory birds, giving rise to the avian influenza virus H7N9, which is highly pathogenic to humans. It is possible for the virus to be transmitted to domestic poultry and then to humans through local wild birds, or further spread through trade in wholesale poultry markets. The epidemic in the first half of the year was brought under control with the measures taken to warm up the weather, end the poultry trade and facilitate health communication. However, the source of infection in the triangle area around Lake Taihu still remains. The H7N9 outbreak will likely hit the area later and next spring when migratory birds return, and may even spread to other areas. Therefore, great attention should be paid to wild birds in Lake Taihu as the reservoir and spreader of the virus: research and study of this population is essential.
authors: Ling, F.;Chen, E.;Liu, Q.;Miao, Z.;Gong, Z.

title: Turkey rhinotracheitis virus: in vivo and in vitro polypeptide synthesis
abstract: Turkey rhinotracheitis (TRT) virus is a paramyxovirus associated with recent outbreaks of acute respiratory disease in turkeys. Morphological criteria resemble pneumoviruses more than other members of the paramyxovirus family. In this communication, we report the identification of five virus-derived polypeptides in TRT virus-infected BS-C-1 cells. The Mr of these polypeptides was estimated from their electrophoretic mobilities in SDS-polyacrylamide 6% to 15% gradient gels as 38K, 35K, 30K, 19K and 15K. The virus specificity of four of these five individuals (38K, 35K, 30K, and 19K Mr polypeptides) was confirmed by their dominance as products of in vitro translation of mRNA from TRT virus-infected BS-C-1 cells. An additional virus-specific polypeptide with predicted Bay 22K was revealed by in vitro translation and may be a non-structural polypeptide or a small structural protein. All six polypeptides were immunoprecipitated with a murine antiserum. Three other polypeptides (129K, 57K and 45K) were also immunoprecipitated. The 57K, 45K, and 15K Mr polypeptides are glycosylated, and the 57K glycopolypeptide may be a disulfide-linked dimer of the 45K and 15K glycopolypeptides. Another major glycopolypeptide of 83K Mr was observed, but virus specificity could not be confirmed. Taken together, our results tentatively identify eight or nine TRT virus-specific polypeptides and are consistent with the classification of TRT virus as a novel member of the Pneumovirus genus.
authors: Ling, R.;Pringle, C. R.

title: Viral metagenomics reveals important viruses in genital tract of apparently healthy dairy cows
abstract: Virome was characterized in genital tract secretion samples collected from 80 dairy cattle in Shanghai, China. Among the viruses detected were members of the families Papillomaviridae, Polyomaviridae, Hepeviridae, Parvoviridae, Astroviridae, Picornaviridae and Picobirnaviridae. The viral genome of a member of a new species within the genus Dyoxipapillomavirus and six circular Rep-encoding single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) (CRESS-DNA) was fully sequenced and phylogenetically analyzed. The prevalence of bovine polyomaviruses 1 and 2 was measured by PCR as 10% (8/80) and 6.25% (5/80), respectively. PCR scanning also showed that the novel papillomavirus ujs-21015 and bovine herpesvirus 6 were present in three and two of the 80 samples.
authors: Ling, Y.;Zhang, X.;Qi, G.;Yang, S.;Jingjiao, L.;Shen, Q.;Wang, X.;Cui, L.;Hua, X.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.;Zhang, W.

title: Fecal viroma of children with hand, foot, and mouth disease who test negative by PCR for pathogenic enteroviruses
abstract: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) affects infants and young children. A viral metagenomic approach was used to identify eukaryotic viruses in stool samples from 29 Thai children with a clinical diagnosis of HFMD collected during the 2012 outbreak. These children had previously tested negative for enterovirus 71 and coxsackieviruses A16 and A6 by PCR. Deep sequencing revealed nine virus families: Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Parvoviridae, Caliciviridae, Paramyxoviridae, Adenoviridae, Reoviridae, Picobirnaviridae, and Polyomaviridae. The highest number of viral sequences belonged to human rhinovirus C, astrovirus-MLB2 and coxsackievirus A21.
