Our study provides an overview of the virus community and highlights the wide variety of viruses found in the stool of children with HFMD. Copyright:
authors: Linsuwanon, P.;Poovorawan, Y.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Vongpunsawad, S.;Delwart, E.

title: Influenza (H5N1) viruses in poultry, Russian Federation, 2005-2006
abstract: We studied 7 influenza (H5N1) viruses isolated from poultry in Western Siberia and the European part of the Russian Federation during the period July 2005-February 2006. Whole genome sequences showed high homology to Qinghai-like influenza (H5N1) viruses. Phylogenetic analysis not only showed a close genetic relationship between H5N1 strains isolated from poultry and wild migratory waterfowl, but also suggested genetic reclassification among the analyzed isolates. Analysis of the deduced amino acid sequences of the M2 and neuraminidase proteins showed that all isolates were potentially susceptible to currently available antiviral drugs. Pathogenicity testing showed that all viruses studied were highly pathogenic in chickens; Pathogenicity was heterogeneous for 3 isolates tested in mice and 2 isolates tested in ferrets. Pathogenicity in mammalian models was generally associated with Lys at residue 627 of polymerase basic protein 2.
authors: Lipatov, A. S.;Evseenko, V. A.;Yen, H. L.;Zaykovskaya, A. V.;Durimanov, A. G.;Zolotykh, S. I.;Netesov, S. V.;Drozdov, I. G.;Onishchenko, G. G.;Webster, R. G.;Shestopalov, A. M.

title: Viral surveillance and discovery
abstract: The field of virus discovery has sprung up with the emergence of high-throughput sequencing platforms and bioinformatics programs that enable rapid identification and molecular characterization of known and novel agents, global investments in microbial surveillance, and their recognition, involving humans as well as wildlife and pets. Viruses can play a role in chronic as well as acute illness. Here we review methods of viral surveillance and discovery, strategies and pitfalls in linking discovery to disease, and identify opportunities for improvement in sequencing instrumentation and analysis, use of social media and medical informatics that will further advance clinical medicine and public health. Â© 2013 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Lipkin, W. I.;Firth, C.

title: Genetic characterization and mutation analysis of Qihe547 Aujeszky disease virus in China
abstract: Background: Aujeszky disease virus (ADV) can cause neurological disease in young pigs, respiratory disease in aged pigs, and miscarriage or delivery of mummified fetuses or stillborn newborns. The reemergence of Aujeszky disease (AD) in pig farms vaccinated with live vaccine (Bartha-K61) has caused significant economic losses to the Chinese pig industry since late 2011. A field ADV named Qihe547 was isolated from pigs with suspected AD clinical presentation. symptoms. To better understand the genetic characteristics and mutations of Qihe547 ADV, the whole genome was sequenced and analyzed. Results: The genomic length of Qihe547 ADV was 143,404 bp with a G+C content of 73.59%. Phylogenetic analysis based on the entire genome of the ADV strains revealed that the Chinese ADV strains were placed in a three-subgroup group. Qihe547 ADV was closely related to these new ADV strains isolated in China since 2012. Qihe547 presented multiple hypervariable regions compared to overseas ADV strains. Amino acid (AA) insertion or deletion was observed in 34 genes of Qihe547 ADV. In addition, multiple AA mutations were found in major protective antigen genes (gB, gC and gD genes). Differences of potential antigenic peptides in major protective antigens between Qihe547 ADV and ADV Bartha were discovered in the dominant antigenic regions of gB (AA59-AA126, AA507-AA734), the extracellular region of gC and gD. Conclusion: High diversity was observed between Qihe547 and foreign ADV isolates. AA variations in key functional regions of the major protective antigen (gB, gC, and gD) of ADV Qihe547 and differences in potential antigenic peptides may contribute to virus immunity and may be a partial reason for virus evasion. Bartha-K61 vaccine. In a word, the effect of variations clearly requires further research.
authors: Liu, C.;Liu, Y.;Tian, Y.;Wei, X.;Zhang, Y.;Tian, F.

title: First report of feline bocavirus associated with severe feline enteritis in northeastern China, 2015
abstract: Feline bocavirus (FBoV) is a newly identified bocavirus of cats in the Parvoviridae family. A new FBoV HRB2015-LDF was first detected from cat with severe enteritis in Northeast China, with an overall positive rate of 2.78% (1/36). Phylogenetic and homologous analysis of the whole genome showed that FBoV HRB2015-LDF clustered in the FBoV branch and was closely related to other FBoVs with 68.7-97.5% identity. And the VP1, NPA, and NS1 genes shared 70.7-97.6%, 72.4-98.6%, and 67.2-98.0% nucleotide identities with other FBoVs, respectively. The results showed that FBoVs can be split into two distinct lineages and the difference in nucleotide identities between lineages is >20-30%.
authors: Liu, C. G.;Liu, F.;Li, Z. G.;Qu, L. D.;Liu, D. F.

title: Multiple reassortant H5N5 avian influenza viruses in ducks, China, 2008
abstract: Three highly pathogenic H5N5 avian influenza viruses (HPAI), A/duck/Guangdong/wy11/2008 (WY11), A/duck/Guangdong/wy19/2008 (WY19) and A/duck/Guangdong/wy24/2008 (WY24) It was isolated from ducks in southern China in April 2008. Here, we characterized these viruses by performing sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes of their viral genes, assessing their virulence in ducks and mice, and performing cross-protection experiments in chickens. Sequence analysis showed that the HA genes of these H5N5 viruses showed 97.1-97.8% homology to the A/wild duck/Hunan/211/2005 (H5N1) influenza virus and the NA genes of the A/duck/Hunan/5613/2003 (H6N5) influenza virus belonging to the Eurasian lineage. . Genotypic analysis showed that these H5N5 viruses are multiple reassociators between H5N1, H5N2, H6N2 and H6N5 viruses. Analysis of the HA sequence showed that these H5N5 viruses clustered in section 2.3.4. In animal experiments, these H5N5 viruses caused 50% mortality in ducks and 100% in chickens. In cross-protection experiments, the clade 2.3.2 avian influenza vaccine could only provide 75% protection against the H5N5 virus challenge in chickens. Furthermore, the H5N5 virus replicated efficiently in the lungs of mice, indicating that H5N5 viruses have the potential to infect mammalian hosts. Because ducks serve as reassortant vessels by playing important roles in the formation of new subtypes of influenza viruses, it is important to monitor the emergence of this new subtype of influenza viruses in waterfowl to understand their ecology and evolution and to control the spread of new influenza viruses. viruses. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Liu, C. G.;Liu, M.;Liu, F.;Lv, R.;Liu, D. F.;Qu, L. D.;Zhang, Y.

title: Development of a reverse genetic system for small ruminant morbillivirus: rescue of recombinant virus to express Echinococcus granulosus EG95 antigen.
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants and cystic hydatidosis may be simultaneously endemic in a particular region. Its pathogens are small ruminant morbillivirus (SRMV) and Echinococcus granulosus (E. granulosus), respectively. Formerly called peste-des-petits-ruminants virus (PPRV), SRMV is classified in the genus Morbillivirus in the family Paramyxoviridae. This virus is an ideal vaccine vector for delivering immunogenic proteins. In this study, a reverse genetic system was developed to rescue a recombinant SRMV (Nigeria 75/1 strain) expressing the E. granulosus EG95 antigen in vitro. Although recombinant SRMV replicates more slowly than its parent virus, it can effectively express the EG95 antigen in cells by Western blot, indirect immunofluorescence and mass spectrometry analyses. An EG95 subunit vaccine is widely used for the prevention of cystic hydatidosis in parts of China. If SRMV expressing EG95 is proven to induce effective immune responses against both diseases in a future animal experiment, it would be a potential bivalent vaccine candidate.
authors: Liu, F.;Li, L.;Liu, Y.;Sun, C.;Liu, C.;Wu, X.;Wang, Z.

title: Rescue of eGFP-expressing small ruminant morbillivirus to determine their susceptibility to infection of eight mammalian cell lines.
abstract: Small ruminant morbillivirus (SRMV), formerly called peste-des-petits-ruminants virus (PPRV), is classified in the genus Morbillivirus in the family Paramyxoviridae. If genetically modified using reverse genetics, SRMV would be a useful vector for expressing foreign proteins in vitro and in vivo. In this study, a recombinant SRMV was rescued by reverse genetics to efficiently express an enhanced green fluorescent protein (eGFP) in vitro. Based on the green fluorescence traced properties of recombinant SRMV, eight mammalian cell lines (BHK-21, F81, MDBK, RK13, MDCK, PK15, Vero and GT) were selected to determine their susceptibility to SRMV infection. The result showed that all cell lines could be infected with recombinant SRMV but with different efficiencies. Vero and PK15 cell lines showed the highest and lowest susceptibility to infection, respectively, if only comparing the proportions of cells emitting green fluorescence among eight cell monolayers.
authors: Liu, F.;Zhang, Y.;Li, L.;Zuo, Y.;Sun, C.;Xiaodong, W.;Wang, Z.

title: Identification and analysis of novel viral and host dysregulated MicroRNAs in variant pseudorabies virus-infected PK15 cells
abstract: Pseudorabies (PR) are one of the most devastating diseases in the pig industry. To identify changes in microRNA(miRNA) expression and post-transcriptional regulatory responses to PRV infection in porcine kidney epithelial (PK15) cells, we sequenced a small RNA (sRNA) library prepared from infected PK15 cells and compared it to a library prepared from uninfected ones. Cells using Illumina deep sequencing. Here we found 25 novel viral miRNAs by high-throughput sequencing, and 20 of these miRNAs were validated by stem loop RT-qPCR. Surprisingly, unlike the usual miRNAs encoded by Î±-herpes viruses that are clustered in the large delay transcript (LLT), these new viral miRNAs are throughout the PRV genome, such as Î²-herpes viruses. Viral miRNAs are predicted to target multiple genes and form a complex regulatory network. GO analysis of viral miRNAs on their host targets was involved in complex cellular processes including metabolic pathway, bioregulation, stimulus response, signaling process and immune response. Moreover, 13 host miRNAs were expressed after infection with PRV with a significant difference: 8 miRNAs were up-regulated and 5 miRNAs were down-regulated, which could affect viral replication in the host cell. Our results provided new insight into the properties of miRNAs in response to PRV infection, which is important for further investigation of the function of these miRNAs.
authors: Liu, F.;Zheng, H.;Tong, W.;Li, G. X.;Tian, Q.;Liang, C.;Li, L. W.;Zheng, X. C.;Tong, G. Z.

title: Genetic diversity of the VP1 gene of duck hepatitis virus type I (DHV-I) isolates from southeast China is related to isolate attenuation.
abstract: The complete sequence of a Duck hepatitis virus I (DHV-I) isolate (ZJ-V) originally from the field in southeast China was determined. It was 7691 nucleotides long and had 5”² and 3” terminal noncoding regions of 626 and 315 nucleotides, respectively. The poly(A) tail contained at least 22 residues and the single open reading frame encoded a 2249 amino acid polypeptide. The VP1 gene was also sequenced from nine southeast China field isolates and three attenuated DHV-I vaccine strains. In phylogenetic analysis of isolates and other published sequences, attenuated and tissue-adapted isolates (including ZJ-V) clustered as genotypes that differed significantly from unpassaged field isolates in chicken/duck embryos. There were two consistent amino acid substitutions (E129 - V129 and A142 - S142) between all domain isolates and all tissue adapted. The carboxyl terminal region was generally the most variable, with six consistent differences from the four attenuated Chinese isolates field isolates (S181 â†' L181, H183K184 â†' R183G1841, N193 â†' D193, E205 â†' K205, R217 â†' K217, N235 â†' D235). It seems likely that at least some of these differences are due to isolated attenuation-inducing mutations. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, G.;Wang, F.;Ni, Z.;Yun, T.;Yu, B.;Huang, J.;Chen, J.

title: Complete genomic sequence of a Chinese isolate of duck hepatitis virus
abstract: The complete genomic sequence of the Duck hepatitis virus 1 (DHV-1) ZJ-V isolate was sequenced and determined to have a 5â€²-terminal untranslated region (UTR) of 626 nt and 7 691 nucleotides (nt) long, with a 3â€²- terminal UTR (not including poly(A) tail). A large open reading frame (ORF) was found within the genome (nt 627 to 7 373) encoding a 2 249 amino acid polypeptide. Our data also showed that the poly(A) tail of DHV-1 has at least 22 A. Sequence comparison revealed significant homology (from 91.9% to 95.7%) between the protein sequences of the ZJ-V isolate and the protein sequences of 21 reference isolates. Although DHV-1 is classified as an unassigned virus in the Picornaviridae family, its genome has shown some unique features. DHV-1 contains 3 copies of the 2A gene and only 1 copy of the 3D gene, and its 3â€²-NCR is longer than that of other picornaviruses. Phylogenetic analysis to perform sequence homology based on VP1 protein sequences showed that ZJ-V isolate shares high sequence similarity with reported DHV-1 isolates (from 92.9% to 99.2%), indicating that DHV-1 is genetically stable.
authors: Liu, G. Q.;Wang, F.;Ni, Z.;Yun, T.;Yu, B.;Huang, J. G.;Chen, J. P.

title: Genomic characterization of first-class I Newcastle disease virus isolated from mainland China.
abstract: The complete genomic sequence of the Newcastle disease virus (NDV) NDV08-004 strain isolated from domestic ducks in China was determined in this study. The genome is 15198 nucleotides (nt) long, follows the "rule of six", and contains 55 nt leader sequences at the 3–² end and 114 nt fragment sequences at the 5–² end. Compared with the whole genome sequences of class II NDV strains, isolate NDV08-004 has a 12-nt insertion (TGGGGA GACGGGG) in the phosphoprotein gene between nucleotides 2381 and 2382 of the genome (numbered according to the genomic sequence of La Sota). strain consisting of 15186 nt). The NDV08-004 strain has the 112E-QQER-L117 motif at the cleavage site of the fusion protein typical for lentogenic NDV strains, which is consistent with the results of pathogenic tests based on the mean time to death (MDT) and intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI). Whole genome-based phylogenetic analysis revealed that all NDV strains studied could be divided into two different clades, class I and class II, and the NDV08-004 isolate characterized in this study was grouped in class I. A 374-bp fragment of the F gene in class I strains of NDV indicated that NDV08-004 belongs to genotype 3 and should therefore be similar to strains obtained from live bird markets in Hong Kong in recent years. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2010.
authors: Liu, H.;Chen, F.;Zhao, Y.;Zheng, D.;Li, J.;Xu, T.;Qi, L.;Wang, Z.

title: Isolation and molecular and phylogenetic analyzes of encephalomyocarditis virus from wild boar in central China.
abstract: Encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) can infect many host species and cause acute myocarditis and respiratory failure in piglets and reproductive failure in pregnant sows. In this study, an EMCV strain designated JZ1202 was isolated from semi-captive wild boars presenting with acute myocarditis and sudden death in central China. Hemagglutination inhibition (HI) assay was identified by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and genome sequencing. Subsequent results showed that the virus could produce a specific cytopathic effect on BCC cells and cause clinical symptoms and pathological changes in mice. Whole genome sequencing and multiple sequence alignment showed strain JZ1202 to be 81.3%-99.9% identical to other isolates worldwide. Phylogenetic analysis of the whole genome, ORF, VP3/VP1 and 3D genes using the neighbor splicing method revealed that isolate JZ1202 grouped in lineage 1. The results of this study provided new epidemiological data on EMCV in China and lethality to mice of an EMCV strain JZ 1202 isolated from wild boar in Central China.
authors: Liu, H.;He, X.;Song, X.;Xu, L.;Zhang, Y.;Zhou, G.;Zhu, W.;Chang, C.;Yin, Z.;Shi, Y.;Wang, C.;Chang, H.

title: Complete genome sequences and phylogenetic analysis of porcine and rat encephalomyocarditis virus strains
abstract: To assess the genetic variability of encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV), the whole genomes of six EMCV domain isolates of pig and rat origin from different regions of central China were analyzed phylogenetically and comparatively. Phylogenetic analysis of whole genome sequences using open reading frame (ORF), capsid coding region (CCR), and neighbor-joining analysis of VP3/VP1 revealed that these isolates belong to lineage 1. The nucleotide sequences of the six isolates showed greater than 99% double identity. ratios and sequences of isolates from pigs and pigs from the same region were exactly the same, without any genetic deletion or insertion. From the comparative analysis of the variability of each EMCV protein coding region, the 3D and VP3 regions showed the highest average identity ratios and were confirmed as highly conserved. In contrast, protein coding regions 3A and 3B were confirmed to be the highly variable region with the lowest average identity ratio. Our data confirmed that EMCV strains isolated from pigs and rats have high homology with each other; this implied that rats may play an important role in EMCV transmission between domestic pigs and wild boars.
authors: Liu, H.;Li, Y.;Zhang, G.;Sang, S.;Wang, C.;Chang, H.

title: Japanese encephalitis virus in mosquitoes and pigs 2009-2010 in Yunnan province, China
authors: Liu, H.;Lu, H. J.;Liu, Z. J.;Jing, J.;Ren, J. Q.;Liu, Y. Y.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolated from waterfowl in China
abstract: Ten representative Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates from outbreaks in waterfowl (geese and ducks) in China since 1997 were characterized both pathotypically and genotypically. The mean time to death and the intracerebral pathogenicity index were used to evaluate the virulence of the isolates. Pathogenicity tests showed that all 10 isolates were velogenic strains. The main functional region of the F gene, consisting of 535 nucleotides, was amplified and sequenced by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction. The deduced amino acid sequence of the fusion protein cleavage site in all 10 isolates was 112RRQKRF117, which is a typical velogenic strain sequence and is consistent with the results of in vivo pathogenicity tests. For genotyping, a phylogenetic tree was constructed based on nucleotides 47-435 of the F gene. Phylogenetic analysis showed that most of the isolates belonged to genotype VII virus. Only one strain, WG, was found to be genotype IX virus. This strain was closest to F48E9, which was isolated in China in 1946 and used as a standard challenge strain in vaccine evaluation in China. Therefore, genotype IX virus still causes sporadic infections in geese in China. Further phylogenetic analyzes on the genotype VII strains found that all these strains could be divided into 5 subgenotypes and most of the isolates (8 strains) were classified as VIId, a dominant genotype responsible for most of the Newcastle disease (ND) outbreaks since its end. last century in China. Only 1 strain, NDV03-053, has been shown to be genotype VIIc virus. The results show that strains of the VIId NDV genotype are the main pathogen responsible for most epizootic ND outbreaks in waterfowl in China since 1997.
authors: Liu, H.;Wang, Z.;Wang, Y.;Sun, C.;Zheng, D.;Wu, Y.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis of novel Newcastle disease virus isolates from mainland China.
abstract: Seventy-nine velogenic Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates were obtained from infected chicken flocks during Newcastle disease (ND) outbreaks in various parts of mainland China in 2006. The F gene fragment (535 bp, nt 47 to 581) of the F gene encoding the major functional region of the F protein) was obtained by RT-PCR and sequenced. All sequences obtained in this study have been submitted to GenBank. All isolates have the 112R-RQ/RK/RR-F117 motif at the cleavage site of the fusion protein, which is typical of velogenic NDV isolates. For genotyping, a phylogenetic tree based on nucleotides 47-435 of the F gene was constructed and 79 isolates could be divided into two genotypes, VIId and III. Most of the isolates proved to be genotype VIId; only two isolates were genotype III. Genotype VIId NDV has been the predominant pathogen responsible for most of the Newcastle disease outbreaks in China. According to studies on the molecular epidemiology of NDV in China from 2002 to 2006, the proportion of genotype VIId NDV isolates shows an increasing trend. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, H.;Wang, Z.;Wu, Y.;Wu, Y.;Sun, C.;Zheng, D.;Xu, T.;Li, J.

title: Molecular epidemiological analysis of Newcastle disease virus isolated in China in 2005.
abstract: Eighty-three Newcastle disease virus (NDV) strains were obtained from outbreaks in chickens, pigeons, geese and ducks in China in 2005 and were genotypically characterized. The major functional region of the F gene (535 nucleotides) was amplified and sequenced. A phylogenetic tree based on nucleotides 47-435 of the F gene was constructed using sequences from 83 isolates and representative NDV sequences from GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all newly characterized strains belonged to six genetic groups: I, II, III, VIb, VIIc and VIId. All isolates from Groups I and II (14 in total) were lentogenic to the amino acid sequences of the fusion protein cleavage site and were V4 or LaSota type depending on the vaccines used. Most of the isolates (64 in total) were classified in group VIId, a dominant genotype responsible for most of the Newcastle disease outbreaks since the end of the last century. One strain, NDV05-055, was in group VIIc, three pigeon strains were in group VIb and one isolate, NDV05-041, was in group III and was characterized as a velogenic strain. This study revealed that genotype VIId is the main NDV strain responsible for the 2005 ND epizoonosis that occurred in China. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, H.;Wang, Z.;Wu, Y.;Zheng, D.;Sun, C.;Bi, D.;Zuo, Y.;Xu, T.

title: Phylogenetic characterization and virulence of two Newcastle disease viruses isolated from wild birds in China.
abstract: Wild birds are considered a natural reservoir of the Newcastle disease virus (NDV). However, there is no information on genotype IX NDV from wild birds, especially Columbiformes. In this study, two genotype IX NDV viruses were isolated from wild birds. One was from the Eurasian Blackbird, the other from the Spotted-necked pigeon. After purification by the plaque technique, the complete genomes of both viruses were sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis of the partial fusion (F) gene and the whole genome showed that both strains belonged to genotype IX. According to the intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI), the virus from the Eurasian Blackbird was velogenic virus, while the Spotted-necked pigeon strain was lentogenic virus. However, both strains showed one of the velogenic cleavage sites. In addition, the strain from the Eurasian Blackbird showed greater replication ability and produced larger fusion foci in vitro than the strain from the Spotted-necked pigeon. When all corresponding protein sequences of both strains were compared, there were only 9 different amino acid residues between them. Also, after the analysis of these differences, information about the multi-basic cleavage site and lentogenic NDV is presented.
authors: Liu, H.;Zhang, P.;Wu, P.;Chen, S.;Mu, G.;Duan, X.;Hao, H.;Du, E.;Wang, X.;Yang, Z.

title: Rapid characterization of avian reoviruses using phylogenetic analysis, reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction and restriction enzyme fragment length polymorphism
abstract: reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction has been described that amplifies the full-length sigmaC-encoding and sigmaNS-encoding genes of avian reovirus (ARV). DNA fragments of 1022 and 1152 base pairs, respectively, were amplified among ARV isolates, indicating no significant deletions or insertions in these regions. Fragments amplified from vaccine strains and field isolates were digested with five different restriction enzymes, Bcn I, Hae III, Taq I, Dde I and Hinc II, respectively. Restriction fragment profiles observed on polyacrylamide gels showed heterogeneity between vaccine and Taiwan isolates. All tested ARV isolates showed distinct restriction enzyme degradation patterns and were clearly distinguishable. Strain typing based on cleavage sites in the sigmaC-encoding gene of ARV showed that viruses can be classified into four different groups. A phylogenetic tree based on the nucleotide sequences of the gene encoding SigmaC revealed that Taiwanese ARV isolates were classified into four distinct groups; this indicates that genotyping is consistent with typing based on restriction enzyme fragment length polymorphism of the sigmaC encoding gene of ARV. The results suggested that restriction enzyme analysis following polymerase chain reaction provides a simple and rapid approach for the characterization of ARV isolates. It is also possible to determine whether a new variant strain has been introduced into a flock or whether a particular virus strain has spread from one flock to another.
authors: Liu, H. J.;Lee, L. H.;Shih, W. L.;Li, Y. J.;Su, H. Y.

title: Complete genome sequence of goose parvovirus Y strain isolated from Muscovy ducks in China.
abstract: goose parvovirus (GPV) Y strain was isolated from Muscovy ducks in Anhui Province, China. The complete genomic sequence consisting of 444-bp reverse terminal repeat, 1,844-bp non-structural protein and 2,199-bp capsid protein (VP) regions was found to be 5,106 bp in length by polymerase chain reaction method. Its sequence was then aligned with the GPV and Muscovy duck parvovirus sequences published in GenBank using the neighbor-joining method. Phylogenetic analyzes based on the VP3 gene sequences revealed that the GPV Y strain together with those from Taiwan belonged to subgroup IIb, other GPV strains from Muscovy ducks clustered into subgroup Ib and most of the other GPV strains isolated from mainland China. In subgroup IIa. The absence of the 703-705NRT glycosylation site deduced in the VP region may explain the host specificity of the GPV Y strain. The complete genomic sequence of the GPV Y strain from Muscovy ducks will help to understand the molecular and evolutionary features of GPV. Â© Springer Science+Business Media 2013.
authors: Liu, H. M.;Wang, H.;Tian, X. J.;Zhang, S.;Zhou, X. H.;Qi, K. Z.;Pan, L.

title: Construction of phylogenetic tree and sequence analysis on the BDV p24 gene in both livestock and hosts in Ningxia
authors: Liu, J.;Liu, Y.;Wang, Z. H.;Xie, P.

title: Interregional transmission of internal protein genes of H2 influenza virus in migratory ducks from North America to Eurasia.
abstract: The H2 influenza virus caused a pandemic in 1957 and is likely to cause epidemics in the future. To evaluate the evolutionary characteristics of H2 influenza viruses isolated from migratory ducks collected on migratory flights from Siberia in Hokkaido, Japan in 2001, we investigated the phylogenetic relationships between these viruses and the avian and human viruses previously described. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the PB2 gene (H2N3) of Dk/Hokkaido/107/01 and the PA gene of Dk/Hokkaido/95/01 (H2N2) belonged to the American lineage of the avian virus and other genes of the isolates. Eurasian ancestry. These results suggest that internal protein genes can be transferred from the Americas to the Eurasian avian host. Thus, the occurrence of interregional influenza virus transmission between North American and Eurasian birds has also been confirmed. The fact that reassortants can be produced in migratory ducks between the North American and Eurasian avian virus lineage further highlights the importance of global surveillance among migratory ducks.
authors: Liu, J.;Okazaki, K.;Bai, G.;Shi, W.;Mweene, A.;Kida, H.

title: Recombination of swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses in lineages 1, 3, 5 and 8 in China.
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) is one of the most important viral swine diseases that cause huge economic losses in the Chinese pig industry. Currently, four major strains: strain 1 (NADC30-like), 3 (QYYZ-like), 5.1 (VR2332-like) and 8.7 (JXA1-like) type 2 PRRSV (North American type) circulate in China. classification system that raises concerns about virus recombination potential. In this study, a novel PRRSV strain variant named FJLIUY-2017 was isolated from the abortion rate (25%) in pregnant gilts in Fujian Province, China in 2017. FJLIUY-2017. Comparison with PRRS sequences in GenBank confirmed the absence of close relatives (<92%), but indicated that FJLIUY-2017 belonged to the NADC30-like PRRSV. The full length of FJLIUY-2017 was determined to be 15017 nucleotides (nt), excluding the poly(A) tail, shared 86.2%-86.6% identity with JXA1-like strains (JXA1, TJ, and FJYR), 88.9%-NADC30 90.6% with similar PRRSVs (NADC30, FJZ03 and CHsx1401), 86.4%-86.5% with VR2332-like (VR2332, RespPRRS MLV and BJ-4) and only 60% with LV (European type), 8. Recombination analyzes revealed genomic breakpoints in structural (ORF3, ORF4 and ORF7) and non-structural (Nsp1, Nsp2, Nsp6, Nsp9, Nsp11 and Nsp12) regions of the genomes and evidence of recombination events between lineages 1, 3, 5.1 and 8.7. Taken together, the results of our study provide further confirmation that PRRSV is prone to undergo recombination events. Therefore, it is very important to monitor the development of PRRSV in China and to establish an effective strategy for the control of PRRS.
authors: Liu, J.;Wei, C.;Lin, Z.;Fan, J.;Xia, W.;Dai, A.;Yang, X.

title: Genetic characterization of VP4-VP2 of two coxsackieviruses A4 isolated from patients with hand, foot, and mouth disease.
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To examine the genetic characteristics of VP4-VP2 of Coxsackievirus A4 (CVA4) isolated from clinical specimens of patients with hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in Gansu in 2008. METHODS: Two clinical specimens were collected from outpatient HFMD patients. Viral isolation was performed by inoculation of RD cells and then serval. The VP4-VP2 region of the two viral isolates was amplified using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction methods, and then the PCR products were sequenced; Molecular typing was used to determine the serotype of these two viral isolates. Finally, a phylogenetic tree was constructed between these two Gansu viral isolates and 16 CVA4 strains downloaded from the GenBank database. RESULTS: Two Viruses were isolated by inoculating RD cells from clinical specimens from two HFMD patients and identified as CVA4 using molecular typing methods. The homology of nucleotide sequences in the VP4-VP2 region between the two Gansu CVA4 strains was 94.6% and the homology of amino acid sequences was 100%. Compared to the prototype strain of CVA4 (Strain High Point/USA/1948), the homology of nucleotide sequences and amino acid sequences was 85.5%-85.8% and 99.3%, respectively. It revealed that two Gansu CVA4 strains were present in the independence group. CONCLUSION: Compared with the CVA4 strains isolated from Japan and Mongolia downloaded from the GenBank database, the two Gansu CVA4s were found to have major differences on the VP4-VP2 region, and phylogenetic analysis revealed that they belonged to an independent evolutionary lineage.
authors: Liu, J. F.;Zhang, Y.;Li, H.

title: Phylogenetic Analysis of Hemagglutinin and Neuraminidase Genes of H9N2 Viruses Isolated from Migratory Ducks
abstract: Genetic analysis showed that pandemic influenza strains derived from wild waterfowl harbor viruses of 15 hemagglutinin (HA) and 9 neuraminidase (NA) antigenic subtypes. Surveillance studies have shown that H9N2 subtype viruses are found in domestic poultry worldwide and can infect mammalian species, including humans. Here, we genetically analyzed the HA and NA genes of five H9N2 viruses isolated from migratory ducks in Hokkaido, Japan, the migration route from Siberia between 1997 and 2000. The results showed that the HA and NA genes of these viruses belonged to the same lineage, respectively. Compared with A/quail/Hong Kong/G1/97-like and A/duck/Hong Kong/Y280/97-like viruses, HA and NA of migratory duck isolates had a close association with that of isolated H9N2 viruses. Chicken in Korea indicates that Korean H9N2 viruses may have been derived from migratory ducks. The NA genes of the five isolates were in the same cluster as those of the N2 viruses that caused a human pandemic in 1968; this suggests that the NA genes of previous pandemic strains are still circulating in waterfowl reservoirs. The present results further highlight the importance of conducting molecular epidemiological surveillance of H9N2 viruses in wild ducks to gain further information in preparation for future human influenza pandemics.
authors: Liu, J. H.;Okazaki, K.;Shi, W. M.;Kida, H.

title: Identification of a novel bufavirus in domestic pigs by a viral metagenomic approach
abstract: Bufavirus is a single-stranded DNA virus belonging to the genus Protoparvovirus. This study reports the identification and characterization of a porcine bufavirus using a metagenomic approach and a limited epidemiological investigation of bufavirus in six pig farms. A comparative genome analysis showed 93% similarity to Hungarian porcine bufavirus. Bayesian and maximum likelihood analyzes of genome sequences showed a close association of porcine bufaviruses with human and monkey bufaviruses. Molecular dating of the most recent common ancestors supported the recent introduction of bufaviruses into human and pig populations, respectively. A real-time PCR method was developed to screen 60 stool samples for porcine bufavirus DNA, and eight positive samples were found in two neighboring farms, indicating a relatively low prevalence (13.3%). No direct transmission of swine bufaviruses was found between the two neighboring farms, suggesting that bufaviruses may have spread widely in different geographic areas.
authors: Liu, L.;Schwarz, L.;Ullman, K.;Ahola, H.;Qiu, Y.;Ma, Z.;Hennig-Pauka, I.

title: Phylogeny, classification, and evolutionary insights into pestiviruses
abstract: The genus Pestivirus consists of four established species: Bovine viral diarrhea viruses 1 (BVDV-1) and 2 (BVDV-2), Border disease virus (BDV) and Classical swine fever virus (CSFV); and a transient species, the giraffe Pestivirus. Additional pestiviruses have been identified and proposed to be recognized as new subgroups/species. To arrive at a reliable phylogeny as the basis for classification of pestiviruses, a molecular dataset of 56 pestiviruses and 2089 characters containing the 5-UTR, complete Npro and E2 gene regions was analyzed by Maximum likelihood and Bayesian approach. An identical, robust tree topology was deduced, where seven well-supported monophyletic branches and two quite distinct lineages were identified. Dating to the most recent common ancestor for major pestivirus lineages was estimated and their evolutionary history revealed. Accordingly, a new proposal is presented for the classification of pestiviruses into nine species: BVDV-1, BVDV-2, BVDV-3 (atypical bovine pestiviruses), giraffe Pestivirus, CSFV, BDV, Tunisian sheep virus (TSV; formerly "Tunisia isolates") , Antelope and Bungowannah. Â© 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, L.;Xia, H.;Wahlberg, N.;BelÃ¡k, S.;Baule, C.

title: Characterization of Clade 7.2 H5 Avian Influenza Viruses Continuing to Circulate in Chickens in China
abstract: H5N1 avian influenza viruses originated in Southeast Asia in the late 20th century and have evolved into multiple phylogenetic branches based on genes encoding hemagglutinin (HA). Clad 7.2 viruses were first detected in chickens in northern China in 2006, and vaccines specifically targeting the branch have been developed and used in poultry in China since 2006. During routine surveillance and disease diagnosis, we isolated seven H5 viruses between 2011 and 2011. Carrying 7.2 HA genes 2014. Here we did extensive studies to understand how 7.2 H5 viruses evolved in chickens in China. Whole genome sequence analysis revealed that the seven viruses derived genes from other influenza viruses to form two subtypes (four H5N1 viruses and three H5N2 viruses) and four genotypes. All of the viruses were antigenically entrained from viruses in the 7.2 sequence isolated in 2006. Pathogenicity studies of four viruses, one from each genotype, revealed that all of the viruses were highly pathogenic in chickens, but none replicated in ducks. The four viruses bind only to avian receptors and are replicated only in the turbinates and/or lungs of mice; none were lethal to mice at 10%<sup>6</sup> 50% egg infective dose (EID<sub>50</sub>). Our study shows that although 7.2 viruses are not eradicated from poultry by vaccination, they do not become more dangerous to other animals (eg ducks and mice) and humans. IMPORTANT: Animal influenza viruses can acquire the ability to infect and kill humans. H5N1 viruses have been a concern in recent years due to their clear pandemic potential. We divided the H5N1 influenza viruses into different phylogenetic branches according to their HA genes. Clade 7.2 viruses were detected in chickens in various provinces of northern China in 2006. Vaccines for these viruses were later developed and have since been used to control infection of poultry. Here, we analyzed the genetic and biological characteristics of seven clade 7.2 viruses isolated from chickens between 2011 and 2014. After approximately 9 years of circulation in chickens, clade 7.2 viruses still bind to avian-type receptors only and the low pathogenicity for mice suggests that these H5 viruses pose a low risk to human public health.
authors: Liu, L.;Zeng, X.;Chen, P.;Deng, G.;Li, Y.;Shi, J.;Gu, C.;Kong, H.;Suzuki, Y.;Jiang, Y.;Tian, G.;Chen, H.

title: Genotypic and pathotypical characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolated from racing pigeons in China.
abstract: In this study, a Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated from an outbreak in racing pigeons in China was characterized. The complete gene of the NDV isolate was sequenced and phylogenetic analysis was performed. Pathogenicity assay was conducted in pigeons, chickens and ducks. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the strain clustered with Class II viruses was phylogenetically quite similar to the NDV strains isolated from pigeons in China, but far from the virus prevalence in chickens and vaccine strains used in China. The deduced amino acid sequence of the cleavage site of the fusion (F) protein confirmed that the isolate contained the virulent motif (112)RRQKRF(117) at the cleavage site, but did not cause disease manifestations in chickens and ducks. However, the isolate had virulence in pigeons, resulting in severe nervous manifestations and a high rate of death. Pigeons were recognized as a potential source of NDV infection and disease for commercial poultry flocks. Therefore, new vaccines to prevent NDV infection in pigeon flocks should be developed as soon as possible and strict biosecurity measures should be taken to reduce the risk of pigeon Newcastle disease epidemic.
authors: Liu, M.;Qu, Y.;Wang, F.;Liu, S.;Sun, H.

title: High reversal potential of a cell-adapted vaccine candidate against highly pathogenic swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome
abstract: The modified live vaccine (MLV), based on the highly pathogenic porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (HP-PRRSV), tends to rapidly reverse virulence after circulating in host animals. The aim of this study was to evaluate the virulence reversion potential of HP-PRRSV MLV and to identify elements within the HP-PRRSV genome that contribute to this phenomenon. A blind passage, cell adaptation strategy was attempted to attenuate an HP-PRRSV strain JX143 isolated during the atypical PRRS epidemic in 2006. The two attenuated candidate passages 87 (JXM87) and passage 105 (JXM105) used as MLVs showed the best balance of safety and efficacy in 4-week old piglets (unpublished data). Two studies were conducted in which candidates were evaluated for return to virulence via five back passages in susceptible piglets (21 +/- 3 days old). Both study results showed an increase in clinical signs, fever and lung lesions in susceptible pigs, as well as a reduction in mean daily weight gain from passage 3, showing that both candidates regained virulence regardless of the transition level. The increase in relevant parameters was accompanied by an increase in viremia in piglets: JXM87 virus titer, Pass 1 (P1) 4.40 Lg TCID<sub>50</sub>/mL to P4 5.75 Lg TCID<sub>50</sub> increased to /mL and the JXM105 virus titer increased from P1 3.78 Lg TCID<sub>50</sub>/mL to P4 6.42 Lg TCID<sub>50</sub>/mL. Next generation sequencing (NGS) was performed on clinical samples (serum, lung tissue) from P4 animals. Sequence analysis comparing P4 materials with parental strains revealed 10 amino acid mutations in 4 proteins for JXM87 and 14 amino acid mutations in 9 proteins for JXM105, respectively. Interestingly, five amino acid mutations were identical for the two candidates located in the nsp1beta, GP5a and nsp10 coding regions, suggesting that nsp1beta, GP5a and nsp10 may contribute to virulence in HP-PRRSV.
authors: Liu, P.;Bai, Y.;Jiang, X.;Zhou, L.;Yuan, S.;Yao, H.;Yang, H.;Sun, Z.

title: Phylogenetic analysis (1986-2011) of 626 hepatitis E viruses (HEV) from humans and animals in China, showing genotype diversity and zoonotic transmission
abstract: Hepatitis E is recognized as a public health problem in China. To determine the overall molecular epidemiology of hepatitis E virus (HEV) and to analyze the status of cross-species transmission between humans and pigs in the last 25 years (1986-2011) in China, 626 HEV complete and partial sequences (89 isolates were identified by our group) in China. The genbank isolated from humans and animals in Turkey was retrieved from GenBank and subjected to phylogenetic analysis. There were three genotypes and 11 subgenotypes of HEV prevailing in China. Rabbit HEVs of controversial genotype are also common in China. Genotype 1 was the most isolated genotype before 2000 and was mainly detected in Xinjiang, Beijing, and eastern China. However, genotype 4, which was detected in most regions of China in the last 10 years, surpassed genotype 1 in isolation frequency throughout the country. Genotype 3 HEV strains were found only in eastern China and were thought to have been imported from Japan. Both genotypes 3 and 4 were found in humans, and swine and cross-species transmission of the two genotypes from pigs to humans may have occurred in Northeast, Northwest, Northern, Eastern and Southern China. These results indicate that HEV strains with considerable genetic diversity are common and zoonotic transmission between pigs and humans is ubiquitous in China. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Liu, P.;Li, L.;Wang, L.;Bu, Q.;Fu, H.;Han, J.;Zhu, Y.;Lu, F.;Zhuang, H.

title: Characterization of a highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 clade 2.3.4 virus isolated from a tree sparrow
abstract: The spread of the H5N1 virus to a wide variety of avian and mammalian species may facilitate the virus's adaptation to human populations. In this study, avian influenza virus research was conducted in tree sparrows and a HPAI H5N1 virus (A/tree sparrow/Jiangsu/1/08) was isolated. H5N1 virus, newly emerged in Southern China in 2005, 2.3.4. In 2007 it was thought to be responsible for possible limited person-to-person transmission in a family cluster in China. Pathogenicity studies have shown that the virus is highly lethal when experimentally inoculated in chickens, tree sparrows, and mice. In section 2.3.4, the genotype V variant of the H5N1 virus has been implicated in the majority of human mortal cases in China during 2005-2008, the presence of such H5N1 variants in tree sparrows highlighting the potential threat of such wild bird infection. for veterinary and public health. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, Q.;Ma, J.;Kou, Z.;Pu, J.;Lei, F.;Li, T.;Liu, J.

title: Systematic review of severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome: Virology, epidemiology and clinical features.
abstract: SUMMARY: Severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome (SFTS) was first discovered in China in 2010, followed by various reports from many countries around the world. SFTS virus (SFTSV) has been identified as the disease-causing agent and has been recognized as a public health threat. This new Bunyavirus belongs to the genus Phlebovirus in the family Bunyaviridae. This review also describes different aspects of virology, pathogenesis, epidemiology, and clinical symptoms based on phylogenetic analyzes of viral sequences of large, medium, and small segments retrieved from the database using mega 5.05, simplot 3.5, and published article surveillance data. 1, network 4.611 and epi information system 3.5.3 software. SFTS is manifested by fever, thrombocytopenia, leukocytopenia, and significant changes in various serum biomarkers. The disease has a mortality rate of 10-15%, usually due to multiple organ dysfunction. SFTSV is mostly reported in rural areas of Central and North-East China, occurring seasonally from May to September and mainly targeting â‰¥50-year-olds. A wide variety of pets have proven seropositive for SFTSV, including sheep, goats, cattle, pigs, dogs and chickens. Ticks, particularly Haemaphysalis longicornis, are suspected to be potential vectors with a wide range of animal hosts worldwide. Further work is needed to elucidate the vector-animal-human ecological cycle, pathogenic mechanisms in high-level animal models, and vaccine development. Â© 2013 Authors. John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. Reviews in Medical Virology, published by
authors: Liu, S.;Chai, C.;Wang, C.;Amer, S.;Lv, H.;He, H.;Sun, J.;Lin, J.

title: Identification of avian infectious bronchitis coronaviruses with mutations in gene 3
abstract: The sequence of a 6.0 kb fragment was compared in the 3 encoding region of the genome in 27 infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) strains. All these strains have the same S-3-M-5-N gene arrangement as in other IBVs. However, the sizes of the corresponding open reading frames (ORFs) of some genes varied between virus strains. Phylogenetic analysis and sequence alignments showed that recombination events occurred in the origin and evolution of strains CK/CH/LSD/03I and CK/CH/LLN/98I, and possible recombinant splice sites can be found in the 3c and M genes, respectively. The normal product of ORF 3a is 57 amino acids long, whereas a 43-bp deletion was detected at the 3â€²-end of the CK/CH/LSD/03I 3a gene, with a frameshift event and C-terminal truncated protein. resulted in 47 amino acids. Comparison of growth ability and replication and pathogenicity in embryos in chickens with IBV carrying the normal 3a gene showed that this deleted sequence in the 3a gene of CK/CH/LSD/03I is not required for viral pathogenesis and replication in vitro or in vitro. live. Occurrence of a mutation in the 3a gene at the corresponding position of the start codon CK/CH/LLN/98I resulted in the absence of ORF 3a in this virus, resulting in a new genomic organization in the 3â€² coding regions: S-3b, 3c-M-5a , 5b-N. Compared with other viruses carrying the normal 3a gene, CK/CH/LLN/98I appeared to have similar replication and pathogenicity abilities in vivo as other IBVs; however, growth ability in embryos was lower, although the association between low growth ability and ORF 3a defect requires further confirmation. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Liu, S.;Zhang, Q.;Chen, J.;Han, Z.;Shao, Y.;Kong, X.;Tong, G.

title: Swine Outbreak Diarrhea Virus Infection Triggers Intestinal Microbiota Imbalance in Piglets
abstract: Pig epidemic diarrhea (PED) is a devastating disease in the livestock industry. Most previous studies on PED have focused on the pathology and etiology of the porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV). Little was known about the state of the gut microbiota after PEDV-infected piglets. In this study, gut microbiota profiles in faeces of viral diarrhea (VD) and viral control (VC) piglets were investigated with the aid of metagenome sequencing technology. The results showed that the abundance of the four dominant phyla (Fusobacteria, Actinobacteria, Verrucomicrobia and Proteobacteria) in feces was greatly affected by swine epidemic diarrhea. Notably, the abundance of Fusobacteria was higher in VD piglets (36%Â) than in VC piglets (5Â%). In contrast, Verrucomicrobia was detected at a lower dispersion rate in VD piglets (approximately 0%) compared to VC piglets (20%). Also, at the breed level, 25 breeds differed significantly between VC and VD piglets. Among the 25 genera, Leptotrichia belonging to Fusobacteria were considerably lower in VC piglets than in VD piglets. Akkermansia belonging to Verrucomicrobia was higher in VC piglets than in VD piglets. Our findings implied that PED-associated gut microbiota provide substantial insight into the pathology and physiology of PED.
authors: Liu, S.;Zhao, L.;Zhai, Z.;Zhao, W.;Ding, J.;Dai, R.;Sun, T.;Meng, H.

title: Identification of natural recombination in duck hepatitis B virus
abstract: Due to its high similarity to human hepatitis B virus (HBV), duck HBV (DHBV) is often used as an important model for HBV research. Although intergenotypic recombination of HBV is common, it has not been reported with DHBV. In this study, 32 nonredundant DHBV whole genomes were analyzed using phylogenetic methods and classified into two clusters corresponding to the 'China' and 'West country' clades previously reported based on geographic distribution. One 'Chinese' branch strain was isolated in Australia and three 'Western country' branch strains were isolated in China, suggesting the geographic distribution of both branches. Recombination analyzes of 32 DHBV genomes identified two possible inter-genotypic recombination events with high confidence. These recombination events occurred between lineages represented by the Chinese isolate GD3 (AY536371, 'Chinese' branch) and the American isolate DHBV16 (K01834, 'Western country' branch), respectively, giving rise to two Chinese recombinant isolates CH4 (EU429324). and CH6 (EU429326). The identification of genotypic recombination among circulating DHBV isolates demonstrates the usefulness of DHBV as a model to study the mechanism of HBV recombination. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Liu, W.;Zhai, J.;Liu, J.;Xie, Y.

title: Genome sequencing and analysis of a peste des petits ruminant virus isolate, China/Tib/07
abstract: Peste des petits ruminant virus is a member of Morbillivirus Paramyxoviridae. The complete genome of a Peste des petits ruminant virus (PPRV) isolate, China/Tib/07 was sequenced and molecular features analyzed. Internal sequences of the virus genome were amplified by RT-PCR with primers designed according to data published in GenBank, while the 3' and 5' ends of the genome were sequenced by RACE. Amplification products were directly sequenced, assembled and analyzed with DNAStar4.0. The results showed that the China/Tib/07 genome, like other known PPRV genomes, consists of 15 948 nucleotides in length, encoding six structural proteins and two nonstructural proteins. Phylogenetically, the virus genome shared 91.6-98.1% homology with Southwest Asian isolates among PPRV strains and the highest homology of 64.3% with rinderpest virus among morbillivirus members.
authors: Liu, W. H.;Bao, J. Y.;Wu, X. D.;Wang, Z. L.

title: Molecular phylogenetic and positive selection analysis of Japanese encephalitis virus strains isolated from pigs in China.
abstract: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is one of the most important viruses that cause encephalitis. This disease is most common in the southern, southeastern and eastern parts of Asia. In this study, two strains of JEV, JEV/SW/GD/01/2009 and JEV/SW/GZ/09/2004, were isolated from aborted fetuses and seminal fluid of pigs in China. To characterize these virus isolates, the virulence of two new JEV isolates was investigated, the result proving that JEV/SW/GD/01/2009 did not kill mice while JEV/SW/GZ/09/2004 did not kill mice. Neurovirulence with 0.925log10 pfu/LD50. In addition, whole genome sequences of JEV were determined and compared with other known JEV strains. The results showed that the genome of the two JEV isolates was 10,976 nucleotides (nt) long. Compared with the Chinese vaccine strain SA14-14-2, JEV/SW/GD/01/2009 and JEV/SW/GZ/09/2004 showed 99.7% and 97.5%, 99.6% and 96.7% identity at the nucleotide level. percent identity at amino acid level, respectively. Phylogenetic analysis based on the full-length genome revealed that the two JEV isolates all clustered in genotype III compared to reference strains. Furthermore, selection analyzes revealed that the dominant selective pressure acting on the JEV genome purified the selection. Four regions under positive selection were identified: codon 521 (amino acid E-227), 2296 (amino acid NS4b-24), 3048 (amino acid NS5-521), and 3055 (amino acid NS5-528). Amino acid E-227 has been proven to be associated with neurovirulence. Taken together, the molecular epidemiology and functionality of the positively selected amino acid regions of the two novel JEV isolates are fully understood, which may help predict possible changes in virulence. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Liu, W. J.;Zhu, M.;Pei, J. J.;Dong, X. Y.;Liu, W.;Zhao, M. Q.;Wang, J. Y.;Gou, H. C.;Luo, Y. W.;Chen, J. D.

title: Identification and analysis of porcine MicroRNA in porcine cytomegalovirus-infected macrophages using deep sequencing.
abstract: Porcine cytomegalovirus (PCMV; genus Cytomegalovirus, subfamily Betaherpesvirinae, family Herpesviridae) is an immunosuppressive virus that mainly inhibits the immune function of T lymphocytes and macrophages and causes significant damage to the farming industry. In this study, we obtained miRNA expression profiles of PCMV-infected porcine macrophages by high-throughput sequencing. Comprehensive analysis of miRNA profiles revealed that 239 miRNA database Annotated and 355 new porcine-encoded miRNAs were detected. Of these, 130 miRNAs showed significantly different expression between PCMV-infected and uninfected porcine macrophages. 10 differentially expressed porcine-encoded miRNAs were further determined by stem-loop reverse Transcription polymerase chain reaction, and the results were consistent with high-throughput sequencing. Gene Ontology analysis of target genes of miRNAs in PCMV-infected porcine macrophages showed that differentially expressed miRNAs are mainly involved in immune and metabolic processes. This is the first report of the miRNA transcriptome in porcine macrophages and an analysis of miRNA regulatory mechanisms during PCMV infection. Further research into the regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs during immunosuppressive viral infections should contribute to the treatment and prevention of immunosuppressive viruses.
authors: Liu, X.;Liao, S.;Xu, Z.;Zhu, L.;Yang, F.;Guo, W.

title: MicroRNA transcriptome analysis of vital organ responses to immunosuppressive porcine cytomegalovirus infection in pigs.
abstract: Background: Porcine cytomegalovirus (PCMV) is an immunosuppressive virus that mainly inhibits T-lymphocyte and macrophage immune functions; caused great damage to the agricultural sector. Although recent studies have shown that miRNAs play important roles in immune responses, the regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs during immunosuppressive virus infection remain unclear. Methods: In this study, porcine small RNA transcriptomes of PCMV-infected and uninfected vital organs were first characterized by high-throughput sequencing. MiRDeep2 software was used to predict novel porcine-encoded miRNAs. To verify the accuracy of the high-throughput sequencing results, stem-loop qRT-PCR was performed on a substantial 12 DE miRNA. Physical and functional interactions between immune-related target genes of DE miRNAs in PCMV-infected organs were analyzed using the STRING database. Results: 306 annotated and 295 new miRNAs were identified from PCMV-infected and uninfected pig organs, respectively, by alignment with known Sus scrofa pre-miRNAs. Overall, 92, 107, 95, 77 and 111 miRNAs, respectively, were significantly differentially expressed in lung, liver, spleen, kidney, and thymus after PCMV infection. According to the Gene Ontology enrichment analysis, target genes of differentially expressed miRNAs associated with immune system processes, regulation of biological processes, and metabolic processes were enriched in each sample. Integrated expression analysis of differentially expressed miRNAs and their target mRNAs in PCMV-infected thymus showed that significantly differential expression of specific miRNAs under pressure from PCMV infection in central immune organs interferes with the expression of genes involved in important immune-related signaling pathways. , thereby promoting viral infection. Results: This is the first comprehensive analysis of the responses of host small RNA transcriptomes to PCMV infection in vital porcine organs. It provides new insights into the regulatory mechanisms of miRNAs during infection by immunosuppressive viruses.
authors: Liu, X.;Wei, H.;Liao, S.;Ye, J.;Zhu, L.;Xu, Z.

title: Characterization of a highly pathogenic H5N1 clan 2.3.2 influenza virus isolated from swans in Shanghai, China.
abstract: In spring 2009, a strain of H5N1 clade 2.3.2 virus was isolated from wild swans in Shanghai, demonstrating the importance of wild swan in the ecology of this highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) in eastern China. Pathogenicity experiments conducted in this study showed that the virus was highly pathogenic for chickens but low pathogenic for mammalian hosts, as evidenced by the reduced infection of mice. Analysis of whole genome sequences and genetic evolution indicated that A/Swan/Shanghai/10/09 (SW/SH/09) could be derived from strain A/silky Chicken/Shantou/475/2004 (CK/ST/04). Homologous to influenza viruses isolated in 2007 from chicken, duck, pika, little egret, swan, mandarin duck and stick-headed goose in Hunan, China, Qinghai, Mongolia, Russia, Japan, Korea, Laos, and Hong Kong, 2007-2011 shows that the virus has retroinfected a variety of wild birds from chicken, and significant spread of the virus via overlapping migratory flight paths still continues. On the basis of molecular analysis, we found that the deletion of the glycosylation site (NSS) at amino acid 156 of the hemagglutinin (HA) protein was compared with other Clade 2.3.2 viruses isolated between 2007 and 2007. 2011. More importantly, sequence analysis of the SW/SH/09 virus revealed drug-resistant mutations in the matrix protein (M2) and neuraminidase (NA) genes. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2011.
authors: Liu, X.;Zhao, G.;Zhong, L.;Lu, X.;Hu, J.;Gu, X.;Kai, Y.;Song, Q.;Sun, Q.;Liu, J.;Peng, D.;Wang, X.;Liu, X.

title: Porcine microRNA transcriptome response to infectious gastroenteritis virus infection
abstract: Infectious gastroenteritis virus (TGEV; family Coronaviridae) causes great economic losses in the pig industry. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play a regulatory role in viral infection and may play a role in the mammalian immune response. Here, we report a comprehensive analysis of host miRNA expression in TGEV-infected porcine testis (ST) cells. Deep sequencing produced 3,704,353 and 2,763,665 reads from uninfected ST cells and infected ST cells, respectively. Reads were aligned to known Sus scrofa pre-miRNAs in miRBase 19 and 284 annotated miRNAs were identified. Some miRNAs are differentially regulated during TGEV infection. 59 unique miRNAs exhibited significantly differential expression between normal and TGEV-infected ST cell samples: 15 miRNAs were significantly up-regulated and 44 were significantly down-regulated. Root loop RT-PCR was performed to determine the expression levels of specific miRNAs in the two samples and the results were consistent with sequencing. Gene ontology enrichment analysis of host target genes indicated that differentially expressed miRNAs are involved in regulatory networks, including cellular process, metabolic process, immune system process. This is the first report on the identification of ST cell miRNAs and comprehensive analysis of the miRNA regulatory mechanism during TGEV infection, revealing miRNA molecular regulatory mechanisms for viral infection, expression of viral genes, and expression of immune-related genes. The results presented here will aid research into the prevention and treatment of viral diseases.
authors: Liu, X.;Zhu, L.;Liao, S.;Xu, Z.;Zhou, Y.

title: Whole genome sequence analysis of a dominant infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) strain in China
abstract: Infectious bronchitis (IB) is one of the main diseases caused by the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) in poultry flocks worldwide. In the study, the whole genome sequence of strain A2, a dominant IBV strain in China, was sequenced and analyzed. The results showed mutations, insertions and deletions scattered throughout the genome. The A2 virus had the highest identity to S14 and BJ in terms of the whole genome, with a greater distance to the Massachusetts strains. Phylogenetic analysis showed that isolate A2 clustered together with most Chinese strains. The results of this study suggest that strain A2 may play an important role in the evolution of IBV, and A2-like IBVs are the dominant strains in China. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Liu, X. L.;Su, J. L.;Zhao, J. X.;Zhang, G. Z.

title: Phylogenetic diversity and genotypic complexity of H1N1 subtype swine flu viruses isolated in mainland China.
abstract: Background: Following the emergence of the 2009 pandemic H1N1, close attention has been paid to H1N1 subtype swine flu viruses (H1N1 SIV) by the scientific community in many countries. A large-scale series analysis of the NCBI Influenza Virus Resource Database on H1N1 SIVs was performed from 1992 to 2011, primarily submitted by scientists in China. The aim of this study was to elucidate the genetic and evolutionary characteristics of H1N1 SIVs, to identify and combine the lineages and genetic traits of H1N1 SIVs isolated in mainland China. Results: Most of the strains were isolated from Guangdong and Shandong provinces of China during 2008-2010. Based on phylogenetic and genotypic analyses, all H1N1 SIV strains can be classified into 8 lineages and 10 genotypes. All strains had characteristics of low pathogenic influenza viruses. Viruses of different lineage are characterized by different amino acid residues at their receptor binding sites. Viruses containing the PB2 genes of the classical swine, early-season human, and late-season human lineage may be more contagious to humans. Some genotypes were directly related to human influenza viruses, including strains harboring genes derived from human influenza viruses. Results: There was phylogenetic diversity and complexity in H1N1 SIVs isolated in mainland China. These H1N1 SIV strains were closely related to other subtypes of influenza viruses, particularly human influenza viruses. Furthermore, it has been shown recently that new strains and genotypes of H1N1 SIVs are emerging in mainland China. These findings provided new and fundamental information for a better understanding of genetic and evolutionary traits and monitoring of H1N1 SIVs in mainland China. Â© 2012 Liu et al.; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Liu, Y.;Wang, J.;Ji, J.;Chang, S.;Xue, C.;Ma, J.;Bi, Y.;Xie, Q.

title: Application of a Molecular Method for Classification of Human Enteroviruses and Relation to Clinical Symptoms
abstract: Background/Purpose: A new molecular classification scheme has recently been adopted that groups all enteroviruses into four types, designated human enteroviruses A (HEV-A) to D. In this study, we tried to show the correlation between this molecular classification scheme and the clinic. manifestations in patients. Methods: We retrospectively reclassified clinical isolates of enteroviruses from the previous 4.5 years using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction in our virology laboratory and reviewed the clinical manifestations of 138 pediatric patients. Results: From five serotypes, 23 isolates were reclassified to HEV-A group, 110 isolates to 16 serotypes to HEV-B group, five isolates to HEV-C group, and no isolates from HEV-D group. HEV-A strains caused significantly more hand-foot-mouth disease (p < 0.001), herpangina (p = 0.029), and myoclonic jerks (p < 0.001) compared to HEV-B strains. However, HEV-B strains caused significantly more pharyngitis (p = 0.043), respiratory tract infections (p = 0.046), nausea and vomiting (p = 0.007), and aseptic meningitis (p = 0.001). The only death in our report was caused by coxsackievirus A16, which belongs to the HEV-A group. Conclusion: The relationship between the molecular classification of enteroviruses and associated disease patterns is an important finding. We suggest that this molecular classification can be applied in a clinical laboratory as an alternative method under certain conditions, such as limited antiserum availability or questionable serotyping results, to identify nontypeable isolates. Â© 2010 Taiwan Microbiology Society.
authors: Lo, C. W.;Wu, K. G.;Lin, M. C.;Chen, C. J.;Ho, D. M. T.;Tang, R. B.;Chan, Y. J.

title: Origin and evolution of the Nipah virus
abstract: Nipah virus, a member of the Paramyxoviridae family, is classified as a Biosafety Level-4 agent and a category C priority pathogen. Nipah virus disease is endemic in South Asia, and outbreaks have been reported in Malaysia, Singapore, India and Bangladesh. Bats of the genus Pteropus seem to be the natural reservoir of this virus. The aim of this study is to investigate the genetic diversity of Nipah virus, to estimate the origin date and spread of the infection. The mean value of the Nipah virus N gene evolution rate was 6.5×10-4 substitutions/site/year (95% HPD: 2.3×10-4-1.18×10-3). Time-scale phylogenetic analysis showed that the root of the tree emerged in 1947 (95% HPD: 1888-1988) when the virus entered Southeast Asian regions. Separation of sequences in two main sections (I and II) indicates that Nipah virus had two different entries: one corresponding to section I in 1995 (95% HPD: 1985-2002) and the other in 1985 (95% HPD: 1971) -1996) II. Phylogeographic reconstruction showed that the epidemic followed two different paths, spreading to other regions. Trade in infected pigs may have played a role in the spread of the virus. Bats of the genus Pteropus, which can travel long distances, may have contributed to the spread of the infection. Statistically supported regions selected as negative may reflect the stability of the viral N protein.
authors: Lo Presti, A.;Cella, E.;Giovanetti, M.;Lai, A.;Angeletti, S.;Zehender, G.;Ciccozzi, M.

title: Comparative genomics uncovers multiple pathways to reciprocity for tick-borne pathogens
abstract: BACKGROUND: A number of important human and livestock pathogens use ticks as their primary host vectors. It is currently unknown whether this way of infecting a host occurred once or many times during evolution. RESULTS: To address this question, we performed a comparative genomic analysis on a range of bacterial pathogens from seven genera (Borrelia, Rickettsia, Anaplasma, Ehrlichia, Francisella, Coxiella and Bartonella) and species from three different host vectors - ticks, lice and fleas. The final set of 102 genomes used in the study encoded a total of 120,046 protein sequences. We found that no genes or metabolic pathways were found in all of the tick-borne bacteria. However, we found that some genes and pathways were found in subsets of tick-borne organisms, while not found in bacteria transmitted by lice or fleas. CONCLUSION: Our analysis shows that the ability to transmit pathogens by ticks has emerged multiple times throughout evolution. To our knowledge, this is the most comprehensive study of tick transmissibility to date.
authors: Lockwood, S.;Brayton, K. A.;Broschat, S. L.

title: A universal protocol for generating consensus-level genome sequences for foot-and-mouth disease virus and other positively-sense polyadenylated RNA viruses using Illumina MiSeq.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) is revolutionizing molecular epidemiology by providing new approaches to undertake whole genome sequencing (WGS) in diagnostic settings for a variety of human and veterinary pathogens. Previous sequencing protocols have been subject to biases, such as those encountered during PCR amplification and cell culture, or have been restricted by the need for large amounts of starting material. Here, we describe a simple and robust methodology for constructing whole genome sequences on Illumina MiSeq. This protocol is specific for foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) or other polyadenylated RNA viruses, eliminating both the use of PCR and the need for large quantities of initial templates. RESULTS: The protocol was successfully validated using a representative panel of viruses from all seven serotypes as well as five FMDV positive clinical samples from the 2001 outbreak in the United Kingdom. In addition, this protocol was successfully used to recover 94% of an FMDV genome previously identified as cell culture negative. Genome sequences from three other non-FMDV polyadenylated RNA viruses (EMCV, ERAV, VESV) were also obtained with minor protocol changes. We calculated that a minimum coverage depth of 22 reads is required to produce an accurate consensus sequence for FMDV O. This was obtained in 5 FMDV/O/UKG isolates and type O FMDV from the 5' genomic excluded serotype panel. termini and the area immediately adjacent to the poly(C) region. RESULTS: We developed a universal WGS method for FMDV and other polyadenylated RNA viruses. This method works successfully from a limited amount of starting material and eliminates the need for genome-specific PCR amplification. This protocol has the potential to generate consensus-level arrays in a routine high-throughput diagnostic setting.
authors: Logan, G.;Freimanis, G. L.;King, D. J.;Valdazo-Gonzalez, B.;Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;Sanderson, N. D.;Knowles, N. J.;King, D. P.;Cottam, E. M.

title: Neutral Characterization of Anopheles Mosquito Blood Meals by Targeted High-throughput Sequencing
abstract: Understanding mosquito host selection is important for assessing vector competence or identifying disease reservoirs. Unfortunately, the availability of an unbiased method for comprehensively evaluating the composition of insect blood baits is very limited, as most current molecular analyzes only test for the presence of a few preselected species. These approaches also have limited ability to detect the presence of multiple mammalian hosts in a single blood meal. Here, we describe a new high-throughput sequencing method that enables simultaneous analysis of 96 mosquitoes and provides a comprehensive and quantitative perspective on the composition of each blood meal. In silico, we confirmed that universal primers targeting mammalian mitochondrial 16S ribosomal RNA genes (16S rRNA) should amplify more than 95% of mammalian 16S rRNA sequences found in the NCBI nucleotide database. We performed this method on 442 female Anopheles punctulatus sl mosquitoes collected from Papua New Guinea (PNG). While human (52.9%), dog (15.8%) and pig (29.2%) were the most common hosts detected in our study, we also detected DNA from mouse, one marsupial species and two bat species. Our analyzes also revealed that 16.3% of mosquitoes feed on more than one host. Analysis of the human mitochondrial hypervariable region I in 102 human blood meals showed that 5 (4.9%) of the mosquitoes clearly fed on more than one individual. Overall, analysis of PNG mosquitoes demonstrates the potential of this approach to identify suspect hosts and characterize mixed blood meals, and demonstrates how this approach can be adapted to assess interindividual variations between human blood meals. Furthermore, this approach can be applied to any disease-infecting arthropod and can be easily customized to search for non-mammalian host sources.
authors: Logue, K.;Keven, J. B.;Cannon, M. V.;Reimer, L.;Siba, P.;Walker, E. D.;Zimmerman, P. A.;Serre, D.

title: Virus particles in the cochlear spiral ganglia of guinea pigs
abstract: All spiral ganglia examined from several populations of guinea pigs of different breeds showed intracytoplasmic viruses in some of the granular spiral ganglion cells. We classify these viruses with the oncorne group according to their localization and morphology. This is not in line with the classification of other authors. There seems to be a worldwide latent viral infection in guinea pigs. Next to the virus particles, we found an accumulation of lysosomes indicating locally increased lysosomal activity of the infected ganglion cells. Other effects on infected cells can neither be demonstrated nor denied.
authors: Lohle, E.;Kistler, G. S.;Riede, U. N.;Merck, W.

title: Columbian circoviruses detected in free-range pigeons from southern Brazil: insights on PiCV evolution.
abstract: Pigeon circovirus (PiCV) is taxonomically classified as a member of the genus Circovirus, family Circoviridae. The virus contains a single-stranded DNA genome of about 2 kb, with small differences in length between different isolates. The occurrence of PiCV infections in pigeons (Columba livia) has been documented worldwide over the past 20 years; however, there are still no reports of PiCV detection in Brazil. This study identifies seven PiCV genomes obtained by high-throughput sequencing from domesticated pigeons of Southern Brazil and shows a high frequency of PiCV infection via quantitative real-time PCR. Phylogenetic classification was performed by maximum likelihood analysis of whole genomes, ORF V1 (Rep) and ORF C1 (Cap). The results show that whole-genome or Cap-based analysis allows for PiCV classification in five major branches (groups A to E), where Brazilian sequences are classified as A, C or D. Recombination analyzes were performed with Simplot and RDP4, and the results show that both Rep and Cap ORFs contain several recombination hotspots, indicating an important role for such events in PiCV evolution.
authors: Loiko, M. R.;Junqueira, D. M.;Varela, A. P. M.;Tochetto, C.;Scheffer, C. M.;Lima, D. A.;Morel, A. P.;Cerva, C.;Paim, W. P.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Fecal virus of red foxes from urban areas
abstract: Red foxes (Vulpes vulpes) are the most abundant carnivorous species in the Northern Hemisphere. Because their populations are well established in urban and urban areas, they represent a potential reservoir of viruses that infect humans or pets from wildlife. In this study, we evaluated fecal virus of juvenile and adult foxes from peri-urban areas in central Croatia. The predominant mammalian viruses were fox picobirnavirus and parvovirus. The highest viral read count (N = 1412) was attributed to a novel fox circovirus and the complete viral genome was de novo assembled from high-throughput sequencing data. Fox circovirus is very similar to canine circoviruses identified in diseased dogs in the USA and Italy, and fox circovirus, a neurological disease recently discovered in the UK. Our fox picobirnavirus was more closely related to porcine and human picobirnaviruses than to the known fox picobirnaviruses.
authors: LojkiÄ‡, I.;Bidin, M.;PrpiÄ‡, J.;Å imiÄ‡, I.;KreÅ¡iÄ‡, N.;BedekoviÄ‡, T.

title: Study of non-pathogenic influenza virus A/seagull/Moscow/3100/2006 (H6N2) isolated in Moscow
abstract: Influenza virus A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 (H6N2) was isolated from gull feces around Moscow in autumn 2006. The whole genome (GenBank, EU152234-EU152241) and genotype (K, G, D, 6B, F, 2D, F, 1E for this virus) were determined. Phylogenetic analysis shows that the H6N2 virus has descended from numerous reclassifications between different birds in Europe since 1999 and among viruses circulating in Southeast Asia (NA gene) in recent years. Migratory birds likely brought some of these viruses from Southeast Asia earlier. The strain A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 is not pathogenic to chicken embryos and mice and induces specific antibody production in mice. Similar to all avian influenza viruses A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006, it binds to Neu5Ac(2-3Gal receptors), but was clarified in the receptor specificity analysis and modeling of SLex's conformation to the duck and gull influenza virus hemagglutinin receptor binding site.
authors: Lomakina, N. F.;Gambarian, A. S.;Boravleva, E. I.;Kropotkina, E. A.;Kirillov, I. M.;Lavrent'ev, M. V.;Iamnikova, S. S.

title: Character of apathogenic influenza a virus found in Moscow, Russia
abstract: An influenza virus A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 (H6N2) was isolated from seagull feces around Moscow in autumn 2006. The nucleotide sequence of the complete genome (GenBank, EU152234-EU152241) and genotype (K, G, D), 6B, F, 2D, F, 1E) were determined for this virus. Phylogenetic analysis shows that the H6N2 virus is descended from numerous reclassifications between viruses circulating among different birds in Europe since 1999 and in Southeast Asia (NA gene) in recent years. Some of these viruses were probably introduced earlier by migratory birds from Southeast Asia. The strain A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 is not pathogenic to chicken embryos and mice and induces specific antibody production in mice. Similar to all avian influenza viruses, A/gull/Moscow/3100/2006 binds to Neu5Ac alpha 2-3Gal receptors, but as demonstrated in receptor specificity analysis and modeling of SLex's conformation to the duck and gull influenza virus hemagglutinin receptor binding site.
authors: Lomakina, N. F.;Gambaryan, A. C.;Boravleva, E. Y.;Kropotkina, E. A.;Kirillov, I. M.;Lavrient'ev, M. V.;Yamnikova, S. S.

title: Specificity of antibody against RD 114 viral polymerase
abstract: The use of antiserum against RNA-dependent DNA polymerase (RDP) of type viruses has allowed separation of these enzymes from cellular enzymes that can use RNA templates for DNA synthesis. Such serums also allowed some degree of subclassing of the viruses themselves, as well as discrimination between other RDP-containing viruses. Thus, within the type C family, viper, chicken, and mammalian viruses are easily distinguished, while within the mammalian group, the polymerases of the two novel primate isolates, woolly monkey and gibbon monkey, appear to differ from viruses of lower mammals. The newly identified RD 114 virus, which is currently being evaluated as a human candidate virus, was also differentiated from sub-mammalian viruses by polymerase inhibition tests.
