The main internal protein of the RD 114 virus differs from all other type C viruses both antigenically and by virtue of a unique isoelectric point. In the absence of other criteria for species classification, it has been suggested that polymerase inhibition tests may provide evidence for a group of primate viruses that may hopefully include RD 114. If so, this would provide strong circumstantial evidence for the human origin of RD 114. This report describes experiments with a hyperimmune guinea pig antiserum prepared against purified RD 114 RDP. The RD 114 RDP appears to be more closely related to the RDP of the two primate viruses than the RDP of viruses from sub-mammalian and non-mammalian species. The enzyme also differs from an RD cellular activity that can use RNA templates.
authors: Long, C.;Sachs, R.;Norvell, J.

title: Naturally occurring picornavirus infection of domestic mink
abstract: Isolation and preliminary characterization of a virus from domestic mink has been reported. The virus was tentatively classified as a member of the Picornaviridae family on the basis of its physicochemical properties. Mink virus was not neutralized by antiserum against some known members of the calicivirus genus, which includes nine serotypes of vesicular exanthema of porcine virus, ten serotypes of San Miguel sea lion virus, and feline calicivirus. Seroepidemiological studies have shown that the incidence of mink virus infection is common in domestic mink populations. Although the virus has been isolated from mink in farms with a history of hemorrhagic pneumonia (pseudomonas pneumonia), no specific disease process can be attributed to virus infection.
authors: Long, G. G.;Evermann, J. F.;Gorham, J. R.

title: Bacteria, phages and pigs: effects of antibiotics fed in different gut locations on the microbiome
abstract: Disruption of the beneficial gut microbial community is a potential side effect of antibiotics, which have many uses in animal agriculture (disease treatment or prevention and improvement of feed efficiency). Understanding the effects of antibiotics on bacterial communities in different gut regions is essential to understanding the full benefits and consequences of in-feed antibiotics. In this study, we identified lumenal and mucosal bacterial communities from the small intestine (ileum) and large intestine (caecum and colon) plus stool and characterized the effects of dietary antibiotics (chlortetracycline, sulfamethazine and penicillin (ASP250)) on the body. these communities. Metagenomic analyzes of 16S rRNA gene sequence and bacterial membership and functions revealed dramatic differences between small and large intestine locations, including enrichment of Firmicutes and phage-encoding genes in the ileum. The large intestine microbiota encoded numerous genes for degrading plant cell wall components and these genes were absent in the ileum. The mucosa-associated ileal microbiota harbors a greater diversity of bacteria than the lumen, but has similar membership to the mucosa of the large intestine; this suggests that most gut microbes may associate with the mucosa and act as a vaccine for the lumen. Adverse effects on the microbiota of the animals fed the antibiotic resulted in differentiation from those of the control animals and the ileum, Lachnobacterium spp. in all intestinal regions and resistance genes to antibiotics were not applied. Characterizing the different metabolic capacities and response to spoilage in different gut locations will inform strategies to improve gut health and food safety.
authors: Looft, T.;Allen, H. K.;Cantarel, B. L.;Levine, U. Y.;Bayles, D. O.;Alt, D. P.;Henrissat, B.;Stanton, T. B.

title: Pig gut microbiota: localized adaptations and responses to in-feed antibiotics
authors: Looft, T. P.

title: Automatic classification of tailed bacteriophages according to their neck organization
abstract: Background: The genetic diversity observed among bacteriophages remains a major barrier to the identification of homologs and comparison of their functional modules. Although several classes of homologous proteins can be identified in the structural module that contribute to head and tail structure, proteins attached from head to tail (or neck) are usually more distinct. Nevertheless, molecular analyzes of several tailed phages belonging to different morphological classes suggested that only a limited number of structural solutions were used to generate a functional virion. To challenge this hypothesis and analyze protein diversity in the virion neck, we developed a specific computational strategy to deal with sequence variation in phage proteins. We searched for homologues of a set of proteins encoded in the structural module using a phage learning database. Results: Using a combination of iterative profile-profile comparison and gene context analyses, we have shown that we can identify a range of head, neck and tail proteins in the most tailed bacteriophages of our database. Classification of phages based on neck protein sequences identifies 4 Types corresponding to known morphological subfamilies. Further analysis of the most abundant Type 1 yields 10 Clusters characterized by consistent sets of head, neck and tail proteins. We developed Virfam, a web server that automatically identifies proteins of the phage head-neck-tail module and assigns phages to the most closely related phage cluster. This server was tested with 624 new phages from the NCBI database. 93% of tailed and unclassified phages can be assigned to our head-neck-tail-based categories, thus highlighting the large representation of virion architectures identified. Species and Clusters describe consistent subgroups of Caudovirales that are associated with various virion traits. Results: Our method and web server is capable of automatically classifying most tailed phages, detecting their structural modules, assigning a function to a group of head, neck and tail genes, providing their morphological subtypes, and localizing these phages within a "head-neck". -tail"-based classification. It should enable the analysis of large phage genome sets. In particular, it should contribute to the classification of the abundant unknown viruses found in the assembled contigs of metagenomic samples.
authors: Lopes, A.;Tavares, P.;Petit, M. A.;Guerois, R.;Zinn-Justin, S.

title: Mapping of subgroup epitopes of the rotavirus protein VP6
abstract: VP6, the most abundant protein of rotaviruses, contains epitopes that allow these viruses to be classified into four subgroups (SG) based on the presence or absence of two epitopes, designated I and II. Subgroup-specific epitopes are conformational and appear to be present on the trimeric but not on the monomeric VP6. In VP6, we identified some amino acids that determine the reactivity of the subgroup-specific mAbs 255/60 and 631/9. A single amino acid mutation at positions 172 (Met to Ala) or 305 (Asn to Ala) was sufficient to change the subgroup specificity of the human rotavirus Wa VP6 protein from SGII to SGI/II, as any of these mutations resulted in the protein's SGII mAb 631/ 9 must be recognized by the SGI mAb 255/60 while retaining its capacity to interact with it. In the case of the SGII epitope, mutation of two adjacent amino acids (Ala305 Asn306 to Asn305 Ala306) in the porcine rotavirus YM VP6 protein (SGI) enabled the protein to be efficiently recognized by the SGII mAb 631/9, while the YM VP6 protein increased its capacity to interact with mAb 255/60 . These results suggest that both subsets of mAbs interact with an antigenic domain in VP6, which consists of at least two regions of the protein, and may be close in the constructed VP6 trimer, although distant in the linear sequence.
authors: Lopez, S.;Espinosa, R.;Greenberg, H. B.;Arias, C. F.

title: Initial detection and analysis of a fish circovirus
abstract: Circoviruses are found worldwide in birds and pigs, but their occurrence in fish has not yet been reported. Recently, increased mortality in barbel puppies (Barbus barbus) has been observed in Hungary. This article reports the detection of previously unknown circular viral DNA genomes in barbels using a circovirus-specific wide-range nested PCR. Analysis of two complete genomes (Barbel circovirus, BaCV1 and BaCV2) indicated that they belonged to a new genetic group within the family Circoviridae, distinct from known circoviruses and circovirus-like genomes. The genome sizes were 1957 bases and contained two main ORFs similar to the capsid and replication-associated protein genes of circoviruses. A link between the presence of the virus and the clinical manifestations of infection could not be proven.
authors: Lorincz, M.;Csagola, A.;Farkas, S. L.;Szekely, C.;Tuboly, T.

title: Bluetongue virus serotypes 1 and 4 in Sardinia in autumn 2012: New invasions or reinfection with old strains?
abstract: Since 2000, several bluetongue virus (BTV) infestations, including serotypes 1, 2, 4, 8 and 16, have occurred in Sardinia (Italy). In October 2012, new IT outbreaks caused by BTV-1 and BTV-4 were reported. About 500 herds were infected and 9238 sheep died due to the infection. When sequenced, Seg-10 of both strains shared 99% similarity at the nucleotide level with the BTV strains that have circulated in the Mediterranean basin in the past few years. Similarly, the Seg-5 sequences of newly isolated Sardinian strains BTV-1 and BTV-4 clustered together with the same and the last BTV-1 strains circulating in the Mediterranean Basin and BTV-4 strains isolated in Tunisia in 2007 and 2009. These BTV-4 strains differ from those circulating in Europe from 2003 to 2005 and appear to be reassortant strains. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Lorusso, A.;Sghaier, S.;Carvelli, A.;Di Gennaro, A.;Leone, A.;Marini, V.;Pelini, S.;Marcacci, M.;Rocchigiani, A. M.;Puggioni, G.;Savini, G.

title: Innate immune recognition of poxviral vaccine vectors
abstract: The study of poxviruses pioneered the field of vaccinia after Jenner's remarkable discovery that 'vaccinating' with phylogenetically related cowpox virus confers immunity against a devastating disease such as smallpox. The study of smallpox viruses continues to enrich the field of virology, as the global eradication of smallpox provides a unique example of the potential of effective immunization. Other smallpox viruses have since been developed as vaccine vectors for clinical and veterinary applications and include modified vaccine virus strains such as Ankara and NYVAC, as well as avipox viruses, avian pox virus, and canary pox virus. Despite the empirical development of poxvirus-based vectored vaccines, it is only now emerging that we need to better understand how the innate arm of the immune system drives adaptive immunity against smallpox viruses and how this knowledge relates to vaccine design strategies. topics covered in this article. Â© 2011 Expert Reviews Ltd.
authors: Lousberg, E. L.;Diener, K. R.;Brown, M. P.;Hayball, J. D.

title: Classical swine fever virus diversity and evolution
abstract: By analyzing nucleotide sequence data generated from both the E2 (gp55) and NS5B genes of classical swine fever virus (CSFV), we were able to separate 115 CSFV isolates into two main groups, in addition to previously published data from the 5'NCR. groups, five subgroups and two different isolates. Further separation was possible with the analysis of sequence data from the E2 region. Three sequencing-based methods were compared with monoclonal antibody (MAb) typing and limited restriction enzyme (RE) mapping. Although both the MAb and RE methods confirmed the previous classification, the resolution was lower. We estimated an approximate evolutionary rate for CSFV from an analysis of virus variation observed in a single geographic area over a 6-year period. Applying this recommended ratio to each of our deduced CSFV subgroups allowed us to calculate approximate divergence dates for each subgroup.
authors: Lowings, P.;Ibata, G.;Needham, J.;Paton, D.

title: Evaluation of a monoclonal antibody panel for Lyssavirus typing in Mexico.
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the ability of a panel of eight antinucleocapsid monoclonal antibodies developed in Europe to identify different strains of rabies virus isolated from various animal species from various geographic regions in Mexico. 51 virus-positive brain tissue samples from various animal species and humans were studied. Material from these samples was used to infect mice whose brains were then tested by indirect immunofluorescence using the monoclonal antibodies described above. Strains of the virus showing antigenic variations were sent to the Pasteur Institute in Paris to confirm the results. No mouse brain samples showed a pattern of antigenic reactivity indicating the presence of a Lyssavirus other than the classical rabies virus. However, four antigenic variations were found from the classical rabies serotype 1. The antibodies panel was judged useful for rapid classification of the rabies virus in Mexico. Autochthonous antigenic variations are likely to arise among strains circulating in that country; this is a scenario that may explain some of the failures observed with certain vaccines. Therefore, there is a need to produce antinucleocapsid monoclonal antibodies with site-specific rabies virus strains.
authors: Loza-Rubio, E.;Vargas, R.;HernÃ¡ndez, E.;Batalla, D.;Aguilar-SetiÃ©n, A.

title: Novel bovine hepacivirus in dairy cattle, China
authors: Lu, G.;Jia, K.;Ping, X.;Huang, J.;Luo, A.

title: In vitro and in vivo identification of structural and sequence elements in the 5' untranslated region of Ectropis obliqua picorna-like virus required for internal initiation.
abstract: Ectropis obliqua picorna-like virus (EoPV) is a newly identified insect virus classified as a putative member of the genus Iflavirus. The virus has a large, positive-sense RNA genome that encodes a single polyprotein that shares physicochemical properties with those of its members. It is from the Picornaviridae family. The 5' untranslated region (5' UTR) plays an important role in picornavirus translation initiation as it contains an internal ribosome entry site (IRES) that mediates cap-independent translation. To investigate translation in EoPV, a wide variety of mutations were designed within the 5' UTR and the effects of these changes were studied in vitro and in vivo using a bicistronic structure. The results showed that deletions within the first 63 nt had little effect on IRES activity, while core IRES function was located within the C and D root loops, as their removal significantly abrogated IRES activity. In contrast to these findings, removal of root ring G containing two cryptic AUGs resulted in a notable increase in IRES activity, which was further explored by site-directed mutagenesis at these two positions. It was also confirmed that initiation of protein synthesis occurs at AUG6 (position 391-394) and not at AUG just downstream of the polypyrimidine pathway. Mutation of the polypyrimidine pathway (CCTTTC) had a slight effect on EoPV IRES activity. Also, mutations of the RAAA motif led to an approximately 40% reduction in IRES activity in vitro, but these results were not supported by in vivo experiments. In conclusion, this study reveals that the EoPV IRES is unique, although it shares features with type II IRESs.
authors: Lu, J.;Zhang, J. M.;Wang, X. C.;Jiang, H.;Liu, C. F.;Hu, Y. Y.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of eight genes of the H9N2 subtype influenza virus: A mainland Chinese strain with genes from early circulating isolates.
abstract: The H9N2 subtype influenza virus has become widespread worldwide and in China. Previous studies have shown that at least three sublineages have been established in terrestrial poultry of the Eurasian bird. In this presentation, eight full-length genes of an H9N2 strain, A/Chicken/Shanghai/F/98 (Ck/SH/F/98) were obtained. Sequence analysis and phylogenetic studies were performed by comparing eight genes with those of all H9N2 strains available from GenBank. The results showed that four genes of Ck/SH/F/98 (genes HA, NA, M and NS) were included in the subsequence represented by the early mainland Chinese strain, Ck/BJ/1/94. However, the other four RNP genes of Ck/SH/F/98 did not show close association with those of the three known sublineage viruses. Therefore, Ck/SH/F/98 was a natural reasorant between different sublineages. In addition, comparison showed that Ck/SH/F/98 could be a putative precursor of a later isolate Dk/ST/1605/01 from southern China with at least six closely related genes, both of which display Ck/SH genes. . /F/98 and the first isolates were always in circulation. Further comparison in terms of molecular markers of HA1 species specificity revealed that DK/ST/1605/01 also more closely resembled Ck/SH/F/98 than a previous common duck strain. The results supported the idea of bidirectional transmission between land and waterfowl, emphasizing the importance of raising concerns about the natural evolution of all eight genes of H9N2 avian influenza viruses. © 2005 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Lu, J. H.;Liu, X. F.;Shao, W. X.;Liu, Y. L.;Wei, D. P.;Liu, H. Q.

title: Turkey Fecal Microbial Community Structure and Functional Gene Diversity Revealed by 16S rRNA Gene and Metagenomic Sequences
abstract: The primary aim of this study was to better understand the microbial composition and functional genetic diversity associated with turkey fecal populations. To achieve this, libraries of 16S rRNA gene and metagenomic clones were sequenced from turkey stool samples. Analysis of 382 16S rRNA gene sequences showed that the most abundant bacteria were closely related to Lactobacillales (47%), Bacillales (31%), and Clostridiales (11%). The sequences Actinomycetales, Enterobacteriales, and Bacteroidales were also identified, but represented a smaller fraction of the community. Analysis of 379 metagenomic sequences showed that most of the clones were similar to bacterial protein sequences (58%). Bacteriophage (10%) and avian viruses (3%) sequences were also represented. Most of all metagenomic clones potentially encoding bacterial proteins were similar to low G+C Gram-positive bacterial proteins, particularly from Lactobacillales (50%), Bacillales (11%), and Clostridiales (8%). Bioinformatic analyzes revealed the presence of genes encoding membrane proteins, lipoproteins, hydrolases, and functional genes associated with the metabolism of nitrogen and sulfur-containing compounds. The results of this study further confirmed the dominance of Firmicutes in the avian gut and highlighted the value of combining 16S rRNA gene and metagenomic sequencing data analysis to study the microbial composition of bird fecal microbial communities.
authors: Lu, J. R.;Domingo, J. S.

title: Goose genome sequence leads to insights into waterfowl evolution and susceptibility to fatty liver.
abstract: Background: Geese were domesticated more than 6,000 years ago, making them one of the first domesticated poultry. Geese have rapid growth, disease resistance and high liver lipid storage capacity and can be easily fed with roughage. Here we sequence and analyze the whole genome sequence of an economically important goose breed in China and compare it to that of terrestrial bird species. Results: The draft sequence of the entire goose genome was obtained by shotgun sequencing and 16,150 protein-coding genes were predicted. Comparative genomics shows that significant differences occur between the geese genome and those of other terrestrial bird species, particularly in terms of major histocompatibility complex, Myxovirus resistance, Retinoic acid-inducible gene I, and other genes related to disease resistance in geese. In addition, analysis of transcriptome data also reveals a potential molecular mechanism involved in geese susceptibility to fatty liver disease and associated symptoms, including high levels of unsaturated fatty acids and low cholesterol levels. The results of this study suggest that deletion of the goose lep gene may be the result of positive selection, thus allowing the liver to adopt energy storage mechanisms for long-distance migration. Conclusions: This is the first report describing the complete goose genome sequence and adds to the available genomic resources for studying waterfowl. The findings in this study are useful not only for genetic breeding programs, but also for the study of lipid metabolism disorders.
authors: Lu, L.;Chen, Y.;Wang, Z.;Li, X.;Chen, W.;Tao, Z.;Shen, J.;Tian, Y.;Wang, D.;Li, G.;Chen, L.;Chen, F.;Fang, D.;Yu, L.;Sun, Y.;Ma, Y.;Li, J.;Wang, J.

title: Subtypes of genotype 3 hepatitis E virus in pigs
abstract: The prevalence of hepatitis E virus (HEV) RNA was determined by reverse transcriptase PCR in stool and bile samples from pigs from slaughterhouses in East and Southwest China from 2006 to 2011. HEV-3 was detected in 4/5952 (0.07%) pigs and HEV-4 was detected in 287/5952 (4.8%) pigs. Two HEV-3 subtype 3a strains from South West China had 87.1-89.7% sequence identity. The two HEV-3 subtype 3b strains from eastern China had 91.8%–93.8% sequence identity and were similar to strains previously reported in eastern and central China. Different HEV-3 subtypes in different regions of China revealed multiple origins of HEV infection. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Lu, Y. H.;Qian, H. Z.;Qin, X.;Jiang, Q. W.;Zheng, Y. J.

title: Beyond whole genome consensus: unraveling PRRSV phylogenomics using next-generation sequencing technologies
abstract: The highly heterogeneous swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) is the causative agent of an economically important swine disease with characteristic symptoms of reproductive losses in breeding sows and respiratory diseases in young piglets. The virus can be broadly divided into genotypes 1 and 2, similar to Europe and North America, respectively. In addition to this intra-species variability, the influence of coexisting viral half-species on disease development has received much attention recently; thanks to the advent of next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies. Genomic data generated from the enormous sequencing capacities of NGS have allowed PRRSV to be studied at an unprecedented rate and detail. Unlike traditional sequencing methods that require knowledge of conserved regions, NGS allows de novo assembly of whole viral genomes. Evolutionary variations from different genotypic strains provide valuable information about functionally important regions of the virus. With the advancement of advanced bioinformatics tools, ultra-deep NGS technologies enable low-frequency co-evolving quasispecies detection. This brief review provides an overview, including a proposed workflow, of the use of NGS to investigate genetic diversity of PRRSV at both macro and microevolutionary levels.
authors: Lu, Z. H.;Archibald, A. L.;Ait-Ali, T.

title: Genomic variation in macrophage cultured European porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus Olot/91 revealed using ultra-deep next-generation sequencing
abstract: BACKGROUND: Swine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) is a disease with significant economic impact worldwide. The etiological agent of this disease is the PRRS virus (PRRSV). Increasing evidence suggests that microevolution within a coexisting half-species population can lead to high sequence heterogeneity in PRRSV. RESULTS: We developed a pipeline based on an ultra-deep next-generation sequencing approach to first construct the complete genome of a European PRRSV strain Olot/9 cultured on macrophages and then capture rare variants representing a mixed half-species population. Olot/91 differs by approximately 5% from the reference Lelystad strain, and a total of 88 variants were detected in the mixed population with frequencies as low as 1%. These variants include 16 non-synonymous variants concentrated in genes encoding structural and non-structural proteins; Including glycoproteins 2a and 5. CONCLUSION: Using an ultra-deep sequencing methodology, the complete genome of Olot/91 was constructed without any prior knowledge of the sequence. Rare variants that make up small fractions of the heterogeneous PRRSV population can be successfully detected to allow further investigation of microevolutionary events.
authors: Lu, Z. H.;Brown, A.;Wilson, A. D.;Calvert, J. G.;Balasch, M.;Fuentes-Utrilla, P.;Loecherbach, J.;Turner, F.;Talbot, R.;Archibald, A. L.;Ait-Ali, T.

title: Wuhan large swine roundworm virus detected in human feces in Brazil
abstract: Here, we present the complete genome sequence of bipartite virus designated WLPRV/human/BRA/TO-34/201 from a sample from a two-year-old boy with acute gastroenteritis in Brazil in 2015. The virus has 98-99% identity (segments 2 and 1, respectively) with the Wuhan large pig roundworm virus (unclassified RNA virus), which was recently discovered in the stomachs of pigs from China. This is the first report of a Wuhan large swine roundworm virus detected in human samples and the second genome revealed worldwide. However, further sequence data generation and further functional studies are required to fully understand the ecology, epidemiology and evolution of this new unclassified virus.
authors: Luchs, A.;Leal, E.;Komninakis, S. V.;de PÃ¡dua Milagres, F. A.;Brustulin, R.;da Aparecida Rodrigues Teles, M.;Gill, D. E.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.;Sabino, E. C.;da Costa, A. C.

title: Identification of viruses with two- and three-part double-stranded RNA genomes in the stool of children with gastroenteritis
abstract: Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis of nucleic acid extracted from stool specimens of children with diarrhea revealed the presence of group A rotavirus in 50 (23.4%) of 214 specimens tested and group C rotavirus in 1 (0.5%) of 214 specimens tested. Another example demonstrated the presence of three bands (with apparent length of 2.92, 2.37 and 1.32 kbp) which were shown to be composed of double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) by enzymatic digestion analysis. It was demonstrated by electron microscopy that the sample contained virus particles with a diameter of 32-34 nm. Based on morphology and genomic features, this virus has so far only been detected in chickens by Leite et al. In 1990 and tentatively named 'picotirnavirus'. A sample containing a 'picobirnavirus' was also detected from the same group of 214 individuals. Thus, small icosahedral viruses with two or three segmented dsRNA genomes appear to infect humans. However, their pathogenic potential has yet to be determined.
authors: Ludert, J. E.;Liprandi, F.

title: Serotype Diversity of Foot and Mouth Virus in Livestock Without Vaccination History in the Far North Region of Cameroon
abstract: Little is known about the natural cycle of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) in the absence of control measures such as vaccination. Cameroon offers a unique opportunity for epidemiological studies as there is no FMD vaccination. To gain insight into the natural ecology of the virus, we conducted a prospective study involving serological, antigenic and genetic aspects of FMD virus (FMDV) infections among different livestock production systems in the Far North of Cameroon. We found serological evidence of FMDV infection in more than 75% of the sampled animals, with no significant prevalence differences observed among the sampled groups (i.e. market, resident, cross-border trade, and mobile). We also found reactive antibodies to five of the seven FMDV serotypes (A, O, SAT1, SAT2 and SAT3) among the sampled animals. Finally, we were able to genetically characterize viruses from clinical and subclinical FMD infections in Cameroon. Serotype O viruses are divided into two topotypes (West and East Africa). SAT2 viruses were grouped with viruses from Central and North Africa, particularly within the subclade that caused the major epidemic in North Africa in 2012, suggesting a common origin for these viruses. This research will guide future interventions for the control of FMD, such as improved diagnosis, guidance for vaccine formulation, and epidemiological understanding to support progressive control of FMD in Cameroon.
authors: Ludi, A.;Ahmed, Z.;Pomeroy, L. W.;Pauszek, S. J.;Smoliga, G. R.;Moritz, M.;Dickmu, S.;Abdoulkadiri, S.;Arzt, J.;Garabed, R.;Rodriguez, L. L.

title: Close genetic relatedness of picornaviruses from European and Asian bats
abstract: Extensively reactive nested reverse transcription-PCR for picornaviruses from European bats in 1004 stool samples found picornaviral RNA in 28 samples (2.8%). Phylogenetic analysis of the partial 3D genomic region showed that a bat virus belongs to the Enterovirus G (EV-G, formerly Porcine enterovirus B) strain. Bat infection was promoted by 1.1 x 106 RNA copies with relatively high concentrations of EV-G per gram of feces. All other bat viruses belonged to either the bat-related genus Mischivirus or an unclassified group Picornaviridae remotely related to the genus Sapelovirus. Members of this unclassified sapelovirus-related group had RNA secondary structures in their 3-untranslated region, similar to structures unique to enteroviruses and occurring in bat-associated coronaviruses, suggesting ancient recombination events. Based on sequence distances, several picornaviruses from European and Chinese bats were likely homologous, suggesting connectivity of virus populations. Because of their high mutation rate and diversity, picornaviruses can be useful tools for bat and virus ecology studies.
authors: Lukashev, A. N.;Corman, V. M.;Schacht, D.;Gloza-Rausch, F.;Seebens-Hoyer, A.;Gmyl, A. P.;Drosten, C.;Drexler, J. F.

title: Evolutionary relationships among parvoviruses: virus-host coevolution among autonomous primate parvoviruses and links between adeno-associated and avian parvoviruses.
abstract: While the current classification of parvoviruses is based on virus host range and helper virus dependence, little data is available on evolutionary relationships between viruses. We identified and analyzed 472 parvovirus sequences with (almost) full-length genomes of 41 viruses currently recognized as individual species within the Parvoviridae family. Our phylogenetic analysis of open reading frames as well as full-length genomes distinguished three evolutionary groups of parvoviruses from vertebrates: (i) human helper dependent adeno-associated virus (AAV) serotypes 1 to 6 and autonomous avian parvoviruses; (ii) bovine, squirrel and autonomic primate parvoviruses, including human viruses B19 and V9; and (iii) parvoviruses from rodents (except squirrels), carnivores and pigs. Each of these three evolutionary groups can be subdivided in the evolutionary history of parvoviruses, reflecting both virus-host coevolution and multiple interspecies transitions. No parvovirus from invertebrates clustered with vertebrate parvoviruses. Our analysis provided evidence for negative selection among parvoviruses, independent evolution of their genes, and recombination between parvoviruses from rodents. The topology of the phylogenetic tree of autonomous human and monkey parvoviruses exactly matched the topology of the primate family tree, based on analysis of primate mitochondrial DNA. Viruses belonging to the AAV group were evolutionarily linked to avian parvoviruses and not to other palmate parvoviruses. Two lineages of human parvoviruses may have originated from independent ancient zoonotic infections. Our results provide an argument for the reclassification of Parvovirinae based on evolutionary relationships between viruses.
authors: Lukashov, V. V.;Goudsmit, J.

title: Evolutionary relationships among Astroviridae
abstract: All available sequences for members of the Astroviridae family were collected to examine evolutionary relationships among astroviruses. Phylogenetic analysis distinguished two well-established groups: one containing mammalian astroviruses, ovine astrovirus an outlier, and the other containing avian astroviruses. All virus types and serotypes of human astroviruses represented individual lineages within the tree. All human viruses clustered separately and together from non-human viruses, which oppose their common evolutionary origin and continued animal-to-human transitions. The branching order of mammalian astroviruses was the opposite of that of the host species, suggesting at least two interspecies transmission, possibly involving pigs, cats, and humans, via intermediate hosts. Analysis of synonym (Ds) and non-synonymous (Da) distances revealed that negative selection predominates in the evolution of astroviruses, with Ds:Da ratios up to 46 for comparison of the most closely related viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes of all open reading frames (ORFs) based on D's resulted in loss of tree structures in virus species and ORF2, even with serotypes of human astroviruses and branched from almost a single node, suggesting their ancient divergence. Strong selection against nonsynonymous substitutions, hence its low number, is not evidence of a recent divergence between lineages and, together with the location of the oldest extant human astrovirus strain (1971) away from the common node of serotype 4, suggesting that intraserotype diversification arose from an earlier date. progress.
authors: Lukashov, V. V.;Goudsmit, J.

title: In-Silico Identification of Plant miRNAs in Mammalian Breast Milk Exosomes - A Small Step Forward?
abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of small RNA molecules that regulate gene expression by inhibiting protein translation or targeting mRNA cleavage. They play many important roles in living organism cells; however, knowledge of the functions of miRNAs has become more extensive upon recent reports of their identification in biological fluids and the abundance of plant-derived miRNAs in human plasma and serum. With these findings in mind, we performed a rigorous bioinformatics analysis of publicly available, raw data from high-throughput sequencing studies on the composition of miRNAs in human and pig breast milk exosomes to determine the fraction of food-derived miRNAs. Various processing and filtering steps were applied to improve accuracy and avoid false positives. The above-mentioned analyzes identified 35 and 17 miRNA species belonging to 25 and 11 MIR families, respectively. In human samples, the highest abundance levels were ath-miR166a, pab-miR951, ptc-miR472a and bdi-miR168, while zma-miR168a, zma-miR156a and ath-miR166a were identified in pig breast milk exosomes. largest quantities. Consensus prediction and annotations of potential human targets for selected plant miRNAs suggest that the aforementioned molecules can interact with mRNAs encoding several transcription factors, protein receptors, transporters and immune-related proteins, thereby potentially affecting the human organism. Taken together, the presented analysis shows evidence of abundant plant miRNAs in mammalian breast milk exosomes and also points to new possibilities arising from this discovery.
authors: Lukasik, A.;Zielenkiewicz, P.

title: Infectious bursal disease virus: growth and characterization in cell cultures
abstract: Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) was adapted to chicken embryo bursal (CEB) and kidney (CEK) cells. The virus did not replicate in kidney cells until 4 serial passages were made in bursal cells. The virus produced plaques in CEK cells within 3 to 5 days. Replication of the virus was not altered by 5 iodo 2' deoxyuridine, suggesting that it is a ribovirus. The infectivity of the virus was not destroyed by chloroform and remained stable for 90 minutes at 56°C. The virus bound to the CEK cell monolayer at a maximum of 75 minutes had a retention period of 9 to 10 hours before virus maturation and release. Immunofluorescence studies of infected cells showed that the first antigen was detected 6 hours after infection and all fluorescent antigen was confined to the cytoplasm. All of these features support the classification of IBDV in the diplornavirus riboviruses group.
authors: Lukert, P. D.;Davis, R. B.

title: Phylogenetic position of an uncharacterized Brazilian bovine papillomavirus strain in the genus Xipapillomavirus based on sequencing of the L1 open reading frame.
abstract: The use of PCR experiments with degenerate primers has revealed the presence of a large number of bovine papillomaviruses (BPV) that have not yet been characterized. Despite the endemic nature of BPV infections, identification of BPV types in Brazilian cattle is still only sporadic. However, in a recent analysis of a partial segment of the L1 gene, we observed remarkable diversity among the detected BPV strains. The aim of this study was to determine the phylogenetic position of the previously identified wild strain BPV/BR-UEL2 detected in the Brazilian state of ParanÃ¡. Since previous analysis of the partial L1 sequence showed that this strain is most closely related to BPV type 4, strain-specific primers were designed. Phylogenetic analysis using full L1 ORF sequences revealed that BPV/BR-UEL2 is associated with BPV types classified in the Xipapillomavirus genus and shares the highest L1 nucleotide sequence similarity with BPV type 4 (78%). This finding suggests that BPV/BR-UEL2 should be classified as a potential new BPV strain in the Xipapillomavirus genus. © 2010, Sociedade Brasileira de Genética.
authors: Lunardi, M.;Claus, M. P.;Alfieri, A. A.;Fungaro, M. H. P.;Alfieri, A. F.

title: An outbreak of acute bovine viral diarrhea in Brazilian cattle: clinicopathological findings and molecular characterization of wild-type BVDV strain subtype 1b.
abstract: When first described in 1946, bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) was characterized as an acute infectious disease associated with severe leukopenia, high fever, depression, diarrhea, gastrointestinal erosions, and bleeding. Recently, the severe acute form has only been associated with some hypervirulent BVDV-2 strains. This article reports the detection of BVDV-1b associated with an acute and fatal BVD outbreak in a Brazilian cattle herd. Depression, anorexia, watery diarrhea, sialorrhea and malaise were observed in six cattle. One of these animals was evaluated for laboratory, clinical and pathological changes. Laboratory findings were not specific; clinically the animal was frail, with dehydration and erosive mouth lesions. Pathological changes were predominant in the tongue, esophagus and rumen. An RT-PCR assay using primers was performed to partially amplify the 5â€² untranslated regions (5â€²UTR) of the BVDV genome and identified BVDV in all clinical samples analyzed. Phylogenetic analysis of lymph node-derived BVDV revealed that this strain clustered within BVDV subtype 1b. Since both clinical presentation and pathological findings are similar to BVDV-2 infection, this distinction could only be made by molecular characterization. Â© 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Lunardi, M.;Headley, S. A.;LisbÃ´a, J. A. N.;Amude, A. M.;Alfieri, A. A.

title: Hierarchical molecular labeling to resolve long continuous sequences with massively parallel sequencing
abstract: Here we demonstrate the use of large sequencing systems with short reads to achieve longer read lengths through hierarchical molecular labeling. We show how indexed and PCR-amplified target libraries are degraded, subsampled, and stopped at time intervals to yield pools of different average lengths, each indexed with a new tag. With this process, the indices of sample origin, molecular origin, and degree of decay are included to obtain a nested hierarchical structure and are then used in data processing to order reads at a greater distance than the sequencing system originally allowed. With this protocol, we show how continuous regions beyond 3000 bp can be resolved by an Illumina sequencing system and demonstrate potential applications by calling variants of the lambda genome, analyzing TP53 in cancer cell lines, and targeting a variable canine mitochondrial region.
authors: Lundin, S.;Gruselius, J.;Nystedt, B.;Lexow, P.;KÃ¤ller, M.;Lundeberg, J.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the S1 glycoprotein gene of infectious bronchitis viruses isolated in China during 2009-2010.
abstract: As part of our ongoing surveillance program, 40 field avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) strains were isolated from dead or diseased chicken flocks in different regions of China between 2009 and 2010. The S1 glycoprotein genes of these strains were sequenced and analyzed with 38 strains. Published in GenBank. The S1 genes of these isolated strains and vaccine strains showed nucleotide homologies ranging from 65.2% to 82% and amino acid homologies ranging from 58.4% to 81.9%. Meanwhile, the mainly nephropathogenic Chinese IBV strains isolated in this study can be divided into six variant strains (CH I-CH VI), and the current vaccine strains used in China constituted the Mass variant strain, which is evolutionarily distant from the Chinese isolates. Furthermore, CK/CH/GD/NC10, CK/CH/GD/KP10 and our previous isolates TC07-2 formed the CH VI lineage, which showed greater evolutionary distances than other strains. Taken together, these findings suggested that several variant strains are currently in common circulation and are constantly evolving in China, suggesting that alternative domestic vaccines indeed need effective control of IB in China. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2011.
authors: Luo, H.;Qin, J.;Chen, F.;Xie, Q.;Bi, Y.;Cao, Y.;Xue, C.

title: Serological evidence for high prevalence of influenza D viruses in cattle, Nebraska, United States, 2003–2004
authors: Luo, J.;Ferguson, L.;Smith, D. R.;Woolums, A. R.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the E2 gene of the classic swine fever virus from Guangxi Province, southern China.
abstract: In this study, samples of suspected classical swine fever (CSF) from Guangxi Province, China were obtained from pigs with acute CSF, miscarriage fetuses, newborn pigs that died at 1-2 days of age, tonsils of healthy pigs, and inoculated leukocytes. Breads in 2001-2009. Approximately 92 of 775 samples were found positive by RT-PCR and 41 isolates were obtained. Phylogenetic analysis was performed on 31 isolates by sequencing the E2 gene and found that the isolates clustered in two groups: (1) isolates from aborted fetuses (except GXGZ02), deceased newborn baby pigs, tonsils of healthy pigs, and leukocytes. Pigs co-vaccinated with vaccine strain, HCLV and standard virulent strain, China Shimen belonged to group 1.1 and (2) 20 isolates from pigs with acute CSF belonged to group 2.1, 13 of which clustered in subgroup 2.1b . The isolates from other provinces of China and 7 of these, together with the isolates from Italy and Germany, were clustered in subgroup 2.1a. © 2011 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Luo, T. R.;Liao, S. H.;Wu, X. S.;Feng, L.;Yuan, Z. X.;Li, H.;Liang, J. J.;Meng, X. M.;Zhang, H. Y.

title: Pathogenicity and genomic characterization of a pseudorabies virus variant isolated from the Bartha-K61-vaccinated pig population in China.
abstract: Pseudorabies (PR) or Aujeszky disease (AD) is a worldwide economically important viral disease caused by the pseudorabies virus (PRV). Recently, PR outbreaks have occurred in large herds of Bartha-K61-vaccinated pigs in many regions of China. Here, we isolated a PRV variant named TJ strain from a Bartha-K61-vaccinated pig farm in China, evaluated the pathogenicity of the TJ strain in susceptible animals, and analyzed its complete genomic sequence obtained by 454 pyrosequencing. The inoculation-forced experiment in sheep showed that the classical Bartha-K61 vaccine could not provide full protection against challenge with the PRV TJ strain. In mice, the 50% lethal dose (LD<inf>50</inf>) of strain TJ (10<sup>2.3</sup> TCID<inf>50</inf>) was lower than the conventional one. PRV SC strain (10<sup>3.0</sup> TCID<inf>50</inf>). Also, the TJ strain exhibited higher mortality for pigs compared to the SC strain. The genome of the PRV TJ strain was determined to be 143,642bp long, encoding 67 open reading frames. The TJ strain clustered on an independent branch with some recent PRV isolates from China in the phylogenetic tree, which is relatively distant from previous PRV isolates. The TJ strain showed unique variations in viral proteins that play a key role in the viral replication cycle. Taken together, the TJ strain is a highly pathogenic PRV variant with unique molecular signatures. More studies are needed to investigate the relationship between the virulence change of the PRV variant and the sequence differences.
authors: Luo, Y.;Li, N.;Cong, X.;Wang, C. H.;Du, M.;Li, L.;Zhao, B.;Yuan, J.;Liu, D. D.;Li, S.;Li, Y.;Sun, Y.;Qiu, H. J.

title: A molecular epidemiology study based on VP2 gene sequences reveals that a new genotype of infectious bursal disease virus is predominantly prevalent in Italy.
abstract: distinct infectious bursal disease (IBD) virus genotype (ITA) was detected in IBD-live vaccinated chickens in Italy without clinical signs of IBD. It was isolated in specific pathogen-free eggs and molecularly characterized in the hypervariable region of the virus protein (VP). From GenBank or previously reported and vaccine strains in Italy. The new genotype displays distinctive molecular features at key positions of the VP2 hypervariable region affecting charged or potentially glycosylated amino acids that are virtually associated with significant changes in virus properties. Characterization of 41 IBDV strains detected in Italy between 2013 and 2014 revealed that ITA emerged in densely populated poultry areas of Italy, accounting for 68% of IBDV detections made during routine diagnostic activity over a two-year period, despite immune-mediated stimuli. showed that it was created. with large-scale grafting. Along with eight vaccine strains, four highly virulent strains (DV86) and one classical strain (HPR2) were also detected. Currently available epidemiological and clinical data do not allow to define the degree of pathogenicity of the ITA genotype. Only in vivo experimental pathogenicity studies conducted under conditions of safe isolation, evaluation of clinical signs and macro/microscopic lesions will definitively clarify the virulence of the new Italian genotype.
authors: Lupini, C.;Giovanardi, D.;Pesente, P.;Bonci, M.;Felice, V.;Rossi, G.;Morandini, E.;Cecchinato, M.;Catelli, E.

title: Accurate and precise real-time RT-PCR tests for the identification of astrovirus-associated encephalitis in cattle
authors: LÃ¼thi, R.;Boujon, C. L.;Kauer, R.;Koch, M. C.;Bouzalas, I. G.

title: Genetic evolution of Gallid herpesvirus 2 isolated in China
abstract: Gallid herpesvirus 2 (GaHV-2), which causes Marek's disease in chickens and causes great economic losses, has recently developed increased virulence in China. To better understand the genetic basis of altered and virulence-enhancing pathogenic traits, we sequenced the genomes of six novel GaHV-2 strains (LCC, LTS, WC/1203, JL/1404, CC/1409 and HS/1412) isolated. failed immunization chickens as well as a previously isolated Chinese strain of GaHV-2, J-1. Based on multiple sequence alignment, several characteristic point mutations were detected in the open reading frames of the Chinese isolates. In addition, two deletions and one insertion were identified at the unique short region and terminal repeat short region junctions in Chinese isolates, and the insertion was a feature of the new Chinese isolates. According to a phylogenetic analysis, the GaHV-2 genome has diverged significantly over the past two decades in China. Based on the internal repeat long region, the new isolates were closely related to very virulent or very virulent plus strains. In addition, new Chinese isolates were separated from previously isolated J-1 and 814 strains. In conclusion, our results provide evidence that Chinese GaHV-2 strains contain characteristic sequences, particularly novel isolates. The genetic variation observed in new Chinese GaHV-2 strains over the past two decades may be related to the observed changes in pathogenic traits and virulence.
authors: Lv, H.;Zhang, Y.;Sun, G.;Bao, K.;Gao, Y.;Qi, X.;Cui, H.;Wang, Y.;Li, K.;Gao, L.;Pan, Q.;Wang, X.;Liu, C.

title: Gene expression analysis of pig whole blood cells infected with foot-and-mouth disease virus using high-throughput sequencing technology.
abstract: Foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV) is a single-stranded positive RNA virus belonging to the Picornaviridae family. FMDV infects cloven-hoofed animals such as pigs, sheep, goats, cattle and various wildlife species and remains a major threat to the livestock industry worldwide. In this study, a transcriptome analysis of whole blood from FMDV-infected pigs was performed using the double-ended Illumina sequencing technique to understand the interactions between the pathogen and its host cells. During infection with FMDV, a total of 120 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified, including 110 up-regulated genes and 10 down-regulated genes. Gene ontology (GO) annotation and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genes (KEGG) enrichment were performed to further investigate DEGs involved in interactions between virus and host. The GO annotation showed enrichment of a number of DEGs in categories involved in host-virus interactions, such as stimulus response, immune system process, and regulation of biological process. KEGG enrichment analysis showed that DEGs are primarily involved in the ribosome signaling pathway and immune-related signaling pathways. Ten DEGs, including immune-related genes BTK1, C1QB, TIMD4, and CXCL10, were selected and validated using quantitative PCR; this showed that the expression patterns of these genes were consistent with the results of in silico expression analysis. In conclusion, this study presents the first transcriptome analysis of FMDV-infected porcine whole blood cells, and the results obtained in this study improve our understanding of the diagnosis and control of FMD as well as the interactions between FMDV and host cells.
authors: Lv, J.;Ding, Y.;Liu, X.;Pan, L.;Zhang, Z.;Zhou, P.;Zhang, Y.;Hu, Y.

title: [Haemaphysalis punktata Canestrini et Fanzago, 1877 and the taxonomic status of Burana virus (BURV) (Bunyaviridae, Nairovirus, Tamdy group) isolated from Haem ticks. concinna Koch, 1844 (Ixodidae, Haemaphysalinae), in Kyrgyzstan]
authors: L'Vov D, K.;Al'khovskiÄ­, S. V.;Shchelkanov, M. Iu;Shchetinin, A. M.;Deriabin, P. G.;Gitel'man, A. K.;Aristova, V. A.;Botikov, A. G.

title: West Nile virus and other zoonotic viruses in Russia: examples of reemerging situations
abstract: Studies on the interactions of vertebrates, viruses and arthropod vectors of these viruses were followed in terms of different ecological groups of viruses carried by mosquitoes and ticks over an area of more than 15 million km2 in northern Eurasia. About 90 viruses have been isolated, including 24 new for science. Newly recognized infections of vertebrates, including humans, have been described. Many unusual epidemic situations were analysed. Persistent efforts have been established to prevent bioterrorist activities and their consequences. Widespread outbreaks of epidemics with unusually high death rates have occurred in southern Russia over the past four years, such as West Nile fever (WNF; i.e. fever caused by West Nile virus) and Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF). We determined infection rates in humans, domestic and wild animals, mosquitoes and ticks from natural and synanthropic biocenoses [Text note: "Synanthropic" means roughly all species that live in or near humans (see lice, fleas) as in homes (see house mice). ), parks (cf. Rattus spp.) and the like are more like "peridomestic" but not quite so; "biocenosis" is a biome, which is "the sum of the populations living in a particular habitat that is itself only a part of the ecosystem".]. CCHF virus strains were phylogenetically similar to strains isolated in this region 35 years ago but different from Central-South-Asian and African strains. Prior to the onset of the current emergence of epidemic WNF, three genetic variants of this virus had been isolated in the USSR, two African and one Indian. Phylogenetic analysis of whole genome sequences of epidemic strains showed significant similarity with strains from the USA and Israel and differences from strains isolated in the same USSR regions 20-30 years ago. In addition to the strains of genotype 1, we isolated strains of the second and third strains and a strain of a fourth genetic variant. The nucleotide differences of these strains from all three genotypes were approximately 30%. The WNF situation that has emerged in Russia over the last 4 years has probably been the result of not only natural and social factors, but also the emergence of more virulent strains or the evolution of the virus.
authors: Lvov, D. K.;Butenko, A. M.;Gromashevsky, V. L.;Kovtunov, A. I.;Prilipov, A. G.;Kinney, R.;Aristova, V. A.;Dzharkenov, A. F.;Samokhvalov, E. I.;Savage, H. M.;Shchelkanov, M. Y.;Galkina, I. V.;Deryabin, P. G.;Gubler, D. J.;Kulikova, L. N.;Alkhovsky, S. K.;Moskvina, T. M.;Zlobina, L. V.;Sadykova, G. K.;Shatalov, A. G.;Lvov, D. N.;Usachev, V. E.;Voronina, A. G.

title: Razdan virus, a novel ungrouped bunyavirus isolated from Dermacentor marginatus ticks in Armenia
abstract: virus called Razdan was isolated from Dermacentor marginatus ticks in the Armenian SSR in 1973. Complement fixation tests did not reveal an antigenic association with 74 tick-borne arboviruses. The size of the virus is about 100 nm; agglutinates goose erythrocytes at pH 5.5-7.0, is pathogenic to newborn, 14-day-old and adult white mice, and grows in primary and continuous cell cultures. The morphological features of the virus allow it to be classified as a member of the Bunyaviridae family.
authors: Lvov, D. K.;Gromashevsky, V. L.;Zakaryan, V. A.;Skvortsova, T. M.;Berezina, L. K.;Gofman, Y. P.;Klimenko, S. M.;Chubkova, A. L.

title: Batken virus, a novel arbovirus isolated from ticks and mosquitoes in the Kyrgyzstan SSR Brief report
abstract: Three virus strains were isolated in 1970. Two of these (LEIV 300 K and LEIV 306 K) were isolated from Hyalomma plumbeum plumbeum Panz., 1795, ticks were collected from sheep in the Batken District, Oshsk Province, and a virus strain mixed Aedes caspius caspius Pallas, 1771 and Culex (Neoculex) hortensis Mosquitoes were caught in the Ficalb, 1889 ponds, Leninsk Region, Oshsk Province, Kyrgyz USSR. Ticks were collected on the semi-desert foothills of the Turkestan Mountains near Batken village at 700 m above sea level (40° 04' N, 70° 51' E). A total of 146 ticks were examined by virological methods. Mosquitoes congregated in rice fields in the Naryn river valley at an altitude of 650 M above sea level (41° N, 72° E). A total of 20,000 mosquitoes from the two species were studied by virological methods. Virus isolation experiments were performed in 1-2 day old white sucking mice. Antigens were prepared from the brains of nauseated lactating mice by the sucrose acetone method. Immune acid fluids (IAF) were prepared. Serological identification of isolates was performed in complement fixation tests (CFT) with a macro method containing 57 IAF sets against arboviruses. Since all isolates were found to be serologically identical, the prototype strain LEIV 306 K can be studied in detail. Examination of the virus antigen in the CF tests revealed that it did not react with any of the IAFs used. Data collected together with the isolation of the virus from ticks and mosquitoes suggest that the virus is a new ungrouped arbovirus. It was named the Batken virus after its initial isolation.
authors: Lvov, D. K.;Karas, F. R.;Tsyrkin, Y. M.

title: Antigenic cross-reactivity among avian pneumoviruses of subgroups A, B, and C in matrix, but not nucleocapsid proteins
abstract: Earlier findings from our laboratory based on nucleotide analysis and predicted amino acid sequence identities of 15 avian pneumoviruses (APVs) isolated from the United States (subgroup C) indicate that the viruses are phylogenetically differentiated from European subgroup A and subgroup B viruses. has shown. Here, we investigated whether viruses from the three subgroups were cross-reactive in an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) assay with recombinant matrix (M) and nucleoprotein (N) proteins by testing field sera positivity for each of the APV subgroups. a Minnesota APV isolate (APV/MN2A). Sera from turkeys infected with APV subgroup A, B or C reacted with recombinant M protein derived from APV/MN2A. In contrast, the recombinant N protein from the APV/MN2A virus was reactive with sera from subtype A and C viruses, but not from subtype B virus. The results show that viruses from the three APV subtypes share antigenic homology and M protein-based ELISA is sufficient to monitor APV outbreaks but not to distinguish between different subtypes.
authors: Lwamba, H. C. M.;Halvorson, D. A.;Nagaraja, K. V.;Turpin, E. A.;Swayne, D.;Seal, B. S.;Kariuki Njenga, M.

title: Porcine circovirus type 1 (PCV1) studies in vaccine-related and other cell lines
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 1 (PCV1) is very common in pigs and has been recently reported in some rotavirus vaccines. Because animal-derived raw materials such as cells, trypsin and serum can be a major source of virus contamination in biological products, we investigated PCV1 in several cell lines from ATCC that have extensive use in research, diagnostics or diagnostics. vaccine development. These cell lines are expected to be exposed to bovine and porcine viruses during their establishment and migration history due to the use of serum and trypsin that is inappropriate according to current testing guidelines or that has not been processed using new virus inactivation methods. This study showed that Vero, MRC-5 and CEFs, which represent cell substrates used in some US licensed vaccines, and other cell lines used in research vaccines such as MDCK, HEK-293, HeLa and A549 are negative for PCV1. using a nested PCR test: some were also confirmed negative by infection analysis. However, MDBK cells used for some animal vaccines contained PCV1 sequences, although no virus was isolated. While the results suggest that PCV infection may not have occurred under previous culture conditions, recent cases of vaccine contamination highlight the need for continued efforts to reduce the possibility of virus transmission from animal-derived materials used in product manufacture. Elsevier Ltd. Published by
authors: Ma, H. L.;Shaheduzzaman, S.;Willliams, D. K.;Gao, Y. M.;Khan, A. S.

title: Identification and phylogenetic analysis of Coxsackie-virus B5 causing viral encephalitis epidemic in Henan region
abstract: Objective: To determine the pathogen that caused the viral encephalitis epidemic in Henan region in 2011. Phylogenetic analysis was performed on Coxsackie-virus B5 (CVB5) isolated during this outbreak. Methods: Five throat swabs, 21 stools, and 14 cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples were collected from 29 inpatients during this outbreak. Viral isolation and real-time RT-PCR were then performed for all samples. Enterovirus 71 (EV71), coxsackievirus A 16 (CA16), and pan-enterovirus (PE) viral nucleic acid were detected by real-time RT-PCR. The phylogenetic tree based on all VP1 sequences was constructed among CVB5 isolates from 2 stool and 3 CSF samples of 5 hospitalized patients and other published data from GenBank. Results: Real-time RT-PCR results showed that PE nucleic acid positive rates of throat swab, stool, and CSF samples were 60.0% (3/5), 61.9% (13/21) and 85.7% (12/14), respectively. . All of these samples were negative for EV71 and CA16. The isolation rates of throat swab, stool and CSF samples were 20.0% (1/5), 25.0% (5/21) and 29.0% (4/14), respectively. With both VP1 and 5'-UTR sequences and molecular typing, BLAST showed that CVB5 is the main pathogen. Analysis among 5 positive isolates based on complete VP1 sequences showed 97.9% - 99.5% homology. Data from homologous comparisons showed that these isolates had the highest nucleotide acid identity with the Changchun CVB5 CC10/10/Changchun strain (97.1% vs 98.1%), which caused an outbreak of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in Changchun in 2010. and lower identity (89.0% vs. 89.6% and 91.8% vs. 92.5%) with strain COXB5/Henan/2010 and 03001N isolated from Pingdingshan, Henan in 2010 and 2012, respectively. The phylogenetic tree in the VP1 region showed that isolates of this outbreak belonged to genotype D, the same branch as the Changchun strain. Conclusion: CVB5 was the main etiologic agent associated with this outbreak. The shift of the dominant genotype may serve as one of the causes associated with these outbreaks. Copyright © 2012 by the Chinese Medical Association.
authors: Ma, H. X.;Mu, Y. J.;Li, X. L.;Kang, K.;Huang, X. Y.;Tang, X. Y.;Wei, W.;Xu, B. L.

title: A nanoparticle-assisted PCR assay to improve sensitivity for rapid detection and differentiation of wild-type pseudorabies virus and gene deleted vaccine strains
abstract: Nanoparticle assisted polymerase chain reaction (nanoPCR) is a new method for rapid amplification of DNA and has been adopted for virus detection due to its simplicity, rapidity and specificity. A nanoPCR assay was developed to detect and distinguish between wild-type and gene-deleted pseudorabies virus (PRV). Three pairs of primers for nanoPCR developed in this study were selected from conserved regions of the PRV and produced specific amplicons of 431.bp (gB), 316.bp (gE), and 202.bp (gG). Using purified plasmid constructs containing specific gene fragments, the sensitivity of this assay was 100-1000 times higher than conventional PCR. The PRV nanoPCR assay did not amplify porcine parvovirus, porcine circovirus type 2, porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus, porcine teschovirus, or African swine fever virus, but produced three bands of the expected size with PRV and two bands of the expected size with the gene deletion. PRV-Bartha-K61. Of 110 clinical samples collected from seven provinces in China, 53% and 48%, respectively, were positive for wild-type PRV by nanoPCR assay and virus isolation. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Ma, X.;Cui, Y.;Qiu, Z.;Zhang, B.;Cui, S.

title: Completion of sequence analysis and comparisons of genome segment 2 (encoding the outer capsid protein VP2) from representative isolates of 24 bluetongue virus serotypes
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) is a non-contagious, arthropod-transmitted viral disease of domestic and wild ruminants. It is caused by bluetongue virus (BTV), a double-stranded (ds) RNA virus classified in the Orbivirus genus, family Reoviridae. There are at least twenty-four BTV serotypes worldwide, of which five (1, 2, 4, 9 and 16) have been recently identified in Europe. BTV infects ruminants and its distribution in temperate and tropical regions of the world is dependent on the activity and abundance of some vector competent species of Culicoides sandflies. The outer capsid protein of BTV, VP2, is a major protective antigen and the primary determinant of the virus serotype. For the first time, the authors completed sequence analysis of full-length VP2 genes from reference strains for each of the 24 BTV serotypes and their amino acid sequences were extracted. Multiple alignments of VP2 gene (protein) sequences revealed that the level of nucleotide (amino acid) sequence variation between serotypes ranged from 29% (23%) to 59% (73%), confirming that segment 2/VP2 was the most variable. BTV gene/protein. Phylogenetic analysis of VP2 grouped together the BTV types known to cross-react serologically. Low identity between types is demonstrated for specific regions within the VP2 amino acid sequences that have been shown to be antigenic and play a role in virus neutralization. The sequence data represents the completion of an important step in the creation of a comprehensive BTV sequence database that will support the ongoing molecular epidemiology and surveillance studies of BTV, as well as faster molecular methods for the diagnosis and identification of BTV 'types'.
authors: Maan, S.;Maan, N. S.;Samuel, A. R.;O'Hara, R.;Meyer, A. J.;Rao, S.;Mertens, P. P.

title: Development of reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction-based assays and sequencing for typing European strains of bluetongue virus and differential diagnosis of field and vaccine strains
abstract: Bluetongue virus (BTV) is a double-stranded (ds) RNA virus classified in the genus Orbivirus, family Reoviridae, that causes bluetongue disease (BT), a contagious, non-contagious disease of ruminants. The virus is currently available as 24 different serotypes identified by virus isolation and serum neutralization assays. The most variable outer capsid protein, VP2 (encoded by genome segment 2), is the primary determinant of the BTV serotype. Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) tests based on the amplification of segment 2 have been developed for the identification of five European BTV types (BTV-1, BTV-2, BTV-4, BTV-9 and BTV-). 16). Specific primer pairs were designed for each BTV serotype. The resulting RT-PCR test was both sensitive and specific and provided BTV typing within 24 hours. Excellent agreement was noted between the RT-PCR and virus neutralization experiments. Primers for each serotype were able to successfully amplify BTV isolates from different regions of that serotype and did not show cross-amplification of the most closely related BTV serotypes. RT-PCR primers have also been developed for the differentiation of field and vaccine strains of BTV serotypes currently circulating in Europe. Primer pairs capable of amplifying field and vaccine strains of BTV-1, BTV-2, BTV-4, and BTV-9 have been validated worldwide with several isolates of each serotype from various geographic origins, and their type specificities, BTV-1, BTV-2, Tested again with BTV-4 and BTV-9. most closely related serotypes. Overall, these RT-PCR assays provide a fast and reliable method for the identification and differentiation of field and vaccine strains of different types of BTV. The primers used in this study are listed on the Pirbright Institute for Animal Health website.
authors: Maan, S.;Maan, N. S.;Singh, K. P.;Samuel, A. R.;Mertens, P. P.

title: Genome-Wide Identification and Quantification of Cis- and trans-Regulated Genes Responding to Marek's Disease Virus Infection by Analysis of Allele-Specific Expression
abstract: Marek's disease (MD) is a commercially important neoplastic disease of chickens caused by Marek's disease virus (MDV), a naturally occurring oncogenic alphaherpes virus. Selecting for increased genetic resistance to MD is a control strategy that can enhance vaccine control measures. To identify high-confidence candidate MD resistance genes, we performed a genome-wide screen for allele-specific expression (ASE) between the F(1) lines of two inbred chicken lines that differed significantly in MD resistance. High-throughput sequencing was used to initially profile transcriptomes from pools of uninfected and infected individuals 4 days after infection to identify any gene that exhibits ASE in response to MDV infection. RNA sequencing identified 22,655 single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in 3,773 genes, of which 5,360 exhibit significant allelic imbalance. Illumina GoldenGate assays were then used to quantify regulated regulatory variation in the gene (cis) and elsewhere in the genome (trans) by examining the expression differences between F(1) individuals and artificial F(1) RNA pools over six time periods in 1,536. Allelic imbalance as a result of Cis-regulatory changes from the most important SNPs identified by RNA sequencing was confirmed in 861 of the 1,233 GoldenGate assays successfully examined. We also identified seven genes that only show trans-regulation in infected animals and ~500 SNPs that show a complex interaction between cis- and trans-regulatory changes. Our results suggest that ASE analyzes are a powerful approach to identify regulatory variation responsible for differences in transcript abundance in genes underlying complex traits. And genes with SNPs exhibiting ASE provide a strong basis for further investigating causal polymorphisms and genetic mechanisms for MD resistance. Finally, the methods used here to identify specific genes and SNPs have practical implications for applying marker-assisted selection to complex traits that are difficult to measure in agricultural species, while differences in expression are expected to control some of the phenotypic variance.
authors: Maceachern, S.;Muir, W. M.;Crosby, S. D.;Cheng, H. H.

title: Potential strategies for the control of blue tongue, a viral disease transmitted by Culicoides of ruminant livestock and wildlife, which has emerged globally.
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) is a non-zoonotic arboviral disease of some wild and domesticated species of ungulates. The causative agent, the bluetongue virus (BTV), spreads to temperate and tropical regions of the world by biting Culicoides midges. Control of BTV infection is complicated by the large number of virus serotypes and the ubiquity of its sandfly vector and its opportunistic feeding behavior. The global distribution of BTV infection has changed recently, perhaps in part due to climatic influences on sandfly species living in different regions. The purpose of this review is to evaluate realistic strategies that can be used to control or prevent future outbreaks of BT and other Culicoides-transmitted diseases. More importantly, optimal control of emerging, rapidly evolving arbovirus diseases such as IT will require integrated countermeasures that reduce all aspects of the virus transmission cycle. This will be best accomplished using preventive strategies rather than purely reactive strategies. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Maclachlan, N. J.;Mayo, C. E.

title: Sequence analysis of American-type swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus collected from Danish pig herds.
abstract: Vaccine-like viruses of American-type porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) were detected in serum samples by RTPCR. Viruses were analyzed by nucleotide sequencing of the genomic region encoding open reading frames 2 through 7. Danish breeder herds. These atypical viruses most likely originate from pigs vaccinated with the American-type live vaccine (MLV RespPRRS), taken to artificial insemination centers and reunited with unvaccinated pigs already in the centres. The nucleotide sequences of three Danish viruses of the American type PRRSV were compared with those of known PRRSV isolates. The nucleotide sequence identities of the atypical Danish isolates ranged from 99.299.5% against the vaccinia virus RespPRRS and 99.0-99.3% against VR2332, the parental virus of the vaccinia virus. Phylogenetic analysis including field isolates of the American type supports the conclusion that the introduction of the American type PRRSV in Denmark was due to the spread of the vaccinia virus.
authors: Madsen, K. G.;Hansen, C. M.;Madsen, E. S.;Strandbygaard, B.;BÃ¸tner, A.;SÃ¸rensen, K. J.

title: Novel molecular mechanisms of virus-mediated carcinogenesis: oncogenic transformation of cells by retroviral structural protein Envelope
abstract: Classified within retroviruses, RNA tumor viruses have been isolated and described over the past 100 years since the first was reported in 1908 to induce tumors in a variety of animals, including chickens, mice, and rats, and even humans. Tumor viruses have historically been divided into two groups, acute transforming RNA tumor viruses and non-acute RNA tumor viruses. Acute transforming RNA tumor viruses are essentially replication-defective and rapidly induce tumors by expressing viral oncogenes captured from the cellular genome in host cells. The first oncogene derived from the Rous sarcoma virus was the src non-receptor tyrosine kinase identified to play important roles in signal transduction. On the other hand, non-acute RNA tumor viruses consisting only of the gag, pro, pol and env regions but do not carry oncogenes are replication competent and can activate cellular proto-oncogenes by inserting them near the viral long terminal repeat. Proto-oncogenes induce tumors with a long incubation period called promoter insertion. These molecular mechanisms are thought to induce tumors. However, very recently several reports have disclosed that the retroviral structural protein Envelope can directly induce tumors in vivo and transform cells in vitro. These are very unusual examples of natural retroviral structural proteins with transformation potential. In this review, we look at the history of oncogenic retrovirus research and summarize recent advances in our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of oncogenic transformation by retrovirus Envelope proteins.
authors: Maeda, N.;Yoshikai, Y.

title: Molecular characterization of Orf virus in goats from Gabon, Central Africa.
abstract: Background: Orf, or contagious ecthyma, is a zoonotic viral infection with a potential serious health threat to the small ruminant industry and humans. It is currently spawning in new regions. Results: In January 2013, eight suspected clinical cases of pustular dermatitis occurred in goats in the rural area of Tebe, southeast of Gabon. Orf virus (ORFV) was detected by high-throughput sequencing on serum, buccal swabs and shell pool samples. It was validated in six out of eight patient goats using specific PCR targeting the main envelope protein (B2L) and orf virus interferon resistance (VIR) genes. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the Gabonese and South Korean strains evolved from a common ancestor, suggesting that the ORFV' Gabonese strain is of Asian origin. Conclusions: This study provides molecular detection of the ORFV strain implicated in cases of pustular dermatitis in goats and highlights its circulation in Gabon.
authors: Maganga, G. D.;Relmy, A.;Bakkali-Kassimi, L.;Ngoubangoye, B.;Tsoumbou, T.;Bouchier, C.;N'Dilimabaka, N.;Leroy, E. M.;Zientara, S.;Berthet, N.

title: Spread of Peste des Petits Ruminant Virus from Pets to Wild Ruminants in the Serengeti Ecosystem, Tanzania
abstract: We tested wildlife living near pets, pastures and water sources in the Ngorongoro region in the Serengeti ecosystem in northern Tanzania and found 63% seropositivity for peste des petits ruminant virus. Sequencing of the viral genome from sick sheep in the region confirmed lineage II virus circulation.
authors: Mahapatra, M.;Sayalel, K.;Muniraju, M.;Eblate, E.;Fyumagwa, R.;Shilinde, L.;Mdaki, M.;Keyyu, J.;Parida, S.;Kock, R.

title: Surveillance of avian influenza virus of the H5N1 subtype in backyard animals and its introduction in Bali, Indonesia.
abstract: Epidemiological studies of the avian influenza virus H5N1 (HPAIV-H5N1), which is highly pathogenic in pets and backyard animals, are limited. Here we present serological and virological evidence of infection in various animals in homes in Bali, Indonesia, in 2005 and 2006. Serum and swab samples from poultry, pigs, dogs and cats were collected using a stratified random sampling design. Antibodies to HPAIV-H5 were detected in sera using the standard hemagglutination inhibition test, and the presence of HPAIV-H5N1 in swabs was confirmed using the egg inoculation technique, a hemagglutination test, and molecular methods. The phylogeny and virus distribution were inferred using BEAST and SPREAD software. The results showed that the seroprevalence of backyard chickens to waterfowl, poultry to pigs and study year varied significantly across the province (P < 0.001). Seroprevalence in dogs and cats was 1.85% and 7.50%, respectively. In addition, HPAIV-H5N1 has been isolated in all species except cats. Isolation rates also varied between species and between years of surveillance. Virus distribution analysis showed that isolates from Bali grouped into two major branches with good statistical support. In light of these findings, HPAIV surveillance should be expanded to include all avian and mammalian species in the backyard environment.
authors: Mahardika, G. N.;Adi, A. A. A. M.;Besung, N. K.;Dharmawan, N. S.;Kencana, G. A. Y.;Rompis, A. L. T.;Sampurna, P.;Setiasih, L. E.;Suardana, W.;Suardana, I. B. K.;Suarjana, G. K.;Suartha, N.;Suartini, G. A. A.;Suwiti, N. K.;Utama, I. H.

title: Genetic analysis of bovine viral diarrhea viruses from Australia
abstract: Eighty-nine bovine viral diarrheal viruses (BVDV) from Australia were genetically typed by sequencing the 5'² untranslated region (5'²-UTR) and the Npro region of the viral genome for selected isolates. Phylogenetic reconstructions showed that all examined samples clustered in the BVDV type 1 genotype. Of the 11 previously identified genetic groups of BVDV-1, 87 of the samples examined in this study clustered with BVDV-1c, while two samples clustered with BVDV-1a. Based on these analyses, there appears to be limited genetic variation within Australian BVDV field isolates. In addition, phylogenetic reconstructions show that clustering of Australian BVDV in phylogenetic trees is not a result of geographic isolation. Â© 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Mahony, T. J.;McCarthy, F. M.;Gravel, J. L.;Corney, B.;Young, P. L.;Vilcek, S.

title: Introduction and history of the foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) has been recognized as a major epidemic threatening the cattle industry since the sixteenth century and was shown to be caused by a submicroscopic, filterable infectious agent by Loeffler and Frosch in the late nineteenth century. smaller than any known bacterium. The FMD-causing agent was thus the first vertebrate virus discovered shortly after the discovery of the tobacco mosaic virus of plants. It was not until 1920 that Waldmann and Pape created a suitable animal model for the study of FMD virus using guinea pigs, and later with the development of in vitro cell culture systems for the virus, the chemical and physical properties of FMD. The virus was elucidated throughout the rest of the twentieth century, culminating in a full description of the three-dimensional structure of the virion in 1989. FMD virus is classified as a species in the Aphthovirus genus of the Picornaviridae family. The virus is acid labile and its genome RNA contains a characteristic polyC pathway located approximately 360 nucleotides from the 5-² terminal. There are seven main serotypes and numerous subtypes in the world. The World Reference Laboratory for FMD is located in Pirbright, Surrey, UK and undertakes surveillance of FMD outbreaks through serotyping as well as genotyping of virus isolates. A major FMD outbreak occurred in the UK in 2001 and was caused by a virulent FMD virus strain that had its origins in Asia. The advantages and some disadvantages of controlling foot and mouth outbreaks with vaccination are discussed.
authors: Mahy, B. W. J.

title: Detection and phylogenetic characterization of Columbid circoviruses in Chaharmahal va Bakhtiari province, Iran
abstract: The virus genus Circovirus belongs to the family Circoviridae and includes virus species with circular single-stranded DNA genomes. Viruses are known to infect vertebrate species including pigs, dogs, pigeons and ducks. In this study, a nested polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was applied to investigate the prevalence of circoviruses in pigeons in Chaharmahal va Bakhtiari province, Iran. A total of 50 stool samples were subjected to nucleic acid extraction, PCR amplification and DNA sequencing. Nested PCR primers are designed to amplify the 508 base pair segment of the pigeon circovirus (PiCV) capsid gene.
