Of the 50 stool samples examined, 12 (24%) produced the expected DNA amplicons with the same DNA sequences. Phylogenetic analysis has grouped viruses into those classified as group A circoviruses. The viruses were closely related to PiCVs found in Poland, Northern Ireland, the USA, Nigeria and Hungary. To the authors' knowledge, this is the first report of the molecular detection and genomic characterization of PiCV from Iran.
authors: Mahzounieh, M.;Heidari Khoei, H.;Ghasemi Shamsabadi, M.;Dastjerdi, A.

title: Detection and phylogenetic analysis of swine deltacoronavirus from Guangdong Province in southern China
abstract: Porcine deltacoronavirus (PDCoV) is a newly discovered coronavirus that causes diarrhea, vomiting, and dehydration while suckling and nursing piglets. It was first reported in Hong Kong in 2012 and has since been discovered in the United States, Canada, South Korea, mainland China, Thailand, and Laos. PDCoV was experimentally proven to cause diarrhea in pigs and was positive in pigs from Guangdong, southern China. In our study, 252 fecal and intestinal samples from suckling piglets and pigs with diarrhea were investigated for common enteric viruses. We found prevalences of PDCoV (21.8%), swine epidemic diarrhea virus (65.5%), infectious gastroenteritis virus (0%), rotavirus group A (25.0%), and porcine cobuvirus (68.7%). We isolated 13 PDCoV strains and discovered that PDCoV infections are often coinfections with cobuvirus rather than the commonly associated swine epidemic diarrhea virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the S gene and N gene revealed that 11 of the 13 PDCoV strains belonged to the Chinese ancestry. As for the left two strains, a single strain (CHN-GD16-05) belonged to American and Korean ancestry, while another strain (CHN-GD16-03) was similar to a Thai strain, but only in the S gene. This suggested a possible recombination event between the Thai and the newly identified Chinese strain.
authors: Mai, K.;Feng, J.;Chen, G.;Li, D.;Zhou, L.;Bai, Y.;Wu, Q.;Ma, J.

title: [Virosphere and gyri]
abstract: New findings and concepts in the field of virology, particularly regarding the virosphere and gyri - a group of large nuclear cytoplasmic deoxyriboviruses are briefly summarized. In the context of the new understanding, major taxonomic features and virus pathogenicity are interpreted, including African swine fever.
authors: Makarov, V. V.

title: Avian Flu Virus Review
abstract: Influenza viruses are classified as A, B or C based on the antigenicity of their nucleoproteins and matrix proteins. Influenza A viruses are further divided into subtypes based on the antigenicity of two of their surface proteins, hemagglutinin and neuraminidase. All avian influenza viruses are type A viruses. While most avian influenza viruses are avirulent, a limited number of subtypes cause serious illness in birds. This difference in pathogenicity between avian influenza viruses is primarily determined by the amino acid sequence at the cleavage site of viral hemagglutinin. Since 1997, there have been numerous reports of human infection by highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses. The acquisition of the ability to cause human-to-human transmission by avian flu viruses would expose the human population to a flu epidemic crisis. Here, we review the molecular basis of the pathogenicity of avian influenza viruses in humans. [References: 8]
authors: Makino, A.;Kawaoka, Y.

title: Profile of human microRNAs in response to influenza A viruses (pH1N1, H3N2 and H5N1 subtypes)
abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play an important role in the regulation of gene silencing and are involved in many cellular processes, including inhibition of infected viral replication. This study investigated cellular miRNA expression profiles operating in response to influenza virus in the early phase of infection, which may be useful for understanding and control of viral infection. A549 cells were infected with different subtypes of influenza virus (pH1N1, H3N2 and H5N1). MiRNAs were extracted 24 hours after infection and then used for DNA library construction. All DNA libraries with different indices were pooled at equal concentration, followed by high-throughput sequencing based on the MiSeq platform. MiRNAs were identified and counted from sequencing data using MiSeq reporter software. miRNA expressions were classified as up- and down-regulated miRNAs compared to those found in uninfected cells. For the most part, each subtype of influenza A virus triggered upregulated responses in miRNA expression profiles. Hsa-miR-101, hsa-miR-193b, hsa-miR-23b, and hsa-miR-30e* were up-regulated when infected with all three subtypes of influenza A virus. The target prediction results showed that virus infection can trigger genes in cellular process, metabolic process, developmental process and biological regulation. This study has provided some insight into cellular miRNA profiling in response to various subtypes of influenza A viruses that cause epidemics in the circulation and in the human population. Regulated miRNAs may be involved in virus-host interaction or host defense mechanism, which should be investigated for effective antiviral therapeutic interventions.
authors: Makkoch, J.;Poomipak, W.;Saengchoowong, S.;Khongnomnan, K.;Praianantathavorn, K.;Jinato, T.;Poovorawan, Y.;Payungporn, S.

title: The need for new technologies for the detection of incidental agents in vaccines and other biological products
abstract: From an industrial perspective, conventional in vitro and in vivo testing for the detection of viral contaminants has demonstrated their limitations, as demonstrated by the unfortunate detection of porcine circovirus contamination in a licensed rotavirus vaccine. This contamination event illustrates gaps in the current random agent strategy and the potential use of new broader molecular detection methods. This article serves to summarize current testing approaches and challenges, along with opportunities for the use of these new technologies.
authors: Mallet, L.;Gisonni-Lex, L.

title: Non-specific immunostimulation against viruses
abstract: trypsinized preparation from the chromogenic selected strain of Mycobacterium phlei (NSI) non-specifically stimulated the recipient's immune system, for example, against various viruses. Rabies virus (RNA virus), Marek's disease (DNA virus) and Foot and Mouth disease virus (RNA virus) in phylogenetically diverse hosts such as mice, chicks and guinea pigs, respectively. The investigation of such non-specific immunostimulation mechanisms includes LMIT, lymphokine (LyIF) test and lymphocyte transformation test etc. revealed induction of potent cell-mediated immune response (CMIR) against both specific and non-specific viral antigens, as evidenced by There was induction. Significant amount of non-classic antibody (Ig) 'infectivity-inhibiting substance(s)' (IIS) in the serum of animals and birds vaccinated with NSI. This substance(s) neutralized FMD, IBR, rabies and Newcastle disease virus in cell culture, mice and embryonated eggs. Electrophoretic separation of NSI-induced serum revealed an increase in the Î² fraction of globulin.
authors: Mallick, B. B.;Kishore, S.;Das, S. K.;Garg, A.

title: Evidence of emerging porcine circovirus 2 isolation and characterization in Kazakhstan
abstract: This report describes the initial isolation and characterization of porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2) in the Republic of Kazakhstan. The virus was isolated from a dead piglet that did not exhibit the typical clinical symptoms of swine circovirus disease in a pig factory in the Northern Kazakhstan oblast (region). The virus isolated belongs to genotype 2 (PCV2) and has 96.6% sequence homology with one isolate and two strains from China and group 1, two French strains in cluster 1ab and two strains isolated from China and one from Hungary. It shares 96.4% homology with the strain. Electron microscopy revealed that the isolated virus had the morphological structure typical of PCV. This is evidence of the emergence of porcine circovirus 2 isolation and characterization in Kazakhstan.
authors: Mambetaliyev, M.;Yesimbekova, N. B.;Strochkov, V. M.;Tabynov, K. K.;Sultankulova, K. T.;Abduraimov, Y. O.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis of Murray Valley encephalitis virus and West Nile virus (Kunjin subtype) from an equine arbovirus disease outbreak in Victoria, Australia in 2011.
abstract: The virus has been detected in the central nervous system (CNS) tissue of 11 horses from Victoria who died of neurological symptoms during a disease outbreak in Australia in 2011. Five horses infected with Murray Valley encephalitis virus (MVEV) and 6 horses infected with West Nile virus subtype Kunjin (WNVKUN). Analysis of partial sequence information from the NS5 and E genes showed that MVEVs within the samples were highly homogeneous and all belonged to lineage I enzootic to tropical regions of northern Australia. Similarly, analysis of partial NS5 and E gene and whole genome sequences showed that WNVKUN within the samples was also highly homogeneous and clustered with WNV strain 1, clade b, which is consistent with other WNVKUN isolates. The complete genomes of 1 MVEV isolate and 2 WNVKUN isolates were sequenced and characterized. The genome sequences of Victorian WNVKUN are nearly identical (3 amino acid differences) to those of the recently sequenced WNV isolate WNVNSW2011. Metagenome sequencing directly from CNS tissue identified the presence of WNVKUN and MVEV in infected CNS tissue. Â© 2013 Author(s).
authors: Mann, R. A.;Fegan, M.;O'Riley, K.;Motha, J.;Warner, S.

title: Investigation of the diversity of the 18S SSU rRNA hypervariable region of Theileria in cattle and Cape buffalo (Syncerus caffer) from South Africa using a next-generation sequencing approach.
abstract: The molecular classification and systematics of Theileria is based on the analysis of the 18S rRNA gene. Reverse blot or conventional sequencing approaches have disadvantages in the study of 18S rRNA diversity, and a next-generation 454 sequencing approach has been investigated. The 18S rRNA gene was amplified using RLB primers linked to 96 unique sequence identifiers (MIDs). Theileria positive samples from African buffalo (672) and cattle (480) from South Africa were pooled in batches of 96 and sequenced using the GS Junior 454 sequencer to produce 825711 informative sequences. Sequences were extracted based on MIDs and analyzed to identify Theileria genotypes. While the genotypes observed in buffalo and cattle were confirmed in this study, no new genotypes were discovered. Genotypes showed specific geographic distributions, most likely linked to vector distributions. The host specificity of the buffalo and bovine genotypes was confirmed and the relative parasitemia trends as well as the prevalence data indicate preference for different hosts. Mixed infections are common in African buffalo, which carry more genotypes than cattle. Relational or exclusionary co-infection profiles were observed between genotypes that may have implications for speciation and systematic: more Theileria species than currently recognized may be found, particularly in cattle and buffalo. Analysis of the primers used for the diagnosis of Theileria parva shows that no new genotypes will be amplified by existing primer sets, confirming their specificity. T. parva SNP variants occurring in the 18S rRNA hypervariable region were confirmed. The next-generation sequencing approach is useful in gaining comprehensive knowledge of 18S rRNA diversity and prevalence of Theileria, and allows the evaluation of systematic and diagnostic analyzes based on the 18S gene.
authors: Mans, B. J.;Pienaar, R.;Ratabane, J.;Pule, B.;Latif, A. A.

title: Animal-Associated Microbiomes: Their Impact on Livestock and Animal Production
authors: Mantovani, H. C.;Lopes, D. R. G.;Bento, C. B. P.

title: Infectious particles, stress and induced prion amyloids: A unifying perspective.
abstract: Infectious encephalopathies (TSEs) are believed by many to result from spontaneous conversion of the host prion protein (PrP) to a non-nucleic acid infectious amyloid (PrP-res, PrPSc). Many TSE agents are present in the environment and infection is controlled by public health measures. These include the disappearance of kuru with the end of ritual cannibalism, the dramatic reduction of epidemic bovine encephalopathy (BSE) by removal of contaminated feed, and the absence of endemic scrapie in geographically isolated Australian sheep with susceptible PrP genotypes. While prion protein modeling provides an intense focus on common types of protein misfolding and amyloid formation in a variety of organisms and diseases, the biological properties of infectious TSE agents and their recognition as foreign entities by the host reveal several fundamental new directions for efficient research. For example: (1) unrecognized microbial agents in the environmental metagenome that can cause latent neurodegenerative disease, (2) evolutionary social and protective functions of different amyloid proteins in organisms ranging from bacteria to mammals, and (3) the innate immune response to stress as a beneficial amyloid formation (infectious and non-infectious). But this innate process, once initiated, can become unstoppable in accelerated neuronal aging. © 2013 Landes Bioscience.
authors: Manuelidis, L.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of M genes of influenza viruses isolated from free-flying waterfowl from the Northern Territory to Hokkaido, Japan.
abstract: Between 2000 and 2007, 218 influenza viruses were isolated from 28 different combinations of HA (H1-H13) and NA (N1-N9) subtypes from fecal samples of free-flying waterfowl in two remote lakes in Hokkaido, Japan. Phylogenetic analysis of matrix (M) genes of 67 strains selected according to their subtype combinations revealed that A/duck/Hokkaido/W95/2006 (H10N8) is a reassortant of the M gene for North American gulls. bird and seven other genes belong to non-Eurasian gull bird lineages. The M genes of the other 65 strains belonged to non-Eurasian gull-non-avian and one Eurasian gull strains. The M genes of 65 strains were grouped into three distinct sublineages, indicating that influenza viruses circulating in different populations of free-flying waterfowl evolved independently in nature. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Manzoor, R.;Sakoda, Y.;Mweene, A.;Tsuda, Y.;Kishida, N.;Bai, G. R.;Kameyama, K. I.;Isoda, N.;Soda, K.;Naito, M.;Kida, H.

title: Identification of Clade E Avipoxvirus, Mozambique, 2016
abstract: Analysis of shell samples collected from poultry during the poultry disease outbreaks in Mozambique in 2016 revealed the presence of guideline E avipoxviruses. Infected poultry were from flocks vaccinated against avian pox virus. These findings warrant an urgent reassessment of vaccine formulation and control strategies in this country.
authors: Mapaco, L. P.;Lacerda, Z.;Monjane, I. V. A.;Gelaye, E.;Sussuro, A. H.;Viljoen, G. J.;Dundon, W. G.;Acha, S. J.

title: Development of RT-qPCR assays for specific identification of two major genotypes of avian infectious bronchitis virus
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (Gammacoronavirus, Coronaviridae) is a genetically variable RNA virus (27.6 kb) that causes one of the most persistent respiratory diseases in poultry. The virus is classified into genotypes with different epidemiological relevance and clinical implications. This study reports the development and validation of specific RT-qPCR assays for the detection of two major IBV genotypes: South America I (SAI) and Asia/South America II (A/SAII). The SAI genotype is a special and widespread South American strain, while the A/SAII genotype is distributed in Asia, Europe, and South America. Both identification assays use TaqMan probes that hybridize with unique sequences in the spike glycoprotein gene. The tests successfully detected all strains evaluated for both genotypes and showed high specificity and absence of cross-reactivity. Using serial dilutions of in vitro transcribed RNA, we obtained acceptable detection coefficients, PCR efficiencies, and relatively small intra- and inter-assay variability. The tests showed a wide dynamic range between 101-107 and 102-107 RNA copies/reaction for SAI and A/SAII strains, respectively. The possibility of rapidly, sensitively and reproducibly characterizing large numbers of samples makes these techniques suitable tools for routine testing, IBV control and epidemiological research in poultry.
authors: Marandino, A.;TomÃ¡s, G.;HernÃ¡ndez, M.;Panzera, Y.;Craig, M. I.;Vagnozzi, A.;Vera, F.;Techera, C.;Grecco, S.;Banda, A.;HernÃ¡ndez, D.;PÃ©rez, R.

title: Whole genome characterization of strains of Uruguayan avian infectious bronchitis virus reveals extensive recombination between two major South American lineages.
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (Gammacoronavirus, Coronaviridae) is a genetically variable RNA virus that causes one of the most persistent respiratory diseases in poultry. The virus is classified into genotypes and lineages with different epidemiological relevance. Two strains (11 and 16) of the GI genotype have circulated widely in South America for decades. The GI-11 strain is a special South American strain, while the GI-16 strain is distributed in Asia, Europe, and South America. Here, we obtained the entire genome of two Uruguayan strains of the GI-11 and GI-16 strains using Illumina high-throughput sequencing. The strains listed here are the first strains obtained for the infectious bronchitis virus in South America and provide new insights into the origin, spread and evolution of viral variants. The complete genomes of GI-11 and GI-16 strains have 27,621 and 27,638 nucleotides, respectively, and have the same genomic organization. Phylogenetic discordance analysis reveals that both strains have a mosaic genome that arose by recombination between the European Asian strains of the GI-16 lineage and the ancestral South American GI-11 viruses. The recombination occurred in South America and produced two viral variants that retained the full-length S1 sequences of the parental strains but were extremely similar in the remainder of their genomes. These recombinant viruses have been extraordinarily successful and have been present for several years on the continent with a notoriously wide geographic distribution. Our findings reveal a singular viral dynamic and highlight the importance of complete genomic characterization for understanding the emergence and evolutionary history of viral variants.
authors: Marandino, A.;TomÃ¡s, G.;Panzera, Y.;Greif, G.;Parodi-Talice, A.;HernÃ¡ndez, M.;Techera, C.;HernÃ¡ndez, D.;PÃ©rez, R.

title: A novel approach to investigate host-pathogen interactions of bovine digital dermatitis, a complex polymicrobial infection model.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Polymicrobial infections pose a major challenge for elucidating disease etiology and developing comprehensive diagnostic or therapeutic tools, particularly for growing and hard-to-cultivate bacteria. Using bovine digital dermatitis (DD) as a disease model, we present a new strategy to study the pathogenesis of complex infections. RESULTS: The strategy combines meta-transcriptomics with high-density peptide-microarray technology to screen for microbial genes expressed in vivo and host antibody response at the site of infection. Bacterial expression patterns supported the assumption that treponems were the major DD pathogens, but also showed active involvement of other phyla (primarily Bacteroidetes). Bacterial genes involved in chemotaxis, flagellar synthesis, and protection against oxidative and acidic stress were among the major factors defining the disease. RESULTS: The remarkable variation observed in bacterial expression, antigens, and host antibody responses among individual cows pointed to microbial variability as a hallmark of DD. Persistence of infection and DD re-infection in the same individual are common; therefore, high microbial diversity may impair the host's capacity to mount an efficient immune response and maintain immune memory against DD. Common antigenic markers identified here using high-density peptide microarray address this issue and may be useful for future preventive measures against DD.
authors: Marcatili, P.;Nielsen, M. W.;Sicheritz-Ponten, T.;Jensen, T. K.;Schafer-Nielsen, C.;Boye, M.;Nielsen, M.;Klitgaard, K.

title: Characterization of the h5n1 influenza virus isolated during an epidemic among wild birds in Russia (tuva republic) in 2010.
abstract: study of key biological characteristics of the H5N1 subtype strain isolated during an outbreak among wild birds in Russia in 2010 is presented. The study was carried out using conventional methods according to WHO recommendations. The H5N1 influenza virus isolated in Siberia belonged to the 2.3.2 clade of the hemagglutinin gene and phylogenetic analysis was performed. Antigenic properties and basic genetic markers of biological traits were investigated. All strains have been shown to be highly pathogenic to chickens and white mice. Thus, in Russia, the 2010 H5N1 virus, which is phylogenetically closely related to Asian variants, has been shown to cause epizootics among wild birds. The potential danger to humans of this variant of the virus has been confirmed by different methods. We discussed the possibility of formulating the natural focus of H5N1 influenza. Â© 2011 Allerton Press, Inc.
authors: Marchenko, V. Yu;Sharshov, K. A.;Silko, N. Yu;Susloparov, I. M.;Durymanov, A. G.;Zaykovskaya, A. V.;Alekseev, A. Yu;Smolovskaya, O. V.;Stefanenko, A. P.;Malkova, E. M.;Shestopalova, A. M.

title: Nairobi sheep disease virus, an important tick-borne pathogen in sheep and goats in Africa, is also present in Asia.
abstract: Nairobi sheep disease (NSD) virus is the prototype of the tick-borne NSD serogroup, genus Nairovirus, family Bunyaviridae. It is highly pathogenic to sheep and goats, causes disease in humans, and is common in East Africa. Ganjam virus has caused disease in goats and humans in India. Because of their presence on different continents and associated with different ticks, these viruses were considered distinct despite serological cross-reactivity. S RNA genome segments and encoded nucleocapsid proteins were found to be 1590 nucleotides and 482 amino acids long and differed only 10% and 3% in nucleotide and amino acid levels, respectively. Genetic and serological data suggest that Ganjam virus is an Asian variant of the NSD virus. These viruses were phylogenetically closer to Hazara virus than Dugbe virus. © 2002 Elsevier Science (USA).
authors: Marczinke, B. I.;Nichol, S. T.

title: A highly virulent genotype of infectious bursal disease virus associated predominantly with recurrent infectious bursal disease outbreaks in vaccinated herds in Tunisia.
abstract: Infectious bursal disease (IBD) outbreaks continue to affect the Tunisian poultry industry, even in flocks with a strict vaccination schedule. To characterize viruses that exceed the protection afforded by vaccination, field isolates of infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) from vaccinated flocks that experienced repeated IBDV epidemic episodes were analyzed from bursal samples by reverse transcription coupled with polymerase chain reaction and dideoxynucleotide sequencing. VP2 hypervariable region. Although sequence data were obtained from samples collected from three different flocks over a 3-year period, only limited sequence variation was observed. Few nucleotide changes were silent and the deduced amino acid sequences were identical. Thus, the dominant virus population in the field appears to represent a homogeneous antigenic pool. Compared with the VP2 sequences of several IBDV strains, this dominant pool was found to be closely related to the highly virulent (vv) IBDV viruses identified in Europe and Asia. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the lead polyprotein coding sequence of a representative Tunisian isolate further confirmed its assignment to the vv genotype. The inferred amino acid sequence of the entire polyprotein of the Tunisian isolate was found to be identical to that of a South Korean IBDV strain. Alignment of the polyprotein amino acid sequence of 35 IBDV strains identified additional mutations outside the VP2 variable domain and frequently occurring in vv strains. Based on this comparative analysis, the group of amino acid residues that should represent a typical vv profile includes Ala222, Ile242, Ile256, Ile294, Leu451, Tyr680, N685, Ser715, Asp751, Val990, and Ala1005. Such a combination of amino acid changes was observed for most of the vvIBDV strains that defined a different phylogroup.
authors: Mardassi, H.;Khabouchi, N.;Ghram, A.;Namouchi, A.;Karboul, A.

title: Complete genome sequences of pigeon adenovirus 1 and duck adenovirus 2 increase the number of species within the genus Aviadenovirus
abstract: The complete genomes of the first isolates of pigeon adenovirus 1 (PiAdV-1) and Muscovy duck adenovirus (duck adenovirus 2, DAdV-2) were sequenced. The PiAdV-1 genome is 45,480. bp in length and has a gene organization most similar to turkey adenovirus 1. Near the left end of the genome, ORF0 lacks ORF1A, ORF1B and ORF1C and has ORF52, whereas six new genes were found near the right end. The DAdV-2 genome is 43,734. bp in length and has a gene organization similar to that of goose adenovirus 4 (GoAdV-4). ORF51 lacks ORF1C and ORF54 and has ORF55A and five other novel genes. The PiAdV-1 and DAdV-2 genomes contain two and one fiber genes, respectively. Genome organization, G+C content, molecular phylogeny, and host type confirm the need to establish two new species (Pigeon aviadenovirus A and Duck aviadenovirus B) within the genus Aviadenovirus. Phylogenetic data suggest that DAdV-2 is most closely related to GoAdV-4. © 2014 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Marek, A.;KajÃ¡n, G. L.;Kosiol, C.;Harrach, B.;SchlÃ¶tterer, C.;Hess, M.

title: Two fiber genes of nearly equal length are a common and distinctive feature of Fowl adenovirus C members.
abstract: The whole genome or genome region was sequenced, containing two fiber genes of the two reference strains and a domain isolate representing both serotypes of Fowl adenovirus C. Two fiber genes were uncovered in the genomes of all three isolates. The fiber-1 and fiber-2 genes of several Fowl adenovirus C isolates were also sequenced. Serotypes 4 and 10 both have two fiber genes. The genome region containing the fiber gene was also sequenced for the reference strain of Fowl adenovirus B. Only one fiber gene was revealed in this strain. The predicted amino acid sequences were compared with currently published fiber sequences of different adenovirus isolates and an amino acid substitution within fiber-2 was detected in all Fowl adenovirus C isolates isolated from chickens with hepatitis-hydropericardium syndrome compared to apathogenic isolates. Phylogenetic analyzes provided insight into the evolution of fiber genes and their genetic relationships in avian adenoviruses.
authors: Marek, A.;Nolte, V.;Schachner, A.;Berger, E.;Schlotterer, C.;Hess, M.

title: When African swine fever plays out at home - Description of an epidemic in Namibia
abstract: Introduction - African swine fever (ASF) is considered the most serious health threat to the global swine industry and is caused by a complex linear double-stranded DNA virus (ASF virus, ASFV) currently classified as the only member of the Asfarviridae family. . Purpose - To describe an outbreak of ASF that occurred in Namibia, where it was managed during international cooperation led by the Istituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale dell'Abruzzo e Molise "G. Caporale" (Teramo, Italy). Materials and methods - The ASF outbreak occurred in the Omaruru (Namibia) area and affected a small herd of about 100 pigs. The herd was part of a hunting farm and was very close to a small slaughterhouse where wild boars were recently slaughtered. The clinical manifestations begin abruptly and affect pigs of different age classes. Two pig autopsies were performed for diagnostic purposes: histopathology, direct immunofluorescence and polymerase chain reaction. Results - At autopsy, generalized hemorrhagic lesions were seen in all pigs examined. Microscopically, recent hemorrhages were observed with a severe lymphocytolysis in all lymphoid tissues. Laboratory investigations confirmed the diagnosis of ASF. The epidemic was finally resolved by stigma. Discussion - ASFV infection in Africa is strictly linked to the "silvatic cycle" involving wild boars and ticks of the Ornithodoros moubata complex. Mechanisms of transmission from wildlife and domestic pigs are still unclear, but ticks likely play a key role. Therefore, the ASF outbreak described here may represent the prototype of ASF in South Africa. In this region, eradication of ASFV seems unlikely and ASF control should focus on biosecurity measures. As in this report, acute ASF usually occurs with very high morbidity and mortality, at least in previously unexposed pigs. On the contrary, subclinical and chronic infections are more common in endemic areas. Pathological findings are extremely helpful for diagnosing and eliminating ASF. A number of hemorrhagic diseases should be considered in the differential diagnosis. Anamnestic and epidemiological data help to properly handle the diagnostic process. Conclusions - The latest outbreak in Eastern Europe confirms further confirmation of ASF, a serious transboundary disease still negatively affecting the swine industry worldwide. The epidemiological and pathological features described here have diagnostic value and are important for promptly eliminating the spread and economic impact of the disease.
authors: Marruchella, G.;Maseke, M.;Scacchia, M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of rabies viruses from Sudan provides evidence of a viral clade with a unique molecular signature.
abstract: Rabies is endemic in Sudan and remains a constant threat to public health, as transmission to humans is mainly dog mediated. In addition, large-scale animal losses each year cause economic and social dilemmas. In this study, we analyzed a cohort of 143 rabies viruses circulating in Sudan collected from 10 different animal species between 1992 and 2006. Partial nucleoprotein sequence data (400 bp) were obtained and compared with available sequence data of African classical rabies virus (RABV). isolates. The Sudanese sequences formed a distinct cluster within the African 1a group, which included few sequences clustered with sequences from Ethiopian RABV. These latter sequences share an Aspartic Acid at position 106 (Asp106) with all other African group 1a members, in contrast to the remaining Sudan strains that encode Glutamic Acid (Glu106) at this location. Furthermore, when representatives of other African and European ancestry are aligned, Glu106 is unique to Sudan, supporting the concept of a single distinct virus strain circulating in Sudan. High sequence identity in all Sudan isolates studied indicates the presence of a single rabies virus biotype, with the domestic dog as the main reservoir. Crown Copyright © 2009.
authors: Marston, D. A.;McElhinney, L. M.;Ali, Y. H.;Intisar, K. S.;Ho, S. M.;Freuling, C.;MÃ¼ller, T.;Fooks, A. R.

title: Zoonotic aspects of rotaviruses
abstract: Rotaviruses are important enteric pathogens of humans and animals. Group A rotaviruses (GARVs) cause up to 1 million child deaths each year, mainly in developing countries, and human vaccines are now available in many countries. Rotavirus-associated enteritis is a major problem in livestock, particularly in young calves and piglets. Early epidemiological studies of GARV in humans identified either sporadic cases or outbreaks caused by atypical, animal-like GARV strains. Whole genome sequencing of human and animal GARV strains revealed striking genetic heterogeneity in 11 double-stranded RNA segments across different rotavirus strains, providing evidence for frequent intersections between the evolution of human and animal rotaviruses as a result of multiple repetitive events. interspecies transmission and subsequent adaptation. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Martella, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Matthijnssens, J.;Buonavoglia, C.;Ciarlet, M.

title: Enteric viral infections in lambs or children
abstract: Diarrhea in lambs and puppies is often a complex, multifactorial syndrome. Common infectious causes of diarrhea in lambs and kids in the first month of life are bacterial or parasitic in nature. However, despite remarkable advances in management practices and prevention and treatment strategies over the past decade, diarrhea is still a common and costly syndrome that affects newborn small ruminants. Recent advances in diagnostic and metagenomic research of the enteric medium have allowed the discovery of a number of new viruses, although their pathobiological characteristics are largely unknown. A more in-depth assessment of the impact of these viruses on the health and production of these livestock is required and requires the development of accurate diagnostic tools and updating of diagnostic algorithms for enteric pathological conditions.
authors: Martella, V.;Decaro, N.;Buonavoglia, C.

title: Novel Parvovirus Related to Primate Bufaviruses in Dogs
abstract: new strain of protoparvovirus genetically related to human bufaviruses has been identified in dogs with respiratory symptoms. Canine bufavirus is distantly related to the well-known canine protoparvovirus, canine parvovirus type 2, sharing low amino acid identities in nonstructural protein 1 (40.6%) and capsid protein 1 (33.4%). By screening fecal, nasal, and oropharyngeal specimen collections from juvenile dogs (<= 1 year old), canine bufavirus DNA emerged as a common component of canine virome. The virus was prevalent in stool samples from dogs with or without enteric disease, and in nasal and oropharyngeal swab samples from dogs with respiratory manifestations. However, no virus was detected in nasal and oropharyngeal swab samples from animals without clinical signs.
authors: Martella, V.;Lanave, G.;Mihalov-Kovacs, E.;Marton, S.;Varga-Kugler, R.;Kaszab, E.;Di Martino, B.;Camero, M.;Decaro, N.;Buonavoglia, C.;Banyai, K.

title: Rapid detection, complete genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of swine deltacoronavirus
abstract: In February 2014, swine deltacoronavirus (PDCoV) was detected in the United States. We developed a PDCoV real-time reverse transcription PCR that identified PDCoV in 30% of the samples tested. Four additional PDCoV genomes from the United States were sequenced; they had = 99%-100% nt similarity to other US PDCoV strains.
authors: Marthaler, D.;Raymond, L.;Jiang, Y.;Collins, J.;Rossow, K.;Rovira, A.

title: Common rotavirus H in commercially reared pigs, United States
abstract: We investigated the presence of rotavirus H (RVH) identified in pigs from Japan and Brazil in US pigs. Out of 204 samples collected between 2006 and 2009, we identified RVH in 15% of stool samples from 10 US states, suggesting that RVH has been in circulation in the US since 2002, but possibly longer.
authors: Marthaler, D.;Rossow, K.;Culhane, M.;Goyal, S.;Collins, J.;Matthijnssens, J.;Nelson, M.;Ciarlet, M.

title: VP6 genetic diversity, reclassification, intragenic recombination and classification of rotavirus B in American and Japanese pigs
abstract: Rotavirus B (RVB) has been identified as a diarrhea-causing agent in rats, humans, cattle, lambs and pigs. Recently, 20 RVB VP7 genotypes were identified based on 80% nucleotide percent cut-off. In this study, we sequenced the RVB VP6 gene segment from 80 RVB-positive pig samples from the United States and Japan. Phylogenetic analyzes using 30 existing RVB VP6 sequences from GenBank and our 80 new RVB VP6 sequences revealed a large genetic diversity of RVB strains, mainly in pigs. For classification purposes, pairwise identity frequency analyzes suggested a nucleotide percent cut-off value of 81%, resulting in 13 RVB VP6(I) genotypes. In addition, an intragenic recombinant RVB VP6 segment from Japan was identified. Furthermore, the data show frequent reassortment events occurring between porcine RVB VP7 and VP6 gene segments. Â© 2014 Authors.
authors: Marthaler, D.;Suzuki, T.;Rossow, K.;Culhane, M.;Collins, J.;Goyal, S.;Tsunemitsu, H.;Ciarlet, M.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Pestivirus infections at the interface of wild and domesticated ruminants in the French Southern Alps
abstract: In alpine pastures, interspecies transmission has recently been implicated in the epidemiology of pestivirus infection. The aim of this study was to investigate pestivirus infections in wild and domestic ruminants sharing pastures in the French Southern Alps. Animal sera were screened for pestivirus antibodies to the pestivirus NS3 protein with a commercial blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). All 38 native flocks tested were positive for pestivirus-specific antibodies. Individual seroprevalence reached 76.5% (95% CI [95% CI]: [74.2-78.8%]) of 1383 sheep tested. For wild ruminants, 38.7% (95% CI: [33.8-43.9%]) of 369 ibex tested, 28.7% (95% CI: [17.4-38.1%]) and 22.2% of 72 roe deer. (95%) 27 mouflons CI: [6.5-37.9%]) were seropositive. Virus screening was performed by a conventional reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) on spleen samples from hunted wild animals (.n=.160) and 15 domestic ruminants (clinically suspected to be permanently infected). Three pestivirus strains were isolated from positive sheep samples by RT-PCR. Viruses were classified in the genotypes BDV-3, BDV-Tunisia and BDV-6. For the first time, a strain (strain RUPI-05) was isolated from a mountain chamois and clustered in the BDV-6 genotype, showing 92% identity with the sheep isolate from the same area in the 5'-UTR region. Thus, an active circulation of pestiviruses was demonstrated in both wild and domestic ungulates in the French Southern Alps. The results indicate that interspecies crossing is likely to occur between sheep and chamois.
authors: Martin, C.;Duquesne, V.;Adam, G.;Belleau, E.;Gauthier, D.;Champion, J. L.;Saegerman, C.;ThiÃ©ry, R.;Dubois, E.

title: Recombination in eukaryotic single-stranded DNA viruses
abstract: While single-stranded (ss) DNA viruses that infect humans and domesticated animals do not usually cause major disease, arthropod-derived ssDNA viruses of plants do, severely restricting food production in most temperate regions of the world. Besides the well-known ssDNA viruses that infect plants and animals, it has recently become clear, through metagenomic studies of ssDNA molecules, that a large number of other diverse ssDNA viruses are also present in nearly all terrestrial and aquatic environments. The host sequences of these viruses likely span the tree of life and will likely become important components of global ecosystems. Various evidence suggests that an important evolutionary process during the formation of this global ssDNA virus diversity was probably genetic recombination. Highly homologous recombination, non-homologous recombination, and genome component reassortment are known to occur within and between a variety of different ssDNA virus strains, and here we look at the diverse roles these different types of recombination can both play from day to day. everyday biology and the long-term evolution of these viruses. We specifically focus on the ecological, biochemical and selective factors underlying the patterns of genetic variation detectable among ssDNA viruses and discuss how all of these should be taken into account when assessing the adaptive value of recombination during ssDNA virus evolution. Â© 2011 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Martin, D. P.;Biagini, P.;Lefeuvre, P.;Golden, M.;Roumagnac, P.;Varsani, A.

title: The course of BVDV-2 infection in a dairy herd. a case study
abstract: Objective: A serious, acute clinical disease case that causes high economic losses following BVDV-2 infection in a dairy herd is described and the course of the infection is monitored. Material and methods: The affected herd consisted of 25 Deutsch Fleckvieh cows and their calves. The farm does not contain BHV-1 and the annual milk production averages 6500 kg. Disease cases and clinical manifestations from September 2002 to April 2003 were collected and analyzed. Evidence of BVDV-antibodies was carried out by indirect antibody-ELISA. BVDV-antigens were detected by antigen-ELISA and immunofluorescence flow cytometry. Isolated viruses were classified as BVDV-2 using monoclonal antibodies and PCR. Results: Six cows and one heifer fell with hemorrhagic enteritis. Two of these cows were euthanized and one cow died during illness. Six cows gave birth or gave birth prematurely. In addition, four calves died and three calves born weak or had severe diarrhea were euthanized. Two calves remained persistently infected. As the cause of the disease, infection of the flock with BVDV-2 was diagnosed. Outcome and clinical relevance: The results show that the flock was BVDV-2 naive prior to infection. The virus must have circulated in the herd for some time, even without the presence of permanently infected animals.
authors: Martin, R.;Kuhne, S.;Mansfeld, R.

title: Genomic characterization of a rotavirus G8P[1] detected in a child with diarrhea reveals direct animal-to-human transmission.
abstract: Group A rotavirus is the leading cause of severe gastroenteritis in children and young animals. We detected the presence of viral metagenomic and bovine rotavirus sequences during a retrospective analysis of samples from Paraguayan children under 5 years of age with diarrhea and previously negative for rotavirus and norovirus. The nucleic acid was extracted directly from the stool sample and determined to be G8P[1]. Genomic analyzes revealed that the strain presented an Artiodactyl-like genome (G8-P[1]-I2-R2-C2-M1-Ax-N2-T6-E12-H3), suggesting a direct transmission from animal to human.
authors: Martinez, M.;Phan, T. G.;Galeano, M. E.;Russomando, G.;Parreno, V.;Delwart, E.;Parra, G. I.

title: Molecular and phylogenetic analysis of bovine coronavirus based on the spike glycoprotein gene.
abstract: Bovine coronavirus has been associated with diarrhea in newborn calves, winter dysentery in adult cattle, and respiratory infections in calves and beef cattle. In Cuba, the presence of BCoV was first reported in 2006. Since then, sporadic outbreaks have continued to occur. This study aimed to deepen the knowledge about the evolution, virulence molecular markers and epidemiology of BCoV in Cuba. A total of 30 samples collected between 2009 and 2011 were used for PCR amplification and direct sequencing of the partial or complete S gene. Sequence comparison and phylogenetic studies were performed using partial or complete S gene sequences as phylogenetic markers. All Cuban bovine coronavirus sequences were placed in a single cluster supported by 100% bootstrap and posterior probability values of 1.00. Cuban bovine coronavirus sequences were also clustered with US BCoV strains corresponding to GenBank accession numbers EF424621 and EF424623, suggesting a common origin for these viruses. This phylogenetic cluster was also the only sequence group in which no recombination events were detected. Of the 45 amino acid changes found in Cuban strains, four were unique. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: MartÃ­nez, N.;BrandÃ£o, P. E.;de Souza, S. P.;Barrera, M.;Santana, N.;de Arce, H. D.;PÃ©rez, L. J.

title: Swine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus isolates differ in their susceptibility to neutralization.
abstract: Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome Virus (PRRSV) is highly heterogeneous. This heterogeneity has an impact on the antigenic composition of PRRSV and may create differences in susceptibility to neutralization between isolates. Susceptibility to neutralization may be an important feature of PRRSV isolates, as neutralization-resistant isolates are likely to pose a significant challenge for the development of vaccines that confer broad protective immunity. However, little information is available to understand or categorize the viral neutralization phenotype of PRRSV isolates. In conclusion, the main purpose of this study is to determine whether PRRSV isolates differ in their neutralization susceptibility and can be classified into different categories according to their neutralization phenotype. For this purpose, a panel of 39 PRRSV isolates and a set of 30 hyperimmune monospecific sera were used in cross-neutralization experiments. The results of this study show that PRRSV isolates differ in their susceptibility to neutralization, and the k-means clustering system allows isolates to be classified into four different categories based on their neutralization phenotype: highly susceptible, susceptible, intermediate, and neutralization-resistant. Other analyzes using two additional clustering systems that take into account individual data for classification of isolates confirmed that the classification obtained by k-means was correct in most cases, and in only a few cases the classification was less stringent. The GP3, GP4 and GP5 sequences were analyzed, but no correlation was found between the sequence of predefined neutralizing epitopes or the number of N-linked glycosylation sites in different proteins and the neutralization phenotype of the isolates. These data provide the first systematic assessment of the overall neutralization sensitivities of a panel of various PRRSV isolates. Classification of isolates provides a useful tool to facilitate the systematic characterization of neutralizing antibody production elicited by new vaccine candidates. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: MartÃ­nez-Lobo, F. J.;DÃ­ez-Fuertes, F.;Simarro, I.;Castro, J. M.;Prieto, C.

title: Whole genome sequencing of a rare rotavirus from an archived fecal sample demonstrates independent zoonotic origin of human G8P[14] strains in Hungary.
abstract: Rotaviruses of genotype P[14] in humans are thought to be zoonotic strains originating from cattle or ovine species. In the past 30 years, only a few genotype P[14] strains have been identified, accounting for <0.1% of all genotyped human rotaviruses in Hungary. In this study, we report the genome sequence and phylogenetic analysis of a human genotype G8P[14] strain, RVA/Human-wt/HUN/182-02/2001/G8P[14]. The whole genome constellation of this strain (G8-P[14]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A11-N2-T6-E2-H3) was shared with another Hungarian zoonotic G8P[14] strain, RVA/Human-wt. /HUN/BP1062/2004/G8P[14], however, phylogenetic analyzes revealed that the two rotaviruses likely have different progenitors. Overall, our findings suggest that human G8P[14] rotavirus, which has been detected in Hungary in the past, is due to independent zoonotic events. Further studies are needed to assess the public health risk associated with infections caused by various strains of animal rotavirus.
authors: Marton, S.;DÃ³rÃ³, R.;FehÃ©r, E.;ForrÃ³, B.;IhÃ¡sz, K.;Varga-Kugler, R.;Farkas, S. L.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Characterization of H9N2 influenza A viruses isolated from chicken products imported from China to Japan.
abstract: We characterized eleven H9N2 influenza A viruses isolated from chicken products imported from China. Genetically, they were classified into six different genotypes, including five already known genotypes and one new genotype. This suggested that such multiple genotypes of the H9N2 virus are probably already becoming common and endemic in China. Two isolates have amino acid substitutions in the M2 region that confer resistance to amantadine, supporting evidence that this mutation may be a result of the wide application of amantadine for the treatment of avian influenza in China. These findings highlight the importance of avian influenza virus surveillance and quarantine of imported chicken products as potential sources for influenza virus transmission in this region. Â© 2006 Cambridge University Press.
authors: Mase, M.;Eto, M.;K, I. Mai;Tsukamoto, K.;Yamaguchi, S.

title: Genetic diversity of avian infectious bronchitis viruses in Japan based on analysis of the S2 glycoprotein gene
abstract: To understand the genetic diversity of the S2 gene of infectious bronchitis viruses (IBV) isolated in Japan, we determined the nucleotide sequences of these IBVs using the reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction method combined with direct sequencing. IBV isolated in Japan were divided into six different groups by phylogenetic analysis based on the S2 gene. However, the classification based on the S2 gene of IBV isolated in Japan was different from that obtained by our previous analysis of the S1 gene for some strains. This suggested that genetic recombination had occurred between virus strains classified in different genetic groups in poultry and that recombinant viruses may have been epidemic in Japan.
authors: Mase, M.;Inoue, T.;Yamaguchi, S.;Imada, T.

title: Genetic comparison of H5N1 influenza A viruses isolated from chickens in Japan and Korea.
abstract: Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) caused by the H5N1 virus occurred in Korea and Japan from 2003 to 2004. H5N1 viruses isolated in both countries were genetically similar with >99% identity in nucleotide sequences of all eight RNA segments, suggesting that they belong to genotype V and differ from HPAI viruses that are common in southeast Asia and belong to genotype Z. . These findings suggest that the H5N1 viruses that cause HPAI outbreaks in both Korea and Japan are derived from a common ancestor.
authors: Mase, M.;Kim, J. H.;Lee, Y. J.;Tsukamoto, K.;Imada, T.;Imai, K.;Yamaguchi, S.

title: Analysis of the fusion protein gene of Newcastle disease viruses isolated in Japan
abstract: The complete nucleotide sequences (total of 45 strains) of the fusion (F) protein gene of Newcastle disease viruses (NDV) isolated in Japan from 1930 to 2007 were determined and genetically analyzed. In the deduced amino acid sequences of the fusion protein, all 5 potential asparagine-linked glycosylation sites and 10 cysteine residues were conserved in the NDV examined in this study. Major epitopes involved in virus neutralization are conserved in most of the NDV strains isolated in Japan, except for a few strains. With the virus neutralization test, no large antigenic differences were observed between representative strains of each genotype in Japan. All chickens vaccinated with strain B1 survived clinical manifestations after challenge with 2 strains of NDV (velogenic strains, JP/Ibaraki/2000 and JP/Kagoshima/91) isolated in Japan with amino acid substitutions in protein F involved in virus neutralization. remained. gene.
authors: Mase, M.;Murayama, K.;Karino, A.;Inoue, T.

title: Viral metagenomics shows domestic pigs as a potential reservoir for Ndumu virus
abstract: Background: Increasing demand for pork has resulted in a massive expansion of pork production in Uganda. This resulted in increased contact between humans and pigs. Pigs can serve as reservoirs for emerging infectious diseases. Therefore, identification of potential zoonotic pathogens is important for public health surveillance. In this study, during a routine general surveillance for African swine fever, domestic pigs from Uganda were screened for the presence of RNA and DNA viruses using a high-throughput pyrosequencing method. Results. Serum samples were collected from 16 domestic pigs from five sites in Uganda and pooled accordingly. Genomic DNA and RNA were extracted and sequenced on the 454 GS-FLX platform. Among the sequences assigned to a taxon, 53% were mapped to the domestic pig (Sus scrofa). African swine fever virus, Torque teno viruses (TTVs), and swine endogenous retroviruses were identified. Interestingly, the two RNA-derived pools (B and C) had sequences showing 98% sequence identity to Ndumu virus (NDUV). None of the reads had identity to the class Insecta, suggesting that these sequences were less likely to result from contamination with mosquito nucleic acids. Conclusions: This is the first report of the domestic pig as a vertebrate host for Ndumu virus. The NDUV had previously only been isolated from kitchen mosquitoes. NDUV therefore represents a potential zoonotic pathogen, especially given the increased risk of human-animal-mosquito contact. Â© 2012 Masembe et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Masembe, C.;Michuki, G.;Onyango, M.;Rumberia, C.;Norling, M.;Bishop, R. P.;Djikeng, A.;Kemp, S. J.;Orth, A.;Skilton, R. A.;StÃ¥hl, K.;Fischer, A.

title: Molecular biology of swinepox virus. II. contagious cycle
abstract: Studies based on low stringency hybridizations of radiolabeled porcinepox virus (SPV) DNA to Southern blots containing DNA of the Orthopoxvirus, Leporipoxvirus and Avipoxvirus genera and representative members of the Entomopoxvirus subfamily have revealed no DNA homology at this resolution level. The antigenic relationship between SPV and vaccine was also analyzed using immunoprecipitations and revealed little if any cross-reactivity. The growth characteristics of SPV in tissue culture were examined by light microscopy and revealed both a delayed and different cytopathology from the vaccinia virus. While SPV causes foci in porcine kidney cells that are not apparent until at least 4 days after infection, the vaccine rapidly forms plaques on these cells. The kinetics of DNA accumulation, protein expression, and RNA transcription of SPV have been studied, indicating that each of these aspects of the SPV growth cycle is significantly delayed compared to vaccinia virus. Our data show that porcinepox virus is unique from other smallpox viruses characterized to date and supports the classification of porcinepox virus as a separate genus, Suipoxvirus, within the smallpox family.
authors: Massung, R. F.;Moyer, R. W.

title: Identification of novel bovine group A rotavirus G15P[14] strain from epizootic diarrhea of adult cows by de novo sequencing using a next-generation sequencer.
abstract: There are few reports describing diarrhea in adult cattle caused by group rotaviruses. Here we report the identification of a new bovine group A rotavirus from diarrhea of adult cows. Group A rotavirus was detected in an outbreak of epizootic diarrhea in adult cows with a decline in milk production in Japan in 2013. Extensive genomic analysis of fecal samples with viral metagenomics using a next-generation sequencer revealed that it had an unreported combination of genotypes. G15P[14]. The genome constellation of this strain was RVA/Cow-wt/JPN/Tottori-SG/2013/G15P[14], G15-P[14]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A3-N2-T6-E2. -H3 represents VP7-VP4-VP6-VP1-VP2-VP3-NSP1-NSP2-NSP3-NSP4-NSP5, respectively. Each gene segment of Tottori-SG was most closely associated with Japanese bovine group A rotaviruses, suggesting that Tottori-SG may have been derived from multiple reclassification events from group A rotavirus strains circulating among Japanese cattle. No other diarrheal pathogens were detected in adult cattle with routine diagnosis and metagenomics. Viral metagenomics, using a next-generation sequencer, is useful for characterizing group A rotaviruses from stool samples and offers unbiased comprehensive pathogen studies. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Masuda, T.;Nagai, M.;Yamasato, H.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Nishiura, N.;Sassa, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Koyama, S.;Shirai, J.;Taniguchi, K.;Fujii, Y.;Todaka, R.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.

title: Whole genome analysis of a novel picornavirus related to the Enterovirus/Sapelovirus supergroup from pig feces in Japan
abstract: novel virus related to the Enterovirus/Sapelovirus supergroup in the Picornaviridae family was identified in healthy pig feces from Japan using a metagenomic approach. The genome of the virus, named Sapelo-like porcine picornavirus Japan (SPPVJ) Pig/Isi-Im1/JPN/2016, had a type IV internal ribosomal entry site and carried a single 6978 nucleotide long open reading frame encoding 2326. amino acids (aa) polyprotein precursor. The coding sequence region consisted of the leader protein (68 aa), a structural protein region P1 (824 aa), and non-structural protein regions P2 (672 aa) and P3 (762 aa). Among representative picornaviruses, the P1, 2C and 3CD regions of SPPVJ had the highest aa identities of 64.4%, 61.9% and 73.3%, respectively, with the corresponding regions of the sapelo-like bat picornavirus BtVs-PicoV/SC2013. Sequence analysis of RT-PCR products derived from 5' untranslated and 3D regions revealed the presence of SPPVJ in 17.8% (19/107) of faeces from healthy and diarrheal pigs on 12 farms in 2015-2016. Further studies are needed to determine the origin and pathogenic potential of SPPJV in pigs and other mammals.
authors: Masuda, T.;Sunaga, F.;Naoi, Y.;Ito, M.;Takagi, H.;Katayama, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Oba, M.;Sakaguchi, S.;Furuya, T.;Yamasato, H.;Shirai, J.;Makino, S.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Genomic integration of the lambda EG10 transgene in gpt delta transgenic rodents
abstract: Background: Transgenic gpt delta mouse and rat models have been developed to perform gpt and Spiassays for in vivo mutagenicity tests. Animals were constructed by integrating lambda EG10 phage DNA into the genome as a transgene. The inserted position of the transgene on the chromosome was determined by fluorescent in situ hybridization and Southern blot analysis; however, the exact location and order of the added link was unknown. To determine the location and pattern of genomic integration of transgene copies, genomic DNAs extracted from C57BL/6J gpt delta mice and F344 gpt delta rats were applied to whole genome sequencing and co-pair analysis. Results: The result confirmed that the multiplexed lambda EG10 transgenes are inserted in a single location on mouse chromosome 17. The linkage contains 70 bp of overlapping genomic sequence and has short homology at both ends. A copy number analysis suggested that the inserted transgenes could contain 41 links from other types, such as head-to-tail linkages and rearranged aberrant links. He suggested that the number of intact copies could be around 40 at the maximum. In F344 gpt delta rats, the transgenes are placed in a single location on rat chromosome 4. The linkage does not contain an overlapping sequence, but the 72-kb genomic sequence containing a gene was deleted. Inserted transgenes may contain 15 end-to-end linkages and two rearranged linkages. He suggested that the number of intact copies could be at most 14. A germline base substitution in the gpt gene rescued from gpt delta rats was characterized. Results: Exactly inserted positions of the lambda EG10 transgene were identified in the genome of gpt delta transgenic rodents. The copy number and arrangement of the transgene were analyzed. PCR primers were designed for rapid genotyping of gpt delta mice and rats.
authors: Masumura, K.;Sakamoto, Y.;Kumita, W.;Honma, M.;Nishikawa, A.;Nohmi, T.

title: A new line of duck circoviruses detected in Velvet scoter (Melanitta fusca) supports great diversity among these virus species.
abstract: Background: The aim of this study was to investigate the presence of circoviruses in wild bird populations in Poland. Circoviruses have immunosuppressive properties and can interfere with the health of wild birds. Method: 83 birds from 23 species were tested by wide-range nested PCR. The resulting PCR products were sequenced and new primers were designed to analyze the full-length viral genome. A phylogenetic analysis was performed to find any association with known circoviruses. Results: The circovirus DNA sequence was found in 4 birds. All specimens were obtained from the velvet predator (Melanitta fusca), a sea duck of the subfamily Merginae. On the Baltic coast, birds that tested positive for circovirus were found dead in fishing nets. At autopsy, only slight weakening was seen in the carcasses of two of the two scooters, while the other two birds appeared healthy. The resulting full-length circovirus sequence revealed the presence of 1,988 nucleotides and typical features (ie Cap, Rep and ORF3). The nucleotide similarity to other duck circoviruses was 84 to 86%. Phylogenetic analysis of the whole genome and cap gene showed that the novel circovirus is related to known duck circoviruses, particularly subtypes sometimes called duck circovirus genotype 1, but not genotype 2. Results: In this study, we reported. A new strain of duck circovirus has been detected in the velvet spider, a species of sea duck. Sequence comparison and phylogenetic analysis of the novel virus sequence support previous reports that duck circovirus (DuCV) is a highly diverse species. The viral sequence from the velvet predator suggests that DuCV may infect birds from the subfamily Anatinae. More studies are needed to prove whether the velvet scoter and other sea ducks serve as a reservoir for DuCV.
authors: Matczuk, A. K.;Krawiec, M.;Wieliczko, A.

title: B-cell epitopes of African equine disease virus serotype 4 recognized by the immune equine sera
abstract: Identification of antigenic proteins and mapping of their epitopes are important for the development of diagnostic reagents and recombinant vaccines. B cell epitopes of African equine disease virus (AHSV) have been previously mapped on VP2, VP5, VP7 and NS1 using mouse, rabbit and chicken monoclonal antibodies. A comprehensive study of the humoral immune response to AHSV-4 antigenic peptides from five vaccinated horses was conducted. A fragmented genome phage display library was constructed expressing a whole genome-wide repertoire of AHSV-4 peptides. The library was selected for affinity for binders on immobilized polyclonal immunoglobulin G (IgG) isolated from horse sera collected before and after immunization with an attenuated AHSV-4 monovalent vaccine. DNA inserts of the binding phages were sequenced by Illumina high-throughput sequencing. Data were normalized using sequences selected by preimmune IgG. More sequences were mapped to the genes encoding NS3, VP6 and VP5 than any other genes. However, VP2 and VP5 each had more antigenic regions than each of the other proteins. This study identified a set of epitopes to which the equine humoral immune system responds during vaccination with AHSV-4.
authors: Mathebula, E. M.;Faber, F. E.;Van Wyngaardt, W.;Van Schalkwyk, A.;Pretorius, A.;Fehrsen, J.

title: Human parvovirus 4 'PARV4' is hard to find despite ten years of study
abstract: Human parvovirus 4 ('PARV4') is a small DNA tetraparvovirus first reported in 2005. In some populations, PARV4 infection is rare and evidence of exposure is only found in individuals with risk factors for parenteral infection and other blood-infected individuals. transmitted viruses. In other settings, seroprevalence studies suggest an endemic, age-related pattern of transmission, independent of any specific risk factors. The clinical impact of PARV4 infection remains unclear, but reported disease associations include an influenza-like syndrome, encephalitis, acceleration of HIV disease, and fetal hydrops. In this review, we begin to report progress updates in the recent literature, now focusing on the study of cohorts in different geographic settings, including insights from Asia, the Middle East, and South America, and discussing whether there are characteristics of viral or host populations. forms the basis of striking differences in epidemiology. We review progress in understanding viral phylogeny and biology, diagnostic approaches, and insights that can be gained from studies of closely related animal pathogens. Important questions about pathogenicity remain unanswered, but we highlight new evidence supporting a possible link between PARV4 and an encephalitis syndrome. Conclusive evidence that PARV4 is endemic in certain populations should guide ongoing research efforts to understand its risk factors and modes of transmission, and to gain new insights into the human health impact of this virus.
authors: Matthews, P. C.;Sharp, C.;Simmonds, P.;Klenerman, P.

title: Whole genome-based classification of rotaviruses reveals a common origin between human wa-like and porcine rotavirus strains and human DS-1-like and bovine rotavirus strains.
abstract: Group A rotavirus classification is currently based on the molecular properties of the two outer layer proteins, VP7 and VP4, and the middle layer protein VP6. Since reclassification of all 11 rotavirus gene segments plays a key role in establishing rotavirus diversity in nature, a classification system based on all rotavirus gene segments is desirable to determine which genes influence rotavirus host range restriction, replication, and virulence. as well as to study the epidemiology and evolution of rotavirus. In order to establish such a classification system, in addition to those found in the databases, gene sequences coding from VP1 to VP3, VP6 and NSP1 to NSP5 were determined for human and animal rotavirus strains belonging to different G and P genotypes and used in phylogenetic identification. Relationships among all rotavirus genes. Based on these phylogenetic analyses, appropriate identity thresholds were determined for each gene. For the VP4 gene, an 80% nucleotide identity cut-off value fully correlated with the 27 established P genotypes. For the VP7 gene, a nucleotide identity cut-off of 80% largely overlapped with established G genotypes, but identified four additional distinct genotypes consisting of murine or avian rotavirus strains. Phylogenetic analyzes of the VP1 to VP3, VP6 and NSP1 to NSP5 genes showed the presence of 4, 5, 6, 11, 14, 5, 7, 11 and 6 genotypes, respectively, based on nucleotide identity cut-offs of 83%. , 84%, 81%, 85%, 79%, 85%, 85%, 85% and 91%. Consistent with these data, a revised nomenclature of rotavirus strains has been proposed. The new classification system includes (i) different genotypes, possibly following separate evolutionary paths; (ii) interspecies transfers and multiple reclassification events; and (iii) certain gene constellations that reveal a common origin between (a) human Wa-like rotavirus strains and porcine rotavirus strains, and (b) a common origin between human DS-1-like rotavirus strains and bovine rotaviruses. These close evolutionary links between human and animal rotaviruses highlight the need for close simultaneous monitoring of rotaviruses in animals and humans. Copyright © 2008, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Matthijnssens, J.;Ciarlet, M.;Heiman, E.;Arijs, I.;Delbeke, T.;McDonald, S. M.;Palombo, E. A.;Iturriza-GÃ³mara, M.;Maes, P.;Patton, J. T.;Rahman, M.;Van Ranst, M.

title: Complete molecular genome analyzes of equine rotavirus a strains from different continents reveal several new genotypes and a highly conserved genotype constellation.
abstract: In this study, seven strains of equine group A rotavirus (RVA) (RVA/Horse-tc/GBR/L338/1991/G13P[18], RVA/Horse-wt/IRL/03V04954/2003/G3P[ 12] and RVA/Horse) -wt/IRL/04V2024/2004/G14P[12] from Europe RVA/Horse-wt/ARG/E30/1993/ G3P[12] RVA/Horse-wt/ARG/E403/2006 from Argentina /G14P [12] and RVA/Horse-wt/ARG/E4040/2008/G14P[12] and RVA/Horse-wt/ZAF/EqRV-SA1/2006/G14P[12] from South Africa). Multiple new genotypes were identified and assigned genotype numbers by the Rotavirus Classification Working Group: R9 (VP1), C9 (VP2), N9 (NSP2), T12 (NSP3), E14 (NSP4), and H7 and H11 (NSP5). The genotype constellation of L338 was unique: G13-P[18]-I6-R9-C9-M6-A6-N9-T12-E14-H11. The remaining six equine RVA strains showed a highly conserved genotype constellation: G3/G14-P[12]-I2/I6-R2-C2-M3-A10-N2-T3-E2/E12-H7, quite different from the other. constellations of known non-equine RVA genotypes. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that the sequences of these equine RVA strains were distantly related to the non-equine RVA strains, with at least three lineages present within the equine RVA strains. Few reclassification events were observed. Interestingly, three RVA strains from Argentina had the E12 genotype, while three RVA strains from Ireland and South Africa had the E2 genotype. The unusual E12 genotype has so far been identified in Argentina only among RVA strains collected from guanaco, cattle and horses, suggesting geographic isolation of this NSP4 genotype. This conserved genetic configuration of equine RVA strains could be useful for future vaccine development or improvement of currently used equine RVA vaccines. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Matthijnssens, J.;MiÃ±o, S.;Papp, H.;Potgieter, C.;Novo, L.;Heylen, E.;Zeller, M.;Garaicoechea, L.;Badaracco, A.;Lengyel, G.;Kisfali, P.;Cullinane, A.;Collins, P. J.;Ciarlet, M.;O'Shea, H.;ParreÃ±o, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Barrandeguy, M.;van Ranst, M.

title: Pathogenic characteristics of six bovine picornavirus isolates in mice
abstract: Six bovine picornavirus isolates were classified according to mouse pathogenicity. Of the 6 isolates, 4 (6727 cm, 4155 cm, 3039, and 7109) produced lesions and 3 (6727 cm, 4155 cm, and 3039) caused death in lactating mice. Microscopic lesions included necrosis of the brain, heart, lung, liver, and kidney. A correlation was found between mouse pathogenicity and hemagglutination, suggesting that hemagglutination properties may be helpful in classifying picornaviruses.
authors: Mattson, J. M.;Vorhies, M. W.;Reed, D. E.

title: Cowpox virus: What's in a name?
abstract: Traditionally, virus taxonomy was based on phenotypic traits, but a sequence-based virus taxonomy has become necessary since a species has recently been required to exhibit monophilicity. The Cowpox virus strain did not meet this requirement and required reexamination of this strain. Here, we report the genomic sequences of nine Cowpox viruses, and combining them with existing data from 37 additional genomes, we confirm the polyphylesis of Cowpox viruses and find statistical support based on genetic data for more than a dozen species. These results are discussed in light of the current International Committee on Virus Taxonomy species definition as well as near and future implications for poxvirus taxonomic classification schemes. The data support the recognition of five monophyletic strains of Cowpox viruses as valid strains.
authors: Mauldin, M. R.;Antwerpen, M.;Emerson, G. L.;Li, Y.;Zoeller, G.;Carroll, D. S.;Meyer, H.

title: Molecular evolution and epidemiological links study of Newcastle disease virus isolates in Iran from 1995 to 2016
abstract: In the case of Newcastle disease virus, it has been suggested that many factors such as host adaptation, avoidance of immune response and selective pressures result in the evolution of viruses and the emergence of genetic variants. Numerous studies on virus classification and global epidemiological links have provided consistent data. Here, we performed a molecular analysis study of Newcastle disease viruses circulating in Iran (1995-2016). According to evolutionary differences, VIg, VIj, VIIj, VIId, XIIIa and XIIId subgenotype isolates have been circulated in the country over a 21-year period. Based on data analysis, VIg isolates shared the highest sequence identity with Russian and Polish isolates of the VIg subgenotype, while isolates of VIj subgenotype (2012) were most similar to a virus isolated in India in 2015. Analysis of the evolutionary divergence of the VIIj subgenotype suggests that Chinese and Ukrainian viruses may have played a crucial role in the emergence of VIIj isolates. Evolutionary divergence studies have also shown that XIIIa isolates circulating in Iran may have resulted in the emergence of adapted variants of the XIIId subgenotype. Therefore, we propose that evolutionary and epidemiological study of virulent Newcastle disease viruses can help provide accurate molecular data on variants circulating in the region, thereby aiding the design of more efficient recombinant vaccines.
authors: Mayahi, V.;Esmaelizad, M.

title: Protective efficacy of a recombinant bacterial artificial chromosome clone of a highly virulent Marek's disease virus containing a reticuloendotheliosis virus long terminal repeat
abstract: Marek's disease virus (MDV), an alphaherpes virus, causes Marek's disease (MD), a lymphoproliferative disease in poultry characterized by T-cell lymphomas, nerve lesions, and death. Vaccination is used worldwide to control MD, but increasingly virulent field strains may overcome this protection and trigger the need to create new vaccines. Previous studies revealed that insertion of the long terminal repeat (LTR) of the reticuloendotheliosis virus (REV) into a bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) clone of a very virulent MDV, Md5 strain completely attenuated the resulting recombinant virus, rMd5 REV-LTR BAC. In maternal antibody positive (Mab+) chickens at passage 40. In the current study, the protective efficacy of rMd5 REV-LTR BAC was evaluated. First, passage 70 was determined to be completely attenuated in maternal antibody negative chickens and was chosen as the optimal crossover level for use in protective efficacy studies. Second, three trials of protective efficacy were conducted comparing the rMd5 REV-LTR p70 BAC with the CVI988/Rispens vaccine. Mab+ and Mab- 15I5â€‰â-â€‰71 chicken groups were vaccinated either in the egg or intraabdominal after hatching at day 18 of embryonation and challenged with vv+MDV strain 686 5 days after hatching. Day of hatch and in ovo vaccination with rMd5 REV-LTR p70 BAC protected chickens against MDV-induced bursa and thymic atrophy, but did not provide the same level of protection against MD tumors as that provided by the commercial vaccine CVI988/Rispens.
authors: Mays, J. K.;Black-Pyrkosz, A.;Spatz, S.;Fadly, A. M.;Dunn, J. R.

title: Comparison of sample sequences of the Salmonella typhi genome with the sequence of the complete Escherichia coli K-12 genome
abstract: Raw sequence data, representing the majority of a bacterial genome, can be obtained at a fraction of the cost of a completed sequence. To demonstrate the utility of such a resource, 870 single-stranded M13 clones of the Salmonella typhi Ty2 genome were sequenced from a shotgun library. The sequence reads on average over 400 bases and sampled the genome with an average spacing of every 5,000 bases. A total of 339,243 base unique sequences were generated (approximately 7% representation). The sample of 870 sequences was compared with the rest of the GenBank database, which can be considered a complete Escherichia coli K-12 genome as well as a collection of sampled sequences. Despite the incomplete S. typhi dataset, interesting categories can be easily distinguished. Sixteen percent of the sequences identified from S. typhi had close homologues between known Salmonella sequences (P < 1e-40 in BlastX or BlastN), reflecting the proportion of these genomes that were previously sequenced; 277 sequences (32%) had no significant orthologs across the entire E. coli K-12 genome (P > 1e-20), of which 155 (18%) had no close similarity to any sequences in the database (P > 1e) . -5). Eight of the 277 sequences had similarities with genes in other E. coli strains or plasmids, and six sequences showed evidence of sequence residues of novel phage lysogens or phage integrations, including a member of the lambda family (P < 1e-15). Twenty-three sample sequences had significantly closer similarity to a sequence in the database than organisms (including Shigella and Citrobacter) other than the E. coli/Salmonella line. These sequences are new candidate lateral transfer events to the S. typhi strain or deletions in the E. coli K-12 strain. Eleven possible associations of insertion/deletion events greater than 100 bp were observed in the sample; this indicates that more than 150 such events can distinguish S. typhi from E. coli K-12. The need for automated methods to exploit sample sequences more effectively is discussed.
authors: McClelland, M.;Wilson, R. K.

title: Evaluation of cells and biological reagents for incidental agents using degenerate primary PCR and massively parallel sequencing.
abstract: massively parallel sequencing (MPS)-based approach to test reagents and model cell substrates, including Chinese hamster ovary (CHO), Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK), African green monkey kidney (Vero), and High Five insect cell lines we used for adventurous agents. RNA and DNA were extracted either directly from samples or from viral capsid-enriched preparations and then subjected to MPS-based non-specific virus detection by degenerate oligonucleotide primer (DOP) PCR. MPS by 454, Illumina MiSeq, and Illumina HiSeq were compared on independent samples. Using these methods, virus detection was achieved in a reproducible manner. Unclassified sequences from CHO cells typically represented cellular sequences not yet submitted to databases used for sequence identification. The sensitivity of MPS-based virus detection was consistent with theoretically expected limits based on dilution of virus in cellular nucleic acids. Capsid priming increased the number of viral sequences detected. Potential viral sequences were detected in several samples; in any case, these sequences were either artificial or (based on additional studies) were not shown to be associated with replication competent viruses. Virus-like sequences were more likely to be identified in BLAST searches using virus-specific databases that did not contain cellular sequences. The viral sequences detected included the previously described retrovirus and retrovirus-like sequences in CHO, Vero, MDCK and High Five cells, and the nodavirus and endogenous bracovirus sequences in High Five insect cells. Sequences of bovine viral diarrhea virus, bovine hocovirus and porcine circovirus were detected in some reagents. A recently described parvo-like virus found in some nucleic acid extraction resins has also been identified in cells and in extraction controls from some samples. This study helps to demonstrate the potential of MPS-based strategies in assessing the presence of viral nucleic acids in a variety of sample types, including cell culture substrates and vaccines.
authors: McClenahan, S. D.;Uhlenhaut, C.;Krause, P. R.

title: Interruption of Cytokine Networks by Poxviruses - Lessons from Myxoma Virus
abstract: Myxoma virus is an infectious poxvirus pathogen that induces a virulent systemic disease called myxomatosis in European rabbits. virus genes are classified as virulence factors because virus constructs carrying targeted gene disruptions induce attenuated disease symptoms. Many of these genes encode proteins that interact directly with effector elements of the host immune system. These immunodeficiency viral proteins include secreted mimics of host ligands or regulators (virokines) and homologues of cellular cytokine receptors (viroceptors). Five examples of these immune modulatory proteins encoded by myxoma virus are reviewed: (1) myxoma growth factor, a member of the epidermal growth factor ligand superfamily; (2) SERF-1, a secreted serine proteinase inhibitor; (3) M11L, a receptor-like surface protein; (4) T2, a tumor necrosis factor receptor homolog; and (5) T7, an interferon-gamma receptor homologue, the origin of viral strategies designed to disrupt immune regulation by host cytokines is evaluated in the context of myxoma virus biology in immunocompetent hosts.
authors: McFadden, G.;Graham, K.;Ellison, K.;Barry, M.;Macen, J.;Schreiber, M.;Mossman, K.;Nash, P.;Lalani, A.;Everett, H.

title: Sequence analysis of the gene encoding the S1 glycoprotein of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) strains from New Zealand.
