abstract: Four novel infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) strains (T6, K32, K43 and K87) were isolated from clinically infected chickens in New Zealand. These strains were compared to four circulating strains (A, B, C and D) 25 years ago by sequencing the gene encoding the S1 subunit of the spike glycoprotein. Analysis of nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences revealed that eight strains from New Zealand were genetically related and shared more than 82.8% nucleotide and 79% amino acid homology in the S1 region. T6, K43 and K87 strains were more than 99% homologous to previously described strains C and D. A fourth novel strain (K32) was most closely related to the previously described strain B. Phylogenetic analysis of the strains revealed that New Zealand strains were more closely related to Australia than European or North American strains. The New Zealand A strain shared 99.5% nucleotide and 98.7% amino acid homology with the Australian Vic S strain. The deduced amino acid sequence of the S1 glycoprotein showed differences between strains that were generally consistent with virus neutralization patterns. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: McFarlane, R.;Verma, R.

title: Tracing patient virus origins with molecular phylogenetic analysis
abstract: Nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of louping patient (LI) virus isolates collected from representative regions of the British Isles and Norway were determined for either the entire envelope gene (20 isolates) or a portion comprising a portion of the envelope gene. is the hypervariable region and contains an LI virus-specific marker sequence (53 isolates). Phylogenetic analysis reveals the presence of three main geographic populations of LI virus in the British Isles, i.e. Irish, Welsh and English LI viruses that cause encephalomyelitis in animals, mainly sheep, and co-exist in the same tick population. British LI virus occurs in Scotland, England, Ireland and Norway. Irish and Welsh LI viruses occur only in Ireland and Wales, respectively. Phylogenetic analysis also predicts that the LI virus originally arose in Ireland, with one lineage being brought to Great Britain via Wales and later to the borders of Scotland, from where it spread to Scotland, northern England and Norway. More recently, the British LI virus has been reintroduced to Ireland and also south-west England. Lineage divergence dates calculated from synonymous substitution rate indicate that LI virus originated in the British Isles less than 800 years ago, with most LI virus spreads occurring in the last 300 years. Combining these data with historical records, it appears that livestock movement may play a role in the spread of the LI virus.
authors: McGuire, K.;Holmes, E. C.;Gao, G. F.;Reid, H. W.;Gould, E. A.

title: Type-specific antigenicity of avian reoviruses
abstract: The type specificity of neutralizing activity against avian reoviruses in chicken antiserum was affected by the antiserum production method. The neutralizing activity produced in response to virus infection had higher type specificity than that produced by immunization with inactivated virus emulsified in adjuvant. Induction of type-specific neutralizing activity using reasortant viruses was shown to be associated with the sigma C (sigmaC) virion protein. Antigenic classification of virus strains was attempted based on immunoprecipitation of sigmaC protein by chicken antiserum and results were similar to those obtained by reciprocal serum neutralization tests. Unidirectional immunoprecipitation of sigmaC protein against some heterologous viruses by antisera made it difficult to assign individual viruses to serogroups, similar to what was reported in mutual neutralization tests, showing that the type specificity of the sigmaC protein is not absolute. Neutralizing activity of monoclonal antibodies against sigmaC protein of the RAM1 strain of avian reovirus suggested that there are distinct type and group-specific antigenic areas on the sigmaC protein, and that group-specific areas may be associated with induction of the antibody. heterologous viruses.
authors: Meanger, J.;Wickramasinghe, R.;Enriquez, C. E.;Robertson, M. D.;Wilcox, G. E.

title: Canine distemper virus infection in a smaller grison (Galictis cuja): first report and virus phylogeny
abstract: Megid J., Teixeira CR, Cortez A., Heinemann MB, Antunes JMAP, Fornazari F., Rassy FB & Richtzenhaim LJ 2013. Canine distemper virus infection in lesser grison (Galictis cuja): initial report and virus phylogeny. Pesquisa Veterinary Brasileira 33(2):247-250. Departamento de Higiene Veterinaria e Saude Publica, Faculdade de Medicina Veterinariae Zootecnia, Universidade Estadual Paulista, Distrito de Rubiao Jr s/n, Botucatu, SP 18618-970, Brazil. E-mail: jane@fmvz.unesp.br Infectious diseases in wild animals are increasing as a result of habitat changes and closer contact with domestic animals. Canine distemper virus (CDV) has been reported in several species of wild carnivores, posing a threat to wildlife conservation. We describe the first case of canine distemper virus infection in the little grison (Galictis cuja). A free-range individual with no visible clinical signs presented sudden death one day after captivity. Molecular diagnosis for CDV infection was made using whole blood collected by postmortem intracardiac puncture and was positive. Virus phylogeny indicated that domestic dogs are possible sources of infection.
authors: Megid, J.;Teixeira, C. R.;Cortez, A.;Heinemann, M. B.;Antunes, Jmap;Fornazari, F.;Rassy, F. B.;Richtzenhain, L. J.

title: Localization of VZV in the saliva of Zoster patients
abstract: Varicella zoster virus (VZV) in the saliva of six herpes zoster patients and one chickenpox patient was found to be associated only with epithelial cells by confocal microscopy. With the VZV glycoprotein E-specific antibody, VZV localization was detected mainly on the membrane, but was also inside the cell. Epithelial cells with VZV were still present in saliva in one of the two zoster patients tested after 10 months of recovery. Saliva from healthy controls (patients without shingles, n = 5) did not show any signs of VZV by polymerase chain reaction or confocal microscopy. VZV was not found in the fluid fraction of saliva. More studies are needed to understand the action of VZV in the salivary cells of infected patients.
authors: Mehta, S. K.;Nelman-Gonzalez, M.;Tyring, S. K.;Tong, Y.;Beitman, A.;Crucian, B. E.;Renner, A. N.;Pierson, D. L.

title: Antibody titer to bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) in bulk milk samplers from Bavaria, Germany
abstract: total of 5204 batches of milk samples were tested for antibodies to bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV), classified according to the scheme after Alenius. Forty-five percent of the 2002 samples were classified as class 0 and class 1, and 55% as class 2 and class 3. In an independent study of 6420 bulk milk samples from 1997, 65.6% were classified as class 0 and 1 and 34.4%. class 2 and 3 farms in class 0 and class 1 only very rarely have persistent viremic animals, while in classes 2 and 3 their presence is highly probable. Our work with unselected sera identified serological screening of bulk milk samples as a promising tool for a possible BVDV eradication program in Bavaria.
authors: Meier, N.;Meier, B.;Banzhaf, K.;Wittkowski, G.;Schmitt, D.;Truyen, U.

title: Molecular epidemiological investigation and phylogenetic analysis of bovine influenza D virus in Japan
abstract: Influenza D virus, a new member of the Orthomyxoviridae family, is predominantly found in cattle. Although viral pathology and clinical disease in cattle may seem mild, this virus plays an important role as a trigger of bovine respiratory disease (BRD). BRD is a costly disease worldwide. Therefore, epidemiological studies of influenza D virus are necessary. Here, we performed a molecular epidemiological investigation for influenza D virus in healthy and respiratory diseased cattle in Japan. We found that 2.1% (8/377) of cattle were infected with influenza D. Cattle with and without respiratory symptoms had approximately equal amounts of the virus. A whole-genome sequencing analysis revealed that influenza D virus isolated in Japan formed an individual cluster distinct from strains found in other countries. These results suggest that this virus may have uniquely evolved over a long period of time in Japan and that the viral pathology of Japanese strains may differ from strains found in other countries. Continuous surveillance is required to determine the significance of this virus and to characterize its evolution.
authors: Mekata, H.;Yamamoto, M.;Hamabe, S.;Tanaka, H.;Omatsu, T.;Mizutani, T.;Hause, B. M.;Okabayashi, T.

title: Discovery of enteroviruses and classification of polioviruses among them
abstract: It describes the history of enteroviruses and how the polio virus is considered the prototype species of the genus, a subdivision of the Picornaviridae family. Albert Sabin was one of the main contributors. He isolated several types of enteroviruses and identified them as causative agents of human disease. Enteroviruses were discovered only after new methods of working with viruses were introduced. They are now considered to constitute one of the genera of the picornavirus family. Pico-rna-virus refers to viruses that are small (pico) and have an RNA genome. The genus Enterovirus includes human polioviruses, coxsackie viruses, and ecoviruses, as well as a number of enteroviruses of lower animals (eg, monkeys, cattle, pigs, mice). More than 100 serotypes are now recognized, the first being polioviruses.
authors: Melnick, J. L.

title: Phylogenetic classification and clinical aspects of a novel putative Deltapapillomavirus associated with skin lesions in cattle
abstract: Bovine papillomaviruses (BPVs) are recognized as causative agents of benign and malignant tumors in cattle. Thirteen BPV species have been previously described and classified in 3 different genera. Differences in the nucleotide sequence of the L1 gene are used to identify new viral types through the use of PCR experiments with degenerate primers. In the current study, a method for identifying BPVs based on PCR-RFLP and DNA sequencing allowed the identification of a new putative Deltapapilloma virus designated JN/3SP (JQ280500.1). Analysis of the L1 gene showed that this strain was most closely related to BPVs -1, -2, -13 and OaPV1 (71-73% genetic similarity). In this study, we describe the detection of this new putative Deltapapillomavirus type and confirm its phylogenetic position within the genus. Â© FUNPEC-RP.
authors: Melo, T. C.;Carvalho, R. F.;Mazzucchelli-de-Souza, J.;Diniz, N.;Vasconcelos, S.;Assaf, S. L. M. R.;Araldi, R. P.;Ruiz, R. M.;Kerkis, I.;BeÃ§ak, W.;Stocco, R. C.

title: Whole genome sequencing and biological characterization of Duck/JS/10, a novel lentogenic class I Newcastle disease virus.
abstract: lentogenic Newcastle disease virus (NDV), Duck/JS/10 (JS10), was isolated from an unvaccinated duck in China. The complete genome of the virus contained 15,198 nucleotides. Based on the length of the genome and the partial sequence of the F gene, the virus was classified as class I genotype 4 NDV. The antigenicity of the virus was compared with that of the NDV strain La Sota via hemagglutination inhibition (HI), virus neutralization (VN) assay and animal experiments. Our results show that JS10 produces higher HI and VN titers than La Sota against both class I and II virulent NDV strains. Animal experiments show that virus transmission from chickens vaccinated with JS10 is significantly reduced compared to those vaccinated with La Sota. Overall, this study strongly suggests that JS10 may qualify as a novel vaccine candidate against Newcastle disease. © 2012 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Meng, C.;Qiu, X.;Jin, S.;Yu, S.;Chen, H.;Ding, C.

title: Potential of genotype VII Newcastle disease viruses to cause different infections in chickens and ducks
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND), caused by the ND virus (NDV), is one of the most contagious and economically important diseases of the poultry industry worldwide. Although infections have been reported in a wide range of avian species, the pathogenicity of virulent chicken-derived NDV isolates in ducks remains unclear. In this study, two strains of NDV were isolated and biologically and genetically characterized from an outbreak in chickens and apparently healthy ducks. Pathogenicity assessment indices, including mean time to death (MDT), intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI), and cleavage motifs in the fusion (F) protein indicated that both isolates were velogenic. While these isolates were pathogenic, interestingly, they showed different pathogenicity in ducks. Chicken-derived isolate caused high (70%) mortality in 4-week-old ducks, while duck-borne virus caused low (20%) mortality. Surprisingly, both isolates showed comparable disease pathologies in chickens. Whole genome sequence analysis showed that the virus genome contained 15×192 nucleotides and was characteristic of velogenic strains of NDV. A phylogenetic analysis revealed that both isolates clustered in class II and genotype VII. However, there were several mutations in functionally important regions of the fusion (F) and hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) proteins that may be responsible for the differential pathogenicity of these viruses in ducks. In summary, these results show that NDV strains with the same genotype show different pathogenicity in chickens and ducks. Furthermore, virulent NDVs from chicken are more pathogenic to ducks than duck-borne viruses. These findings suggest a role in the evolution of viral pathogenicity of chickens and potential genetic resistance of ducks to poultry viruses.
authors: Meng, C.;Rehman, Z. U.;Liu, K.;Qiu, X.;Tan, L.;Sun, Y.;Liao, Y.;Song, C.;Yu, S.;Ding, Z.;Nair, V.;Munir, M.;Ding, C.

title: Virome analysis of tick-borne viruses in Heilongjiang Province, China
abstract: Ticks are involved in the transmission of a variety of human and animal pathogens worldwide. This study aimed to understand the geographic distribution of tick species and tick-associated viruses in Heilongjiang Province in northeastern China. Next-generation sequencing and polymerase chain reaction-based analyzes were used to evaluate tick viromes from four representative sampling locations in the Greater Khingan Mountains, and molecular methods were used to classify tick species. Five species of ixodid ticks have been identified, including Ixodes persulcatus, Dermacentor nuttalli, Dermacentor silvarum, Haemaphysalis longicornis, and Haemaphysalis concinna. From 1102 ticks, 3,568,561 high-quality reads were obtained with next-generation sequencing. After trimming, 302,540 reads were obtained, of which 6577 (2.16%) reads were annotated to viruses. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the viral sequences share a close relationship with the Orthonairovirus, Phlebovirus, deer tick Mononegavirales-like virus and Jingmen tick virus sequences, but the significance of these newly identified tick-borne viruses for human and animal health requires further investigation. The results of this study provide a basis not only for further studies of the relationship between ticks and tick-borne viruses, but also for the prevention of future tick-borne epidemics through vector control.
authors: Meng, F.;Ding, M.;Tan, Z.;Zhao, Z.;Xu, L.;Wu, J.;He, B.;Tu, C.

title: A deep sequencing reveals significant variation between the dominant variants and evolutionary dynamics of avian leukosis viruses in the two infectious ecosystems.
abstract: BACKGROUND: As a typical retrovirus, the evolution of Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) in different infectious ecosystems is uncharacterized, what we do know is that it is a cloud of diverse variants such as half-species with significant genetic diversity. This study is to investigate the selection of infectious ecosystems on dominant variants and the evolutionary dynamics of ALV-J between DF1 cells and specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens. High-throughput sequencing platforms provide an approach to more precisely detect quasi-species diversity. RESULTS: An average of approximately 20,000 valid reads from the two variable regions of the gp85 gene and the LTR-U3 region were obtained from each sample in different infectious ecosystems. The top 10 dominant variants of ALV-J from chicken plasmas, DF1 cells and liver tumor were completely different from each other. Also, there was a difference between shannon entropy and global selection pressure values (Ï‰) in different infectious ecosystems. In the plasmas of two chickens, the majority of half-species contained only less than 0.01% of 3-peptide "LSD" repeat insertion in DF1 cell culture supernatants. In parallel studies, the LTR-U3 region of ALV-J from chicken plasmas showed more variants with mutations in transcription regulatory elements than those from DF1 cells. CONCLUSIONS: Our combined data suggest that molecular epidemiology based on ALV-J isolated in cell culture may not represent the true evolution of the virus in field chicken flocks. The biological significance of the "LSD" suffix and mutations in LTR-U3 need further investigation.
authors: Meng, F.;Dong, X.;Hu, T.;Chang, S.;Fan, J.;Zhao, P.;Cui, Z.

title: Analysis of Half-species of Avain Leukosis Virus J Subgroup Using Sanger and High-throughput Sequencing
abstract: BACKGROUND: The avian leukosis viruses subgroup J (ALV-J) exists as a complex mixture of distinct, but closely related genomes, called quasispecies, which are subject to constant change according to Darwinian Principles of evolution. METHODS: This study aims to compare deep sequencing with conventional Sanger sequencing using the MiSeq platform to study the half-species dynamics of ALV-J. RESULTS: The accuracy and reproducibility of MiSeq sequencing was better determined than Sanger sequencing by running each experiment in duplicate. According to the mutation rate of the single position and the ability to distinguish dominant half-species by two sequencing methods, the traditional Sanger sequencing technique shows high randomness due to the small number of sequencing samples, while deep sequencing can more accurately reflect the composition of the half-species. Meanwhile, half-species search via Sanger sequencing was simulated and analyzed from high-throughput sequencing data with the help of a resampling strategy instead of 1000 times; this resulted in higher antibody titer, higher sequence entropy, more difficult analysis with conventional Sanger sequencing, lower proportions of dominant variants. CONCLUSIONS: In summary, deep sequencing is more appropriate for comprehensively detecting rare variants. The Sanger sequencing simulation we propose here will also assist in standardizing half-species researching under differential selection pressure based on next-generation sequencing data.
authors: Meng, F.;Dong, X.;Hu, T.;Liu, Y.;Zhao, Y.;Lv, Y.;Chang, S.;Zhao, P.;Cui, Z.

title: Characterization of subgroup Javian Leukosis virus isolated from Chinese domestic chickens
abstract: Background: Despite remarkable successes in the purification of laying hens and broiler avian leukosis virus (ALV), ALV infection in Chinese domestic chickens was still serious. Methods: To assess the epidemic status of avian leukosis virus in domestic chickens in China, 10 novel strains of ALV subgroup J (ALV-J), designated JS16JH01 to JS16JH10, were isolated and identified by virus isolation and immunofluorescence antibody assays. Chinese local breed farm with sporadic tumor incidence. To better understand its virological properties, the proviral genome of ENV-LTR was sequenced and compared with reference strains. Results: Homology of the gp85 gene between the ten ALV-J strains and NX0101 ranged from 89.7–94.8% at the nuclear acid level. In addition, the gp85 genes were highly diverse, with 92-98% identity to themselves at the nuclear acid level. There were several snp and indel sites in the amino acid sequence of the gp85 genes after comparison with other reference strains of ALV. Interestingly, a novel insertion in the gp85 region was found in two strains, JS16JH01 and JS16JH07, compared with NX0101 and HPRS-103. Discussion: Currently, due to the large-scale purification of ALV in China, ALV-infected laying hens and broilers are rarely detected, but ALVs are still frequently detected in local chickens, suggesting that further efforts should be made into ALV. . Purification of ALV from domestic chickens.
authors: Meng, F.;Li, Q.;Zhang, Y.;Zhang, Z.;Tian, S.;Cui, Z.;Chang, S.;Zhao, P.

title: [Isolation and identification of arboviruses from mosquito pools in parts of Liaoning province, China]
abstract: To isolate and identify arboviruses from mosquito pools in parts of Liaoning province. Mosquitoes were collected from Shenyang, Yingkou, Panjin, Jinzhou and Dandong cities of Liaoning province in 2006. Viruses were isolated by inoculating the samples into C6/36 and BHK-21 cells. New isolates were identified using serological and molecular biological methods. A total of 5410 mosquitoes were collected from five provinces. Three isolates produced CPE in C6/36 cells and five isolates produced CPE in both C6/36 and BHK-21 cells. Three isolates (LN0684, LN0688 and LN0689) were identified as Banna virus and one isolate (LN0636) as Getah virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the three Banna virus strains clustered in the same evolutionary branch as other Chinese isolates. The identity of the nucleotide sequence was between 91.2% and 94.7% compared with other Banna virus strains. The newly isolated Getah virus clustered in the same branch as the South Korean (swine) strain. The identity of the nucleotide sequence was 99.2% compared to the South Korean strain and 95% to 99% with strains from the Russia, mainland China and Taiwan region. Result Eight virus isolates, including three Banna viruses, one Getah virus, and four unknown virus strains, were isolated from mosquitoes in Liaoning province. Banna virus and Getah virus were first reported in Liaoning province, while Getah virus showed the highest nucleotide homology with South Korean strains.
authors: Meng, W. S.;Zhang, J. B.;Sun, X. H.;Liu, Q. N.;Chen, Z.;Zhai, Y. G.;Fu, S. H.;Cao, Y. X.;Wang, H. Y.;Ding, J.;Chu, F. J.;Li, Z.;Zhang, L. T.;Zhao, Y. J.;Liang, G. D.

title: Porcine hepatitis E virus: risk of interspecies infection and xenotransplantation
abstract: Porcine hepatitis E Virus (swine HEV), a recently discovered ubiquitous agent in pigs, is antigenically and genetically closely related to human HEV. HEV infection in pigs usually occurs at 2-3 months of age and approximately 80-100% of pigs on commercial farms in the USA are infected. Swine HEV infections are now recognized in pigs in many other countries of the world. Interspecies transmission has been documented, as swine HEV infects non-human primates and some human HEV strains infect pigs. Recent seroepidemiological studies have shown that swine veterinarians and other swine handlers are at risk for HEV infection compared to normal blood donors. In addition, novel human HEV strains from hepatitis patients in the USA, Japan, and Taiwan are more closely related to swine HEV strains in genetically related countries than other human HEV strains. The ubiquitous nature of the virus in pigs and the proven ability of interspecies infection raise a potential concern for porcine HEV infection in xenotransplantation with porcine organs. This section discusses recent advances in HEV research, with emphasis on potential zoonosis and xenozoonosis.
authors: Meng, X. J.

title: Molecular cloning and nucleotide sequencing of 3'-terminal genomic RNA of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus
abstract: Genomic RNA of a porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) isolate from the USA, VR 2385 (ATCC), was transcribed into cDNA and cloned into phage lambda after preparation with oligo(dT). The cDNA clones representing the 3'-terminal genomic RNA of the virus were isolated and sequenced. The genome is a positive-stranded, polyadenylated RNA with an estimated size of 15 kb. Analysis of the resulting sequence identified three fully open reading frames (ORFs) with the potential to encode polypeptides with predicted M(r)s of 22.2K (ORF 5), 19.1K (ORF 6) and 13.6K (ORF 7). ORF 7, closest to its 3' end, is predicted to encode a highly basic nucleocapsid protein that exhibits 58% amino acid identity to the corresponding protein of Lelystad virus (LV), a European isolate of PRRSV. ORF 6 and 5, preceding ORF 7, are each predicted to encode proteins containing several hydrophobic domains thought to be membrane-associated. The VR 2385 ORF 6 protein is the most conserved structural protein. It has 78% amino acid identity to the equivalent LV protein and shares only 54% of the ORF 5 amino acid sequence. Northern blot analysis revealed six 3'-coterminal nested sub-genomic RNA clusters in VR 2385 virus-infected CRL 11171 cells. Our results show that VR 2385, like LV, is a member of the newly proposed arterivirus group. However, the striking difference in genetic diversity and pathogenicity between LV and VR 2385 suggests that the viruses that cause PRRS in the USA and Europe are highly variable and may represent different genotypes.
authors: Meng, X. J.;Paul, P. S.;Halbur, P. G.

title: Sequence comparison of 2 to 5 open reading frames of low and high virulence United States isolates of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus
abstract: ORF sequences of 2 to 5 of five United States (USA) porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) isolates with differential virulence were determined. The nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of these isolates were compared with those of other known PRRSV isolates. Amino acid sequence similarity among the seven US PRRSV isolates was 91-99% in ORF 2, 86-98% in ORF 3, 92-99% in ORF 4, and 88-97% in ORF 5. sequence variation in ORF 2 to 4 compared to other US isolates. A hypervariable region with antigenic potential was identified within the main envelope glycoprotein. Phylogenetic analysis of ORFs 2 to 7 showed the presence of at least three minor genotypes in the major US genotype. The low virulence US isolate formed a distinct branch from the other US isolates. The results of this study have implications for both the taxonomy of PRRSV and vaccine development.
authors: Meng, X. J.;Paul, P. S.;Halbur, P. G.;Morozov, I.

title: Oncorn-like virus particles in the cochlear spiral ganglia of guinea pigs
abstract: Virus particles in the spiral ganglion cells of the guinea pig are mostly grouped with herpes viruses. The aim of this study is to evaluate this classification of viruses and their effects on cell morphology. Healthy, adult guinea pigs were studied. The spiral ganglion was cut serially and examined electron microscopically. All spiral ganglia examined in several populations of guinea pigs of different breeds showed intracytoplasmic viruses in some granular spiral ganglion cells. Based on their localization and morphology, these viruses are classified into the oncorn virus group, which does not agree with the classification of other authors. There seems to be a worldwide latent viral infection in guinea pigs. The accumulation of lysosome-like vacuoles around the virus indicates increased local lysosomal activity of infected ganglion cells. Given the normally normal superstructure of infected cells, an additional effect of these viruses on intracellular metabolism can neither be demonstrated nor denied.
authors: Merck, W.;Kistler, G. S.;Riede, U. N.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease viruses isolated from chickens, gamebirds, pigeons and quails in Mexico
abstract: Velogenic Newcastle disease has threatened the Mexican poultry industry since 1946. From 1998 to 2006, seven strains of velogenic Newcastle disease virus were isolated from poultry and other avian species in central and northern Mexico and subjected to phylogenetic analysis and biological characterization using standard pathogenicity tests and challenge. studies. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all velogenic strains belonged to genetic group V and were clearly divided into two lineages as phylogenetic similarities between groups were only 93-94%. The isolates from 1998 to 2001 are closely related to the strain responsible for the 2000-year epidemic that occurred in the La Laguna region (Torreon strain) and are phylogenetically different from viruses isolated between 2004 and 2006 that are genetically related to the Chimalhuacan strain isolated in 1973. . All viruses of both the Chimalhuacan and Torreon groups contained a virulent fusion protein cleavage site represented by the "GGRRQKRF" motif, suggesting that evolutionary changes occurred at a different site. The chicken embryo mean time to death value was shorter for Chimalhuacan-like viruses (43.9 hours) compared to the 1998-2001 mean (54.3 hours). The ICPI mean value (1.92) for viruses isolated during 2004-2006 was higher than for viruses isolated before 2001 (1.74). Microscopic evaluation of the bursa Fabricius and thymus of 5w-o broilers challenged with 106 LD50/0.2 ml showed that the Chimalhuacan-like isolate caused more severe lesions in the bursa at 48 hpi and the thymus at 72 and 96 hpi than the Torreon-like isolate. Alongside the MDT, ICPI and microscopic results, our findings suggest that some significant selective pressure on the highly virulent Chimalhuacan strain isolated in the early 1970s may have led to the emergence of a new still velogenic but less virulent strain (Torreon-like) in Europe. mid 1990's. Â© 2009 Springer Science+Business Media BV
authors: Merino, R.;Villegas, H.;Quintana, J. A.;Calderon, N.

title: Evaluation of phenotypic markers in whole genome sequences of avian flu isolates from California.
abstract: We evaluated phenotypic markers in whole genome sequences of avian influenza isolates to identify avian strains with increased potential for transmission and pathogenicity in mammals. Of the 149 markers examined, 67 were positive on consensus sequences from 206 bird isolates. Analysis of deep sequencing data from a subset of 24 isolates revealed that 344 subpopulations occurred at marker locations. Markers in subpopulations were significantly more likely to be negative (258/344) than positive (86/344), but nearly all (78/86) of marker-positive subpopulations were associated with marker-negative consensus sequences. Our analysis revealed substantial variation in important markers among avian isolates and showed that consensus sequences do not fully convey an isolate's potential for increased infectivity and pathogenicity in mammals.
authors: Mertens, E.;Dugan, V. G.;Stockwell, T. B.;Lindsay, L. L.;Plancarte, M.;Boyce, W. M.

title: The First "Virus Hunters"
abstract: The history of virology is the history of conceptual and technological inventions and breakthroughs. Towards the end of the 19th century, the development of filters made of porcelain or kieselgur that retained bacteria allowed the identification of infectious agents that were smaller than bacteria and could not be produced in the media then known and used to grow bacteria. Even finer-grained filters resulted in the observation that ultra-visible new infectious agents were actually particulate in nature. Infections of plants and animals were the first to be attributed to these little beings. Evidence has been obtained from experimental infection of natural hosts (including humans). Thus, 20 of the first 30 viruses identified are veterinary viruses, that is, infectious agents of poultry and livestock. The discovery in the 1910s that bacteria also carry viruses expanded the viral universe, which continues today. Filterability and ultravisibility remained a hallmark for the identification of viruses until the advent of the electron microscope in the late 1930s, marking another technological breakthrough in virology. Cell culture techniques allowed the virus to spread outside the infected organism. Over the past years, the emergence and development of molecular biology has brought further innovations, resulting in the rapid and accurate determination of the genomic material of various living things, including viruses, at a speed and depth not previously known, using next-generation sequencing and metagenomic analyses. It is therefore not surprising that new viruses are constantly being detected, including specimens of unprecedented size and shape. Virologists agree that the viral universe is enormous, and only a small part of it has yet been discovered.
authors: Mettenleiter, T. C.

title: Interspecies transmission of influenza virus
abstract: Influenza is an infection of humans and various animal species. It is caused by influenza viruses belonging to the Orthomyxoviridae family. Type A influenza viruses are the most important, as they cause severe epidemics and are responsible for significant pathological problems. Type A influenza viruses are classified into different subtypes based on the nature of their surface glycoproteins: hemagglutinin (H) and neuraminidase (N). The nature of the genome and the mode of replication of influenza viruses account for the high variability of these two proteins, which are responsible for virus immunity. The constant emergence of point mutations in the gene encoding the H protein results in the progressive emergence of new viral strains. This phenomenon, called antigenic drift, requires an annual evaluation of the composition of the human flue vaccine. Genetic reclassification is another mechanism of antigenic variation. When the gene encoding the H protein or both genes encoding the H and N proteins are included in the genetic reclassification, a new viral subtype arises that replaces the previous one. This event, called antigenic shift, occurs occasionally every 10 to 30 years and is responsible for major human pandemics. The role of animals and especially the importance of pigs and poultry in the emergence of these new viruses are discussed.
authors: Meulemans, G.

title: Isolation of orthreoviruses from psittacine birds
abstract: Orthoreoviridae have been regularly isolated from imported psittacine birds in the absence of other pathogens or in combination with salmonella. These viruses were grown in embryonated eggs, chicken embryo fibroblasts, and hepatic cell cultures. Viral isolates were classified as orthoreoviridae according to their morphological and physico-chemical properties.
authors: Meulemans, G.;Dekegel, D.;Charlier, G.;Froyman, R.;Van Tilburg, J.;Halen, P.

title: Characterization of proteins encoded by ORFs 2 to 7 of Lelystad virus
abstract: The genome of Lelystad virus (LV), a positive-stranded RNA virus, is 15 kb in length and contains 8 open reading frames (ORFs) encoding putative viral proteins. ORFs 2 to 7 were cloned in plasmids downstream of the Sp6 RNA polymerase promoter, and translation of in vitro generated transcripts yielded proteins that could be immunoprecipitated with porcine anti-LV serum. Synthetic polypeptides of 15 to 17 amino acids were selected from the amino acid sequences of ORF 2 to 7 and antipeptide sera were grown in rabbits. Antisera immunoprecipitating in vitro translation products of ORFs 2 to 5 and 7 were obtained. Serum containing antibodies directed against peptides from ORF 3 to 7 reacted positively with LV-infected alveolar lung macrophages in the immunoperoxidase monolayer assay. Using these antipeptide sera and porcine anti-LV serum, we identified three structural proteins and assigned their corresponding genes. Virions were found to contain a 15 kDa (N) nucleocapsid protein, an 18 kDa (M) non-glycosylated membrane protein, and a 25 kDa (E) glycosylated membrane protein. The N protein is encoded by ORF7, the M protein is encoded by ORF6, and the E protein is encoded by ORF5. Protein E in virus particles contains one or two N-glycans resistant to endo-Î²-N-acetyl-D-glucosaminidase H. This finding indicates that high mannose glycans are processed into complex glycans in the Golgi compartment. The protein composition of LV virions further confirms that LV is evolutionarily related to equine arthritis virus, simian hemorrhagic fever virus, and lactate dehydrogenase-raising virus.
authors: Meulenberg, J. J. M.;Besten, A. P. D.;De Kluyver, E. P.;Moormann, R. J. M.;Schaaper, W. M. M.;Wensvoort, G.

title: Characterization of orthopoxviruses isolated from humans and animals in Germany
abstract: Fourteen orthopoxvirus strains isolated from humans, cats, dogs, cows and elephants were characterized in Germany. All were classified as cowpox virus based on hemorrhagic lesions induced in the chorioallantoic membrane of chicken eggs and reactivity of a 160 kDa protein in Western blot with anti-A-type inclusion protein hyperimmune serum. Further comparison of isolates by restriction endonuclease mapping using HindIII and XhoI showed close association between all isolates and confirmed that they are cowpox viruses. However, some minor differences were detected among the isolates that proved to be of epidemiological value. A group of five closely related isolates contained a unique 4.0 kb HindIII fragment. In a Southern blot, this fragment failed to hybridize with other cowpox virus isolates, including the reference strain.
authors: Meyer, H.;Schay, C.;Mahnel, H.;Pfeffer, M.

title: Comprehensive Phylogenetic Reconstruction of African Swine Fever Virus: Proposal for a New Classification and Molecular Dating of the Virus
abstract: African swine fever (ASF) is a highly fatal disease of domestic pigs, caused by the only known DNA arbovirus. It was first described in Kenya in 1921 and since then many isolates have been collected worldwide. However, molecular dating analyzes have not been performed so far, although several phylogenetic studies have been conducted to understand the relationships between isolates. In this paper, extensive phylogenetic reconstructions have been performed using newly established, publicly available sequences of hundreds of ASFV isolates over the past 70 years. Analyzes focused on the B646L, CP204L and E183L genes from 356, 251 and 123 isolates, respectively. Phylogenetic analyzes were obtained using maximum likelihood and Bayesian coupling methods. A new lineage-based nomenclature was proposed to identify 35 different clusters. In addition, dating of ASFV origin was made from molecular datasets. To avoid bias, diversity was neutralized due to positive selection or recombination events. Molecular clock analyzes revealed that currently circulating ASFV strains evolved over 300 years, with a time span from the most recent common ancestor (TMRCA) of the early 18th century. Â© 2013 Michaud et al.
authors: Michaud, V.;Randriamparany, T.;Albina, E.

title: Henipaviruses in natural animal hosts
abstract: Hendra virus (HeV) and Nipah virus (NiV) form a separate genus of Henipavirus within the family Paramyxoviridae and are classified as biosafety level 4 pathogens due to high case fatality rates and lack of effective vaccines or treatments following human infection. Both viruses emerged from their natural reservoirs in the last decade of the twentieth century and caused serious illness in humans, horses and pigs, and infected a number of other mammalian species. The present review summarizes our current understanding of pathology and pathogenesis in natural reservoir species, the Pteropus bat, and species infecting equine and pig species. Â© 2012 Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Middleton, D. J.;Weingartl, H. M.

title: Rotavirus vaccines: an overview
abstract: Rotavirus vaccine development has focused on oral administration of live attenuated strains of rotavirus. The first 'Jennerian' approach involving bovine (RIT4237, WC3) or rhesus (RRV) rotavirus vaccine candidates showed that these vaccines were safe, well tolerated and immunogenic, but induced highly variable rates of protection against rotavirus diarrhea. The purpose of the rotavirus vaccine is to prevent serious diseases that can lead to dehydration in infants and young children in both developed and developing countries. These studies led to the concept that a multivalent vaccine representing each of the four epidemiologically important VP7 serotypes may be required to induce protection in young infants, the target population for vaccination. Human-animal rotavirus reassortants, whose gene encoding VP7 is derived from the human rotavirus parent, but whose remaining genes are derived from the animal rotavirus parent, were developed as vaccine candidates. The greatest experience with a multivalent vaccine to date has been achieved with the quadrivalent preparation containing human-RRV reassortants of RRV (VP7 serotype 3) and VP7 serotype 1, 2 and 4 specificity. Preliminary efficacy trial results in the United States were promising, while a study in Peru showed only limited protection. Human-bovine reassortant vaccines are also being studied, including a candidate containing the VP4 gene of a human rotavirus (VP4 serotype 1A).
authors: Midthun, K.;Kapikian, A. Z.

title: Fecal viroma of domesticated animals
abstract: Next-generation sequencing is a new research tool at our disposal that helps us explore still unknown areas of human and veterinary virology. Metagenomic analysis has enabled the discovery of putative new pathogens and the identification of etiological agents of various diseases, solving long-standing mysteries caused by different viruses. This approach has been used in many studies investigating fecal samples of livestock and companion animal species, providing information on the diversity of animal fecal virus, helping to elucidate the etiology of diarrheal disease in animals, and identifying potential zoonotic and emerging viruses.
authors: Mihalov-KovÃ¡cs, E.;FehÃ©r, E.;Martella, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.;Farkas, S. L.

title: Nyamanini and midway viruses describe a new taxon of RNA viruses in the order Mononegavirales.
abstract: Here we report the sequencing and classification of two antigenically related viruses, Nyamanini virus (NYMV) and Midway virus (MIDWV), which were first isolated in 1957 and 1966, respectively. Although these viruses have been cultured multiple times from bovine egrets, seabirds, and their ticks, efforts to taxonomically classify them using traditional serological and electron microscopic approaches have been completely unsuccessful. We used a random shotgun sequencing strategy to identify the genomes of NYMV and MIDWV. Contigs of 11,631 and 11,752 nucleotides representing the complete genome of NYMV and the nearly complete genome of MIDWV, respectively, were combined. Each virus genome was estimated to carry six open reading frames (ORFs). BLAST analysis showed that only two of the ORF proteins of each virus, the putative nucleocapsid and polymerase, had detectable sequence similarity to known viral proteins. Phylogenetic analysis of these ORF proteins indicated that the closest relatives of NYNV and MIDWV are negative-stranded RNA viruses of the order Mononegavirales. On the basis of very limited sequence similarities to known viruses, we propose NYMV and MIDWV to define a new genus, Nyavirus, in that order. Copyright © 2009, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Mihindukulasuriya, K. A.;Nguyen, N. L.;Wu, G.;Huang, H. V.;Travassos Da Rosa, A. P. A.;Popov, V. L.;Tesh, R. B.;Wang, D.

title: First look at the Oxford Nanopore MinION sequencer
abstract: Oxford Nanopore's third-generation single molecule sequencing platform promises to reduce reagents and instrumentation costs. After a 2-year hiatus after the initial announcement, the first devices were released as part of the early access program. We explore the performance of this platform by resequencing the lambda phage genome and amplicons from a snake venom gland transcriptome. Although the handheld MinION sequencer can generate more than 150 megabases of raw data in one run, no more than a quarter of the resulting reads are mapped to the reference with an average of less than 10% identity. Most of the array consists of insertion/deletion errors or does not resemble the template. Using lambda phage data as an example, reads average 5 kb although long, at best 890 ± 1932 bases per mapped read, can be matched to reference without soft clipping. During a 36-hour run on Minion, it was possible to reorder the 48kb lambda phage reference in 16Ã scope. Currently, significantly larger projects will not be possible using Minion. Without the increases in accuracy that would be required for applications such as genome scaffolding and phasing, Minion's current usefulness appears limited. Library preparation requires access to a molecular laboratory and is of similar complexity and cost to other next-generation sequencing platforms. While Minion requires dramatic reductions in error rates before delivering on its promise, it is an exciting step in a new direction for single molecule sequencing.
authors: Mikheyev, A. S.;Tin, M. M.

title: Vaccine immune pressure influences viral population complexity of avian influenza virus during infection
abstract: Vaccines are useful tools for controlling influenza A virus infection in poultry, but they must be periodically reformulated to guarantee appropriate protection from infection and limit viral replication and circulation that may favor the emergence of new variants. In this study, a deep sequencing approach was used to characterize and follow the evolution of the hemagglutinin of the H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza viral population in infected animals vaccinated with two vaccines that provide different levels of protection.
authors: Milani, A.;Fusaro, A.;Bonfante, F.;Zamperin, G.;Salviato, A.;Mancin, M.;Mastrorilli, E.;Hughes, J.;Hussein, H. A.;Hassan, M.;Mundt, E.;Terregino, C.;Cattoli, G.;Monne, I.

title: Differential interactions between isolates of peanut stunt cucumovirus and satellite RNA
abstract: The interactions of seven pistachio stunt cucumovirus (PSV) isolates and two PSV satellite RNA (sat RNA) variants from North America, Europe and Africa were analyzed. Electrophoretic and immunoblot analyzes of coat protein (CP) and Northern blot hybridization analyzes of viral RNAs indicated that isolates PSV F352, 1339 and 1507 belonged to subgroup I, and isolates PSV W, Su and B belonged to subgroup II. The seventh isolate, robinia mosaic virus (RoMV), clustered with subgroup isolates by CP analysis, but was associated with both subgroups by RNA hybridization analysis. The ability of the two newly identified sat RNA variants to promote accumulation of P4 and P6 sat RNAs was not relevant to PSV isolate classification: neither PSV W nor RoMV were helper viruses for these PSV sat RNAs. Symptom modulation by both saturated RNAs was the same: the presence of sat RNA did not alter symptoms induced by subgroup I isolates, but exacerbated symptoms induced by subgroup II isolates in both tobacco and cowpea. Sat RNAs P4 and P6 contained 393 nucleotides and differed in only three nucleotide substitutions. This resulted in significant differences in infectivity, level of accumulation, and relative encapsulation between both sold RNAs. The accumulation levels and relative encapsulation of saturated RNAs were also affected by the helper virus isolate.
authors: MilitÃ£o, V.;Moreno, I.;RodrÃ­guez-Cerezo, E.;GarcÃ­a-Arenal, F.

title: Newcastle disease: evolution of genotypes and related diagnostic challenges
abstract: Since the discovery of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) in 1926, nine class I viruses and ten class II genotypes have been identified, representing a diverse and constantly evolving group of viruses. The emergence of new virulent genotypes from global epizootics and the observed year-to-year changes in the genomic sequence of low and high virulence NDV imply that different NDV genotypes have evolved simultaneously in different geographic locations around the world. This wide genomic diversity may be supported by the wide variety of bird species susceptible to NDV infection and the availability of highly mobile wild bird reservoirs. The genomic diversity of NDV increases the likelihood of diagnostic failure, resulting in unidentified infections. Continuous epidemiological surveillance and proactive characterization of circulating strains are required to ensure that immunological and PCR reagents are effective in identifying circulating NDV worldwide. For example, in the United States, the real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) matrix gene assay, which is widely used for the identification of NDV, fails to detect low virulence APMV-1 from waterfowl, whereas the RRT-PCR fusion is virulent. Gene assay used to identify isolates often fails to detect certain virulent NDV genotypes. A new matrix-polymerase multiplex assay that detects most of the viruses circulating worldwide has recently been developed, and a modified fusion assay for the identification of virulent pigeon viruses circulating in the USA and Europe. For newly isolated viruses with unknown sequences, recently developed randomization sequencing methods need to be included in the diagnostic arsenal. In addition, the current system for classifying NDV by genotypes or strains is inadequate. Here, we review the molecular epidemiology and recent diagnostic problems of the viral evolution of NDV and explain why a new system based on objective criteria is needed to categorize genotypes.
authors: Miller, P. J.;Decanini, E. L.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Common evolutionary origin of hepatitis B virus and retroviruses
abstract: Although hepatitis B virus (HBV) is classified as a double-stranded DNA virus, it has recently been shown to replicate by reverse transcription of an RNA intermediate. Furthermore, the putative viral polymerase was found to share amino acid homology with the reverse transcriptase of retroviruses. Using computer-assisted DNA and protein sequence analyses, we analyzed the genomes of 13 hepadnavirus isolates (nine human, two ducks, one woodchuck and one ground squirrel) and found that other conserved regions of the hepadnavirus genome share homology with corresponding regions of the hepadnavirus genome. Genomes of type C retroviruses and retrovirus-like endogenous human DNA elements. Specifically, the highest conserved sequence of the HBV genome located at or near the start site for first-stranded HBV DNA synthesis is over 67 nucleotides homologous to the U5 region, a region comparable in retrovirus long terminal repeats. Within a highly conserved (ie, 90%) 16-nucleotide sequence, a heptanucleotide sequence CCTTGGG is 97% homologous among 27 virus isolates. We also found that the highly conserved HBV core or nucleocapsid protein shares 41% homology over 98 amino acids with the carboxyl-terminal region of the p30 gag nucleocapsid protein of type C retroviruses. In both cases, as with the previously reported polymerase homology, HBV is most homologous to murine leukemia/sarcoma retroviruses. Further analysis revealed additional similarities between the hepadnavirus and retroviral genomes. Taken together, our results suggest that HBV and retroviruses have a common evolutionary origin and result from the deletion process of HBV from a retrovirus or retrovirus-like progenitor.
authors: Miller, R. H.;Robinson, W. S.

title: Detection of bovine group A rotavirus using rapid antigen detection kits, RT-PCR and next generation DNA sequencing
abstract: We investigated the sensitivity of human rotavirus rapid antigen detection (RAD) kits, RT-PCR, and next-generation DNA sequencing (NGS) for the detection of bovine group A rotavirus (RVA). Dipstick 'Eiken' Rota (Dipstick) showed the highest sensitivity out of the seven RAD kits against all strains selected in limited dilution analyzes, consistent with previously reported equine rotavirus results. RT-PCR had 100-103 times higher sensitivity than Dipstick. Using thirteen RT-PCR-negative stool samples, NGS revealed that all samples gave RVA reads, and two of these in particular covered all 11 genome segments. Also, the mapping reads reference sequences that allow genotyping. NGS will be sensitive and useful for screening genotypes and analyzes that are less dependent on specific primers. Â© 2013 Japanese Veterinary Science Association.
authors: Minami-Fukuda, F.;Nagai, M.;Takai, H.;Murakami, T.;Ozawa, T.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Nishiura, N.;Sassa, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Koyama, S.;Shirai, J.;Tsunemitsu, H.;Fujii, Y.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.

title: A systematic review of the natural virome of Anopheles mosquitoes.
authors: Minkeu, F. Nanfack;Vernick, K.

title: Rapid evolution of human intestinal virus
authors: Minot, S.;Bryson, A.;Chehoud, C.

title: Conservation of Gene Cassettes Among Various Viruses of Human Intestines
abstract: Viruses are a crucial component of the human microbiome, but large population sizes, high sequence diversity, and high frequencies of novel genes have hindered genomic analysis by high-throughput sequencing. Here, we explore metagenomic assembly approaches to probe genome structure in a 5.6 Gb intestinal viral DNA sequence sample from six individuals. Testing has shown that a new pipeline based on DeBruijn graphics compilation provides longer contigs that can take more reads than the equivalent non-optimized, single-pass approach. To characterize the gene content, the database of viral RefSeq proteins was compared with the combined viral contigs and generated a two-part graph with functional cassettes linking the viral contigs; this revealed a high degree of interconnection between various genomes containing multiple genes of the same functional class. In a second step, open reading frames were grouped according to their co-occurrence in contigs in a database-independent manner, revealing conserved cassettes of co-orientation ORFs. These methods reveal that free-living bacteriophages often have significant similarities at the level of encoded amino acid motifs, gene arrangement, and gene orientation, while differing generally at the nucleotide level. These findings link contemporary metagenomic analysis with classical studies of bacteriophage genomic cassettes. The software is available at https://sourceforge.net/projects/optitdba/.
authors: Minot, S.;Wu, G. D.;Lewis, J. D.;Bushman, F. D.

title: Phylogenetic evidence for the recent spread of two human enterovirus 71 populations in European countries
abstract: Human enterovirus 71 (EV-71) is the cause of seasonal epidemics of hand, foot, and mouth disease and less common but serious neurological manifestations. Uncertainty remains regarding the circulation and time of spread of virus populations in various geographic regions. We identified EV-71 sequences at locus 1D (VP1 capsid protein) and 3CD (nonstructural proteins) in 86 strains recovered in Austria, France and Germany and performed an evolutionary genetic study of current virus populations. Phylogenetic analyzes positioned 78 of the 86 sequences within two divisions between subgenogroups C1 and C2. A small set of sequences has been assigned to subgenogroup C4. Analyzes involving existing sequences estimated the rate of substitution in genogroup C as 3.66×10-3 and 4.46×10-3 substitutions per site year-1 for loci 1D and 3CD, respectively, assuming a loose molecular clock model for sequence evolution. . Most of the 'European' strains belonged to branches C1b and C2b that emerged in 1994 [95% confidence interval (CI), 1992.7-1995.8) and 2002 (95% CI, 20011.6-203.8, respectively). Estimates of divergence times for locus 3CD were consistent with those measured for locus 1D. In the 3CD phylogeny, interbreeding between clades representing the EV-71 subgenogroups and clades corresponding to other enterovirus types (especially early coxsackievirus A prototype strains) is largely indicative of ancestral recombination events. Discordant phylogenetic models estimated for locus 1D and 3CD suggest that no single tree is able to model the epidemic history of circulating EV-71 populations. The evolutionary timescale of genogroup C estimated for both loci has been measured in only decades, indicating recent spread. © 2010 SGM.
authors: Mirand, A.;Schuffenecker, I.;Henquell, C.;Billaud, G.;Jugie, G.;Falcon, D.;Mahul, A.;Archimbaud, C.;Terletskaia-Ladwig, E.;Diedrich, S.;Huemer, H. P.;Enders, M.;Lina, B.;Peigue-Lafeuille, H.;Bailly, J. L.

title: Genetic diversity of bovine diarrhea and mucosal disease virus
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is classified as a member of the Pestivirus genus of the Flaviviridae family. BVDV is one of the most important viral pathogens of ruminants worldwide and causes serious economic losses. Infection results in a wide variety of clinical manifestations, from mild respiratory disease to fetal death to mucosal disease. The virus particles are small and contain a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA molecule of approximately 12.3 kb with a large open reading frame flanked by two untranslated regions (5'UTR and 3'UTR). The polyprotein is proteolytically cleaved by viral and host proteases, resulting in the formation of mature viral proteins. It is well known that BVDV strains show significant genetic diversity. BVD viruses are classified into two types: BVDV-1 and BVDV-2. Quite recently, a new default strain, BVDV-3, has been identified. Viruses exist as one of two biotypes: cytopathic or non-cytopathic, depending on their activity in cell cultures. Phylogenetic analysis of the 5'UTR and Npro region revealed at least 21 different subtypes of BVDV-1 and 4 subtypes of BVDV-2. The genetic diversity of BVD viruses has serious clinical effects such as immune evade, increased virulence, host range change, and also affects the effectiveness of vaccination programs and diagnostic methods.
authors: MirosÅ‚aw, P.;Antos, A.;Polak, M.

title: VARV B22R homolog as phylogenetic marker gene for Capripoxvirus classification and divergence time dating
abstract: Sheep sickness disease is associated with significant losses in sheep production worldwide. Sheeppox virus, goat pox virus, and tuberous skin disease virus cannot be distinguished by conventional serological testing. Identification of these pathogens requires molecular methods. In this study, seven genes viz. EEV maturation protein – F12L, Virion protein – D3R, RNA polymerase subunit – A5R, Virion core protein – A10L, EEV glycoprotein – A33R, VARV B22R homolog and beginning, Kelch-like protein covering middle – A55R, and end of genome were selected. These genes were amplified, cloned and sequenced from the Romanian-Fanar vaccine strain and the Jaipur virulent strain. In analysis with available database sequences, the VARV B22R homolog was identified as a marker for phylogenetic restructuring to classify ungulates sheeppox viruses. Moreover, divergence time dated with the VARV B22R gene accurately predicted the sheeppox epidemic involving the Jaipur lethal strain.
authors: Mishra, B.;Mondal, P.;Patel, C. L.;Zafir, I.;Gangwar, R.;Singh, N.;Sonowal, J.;Bisht, D.;Sahu, A. R.;Baig, M.;Sajjanar, B.;Singh, R. K.;Gandham, R. K.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the sheep pox virus (SPPV) virion core protein P4a gene revealed extensive sequence conservation among capripox viruses.
abstract: In this study, virion core protein P4a gene was PCR amplified from sheep pox virus (SPPV) Jaipur isolate and Rumen Fanar (RF) vaccine strain and amplified in lamb testis/vero cells. Gene-specific primers are designed for amplification of the P4a gene. The amplified P4a gene fragment was sequence-characterized and the 808 bp sequence compared between SPPV, GTPV, and LSDV isolates in the GenBank database, demonstrating 97% to 100% comprehensive sequence conservation within smallpox groups. Sheeppox virus Jaipur isolate was found to be closely related to Roumaninan Fanar (RF) and TU isolates. Furthermore, phylogenetic analysis of the P4a gene sequence showed three different clusters of Capripox viruses with GTPV, interestingly located close to the LSDV group.
authors: Mishra, B.;Ravi Kumar, G.;Sonal;Patel, C. L.;Chaturvedi, V. K.

title: Molecular characterization of bovine viral diarrhea virus type 2 isolate from a native Indian sheep (Ovies aries)
abstract: The wide widespread prevalence of bovine viral diarrhea virus type 1 (BVDV-1) in cattle and the recent identification of BVDV-2 in goats in India have warranted pestivirus surveillance in sheep. Nested reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used to detect BVDV-2 in one of 1561 blood samples randomly collected from 78 flock of sheep in 11 states of India. Antigenic characterization of the isolated pestivirus using polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies typified the isolate as BVDV-2. When analyzed at the genetic level in Npro (N-terminal autoprotease) and the entire gene region encoding structural proteins, namely capsid (C) protein and Erns (ribonuclease secreted) envelope proteins, the genomic organization of E1 and E2 was the same for all pestiviruses, nucleic acid and amino acid sequences. showed the highest similarity with those of BVDV-2. Compared to BVDV-2 isolate 890, sequence homology was 83.7% for C, 84.6% for Erns and E1, and 81.5% for E2. While Npro/C was only protected from the C-terminus of Npro, the C/Erns cleavage site was found to be fully conserved, the Erns/E1 site was protected only from the C-terminus of Erns, and the E1/E2 site was only preserved from the C-terminus of Npro. E1. Phylogenetic analysis of nucleotide sequences in regions 5–² untranslated (UTR), Npro, E2, NS3, and NS5B placed the sheep isolate in a distinct clade within BVDV-2 subtype b. This was supported by the presence of unique mutations in the structural protein coding regions besides NS3 and NS5B. To our knowledge, this is the first report on sequence analysis of the entire structural gene coding region of a BVDV-2b isolate. This is also the first occurrence of BVDV-2 subtype b in sheep, providing evidence that this subtype can occur in species other than cattle. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Mishra, N.;Rajukumar, K.;Vilcek, S.;Tiwari, A.;Satav, J. S.;Dubey, S. C.

title: Metagenomic characterization of viromen associated with bovine respiratory disease in beef cattle identified novel viruses and suggested an etiological role.
authors: Mitra, N.;Cernicchiaro, N.;Torres, S.;Li, F.

title: Metagenomic characterization of viromenin associated with bovine respiratory disease in beef cattle identified novel viruses and suggested an etiological role for influenza D virus.
abstract: Bovine respiratory disease (BRD) is the most costly disease affecting the cattle industry. The pathogenesis of BRD is complex and includes contributions from microbial pathogens as well as host, environmental and animal management factors. In this study, we used viral metagenomic sequencing to investigate the virome of nasal swab samples obtained from beef cattle and asymptomatic couples with acute BRD in six and four mediums, respectively, in Mexico and the USA, in April-October 2015. Twenty Bovine rhinitis A (52.7%) and B (23.7%) viruses and one virus were detected, with bovine coronavirus (24.7%) being the most frequently identified. The resulting influenza D virus (IDV) tended to be significantly associated with disease (P=0.134; odds ratio=2.94), while viruses commonly associated with BRD such as bovine viral diarrhea virus, bovine herpesvirus 1, bovine respiratory syncytial virus, and bovine parainfluenza 3 viruses detected less frequently. Detection of IDV was further confirmed using a real-time PCR assay. Nasal swabs from symptomatic animals had significantly more IDV RNA than those collected from healthy animals (P=0.04). In addition to known viruses, new genotypes of bovine rhinitis B virus and enterovirus E have been identified and a newly proposed strain of bocaparvovirus, Ungulate bocaparvovirus 6, has been characterized. Ungulate tetraparvovirus 1 was also detected, to our knowledge, for the first time in North America. These results illustrate the complexity of the BRD-associated virome and highlight the need for further research on the contribution of other viruses to BRD pathogenesis.
authors: Mitra, N.;Cernicchiaro, N.;Torres, S.;Li, F.;Hause, B. M.

title: Molecular characterization of Indian isolates of infectious bursal disease virus from broiler chickens.
abstract: This study was conducted to characterize end-site isolates of infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) via reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and partial sequencing of the VP2 gene. The virus was detectable in 17 of 20 field samples from broiler chickens in Haryana, India, and in all four vaccine strains. The nucleotide sequences of four field isolates and one vaccine strain were compared with 10 IBDV strains reported from different parts of the world. Nucleotide substitutions at 795G, 827T, 833C, 857C, 897A, 905T, 908T, 1011A, and 1094G specific to highly virulent (vv) strains were conserved in all four domain isolates. However, the unique nucleotide substitutions in 806A-G, 851C-T, 1010 TC, 1019T-C and 1082T-C indicated that these isolates differed more than previously reported vvIBDVs. Amino acid substitutions deduced at 222P-A, 256V-I, 279N-D, 294L-I, and 299N-S specific to vvIBDV strains were also present in all four isolates. The vaccine strain showed amino acid change 279D-N, which is characteristic of attenuated vaccine strains. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all field isolates in this study were closely related to reported UK (UK661) and Japan (OKYM) field isolates. All four domain IBDV strains of this study were closely related, but different from previously reported vvIBDVs of India. Based on nucleotide sequence and phylogenetic analysis, the strains that cause IBD in this part of India are very likely to be very virulent and still undergo changes at the genetic level. Â© 2006 Informa UK Ltd.
authors: Mittal, D.;Jindal, N.;Gupta, S. L.;Kataria, R. S.;Singh, K.;Tiwari, A. K.

title: Full-length genomic sequence analysis of novel subtype 3k hepatitis E virus isolates with 99.97% nucleotide identity from two consecutive acute hepatitis patients in a city in northeastern Japan.
abstract: Full-length genomic sequences of hepatitis E virus (HEV) from two consecutive cases of acute self-limiting hepatitis E in a city in northeastern Japan were determined. Interestingly, two HEV isolates from each patient shared 99.97% nucleotide identity at 7,225 nucleotides, and a phylogenetic analysis showed that they formed a cluster of Japanese isolates considered a novel HEV subtype 3k. The high similarity of the HEV sequences of the two isolates from these patients in this study suggested that a subtype of 3k HEV strain was spread through a widely distributed food in the city, possibly pig liver.
authors: Miura, M.;Inoue, J.;Tsuruoka, M.;Nishizawa, T.;Nagashima, S.;Takahashi, M.;Shimosegawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Isolation of Chuzan virus, a novel member of the Palyam subgroup of the Orbivirus genus, from cattle and Culicoides oxystoma in Japan.
abstract: Five virus strains with identical antigenic properties were isolated from 3 RBC suspensions obtained from 2 healthy sentinel calves and 2 Culicoides oxystoma pools in cultures of a hamster lung cell line (HmLu-1). The virus was tentatively named the Chuzan virus. Chuzan virus was classified as a new member of the Palyam subgroup of the Orbivirus genus on the basis of its physicochemical, morphological and antigenic properties.
authors: Miura, Y.;Goto, Y.;Kubo, M.;Kono, Y.

title: Pestiviruses: a review Review
abstract: Pestiviruses include a group of economically important animal pathogens, namely swine cholera, bovine viral diarrhea and borderline disease viruses. The viruses are serologically closely related and share a common host spectrum, namely pigs and numerous domestic and wild ruminants. Interspecies transfers occur frequently. Despite some common features in their natural hosts, the pathogenesis of pestivirus-borne diseases is complex; Some aspects of the particularly fatal mucosal diseases of cattle are still enigmatic. Pestiviruses are among the smallest enveloped single-stranded RNA viruses with an icosaeder-shaped nucleocapsid. They are currently classified as Togaviridae. However, based on recent advances in the molecular characterization of viruses, their taxonomic true location seems inevitable. Viral RNAs examined so far show a large open reading frame and no subgenomic RNA can be displayed in infected cells. Structural proteins are encoded by genes located at the 5' end of RNA. Most of the genome encodes 2-3 non-structural proteins. Virions consist of a large and a small envelope glycoprotein with molecular weights of 53 and 48 kD, respectively. The core consists of a small protein with a molecular weight of 20 kD. Analysis of viral proteins with monoclonal antibodies provided detailed information on the antigenic composition of both structural and nonstructural proteins. [References: 102]
authors: Moenning, V.

title: Defects in small intestinal epithelial barrier function and morphology associated with growth retardation syndrome (PFTS) during weaning in pigs.
authors: Moeser, A. J.;Borst, L. B.;Overman, B. L.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of bovine cobuvirus from calves in Egypt
abstract: Kobuviruses are small, non-enveloped RNA viruses that likely cause diarrhea in cattle and pigs. Since its discovery in 2003, few studies have addressed bovine cobuvirus (BKoV; a strain of Aichivirus B) infections. BKoV has been reported in Europe, Asia and South America, indicating a worldwide distribution. To investigate the presence of BKoV in Egypt, 36 stool samples from calves with diarrhea from two different provinces of Egypt (Cairo and Sharkia) were screened by RT-PCR and 24 (66.7%) were found positive for BKoV. RNA from one of the positive samples (BKoV/Egy-1/KY407744) was subjected to next-generation sequencing to determine the complete BKoV genome sequence. Compared with the single recorded BKoV genome sequence (BKoV/U-1/AB084788), the studied strain showed 94 amino acid (aa) substitutions, one nucleotide (nt) insertion and one nt deletion across its entire polyprotein (2463 aa). 2D gene and 4-nt deletions (2 each) in UTRs. In addition, five VP1 and seven 3D arrays were obtained from other samples using RT-PCR and Sanger sequencing. An inconsistency was observed in the phylogenetic topography of VP1 and 3D, where the Egyptian VP1 sequences were classified as a distinct cluster within the proposed lineage 1 (genotype A), which also included strains from the United Kingdom, Brazil, and Japan. The 3D series from Cairo were related to the Chinese genres, unlike the Sharkia series which were closer to the Korean genres. To our knowledge, this is the first detection and genomic characterization of BKoV in Egypt or indeed in Africa.
authors: Mohamed, F. F.;Mansour, S. M. G.;Orabi, A.;El-Araby, I. E.;Ng, T. F. F.;Mor, S. K.;Goyal, S. M.

title: Effect of phylogenetic diversity of velogenic Newcastle disease virus challenge on virus shedding after homologous and heterologous DNA vaccination in chickens.
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is a devastating disease for the poultry industry as it causes high economic losses. In this study, a DNA vaccine containing the F and HN surface antigens of the highly virulent Newcastle disease virus (NDV), NDV/1/Chicken/2005 (FJ939313) was successfully created. Cell transfection testing showed that the vaccine expressed the F and HN genes in Hep-2 cells. The main objective of this study was to compare the extent of protection induced by DNA vaccination after homologous and heterologous NDV challenge, as determined by the amount of NDV scattering after challenge. NDV-antibody-negative chickens were vaccinated one, two or three times intramuscularly at 7, 14 and 21 days of age and challenged with homologous virus (vaccine-matched velogenic visserotropic Newcastle disease virus (vvNDV) strain, FJ939313) 14 days post-vaccination. , a heterologous virus (mismatched vvNDV strain, AY968809), phylogenetically related to or phylogenetically distinct from group VII, belongs to genogroup VI and shows 84.1% nucleotide similarity to the NDV sequences of the DNA vaccine. Our data show that birds receiving a single dose of DNA vaccine are poorly protected, with only 30-40% of these birds surviving after challenge with high virus shedding titer. Multiple administrations of the DNA vaccine provided high protection rates of 70-90%, with less transmission of the virus compared to unvaccinated and threatened birds. Overall, homologous challenge led to reduced tracheal and cloacal shedding compared to the heterologous vvNDV strain. This study offers a promising approach for the control of ND in chickens using DNA vaccines that are phylogenetically closely related to circulating field strains.
authors: Mohamed, M. H.;Abdelaziz, A. M.;Kumar, S.;Al-Habib, M. A.;Megahed, M. M.

title: Complete genome sequence of a virulent Newcastle disease virus isolated from an outbreak in chickens in Egypt
abstract: The complete genome sequence of virulent Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolated from chickens in Egypt was determined and compared to the sequence of NDV strains isolated from different parts of the world. The genome is 15,186 nucleotides (nt) long and consists of 6 genes in the order 3â€²-NPMF-HN-L-5â€². The genome contains 55 nt leader regions at the 3â€² ends and 114 nt trailer regions at the 5â€² ends. Interestingly, phylogenetic analysis showed that Egyptian ancestry was closely related to NDV strains isolated in China. In addition, the sequence of the fusion protein cleavage site of the Maize strain was identical to that of the NDV strain recently isolated in Mali. To understand the epidemiology of the viruses currently circulating in Africa, it is necessary to determine the complete genome sequences of additional NDV strains from Africa. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Mohamed, M. H. A.;Kumar, S.;Paldurai, A.;Megahed, M. M.;Ghanem, I. A.;Lebdah, M. A.;Samal, S. K.

title: Application of molecular biological techniques for the detection of epizootic hemorrhagic disease virus (EHDV-318) from a sentry calf in Central Sudan.
abstract: Epizootic hemorrhagic disease virus (EHDV), isolate 318 (EHDV-318), an untyped virus from a herd of sentinel calves at the University of Khartoum farm in central Sudan, was characterized using molecular biological techniques. By dot blot hybridization technique, a cDNA probe derived from genome segment 6 of EHDV-2 (Alberta strain) was hybridized with RNA from EHDV-318. Application of the serogroup-specific EHDV polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to EHDV-318 RNA resulted in specific amplification of a 387 bp PCR product. The amplification product was visualized on ethidium bromide stained agarose gel. The specificity of the PCR products was confirmed by chemiluminescent hybridization with a non-radiolabeled internal probe. No amplification products or hybridization signals were detected when serotype-specific EHDV-1 or EHDV-2 PCR-based assays were applied to RNA from EHDV-318. The scientific data presented in this study demonstrated that cDNA probes and serogroup-specific PCR-based testing can be used to classify the virus as a member of the EHDV serogroup and serotypically distinct from EHDV-1 and EHDV-2.
authors: Mohammed, M. E. H.;Aradaib, I. E.;Mukhtar, M. M.;Ghalib, H. W.;Riemann, H. P.;Oyejide, A.;Osburn, B. I.

title: Analysis of the phylogeny of the leader proteinase (Lpro) region of type A foot-and-mouth disease virus with emphasis on the evolution of the VP359-deletion lineage emerging from India
abstract: Genotype-inclusive grouping of Indian type A isolates as observed in 1B region-based phylogeny is skewed in the full Lpro region, where the VP359-deletion group lineages of genotype VII clustered away from both VII and VI genotypes, confirming its uniqueness and independent evolution of Lpro and 1B zone. Similar to region 1B, this deletion group is genetically diverging even in region L, which generates more lineages, and the lineage distance in region L is considerably greater than region 1B. The deletion group is limited to India only, as none of the exotic sequences are clustered within this group. Notably, the L protein exhibited comparable variability to the external capsid proteins, as indicated by a high dN/dS ratio (0.105), the number of variable amino acid positions (41%), a low Ts/Tv ratio (3.47), and the N-terminal region revealed by the alignment. The Î²2 plate and C-terminal extension are highly variable. The basic residues at P1, P3, and only leucine at P2 were predicted to provide an optimal autocatalytic cleavage site at the L/P1 junction. All eight regions identified as being under positive selection revealed a substitution of various physicochemical traits, and lineage-specific signatures were observed at two locations; this supports the claim that lineages evolved under differential selection pressure to adapt to diverse ecological environments. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Mohapatra, J. K.;Priyadarshini, P.;Pandey, L.;Subramaniam, S.;Sanyal, A.;Hemadri, D.;Pattnaik, B.

title: Genetic variability of the VP6, VP7, VP4 and NSP4 genes of the porcine rotavirus H group detected in Brazil
abstract: Rotaviruses (RV) are a common cause of viral gastroenteritis in humans and animals. Despite the seven groups/types of RV (AG), a new RV group/type H (RVH) has recently been proposed based on VP6 sequence analysis. In this study, we identified the nucleotides VP6, VP7, VP4, and NSP4 and extracted the amino acid sequences of 6 (BR59-BR64) RVH-positive stool samples from piglets with diarrhea in Mato Grosso do Sul, the Midwest region of Brazil. 2012, using the RT-PCR test. Based on the high sequence identities (>99%) of the VP6, VP4, VP7 and NSP4 genes among 5 (BR59-BR63) of the stool samples studied, they are considered to be the same local strain of rotavirus designated RVH/BRA-1. In contrast, once stool sample BR64 showed a relatively high difference (81.6% nt identity and 83.4% aa identity) in the VP7 sequence compared to the other 5 samples, it was termed RVH/BRA-2 strain. Comparative phylogenetic analysis showed that 6 RVH strains did not cluster together with any existing sequences of members of the established RV groups (RVA-RVG), but appeared to be associated with RVB and RVG. These results confirm the existence of RVH in Brazil, demonstrate its genetic diversity, and provide new data to aid in explaining viral evolutionary patterns and biological features of RVH, as well as viral phylogeny and epidemiology.
authors: Molinari, B. L. D.;Alfieri, A. F.;Alfieri, A. A.

title: Phylogenetic Analysis of Pigeon Paramyxoviruses Type-1 Identified in Mourning Collar Pigeons (Streptopelia decipiens) in Namibia, Africa
abstract: We generated the full sequence of the fusion (F) protein gene from six pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1) isolated from Mourning Collared-pigeons (Streptopelia decipiens) in Namibia, Africa, between 2016 and 2017. The gene cleavage site motif of 112RRQKRF117, characteristic of virulent viruses. A phylogenetic analysis using the full F gene sequence revealed that the viruses belonged to genotype VIa and were epidemiologically related to PPMV-1s from Asia, Europe, and North America.
authors: Molini, U.;Aikukutu, G.;Khaiseb, S.;Cattoli, G.;Dundon, W. G.

title: Genome of chicken DT40 bursal lymphoma cell line
