abstract: The chicken DT40 cell line is a widely used model system for the study of multiple cellular processes due to the effectiveness of homologous gene targeting. The cell line was derived from a bursal lymphoma caused by avian leukosis virus infection. In this study, we characterized the genome of the cell line using whole-genome shotgun sequencing and single-nucleotide polymorphism sequence hybridization. The results show that wild-type DT40 has a relatively normal karyotype except for whole chromosome copy number gains and there is no karyotype variability within the stocks. Compared to the two domestic chicken genomes and the Gallus gallus reference genome, we did not find any unique mutational processes that shaped the DT40 genome, except for a slight increase in insertion and deletion events, particularly deletions in tandem repeats. We mapped coding sequence mutations specific to the DT40 genome; Mutations that inactivate the PIK3R1 and ATRX genes likely contributed to the oncogenic transformation. In addition to a known avian leukosis virus integration in the MYC gene, we identified other integration sites that are likely to de-regulate gene expression. The new findings support the hypothesis that DT40 is a typical transformed cell line with a relatively intact genome; therefore, it is well suited to the role of a model system for DNA repair and related processes. The sequence data generated by this work, including a searchable de novo genome assembly and annotated lists of mutated genes, will support future research using this cell line.
authors: MolnÃ¡r, J.;PÃ³ti, A.;Pipek, O.;Krzystanek, M.;Kanu, N.;Swanton, C.;TusnÃ¡dy, G. E.;Szallasi, Z.;Csabai, I.;SzÃ¼ts, D.

title: Altered virome and bacterial microbiome in human immunodeficiency virus-associated acquired immunodeficiency syndrome
authors: Monaco, C. L.;Gootenberg, D. B.;Zhao, G.;Handley, S. A.

title: Viruses isolated from reptiles: identification of three new members of the Rhabdoviridae family
abstract: The growth of four viruses isolated from lizards in Brazil (Marco, Chaco and Timbo viruses) and Australia (Almpiwar virus) was studied in various continuous cell lines of mammalian, reptilian, amphibian and fish origin. Although replication was found in certain cell lines derived from cold-blooded species, the cytopathic effect (CPE) was absent or minimal and growth was less than or equal to that in mammalian cells. These observations seem to limit the value of poikilothermic cells for the primary isolation of viruses from field-collected cold-blooded vertebrates or arthropods that feed on them. The four reptilian viruses were found to be naturally occurring temperature sensitive agents, with around 30°C being optimal for growth. Electron microscopy studies showed that three of the viruses (Marco, Chaco and Timbo) are new members of the Rhabdoviridae family. Marco virus particles were cone-shaped and resembled bovine ephemeral fever virus and two lyssaviruses (Kotonkan and Obodhaing). Chaco and Timbo viruses were cylindrical viruses similar to other rhabdoviruses with longer particle lengths than the prototype VSV. No serological associations were found in cross complement fixation tests between these viruses, Marco virus and 34 other rhabdoviruses.
authors: Monath, T. P.;Cropp, C. B.;Frazier, C. L.

title: Detection of orf virus from an outbreak in goats and its genetic association with other parapoxviruses
authors: Mondal, B.;Bera, A. K.;Hosamani, M.;Tembhurne, P. A.;Bandyopadhyay, S. K.

title: Comparison of four regions in the replicase gene of heterologous infectious bronchitis virus strains
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) produces six subgenomic (sg) mRNAs, each containing 64 nucleotide (nt) leader sequences, derived from the 5'² end of the genome in a discontinuous process. Several putative functional domains such as papain-like proteinase (PLpro), major protease (M pro), RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), and RNA helicase encoded by the replicase gene are important for virus replication. We sequenced the 5â€²-terminal sequence, four regions of replicase genes corresponding to the PLpro, Mpro and RdRp domains from 20 heterologous IBV strains and compared them with previously published coronavirus sequences. In contrast to the highly conserved Mpro and RdRp domains with 28% and 48% conserved residues, respectively, all coronavirus 5-termini and PLpro domains were different. Among the IBV strains, the 5â€² untranslated regions containing the leader sequence were highly conserved (>94% identical); whereas the N-terminal coding region and PLpro domains were highly variable, ranging from 84.6% to 100% and 77.6% to 100% identity, respectively. The IBV Mpro and RdRp domains were highly conserved with 82.7% and 92.7% conserved residues, respectively. The BJ strain was most different from other IBVs in all four regions of the replicase. The phylogeny-based clustering based on replicase genes was the same as the classification of coronaviruses into three antigen-based groups. However, IBV strain classification based on replicase gene domains did not correlate with that of the type-specific antigenic groups. The replicase gene sequences of many IBVs from infected chickens were identical to those of vaccine viruses, regardless of serotype, suggesting an exchange of genetic material between vaccine and field isolates or a convergent evolution in a specific replicase genotype. . There was no correlation between the genotype of any region of the replicase gene and the pathotype, suggesting that replicase is not the only determinant of IBV pathogenicity. Â© 2004 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Mondal, S. P.;Cardona, C. J.

title: Molecular characterization of bovine rotavirus strains circulating in northern Italy, 2003-2005
abstract: total of 232 faeces collected from calves with rotavirus infection in herds in northern Italy between 2003 and 2005 were examined. Identification of rotavirus G and P types was performed using nested RT-PCR. G6 was the most common genotype, constituting 78.5% of the samples, G10 viruses were found in 9.9% of the samples and G8 type viruses were found in 4.7% of the samples. In 3% of samples, viruses were not classified due to concomitant infection with more G-type strains, whereas in 3.9% of samples viruses could not be characterized by any of the G-specific primers used in this study. The most common P types were P[11] and P[5] corresponding to 65.1% and 25%, respectively. In 2.6% of cases, samples reacted with more than one P-specific primer; no P[1] serotypes were identified. The G6P[11] combination was dominant throughout the study period, ie 52.5% in 2003, 50% in 2004 and 40% in 2005. The incidence of G6P[5] increased from 13.1% in 2003 to 27% and 25.5% in 2004. The G10P[11] combination fell from 18% in 2003 to 2.6% in 2004 and rose again to 7.3% in 2005. G8P[11] viruses were similarly present in 2003 (5%) and 2004 (4.3%). A slight decrease (1.8%) in 2005. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Monini, M.;Cappuccini, F.;Battista, P.;Falcone, E.;Lavazza, A.;Ruggeri, F. M.

title: Reassortant avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses with H9N2-PB1 gene in poultry, Bangladesh
abstract: Bangladesh has reported multiple outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) (H5N1) in poultry. We identified a natural reassortant HPAI (H5N1) virus containing the H9N2-PB1 gene in poultry in Bangladesh. Our findings highlight the risks associated with long-term co-circulation of avian influenza viruses and the need to monitor their evolution.
authors: Monne, I.;Yamage, M.;Dauphin, G.;Claes, F.;Ahmed, G.;Giasuddin, M.;Salviato, A.;Ormelli, S.;Bonfante, F.;Schivo, A.;Cattoli, G.

title: Immunomodulatory effects of heat stress and lipopolysaccharide on bursal transcriptome in two different chicken lines
abstract: BACKGROUND: Exposure to heat stress suppresses poultry immune responses, which can increase susceptibility to infectious diseases and thus intensify the adverse effects of heat on poultry welfare and performance. Identifying genes and pathways affected by high temperatures, particularly heat-induced changes in immune responses, may provide targets for improving disease resistance in chickens. In this study, RNA sequencing (RNA sequencing) was used to investigate transcriptome responses in the bursa of Fabricius, a primary immune tissue, after exposure to acute heat stress and/or subcutaneous immune stimulation with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in a 2×2 factor design. : Thermoneutral + Salty, Heat + Salty, Thermoneutral + LPS and Heat + LPS. All treatments were investigated in two chicken lines: the relatively heat and disease resistant Fayoumi line and a more susceptible broiler line. RESULTS: Differential expression analysis determined that Heat + Salt Water had a limited effect on gene expression (N = 1 or 63 genes) in broiler or Fayoumi bursa. However, Thermoneutral + LPS and Heat + LPS produced many expression changes in Fayoumi bursa (N = 368 and 804 genes). Thermoneutral + LPS was predicted to increase immune-related cell signaling and cell migration, while Heat + LPS would activate death-related functions and decrease expression in WNT signaling pathways. Other inter-process comparisons in the Fayoumi line revealed that heat stress prevented most LPS-induced expression changes. Both treatments were predicted to increase cell migration, although less significant expression changes were observed in broiler bursa after exposure to Thermoneutral + LPS (N = 59 genes) or Heat + LPS (N = 146 genes). Direct comparison between lines (broiler to Fayoumi) confirmed that each line had different response to treatment. RESULTS: Transcriptome analysis identified genes and pathways involved in bursal responses to heat stress and LPS, explaining that these effects were greatest with combined therapy. The interaction between heat and LPS was primarily even dependent, with suppressive expression changes in the Fayoumi line. Potential target genes, particularly those related to cell migration and immune signaling, could inform future research on heat stress in poultry and be useful for improving disease resistance.
authors: Monson, M. S.;Van Goor, A. G.;Ashwell, C. M.;Persia, M. E.;Rothschild, M. F.;Schmidt, C. J.;Lamont, S. J.

title: Genetic analysis of avian influenza virus from migratory waterfowl in Mexico
abstract: This study describes the genetic characterization of avian influenza virus from waterfowl in Mexico. Partial sequences of two H5, one H6 and one H9 hemmaglutinin (HA) genes were determined. The deduced amino acid sequences indicated that they were low pathogenic viruses (LPAI). Phylogenetic analysis of H5 and H6 HA shows a North American lineage closely related to contemporary California isolates, and H9 HA is more closely related to Korean-like lineages. These results suggest that a diverse pool of genetic subtypes was introduced into Sonora's estuaries through the circulation of avian species carriers from the Pacific passageway.
authors: Montalvo-Corral, M.;Hernandez, J.

title: Genetic grouping of avian infectious bronchitis virus isolated in Brazil based on RT-PCR/RFLP analysis of the S1 gene
abstract: Twelve Brazilian isolates and one reference vaccine strain of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were propagated in embryonated chicken eggs. The entire S1 glycoprotein gene of these viruses was analyzed by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction and restriction fragment length polymorphism (RT-PCR-RFLP) using restriction enzymes HaeIII, XcmI and Bstyl. RFLP patterns led to the classification of these isolates into five distinct genotypes, A, B, C, D, and Massachusetts. Five of the twelve isolates were grouped into the Massachusetts genotype, and the remaining seven viruses were classified into four different genotypes: A (2), B (2), C (2), or D (1). This type of genotyping classification agreed with previous immunological analyzes for most of these viruses, highlighting the emergence of a relevant variability among IBV strains circulating in Brazilian commercial poultry flocks.
authors: Montassier, M. D. S.;Brentano, L.;Montassier, H. J.;Richtzenhain, L. J.

title: Detection and genetic identification of pestiviruses in lots of Brazilian fetal bovine serum collected from 2006 to 2014.
abstract: This study performed a genetic identification of pestiviruses that contaminate batches of fetal bovine serum (FBS) produced in Brazil from 2006 to 2014. Seventy-three FBS lots were screened with an RT-PCR targeting the 5' untranslated region (UTR) of the pestivirus. genetic code. Thirty-nine lots (53.4%) were positive for pestivirus RNA and one contained infectious virus. Nucleotide sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the 5'UTR, 34 lots (46.6%) containing bovine viral diarrhea virus type 1 (BVDV-1) RNA, including 23 BVDV-1a (5' UTR identity 90.8-98.7%), eight BVDV ) revealed. -1b (93.9-96.7%) and three BVDV-1d (96.2%-97.6%). Six batches (8.2%) contained two BVDV-2a, BVDV-2 (90.3%-100% UTR identity); three BVDV-2b and one indeterminate. Four FBS series (5.5%) were found to be contaminated with HoBi-like virus (98.3% to 100%). Five series (6.8%) contained more than one pestivirus. The high frequency of contamination of FBS with pestivirus RNA reinforces the need for systematic and up-to-date guidelines for monitoring this product to reduce the risk of contamination of biologics and entry of contaminants into free areas.
authors: Monteiro, F. L.;Cargnelutti, J. F.;Braunig, P.;Folgueras-Flatschart, A. V.;Santos, N. C.;Pituco, E. M.;Weiblen, R.;Flores, E. F.

title: Hepatitis E virus circulation in Italy: Phylogenetic and evolutionary analysis
abstract: Background: Hepatitis E virus (HEV), the major cause of acute viral hepatitis in developing countries, has been classified into four main genotypes and a number of subtypes. New genotypes have recently been identified in various mammals, including the HEV genotype 3, which has a worldwide distribution. It is common among pigs in developed countries. Objective: This study investigated the genetic diversity of HEV among humans and pigs in Italy. HEV's date of origin and demographic history were also estimated. Material and Methods: A total of 327 HEV pig and human sequences from Italy were downloaded from the national center for biotechnology information. Three different data sets were created. The first and second datasets were used to confirm the genotype of the analyzed sequences. The third dataset was used to estimate the mean rate of evolution and to determine time-scale phylogeny and demographic history. Results: The Bayesian maximum clade confidence tree and time of most common ancestor estimates showed that the root of the tree dates back to 1907 (95% HPD: 1811 - 1975). Two major branches were found, divided into two subsections. Skyline plot analysis for the human and pig lines separately showed the presence of a bottleneck only in the horizon plot of the pig lines. Selective pressure analysis revealed only negatively selected regions. Conclusions: This study supports the hypothesis that humans are likely infected after contact with swine sources. The findings highlight the importance of controlling the pig's country of origin and improving veterinary sanitary control measures to prevent the spread of HEV infection in Italy.
authors: Montesano, C.;Giovanetti, M.;Ciotti, M.;Cella, E.;Lo Presti, A.;Grifoni, A.;Zehender, G.;Angeletti, S.;Ciccozzi, M.

title: Viral interactions with host and microbiota in the gut
abstract: This review explores recent advances in our understanding of host-viral interactions in the gut. Technical advances have allowed the first description of intestinal viromes in many species, including humans. Significant advances in our knowledge of the host response to viral infection have demonstrated that interferon lambda has a unique role from type I interferons in the gut. Finally, our understanding of virally induced phenotypes has been expanded with new studies showing that bacteria may play an important role in the outcome of viral infection in the gut. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Moon, C.;Stappenbeck, T. S.

title: Sequence comparison of avian infectious bronchitis virus S1 glycoproteins of Florida serotype and five variant isolates from Georgia and California
abstract: The infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) spike glycoprotein S1 subunit is required to initiate infection and contains virus neutralizing and serotype-specific epitope(s). S1 gene nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences have been reported for Florida 18288 strain and isolates GA-92, CV-56b, CV-9437, CV-1686 and 1013. These sequences were compared with previously published gene sequences of IBV strains, and phylogenetic relationships were reported. The SI amino acid sequence of Florida 18288 was 94.9% similar to the Connecticut strain and 92.8% similar to the GA-92, Arkansas 99 strain. The S1 amino acid sequences of the California variants CV-56b, CV-9437 and CV-1686 were 97.6-99.3% similar to each other and only 76.-76.8% to the Arkansas-type strains. The Isolate 1013, also from California, was 84.0% similar to the Ark DPI and 77.9% to the CV-56b. When comparing 19 viruses isolated from the United States, sequence variations were observed between amino acids 55-96, 115-149, 255-309, and 378-395. Similar regions have been reported to be located in virus neutralizing and/or serotype-specific epitopes. These data suggest that variant IBV strains continue to emerge and unique variants may circulate among poultry in geographically isolated areas.
authors: Moore, K. M.;Bennett, J. D.;Seal, B. S.;Jackwood, M. W.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin genes of 12 H9N2 influenza viruses isolated from chickens in Iran between 2003 and 2005.
abstract: In this study, hemagglutinin genes from 12 influenza viruses of H9N2 subtype were isolated, amplified and sequenced from chicken flocks in different provinces of Iran between 2003 and 2005. All 12 isolates showed similar sequences in RSSF/GLF at the cleavage site, which carries eight potential glycosylation sites and shares characteristic amino acid residues alanine-190, glutamine-226 and glutamine-227 at the receptor binding site. Of these 12 isolates, 10 had leucine at the predominant position 226 in sequences found in human H2 and H3 strains. Overall, the presence of H9N2 viruses of the sequence known to bind to human-type receptors in these Iranian poultry and the presence of antibodies to H9N2 in the Iranian human population indicated that it is possible for H9N2 avian influenza viruses circulating in Iran to infect humans. . Therefore, comprehensive surveillance of H9N2 in this country is highly recommended. Â© 2010 American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Moosakhani, F.;Shoshtari, A. H.;Pourbakhsh, S. A.;Keyvanfar, H.;Ghorbani, A.

title: Detection and molecular characterization of Swine astrovirus strains associated with swine diarrhea
abstract: Astrovirus has been reported to be associated with diarrhea in pigs. The current study was conducted for the detection and molecular characterization of astroviruses in swine with diarrhea sent to the University of Minnesota Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory. Intestinal contents from 269 pigs were analyzed by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and 62% were positive for astroviruses. 20% of the positive samples were positive for astrovirus alone, astrovirus with rotavirus was detected in 58% of the samples. The remaining 22% revealed the presence of astrovirus together with Porcine hemagglutinated encephalomyelitis virus, Infectious gastroenteritis virus or Porcine circovirus-2. Sequencing of the capsid gene of 56 randomly selected samples confirmed that they were Porcine astrovirus type 4 (PAstV-4) with 58-100% nucleotide identity within these viruses. Phylogenetic analysis revealed 2 possible subgroups. The results suggest that PAstV has been found in pig farms in the United States and may be associated with diarrhea alone or in combination with other enteric viruses. Further studies are needed to determine strain diversity among porcine astroviruses so that appropriate control strategies can be designed and implemented. Â© 2012 Author(s).
authors: Mor, S. K.;Chander, Y.;Marthaler, D.;Patnayak, D. P.;Goyal, S. M.

title: Molecular characterization of class L genome segments of a newly isolated turkey arthritis reovirus.
abstract: Seven turkey arthritis reovirus (TARV) strains isolated from turkey arthritis cases were characterized on the basis of class L genome segment sequences, which were then compared with turkey enteric reovirus (TERV) and chicken reovirus (CRV). All three L-class gene segments of TARVs and TERVs and their encoded proteins Î»A, Î»B and Î»C were similar in size to those of the CRV reference strain S1133. Conserved motifs such as the C2H2 zinc-binding motif and the conserved polymerase domain were present in Î»A and Î»B, respectively. A conserved motif for the ATP/GTP-binding site and an S-adenosyl-. The l-methionine (SAM) binding pocket for methyltransferase was observed in the Î»C protein of TARVs and TERVs with only one substitution compared to that in CRV. We propose a new genotype classification system for avian reoviruses (ARVs) based on the nt identity cut-off value for each of the L class. According to this new genotype classification, all ARVs were divided into six, seven and eight genotypes in the L1, L2 and L3 genes, respectively. Interestingly, TARVs and TERVs were grouped in the L1-I genotype with three CRVs (two arthritic strains from Taiwan and one enteritic strain from Japan) and a different genotype (L2-I, L3-I) formed. Maximum nucleotide differentiation was observed in the genotypes of the L1 and L2 genes, but less at the amino acid level, indicating that the changes were mostly synonymous type. Non-synonymous changes were more common in the L3 gene compared to the L1 and L2 genes. Point mutations and possible reclassifications were also observed among TARVs, TERVs, and CRVs. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Mor, S. K.;Sharafeldin, T. A.;Porter, R. E.;Goyal, S. M.

title: Characterization of canine fecal virus in healthy dogs and dogs with acute diarrhea using shotgun metagenomics.
authors: Moreno, P. S.;Wagner, J.;Mansfield, C. S.;Stevens, M.

title: Concise and broadly applicable method for determining the genomic sequences of North American-type porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses in various clusters
abstract: We have developed a concise and broadly applicable method for accurate genomic sequencing of North American genotype (NA type) porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses (PRRSVs), which overcomes the high genetic variability of viruses. The method, called "combination of consensus oligonucleotide reverse transcription and multiple displacement amplification" (CORT-MDA), involves reverse transcription of viral RNA followed by shotgun sequencing after amplification using only 11 degenerate oligonucleotide primers; these primers were designed against consensus regions in open reading frames of 124 NA-type PRRSV strains with reported full-length genomic sequences. Sequencing of 192 shotgun clones generated per virus showed 80% to 94% coverage on the reported PRRSV genomic sequence, such that only 2 or 3 unread regions were resequented after PCR amplification using custom primers. Direct sequencing of RT-PCR products confirmed the absolute consistency between sequences determined by the CORT-MDA method and sequences from RT-PCR. These results demonstrate that our method is applicable to various NA-type viruses.
authors: Morozumi, T.;Iseki, H.;Toki, D.;Takagi, M.;Tsunemitsu, H.;Uenishi, H.

title: Genomic evolution, recombination, and interspecies diversity of fibropapillomatous chelonid alphaherpesvirus 5 from Florida and Hawaii green sea turtles.
abstract: Chelonid alphaherpesvirus 5 (ChHV5) is a herpes virus associated with fibropapillomatosis (FP) in sea turtles worldwide. Single locus typing has previously shown differentiation between Atlantic and Pacific strains of this virus, with low variation in each geographic branch. However, the lack of multi-locus genomic sequence data precludes understanding of the rate and mechanisms of ChHV5 evolutionary divergence, as well as how these genomic changes may contribute to differences in disease manifestation. To assess genomic variation in ChHV5 among five Hawaiian and three Florida green sea turtles, we used high-throughput short-read sequencing of long-range PCR products amplified from tumor tissue using primers designed from the only available ChHV5 reference genome from the Hawaiian green sea. tortoise. This strategy recovered sequence data from both geographic regions for approximately 75% of the predicted ChHV5 coding sequences. The mean nucleotide difference between geographic populations was 1.5%; most of the substitutions were constant differences between regions. Protein deviation was generally low (mean 0.08%) and ranged from 0% to 5.3%. Several atypical genes originally identified and annotated in the reference genome were validated in ChHV5 genomes from both geographic locations. Certain recombination events have been identified across geographic regions, and clustering of specific alleles reveals the prevalence of recombination in the evolutionary history of ChHV5. This study significantly increased the amount of sequence data from ChHV5 strains, enabling informed locus selection for future population genetic and natural history studies, suggesting co-infection of individuals by (possibly latent) well-differentiated geographic variants.
authors: Morrison, C. L.;Iwanowici, L.;Work, T. M.;Fahsbender, E.;Breitbart, M.;Adams, C.;Iwanowiczi, D.;Sanders, L.;Ackermann, M.;Cornman, R. S.

title: Myeloid and erythroid neoplastic responses to avian defective leukemia viruses in chickens and quails
abstract: comparative study of the oncogenic potential of two avian defective leukemia viruses (DLVs) shows that avian erythroblastosis virus induces myeloid leukemia in quails and confirms that E26 causes erythroid leukemia in chickens. These results suggest that the bird response to these two DLVs is dependent on the host species, and classification of DLVs based on in vitro studies alone may not be conclusive.
authors: Moscovici, C.;Samarut, J.;Gazzolo, L.;Moscovici, M. G.

title: Universal Next-Generation Sequencing Protocol for Creating Non-Infectious Barcoded cDNA Libraries from High Coverage RNA Viruses
abstract: few biosafety level 3 and/or 4 (BSL-3/4) pathogens are high-result, single-stranded RNA viruses, and their genomes are infectious when introduced into permissive cells. Also, most of these viruses are elite agents (SAs) and their genomes are also considered SAs. Therefore, cDNAs and/or their derivatives should be tested to ensure the absence of infectious virus and/or viral RNA prior to transfer from the BSL-3/4 and/or SA laboratory. This greatly limits the capacity to conduct viral genomic research, particularly the application of next-generation sequencing (NGS). Here, we present a sequence-independent method to simultaneously eliminate both viral and genomic RNA infectivity among multiple families of single-stranded positive-sense RNA (ssRNA+) viruses while rapidly replicating viral genomic RNA. The process produces barcoded DNA amplicons ranging in length from 300 to 1,000 bp, which cannot be used to rescue a virus and are stable for transport at room temperature. Our barcoding approach allows up to 288 barcoded samples to be collected in a single library and run on a variety of NGS platforms without the potential need to reconstruct the viral genome. Our data demonstrate that this approach not only provides full-length genomic sequence information from high-titer virion preparations, but can also recover specific viral sequence from samples with limited starting material in the cellular RNA background and can be used to identify pathogens. In summary from unknown samples, we describe a rapid, universal standard operating procedure that generates high-quality NGS libraries free of infectious virus and infectious viral RNA. IMPORTANT This report describes a standard operating procedure for selected agents (SAs) and other biosafety level 3 and/or 4 (BSL-3/4) RNA viruses to rapidly generate non-infectious, barcoded cDNA suitable for next-generation sequencing. SOP) and validates. (NGS). This removes the burden of testing all processed samples derived from high-result pathogens before they are transferred from high-content laboratories to lower-content facilities for sequencing. Our built-in protocol is scalable for high-throughput sequencing of hundreds of samples simultaneously, significantly reducing the cost and effort required for NGS library construction. NGS data from this SOP can provide full genome coverage from viral stocks and also detect virus-specific reads from limited starting material. Our data demonstrate that the procedure is applicable and easily validated by institutional biosafety committees in research laboratories.
authors: Moser, L. A.;Ramirez-Carvajal, L.;Puri, V.;Pauszek, S. J.;Matthews, K.;Dilley, K. A.;Mullan, C.;McGraw, J.;Khayat, M.;Beeri, K.;Yee, A.;Dugan, V.;Heise, M. T.;Frieman, M. B.;Rodriguez, L. L.;Bernard, K. A.;Wentworth, D. E.;Stockwell, T. B.;Shabman, R. S.

title: RNA2DMut: a web tool for the design and analysis of RNA structure mutations
abstract: With the widespread application of high-throughput sequencing, new RNA sequences are being discovered at an astonishing rate. However, function analysis lags behind. In both the cis- and trans-regulatory functions of RNA, the secondary structure (2D base pairing) plays essential regulatory roles. To test RNA function, being able to design and analyze mutations that may affect the construct is essential. This was the motivation for the creation of the RNA2DMut web tool. With RNA2DMut, users can tap into RNA sequences to analyze, limit mutations to certain residues or limit changes in purines/pyrimidines. The sequence is analyzed on each basis to determine the effect of each possible point mutation on the 2D structure. The metrics used in RNA2DMut are based on calculation of the Boltzmann group of structures and do not require a robust 2D RNA structure model to design mutations. This tool can facilitate a wide range of uses involving RNA: for example, in designing and evaluating mutants for biological testing, interrogating RNA-protein interactions, identifying key regions to modify in SELEX experiments, and improving RNA folding and crystallization properties for structural biology. Additional tools are available to help users introduce other mutations (for example, indels and substitutions) and evaluate their effect on RNA structure. Exemplary calculations are shown for five RNAs that require 2D structure for their function: MALAT1 mascRNA, an influenza virus splice regulatory motif, EBER2 viral noncoding RNA, Xist lncRNA repA region, and human Y RNA 5. RNA2DMut is available at https. ://rna2dmut.bb.iastate.edu/.
authors: Moss, W. N.

title: Viral detection by high-throughput sequencing
abstract: We applied Ion PGM, a high-throughput sequencing platform for viral detection in stool samples from adult cows collected in Hokkaido, Japan. Random RT-PCR was performed to amplify RNA extracted from 0.25 ml stool samples (N = 8) and more than 5 µg of cDNA was synthesized. Unbiased high-throughput sequencing using the 318 v2 semiconductor chip of these eight samples gave readings of 57–580 K (average after data analysis: 270 K) in a single run. As a result, viral genome sequences were detected in each sample. In addition to viruses of bacteriophage, mammalian and insect origin, partial genome sequences of plant, algal and protozoal viruses were detected. Therefore, this metagenomic analysis of fecal samples may be useful for a comprehensive understanding of viral populations of gut and food sources in animals.
authors: Motooka, D.;Nakamura, S.;Hagiwara, K.;Nakaya, T.

title: Hepatitis E in three immunocompromised children in southeastern France
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) causes an autochthonous disease that occurs in developed countries where links with a viral swine reservoir have been proven. In addition, chronic HEV infection and associated cirrhosis have been described in severely immunocompromised patients. However, only a few studies worldwide have focused on pediatric HEV infections, and only four autochthonous cases have been reported in children in developed countries. Here we describe acute hepatitis E in three immunocompromised children. Case number 1 was a 9-year-old liver transplant recipient who was diagnosed with H1N1 2009 flu infection concurrently with hepatitis E. case no. 2 was a 12-year-old boy presenting early medullary recurrence of type B lymphoblastic leukemia and HEV RNA was detected over a 29-week period. Case number 3 was a 9-year-old boy with a rare primary immunodeficiency due to XIAP deficiency. All HEV infections were autochthonous and included different viruses classified as subtypes f, c and e of genotype 3 identified in autochthonous cases in Europe. These three observations have led to the consideration of HEV as a hepatitis-causing agent in children in developed countries, and to testing for HEV, particularly in severely immunocompromised individuals who may develop chronic hepatitis E. Â© 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Motte, A.;Roquelaure, B.;Galambrun, C.;Bernard, F.;Zandotti, C.;Colson, P.

title: blood DNA virome in 8,000 people
authors: Moustafa, A.;Xie, C.;Kirkness, E.;Biggs, W.;Wong, E.

title: Epidemiological investigation of enteric viruses in wild boars in the Czech Republic: first evidence of close association between wild boar and human rotavirus A strains.
abstract: The wild boar population is increasing all over Europe, with animals migrating close to human habitats, greatly increasing the likelihood of natural transmission between domestic animals or humans and wild boars. The aim of the study was to estimate the prevalence of enteric viral pathogens, namely rotavirus groups A and C (RVA and RVC), porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) in the free-living wild boar population in the Czech Republic. Members of the Coronaviridae family (infectious gastroenteritis virus – TGEV, porcine epidemic diarrhea virus – PEDV, porcine respiratory coronavirus – PRCV and porcine hemagglutination encephalomyelitis virus – PHEV) and Picornaviridae,(teschovirus A – PTV, sapelovirus A – PSV and enterovirus G – EV-G ). In our study, fecal samples from 203 wild boars culled in the 2014-2015 (October-January) hunting season were examined by RT-PCR. RVA was detected in 2.5% of the samples tested. Nucleotide analysis of the VP7, VP4 and VP6 genes revealed that the four RVA strains belonged to the genotypes G4P[25I1, G4P[6]I5, G11P[13]I5 and G5P[13]I5, and phylogenetic analysis showed close association with pig. and human RVAs. The prevalence of RVC in the wild boar population was found to be 12.8%, PTV 20.2%, PSV 8.9%, and EV-G 2.5% of the samples. No PRRSV or coronavirus was detected during our study. Our study provides the first evidence of the prevalence of RVC in wild boars and demonstrates that wild boars may contribute to the genetic variability of RVA and also serve as an important reservoir of other enteric viruses.
authors: MoutelÃ­kovÃ¡, R.;DufkovÃ¡, L.;Kamler, J.;Drimaj, J.;Plhal, R.;ProdÄ›lalovÃ¡, J.

title: Identifying an emerging disease
abstract: It is not easy to identify an emerging disease, as there are several different types of disease manifestation. For example, there may be a 'true' emergence of a brand new disease, such as the emergence of bovine spongiform encephalopathy in the 1980s, or a geographical manifestation in a previously unaffected region, such as the emergence of blue tongue in northern Europe. 2006. In addition, disease may occur in species previously thought to be unaffected, for example the occurrence of bovine tuberculosis in wildlife species in France since 2000. There may also be an unexpected increase in the incidence of disease in a known area and a known type, or an increase in our knowledge or awareness of a particular disease. The common point of all these emerging diseases is that human activities often play a role in their emergence. For example, bovine spongiform encephalopathy most likely arose as a result of changes in meat-bone meal production, bluetongue spread to colder climates as a result of uncontrolled animal trade, and as a result of relaxed screening and surveillance for animals. bovine tuberculosis has allowed the disease to re-emerge in areas that can significantly reduce the number of cases. Globalization and population growth will continue to affect the epidemiology of diseases in the coming years, and ecosystems will continue to evolve. In addition, new technologies such as metagenomics and high-throughput sequencing are always identifying new microorganisms. The only constant is change, and diseases will continue to arise and when dealing with these diseases in the future we must consider the causes and the different types of manifestation.
authors: Moutou, F.;Pastoret, P. P.

title: Root loop recognition by DDX17 facilitates miRNA processing and antiviral defense
abstract: DEAD-box helicases play important roles in RNA metabolism across species, but emerging data suggest they have additional functions in immunity. Through RNAi screening, we identified an evolutionarily conserved and interferon-independent role for DEAD box helix DDX17 in restricting Rift Valley fever virus (RVFV), a mosquito-borne virus in the bunyavirus family that causes severe morbidity and mortality in humans and livestock. . Loss of Drosophila DDX17 (Rm62) in cells and flies increased RVFV infection. Similarly, depletion of DDX17, but not its related helix DDX5, increased RVFV replication in human cells. Using cross-linking immunoprecipitation high-throughput sequencing (CLIP-seq), we show that DDX17 binds stem loops of host pri-miRNA to facilitate processing, as well as an important stem loop in bunyaviral RNA to restrict infection. Thus, DDX17 has a dual role in the recognition of stem loops: in the nucleus for endogenous microRNA (miRNA) biogenesis and in the cytoplasm for surveillance against structured core elements. © 2014 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Moy, R. H.;Cole, B. S.;Yasunaga, A.;Gold, B.;Shankarling, G.;Varble, A.;Molleston, J. M.;Tenoever, B. R.;Lynch, K. W.;Cherry, S.

title: Phylogeographic analysis of African swine fever virus based on the p72 gene sequence.
abstract: The African swine fever virus (ASFV) epidemic has been recognized as an emerging and reemerging disease for almost a century. For diagnosis, simple polymerase chain reaction and sequencing-based molecular detection can be used for both viral identification and genotyping. This study established a new phylogenetic analysis and epidemiology comparison based on the 205 bp p72 gene sequences. Based on this partial p72 fragment, an updated list of 44 different genotypes was generated from a total of 516 ASFV sequences compiled from GenBank. The nucleotide diversity was 0.04325 Â± 0.00231. Analysis of spatial genetic diversity divided the ASFV populations of the African continent into four segments (section A: central and upper eastern Africa; segment B: eastern Africa; segment C: eastern and southern Africa; and segment D: southern Africa). These results and the developed protocol can serve as useful molecular tools for the diagnosis of ASFV from degraded DNA or decomposed samples, and also facilitate decision planning to limit their spread by providing a phylogeographic perspective to determine the origin of viral outbreaks.
authors: Muangkram, Y.;Sukmak, M.;Wajjwalku, W.

title: 'Next Generation' Surveillance: An Epidemiologists' Perspective on the Use of Molecular Information in Food Safety and Animal Health Decision Making
abstract: Advances in the availability and affordability of molecular and genomic data are transforming human health care. Surveillance aimed at promoting and improving food safety and animal health is likely to undergo a similar transformation. In this context, we propose a definition of "molecular surveillance" and argue that molecular data is a complement rather than a substitute for robust epidemiological study and surveillance design. Special considerations regarding sample collection were also raised, such as the importance of the relationship between the molecular clock rate of genetic markers and the space-time scale of surveillance effectiveness, which can be control or strategy driven. Along with the development of an interdisciplinary skill base covering both molecular and epidemiological principles, there is a need to develop standards for study design and evaluation of molecular surveillance system features.
authors: Muellner, P.;StÃ¤rk, K. D. C.;Dufour, S.;Zadoks, R. N.

title: Molecular epidemiology and loop-mediated isothermal amplification method for diagnosis of rabies virus infection in Zambia.
abstract: The National Center for Livestock Epidemiology and Information (NALEIC) in Zambia reported more than 132 cases of canine rabies diagnosed by direct fluorescent antibody testing (DFAT) from 2004 to 2009. In this study, the strain of rabies virus (RABV) in Zambia was determined. by phylogenetic analysis of nucleoprotein (N) and glycoprotein (G) gene sequences. Total RNA was extracted from 87-DFAT brain samples, of which only 35 (40%) were positive on the nested reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for each gene and 26 were positive for both genes. Positive samples for the N (n= 33) and G (n= 35) genes were used for phylogenetic analysis. Phylogenetic analysis of the N gene showed two phylogenetic clusters belonging to the African 1b lineage found in eastern and southern Africa in Zambia. One cluster consisted of Zambian strains only, while the other was more heterogeneous in RABV origins and included strains from Tanzania, Mozambique, and Zambia. Phylogenetic analysis of the G gene revealed similar RABV strains in different hosts and regions of Zambia. To improve the molecular diagnosis of RABV in Zambia, we designed primers for reverse transcription loop-mediated isothermal amplification (RT-LAMP) assay from the consensus sequence of the N gene. The specificity and reproducibility of the RT-LAMP assay has been validated with real clinical samples. Therefore, the RT-LAMP test presented in this study may prove useful for routine rabies diagnosis in Zambia. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Muleya, W.;Namangala, B.;Mweene, A.;Zulu, L.;Fandamu, P.;Banda, D.;Kimura, T.;Sawa, H.;Ishii, A.

title: A polyoma-like virus (Melopsittacus undulatus) associated with acute illness of baby budgerigars
abstract: virus previously isolated from acutely infected budgerigars (Melopsittacus undulatus) was purified and its structural properties were determined. With a buoyant density of 1.34 g/ml, virions are non-enveloped icosahedral particles about 46-48 nm in diameter. DNA genomes have a molecular weight of approximately 3.3 x 106 d and exist as supercoiled circular, loose circular and linear molecules. There are eight structural proteins, the most abundant gas, with a molecular weight of about 42,000 d. Empty capsid shells with floating densities of 1.31 g/ml are similar in size and shape, but lack DNA and histone-like polypeptides. Virus replication in chicken embryo cells results in cytopathic changes characterized by rounding and enlargement of the nucleus and formation of intranuclear inclusion bodies. All these features confirm the classification of the virus as polyoma-like.
authors: Muller, H.;Nitschke, R.

title: Genomic characterization of feline sarcoid-associated papillomavirus and proposed classification as Bos taurus papillomavirus type 14
abstract: Feline sarcoids are rare mesenchymal neoplasms of domestic and exotic cats. Previous studies have consistently detected short DNA sequences from a papillomavirus (PV) called feline sarcoid-associated papillomavirus (FeSarPV) in these neoplasms. The FeSarPV sequence has never been detected in any non-sarcoid samples from cats, but was amplified from bovine skin, suggesting that feline sarcoids are caused by interspecies infection by a bovine papillomavirus (BPV). The aim of this study was to determine the genome of PV containing the FeSarPV sequence. Using the circular structure of PV DNA, four specially designed "outward-facing" primers were used to amplify two DNA fragments of approximately 4,000 bp from a cat sarcoid. The two PCR products were sequenced using next-generation sequencing, and the 7,966 bp complete genome of PV was assembled and analyzed. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that PV is closely related to the 4 species of delta BPVs-1, -2 and -13, but distantly related to any carnivorous PV genera. These results are consistent with feline sarcoids caused by one type of BPV, and we propose a BPV-14 classification for this new PV. Initial analysis suggests that, like other delta BPVs, BPV-14 E5 protein may bind to the platelet-derived growth factor beta receptor, causing mesenchymal proliferation. Interestingly, the lack of detection of BPV-14 in any equine sarcoid suggests that BPV-14 has a limited host range to bovids and felines.
authors: Munday, J. S.;Thomson, N.;Dunowska, M.;Knight, C. G.;Laurie, R. E.;Hills, S.

title: Transcriptome sequencing reveals a complete genome sequence of cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus from passion fruit in Kenya.
abstract: Analysis of transcriptome sequencing (RNA-Seq) data revealed a complete Cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CABMV) genome from infected passion fruit in Kenya. We compared this to six complete CABMV genomes, each from Zimbabwe and Uganda, and each from Brazil and India. The Zimbabwean isolate CABMV-Z was closest, with 83.0% nucleotide identity.
authors: Munguti, F.;Maina, S.;Nyaboga, E. N.;Kilalo, D.;Kimani, E.;Macharia, M.;Holton, T.

title: Transcriptional response of avian cells to infection with Newcastle disease virus
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) causes widespread disease in poultry and wild birds worldwide. cDNA microarray analysis was used to examine the effect of NDV infection on host cell transcription. The results show that NDV infection causes significant suppression of interferon response genes in the early stages of infection. In addition, the results reveal transcriptional silencing of cytoskeletal proteins such as Î±, Î² and Î³ actin species and downregulation of the thioredoxin gene, a possible mediator of apoptosis with possible implications in NDV pathogenesis. Comparative analyzes suggest that most of the genes that are transcriptionally regulated during infection with avian pneumovirus, another common respiratory pathogen of poultry, remain unchanged during NDV infection, suggesting that even phylogenetically related viruses reveal unique or "signature" patterns of host transcriptional profiles during infection. . infection of host cells. Â© 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Munir, S.;Sharma, J. M.;Kapur, V.

title: Molecular epidemiological investigation of infectious bursal disease viruses in broiler farms reared under different vaccination schedules.
abstract: Over a period of approximately 4 years, 246 bursal tissue samples were collected from Brazilian commercial broiler flocks (Gallus gallus) across the country and printed on sample collection cards (Flinders Technology Associates (FTA) cards). A total of 75 infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) strains were successfully detected from FTA card prints and submitted for further identification and molecular characterization. The nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences of the IBDV surface protein VP2 were used to identify strains of the virus and place them into phylogenetic groups. Amino acids in the hypervariable region of VP2 were changed in this study, but about half of all positive samples were classified as vaccinia virus. IBD viruses were divided into 3 categories: variant IBDV, classic IBDV (vaccine), and very virulent (vv) IBDV. Samples were collected according to 3 different vaccination strategies used in broilers: vectored vaccine, antigen-antibody complex vaccine and traditional live vaccine. The genetic profile and frequency of strains obtained from the herds were highly dependent on the vaccination schedule. This information helps us better understand the current state of IBD in Brazil and provides additional scientific data to support the selection of the most effective vaccination strategies, products and practices to prevent the disease.
authors: Muniz, E. C.;Verdi, R.;Jackwood, D. J.;Kuchpel, D.;Resende, M. S.;Mattos, J. C. Q.;Cookson, K.

title: Classical swine fever virus vs. Classical swine fever virus: a superinfection exclusion phenomenon in experimentally infected wild pig.
abstract: Two groups of three wild boars each were used: Group A (1 to 3) served as control and Group B (animals 4 to 6) were permanently infected postnatally with the Cat01 strain (primary virus) of CSFV. Six-week-old and clinically healthy animals were vaccinated with the lethal Margarita strain (secondary virus). For the specific detection of the Margarita strain, a specific qRT-PCR assay was designed, which proved to have no cross-reactivity with the Cat01 strain. Wild boars consistently infected with CSFV were protected from superinfection by the lethal CSFV Margarita strain, as evidenced by the absence of clinical signs and the absence of detection of Margarita RNA in serum, swab, and tissue samples. In addition, in PBMCs, a well-known target for CSFV viral replication, only primary infecting virus RNA (strain Cat01) could be detected even after isolation in ST cells, demonstrating SIE at the tissue level in vivo. Furthermore, data analysis of Margarita qRT-PCR via calculated Î”Ct values supported that PBMCs from persistently infected animals were significantly protected from superinfection after in vitro vaccination with the Margarita virus strain and this virus could be infected. In parallel, IFN-β values could not be detected in sera from animals in Group B after vaccination with the CSFV Margarita strain. Furthermore, these animals failed to elicit adaptive humoral (no E2-specific or neutralizing antibodies) or cellular immune responses (in terms of IFN-β-producing cells) after vaccination with the second virus. Finally, a sequence analysis failed to detect CSFV Margarita RNA in the tested samples from Group B. Our results showed that the SIE phenomenon may play a role in the evolution and phylogeny of the virus, as well as in the control of CSFV by vaccination. To our knowledge, this study was one of the first to demonstrate effective suppression of superinfection in animals, particularly in the absence of IFN-α, which may be associated with a lack of innate immune mechanisms.
authors: MuÃ±oz-GonzÃ¡lez, S.;PÃ©rez-SimÃ³, M.;Colom-Cadena, A.;CabezÃ³n, O.;BohÃ³rquez, J. A.;Rosell, R.;PÃ©rez, L. J.;Marco, I.;LavÃ­n, S.;Domingo, M.;Ganges, L.

title: Electron microscopic studies of 'nonsyncytia-forming' bovine herpesviruses isolated in Tanzania
abstract: description of the morphology of 4 viruses recently isolated from cattle with substantially different clinical symptoms is given. The morphological features of the isolates are characteristic of the herpes virus group, therefore confirming the preliminary classification of virus strains according to their biological and serological behavior. The findings also show that the differential diagnosis of herpes viruses based on morphological criteria is not possible.
authors: Munz, E.;Goebel, E.;Rweyemamu, M. M.

title: Variations in the viral genome and biological characteristics of bovine leukemia virus wild-type strains
abstract: Bovine leukemia virus (BLV) is the etiologic agent of enzootic bovine leukosis (EBL), which causes enormous economic losses to the livestock industry worldwide. To reduce the economic loss caused by BLV infection, it is important to clarify the characters associated with BLV transmissibility and pathogenesis in cattle. In this study, we focused on viral characters and examined spontaneous mutations and viral characteristics in the virus by whole genome sequences and analyzes of BLV molecular clones from cows with and without EBL. Genomic analysis showed that all 28 strains harbor limited genetic variations, but no deletion mutations, which allowed classification into three groups (A, B, and C) except for one strain. Some nucleotide/amino acid substitutions were group specific. On the other hand, these genetic variations were not associated with the host bovine leukocyte antigen-DRB3 allele, which is known to be associated with BLV pathogenesis. In vitro viral replication activity was high, moderate and low in groups A, B and C, respectively. In addition, the proviral load associated with BLV transmissibility and pathogenesis was found to be high in cows infected with group A strains and low in those infected with group B/C strains. Therefore, these results suggest that limited genetic variations may affect viral traits related to BLV transmissibility and pathogenesis.
authors: Murakami, H.;Uchiyama, J.;Suzuki, C.;Nikaido, S.;Shibuya, K.;Sato, R.;Maeda, Y.;Tomioka, M.;Takeshima, S. N.;Kato, H.;Sakaguchi, M.;Sentsui, H.;Aida, Y.;Tsukamoto, K.

title: Physicochemical and morphological relationships of some arthropod-derived viruses with bluetongue virus - a new taxonomic group. Electron microscopic studies
authors: Murphy, F. A.;Borden, E. C.;Shope, R. E.;Harrison, A.

title: Molecular and biophysical characterization of the TT virus: Evidence for a new family of viruses infecting humans.
abstract: Recent isolation of a novel DNA virus from the serum of a Japanese patient (TT) provided the last possible candidate virus associated with cryptogenic hepatitis. In this study, we report the complete nucleotide sequence of this virus (TTV) isolated from the serum of a West African. Based on PCR studies designed to amplify overlapping regions of the viral genome and susceptibility to digestion with mung bean nuclease, the vital genome is circular and negative-stranded and contains 3,852 nt, which is 113 nt longer than the prototype isolate from Japan. Cesium chloride density gradient centrifugation showed virus banding at 1.31-1.34 g/ml; filtration studies have shown that TTV has a particle size of 30-50 nm. These results indicate that the virus is similar to Circoviridae, viruses known to infect plants and vertebrates (eg, birds and pigs); however, sequence similarity searches of existing databases did not reveal identity between TTV and other viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes of a 260 nt region from 151 globally distributed isolates demonstrated the presence of three major TTV genotypes. A few individuals at high risk of infection with parenterally transmitted viruses have been infected with more than one genotype. There was no association between genotype and geographic origin. Finally, intravenous inoculation of TTV-positive human serum into chimpanzees demonstrated that TTV can be transmitted to primates; No biochemical or histological evidence for hepatitis was obtained. The distinct biophysical and molecular features of TTV suggest that it is a member of a new family of viruses that we tentatively name Circinoviridae.
authors: Mushahwar, I. K.;Erker, J. C.;Muerhoff, A. S.;Leary, T. P.;Simons, J. N.;Birkenmeyer, L. G.;Chalmers, M. L.;Pilot-Matias, T. J.;Dexai, S. M.

title: Avian influenza virus wild bird surveillance in the Azov and Black Sea regions of Ukraine (2010-2011)
abstract: The Azov and Black Sea basins are part of transcontinental wild bird migration routes from North Asia and Europe to the Mediterranean, Africa and Southwest Asia. These regions constitute transitional, stopping and nesting areas for many different bird species. From September 2010 to September 2011, a wild bird surveillance study was conducted in these areas to identify avian influenza viruses. Biological samples from cloacal and tracheal swabs and faecal samples were collected from wild birds belonging to different ecological groups, including waterfowl and marine and terrestrial birds, at sites of mass bird accumulations in the Sivash Bay and Utlyuksky and Molochniy estuaries. The sampling covered the following wild bird biological cycles: autumn migration, wintering, spring migration, nesting, and post-nesting seasons. A total of 3634 specimens from 66 different bird species were collected. During the autumn migration, 19 hemagglutinating viruses were isolated, 14 of which were identified as low pathogenicity avian influenza (LPAI) virus subtypes H1Ny, H3N8, H5N2, H7Ny, H8N4, H10N7 and H11N8. Of the overwintering samples, 36 were LPAI virus subtypes H1N1, H1N? 45 hemagglutination viruses, defined as H1N2, H4N?, H6N1, H7N3, H7N6, H7N7, H8N2, H9N2, H10N7, H10N4, H11N2, H12N2 and H15N7. Only three viruses were isolated during the spring migration, nesting, and post-nesting seasons (serotypes H6, H13, and H16). HA and NA genes were sequenced from isolated H5 and N1 viruses, and phylogenetic analysis revealed possible ecological links between Azov and Black Sea regions and Europe. LPAI viruses were mostly isolated from mallard ducks, but also from shell ducks, oarsmen, teal and white-fronted geese. The remainder of the 14 isolated hemagglutinating viruses were identified as different avian paramyxovirus serotypes (APMV-1, APMV-4, APMV-6 and APMV-7). This information improves our understanding of the ecology of avian influenza viruses in wild avian species.
authors: Muzyka, D.;Pantin-Jackwood, M.;Spackman, E.;Stegniy, B.;Rula, O.;Shutchenko, P.

title: Prevalence and Molecular Characterization of Hepatitis E Virus in Retail Pork Products Marketed in Canada
abstract: Infection with the hepatitis E virus (HEV) is very common worldwide. HEV causes acute viral hepatitis with approximately 20 million cases per year. HEV genotypes 1 and 2 cause major aquatic and foodborne outbreaks with a significant mortality rate in developing countries, while genotypes 3 and 4 are more common in developed countries where transmission is mostly zoonotic. HEV is increasingly detected in pigs in North America and Europe, and exposure to pork and pork products is thought to be the primary source of infection. Therefore, we set out to investigate the prevalence of HEV in retail pork products available in Canada by screening meal-sized portions of bacon, raw pork sausage, and raw pork liver. The presence of HEV genomes was determined by RT-PCR and viral RNA was quantified by digital droplet PCR. Overall, HEV was detected in 47% of sampled pork purees and 10.5% of sampled raw pork livers, but not in sampled pork sausages, and sequencing confirmed that all HEV strains belonged to genotype 3. revealed that all isolates belonged to subtype 3a, except for one isolate with subtype 3d. Amino acid variations among isolates were also observed in the ordered capsid region. In conclusion, the prevalence of HEV in mashed potatoes and raw pork liver observed in this study is consistent with the current distribution of HEV in pork products reported in other developed countries.
authors: Mykytczuk, O.;Harlow, J.;Bidawid, S.;Corneau, N.;Nasheri, N.

title: Single primer isothermal amplification (SPIA) combined with next-generation sequencing provides full bovine coronavirus genome coverage and greater sequence depth compared to sequence-independent single primer amplification (SISPA).
abstract: Coronaviruses are of great importance for both animal and human health. With the emergence of novel coronaviruses such as SARS and MERS, the need for rapid genome characterization has become more important than ever. In addition, deep array and full-length viral genome analysis techniques are needed to understand the impact of half-species of these viruses on biology. In this study, we compared the efficiency of two sequence-independent approaches [sequence-independent single primer amplification (SISPA) and single primer isothermal amplification (SPIA, represented by the Ovation kit)] combined with high-throughput sequencing. Bovine coronavirus (BCoV) long genome from a nasal swab. Both methods achieved high genome coverage (100% for SPIA and 99% for SISPA), but there was a clear difference in the percentage of reads mapped to BCoV. Approximately 45% of Ovation reads are mapped to BCoV (sequence depth 169–284 944), while only 0.07% of SISPA reads (0–249 sequence depth) are mapped to the reference genome. Although BCoV was the focus of the study, we also identified a bovine rhinitis B virus (BRBV) in the datasets. The trend for this virus was similar to that observed for BCoV with respect to Ovation versus SISPA, but fewer sequences were mapped to BRBV due to a lower amount of this virus. In summary, the SPIA approach used in this study produced full BCoV (high copy number) and BRBV (low copy number) coverage and high sequence/genome depth compared to SISPA. Although this is a limited study, the results suggest that the Ovation method may be the preferred approach for whole genome sequencing if low numbers of viral RNA are expected and high sequence depth is desired.
authors: Myrmel, M.;Oma, V.;Khatri, M.;Hansen, H. H.;Stokstad, M.;Berg, M.;BlomstrÃ¶m, A. L.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of bovine viral diarrhea viruses using five different genetic regions
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of five different regions (5-non-coding region (5-NCR), Npro, E2, NS3 and NS5B-3-NCR) of the 48 Japanese and reported bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) genomes was performed. Japanese BVDVs were divided into six subgroups and BVDV1 divided into BVDV2. An isolate, So CP/75, isolated in 1975 and previously proposed as subgroup 1e to the 5-NCR sequence, was highly unique and constituted an independent lineage in the tree of any region. Another isolate from an experimental case of mucosal disease, 190CP, was classified as subgroup 1e identified by Becher et al. It is classified as subgroup 1a in the 5–²NCR, Npro and E2 regions, and in the NS5B-3–NCR region. The genomic sequences of the American isolates ILLC and ILLNC obtained from the GenBank database show subgroup 1b in the 5â€²NCR, Npro, E2 and NS5B-3â€²NCR regions, and subgroup 1a in the NS3 region, indicating that recombination between virus strains classified in different subgroups in one animal. think it occurs. These findings suggest that phylogenetic analysis of several genetic regions is useful for further characterization of field BVDV isolates. Â© 2003 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Nagai, M.;Hayashi, M.;Sugita, S.;Sakoda, Y.;Mori, M.;Murakami, T.;Ozawa, T.;Yamada, N.;Akashi, H.

title: Genomic and serological diversity of bovine viral diarrhea virus in Japan
abstract: The genomic characteristics of 62 field isolates of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) collected in Japan between 1974 and 1999 were investigated. The 5-² untranslated region (UTR) was amplified by reverse transcriptase-Polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and nucleotide sequences of 244 to 247 bases were determined. Serological properties were also characterized by the cross Neutralization test using antisera against the representative strain of the classified genotype. Using phylogenetic tree analysis, BVDV 1 was divided into two main clusters, BVDV-1a (29 isolates) and BVDV-1b (27 isolates). In group 1a, 3 was different from the other viruses and were classified in a branch assigned as 1aâ€². However, 4 isolates (ie CP/75, 190 CP, 190 NCP and KS86-1-NCP) could not be assigned to group 1a or 1b. Compared with published sequence data, KS86-1-NCP, 190 CP and 190 NCP were similar to South African isolates recently proposed as BVDV 1c. The 5–²UTR sequence of So CP/75 was unique among those in BVDV 1, suggesting that the isolate should be classified into a new genotype. Of the 62 isolates collected in 1989 and 1990, only 2 were identified as BVDV 2. The results of the Cross Neutralization test strongly supported these data and revealed a close correlation between the 5-UTR sequence and BVDV antigenicity.
authors: Nagai, M.;Ito, T.;Sugita, S.;Genno, A.;Takeuchi, K.;Ozawa, T.;Sakoda, Y.;Nishimori, T.;Takamura, K.;Akashi, H.

title: Identification and whole genome analysis of a novel bovine picornavirus in Japan
abstract: Using a metagenomic approach, we identified novel viruses in the stool of cattle with diarrhea collected in Hokkaido Prefecture, Japan in 2009, and identified the (almost) complete sequences of the virus. Sequence analyzes revealed that they have a standard picornavirus genome organization, namely the 5' untranslated region (UTR) - L- P1 (VP4- VP3- VP2- VP1) - P2 (2A-2B-2C) - P3 (3A-3B- 3C -3D) - 3'UTR- poly(A). They are closely related to other unclassified Chinese picornaviruses; bat picornaviruses group 1-3, feline picornavirus and canine picornavirus share amino acid identities of 45.4%-51.4% (P1), 38.0-44.9% (P2) and 49.6-53.3% (P3), respectively. Phylogenetic analyzes and detailed genome characterization showed that, together with the unclassified Chinese picornaviruses, they are grouped together as a cluster for the P1, 2C, 3CD and VP1 coding regions. These viruses have conserved features suggesting a common ancestry (eg, reverse transcription-PCR assays using specific primers designed from the 5'UTR sequence of these viruses showed that 23.0% (20/87) of stool samples from cattle with diarrhea were positive, which shows the prevalence of picornavirus in Japanese cattle population in Hokkaido Prefecture, however, further studies are needed to investigate the pathogenic potential and etiological role of these viruses in cattle.
authors: Nagai, M.;Omatsu, T.;Aoki, H.;Kaku, Y.;Belsham, G. J.;Haga, K.;Naoi, Y.;Sano, K.;Umetsu, M.;Shiokawa, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Furuya, T.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.

title: Whole genome analysis of bovine astrovirus from fecal samples of cattle in Japan: identifying possible interspecies transmission of bovine astrovirus.
abstract: viral metagenomic approach was used to investigate stool samples from diarrheal and nondiarrheal Japanese calves. Of the different viral pathogens detected, read counts in 15 of 146 stool samples collected from three different regions (Hokkaido, Ishikawa and Kagoshima Prefectures) between 2009 and 2015 yielded nearly all of the astrovirus-related RNA sequences. Due to the lack of genetic information about bovine astroviruses (BoAstVs) in Japan, these sequences were analyzed in this study. Nine of the 15 Japanese BoAstVs were closely related to the Chinese BoAstVs and clustered into a lineage (temporarily designated lineage 1) across all phylogenetic trees. Three of the 15 strains were phylogenetically distinct from lineage 1, showing low sequence identities and instead clustered with an American strain isolated from cattle with respiratory disease (tentatively designated lineage 2). Interestingly, two of the 15 strains clustered with lineage 1 in the open reading frame (ORF)1a and ORF1b regions clustered with lineage 2 in the ORF2 region. Remarkably, one of the 15 strains exhibited low amino acid sequence similarity to other BoAstVs and clustered separately with porcine astrovirus type 5 and ovine astrovirus in the ORF2 region in all trees, suggesting past interspecies transmission.
authors: Nagai, M.;Omatsu, T.;Aoki, H.;Otomaru, K.;Uto, T.;Koizumi, M.;Minami-Fukuda, F.;Takai, H.;Murakami, T.;Masuda, T.;Yamasato, H.;Shiokawa, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Naoi, Y.;Sano, K.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Furuya, T.;Shirai, J.;Mizutani, T.

title: GiRaF: Robust, computational identification of influenza reclassifications via graph mining
abstract: Reclassifications in influenza virus, a process in which strains alter genetic segments, played a role in two of the three 20th century pandemics and the 2009 H1N1 epidemic. While advances in sequencing have led to an explosion in the number of whole genome sequences available, an understanding of the rate and distribution of reassortments and their role in viral evolution is still lacking. A major factor in this is the lack of automated tools for the safe identification of reclassifications from sequence data due to the difficulties of analyzing large, uncertain viral phylogenies. Here we describe a new computational method called GiRaF (Graph mismatch-based Reclassification Finder) that powerfully identifies reclassifications in a fully automatic manner while accounting for uncertainties in inferred phylogenies. The algorithms behind GiRaF search large collections of Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampled trees for mismatched partition groups using a fast biclique numbering algorithm combined with several statistical tests to identify clusters of taxa with distinct phylogenetic placement. GiRaF accurately finds known reclassifications in human, avian and swine flu populations, including the evolutionary events that led to the recent 'swine flu' epidemic. GiRaF also identifies several previously unreported reclassifications through whole genome studies to catalog events in H5N1 and swine flu isolates. Â© Author(s) 2010. Published by Oxford University Press.
authors: Nagarajan, N.;Kingsford, C.

title: Novel Reassortant Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (H5N8) Virus in Zoos, India
abstract: In October 2016, highly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N8) viruses were detected in waterfowl in 2 zoos in India. Both viruses were 7:1 differential reassortants of H5N8 viruses isolated from wild birds in the Russian Federation and China in May 2016, indicating that the virus is currently spreading. winter migration of birds to the south.
authors: Nagarajan, S.;Kumar, M.;Murugkar, H. V.;Tripathi, S.;Shukla, S.;Agarwal, S.;Dubey, G.;Nagi, R. S.;Singh, V. P.;Tosh, C.

title: Genetic analysis of Indian foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype A and detection of positive selection and recombination in leader protease and capsid-encoding regions.
abstract: Leader protease (Lpro) and capsid encoding sequences (P1) make up approximately 3 kb of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV). We examined the phylogenetic relationship of 46 FMDV serotype A isolates of Indian origin collected during 1968-2005, as well as eight vaccine strains using the neighboring tree and Bayesian tree methods. Viruses were categorized under three main groups: Asia, Europe-South America and Europe. The Indian isolates formed a separate genetic group among the Asian isolates. Indian isolates were further divided into different genetic subgroups (<5% divergence). Post-1995 isolates were divided into two subgroups, while in 2005 several isolates originating from Andhra Pradesh formed a separate group. These isolates were closely related to the isolates of the 1970s. FMDV isolates appear to undergo reverse mutation or convergent evolution, with ancestral identical sequences found in circulating isolates. The eight vaccine strains included in the study were unrelated and belonged to different genetic groups. Recombination was detected in the Lpro region in one isolate (A IND 20/82) and in the 1D region encoding VP1 in another isolate (A RAJ 21/96). Positive selection was identified at positions 23 of aa in Lpro (P<0.05; 0.046*) and aa at 171 in capsid protein VP1 (P<0.01; 0.003**). Â© 2009 Indian Academy of Sciences.
authors: Nagendrakumar, S. B.;Madhanmohan, M.;Rangarajan, P. N.;Srinivasan, V. A.

title: Novel real-time PCR-based patho- and phylotyping of potentially zoonotic avian influenza a subtype H5 viruses at risk of spreading to Europe in 2017.
abstract: Since November 2016, Europe has been witnessing another wave of invasion of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) A(H5) viruses from the Asian goose/Guangdong (gs/GD) lineage. Infections with the H5 viruses of section 2.3.4.4b affect wild bird and poultry populations. H5 viruses belonging to groups 2.2, 2.3.1.2c and 2.3.4.4a were previously detected in Europe in 2006, 2010 and 2014. deaths. There is evidence of their joint circulation in the Middle East. Low pathogenicity (LPAI) subtype H5 viruses are endemic in migratory wild bird populations. They develop into potentially highly pathogenic phenotypes following infestation in poultry holdings. However, to date, only the gs/GD H5 strain has had an impact on human health. Rapid and specific diagnosis is the cornerstone for the control and elimination of HPAI virus attacks. We present the development and validation of five real-time RT-PCR assays (RT-qPCR) that allow sequencing-independent pathotype and sequence-specific discrimination of major gs/GD HPAI H5 virus sequences and currently circulating Eurasian LPAI viruses. Combined testing with an influenza A virus generic RT-qPCR significantly speeds up diagnostic time and reduces reaction times in the OneHealth approach to inhibiting the spread of gs/GD HPAI viruses.
authors: Naguib, M. M.;Graaf, A.;Fortin, A.;Luttermann, C.;Wernery, U.;Amarin, N.;Hussein, H. A.;Sultan, H.;Al Adhadh, B.;Hassan, M. K.;Beer, M.;Monne, I.;Harder, T. C.

title: Whole genome sequence analysis of newly emerged QX-like infectious bronchitis virus from Sudan reveals distinct recombination points
abstract: Different geno- and serotypes continue to circulate worldwide, while infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) infection continues to cause economically significant disease in poultry. Two infectious bronchitis viruses (IBV) were isolated from chickens with respiratory disease in Sudan. Sequence analysis of the hypervariable regions of the S1 gene revealed a close association with the QX-like genotype, which had not been previously detected in Sudan. Whole genome analysis of the IBV/Ck/Sudan/AR251-15/2014 isolate by next-generation sequencing revealed a genome size of 27,646 nucleotides containing 13 open reading frames: 5'-1a-1b-S-3a-3b-EM-4b- 4c-5a-5b-N-6b-3'. The highest nucleotide sequence identity of 93% for the whole genome was found with the Chinese IBV strain Ck/CH/LHLJ/140906, the Italian IBV isolate ITA/90254/2005 and the 4/91 vaccine strain. Phylogenetic analysis of the S1 gene revealed that the IBV/Ck/Sudan/AR251-15/2014 isolate clustered together with viruses belonging to the GI-19 lineage. Recombination analysis provided evidence for different origin patterns of RNA in the Sudan isolate in multiple genes. The dispersion of various recombination sites throughout the genome suggests that the Sudan-QX-like strain emerged as a uniquely recombinant from multiple recombination events of parent viruses from genotypes 4/91, H120 and ITA/90254/2005. The Sudanese QX-like isolate is reasonably genetically distinct from previously reported IBV strains in Africa and elsewhere.
authors: Naguib, M. M.;Hoper, D.;Arafa, A. S.;Setta, A. M.;Abed, M.;Monne, I.;Beer, M.;Harder, T. C.

title: Sequence analysis of the porcine adenovirus serotype 5 fiber gene: Evidence for recombination.
abstract: The nucleic acid and the deduced amino acid sequence of the fiber gene of the HNF-61 strain of porcine adenovirus serotype 5 (PAdV-5) were determined and compared with that of the HNF-70 strain of the same serotype (Nagy et al., J Gene Virol 82, 525-529, 2001) and also to adenovirus fiber genes from the genus Mastadenovirus and Atadenovirus. The putative HNF-61 and HNF-70 proteins were similar with 90% amino acid identity. Conserved amino acid sequences described for mastadenovirus fiber shafts were identified in the shaft regions of both PAdV-5 fibers, except for the TLWT motif. The head regions of the PAdV-5 fiber did not resemble any of the known mastadenovirus fiber heads, but showed features of the fiber head protein sequences of viruses grouped in the proposed Atadenovirus genus (BenkÃ¶ et al., Virus Taxonomy, Seventh Report) International Committee on Virus Taxonomy, Academic Press, New York, San. Diego, 2000, p. 227-238). The findings suggested recombination between viruses belonging to different adenovirus genera.
authors: Nagy, M.;Nagy;Tuboly, T.

title: Dynamic evolution of endogenous retrovirus-derived genes expressed in bovine concepts during the insertion period.
abstract: In mammalian evolution, syncytin-1, which is derived from the envelope (env) gene of an endogenous retrovirus (ERV), helps placenta cell fusion in humans, so some genes required for placental development are known to be retroviralorigin. Although the placenta functions the same in all placental mammals, the env-derived genes responsible for trophoblast cell fusion and maternal immune tolerance differ between species and remain largely unidentified in bovine species. To comprehensively examine env-derived genes involved in bovine placental development, we determined the transcriptomic profiles of bovine concepts during three key implantation periods using a high-throughput sequencer. Sequence reads were mapped into the bovine genome where ERV candidates were annotated using RetroTector® (7,624 and 1,542 for ERV-derived and env-derived genes, respectively). Matched reads showed that approximately 18% (284 genes) of env-derived genes in the genome were expressed during placental formation, and approximately 4% (63 genes) were detected for all days studied. We confirmed three env-derived genes expressed in trophoblast cells by polymerase chain reaction. Of these three, the env-derived gene sequence with the longest open reading frame (termed BERV-P env) was found to show high expression levels in trophoblast cell lines and was similar to that of the syncytin-Car1 genes found in dogs. and cats, despite their different origins. These results suggest that placentation is dependent on several retrovirus-derived genes that may replace endogenous precursors during evolution. Â© 2013 Author(s).
authors: Nakagawa, S.;Bai, H.;Sakurai, T.;Nakaya, Y.;Konno, T.;Miyazawa, T.;Gojobori, T.;Imakawa, K.

title: Identification of European-type hepatitis E virus subtype 3e isolates in Japanese wild boars: Molecular follow-up of HEV from pigs to wild boars.
abstract: The nucleotide sequences of hepatitis E virus (HEV) isolates infecting wild boars in Mie prefecture, located in central Japan and far from the areas where HEV infection is most common in Japan, were determined and characterized. Of the 144 wild boar serum samples captured in Mie prefecture, 7 were positive for HEV-RNA. The nucleotide sequence of nearly the entire genome was determined for 4 out of 7 positive samples. Phylogenetic tree analyzes showed that of the 7 isolates, 6 samples were subtype 3e and 1 sample was subtype 3a. We identified localization of subtype 3e isolates in Japanese wild boars. Moreover, 5 subtype 3e isolates were closely related and included in the peripheral branch of subtype 3e isolates from European countries in the phylogenetic tree. The construct indicated that the ancestor of the 5 subtype 3e isolates was of European origin. Phylogenetic structure and association analyzes suggested that subtype 3e isolates entered Japan from Europe around 1966 with the importation of large breed pigs. The results also showed that several lineages of subtype 3e spread over a wide area of Japan and 1 of the lineages around 1992. It was domesticated in wild boars in Mie County between 1992 and 2009. The appearance of a boar cluster on the peripheral branch in the phylogenetic lineage may indicate the direction of gene flow of HEV subtype 3e from pigs to wild boars. Clarifying the route or route of transmission should help prevent a future outbreak of endemic or HEV infection. © 2013 Elsevier BV.
authors: Nakano, T.;Takahashi, K.;Arai, M.;Okano, H.;Kato, H.;Ayada, M.;Okamoto, H.;Mishiro, S.
