title: Dysfunction of bovine endogenous retrovirus K2 envelope glycoprotein is related to its failed intracellular trafficking.
abstract: Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) are remnants of retroviral infection of ancestral germ cells. Mutations introduced into ERVs stop the production of infectious agents, but their effect on the function of retroviral proteins is not fully understood. Retroviral envelope glycoproteins (Envs) are used in membrane fusion during viral entry, and we recently identified intact coding sequences for bovine endogenous retrovirus K1 (BERV-K1) and BERV-K2 Envs. The amino acid sequences of BERV-K1 Env (also called Fematrin-1) and BERV-K2 Env are similar, and both viruses are classified in the Betaretrovirus genus. Fematrin-1 plays an important role in cell-to-cell fusion in the bovine placenta, while the BERV-K2 envelope gene is marginally expressed in vivo and the recombinant Env protein is defective in membrane fusion due to insufficient surface division (SU). and transmembrane subunits. Here, we performed chimeric analyzes of Fematrin-1 and BERV-K2 Envs and revealed that defective maturation of BERV-K2 Env contributes to failed intracellular trafficking. Fluorescence microscopy and flow cytometric analysis suggested that, unlike Fematrin-1 Env, BERV-K2 Env could not be transported from the endoplasmic reticulum to the trans-Golgi network where cellular proteases required for processing retroviral Envs are localized. We also determined that one of the regions responsive to this phenomenon is located in a 65 amino acid region of BERV-K2 SU. This is the first report to identify a role for retroviral Env SU in the regulation of intracellular trafficking and may help illuminate the maturation process of Fematrin-1 and other related Envs. Â© 2014, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Nakaya, Y.;Miyazawa, T.

title: A metagenomic study of rumen virus in native caprids.
abstract: This project aimed to investigate the native caprid rumen virus by developing a robust viral DNA isolation and enrichment protocol (using membrane filtration, ultracentrifugation, overnight PEG treatment and nuclease treatment) and using RSD-PCR and high-throughput sequencing (HTS) techniques. 3.53% of the reads obtained were similar to those of viruses indicating Siphoviridae, Myoviridae, Podoviridae, Mimiviridae, Microviridae, Poxviridae, Tectiviridae, and Marseillevirus. Most sequential reads from rumen were similar to those of phages, which are critical in keeping rumen microbial populations below carrying capacity. Although described in the rumen, many of these viruses have also been reported in other settings. Improvements to the viral DNA enrichment and isolation protocol are needed to obtain data that is more representative of the rumen virus. The 102,130 unknown reads (92.31%) for goat and 36,241 unknown reads for sheep (93.86%) could represent novel genomes that require further study.
authors: Namonyo, S.;Wagacha, M.;Maina, S.;Wambua, L.;Agaba, M.

title: Detection and Phylogenetic Analysis of Hepatitis E Virus in the Canadian Pig Production Network
abstract: Viral contamination along the production chain is a major concern for both food safety and animal health. Pigs have been reported to act as a reservoir for occasionally emerging zoonotic viruses, and epidemiological studies have shown direct links between consumption of uncooked pork offal and cases of hepatitis in humans caused by genotype 3 of the hepatitis E virus (HEV). The presence of HEV in swine herds has been reported, but its spread in swine production environments is still unknown. To investigate sources of viral contamination in the swine industry, 452 environmental and faecal samples, including samples from livestock transport vehicles, were collected over an 11Â month period from ten farms and an abattoir, which together represent a single production network. Hepatitis E virus RNA was detected by nested RT-PCR in 32 samples from both inside and outside farm buildings, from trucks, and mostly from fomites collected in a slaughterhouse, such as a commercial vehicle. Phylogenetic analysis showed a wide variety of HEV genotype 3 strains similar to previously found human and porcine strains. According to the results of this study, the movements of trucks and commercial vehicles can play an important role in the spread of HEV in a slaughterhouse and throughout the network.
authors: Nantel-Fortier, N.;Letellier, A.;Lachapelle, V.;Fravalo, P.;Lâ€™Homme, Y.;Brassard, J.

title: Genetic Predisposition to Acquire a Polybasic Cleavage Site for the Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza Virus Hemagglutinin
abstract: Highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses with H5 and H7 hemagglutinin (HA) subtypes evolve from low pathogenic precursors through the acquisition of multiple basic amino acid residues at the HA cleavage site. Although this mechanism has only been observed to occur naturally in these HA subtypes, little is known about the genetic basis for the acquisition of the polybasic HA cleavage site. Here we show that sequential adenine residues and a stem loop structure, which are frequently found in the viral RNA region encoding amino acids around the cleavage site of low pathogenic H5 and H7 viruses isolated from waterfowl reservoirs, are important for nucleotide additions to it. RNA region. A reporter assay to detect template-free nucleotide insertions and deep sequencing analysis of viral RNAs revealed that the increased number of adenine residues and the expanded stem-loop structure in the RNA region accelerate the multiple adenine and/or guanine insertions required to form codons for the essential amino. acids. Interestingly, nucleotide insertions associated with the HA cleavage site motif were not mainly observed in viral RNA of the other subtypes tested (H1, H2, H3, and H4). Our findings suggest that RNA editing-like activity is the key mechanism for nucleotide additions and provides a clue as to why the acquisition of the polybasic HA cleavage site is limited to certain HA subtypes.IMPORTANCE Influenza A viruses contain the viral surface glycoproteins hemagglutinin (HA). ) and subtypes according to the antigenicity of neuraminidase. Of the 16 HA subtypes (H1 to -16) of influenza A viruses conserved in waterfowl reservoirs, H5 and H7 viruses frequently become highly pathogenic via uptake of multiple basic amino acid residues at the HA cleavage site. Although this mechanism has been known since the 1980s, the genetic basis of nucleotide additions remains unclear. This study demonstrates the potential role of viral RNA secondary structure for nucleotide insertions and illustrates a key mechanism explaining why acquisition of the polybasic HA cleavage site is limited to certain HA subtypes in nature. Our findings will contribute to a better understanding of the ecology of influenza A viruses and will also be useful for the development of genetically modified vaccines with increased stability against H5 and H7 influenza A viruses.
authors: Nao, N.;Yamagishi, J.;Miyamoto, H.;Igarashi, M.;Manzoor, R.;Ohnuma, A.;Tsuda, Y.;Furuyama, W.;Shigeno, A.;Kajihara, M.;Kishida, N.;Yoshida, R.;Takada, A.

title: Characterization and phylogenetic analysis of a novel picornavirus from pig feces in Japan.
abstract: During the investigation of porcine fecal viruses using a metagenomic approach, a novel picornavirus was identified in the feces of a healthy two-month-old pig. Named Porcine picornavirus Japan (PPVJ), this virus had a standardized picornavirus genome organization, including the L protein region. The 5' untranslated region harbored a type II internal ribosomal entry site. This virus was most closely related to lesavirus 1 (amino acid sequence identity: 38.2%Â) at P1, equine rhinitis A virus (25.8%) to P2, and lesavirus 2 (40.9%) to P3. According to the genus boundaries for the Picornaviridae family (40%, 40%, and less than 50% amino acid sequence identity in P1, P2 and P3, respectively), PPVJ represents a new genus in the Picornaviridae family. In 23.3% of fecal samples (from 58.3% of farms in a large area) from pigs less than four months old, PPVJ was detected by reverse transcription PCR followed by sequencing using specific primers designed from the 3D array. The host range and pathogenic potential of this virus in animals have not yet been determined.
authors: Naoi, Y.;Kishimoto, M.;Masuda, T.;Ito, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Sano, K.;Yamasato, H.;Omatsu, T.;Aoki, H.;Furuya, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Okada, T.;Shirai, J.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Six-year surveillance of Newcastle disease virus in wild birds in northeastern Spain (Catalonia).
abstract: Given that Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the biggest threats to the poultry industry, testing for Newcastle disease virus (NDV) has been carried out since 2010 in cases of wild bird death (passive surveillance) in Catalonia. The aim is to provide an early warning system to prevent infection of poultry. Since 2010, 35 deaths in wild birds have been attributed to NDV infection. During this period, the gradual expansion of NDV to new areas has seen an increase in deaths, although it is unclear whether these were the result of the spread of the virus or improved surveillance. Phylogenetic analyzes show that two distinct sublineages of NDV, 4a and 4b, are circulating in Catalonia. Both sublineages appear to be endemic to the wild bird population and mainly affect Eurasian collared pigeons and their spatial distribution (overlaps with that of this species) and temporal distribution (mostly between September and February). So far, endemicity in wild birds has not led to ND outbreaks in poultry. However, there are still many uncertainties about, for example, whether NDV could expand into new regions of Catalonia (where the poultry density is higher) or the threat that the apparently newer subclade 4a could represent. Therefore, efforts should be made to promote measures to prevent infection of poultry farms (especially in high-risk areas and periods) and to maintain surveillance.
authors: Napp, S.;Alba, A.;Rocha, A. I.;SÃ¡nchez, A.;Rivas, R.;MajÃ³, N.;Perarnau, M.;Massot, C.;Miguel, E. S.;Soler, M.;Busquets, N.

title: Genotypic and epitope characteristics of group A swine rotavirus strains circulating in Canada
abstract: Surveillance of Rotavirus A (RVA) infections in North American swine populations is limited and has not been performed over a significant time period to appropriately assess the diversity of RVA strains in pigs. The VP7 (G) and VP4 (P) genes of 32 Canadian RVA strains circulating between 2009 and 2015 were sequenced, identifying G3P[13], G5P[7], G9P[7], G9[13] and G9[. 19] genotype combinations. Canadian RVA strains were compared with RVA strains contained in the porcine ProSystems RCE rotavirus vaccine. The comparison revealed multiple amino acid differences in the G and P antigenic epitopes, independent of the G and P genotypes, but particularly in the Canadian G3, P[13] and P[19] genotypes. Our study also contributes to the characterization of the evolution of RVA and disease mitigation among pigs, which can optimize target vaccine design and thereby minimize RVA disease in this economically important animal population.
authors: Naseer, O.;Jarvis, M. C.;Ciarlet, M.;Marthaler, D. G.

title: Long-term evolution of viruses: A Janus-faced balance
abstract: The popular textbook image of viruses as harmful and selfish genetic parasites vastly underestimates their beneficial contribution to the biosphere. Given the significant dependence of viruses for replication in an intracellular environment, viruses that engage in excessive killing (lysis) can cause extinction of their cellular hosts and are unable to survive. Therefore, the lytic mode of virus propagation must be tempered and balanced by the non-lytic modes of virus delay and symbiosis. Here, we review recent bioinformatics and metagenomic studies to discuss how viral endogenization and domestication may be more common mechanisms of virus persistence than lysis. We use a triangular diagram to explain the three main virus persistence strategies that explain the global extent of virus-cell interactions, including fragmentation, latency, and virus-cell symbiont. This paradigm could help identify new directions in virology research where scientists can artificially gain control over altering lytic and beneficial viral lifestyles.
authors: Nasir, A.;Kim, K. M.;Caetano-Anolles, G.

title: Biological and molecular characterization of Indian chicken anemia virus isolates
abstract: In this study, four chicken anemia virus (CAV) isolates (CAV-A, -B, -E and -P) obtained from different geographical regions of India were characterized. The CAV genome of the 1766 bp nucleotide region containing the complete coding region of the VP2 and VP3 proteins and the partial coding region of the VP1 protein was sequenced. The nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequence of Indian CAV isolates were aligned and compared with CAV isolates from Europe, Asia, America and Australia. Phylogenetic analysis of Indian CAV isolates was also performed based on nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences. The results showed that the Indian isolates evolved genetically from different parts of the world. The Indian isolate, CAV-A, was found to be closely related to the European Cux-1 strain, CAV-B and -P were found to be closely related to the Bangladesh BD-3 strain, and CAV-E was found to be closely related to the Australian 704 strain. The pathogenicity of four CAV isolates was studied in one-day-old specific pathogen-free (SPF) chicks. One-day-old SPF chicks (n = 50) were divided into five groups of 10 chicks in each group. Group 1 was kept as a control, and groups 2-5 were infected with each CAV isolate separately. Chicks were infected intramuscularly at a dose rate of 1 ml cell culture fluid (104.5 TCID50/0.1 ml) per bird. Clinical signs, mortality and packed cell volume (PCV) and body weight gain were recorded at 5, 10, and 15 days after infection. On day 15, all birds were sacrificed and various organs, namely thymus, bone marrow, spleen, liver and bursa, were examined for gross and microscopic changes. The pathogenicity study showed that all CAVs except CAV-B were able to produce clinical disease and immunosuppression in young chicks, whereas the CAV-B isolate did not produce clinical disease, but only induced immunosuppression revealed by microscopic examination of lymphoid organs. The study showed valuable information on the molecular epidemiological status of CAV isolates prevalent in India for the first time. Â© 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Natesan, S.;Kataria, J. M.;Dhama, K.;Rahul, S.;Baradhwaj, N.

title: Comparison of exosomes purified by ultracentrifugation (UC) and Total Exosome Isolation (TEI) reagent from serum of hens vaccinated with Marek's disease virus (MDV) and tumor bearing
abstract: Extracellular vesicles (EVs) is a collective term used to denote microparticles, exosomes, and apoptotic bodies produced by various cells and released into interstitial spaces and body fluids. Serum exosomes can serve as invaluable biomarkers containing m/miRNAs, lipids and proteins that are indicative of various conditions. There are currently limited studies on the characterization and mutual consensus of biomarker profiles of serum exosomes purified by different methods. Here, we compared the advantages and disadvantages of two commonly used serum exosome purification procedures, including ultracentrifugation (UC) and Total Exosome Isolation (TEI) reagent, by analyzing the exosome size distribution, concentration, morphology, and miRNA expression profiles. The serum was obtained from chickens infected with Marek's disease virus (MDV) vaccinated against Marek's disease (MD) and thus protected or unvaccinated and carrying tumors caused by MDV. Nanoparticle tracking analysis (NTA) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) were performed to evaluate particle size, concentration and morphological integrity, respectively. Our results show that the size distribution of particles purified by both procedures is consistent with that of exosomes (30–150 nm). The TEI reagent produced slightly larger (âˆ¼180 nm) higher yields and additional populations of co-isolated EVs. Based on miRNA expression profiles from a previous high-throughput sequencing experiment of exosome small RNAs, we selected six cellular and four MDV1 miRNAs to confirm their expression in UC and TEI-purified exosomes. miRNA expression profiles exhibited relative correlation between the two procedures, but abundant marked differences were observed in TEI-purified exosomes, which showed higher miRNA expression consistent with higher yield than those purified with UC. TEI-purified exosomes from vaccinated chickens showed greater expression of tumor suppressor miRNA, gga-mir-146b and at least oncomiR, gga-mir-21, compared to those from tumor-bearing chickens. We propose that gga-mir-146 and -21 may serve as serum exosome biomarkers for vaccine-induced protection and MD tumors, respectively.
authors: Nath Neerukonda, S.;Egan, N. A.;Patria, J.;Assakhi, I.;Tavlarides-Hontz, P.;Modla, S.;MuÃ±oz, E. R.;Hudson, M. B.;Parcells, M. S.

title: Origins of the new influenza A(H1N1) virus: time to act
abstract: To gain insight into the possible origins of the 2009 novel influenza A(H1N1) epidemic, we performed two independent analyzes of the genetic evolution of the novel influenza A(H1N1) virus. First, protein homology analyzes of more than 400 sequences revealed that this virus most likely evolved from recent porcine viruses. Second, phylogenetic analyzes of the 5,214 protein sequences of influenza A(H1N1) viruses (avian, pig, and human) circulating in North America over the past two decades (from 1989 to 2009) show that the novel influenza A(H1N1) virus has a unique evolutionary history. trait (genetic difference). This appears to be a special feature in the swine-human interspecies transmission of influenza A. Therefore, these analyzes add to the evidence for the role of swine populations as "scramblers" for influenza A(H1N1) viruses.
authors: Nava, G. M.;Attene-Ramos, M. S.;Ang, J. K.;Escorcia, M.

title: Genetic and antigenic analysis of type A foot and mouth disease viruses isolated in India in 1987-1996.
abstract: Twenty-three foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) type A field isolates recovered from different outbreaks in India between 1987-1996 were subjected to antigenic and genetic analysis. Isolates, a vaccine strain (IND 17/77) antiserum and a peptide (A22/ Azerbaijan/65 strain) antiserum. However, the isolates revealed minor antigenic differences in their reactivity with the three neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (MAb) that recognize trypsin-sensitive conformation-independent epitopes of the vaccinia virus strains. Phylogenetic association between isolates was established using a portion of the ID gene (168 nucleotides at the 3-â€²-terminus). An additional seven previously reported Indian field isolates of type A were included in the analysis. The percent similarity between Indian isolates ranged from 82.7% to 99.4% at the nucleotide level and between 83.9% and 100% at the amino acid level. These observations clearly demonstrate the genetic heterogeneity of field isolates. The current vaccine strain IND 17/77 deviated 9.7% at the nucleotide level and 5.6% at the amino acid level from the A22 Iraq 24/64 isolate. The field strains differed from the IND 17/77 vaccine strain by 5.6%-14.6% and 3.7-13.7% in nucleotide and amino acid level, respectively. In the phylogenetic tree, the isolates were distributed into 21 genetic groups. The clustering pattern of isolates in the phylogenetic tree did not reveal a specific distribution pattern of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) outbreaks by geographic location, resulting from unrestricted animal movement and the endemic nature of the disease.
authors: Nayak, B.;Pattnaik, B.;Tosh, C.;Sanyal, A.;Hemadri, D.;Patil, S. S.;Venkataramanan, R.

title: Detection of novel porcine bocaviruses in stool samples of asymptomatic pigs in Cameroon
abstract: The development and widespread use of nucleic acid amplification and sequencing methods has led to the recognition of novel virus diversity in various domestic animals, including pigs. In this study, we used strain-specific or broadly reactive PCR assays to describe the occurrence and genetic diversity of selected DNA viruses belonging to the families Adenoviridae, Circoviridae, Anelloviridae, and Parvoviridae in Cameroonian pigs. Fecal samples were collected in the spring of 2011. No adenoviruses, circoviruses, and anelloviruses were detected, but high prevalence and remarkable genetic diversity were observed in the identified parvoviruses, and particularly bocaviruses. PPV4 was the most common (20%), followed by PBoV3 (18%), PBoV4 (18%), PBoV5 plus 6V/7V (16%), and PBoV1 plus PBoV2 (6%). The frequency of mixed infections with various combinations of these virus strains reached 20%. Genetic analysis of the identified viruses showed that the PBoV1 and PBoV2 strains shared up to 91% and 94% of the capsid gene. nt sequence similarities with reference strains PBoV1 and PBoV2, respectively. Identified PBoV3 and PBoV4 strains shared -95% and -98%. Along the NS gene, reference PBoV3 and PBoV4 strains shared nt identities, while PBoV5 strains shared 86%. Hungarian and nt ids with 87%. nt identities with Chinese PBoV5 strains along the capsid gene. Additionally, a single PBoV5-like strain shared 71%. nt sequence identity with other PBoV5 strains. This is the first study to report evidence of the circulation of bocaviruses in Africa and adds to our understanding of the impact of globalization on the spread of new and emerging viruses. © 2013.
authors: Ndze, V. N.;Cadar, D.;CsÃ¡gola, A.;Kisfali, P.;KovÃ¡cs, E.;Farkas, S.;Ngu, A. F.;Esona, M. D.;DÃ¡n, T.;Tuboly, T.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Avian Leukosis Virus Activation of an Antisense RNA Upstream of TERT in B-Cell Lymphomas
abstract: UNLABELED: Avian leukosis virus (ALV) induces tumors by integrating its proviral DNA into the chicken genome and altering the expression of nearby genes through strong promoter and enhancer elements. Sites of viral integration that contribute to oncogenesis are selected in tumor cells. Deep sequencing analysis of B-cell lymphoma DNA confirmed that the telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) gene promoter is a common ALV integration target. Twenty-six unique proviral integration sites were mapped from 46 to 3,552 nucleotides (nt) upstream of the TERT transcription start site, predominantly in the opposite transcriptional orientation to TERT Transcripto-sequencing (RNA-seq) analysis of normal bursa, revealing a transcribed region upstream. TERT is upside down, suggesting that the TERT promoter is bidirectional. This transcript appears to be an uncharacterized antisense RNA. We have previously shown that TERT expression is upregulated in tumors by integrations in the TERT promoter region. We now report that the viral promoter drives the expression of a chimeric transcript containing viral sequences spliced in exons 4 to 7 of this antisense RNA. Clonal expansion of cells by ALV integrations that overexpress TERT antisense RNA suggests that it may have a role in tumorigenesis. IMPORTANCE: The data show that ALV integrations in the TERT promoter region trigger overexpression of a novel antisense RNA and contribute to the development of lymphomas.
authors: Nehyba, J.;Malhotra, S.;Winans, S.;O'Hare, T. H.;Justice, J. t;Beemon, K.

title: Molecular biology of bovine viral diarrhea virus
abstract: Bovine viral diarrheal viruses (BVDV) are arguably the most important viral pathogen of ruminants worldwide and can cause serious economic losses. The clinical symptoms of the disease caused by BVDV range from subclinical to severe acute hemorrhagic syndrome, and the severity of the disease depends on the strain. These viruses are classified as members of the Pestivirus genus of Flaviviridae. BVDV is considered primarily a cattle pathogen, but can infect most ruminant species. The virus particle consists of a lipid bilayer membrane surrounding the encapsulated genomic RNA. Included in the outer membrane are two virus-encoded glycoproteins containing major antigenic determinants of the virus as well as receptor binding and cell fusion functions. A third glycoprotein is weakly associated with the virion, but also has unique properties that play important roles in suppressing innate immunity. Viral proteins are encoded in a single, large open reading frame. Viral proteins are proteolytically separated from polyprotein by different proteases. Structural proteins are processed by cellular signal peptidases while non-structural proteins are processed by viral serine protease. The virus collects and matures in the endoplasmic reticulum and golgi bodies of the cell. The virus is released via exocytosis, where the viral proteins are not exposed on the cell surface. © 2012.
authors: Neill, J. D.

title: Simultaneous rapid sequencing of multiple RNA virus genomes
abstract: Comparison of archived virus sequences collected over many years to date allows the study of viral evolution and contributes to the design of new vaccines. However, the difficulty, time, and cost of producing full-length sequences from each archived sample separately hindered these studies. Next-generation sequencing technologies have been used for analysis of clinical and environmental samples to identify viral pathogens that may be present. This has led to the discovery of many new, uncharacterized viruses from a number of viral families. The use of these sequencing technologies would be advantageous in studying viral evolution. In this study, a sequencing procedure was used to simultaneously and rapidly sequence multiple archived samples using a single standard protocol. This procedure used primers consisting of 20 bases of known sequence with 8 random bases at the 3'-end, which also serve as an identifying barcode allowing differentiation of each viral library after pooling and sequencing. This provided sequence independence by randomly priming both first and second strand cDNA synthesis. Viral stocks were treated with a nuclease cocktail to reduce the presence of host nucleic acids. Viral RNA was extracted, followed by synthesis of single-tube randomized double-stranded cDNA. The resulting cDNAs were amplified by primer-specific PCR, pooled, size fractionated and sequenced on the Ion Torrent PGM platform. Individual virus genomes were easily assembled with both de novo and template-assisted assembly methods. This procedure consistently resulted in full-length, if not full-length, genomic sequences and was used to sequence multiple isolates of bovine pestivirus and coronavirus simultaneously.
authors: Neill, J. D.;Bayles, D. O.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: Genetic kinship of caliciviruses: vesicular exanthemas of San Miguel sea lion and pig viruses form a single genotype within the Caliciviridae
abstract: Vesicular exanthema (VESV) of San Miguel sea lion viruses (SMSV) and swine viruses are morphologically and antigenically related, but little has been done to determine their genotypic relationship to each other and to other caliciviruses. To examine this relationship, reverse transcriptase PCRs were performed using oligonucleotide primer sets designed to amplify portions of the 2C RNA helix-like and RNA-dependent RNA polymerase regions with total cellular RNA purified from virus-infected cell cultures as a template. 2C RNA helicase primers directed the amplification of this region from eight SMSV serotypes, five VESV serotypes and four related viruses. The RNA polymerase primer sets amplified products from all but one of these viruses. Phylogenetic comparison of caliciviruses showed that SMSV, VESV and four related viruses are different from feline calicivirus, human calicivirus (small, round-shaped viruses) and rabbit hemorrhagic disease virus, but closely related and should be classified as hemorrhagic disease viruses. Single genotype in Caliciviridae.
authors: Neill, J. D.;Meyer, R. F.;Seal, B. S.

title: Donor-derived infections and infection risk in xenotransplantation and allotransplantation
abstract: Post-transplantation infections are common in allograft recipients and should be expected in all immunocompromised hosts. Based on the need for immunosuppression in xenotransplantation, procedures developed to improve safety in allotransplantation could be applied in future xenotransplantation clinical trials. Standardized approaches can be developed to guide the assessment of common infectious syndromes in xenograft recipients. The opportunity created by screening pigs intended as xenograft donors has equal applicability to allotransplantation – particularly broader screening strategies for allograft donors such as the use of advanced sequencing modalities including wide-range molecular probes, microarrays and high-throughput pyrosequencing. Considerations in the management of allotransplant and xenotransplant-associated infections are largely the same. Experience in xenotransplantation will continue to inform thinking about donor-derived infections in allotransplantation. We hope that experience in the management of complex allotransplant recipients will similarly inform clinical trials in xenotransplantation.
authors: Nellore, A.;Fishman, J. A.

title: Swine, Human Influenza A(H3N2) Reassortant Viruses in Southeast Mexico
abstract: The genetic diversity of influenza A viruses circulating in pigs in Mexico complicates animal control efforts and poses a threat to humans, as demonstrated by the influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. To describe the evolution of swine flu A viruses in Mexico and evaluate strains for vaccine development, we sequenced the genomes of 59 viruses and performed antigenic cartography on strains from 5 regions. We found that genetic and antigenic diversity was particularly high in southeastern Mexico due to repeated virus transmission from humans and pigs in other parts of Mexico. We identified novel reassortant H3N2 viruses with genome segments derived from 2 different viruses that were administered to pigs independently of humans: pandemic H1N1 viruses and seasonal H3N2 viruses. Mexican swine viruses are antigenically different from US swine strains. Protection against these viruses is unlikely to be provided by US virus vaccines and will require the development of new vaccines specifically targeting these various strains.
authors: Nelson, M. I.;Souza, C.;Trovao, N. S.;Diaz, A.;Mena, I.;Rovira, A.;Vincent, A. L.;Torremorell, M.;Marthaler, D.;Culhane, M. R.

title: Evolutionary pathways of N2 neuraminidases of swine and human influenza A viruses: origin of the neuraminidase genes of two reasortants (H1N2) isolated from pigs.
abstract: The complete nucleotide sequences of the neuraminidase (NA) genes of two reassortant (H1N2) and two H3N2 influenza A viruses isolated from pigs were determined and phylogenetic relationships between these and previously reported N2 NA genes were investigated. On the basis of dual nucleotide sequence identity, the NA genes of the two reassortants, A/sw/Kanagawa/2/78 and A/sw/Ehime/1/80, were most closely related to the genes of the isolated human influenza A virus strains. 1972 and the oldest existing porcine H3N2 influenza A viruses, respectively. Phylogenetic trees showed that NA genes can be divided into three groups, including (i) swine species, (ii) oldest human species, and (iii) lineages for recent human species. The evolutionary tree for 11 nucleotide and amino acid sequences suggested that the NAs of A/sw/HK/4/76 and A/sw/Kanagawa/2/78 belong to the lineage of recent human viruses. In contrast, the NA genes of the A/sw/HK/3/76 and H1N2 reassortant A/sw/Ehime/1/80 viruses were found to be from a pig lineage. The swine virus NA genes were also characterized by co-circulation of two distinct lineages. Although the rates of synonymous (silent) substitutions for porcine and human viruses were almost the same (from 0.00946 to 0.00884 per year for each region), the rate of non-synonymous (amino acid-changing) substitutions for the porcine virus NA genes was approximately 60%. for this human virus.
authors: Nerome, K.;Kanegae, Y.;Yoshioka, Y.;Itamura, S.;Ishida, M.;Gojobori, T.;Oya, A.

title: Approved and experimental measures against pestiviral diseases: Bovine viral diarrhea, classic swine fever and borderline disease
abstract: Pestiviruses, bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV), classic swine fever (CSFV) and borderline disease virus are important livestock pathogens in many countries, but current vaccines do not completely prevent the spread of infection. Control of pestiviral diseases is particularly challenging due to the constant viremia and viral shedding of persistently infected (PI) animals, which must be identified and eradicated to prevent disease transmission. Current vaccines are limited by the delay between vaccination and onset of protection, the difficulty of serologically distinguishing between vaccinated and naturally infected animals, and the need for broad vaccine cross-protection against a variety of virus strains. Antiviral therapy can potentially supplement vaccination by providing immediate protection in the event of an outbreak. Numerous compounds with in vitro antiviral activity against BVDV have been identified with a surrogate role for hepatitis C virus. Fewer drugs active against CSFV have been identified, but many compounds active against BVDV will likely inhibit CSFV given their similar genomic sequences. While in vitro research is promising, the paucity of efficacy studies in animals has hindered the commercial development of antiviral drugs effective against pestiviruses. In this article, we summarize the clinical syndromes and modes of transmission of BVD, CSF, and borderline disease, discuss currently approved vaccines, review efforts to develop antiviral therapies for use in epidemic control, and propose promising directions for future research. Â© 2013 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Newcomer, B. W.;Givens, M. D.

title: Characterization of a rotavirus
abstract: Acute gastroenteritis is one of the most common causes of illness in children, calves and piglets and causes serious economic losses in domestic animals. Although some outbreaks of gastroenteritis have been associated with bacterial pathogens, particularly Escherichia coli, no known pathogens have been isolated from a significant proportion of the outbreaks until recently, when viruses with a distinct morphology and antigenic similarity were associated with diarrhea in piglets, calves, and children. . These viruses are the main pathogens, and viruses isolated from humans have also been shown to be infectious to pigs. Initially, these viruses were described as reovirus-like, but later the names rotavirus and duovirus were proposed. They differ morphologically and antigenically from both reoviruses and orbiviruses, and also differ from them in some physicochemical properties. Studies of the structure of rotaviruses have been limited to the nucleic acid of calf virus and the related epizootic diarrhea of infants (EDIM) virus of infant mice. Both viruses have been shown to contain RNA, and it has been suggested that calf virus RNA may be double-stranded. The results of the experiments described here show that calf rotavirus has several of the characteristic features of rheo and bluetongue viruses and should be classified by these. Although calf rotavirus has a smaller sedimentation coefficient and is morphologically different from rheo and bluetongue viruses, the segmented and double-stranded nature of its RNA and the number and molecular weights of RNA and polypeptides suggest that it should be considered as a member. reo and bluetongue virus group. However, its definitive association with other members of the group will require extensive cross-hybridization studies of virus RNAs.
authors: Newman, J. F. E.;Brown, F.;Bridger, J. C.;Woode, G. N.

title: Oral papillomatosis caused by Enhydra lutris papillomavirus 1 (ElPV-1) in southern sea otters (Enhydra lutris nereis) in California, USA
abstract: The southern otter (Enhydra lutris nereis) is a threatened marine ranger. During postmortem studies of stranded sea otters in California, USA from 2004 to 2013, papillomas were identified in the oral cavity of at least seven otters through autopsy and histopathology. Next-generation sequencing of viral particles purified from a single papilloma revealed a novel papillomavirus, Enhydra lutris papillomavirus 1 (ElPV-1). The ElPV-1 genome has been obtained, representing the first fully sequenced viral genome from southern sea otters. Phylogenetic analysis of the entire L1 gene as well as a sequential plot of protein identities of all papillomaviral genes revealed that ElPV-1 is an α-papillomavirus, related to a raccoon papillomavirus (Procyon lotor papillomavirus type 1) and a canine oral papillomavirus. . Immunohistochemical staining using a cross-reactive bovine papillomavirus antibody suggested that ElPV-1 is present in intranuclear inclusions and intracytoplasmic keratin granules. Virus-infected cells are distributed throughout the stratum granulosum and stratum spinosum of the gingival and buccal papillomas. Using ElPV-1-specific PCR, we confirmed viral DNA in oral papillomas from all seven-stranded sea otters with identical L1 sequences. This virus is associated with the development of oral papillomatosis in southern sea otters.
authors: Ng, T. F.;Miller, M. A.;Kondov, N. O.;Dodd, E. M.;Batac, F.;Manzer, M.;Ives, S.;Saliki, J. T.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: Metagenomic identification of a new anellovirus in Pacific harbor seal (Phoca vitulina richardsii) lung samples and detection in samples from several years
abstract: Direct viral metagenomics was performed on lung samples from five individuals to investigate viral pathogens potentially involved in a death event of 21 Pacific harbor seals (Phoca vitulina richardsii) in California in 2000. Metagenomics has revealed a novel seal anellovirus (SealAV) that phylogenetically clusters with anelloviruses from California sea lions and domestic cats. Using specific PCR, SealAV was identified in the lung tissue of two of five animals involved in 2000 deaths, and in one of 20 harbor seal samples examined postmortem in 2008. Identification of SealAV over several years is persistent in the harbor seal population of this virus. SealAV is the second anellovirus reported in the lungs of pinnipeds, suggesting that anellovirus infections may be common among cetaceans and further research is needed to understand the roles of these viruses in cetacean health and disease.
authors: Ng, T. F.;Wheeler, E.;Greig, D.;Waltzek, T. B.;Gulland, F.;Breitbart, M.

title: A metagenomic and case-control study to identify viruses associated with bovine respiratory disease
abstract: Bovine respiratory disease (BRD) is a common health problem that causes significant economic losses for both dairy and beef cattle. To identify BRD-associated viruses, we used a metagenomic approach to enrich and sequence viral nucleic acids in nasal swabs of 50 young dairy cattle with BRD symptoms. After deep sequencing, de novo splicing and translated protein sequence similarity searches, a large number of known and previously uncharacterized viruses were identified. Multiple genotypes of bovine adenovirus 3, bovine adeno-associated virus, bovine influenza D virus, bovine parvovirus 2, bovine herpesvirus 6, bovine rhinitis A virus and bovine rhinitis B virus were identified. The genomes of a previously uncharacterized astrovirus and picobirnaviruses were also partially or fully sequenced. Using real-time PCR, detection rates of the eight most read viruses were compared for nasal secretions of 50 animals with BRD with 50 location-matched healthy control animals. Viruses were detected in 68% of BRD-affected animals versus 16% of healthy control animals. Thirty-eight percent of sick animals were infected with more than one respiratory virus versus 8% of controls. Significantly associated with BRD were bovine adenovirus 3 (P<0.0001), bovine rhinitis A virus (P = 0.005) and the recently disclosed bovine influenza D virus (P = 0.006), of which 62% either alone or detected in combination. animals with BRD. A metagenomic and real-time PCR detection approach in carefully matched cases and controls could provide a rapid tool to identify viruses associated with a complex disease, paving the way for further confirmatory testing and ultimately effective intervention strategies.
authors: Ng, T. F. F.;Kondov, N. O.;Deng, X.;Van Eenennaam, A.;Neibergs, H. L.;Delwart, E.

title: Discovery of a novel single-stranded DNA virus from a sea turtle fibropapilloma using viral metagenomics.
abstract: Viral metagenomics, consisting of viral particle purification and shotgun sequencing, is a powerful technique for discovering disease-associated viruses with no definite etiology, viruses that share limited homology with known viruses, or viruses that cannot be cultured. Here, we used viral metagenomics to study viruses associated with sea turtle fibropapillomatosis (FP), a debilitating neoplastic disease that affects sea turtles worldwide. A new single-stranded DNA virus, sea turtle tornovirus 1 (STTV1), has been discovered by directly purging the viral community from Florida green sea turtle fibropapilloma and shotgun sequencing. The single-stranded, circular genome of Sâ€²â€²â€²V1 was approximately 1,800 nucleotides long. Sâ€²â€²â€²V1 has only weak amino acid level identities (25%) against chicken anemia virus in short regions of its genome; thus STTV1 may represent the first member of a new virus family. A total of 35 healthy turtles and 27 turtles with FP were tested for STTV1 using PCR, and only 2 turtles severely affected by FP were positive. Because STTV1 is present in the blood and in all major organs, affected turtles were systemically infected with Sâ€²â€²V1. Sâ€²â€²lâ€²V1 exists as a semispecies with several genome variants identified in the fibropapilloma of each positive turtle, suggesting the rapid evolution of this virus. STTV1 variants were identical over the majority of their genomes but contained a hypervariable region with wide divergence. This work demonstrates the potential of viral metagenomics to discover new viruses directly from animal tissue, which can improve our understanding of viral evolution and diversity. Copyright © 2009, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Ng, T. F. F.;Manire, C.;Borrowman, K.;Langer, T.;Ehrhart, L.;Breitbart, M.

title: Feline fecal virome reveals new and common enteric viruses
authors: Ng, T. F. F.;Mesquita, J. R.;Nascimento, M. S. J.

title: New anellovirus discovered from death of captive California sea lions
abstract: viral metagenomic study was conducted to investigate potential viral pathogens associated with a death event of three arrested California sea lions (Zalophus californianus). This study identified a novel California sea lion anellovirus (ZcAV) with 35% amino acid identity to feline anelloviruses in the ORF1 region. The double-stranded replicative form of ZcAV was detected in lung tissue, suggesting that ZcAV replicates in sea lion lungs. Specific PCR revealed the presence of ZcAV in the lung tissue of all three sea lions involved in the demise, but not in three other sea lions from the same zoo. In addition, low frequency (11%) ZcAV was detected in the lungs of wild sea lions. The higher prevalence of ZcAV and the presence of the double-stranded replicative form in the lungs of sea lions from the death event suggest that ZcAV is associated with the death of these animals.
authors: Ng, T. F. F.;Suedmeyer, W. K.;Wheeler, E.;Gulland, F.;Breitbartt, M.

title: Development and evaluation of non-ribosomal random PCR and next-generation sequencing-based assay for detection and sequencing of hand, foot, and mouth disease pathogens.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) has become a major public health problem in the Asia-Pacific region and is commonly associated with enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) and coxsackievirus A6 (CV-A6), CV-A10 and CV-A16. Generating pathogen whole genome sequences is essential to understanding their evolutionary biology. Frequent exchanges between EV serotypes and the limited number of available whole-genome sequences hinder the development of overlapping PCRs for whole-genome sequencing. We have developed and evaluated a non-ribosomal random PCR (rPCR) and next-generation sequencing-based assay for sequence-independent whole-genome amplification and sequencing of HFMD pathogens. A total of 16 EV-A71/CV-A6/CV-A10/CV-A16 PCR positive rectal/throat swab (Cp values: 20.9-33.3) were used for test evaluation. RESULTS: Our test clearly outperformed conventional rPCR in terms of total EV-A71 reads and EV-A71 read percentage: 2.6% (1275/50,000 reads) vs. 0.1% (31/50,000) and 6% (3008/50,000 for two samples with Cp values of 30 and 26, respectively) and 0.9% (433/50,000). In addition, the assay can generate genome sequences with coverage percentages of 94-100% of the 4 different enterovirus serotypes in 73% of the tested samples, representing the first complete genome sequences of CV-A6/10/16 from Vietnam. Assign correct serotyping results in 100% of 24 samples. The consensus of two replicates of the same sample in all but three was 100% identical, indicating that our test was highly reproducible. CONCLUSIONS: In conclusion, we have successfully developed a non-ribosomal rPCR and next-generation sequencing-based assay for the sensitive detection and direct whole-genome sequencing of HFMD pathogens from clinical specimens.
authors: Nguyen, A. T.;Tran, T. T.;Hoang, V. M.;Nghiem, N. M.;Le, N. N.;Le, T. T.;Phan, Q. T.;Truong, K. H.;Le, N. N.;Ho, V. L.;Do, V. C.;Ha, T. M.;Nguyen, H. T.;Nguyen, C. V.;Thwaites, G.;van Doorn, H. R.;Le, T. V.

title: Evolution of highly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N1) virus populations in Vietnam between 2007 and 2010.
abstract: We report the genetic analysis of 213 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 viruses isolated from poultry in Vietnam between 2007 and 2010. Phylogenetic analyzes of viral genomes revealed 38 different viral genotypes, 29 novel and 9 reported in Vietnam or neighboring countries. countries in recent years. Only viruses from six genotypes persisted for a season or year. Therefore, most reasortant viruses were transient, suggesting that such genotypes lack significant fitness advantages. 2.3.2.1 Viruses with HA were reintroduced to Vietnam in 2009 and their prevalence increased rapidly towards the end of 2010. Clade 2.3.4-like viruses (genotype V) predominated in northern Vietnam and caused the majority of zoonotic infections. clade 1.1 (genotype Z) viruses were detected only in the Mekong delta region in southern Vietnam. Antigenic analysis of representative viruses from the four branches showed significant shifting. © 2012.
authors: Nguyen, T.;Rivailler, P.;Davis, C. T.;Thi Hoa, D.;Balish, A.;Hoang Dang, N.;Jones, J.;Thi Vui, D.;Simpson, N.;Thu Huong, N.;Shu, B.;Loughlin, R.;Ferdinand, K.;Lindstrom, S. E.;York, I. A.;Klimov, A.;Donis, R. O.

title: Identification and genomic characterization of a novel porcine parvovirus (PPV6) in China
abstract: Background: Parvoviruses are divided into two subfamilies based on host range: Parvovirinae, which infects vertebrates, and Densovirinae, which mainly infects insects and other arthropods. In recent years, a number of new parvoviruses belonging to the Parvovirinae subfamily have been identified from various animal species and humans, including human parvovirus 4 (PARV4), porcine hocovirus, ovine partetravirus, porcine parvovirus 4 (PPV4), and porcine parvovirus 5. PPV5). Methods: Using sequence-independent single primer amplification (SISPA), a novel parvovirus was identified within the Parvovirinae subfamily that differed from any known parvovirus, and five full-length genome sequences were identified and analyzed. Conclusions: A new porcine parvovirus, tentatively designated PPV6, was originally identified from aborted porcine fetuses in China. Retrospective studies revealed a higher prevalence of PPV6 in aborted pig fetuses and piglets (50% and 75%, respectively) than in dressage pigs and sows (15.6% and 3.8%, respectively). Also, the prevalence of PPV6 in the finishing pig was similar in affected and unaffected farms (ie 13.6% vs 21.7% versus 16.7%). This finding indicates that animal age strongly influences the level of PPV6 viremia, possibly due to increased innate immune resistance. Whole genome sequencing and multiple alignments showed that nearly full-length genome sequences were approximately 6,100 nucleotides long and shared 20.5%–42.6% DNA sequence identity with other members of the Parvovirinae subfamily. Phylogenetic analysis showed that PPV6 differed significantly from other known parvoviruses and was most closely related to PPV4. Conclusion: Our findings and review of published parvovirus sequences suggested that a novel porcine parvovirus is currently circulating in China and could be classified within the novel Copiparvovirus genus within the Parvovirinae subfamily. However, clinical manifestations of PPV6 are still unknown, as the prevalence of PPV6 was similar between healthy pigs and sick pigs in a retrospective epidemiological study. Identification of PPV6 within the Parvovirinae subfamily provides further insight into the viral and genetic diversity of parvoviruses.
authors: Ni, J.;Qiao, C.;Han, X.;Han, T.;Kang, W.;Zi, Z.;Cao, Z.;Zhai, X.;Cai, X.

title: hepatitis E virus
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a non-enveloped, positive-sense RNA virus currently classified in a new family of "Hepeviridae genus hepevirus" (single-stranded RNA viruses). The genome (7.2kb) contains three open reading frames (ORFs) encoding non-structural (ORF1) and structural proteins (ORF2 & ORF3). HEV infection has been associated with developing countries as the major cause of epidemic acute hepatitis transmitted by the fecal-oral route. However, sporadic cases of hepatitis have been reported in Western countries without a history of travel to endemic areas. Phylogenetic analysis of diverse geographic HEV identified four major genotypes: genotype I, which collected Asian (I1) and African (I2) isolates, genotype II found in Mexico and Nigeria, genotype III discovered among US humans and US pigs, and genotype IV in Taiwan. . Additional genotypes have been identified in non-HEV endemic regions (Greece, Italy, Argentina). HEV isolation in pets supports the environmental reservoir of HEV. Current diagnosis of HEV infection includes molecular tools for the detection of the virus in stool or serum samples, and serological tests for the identification of anti-HEV IgG and IgM.
authors: Nicand, E.;Grandadam, M.

title: Occurrence of Adenovirus Field Strains in Birds Infected with Marek's Disease Virus
abstract: Strains of adenoviruses were isolated from 356 birds with the clinical form of Marek's disease and coinfection with adenoviruses. A hexon gene fragment coding loop L1 of adenovirus strains was sequenced and the data obtained were compared with the nucleotide sequences of reference strains of two turkey adenoviruses of poultry adenoviruses (FAdV-1-FadV-12) and analyzed with the software BLAST, Geneious 5.3 and MEGA5. and two strains of goose adenovirus. On this basis, serotypes of adenovirus strains were determined. Sequences of all adenovirus strains isolated from birds infected with Marek's disease virus were classified into six serotypes representing four species. Mostly FAdV-7, FAdV2/11 and FAdV-8a serotypes were found.
authors: Niczyporuk, J. S.;Samorek-Salamonowicz, E.;Czekaj, H.

title: Detection and phylogenetic analysis of Hepatitis E Viruses from mongooses in Okinawa, Japan
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection has previously been reported in wild mongooses on Okinawa Island; however, to date, only one HEV RNA sequence has been identified in a mongoose. Therefore, this study was conducted to detect HEV RNA in 209 wild mongoose on Okinawa Island. Six (2.9%) samples tested positive for HEV RNA. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that 6 HEV RNAs belonged to genotype 3 and were classified as groups A and B. In group B, mongoose-derived HEV sequences were very similar to mongoose HEV and those of a pig previously detected on Okinawa Island. This research highlighted the possibility that the mongoose is a reservoir animal for HEV on Okinawa Island. Â© 2012 Japanese Veterinary Science Association.
authors: Nidaira, M.;Takahashi, K.;Ogura, G.;Taira, K.;Okano, S.;Kudaka, J.;Itokazu, K.;Mishiro, S.;Nakamura, M.

title: Genetic characterization of H5N1 influenza viruses isolated from chickens in Indonesia in 2010.
abstract: Since 2003, highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza viruses have caused outbreaks among poultry each year in Indonesia, causing the largest number of human casualties worldwide. But little is known about the H5N1 influenza viruses circulating in recent years. Therefore, we conducted surveillance studies and isolated eight H5N1 viruses from chickens. Phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes for all eight viruses 2.1.3. revealed that it belonged to the item. However, on the basis of their nucleotide differences, these viruses can be divided into two groups. Other viruses genetically closely related to these two virus groups were all Indonesian isolates, suggesting that these new isolates evolved within Indonesia. Among these viruses are two different viruses circulating in the Kalimantan islands during the same season of 2010. Our data reveal the continued evolution of H5N1 viruses in Indonesia. Â© Author(s) 2012.
authors: Nidom, C. A.;Yamada, S.;Nidom, R. V.;Rahmawati, K.;Alamudi, M. Y.;Kholik;Indrasari, S.;Hayati, R. S.;Iwatsuki Horimoto, K.;Kawaoka, Y.

title: Near-complete genome sequencing of porcine vesicular disease virus using the Roche GS FLX sequencing platform
abstract: Porcine vesicular disease virus (SVDV) is an enterovirus closely related both genetically and antigenically to human coxsackievirus B5 in the Picornaviridae family. SVDV is the causative agent of a highly contagious (though rarely fatal) vesicular disease in pigs. We report a rapid method suitable for sequencing the complete protein-coding sequences of SVDV isolates in which RNA is relatively intact. The approach combines a single PCR amplification reaction using only a single set of PCR primers to amplify the nearly complete SVDV genome with deep sequencing using a small fraction of the capacity of the Roche GS FLX sequencing platform. Sequences were initially validated via one of two criteria; either a match between a de novo assembly and a reference match, or a match between all five different reference matches against a fixed set of initial reference genomes with significant genetic distances within the same virus species. All reference mappings used an iterative method to avoid bias. Further validation was provided by phylogenetic analysis against published SVDV genomes and additional Enterovirus B sequences. This approach gives high confidence in the resulting consensus sequences, while providing sufficiently high and evenly distributed sequence coverage to allow future studies of intra-host variation. Â© 2014 Nielsen et al.
authors: Nielsen, S. C. A.;Bruhn, C. A. W.;Samaniego, J. A.;Wadsworth, J.;Knowles, N. J.;Gilbert, M. T. P.

title: Whole genome sequences of Japanese porcine type C rotaviruses reveal a high diversity of genotypes of individual genes and contribute to a comprehensive, generally accepted classification system.
abstract: Porcine rotavirus C (RVC) is distributed worldwide and is thought to be a pathogenic agent of diarrhea in piglets. Although the VP7, VP4 and VP6 gene sequences of Japanese porcine RVCs are currently available, complete genome sequence data of Japanese RVC are not available. Moreover, only one to three sequences are available for the porcine RVC VP1-VP3 and NSP1-NSP3 genes. Therefore, we identified nearly full-length full-genome sequences of nine Japanese pig RVCs from seven piglets with diarrhea and two healthy pigs and compared them with published RVC sequences from a database. The VP7 genes of two Japanese RVCs from healthy pigs were quite different from other known RVC strains and were tentatively classified as G12 and G13 based on the 86% nucleotide identity cut-off value. Binary sequence identity calculations and phylogenetic analyzes revealed that candidate novel genotypes of porcine Japanese RVC were identified in genes encoding NSP1, NSP2 and NSP3, respectively. Furthermore, VP3 of Japanese porcine RVCs was shown to be closely related to human RVCs, suggesting a gene reclassification event and past interspecies transmission between porcine and human RVCs. This study showed that porcine RVCs showed greater genetic diversity among strains than human and bovine RVCs.
authors: Niira, K.;Ito, M.;Masuda, T.;Saitou, T.;Abe, T.;Komoto, S.;Sato, M.;Yamasato, H.;Kishimoto, M.;Naoi, Y.;Sano, K.;Tuchiaka, S.;Okada, T.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Aoki, H.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Shirai, J.;Taniguchi, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Different RNA splicing mechanisms contribute to various infective outcomes of classical swine fever viruses of different virulence: Information from deep sequencing data in porcine umbilical vein endothelial cells.
abstract: The molecular mechanisms underlying RNA splicing regulation in response to viral infection are poorly understood. Classic swine fever (CSF), one of the most economically important and highly contagious swine diseases worldwide, is caused by the classic swine fever virus (CSFV). Here, we used high-throughput sequencing to obtain digital gene expression (DGE) profiling in pig umbilical vessel endothelial cells (SUVEC) to identify different response genes for CSFV using both Shimen and C strains. The number of clean tags from the control libraries and both CSFV-infected libraries was 3,473,370, 3,498,355, and 3,327,493, respectively. In comparison between the control, CSFV-C and CSFV-Shimen groups, 644, 158 and 677 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were confirmed in the three groups. Pathway enrichment analysis shows that most of these DEGs are involved in spliceosome, ribosome, proteasome, ubiquitin-mediated proteolysis, cell cycle, focal adhesion, Wnt signaling pathway, etc. showed enrichment in terms of here the processes differ between different virulence CSFV strains. To further elucidate the important mechanisms involved in differential infection by CSFV Shimen and Cstrains, we identified four possible profiles to evaluate only genes significantly expressed by CSFV Shimen or CSFV C strain. GO analysis showed that infection with CSFV Shimen and Cstrains disrupted the "RNA splicing" of SUVEC, resulting in differential "gene expression" in SUVEC. The mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) was identified as an important response regulator for CSFV Shimen, contributing to the effect on SUVEC function. This computational study suggests that differentially virulence CSFV may induce changes in RNA splicing regulation in the host cell to alter cell metabolism, resulting in acute bleeding and pathological damage or infectious tolerance.
authors: Ning, P.;Zhou, Y.;Liang, W.;Zhang, Y.

title: Analysis of the whole genomes of fifteen torque teno midi virus variants that can be classified into a third group of the Anellovirus genus.
abstract: Recently, a 3.8-3.9 kb torque teno virus (TTV)-like genomic organization and torque teno mini-virus with a 3.2 kb circular DNA genome, tentatively termed torque teno midi virus (TTMDV), has been described. We have identified a new human virus with virus (TTMV) 2.8-2.9 kb. To explore the extent of genomic variability of TTMDV genomes, full-length sequences were determined for 15 TTMDV isolates from viremic individuals in Japan. The 15 TTMDV isolates consisted of 3175-3230 bases and shared 67.0-90.3% identity with each other and only 68.4-73.0% identity with the 3 TTMDV isolates reported on the whole genome. TTMDV had a genomic organization similar to TTV and TTMV with four open reading frames (ORF1-ORF4) with characteristic sequence motifs and stem and loop structures with high GC content. The total of 18 TTMDV genomes differed from each other by up to 60.7% in the amino acid sequence of ORF1 (658-677 amino acids), but were phylogenetically divided into the same cluster distantly related to TTVs and TTMVs. These results show that TTMDV, with a 3.2 kb circular DNA genome, has an extremely high degree of genomic variability and can be classified into a third group in the genus Anellovirus.
authors: Ninomiya, M.;Takahashi, M.;Shimosegawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Monoclonal antibodies against the HN glycoprotein of Newcastle disease virus. Use for biological characterization and strain comparisons
abstract: We isolated nine hybridomas expressing monoclonal antibodies directed against the HN glycoprotein of strain D26 of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) and divided them into three groups according to their biological reactivity. Group I antibodies from the six clones had high hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and neutralization titers and exhibited neuraminidase inhibition (NI) activity with both bovine fetuin and N-acetyl neuraminlactose substrates, although maximal inhibition levels were higher with the former substrate. . Group II antibodies from the two clones also had high HI activity, but showed a strongly substrate-dependent NI with a lack of effective inhibition against fetuin and total inhibition against neuraminlactose. These antibodies had neutralizing capacity, but the titers were much lower than those of group I antibodies. One clone (group III) secreted antibodies with both substrates that displayed HI and NI but had no detectable neutralizing activity. The frequency of isolation of antigenic variants and competitive binding experiments showed that group I and group II antibodies could recognize different non-overlapping regions, whereas antibodies inserted into each of the two groups belonged to the same overlapping regions of interest. The group III region seemed to be close to or overlapping the group I determinant, but differed from the group II region. We compared seven heterologous strains with HI and neutralization tests, as well as enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, using isolated monoclonal antibodies. The results showed that regions recognized by group I antibodies would be conserved between strains, while regions recognized by the other two antibody groups could undergo significant variation.
authors: Nishikawa, K.;Isomura, S.;Suzuki, S.

title: Production of monoclonal antibodies against classical swine fever virus and their use for antigenic characterization of Japanese isolates
abstract: Twenty monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) were produced against virulent ALD or vaccine GPE strains of classical swine fever (CSF) virus. The MAbs were divided into 7 groups based on the difference in the spectrum of reaction against various CSF and bovine viral diarrhea-mucosal disease (BVD-MD) viruses. The panel of MAbs can classify 20 CSF viruses into 6 types and distinguish not only CSF and BVD-MD viruses, but also field isolates of vaccine GPE-strain and CSF virus. The results showed that MAbs are useful for the diagnosis and investigation of CSF viruses.
authors: Nishimori, T.;Yamada, S.;Shimizu, M.

title: Identification and whole genome characterization of novel circoviruses in masked palm civets (Paguma larvata)
abstract: The Circoviridae family includes a large group of small, circular, single-stranded DNA viruses and is divided into two genera: Circovirus and Cyclovirus. They have significant genetic diversity and a wide host range. In this study, three novel circovirus genomes were identified from masked palm civets (Paguma larvata) wild-caught in Japan and classified as a new species within the genus Circovirus based on the boundary criteria of the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy. Of note, the presence of two predicted introns at the 5'-terminus of the rep gene has been suggested in Paguma larvata circovirus genomes.
authors: Nishizawa, T.;Sugimoto, Y.;Takeda, T.;Kodera, Y.;Hatano, Y.;Takahashi, M.;Okamoto, H.

title: Association of Theiler's murine encephalomyelitis viruses with the cardiovirus genus of picornaviruses
abstract: Sequence analysis of VP1 in the DA strain of Theiler's murine encephalomyelitis viruses (TMEV) showed that 13 of the first 23 N-terminal amino acids were identical to those in the corresponding protein of the encephalomyocarditis virus. There was little similarity with the corresponding VP1 sequences of poliovirus types 1, 2 and 3, coxsackievirus B3, human rhinoviruses 2 and 14, human hepatitis A virus or foot-and-mouth disease virus. These results, along with the serological associations detected by immunoblotting, suggest that TMEV is more closely related to cardioviruses rather than the enteroviruses for which they are currently classified. This newly recognized association suggests potential for recombinant infectious cDNA studies between TMEV and cardioviruses.
authors: Nitayaphan, S.;Omilianowski, D.;Toth, M. M.

title: Epidemiological investigation of geese H9 avian influenza virus, Newcastle disease virus, Tembusu virus, goose parvovirus and goose circovirus infection in China
abstract: To deepen the knowledge on the prevalence of the epidemic in the goose breeding area, a triplex PCR assay was established and 478 samples were collected from scaled goose farms in 11 provinces in China. The results of this epidemiological study showed that the incidence rates of H9 avian influenza and goose circovirus were the highest among the five infectious diseases evaluated. In addition, the triplex PCR test provided remarkable sensitivity, speed, and versatility compared to other diagnostic methods. Double infection accounted for the majority of coinfections in the field, with combinations of H9/Tembusu, H9/goose circovirus and goose circovirus/Temusu co-infected cases being more common. Outbreaks were more severe in winter and spring. In addition, significant differences in the prevalence of these infectious diseases were observed in relation to different age groups. In addition, phylogenetic analysis determined by the neighbor-joining method was performed to investigate the evolution of these viruses during the study period. For the most part, the virus strains isolated during the study were consistent with most of the goose-derived strains isolated from mainland China in the past few years. However, mutations were observed between the isolated strains of H9 avian influenza virus and the sequences available from GenBank, which should attract much attention.
authors: Niu, X.;Wang, H.;Wei, L.;Zhang, M.;Yang, J.;Chen, H.;Tang, Y.;Diao, Y.

title: Metapneumoviruses in birds and humans
abstract: Avian pneumovirus (APV, Turkey rhinotracheitis virus) and Human metapneumovirus (hMPV) are pathogens of birds and humans, respectively, associated with upper respiratory tract infections. Based on their distinct genomic organization and low level of nucleotide (nt) and amino acid (aa) identity with paramyxoviruses of the genera Pneumovirus, APV and hMPV, it has been classified in a new genus called Metapneumovirus. First isolated in the 1970s, strains of APV have since been isolated in Europe, Africa, the Middle East and the United States (USA) and have been identified as APV/A, APV/B, APV/C and APV/D by nt. classified into four subgroups. and a predicted array id. Although first isolated in 2001, serological evidence indicates that hMPV may have been present in the human population since the 1950s. So far there is only one subgroup of hMPV; The sequence identity nt and aa indicates that it is more closely related to APV/C than to APV/A, APV/B, or APV/D. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Njenga, M. K.;Lwamba, H. M.;Seal, B. S.

title: Isolation of Fukuoka virus, a member of the Kern Canyon serogroup viruses of the Rhabdoviridae family, from cattle.
abstract: Four virus strains with identical antigenic properties were isolated from blood samples of 4 sentinel calves with fever and leukopenia in HmLu-1 cell cultures obtained from baby hamster lung. The virus was identified as Fukuoka virus, classified as a member of the Kern Canyon serogroup viruses of the Rhabdoviridae family on the basis of its antigenic properties.
authors: Noda, M.;Inaba, Y.;Banjo, M.;Kubo, M.

title: Pestivirus infection in cattle dairy farms: E2 glycoprotein ELISA reveals the presence of bovine viral diarrhea virus type 2 in northwestern Italy.
abstract: Background: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) types 1 and 2 are members of the Pestivirus genus of the family Flaviviridae. This genus also includes the HoBi-like virus tentatively classified as BVDV type 3. BVDV-1 is widely distributed in Italy despite the widespread use of BVDV-1-based vaccines, while Pestivirus like BVDV-2 and HoBi have been detected occasionally. . Monitoring the occurrence of sporadic or atypical pestiviruses is a useful approach to assess the need for additional vaccine strains that can be used in BVDV control programs. Results: In this study, we developed a multi-well antibody ELISA based on the recombinant E2 protein of three bovine pestiviruses. We evaluated the applicability of the test for surveillance purposes using pooled milk samples, each prepared from up to 35 lactating cows and collected from 176 dairy herds. As expected, most of the pooled samples reacted to a greater extent against the BVDV-1 E2 antigen. However, all three milk pools on a single farm responded to the BVDV-2 antigen. Further analyzes using spot tests, antigen detection and sequence analysis of the 5'-UTR region confirmed the presence of five permanently infected calves carrying a BVDV-2a strain. Conclusions: This study highlights for the first time that sporadic circulation of BVDV-2 can be predicted by immunoenzymatic methods in the absence of specific vaccination.
authors: Nogarol, C.;Decaro, N.;Bertolotti, L.;Colitti, B.;Iotti, B.;Petrini, S.;Lucente, M. S.;Elia, G.;Perona, G.;Profiti, M.;Buonavoglia, C.;Rosati, S.

title: Genetic analysis of a bovine viral diarrhea virus 2 isolate from Slovakia
abstract: Identification and genetic characterization of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) isolate 17237 detected in western Slovakia is described. Analysis of the 5â€²-untranslated region (5â€²-UTR), autoprotease (N pro) gene and structural genes (C, Erns, E1, E2) was performed. The percentage of nucleotides in the analyzed genes and the deduced amino acid identity implied that the isolate was closely related to bovine viral diarrhea virus 2 (BVDV-2). In addition, phylogenetic analysis revealed that this isolate falls into the BVDV-2b subtype, which is sporadic in Europe. Cleavage sites between viral proteins were similar to a reference strain of BVDV-2.
authors: NovÃ¡ÄkovÃ¡, M.;JackovÃ¡, A.;KolesÃ¡rovÃ¡, M.;VilÄek, Å

title: Rotavirus-associated diarrhea in foals in Greece
abstract: During two consecutive breeding seasons, 2006 and spring 2007, outbreaks of severe diarrheal syndrome occurred in young foals on the same stud farm. Rotavirus-like particles were detected by electron microscopy in the feces of affected foals and group A rotavirus infection was confirmed by Reverse. -Transcription (RT)-PCR with selected rotavirus-specific primer sets. Sequence analysis of the genes encoding the outer capsid rotavirus proteins VP7 and VP4 allowed the viruses to be classified as G3AP[12] and revealed that the viruses were highly similar to the recently reported strains of equine rotavirus circulating in Europe. All Greek equine rotavirus isolates were genetically identical, suggesting that the same viral strain persisted in the stud farm for two consecutive breeding seasons. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Ntafis, V.;Fragkiadaki, E.;Xylouri, E.;Omirou, A.;Lavazza, A.;Martella, V.

title: Differential expression of swine microRNAs in pigs infected with African swine fever virus: a proof-of-concept study.
abstract: Background: African swine fever (ASF) is a devastating re-emerging viral disease that is currently threatening the swine industry worldwide. MicroRNAs are a class of 17-25 nucleotide non-coding RNAs that have been shown to have critical functions in a wide variety of biological processes such as cell differentiation, cell cycle regulation, carcinogenesis, apoptosis, immune regulation and viral diseases. Infections by cleavage or translational repression of mRNAs. However, there is no information on miRNA expression in an ASFV infection. Methods: In this proof-of-concept study, we analyzed miRNAs expressed in the spleen and submandibular lymph node of experimentally infected pigs with a virulent (E75) or its derived attenuated (E75CV1) ASFV strain, as well as at different times postoperatively. - infection with the virulent strain through high-throughput sequencing of small RNA libraries. Results: The spleen presented a different expression pattern than lymph nodes in an ASFV infection. 12 of the most abundant miRNAs were differentially expressed in both tissues at two different times in animals infected with the virulent strain. Of these, miR-451, miR-145-5p, miR-181a and miR-122 showed upregulation late after infection, while miR-92a, miR-23a, miR-92b-3p, miR-126-5p, miR-126- 3p, miR-30d, miR-23b and miR-92c showed downregulation. The attenuated strain presented miR-126-5p, miR-92c, miR-92a, miR-30e-5p and miR-500a-5p upregulation, while miR-125b, miR-451 and miR-125a were downregulated. All these miRNAs have been shown to be associated with various viral genes as well as cellular genes involved in pathways related to the immune response, virus-host interactions. Conclusion: Examination of miRNA expression will contribute to a better understanding of African swine fever virus pathogenesis, which is essential for the development of any disease control strategy.
authors: NÃºÃ±ez-HernÃ¡ndez, F.;PÃ©rez, L. J.;MuÃ±oz, M.;Vera, G.;Accensi, F.;SÃ¡nchez, A.;RodrÃ­guez, F.;NÃºÃ±ez, J. I.

title: Identification of microRNAs by high-throughput sequencing in PCV2 subclinically infected pigs.
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) is the main etiological infectious agent of PCV2-systemic disease and has been associated with other swine diseases, all collectively known as porcine circovirus diseases. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a new class of non-coding small RNAs that regulate post-transcriptional gene expression. miRNAs play an increasing role in many biological processes. The study of miRNA-mediated host-pathogen interactions has emerged in the last decade because of the important role miRNAs play in antiviral defense. The aim of this study was to determine the miRNA expression pattern in PCV2 in subclinically infected and uninfected pigs. For this purpose, an experimental PCV2 infection was performed and small RNA libraries were constructed from tonsil and mediastinal lymph node (MLN) of infected and uninfected pigs. High-throughput sequencing identified differences in miRNA expression between infected and non-infected in the MLN, while a highly conserved pattern was observed in the tonsil. In the MLN, miRNA 126-3p, miRNA 126-5p, let-7d-3p, mir-129a, and mir-let-7b-3p are up-regulated, while mir-193a-5p, mir-574-5p, and mir-34a are down-regulated. . The prediction of functional analysis indicated that these miRNAs may be involved in immune system-related pathways and processes related to the pathogenesis of PCV2, but functional analyzes are needed to support these predictions. This is the first study on miRNA gene expression in PCV2-infected pigs using a high-throughput sequencing approach in which several host miRNAs are differentially expressed in response to PCV2 infection.
authors: NÃºÃ±ez-HernÃ¡ndez, F.;PÃ©rez, L. J.;MuÃ±oz, M.;Vera, G.;TomÃ¡s, A.;Egea, R.;CÃ³rdoba, S.;SegalÃ©s, J.;SÃ¡nchez, A.;NÃºÃ±ez, J. I.

title: African swine fever virus does not express viral microRNAs in experimentally infected pigs
abstract: Background: African swine fever virus (ASFV) is the etiologic agent of African swine fever (ASF), a devastating re-expanding and highly fatal hemorrhagic viral disease. microRNAs (miRNAs) are a new class of non-coding small RNAs that regulate post-transcriptional gene expression. The discovery of virus-specific miRNAs has increased in both number and importance over the past few years. We recently identified differential expression of several porcine miRNAs during in vivo infection with attenuated and virulent ASFV strains. Here we extend these studies attempting to identify the presence of viral miRNAs encoded by ASFV in an in vivo infection in pigs. Results: Sixteen small RNA libraries were analyzed from spleen and submandibular lymph nodes obtained from eight pigs infected with seven virulent E75 ASFV strains or its attenuated counterpart E75CV1 or pigs that survived E75CV1 infection and challenged with BA71 (heterologous challenge) and infected as negative controls. one who is not. Samples were taken at different times after infection. Libraries were analyzed by next-generation sequencing. Some viral miRNA candidates were identified that did not initially correspond to porcine miRNAs. Further structural analysis was performed to confirm whether they met the conformational requirements to be considered a viral miRNA. Results: Analysis of sixteen small RNA libraries prepared from two different tissues from pigs experimentally infected with E75, E75CV1 or E75CV1 plus BA71 revealed the presence of six potential miRNA sequences, but none of them met the requirements to be considered viral miRNAs. . Therefore, we can conclude that ASFV does not express miRNAs in vivo, at least under the experimental conditions described here.

title: PRODUCTION OF SIGNAL NUCLOCAPSYD PROTEIN
