title: Discovery of the genome of an immunodeficiency-associated virus-like virus from pig feces in Japan
authors: Oba, M.;Katayama, Y.;Tsuchiaka, S.

title: Metagenomic identification and sequence analysis of a virus related to Teschovirus A in pig feces in Japan, 2014-2016
abstract: Porcine Teschoviruses (PTVs) are associated with various diseases of pigs and wild boars, including polioencephalomyelitis and reproductive and gastrointestinal disorders, and are also detected in the feces of healthy pigs. The genus Teschovirus contains a single strain of Teschovirus A, which currently includes 13 serotypes. In this study, we identified novel PTVs distantly related to Teschovirus A found in stool samples of pigs with or without diarrhea in Japan. Phylogenetic analysis of the amino acid (aa) sequences of the complete coding region revealed that these newly identified viruses did not cluster with any PTV strains or other strains within the picornavirus supergroup 1, suggesting that the viruses may not belong to Teschovirus A or any genus. It is from the Picornaviridae family. These new PTVs share a type IV internal ribosomal entry site and show conserved characteristic motifs in the coding region, but still 62.2%-79.0%, 86.6%-92.8%, 77.1%-81.0%, and 84.3% -86.7% exhibits. aa identities to PTV strains in regions P1, 2C, 3C and 3D, respectively. In contrast, the PTV 1-13 strain of Teschovirus A was 76.5%-92.1%, 88.1%-99.7%, 93.2%-100%, and 95.8% in P1, 2C. -100% shares aa identities, 3C and 3D respectively within Types. These data imply that the newly identified viruses belong to teschoviruses and may represent a new species in the genus Teschovirus.
authors: Oba, M.;Naoi, Y.;Ito, M.;Masuda, T.;Katayama, Y.;Sakaguchi, S.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Yamasato, H.;Sunaga, F.;Makino, S.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: A novel and comprehensive method for the detection of livestock-related pathogenic viruses using a target enrichment system.
abstract: We tested the usefulness of the target enrichment system SureSelect, a comprehensive viral nucleic acid detection method for rapid identification of viral pathogens in bovine, pig and goat fecal samples. This system enriches the nucleic acids of target viruses in clinical/field samples using a biotinylated RNA library with sequences complementary to the target viruses. Enriched nucleic acids are amplified by PCR and subjected to next-generation sequencing to identify target viruses. In many examples, the SureSelect target enrichment method increased efficiency for detection of viruses listed in the biotinylated RNA library. Furthermore, this method allowed us to determine in swine samples the nearly full-length genome sequence of porcine parainfluenza virus 1 and greatly increased Width, a value indicating the ratio of the mapping consensus length in the reference genome. Our data demonstrated the usefulness of the SureSelect target enrichment system for comprehensive analysis of genomic information of various viruses in field samples.
authors: Oba, M.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Otomaru, K.;Hirata, T.;Aoki, H.;Murata, Y.;Makino, S.;Nagai, M.;Mizutani, T.

title: FULL GENOMIC SEQUENCE OF VIRULENT PIGEON PARAMIXOVIRUS IN SMILING TREE (STREPTOPELIA SENEGALENSIS) IN KENYA
abstract: After the mass deaths of Laughing Pigeons (Streptopelia senegalensis) in different parts of Kenya, the internal organs obtained during the autopsy of two moribund birds were sampled and analyzed by next-generation sequencing. We isolated a virulent strain of pigeon paramyxovirus type-1 (PPMV-1), PPMV1/Laughing Dove/Kenya/Isiolo/B2/2012, which has a characteristic fusion gene motif (110) GGRRQKRF(117). We obtained a partial complete genome of 15,114 nucleotides. The phylogenetic relationship based on the fusion gene and genomic sequence grouped our isolate as class II genotype VI, a group of viruses commonly isolated from wild birds but potentially lethal to Chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus). Clustered fusion gene isolate with PPMV-I strains from pigeons (Columbidae) from Nigeria. The whole genome showed a basal and quite different ancestry than the American, European and Asian strains, indicating a different evolutionary path. The isolated strain is highly virulent and apparently endemic to the Laughing Pigeons in Kenya. Poultry transmission risk of such a strain is potentially high, whereas cyclic epizootic in pigeons is a threat to the conservation of wild Columbidae in Kenya.
authors: Obanda, V.;Michuki, G.;Jowers, M. J.;Rumberia, C.;Mutinda, M.;Lwande, O. W.;Wangoru, K.;Kasiiti-Orengo, J.;Yongo, M.;Angelone-Alasaad, S.

title: Cross-hybridization and relationships of various papillomavirus DNAs of different stiffnesses
abstract: Cloned DNAs of 21 different papillomaviruses that naturally infect mammals and an avian papillomavirus were compared for relative homology by Southern blot hybridization. Stains were performed under low (T(m)-40°), medium (T(m)-33°) and high (T(m)-22°) hardness conditions. At higher stringency, human papillomaviruses cross-hybrid with each other, reflecting species-specific similarities. Bovine papillomavirus types 1, 2, 5, European elk papillomavirus and deer papillomavirus also cross-hybridize at higher stringency, possibly reflecting the association of these viruses with fibroblast-producing lesions. The hybridization data presented here may be useful in future classification experiments. They are also useful as a guide in the selection of papillomavirus DNA probes for the analysis of extracts from warts and tumors.
authors: O'Banion, M. K.;Sundberg, J. P.;Reszka, A. A.;Reichmann, M. E.

title: Molecular evolution of human enteroviruses: serotype correlation with VP1 sequence and application to picornavirus classification
abstract: Sixty-six human enterovirus serotypes have been identified by serum neutralization, but the molecular determinants of the serotypes are unknown. Since the picornavirus VP1 protein contains a set of neutralization domains, we hypothesized that the VP1 sequence should correspond to neutralization (serotype) and thus phylogenetic origin. To test this hypothesis and analyze phylogenetic relationships among human enteroviruses, we determined the complete VP1 sequences of prototype strains of 47 human enterovirus serotypes and 10 antigenic variants. Our sequences include a database of complete VP1 sequences for all 66 human enterovirus serotypes, along with those available from GenBank, as well as additional strains of seven serotypes. Phylogenetic trees constructed from complete VP1 sequences produced the same four major clusters as published trees based on partial VP2 sequences; Unlike VP2 trees, but in VP1 trees, strains of the same serotype were always monophyletic. In pairwise comparisons of whole VP1 sequences, enteroviruses of the same serotype were clearly distinguished from those of heterologous serotypes, and the margins of intraserotypic divergence appeared to be approximately 25% nucleotide sequence difference or 12% amino acid sequence difference. Pairwise comparisons suggested that coxsackie A11 and A15 viruses should be classified as strains of the same serotype as coxsackie A13 and A18 viruses. Dual identity scores also distinguished between enteroviruses from different clusters and enteroviruses from picornaviruses of different genera. The data suggest that VP1 sequence comparisons may be valuable in enterovirus typing and picornavirus taxonomy as an aid to genus assignment of unclassified picornaviruses.
authors: Oberste, M. S.;Maher, K.;Kilpatrick, D. R.;Pallansch, M. A.

title: Genomic evidence that simian virus 2 and six other simian picornaviruses represent a new genus in Picornaviridae
abstract: Analysis of the VP1 capsid protein coding region of Simian virus (SV) 2, SV16, SV18, SV42, SV44, SV45, and SV49 shows that they are clearly different from members of the Enterovirus genus and other extant picornaviruses. To further characterize this group of viruses and clarify their classification within the Picornaviridae, we determined the complete genomic sequence of SV2 (8126 nucleotides). The genome was typical for Picornaviridae members encoding a single open reading frame. The putative polyprotein contained typical picornavirus protease cleavage sites that yield mature proteins homologous to each of the known picornavirus proteins. SV2 contained an amino-terminal extension of the reading frame, similar to the leader protein of members of the genera Aphthovirus, Cardiovirus, Erbovirus, Kobuvirus, and Teschovirus, but lacked significant amino acid homology with any of these known leader proteins. . The 2A protein is also poorly aligned with the 2A proteins of other picornaviruses. The deduced amino acid sequences of the SV2 structural and nonstructural proteins were related to those of enteroviruses and human rhinoviruses but were phylogenetically different. The main distinguishing features of SV2 were the presence of a type 2 internal ribosome entry site in the 5-NTR, a putative leader protein encoded upstream of structural proteins, and an unusually large 2A protein. On the basis of molecular analysis, we propose that SV2, SV16, SV18, SV42, SV44, SV45, SV49 and porcine enterovirus 8 be classified as members of a new genus in Picornaviridae and designated as SV2 (strain 2383). kind of stretch. Â© 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Oberste, M. S.;Maher, K.;Pallansch, M. A.

title: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrhea virus in cattle on Irish farms
abstract: The aim was to conduct a phylogenetic study of bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDV) circulating in Irish cattle herds from 2011 to 2014. Three hundred and twenty-five viruses from 267 herds were subtyped by 5â€²UTR and/or nucleotide sequence analysis. Npro zones. All viruses examined in this study belonged to the BVDV-1 strain, with the distinct subtype (97%) being BVDV-1a. Subtypes BVDV-1b, BVDV-1d and BVDV-1e were also first described in Ireland. Pairwise alignments of 225 fully sequenced viruses for the 5-UTR and Npro regions were performed to determine a low overlap threshold for virus strain restriction. One hundred and seventy-seven unique virus strains were identified. The study revealed significant herd-specific clustering of species, but no geographic or temporal clustering. By combining sequence analysis with animal movement data, similar virus strains were identified in different districts, provinces and years, demonstrating the potential to investigate the epidemiology of the disease.
authors: O'Brien, E.;Garvey, M.;Walsh, C.;Arkins, S.;Cullinane, A.

title: High-throughput genomic sequencing of bioaerosols in broiler plants
abstract: Chronic inhalation exposure to agricultural dust promotes the development of chronic respiratory diseases among poultry workers. It consists of poultry dust, bran, chicken feed, litter and microbes. However, the microbial composition and abundance have not been fully elucidated. Genomic DNA was extracted from settling dust and personal respirable dust collected when performing garbage sampling or death collection tasks. DNA libraries were sequenced using a paired approach by synthesis on an Illumina HiSeq 2500. Sequencing data showed that the poultry dust consisted predominantly of bacteria (64-67%) and small amounts of bird, human and feed DNA (<2% of total reads). staphylococcus sp. AL1, Salinicoccus carnicancri, and Lactobacillus crispatus were the most abundant bacterial species in samples of personal exposure to respirable dust. The settled dust had a moderate relative abundance for these species as well as Staphylococcus lentus and Lactobacillus salivarius. There was a statistical difference between the microbial composition of the aerosolized and precipitated powder. Unlike the established powder composition, the aerosolized powder composition had little variation between samples. These data provide a comprehensive analysis of the microbial composition and relative abundance in personal respirable poultry powder and precipitated poultry powder.
authors: O'Brien, K. M.;Chimenti, M. S.;Farnell, M.;Tabler, T.;Bair, T.;Bray, J. L.;Nonnenmann, M. W.

title: Molecular detection and characterization of bovine viral diarrhea virus in and near Mongolian cattle
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is classified into two types, Bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 and Bovine viral diarrhea virus 2, affecting cattle worldwide, causing significant economic losses. The prevalence and genotypes of BVDV-1 and BVDV-2 infections in Mongolian animals have not been studied. In this study, we investigated BVDV infection in dairy cattle and yaks from Bornuur and Bulgan counties by RT-PCR, and the mean infection rate in the sampling areas was 15.8% and 20.0%, respectively. In addition, the molecular features of the 5'-UTR region of the BVDV genome in Mongolian cattle and yaks were determined to belong to the BVDV-1a and BVDV-2a subtypes, respectively. Determining the prevalence, geographic distribution and molecular diversity of BVDV-1 and BVDV-2 in various host species in Mongolia is important for further studies and process control programs.
authors: Ochirkhuu, N.;Konnai, S.;Odbileg, R.;Odzaya, B.;Gansukh, S.;Murata, S.;Ohashi, K.

title: Characterization and Distribution of a Potyvirus Associated with Passion Fruit Woody Disease in Uganda
abstract: This article describes the incidence and etiology of a viral disease of passion fruit in Uganda. Symptoms, including characteristics of passion fruit woody disease (PWD), were observed in 32% of the plants in the production areas. Electron microscopic observations of infected tissues, ca. 780nm. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent experiments demonstrated serological association with Cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CABMV) and Passion fruit ringspot virus (PFRSV). In host range studies, only species in the families Solanaceae and Chenopodiaceae were susceptible, and neither Vigna unguiculata nor Phaseolus vulgaris were infected. The coat protein (CP) gene sequences of the eight isolates exhibited potyvirus-specific features and were highly similar (88% to 100% identity). However, the sequences had sequence identity limited to the CP genes of two of the three potyviruses reported to cause PWD: East Asian Passiflora virus and Passion fruit woodland virus (PWV). Amino acid sequences inferred for CP of isolates from Uganda range from Bean common mosaic necrosis virus (BCMNV) (72 to 79%, evolutionary divergence values 0.17 and 0.19) and CABMV (73 to 76%, with divergence values between 73% and 76%). 76) had the highest identity. 0.21 and 0.25). Based on these results and in accordance with the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses criteria for species restriction in the family Potyviridae, we conclude that a previously unreported virus caused viral diseases in passion fruit in Uganda. The name "Uganda Passiflora virus" has been suggested for this virus.
authors: Ochwo-Ssemakula, M.;Sengooba, T.;Hakiza, J. J.;Adipala, E.;Edema, R.;Redinbaugh, M. G.;Aritua, V.;Winter, S.

title: Bovine viral diarrhea virus genomic associations in outbreaks of mucosal disease, enteritis, and generalized dermatitis in Argentina.
abstract: The aim of this study is to describe outbreaks caused by bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) on commercial cattle farms in Argentina. Genetic linkage and their association with clinical manifestations were established with five BVDV isolates from one mucosal disease (MD) (Outbreak #1), acute enteritis (Outbreak #2 and #3), and generalized dermatitis (Epidemic #4 and #). 5). Upon genetic analysis, the CP BVDV isolate of Outbreak #1 clustered closely to BVDV Oregon (Genotype 1). BVDV isolates from generalized dermatitis outbreaks (Outbreaks #4 and #5) were located close to BVDV Osloss within Genotype 1. Identification of BVDV by immunohistochemistry in exudative dermatitis indicates epithelial cell tropism of the virus. Phylogenetic characterization of BVDV from Outbreaks #2 and #3, positioning them as BVDV-2. The 5â€²UTR sequence of these viruses showed 88% and 90% homology to BVDV-890 (Genotype 2) and 77% and 75% homology to BVDV-SD1 (Genotype 1), respectively. The association of BVDV-2 with severe disease indicates the presence of highly virulent strains. Data from natural outbreaks in which BVDV-1 and BVDV-2 were isolated revealed overlap of pathology and clearly did not allow for discrimination between genotypes based on gross or microscopic lesions. Therefore, further virology and molecular studies are needed for definitive diagnosis. In addition, the results of this study focused on the origin and consequences of genetic variations of BVDV with regard to pathogenesis and suggested the association between genotype and a defined clinical syndrome. authors: OdeÃ³n, A. C.;Risatti, G.;Kaiser, G. G.;Leunda, M. R.;Odriozola, E.;Campero, C. M.;Donis, R. O.

title: African Swine Fever Virus Georgia 2007 Deletion of Virulence-Associated Gene 9GL (B119L) Causes Virus Attenuation in Pigs When Administered at Low Doses and Provides Effective Protection Against Homologous Challenge
abstract: UNLABELED: African swine fever virus (ASFV) is the etiologic agent of an often fatal disease of domestic pigs. The absence of vaccines against ASFV has hampered disease control strategies. A highly virulent virus, ASFV Georgia 2007 (ASFV-G), has caused an epidemic that has spread rapidly to Eastern European countries since its introduction in the Republic of Georgia. No vaccine is currently available or developed to control ASFV-G. In the past, genetically modified ASFVs harboring deletion of virulence-related genes have been proven to be attenuated in pigs and induce protective immunity against challenge with homologous parental viruses. Deletion of the 9GL gene (open reading frame [ORF] B119L) in the highly virulent ASFV Malawi-Lil-20/1 produced an attenuated phenotype even when administered to pigs at 10%(6) 50% hemadsorption doses (HAD50). Here we report the construct of a genetically modified ASFV-G strain (ASFV-G-DELTA9GLv) harboring the 9GL (B119L) gene deletion. Like Malawi-Lil-20/1-DELTA9GL, ASFV-G-DELTA9GL showed limited replication in primary porcine macrophages. However, intramuscular vaccination of pigs with 10(4) HAD50 ASFV-G-DELTA9GL produced a lethal phenotype, unlike Malawi-Lil-20/1-DELTA9GL, that caused a fatal disease in pigs, such as parent ASFV-G. Interestingly, lower doses (10(2) to 10(3) HAD50 of ASFV-G-DELTA9GL did not induce a virulent phenotype when challenged for disease in pigs and guarded pigs. A 10(2) HAD50 dose of ASFV-G-DELTA9GLv provided partial protection when pigs were challenged at 21 or 28 days (dpi) after infection. A 10(3) ASFV-G-DELTA9GL HAD50 provided partial and full protection at 21 and 28 dpi, respectively. The information provided here adds to our final report on first attempts at experimental vaccines against ASFV-G. IMPORTANCE: The main problem with controlling ASF is the lack of vaccines. Studies of ASFV virulence lead to the production of genetically modified attenuated viruses that protect in pigs but only against homologous virus threats. Here, in an attempt to produce a vaccine against the virulent ASFV-G, a highly virulent virus isolate that was detected in the Caucasus region in 2007 and is now spreading in the Caucasus region and Eastern Europe, we generated a recombinant ASFV lacking the virulence-associated gene 9GL. Deletion of 9GL did not completely reduce ASFV-G, unlike other ASFV isolates. However, once given at low doses, recombinant ASFV-G-DELTA9GL provides protection against parental ASFV-G in pigs. Protection against ASFV-G was highly effective at 28 days post-vaccination, whereas at 21 days post-vaccination the animals survived the fatal challenge but showed signs of ASF. Here we report the design and development of an experimental vaccine that protects against virulent ASFV-G.
authors: O'Donnell, V.;Holinka, L. G.;Krug, P. W.;Gladue, D. P.;Carlson, J.;Sanford, B.;Alfano, M.;Kramer, E.;Lu, Z.;Arzt, J.;Reese, B.;Carrillo, C.;Risatti, G. R.;Borca, M. V.

title: Isolation and characterization of orf viruses from Korean black goats
abstract: Between 2010 and 2011, five cases of orf virus infection in Korean land goats were diagnosed in our laboratory. An orf virus (ORF/2011) was isolated from a sheep testis cell line (OA3.Ts) for use as a vaccine candidate. Sequences of major envelope protein and orf virus interferon resistance genes were determined and compared with published reference sequences. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that orf viruses from Korean land goats were most closely related to an isolate from Korean dairy goats (ORF/09/Korea). This result indicates that orf viruses may have entered the Korean black goat population from dairy goats. Â© 2013 Korean Veterinary Science Association.
authors: Oem, J. K.;Chung, J. Y.;Kim, Y. J.;Lee, K. K.;Kim, S. H.;Jung, B. Y.;Hyun, B. H.

title: Complete genome sequences of three rabies viruses isolated from rabid raccoon dogs and a cow in Korea
authors: Oem, J. K.;Kim, S. H.;Kim, Y. H.;Lee, M. H.;Lee, K. K.

title: Re-emergence of rabies in the southern Han river region, Korea
abstract: Recently, 11 cases of animal rabies have been reported in the southern region of Gyeonggi Province (Suwon and Hwaseong cities), South Korea. Cases were tentatively divided into two cases in dogs (Canis lupus familyis) in spring 2012 and nine cases in pets and wildlife in winter 2012-13. All carcasses were sent for histopathological examination and viral antigen identification. The sequences of glycoprotein, nucleoprotein and glycoprotein-large polymerase protein intergenic noncoding loci of 11 strains were determined and compared with published reference sequences. All rabies strains were closely related to Gangwon strains isolated in 2008-09, suggesting that the rabies virus strains isolated in Gyeonggi were brought from Gangwon Province.
authors: Oem, J. K.;Kim, S. H.;Kim, Y. H.;Lee, M. H.;Lee, K. K.

title: Bovine papular stomatitis virus (BPSV) infections in Korean domestic cattle
abstract: An outbreak of the disease with parapox-like symptoms was reported in South Korea in April 2012. Three of 45 Korean domestic cattle aged 20-24 months were affected. Parapoxviruses were detected and identified by electron microscopy and polymerase chain reaction (PCR). To determine the genetic characteristics of Korean strains, the sequence of the major envelope protein (B2L) was determined and compared with published reference sequences. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that parapoxvirus strains were closely related not only with isolates from Japan, but also with isolates from Germany, Sudan, and the United States. This is the first report on an outbreak and molecular characterization of BPSV in Korea. Â© 2013 Japanese Veterinary Science Association.
authors: Oem, J. K.;Lee, E. Y.;Lee, K. K.;Kim, S. H.;Lee, M. H.;Hyun, B. H.

title: Novel Kobuvirus strains detected from diarrheal black goat
authors: Oem, J. K.;Lee, M. H.;Lee, K. K.;An, D. J.

title: Foot and mouth disease in Asian black bears (Ursus thibetanus)
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is a highly contagious, debilitating, and globally important viral disease that typically affects equidae-hoofed hosts. Diagnosis of FMD in bears in Vietnam is described. The present study describes a confirmed case of FMD in a bear species and clinical signs consistent with FMD in a Malayan sun bear. Thirteen Asian black bears (Ursus thibetanus) and 1 Malayan sun bear (Helarctos malayanus) were apparently affected. In August 2011, an adult bear became lethargic and developed foot vesicles. For 15 days, 14 out of 17 bears had similar symptoms; There were no remaining 3 common bears and 57 resident bears. All affected bears developed vesicles on all soles of their feet, and most were lethargic for 24-48 hours. Nasal and oral lesions were recorded in 6 and 3 cases, respectively. Within 1 month everything seemed normal. Foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV) was detected by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction, classified as serotype O, and isolated by virus isolation techniques. Phylogenetic analysis showed that 3 bear isolates clustered in a different branch from other FMDV type O isolates. The outbreak most likely occurred due to indirect contact with livestock and was facilitated by the high density of captive bears. It showed that Asian black bears are capable of contracting FMDV and developing clinical disease, and the virus spreads easily among bears in close contact.
authors: Officer, K.;Lan, N. T.;Wicker, L.;Hoa, N. T.;Weegenaar, A.;Robinson, J.;Ryoji, Y.;Loukopoulos, P.

title: Two new subfamilies of DNA mismatch repair proteins (MutS) particularly abundant in the marine environment
abstract: MutS proteins are ubiquitous in cellular organisms and have important roles in DNA mismatch repair or recombination. In the virus world, the amoeba-infected Mimivirus, as well as the recently sequenced Cafeteria roenbergensis virus, are known to encode a MutS related to homologues found in octochorae and epsilon-proteobacteria. To investigate the presence of MutS proteins in other viral genomes, we performed a genomic search of four giant viruses ('giruses') (Pyramimonas orientalis virus (PoV), Phaeocystis bag etii virus (PpV), Chrysochromulina ericina virus (CeV) and Heterocapsa circularisquama). Our analysis of single-celled seaweed-infecting DNA virus (HcDNAV) revealed the presence of a close homologue of Mimivirus MutS in all analyzed gyri. These viral homologues have a specific domain structure, including a C-terminal HNH-endonuclease domain that defines the novel MutS7 subfamily. We confirmed the presence of conserved mismatch recognition residues in all members of the MutS7 subfamily, suggesting their role in DNA mismatch repair rather than DNA recombination. PoV and PpV were found to contain an additional type of MutS, which we propose to call MutS8. MutS8 proteins in PoV and PpV were found to be closely related to homologues from Candidatus Amoebophilus asiaticus, an obligate intracellular amoeba symbiont of Bacteroidetes. Furthermore, our analysis revealed that MutS7 and MutS8 are abundant in marine microbial metagenomes, and the vast majority of these environmental sequences likely originate from the gyrus. The gyri therefore appear to represent an important source of underexplored diversity of the MutS family in the microbial world. ISME Journal (2011) 5, 1143-1151; doi:10.1038/ismej.2010.210; Posted online January 20, 2011 Subject Category: evolutionary genetics
authors: Ogata, H.;Ray, J.;Toyoda, K.;Sandaa, R. A.;Nagasaki, K.;Bratbak, G.;Claverie, J. M.

title: Remarkable sequence similarity between dinoflagellate-infected marine gyrus and the terrestrial pathogen African swine fever virus
abstract: Heterocapsa circularisquama DNA virus (HcDNAV; previously named HcV) is a giant virus (gyrus) with a âˆ¼356-kbp double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) genome. HcDNAV lytically infects the bivalve-killing marine dinoflagellate H. circularisquama and represents the only DNA virus currently isolated from dinoflagellates, one of the most abundant protists in marine ecosystems. Its morphological features, genome type, and host range have previously suggested that HcDNAV may be a member of the Phycodnaviridae family of Nucleo-Sytoplasmic Large DNA Viruses (NCLDVs), but no supporting sequence data are available. NCLDVs include two families currently found in aquatic environments (Phycodnaviridae, Mimiviridae), one mostly infecting terrestrial animals (Poxviridae), the other isolated from fish, amphibians and insects (Iridoviridae) and the last (Asfarviridae) African only represented by the animal pathogen . swine fever virus (ASFV) is the causative agent of a fatal hemorrhagic disease in domestic pigs. In this study, we determined the full sequence of the B-type DNA polymerase (PolB) gene of HcDNAV. Viral PolB was transcribed at least 6 hours after inoculation (hpi), revealing its crucial function for viral replication. Most unexpectedly, the PolB sequence of HcDNAV was found to be closely related to the PolB sequence of ASFV. In addition, the amino acid sequence of HcDNAV PolB showed a rare amino acid substitution within a highly conserved motif-containing motif: YSDTDS was found in HcDNAV PolB instead of YGDTDS in most dsDNA viruses. Together with the previous observation of ASFV-like sequences in the Sorcerer II Global Ocean Sampling metagenomic datasets, our results further strengthen the idea that terrestrial ASFV has evolutionary origin in marine environments. Â© 2009 Ogata et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Ogata, H.;Toyoda, K.;Tomaru, Y.;Nakayama, N.;Shirai, Y.;Claverie, J. M.;Nagasaki, K.

title: Complete genome and phylogenetic position of bovine papillomavirus type 7
abstract: Six bovine papillomavirus (BPV) types and 16 possible BPV types have been previously reported. Here, the whole genome sequence of BAPV6, a novel putative type of BPV isolated from cattle in Japan, was determined using multi-primed rolling circle amplification. The genome consisted of 7412 bp (46 mol G+C content) encoding five early (E1, E2, E4, E6 and E7) and two late (L1 and L2) genes but not the E5 gene. The E6 protein contained a non-consensus CxxC(x)33CxxC and a consensus CxxC(x)29CxxC zinc-binding domain, and the E7 protein lacked the LxCxE motif. The nucleotide sequence of the L1 open reading frame (ORF) was most closely related (57-58%) to the L1 ORF of the member(s) of the Betapapillomavirus, Gammapapillomavirus and Pipapillomavirus genera. Phylogenetic analysis based on the full L1 ORF suggests that BAPV6 should be classified as BPV-7 within a new genus in the Papillomaviridae family. © 2007 SGM.
authors: Ogawa, T.;Tomita, Y.;Okada, M.;Shirasawa, H.

title: Human intestinal virus: an all-round majority
authors: Ogilvie, L. A.;Jones, B. V.

title: Human gut virus: form and function
authors: Ogilvie, L. A.;Jones, B. V.

title: Isolation of maedi/visna virus from a sheep in Japan
abstract: Maedi/visna (MV) is a sheep lentiviral disease caused by the maedi/visna virus (MVV). Although MV is common in many countries, it has not been reported in Japan. In 2011, however, three sheep in northern Japan were reported to be seropositive to the MVV antigen, indicating a persistent MVV infection. In this study, we isolated MVV from a sheep and performed genomic classification of the virus to confirm MVV infection. Co-culture of fetal goat lung cells and leukocytes from a seropositive sheep resulted in the formation of syncytial cells and amplification of a long terminal repeat MVV sequence by polymerase chain reaction. The isolate was confirmed to be MVV rather than goat arthritis-encephalitis virus based on phylogenetic analysis of the gag gene sequence. Although the sheep were asymptomatic, non-purulent meningitis and demyelination were found in the spinal cord. These were considered as early lesions associated with pathogenic MVV infection. Therefore, this study demonstrated that MVV is distributed in Japan. Â© 2014 Japanese Veterinary Science Association.
authors: Oguma, K.;Tanaka, C.;Harasawa, R.;Kimura, A.;Sasaki, J.;Goryo, M.;Sentsui, H.

title: Evidence of an antigenic shift among Palyam serogroup orbiviruses
abstract: Japanese isolates of Palyam serogroup viruses isolated from 1985 to 2001 were searched for genome sequence of segments 2 and 7 and analyzed phylogenetically in comparison with Australian and African isolates of the same serogroup. The nucleotide sequences of segment 7 were highly conserved in Japanese isolates (95.1 to 100%) and between Japanese and Taiwanese isolates (96.0 to 100%), while identities between Japanese and Taiwanese isolates and Australian and African isolates were highly conserved ( 84.2 to 100%) 92.0%). Phylogenetic analysis based on segment 7 revealed three clusters by geographic origin. As a result of nucleotide sequence analysis of segment 2 encoding a serotype-specific antigen, Japanese isolates were divided into two groups according to genome length and nucleotide identity. Of the nine Japanese isolates, four were categorized in the same group as the prototype strain K-47 of Chuzan virus, and the remaining isolates were categorized in the same group as D'Aguilar virus and Nyabira virus. Segment 2-based phylogenetic analysis revealed two clusters, the cluster containing the Chuzan virus and the cluster containing the D'Aguilar and Nyabira viruses. We performed a cross-neutralization test to examine the antigenic relationship between viruses classified in different clusters. KSB-29/E/01, isolated in Japan in 2001, was neutralized with antiserum not only for the B8112 strain of D'Aguilar virus, but also for Chuzan virus. These results indicated that the genetically and antigenically unique features of KSB-29/E/01 were attributed to the genetic reclassification of segment 2 between Chuzan virus and D'Aguilar virus.
authors: Ohashi, S.;Matsumori, Y.;Yanase, T.;Yamakawa, M.;Kato, T.;Tsuda, T.

title: Sequence analysis of an Asian canine tooth virus (canine parvovirus type 1)
abstract: Minute Canines Virus (MVC), also known as Canine parvovirus (CPV) type 1, is an autonomous parvovirus that infects domestic dogs worldwide and is responsible for clinical problems of newborns and pregnant bitches. It has been previously described that MVC is antigenic and genetically different from the later emerging CPV type 2. However, much of MVC is still unclear as only a limited number of MVC isolates are available for study. MVC infections of Japanese and Korean dogs have been epidemiologically investigated in the previous study and several MVC isolates could be grown in vitro. In this study, an almost full-length nucleotide sequence of the genome of a Korean MVC strain HM-6 was obtained and analyzed in comparison with that of the recently characterized American MVC strain GA3. The genome structure of the HM-6 strain was similar to the GA3 strain, with 96.4% identity in the nucleotide sequence. The deduced amino acid sequences of NS1, NP-1 and VP1/2 each showed 96.5%, 92.5% and 97.5% homology between HM-6 and GA3 strains. Compared with other parvovirus strains, strain HM-6 was most closely related to bovine parvovirus (BPV) as described for strain GA3. These results suggest that MVC may be classified together with BPV in a new clade, possibly in the Parvovirinae subfamily. Â© 2004 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
authors: Ohshima, T.;Kishi, M.;Mochizuki, M.

title: Initial isolation and genetic characterization of pseudocowpox virus from cattle in Japan
abstract: Background: Pseudocowpox virus (PCPV) infects cattle worldwide with zoonotic potential, but has not been isolated in Japan. Therefore, the epidemiological status of PCPV infection in cattle has not been determined. Results: In May 2016, white vesicles and hyperemia were seen on the mucosa under the tongue surface in a cattle on a farm in Yamaguchi Prefecture, but not on the nipples and coronary cushions. A parapoxvirus was isolated from the oral lesion swab and genetically characterized based on the full-length sequence of the B2L gene encoding the viral envelope. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the isolated virus was classified as PCPV. Conclusion: This case illustrates its potential spread in Japan. This is the first report of PCPV isolation in Japan.
authors: Ohtani, A.;Yokoyama, A.;Narushige, H.;Inoshima, Y.

title: Genetic characterization and classification of human and animal sapoviruses
abstract: Sapoviruses (SaVs) are enteric caliciviruses that have been detected in many mammalian species, including humans, pigs, mink, dogs, sea lions, chimpanzees, and rats. They show a high level of diversity. A SaV genome usually encodes seven nonstructural proteins (NSs), including the RNA polymerase protein NS7 and two structural proteins (VP1 and VP2). We classified human and animal SaVs into 15 genogroups (G) based on available VP1 sequences, including three newly characterized genomes from this study. We sequenced the full-length genomes of one novel genogroup V (GV), one GVII, and one GVIII porcine SaV using long-range RT-PCR including newly designed forward primers located in conserved motifs of putative NS3, as well as 5" RACE methods. We also identified the 5"² and 3" ends of lion GV SaV and canine GXIII SaV. While complete genomic sequences of GIX-GXII and GXV SaVs are not available, common features of SaV genomes include: 1) at the 5â€²-end of the genome. GTG" and short (9-14 nt) 5â€²-untranslated region; and 2) the first five amino acids of putative NS1 (M [A/V] S [K/R] P) and putative cleavage between NS7 and VP1 The five amino acids (FEMEG) surrounding the region are conserved among chimpanzees, two of the five genogroups (GV and GVIII), sea lion, canine and human SaVs.In contrast, these two amino acid motifs are pig (GIII, GVI and GVII) and bat It was clearly different in the three genogroups of SaVs.Our results suggest that several animal SaVs have genetic similarities to human SaVs. shows the However, the ability of SaVs to be transmitted between humans and animals is unclear.
authors: Oka, T.;Lu, Z.;Phan, T.;Delwart, E. L.;Saif, L. J.;Wang, Q.

title: Bovine rotavirus G and P types and sequence analysis of the VP7 gene of two G8 bovine rotaviruses from JPN
abstract: total of 1481 stool samples were collected from calves under 1 month old with diarrhea from 29 dairy and fattening farms in 11 provinces in Japan during the 1987-2000 period. These calves and their mothers have not been vaccinated against rotavirus. One hundred and forty-two bovine rotaviruses were isolated in MA-104 cell cultures and detected by latex agglutination test. 18 G6P[1] (11.2%), 53 G6P[5] (37.3%), 15 G6P[11] (10.6%), 12 G10P[5] (8.5%), 42 G10P [11] (29.6%) and 1 G8P[11] (0.7%) by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction. A serotype G8 virus could not be typed for the P genotype, suggesting a new strain of bovine origin. The least common G8 serotype viruses were isolated from farm samples from Niigata and Tokushima prefectures. The VP7 gene sequences of the two isolates showed a high degree of homology with the previously reported G8 viruses, with 93.3-98.8% identity of deduced amino acids. A phylogenetic analysis of the two G8 viruses and the VP7 gene of the 13 previously reported G8 viruses by the neighbor splicing method showed that the two newly isolated G8 rotaviruses had a common origin and were assigned to a new distinct cluster. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Okada, N.;Matsumoto, Y.

title: Isolation and characterization of a novel rotavirus strain A in sugar gliders (Petaurus breviceps)
abstract: To estimate the risk of interspecies transmission of rotavirus type A (RVA) from exotic domestic animals to other mammalian species, the prevalence of RVA in sugar gliders (Petaurus breviceps) was investigated. RVAs were detected by reverse transcription (RT) semisted PCR in 10 of 44 sugar gliders. These viruses were classified as G27P[3] and G27P[36] genotypes, and G27 and P[36] were the new genotypes assigned by the Rotavirus Classification Working Group. To characterize the sugar glider RVA in detail, a strain, RVA/SugarGlider-tc/JPN/SG385/2012/G27P[36] (SG385-tc), was isolated. All genes belonging to the strain were classified as new genotypes (G27-P[36]-I19-R10-C10-M9-A20-N11-T13-E17-H12). The enterotoxin domain in NSP4, which is important for induction of diarrhea, was conserved between SG385-tc and previously reported mammalian strains, suggesting the potential of the sugar glider RVA to cause diarrhea in mammalian species. In fact, seven of nine suckling mice orally inoculated with 3.9 x 10(4) ffu of the SG385-tc strain had diarrhea, and the 50% diarrhea-inducing dose (DD50) of SG385-tc strain in suckling mice was 1.2 x 10(4) ffu. shows that glider RVA is infective and possibly pathogenic for other mammalian species.
authors: Okadera, K.;Abe, M.;Ito, N.;Mitake, H.;Okada, K.;Nakagawa, K.;Une, Y.;Tsunemitsu, H.;Sugiyama, M.

title: Genetic and antigenic diversity of avian influenza viruses isolated from domestic ducks, musk duck and chickens in northern and southern Vietnam, 2010-2012
abstract: To estimate the prevalence of avian influenza virus infection in Vietnam, surveillance of domestic and wild birds from Vietnamese households, live bird markets, slaughterhouses and bird shelters was conducted between October 2010 and October 2012. Of the 4,550 samples collected, 226 influenza A virus isolates were obtained from domestic ducks, musk duck and chickens. Of these, 25 and 22 H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIVs) were isolated from apparently healthy domestic ducks in live bird markets and slaughter areas in northern and southern Vietnam, respectively. HA genes of H5 viruses isolated from birds in northern Vietnam belonged phylogenetically to genetic division 2.3.2.1, and those from southern Vietnam to genetic division 1.1. In addition, 39 H3, 12 H4, 1 H5, 93 H6, 2 H7, 18 H9, 3 H10 and 11 H11 viruses were isolated. Phylogenetic and antigenic analyzes of H6 and H9 viruses revealed that they are closely related to isolates from domestic poultry in China. Phylogenetic analyzes of internal gene segments of these isolates revealed that these viruses circulate in both domestic and wild birds in Asia and frequent reclassification events occur. Therefore, it will be important to maintain surveillance and strict controls over the movement and trade of poultry and poultry products to eradicate H5N1 HPAIV from Asia. Â© 2013 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Okamatsu, M.;Nishi, T.;Nomura, N.;Yamamoto, N.;Sakoda, Y.;Sakurai, K.;Chu, H. D.;Thanh, L. P.;Van Nguyen, L.;Van Hoang, N.;Tien, T. N.;Yoshida, R.;Takada, A.;Kida, H.

title: Characterization of High Pathogenic Avian Influenza Virus A(H5N6), Japan, November 2016
abstract: Highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIVs) A(H5N6) were introduced simultaneously to several remote areas of Japan in November 2016. These viruses were classified in genetics section 2.3.4.4c and were genetically closely related to H5N6 HPAIVs recently isolated in South Korea. and China. In addition, these HPAIVs showed greater antigenic shift.
authors: Okamatsu, M.;Ozawa, M.;Soda, K.;Takakuwa, H.;Haga, A.;Hiono, T.;Matsuu, A.;Uchida, Y.;Iwata, R.;Matsuno, K.;Kuwahara, M.;Yabuta, T.;Usui, T.;Ito, H.;Onuma, M.;Sakoda, Y.;Saito, T.;Otsuki, K.;Ito, T.;Kida, H.

title: Genetic variability and evolution of the hepatitis E virus
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is the only member of the Hepevirus genus in the Hepeviridae family. HEV is transmitted primarily by the fecal-oral route, and waterborne outbreaks are characteristic of hepatitis E in many developing countries in Asia, Africa, and Latin America where sanitation conditions are poor. Accumulating evidence indicates that HEV-associated hepatitis also occurs locally among individuals in industrialized countries, that there are animal reservoirs of HEV such as domestic pigs and wild boars, and that hepatitis E is a zoonosis. Based on the wide genomic variability among HEV isolates, HEV sequences have been classified into four genotypes: genotype 1 consists of epidemic strains in developing countries in Asia and Africa; genotype 2 has been identified in Mexico and several African countries; genotype 3 HEV is widely distributed in many countries of the world except African countries and has been isolated from sporadic acute cases of hepatitis E and/or domestic pigs; and genotype 4 includes strains isolated from humans and/or domestic pigs in Asian countries only. This article reviews current knowledge of the genomic variability, geographic distribution, and zoonotic aspects of HEV, as well as the clinical significance of the genotype and evolution of HEV. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Okamoto, H.

title: Features of hepatitis E virus infection in Japan
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is the main cause of acute hepatitis in many developing countries. HEV is transmitted mainly by the fecal-oral route, and waterborne outbreaks are characteristic of hepatitis E. Recently, there is a growing consensus that HEV-associated hepatitis also occurs among individuals in industrialized countries without a history of travel to endemic areas. Zoonotic spread of HEV has been proposed as human and porcine HEV strains are genetically closely related, and experimental cross-species infection of swine HEV to a chimpanzee and human HEV to pig has been demonstrated. This review describes the clinical, epidemiological, and virological features of domestic HEV infection in Japan, the genetic association of Japanese human and porcine HEV strains, and possible modes of transmission of HEV, and highlights that HEV should be considered in the diagnosis of acute or fulminant hepatitis. Non-A, non-B, non-C etiology, even in patients who have not traveled abroad.
authors: Okamoto, H.;Takahashi, M.;Nishizawa, T.

title: Characterization of sporadic acute hepatitis E and comparison of hepatitis E virus genomes in acute hepatitis patients and pork liver sold as food in Mie, Japan.
abstract: Objective: To characterize hepatitis E in Mie Prefecture and to investigate whether raw pork liver sold as food in Mie is contaminated with hepatitis E virus (HEV) strains similar to those from patients. Methods: Seventeen patients with sporadic acute hepatitis E treated from 2004 to 2012 were studied. A total of 243 packages of raw pork liver from regional grocery stores were tested for the presence of HEV RNA. Partial genomic sequences of human and porcine HEV isolates were determined and subjected to phylogenetic analysis. Results: HEV isolates and 15 genotype 3 isolates obtained from 17 patients separated as genotype 3 (n=15) and genotype 4 (n=2) were further divided into 3e (n=11) and 3b (n=4). Pig liver samples from 12 (4.9%) of 243 packages had detectable HEV RNA. All 12 porcine HEV isolates were grouped as genotype 3 (3a or 3b). Although no 3e strains were isolated from the porcine liver samples, the two 3b porcine strains were 99.5-100% identical to the two HEV strains from hepatitis patients in 412-nt partial sequences. Conclusion: 3e HEV was common in hepatitis E patients. HEV RNA was detected in approximately 5% of pig liver sold as food. The availability of identical HEV strains between hepatitis patients and pig liver suggested that pigs play an important role as reservoirs for HEV in humans in Mie. Further studies are needed to clarify the 3e source of HEVs in animal and environmental reservoirs.
authors: Okano, H.;Takahashi, M.;Isono, Y.;Tanaka, H.;Nakano, T.;Oya, Y.;Sugimoto, K.;Ito, K.;Ohmori, S.;Maegawa, T.;Kobayashi, M.;Nagashima, S.;Nishizawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Application of antisense molecules to poultry production
abstract: Antisense molecules, which are single-stranded nucleic acids complementary to a specific mRNA, target and bind to the mRNA, blocking and inhibiting translation of the mRNA encoding a specific protein. Recently, phosphorothioate antisense oligodeoxynucleotides and protein nucleic acids have been used to avoid antisense molecules from nucleases, which were originally developed as nuclease resistant alternatives to phosphodiester oligomers. The delivery system for insensitive molecules is basically equivalent to the DNA delivery system. Traditionally, DNA delivery systems have been classified as viral vector-mediated systems and non-viral vector-mediated systems. As the importance of the current methodology can be attributed to the limitation of viral vector-mediated delivery, non-viral vector-mediated systems, particularly synthetic DNA delivery systems, have become increasingly desirable. The possibility of administering antisense protein nucleic acids against leptin MRNA to stimulate the appetite of poultry is discussed. Antisense phosphorothioate oligodeoxynucleotide against insulin-like growth factor binding protein-2 mRNA successfully suppressed hepatic gene expression in chicken. Protein synthesis of chicken embryo myoblasts was decreased by administration of antisense phosphorothioate oligodeoxynucleotide against myostatin mRNA, suggesting reduction in protein degradation by antisense administration.
authors: Okumura, J.;Kita, K.

title: Distribution of gene segments of the pandemic A(H1N1) 2009 virus strain in pig populations
abstract: Swine flu viruses (SIVs) are important not only for swine farming but also for public health. In fact, pandemic A(H1N1) 2009 viruses [A(H1N1)pdm09] are derived from SIVs. Thus, timely characterization of locally circulating SIVs is essential to understanding the global status of SIVs. To genetically characterize circulating SIVs in Japanese pig populations, we isolated 24 SIVs in three subtypes (17 H1N1, four H1N2 and three H3N2 strains) from 14 pig farms in Japan from 2013 to 2016. Genetic analyzes included genes of hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase 17 H1N1 (NA), and an H1N2, A/swine/Aichi/02/2016 (H1N2), HA gene of SIVs, belonging to the A(H1N1)pdm09 lineage. More importantly, all six remaining gene segments of 24 SIVs (i.e., PB1, PB1, PA, NP, M, and NS), independent of HA and NA subtype, were also classified as belonging to A(H1N1)pdm09. strain. These results indicate that gene segments of the A(H1N1)pdm09 lineage are widely distributed in SIVs circulating in Japanese pig populations. The closest relative isolated in Japan in 2003 is that of A/swine/Miyagi/5/2003 (H1N2). These results demonstrate the sustained circulation of classical H1N2-derived SIVs with remarkable diversity in NA genes in Japanese pig populations. These findings highlight the necessity of both intensive biosafety systems and active SIV surveillance in swine populations worldwide for both animal and public health.
authors: Okuya, K.;Matsuu, A.;Kawabata, T.;Koike, F.;Ito, M.;Furuya, T.;Taneno, A.;Akimoto, S.;Deguchi, E.;Ozawa, M.

title: Molecular characterization of canine cobuvirus in wild carnivores and domestic dogs in Africa
abstract: Knowledge of Kobuvirus (Family Picornaviridae) infection in carnivores is limited and has not been described in African domestic or wild carnivores. To fill this gap in knowledge, we used RT-PCR to screen fresh faeces from several African carnivores. We detected cobuvirus RNA in samples from the domestic dog, golden jackal, side-striped jackal, and spotted hyena. We obtained a complete Kobuvirus genome sequence from each of these strains using next-generation sequencing. Our phylogenetic analyzes revealed canine cobuvirus (CaKV) infection in all four species and placed CaKVs from Africa together and separately from CaKVs from elsewhere. Wild carnivorous strains were more closely related to each other than those obtained from domestic dogs. We found that the secondary structure pattern of IRES is similar to the Aichivirus-like subclass of IRES and is conserved among African strains. We identify the first CaKVs from Africa and expand the known CaKV host range.
authors: Olarte-Castillo, X. A.;Heeger, F.;Mazzoni, C. J.;Greenwood, A. D.;Fyumagwa, R.;Moehlman, P. D.;Hofer, H.;East, M. L.

title: Characterization of infectious laryngotracheitis virus isolates from the USA by polymerase chain reaction and restriction fragment length polymorphism of multiple genome regions
abstract: Infectious laryngotracheitis (ILT) is an acute viral respiratory disease primarily seen in chickens. The economic losses attributable to ILT affect many poultry producing regions in the United States (US) and around the world. Despite efforts to control the disease through vaccination, prolonged ILT outbreaks remain a threat to the poultry industry. Previous epidemiological and molecular evidence has shown that outbreaks in the US are caused by vaccine-related strains. In this study, polymerase chain reaction and restriction fragment polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) of four genome regions was used to characterize 25 isolates from commercial poultry and backyard flocks from the USA. Combinations of PCR-RFLP models classified ILT virus isolates into nine groups. Backyard swarm isolates were classified into three separate groups. The ILT virus US Department of Agriculture (USDA) reference strain and the tissue culture origin (TCO) vaccine strain were divided into two separate groups. Twenty-two isolates from commercial poultry were divided into four groups: one group of six isolates showed the same patterns as chicken embryo-derived (CEO) vaccines; a second group of nine isolates differed from CEO vaccines in only one model; a third group of two isolates differed from the TCO vaccine in only one model; A fourth group of five isolates differed from the CEO and TCO vaccines in six and nine models, respectively. The results from this study clearly showed that most of the commercial poultry isolates (17 out of 22 isolates) were closely related to the vaccine strains. However, different isolates from vaccine strains were also detected in commercial poultry. © 2007 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Oldoni, I.;GarcÃ­a, M.

title: Epidemiological research in single-species herds from Poland reveals expanded genetic and antigenic diversity of small ruminant lentiviruses.
abstract: Small ruminant lentivirus (SRLV) infections are common in Poland and the circulation of subtypes A1, A12, A13, B1 and B2 has been identified. The current study aimed to extend the previous study based on the analysis of larger numbers of animals than single-species herds. Animals were selected for genetic analysis based on serological reactivity to a number of recombinant antigens derived from Gag and Env viral proteins. Phylogenetic analysis revealed the presence of B2 and A12 subtypes in both goats and sheep, and A1 and B1 subtypes in goats only. In addition, two new subtypes, A16 and A17, were found in goats. Co-infection with strains of different subtypes in groups A and B was detected in 1 sheep and 4 goats from four herds. Although the reactivity of serum samples to recombinant antigens confirmed the immunological relationship between Gag epitopes of different subtypes and the cross-reactive nature of Gag antibodies, eleven serum samples did not react with antigens representing all subtypes currently detected in Poland. limitations of serological diagnosis. These data demonstrated the complex nature of SRLV subtypes circulating in sheep and goats in Poland and the need to improve SRLV-related diagnostic capacity.
authors: Olech, M.;Valas, S.;KuÅºmak, J.

title: Porcine B-cells recognize conserved epitopes between structural proteins of American and European porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus.
abstract: By selecting phage display libraries with immune serum from experimentally infected pigs, porcine B-cell epitopes in the open reading frame (ORF) and 2, 3, 5 and 6 proteins of European type porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) were identified. The sequences of all epitopes were well conserved in European-type PRRSV and even between European-type and American-type PRRSV. Accordingly, sera from pigs infected with American-type PRRSV cross-reacted with European-type epitopes. Thus, this study demonstrated for the first time the presence of highly conserved epitopes in the matrix protein and envelope glycoproteins of PRRSV. The ORF5 and 6 epitopes are localized to protein fragments that are predicted to be hidden in PRRSV virions. In contrast, the ORF2 and 3 epitopes were localized to putative protein ectodomains. Because of the interesting localization, the sequence surrounding the ORF2 and 3 epitopes was subjected to closer examination. ORF2 and the heptad motif VSRRIYQ, which is found in single copy in 3 proteins, were identified; this arrangement is fully conserved in all existing European type PRRSV sequences. Modeling of the VSRRIYQ repeat motif and secondary structure closely related to one of the ORF2 epitopes indicated that this segment of the ORF2 protein can form an amphipathic helix. Surprisingly, a mutation associated with virulence/attenuation of an American vaccine strain of PRRSV was also localized in this ORF2 protein segment and affected the hydrophobic facet of the predicted amphipathic helix. Further work is needed to determine whether these findings identify a functional domain in the PRRSV ORF2 protein.
authors: Oleksiewicz, M. B.;BÃ¸tner, A.;Normann, P.

title: Determination of the complete open reading frame sequence and the 5–²NTR of the Paderborn isolate of classic swine fever virus
abstract: The classic swine fever (CSF) epidemic in the Netherlands in 1997-1998 lasted 14 months, during which 429 infected and 1300 at-risk herds were culled, with an estimated economic cost of US$2 billion. Despite the overwhelming scale of epizootics, the CSFV strain causing the epidemic remains largely unidentified. Dutch epizootic is epidemiologically linked to a small CSF outbreak that occurred in Paderborn, Germany, in 1997. E2 and partial sequencing of 5–²NTR showed that the Paderborn isolate index and several Dutch isolates taken during the 1997-1998 epizootic were almost identical, confirming that the Paderborn isolate triggered the Dutch epidemic and also showed that this single isolate was stable. throughout the entire Dutch epidemic (reviewed above [C. Terpstra, AJ de Smit, Veterinary Microbiol. 77 (2000) 3-15]). We determined the nucleotide sequence of 5â€²NTR (by 5â€²RACE) and the fully open reading frame of the Paderborn isolate (GenBank AY072924). Our sequence was identical to the previously published partial sequences of 5–²NTR and E2 for the sequence Paderborn 1997 and Dutch 1997 (Venhorst) isolates, confirming the identity of the virus we sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis based on the full open reading frame showed that Paderborn was genetically very different from common European laboratory reference strains. Neutralization studies have shown that Paderborn is very different antigenically from common laboratory strains such as Alfort 187. Paderborn is the only novel European CSFV field isolate for which a complete sequence is available, and given the genetic and antigenic uniqueness of Paderborns, the Paderborn sequence may be practical. Use for diagnosis and vaccine antigen development. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Oleksiewicz, M. B.;Rasmussen, T. B.;Normann, P.;Uttenthal, Ã…

title: Screening of viral foreign agents in live attenuated avian vaccines using microbial microarray and sequencing
abstract: The absence of foreign agents (EA) in the raw materials and finished products used for production is one of the main safety aspects for all medical products of biological origin, such as live attenuated vaccines. The aim of this study was to explore the feasibility of Lawrence Livermore Microbial detection array version 2 (LLMDAv2) combined with whole genome amplification and sequencing for screening viral EAs in live attenuated vaccines and specific pathogen-free (SPF) eggs. We detected positive microarray signals for several viruses belonging to the avian endogenous retrovirus EAV-HP and Alpharetrovirus genera in all analyzed vaccines and SPF eggs. In addition to PCR analysis, several positive microarray signals most likely EAV-HPDELTApol and ALV-E ev1, ev3 and ev6 locus sequences originating from the chicken genome. Sequencing the vaccines on a MiSeq instrument confirmed the microarray findings and showed similar cross-hybridization. Our results show that sequencing of genomic microarrays and avian attenuated vaccines can be applied in EA assays.
authors: Olesen, M. L.;Jorgensen, L. L.;Blixenkrone-Moller, M.;Sandberg, E.;Frandsen, P. L.;Ostergaard, E.;Baekdahl, E. R.;Fridholm, H.;Fomsgaard, A.;Rosenstierne, M. W.

title: Genetic variability of HEV isolates: inconsistencies of current classification
abstract: In recent years, many HEV and HEV-like sequences have been reported within the family Hepeviridae, including isolates that may represent a number of potential new genera, new genotypes or new subtypes. Difficulties in establishing subtypes have been reported using the most common classification system. In addition, the relevance of subtype classification to epidemiology can be questioned. In this study, we performed phylogenetic analyzes based on the complete capsid gene and complete HEV genomic sequences to evaluate the current classification of HEV at the genotype and subtype levels. The results of our analyzes change the existing taxonomy of genotype 3 and improve the established system for typing HEV. In addition, we propose a classification for hepeviruses recently isolated from bats, ferrets, rats and wild boars. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Oliveira-Filho, E. F.;KÃ¶nig, M.;Thiel, H. J.

title: Virological and serological surveillance for human, swine, and avian influenza virus infections among pigs in the north-central United States
abstract: Influenza virus infection in pigs is both an animal health problem and a public health problem. Therefore, surveillance and characterization of influenza viruses in pigs is important to the veterinary community and should be part of human pandemic preparedness planning. Studies in 1976/1977 and 1988/1989 showed that pigs in the USA were commonly infected with classical swine H1N1 viruses, whereas human H3 and avian influenza virus infections were very rare. In contrast, human H3 and avian H1 viruses have been frequently isolated from pigs in Europe and Asia over the past two decades. From September 1997 to August 1998, we isolated 26 influenza viruses at cutoff point from pigs in the northern central United States. All 26 isolates were H1N1 viruses, and phylogenetic analyzes of hemagglutinin and nucleoprotein genes from 11 representative viruses indicated that they were classical porcine H1 viruses. However, monoclonal antibody analyzes revealed antigenic heterogeneity among the HA proteins of 26 viruses. Serologically, 27.7% of the 2,375 pigs tested had hemagglutination inhibitory antibodies to the classic swine H1 influenza virus. Of particular importance, however, is that seropositivity rates against avian H1 (7.6%) and human H3 (8.0%) viruses were significantly higher than in previous studies.
authors: Olsen, C. W.;Carey, S.;Hinshaw, L.;Karasin, A. I.

title: Characterization of swine-like reassortant H1N2 influenza virus isolated from a mallard in the United States.
abstract: In 2001, an H1N2 influenza virus (A/Duck/North Carolina/91347/01) (Dk/NC) was isolated from a mallard in the United States. Genetic analyzes showed that this duck virus has the same human/classic pig/bird. Reassortant genotype as H1N2 viruses isolated from pigs and turkeys in the USA since 1999. Phylogenetic analyzes of each gene segment further confirmed that Dk/NC virus was closely related to pet H1N2 isolates. In particular, Dk/NC is most closely related to a porcine H1N2 virus also isolated from North Carolina. These two viruses and an additional phylogenetically defined subset of porcine H1N2 viruses share a common mutation in the Sb antigenic region on the hemagglutinin protein. Recovery of Dk/NC from a wild bird raises concerns about the even more widespread distribution of these H1N2 viruses via waterfowl migration. Â© 2003 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Olsen, C. W.;Karasin, A.;Erickson, G.

title: Genetic changes in pigeon paramyxovirus type-1 caused by serial passages in chickens and virus-induced microscopic lesions in various avian hosts
abstract: Introduction: Genotype VI of avian avulavirus 1 (AAvV-1) has pigeons and pigeons as its reservoir and is often referred to as pigeon paramyxovirus type-1 (PPMV-1). The pathogenesis of PPMV-1 infections in poultry is largely unclear. PPMV-1 is known to require a series of crossings in chickens before adapting to biliary poultry. Material and Methods: Changes in the PPMV-1 genome were analyzed using high-throughput sequencing after serial passages in specific pathogen-free (SPF) chickens. In addition, histopathological lesions caused by PPMV-1 in experimentally vaccinated pigeons, chickens and turkeys were evaluated. Results: Following six PPMV-1 passages in chickens, 10 unnamed substitutions were found, including one (in the NP protein) that dominates the genetic pool of viral half-species. The histopathological changes induced by the post-passage PPMV-1 strain were more pronounced than those by the previously passaged PPMV-1 strain, with lesions most intensely seen in pigeons, followed by chickens and turkeys. Conclusion: PPMV-1 is highly adapted to pigeons and transmission from chickens results in the acquisition of new amino acids in the polymerase complex that can alter the pathogenic potential of the virus.
authors: Olszewska-Tomczyk, M.;Dolka, I.;ÅšwiÈ©toÅ„, E.;Åšmietanka, K.

title: Detection and Phylogenetic Studies of Chicken Anemia Virus in Polish Broiler Herds
abstract: Chicken anemia virus (CAV) is a common chicken pathogen of significant economic importance. In 2013, broiler flocks in Poland were examined for the presence of CAV and a phylogenetic relationship was established between the strains. Ten cloacal swabs were collected from 106 broiler flocks (3-6 weeks old birds) in different regions of the country and tested using real-time PCR (all samples) and conventional PCR (these samples were positive in real time). PCR) assays. The presence of CAV was detected in 16 of the tested flocks. Phylogenetic analysis clearly confirmed the existence of genetic diversity within the group of circulating CAV species and their distinctiveness from the vaccine strains used in Poland.
authors: Olszewska-Tomczyk, M.;ÅšwiÄ™toÅ„, E.;Minta, Z.;Åšmietanka, K.

title: Applying phylogenetic analysis to viral livestock diseases: Going beyond molecular typing
abstract: Changes in livestock production systems in recent years have changed the presentation of many diseases, resulting in the need for more complex control measures. At the same time, new molecular tests have been developed to support the diagnosis of animal viral disease. The nucleotide sequences produced by these diagnostic techniques can be used in phylogenetic analysis to infer sequence homology and phenotypes and to perform molecular epidemiology studies. In this review, some key elements of phylogenetic analysis are highlighted, such as the selection of the appropriate neutral phylogenetic marker, the appropriate phylogenetic method, and different techniques to test the reliability of the obtained tree. Examples of current and future applications of phylogenetic reconstructions in viral livestock diseases are given. Â© 2009 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Olvera, A.;Busquets, N.;Cortey, M.;Deus, N. d;Ganges, L.;NÃºÃ±ez, J. I.;Peralta, B.;Toskano, J.;Dolz, R.

title: Detection of enterovirus genome sequence from diarrheal stool of goat
abstract: Goat diarrheal stools were subjected to metagenome analysis by next-generation sequencing. Nucleotide sequences with homology to enteroviruses were obtained. Primers for RT-PCR were designed based on the nucleotide sequence of these sequences in the 5â€²-untranslated region, and we identified 563 bp nucleotide sequences showing homology to bovine and ovine enteroviruses (77-87%). We named the virus detected in this study as goat enterovirus G1 (GEV-G1). In phylogenetic analysis, GEV-G1 belonged to a cluster containing ovine enteroviruses. To our knowledge, this is the first report on the nucleotide sequences of an enterovirus infecting Japanese goats. Â© Springer Science+Business Media 2014.
authors: Omatsu, T.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Hirata, T.;Shiroma, Y.;Okazaki, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Nishiura, N.;Sassa, Y.;Furuya, T.;Nagai, M.;Ochiai, H.;Tamaki, S.;Mizutani, T.

title: Influenza A Virus: Phylogeny of Neuraminidase Primers and Amplification of Polymerase Basic Protein 2 and Neuraminidase Genes
authors: Omega, M.;Lai, R.;Hein, H.

title: Massively parallel sequencing: a new tool in virus discovery and vaccine safety
abstract: The introduction of new sequencing technologies revolutionizes virus discovery and provides a new tool to demonstrate the safety of vaccines. Because these methods did not depend on previous assumptions of virus types that might be present, they detected viruses that were missed by other methods, such as degenerate or family-specific PCRs. We used massively parallel sequencing (MP-Seq) to detect novel viruses in bovine serum and animal feces. When MP-Seq is applied to sequencing the transcriptome, it can reveal occult or silent infections. While sequencing technology is impressive, the key to its successful application is bioinformatics.
authors: Onions, D.

title: Ensuring the safety of vaccine cell substrates by substantially parallel sequencing of the transcriptome
abstract: The massively parallel, deep sequencing of the transcriptome combined with algorithmic analysis to identify random agents (MP-SeqTM) is an important aid in ensuring the safety of cells used in vaccine production. Such cells may harbor novel viruses of unknown sequence or latent viruses that are only expressed after stress has been applied to the cells. MP-Seq is an unbiased and comprehensive method for identifying such viruses and other incidental agents without prior knowledge of the nature of these agents. Here, we demonstrate its utility as part of an integrated approach to identify and characterize potential contaminants in widely used virus and vaccine production cell lines. Through this analysis, along with more traditional approaches, we excluded the presence of porcine circoviruses in the ATCC Vero cell bank (CCL-81), but found that a SRV-related full-length betaretrovirus could be expressed in these cells, a factor that may be important in the production of some vaccines. Similarly, insect cells have proven valuable for the production of virus-like particles and subunit vaccines, but they can harbor a range of latent viruses. We show that, following MP-Seq of the Trichoplusia ni (High Five cell line) transcriptome, we can detect a contaminating, latent nodavirus and identify an expressed errantivirus genome. Collectively, these studies have strengthened the role of MP-Seq as an integral tool for the identification of contaminating agents in vaccine cell substrates.
authors: Onions, D.;Cote, C.;Love, B.;Toms, B.;Koduri, S.;Armstrong, A.;Chang, A.;Kolman, J.

title: Uncovering vector, parasite, blood meal and microbiome patterns from mixed DNA samples of the Chagas disease vector Triatoma dimidiata.
abstract: Chagas disease, considered a neglected disease by the World Health Organization, is caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi and is transmitted by >140 triatomine species in the Americas. In Central America, the main vector is Triatoma dimidiata, an opportunistic blood meal feeder that lives in both local and syllabic ecotopes. Given the diversity of interacting biological agents involved in the epidemiology of Chagas disease, having simultaneous knowledge of the dynamics of the parasite, vector, the gut microbiome of the vector, and the blood meal source will facilitate the identification of key biotic factors associated with risk. T.cruzi gearbox. In this study, we developed a RADseq-based analysis line to examine mixed-species DNA extracted from T. dimidiata bellies. To evaluate the effectiveness of the method at spatial scales, we used a nested spatial sampling design ranging from individual villages in Guatemala to large biogeographic regions of Central America. Information from each biotic source was distinguished by bioinformatic tools and used to assess the prevalence of T. cruzi infection and dominant Discrete Typing Units (DTUs) in the region, population genetic makeup, gut microbial diversity, and blood meal of T. dimidiata. Date. An average of 3.25 million reads were obtained per sample, assigned to approximately 1% parasites, 20% vectors, 11% bacteria, and 4% putative blood meals. Using a total of 6,405 T. cruzi SNPs, we identified nine infected vectors harboring two different DTUs: TcI and a second unidentified strain, possibly TcIV. Vector samples were sufficiently variable for population genomic analyzes and all samples had a total of 25,710 T. dimidiata SNPs, sufficient to detect geographic genetic makeup at both local and regional scales. We observed a diverse microbiotic community in infected T. dimidiata abdomens with significantly higher bacterial species richness than uninfected ones. The Unifrac analysis suggests a common infection-associated bacterial community co-occurring with the typical gut microbial community derived from the local environment. We identified five T. dimidiata abdominal vertebrate blood meals, including chicken, dog, duck, and human; however, additional detection methods will be required to confidently identify sources of blood meal from most samples. Overall, our study shows that this method is effective for simultaneously generating genetic data on vectors and their associated parasites, as well as PCR-based parasite detection, 18S eukaryotic and 18S eukaryotic and 16S bacterial barcoding.
authors: Orantes, L. C.;Monroy, C.;Dorn, P. L.;Stevens, L.;Rizzo, D. M.;Morrissey, L.;Hanley, J. P.;Rodas, A. G.;Richards, B.;Wallin, K. F.;Helms Cahan, S.

title: Host-independent evolution and genetic classification of the Hepadnavirus family based on nucleotide sequences.
abstract: molecular phylogeny analysis was performed to examine whether the evolution of the Hepadnavirus family was host dependent. We constructed phylogenetic trees using the nucleotide sequences of 18 strains. The resulting trees show that all 12 strains of hepatitis B virus can be divided into four subgroups incompatible with conventional subtypes. We estimated the synonymous (silent) substitution rate for hepatitis B virus to be 4.57 x 10-5 per site per year. Applying this ratio to the phylogenetic tree, we estimated that the duck hepatitis B virus diverged from a common ancestor at the earliest about 30,000 years ago, the woodchuck hepatitis virus and ground squirrel hepatitis virus split about 10,000 years ago, and the hepatitis B virus itself split. This suggests that the hepadnavirus family evolved independently of host-species diversity, as these divergence times of viruses are much more recent than that of the host species.
authors: Orito, E.;Mizokami, M.;Ina, Y.;Moriyama, E. N.;Kameshima, N.;Yamamoto, M.;Gojobori, T.

title: Degenerate primers for PCR amplification and sequencing of the avian influenza A neuraminidase gene
abstract: This work describes the design of degenerate primers and their use for the synthesis of full-length avian influenza A neuramindase (NA). Each reaction was carried out using either two forward primers and one reverse primer, or one forward primer and one reverse primer. Both primer combinations had comparable amplification efficiencies for all NA subtypes (1-9). A total of 115 virus strains, including both field isolates and reference strains, were successfully amplified using these degenerate primer sets. Of the amplified sequences, 108 strains (93.9%) resulted in nearly full-length NA cDNAs after two reads with one forward primer and one reverse primer. Of the remaining sequences, five strains (4.3%) gave reads by BLAST with sufficient information for subtype classification, although they were of insufficient quality for assembly. While one strain (0.9%) gave different subtypes from both sequence reads, it was not possible to combine and subtype the other (0.9%). This successful demonstration of these degenerate primers for amplification and sequencing of all avian NA subtypes suggests that these primers can be used in avian influenza surveillance program as well as in studies of antiviral resistance, virus ecology or viral phylogeny.
authors: Orozovic, G.;Latorre-Margalef, N.;Wahlgren, J.;Muradrasoli, S.;Olsen, B.

title: In vitro surrogate models to aid the development of antivirals to control foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks
abstract: Foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV) is a highly pathogenic member of the genus Aphthovirus (family Picornaviridae) and is only manipulated in high-restriction facilities, thus complicating antiviral research and discovery of antiviral strategies against the virus. Bovine rhinitis B virus (BRBV) and equine rhinitis A virus (ERAV), which are most phylogenetically related to FMDV, have been investigated as surrogates of FMDV in antiviral studies. Although an effective cell culture system for BRBV has not been reported so far, we show that infection of primary bovine kidney cells results in extensive but rather weak reproducible induction of cytopathic effects (CPE). Madin-Darby bovine kidney cells supported viral replication in the absence of CPE. Antiviral tests have been developed for ERAV in Vero A cells using a viral RNA-reduction assay and CPE-reduction assay; the latter has a Z' factor of 0.83. ±. 0.07. The BRBV and ERAV models were then used to evaluate the anti-aftovirus activity of the two broad-spectrum antiviral agents 2'-C-methylcytidine (2CMC) and ribavirin, as well as the enterovirus-specific inhibitor enviroxime. The effects of the three compounds were comparable in CPE-reduction (ERAV) and viral RNA-reduction assays (BRBV and ERAV). Similar to 2CMC, compound A, a recently discovered non-nucleoside pan-serotype FMDV inhibitor, inhibited the replication of both BRBV and ERAV, while enviroxime lacked activity. The BRBV and ERAV surrogate models reported here can be manipulated in BSL-2 laboratories, facilitating studies to unravel the mechanism of action of new FMDV inhibitors. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Osiceanu, A. M.;Murao, L. E.;Kollanur, D.;Swinnen, J.;De Vleeschauwer, A. R.;Lefebvre, D. J.;De Clercq, K.;Neyts, J.;Goris, N.

title: Spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N1 subtype) in Bangladesh, 2010 and 2011
abstract: Since the global spread of the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 between 2005 and 2006, control programs have been successfully implemented in most affected countries. HPAI H5N1 was first reported in Bangladesh in 2007 and since then 546 outbreaks have been reported to the OIE. The disease has apparently become endemic in Bangladesh. Spatial-temporal information was analyzed on 177 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks that occurred in Bangladesh between February 2010 and April 2011, and 37 outbreaks in which H5N1 viruses isolated from these outbreaks were phylogenetically identified as clades. Three branches were identified, 2.2 (21 cases), 2.3.4 (2 cases), and 2.3.2.1 (14 cases). Clade 2.2 was identified over the time period and was widely distributed in a southeast-northwest direction. Item 2.3.2.1 arose later and was generally limited to central Bangladesh in a north-south direction. Based on directional testing, section 2.2 viruses spread from southeast to northwest, while section 2.3.2.1 spread from west to east. The diffusion size of section 2.3.2.1 was greater than that of section 2.2 (angular concentration 0.2765 vs. 0.1860). In both cases, the first outbreak(s) were identified as early outliers, but additionally, early outbreaks of item 2.2 (one each) were also detected in central Bangladesh and northwestern Bangladesh, which were significantly apart. Avian influenza H5N1 in Bangladesh is characterized by reported long-distance translocation events. This poses a challenge to disease control efforts. There is a need for greater enforcement of biosecurity and stronger control of movements between affected farms and sensitive farms, and better surveillance and reporting.
