Although the movement of poultry and equipment seems to be the more likely explanation for the identified patterns, the relative contribution of the trade and market chain to wild poultry in disease spread needs further investigation. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Osmani, M. G.;Ward, M. P.;Giasuddin, M.;Islam, M. R.;Kalam, A.

title: Some viral zoonoses transmitted by pets (author's translation) in Dutch
abstract: Besides dogs and cats, various other animals are more or less popular as pets in the Netherlands. It is important for the veterinarian to know what diseases can be transmitted to humans by these animals. From viral zoonoses. Rabies poses a threat to man, where dogs and to a lesser extent cats provide a link between man and free-living wild animals. Another viral zoonosis of interest in recent years is lymphocytic choriomeningitis (LCM), caused by a virus that is often latent in mice but can also be detected in young hamsters. A human disease caused by a pathogenic agent that should not be classified with viruses is chlamydia (psittacosis, ornithosis), this disease is usually transmitted to man by psittacin birds or pigeons. Pathogenic agents from the above disease, clinical manifestations in humans and animals, mode of transmission and possible preventive and therapeutic measures are discussed. Finally, the risk of transmission of viral zoonoses by less current "pets" is highlighted.
authors: Osterhaus, A. D.

title: Epidemiology and molecular characterization of chicken anemia virus from commercial and domestic chickens in Taiwan.
abstract: Chicken infectious anemia (CIA) is a disease with a very economic impact in the poultry industry. Infected chickens are characterized by aplastic anemia and excessive immunosuppression, followed by increased susceptibility to secondary infectious pathogens and inadequate immune responses to vaccination. Commercially available CIA vaccines are routinely used by breeders in Taiwan to protect their offspring with antibodies of maternal origin. However, CIA cases still occur in the field and little is known about the genetic characteristics of Taiwanese chicken anemia viruses (CAVs). In this study, CAV DNA was detected in 72 of 137 herds collected between 2010-2015. The coding regions of 51 CAVs were sequenced among the PCR positive samples. Phylogenetic analysis of the VP1 gene revealed that although most Taiwanese CAVs belonged to genotypes II and III, some isolates clustered into a new genotype (genotype IV). Furthermore, a Taiwanese isolate in this novel genotype IV appeared to be derived from a recombination event between genotype II and III viruses. The five Taiwanese CAV isolates were highly similar to the 26P4 or Del-Ros vaccine strains. Taken together, these results suggest that CAV sequences in Taiwan are variable and genotypic recombination has occurred between viruses of different genotypes. Furthermore, vaccine-like strains can induce clinical signs of CIA in chickens. Our findings may be useful for understanding the evolution of CAVs and developing a better control strategy for the CIA.
authors: Ou, S. C.;Lin, H. L.;Liu, P. C.;Huang, H. J.;Lee, M. S.;Lien, Y. Y.;Tsai, Y. L.

title: Phylogenetic variations of highly pathogenic H5N6 avian influenza viruses isolated from wild birds in the Izumi plain of Japan during the 2016-17 winter season.
abstract: During the 2016-2017 winter season, we isolated 33 highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIVs) and three low pathogenic avian influenza viruses (LPAIVs) of the H5N6 subtype from weakened or dead wild birds, duck droppings, and collected environmental water samples. The Izumi plain is a wintering place for migratory birds in Japan. Genetic analyzes of H5N6 HPAIV isolates revealed previously unreported phylogenetic variations in the PB2, PB1, PA and NS gene segments, allowing us to propose two new genotypes for contemporary H5N6 HPAIVs. In addition, analysis of four gene segments identified close phylogenetic relationships between our three LPAIV isolates and our contemporary H5N6 HPAIV isolates. Our results implied co-circulation and co-evolution of HPAIVs and LPAIVs within the same wild bird populations, thus emphasizing the importance of avian influenza surveillance targeting not only HPAIVs but also LPAIVs.
authors: Ozawa, M.;Matsuu, A.;Khalil, A. M.;Nishi, N.;Tokorozaki, K.;Masatani, T.;Horie, M.;Okuya, K.;Ueno, K.;Kuwahara, M.;Toda, S.

title: Theiler's virus genome is closely related to that of the prototypical cardiovirus, the encephalomyocarditis virus.
abstract: Theiler virus causes a persistent demyelinating infection of the mouse central nervous system. Our study of the molecular mechanism of persistence led us to the 1925 nucleotide sequence located at the 3' end of the viral genome. We observed extensive homologies between this region and the corresponding region of encephalomyocarditis virus, only some homologies with the 3' ends of the prototypical cardiovirus and foot-and-mouth disease virus, rhinovirus and polio virus genomes.
authors: Ozden, S.;Tangy, F.;Chamorro, M.;Brahic, M.

title: Genetic and epidemiological information on the emergence of peste des petits ruminant virus (PPRV) in Asia and Africa
abstract: Small ruminants are an important source of livelihood for millions of households in many parts of the world. The spread of the highly contagious peste des petits ruminant (PPR) disease, caused by PPRV, an RNA virus, to Asia and Africa remains a major concern. This study investigated the evolutionary and epidemiological dynamics of PPRV through analyzes of the virus' partial N-gene and F-gene sequences. All four previously identified PPRV lineages (I-IV) diverged from their common ancestor in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Among the four lineages, PPRV-IV showed significant region-wide genetic variation; however, haplotype sharing between geographic regions, together with the presence of multiple genetic clusters within a country, indicates the likelihood of frequent movement of diseased individuals across the region. The gradual decline in the number of effective infections points to a limited genetic variation attributable to effective vaccination that has been in place since the 1990s. However, movement of infected animals across the region likely contributes to the spread of PPRV-IV. No evidence of positive selection was identified from this study.
authors: Padhi, A.;Ma, L.

title: Time-dependent selection pressure on two arthropod-derived RNA viruses in the same serogroup
abstract: Understanding the genetic basis of viral adaptation to taxonomically diverse groups of host species living in different eco-climatic zones is crucial for the discovery of factors that support the successful establishment of these infectious pathogens in new hosts/environments. To gain insight into the dynamics of non-synonymous (dN) and synonymous substitutions (dS) and the ratio between the two (Ï‰ = dN/.dS), we analyzed data of the complete nucleotide coding sequence encoding the glycoproteins of the M segment. two negative-sense RNA viruses belonging to the same serogroup, Akabane virus (AKV) and Schmallenberg virus (SBV). AKV is relatively older and has circulated in ruminant populations since the 1970s, while SBV was first reported in 2011. Many times higher than AKV. Given the different evolutionary stages of the two viruses, most of the mildly deleterious mutations were likely cleared or kept at low frequency in the AKV genome, whereas positive selection, along with the accumulation of mildly deleterious mutations, may contribute to such an inflated mutation rate. SBV. Evolutionary distance (d) correlates nonlinearly and negatively with Ï‰ but positively with dN and dS. Collectively, the different patterns in Ï‰, dN, dS, and d between AKV and SBV identified in this study provide empirical evidence for a time-dependent selection pressure.
authors: Padhi, A.;Ma, L.

title: Detection and characterization of a new genotype of porcine astrovirus 4 from nasal swabs from pigs with acute respiratory disease.
abstract: Metagenomic sequencing of three nasal swab collected from 10-21-day-old pigs exhibiting unexplained acute respiratory disease from two different commercial production facilities in Oklahoma identified a novel porcine astrovirus 4 (PAstV-4) genotype. Genomes had only ~75% nucleotide sequence identity to previously characterized PAstV-4 isolates, whereas capsid-encoding ORF2 had only ~53% amino acid sequence identity to reference strains. A TaqMan assay targeting the novel ORF2 gene found incidences of 21% and 19%, respectively, in nasal and fecal swabs submitted for unrelated diagnostic testing. PAstV-4 RNA levels were significantly higher (PÂ =Â 0.04) in nasal swabs, suggesting a possible atypical respiratory tropism.
authors: Padmanabhan, A.;Hause, B. M.

title: Serological and molecular investigation of the prevalence of Aujeszky's disease in wild pigs (Sus scrofa) in the subregions of the Pantanal wetland, Brazil
abstract: The wild boar (FS) comes from the domestic swine and is found in the Brazilian marshy plain (Pantanal). Aujeszky disease (AD) was first confirmed serologically in 2001 in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul (MS); however, there was no viral confirmation. The aim of this study was to search for antibodies against -SuHV-1 in the sera of wild pigs in the studied areas, to detect SuHV-1 by PCR and to classify the viral genome. Of the 218 animals sampled, 186 were analyzed by ELISA and 88 (47.3%) reactive samples were obtained. In the serum neutralization test (SN), 57/179 (31.8%) samples showed antibodies to AD virus (SuHV-1). By nested PCR, 104 DNA samples were extracted for analysis and confirmed by amplification of a glycoprotein B (gB) fragment in five samples. SuHV-1 was detected in 12 samples using primers for glycoprotein E (gE) and the viral genome was classified as Type I by ul44 partial sequencing. Amplification of SuHV-1 glycoprotein fragments in fetuses of seropositive pigs indicates that vertical transmission contributes to the maintenance of SuHV-1 in a free-living wild pig population. The origin of AD in wild pig populations of the Pantanal is unknown, but determination of viral latency, vertical transmission of antigen and genome typing by amplification of SuHV-1 glycoprotein fragments in fetuses of seropositive pigs, and genome typing are illuminating the epidemiology of this disease in the wetlands of MS, Brazil. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Paes, R. D. C. D. S.;Fonseca, A. A.;Monteiro, L. A. R. C.;Jardim, G. C.;Piovezan, U.;Herrera, H. M.;Mauro, R. A.;Vieira-da-Motta, O.

title: Cardiac and skeletal muscle inflammation of farmed salmon is associated with a new reovirus infection.
abstract: Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar L.) farming has been associated with epidemics of infectious diseases that threaten not only local production, but also wild fish that come close to marine poultry and fish that escape from them. Cardiac and skeletal muscle inflammation (HSMI) is an often fatal disease of farm-raised Atlantic salmon. First recognized on a farm in Norway in 1999, HSMI later caused outbreaks on other farms in Norway and the United Kingdom[2]. Although studies of pathology and disease transmission showed an infectious basis, efforts to identify an agent were unsuccessful. Here we provide evidence that HSMI is associated with piscine reovirus (PRV) infection. PRV is a novel reovirus identified by unbiased high-throughput DNA sequencing and a bioinformatics program focused on nucleotide frequency as well as sequence alignment and motif analysis. The formal meaning of PRV in HSMI would require isolation in cell culture and fulfillment of Koch's assumptions, or prevention or modification of disease through the use of specific drugs or vaccines. However, as our data suggest that a causal relationship is plausible, measures must be taken to control PRV not only because it threatens native salmon production, but also because of its potential to infect wild salmon populations. Â© 2010 Palacios et al.
authors: Palacios, G.;Lovoll, M.;Tengs, T.;Hornig, M.;Hutchison, S.;Hui, J.;Kongtorp, R. T.;Savji, N.;Bussetti, A. V.;Solovyov, A.;Kristoffersen, A. B.;Celone, C.;Street, C.;Trifonov, V.;Hirschberg, D. L.;Rabadan, R.;Egholm, M.;Rimstad, E.;Lipkin, W. I.

title: High prevalence of Turkish parvovirus in Turkey, herds from Hungary experiencing enteric disease syndromes
abstract: In 2008 and 2009, samples collected from 49 turkeys aged 6 to 43 days, showing clinical signs of enteric disease and high mortality, were tested for the presence of viruses currently associated with enteric disease by polymerase chain reaction and reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction. (ED) syndromes: astrovirus, reovirus, rotavirus, coronavirus, adenovirus, and parvovirus. Turkish astroviruses were found in 83.67% of cases and turkey astrovirus 2 (TAst-2) in 26.53% of cases. Studies directly demonstrated the high prevalence of turkey parvovirus (TuPV) in 23 flocks (46.9%) experiencing symptoms of ED, making this pathogen the second most identified after astroviruses. Phylogenetic analysis on a 527 base pair long region from the NS1 gene revealed two main clusters, a chicken parvovirus (ChPV) and a TuPV group, but also the presence of a distinct branch of the tentatively named "TuPV-like ChPV" strains. 23 Hungarian TuPV strains were placed separately in two groups from strains of American origin in the TuPV cluster. An AvalII-based restriction fragment length polymorphism assay was also developed for rapid differentiation of TuPV, ChPV, and different TuPV-like ChPV strains. The epidemiology of this disease complex remains unclear, as most of the detected enteric viruses were also directly demonstrated in healthy turkey flocks, suggesting that a certain combination of pathogens, environmental factors, or both is required for the development of clinical manifestations. Â© American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Palade, E. A.;Demeter, Z.;HornyÃ¡k, A.;Nemes, C.;Kisary, J.;Rusvai, M.

title: Metagenomic-based screening and molecular characterization of viruses infecting cowpea in Burkina Faso.
abstract: Cowpea (Vigna unguiculata L. (Walp)) is an annual tropical grain legume. Commonly referred to as "poor man's meat", cowpea is one of the most important subsistence legumes grown in West Africa due to the high protein content of its seeds. However, African cowpea production can be severely restricted by viral diseases that reduce yields. Although the virus infecting twelve cowpea beans has been reported from Africa, only three of these have been reported from Burkina Faso so far. Here, we use virion-associated nucleic acids (VANA)-based metagenomic method to screen for the presence of cowpea viruses from plants collected from three agro-climatic regions of Burkina Faso. Besides the three cowpea-infecting virus strains previously reported from Burkina Faso (Copea aphid-borne mosaic virus [Family Potyviridae]), Blackeye cowpea mosaic virus - A strain of Bean common mosaic virus - [Family Potyviridae] and Cowpea spotted virus [Family Tombusviridae]) five additional viruses were identified: Southern cowpea mosaic virus (Sobemovirus genus), two previously uncharacterized polerovirus-like species (Family Luteoviridae), a previously uncharacterized tombusvirus-like species (Family Tombusviridae), and a previously uncharacterized mycotymovirus-like species (family Timoviridae). Overall, potyviruses were the most common cowpea viruses (detected in 65.5% of samples) and the South Sudan region of Burkina Faso was found to harbor the highest viral diversity and viral prevalence. Partial genome sequences of two new polerovirus-like and tombusvirus-like strains were determined and RT-PCR primers were designed for use in Burkina Faso for the routine detection of all these cowpea-associated viruses.
authors: Palanga, E.;Filloux, D.;Martin, D. P.;Fernandez, E.;Gargani, D.;Ferdinand, R.;ZabrÃ©, J.;Bouda, Z.;Neya, J. B.;Sawadogo, M.;Traore, O.;Peterschmitt, M.;Roumagnac, P.

title: A novel porcine circovirus, distantly related to known circoviruses, is associated with swine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome and reproductive failure.
abstract: Porcine circovirus-associated disease (PCVAD) is clinically manifested by post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome (PMWS), respiratory and enteric disease, reproductive failure, and swine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome (PDNS). Porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2) is an essential component of PCVAD, although its etiological role in PDNS has not been fully determined. Here, a novel circovirus, designated porcine circovirus 3 (PCV3), was identified in pigs that died acutely with PDNS-like clinical manifestations. The capsid and replicase proteins of PCV3 are only 37% and 55% identical to PCV2 and bat circoviruses, respectively. Fetuses from sows with PDNS contained high levels of PCV3 (7.57 × 107 genome copies/ml) and no other viruses were detected by PCR and metagenomic sequencing. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) analysis of porcine tissue samples identified PCV3 antigen in skin, kidney, lung, and lymph node samples localized in typical PDNS lesions, including necrotizing vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, granulomatous lymphadenitis, and bronchointerstitial pneumonia. Further study of archived PDNS tissue samples negative for PCV2 by IHC analysis identified 45 out of 48 positive for PCV3 by quantitative PCR (qPCR), and 60% of a subset tested positive for PCV3 by IHC analysis. Analysis by qPCR of 271 porcine respiratory disease diagnostic submission samples identified 34 PCV3 positive cases (12.5%), and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay detection of anti-PCV3 capsid antibodies in serum samples found 46 (55%) of 83 samples tested. positive. These results suggest that PCV3 is widely circulated in US pigs and may play an etiological role in reproductive failure and PDNS. Due to the high economic impact of PCV2, this new circovirus warrants further study to elucidate its importance and role in PCVAD.
authors: Palinski, R.;PiÃ±eyro, P.;Shang, P.;Yuan, F.;Guo, R.;Fang, Y.;Byers, E.;Hause, B. M.

title: Discovery of a novel Parvovirinae virus, porcine parvovirus 7, by metagenomic sequencing of porcine rectal swabs.
abstract: Parvoviruses are a diverse group of viruses that can infect a wide variety of animals, including some of the smallest known species. Metagenomic sequencing of pooled rectal swabs from adult pigs identified a 4103-bp contig consisting of two main open reading frames encoding proteins of 672 and 469 amino acids (aa) lengths. BLASTP analysis of the 672-aa protein found 42.4% identity with fruit bat (Eidolon helvum) parvovirus 2 (EhPV2) and 37.9% with turkey parvovirus (TuPV) TP1-2012/HUN NS1 proteins. The 469-aa protein had no significant similarity to known proteins. Genetic and phylogenetic analyzes show that PPV7, EhPV2 and TuPV represent a new genus in the Parvoviridae family. Quantitative PCR scanning of 182 porcine diagnostic samples found a total of 16 positive (8.6%Â). Together, these data suggest that PPV7 is a highly different novel parvovirus common in US pigs.
authors: Palinski, R. M.;Mitra, N.;Hause, B. M.

title: Molecular cloning and sequence analysis of the duck enteritis virus UL5 gene
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) is a herpes virus that causes an acute, contagious and fatal disease. In this article, the DEV UL5 gene was cloned and sequenced from a vaccinia virus. According to the consensus sequence of herpesvirus, UL5 and UL3 gene degenerate oligonucleotide primers were designed and used to amplify 4577 bp DNA products in polymerase chain reaction (PCR). DNA sequence analysis revealed a 2568 bp open reading frame (ORF) encoding an 855 amino acid polypeptide homologous to the herpes virus UL5 proteins. The DEV UL5 gene has a base composition of 769 adenines (29.95%), 556 cytosines (21.65%), 533 guanines (20.76%), and 710 thymines (27.65%). Sequence comparison revealed that the nucleotide sequence of the DEV UL5 gene was quite similar to other alphaherpes viruses. Phylogenetic tree analysis showed that the fifteen herpesvirus viruses analyzed were divided into four large groups, with duck enteritis virus itself branching and most closely related to meleagrid herpesvirus 1, gallid herpesvirus 2, and gallid herpesvirus 3 subtrees. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Pan, H.;Cao, R.;Liu, L.;Niu, M.;Zhou, B.;Chen, P.;Hu, J.

title: Molecular characterization of the duck enteritis virus UL4 gene
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) is a herpes virus that causes an acute, contagious and fatal disease. In this article, the DEV UL4 gene was cloned and sequenced from a vaccinia virus. A degenerate oligonucleotide primer for the consensus region of the herpesvirus UL3 gene and a specific primer located at UL5 were used in polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to amplify a 2 086 bp DNA product. DNA sequence analysis revealed that a 714 bp open reading frame (ORF) of DEV, which encodes a 237 amino acid polypeptide, is homologous to the herpes virus UL4 family of proteins and has therefore been characterized as a DEV UL4 gene. Alignment of the DEV UL4 protein sequence with that of other alphaherpes viruses showed that the 10 amino acid residues were fully conserved. The phylogenetic tree analysis shows that the seventeen alphaherpes virus viruses analyzed are divided into four large groups and the duck enteritis virus branches separately, Gallid herpes virus 2 (GaHV-2), Gallid herpes virus 3 (GaHV-3) and Gallid herpes virus 3 ( showed that it is closely related to the group of Mardiviruses containing GaHV-3. Meleagrid herpes virus 1 (MeHV-1). This study demonstrated that the evolutionary relevance of the UL4 protein can be used for classification of alphaherpes viruses. Â© Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer-Verlag GmbH 2009.
authors: Pan, H. Q.;Wang, N.;Liu, L.;Liu, L.;Hu, J. C.;Chen, P. Y.;Wang, S. J.;Cao, R. B.

title: Glycoprotein GP85 glycoprotein and phylogenetic analysis of ALV-J isolates from Mainland China between 1999 and 2010: Coexistence of two highly divergent subgroups in strata.
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J), first isolated in 1989, preferentially infects meat-type birds. However, layer flocks in China have experienced outbreaks of this virus since 2008. To understand the genetic diversity of ALV-J in Chinese eggs, we compared and analyzed the GP85 gene sequences of 106 ALV-J isolates isolated between 1999 and 2010. Chinese territory. The GP85 gene sequences of 41 layered isolates collected from 9 provinces of China between 2008 and 2010 belonged to two distinct, highly diverse subgroups and were distinguished from meat-type chicken isolates. Compared with all meat-type isolates from China, Subgroup 1 included only existing layer isolates and appeared to be dominant; all isolates in this subgroup exhibited gene diversity and many unique amino acid mutations were present. In contrast, the viruses in Subgroup 2 were perfectly conserved and shared high identity with the prototype meat-type chicken ALV-J strain HPRS-103. The two subgroups contained only two simultaneous mutations at the same position. Also, most isolates in Subgroup 1 had two additional glycosylation sites (at positions 101 and 191) compared with those in Subgroup 2. 2010 supports the need for vaccine development and purification measures to prevent ALV-J infection in layers in China. © 2011.
authors: Pan, W.;Gao, Y.;Qin, L.;Ni, W.;Liu, Z.;Yun, B.;Wang, Y.;Qi, X.;Gao, H.;Wang, X.

title: Modulation of the host miRNA transcriptome in the lung and spleen of sheep and goats infected with ruminant peste des petits virus.
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is one of the highly contagious viral diseases that primarily affects sheep and goats, characterized by fever, mouth pain, conjunctivitis, gastroenteritis and pneumonia. Reports suggested variable host response in goats and sheep, and this host response was not investigated against expression of microRNAs (miRNAs). Here, miRNAs were sequenced and proteomic data were generated to determine the role of differentially expressed miRNA (DEmiRNA) in PPR virus (PPRV)-infected lung and spleen tissues of sheep and goats. 67 and 37 DEmiRNAs were identified in the lungs of goats and sheep, respectively. Similarly, 50 and 56 DEmiRNAs were identified in the spleen in goats and sheep, respectively. A total of 20 and 11 miRNAs were found to be co-differentiated in PPRV-infected spleen and lung, respectively, in both species. Six DEmiRNAs-miR-21-3p, miR-1246, miR-27a-5p, miR-760-3p, miR-320a and miR-363 were selected based on their roles in viral infections, apoptosis and fold change. Target prediction analysis of these six DEmiRNAs selected from the generated proteome data revealed greater numbers of genes involved in the lungs and spleens of goats than in sheep. In gene ontology analysis of host target genes, these DEmiRNAs were found to regulate several immune response signaling pathways. Your roads viz. T cell receptor signaling, Rap1 signaling, Toll-like receptor signaling, and B cell receptor signaling mediated by DEmiRNAs were more disturbed in goats than in sheep. The data suggest that PPRV-induced miR-21-3p, miR-320a and miR-363 may act cooperatively to enhance viral pathogenesis in sheep lung and spleen by downregulating several immune response genes. The study provides important insight into the molecular pathogenesis of PPR by determining that the PPRV-Izatnagar/94 isolate elicits a stronger host response in goats than in sheep.
authors: Pandey, A.;Sahu, A. R.;Wani, S. A.;Saxena, S.;Kanchan, S.;Sah, V.;Rajak, K. K.;Khanduri, A.;Sahoo, A. P.;Tiwari, A. K.;Mishra, B.;Muthuchelvan, D.;Mishra, B. P.;Singh, R. K.;Gandham, R. K.

title: Genomic diversity and adaptation of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium from analysis of six genomes of different phage types.
abstract: Background: Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium (or simply Typhimurium) is the most common serovar in both human infections and livestock in Australia and many other countries. Typhimurium is a wide host range serovar, but has also evolved into host-adapted variants (ie isolated from a particular host such as pigeons). Six Typhimurium strains from different phage types (identified by their susceptibility patterns to degradation by a number of bacteriophages) were analyzed using Illumina high-throughput genome sequencing. Results: Variations between strains were mainly due to single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) with an average of 611 SNPs per strain, from 391 to 922 SNPs. There were seven insertions/deletions (indel) involving complete or partial gene deletions, four inactivation events due to IS200 insertion, and 15 pseudogenes due to premature termination. Four of these inactivated or deleted genes may be related to virulence. Nine prophage or prophage residues were detected in six strains. Gifsy-1, Gifsy-2, and sopE2 and sspH2 phage residues were present in all six genomes, while Fels-1, Fels-2, ST64B, ST104 and CP4-57 were variably present. Four strains carried the 90 kb plasmid pSLT containing several known virulence genes. However, two strains were found to lack the plasmid. In addition, one strain had a novel plasmid similar to the Typhi strain CT18 plasmid pHCM2. Conclusion: Genome data indicate that variations between strains are mainly due to accumulation of SNPs, some of which result in gene inactivation. No unique genetic elements common between host-adapted phage species were found. This work has improved our understanding of the evolution and adaptation of Typhimurium at the genomic level. Â© 2013 Pang et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Pang, S.;Octavia, S.;Feng, L.;Liu, B.;Reeves, P. R.;Lan, R.;Wang, L.

title: Detection of a mammal-like astrovirus in bird, European cylinder (Coracias garrulus)
abstract: Astroviruses are small, non-enveloped viruses with positive sense, single-stranded RNA genomes. The Astroviridae family includes two genera, Mamastrovirus and Avastrovirus, which infect mammals and birds, respectively, based on our current knowledge. However, recent seroprevalence study has shown that people who come into contact with turkeys may develop serological responses to turkey astrovirus and minks may be infected with aastrovirus. These data suggest that the "host species/astrovirus genus" relationship should be permeable; however, mamastrovirus infection from avian species has not yet been reported. In this study, a novel astrovirus was identified by viral metagenomic and RT-PCR methods in 2 (11%) of 19 stool samples collected from European rollers (. Coracias garrulus), a wild, carnivorous bird species from two breeding sites in Hungary. . The complete genome sequence of astrovirus Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011 (KP663426) was 7025 nt long and had some unique genomic features, including an unusually long spacer between the subgenomic RNA promoter and the ORF2 initiation codon. Use of BLASTp Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011 has been shown to attack MAstV 32 (JF713710, host: pig), MAstV 23 (JF729316, host: rabbit) and unclassified porcine astrovirus (JX684071) in ORF1a, ORF1b and ORF2, respectively. . The same proteins of Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011 had 25%, 66% and 33% aa identity with the corresponding proteins of murine astrovirus (JX544743) as the closest strain. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis showed that Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011 represents the first member of a new mamastrovirus species. The data suggest that both mammals and birds may have been exposed to mamastroviruses and avastroviruses, which provide opportunities for interspecies infection and viral adaptation with cross-class astroviruses, particularly in carnivorous animals. Further research is needed to determine the origin, natural host species spectrum, distribution and spread of Er/SZAL6/HUN/2011 among vertebrates.
authors: Pankovics, P.;Boros, A.;Kiss, T.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: First detection of nebovirus (Caliciviridae) in stool sample of calf with diarrhea in Hungary
abstract: Neboviruses are the newest members of the Nebovirus genus Calicivirdae family, which can be the etiological agents of diarrhea and intestinal diseases of calves (Bos taurus). There are two prototypes of the genus: Newbury-1 (Bo/Newbury1/1976/ UK, DQ013304) and Nebraska (BEC/NB/80/US, AY082891) viruses. Based on the viral capsid protein (VP1), neboviruses are classified into 4 phylogenetic lineages (lineage 1-4). The authors' aim is the detection, genetic characterization and phylogenetic classification of neboviruses from 1-1 stool samples collected from diarrheal calves living in two different cattle farms in Hungary. After routine diagnostic bacteriological and virological research, detection of nebovirus and whole genome detection were performed by molecular biological methods (454-pyrosequencing, RT-PCR, 5'/3' RACE RT-PCR and direct chain termination sequencing). Using the pyrosequencing method, contigs of nebovirus sequences were aligned from one of the stool samples and the complete viral genome was amplified with the aid of an additional 4 RT-PCR reactions. Bo/M3641/2011/HUN (JX018212) nebovirus - 5'UTR (74nt)/ORF1 (6630nt)/ORF2 (677nt)/3'UTR(67nt) - has a genome of 7453nt long and Bo/BEC/Penrith140/2000/UK 95% nucleotide match to the virus. The strain Bo/M3641/2011/HUN virus can be phylogenetically classified as strain 1; Newbury-1-like phylogenetic group. In this study, the authors report that the initial detection, characterization and phylogenetic analysis of nebovirus, the pseudo-pathogenic agents, are already available in Hungarian cattle herds and may contribute to diarrheal diseases of calves of unknown origin.
authors: Pankovics, P.;Boros, A.;Nemes, C.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Molecular characterization of a novel picobirnavirus in a chicken
abstract: Picobirnaviruses (PBVs) are bipartite viruses with a wide geographic and host species distribution. The number of new PBV sequences is increasing with the help of viral metagenomics. A new picobirnavirus strain, pbv/CHK/M3841/HUN/2011, was identified by viral metagenomics; complete segments 1 (MH327933) and 2 (MH327934) sequences were obtained by RT-PCR from a cloacal sample of a diseased broiler breeder pullet in Hungary. Although conserved nucleotide (eg, ribosome binding site) and amino acid motifs (eg, ExxRxNxxxE, motifs in the S domain of the viral capsid and RNA-dependent RNA polymerase) could be identified in the chicken picobirnavirus genome, putative segment 1 showed that woodchuck and dromedary PBVs low (<30%) amino acid sequence identity to their corresponding proteins, while segment 2 showed higher (<70%) amino acid sequence identity to a wolf PBV protein sequence. This is the first complete genome picobirnavirus sequence from a broiler chicken, but the pathogenicity of this virus is still controversial.
authors: Pankovics, P.;Boros, Ã;Nemes, C.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: A new passerivirus (Picornaviridae family) in an epidemic of enteritis with high mortality in estrildid finches (Uraeginthus sp.)
abstract: An enteric outbreak with high mortality (34/52, 65.4%) was recorded in home-grown estrildid finches (Estrildidae) in Hungary in 2014. A novel paserivirus was identified in a diseased violet-eared waxwing beak using viral metagenomics and confirmed by RT-(q)PCR. The complete genome of Finch picornavirus strain waxbill/DB01/HUN/2014 (MF977321) showed the highest amino acid sequence identity to passerivirus A1 (GU182406) at 38.9%, 61.6%, 69.6% in P1cap, 2Chel and 3CproDpol, respectively. A high viral load (6.58Â x 1010 genomic copies/ml) was measured in a sample of cloaca and in tissues (spinal cord, lung and intestines) of two additional affected finches. In addition to intestinal symptoms (diarrhea), the presence of extra-intestinal virus suggests a generalized infection in this deadly disease in which passerivirus may be a causative agent.
authors: Pankovics, P.;Boros, Ã;Phan, T. G.;Delwart, E.;Reuter, G.

title: Enteric viruses detected by molecular methods in commercial chicken and turkey flocks in the United States between 2005 and 2006.
abstract: Intestine samples collected from 43 commercial broiler and 33 commercial turkey flocks from all regions of the United States in 2005 and 2006 were examined for the presence of astrovirus, rotavirus, reovirus, and coronavirus by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Presence of group 1 and 2 adenovirus by PCR. Phylogenetic analysis was performed to further characterize viruses and to evaluate species association and geographic patterns. Astroviruses were detected in samples from 86% of chicken flocks and 100% of turkey flocks. Both chicken astrovirus and avian nephritis virus (ANV) were identified in chicken samples, and generally both viruses were detected in the same flock. Turkey astrovirus type-2 and turkey astrovirus type-1 were found in 100% and 15.4% of turkey flocks, respectively. In addition, 12.5% of turkey flocks were positive for ANV. Rotaviruses were present in 46.5% of chicken flocks tested and 69.7% of turkey flocks tested. Based on the rotavirus NSP4 gene sequence, chicken and turkey rotaviruses are classified in a species-specific manner. Rotaviruses originating from Turkey are also diversified according to geographical location. Reoviruses were detected in 62.8% and 45.5% of chicken and turkey flocks, respectively. Based on the reovirus S4 gene segment, chicken and turkey viruses were classified separately and differed from all previously reported avian reoviruses. Coronavirus was detected in the intestinal contents of chickens, but not in turkeys. Adenoviruses were not detected in any chicken or turkey flock. Of a total of 76 chicken and turkey flocks tested, only three were negative for all viruses targeted by this study. Most of the swarms were positive for two or more viruses and overall there was no clear pattern of the geographic distribution of the virus. This study provides updated enteric virus prevalence data for the United States using molecular methods and reinforces the prevalence of enteric viruses in poultry in the United States, although the clinical significance of many of these viruses remains unclear.
authors: Pantin-Jackwood, M. J.;Day, J. M.;Jackwood, M. W.;Spackman, E.

title: Periodic monitoring of commercial turkeys for enteric viruses indicates the continued presence of astrovirus and rotavirus on farms.
abstract: longitudinal study was conducted using molecular detection methods to detect enteric viruses in gut contents collected from turkeys at eight commercial operations and one research facility. Intestinal contents were collected from turkeys prior to placement, with each flock resampled at 2, 4, 6, 8, 10, and 12 weeks of age. Samples were screened for astrovirus, rotavirus, reovirus and turkey coronavirus (TCoV) by a reverse transcriptase and polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and for group 1 and 2 adenovirus by PCR. Rotavirus was the only virus detected prior to insertion (7 out of 16 samples examined). All commercial flocks were positive for rotavirus and astrovirus at 2 to 6 weeks of age, and most were intermittently positive up to 12 weeks of age when the birds were handled. Of 96 samples collected from farm birds, 89.5% were positive for astrovirus and 67.7% for rotavirus. All flocks were negative for TCoV, reovirus and group 1 adenovirus at all time points and positive for group 2 adenovirus (hemorrhagic enteritis virus) at week 6. All monitored flocks were considered healthy or normal by field personnel. Turkeys placed in research facilities that had been empty and thoroughly cleaned for months had higher body weights and lower feed conversion rates at 5 weeks of age than turkeys placed on commercial farms. Intestinal samples from these turkeys at 1, 2, and 3 weeks of age were free of enteric virus. This report shows that astroviruses and rotaviruses can be present in a turkey flock throughout the life of the flock. Comparison of birds infected with a group of turkeys negative for enteric viruses with the methods used herein suggests that astrovirus and/or rotavirus may affect production. The exact impact on herd performance needs to be further determined.
authors: Pantin-Jackwood, M. J.;Spackman, E.;Day, J. M.;Rives, D.

title: Molecular characterization and typing of chicken and turkey astroviruses circulating in the United States: Implications for diagnosis
abstract: Avian astroviruses were detected by reverse transcriptase and polymerase chain reaction in intestinal contents collected from commercial chickens and turkeys in the United States from 2003 to 2005. Astroviruses were detected in birds from both healthy and underperforming flocks with or without enteric disease. Phylogenetic analysis was performed with sequence data obtained from polymerase (ORF-1b) genes of 41 turkey astroviruses and 23 chicken astroviruses. All currently available avian astrovirus sequence data and selected mammalian astrovirus sequence data were included in the analysis. Four groups of avian astroviruses were observed by phylogenetic analysis: turkey astrovirus type 1 (TAstV-1)-like viruses, turkey astrovirus type 2 (TAstV-2)-like viruses, both detected in turkeys; avian nephritis virus (ANV)-like viruses detected in both chickens and turkeys; and a new group of chicken-borne astroviruses (CAstV). Amino acid identity between these four groups ranged from 50.1% to 73.8% for all avian isolates, with a maximum of 49.4% compared with mammalian astroviruses. There were multiple phylogenetic subgroups based on 9% nucleotide sequence differences within the TAstV-2, ANV, and CAstV groups. Phylogenetic analysis showed no clear variation by geographic region or date of isolation. Also, no association was observed between the detection of a particular astrovirus and the presence of enteric disease or poor performance. Based on these data, a revision of the current taxonomic classification for avian astroviruses within the genus Avastrovirus is warranted.
authors: Pantin-Jackwood, M. J.;Spackman, E.;Woolcock, P. R.

title: Two oncogenes in avian carcinoma virus MH2: myc and mht
abstract: The 5.2-kilobase (kb) RNA genome of avian carcinoma MH2 has 5' - delta gag (0.2 kb)-mht (1.2 kb)-myc (1.4 kb)-c(0.4 kb)-poly (A) genetic structure. (0.2kb)-3'. delta gag is a partial retroviral core protein, mht and myc are cell-derived MH2-specific sequences, and c is the 3'-terminal retroviral vector sequence. The following results were obtained from the complete nucleotide sequences of the mht and myc genes in MH2. (i) delta gag-mht constitutes a hybrid gene with a contiguous reading frame of 2682 nucleotides that ends with a stop codon near the 3' end of the mht gene. The 3' 969 nucleotides of mht up to the stop codon are 80% sequence related to the onc-specific raf sequence of murine sarcoma virus 3611 (MSV 3611) (94% homologous at the amino acid level removed). (ii) The myc coding region in MH2 is preceded by 181 nucleotides derived from the intron just upstream of the second exon of the chicken cellular proto-myc gene, followed by an RNA splice acceptor region shared with the proto-myc gene, followed by an RNA splice acceptor shared with proto-myc site is in line beyond that to the 3'-termination codon and 40 non-coding nucleotides with the sequences of avian retrovirus MC29 and chicken proto-myc myc. Thus myc forms a second MH2-specific gene together with a 5' retroviral exon. It was concluded that MH2 contains two genes with oncogenic potential, the delta gag-mht gene, which is closely related to the delta gag-raf transforming gene of MSV 3611, and the myc gene, which is closely related to the MC29 transforming gene. It can also be concluded that cellular proto-onc genes that become viral onc genes in sequence transduction are a small group, as 5 out of 19 known onc sequences are shared by different taxonomic virus groups of mht/raf. homology is the closest so far.
authors: Papas, T. S.;Kan, N. C.;Watson, D. K.;Flordellis, C.;Lautenberger, J. A.;Psallidopoulos, M. C.;Rovigatti, U. G.;Samuel, K. P.;Ascione, R.;Duesberg, P. H.

title: Classification and characterization of a laboratory chicken rotavirus strain carrying G7P[35] neutralization antigens on the genotype 4 backbone gene configuration.
abstract: The laboratory rotavirus strain, BRS/115, has been used for over two decades to monitor rotaviruses in certain pathogen-free layers of hen flocks. However, the virus strain has not been characterized in detail. Therefore, we aimed to identify the molecular properties of BRS115 using randomly prepared reverse transcription-PCR of genomic RNA followed by large parallel sequencing using semiconductor sequencing technology. More than 64,000 trimmed reads mapped to reference sequences from GenBank. The strain is classified as Rotavirus strain A and genotyped G7-P[35]-I4-R4-C4-M4-A16-N4-T4-E11-H4 according to the guidelines of the Rotavirus Classification Working Group. Phylogenetic analysis identified common features with chicken, turkey and pigeon-derived rotaviruses. This study demonstrates the robustness of next-generation sequencing in the characterization of reference virus materials used in private laboratories.
authors: Papp, H.;Marton, S.;Farkas, S. L.;Jakab, F.;Martella, V.;Malik, Y. S.;Palya, V.;BÃ¡nyai, K.

title: Phylogenetic tracing of current swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) strains in the Philippines.
abstract: To trace the possible route of entry of swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV), phylogenetic relationships of PEDV strains from epidemic sites in the Philippines with PEDV strains endemic in other countries were investigated. Partial nucleotide sequences of the S1 spike gene were determined from PEDV-positive samples and compared with S1 sequences from other countries. Phylogenetic analysis showed that PEDV strains in the Philippines were divided into two groups. Members of group 1 relate to strains from the USA, Taiwan, Japan and Canada, while those of group 2 relate to strains from China and Vietnam.
authors: Paraguison-Alili, R.;Domingo, C. Y.

title: Ten years (2004-2014) influenza surveillance in northern Italy
abstract: As the regional influenza reference center operating within the Italian network InfluNet, we report here data on virological and epidemiological surveillance of influenza, as well as vaccine coverage rates achieved in Lombardy (Northern Italy) over 10 consecutive winter seasons (2004-2014). . In the last 10 years, influenza vaccine coverage has declined both in the general population (from 15.7% in 2004-2005 to 11.7% in 2013-2014) and in the vaccine-targeted population of 65-year-olds. (from 65.3% in 2004-2005 to 48.6% in 2013-2014) and well below the planned minimum threshold (75%). The highest rates of influenza-like illness (ILI) were recorded during the 2004-2005 and 2009-2010 epidemics (highest incidences: 12.04– and 13.28–, respectively). Both seasons were characterized by the introduction of new viral strains: A/Fujian/411/2002(H3N2) (an entrained hemagglutinin variant) and A/California/7/2009(H1N1) pandemic virus (a swine quadruple reassortant), . As the antigenic compatibility between the vaccine and the circulating strains was good in both seasons, a significant portion of the cases could have been prevented by the vaccine. A different situation was observed in the 2011-2012 season, in which ILI morbidity rates in individuals aged 65 years were 1.5-6 times higher than those recorded during the other outbreaks studied. Higher morbidity resulted from circulation in the 2011-2012 season of a variant similar to A/Victoria/361/2011(H3N2) that presented a reduced genetic match to the A(H3N2) strain included in the 2011-2012 vaccine composition. Continuous surveillance of the traits of circulating viruses is an important tool for monitoring their mating with seasonal vaccine strains. Strategies to increase coverage rates are guaranteed.
authors: Pariani, E.;Amendola, A.;Piatti, A.;Anselmi, G.;Ranghiero, A.;Bubba, L.;Rosa, A. M.;Pellegrinelli, L.;Binda, S.;Coppola, L.;Gramegna, M.;Zanetti, A.

title: Molecular detection and genetic characterization of cobuviruses in stool samples collected from cattle with diarrhea in Korea.
authors: Park, S. J.;Kim, H. K.;Song, D. S.;Moon, H. J.

title: Whole genome analysis of a novel adenovirus from the Antarctic South Pole skua (Cathracta maccormicki)
abstract: Adenoviruses have been described in humans and a wide variety of vertebrates, but not previously in the polar region. Here we report the complete 26,340-bp genome of a novel adenovirus detected by PCR in the tissues of six of nine South Pole skua (Catharacta maccormicki) collected from King Sejong Lake, Antarctica, King George Island, Antarctica from 2007 to 2009. The DNA polymerase, penton base, hexon and fiber genes of Southern Polar squamous adenovirus (SPSAdV) exhibited 68.3%, 75.4%, 74.9% and 48.0% nucleotide sequence similarity with their counterparts in turkey hemorrhagic enteritis virus. Whole genome-based phylogenetic analysis revealed that SPSAdV belongs to the genus Siadenovirus, family Adenoviridae. This is the first evidence of a new adenovirus, SPSAdV, from a large arctic seabird (family Stercorariidae) from Antarctica.
authors: Park, Y. M.;Kim, J. H.;Gu, S. H.;Lee, S. Y.;Lee, M. G.;Kang, Y. K.;Kang, S. H.;Kim, H. J.;Song, J. W.

title: Focus: The Microbiome: The Ecological Framework of the Human Virus Classifies Current Knowledge and Defines Future FieldsÂ â€¦
authors: Parker, M. T.

title: Characterization of Wongorr virus, an Australian orbivirus
abstract: Sequence analyzes of the VP3 gene segments of Wongorr virus isolates from the Northern Territory of Australia were compared with the cognate gene segments of Picola and Paroo River viruses. Previous serological studies had shown some association between these viruses, but VP3 gene sequence and phylogenetic analyzes placed these viruses within the same serogroup, unlike the other orbivirus serogroups described. A polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was developed for the detection of this serogroup and was used to identify and determine partial sequence data for other isolates of the virus. Wongorr virus and other tick- and mosquito-borne orbiviruses (Kemerovo and Corriparta) were more closely related than Culicoides-transmitted orbiviruses such as bluetongue (BTV) and African equine disease virus (AHSV), which were shown to be in a separate clade. from the orbivirus phylogenetic tree.
authors: Parkes, H.;Gould, A. R.

title: Rumen virome: evaluation of viral communities and their functions in the rumen of an Indian buffalo.
abstract: Viruses play a key role in stabilizing the bacterial population in any ecosystem of the planet. Being a very diverse ecosystem, the Romanian is still understudied for its viral communities and metabolic capabilities. We performed shotgun sequencing of enriched viral particles from rumen fluid collected from an Indian buffalo. The study revealed that the well-joined contigs of Newbler and Velvet had most of the assignments in the virus domain, making Caudovirales a grand order. Most of the Firmicutes bacteriophages were found in the study, which also confirms the presence of conserved domains such as peptidases against Firmicutes phages.
authors: Parmar, N. R.;Jakhesara, S. J.;Mohapatra, A.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Development of cDNA probes for typing group A bovine rotaviruses based on VP4 specificity
abstract: For P typing of group bovine rotaviruses (BRV), Dot and Northern (RNA) blot hybridization experiments were developed using cDNA probes prepared from gene segment 4. Probes were prepared by polymerase chain reaction amplification of hyperdivergent regions (nucleotides 211 to 686). ) using specific oligonucleotide primers of BRV strain UK, IND, NCDV and Cr VP4 cDNA. The probes were P-type specific (VP4) and showed little or no cross-reactivity with double-stranded RNA from heterologous rotavirus P-types. Our studies show that among the seven BRV isolates tested, there are at least three P-types identified by VP4 gene probes derived from polymerase chain reaction from UK, NCDV and Cr strains.
authors: Parwani, A. V.;Rosen, B. I.;McCrae, M. A.;Saif, L. J.

title: Complete genome sequence analysis of chicken astrovirus isolate from India
abstract: Objective: Chicken astroviruses are known to cause increased mortality in chickens and serious diseases that lead to the "white chicks" condition. Here, we aim to characterize the causative agent of visceral gout suspected of astrovirus infection in broiler chickens. Methods: Total RNA isolated from the allantoic fluid of SPF embryo passaged with infected chicken sample was sequenced by whole-genome shotgun sequencing using the ion-torrent PGM platform. The sequence was analyzed for the presence of coding and non-coding features, similarity to reported isolates, and epitope analysis of the capsid structural protein. Results: The consensus length of the 7513Â bp genome sequence of the Indian isolate of chicken astrovirus was obtained after combining 14,121 high-quality reads. The genome consists of three open reading frames (ORFs), including 13Â bp 5â€²-UTR, ORF1a encoding serine protease, ORF1b encoding RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), and ORF2 encoding capsid protein, and 298Â bp 3â€²-UTR. ) was formed. It harbored two coronavirus stem loop II, such as "s2m" motifs and a 19 nucleotide poly A extension. Genetic analysis of CAstV/INDIA/ANAND/2016 suggested the highest sequence similarity at 86.94% with the chicken astrovirus isolate CAstV/GA2011, followed by 84.76% with CAstV/4175 and 74.48% with CAstV/Poland/G059/2014 isolates. The capsid structural protein of CAstV/INDIA/ANAND/2016 showed 84.67% homology with chicken astrovirus isolate CAstV/GA2011, 81.06% with CAstV/4175 and 41.18% with CAstV/Poland/G059/2014 isolates. However, the capsid protein sequence showed a high degree of sequence identity at the nucleotide level (98.64–99.32%) and amino acid level (97.74–98.69%), and the reported sequences of Indian isolates revealed their common origin and limited sequence differences. Epitope analysis by SVMTriP identified two unique epitopes in our isolate, seven shared epitopes among Indian isolates, and two common epitopes among all isolates except the Polish isolate, which carried all different epitopes.
authors: Patel, A. K.;Pandit, R. J.;Thakkar, J. R.;Hinsu, A. T.;Pandey, V. C.;Pal, J. K.;Prajapati, K. S.;Jakhesara, S. J.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Metagenomics of clinically diseased and healthy chickens affected by respiratory disease complex.
abstract: In the recent past, respiratory infection has emerged as a major challenge for poultry farmers. Including Avian pneumovirus (APV), Avian influenza virus (AIV), Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) and Newcastle disease virus (NDV), Avibacterium paragallinarum, Ornithobacterium rhinotracheale (ORT), Mycoplasma synoviae (MS), Mycoplasma gallisepticum (MG) various pathogens and Avian pathogenic Escherichia coli (APEC) are involved in the avian respiratory disease complex [1], [2] (Bradbury, 1984; Roussan et al., 2008). Therefore, the respiratory disease complex is the most serious disease affecting poultry and causes heavy economic losses to the poultry industry worldwide [3] (Murthy et al., 2008). In recent years, metagenomics has been a powerful analysis tool for the detection of pathogens directly from clinical samples without any prior knowledge of the organism in a particular sample [4], [5] (Schuster, 2008; Pereira et al., 2010). High-throughput Next Generation Sequencing technology was used for sequencing of isolated genomic DNA. These data give an idea about the taxonomic and functional status of microorganisms that cause respiratory tract infections in broilers. Data for this metagenome are available on the BioSample Submission Portal as Bioproject PRJNA339659 and SRA accession number SRR5997823, SRR5992854, SRR6037376, SRR6024702, SRR6012248, and SRR6008913.
authors: Patel, J. G.;Patel, B. J.;Patel, S. S.;Raval, S. H.;Parmar, R. S.;Joshi, D. V.;Chauhan, H. C.;Chandel, B. S.;Patel, B. K.

title: Equine herpesviruses 1 (EHV-1) and 4 (EHV-4) - Epidemiology, disease and immunoprophylaxis: a brief review
abstract: This review focuses on the epidemiology, latency and pathogenesis of approaches taken to control infection of equine by equine herpesvirus types 1 (EHV-1) and 4 (EHV-4). Although both viruses can cause febrile rhinopneumonia, EHV-1 is the main cause of miscarriage, paresis, and neonatal foal death. The central lesion of these three conditions is necrotizing vasculitis and thrombosis, resulting from lytic infection of the endothelial cells lining the blood capillaries. Initiation of infection in these lesions will likely be by reactivated EHV-1 from latently infected leukocytes. However, the host factors responsible for reactivation are poorly understood. While the development of vaccines against these important equine viruses, which includes classical and modern approaches, has continued for over fifty years, progress has been slow compared to other veterinaryly important alpha herpes viruses affecting cattle and pigs. However, recent data on a live temperature-sensitive EHV-1 vaccine are promising. Â© 2004 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Patel, J. R.;Heldens, J.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the NS5B gene of classical swine fever virus isolates indicates that Indian subgroup 2.2 viruses are of plausible Chinese origin.
abstract: Twenty-three CSFV isolates recovered from field outbreaks in various regions of India between 2006-2009 were used for genetic analysis in the NS5B region (409 nts). Of these, 17 were previously studied in the 50UTR region [16]. Phylogenetic analysis showed continued dominance of subgroup 1.1 strains in the country. Detailed analysis of a subgroup 2.2 virus showed that this subgroup plausibly originated in India and provided indirect evidence of CSFV modes of movement in the South East Asian region. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2011.
authors: Patil, S. S.;Hemadri, D.;Veeresh, H.;Sreekala, K.;Gajendragad, M. R.;Prabhudas, K.

title: A proposed division of the pestivirus genus using monoclonal antibodies supported by cross-neutralization experiments and genetic sequencing
abstract: Sixty-six pestiviruses from ruminant and porcine hosts were analyzed with a panel of 76 monoclonal antibodies raised against 9 different viruses. Reactivity was used to generate epitope similarity maps for all viruses. Four main virus subgroups were shown. One subgroup equated to the classic swine fever virus (CSFV) and contained most of the swine pestiviruses but none of the ruminant ones. A second subgroup includes viruses primarily of bovine origin, including reference bovine viral diarrhea viruses (BVDV) such as NADL; however, viruses from pigs and sheep were also represented. A third subgroup, represented by reference strains of border disease virus (BDV), includes mainly ovine isolates but also porcine viruses. The fourth and most recently identified subgroup did not include reference strains of CSFV, BVDV or BDV, but included atypical viruses from cattle, sheep and pigs. The subgrouping scheme was supplemented by genetic comparisons between representative viruses from the 4 subgroups and virus neutralization with polyclonal sera.
authors: Paton, D. J.;Sands, J. J.;Lowings, J. P.;Smith, J. E.;Ibata, G.;Edwards, S.

title: Options for foot-and-mouth disease control: knowledge, skills and policy
abstract: Foot and mouth disease can be controlled with zoo sanitation and vaccination, but this is difficult due to the presence of multiple serotypes of the causative virus, multiple host species including wildlife, and extreme contagiousness. Although intolerable to modern high production livestock systems, the disease is not usually fatal and is often not a priority for control in many developing countries that remain reservoirs for viral spread. Phylogenetic analysis of viruses circulating worldwide reveals seven major reservoirs, each requiring a specific regional control strategy. Countries that have eradicated the disease but require regional cooperation as well as obtaining and maintaining this status using existing tools provide significant commercial benefits to countries that require a great deal of time, money and effort. Therefore, a progressive approach is needed that can provide temporary benefits along the way to eventual eradication. Research is needed to understand and predict viral persistence and emergence patterns and to improve vaccine selection. Better diagnostic methods, and especially better vaccines, can significantly improve control in both free and affected parts of the world. In particular, vaccines with improved thermostability and a longer duration of immunity will facilitate control and make them less dependent on advanced veterinary infrastructures. Â© 2009 Royal Society.
authors: Paton, D. J.;Sumption, K. J.;Charleston, B.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of Indian field isolates of foot-and-mouth disease virus serotype O revealed by partial sequencing of the 1D gene.
abstract: 165 nucleotide sequences at the 3' end of the 1D gene identified from RT-PCR amplified cDNA fragments of 25 type O strains and vaccine strains (R2/75) isolated from different regions/regions of India between 1987-1995. has been subjected. An isolate from the neighboring country Nepal was also included in the study. The virus/domain strains showed a high degree of genetic heterogeneity among themselves, with variation in nucleotide sequence ranging from 1.2% to 19.4%. Indian strains were far from exotic type O strains of O1BFS, O1K and O1Campos (13.3-20.6%). Type O strains analyzed were classified into three genotypes according to the level of difference observed in nucleotide sequence. Type O vaccinia virus (R2/75) was >7% different (7.3-15.2%) from field strains, which revealed significant (>5%) genetic heterogeneity between the two. Phylogenetic analysis identified three distinct lineages, i.e. (i) lineage 1 represented by exotic strains, (ii) lineage 2 represented by 25 domain species clustered into seven subgroups/sublines (2a-2g), and (iii) ) lineage 3. represented by a unique field isolate that shares branching/origin with the graft strain 3. Lineage 2, consisting of 25 of the 26 type O field strains analyzed, was placed almost equidistantly from lineages 1 and 3 in the phylogenetic tree. The vaccine strain was closer to the viruses in strain 2. The viruses/sequences in subgroup 2f appeared restricted to the southern states, although the sequences did not have a specific distribution pattern in different geographic regions of India. Comparison of the amino acid sequence deduced at immunodominant regions 133-160 and 200-208 of the 1D gene product (VP1) showed that the two viruses in lineage 3 have unique amino acid residues at positions 138 (D), 139 (G). , 144(I) and 158(A) compared to the remaining strains, including exotic ones. Comparison of amino acid residues at critical positions 144, 148, 149, 151, 153, 154 and 208 revealed similarity between the analyzed type O strains. Virus strains showed variation (V/L/I) at position 144. One field strain showed variation from Q149â†'E and the other from P208â†'L. Thus, the study revealed that the populations of O-type FMD viruses circulating in India that cause disease outbreaks are genetically very heterogeneous but associated with the immunodominant region of the VP1 polypeptide, with multiple genetically distinct virus populations in almost every region of the country. this is possible due to the unlimited movement of animals in the country. Involvement of the vaccinia virus in disease outbreaks was excluded, as the field strains (except for the 3rd generation) were phylogenetically different from it. Copyright (C) 1998 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Pattnaik, B.;Venkataramanan, R.;Tosh, C.;Sanyal, A.;Hemadri, D.;Samuel, A. R.;Knowles, N. J.;Kitching, R. P.

title: Isolation of a bovine rotavirus with a 'super-short' RNA electrophoretic pattern from a calf with diarrhea
abstract: rotavirus with the 'super-short' RNA electropherotype was isolated from a calf with diarrhea and named the VMRI strain. Segments 10 and 11 of this rotavirus migrated more slowly than those of the bovine rotavirus strains NCDV, B641 and B223. The electrophoretic pattern of the VMRI strain was similar to that reported for rotaviruses with super-short RNA electropherotypes from humans and rabbits. Northern (RNA) blot hybridization showed that the VMRI strain had gene 11 replaced and migrated between gene segments 9 and 10. The subgroup of the VMRI strain was shown to be subgroup I. The VMRI strain of bovine rotavirus was neutralized with antisera containing polyclonal. via ascitic fluid containing antibodies to rotavirus serotype 6 (bovine rotavirus serotype I) strains NCDV and B641 and monoclonal antibodies to VP7 of serotype 6 rotavirus. The VMRI strain was not neutralized by polyclonal or monoclonal antibodies to strain B223 (bovine rotavirus serotype II). Aggregated data on neutralization of the VMRI strain with monoclonal antibodies and polyclonal antibodies indicate that this virus is a member of the NCDV group (serotype 6) of rotaviruses (bovine rotavirus serotype I).
authors: Paul, P. S.;Lyoo, Y. S.;Woode, G. N.;Zheng, S.;Greenberg, H. B.;Matsui, S.;Schwartz, K. J.;Hill, H. T.

title: Characterization of full-length genomic sequences of vesicular stomatitis Cocal and Alagoas viruses
abstract: In Brazil and Argentina, vesicular stomatitis (VS) is caused by different viral strains serologically related to the classic vesicular stomatitis virus Indiana (VSIV), namely VS Indiana-2 (VSIV-2) and VS Indiana-3 (VSIV-3). Here, we describe the full-length genomic sequences and organization of prototype strains of VSIV-2 Cocal virus (COCV) and VSIV-3 Alagoas virus (VSAV). These viruses showed genomic organizations similar to VSIV domain isolates, except that nonstructural C'/C proteins, which are markedly conserved throughout vesiculoviruses, are absent in VSAV. Phylogenetic analyzes consistently group COCV, VSAV, and VSIV in a different monophyletic group than VSNJV, supporting the classification of these viruses within the Indiana serogroup.
authors: Pauszek, S. J.;Allende, R.;Rodriguez, L. L.

title: Genetic and antigenic relationships of vesicular stomatitis viruses from South America
abstract: Vesicular stomatitis (VS) viruses have been classified into two serotypes: New Jersey (VSNJV) and Indiana (VSIV). Here, we describe field isolates that produced vesicular stomatitis in Brazil and Argentina over a 35-year period. Cluster analysis based on serological relatedness or the nucleotide sequences of two separate genes (phosphoprotein or glycoprotein) as inferred from virus neutralization and complement fixation experiments grouped domain isolates into two distinct monophyletic groups within the Indiana serogroup. One group contained seven viruses from Brazil and Argentina that were serologically classified as Indiana-2 and Cocal virus (COCV). The other group contained three viruses from Brazil serologically classified as Indiana-3 and the prototype of this group, Alagoas virus (VSAV). Interestingly, two vesiculoviruses, one isolated from insects but not animal disease, from Brazil (Maraba virus; MARAV) and the other from Colombia (CoAr 171638), are grouped into two distinct genetic lineages within the Indiana serotype. Our data provide support for the classification of viruses that cause clinical VS in livestock in Brazil and Argentina into two distinct groups: Indiana-2 (VSIV-2) and Indiana-3 (VSIV-3). For these viruses, we recommend using naming that includes the serotype, year and location of occurrence, and the affected host. This nomenclature is consistent with what is currently used in the scientific literature to describe VSNJV or VSIV field isolates. Â© 2011 Springer-Verlag (outside the USA).
authors: Pauszek, S. J.;del Barrera, J. C.;Goldberg, T.;Allende, R.;Rodriguez, L. L.

title: Zoonotic hepatitis E: animal reservoirs and emerging risks
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is responsible for enterically transmitted acute hepatitis in humans with two different epidemiological patterns. Large waterborne outbreaks have been observed in endemic areas, affecting thousands of people, while sporadic cases have been described in non-endemic areas. Although contaminated water is well documented as a source of infection in endemic areas, routes of transmission are much less known in non-endemic areas. HEV is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus classified in the family Hepeviridae with at least four major known genotypes (1-4) of mammalian HEV and one avian HEV. HEV is unique among hepatitis viruses known to have an animal reservoir. Unlike humans, HEV-infected swine and other mammalian species generally remain asymptomatic, while chickens infected with avian HEV can develop a disease known as the Hepatitis-Splenomegaly syndrome. HEV genotypes 1 and 2 are found only in humans, while genotypes 3 and 4 are found in both humans and other mammals. Several lines of evidence suggest that animal-to-human transmission has occurred in some cases involving HEV genotypes 3 and 4. Also, people who have direct contact with animals have a higher risk of HEV infection. Interspecies infections with HEV genotypes 3 and 4 have been demonstrated experimentally. However, not all sources of human infections have been identified so far, and in many cases the source of HEV infection in humans is unknown. Â© INRA, EDP Sciences, 2010.
authors: Pavio, N.;Meng, X. J.;Renou, C.

title: A new subgroup of exogenous avian leukosis viruses in chickens
abstract: An avian leukosis virus with a wide host range was isolated from meat-type chicken lines, belonging to a novel subgroup for chickens. The virus, of which the HPRS-103 strain is the prototype, had low oncogenicity in chickens but appeared to behave like an exogenous leukosis virus. Neutralizing antibodies to the virus were found in three of the five meat-type chicken lines, but not in the seven-layer lines. The virus and its Rous sarcoma virus pseudotype did not replicate or transform in mammalian cells.
authors: Payne, L. N.;Brown, S. R.;Bumstead, N.;Howes, K.;Frazier, J. A.;Thouless, M. E.

title: Rous sarcoma virus pseudotype RSV(HPRS-103) host range in 12 avian species: support for a new avian retrovirus envelope subgroup designated J
abstract: The host ranges of a novel avian leukosis virus (ALV) Rous sarcoma virus (RSV) pseudotype RSV(HPRS-103), strain HPRS-103 and representative RSV pseudotypes of subgroups A to F were determined in embryo fibroblasts. 12 bird species. Domestic poultry, red grouse, Sonnerat's grouse, and turkey were susceptible to RSV(HPRS-103) infection; ring-necked pheasant, Japanese green pheasant, golden pheasant, Japanese quail, guinea fowl, Peking duck, Musk duck and goose were resistant. The host spacing pattern of RSV(HPRS-103) differs from that of viruses in subgroups A to G and I and provides support for insertion of HPRS-103 strain of ALV into a new envelope subgroup designated J.
authors: Payne, L. N.;Howes, K.;Gillespie, A. M.;Smith, L. M.

title: Limited evidence of hemispherical movement of avian influenza viruses among contemporary North American shorebird isolates
abstract: Migratory routes of gulls, sea terns and shorebirds (Charadriiformes) are known to cross hemispheric borders and intersect with epidemic areas of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI). Previous assessments of low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) among species of this taxonomic order have found some evidence for trans-hemispheric movement of virus genes. To specifically elucidate the role of shorebird species in the trans-hemispheric movement of influenza viruses, to evaluate the temporal variation of Eurasian lineages previously observed among North American shorebirds, and to evaluate the necessity of continuous sampling for HPAI from these birds in North America, we did the following: isolated between 2000 and 2008. Phylogenetic analysis of >700 contemporary sequences. Evidence for trans-hemispheric reclassification among North American shorebird LPAI gene segments was lower than in previous assessments (0.88%) and occurred only among eastern North American isolates. Also, half of the reclassification events occurred in only two isolates. The unique phylogenetic placement of these specimens suggests secondary infection and/or involvement of other migratory species such as gulls. Eurasian lineages observed in North American shorebirds before 2000 were not detected among contemporary specimens, suggesting temporal variation of LPAI lineages.
authors: Pearce, J. M.;Ramey, A. M.;Ip, H. S.;Gill, R. E., Jr.

title: Viral recombination blurs taxonomic lines: Study of single-stranded DNA viruses in a wastewater treatment plant.
abstract: Understanding the structure and dynamics of microbial communities, particularly of economic concerns, is of paramount importance for maintaining healthy and productive microbial communities in agricultural fields and large industrial cultures, including bioprocessors. Wastewater treatment plants are large bioprocessors that take water from multiple sources and become reservoirs for the collection of many viral families that infect a wide range of hosts. To examine this complex virus collection, full-length genomes of circular ssDNA viruses were isolated from a wastewater treatment plant using a combination of sucrose-gradient size selection and rolling circle amplification and sequenced on an Illumina MiSeq. Single-stranded DNA viruses are among the least understood groups of microbial pathogens due to genomic biases and culturing difficulties, particularly when compared to the larger, more frequently studied dsDNA viruses. However, the group includes several well-studied notable examples, including agricultural pathogens (Circoviridae and Geminiviridae) infecting both livestock and crops, and model organisms for genetic and evolutionary studies (Microviridae). Examination of the collected viral DNA provided evidence for 83 unique genotypic groupings that were genetically dissimilar to known viral types and exhibited wide variation within the community. Also, although these genomes express similarities with known viral families such as Circoviridae, Geminiviridae, and Microviridae, many of them are different enough to represent new taxonomic groups. This study demonstrated the efficacy of the protocol for separating bacteria and large viruses from sought-after ssDNA viruses and the ability to use this protocol to obtain an in-depth analysis of the diversity in this group.
authors: Pearson, V. M.;Caudle, S. B.;Rokyta, D. R.

title: First finding of genetic and antigenic diversity in 1b-BVDV isolates from Argentina
abstract: Infection with Bovine Viral Diarrhea Viruses (BVDV) in cattle results in a wide variety of clinical manifestations, from mild respiratory illness to fetal death and mucosal disease, depending on the virulence of the virus and the immune and reproductive status of the host. In this study, 30 Argentine BVDV isolates were characterized by phylogenetic analysis. Isolates were genotyped based on the comparison of the 5' untranslated region (5' UTR) and the E2 gene. In both phylogenetic trees, 76% of viruses were assigned to BVDV 1b, while BVDV 1a, 2a and 2b were also found. Eight of the BVDV 1b isolates were further characterized by cross-neutralization tests using guinea pig antisera and sera from cattle vaccinated with two different commercial vaccines. The results demonstrated the existence of significant antigenic diversity among Argentine BVDV isolates, suggesting the need to include BVDV 1b isolates in diagnostic strategies. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Pecora, A.;Malacari, D. A.;Ridpath, J. F.;Perez Aguirreburualde, M. S.;Combessies, G.;OdeÃ³n, A. C.;Romera, S. A.;Golemba, M. D.;Wigdorovitz, A.

title: Neuraminidase inhibition test for identification of influenza A virus neuraminidase subtype or neuraminidase antibody specificity
abstract: The neuraminidase inhibition (NI) assay is a laboratory procedure for the identification of the neuraminidase (NA) glycoprotein subtype in influenza viruses or the NA subtype specificity of antibodies to influenza virus. A serological procedure for subtyping the NA glycoprotein is critical for the identification and classification of avian influenza (AI) viruses. The macro procedure was first described in 1961 by D. Aminoff et al. [2] and later Van Deusen et al. [4]. The micro-NI procedure reduces the amount of reagents required, allows antigenic classification of many isolates simultaneously, and eliminates spectrophotometric interpretation of results. While macro-NI has been shown to be more sensitive than micro-NI, the micro-NI assay is well suited for testing sera for the presence of NA antibodies and has proven to be a practical and rapid method for virus classification. This section will provide an overview of the USDA approved micro-NI procedure for the identification of subtype-specific NA and antibodies in AIV.
authors: Pedersen, J. C.

title: Phylogenetic Relationships Between Virulent Newcastle Disease Virus Isolates from the 2002-2003 Outbreak in California and Other Recent Outbreaks in North America
abstract: In the United States, isolates from the 2002-2003 virulent Newcastle disease virus (v-NDV) outbreak in Southern California, Nevada, Arizona, and Texas were compared with each other, along with new v-NDV isolates from Mexico and Central America and the reference bird. . paramyxovirus type 1 strains. Nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes were performed on a 1,195-based genomic segment comprising the 3-inch region of the matrix (M) protein gene and a 5-inch portion of the fusion (F) protein gene containing the MF intergenic region. This includes the coding sequences for the nuclear localization signal of the M protein and the F protein cleavage activation site. A dibasic amino acid motif was present in the predicted F protein cleavage activation region in all v-NDVs, including California 2002-2003, Arizona, Nevada, Texas, Mexico, and Central American isolates. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that viruses from California 2002-2003, Arizona, Nevada and Texas were most closely related to isolates from Mexico and Central America. An isolate from Texas in 2003 appeared to represent a separate entry of v-NDV into the United States because this virus was more closely related to Mexico 2000 isolates than to the California, Arizona, and Nevada viruses. The close phylogenetic relationship between recent 2002-2003 US v-NDV isolates and viruses from countries geographically close to the United States warrants continued surveillance of commercial and non-commercial poultry for early detection of highly virulent NDV.
authors: Pedersen, J. C.;Senne, D. A.;Woolcock, P. R.;Kinde, H.;King, D. J.;Wise, M. G.;Panigrahy, B.;Seal, B. S.

title: Emerging and re-emerging enterovirus diseases: from poliomyelitis to hand, foot and mouth disease
abstract: Several picornaviruses (Picornaviridae) are currently attracting attention without being "urgent". Confirmed 40 years after the discovery of the first two members ("ecoviruses 22 and 23"), the genus Parechovirus includes neurotropic viruses whose molecular diagnosis has shown their involvement in infant meningitis and neonatal sepsis, particularly type 3. respiratory infections – thanks to the Influenza AH1N1pdm2009 pandemic – showed that rhinoviruses can play a role in severe forms. The risk of a re-emergence of polio in Europe after an 11-year elimination period poses a serious threat as the wild-type polio virus circulates in the Middle East and Africa due to conflict, population displacements and poverty. . The current widespread outbreaks of infections of hand-foot-mouth disease and/or meningitis due to enterovirus 71 are clear evidence that it originated in Southeast Asia with fatal encephalitis and cardio-pulmonary failure. Although coxsackie viruses A6 and A10 are less common in Europe and are less to blame for hand-foot-mouth disease, EV71 poses a real risk for the future. Comprehensive genotyping of enteroviruses by the Enterovirus Surveillance Network should fend off these two potential risks of emergence/reemergence.
authors: Peigue-Lafeuille, H.;Mirand, A.;Archimbaud, C.;Bailly, J. L.;Henquell, C.

title: Co-circulation of avian H9N2 and contemporary "human" H3N2 influenza A viruses in pigs in southeast China: potential for genetic reclassification?
abstract: Pigs are allowed both human and avian influenza viruses and have been suggested to be an intermediate host for the generation of pandemic influenza viruses through reclassification or adaptation of avian viruses. Prospective virological surveillance of pigs imported from southeast China in Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, People's Republic of China, between March 1998 and June 2000, provides the first evidence of interspecies transmission of avian H9N2 viruses to pigs and documents their co-circulation with contemporary viruses. human H3N2 (similar to A/Sydney/5/97, similar to Sydney97) viruses. All gene segments of swine H9N2 viruses were closely related to viruses similar to those of chicken/Beijing/1/94 (H9N2), duck/Hong Kong/Y280/97 (H9N2) and later virus strains. Phylogenetic analysis suggested that recurrent events of interspecies transmission occur from bird host to pigs. Sydney97-like (H3N2) viruses isolated from pigs were closely related to contemporary human H3N2 viruses in all gene segments and had not undergone genetic reclassification.
