The co-circulation of avian H9N2 and human H3N2 viruses in pigs provides an opportunity for genetic reclassification that leads to the emergence of viruses with pandemic potential.
authors: Peiris, J. S. M.;Guan, Y.;Markwell, D.;Ghose, P.;Webster, R. G.;Shortridge, K. F.

title: Mutation dynamics for the origin of the novel avian influenza a (H7N9) and its capacity for human-to-human transmission.
abstract: In February 2013, a new bird flu virus, H7N9 (A/H7N9/2013-China), broke out in eastern China and caused human death. Discovering its origin and the point at which it will become communicable between humans is a global priority. Here, we present an interdisciplinary method to trace the origin of the H7N9 virus in China and construct an evolutionary dynamic model for human-to-human transmission through mutations. After comparing influenza viruses from China since 1983, we constructed an A/H7N9/2013-Chinese virus evolutionary phylogenetic tree and found that human samples of virus infection were avian origin and clustered in an independent line. Comparing the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) gene sequences of A/H7N9/2013-Chinese viruses with all human-to-human, avian and swine flu viruses in China over the past 30 years, A/H7N9/ 2013-Chinese viruses, Hu Nan Province 2010 Baer's By genetic rediversification from Pochard H7N1 virus (HA gene, EPI: 370846, similarity with H7N9 95.5%) and from Nanchang city 2000 duck flu viruses (NA gene, EPI: 387555, similarity with H7N9 97%). HA and NA gene sequence comparison showed that the A/H7N9/2013-Chinese virus is not similar to influenza viruses that can be transmitted from person to person. We used the Markov model to simulate the evolutionary dynamics required for human-to-human transmission mutations of the H7N9 virus. The result of this calculation showed that the virus would acquire characteristics for human-to-human transmission within 11.3 years (95% confidence interval (CI): 11.2-11.3, HA gene). Â© 2014 Peng et al.
authors: Peng, J.;Yang, H.;Jiang, H.;Lin, Y. X.;Lu, C. D.;Xu, Y. W.;Zeng, J.

title: Analysis of the whole genomes of thirteen TT virus variants isolated from viremic infants, which can be classified in the fourth and fifth genetic groups.
abstract: TT virus (TTV) DNA in serum samples from 24 TTV-infected infants was amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) with reverse primers derived from the untranslated region. The amplified PCR products were molecularly cloned; six clones each were analyzed. Seventy-six (53%) of 144 TTV clones were classified as group 4 (YONBAN isolates) and 22 (15%) as a new genetic group (group 5). TTV clones in group 4 were divided into 9 types, and clones in group 5 were divided into 4 types. The entire nucleotide sequence of a representative clone of 13 species each was determined; they contained 3570-3770 nucleotides and had weak homology to group 1-3 TTVs (TA278, PMV and SANBAN isolates). A phylogenetic tree based on the entire nucleotide sequence of open reading frame 1 confirmed the existence of five distinct clusters separated by a bootstrap value of 100%. Analysis of 13 TTV variants showed that genomic organization and transcriptional profile were preserved in all TTV groups. TTV group 4 was detected in 54% or 72% of infants aged 7 to 12 months in Japan and China, respectively; this is comparable to adults in the respective country, indicating early and frequent acquisition of this TTV group. in infancy.
authors: Peng, Y. H.;Nishizawa, T.;Takahashi, M.;Ishikawa, T.;Yoshikawa, A.;Okamoto, H.

title: Maedi-visna virus infection in sheep: a review
abstract: Maedi-visna virus (MVV) is classified as a lentivirus of the retroviridae family. The genome of MVV contains three genes: gag, which encodes group-specific antigens; pol encoding reverse transcriptase, integrase, RNAse H, protease and dUTPase, and env, the gene encoding the surface glycoprotein responsible for receptor binding and entry of the virus into the host cell. Additionally, similar to other lentiviruses, it contains genome regulatory proteins, namely genes for vif, rev, and tat. The coding regions of the genome are surrounded by long terminal repeats (LTRs), which play a crucial role in the replication of the viral genome and provide binding sites for cellular transcription factors. The organs targeted by MVV are, in decreasing order of importance, the lungs, mammary glands, joints, and brain. In these organs, the virus replicates in mature macrophages and induces slowly progressive inflammatory lesions containing B and T lymphocytes. The clinical manifestations of MVV infection, namely dyspnea, weight loss, mastitis and arthritis, are associated with the location of these lesions. Infection with MVV induces the formation of antibodies that can be detected by agar gel immunodiffusion, ELISA, and serum neutralization assay. As neither antiviral therapy nor vaccine is available, diagnostic tests are the backbone of most plans to prevent the spread of MVV. However, as current serological tests still lack sensitivity and specificity, molecular biological methods are being developed that allow detection of the virus in peripheral blood, milk and tissue samples. Future research will have to focus on both the development of new diagnostic tests and a better understanding of the pathogenesis of MVV infection.
authors: PÃ©pin, M.;Vitu, C.;Russo, P.;Mornex, J. F.;Peterhans, E.

title: Identification and molecular characterization of Orf virus in Argentina
abstract: Orf virus (ORFV) is the etiological agent of infectious ecthyma (CE), pustular dermatitis of sheep and goats. ORFV outbreaks have been observed in all geographic regions of the world, including Argentina. The origin and identity of Argentine ORFVs are unknown and comparative or phylogenetic studies of these viruses have not been conducted. In this study, we identified the sequencing and analysis of five ORFV molecular markers: a partial B2L gene (ORF011), VIR (ORF020), an envelope mature protein (ORF109), vIL10 (ORF127) and GIF (ORF117) from two specifics. Argentina CE outbreaks.
authors: Peralta, A.;Robles, C.;MartÃ­nez, A.;Alvarez, L.;Valera, A.;Calamante, G.;KÃ¶nig, G. A.

title: Avian influenza virus isolated in wild waterfowl in Argentina: evidence of a potentially unique phylogenetic lineage in South America.
abstract: Avian influenza (AI) viruses have been sporadically isolated in South America. The most recent reports are from an outbreak in commercial poultry in Chile in 2002 and its presumed ancestry from a wild bird in Bolivia in 2001. Extensive surveillance of wild birds was carried out in Argentina between 2006 and 2007. Using RRT-PCR, 12 AI positive detections were made from cloaca swabs. One of these positive samples yielded an AI virus isolated from a wild kelp gull (Larus dominicanus) caught off the South Atlantic coastline of Argentina. Further characterization by nucleotide sequence reveals that it belongs to the H13N9 subtype. Phylogenetic analysis of 8 viral genes shows that 6 internal genes are associated with isolates from Chile and Bolivia. The analysis also shows that a cluster of phylogenetically related AI viruses from South America may have evolved independently from influenza viruses at other latitudes, with minimal gene variation. Data from our research are valuable additions to the study of AI viruses in South America. Â© 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Pereda, A. J.;Uhart, M.;Perez, A. A.;Zaccagnini, M. E.;La Sala, L.;Decarre, J.;Goijman, A.;Solari, L.;Suarez, R.;Craig, M. I.;Vagnozzi, A.;Rimondi, A.;KÃ¶nig, G.;Terrera, M. V.;Kaloghlian, A.;Song, H.;Sorrell, E. M.;Perez, D. R.

title: Isolation and whole genomic characterization of pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza viruses from Cuban pig herds.
abstract: The emergence of the pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza virus poses a potential global threat to human and animal health. In this study, we performed pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza virus surveillance in pig herds in Cuba to determine whether the virus is circulating among pig populations. In conclusion, we describe for the first time the detection of the pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza virus in pig herds in Cuba. In addition, phylogenetic analysis and molecular characterization of three viral isolates were performed. Phylogenetic relationships confirmed that all eight genes of the three isolates were derived from the pandemic H1N1/2009 virus. Cuban isolates formed an independent cluster within the pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza strains. Previously, in pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza viruses, different molecular markers of adaptive evolution, viral escape from the host immune response, virulence and spread were also present in Cuban pandemic H1N1/2009 isolates. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: PÃ©rez, L. J.;Perera, C. L.;Vega, A.;FrÃ­as, M. T.;Rouseaux, D.;Ganges, L.;NuÃ±ez, J. I.;DÃ­az de Arce, H.

title: Hepatitis E: an emerging disease
abstract: Currently, infection with the hepatitis E virus is the most common cause of acute hepatitis and jaundice in the world. According to WHO estimates, approximately two billion people, representing one-third of the world's population, live in areas endemic for HEV and are therefore at risk of infection. In developed countries, circulation of the virus in both human and animal (pig, wild boar, deer) sewage has been confirmed; however, the incidence rate is low compared to developing countries, where outbreaks of acute hepatitis transmitted by the fecal-oral route occur more frequently during flood season or after natural disasters with inadequate sanitary conditions. HEV genotypes. While genotypes 1 and 2 have been isolated in all human outbreaks in developing countries, genotypes 3 and 4 have been isolated not only in humans but also in animals in both developing and industrialized countries. These data support genotypes 3 and 4 of a zoonotic nature. Diagnosis of this disease is based on the detection of anti-HEV IgG and IgM in blood serum using enzyme-linked immunosorbent methods. However, the method that best confirms the diagnosis is RT-PCR, which detects HEV RNA in blood serum and also provides the genotype. The clinical course is usually acute hepatitis, which in some cases may require hospitalization and may develop into chronic hepatitis in transplant patients or HIV-infected persons. In addition, the virus poses a significant risk for pregnant women. Hepatitis E can present with a wide variety of symptoms, from a subclinical case to chronic liver disease with extrahepatic manifestations. Therefore, diagnosis is difficult if a differential diagnosis is not included. There is no specific antiviral drug for hepatitis E, but satisfactory results have been observed in some patients treated with pegylated interferon alfa2a and/or ribavirin. This revision is an update of all molecular, epidemiological, clinical and preventive information regarding this emerging disease. until today.
authors: PÃ©rez-Gracia, M. T.;Suay, B.;Mateos-Lindemann, M. L.

title: Y155H amino acid substitution in influenza A(H1N1) pdm09 viruses does not confer a reduced susceptibility phenotype to neuraminidase inhibitors
abstract: Y155H amino acid substitution in the neuraminidase gene (NA) was previously associated with highly reduced inhibition by neuraminidase inhibitors in seasonal H1N1 influenza A virus circulating in humans prior to the 2009 pandemic. During the 2012/13 epidemic season in Spain, two A(H1N1) pdm09 viruses carrying the specific Y155H substitution were detected in NA and isolated from two patients diagnosed with severe respiratory syndrome and pneumonia who required admission to the intensive care unit. Contrary to what is observed with seasonal A(H1N1) viruses, none of the Y155H A(H1N1) pdm09 viruses described here showed a reduced inhibition phenotype by NAIs as determined by the neuraminidase enzyme inhibition assay (MUNANA). High-throughput sequencing of NA of both Y155H viruses showed that they were composed of >99% of H155 variants. We believe that this report may contribute to a better understanding of the biological significance of amino acid substitutions in the neuraminidase protein in relation to the susceptibility of influenza viruses to neuraminidase inhibitors. This is critical for optimal management of influenza patients.
authors: Perez-Sautu, U.;Pozo, F.;Cuesta, I.;Monzon, S.;Calderon, A.;Gonzalez, M.;Molinero, M.;Lopez-Miragaya, I.;Rey, S.;Canizares, A.;Rodriguez, G.;Gonzalez-Velasco, C.;Lackenby, A.;Casas, I.

title: Molecular characterization of glycoprotein genes of H5N1 influenza A viruses isolated in Israel and the Gaza Strip during the 2006 outbreaks.
abstract: Highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza A viruses (AIV) have caused epidemics among domestic poultry and wild waterfowl in many Asian, European and African countries since 1997. In March 2006, an avian H5N1 influenza A virus was isolated from poultry in Israel. In this study, we molecularly characterized the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes of eleven H5N1 viruses isolated from domestic poultry in Israel and Gaza in March-April 2006. Phylogenetic analysis of HA and NA genes, Israel and Gazi viruses were closely related to viruses isolated in Egypt in 2006. © 2007 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Perk, S.;Banet-Noach, C.;Golender, N.;Simanov, L.;Rozenblut, E.;Nagar, S.;Pokamunski, S.;Pirak, M.;Tendler, Y.;GarcÃ­a, M.;Panshin, A.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin, neuraminidase and nucleoprotein genes of H9N2 avian influenza viruses isolated in Israel during the 2000-2005 epizootic.
abstract: In Israel, the first two isolates of H9N2 influenza virus were collected from turkey and chicken hosts in May 2000. The actual epizootic of the H9N2 virus began in December 2001 after a 1.5-year period of silence and is still ongoing. A total of more than 500 isolations from turkeys and chickens were recorded during the outbreaks. This study revealed some genetic traits among local isolates, namely: all isolates belong to the same G1-like phylogenetic lineage in which they form a single group, which in turn is divided into three subgroups. Two subgroups in the case of HA and NP genes and NA gene. The results provide a basis for suggesting the existence of two parallel evolutionary trends originating from the same local "prototype" isolate. Â© 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Perk, S.;Golender, N.;Banet-Noach, C.;Shihmanter, E.;Pokamunsky, S.;Pirak, M.;Tendler, Y.;Lipkind, M.;Panshin, A.

title: Henipavirus receptor use and tropism
abstract: Nipah (NiV) and Hendra (HeV) viruses are the deadliest human pathogens in the family Paramyxoviridae, which includes human and animal pathogens of global biomedical importance. NiV and HeV infections cause respiratory and encephalitic diseases with high mortality rates in humans. Henipaviruses (HNV) are the only Paramyxoviruses to be classified as biosafety level 4 (BSL4) pathogens due to their extreme pathogenicity, potential for bioterrorism, and the absence of licensed vaccines and therapeutics. HNV uses the highly conserved proteins ephrin-B2 and ephrin-B3 as viral entry receptors. This likely explains their unusually broad species tropism, and also provides opportunities to examine how receptor utilization, cellular tropism, and end-organ pathology are related to the pathobiology of HNV infections. Clinical and pathological manifestations of NiV and HeV virus infections Wong et al. and Geisbert et al. In this respect. Here, we will review the biology of HNV receptors and how receptor utilization relates to HNV cell tropism in vitro and in vivo. Â© 2012 Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Pernet, O.;Wang, Y. E.;Lee, B.

title: Biological and phylogenetic characterization of the virulent Newcastle disease virus circulating in Mexico
abstract: In 2002-2003, outbreaks of velogenic Newcastle Disease Virus closely related to Mexican isolates were confirmed in the United States (USA) in southern California, Arizona, Nevada, and Texas. In this report, virulent NDVs isolated in Mexico between 1998 and 2006 were subjected to biological characterization and phylogenetic analysis using standard pathogenicity tests. Chicken embryo mean time to death (MDT) test results ranged from 39.7 to 61.5 hours, and intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) values ranged from 1.59 to 1.94, compared with a possible maximum value of 2.0. These isolates showed a dibasic amino acid motif in the fusion protein cleavage site sequence required for host systemic replication. Phylogenetic analysis showed that Mexican virulent NDVs belong to class II, genotype V viruses and can be clearly divided into two groups as follows: isolates from 1998 to 2001 and isolated phylogenetically distinct viruses with close epidemiological relationship to the most recent US NDV outbreaks. . From 2004 to 2006, it showed higher virulence. Evaluating the evolution of viruses from Mexico and other neighboring countries will aid US surveillance efforts for early detection of highly virulent NDV.
authors: Perozo, F.;Merino, R.;Afonso, C. L.;Villegas, P.;Calderon, N.

title: Antigen-specific cell-mediated immune response in mice is suppressed by infection with pathogenic lyssaviruses
abstract: The response of cells (RTC) was examined in BALB/c mice intramuscularly infected with various lyssaviruses. After infection by this peripheral route, two types of viruses can be classified according to their effects: 1) pathogenic viruses, including fixed rabies Pasteur virus (serotype 1) and wild viruses of serotype 1 (from a rabid fox in France and a vampire bat in Brazil). infected cow) or serotype 5 (European bat lyssavirus 1); and 2) non-pathogenic viruses, including Mokola virus (serogenotype 3). RTC was tested in vitro by assaying the cytokine production capacity of splenic T cells from infected BALB/c mice after antigenic (purified lyssavirus antigens) or polyclonal stimulation (concanavalin A). Assay for cytokine production, biological activity of interteukin-2 and transcription to complementary DNA and amplification by polymerase for interleukin-2, interleukin-4 and interferon-Î³ (IL2, IL4 and IFNÎ³) messenger RNAs (mRNA) followed up. chain reaction. The first production of biologically active IL2 and cytokine mRNA was observed in mice infected with pathogenic or non-pathogenic lyssaviruses. Mice with only symptoms (infected with pathogenic viruses) lost the capacity to produce cytokines in vitro after antigen-specific stimulation. No such loss was observed after polyclonal stimulation. In mice peripherally infected with non-pathogenic viruses, no loss was observed after stimulation with lyssavirus antigens. Thus, infection with pathogenic lysaviruses via the peripheral route causes a loss of T-cell response in BALB/c mice after antigen activation, but not after polyclonal activation.
authors: Perrin, P.;Tino De Franco, M.;Jallet, C.;Fouque, F.;Morgeaux, S.;Tordo, N.;Colle, J. H.

title: Conserved presence of G-quadruplex-forming sequences in the Long Terminal Repeat Promoter of Lentiviruses
abstract: G-quadruplexes (G4s) are secondary structures of nucleic acids that epigenetically regulate cellular processes. In human immunodeficiency lentivirus 1 (HIV-1), dynamic G4s are located in the unique viral LTR promoter. Folding of HIV-1 LTR G4s inhibits viral transcription; Stabilization with G4 ligands intensifies this effect. Cellular proteins modulate viral transcription by inducing/turning on LTR G4s. Here, we extended our search for the presence of LTR G4s to include all lentiviruses. G4s in the 5'-LTR U3 region are fully conserved in primate lentiviruses. A G4 was also present in a lentivirus that infects cattle. All other non-primate lentiviruses showed hints of less stable G4s. In primate lentiviruses, the probability of folding into G4s was highly conserved between strains. While the LTR G4 sequences were very similar among phylogenetically related primate viruses, they were increasingly differentiated in viruses that diverged early from a common ancestor. A strong correlation was found between primate lentivirus LTR G4s and Sp1/NFÎºB binding sites. All LTR G4s were folded: their complexity was evaluated by the polymerase inhibition test. Our data support the role of the lentiviruses 5'-LTR G4 region as the control center of viral transcription; this can include folding/unfolding of G4s and multiple retrieval of both sequence and structure based factors.
authors: Perrone, R.;Lavezzo, E.;PalÃ¹, G.;Richter, S. N.

title: Comparison and comparison of genes and biological pathways responsive to Marek's disease virus infection using allele-specific expression and differential expression in broilers and laying hens.
abstract: Background: Marek's disease (MD) is a commercially important neoplastic disease of chickens caused by Marek's disease virus (MDV), a naturally occurring oncogenic alphaherpes virus. Increasing MD genetic resistance is desirable to increase existing vaccines and other MD control measures. High-throughput sequencing was used to profile spleen transcriptomes from individual F1 strains infected with MDV at 4 days of age from both self-bred broilers (meat-type) and self-bred layer (egg-type) chicken lines that differ in MD genetic resistance. The information obtained was used to identify SNPs, genes and biological pathways that exhibit allele-specific expression (ASE) in response to MDV infection in each chicken type. In addition, we compared and compared the results of pathway analyzes (ASE and differential expression (DE)) between chicken species to inform about the biological response to MDV infection. Results: With 7 individuals per line and the high power treatment group, we identified 6,132 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in 4,768 genes and 4,528 SNPs in 3,718 genes in broilers and eggs, respectively, that exhibited ASE in response to MDV infection. In addition, 548 and 434 genes were found to show DE following MDV infection in broilers and layer hens, respectively. When the datasets were compared, only 72 SNPs and 850 genes for ASE and 20 genes for DE were common between the two bird species. Although the chicken strains used in this study were genetically different, at the pathway level, both the TLR receptor and JAK/STAT signaling pathways were enriched, and a high proportion of ASE genes were displayed, especially at the start of both of the above-mentioned regulatory pathways. Conclusions: RNA sequencing with sufficient biological replicates is a powerful approach to identify highly reliable SNPs, genes and pathways associated with the transcriptional response to MDV infection. In addition, SNPs that exhibit ASE in response to MDV infection provide a strong basis for determining the extent to which variation in expression affects the incidence of MD, and also provides genetic markers for genomic selection. However, given the little overlap between the ASE SNP sets (broilers vs. layers), it is likely that separate screens for each population should be included. Finally, comparison of the gene lists obtained between these two different chicken strains indicates that TLR and JAK/STAT signaling are conserved in response to MDV infection and can be altered by selecting for ASE exhibiting genes located at the start of each pathway. Â© 2013 Perumbakkam et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Perumbakkam, S.;Muir, W. M.;Black-Pyrkosz, A.;Okimoto, R.;Cheng, H. H.

title: Foot and mouth disease outbreaks due to an exotic virus serotype A strain (A/AFRICA/G-IV) in Algeria in 2017
abstract: This study describes the genetic characterization of serotype A viruses collected during the foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) epidemics that occurred in Algeria in 2017. These are the first reports of clinical cases of this serotype in the country since 1977. genomic sequence (containing 8,119 nucleotides) and three additional nearly complete genomic sequences were generated. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that these viruses were classified in the A/AFRICA/G-IV lineage most closely related to the viruses circulating in Nigeria between 2009 and 2015. These unexpected results motivate further studies to identify the precise pathways of this viral lineage. It was introduced to North Africa to understand the risks of future disease attacks to the region.
authors: Pezzoni, G.;Bregoli, A.;Grazioli, S.;Barbieri, I.;Madani, H.;Omani, A.;Sadaoui, H.;Bouayed, N.;Wadsworth, J.;Bachanek-Bankowska, K.;Knowles, N. J.;King, D. P.;Brocchi, E.

title: Natural reservoirs for homologues of the hepatitis C virus
abstract: The hepatitis C virus is considered an important public health problem, infecting 2-3% of the human population. Hepatitis C virus infection causes acute and chronic liver disease, including chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma. In fact, hepatitis C virus infection is the most common indication for liver transplant and a vaccine is not available. The hepatitis C virus exhibits a narrow host-type tropism, naturally infecting only humans, although chimpanzees are also susceptible to experimental infection. To date, there is no evidence of a reservoir of animal viruses closely related to hepatitis C virus that may have crossed the species barrier to cause disease in humans and have resulted in the current pandemic. Indeed, due to this limited host range, a robust immune-sufficient small animal model is still lacking, hindering mechanistic analysis of virus pathogenesis, immune control, and prophylactic vaccine development. Recently, several studies have discovered new viruses related to hepatitis C virus belonging to the hepaci- and pegivirus genera in small wild mammals (rodents and bats) and domestic animals (dogs and horses) living in close contact with humans. The genetic and biological characterization of these newly discovered hepatitis C virus-like viruses that infect different mammals will contribute to our understanding of the origins of hepatitis C virus in humans and will improve our ability to study pathogenesis and immune responses using traceable animal models. In this review article, we begin with an introduction to the genetic diversity of the hepatitis C virus and then focus on newly discovered viruses closely related to the hepatitis C virus. Finally, we discuss possible theories about the origin of this important viral human pathogen. © 2014 SSCC. All rights reserved.
authors: Pfaender, S.;Brown, R. J. P.;Pietschmann, T.;Steinmann, E.

title: A novel astrovirus associated with encephalitis and ganglionitis in domestic sheep.
abstract: In June 2013, a 4-year-old Welsh Mountain sheep and a 10-day-old lamb of the same breed and herd in March 2014 showed progressive neurological signs such as depressed sensation, tremors, and unusual behavior. Neuropathological examination of the brain and spinal cord detected non-suppurative polioencephalomyelitis and dorsal root ganglionitis, characteristic of the neurotropic viral agent, in both sheep. Metagenomic analysis of different tissue samples from both animals identified a novel Ovine Astrovirus (OvAstV). The presence of the viral genome in the central nervous system was confirmed by RT-qPCR. Although cases were presented nine months apart, the identified OvAstV shared nearly identical sequences that differed only at three nucleotide positions throughout the entire genome. Phylogenetic analysis revealed a close association of OvAstV with neurotropic bovine astroviruses and an enteric OvAstV. In conclusion, these are the first reported cases of astrovirus infection associated with encephalitis and ganglionitis in domestic sheep.
authors: Pfaff, F.;Schlottau, K.;Scholes, S.;Courtenay, A.;Hoffmann, B.;HÃ¶per, D.;Beer, M.

title: Porcine bocavirus infection associated with encephalomyelitis in a pig, Germany
authors: Pfankuche, V. M.;Bodewes, R.;Hahn, K.;Puff, C.;Beineke, A.;Habierski, A.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.;BaumgÃ¤rtner, W.

title: Fecal virome of South and Central American children with diarrhea contains small circular DNA viral genomes of unknown origin.
abstract: Viral metagenomics of feces collected from 58 Peruvian children with unexplained diarrhea revealed several small circular ssDNA genomes. Two genomes related to previously reported sequences, recently termed smacoviruses, were characterized in feces from chimpanzees and other mammals, and subsequently detected by PCR in 1.7% (1/58) and 19% (11/58) of diarrhea samples, respectively. Three other genomes from a separate small circular ssDNA viral group tentatively termed pecoviruses encoded the Cap and Rep proteins with <35% identity to those in the respective genomes reported in human, seal, pig and dromedary feces. Pecovirus DNA was detected in 15.5% (9/58), 5.9% (3/51) and 3% (3/100) of stool samples from unexplained diarrhea in Peru, Nicaragua, and Chile, respectively. . Feces containing these ssDNA genomes also contained known human enteric viral pathogens. The cellular origins of these circular ssDNA viruses, whether human cells, digested plants, animals or fungal food, or inhabitants of the gut microbiome are currently unknown.
authors: Phan, T. G.;da Costa, A. C.;Del Valle Mendoza, J.;Bucardo-Rivera, F.;Nordgren, J.;O'Ryan, M.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: A new gyrovirus in human feces
abstract: A novel gyrovirus genome found in the stool of an adult with diarrhea is described. The genome displays three expected major ORFs encoding a structural protein (VP1), non-structural protein (VP2) and Apoptin protein (VP3); they share identities of 41, 42 and 38Å with those of the most closely related gyrovirus proteins, respectively. Given the high diversity in its genome, this gyrovirus can be considered as the prototype of a new viral strain (GyV9) in the genus Gyrovirus. Since the closest relatives of this gyrovirus infect chicken, a possible dietary source of the presence of this virus in human feces is discussed.
authors: Phan, T. G.;da Costa, A. C.;Zhang, W.;Pothier, P.;Ambert-Balay, K.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: Detection of a novel circovirus PCV3 in pigs with cardiac and multisystemic inflammation
abstract: Background: Porcine circovirus 2 causes different clinical syndromes that cause significant economic loss in the swine industry. Three pigs with unexplained cardiac and multi-organ inflammation and tested negative for PCV2 and other known porcine pathogens were further analyzed. Methods: Histology was used to identify microscopic lesions in multiple tissues. Metagenomics was used to detect viral sequences in tissue homogenates. In situ hybridization was used to detect viral RNA expression in heart tissue. Results: In all three cases, we characterized the genome of a novel circovirus, which we named PCV3, with a replicase and capsid proteins, with proteins that were 55% and 35% identical to, or even further away from, the genetically closest proteins from a bat feces-associated circovirus. porcine circovirus 1 and 2. Common microscopic lesions include non-suppurative myocarditis and/or cardiac arteriolitis. Viral mRNA was detected intralesional in heart cells. Deep sequencing of tissues revealed the presence of porcine astrovirus 4 as well as rotavirus A, porcine cytomegalovirus and in individual cases porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus in all three animals. Conclusion: The pathogenicity and molecular epidemiology of this new circovirus warrants further investigation, either alone or in the context of coinfections.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Giannitti, F.;Rossow, S.;Marthaler, D.;Knutson, T.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Resende, T.;Vannucci, F.;Delwart, E.

title: Sesavirus: prototype of a new genus of parvovirus in the feces of a sea lion
abstract: From the feces of a California sea lion cub (Zalophus californianus) afflicted with malnutrition and pneumonia, we describe the nearly complete genome of a highly different parvovirus, which we tentatively call Sesavirus. The 5,049-base long genome of pigs and cows Given the low degree of similarity, Sesavirus can be considered the prototype for a new genus with the proposed name Marinoparvovirus in the subfamily Parvovirinae.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Gulland, F.;Simeone, C.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: Fecal Viral Flora of Wild Rodents
abstract: The frequent interactions of rodents with humans make them a common source of zoonotic infections. To obtain an initial unbiased measure of viral diversity in the enteric tract of wild rodents, we sequenced partially purified, randomly amplified viral RNA and DNA in the feces of 105 wild rodents (mouse, rat, and rat) collected in California and Virginia. We identified decreasing frequency sequences related to the mammalian virus families Circoviridae, Picobirnaviridae, Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Parvoviridae, Papillomaviridae, Adenoviridae, and Coronaviridae. Seventeen small circular DNA genomes containing one or two replicase genes distantly related to Circoviridae, representing several potentially novel viral families, were characterized. Two new candidate genera, as well as a close genetic relative of the human pathogen Aichi virus, have been characterized in the Picornaviridae family. Fragments of the first mouse sapelovirus and picobirnaviruses were identified and the first murine astrovirus genome characterized. A mouse papillomavirus genome and fragments of a novel adenovirus and adenovirus-associated virus were also sequenced. The next largest fraction of rodent fecal virus was related to insect viruses of the families Densoviridae, Iridoviridae, Polydnaviridae, Dicistroviriade, Bromoviridae and Virgaviridae, followed by plant virus-related sequences in Nanoviridae, Geminiviridae, Phycodnaviridae, Secoviridae, Partitiviridae, Tymoviridae. Families Alphaflexiviridae and Tombusviridae, largely reflecting the insect and plant rodent diet. Thus, phylogenetic analyzes of complete and partial viral genomes revealed many previously unreported viral species, genera, and families. The close genetic similarities noted between some rodent and human viruses may reflect past zoonoses. This work increases our understanding of viral diversity in wild rodents and highlights the large number of viruses still uncharacterized in mammals.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Kapusinszky, B.;Wang, C. L.;Rose, R. K.;Lipton, H. L.;Delwart, E. L.

title: A third strain of gyrovirus in human feces
abstract: Until 2011, the genus Gyrovirus in the family Circoviridae consisted of a single virus (Chicken anemia virus or CAV) that causes a common immunosuppressive illness in chickens, when a second gyrovirus (HGyV) was reported in the skin of 4% of healthy humans. HGyV is very closely related to AGV2, a recently identified chicken gyrovirus, suggesting that they belong to the same viral strain. During viral metagenomic analysis of 100 human feces from children with diarrhea in Chile, we identified a large number of known human pathogens (adenoviruses, enteroviruses, astroviruses, sapoviruses, noroviruses, parecoviruses, and rotaviruses) and a new strain of gyrovirus, which we named GyV3, and shared <63% similarity. Other gyrovirus proteins with evidence of recombination with CAV in its UTR. Gyroviridae consensus PCR revealed a high prevalence of CAV DNA in diarrhea and normal stool from Chilean children and in stool from US cats and dogs, which may reflect consumption of CAV-infected/vaccinated chickens. Whether GyV3 can infect humans and/or chickens requires further study. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Li, L.;O'Ryan, M. G.;Cortes, H.;Mamani, N.;Bonkoungou, I. J. O.;Wang, C.;Leutenegger, C. M.;Delwart, E.

title: New astrovirus in human feces from Burkina Faso
abstract: Background: A significant proportion of diarrheal cases, one of the leading causes of childhood deaths worldwide, remain unexplained. Objectives: To identify viruses in cases of unexplained diarrhea using an unbiased metagenomic approach. Study design: Viral nucleic acids were enriched from the stool of 48 cases of unexplained diarrhea from Burkina Faso, sequenced and compared with all known viral genomes. Results: The complete genome of a highly different astrovirus was sequenced in a sample co-infected with parechovirus 1. RT-PCR identified a single astrovirus infection, indicating a low prevalence in these 48 patients. Human astrovirus-BF34 was most closely related to human maastrovirus strains 8 and 9, which shared protease, RNA-linked RNA polymerase, and amino acid identities of 62%, 74%, and 57%, respectively, on their capsid proteins. Results: Burkina Faso astrovirus has been proposed as a prototype for a new strain in the Mamastrovirus genus, which represents the fifth human astrovirus species, herein provisionally referred to as Mamastrovirus 20. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Phan, T. G.;Nordgren, J.;Ouermi, D.;Simpore, J.;Nitiema, L. W.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.

title: Acute Diarrhea in West African Children: Various Enteric Viruses and a Novel Parvovirus Species
abstract: Parvoviruses cause a variety of mild to severe symptoms or asymptomatic infections in humans and animals. During viral metagenomic analysis of feces from children with acute diarrhea in Burkina Faso, we determined a decreased prevalence of nucleic acids from anelloviruses, dependent viruses, sapoviruses, enteroviruses, bocaviruses, noroviruses, adenoviruses, parecoviruses, rotaviruses, cosavirus, astroviruses, and hepatitis B virus. . Sequences from a highly different parvovirus provisionally termed bufavirus were also detected, with NS1 and VP1 proteins <39% and <31% identity to those of previously known parvoviruses. Four percent of the stool samples were PCR positive for this novel parvovirus, including a related strain of bufavirus with only 72% identity in VP1. The high degree of genetic variation of these related genomes from those of other parvoviruses indicates the existence of a proposed new genus Parvoviridae containing at least two species. Studies of the tropism and pathogenicity of these new parvoviruses will be facilitated by the availability of their genome sequences.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Vo, N. P.;Bonkoungou, I. J. O.;Kapoor, A.;Barro, N.;O'Ryan, M.;Kapusinszky, B.;Wang, C. L.;Delwart, E.

title: Viruses of Wild Pigeon Scum
abstract: Birds are frequent sources of emerging human infectious diseases. Viral particles were enriched from the feces of 51 wild city pigeons (Columba livia) from Hong Kong and Hungary, their nucleic acids were randomly amplified and then sequenced. We identified sequences from known and new species from the viral families Circoviridae, Parvoviridae, Picornaviridae, Reoviridae, Adenovirus, Astroviridae, and Caliciviridae (listed in decreasing reading number), as well as plant and insect viruses possibly originating from food consumed. The nearly complete genome of a new strain of a proposed parvovirus genus tentatively termed Aviparvovirus contained an unusually long intermediate ORF with weak resemblance to an ORF of unknown function from a fowl adenovirus. Picornaviruses found in both Asia and Europe, distantly related to turkey megrivirus and containing a rather distinct 2A1 region, have been termed mesiviruses. All eleven segments of a novel rotavirus subgroup associated with a chicken rotavirus in Group G were sequenced and phylogenetically analyzed. This study provides the first assessment of enteric viroma in the feces of pigeons, a wild urban species with frequent human contact. Â© 2013 Phan et al.
authors: Phan, T. G.;Vo, N. P.;Boros, Ã;Pankovics, P.;Reuter, G.;Li, O. T. W.;Wang, C.;Deng, X.;Poon, L. L. M.;Delwart, E.

title: Nucleotide sequence analysis of a new canary circovirus and its association with other members of the Circovirus genus of the family Circoviridae.
abstract: The circular, single-stranded DNA genome of a novel canary circovirus, tentatively termed canary circovirus (CaCV), has been cloned and sequenced. Sequence analysis showed that the genome was 1952 nucleotides (nt) in size and had the potential to encode three viral proteins, including the putative capsid and replication-associated (Rep) proteins. The CaCV genome shared the greatest sequence similarity (58.3% nt identity) with the newly characterized columbid circovirus (CoCV) and more distantly with two porcine circovirus strains, PCV1 and PCV2, beak and feather disease virus (BFDV) and a recently isolated virus. was related. goose circovirus (GCV) isolate (46.8-50.9% nt identity). In common with other members of the Circovirus genus, several nt structures and amino acid motifs thought to be involved in virus replication were identified on the putative viral strand. Phylogenetic analysis of both capsid and Rep protein-coding regions provided further evidence that CaCV is more closely related to CoCV and BFDV and more distantly to GCV, PCV1 and PCV2.
authors: Phenix, K. V.;Weston, J. H.;Ypelaar, I.;Lavazza, A.;Smyth, J. A.;Todd, D.;Wilcox, G. E.;Raidal, S. R.

title: Wild bird's eye view of influenza virus A(H1N1) phylogenetic evolution
abstract: Wild bird fecal samples collected and characterized by the USDA as part of a national surveillance study were sequenced to examine the genetic association of avian, porcine, and human H1 and N1 subtypes. Our results show that the 2009 H1N1 human outbreak was closely related to the swine virus, but fell on different branches in H1 and N1 trees. There is also evidence of a large number of viral genetic exchanges between birds and pigs. Ongoing research among host species contributes to the understanding of the circulation of influenza viruses.
authors: Piaggio, A. J.;Clark, L.;Franklin, A. B.;Kolokotronis, S. O.

title: Whole genome sequence-based comparative study of wild-type and vaccine strains of infectious laryngotracheitis virus from Italy.
abstract: Infectious laryngotracheitis (ILT) is an acute and highly contagious respiratory disease of chickens caused by an alphaherpes virus, infectious laryngotracheitis virus (ILTV). Recently, complete genome sequences of wild-type and vaccine strains have been identified worldwide, but none were from Europe. The aim of this study was to identify and analyze the whole genome sequences of five ILTV strains. Sequences were also compared to reveal the similarity of strains over time and to distinguish between wild-type and vaccine strains. The genomes of three ILTV-receiving isolates from the 1980, 2007 and 2011 epidemics in Italy were sequenced using 454 Life Sciences technology and two commercial chicken embryo origin (CEO) vaccines. Comparison with the Serva genome showed that 35 open reading frames (ORFs) differed between the five genomes. Overall, 54 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and 27 amino acid differences in 19 ORFs and two insertions in the UL52 and ORFC genes were identified. The similarity between field strains and between field and vaccine strains varied between 99.96% and 99.99%. Phylogenetic analysis revealed a close relationship between them. This study generated data on genomic variation among Italian ILTV strains, revealing that although genetic variability of the genome is well conserved over time and between wild-type and vaccine strains, some mutations may help differentiate between them and play a role in ILTV virulence. /weakening. The results of this study may contribute to the understanding of the molecular underpinnings of ILTV pathogenicity and provide genetic markers to distinguish between wild-type and vaccine strains.
authors: Piccirillo, A.;Lavezzo, E.;Niero, G.;Moreno, A.;Massi, P.;Franchin, E.;Toppo, S.;Salata, C.;PalÃ¹, G.

title: Evidence of predicted feline origin of sporadic G6P[9] rotaviruses in humans
abstract: Type A rotaviruses are highly diverse and place a significant burden on human and animal health. Interspecies transmission between farm animals, pets, and humans is common, but the spread of animal-like rotaviruses within the human population is limited. During continuous monitoring of rotavirus strains in Germany, an unusual strain of G6P[9] rotavirus was detected in the stool of a child. The complete rotavirus coding sequences revealed a unique constellation of genotypes G6-P[9]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A3-N2-T3-E2-H3. The virus was phylogenetically related to the feline G3P[9] strains and other human G6P[9] rotaviruses, possibly of zoonotic origin. Analysis of the primary binding sites of G6-specific genotyping revealed further evidence of a G6P[9] cat reservoir. In addition, significant shortcomings of traditional semi-nested PCR genotyping approaches have emerged in contemporary G6P[9] detection. Rotavirus strain GER29-14 most likely resulted from a direct or recent interspecies transmission from a cat to a human. Further studies can evaluate the nucleic acid sequences and genotype constellations of feline rotavirus to confirm the probable feline origin of sporadic human G6P[9] strains.
authors: Pietsch, C.;Liebert, U. G.

title: The low pathogenic avian influenza virus A/turkey/Ontario/6213/1966 (H5N1) is the precursor to the highly pathogenic A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9).
abstract: A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9) caused the first confirmed outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus infection in North America; however, the phylogeny of this virus is largely unknown. This study performed genomic sequence analysis of 11 avian influenza isolates from 1956 to 1979 for comparison with A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9). Phylogenetic and genetic analyzes included these viruses in combination with all known fullgenome sequences of avian viruses isolated before 1981. 3 months ago, polymerase subunits PB2, PB1 and PA were the closest known genetic relatives, with six genome segments of the common lineage encoding nucleoprotein (NP), hemagglutinin (HA) and nonstructural (NS) proteins. Lineages of these genome segments included reassortment with the HA gene, all originating from the H5N2 serotype, with other North American turkey viruses rooted in North American wild waterfowl. The phylogenies showed adaptation from North American wild birds to turkeys with the possible participation of domestic waterfowl. The turkey isolate A/turkey/Wisconsin/1968 (H5N9) was the second poultry isolate most closely related to A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9) and has five common lineage genome segments (PB2, PB1, PA, HA, and neuraminidase). A/turkey/Ontario/6213/1966 (H5N1) virus was more lethal to chicken embryos and mice than A/turkey/Wisconsin/68 (H5N9), giving a greater incidence to A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966. showed biological similarity (H5N9). Thus, A/turkey/Ontario/6213/1966 (H5N1) was identified as the closest known ancestral relative of HPAI A/turkey/Ontario/7732/1966 (H5N9) and it is a useful reference virus for characterizing early genetics. will serve. and biological features associated with the emergence of pathogenic strains of avian influenza. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Ping, J.;Selman, M.;Tyler, S.;Forbes, N.;Keleta, L.;Brown, E. G.

title: Evaluation of a droplet digital polymerase chain reaction format for DNA copy number measurement.
abstract: Droplet digital polymerase chain reaction (ddPCR) is a new technology recently commercialized to enable precise quantification of target nucleic acids in a sample. ddPCR measures absolute amounts by counting nucleic acid molecules encapsulated in discrete, volume-defined, water-in-oil droplet sections. This new ddPCR format offers a simple workflow that can generate highly stable segmentation of DNA molecules. In this study, we evaluated the key performance parameters of the ddPCR system. A linear ddPCR response to DNA concentration was obtained from 0.16% to 99.6% saturation in the assay of 20,000 droplets corresponding to greater than 4 sizes of target DNA copy number per ddPCR. Analysis of the simplex and duplex assays targeting two different loci using the ddPCR platform in the lambda DNA genome agreed, within their expanded uncertainty, with the values obtained using a lower-density microfluidic chamber-based digital PCR (cdPCR). A relative expanded uncertainty of less than 5% was obtained for the copy number concentration using ddPCR. This level of uncertainty is much lower than values typically observed for the quantification of specific DNA target sequences using real-time and digital cdPCR technologies currently commercially available. Â© 2011 American Chemical Society.
authors: Pinheiro, L. B.;Coleman, V. A.;Hindson, C. M.;Herrmann, J.;Hindson, B. J.;Bhat, S.;Emslie, K. R.

title: Development of generic Taqman PCR and RT-PCR assays for the detection of DNA and mRNA of Î²-actin-encoding sequences in a wide variety of animal species
abstract: As a member of the European Virus Archive (EVA) consortium, our laboratory develops and maintains an extensive virus collection. This collection implies the use of a panel of cell lines originating from various animal species. To facilitate the use of such a large panel of cell lines, broad-spectrum real-time PCR and RT-PCR tests have been developed to allow detection. and quantification of DNA and mRNA of Î²-actin, one of the most widely used eukaryotic housekeeping genes. Using two degenerate primers and a unique probe, these two tests were shown to detect nucleic acids from a panel of vertebrate and invertebrate cell lines widely used in animal virology. This panel included human, monkey, rodent, dog, pig, fish, batrakian, mosquito and tick cell lines. In addition, two experiments successfully amplified the Î²-actin-encoding sequences of the midges. Sensitivity evaluation performed on synthetic DNA and RNA sequences showed that the two assays were very sensitive and suitable for accurate quantification. The two tests together form a convenient multi-purpose method. For example, they can be used to estimate the amount of contaminating cellular genetic material prior to sequence-independent amplification of viral genomes obtained prior to high-throughput sequencing, to evaluate the efficacy of DNase and/or RNase treatments performed on the cellular extract, and to control nucleic control. Acid extraction using Î²-actin coding sequences as endogenous control. This assay will constitute a valuable tool for virologists working with multiple cell lines or animal models. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Piorkowski, G.;Baronti, C.;de Lamballerie, X.;de Fabritus, L.;Bichaud, L.;Pastorino, B. A.;Bessaud, M.

title: Transmission of a pestivirus infection in the Pyrenean chamois population
abstract: Outbreaks of a previously unrecorded disease have recently affected Pyrenean ibex (Rupicapra pyrenaica pyrenaica) populations throughout the mountain range. It was assumed that the cause of this emerging disease was a pestivirus, which can cross the species barrier and be transmitted to or from wildlife. Using an epidemiological study conducted in Orlu, France from 1995 to 2004, we identified the virus and analyzed its transmission. Phylogenetic analysis of viral sequences and virus neutralization tests indicated that the virus belonged to the newly identified borderline disease virus-4 group. Increasing seroprevalence with age has shown that infection can occur at any age, resulting in lifelong immunity. Overall, 70.3% of 323 samples were positive for anti-p80 antibodies and 10.2% of 167 samples showed viremia as demonstrated by positive ELISA antigen testing or RT-PCR. Therefore, while infection has been prevalent in this population since 1995, no mass deaths or clinical signs have been observed. The incidence and seroprevalence varied seasonally and according to the number of individuals younger than 2 years in the population, so viral transmission was dependent on the age structure of the host population. We suggest that the virus is now endemic in this population and possibly harmful to reproduction and offspring. More research is needed to estimate the impact of pestivirus on host population dynamics and the risk of cross-contamination to livestock. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Pioz, M.;Loison, A.;Gibert, P.;Dubray, D.;Menaut, P.;Le Tallec, B.;Artois, M.;Gilot-Fromont, E.

title: Influenza A Virus Detected in Pigs in Southern Germany after the H1N1 Pandemic in 2009
abstract: Infections with influenza A viruses (IAV) are quite common in swine populations, and stable coexistence of at least three lineages was well documented until 2009 in European pigs. However, the situation is changing since the human pandemic pdmH1N1 virus emerged in 2009 (re)introduced into individual pig herds worldwide. These variations in relevant IAV pools within pig populations are of great interest and the zoonotic potential of emerging putative viruses needs to be evaluated. Since recent data on IAV in pigs from southern Germany are relatively sparse, the aim of this study was to identify the major IAV subtypes actually present in this region. To this end, 1417 nasal swabs or lung tissue samples from pigs with respiratory disease from 2010 to 2013 were screened for IAV genomes. Overall, IAV genomes at 130 holdings were detected by real-time RT-PCR targeting the matrix protein gene. For further analysis, several PCR protocols were quickly subtyped between the H1, pdmH1, H3, N1 and N2 sequences. Taken together, the co-circulation of three stable European lineages of IAV was confirmed for Bavaria. H1N1 sequences were identified in 59, whereas H1N2 genomes were identified in only 14 and H3N2 was identified in 9 of the analyzed enterprises. However, pdmH1 was detected in combination with N1 in 2010, 2012 and 2013, confirming the presence of pdmH1N2 reassortant viruses, albeit with a low prevalence. Interestingly, individual cases of coinfection with multiple subtypes were diagnosed. Partial genome sequences were determined and phylogenetic analyzes were performed. Clearly unlike the human population, classically circulating IAV was not replaced by pdmH1N1 in Bavarian pigs. However, some interesting viruses have been detected. Further monitoring of these viruses in the Bavarian pig population will be of great importance for monitoring future developments.
authors: Pippig, J.;Ritzmann, M.;BÃ¼ttner, M.;Neubauer-Juric, A.

title: Classification principles illustrated by the virus classification problem
authors: Pirie, N. W.

title: High turnover results in long-term persistence of influenza in managed swine herds
abstract: Pigs have long been hypothesized to play a central role in the emergence of new strains of human influenza A virus (IAV) by serving as mixing vessels for mammalian and avian variants. However, the fundamental issue of viral persistence in pig populations at different scales is poorly understood. We address this gap using epidemiological models calibrated against seroprevalence data from Dutch finishing pigs to estimate 'critical herd size' (CHS) for IAV persistence. Next, we examine viral phylogenetic evidence for persistence by comparing human and porcine IAV. Models suggest a CHS of about 3000 pigs, above which persistence of influenza is likely, ie orders of magnitude lower than persistence thresholds for IAV and other acute viruses in humans. At national and regional scales, we found much stronger empirical signatures of long-term persistence of IAV in pigs compared to human populations. These striking levels of persistence in small populations are driven by the high recruitment rate of susceptible piglets and have important implications for the management of pigs and the overall genetic diversity patterns of IAV.
authors: Pitzer, V. E.;Aguas, R.;Riley, S.;Loeffen, W. L. A.;Wood, J. L. N.;Grenfell, B. T.

title: Bioaerosol sampling for airborne respiratory viruses at an experimental drug pig processing plant, Singapore
authors: Poh, M. K.;Ma, M.;Nguyen, T. T.;Su, Y. C. F.

title: Viral spreaders in a herd vaccinated against infection with bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) without prior testing for the presence of permanently infected animals
abstract: Introduction: Bovine viral diarrhea (BVD), caused by bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV), is one of the most important diseases of cattle worldwide. The aim of the study was to determine the BVDV infection status in a dairy herd vaccinated against BVD. Prior to the start of vaccination in 2008, there was no prior identification or elimination of the possible source of infection (continuously infected animals). The vaccine itself was expected to enable eradication of viral scatterers in the long run. Material and Methods: Although there were no clinical problems indicating the possible presence of BVDV, serological screening for antibodies to BVDV was performed by determining the presence of viral genome by antibody titers, BVDV antigen, and phylogenetic analysis of positive samples in the flock. infection. Results: 19 individuals permanently infected with BVDV were detected among calves and heifers, but not in adult cattle. All virus scatterers were antibody negative and the genotype of the virus isolated was BVDV-lb, indicating a single source of infection. The vaccine used in the herd consisted of the BVDV-Ia strain. In each of the stables tested, antibody titers against BVDV-1b were higher (median values) than against BVDV-1a. Conclusion: Despite a long-term vaccination schedule and relatively high sequence homology (83.6%) of vaccine and field strains of BVDV, it was not possible to avoid transplacental infections of fetuses and the birth of permanently infected calves from vaccinated heifers. clinical disease was performed.
authors: Polak, M. P.;Antos, A.;Rola, J.;Zmudzinski, J. F.

title: Risk factors and molecular characterization of acute sporadic symptomatic hepatitis E virus infection in Thailand.
abstract: Objective: To report the clinical outcomes and viral genotypes of acute symptomatic hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection in Thailand. Methods: Forty patients with acute symptomatic HEV infection between 2009 and 2013 were recruited. Clinical, demographic and laboratory data were collected. Diagnosis was made by detection of anti-HEV IgM and/or HEV RNA in serum or stool. HEV genotypes were classified by direct sequencing of RT-PCR products and phylogenetic analysis. Results: The high-risk group (17 cases) of immunocompromised, hepatic cirrhosis and very elderly (>80 years) patients had higher serum alkaline phosphatase levels at admission compared to the low-risk group. Two fatal cases from acute hepatitis E in the high-risk group. Initial clinical presentation did not show statistically significant differences. In six cases (6/40), the virus was detectable in serum or stool by RT-PCR and sequencing. Upon molecular characterization, the viruses were classified as HEV genotype 3f and were in the same cluster as Thai pig HEV. Conclusions: Our data have demonstrated that acute HEV infection has a variety of clinical presentations and outcomes. Higher serum alkaline phosphatase levels were observed in high-risk patients. All isolated viruses were identified as HEV genotype 3f, presumably of porcine origin. Â© 2014 Hainan Medical College.
authors: Poovorawan, K.;Jitmitrapab, S.;Treeprasertsuk, S.;Thongmee, T.;Theamboonlers, A.;Tangkijvanich, P.;Komolmit, P.;Poovorawan, Y.

title: Identification of the silent human virus with emphasis on giant viruses
authors: Popgeorgiev, N.;Temmam, S.;Raoult, D.;Desnues, C.

title: Molecular detection of hepatitis E virus in eastern Romanian wild boar population
abstract: Representing wild boar and pig as the main reservoirs for the zoonotic genotype HEV-3 in Europe, Hepatitis E is a recognized zoonosis in industrialized countries. Data on HEV infection in the Romanian wild boar population are limited to serological studies. Therefore, our main aim was to determine the prevalence of HEV in the wild boar population and to characterize the HEV strains circulating in Romania. Using the TaqMan real-time RT-PCR assay, we analyzed the presence of RNA HEV in 45 liver samples and five spleen samples collected from 50 wild boars. The specimens were collected during the 2013-2015 hunting seasons. Nine of the 50 samples tested positive for HEV RNA, with an overall prevalence of 18%. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the isolates clustered in different HEV-3 monophyletic groups depending on the sampling county. This is the first study to indicate the presence of HEV in the wild boar population from Romania based on molecular analysis. In addition, HEV detection in wild boar spleen tissue was reported in this study.
authors: Porea, D.;Anita, A.;Demange, A.;Raileanu, C.;Oslobanu, L.;Anita, D.;Savuta, G.;Pavio, N.

title: The basis of arbovirus classification
abstract: The group of biologically defined arboviruses includes more than 300 individual viruses, divided into about 40 serological groups on the basis of antigenic cross-reactivity. More than three-quarters of all arboviruses can be placed in one of the five main taxonomic types based on the virion's fundamental characteristics: alphavirus, flavivirus, orbivirus, rhabdovirus, bunyavirus. There are 20 alphaviruses representing serological Group A and 57 flaviviruses in serological Group B; These two genera belong to the Togaviridae family. 40 orbiviruses in the Reoviridae family contain 8 serological groups, and 8 rhabdoviruses in the Rhabdoviridae family contain 3 more groups. About 160 bunyaviruses, family Bunyaviridae, can be divided into 20 serological groups, 10 of which show intragroup cross-reactions in the supergroup Bunyamwera. An arbovirus contains DNA, ie African swine fever virus; it is classified as an Iridovirus or icosahedral cytoplasmic deoxyvirus. Nodamura virus, classified as a picornavirus, should be reclassified based on evidence that it has a fragmented genome. A number of arboviruses remain taxonomically unclassified. It is of interest that there are no representatives of arboviruses in several main genera, such as adenoviruses and myxoviruses.
authors: Porterfield, J. S.

title: Systemic virus distribution and host responses in the brain and intestines of chickens infected with low pathogenic or highly pathogenic avian influenza virus.
abstract: Background: Avian influenza virus (AIV) is classified into two pathotypes, low pathogenic (LP) and highly pathogenic (HP), based on virulence in chickens. The differences in pathogenicity between HPAIV and LPAIV may ultimately be related to the specific characteristics of the strains, tissue. tropism and host responses. Methods: To examine differences in disease development between HPAIV and LPAIV, we examined the initial appearance and ultimate load of viral RNA in multiple organs, as well as host responses in the brain and intestines of chickens infected with two closely related strains of H7N1 HPAIV or LPAIV. Results: Both H7N1 HPAIV and LPAIV spread systemically in chickens after a combined intranasal/intratracheal vaccination. In the brain, large differences in viral RNA load and host gene expression were found between H7N1 HPAIV and LPAIV-infected chickens. Chicken embryo brain cell culture studies revealed that both HPAIV and LPAIV can infect seeded embryonic brain cells, but LPAIV replication is limited by the absence of essential proteases. Furthermore, the TUNEL test showed apoptosis only in the brain of HPAIV-infected chickens. In the gut where endoproteases that degrade LPAIV HA are present, we found minimal differences in the amount of viral RNA and a large overlap in transcriptional responses between HPAIV and LPAIV-infected chickens. Interestingly, the brain and ileum were clearly different in cellular pathways regulated by an AI infection. Conclusions: Although both H7N1 HPAIV and LPAIV RNA have been detected in a wide variety of tissues beyond the respiratory and gastrointestinal tract, our observations suggest that differences in pathogenicity and mortality between HPAIV and LPAIV may be due to differences in virus replication and resulting host responses. vital organs such as the brain.
authors: Post, J.;Burt, D. W.;Cornelissen, J. B. W. J.;Broks, V.;van Zoelen, D.;Peeters, B.;Rebel, J. M. J.

title: Classical swine fever virus isolates from Cuba generate a new subgenotype 1.4
abstract: The identification and classification of classical swine fever virus (CSFV) based on nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analysis has become an important tool for studying epidemiology and controlling CSF disease. According to phylogenetic analyzes of short sequences from the 5' untranslated region (150nt) and E2 (190nt), most CSFV isolates from South and Central America are classified into subgenotypes 1.1 and 1.3, while CSFV isolates from Cuba are sub-genotype 1.2. Here we show that identification and comparison of full-length E2 sequences as well as sequences encoding Npro, C, Erns, E1 and E2 (3361nt) do not support the separation of Cuban CSFV isolates into subgenotype 1.2. In fact, our analysis revealed that the Cuban isolates differed from other CSFV subgenotype 1 isolates so far known, forming a new distinct subgenotype proposed to be designated subgenotype 1.4. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Postel, A.;Schmeiser, S.;Perera, C. L.;RodrÃ­guez, L. J. P.;Frias-Lepoureau, M. T.;Becher, P.

title: Definition of virome in cerebrospinal fluid in patients with neurological complications after hematopoietic stem cell transplantation
authors: Pou, C.;Barrientos-Somarribas, M.;Marin-Juan, S.

title: Cowpea mosaic virus: effects on host cell processes
abstract: SUMMARY Taxonomy: Cowpea mosaic virus (CPMV) is a type member of Comoviridae and shows a strong similarity to animal picornaviruses both in gene organization and amino acid sequence of replication proteins. Few systematic studies have been done to compare virus isolates from different parts of the world. Physical properties: Purified virus preparations contain three centrifugal components; empty protein shells without RNA (T) and two nucleoprotein components (M and B) containing 24% and 34% RNA, respectively. The icosahedral particles have a diameter of 28 nm, consist of 60 copies of a double protein and are heat stable. Hosts: CPMV causes one of the most commonly reported cowpea (Vigna unguiculata) viral diseases, in which it produces widely circumscribed chlorotic spots on inoculated primary leaves. Trifoliate leaves develop a bright yellow or light green mosaic of increasing severity on young leaves. The host range is very limited and few hosts are known apart from Leguminosae. The virus is transmitted by various insects that bite the mouthparts. It has been reported in Africa, the Philippines, and Iran. Apparently not in North and South America. Useful website: http://mmtsb.scripps.edu/viper/1cpmv.html (build); http://image.fs.uidaho.edu/vide/descr254.htm (general information).
authors: Pouwels, J.;Carette, J. E.;Van Lent, J.;Wellink, J.

title: Development of epitope-blocking ELISA for universal detection of antibodies against human H5N1 influenza viruses
abstract: Background: Human infections with highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza viruses have generally been confirmed by molecular amplification or culture-based methods. Serological surveillance has potential unrealized advantages as rapid and specific serological tests to detect H5N1 infection are not widely available. Methodology/Key Findings: Here we describe an epitope-blocking ELISA to detect specific antibodies against H5N1 viruses in human or animal sera. The test is based on a novel monoclonal antibody (5F8) that binds to an epitope containing amino acid residues 274-281 (CNTKCQTP) in the HA1 region of H5 hemagglutinin. Database search analysis of publicly available sequences revealed that this epitope is conserved in 100% of 163 H5N1 viruses isolated from humans. The sensitivity and specificity of the epitope-blocking ELISA for H5N1 was evaluated using chicken antisera for multiple virus strains and other influenza subtypes, as well as serum samples from individuals naturally infected with H5N1 or seasonal influenza viruses. The epitope-blocking ELISA results were compared with the results of the hemagglutinin inhibition (HI) and microneutralization assays. Antibodies to H5N1 were readily detected in animals immunized by epitope-blocking ELISA or in convalescent human sera, while samples with antibodies to other influenza subtypes gave negative results. The test showed higher sensitivity and specificity compared to HI and microneutralization. Results/Significance: Epitope-blocking ELISA based on a unique 5F8 mAb provided detection of highly sensitive and 100% specific antibodies to H5N1 influenza viruses in human serum.
authors: Prabakaran, M.;Ho, H. T.;Prabhu, N.;Velumani, S.;Szyporta, M.;He, F.;Chan, K. P.;Chen, L. M.;Matsuoka, Y.;Donis, R. O.;Kwang, J.

title: Novel hepatitis B virus of cranes with an unexpectedly wide host range
abstract: All hepadnaviruses known so far have a very limited host range, limited to their natural hosts and a few closely related species. This is thought to be mainly due to sequence variation in the large envelope protein and species-specific differences in host components required for virus propagation. Here we report infection of cranes with a novel hepadnavirus, designated CHBV, which has an unexpectedly wide host range and is only distantly evolutionarily related to avihepadnaviruses of related hosts. Direct DNA sequencing of amplified CHBV DNA, as well as sequencing of cloned viral genomes, shows that CHBV, although different from Ross's goose hepatitis B virus (RGHBV), is most closely related and somewhat less closely related to duck hepatitis B virus (DHBV). revealed that. . Phylogenetically, cranes are far from geese and ducks and are most closely related to herons and storks. The naturally occurring hepadnaviruses in the last two species are quite different in sequence from RGHBV and DHBV and do not infect ducks or do so only marginally. In contrast, recombinant CHBV generated from crane sera CHBV and LMH cells infected primary duck hepatocytes almost as efficiently as DHBV. This is the first report of a fairly wide host range of an avihepadnavirus. Our data imply the use of similar or identical entry pathways and receptors, unusual host and virus adaptation mechanisms, or differential evolution of host genomes and cellular components essential for virus propagation by DHBV and CHBV.
authors: Prassolov, A.;Hohenberg, H.;Kalinina, T.;Schneider, C.;Cova, L.;Krone, O.;FrÃ¶lich, K.;Will, H.;Sirma, H.

title: Genomic characterization of pestiviruses isolated from lambs and kids in southern Italy.
abstract: nested polymerase chain reaction was used to identify 13 pestivirus strains isolated from small ruminant animals in various mixed (sheep and goat) herds of Southern Italy and classify them as bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) type 1, BVDV type 2 and Border disease. virus (BDV) genotypes. Of the nine sheep isolates, two were characterized as BVDV type 1 and seven as BVDV type 2. Four pestiviruses isolated from kids belong to BVDV type 1. None of the tested pestivirus strains could be classified as 'true' BDV (genotype 3). ). Although BVDV type 2 has been rarely identified in Europe, characterization of the BD/90-1M strain as BVDV type 2, which was isolated in Italy in 1990, indicates that this genotype has been circulating in Italy since the 1990s. © 2001 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Pratelli, A.;Martella, V.;Cirone, F.;Buonavoglia, D.;Elia, G.;Tempesta, M.;Buonavoglia, C.

title: Isolation and comparative study of five strains of infectious ecthyma of sheep 'in vitro'
abstract: Five bark samples from sheep bred in various countries and clinically affected by infectious ecthyma yielded infectious agents that caused a cytopathic effect on primary cultures of lamb kidney cells. The 5 infectious agents 'in vitro' showed similar stability characteristics in the presence of various physical and chemical agents. These features associate viruses from the group of pox viruses and identify them as ecthyma viruses. Examination of the 5 agents with serum neutralization made it possible to quantify the respective association and dominance characters. When the serological definitions of strains, types and subtypes recommended for FMD viruses are applied to these characters, it is seen that 4 of the agents can be classified within the same antigenic subtype, and the 5th is very close to the other 4. classified as a different subtype in the limit. The 5 agents are serologically very close to each other, but their different characteristics of dominance may be of interest in choosing one as a vaccine.
authors: Precausta, P.;Stellmann, C.

title: Host Response to Probiotics Determined by Nutritional Status of Newborn Mice Infected with Rotavirus
abstract: Objectives: Beneficial microbes and probiotics are promising agents for the prevention and treatment of enteric and diarrheal diseases in children; however, little is known about its mechanisms of action in vivo. We used the neonatal mouse rotavirus diarrhea model to gain insight into how probiotics ameliorate acute gastroenteritis. Methods: Rotavirus-infected mice were treated with 1 of 2 strains of human Lactobacillus reuteri. We assessed gut microbiome composition by 16S metagenomic sequencing, enterocyte migration and proliferation with 5-bromo-2'-deoxyuridine, and antibody and cytokine concentrations by multiplex analyzes of gut explant cultures. Results: Probiotics reduced diarrhea duration, improved gut histopathology, and increased gut microbiome richness and phylogenetic diversity. The extent of diarrhea reduction by probiotics was strain-specific and influenced by nutritional status. L reuteri DSM 17938 reduced the duration of diarrhea in underweight, normal weight, and overweight pups by 0.1 and 2 days, respectively. The magnitude of the reduction in diarrhea duration is associated with increased enterocyte proliferation and migration. The ATCC PTA 6475 strain reduced the duration of diarrhea by 1 day in all mice without increasing enterocyte proliferation. Both probiotic strains decreased the concentrations of proinflammatory cytokines, including macrophage inflammatory protein-I alpha and interleukin-I beta, in all animals and increased rotavirus-specific antibodies in all animals except low-weight animals. Body weight also affected the host response to rotavirus in terms of diarrhea duration, enterocyte turnover, and antibody production. Conclusions: These data suggest that probiotic increase in enterocyte proliferation, villus repopulation and virus-specific antibodies can contribute to diarrhea resolution and nutritional status influences host response to both beneficial microbes and pathogens.
authors: Preidis, G. A.;Saulnier, D. M.;Blutt, S. E.;Mistretta, T. A.;Riehle, K. P.;Major, A. M.;Venable, S. F.;Barrish, J. P.;Finegold, M. J.;Petrosino, J. F.;Guerrant, R. L.;Conner, M. E.;Versalovic, J.

title: Full-length genome of a novel genotype 3 hepatitis E virus strain from domestic pigs in Japan.
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) causes acute or chronic hepatitis in humans and can be transmitted by the fecal-oral route. Pigs are one of the main reservoirs of this infection. Sixty pigs aged 4-5 months in a herd in Japan had detectable anti-HEV IgG antibodies, and five (8.3%) of these had ongoing genotype 3 HEV infection. Five HEV strains from viremic pigs shared 98.8%-100% nucleotide identity, and one representative strain (swHE1606845), whose whole genomic sequence was determined in this study, differed 14.1%-19.6% from the reported HEV strains. 14.7%-19.1% of subtypes 3a-3k and other genotype 3 HEV strains whose subtypes have not yet been assigned. swHE1606845 showed a higher nucleotide p-spacing value of â‰¥0.143 with genotype 3 HEV strains of 3a–3k subtypes and â‰¥0.143 with other genotype 3 strains of unassigned subtypes. A SimPlot analysis revealed a lack of recombination events. These results indicate that swHE1606845 is a candidate member of a novel genotype 3 subtype. Further efforts to identify the new swHE1606845-like strain are warranted to clarify the origin of this strain and to determine the exact nucleotide sequences of two additional swHE1606845-like strains. To assign a new subtype.
authors: Primadharsini, P. P.;Miyake, M.;Kunita, S.;Nishizawa, T.;Takahashi, M.;Nagashima, S.;Tanggis;Ohnishi, H.;Kobayashi, T.;Nishiyama, T.;Jirintai, S.;Okamoto, H.

title: Virus taxonomy at the XIth International Congress of Virology, Sydney, Australia, 1999
authors: Pringle, C. R.

title: Diagnosis of EDS-76 infection by the filter paper strip method
abstract: Egg drop syndrome - 7E5 (EDS - 76) virus, III of the genus Avisadenovirus in the family Adenoviridae. classified under the group. The virus is closely related to bovine and ovine adenoviruses while not closely related to other avian adenoviruses. The disease caused by the EDS-76 virus is one of the major problems in the poultry industry that causes great economic losses. Hemagglutination inhibition (HI) test is accepted as a rapid, reliable and economical diagnostic test for this disease. Nobuto (1967) and Brugh and Beard (1980) reported that blood can be absorbed and dried on filter paper strips without impairing antibody activity. Therefore, this study was conducted to evaluate the suitability of whole blood dried on filter paper strips for the quantitative analysis of HI antibodies against the EDS-76 virus.
authors: Priya, P. M.;Nair, G. K.;Mini, M.;Jayaprakash, V.

title: Analysis of the S1 gene of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) reveals changes in IBV genetic groups circulating in southern Thailand.
abstract: New variants of avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) produce a range of symptoms and cause global economic losses to the poultry industry. We investigated the S1 glycoprotein of the last 24 IBV isolates from chickens and showed that two dominant genetic groups were circulating in Southern Thailand between 2008 and 2013. Seven IBV variants isolated from 2008 to 2009 clustered in Thailand THA001 group I, while 15 IBV variants isolated from 2009 to 2013 were classified in QX-like group II. In addition, a single isolate from a broiler was categorized as Massachusetts type, and one isolate from one layer belonged to virus type 4/91. Interestingly, both IBV groups I and II were isolated from domestic chickens (62.5%) and caused a range of symptoms. Our results show that QX-like viruses predominated after 2009 and replaced THA001-type viruses. Additionally, domestic chickens may contribute to the epidemiology of IB.
authors: Promkuntod, N.;Thongmee, S.;Yoidam, S.

title: Wild bird migration along the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau: A transmission route for highly pathogenic H5N1.
abstract: Background: Qinghai Lake in central China is at the center of the debate over whether wild birds play a role in the circulation of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1. In 2005, an unprecedented epizootic in Qinghai Lake killed more than 6,000 migratory birds, including more than 3,000 stick-headed geese (Anser indicus). H5N1 then spread to Europe and Africa and reappeared in wild birds several times along the Central Asian passageway in the following years. Methodology/Key Findings: To better understand the possible involvement of wild birds in the spread of H5N1, we examined the movements of stick-headed geese tagged with GPS satellite transmitters in Qinghai Lake regarding virus outbreaks and disease risk factors. We discovered a previously undocumented migration route between Qinghai Lake and Tibet's Lhasa Valley, where 93% of 29 marked geese overwintered. Between 2003 and 2009, sixteen outbreaks in poultry or wild birds were confirmed on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, the majority of which were within the geese's migration route.
