The spatial and temporal alignment between geese movements and three potential sources of H5N1 virus (poultry farms, a captive bar-headed goose facility, and H5N1 outbreak sites) indicated that there are ample opportunities for virus spread in wintering areas and infection of migratory geese. Their potential as H5N1 vector has been supported by the rapid migratory movements of some geese and the genetic inbreeding of the H5N1 virus isolated from geese in Tibet and Qinghai Lake. Conclusions/Significance: This is the first study to compare the phylogenetics of the virus with the spatial ecology of the host, and the combined results suggest that wild birds play a role in the spread of H5N1 in this region. However, the strength of the evidence will be strengthened by additional sequences from both poultry and wild birds on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, where H5N1 has a clear stronghold.
authors: Prosser, D. J.;Cui, P.;Takekawa, J. Y.;Tang, M.;Hou, Y.;Collins, B. M.;Yan, B.;Hill, N. J.;Li, T.;Li, Y.;Lei, F.;Guo, S.;Xing, Z.;He, Y.;Zhou, Y.;Douglas, D. C.;Perry, W. M.;Newman, S. H.

title: ICTV virus classification profile: Hepeviridae
abstract: The Hepeviridae family includes small, non-enveloped positive-sense RNA viruses that are enterically transmitted. It includes the genus Piscihepevirus, whose members infect fish, and Orthohepevirus, whose members infect mammals and birds. Members of the Orthohepevirus genus include hepatitis E virus, which is responsible for self-limiting acute hepatitis in humans and a few mammalian species; The infection may become chronic in immunocompromised individuals. Extrahepatic manifestations of Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuralgic amyotrophy, glomerulonephritis, and pancreatitis have been described in humans. Avian hepatitis E virus causes hepatitis-splenomegaly syndrome in chickens. This is a summary of the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV) Report on Hepeviridae taxonomy available at www.ictv.global/report/hepeviridae.
authors: Purdy, M. A.;Harrison, T. J.;Jameel, S.;Meng, X. J.;Okamoto, H.;Van Der Poel, W. H. M.;Smith, D. B.

title: Characterization of Marek's disease virus from a poultry epidemic in Meghalaya, northeastern India, and phylogenetic analyzes of the meq gene.
abstract: The aim of this study was to characterize the virus from the histopathology and lesions of organs associated with mortality in Kuroiler (dual-purpose poultry variety developed and marketed by Keggfarms Pvt. Ltd, India) birds suspected of Marek disease. Two types of lesions were observed in post mortem examination among 1047 birds from two farms in different locations with 5.5% and 34% mortality; tumors in vital organs-liver, spleen, kidney, lung and ovaries, and generalized small nodular tumor in the abdominal cavity. Molecular characterization based on detection of the ICP4 gene demonstrated the presence of Marek's disease virus (MDV) from tissues and cell culture-adapted isolates in Madin Darby Canine Kidney cell lines. Histopathological examination revealed multinucleated immature lymphoid cell infiltration in the organs. Phylogenetic analysis of the isolates based on the meq gene showed that the isolates belonged to the cluster I genotype of MDV. This is the first time that the MDV virus has been characterized from an outbreak affecting production in a flock of poultry in a farmer's field in the North East Indian state of Meghalaya.
authors: Puro, K. U.;Bhattacharjee, U.;Baruah, S.;Sen, A.;Das, S.;Ghatak, S.;Doley, S.;Sanjukta, R.;Shakuntala, I.

title: Genotype characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolated from commercial chicken flocks in West Java, Indonesia.
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is a worldwide highly contagious poultry disease caused by the Newcastle disease virus (NDV). Despite vaccination, ND outbreaks have been regularly reported in Indonesian commercial chicken flocks. Our study aimed to determine the genotype and genetic association of isolates with other Indonesian NDVs published in GenBank. Four NDV isolates were obtained from vaccinated herds in West Java, Indonesia in 2011, 2014, 2015. Two NDVs belong to virulent strains and the other two belong to avirulent strains. Phylogenetic analyzes of the F gene, genotype VII subgenotype (h) and (i) of NDV/Ck/BGR/11 and NDV/Ck/GS/14; NDV/Ck/CJR/15 and NDV/Ck/BGR/15 belong to genotype II. Virulent NDVs clustered in the same genotype and are closely related to previous Indonesian NDVs isolated in 2007, 2009 and 2010. The result of the present study is high similarity of recent NDVs of subgenotype VIIh and VIIi circulating in commercial poultry farm in West Java, Indonesia with NDVs isolated in 2007 and 2010 in Indonesia. Our findings may be valuable for future studies to develop improved control and diagnostic strategies of ND.
authors: Putri, D. D.;Handharyani, E.;Soejoedono, R. D.;Setiyono, A.;Mayasari, N. L. P. I.;Poetri, O. N.

title: Ecology and age structure of a highly pathogenic avian influenza virus outbreak in wild mute swans
abstract: The first epizootic case of highly pathogenic (HP) H5N1 influenza in wild birds in the UK occurred in 2008 in a population of mute swans that has been the subject of ornithological study for decades. Here we use an innovative combination of ornithological, phylogenetic and immunological approaches to investigate the ecology and age structure of HP H5N1 in nature. We screened samples from swans and waterfowl using PCR and sequenced HP H5N1-positive samples. The origin of the outbreak was investigated by linking bird count data with molecular clock analysis of sampled virus sequences. We used bell recordings to reconstruct the age structure of epidemic deaths and estimated the age distribution of prior exposure to avian influenza. The epidemic mortality rate was low and all HP H5N1-positive mute swans in the affected population were <3 years old. Only the youngest age classes included a significant number of individuals with no detectable antibody response to the viral nucleoprotein. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the epidemic strain circulated locally ~1 month before detection and reached the time when the migration rate of migratory waterfowl was at its highest. Our data are consistent with the hypothesis that HP H5N1 epizootics in wild swans exhibit limited mortality due to immune protection from previous exposure. Our study population can be a valuable resource for investigating the natural ecology and epidemiology of avian influenza.
authors: Pybus, O. G.;Perrins, C. M.;Choudhury, B.;Manvell, R. J.;Nunez, A.;Schulenburg, B.;Sheldon, B. C.;Brown, I. H.

title: Molecular characterization of the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza a virus isolated from raccoon dogs in China.
abstract: Background: The highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus can infect a variety of animals and poses a persistent threat to animal and human health. While many genotypes of the H5N1 virus can be found in chicken, few are associated with infection of mammals. Characterization of genotypes of viral strains in animal populations is important for understanding the distribution of different viral strains in various hosts. It also facilitates the monitoring and detection of the possible emergence of highly pathogenic strains of certain genotypes from unknown hosts or hosts that have not previously been reported to carry these genotypes. Methodology/Basic Findings: Two H5N1 isolates were obtained from lung samples of two raccoon dogs who died of respiratory disease in China. Pathogenicity experiments have shown that the isolates are highly pathogenic to chicken. To characterize the genotypes of these viruses, their genomic sequences were determined and analyzed. The genetic contents of these isolates are almost identical and may come from the same progenitor virus. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that the isolates are genetically closely related to the genotype V H5N1 virus, first isolated in China in 2003, and differ from the dominant virus genotypes (eg, genotype Z) of recent years. The isolates also contain a multibasic amino acid motif at HA cleavage sites and have an E residue at position 627 of the PB2 protein, similar to previously identified avian viruses. Consequences/Significance: This is the first report that genotype V H5N1 virus has been found to be associated with a mammalian host. Our results strongly suggest that genotype V H5N1 virus has the ability to cross species barriers to infect mammals. These findings further highlight the risk posed by the avian influenza H5N1 virus to mammals and humans who may be infected by specific genotypes not known to infect these hosts. Â© 2009 Qi et al.
authors: Qi, X.;Li, X.;Rider, P.;Fan, W.;Gu, H.;Xu, L.;Yang, Y.;Lu, S.;Wang, H.;Liu, F.

title: Genetic characterization of H1N1 swine flu A viruses isolated in eastern China.
abstract: In 2005, three influenza H1N1 viruses were isolated from pigs with respiratory disease on a farm in eastern China. Three isolates were characterized to determine their possible origin. Each of the eight genes of the isolates was most closely related to the corresponding gene from the classic porcine H1N1 virus. In addition, phylogenetic analysis confirmed that each of the eight genes of the isolates are closely related to classical porcine H1N1 viruses, particularly those isolated in China. The HA1 proteins of the three isolates were identical to that of A/Swine/Guangdong/1/01, a virus isolated in China in 2001, although three nucleotide differences were observed. These results further support the concept that the pig may serve as a reservoir of genetically stable influenza viruses. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Qi, X.;Pang, B.;Lu, C. P.

title: MicroRNA expression profile of goat peripheral blood mononuclear cells in response to Peste des petits ruminant virus infection
abstract: Peste des petits ruminant virus (PPRV) belongs to the Morbillivirus genus, which causes an acute and highly contagious disease in goats and sheep. Virus infection can trigger change in the cellular microRNA (miRNA) expression profile, which plays important post-transcriptional regulatory roles in gene expression and can greatly influence viral replication and pathogenesis. Here, we used deep sequencing technology to determine the cellular miRNA expression profile in goat peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) infected with Nigeria 75/1 vaccinia virus, a widely used vaccine strain for mass vaccination programs against Peste des petits ruminants. Expression analysis showed that PPRV infection was able to elicit 316 significantly differentially expressed (DE) miRNAs, including 103 known and 213 novel miRNA candidates, in infected PBMC at 24 h post infection (hpi) compared to a mock control. Target prediction and functional analysis of this DEmiRNA revealed significant enrichment for a variety of signaling pathways, including TLR signaling pathways, PI3K-Akt, endocytosis, viral carcinogenesis, and JAK-STAT signaling pathways. This study provides a valuable basis for further investigation of the roles of miRNA in PPRV replication and pathogenesis.
authors: Qi, X.;Wang, T.;Xue, Q.;Li, Z.;Yang, B.;Wang, J.

title: Identification of genes critical for resistance to infection by West Nile virus using RNA-Seq analysis
abstract: West Nile virus (WNV) is a new infection that raises biodefense concern, and there are no treatments or vaccines available. Here, we used a high-throughput method based on a novel gene expression analysis (RNA-Seq) to give a global picture of differential gene expression by primary human macrophages of 10 healthy donors infected with WNV in vitro. From a total of 28 million reads per sample, we identified 1,514 transcripts that were differentially expressed after infection. Both predicted and novel gene changes, such as gene isoforms, were detected, and while most genes were expressed by all donors, some were unique. Knockdown of genes not previously known to be associated with WNV resistance defined their critical role in controlling viral infection. Our work distinguishes both common gene pathways and novel cellular responses. Such analyzes will be valuable for translational studies of susceptible and resistant individuals and for targeting therapeutics in multiple biological settings. Â© 2013 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Qian, F.;Chung, L.;Zheng, W.;Bruno, V.;Alexander, R. P.;Wang, Z.;Wang, X.;Kurscheid, S.;Zhao, H.;Fikrig, E.;Gerstein, M.;Snyder, M.;Montgomery, R. R.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis of glycoprotein genes of two porcine paramyxoviruses isolated from the United States.
abstract: Two porcine paramyxoviruses (SPMV)-(81-19252 (Texas-81) and 92-7783 (ISU-92)-) were isolated from encephalitic pigs in the United States in 1981 and 1992. The antigenic, morphological, and biological characteristics of these two viruses are essentially Similar to members of the Paramyxoviridae family Antigenic analysis by indirect fluorescent antibody, immunoblot, and one-way cross-neutralization tests placed these viruses together with bovine parainfluenza 3 (BPIV3) viruses. The purified virions were 50-300 nm in size and morphologically indistinguishable from other paramyxoviruses. hemagglutinated red blood cells and had neuraminidase activity Gene linkages of the fusion (F) and hemagglutinin (HN) glycoprotein genes of these viruses contained highly conserved transcription start and stop signal sequences and trinucleotide intergenic regions similar to other Paramyxoviridae F gene of ISU-92 , translation of the 24 nucleotide "U" rich 3 The region was taller than Texas-81 due to the job addition. Structure-based sequence alignment of the glycoproteins of these two SPMVs showed that they were essentially similar in structure and function to parainfluenzaviruses. The Texas-81 strain was closely related to the BPIV3 Shipping Fever (SF) strain at the nucleotide and amino acid level, while the ISU-92 strain was more closely related to the BPIV3 910N strain. The envelope glycoproteins of ISU-92 had only ~92 and ~96% identity with strain BPIV3-SF at the nucleotide and amino acid levels, respectively. High sequence identities for BPIV3 indicated interspecies infection in pigs. Phylogenetic analyzes based on both the F protein and HN protein suggested classification of these viruses within the Paramyxovirinae subfamily, the Respirovirus genus, and the A genotype of BPIV3. © 2009 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Qiao, D.;Janke, B. H.;Elankumaran, S.

title: Viral communities associated with swine respiratory disease complex on busy commercial farms in Sichuan province, China.
abstract: Pig respiratory disease complex (PRDC), a common piglet disease, causes significant economic losses in pig farming. To investigate the viral diversity associated with PRDC, viral communities in serum and nasal swabs from 26 piglets affected by PRDC were investigated using metagenomics. By deep sequencing and de novo splicing, 17 viruses were identified in two pooled libraries (16 viruses from serum, nine from nasal swabs). Porcine circovirus (PCV)-2, porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV), and pseudorabies virus, all commonly associated with PRDC, were identified by metagenomics in two pooled samples, but most viruses are composed of small linear and circular DNAs (e.g. parvoviruses, bocaviruses and circoviruses). PCR was used to compare the detection rates of each virus in serum samples from 36 PRDC-affected piglets versus 38 location-matched clinically healthy controls. The average virus category per sample was 6.81 for PRDC-affected piglets and 4.09 for controls. Single or co-infections with PCV-2 or PRRSV had very high detection rates in PRDC-affected piglets. Interestingly, porcine parvovirus (PPV)-2, PPV-3, PPV-6 and torque tenosus virus 1a were significantly associated with PRDC. These results demonstrate the complexity of viral communities in piglets affected by PRDC and highlight candidate viruses associated with it.
authors: Qin, S.;Ruan, W.;Yue, H.;Tang, C.;Zhou, K.;Zhang, B.

title: Complete genome sequence of the first bluetongue virus serotype 21 (BTV-21) isolated from China: evidence for genetic reclassification between BTV-21 and bluetongue virus serotype 16 (BTV-16)
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) is one of the most important insect-borne, non-contagious viral diseases of ruminants and can cause serious illness and death in sheep. Its pathogen, the bluetongue virus (BTV), has a 10-segment double-stranded RNA genome that provides an opportunity for field and vaccine strains of different serotypes while simultaneously infecting the same animal. We report for the first time the full-length genome sequence of a BTV serotype 21 (5149E) strain isolated from sentinel cattle in Guangxi Province, China in 2015. Sequence analysis showed that isolate 5149E underwent a reclassification event and acquired segments. -6 from a BTV-16 isolate originating from Japan. This study aims to provide more information about the origin and epidemiology of BTV.
authors: Qin, S.;Yang, H.;Zhang, Y.;Li, Z.;Lin, J.;Gao, L.;Liao, D.;Cao, Y.;Ren, P.;Li, H.;Wu, J.

title: A tick-borne segmented RNA virus contains genome segments derived from unsegmented viral ancestors.
abstract: Although cleaved and non-spliced RNA viruses are common, the evolutionary links between these two very different forms of genome organization are unclear. We report the discovery and characterization of a tick-borne virus (Jingmen tick virus (JMTV)) that reveals an unexpected link between segmented and non-segmented RNA viruses. The JMTV genome consists of four segments, two of which are related to nonstructural protein genes of the Flavivirus genus (family Flaviviridae), the remaining segments are unique to this virus, have no known homologues and contain a number of features that show structural features. protein genes. Remarkably, homology search revealed that JMTV-related sequences were present in the cDNA library from Toxocara canis (dog roundworm; Nematoda) and shared strong sequence and structural similarities. Epidemiological studies have shown that JMTV is distributed throughout China in tick populations, particularly Rhipicephalus and Haemaphysalis spp., experiencing frequent host switching and genomic reclassification. To our knowledge, JMTV is the first example of a segmented RNA virus with a genome partially derived from non-segmented viral ancestors.
authors: Qin, X. C.;Shi, M.;Tian, J. H.;Lin, X. D.;Gao, D. Y.;He, J. R.;Wang, J. B.;Li, C. X.;Kang, Y. J.;Yu, B.;Zhou, D. J.;Xu, J.;Plyusnin, A.;Holmes, E. C.;Zhang, Y. Z.

title: Subtyping of animal influenza virus by general multiplex RT-PCR and Liquichip high throughput (GMPLex)
abstract: This study developed a multiplex RT-PCR integrated with luminex technology to rapidly subtype multiple influenza viruses simultaneously. Primers and probes are designed to amplify the NS and M genes of influenza A viruses, the HA gene of H1, H3, H5, H7, H9 subtypes, and the NA gene of N1 and N2 subtypes. Universal super primers were introduced to generate a multiplex RT-PCR (GM RT-PCR). This included three steps of RT-PCR amplification, and then the RT-PCR products were further tested by the LiquiChip probe, which was combined to yield an influenza virus (IV) rapid high-throughput subtyping test called GMPLex. The IV GMPlex rapid high-throughput subtyping assay offers the following features: high throughput, capable of identifying subtypes of 9 target genes in H1, H3, H5, H7, H9, N1 and N2 subtypes of influenza A virus at once; rapid, completion of influenza subtyping within 6 hours; high specificity, using two nested degenerate primers and one probe, guarantees the specificity of different subtypes, no cross-reaction between subtypes, no non-specific reaction with other pathogens, and high sensitivity. When used separately to detect single GM RT-PCR product for single H5 or N1 gene, the GMPLex assay showed a sensitivity of 10-5(=280ELD50) for both assays and Luminex qualitative ratio results were 3.08 and 3.12, respectively. When used concurrently to detect the GM RT-PCR product for strain H5N1, both showed a sensitivity of 10-4(=2800 ELD50). GMPlex rapid high-throughput subtyping test can meet the needs of influenza rapid test.
authors: Qin, Z. F.;Sun, J.;Lu, T. K.;Zeng, S. L.;Hua, Q. Y.;Ling, Q. Y.;Chen, S. K.;Lv, J. Q.;Zhang, C. H.;Cheng, B.;Ruan, Z. X.;Bi, Y. Z.;Giambrone, J. J.;Wu, H. Z.

title: Comprehensive transcriptome analysis reveals competing endogenous RNA networks during avian leukosis virus, subgroup J-induced tumorigenesis in chickens.
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) is an avian oncogenic retrovirus that induces myeloid tumors and hemangiomas in chickens and causes severe economic losses in commercial laying hens and broiler chickens. High-throughput sequencing followed by quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction and bioinformatics analyzes was performed to advance the understanding of the regulatory networks associated with differentially expressed non-coding RNAs and mRNAs that facilitate ALV-J infection. We examined the expression of mRNAs, long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs), and miRNAs in the spleens of ALV-J-infected 20-week-old chickens and uninfected chickens. We found that 1723 mRNAs, 7,883 lncRNAs and 13 miRNAs in the spleen were differentially expressed between uninfected and infected groups (P < 0.05). Transcript analysis showed that compared with mRNA, chicken lncRNAs share relatively less exon numbers and shorter transcripts. Through competing endogenous RNA and co-expression network analyses, we identified several tumor-associated or immune-related genes and lncRNAs. BCL11B showed the greatest change across transcripts, whose expression levels were significantly reduced in both ALV-J-infected spleen and tumor tissues. These results suggest that BCL11B may be mechanically involved in tumorigenesis in chicken and neoplastic diseases, be associated with immune response, and potentially be a novel biomarker for ALV-J infection. Our results provide a new insight into the pathology of ALV-J infection and a high-quality transcriptome resource for in-depth examination of epigenetic effects on disease resistance and the immune system.
authors: Qiu, L.;Chang, G.;Li, Z.;Bi, Y.;Liu, X.;Chen, G.

title: Discovery of novel long non-coding RNAs induced by subgroup Javian leukosis virus infection in chicken
abstract: Avian leukosis virus subgroup J (ALV-J) is an avian oncogenic retrovirus that has caused serious economic losses to the poultry industry in China in recent years. Here, a set of 4804 novel long noncoding transcripts and multiple differentially expressed long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) were identified using high-throughput transcriptome sequencing of HD11 and CEF cells infected with ALV-J. We also found that they share relatively shorter transcripts and less exon number compared to mRNA. Correlation analysis suggested that many lncRNAs could activate gene expression in an enhancer-like manner outside of transcriptional regulation. In vivo expression level analyzes showed that three lncRNAs (NONGGAT001975.2, NONGGAT005832.2 and NONGGAT009792.2) may be associated with immune response regulation and function as novel biomarkers for ALV-J infection. Our findings provide new insight into the pathological process of ALV-J infection and should serve as a high-quality resource for further research on immune system and genomic studies, as well as on epigenetic effects on disease-resistant reproduction.
authors: Qiu, L.;Li, Z.;Chang, G.;Bi, Y.;Liu, X.;Xu, L.;Zhang, Y.;Zhao, W.;Xu, Q.;Chen, G.

title: Detection of viromes of RNA viruses using next-generation sequencing libraries prepared by three methods
abstract: Virome (viral megagenomics) detection using next-generation sequencing is widely applied in virology, but its methods remain complex and require optimization. In this study, we detected viromes of RNA viruses of a mock sample, a pooled duck dung sample, and a pooled mink fecal sample on the Personal Genome Machine platform using sequencing libraries prepared by three methods. Sequencing primers were used by random hybridization and ligation to fragmented viral RNA using the RNA-Seq kit in method 1, by random reverse transcription (RT) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in method 2 developed in our laboratory, and using a single primer in Method 3 hybridization and ligation to fragmented amplicons of random RT-PCR. Although the results of these three samples (nine libraries) all showed that more classified viral families and genera were identified using methods 2 and 3 than with method 1. and more classified viral families and genera were identified using method 2 using method 3, most of the differences not statistically significant. In addition, 11 mammalian viral genera were identified in this study, possibly for the first time in minks.
authors: Qiu, Y.;Chen, J. M.;Wang, T.;Hou, G. Y.;Zhuang, Q. Y.;Wu, R.;Wang, K. C.

title: Evolutionary genomics of pandemic 2009 H1N1 influenza viruses (pH1N 1v)
abstract: Background: In April 2009, a new strain of human H1N1 influenza A viruses emerged, causing a worldwide pandemic emergency. This study attempts to estimate the temporal reclassification history of 2009 H1N1 viruses through phylogenetic analysis based on a total of 394 H1N1virus sequences isolated from pigs, humans and birds. Results: Phylogenetic trees of eight gene segments showed that viruses sampled from human constituted a well-supported segment, whereas pig and avian lineages were intermixed. A new divergence porcine subset was characterized, containing gene segments of 2009 H1N1 viruses closely related to porcine viruses collected in six segments (PB2, PB1, PA, HA, NP, and NS) from the USA and South Korea between 2004-2007 and 2004-2005. to swine viruses isolated from Thailand in NA and M. Substitution rates varied widely among the eight segments, and the mean substitution rate was generally higher in 2009 H1N1 than in porcine and human viruses (F 2.23= 5.972, P < 0.01). Similarly, higher rates of dN/dS substitution were detected in 2009 H1N1 than in porcine and human viruses except for the M2 gene (F2, 25= 3.779, P < 0.05). The 2009 H1N1 viruses were estimated to be between 0.1 and 0.5 years old, while their most closely related swine viruses had a common ancestor 9.3 to 17.37 years ago. Conclusion: Our results implied that at least four reclassifications or transmissions probably occurred prior to 2009 H1N1 viruses. The first reclassification appeared in 1976, and bird-like Eurasian swine viruses appeared. The second transmission occurred in Asia and North America between 1988 and 1992 and mostly affected six segments (PB2, PB1, PA, HA, NP and NS). The third reassortment occurred between 1998-2000 between North American pig and avian viruses containing the PB2 and PA segments. Recent reclassifications have occurred between avian-to-swine reassortant, Eurasian and classical swine viruses between 2004 and 2005. South Korea, Thailand and the USA were identified as the most likely places for reclassifications. The co-circulation of multiple swine subspecies and specialized lifestyles in Asia may have facilitated the mixing of various influenza viruses and resulted in the generation of a new virus strain. Â© 2011 Qu et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Qu, Y.;Zhang, R.;Cui, P.;Song, G.;Duan, Z.;Lei, F.

title: The complex microbiota of raw milk
abstract: Here we review what is known about microorganisms found in raw milk, including cow, sheep, goat and human milk. Milk can support a rich microbiota due to its high nutrient content. These microorganisms enter the milk from a variety of sources, and once in the milk, they can be used to facilitate milk fermentations (e.g. Lactococcus, Lactobacillus, Streptococcus, Propionibacterium and fungal populations), cause spoilage (e.g. and other spore-forming or thermoduric microorganisms), health-promoting (e.g. lactobacillus) and bifidobacteria) or cause disease (for example, Listeria, Salmonella, Escherichia coli, Campylobacter and mycotoxin-producing fungi). There is also concern that the presence of antibiotic residues in milk leads to the development of resistance, especially among pathogenic bacteria. Here, we comprehensively review these issues as we compare both culture-dependent and culture-independent approaches that can be taken to investigate the microbial composition of milk. Â© 2013 European Federation of Microbiology Societies.
authors: Quigley, L.;O'Sullivan, O.;Stanton, C.;Beresford, T. P.;Ross, R. P.;Fitzgerald, G. F.;Cotter, P. D.

title: Direct high-throughput in Cell-ELISA to measure infectivity of cytopathic and non-cytopathic bovine viral diarrhea virus strains applied to the evaluation of antiviral activity
abstract: Screening of antiviral compounds against multiple site strains requires low-cost, high-throughput methods applicable to any virus strain. Colorimetric cell viability assays are used for this purpose as long as the viruses are cytopathic (CP) in cell culture. However, bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) strains circulating in the field are mostly non-cytopathic (NCP). An In Cell-ELISA has been developed that aims to measure viral infectivity by detecting a conserved protein (nonstructural protein 3, "NS3") produced during viral replication. ELISA is performed directly on the 96-well culture plate without harvesting the cells. The NS3 In Cell-ELISA was tested for its ability to assess the BVDV-specific antiviral activity of recombinant bovine type I and III IFNs. Results correlate with those measured by qRT-PCR and virus titration. NS3 In Cell-ELISA was also effective in predicting the IC50 of two compounds with different antiviral activity. Estimation of 50% inhibition dose of each IFN using six BVDV strains from different biotypes and genotypes showed that CP strains were more sensitive to both IFNs than NCP, while type 2 NCP viruses were more sensitive to IFN-I. Using a detector antibody against a conserved nonstructural protein, the In Cell-ELISA format is potentially applicable to accurately measure the infectivity of any viral strain.
authors: Quintana, M. E.;Barone, L.;Forlenza, M. B.;Trotta, M. V.;Turco, C.;Mansilla, F. C.;Cardoso, N. P.;Capozzo, A. V.

title: Genome Dynamics and Molecular Infection Epidemiology of Multidrug-Resistant Helicobacter pullorum Isolates from Broiler and Free Range Chickens in India.
abstract: Some life-threatening, foodborne and zoonotic infections are transmitted through poultry. Inappropriate and indiscriminate use of antimicrobials in the livestock industry has resulted in an increased prevalence of multidrug-resistant bacteria with epidemic potential. Here, we present a functional molecular epidemiological analysis requiring phenotypic and whole genome sequencing-based characterization of 11 H. pullorum isolates from broiler and free-range chickens sampled from retail wet markets in Hyderabad, India. Antimicrobial susceptibility tests revealed that all isolates were resistant to multiple antibiotic classes such as fluoroquinolones, cephalosporins, sulfonamides, and macrolides. The isolates were also found to be broad-spectrum producers of Î²-lactamases and even resistant to clavulanic acid. Whole-genome sequencing and comparative genomic analysis of these isolates revealed the presence of five or six well-characterized antimicrobial resistance genes, including those encoding a resistance-nodulation-splitting efflux pump(s). Phylogenetic analysis combined with pan-genome analysis revealed a remarkable genetic diversity among isolates from free-range chickens; in contrast, a high degree of genetic similarity was observed among broiler isolates. Comparative genomic analysis of all publicly available H. pullorum genomes, including our isolates (n = 16), together with the genomes of 17 other Helicobacter species, revealed a high number of (8,560) H. pullorum-specific protein-coding genes. an average of 535 such genes per isolate. In silico virulence screening identified 182 important virulence genes and also revealed higher strain-specific gene content in isolates from free-range chickens (mean, 34) compared to broiler chicken isolates. A significant prevalence of prophage (range 1 to 9) and a significant presence of genomic islands (0 to 4) were observed in free-range and broiler isolates. Taken together, these observations provide important fundamental data for functional molecular epidemiology of infection by revealing the evolution of non-pyloric Helicobacter species such as H. pullorum in chickens and their possible zoonotic transmission to humans. IMPORTANCE: The poultry industry is expanding globally with an ever-growing consumer base for chicken meat. Given this, food-associated transmission of multidrug-resistant bacteria represents an important healthcare challenge. Our study includes a critical fundamental approach to the genome sequence-based epidemiology and transmission dynamics of H. pullorum, a poultry pathogen with zoonotic potential. We believe our work will facilitate the development of surveillance systems that ensure food safety for humans and guide public health policies regarding the use of antibiotics in animal feed in countries such as India. As part of this study, we sequenced 11 novel H. pullorum genomes. These genomes will add much value to the ongoing comparative genomic studies of helicobacteria.
authors: Qumar, S.;Majid, M.;Kumar, N.;Tiwari, S. K.;Semmler, T.;Devi, S.;Baddam, R.;Hussain, A.;Shaik, S.;Ahmed, N.

title: Identification of bovine papillomavirus 10 in cattle mammary warts by DNase-SISPA
abstract: Papillomaviruses are detected and identified by PCR with consensus primers designed from human papillomavirus sequences. This and other primers failed to detect papillomavirus in bovine mammary wart samples despite repeated attempts. DNase-SISPA, a metagenomic method for identifying viruses, can identify bovine papilloma virus type 10 in bovine mammary warts. Sequence comparison between consensus primers and bovine papilloma virus type 10 sequences revealed many differences between consensus primers and BPV-10 sequences. We suggest that DNase-SISPA can be used as an alternative method for papillomavirus diagnosis in cases where PCR cannot identify papillomaviruses. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Rai, G. K.;Saxena, M.;Singh, V.;Somvanshi, R.;Sharma, B.

title: A review of psittacine beak and feather disease and its impact on Australia's endangered species
abstract: BACKGROUND: Since it was first described in the early 1980s, psittasine beak and feather disease (PBFD) has been recognized as the predominant viral pathogen of psittasine birds in Australia. Our aim was to evaluate and review the impact of PBFD and its position as a significant threatening process to Australian psittacine bird species. We review the origin/evolutionary pathways and potential threat of PBFD to endangered psittasine bird populations and captive breeding flocks. CONCLUSIONS: The latest beak and feather disease virus (BFDV) phylogenetic analyzes indicate that all endangered Australian psittacine avian species are susceptible to and equally likely to be infected with BFDV genotypes from a range of host psittacine species. Disease management in captive breeding programs relied on testing and culling, which proved costly. The risk of PBFD should be very carefully evaluated by management teams considering the establishment of captive breeding herds for endangered species. Alternative disease prevention tools, including vaccination, which are increasingly used in wildlife health, should be more seriously considered to manage and prevent PBFD in captive herds of critically endangered species.
authors: Raidal, S. R.;Sarker, S.;Peters, A.

title: Functional characterization of a novel holin-like antibacterial protein-encoding gene tmp1 from the goat skin surface metagenome.
abstract: We identified a holin-like gene from the goat skin surface metagenome. The ORF encoded for 34 amino acids shared sequence similarity with putative holin-like toxin genes. To analyze the antibacterial activity of the tmp1 encoded protein, this ORF was cloned and expressed in Escherichia coli BL21(DE3). The expressed gene product Tmp1 exhibited antibacterial activity against Gram-positive bacteria but not Gram-negative bacteria. A single transmembrane domain (TMD) was identified within Tmp1, and analysis of the N-terminal region and deletion of TMD showed that TMD was responsible for antibacterial activity. TMD-dependent antibacterial activity was confirmed using a synthetic peptide with the amino acid sequence of TMD. Besides the antibacterial activity, Tmp1 also complemented the function of holin in the lysis-defective bacteriophage lambda. To broaden the spectrum of antibacterial activity, a mutant tmp1 library was constructed by random mutagenesis. Four mutants with amino acid substitutions at the N-terminus of Tmp1 exhibited increased antibacterial activity against Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria and were not hemolytic. An enhanced activity of these mutant proteins is attributed to their increased hydrophobicity. © 2011 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Rajesh, T.;Anthony, T.;Saranya, S.;Pushpam, P. L.;Gunasekaran, P.

title: Sequence analysis of infectious bursal disease virus isolates from India: Phylogenetic relationships.
abstract: The prevalence of infectious bursal disease (IBD) among chickens in different regions of Tamil Nadu, India was studied by collecting bursal samples from suspected flocks and performing reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) for amplification of a particular product. 474 bp from the variable region of the VP2 gene. A positive reaction was seen in 40 of the 53 bursal specimens examined by RT-PCR. The amplified products were subjected to nucleotide sequencing and the resulting sequences were compared with IBD virus (IBDV) vaccine strain Georgia, classical lethal strain 52/70, and Japanese multi-lethal OCIM strain. Nucleotide homology data showed that all Tamil Nadu isolates showed between 91% and 99.6% homology among themselves. Four isolates were grouped with this strain as compared to the highly virulent Japanese OCIM strain. Most of the isolates clustered with the very virulent OCIM strain as evident from the phylogenetic analysis performed using the MEGA program. Comparison of the deduced amino acid sequences of IBDV isolates with Georgia vaccine strain, classical virulent strain 52/70, and very virulent OCIM strain also revealed the presence of conserved serine-rich heptapeptide sequence in most isolates. The results of this study show that most of the IBDV isolates are very virulent; this is evident from the high mortality rates reported in a few poultry flocks despite regular vaccination.
authors: Ramadass, P.;Thiagarajan, V.;Parthiban, M.;Senthil Kumar, T. M. A.;Latha, D.;Anbalagan, S.;Krishnakumar, M.;Nachimuthu, K.

title: Differentiation of bovine herpesvirus1 subtypes based on UL0.5 gene sequence
abstract: Infectious bovine rhinotracheitis/infectious pustular vulvovaginitis is one of the economically important diseases of cattle and is caused by bovine herpesvirus1 (BoHV1). Based on the restriction endonuclease fingerprinting of viral DNA, BoHV1 can be divided into three subtypes such as BoHV1.1, 1.2a and 1.2b. This method is time consuming and labor intensive as it requires pure viral DNA. In the current study, UL0.5 gene-based PCR sequencing was used for subtyping BoHV1. Four of the five isolates had BoHV1-like signatures and one isolate had BoHV1.2-like signatures. Moreover, these viruses are clustered under phylogenetically related subtypes. These results suggest that UL 0.5 gene-based PCR sequencing can be used as an alternative method of subtyping BoHV1.
authors: Ramakrishnan, M. A.;Pundkar, C. Y.;Fayaz, A.;ChandraSekar, S.;Mageswary, R.;Ashokkumar, D.;Bano, R.;Muthuchelvan, D.;Nandi, S.;Gupta, V. K.

title: Molecular Signature of High Yield (Growth) Influenza A Virus Reassortants Prepared as Candidate Vaccine Seeds
abstract: Background: Human influenza virus isolates generally grow poorly in embryonated chicken eggs. Thus, gene reclassification of influenza A wild-type (wt) viruses is performed with the highly egg-adapted donor virus A/Puerto Rico/8/1934 (PR8) to provide high-yield reassortant (HYR) viral 'seeds' for the vaccine. producing. HYR should contain the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes of wt virus and one to six 'internal' genes from PR8. Most studies of influenza wt and HYRs have focused on the HA gene. The main objective of this study was to identify the molecular signature in all eight gene segments of the influenza A HYR candidate vaccine seeds associated with egg high growth. 1976 H1N1-SOIV; 2, 2009 H1N1pdm; 2 H2N2 and 12 H3N2) and PR8 were sequenced using a high-throughput sequencing pipeline with large dye terminator chemistry. Results: Silent and coding mutations were found in all internal genes derived from PR8. Except for the M gene. The PR8-derived M gene was invariant in all 23 HYRs, underlining the critical role of PR8 M in the high-yielding phenotype. Except for the PB1 gene in X-157, none of the wt virus-derived internal genes had silent change(s). The highest number of recurrent silent and coding mutations was found in NS. Regarding surface antigens, the majority of HYRs had coding mutations in HA; only 2 HYRs had coding mutations in NA. Significance: In the era of application of reverse genetics to alter influenza A virus genomes, mutations identified in HYR gene segments associated with high growth in egg could be of great practical benefit to modify PR8 and/or wt virus gene sequences for enhanced growth of vaccine 'seed' viruses. Â© 2013 Ramanunninair et al.
authors: Ramanunninair, M.;Le, J.;Onodera, S.;Fulvini, A. A.;Pokorny, B. A.;Silverman, J.;Devis, R.;Arroyo, J. M.;He, Y.;Boyne, A.;Bera, J.;Halpin, R.;Hine, E.;Spiro, D. J.;Bucher, D.

title: Genetic diversity and mutation of avian paramyxovirus serotype 1 (Newcastle disease virus) in wild birds and evidence of transcontinental spread
abstract: Avian paramyxovirus serotype 1 (APMV-1), or Newcastle disease virus, is the causative agent of Newcastle disease, one of the most economically important diseases for poultry production worldwide, and is a cause of periodic epizootics in wild birds in North America. In this study, we examined the genetic diversity of APMV-1 isolated from migratory birds sampled in Alaska, Japan and Russia and evaluated evidence of transcontinental virus spread using phylogenetic methods. In addition, we estimated viral virulence using the deduced amino acid residues for the fusion protein cleavage site and estimated mutation rates for the fusion gene of class I and class II migratory bird isolates. All 73 isolates sequenced as part of this study were most closely related to virus genotypes previously reported for wild birds; however, five class II genotype I isolates formed a monophyletic lineage that exhibited previously unreported genetic diversity and met the criteria for a new subgenotype designation. Phylogenetic analysis of wild bird isolates provided evidence for transcontinental virus spread, particularly viral strains of APMV-1 class II genotype I subgenotypes Ib and Ic. This result supports migratory bird movement as a possible mechanism for APMV-1 redistribution. None of the predicted inferred amino acid motifs for the fusion protein cleavage site of APMV-1 strains isolated from migratory birds in Alaska, Japan, and Russia were consistent with those of previously identified virulent viruses. These data therefore provide no support for these strains contributing to the emergence of avian pathogens. Estimated mutation rates for fusion genes of class I and class II wild bird isolates were faster than those previously reported for non-virulent APMV-1 strains. Collectively, these findings provide new insights into the diversity, spread, and evolution of APMV-1 in wild birds.
authors: Ramey, A. M.;Reeves, A. B.;Ogawa, H.;Ip, H. S.;Imai, K.;Bui, V. N.;Yamaguchi, E.;Silko, N. Y.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Evidence of common ancestry between viruses isolated from wild birds in Beringia and highly pathogenic intercontinental reassortant H5N1 and H5N2 influenza A viruses
abstract: The highly pathogenic clan 2.3.4.4 H5N8, H5N2 and H5N1 influenza A viruses were first detected in wild, captive and domestic birds in North America in November-December 2014. 2.3.4.4 Initial detection of H5 influenza A viruses in North America: (1) spread of highly pathogenic influenza A viruses from East Asia to North America by migratory birds via Alaska and (2) ancestral origins of clan 2.3 .4.4 Beringia H5 reassortant viruses in . Although we did not detect highly pathogenic influenza A viruses in our sample collection from western Alaska, we did detect viruses containing gene segments that share a recent common ancestry with intercontinental reassortant H5N2 and H5N1 viruses.
authors: Ramey, A. M.;Reeves, A. B.;TeSlaa, J. L.;Nashold, S.;Donnelly, T.;Bahl, J.;Hall, J. S.

title: Fecal virome composition of migratory mallard species
abstract: The fecal virome contains a complex variety of eukaryotic viruses, phages, and viruses that infect the host. However, little is known about the intestinal virus community in wild waterfowl and its structure in wild ducks has not yet been studied. The fecal virome compositions of six mallard ducks and one wild diving duck species were thus analyzed. Fecal samples were collected directly from the rectums of 60 ducks donated by hunters. DNA and RNA virus particles were purified and sequenced using the MiSeq Illumina platform. Reads from sequencing were analyzed and compared to sequences in the GenBank database. Viral-associated sequences from the viral families Herpesviridae, Alloherpesviridae, Adenoviridae, Retroviridae, and Myoviridae showed the highest overall abundance in the samples. Virome analysis identified viruses not found in mallard feces and revealed different virome profiles between different species and samples from the same species. This work enhances our understanding of viruses in wild ducks as possible viral reservoirs and provides a basis for further studying and monitoring transmission of viruses from wild animals to humans and disease outbreaks in domestic animals.
authors: RamÃ­rez-MartÃ­nez, L. A.;Loza-Rubio, E.;Mosqueda, J.;GonzÃ¡lez-Garay, M. L.;GarcÃ­a-Espinosa, G.

title: The nucleotide sequence of the gene encoding the viral polymerase of avian pneumovirus
abstract: Here we report the nucleotide sequence of the L gene of avian pneumovirus (APV). This is the second pneumovirus L gene and the second avian paramyxovirus L gene after Newcastle disease virus to be sequenced. The APV L gene is 6099 nucleotides long and encodes a single large ORF of 2004 amino acids. This makes the APV L protein the smallest protein to be described for any unsegmented, negative-stranded RNA virus. The protein contains six linear noncontiguous domains, a putative ATP-binding site, and four polymerase motifs previously described for L proteins of negative-strand RNA viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of domain III of 14 different L proteins suggests that pneumoviruses are evolutionarily as distant as Filoviridae from other members of Paramyxoviridae.
authors: Randhawa, J. S.;Wilson, S. D.;Tolley, K. P.;Cavanagh, D.;Pringle, C. R.;Easton, A. J.

title: Adventurous agent risk assessment case study: Evaluation of RotaTeqÂ® for the presence of swine circovirus
abstract: In June 2010, results of metagenomic and panmicrobial microarray analysis of a number of commercially available vaccine products were published and identified the unexpected presence of porcine circovirus (PCV) in one of the vaccine products tested. This test did not detect any contaminated virus sequences in RotaTeqÂ® (rotavirus vaccine, live, oral, pentavalent, RV5, Merck & Co., Inc., Whitehouse Station, NJ). To confirm this finding, Merck developed and applied a set of polymerase chain reaction-based analytical methods and a testing algorithm to systematically demonstrate the absence of infectious PCV in RotaTeqÂ®. This document will explain the methodology and rationale developed to comprehensively evaluate key starting materials, product intermediates, and final product to demonstrate the absence of infectious PCV and the continued quality of this product. This approach can be applied to assess the validity of other incidental agent risks encountered in biological processes and products. ©PDA, Inc. 2011.
authors: Ranucci, C. S.;Tagmyer, T.;Duncan, P.

title: Deep sequencing as a method of typing bluetongue virus isolates
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) is an economically important endemic animal disease living in the tropics and subtropics. Also, its recent spread to temperate regions such as North America and northern Europe is of serious concern. Rapid serotyping and characterization of the BT virus (BTV) is an important step in determining the origin of the virus and controlling the disease. Serotyping of BTV is typically accomplished by serum neutralization followed by nucleotide sequencing. This report describes the near-complete genome sequencing and typing of two BTV isolates using the Illumina next-generation sequencing platform. Two of the BTV RNAs were multiplexed with ten other unknown samples. Viral RNA was isolated and fragmented, reverse transcribed, cDNA ends repaired and ligated with a multiplex oligo. The genome library was amplified using primers complementary to the ligated oligo and subjected to single and double end sequencing. Raw reads were combined using a de novo method and reference-based compilation was performed based on contig data. Near-complete sequences of all segments of BTV were obtained with coverage greater than 20x, and the single read sequencing method was sufficient to identify the genotype and serotype of the virus. The two viruses used in this study were typed as BTV-1 and BTV-9E.
authors: Rao, P. P.;Reddy, Y. N.;Ganesh, K.;Nair, S. G.;Niranjan, V.;Hegde, N. R.

title: Full-length genome sequences of the swine epidemic diarrhea virus strain CV777; Use of NGS to analyze genomic and subgenomic RNAs
abstract: The swine epidemic diarrhea virus, strain CV777, was first characterized in 1978 as the causative agent of a disease first described in 1971 in the United Kingdom. This coronavirus is widely distributed among laboratories and has been passaged in both pigs and cell culture. To determine the variability between different stocks of the PEDV strain CV777, sequencing of the full-length genome (approximately 28 kb) was performed in 6 different laboratories using different protocols. Not surprisingly, the different whole genome sequences each differed from each other and from the reference sequence (Accession number AF353511), but were >99% identical. Unique and shared differences between sequences were identified. The coding region for the surface-exposed spike protein showed the highest rate of variability, including both point mutations and small deletions. The predicted expression of the ORF3 gene product was more strikingly affected in three different variants of this virus, either by loss of an initiation codon or by gain of an early termination codon. The genome of one isolate had a substantially rearranged 5'-terminal sequence. This rearrangement was confirmed by analysis of subgenomic mRNAs from infected cells. It is clearly important to know the characteristics of the particular CV777 sample used for experimental studies.
authors: Rasmussen, T. B.;Boniotti, M. B.;Papetti, A.;Grasland, B.;Frossard, J. P.;Dastjerdi, A.;Hulst, M.;Hanke, D.;Pohlmann, A.;Blome, S.;van der Poel, W. H. M.;Steinbach, F.;Blanchard, Y.;Lavazza, A.;Botner, A.;Belsham, G. J.

title: Detection of three porcine vesicular viruses using multiplex real-time primer-probe energy transfer
abstract: Rapid identification of the etiologic agent in infected animals is important for the control of an outbreak of vesicular disease in livestock. In this study, we developed a multiplex real-time reverse transcription-PCR based on primer-probe energy transfer (PriProET) for the simultaneous detection and differentiation of three vesicular viruses classified as Office International des Epizooties (OIE): foot-and-mouth disease virus, vesicular stomatitis virus, and swine vesicular disease causes clinically indistinguishable vesicular disease in pigs. The multiplex assay consists of subtracting total RNA from clinical samples; reverse transcription to cDNA using random primers and single-tube real-time amplification of cDNA using multiplex PriProET with specific fluorescent-labeled primers and probes for detection of three viruses from the vesicular disease complex. Probes are labeled with unique reporter fluorophores induced by donor fluorophores that are incorporated into the 5-² end of specific amplicons by primer extension during amplification. The sensitivity of the multiplex assay was approximately 100 TCID50, which is 10-fold lower for the three vesicular viruses compared to individual PriProET assays. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Rasmussen, T. B.;Uttenthal, A.;AgÃ¼ero, M.

title: A Review of the Use of Genomic Tools to Improve Bovine Health in the Context of Infectious Diseases
abstract: Although communicable diseases place a heavy economic burden on the cattle industry, the etiology of many disorders affecting livestock is not fully elucidated and effective countermeasures are often lacking. The main tools available so far were vaccines, antibiotics and antiparasitic drugs. Although these are very successful in some cases, the appearance of parasite and microbial resistance to these treatments is a cause for concern. Next-generation sequencing offers important opportunities to tackle the problems associated with pathogenic diseases. This review describes the rapid gains in tracking disease progression, identifying pathogens of interest, and mapping host-pathogen interactions. The use of new genomic tools then helps develop treatments and create successful breeding programs for less susceptible farm animals. These can be important tools for mitigating the long-term effects of fighting infection and helping reduce reliance on antibiotic therapy.
authors: Raszek, M. M.;Guan le, L.;Plastow, G. S.

title: Use of genomic tools to improve cattle health in the context of infectious diseases
abstract: Although communicable diseases place a heavy economic burden on the cattle industry, the etiology of many disorders affecting livestock is not fully elucidated and effective countermeasures are often lacking. The main tools available so far were vaccines, antibiotics and antiparasitic drugs. Although these are very successful in some cases, the appearance of parasite and microbial resistance to these treatments is a cause for concern. Next-generation sequencing offers important opportunities to tackle the problems associated with pathogenic diseases. This review describes the rapid gains in tracking disease progression, identifying pathogens of interest, and mapping host-pathogen interactions. The use of new genomic tools then helps develop treatments and create successful breeding programs for less susceptible farm animals. These can be important tools for mitigating the long-term effects of fighting infection and helping reduce reliance on antibiotic therapy.
authors: Raszek, M. M.;Guan, L. L.;Plastow, G. S.

title: Metagenomic profiling of ticks: Identification of novel rickettsial genomes and detection of tick-borne canine parvovirus.
abstract: BACKGROUND: All over the world, ticks act as vectors of human and animal pathogens. Ticks often rely on bacterial endosymbiosis, sharing close and complex evolutionary links with tick-borne pathogens. Because the prevalence, diversity, and virulence potential of tick-borne agents are not fully understood, there is an urgent need for microbial surveillance of ticks as potential disease vectors. METHODOLOGY/KEY FINDINGS: We developed a two-step protocol involving 16S-amplicon screening of hard tick samples collected from dogs, sheep and camels in Palestine followed by shotgun metagenomics on individual ticks to detect and characterize tick-borne pathogens and endosymbiosis. Two ticks isolated from sheep yielded abundant reads from the genus Rickettsia, which were assembled into draft genomes. One of the resulting genomes was highly similar to Rickettsia massiliae strain MTU5. Analysis of signature genes showed that the other represented the first genome sequence of the potential pathogen Candidatus Rickettsia barbariae. Ticks from a dog and a sheep provided draft genome sequences of Coxiella strains. A sheep tick yielded sequences from the sheep pathogen Anaplasma ovis, while Hyalomma ticks from camels yielded sequences from Francisella-like endosymbionts. We have sequenced the genome of a canine parvovirus from the metagenome of a dog tick from Jericho. IMPORTANT: Here we show how a cost-effective two-step protocol can be used to detect and characterize tick-borne pathogens and endosymbionts. We demonstrate the open-ended nature of metagenomics in recovering genome sequences from an unexpected pathogen (canine parvovirus) and a previously unsequenced pathogen (Candidatus Rickettsia barbariae). Furthermore, by providing evidence that ticks can carry canine parvovirus, we raise the possibility that ticks may contribute to the spread of this troublesome virus.
authors: Ravi, A.;Ereqat, S.;Al-Jawabreh, A.;Abdeen, Z.;Abu Shamma, O.;Hall, H.;Pallen, M. J.;Nasereddin, A.

title: Network extraction from multimodal data: A review of approaches to infectious disease transmission.
abstract: Network inference problems are often found in multiple biomedical subfields such as genomics, metagenomics, neuroscience, and epidemiology. Networks are useful for representing a wide variety of complex interactions, from those between molecular biomarkers, neurons, and microbial communities to those found in human or animal populations. Recent technological advances have resulted in an increasing amount of healthcare data in multiple modalities, increasing the dominance of network inference problems. Multi-domain data can now be used to improve the robustness and reliability of networks recovered from single-mode data. Especially for infectious diseases, there is a body of knowledge that focuses on combining multiple linked information. Combining or analyzing disparate modalities has shown greater insight into disease transmission than could be obtained from any single modality alone. This has been helpful in understanding the incidence and transmission, especially in the early stages of potentially pandemic infections. New linked pieces of information in the form of spatial, temporal, and other covariates, including high-throughput sequence data, clinical visits, social networking information, medication prescriptions, and clinical symptoms (reported as free-text data), also spur further exploration of these. methods. The purpose of this review is to provide an in-depth analysis of multimodal infectious disease transmission network inference methods with a particular focus on Bayesian inference. We focus on methods based on analytical Bayesian inference, because it allows simultaneous recovery of multiple parameters, for example, not only the disease transmission network, but also the parameters of epidemic dynamics. Our review examines its assumptions, key inference parameters and limitations, and ultimately provides insights into improving future network inference methods in multiple applications.
authors: Ray, B.;Ghedin, E.;Chunara, R.

title: Finding a needle in the virus metagenome haystack – micro-metagenome analysis captures a snapshot of the diversity of a bacteriophage wardrobe
abstract: Viruses are ubiquitous in the oceans and critical components of marine microbial communities, regulating nutrient transfer to higher trophic levels or the dissolved organic pool via lysis of host cells. Hydrothermal vent systems are oases of biological activity in the deep oceans where biodiversity and its impact on the global ocean biogeochemical cycle are still in their infancy. To gain a biological perspective on viral communities found in hydrothermal vent systems, we developed a method based on deep sequencing of pulsed field gel electrophoretic bands representing significant viral fractions found in and surrounding seawater in a hydrothermal cloud derived from the Loki's Castle vent area. Arctic Mid-Ocean Ridge. The reduction in virus assembly complexity afforded by this new approach allowed an almost complete reconstitution of a lambda-like phage genome from the virus fraction of the feather. Phylogenetic examination of different gene regions in this lambdoid phage genome revealed diversity at loci encoding superinfection exclusion and integrase-like proteins. This highlights the importance of fine-tuning lyosgenic conversion as a viral survival strategy and provides insight into the nature of host-virus and virus-virus interactions within hydrothermal plumes. By reducing the complexity of the viral community through targeted sequencing of prominent dsDNA viral fractions, this method selectively mimicked virus dominance approaching that hitherto achieved only by culturing, enabling bioinformatic analysis to find a lambdoid viral "needle" within the larger viral community. barn". Such targeted analyzes have great potential to accelerate the extraction of biological information from diverse and poorly understood environmental viral communities. Â© 2012 Ray et al.
authors: Ray, J.;Dondrup, M.;Modha, S.;Steen, I. H.;Sandaa, R. A.;Clokie, M.

title: Pig sapelovirus among diarrheal piglets in India
abstract: Porcine sapelovirus (PSV) A belongs to the Sapelovirus genus of the Picornaviridae family. PSV infections in pigs have been reported from European countries, the United States, Japan, China, Korea, and Brazil. The virus has been isolated/detected in the feces of healthy pigs as well as those affected by diarrhea, respiratory symptoms, encephalitis, skin lesions and fertility disorders. This study was planned to investigate whether PSV is prevalent among pigs in India and to characterize PSV encountered in the study population. The study revealed that five (7.14%) of 70 stool samples were positive for PSV using RT-PCR. Three viruses were successfully isolated from fecal samples using the IB-RS-2 cell line. Complete genome sequencing and analysis of an Indian PSV isolate revealed the highest homology (88%) with strain V13 from the UK. Phylogenetic analysis of the complete polyprotein nucleotide sequences of 14 strains of PSV classified the viruses into four distinct clades. This initial report from India adds to our knowledge of the genetic diversity of PSV detected so far among pigs in different countries. Large-scale surveillance of the virus is necessary to understand its genomic diversity and economic impact.
authors: Ray, P. K.;Desingu, P. A.;Kumari, S.;John, J. K.;Sethi, M.;Sharma, G. K.;Pattnaik, B.;Singh, R. K.;Saikumar, G.

title: Genetic diversity of influenza A virus in wild bird populations in southern western Siberia
abstract: Influenza A virus variants of subtypes H3 and H4 have been isolated from wild ducks living in southern West Siberia. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene of these viruses revealed that H3 isolates were closely related to those from avian isolated in Western Europe (A/Teal/Germany/wv01r/01, A/Duck/Ukraine/1/63). and China (A/Waterbird/Hong Kong/399/99); and those isolated from birds living in Germany (A/Garganey/Germany/wv157k/01, A/Teal/Germany/wv153k/01). Therefore, closely related influenza A virus variants circulate in populations of wild birds living in widely spaced regions of Eurasia. Â© KOJIJlEKTHB ABTOPOB, 2005.
authors: Razumova Yu, V.;Shchelkanov, M. Yu;Durymanova, A. A.;Zolotykh, S. I.;Ternovoi, V. A.;Slavsky, A. A.;Yurlov, A. K.;Beklemishev, A. B.;Shestopalov, A. M.;Lvov, D. K.

title: Comparison between Transcriptome Sequencing and 16S Metagenomics for Detection of Bacterial Pathogens in Wildlife
abstract: Background Rodents are the main reservoirs of pathogens responsible for numerous zoonotic diseases in humans and livestock. Assessing their microbial diversity at both the individual and population level is crucial for monitoring endemic infections and revealing patterns of microbial association in reservoirs. Recently, NGS approaches have been used to characterize microbial communities of different ecosystems. However, their relative effectiveness has not been evaluated. Here, we compared two NGS approaches, RNA Sequencing (RNA-Seq) and 16S-metagenomics, assessing their ability to search for neglected zoonotic bacteria in rodent populations. Methodology/Basic Findings We first extracted nucleic acids from the spleen of 190 voles collected in France. RNA extracts were pooled, randomly retro-transcribed, followed by RNA-Seq using HiSeq. Concatenated bacterial sequences were assigned to the closest taxa registered in GenBank. DNA extracts were analyzed with a 16S-metagenomy approach using two sequencers: 454 GS-FLX and MiSeq. The V4 region of the gene encoding 16S rRNA was amplified for each sample using barcoded universal primers. Amplicons were multiplexed and processed on different sequencers. The resulting datasets were demultiplexed and each read was processed through a pipeline to be taxonomically classified using the Ribosomal Database Project. In total, 45 genera of pathogenic bacteria were detected. Bacteria identified by RNA-Seq were comparable to those detected by the 16S-metagenomics approach processed with MiSeq (16S-MiSeq). In contrast, 21 of these pathogens went undetected when the 16S-metagenomics approach was processed via 454-pyrosequencing (16S-454). In addition, 16S-metagenomics approaches revealed high levels of coinfection in bank voles. Conclusions/Importance We conclude that RNA-Seq and 16S-MiSeq are equally sensitive in detecting bacteria. Although only the 16S-MiSeq method enables the identification of bacteria in each reservoir, the subsequent derivation of bacterial prevalence in host populations and establishment of intra-reservoir models of bacterial interactions. Finally, the number of bacterial reads obtained with 16S-MiSeq can be a good proxy for bacterial prevalence.
authors: Razzauti, M.;Galan, M.;Bernard, M.;Maman, S.;Klopp, C.;Charbonnel, N.;Vayssier-Taussat, M.;Eloit, M.;Cosson, J. F.

title: Information on resistome and stress response genes in Bubalus bubalis rumen through metagenomic analysis
abstract: The buffalo rumen microbiota inhabits a diverse diet and represents a large reservoir of mobileom, resistome, and stress responses. However, knowledge of metagenomic responses to such conditions is still rudimentary. We analyzed metagenomes of buffalo rumen in liquid and solid phase of rumen biomaterial from river buffalo adapted at varying rates from concentrate to green or dry roughage, using high-throughput sequencing to know the genesis of antibiotic resistance genes, genetic exchange between bacteria. population and environmental reservoirs. A total of 3914.94 MB of data were generated from all three treatment groups. Data were analyzed with the Metagenome rapid annotation system tools. At the phylum level, Bacteroidetes was dominant in all treatments followed by Firmicutes. Genes encoding functional responses to stress (oxidative stress and heat shock proteins) and resistome genes (resistance to antibiotics and toxic compounds, phages, transposable elements and pathogenicity islands) were similarly common in the liquid and solid fraction of rumen metagenomes. Fluoroquinolone resistance, MDR efflux pumps, and Methicillin resistance genes were widely distributed in 11, 9, and 14 bacterial classes, respectively. Bacteria responsible for phage replication and prophages and phage packaging and rlt-like streptococcal phage genes have mostly been assigned to the phyla Bacteroides, Firmicutes and proteaobacteria. Also, more reads matching sigma B genes were detected in the buffalo rumen. This study highlights the existence of various adaptation mechanisms to different diet, antibiotics and other stresses in buffalo rumen, reflecting the proportional representation of major bacterial groups.
authors: Reddy, B.;Singh, K. M.;Patel, A. K.;Antony, A.;Panchasara, H. J.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Molecular characterization of Indian rabies virus isolates by partial sequencing of nucleoprotein (N) and phosphoprotein (P) genes.
abstract: Rabies is endemic and is an important zoonosis in India. Few reports exist on the molecular epidemiology of the Indian rabies virus. To know the dynamics of rabies virus in this study, a total of 41 rabies positive brain samples from 11 states from dogs, cats, pets, wildlife and humans were subjected to RT-PCR amplification of the N gene between nucleotides N521-N1262 (742 bp) and nucleotide P239- The P gene between P750 (512 bp). The N gene can be amplified from 30 samples, while the P gene can be amplified from 41 samples using specific primer sets. Phylogenetic analysis based on the N gene showed that all Indian virus isolates are genetically closely related to a single cluster under arctic/arctic-like viruses. However, two different clusters of P gene-based phylogeny i.e. Rabies virus isolates of Punjab and Rabies virus isolates of the rest of India (outside Punjab) were performed. All Indian rabies virus isolates were closely related by geography (>95% homology), but not to host species. © 2011 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Reddy, G. B. M.;Singh, R.;Singh, R. P.;Singh, K. P.;Gupta, P. K.;Desai, A.;Shankar, S. K.;Ramakrishnan, M. A.;Verma, R.

title: Genetic Characterization of Belgian Nephropathogenic Infectious Bronchitis Virus (NIBV) Reference Strain B1648
abstract: Virulent nephropathogenic infectious bronchitis virus (NIBV) strain B1648 was first isolated in 1984 in Flanders, Belgium. Despite intensive vaccination, B1648 and its variants still circulate in Europe and North Africa. Here, the full-length genome of this Belgian NIBV reference strain was determined by next-generation sequencing (NGS) to understand its evolutionary relationship with other IBV strains and to identify possible genetic factors that may be associated with nephropathogenicity. Thirteen open reading frames (ORFs) were predicted in strain B1648 (51UTR-1a-1b-S-3a-3b-EM-4b-4c-5a-5b-N-6b-31UTR). ORFs 4b, 4c and 6b, which have been rarely reported in the literature, were present in B1648 and most other IBV complete genomes. Based on phylogenetic analysis of full-length genome, replicase transcriptase complex, spike protein, partial S1 gene and M protein clustered with non-Massachusetts-like type strains B1648 NGA/A116E7/2006, UKr 27-11, QX-like ITA/90254/2005, QX-like CK /SWE/0658946/10, TN20/00, RF-27/99, RF/06/2007 and SLO/266/05. Based on the partial S1 fragment, B1648 was clustered with strains TN20/00, RF-27/99, RF/06/2007 and SLO/266/05 and was also named genotype B1648. The full-length genome of B1648 shared the highest sequence homology with UKr 27-11, Gray, JMK and NGA/A116E7/2006 (91.2% to 91.6%), and the least with reference Beaudette and Massachusetts (89%, 7) was associated. . Nucleotide and amino acid sequence analyzes indicated that strain B1648 may have played an important role in the evolution of IBV in Europe and North Africa. In addition, nephropathogenicity markers may be located on 1a, spike, M and helper proteins (3a, 3b, 4b, 4c, 5a, 5b and 6b). Overall, strain B1648 differs from all strains so far reported in Europe and other parts of the world.
authors: Reddy, V. R.;Theuns, S.;Roukaerts, I. D.;Zeller, M.;Matthijnssens, J.;Nauwynck, H. J.

title: Bird flu in swine: a threat to the human population?
authors: Reeth, K. Van

title: Monitoring the antigenic evolution of the foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: Measuring and predicting the antigenic properties of a virus is the holy grail for infectious disease research due to the emergence of new strains, the severity of epidemics, and its central importance in vaccine selection. However, these traits are defined by the complex interplay of viral and host factors, so phylogenetic measures of viral similarity are often weakly correlated with antigenic relationships. Here, we generate antigenic phylogenies that follow the phenotypic evolution of two serotypes of foot-and-mouth disease virus by combining host serology and viral sequence data to identify regions critical for their antigenic evolution. For the SAT1 serotype, we validate our antigenic phylogeny against monoclonal antibody escape mutants that match all predicted antigenic sites. For the O serotype, we validate against known sites whenever possible and otherwise directly evaluate the effect of substitutions at predicted sites on the antigenic phenotype using reverse genetics and serology. We also highlight a critical and poorly understood issue for vaccine selection by revealing qualitative differences between tests that are often used interchangeably to determine antigenic matching between field viruses and vaccine strains. Our approach provides a means to identify naturally occurring antigenic substitutions, allowing us to monitor the genetic diversity of the virus and its associated antigenic evolution. Despite the crucial role that vaccines play in promoting human and animal health, vaccinology remains a distinctly empirical science. This work advances the field by providing guidance for tuning vaccine strains through site-directed mutagenesis through this high-resolution tracking of the antigenic evolution of the virus amid rare major shifts in phenotype.
authors: Reeve, R.;Borley, D. W.;Maree, F. F.;Upadhyaya, S.;Lukhwareni, A.;Esterhuysen, J. J.;Harvey, W. T.;Blignaut, B.;Fry, E. E.;Parida, S.;Paton, D. J.;Mahapatra, M.

title: Identification and characterization of a potyvirus isolated from cyratro plants
abstract: The present work describes the identification and characterization of a potyvirus isolated from siratro (Macroptilium atropurpureum Urb.) in the north-western region of Sdo Paulo State, Brazil. The virus was transmitted by mechanical vaccination. The host range was mainly limited to Fabaceae members. A cDNA fragment of approximately 930 bp was amplified, cloned and sequenced by RT/PCR. The fragment containing the coat protein gene had amino acid identity percentages between 88 and 98% with Bean common mosaic virus (BCMV) isolates. Phylogenetic analysis is grouped. Ciratro potyvirus and BCMV isolates in 99% of replicates, including Azuki mosaic virus, Dendrobium mosaic virus, Blackeye cowpea mosaic virus and Peanut stripe virus classified as BCMV strains. This is the first citation of the presence of BCMV at siratro facilities in Brazil.
authors: Regatier, L. J.;Gaspar, J. O.;Belintani, P.;Yuki, V. A.

title: Beak and feather disease viruses circulating in Cape parrots (Poicepahlus robustus) in South Africa
abstract: Captive and wild psittacines are vulnerable to the highly contagious psittacin beak and feather disease. The causative agent, beak and feather disease virus (BFDV), was recently detected in the largest remaining population of the endemic Cape parrot (Poicepahlus robustus) endemic to South Africa. Full-length genomes were isolated and sequenced from 26 blood samples collected from wild and captive Cape parrots to identify possible origins of infection. All sequences had characteristic BFDV sequence motifs and were similar in length to those described in the literature. However, the BFDV coat protein (CP) sequences from this study did not contain a predefined bipartite nuclear localization signal (NLS) within residues 39-56; this indicates that an alternative NLS is involved in sending the CP to the nucleus. Sequences from the wild population shared a high degree of similarity regardless of year or location, suggesting that the disease outbreak occurred close to the time the samples were collected. Phylogenetic analysis of full-length genomes showed that captive Cape parrot sequences clustered with those isolated from captive-bred budgerigars in KwaZulu-Natal Province, South Africa. Exposure to captive-bred Cape parrots from a breeding facility in KwaZulu-Natal has been suggested as a possible source for virus infection. Phylogenetic analysis of BFDV isolates from wild and captive Cape parrots showed two distinct events of infection in different populations, highlighting the potential risk of introducing new strains of the virus into the wild population. This study represents the first systematic investigation of BFDV virus diversity in the southernmost population of Cape parrots.
authors: Regnard, G. L.;Boyes, R. S.;Martin, R. O.;Hitzeroth, I. I.;Rybicki, E. P.

title: Detection of non-notifiable H4N6 avian influenza virus in poultry in Great Britain
abstract: 12-month pilot project for notifiable avian disease (NAD) exclusion testing in chicken and turkey flocks in Great Britain (United Kingdom), in partnership with industry, offered opportunities for differential diagnosis and diagnosis in flocks where NAD is not suspected. Undetected or undiagnosed infections. In May 2014, clinical samples from a broiler breeder plant that had been experiencing health and production problems for about a week tested positive by avian influenza (AI) real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR). A non-notifiable H4N6 low pathogenicity (LP) AIV was detected by isolation of embryo-specific pathogen-free (SPF) virus, following prompt escalation to a formal, regulatory investigation to rule out the presence of the notifiable AI virus (AIV; H5 or H7 subtypes). ) poultry eggs, neuraminidase inhibition test, cleavage site sequencing, and AIV subtype H4-specific serology. Building movement restrictions have been lifted and no other disease control measures have been implemented under UK (UK) legislation. Phylogenetic analysis of the virus's hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes revealed the closest relationships to viruses in Swedish mallard ducks in 2007 and 2009. In June 2014, clinical suspicion of NAD was reported in a flock of free-range chickens elsewhere in England. increased daily mortality and decreased egg production over a five-day period. An H4N6 LPAIV with an intravenous pathogenicity index of 0.50 was isolated. This virus was genetically quite similar to the virus detected in May 2014, but not identical. Whole viral genome analyzes showed characteristics of a strain not recently transferred from wild birds, implying that spread within the poultry sector has occurred. A stem deletion in the neuraminidase gene sequence indicated the adaptation of the virus to poultry. Also, there was unexpected evidence of systemic spread of the virus at autopsy. No other cases were reported. Infection with LPAIVs often results in variable clinical presentations in poultry, making disease difficult to detect.
authors: Reid, S. M.;Brookes, S. M.;Nunez, A.;Banks, J.;Parker, C. D.;Ceeraz, V.;Russell, C.;Seekings, A.;Thomas, S. S.;Puranik, A.;Brown, I. H.

title: Complete genome of influenza A (H7N9) virus obtained by direct sequencing without culture
abstract: An outbreak caused by the influenza A (H7N9) virus was recently reported in China. Deep sequencing revealed the complete genome of the virus obtained directly from a patient's sputum without virus culture.
