The whole genome showed significant sequence heterogeneity and large variation when compared with those from embryonated chicken eggs.
authors: Ren, X.;Yang, F.;Hu, Y.;Zhang, T.;Liu, L.;Dong, J.;Sun, L.;Zhu, Y.;Xiao, Y.;Li, L.;Yang, J.;Wang, J.;Jin, Q.

title: Faustovirus, a new giant virus strain related to the asfarvirus that infects amoebae
abstract: Giant viruses are protist-associated viruses belonging to the proposed order Megavirales; almost entirely isolated from Acanthamoeba spp. Their isolation in humans suggests that they are part of the human virome. Using a high-throughput strategy to isolate novel giant viruses from their original protozoan hosts, we obtained eight isolates of the novel giant viral strain from Vermamoeba vermiformis, the most common free-living protist found in human environments. This new strain was proposed as the faustovirus strain. The prototype member, faustovirus E12, forms icosahedral virions of 200 nm - devoid of fibrils and enclosing a 466 kbp genome encoding 451 predicted proteins. Of these, 164 are found in the virion. Phylogenetic analysis of core viral genes showed that faustovirus is distantly related to the mammalian pathogen African swine fever virus, but encodes â‰ˆ 3 times more mosaic gene complements. About two-thirds of these genes do not show significant similarity to any known protein-coding genes. These findings suggest that expanding the panel of protists to discover new giant viruses is an efficient strategy. IMPORTANT Using Vermamoeba, a protist living in humans and their environment, we isolated eight strains of a new giant virus we call faustovirus. The genomes of these strains were sequenced and their sequences showed that faustoviruses are related but distinct from the vertebrate pathogen African swine fever virus (ASFV) belonging to the Asfarviridae family. Furthermore, the faustovirus gene repertoire is 3 times larger than that of ASFV and includes about two-thirds ORFan (open reading frames [ORFs] with detectable homology to other ORFs in the database).
authors: Reteno, D. G.;Benamar, S.;Khalil, J. B.;Andreani, J.;Armstrong, N.;Klose, T.;Rossmann, M.;Colson, P.;Raoult, D.;La Scola, B.

title: Hepatitis C virus/classic swine fever virus chimeric 5–²NTR analysis: Sequences in the hepatitis C virus IRES are required for viral RNA replication
abstract: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is classified in the genus Hepacivirus of the family Flaviviridae, whose members have a positive polarity single-stranded RNA genome encoding a single polyprotein. Within this family, HCV is closely related to viruses of the genus Pestivirus, which includes the classic swine fever virus (CSFV). Translation of hepaci- and pestiviral polyprotein is initiated by internal entry of ribosomes supported by 5–²NTR. The secondary and tertiary RNA structures of HCV and pestivirus 5–²NTRs are well conserved, despite their significantly different sequences. Similar to other positive-stranded RNA viruses, the 5–2NTR of HCV is likely to contain cis-acting determinants for replication as well as for translation. Because these signals can overlap, work on both signals can be complicated. In this study, this issue was addressed by generating chimeric HCV/CSFV 5–²NTRs. A two-step analysis of these 5–2NTRs was carried out: (a) in a translation analysis that provided the opportunity to examine translation independently of possible effects on transcription; and (b) in a replication analysis studying chimeric 5–²NTRs showing only IRES-dependent translation. An overlap was observed between the HCV RNA elements involved in these processes. Exchange of domain II had a minor effect on the translation efficiency of chimeric 5–²NTRs, whereas subgenomic replicons were abolished with these chimeric 5–2NTRs. Alteration of domain III subdomains severely reduced replication efficiency, while replication was preserved.
authors: Reusken, C. B. E.;Dalebout, T. J.;Eerligh, P.;Bredenbeek, P. J.;Spaan, W. J. M.

title: Birds of prey, kestrel (Falco tinnunculus) and red-footed hawk (F. vespertinus), different hepatitis E virus in Hungary
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV), family Hepeviridae, has caused significant public health problems due to its zoonotic potential; however, animal-to-animal transmission and the natural chain of hepevirus infections in wildlife are less well known. Using random amplification and next-generation sequencing technology, a new HEV was incidentally detected in raptors in Hungary. HEV RNA was detected in 2 (18%) and 1 (14%) of 11 stool samples from common kestrels and red-footed hawks. High fecal viral load (2.03x10(8) genomic copies/ml) as measured by qPCR. The complete genome of the Kestrel/MR22/2014/HUN (KU670940) HEV strain is 7033 nt long, including the 35 nt 5' end and 63 nt 3' end (excluding the poly(A)-tail). Sequence analyzes showed that kestrel/MR22/2014/HUN shared the highest identity of ORF1 (4920nt/639 aa), ORF2 (1989nt/662 aa), and ORF3 (360nt/119aa) proteins (58.1%, 66.8% and 28.5%). to the corresponding proteins of ferret, rat and human genotype 4 Orthohepeviruses, respectively. Interestingly, the ORF3 protein is potentially leucine (L) initiated using an alternative non-AUG (UUG) start codon. This study reports the identification and whole genome characterization of a novel Orthohepevirus strain related to mammalian HEVs in raptors. It is important to recognize all potential hosts, reservoirs and spreaders in nature and to reconstruct the phylogenetic history of hepeviruses.
authors: Reuter, G.;Boros, A.;Matics, R.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Pankovics, P.

title: A novel avian-like hepatitis E virus in a wild water bird, the little egret (Egretta garzetta) in Hungary
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV), family Hepeviridae, has public health problems due to its zoonotic potential; however, the spectrum of host species, animal-to-animal transmission, the natural chain of hepevirus infections, and the genetic diversity of HEV in wildlife, especially birds, are less well known. Using random amplification and next-generation sequencing technology, a genetically distinct avian HEV was incidentally identified in wild birds from Hungary. HEV RNA was detected in a stool sample from a small egret (Egretta garzetta) with a high fecal viral load (1.33Â Â Â 108Â genomic copies/ml) measured by real-time PCR. The complete genome of HEV strain little egret/kocsag02/2014/HUN (KX589065) is 6660 nt long, including an 18 nt 5 inch tip and a 103 nt 3 inch tip (excluding poly(A)-tail). . Sequence analyzes showed that ORF1 (4554nt/1517aa), ORF2 (1728nt/593aa) and ORF3 (339nt/112aa) encode proteins of the little heron/kocsag02/2014/HUN (62.8%, 71% and 61%, 5) to the corresponding proteins of genotype 1 avian (chicken) HEV in Orthohepevirus B strains, respectively. This study reports the identification and whole-genome characterization of a novel orthohepevirus distantly related to avian (chicken) HEVs in wild birds for the first time. It is important to recognize all potential hosts, reservoirs and spreaders in nature and to reconstruct the phylogenetic history of hepeviruses. Birds in general can be an important reservoir of HEV and can be infected with genetically quite different HEV strains.
authors: Reuter, G.;Boros, Ã;MÃ¡tics, R.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Pankovics, P.

title: Kobuviruses - a comprehensive review
abstract: Kobuviruses are members of the large and growing Picornaviridae family. So far two formal, Aichi virus and Bovine cobuvirus and one candidate cobuvirus species, 'pork cobuvirus', have been identified in human, bovine and porcine, respectively. In addition, kobu-like viruses have been detected in bats very recently. Aichi virus can be a causative agent of gastroenteritis in humans, and cobuviruses possibly also cause diarrhea in cattle and pigs. Although Aichi virus has been detected relatively rarely (0-3%) in human diarrhea, a high seroprevalence of up to 80-95% was found in the 30-40 years old age group, indicating the general nature of the infection in different human populations. In previous years, a great deal of new information has accumulated regarding cobuviruses and their host species. This review summarizes the current knowledge on cobuviruses, including taxonomy, biology, and viral characteristics, and covers all aspects of infection, including epidemiology, clinical presentation, host species diversity, laboratory diagnosis, and provides a summary of possible future perspectives. © 2011 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.
authors: Reuter, G.;Boros, A.;Pankovics, P.

title: Molecular detection of hepatitis E virus in a case of non-imported hepatitis – Identification of a potential new human hepatitis E virus strain in Hungary Hungarian
abstract: INTRODUCTION: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is one of the most common causes of hepatitis in endemic areas. However, it has recently been shown that human infection can occur in developed countries without any travel history, and the pig can act as a reservoir. OBJECTIVES: The aim of this study was to determine the hepatitis E virus by molecular methods and to determine the viral genetic relationship with known HEV strains in a patient with acute non-AC hepatitis infection who did not have a recent travel history in Hungary. MATERIALS: Laboratory diagnosis of hepatitis E virus infection was made in patient sera by HEV IgM and IgG ELISA, IgM and IgG immunoblot, and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction using primers for the partial viral capsid region. RESULTS: A patient with acute hepatitis of unknown origin was treated at Szeged Hospital in June 2004. The acute patient's serum was positive with HEV IgM and IgG was confirmed by immunoblot. The viral genome was successfully amplified in serum by RT-PCR. By sequence and phylogenetic analysis, the virus designated Hungary-1 showed 95% nucleotide identity to genotype 3 hepatitis E viruses and 90% nucleic acid identity to the human strain due to the highest identity to the porcine HEV strain (Sp354-1-02). (Greece2). CONCLUSION: Hepatitis E virus infection is present in Hungary without traveling to known endemic areas. HEV, first identified in Hungary, representing a new human genetic lineage, supports the possibility of endemic infections caused by genotype 3 strains in developed countries, and the pig may serve as a human HEV reservoir.
authors: Reuter, G.;Fodor, D.;Katai, A.;Szucs, G.

title: Astrovirus in wild boars (Sus scrofa) in Hungary
abstract: The Astroviridae family consists of two genera, Avastrovirus and Mamastrovirus, whose members are associated with gastroenteritis in avian and mammalian hosts, respectively. In this study, we report the first detection of astrovirus from fecal samples of wild boars (Sus scrofa) using viral metagenomic and whole genome sequencing. The boar astrovirus (WBAstV-1/2011/HUN, JQ340310) genome is 6707 nucleotides long and has 76%, 95%, and 56% amino acid (aa) identity in ORF1a (852aa), ORF1b (522aa), and ORF2 (845aa) regions to the closest match, porcine astrovirus 4 (PAstV-4, JF713713), respectively. This study shows that the wild boar may be a reservoir for astroviruses. © 2012 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Reuter, G.;Nemes, C.;Boros, Ã;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Pankovics, P.

title: Pig cobuvirus (Sus scrofa) in wild boars
abstract: Fecal samples (N = 10) from 6-8 week old wild boar piglets (Sus scrofa) collected from an animal park in Hungary in April 2011 were analyzed using viral metagenomic and whole genome sequencing. Kobuvirus (Kobuvirus genus, Picornaviridae family) was detected in all (100%) samples with the closest nucleotide (89%) and amino acid (94%) sequence identity of wild boar/WB1-HUN/2011/HUN (JX177612). ) to the prototype porcine cobuvirus S-1-HUN (EU787450). This study shows that genetically very similar (almost identical geno-/serotype) swine cobuvirus circulates in wild boars, the wild counterpart of domestic pigs. Wild boars can be an important host and reservoir for cobuvirus. © 2012 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Reuter, G.;Nemes, C.;Boros, Ã;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.;Pankovics, P.

title: Nonsuppurative (Aseptic) Meningoencephalomyelitis Associated with Neurovirulent Astrovirus Infections in Humans and Animals
abstract: Astroviruses are thought to be enteric pathogens. Since 2010, a specific group of astroviruses has been increasingly recognized as potential neurovirulent (Ni) pathogens of serious central nervous system (CNS) infections using current random amplification and high-throughput next-generation sequencing (NGS) methods. causes encephalitis, meningoencephalitis, and meningoencephalomyelitis. To date, cases or outbreaks of neurovirulent astrovirus have been reported for humans and domestic mammals, including mink, cattle, ovine, and swine. This comprehensive review summarizes the virology, epidemiology, pathology, diagnosis, treatment, and future perspective of neurovirulent astroviruses in humans and mammals, based on a total of 30 relevant articles found on PubMed (searched using the terms "astrovirus/encephalitis"). and "astrovirus/meningitis" on March 2, 2018). A paradigm shift should be considered based on the growing knowledge regarding the causality-effect relationship between neurotropic astroviruses and CNS infection, and attention should be paid to the role of astroviruses in unknown CNS diseases.
authors: Reuter, G.;Pankovics, P.;Boros, A.

title: Nonsuppurative (Aseptic) Meningoencephalomyelitis Associated with Neurovirulent Astrovirus Infections in Humans and Animals
abstract: SUMMARY Astroviruses are thought to be enteric pathogens. Since 2010, a specific group of astroviruses has been increasingly recognized as potential neurovirulent (Ni) pathogens of serious central nervous system (CNS) infections using current random amplification and high-throughput next-generation sequencing (NGS) methods. causes encephalitis, meningoencephalitis, and meningoencephalomyelitis. To date, cases or outbreaks of neurovirulent astrovirus have been reported for humans and domestic mammals, including mink, cattle, ovine, and swine. This comprehensive review summarizes the virology, epidemiology, pathology, diagnosis, treatment, and future perspective of neurovirulent astroviruses in humans and mammals, based on a total of 30 relevant articles found on PubMed (searched using the terms "astrovirus/encephalitis"). and "astrovirus/meningitis" on March 2, 2018). A paradigm shift should be considered based on the growing knowledge regarding the causality-effect relationship between neurotropic astroviruses and CNS infection, and attention should be paid to the role of astroviruses in unknown CNS diseases.
authors: Reuter, G.;Pankovics, P.;Boros, Ã

title: Identification of a new astrovirus in domestic sheep in Hungary
abstract: The Astroviridae family consists of two genera, Avastrovirus and Mamastrovirus, whose members are associated with gastroenteritis in avian and mammalian hosts, respectively. By viral metagenomic analysis, we incidentally identified a novel ovine astrovirus in a stool sample from a domestic sheep (Ovis aries) in Hungary. Sequencing of the fragment indicated that it was an ORF1b/ORF2/3-â€²UTR sequence and was submitted to the GenBank database as ovine astrovirus type 2 (OAstV-2/Hungary/2009) with accession number JN592482. The unique sequence features and phylogenetic position of OAstV-2 suggest genetically distinct astrovirus lineages in sheep. © 2011 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Reuter, G.;Pankovics, P.;Delwart, E.;Boros, Ã

title: Genetic variability of immunomodulatory genes in ecromelia virus isolates detected by denaturing high performance liquid chromatography
abstract: The genetic variability of nine genes in 12 isolates and strains of ectromelia virus that causes a smallpox-like disease (mousepox) in mice was determined, allowing classification of ecromelia viruses. The low genetic variability suggests that evolutionary pressure maintains the activity of immunomodulatory genes in native smallpox infections.
authors: Ribas, G.;Rivera, J.;Saraiva, M.;Campbell, R. D.;Alcami, A.

title: Kobuvirus (Aichivirus B) infection in Brazilian cattle herds
authors: Ribeiro, J.;Lorenzetti, E.;Alfieri, A. F.;Alfieri, A. A.

title: First demonstration of circulation of a pneumovirus by detection of anti-swine orthopneumovirus nucleoprotein antibodies in French pigs
authors: Richard, C. A.;Hervet, C.;MÃ©nard, D.

title: Further studies on the physical and metabolic properties of foot-and-mouth disease virus temperature-sensitive mutants
abstract: Three temperature sensitive (ts) mutants of foot-and-mouth disease virus were classified as ribonucleic acid negative and belonging to the same complement group, when paired at disallow temperature (38.5 °C), virus yields in mixed infections as measured by the incorporation of [3H]uridine. ). Mutants ts 22, the only mutant capable of producing plaque at 38.5°C, were more acid-sensitive than parental wild-type or other mutant viruses. Diethylaminoethyl dextran did not increase the plaque forming ability of mutant viruses at 38.5°C. All viruses inhibited host cell protein synthesis at both allowable (33°C) and non-permissive (38.5°C) temperatures.
authors: Richmond, J. Y.;Polatnick, J.

title: Borna disease virus: a mystery as an emerging zoonotic pathogen
abstract: To Central European veterinarians, Borna's disease (BD) has long been recognized as a progressive viral polioencephalomyelitis that occurs sporadically, predominantly affecting horses and sheep, and has been affecting an increasing number of domestic and zoo animals over the past decade. The etiologic agent, Borna disease virus (BDV), a negative-sense, single-stranded RNA virus classified in the novel virus family Bornaviridae within the order Mononegavirales, can induce the severe clinical manifestations of a viral encephalitis typically with striking behavioral disturbances. After an incubation period of several weeks to several months, BDV infection causes locomotor and sensory dysfunctions, followed by paralysis and death. Natural infections appear subclinical in most cases. BD has received worldwide attention when it has been reported that serum and/or cerebrospinal fluids from neuro-psychiatric patients may contain antibodies specific to BDV. Since infected animals produce BDV-specific antibodies only after virus replication, the broad spectrum of BDV-susceptible strains has been hypothesized to include humans. However, reports describing the presence of other BDV markers, namely BDV-RNA or BDV-antigen, in peripheral blood leukocytes or brain tissue of neuro-psychiatric patients are highly controversial, and therefore the role of BDV in human neuro-psychiatric disorders is questionable. (c) 2001 Harcourt Publishers Ltd.
authors: Richt, J. A.;Rott, R.

title: Genotypes of bovine viral diarrhea virus
abstract: Isolates of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) were divided into two groups based on comparison of sequences from the 5' untranslated region (UTR) of the viral genome. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these groups, designated BVDV I and BVDV II, were as different from each other as reference BVDV (BVDV-NADL, BVDV-SD-1, BVDV-Osloss) was from porcine cholera virus. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests based on the 5' untranslated region and the genomic region encoding the p125 polypeptide are designed to distinguish between BVDV I and BVDV II. Using these tests, 76 of 140 BVDV isolates were identified as BVDV II. Antigenic and pathological differences were recorded between BVDV I and BVDV II viruses. Among the BVDV I were viruses commonly used in vaccine production, diagnostic testing, and research. BVDV II has been predominantly isolated from fetal bovine serum, from permanently infected cavities born in dams vaccinated against BVDV, and from cattle that died from an acute form of BVDV called the hemorrhagic syndrome.
authors: Ridpath, J. F.;Bolin, S. R.;Dubovi, E. J.

title: Change in predominance of Bovine viral diarrhea virus subgenotypes among samples sent to a diagnostic laboratory over a 20-year timeframe
abstract: Although the causative agent of bovine viral diarrhea was initially categorized as 1 species, phylogenetic analyzes revealed that these viruses belonged to 2 distinct species: Bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 (BVDV-1) and BVDV-2, with 2-11 subgenotypes within each species. The distribution of species and subgenotypes has been shown to vary by geographic region. It is unknown whether the distribution changes over time. Studies conducted between 1994 and 2008 reported 3 subgenotypes circulating among cattle in the United States: BVDV-1a, BVDV-1b, and BVDV-2a. The mean percent prevalence of BVDV-1a, BVDV-1b, and BVDV-2a strains reported in studies prior to 2001 was 21%, 43%, and 36%, respectively. Studies on viruses isolated after 2001 reported that the percentages of BVDV-1a and BVDV-2a strains decreased, with BVDV-1b strains accounting for 75-100% of the samples. Comparing these surveys is confusing due to differences in geographic location, collection methods, and the type of sample used in the survey. The aim of this study was to determine whether the prevalence of BVDV subgenotypes changes over time in samples collected from the same geographical region and the same laboratory. BVDV strains isolated in 1988, 1998 and 2008 at Texas Veterinary Medical Diagnostic Laboratory, Amarillo, Texas were genotyped and the prevalence of BVDV-1a, BVDV-1b and BVDV-2a strains was determined. Typing was performed on 148 samples based on phylogenetic analysis. The strongest trend detected among these samples was a marked reduction in the number of BVDV-1a strains over time.
authors: Ridpath, J. F.;Lovell, G.;Neill, J. D.;Hairgrove, T. B.;Velayudhan, B.;Mock, R.

title: Isolation and characterization of a novel cervid adenovirus from white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus) in a captive herd
abstract: novel adenovirus, CeAdV1, was isolated from buffy coat and nasal swab samples from two captive white-tailed deer (Odocoileus virginianus). The isolation was an accidental finding during the screening of animals for use in a research study on an unrelated pathogen. During the screening process, virus isolation was made in both nasal swab and buffy coat samples, and a cytopathic effect was observed. Electron microscopy revealed viral particles with the shape and morphology of an adenovirus. Next-generation sequencing and subsequent phylogenetic analysis classified this virus into the Mastadenovirus genus. Its sequence was genetically distinct from all other recognized species in this genus with only 76% sequence identity to its closest genetic match, bovine adenovirus 3 (BAdV3). The virus was able to spread in bovine-derived cells, but grew to a higher titer in cypress-derived cells. Vaccination of white-tailed deer with the isolated virus resulted in fever, depletion of thymus tissue, and mild respiratory illness. Comparative serology using convalescent serum revealed significant antigenic differences between the novel cervid adenovirus and BAdV3. Retrospective serological research of a captive deer herd has shown that this virus has been circulating in the herd for at least 14 years without clinical reports of disease. A study of serum collected from free-range mule deer living in Nevada revealed high serum titers against this new adenovirus.
authors: Ridpath, J. F.;Neill, J. D.;Palmer, M. V.;Bauermann, F. V.;Falkenberg, S. M.;Wolff, P. L.

title: Deep sequencing of strains isolated from different hosts and stability of the parainfluenza virus 5 genome upon passage in cell culture.
abstract: UNLABELED: Strain diversity of a rubulavirus, parainfluenza virus 5 (PIV5), was investigated by comparing 11 newly identified and 6 previously published genome sequences. These sequences represent 15 PIV5 strains, of which 6 were isolated from humans, 1 from monkeys, 2 from pigs, and 6 from dogs. Regardless of host, year of isolation or geographical origin, species diversity is very low; 7.8% of total nucleotides are variable and the mean pairwise difference between strains is 2.1%. The variation was unevenly distributed throughout the PIV5 genome, but there was no convincing evidence of selection for antibody-mediated avoidance in hemagglutinin-neuraminidase. The finding that some strains of dogs and pigs, but not non-primate strains, are mutated in the SH gene and do not produce SH raises the possibility that dogs (or pigs) may not be natural hosts of PIV5. The genetic stability of PIV5 was also demonstrated during serial passage of a strain (W3) in Vero cells under conditions of competition with highly defective interfering genomes. A similar observation was made for a W3 mutant strain (PIV5VDELTAC) lacking V gene function, where the dominant changes were related to pseudoversion in this gene. Mutations detected during pseudoversion in PIV5VDELTAC, as well as those characterizing the SH gene in dog and pig strains, predominantly contained UC transitions. This indicates an important role for biased hypermutation through an adenosine deaminase, RNA-specific (ADAR)-like activity. IMPORTANT: Here we report sequence variations of 16 different isolates of parainfluenza virus 5 (PIV5) that have been isolated over 40 years from a range of species including humans, monkeys, dogs and pigs. Surprisingly, species diversity was extremely low regardless of host, year of isolation or geographic origin. The variation was unevenly distributed throughout the PIV5 genome, but no convincing evidence of immunity or host selection was found. This overall genome stability of PIV5 was also observed when the virus was grown in the laboratory, and the genome remained remarkably stable even during the selection of virus mutants. Some of the dog isolates had lost their ability to encode one of the viral proteins called SH; this suggests that although PIV5 commonly infects dogs, dogs may not be natural hosts for PIV5.
authors: Rima, B. K.;Gatherer, D.;Young, D. F.;Norsted, H.;Randall, R. E.;Davison, A. J.

title: New Minto virus: A new rhabdovirus from ticks in Alaska
abstract: Three strains of a virus were isolated from the ticks of Haemaphysalis leporis-palustris (Packard) from snowshoe rabbits (Lepus americanus Erxleben) in mid-eastern Alaska. We suggest naming the virus New Minto for where the ticks congregate. Prototype Novel Minto virus is sensitive to the action of sodium deoxycholate and kills sucking mice intracerebrally, but not intraperitoneally; Weaned mice do not die after intracerebral, intraperitoneal, or subcutaneous vaccination. The virus produces plaque in serially propagated Vero, but not in primary Peking duck embryo cells. It is associated with Sawgrass virus, a hitherto ungrouped virus from New Minto, Florida, by complementary fixation and neutralization tests. It is recommended to set up a Sawgrass group. In addition, Sawgrass virus was found to belong to the Rhabdoviridae Family by electron microscopy.
authors: Ritter, D. G.;Calisher, C. H.;Muth, D. J.

title: Multiple hosts and Influenza A viruses genetic shuffling
abstract: Influenza A viruses have a segmented, negative-stranded RNA genome. These viruses are classified according to the antigenic properties of two glycoproteins expressed on the surface of the virus particles, hemagglutinin (HA or H) and neuraminidase (NA or N). To date, 17 H and 10N have been identified and 116 HxNy combinations or subtypes have been reported. Except for the H17N10 subtype, which was recently identified in bats, all identified subtypes have been described in wild waterfowl. These birds are considered the natural reservoir of influenzaAviruses, from which some subtypes can infect other bird and mammalian species, including humans. Interspecies transfers appear to occur regularly and can sometimes lead to the adaptation and stable establishment of a new viral lineage in a given species. This review recalls the genetic diversity of avian, swine, and human influenza viruses and focuses on lesser-known influenza A viruses identified in horses, dogs, and more recently bats. Discusses the genetic mix that may result from interspecies transmission and the associated risks of epizootic, zoonosis and pandemics.
authors: Rivailler, P.;Moisy, D.;Naffakh, N.

title: Detection of cattle infected with bovine viral diarrhea virus using nucleic acid hybridization
abstract: ribonucleic acid (RNA) hybridization assay is described to identify cattle infected with bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV). The RNA probe is derived from the coding region at the 3' end of the genome of the NADL strain of BVDV. Total RNA was extracted from infected cell cultures or peripheral blood leukocytes from suspect animals and applied to nylon membranes with a slot blot apparatus. Peripheral blood leukocytes were tested for BVDV simultaneously with virus isolation. Hybridization and virus isolation results were concordant for 92% of cases. Compared with virus isolation, hybridization had a detection sensitivity of 59.5% and a specificity of 95%. Cross-reactivity to RNA extracts of cells infected with border disease virus was noted. No cross-reactivity was detected against other common bovine viruses (bovine herpesvirus-1, bovine respiratory syncytial virus, parainfluenza-3 virus and bluetongue virus), viruses classified in related families (equine arteritis virus and Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus) or viruses with similar genomic organization. (dengue virus type 2 and Japanese encephalitis virus).
authors: Roberts, K. L.;Collins, J. K.;Carman, J.;Blair, C. D.

title: Initial Report of Apple mosaic virus in Alaska
abstract: Apple mosaic virus (ApMV; Bromoviridae family, genus Ilarvirus) is one of the oldest and most economically important viruses of apples (Malus x domestica Borkh.) (1,3). Yield losses can range from negligible to 50% depending on the cultivar affected. Although apMV is found worldwide and occurs naturally in more than 65 plant species (1), it has not been reported to occur in Alaska. In July 2011, distinctly bright yellow mosaic leaves were observed on 'Valentine' apple and rhizome 'Ranetka' from an apple orchard in Wasilla, AK. Leaves were harvested and analyzed with total RNA extracted by reverse transcription (RT)-PCR and buffer modifications to the RNeasy Plant Mini Kit (Qiagen, Valencia, CA) using ApMV-specific primers (2). Briefly, 50 mg of leaf tissue was ground in liquid nitrogen and 450 µl SE buffer (0.14 M NaCl, 2 mM KCl, 2 mM KH<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>, 8 mM). Na<sub>2</sub>HPO<sub>4</sub>.2H<sub>2</sub>O [pH 7.4, 0.05% v/v Tween-20, 2% w/v polyvinylpyrrolidone 40 , 0.2% w/v ovalbumin, 0.5% w/v bovine serum albumin and 0.05% w/v sodium azide) were added, and after vigorous vortexing, 80 µl of the mixture was added to 400 µl RLT buffer. kit and then processed as specified by the manufacturer (4). Direct sequencing of the predicted ~260-bp PCR product resulted in 97% to 98% nucleotide identity to ApMV accessions in GenBank when analyzed by BLAST. To determine the distribution and incidence of infection in the Wasilla orchard, all 118 apple trees (99 cultivars) were sampled and according to the manufacturer's protocol (Agdia, Inc., Elkhart, IN). Apple 'Geneva Early' and the same 'Valentine' tree and rootstock tested positive for ApMV by ELISA and RT-PCR. Strong diagnostic ApMV symptoms were not evident in the infected 'Geneva Early', which is typical for most commercially grown apples. No leaves were found for virus indexing in the 'Ranetka' rootstock of 'Geneva Early' infected with ApMV. An additional 21 asymptomatic apple trees from an orchard in AK Talkeetna tested negative for ApMV by ELISA. Limited natural spread of ApMV to other plants may be via pollen and seed transmission. The most common mode of transmission is from rootstocks and vaccines infected with ApMV. It is important to obtain new propagation plant material from certified virus-tested nurseries and to avoid inoculating plant material containing ApMV. As far as I know, this is the first report of ApMV in Alaska. References: (1) RW Fulton. 83. CMI/AAB Definitions of Plant Viruses. 1972. (2) W. Menzel et al. J. Virol.
authors: Robertson, N. L.

title: Genomic and epidemic research: from array to conclusion
abstract: Outbreaks of infection can be devastating for individuals and communities. In this review, we examine the applications of novel high-throughput sequencing approaches to the identification and characterization of outbreaks, focusing on the application of whole genome sequencing (WGS) to bacterial infection outbreaks. We explain traditional epidemiological analysis and show how WGS can be informative at multiple steps in epidemic research, as proven by many recent studies. We conclude that high-throughput sequencing approaches can make important contributions to the investigation of bacterial infection outbreaks and that the integration of WGS with epidemiological research, diagnostic testing and antimicrobial susceptibility testing will accelerate radical changes in clinical microbiology and infectious disease epidemiology. near future. However, some challenges remain before WGS can be used routinely in epidemic research and clinical practice. © 2013 BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Robinson, E. R.;Walker, T. M.;Pallen, M. J.

title: Recent advances in henipavirus research: Molecular biology, genetic diversity, animal models
abstract: Nipah and Hendra virus are members of a newly identified genus of emerging paramyxoviruses, henipaviruses. Both viruses have the ability to cause severe lung infection and severe acute encephalitis. After their discovery in the 1990s, epidemics caused by these zoonotic paramyxoviruses have been associated with high potential for public health and especially economic threats. Currently, only geographic groups in Asia and Australia have been identified for henipaviruses. However, although few viral isolates exist and more detailed characterization is needed, there is recent evidence that different henipaviruses may be present on the African continent. This review attempts to capture the latest developments in the field of henipavirus research by focusing on genome structure and replication mechanisms, reservoir hosts, genetic diversity, pathogenesis, and animal models. © 2012 Elsevier BV.
authors: Rockx, B.;Winegar, R.;Freiberg, A. N.

title: Bovine leukemia virus can be classified into seven genotypes: Evidence for the existence of two new divisions
abstract: Previous studies have classified the env sequences of bovine leukemia virus (BLV) provirus from different locations around the world into two to four genetic groupings. These different studies gave unique names to the identified groups, and no studies have yet integrated all available sequences. Therefore, we hypothesized that most of the different groups identified earlier actually correspond to a limited set of genotypes that are unevenly distributed around the world. To examine this hypothesis, we sequenced env genes from 28 BLV domain types and compared these sequences with 46 env sequences representing all currently identified genetic groupings. Using phylogenetic analyses, we rescued six clades or genotypes, which we named genotypes 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6. An env sequence did not cluster with any of the others and was quite different compared to the six genotypes described here. Thus, an extra genotype, which we call 7, may exist. Similarity comparisons were in good agreement with phylogenetic analyses. Furthermore, our analyzes confirmed the existence of geographic clusters. © 2009 SGM.
authors: Rodriguez, S. M.;Golemba, M. D.;Campos, R. H.;Trono, K.;Jones, L. R.

title: Ultrastructural findings in lymph nodes from pigs suffering from naturally occurring post-weaning multisystem wasting syndrome
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate ultrastructural lesions in lymph nodes from pigs affected by post-weaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS) and correlate these changes with the detection of viral-like particles (VLPs). Lymph node samples were obtained from 4 PMWS-affected pigs and 2 healthy animals and processed by transmission electron microscopy. Significant ultrastructural changes were noted only in pigs affected by PMWS, particularly in histiocytes and rarely in other cell types. Histiocytes showed severe swelling and proliferation of mitochondria and proliferation and enlargement of the rough endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi complex. Infected histiocytes contained multiple intracytoplasmic inclusion (ICI) bodies with VLPs; some histiocytes also had intranuclear inclusions (INIs). Small inclusions were surrounded by a double membrane with a granular appearance or containing paracrystalline arrays; icosahedral VLPs were 8-17 nm in diameter. Large ICIs were or were not confined to the double membrane and often contained VLPs forming paracrystalline arrays. ICIs were often found near and also inside mitochondria with severe swelling. INIs were not membrane-bound and contained virions 10-13 nm in diameter. Lymphocyte depletion was a striking lymph node finding from pigs affected by PMWS. Inclusion bodies containing VLPs referenced in this study should be classified as viral factories, suggesting that viral replication is a frequent event in macrophages, possibly in which mitochondria may play a role.
authors: Rodriguez-CariÃ±o, C.;SegalÃ©s, J.

title: Characterization of p20 gene sequences from a borderline disease-like pestivirus isolated from pigs.
abstract: pestivirus isolated from pigs with hemorrhagic lesions was antigenically more similar to borderline disease (BD) virus than porcine cholera (HC) or bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) viruses. After reverse transcription, the genome at the 5' end, along with the same region from a BD isolate from sheep, was amplified and cloned by polymerase chain reaction. The region of the p20 gene was sequenced and compared with published data for BVD and HC viruses. A number of motifs are conserved in the amino acid sequences of all viruses. The porcine isolate had a higher degree of homology with the BD isolate (87%) compared to the BVD (73%) or HC (74%) viruses in this region. This further confirms the BD-like nature of the virus.
authors: Roehe, P. M.;Woodward, M. J.;Edwards, S.

title: 1 case of natural bovine herpes virus meningoencephalitis in an adult cow
authors: Roels, S.;Charlier, G.;Letellier, C.;Meyer, G.;Schynts, F.;Kerkhofs, P.;Thiry, E.;Vanopdenbosch, E.

title: Characterization of five unclassified orthobunyaviruses (Bunyaviridae) from Africa and America
abstract: The Bunyaviridae family consists of a variety of viruses, some of which cause disease and are of concern to human and veterinary health. Here, we report the genomic and antigenic characterization of five previously uncharacterized bunyaviruses. Based on their superstructure, antigenic relationships, and phylogenomic relationships, the five viruses are classified as members of the Orthobunyavirus genus. Three are viruses in the California encephalitis virus serogroup and are associated with Trivittatus virus; the other two are most similar to Mermet virus in the Simbu serogroup and Tataguine virus which is not currently assigned to a serogroup. Each of these five viruses is pathogenic to newborn mice, demonstrating their potential to cause disease in humans and other animals.
authors: Rogers, M. B.;Gulino, K. M.;Tesh, R. B.;Cui, L.;Fitch, A.;Unnasch, T. R.;Popov, V. L.;Travassos da Rosa, A. P. A.;Guzman, H.;Carrera, J. P.;Vasilakis, N.;Ghedin, E.

title: Re-emergence of a Novel H5N1 Avian Influenza Virus Variant Subguide 2.2.1.1 in Egypt During 2014
abstract: Large-scale surveillance is crucial to understanding the evolution and emergence of avian influenza viruses (AIVs) in endemic areas. The circulation of the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 has consistently caused significant economic losses to the Egyptian poultry industry and is a threat to public health. In this report, a strain of HPAI H5N1 (A/chicken/Egypt/Fadllah-7/2014) was identified from a vaccinated flock showing clinical signs of infection. Genetic characterization of the isolate showed a high level of nucleotide identity (95%-98%) with variant and classical groups of H5N1. Furthermore, multiple nucleotide and amino acid alignments revealed several distinct and characteristic substitutions in the surface glycoprotein that may be biologically relevant to the pathobiology of the virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the reported isolate is closely related to subdivision 2.2.1.1 of H5N1 AIVs, although there have been no reports of this subclade since 2011 from cases reported by AI in Egyptian avian species. In conclusion, our results highlight the re-emergence of a new H5N1 AIV variant subdivision 2.2.1.1 that may evade vaccine-induced immunity. This discovery demonstrates the importance of continuous monitoring of poultry in this country to control AIV, including identifying sources of vaccine seed viruses.
authors: Rohaim, M. A.;El-Naggar, R. F.;Hamoud, M. M.;Nasr, S. A.;Ismael, E.;Laban, S. E.;Ahmed, H. A.;Munir, M.

title: Do the hemagglutinin genes of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses form unique phylogenetic lineages?
abstract: Avian influenza A viruses of the H5 and H7 subtypes cause periodic outbreaks of severe disease in poultry. The question we wish to address in this study is whether these highly pathogenic strains form unique lineages or whether they and related nonpathogenic viruses are derived from common ancestors in the wild bird reservoir. Therefore, we compared the nucleotide and amino acid sequences of the hemagglutinin (HA) genes of 15 H5 and 26 H7 influenza A viruses isolated from various host species in Eurasia, Africa, Australia and North America over 91 years. The HA genes of the H5 and H7 viruses that cause severe disease in domestic birds do not form unique lineages but share common ancestors with the nonpathogenic H5 and H7 viruses. These findings predict that highly pathogenic avian H5 and H7 influenza A viruses will continue to emerge from wild bird reservoirs. Another important question is whether H7 influenza viruses found in mammalian species are derived from avian strains. We included eight equine influenza viruses and one seal isolate in the phylogenetic analysis of the H7 HA genes. We can show that the HA genes of both equine and seal viruses share ancestry with the avian H7 HA genes. This indicates that H7 viruses currently circulating with an avian HA gene may have the potential to adapt to mammalian species and cause an influenza epidemic in the new host.
authors: Rohm, C.;Horimoto, T.;Kawaoka, Y.;Suss, J.;Webster, R. G.

title: 454-pyrosequencing: A molecular battiscope for freshwater viral ecology
abstract: Viruses, the most abundant biological entity on the planet, are capable of infecting organisms from all three branches of life, but the majority infect bacteria with the greatest cellular diversity. However, characterization and assessment of viral diversity in natural settings is just beginning to be a possibility. Thanks to the development of a new technique for collecting viral DNA and 454 pyrosequencing applications, a snapshot of the diversity of DNA viruses collected from a standing pool on a cattle farm has been obtained. A high amount of viral genotype (785) was present in Virome. The absolute numbers of lambdoid and Shiga toxin (Stx)-encoding phages detected were only ca. 8% of the total virus population, figures accepted by estimates by rarity analysis of less than an order of magnitude. The most abundant viral genotypes in the pond were bacteriophages (93.7%). The predominant viral genotypes infecting higher life forms associated with the farm were, for example, disease-causing pathogens in cattle and humans, such as members of the Herpesviridae. The techniques and analyzes described here provide a novel approach to monitoring viral populations in the aquatic environment, with the potential to be integrated into the development of risk analysis tools to monitor the spread of viral agents of animal, plant and human diseases. Â© 2010 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Rooks, D. J.;Smith, D. L.;McDonald, J. E.;Woodward, M. J.;McCarthy, A. J.;Allison, H. E.

title: Studies on genetic relationships between bovine, goat, cypress and rangiferin alphaherpes viruses and on molecular methods developed for virus detection and identification
abstract: Five ruminant alpha herpes viruses, bovine herpes virus 1 (BHV-1), bovine herpes virus 5 (BHV-5), caprine herpes virus 1 (CapHV-1), servine herpes virus 1 and glycoprotein B (gB) from rangiferin and D (gD) genes herpesvirus 1 were partially sequenced. Nucleotide sequence alignments revealed a highly conserved gB gene with homologies ranging from 87.2% to 99.6% and a more variable gD gene with homologies ranging from 71.3% to 98.9%. Phylogenetic analysis of the gB and gD nucleotide and the deduced amino acid sequences revealed that BHV-5 was the virus most closely related to the BHV-1 subtype 1 and BHV-1 subtype 2 cluster, and CapHV-1 was the most distantly related virus. . Phylogenetic data showed that all viruses studied were closely related to suid herpes virus 1. Based on the sequence data for the gB gene, a nested PCR coupled with restriction enzyme analysis (REA) of PCR products for simultaneous detection and identification of the viruses under study. Nested primers from highly conserved sequence extensions were selected to amplify a 294 bp region in all five viruses, and subsequent REA of PCR products allowed specific identification. A mimic molecule was created that serves as the internal standard of amplification efficiency. The practical diagnostic applicability of the test was evaluated with clinical specimens consisting of semen and organ specimens from experimentally infected animals.
authors: Ros, C.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Revising the taxonomy of the Circoviridae family: establishment of the genus Cyclovirus and deletion of the genus Gyrovirus.
abstract: The Circoviridae family includes viruses with covalently closed, circular, single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) genomes, including the smallest known autonomously replicating, capsid-coding animal pathogens. Members of this family are known to cause fatal diseases in birds and pigs, and have historically been classified in one of two genera: Circovirus, which includes avian and swine pathogens, and Gyrovirus, which contains a single species (Chicken anemia virus). However, over the past six years, viral metagenomic approaches as well as degenerate PCR detection in non-traditional hosts and environmental samples have illuminated a wider host range for members of the Circoviridae family, including fish, diverse mammals, and invertebrates. . In particular, these methods have revealed a distinct group of viruses that are closely related to members of the Circovirus genus and include a new genus, Cyclovirus. The discovery of new viruses and a reassessment of the genomic features that characterize members of the Circoviridae led to a review of the classification criteria used for this family of animal viruses. Here, we provide details on an updated Circoviridae taxonomy approved by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses in 2016, which makes up the genus Cyclovirus and reassigns the genus Gyrovirus to the family Anelloviridae, a separate lineage of animal viruses that also contains circular ssDNA genomes. In addition, we provide a novel species restriction threshold with 80% genome-wide binary identity based on pairwise identity distribution analysis for members of the Circoviridae family and list guidelines for distinguishing between members of this family and other eukaryotic viruses with circular, ssDNA. genomes.
authors: Rosario, K.;Breitbart, M.;Harrach, B.;SegalÃ©s, J.;Delwart, E.;Biagini, P.;Varsani, A.

title: RNA viral metagenome of whiteflies leads to discovery and characterization of a whitefly-transmitted Carlavirus in North America
abstract: Whiteflies from the Bemisia tabaci species complex are capable of transmitting a large number of plant viruses and are some of the most harmful pests in agriculture. Although whiteflies are known to transmit both DNA and RNA viruses, most of the diversity has been noted for the former, especially for the Begomovirus genus. This study investigated the overall diversity of DNA and RNA viruses in whiteflies collected from a single site in Florida to assess whether additional previously undetected viral types were present in the B. tabaci vector. Metagenomic analysis of viral DNA extracted from whiteflies resulted in detection of only begomoviruses. In contrast, whiteflies contained similar sequences to RNA viruses from different groups, with a diversity extending beyond the viruses currently described. Metagenomic analysis of whiteflies also led to the first report of a whitefly-infected RNA virus similar to Cowpea mild mottle virus (CpMMV Florida) (genus Carlavirus) in North America. Further investigation resulted in detection of CpMMV Florida in native and cultivated plants growing near the original field site of whitefly collection and determination of experimental host range. Analysis of complete CpMMV Florida genomes from whiteflies and plants indicates that current classification criteria for carlaviruses need to be re-evaluated. Overall, metagenomic analysis supports that the DNA plant viruses carried by B. tabaci are dominated by begomoviruses, whereas significantly less is known about the RNA viruses contained in this pest vector. Â© 2014 Rosario et al.
authors: Rosario, K.;Capobianco, H.;Ng, T. F. F.;Breitbart, M.;Polston, J. E.

title: Diverse circovirus-like genome architectures revealed by environmental metagenomics
abstract: Circular genome single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) viruses are the smallest viruses known to infect eukaryotes. This study identified 10 novel genomes similar to ssDNA circoinuses through data mining of publicly available viral metagenomes. Metagenomic libraries included samples from reclaimed water and three different marine environments (Chesapeake Bay, British Columbia coastal waters and Sargasso Sea). All genomes have similarities with the replication (Rep) protein of circoviruses; however, only half have genomic features compatible with known circoviruses. Some of the genomes exhibit a mix of genomic features associated with different ssDNA virus families (i.e., circoviruses, geminiviruses, and parvoviruses). The unique genome architectures and phylogenetic analysis of the Rep protein indicate that these viruses belong to novel genera and/or families. Investigating the complex community of ssDNA viruses in the environment could lead to the discovery of different species and help elucidate evolutionary links between ssDNA viruses.
authors: Rosario, K.;Duffy, S.;Breitbart, M.

title: Virus discovery in all three major lineages of terrestrial arthropods highlights diversity of single-stranded DNA viruses associated with invertebrates
abstract: Viruses encoding a replication-associated protein (Rep) within the covalently closed, single-stranded (ss)DNA genome are among the smallest viruses known to infect eukaryotic organisms, including economically valuable agricultural crops and livestock. Although Circular Rep-encoding ssDNA (CRESS DNA) viruses are a widespread group from which our knowledge is rapidly expanding, biased sampling of vertebrates and land plants has limited our understanding of their diversity and evolution. Here, we screened terrestrial arthropods for CRESS DNA viruses and reported the identification of 44 viral genomes and replicons associated with specimens representing the three main terrestrial arthropod lineages, namely Euchelicerata (spiders), Hexapoda (insects), and Myriapoda (centipedes). We identified virus genomes from three established CRESS DNA viral families (Circoviridae, Genomoviridae and Smacoviridae); however, more than half of the arthropod-associated viral genomes are only distantly related to the currently classified CRESS DNA viral sequences. Although members of viral and satellite families (Geminiviridae, Nanoviridae, Alphasatellitidae) known to infect plants were not identified in this study, CRESS DNA viruses and replicons that infect this plant are transmitted by hemipterans. Thus, members of six of the seven established CRESS DNA viral families circulate among arthropods. Furthermore, a phylogenetic analysis of Reps, including endogenous viral sequences reported from a wide variety of organisms to date, revealed that most of the known CRESS DNA viral diversity circulates among invertebrates. Our results highlight the wide and unexplored diversity of CRESS DNA viruses among invertebrates and parallel findings from RNA viral discovery efforts in undersampled taxa.
authors: Rosario, K.;Mettel, K. A.;Benner, B. E.;Johnson, R.;Scott, C.;Yusseff-Vanegas, S. Z.;Baker, C. C. M.;Cassill, D. L.;Storer, C.;Varsani, A.;Breitbart, M.

title: Unknown Challenges: Clinical Application of Microbial Metagenomics
abstract: The availability of rapid, high-throughput, and low-cost whole-genome sequencing holds great promise in public health microbiology, with applications ranging from epidemic detection and monitoring of transmission events to understanding the role microbial communities play in health and disease. Within clinical metagenomics, the identification of microorganisms from a complex and host-enriched background remains a central computational challenge. As a proof of principle, we sequenced two metagenomic samples, a known viral mix of 25 human pathogens, and an unknown complex biological model using over-the-counter technology. The datasets were then analyzed using a bioinformatics pipeline developed around recent rapid classification methods. A targeted approach was able to detect 20 viruses against the background of host contamination and bacterial contamination from multiple sources. An alternative non-targeted identification method was highly associated with these classifications, and when applied to the complex biological model, more than 1,600 species were identified, including several species captured at more than 50% genome coverage. In summary, this study demonstrates the great potential of metagenomics application in the clinical in vitro setting and that this can be achieved using existing infrastructure for non-dedicated sequencing centers.
authors: Rose, G.;Wooldridge, D. J.;Anscombe, C.;Mee, E. T.;Misra, R. V.;Gharbia, S.

title: Distribution of genotypes of swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus in Ontario between 2004 and 2007 and the relationship between genotype and clinical manifestations of the disease
abstract: Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) was first proposed in 1998 to classify porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV). The primary aim of this study was to determine associations between different PRRSV RFLP strains and clinical manifestations of the disease in swine herds in southern Ontario. in those herds. Herds included in the study submitted samples to the Animal Health Laboratory at the University of Guelph between September 2004 and August 2007. Each farmer was surveyed to identify clinical disease in the herd and the RFLP model of a PRRSV isolate was derived from one animal. diagnostic sample. The most common isolates were RFLP type 1-4 (25.1%), 252 (14.7%), 134 (12%), and 1-2 (7.7%). The distribution of RFLP species in this study was found to differ from a previous study in Ontario. The RFLP types most associated with clinical disease during the breeding phase of production are 1-4, 1-2, and 134. The only virus strain significantly associated with terminal illness is RFLP type 262. During the study period, RFLP type 184 emerged in the population in November 2005.
authors: Rosendal, T.;Dewey, C.;Young, B.;Carman, S.;Ge, L.;Poljak, Z.

title: Deep sequencing reveals abundant non-canonical retroviral microRNAs in B-cell leukemia/lymphoma
abstract: Viral tumor models have contributed significantly to our understanding of oncogenic mechanisms. However, how transforming delta-retroviruses induce malignancy is poorly understood, particularly since viral mRNA/protein is tightly silenced in tumors. Here, we provide in vivo evidence of production of viral microRNAs transcribed by non-canonical RNA polymerase III (Pol III) in leukemic B cells, using deep sequencing of large windows of small RNA sizes in the bovine leukemia virus sheep leukemia/lymphoma model. Complete absence of Pol II 5â€²-LTR-driven transcriptional activity. Bovine leukemia virus microRNAs processed from a cluster of five independent self-sufficient transcriptional units located in a proviral region indispensable for in vivo infectivity represent ~40% of all microRNAs in both experimental and native malignancy. They are subject to strong purifying selection and are associated with Argonautes, consistent with a critical function in silencing important cellular and/or viral targets. Bovine leukemia virus microRNAs are strongly expressed in preleukemic and malignant cells where constitutive and regulatory gene expression is suppressed, suggesting an important role in tumor initiation and progression. Understanding how Pol III-dependent microRNAs disrupt cellular and viral pathways will contribute to deciphering the complex perturbations underlying malignant transformation.
authors: Rosewick, N.;Momont, M.;Durkin, K.;Takeda, H.;Caiment, F.;Cleuter, Y.;Vernin, C.;Mortreux, F.;Wattel, E.;Burny, A.;Georges, M.;Van Den Broeke, A.

title: Metagenomics of rumen bacteriophage from thirteen lactation dairy cattle.
abstract: Background: Bovine rumen is home to a diverse and complex community of Eukarya, Bacteria, Archaea, and viruses (including bacteriophages). The rumen viral population (rumen virome) has received little attention compared to the rumen microbial population (rumen microbiome). We used highly parallel sequencing of virus-like particles to investigate the diversity of rumen virus in thirteen lactating Australian Holstein dairy cattle all housed, of which 12 were sampled on the same day. Results: Fourteen putative viral sequence fragments over 30 Kbp in length were combined and annotated. Most of the putative genes in the fused contigs showed no homology to previously annotated genes, highlighting the large amount of work still required to fully elucidate the functions encoded in viral genomes. Despite the cattle being the same age, lactating, and fed the same diets, the abundance of adjacent sequences varied greatly between animals. Additionally, twelve cohabiting animals shared a set of dominant viral contigs. We compared the functional properties of our bovine viromes with those of other viromes and rumen microbiomes. At the functional level, we found strong similarities between all viral samples, which were quite different from the rumen microbiome samples. Conclusions: Our findings suggest that there is a large amount of animal variation in the bovine rumen virome and that cohabiting animals may have more similar viromes than non-cohabiting animals. We report the deepest sequence of rumen virus to date. This study highlights the enormous amount of innovation and diversity available in the rumen virome.
authors: Ross, E. M.;Petrovski, S.;Moate, P. J.;Hayes, B. J.

title: Identification and whole genome sequencing of paramyxoviruses in mallard ducks (Anas platyrhynchos) using random access amplification and next-generation sequencing technologies
abstract: BACKGROUND: During a wildlife screening program for avian influenza A viruses (AIV) and avian paramyxoviruses (APMV) in Belgium, two hemagglutinating agents were isolated from cloacal swab pools of wild mallard (Anas platyrhynchos) captured in a single sampling site at two different sampling sites. we did. times. AIV and APMV1 were excluded using the hemagglutination inhibition (HI) test and specific real-time RT-PCR tests. METHODS: Random access amplification in combination with next-generation sequencing was used for sequence-independent identification of viruses to improve virological identification of APMV2-10 in the absence of validated molecular tests for APMV2-10 as performed by HI subtyping tests. their genomes. RESULTS: Three different APMVs were identified. From a pooled sample, the complete genome sequence (15054 nucleotides) of an APMV4 was assembled from random sequences. From the second pooled sample, the nearly complete genome sequence of an APMV6 (genome size of 16236 nucleotides) was determined, as well as a partial sequence for an APMV4. This APMV4 was closely related but not identical to APMV4 isolated from the first sample. Although cross-reactivity with other APMV subtypes did not allow for formal identification, the HI subtype revealed APMV4 and APMV6 in the respective pooled samples but failed to identify APMV4 co-infected in the APMV6-infected pool. CONCLUSIONS: These data also add to the knowledge of genetic diversity within APMV4 and 6 serotypes and confirm the limited sensitivity of the HI subtyping test. Furthermore, this work demonstrates the value of a random access nucleic acid amplification method in combination with massive parallel sequencing. Using only a moderate and economical sequencing effort, characterization and whole-genome sequencing of APMVs, including identification of viruses in mixed infections, can be achieved.
authors: Rosseel, T.;Lambrecht, B.;Vandenbussche, F.;van den Berg, T.;Van Borm, S.

title: False-positive results in metagenomic virus discovery: A strong case for follow-up diagnosis
abstract: viral metagenomic approach using virion enrichment, random amplification and next-generation sequencing was used to investigate an undiagnosed set of dairy cattle presenting with high persistent fever, unresponsive to anti-microbial and anti-inflammatory therapy, diarrhea and nasal and udder redness. Serum and whole blood samples were collected several days later in the presumed hyperviraemic state of an animal showing these clinical signs. Bioinformatic analysis of data from the DNA virus identification workflow (a total of 32 757 sequences with an average read length of 335 bases) showed the presence of parvovirus-like sequences in the blood sample initially tested. Extensive follow-up using specific real-time RT-PCR assays targeting detected sequence fragments confirmed the presence of these sequences in the original sample as well as in an additional animal sample, but negative extraction showed a contamination with the same genetic signature as controls. Further investigation using an alternative extraction method identified contamination of the originally used Qiagen extraction columns with parvovirus-like nucleic acids or virus particles. While we did not find any relevant viruses that might be associated with the disease, these observations clearly demonstrate the importance of using an appropriate control strategy and follow-up diagnostic tests in any viral metagenomic study. © 2014 Blackwell Verlag GmbH.
authors: Rosseel, T.;Pardon, B.;De Clercq, K.;Ozhelvaci, O.;Van Borm, S.

title: DNase SISPA-next-generation sequencing confirms Schmallenberg virus in Belgian field samples and identifies genetic variation in Europe
abstract: In 2011, a new Orthobunyavirus was detected in cattle and sheep in Germany and the Netherlands. This virus was named Schmallenberg virus (SBV). Subsequently, the presence of the virus was confirmed using real-time RT-PCR in cases of congenital malformations in cattle and small ruminants in several European countries, including Belgium. In the absence of specific sequencing protocols for this novel virus, we confirmed its presence in RT-qPCR positive field samples using DNase SISPA-next-generation sequencing (NGS), a virus discovery method based on random amplification and next-generation sequencing. An in vitro transcribed RNA was used to generate a standard curve that allowed quantification of viral RNA in field samples. Two field samples of aborted lambs containing 7.66 and 7.64 log(10) RNA copies per micro L total RNA allowed unambiguous identification of SBV. One sample gave 192 SBV readings covering approximately 81% of the L segment, 56% of the M segment and 13% of the S segment. The other example resulted in 8 reads distributed over the L and M segments. Three weakly positive field samples (one from aborted calf, two from aborted lambs) containing virus amounts equivalent to 4.27-4.89 log(10) RNA copies per micro L did not allow identification using DNase SISPA-NGS. This partial sequence information was compared with the whole genome sequence of SBV isolated from cattle in Germany and several sequence differences were identified. The applied viral discovery method allowed confirmation of SBV in RT-qPCR positive brain samples. However, the inability to confirm SBV in weakly PCR-positive samples demonstrates the importance of selecting appropriately targeted and fresh field samples in any virus discovery method. Partial sequences from field samples showed few differences when compared with sequences from cattle in Germany, indicating sequence variation within the epidemic.
authors: Rosseel, T.;Scheuch, M.;Hoper, D.;De Regge, N.;Caij, A. B.;Vandenbussche, F.;Van Borm, S.

title: Markers of ongoing or previous hepatitis E virus infection are common in wild ungulates as well as in humans in Sweden.
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a human pathogen with zoonotic spread that infects both domestic and wild animals. About 17% of the Swedish population is immune to HEV, although a few cases are reported each year, indicating that most infections are subclinical. However, clinical hepatitis E may also be overlooked. The source of infection for the detected cases is mostly unknown. To determine whether HEV is spreading from wild game animals, the prevalence of past and/or ongoing infection markers was investigated in serum and fecal samples collected from 260 hunted Swedish wild ungulates. HEV markers were found in 43 (17%) of the animals. The most frequently infected animal was deer (Alces alces) with 19 (28%) of 69 animals showing signs of HEV, followed by wild boar (Sus scrofa) and roe deer (Capreolus capreolus) with 21 (15%) of 139 animals. . Red deer (Cervus elaphus) with 2 out of 30 animals, 1 out of 15 animals and fallow deer (Dama dama) with 0 out of 7 animals. Partial open reading frame 1 (ORF1) of viral genomes from animals was sequenced and compared with those from 14 endemic human cases. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that three humans were infected with HEV strains similar to those derived from wild boar. These results indicate that wild animals can be a source of transmission to humans and an unrecognized public health problem.
authors: Roth, A.;Lin, J.;Magnius, L.;Karlsson, M.;BelÃ¡k, S.;WidÃ©n, F.;Norder, H.

title: A new influenza A virus infection in turkeys. VII. comparative immunology
abstract: Four strains of influenza A, as well as Chicken/Scotland/59 strains isolated from turkeys in Ontario, were found to immunize turkeys against the deadly disease caused by the Turkey/Ontario 7732/66 (V7732) virus. These viruses constitute avian influenza A serotype 5 (AA5). Immune protection against V7732 was not obtained with influenza viruses of other serotypes. Immunoprotective relationships between AA5 viruses were not always demonstrable in hemagglutination-inhibition (HI) and serum-neutralization (SN) tests, especially with turkey and mammalian antisera; A better correlation was seen between chicken antisera and immunoprotection and these in vitro tests. The implications of these findings for virus classification, serodiagnosis, and vaccination are discussed.
authors: Rouse, B. T.;Lang, G.;Narayan, O.

title: Investigation of foot and mouth disease epidemic at a pig farm in Kollam district of Kerala, India
abstract: This article describes the investigation of an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) at a private pig farm in Kotty, Kollam district, Kerala, in October 2013. At the clinical stage, severe vesicular lesions were seen in the skin around the nose and coronary bands. seen in pigs. A total of 48 serum samples and 12 clinical samples (ruptured nasal epithelium) were collected. All serum samples were subjected to indirect 3AB nonstructural protein (NSP) ELISA and liquid phase blocker (LPB) ELISA. In the 3AB NSP ELISA, all serum samples were positive for NSP antibodies indicative of infection. In LPB ELISA, 42 of 48 pigs (87.5%) were found to have a protective log10 antibody titre of â‰¥1.8 against FMD virus serotypes O, A and Asia 1. All clinical material was positive for serotype O in the antigen detection ELISA. as well as in the multiplex reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (mRT-PCR). In VP1 region-based phylogenetic analysis, epidemic-causing serotype O isolates were found to cluster within the Ind2001 strain. Pigs infected with FMD can pose a serious threat to other sensitive pets as they inhale enormous amounts of the virus. As a result, they should be included in the ongoing preventive vaccination and surveillance programs in the country.
authors: Rout, M.;Subramaniam, S.;Mohapatra, J. K.;Dash, B. B.;Pattnaik, B.

title: Discovery of a new avian virus genotype in estrildid finches (Estrildidae) in Germany
abstract: Avian bornaviruses (ABV) are known to be the causative agents of proventricular dilatation disease (PDD) in parrots and their relatives (Psittaciformes). A wide range of ABV genotypes have been identified not only in psittacine birds, but also in other bird species, including canaries (Serinus canaria forma domestica) and Bengal finches (Lonchura striata f. dom.), members of the songbird order. (Paseriformes). During this study, 286 specimens collected from captive and wild birds of various passerine species in different regions of Germany were screened for the presence of ABV. Interestingly, only three ABV-positive samples were identified by RT-PCR. They originated from a yellow-winged pytilia (Pytilia hypogrammica) and two black-tailed waxwings (Estrilda troglodytes) from a captive flock of estrildid finches in Saxony. The ABV isolates detected here were only distantly related to ABV isolates found in passerine species from Germany and Japan, forming a new genotype tentatively termed ABV-EF (for "estrildid finches").
authors: Rubbenstroth, D.;Schmidt, V.;Rinder, M.;Legler, M.;Corman, V. M.;Staeheli, P.

title: Phylogenetic characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolated in mainland China between 2001-2009.
abstract: Between 2001 and 2009, twenty Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates from infected chicken flocks in China were biologically and genetically characterized. All 20 NDVs were categorized as velogenic (n = 17) and lentogenic (n = 3) viruses, respectively, according to the mean time to death (MDT) of chicken embryos. Velogenic viruses carry the motif 112R-RQKR/F117 (n = 14) or 112G-RQGR/L117 (n = 3) at the F0 cleavage site, while all lentogenic viruses 112G-RQGR/L117 (n = 3) in the same site. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that at least three different genotypes (genotypes I, II and VII) are present in chicken flocks in China and that VIId of genotype VII is mainly responsible for the current ND panzootic. Two natural recombinants (XD/Shandong/08 and QG/Hebei/07) were hypothesized and identified by the SimPlot program, and their two parent-like strains may be from the NDV vaccine strain and VIId velogenic strain, respectively. The results show that recombination plays a role in NDV evolution and live vaccines have the capacity to increase NDV evolution through homologous recombination with circulating virus. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Rui, Z.;Juan, P.;Jingliang, S.;Jixun, Z.;Xiaoting, W.;Shouping, Z.;Xiaojiao, L.;Guozhong, Z.

title: Potential for the development of A/H5N1 influenza virus transmitted by respiratory droplets in a mammalian host
abstract: Avian A/H5N1 influenza viruses pose a pandemic threat. At least five amino acid substitutions or four reassisted amino acids may be sufficient for mammalian-to-mammalian transmission via respiratory droplets. From the surveillance data, we found that two of these substitutions are common in A/H5N1 viruses, and therefore some viruses may require only three additional substitutions for transmission between mammals via respiratory droplets. We used a mathematical model of intra-host virus evolution to examine factors that may increase and decrease the likelihood of residual substitutions occurring after the virus has infected a mammalian host. These factors, combined with the presence of some of these substitutions in circulating strains, make a wild-evolving virus a potentially serious threat. These results highlight critical areas where more data is needed to assess and potentially prevent this threat.
authors: Russell, C. A.;Fonville, J. M.;Brown, A. E.;Burke, D. F.;Smith, D. L.;James, S. L.;Herfst, S.;van Boheemen, S.;Linster, M.;Schrauwen, E. J.;Katzelnick, L.;Mosterin, A.;Kuiken, T.;Maher, E.;Neumann, G.;Osterhaus, A. D.;Kawaoka, Y.;Fouchier, R. A.;Smith, D. J.

title: H1N1 influenza viruses, which vary widely in the stability of hemagglutinin, are efficiently transmitted from pig to pig and ferret
abstract: pandemic-capable influenza virus requires a hemagglutinin (HA) surface glycoprotein that is not immunologically visible to most humans and can support replication and transmission in humans. HA stabilization has been associated with the 2009 pH1N1 pandemic potential in humans and H5N1 airborne transmissibility in the ferret model. Pig served as an intermediate host for zoonotic influenza viruses, but the evolutionary pressure exerted by this host on HA stability was unknown. For more than 70 contemporary porcine H1 and H3 isolates, we measured HA activation pH between pH 5.1 to 5.9 for H1 viruses and pH 5.3 to 5.8 for H3 viruses. Therefore, contemporary porcine isolates vary widely in HA stability, with values favored by both avian (pH >5.5) and human and ferret (pH <=5.5) species. Using the early 2009 pandemic H1N1 (pH1N1) virus backbone, we generated three viruses that differed only by an HA residue that altered HA stability: WT (pH 5.5), HA1-Y17H (pH 6.0), and HA2-R106K (pH 5.3). All three multiplied in pigs and were transmitted from pig to pig and from pig to ferret. WT and R106 viruses retained the HA genotype and phenotype after transmission. Y17H (pH 6.0) has acquired HA mutations that stabilize the HA protein to pH 5.8 after transfer to pigs and to 5.5 after transfer to ferrets. Overall, we found that pigs for contact transmission support a wide range of HA activation pH, and many recent porcine H1N1 and H3N2 isolates have stabilized (human-like) HA proteins. This poses an increasing pandemic risk and highlights the importance of continued surveillance and control efforts for swine viruses.
authors: Russier, M.;Yang, G.;Marinova-Petkova, A.;Vogel, P.;Kaplan, B. S.;Webby, R. J.;Russell, C. J.

title: Discovery of an expanded set of avian leukosis subgroup E proviruses in chickens using a novel sequence capture and analysis line, Vermillion.
abstract: Transposable elements (TEs), such as endogenous retroviruses (ERVs), are common in the genomes of vertebrates. ERVs arise from retroviral infections of germline cells, and once integrated into host DNA, they become part of the host's inherited genetic material. ERVs have been attributed to positive effects on host physiology, such as novel, adaptive genetic variation and resistance to infection, as well as adverse effects as agents of tumorigenesis and disease. The avian leukosis virus subgroup E family (ALVE) of endogenous viruses of chickens has been used as a model system to study the effects of ERVs on host physiology, and approximately 30 different ALVE proviruses have been identified in the Gallus gallus genome. In this report, we describe the development of a software tool we call Vermillion and its use in conjunction with targeted next-generation sequencing (NGS) to increase the number of known proviruses of the ALVE ERV family in Europe. 4-fold chicken genome, including expanding the number of known ALVE elements on chromosome 1 (Gga1) from the current 9 to a total of 40. Although we have focused on the discovery of ALVE elements in chickens with appropriate target sequence selection, it can be used to develop profiles of other ERV and TE families in chickens and non-chicken species.
authors: Rutherford, K.;Meehan, C. J.;Langille, M. G.;Tyack, S. G.;McKay, J. C.;McLean, N. L.;Benkel, K.;Beiko, R. G.;Benkel, B.

title: Identification and classification of bovine leukemia virus isolates in Russia and Ukraine based on pol viral gene polymorphism.
abstract: Bovine leukemia virus (BLV) is a specific pathogen commonly seen in cattle. Analysis of pol viral gene polymorphism was used to characterize the polymorphism of BLV isolates in livestock farms in Russia and Ukraine. Fragments of the pol gene corresponding to reverse transcriptase and integrase 494 and 233 bp, respectively, were used for analysis. Phylogenetic analysis revealed several variants of BLV clustered in Russia and Ukraine with high bootstrapping support. A new classification of BLV variants is proposed. Comparison of phylograms based on polymorphism of nucleotide sequences of integrase and reverse transcriptase domains showed no topological conflicts. Therefore, no recombination was found among the BLV variants. Â© 2012 Ülker Publishing, Ltd.
authors: Ruzina, M. N.;Andrianov, B. V.;Shaikhaev, G. O.;Sulimova, G. E.

title: Serological differentiation of foot-and-mouth disease virus strains depending on selection of appropriate vaccine viruses.
abstract: For the purposes of selection of appropriate vaccine strains or advice regarding vaccine use, serological differentiations attempt to predict whether a particular vaccine/antigen is likely to induce antibody that will be protective against the dominant field strains. The purpose of such distinctions is not the same as virus classification. Therefore, it is recommended that the most appropriate measure of this association (r) be given by: r = serum activity against heterologous (Area) strain/ activity of serum against homologous (Vaccine) strain. Comparison of the complement fixation test with virus neutralization test systems – namely metabolic inhibition (color), plaque reduction, a two-dimensional microneutralization cytopathic endpoint (microneutralization) and neutralization kinetics showed that the two test systems did not always yield the same. Results. Experience has also shown that there is a good correlation between serum neutralizing titer and protection in cattle in both homologous and heterologous systems. It is possible to demonstrate a dose-response relationship between vaccine antigen dose and serum neutralizing titer. Therefore, it is recommended that the preferred test for strain comparison for vaccine use should be based on the virus neutralization system. When comparing two virus types, they should be assumed to be the same until they are shown to be possibly different. Therefore, for each test system, it is necessary to know the intrinsic test error so that the smallest difference between two statistically significant test values can be recognized. An analysis of the distinctive power of the various test systems used in our laboratory is presented. Experience has shown that methods of processing and storing vaccine viruses can cause significant changes in the biophysical properties of the virus, eg virulence, plaque morphology, behavior in the sucrose density gradient, even antigenic shift and immunogenicity.
