Therefore, it is recommended to prepare reference antisera as much as possible from strains currently in use in vaccine production to compare strains to decide on the use of vaccines.
authors: Rweyemamu, M. M.;Pay, T. W. F.;Parker, M. J.

title: Universal oligonucleotide microarray for subtyping influenza A virus
abstract: universal microchip has been developed for genotyping of influenza A viruses. It contains two sets of oligonucleotide probes that allow viruses to be classified by hemagglutinin (H1-H13, H15, H16) and neuraminidase (N1-N9) subtypes. Additional probe sets are used to detect H1N1 swine flu viruses. The selection of probes was done in two steps. First, amino acid sequences specific to each subtype were determined, and then the most specific and representative oligonucleotide probes were selected. Overall, 19 to 24 probes were used to identify each subtype of hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA). Genotyping involved the preparation of fluorescently labeled PCR amplicons of influenza virus cDNA and their hybridization to microarrays of specific oligonucleotide probes. Of the 40 samples tested, 36 clearly identified the HA and NA subtypes of the Influenza A virus.
authors: Ryabinin, V. A.;Kostina, E. V.;Maksakova, G. A.;Neverov, A. A.;Chumakov, K. M.;Sinyakov, A. N.

title: Invertebrate RNA virus diversity from a taxonomic perspective
abstract: Invertebrates host a variety of RNA viruses with all possible types of encapsulated genomes (positive, negative, and ambisense single-stranded RNA genomes or a double-stranded RNA genome). These viruses also show marked differences in virion morphology and genome structure. Invertebrate RNA viruses are found in three of the four currently recognized RNA virus orders: Mononegavirales, Nidovirales, and Picornavirales, and 10 of 37 RNA virus families that have not yet been assigned to an order. This mini-review describes the general characteristics of taxonomic groups that include invertebrate RNA viruses according to their current classification by the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV). (C) 2016 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Ryabov, E. V.

title: Rabies of the wild dog (Lycaon pictus) and spotted hyena (Crocuta crocuta) canid biotype in Madikwe Game Reserve, South Africa, 2014-2015: Diagnosis, possible origins, and implications for control.
abstract: In South Africa, both domestic and wild carnivorous species are commonly diagnosed with rabies virus (RABV) infection. While most confirmed cases of rabies in wild carnivorous species have been reported from the yellow mongoose (Cynictis penicillata), the remainder are from other wild carnivores, including the endangered wild dog (Lycaon pictus). Lyssavirus infection was confirmed in 2014 and 2015 at the Madikwe Game Reserve in the North West province of South Africa using direct fluorescent antibody testing and immunohistochemistry from two wild dogs and a spotted hyena (Crocuta crocuta). No new wild dog has been introduced into the Madikwe Game Reserve for many years, and the wild dogs were vaccinated against rabies about 11 years ago, about 11 years ago. The first euthanized wild dog was the last surviving dog of a 6-pack, and the second was the last of a larger 18-pack; the rest died with no carcasses found or the carcasses too rotten for sampling. Subsequent antigenic typing of the lyssaviruses showed them to be canid RABVs. Originating from 22 wild carnivorous species, 7 dogs and one goat, mostly from the North West region, RABVs were genetically characterized by targeting a partial region of the nucleoprotein gene. Nucleotide sequence analyzes of these viruses and two previously characterized RABVs confirmed that epidemic viruses were also canid rabies, which phylogenetically clustered with virus isolates originating from black-backed coyotes rescued from the North West state between 2012 and 2015 and domestic dogs from the neighboring community. fields. Sources of deaths and possible reservoir host(s) for the virus can only be estimated from data on specific predator numbers, movements and behaviors, kills, park management and changing environmental ecology closely monitored in Madikwe. for several years. The most likely sources of rabies were from boundary fence contacts between wild carnivores within the park, domestic dogs or cats, and/or naturally occurring wild carnivores outside the park. The risk of associated zoonotic infections and the threat to important and endangered predators can be reduced primarily through regional rabies control in domestic dogs and cats, as well as through preventive vaccination of park workers and pets at risk. Emphasizes the importance of continued prophylactic rabies protection through regular vaccination of endangered wildlife carnivores and the presentation of carcasses for rabies diagnosis of any wild or domestic animal that exhibits uncharacteristic behavior or is found dead.
authors: Sabeta, C. T.;Janse Van Rensburg, D. D.;Phahladira, B.;Mohale, D.;Harrison-White, R. F.;Esterhuyzen, C.;Williams, J. H.

title: Characterization of a novel VII subgenotype of Newcastle disease virus circulating in Iran
abstract: Newcastle disease is an economically important and highly contagious disease affecting wild and domestic bird species. Despite extensive vaccination efforts in the poultry industry, outbreaks of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) still occur, causing significant economic losses. Rural chickens can serve as a potential reservoir of NDV for commercial poultry due to poor biosecurity and inadequate vaccination. The aim of this study was to investigate the phylogenetic relationship and molecular characterization of eight NDVs isolated from backyard poultry in Iran between 2011 and 2013. The complete coding sequence of the fusion (F) and hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) genes of eight NDVs was determined and compared with other published NDVs. Based on the inter-population distances and phylogenetic topology between the current NDV categories, the Iranian isolates formed a new subgenotype VII that differed from the previous groups specified in genotype VII. Moreover, both the F and HN genes of Iranian isolates shared high nucleotide sequence similarity with viruses isolated in China. All viruses analyzed contained a polybasic cleavage site motif (111G/RRRQKRâ†“F117) indicating that all isolates can be categorized as a virulent pathotype. No mutations were observed in the neutralizing epitopes of the F protein. Analysis of amino acids associated with neutralizing antigenic sites within the HN protein revealed that all isolates exhibited a unique amino acid (Q) at position 347. These results highlight the need to strengthen biosecurity measures and implement a mandatory vaccination program in village herds. local poultry. Also, continuous monitoring of NDVs in different avian species could help learn more about the evolution of this virus and prevent future panzootics.
authors: Sabouri, F.;Vasfi Marandi, M.;Bashashati, M.

title: Simultaneous identification of DNA and RNA viruses in pig feces using process-controlled deep sequencing
abstract: BACKGROUND: Animal feces contain a community of many different microorganisms, including bacteria and viruses. Only scarce information is available on the diversity of viruses found in pig feces. Here, we describe an optimized protocol for purification of the total fraction of viral particles from pig feces. Genomes of purified DNA and RNA viruses were simultaneously PCR amplified and deep sequenced, followed by bioinformatics analyses. The effectiveness of the method was monitored using a process control consisting of three bacteriophages (T4, M13 and MS2) with different morphology and genome types. Defined amounts of bacteriophages were added to the sample and their abundance was assessed by quantitative PCR during the preparation procedure. RESULTS: The procedure was applied to a pooled fecal sample of five pigs. 69,613 string reads were generated from this sample. All of the added bacteriophages were identified by sequence analysis of the reads. In total, 7.7% of reads showed significant sequence identities with published viral sequences. It originated mainly from bacteriophages (73.9%) and mammalian viruses (23.9%); 0.8% of the sequences were identical to plant viruses. The most abundant swine viruses detected were kobuvirus, rotavirus C, astrovirus, enterovirus B, sapovirus, and picobirnavirus. In addition, sequences identical to the circular ssDNA virus associated with chimpanzee feces were identified. Whole genome analysis indicates that this virus, tentatively termed pig feces-associated circular ssDNA virus (PigSCV), represents a novel porcine virus. CONCLUSION: The established protocol enables simultaneous detection of DNA and RNA viruses in pig feces, including identification of hitherto unknown viruses. It can be applied in studies investigating the etiology, epidemiology and ecology of diseases. Applied process control functions as quality control, ensures method comparability and can be used for further method optimization.
authors: Sachsenroder, J.;Twardziok, S.;Hammerl, J. A.;Janczyk, P.;Wrede, P.;Hertwig, S.;Johne, R.

title: The overall composition of pig fecal virus is age dependent, but not dependent on feeding with a probiotic bacteria.
abstract: Background: The porcine fecal viroma containing the ensemble of viruses found in pig feces is complex and consists of swine viruses, bacteriophages, transiently passaged plant viruses, and other small virus species. Little is known about the factors affecting its overall composition. Here, the effect of the probiotic bacteria Enterococcus faecium (E. faecium) NCIMB 10415 on porcine fecal viroma composition was analyzed in a pig feeding trial with sows and their piglets with or without probiotic bacteria. Results: DNA and RNA virus particles were prepared from 8 pooled stool samples from the feeding trial and subjected to process-controlled Next Generation Sequencing, resulting in 390,650 sequence reads. On average, 14% of the reads showed significant sequence identities against known viruses. The percentage of detected mammalian virus sequences was highest (55-77%) in samples of the youngest piglets and lowest (8-10%) in samples of pigs. In contrast, the percentage of bacteriophage sequences increased from 22-44% in the youngest piglets to approximately 90% in sows. The dominant mammalian viruses differed significantly between 12-day-old piglets (kobuvirus), 54-day-old piglets (boca-, dependent- and pig feces-associated small circular DNA virus [PigSCV]), and pigs (PigSCV, circovirus and circovirus). -like" viruses CB-A and RW-A). Additionally, the Shannon index, reflecting the diversity of sequences found in a sample, was generally higher for pigs compared to piglets. No consistent difference in virome composition could be detected between the viromes of the probiotic bacteria-treated group and the control group. Conclusion: The analysis shows that the porcine fecal virus has a high variability and its overall composition is mainly dependent on the age of the pigs. Changes caused by feeding with probiotic bacteria E. faecium could not be demonstrated by the applied metagenomic method. Â© 2014 Sachsenröder et al.
authors: SachsenrÃ¶der, J.;Twardziok, S. O.;Scheuch, M.;Johne, R.

title: US beef calf serum Virome
abstract: We analyzed four pools of bovine serum collected from 715 calves in the United States using viral metagenomics. Two parvoviruses, a previously uncharacterized parvovirus named bovine parvovirus 2 (BPV2) and bosavirus (BosaV), were detected in pools 3 and 4, respectively, and their complete coding sequences were generated. Based on the NS1 protein identity, bosavirus qualifies as a member of a new species in the copiparvovirus genus. Also, a low number of matched reads was detected with ungulate tetraparvovirus 2, bovine hepacivirus and several papillomaviruses. This study also characterizes the diversity of viruses in calf serum and fetal bovine serum contaminated cell cultures that have the potential to infect fetuses.
authors: Sadeghi, M.;Kapusinszky, B.;Yugo, D. M.;Phan, T. G.;Deng, X.;Kanevsky, I.;Opriessnig, T.;Woolums, A. R.;Hurley, D. J.;Meng, X. J.;Delwart, E.

title: Detection of Swine Bocavirus in a Child with Acute Respiratory Infection
abstract: Porcine bocavirus is a newly discovered virus classified within the genus Bocavirus. We report a case of swine bocavirus-associated upper respiratory tract infection in a 3-year-old boy in close contact with pigs in northeastern Iran. To our knowledge, this is the first report on human swine bocavirus infection.
authors: Safamanesh, S.;Azimian, A.;Shakeri, A.;Ghazvini, K.;Jamehdar, S. A.;Khosrojerdi, M.;Youssefi, M.

title: No viral association was found in a series of cases of differentiated vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia by human papillomavirus and pan-viral microarray testing
abstract: Vulvar Intraepithelial Neoplasia (VIN) is the precursor lesion of Vulvar Squamous Cell Carcinoma (VSCC) and is more common than differentiated type (dVIN) VSCC. In contrast to the usual type VIN (uVIN) associated with human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, a germline mutation in the p53 gene is thought to be associated with 90% of dVIN cases. To date, no infectious agents associated with dVIN have been identified, and studies investigating this possibility have been hampered by the difficulty in accurately diagnosing dVIN from small biopsies. Here, we used immunostaining to examine 14 uVIN high-grade VIN and 14 dVIN cases for p16<sup>ink4a</sup>, a biomarker for HPV infection, and select 10 dVIN cases to broadly screen all known viruses. pan-viral microarray platform (ViroChip). All uVIN tissue samples, including 8 warts and 6 basaloid cases, showed positivity with the p16<sup>ink4a</sup> immunostain. The staining pattern was full thickness for all but two cases where positive staining was localized in the lower 1/3 of the epidermis. In contrast, immunostaining for p16<sup>ink4a</sup> was negative in all dVIN cases. ViroChip analysis of 10 pure dVIN samples confirmed the absence of human papillomavirus subtypes or any other virus, except for a single sample showing a weak microarray signature against a porcine herpes virus. Subsequent PCR testing of the sample was negative for the herpes virus, and in-depth metagenomic next-generation sequencing revealed only sequences that corresponded to non-pathogenic viral flora and bacterial contamination. In this study, we showed that there was no virus association in 10 dVIN cases. Alternative pathways for carcinogenesis, such as p53 mutation, should be considered to explore potential treatment options in dVIN.
authors: Saglam, O.;Samayoa, E.;Somasekar, S.;Naccache, S.;Iwasaki, A.;Chiu, C. Y.

title: Antigenic subtyping of porcine circovirus type 2 using monoclonal antibodies and competition analysis of its epitopes
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) strains have been classified into two main genotypes (PCV2a and PCV2b) and 8 genetic clusters: PCV2b-1A to PCV2b-1C and PCV2a-2A to PCV2a-2E. To date, no studies have been conducted to antigenically subtype PCV2 strains comprising eight PCV2 clusters. This study aimed to subtyping PCV2 antigenically and to perform competition analysis of epitopes using monoclonal antibodies (mAbs). Fourteen PCV2 strains, representing eight clusters, were tested with 20 mAbs in immunoperoxidase monolayer experiments (fifteen of these were produced against PCV2a strain Stoon-1010 and 5 against PCV2b strain 1147). Four mAbs responded to 14 PCV2 strains and one mAb reacted with all strains except one PCV2a-2C strain. One mAb reacted with all PCV2a strains except one PCV2a-2C strain and one mAb reacted with all PCV2b strains except one PCV2b-1C strain. Nine mAbs reacted with strains PCV2b-1A/1B, PCV2a-2A and PCV2a-2E. The three mAbs only reacted with strains PCV2a-2A and PCV2a-2E. A mAb specifically reacted with strains of PCV2b-1A/1B. This indicates that distinct antigenic differences exist between different PCV2 genetic clusters and that these clusters can be distinguished using a panel of universal and cluster-specific mAbs. Six mAbs were selected for cross-competition analysis by a competitive ELISA using the PCV2 strain Stoon-1010. Six overlapping epitopes were identified on the PCV2 capsid protein. Universal mAbs recognized larger epitopes than cluster-specific mAbs. These findings assist in the development of diagnostic tests and next-generation vaccines against PCV2. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Saha, D.;Huang, L.;Bussalleu, E.;Lefebvre, D. J.;Fort, M.;Van Doorsselaere, J.;Nauwynck, H. J.

title: Comparison of the characteristics of viruses isolated from synovium and avian reoviruses isolated from digestive and respiratory tracts.
abstract: Two-week-old gnotobiotic chicks were inoculated on the soles of the feet with viruses isolated from the synovium and synovial membrane: WVU 1464-29H, WVU 1675, WVU 2937, WVU 2986 and WVU 71-212; from the digestive tract: reoviruses 24, 25 and 59; or from the respiratory tract: reovirus Fahey Crawley (FC). All viruses caused swelling of the soles of the feet and inflammatory changes of the synovial membrane. Serum from infected chicks had a common agar gel precipitin (AGP) line. Viruses were classified into 4 major serotypes based on the plaque reduction test in primary chicken kidney (PCK) cells. All viruses produced cytopathic effects (CPE) in primary chicken tissue cultures. All viruses except Reovirus FC and WVU 1464-29H produced CPE in Vero cell line.
authors: Sahu, S. P.;Olson, N. O.

title: Sequence analysis of defective interference-like RNA of influenza A H1N1 pandemic virus in vivo
abstract: Influenza virus imperfectly mixed (DI) particles are naturally occurring non-infectious virions produced in cell culture of virus at high infection diversity, typically during serial passages in vitro. DI particles are recognized for their role in inhibiting viral replication and their effects on the production of infectious virions. To date, influenza virus DI particles have been reported primarily as a cell culture phenomenon and in experimentally infected embryonated chicken eggs. It has also been isolated from respiratory tract infection of chickens. Using a sequencing approach, we characterize several subgenomic viral RNAs from human nasopharyngeal samples infected with influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. The distribution of these in vivo-derived DI-like RNAs was similar to the distribution of DIs in vitro, with the majority of defective RNAs produced from PB2 (segment 1) of the polymerase complex, followed by PB1 and PA. The lengths of the in vivo-derived DI-like segments are also similar to those of known in vitro DIs, and the in vivo-derived DI-like segments share internal deletions of the same segments. The presence of identical DI-like RNAs in patients bound by direct contact is consistent with transfer between them. The functional role of DI-like RNAs in natural infections has yet to be determined.
authors: Saira, K.;Lin, X.;DePasse, J. V.;Halpin, R.;Twaddle, A.;Stockwell, T.;Angus, B.;Cozzi-Lepri, A.;Delfino, M.;Dugan, V.;Dwyer, D. E.;Freiberg, M.;Horban, A.;Losso, M.;Lynfield, R.;Wentworth, D. N.;Holmes, E. C.;Davey, R.;Wentworth, D. E.;Ghedin, E.;Group, I. F. S.;Group, I. F. S.

title: Characterization of a human H9N2 influenza virus isolated in Hong Kong.
abstract: Two H9N2 viruses were first isolated from humans in 1999 in Hong Kong. The isolation of influenza viruses with a new subtype of hemagglutinin (HA) has drawn the attention of health authorities worldwide in terms of pandemic preparedness. Sequence analysis of HA genes reveals that HA of A/Hong Kong/1073/99 (H9N2) is most closely related to A/quail/HK/G1/97 (H9N2) containing internal genes similar to those of Hong. Kong/97 (H5N1) viruses. Phylogenetic and antigenic analyzes showed diversity among H9 HA. A/Hong Kong/1073/99 was shown to cause respiratory infection in Syrian hamsters, suggesting that the virus can reproduce efficiently in mammalian hosts. We have developed a complete virion test vaccine with formalin-inactivated egg-raised HK1073. Intraperitoneal administration of the vaccine to hamsters twice provided complete protection against infection by MDCK cell-grown homologous virus. The receptor specificity of HK1073 appeared to differ from that of other avian influenza viruses of the H9 subtype, which preferentially recognize α-2.3-linked sialic acid. Hemagglutination of HK1073 with guinea pig erythrocytes was inhibited by polymers containing both α-2.3 and α-2.6 linked sialic acid. These data suggested that HK1073 acquired a wider host range, including humans. Combined with the data available so far, this study suggested that the isolation of H9 influenza viruses from humans should be precautionary against the emergence of a new human flu. Â© 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.
authors: Saito, T.;Lim, W.;Suzuki, T.;Suzuki, Y.;Kida, H.;Nishimura, S. I.;Tashiro, M.

title: DNA Virome: Sequencing and Data Analysis of Viral Metagenome of Poultry Victims of Respiratory Diseases
authors: Sajnani, M. R.;Sudarsanam, D.

title: Viral Metagenomics of chickens with respiratory tract infection using MG-RAST.
authors: Sajnani, M. R.;Sudarsanam, D.

title: Metagenomic data of DNA viruses of poultry affected by respiratory infection
abstract: The incidence and severity of respiratory diseases in commercial broiler flocks in India have increased recently due to the intensification of the broiler industry. The viral population predominates in respiratory tract infections and creates a continuing economic burden to the poultry industry by causing serious economic losses through declining productivity [1], [2]. To understand the viral metagenome of poultry associated with respiratory infections, we performed DNA virome sequencing and data analysis of chickens from 8 regions of the State of Gujarat in India. We report high quality sequence reads and a highly abundant DNA viral population in infected broilers. The raw sequencing data used to perform the metagenomic analysis was obtained from BioProject No. PRJNA322592 and Accession No. MAUZ00000000, MAVA00000000, MAVB00000000, MAVC00000000, MAVD00000000, MAVE00000000, MAVF00000000, MAVG00000000 (https://www. .ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bioproject/?term=PRJNA322592).
authors: Sajnani, M. R.;Sudarsanam, D.;Pandit, R. J.;Oza, T.;Hinsu, A. T.;Jakhesara, S. J.;Solosanc, S.;Joshi, C. G.;Bhatt, V. D.

title: Isolation and characterization of a novel Rhabdovirus from a wild boar (Sus scrofa) in Japan
abstract: novel rhabdovirus was isolated from the serum of a healthy Japanese wild boar (Sus scrofa leucomystax), and viral nucleic acid sequences (RDV) were identified using the rapid detection system for next-generation sequencing and electron microscopy. The virus was tentatively named wild boar rhabdovirus 1 (WBRV1). Phylogenetic analysis of the whole genome sequence showed that WBRV1 is closely related to Tupaia rhabdovirus (TRV) isolated from cultured cells of tree mouse hepatocellular carcinoma tissue. TRV has not been assigned to any Rhabdoviridae genus to date. Analysis of the L gene showed that WBRV1 belongs to the genus Vesiculovirus. These observations indicate that both TRV and WBRV1 belong to a new genus Rhabdoviridae. Next-generation genome sequencing of WBRV1 revealed 5 open reading frames with 1329, 765, 627, 1629 and 6336 base lengths. The WBRV1 gene sequences are similar to those of other rhabdoviruses. Epizootiological analysis of a wild boar population in Wakayama prefecture in Japan showed that 6.5% were positive for the WBRV1 gene and 52% for WBRV1-neutralizing antibodies. Also, such viral neutralizing antibodies were found in domestic pigs from another state. WBRV1 was inoculated intranasally and intraperitoneally into SCID and BALB/c mice, and viral RNA was detected in SCID mice, suggesting that WBRV1 might replicate in immunocompromised mice. These results indicate that this new virus is endemic in wild animals and farm animals in Japan.
authors: Sakai, K.;Hagiwara, K.;Omatsu, T.;Hamasaki, C.;Kuwata, R.;Shimoda, H.;Suzuki, K.;Endoh, D.;Nagata, N.;Nagai, M.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Kurane, I.;Saijo, M.;Morikawa, S.;Mizutani, T.;Maeda, K.

title: Bunyaviruses are common in male and female Ixodes scapularis ticks in central Pennsylvania.
abstract: The black-legged tick Ixodes scapularis is common in the United States and transmits many pathogens to humans, wildlife, and pets. Recently, several novel viruses in the Bunyaviridae family (South Bay virus (SBV) and Blacklegged tick phlebovirus (BTPV)) have been described that infect female I. scapularis ticks collected in New York State. We used metagenomic sequencing to investigate the distribution of viruses that infect male and female I. scapularis ticks collected in Center County, Pennsylvania. We detected both SBV and BTPV in both male and female ticks from all collection locations. The role of male I. scapularis in pathogen epidemiology has been overlooked as they rarely bite and are not considered important pathogen vectors. However, males can serve as reservoirs for pathogens that can then be transferred to females during mating. Our data highlight the importance of examining all potential pathways of pathogen maintenance and transmission throughout the vector-pathogen lifecycle to understand the epidemiology of tick-borne pathogens.
authors: Sakamoto, J. M.;Ng, T. F. F.;Suzuki, Y.;Tsujimoto, H.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.;Rasgon, J. L.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of porcine and ruminant pestiviruses isolated mainly in Japan
abstract: The genetic variability of porcine and ruminant pestiviruses was examined by comparative nucleotide sequence analysis of 73 isolates (42 pigs and 31 ruminants), including 65 Japanese isolates (35 pigs and 30 ruminants). The 5'-untranslated region (UTR) amplified by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was determined by direct sequencing and phylogenetic analysis was performed from the nucleotide sequence data. Most swine isolates were divided into two main subgroups, classical swine fever virus (CSFV) subgroup 1 (CSFV-1 represented by Brecia strain) and subgroup 2 (CSFV-2 represented by Alfort strain). However, the Japanese strains Kanagawa/74, Okinawa/86, Okinawa/86-2 and Thai CBR/93 were the most prominent variants and were assigned to another different subgroup, CSFV-3 (represented by strain p97). Most ruminant isolates were classified as bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) genotype-I (BVDV-I) and subdivided into two subgroups, BVDV-Ia (represented by NADL strain) and Ib (represented by Osloss strain). Two bovine isolates (MS-1 and SY-89) from one ovine cell line and a contaminant strain (V/FLL) were classified as BVDV genotype-II (BVDV-II) based on genetic characteristics. These data suggested that detection and phylogenetic analysis of 5'-UTRs are useful for rapid characterization of domain isolates.
authors: Sakoda, Y.;Ozawa, S. I.;Damrongwatanapokin, S.;Sato, M.;Ishikawa, K.;Fukusho, A.

title: Viral RNA Load in Patients with Tick-Bound Encephalitis, Slovenia
abstract: We determined the levels of tick-borne encephalitis (TBE) virus (TBEV) RNA in serum samples from 80 patients during the initial stage of TBE in Slovenia. For most samples, levels ranged from 3-6 log(10) copies of RNA/mL. Levels were higher in female patients than in male patients, but we found no association between viral load and various laboratory and clinical parameters, including TBE severity. However, a weak humoral immune response was associated with a more severe disease course, suggesting that insufficient clearance of the virus resulted in more serious illness. To determine whether a particular genetic lineage of TBEV has higher virulence potential, we obtained 56 partial envelope protein gene sequences by directly sequencing reverse transcription PCR products from patients' clinical samples. This method provided a large set of patient-derived TBEV arrays. We observed no association between phylogenetic branches and viral load or disease severity.
authors: Saksida, A.;Jakopin, N.;Jelovsek, M.;Knap, N.;Fajs, L.;Lusa, L.;Lotric-Furlan, S.;Bogovic, P.;Arnez, M.;Strle, F.;Avsic-Zupanc, T.

title: Alternative growth promoters Modulate the broiler gut microbiome and increase body weight gain
abstract: Antibiotic growth promoters (AGPs) are often used to increase weight gain in poultry production. However, there is growing concern about the impact of AGP in the emergence of antibiotic resistance in zoonotic bacterial pathogens in the microbial community of the poultry gut. In this study, we adopted mass spectrophotometric, phylogenetic and shotgun-metagenomic approaches to evaluate bioactive phenolic extracts (BPE) from blueberry (Vaccinium corymbosum) and blackberry (Rubus fruticosus) pulp as AGP alternatives in broilers. We performed two trials with 100 Cobb-500 broiler chickens (in each trial) in four equal groups, supplemented with no water, supplemented with AGP (tylosin, neomycin sulfate, bacitracin, erythromycin, and oxytetracycline), or supplemented with 0.1 g. Gallic acid equivalent (GAE)/L of BPE or 1.0 g GAE/L (within the last 72 hours before euthanasia) for 6 weeks. Compared to the control group (water only), chickens supplemented with AGP and 0.1 g GAE/L BPE gained 9.5% and 5.8% more body weight, respectively. The microbiomes of chickens treated with both AGP and BPE had higher Firmicutes/Bacteroidetes ratios. AGP supplementation appears to be associated with relatively higher bacteriophage abundance and unique cecal resistomas compared with BPE supplementation or control. Functional characterization of the cecal microbiomes has revealed significant animal-to-animal variation in the relative abundance of genes involved in energy and carbohydrate metabolism. These findings provided a basis on which plant-based performance-enhancing mechanisms can be investigated in the regulation of animal growth. In addition, the data will help design alternative strategies to improve animal growth performance and therefore production.
authors: Salaheen, S.;Kim, S. W.;Haley, B. J.;Van Kessel, J. A. S.;Biswas, D.

title: Biological and molecular identification of seed-borne viruses in cowpea germplasm of geographically diverse sub-Saharan origin.
abstract: total of 983 cowpea inputs from the University of California, Riverside (UCR) Cowpea Warehouse were analyzed for seed-borne viruses. Most of the entries originated from 11 countries representing different agro-climatic zones in sub-Saharan Africa and included native species, native cultivars and breeding lines. Following initial growth tests, 69 cowpea entries, mostly with symptoms of virus infection, were selected for further evaluation using a combination of host range, reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and sequencing analyses. Analyzes revealed that samples from 46 (67%) accessions harbored one or more known seed-borne cowpea viruses. These include Botswana (13 entries), Ghana (6), Nigeria (6), Mali (1), Kenya (5), Cameroon (7), Niger (4), Cote d'lvoire (1), Benin (1) , India (1) and China (1). Viruses were identified by cloning and sequencing of RT-PCR products amplified using virus strain- and family-specific degenerate oligonucleotide primers, as well as RT-PCR analysis of total RNAs extracted from samples suspected to be virus-infected using virus-type-specific primers. Viruses identified include Cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CABMV), Cucumber mosaic virus (CMV), and Southern bean mosaic virus (SBMV). Phylogenetic analysis of the inferred coat protein (CP) amino acid sequences of selected CMV isolates from five agriculturally diverse locations confirmed their linkage as novel members of the CMV subgroup IB. This is the first time that seed-borne viruses of cowpea accessions in a large collection (UCR) have been identified using RT-PCR and sequencing approaches.
authors: Salem, N. M.;Ehlers, J. D.;Roberts, P. A.;Ng, J. C. K.

title: Identification and characterization of tuberous skin disease virus isolated from cattle in the Republic of North Ossetia-Alanya in 2015.
abstract: The first reports of the unknown disease of cattle appeared in September-October 2015 in the North Caucasus region of Russia (North Ossetia-Alanya). Clinical findings included watery discharge from the eyes, apathy, anorexia, salivation, lameness, and nodular skin lesions. Capripoxvirus genome was detected by real-time PCR in tissue samples of sick animals. The etiologic agent was isolated in primary cell cultures of lamb testis and goat testis, as well as in continuous MDBC cell culture. Further sequencing of the GPCR gene and phylogenetic analysis showed the close genetic association of the isolated capripox virus with a group of tuberous skin disease viruses. Koch's assumptions were fulfilled by experimental infection of four calves with a suspension of tissue samples from sick animals.
authors: Salnikov, N.;Usadov, T.;Kolcov, A.;Zhivoderov, S.;Morgunov, Y.;Gerasimov, V.;Gogin, A.;Titov, I.;Yurkov, S.;Malogolovkin, A.;Kolbasov, D.;Lunitsyn, A.

title: A Complete Array of Chicken BG Haplotypes Demonstrates Dynamic Expansion and Contraction of Two Gene Lines with Special Expression Patterns
abstract: Many genes important in immunity exist as multigene families. Butyrophilin genes are members of the B7 family that play various roles in co-regulation and perhaps antigen presentation. In humans, a fixed number of butyrophilin genes are found in and around the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) and show striking association with certain autoimmune diseases. In chickens, BG genes encode homologues with slightly different site organization. Only a few BG genes have been characterized, one involved in actin-myosin interaction at the intestinal brush border and the other involved in resistance to viral diseases. We characterize all BG genes in B12 chickens, we find a multigene family organized as tandem repeats in the BG region outside the MHC, a single gene in the MHC (BF-BL region) and another single gene on a different chromosome. There is a precise cell and tissue expression for each gene, but in general there are two types, those expressed by hemopoietic cells and those expressed in tissues (probably non-hemopoietic cells), two different types of promoters and associated with a 5² untranslated region. (5â€²UTR). However, the multigene family in the BG region contains many hybrid genes, suggesting recombination and/or deletion as major evolutionary forces. We confirmed the dynamic expansion and contraction within the BG region by identifying BG genes by comparing them to other haplotypes via fiber fluorescent in situ hybridization as well as BG genes in the chicken whole genome shotgun array. Therefore, BG genes in chickens evolve much faster than their mammalian homologues, for reasons that are not yet understood. Â© 2014 Salomonsen et al.
authors: Salomonsen, J.;Chattaway, J. A.;Chan, A. C. Y.;Parker, A.;Huguet, S.;Marston, D. A.;Rogers, S. L.;Wu, Z.;Smith, A. L.;Staines, K.;Butter, C.;Riegert, P.;Vainio, O.;Nielsen, L.;Kaspers, B.;Griffin, D. K.;Yang, F.;Zoorob, R.;Guillemot, F.;Auffray, C.;Beck, S.;SkjÃ¸dt, K.;Kaufman, J.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic study of velogenic Newcastle disease virus isolates in Iran.
abstract: Pathogenicity and genetic characterizations of six Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates obtained from poultry farms in six different regions of Iran were performed using conventional and molecular techniques. According to their pathogenicity indices (MDT, ICPI, and IVPI), these isolates were all found to be velogenic (highly virulent) strains. A sequence analysis of full-length mRNA encoding the fusion glycoprotein precursor (F0) of the fusion proteins F1 and F2 of NDV in these six isolates revealed the presence of point mutations in the form of nucleic acid substitutions at positions 82(Câ†'T). , 83(Tâ†'C), 736(Aâ†'G), and 1.633(Gâ†'A). However, nucleic acid residues at positions 330-347 of the lead F0 gene, corresponding to the cleavage site of the F0 protein, were found to remain conserved among the six NDV isolates. A phylogenetic comparison between six Iranian isolates and NDVs whose F0 gene sequences were previously stored in the GenBank Database showed that all newly characterized Iranian NDV isolates belonged to genotype VII. Â© 2013 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Samadi, S.;Kianizadeh, M.;Najafi, M. F.;Nasab, S. D. M.;Davatgar, A. M. H.;Royaee, A.;Pilvar, P.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of tuberous skin disease viruses in northwest Iran
abstract: Lumpy skin disease (LSD) is a devastating viral disease in cattle that has recently spread from Africa to Middle Eastern countries. The aim of this study is to investigate the relationships between tuberous skin disease viruses (LSDV) isolated from different regions of Iran and the origin and spread of these viruses. In this study, a total of 234 blood samples from clinically affected animals from four provinces in northwest Iran were screened for LSDV using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Of the 80 positive samples for LSDV detected by PCR, the partial P32 gene (759Â bp) of 12 isolates was sequenced and phylogenetically analyzed. LSD viruses were grouped into three subsets with an overall nucleotide identity of 97.1-100%. LSDVs isolated from Gilan showed the lowest nucleotide identity with other LSDVs. The four LSDV isolates, including KO-1, EA-1, EA-3 and WA-3, showed 100% similarity to each other as well as to the Neethling strain. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the identified LSDVs were closely related and had high sequence homology with other LSDV isolates from Africa. It was concluded that the LSD epidemic probably occurred in northwest Iran by LSDVs entering the country from Iraq, and the P32 nucleotide sequence information obtained in this study is a valuable resource for understanding the genetic makeup and molecular epidemiology of local LSDV isolates that can be used. For future vaccine development based on strains circulating in the region.
authors: Sameea Yousefi, P.;Dalir-Naghadeh, B.;Mardani, K.;Jalilzadeh-Amin, G.

title: A Blood Signature of Four Biomarkers Distinguishes Viral Infection-Related Systemic Inflammation Against Other Etiologies
abstract: The innate immune system of humans and other mammals responds to pathogen-associated molecular models (PAMPs) that are conserved in broad classes of infectious agents, such as bacteria and viruses. We hypothesized that a blood-based transcriptional signature could be discovered, indicating a host systemic response to viral infection. Previous work has identified host transcriptional signatures to individual viruses, including influenza, respiratory syncytial virus, and dengue, but the generality of these signatures across all types of viral infections has not been established. Based on 44 publicly available datasets and two clinical studies of our design, we discovered and validated four gene expression signatures in whole blood that are indicative of a general host systemic response to many types of viral infections. The genes of the signature are: Interferon Stimulated Gene 15 (ISG15), Interleukin 16 (IL16), 2',5'-Oligoadenylate Synthetase-Like (OASL) and Adhesion G Protein-Matched Receptor E5 (ADGRE5). In each of the 13 validation datasets covering human, macaque, chimpanzee, porcine, mouse, rat, and all seven Baltimore virus classification groups, the signature provides a statistically significant (p-<-0.05) distinction between viral and non-viral conditions. The signature may have clinical use to differentiate host systemic inflammation (SI) from viral and bacterial or non-infectious causes.
authors: Sampson, D. L.;Fox, B. A.;Yager, T. D.;Bhide, S.;Cermelli, S.;McHugh, L. C.;Seldon, T. A.;Brandon, R. A.;Sullivan, E.;Zimmerman, J. J.;Noursadeghi, M.;Brandon, R. B.

title: Complete genome sequence of Avian Paramyxovirus (APMV) serotype 5 complements analysis of nine APMV serotypes and reveals the longest APMV genome
abstract: Background: Avian paramyxoviruses (APMV) consist of nine known serotypes. The genomes of representatives of all APMV serotypes except APMV type 5 have recently been fully sequenced. Here we report the complete genome sequence of the APMV-5 prototype strain budgerigar/Kunitachi/74. Methodology/Key Findings: APMV-5 Kunitachi virus is unusual in that it does not contain a virion hemagglutinin and does not reproduce in the allantoic cavity of embryonated chicken eggs. However, the virus grew in the amniotic cavity of embryonated chicken eggs and twelve different established cell lines and two primary cell cultures. The genome is 17,262 nucleotides (nt) long, the longest among members of the genus Avulavirus, and encodes six genes that are intergenic and do not overlap in the 3-²N-P/V/WMF-HN-L-5-² order. Regions of 4-57 nt. Genome length follows the 'rule of six' and contains a 55 nt leader sequence at the 3-end and a 552-nt fragment sequence at the 5-end. The phosphoprotein (P) gene contains a conserved RNA editing region and is predicted to encode the P, V, and W proteins. The cleavage site of the F protein (GKRKKR â†“ F) conforms to the cleavage site motif of the ubiquitous cellular protease furin. Consistent with this, exogenous protease was not required for virus replication in vitro. However, in one-day-old chicks, the intracerebral pathogenicity index of APMV-5 strain Kunitachi was found to be zero, indicating that the virus is lethal to chickens despite the presence of a polybasic F cleavage site. Results/Significance: Phylogenetic analysis of the sequences of the APVM-5 genome and proteins against other APMV serotypes showed that APMV-5 was more closely related to APMV-6 than to other APMVs. Furthermore, these comparisons provided evidence of wide genome-wide variation supporting the classification of APMVs into nine distinct serotypes. The structure of the F cleavage site does not appear to be a reliable indicator for virulence among APMV serotypes 2-9. Availability of sequence information for all known APMV serotypes will facilitate studies in epidemiology and vaccination.
authors: Samuel, A. S.;Paldurai, A.;Kumar, S.;Collins, P. L.;Samal, S. K.

title: Climate change impacts global potential distribution of bluetongue virus
abstract: The geographic distribution of arboviruses has received considerable attention after several dramatic worldwide emergence events. Bluetongue virus (BTV) is classified among "A" category diseases that must be reported to the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) and is transmitted among ruminant animals by biting the mid-ends of the genus Culicoides. Here, we developed a comprehensive event dataset to map the current distribution, predict the ecological niche, and explore the potential future distribution of BTV globally using ecological niche modeling and based on various future climate scenarios from general circulation models (GCMs) for the four representatives. concentration pathways (RCPs). The broad ecological niche and potential geographic distribution of BTV in today's conditions reflected the current distribution of the disease around the world in tropical, subtropical and temperate regions. All model predictions were significantly better than random expectations. As a further assessment of model robustness, we compared our model estimates with 331 independent records from the most recent outbreaks from the Food and Agriculture Organization's Emergency Prevention System Information System for Transboundary Animal and Plant Pests and Diseases (EMPRES-i); all have been successfully expected by the BTV model. Finally, we tested ecological niche similarity between possible vectors and BTV and were unable to reject the niche similarity hypotheses. Under future climatic conditions, the potential distribution of BTV was predicted to expand, particularly in Central Africa, the United States, and western Russia.
authors: Samy, A. M.;Peterson, A. T.

title: Antigenic homology between infectious gastroenteritis virus and related coronaviruses
abstract: Antigenic homology of 26 coronavirus isolates, 22 of which were antigenically related to infectious gastroenteritis virus (TGEV), was determined by 42 monoclonal antibodies. Type, group and interspecies specific epitopes were identified. The two group-specific MAbs distinguished enteric (TGEV) isolates from respiratory variants. An antigenic subregion involved in neutralization was conserved in swine, feline and canine coronavirus. It is proposed that the human coronavirus 229E be classified in a different taxonomic cluster from the TGEV group.
authors: Sanchez, C. M.;Jimenez, G.;Laviada, M. D.;Correa, I.;Sune, C.;Bullido, M.;Gebauer, F.;Smerdou, C.;Callebaut, P.;Escribano, J. M.;Enjuanes, L.

title: Analyzing pig serum for titers of functional antibodies to influenza a neuraminidase proteins using enzyme-linked lectin assay (ELLA).
abstract: Neuraminidase (NA) is an envelope glycoprotein of influenza viruses, including swine influenza A viruses. NA has sialidase activity, which is functionally important at many points in viral replication and balances the sialic acid receptor binding activity of the other major envelope glycoprotein, hemagglutinin (HA). The NA proteins of influenza A viruses have been classified into nine serological subtypes and undergo antigenic drift variation similar to that of HA. Antibodies to NA are analyzed much less frequently than antibodies to HA. The traditional assay for NA inhibition (NI) antibody titration, established decades ago, is widely considered cumbersome and inefficient for routine use. In recent years, several new formats have been developed that still measure inhibition of NA enzymatic function, but are more efficient and produce less chemical waste. Described here is enzyme-linked lectin assay (ELLA) performed in 96-well plates and analyzed in a spectrophotometric plate reader. An important factor in the adoption of the ELLA technique for animal studies, such as pig, is the selection of the NA antigen, which can be a purified protein or a whole virus containing an antigenically unrelated HA protein. This NI assay, together with the hemagglutination inhibitory (HI) antibody assay, provides a practical way to more fully characterize viral isolates and to quantify antibodies induced by infection or vaccination.
authors: Sandbulte, M. R.;Eichelberger, M. C.

title: Identifying greater diversity among posaviruses
abstract: Recently, there have been reports of new members of posavirus-like viruses in the order Picornavirales. In this study, 11 posavirus-like sequences (>7,000 nucleotides) were detected in 155 porcine stool samples using a metagenomic approach. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the newly identified virus sequences, along with other posavirus-like viruses, form distinct clusters in the Picornavirales order, which consists of eight genogroups and unassigned sequences based on amino acid sequences of helicase and RNA-dependent RNA polymerase sites. Sequence identity <40Â% and <50Â%, respectively. We propose further classification of a wide variety of posavirus populations based on newly identified sequences from Japanese pig feces.
authors: Sano, K.;Naoi, Y.;Kishimoto, M.;Masuda, T.;Tanabe, H.;Ito, M.;Niira, K.;Haga, K.;Asano, K.;Tsuchiaka, S.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Ouchi, Y.;Yamasato, H.;Ishida, M.;Shirai, J.;Katayama, K.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Detection and characterization of atypical capripox viruses among small ruminant animals in India
abstract: Recent advances in molecular biology have shed light on the interspecies transmission of SPPV and GTPV. This study was planned to characterize capripox viruses circulating in field conditions among sheep and goats using the RPO30 gene-based viral strain (SPPV/GTPV) distinguishing RPO30 and GPCR genes from clinical samples and PCR. Capripox virus infection was found to be positive in 27 sheep and 18 goat shells from 58 shells (35 sheep and 23 goats) scanned. Except for one sheep and one goat shell, all positive samples gave amplicon size relative to host origin, ie SPPV in sheep and GTPV in goats. In the two exceptions above, goat skin and sheep skin gave the amplicon size of SPPV and GTPV, respectively. Furthermore, sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes of the complete ORFs of the RPO30 and GPCR genes from six sheep and three goats' coats revealed that, except for the two examples above, all had host-specific signatures and clustered according to their host origin. In the case of cross-species infecting the samples, sheep scabies had GTPV-like signatures and goat's bark had SPPV-like signatures. Our study identifies the circulation of cross-infected SPPV and GTPV in the field and warrants the development of a single strain of vaccine that can protect animals from both sheep pox and goat pox.
authors: Santhamani, R.;Venkatesan, G.;Minhas, S. K.;Shivachandra, S. B.;Muthuchelvan, D.;Pandey, A. B.;Ramakrishnan, M. A.

title: Human urinary viroma associated with urinary tract infections
authors: Santiago-Rodriguez, T. M.;Ly, M.;Bonilla, N.

title: Genetic characterization of small ruminant lentiviruses circulating in naturally infected sheep and goats in Ontario, Canada.
abstract: Maedi-visna virus (MVV) and goat arthritis encephalitis virus (CAEV) are related members of a group of small ruminant lentiviruses (SRLVs) that infect sheep and goats. SRLVs are endemic in many countries, including Canada. However, little is known about the genetic characteristics of Canadian SRLVs, particularly in the province of Ontario. Given the importance of surveillance and eradication programs for the control of SRLVs, it is imperative that diagnostic tests used to identify infected animals are sensitive to local strains of SRLVs. The aim of this study was to characterize SRLV strains circulating in Ontario and to evaluate the variability of the immunodominant regions of the Gag protein. In this study, a nearly complete plug array of 164 SRLVs from 130 naturally infected sheep and 32 naturally infected goats from Ontario was sequenced. The animals belonged to remote mono and mixed breed (sheep and goat) farms. Sheep lentiviruses from the same farm tended to cluster more closely than goat lentiviruses from the same farm. Sequence analysis revealed a higher degree of heterogeneity between goat lentivirus sequences, with an average between-farm DNA distance of 10% and only 5% in the ovine lentivirus group. Interestingly, amplification of SRLV from ELISA-positive sheep was successful in 81% of cases, whereas amplification of SRLV proviral DNA was possible in only 55% of ELISA-positive goat samples; This suggests that a significant proportion of goat lentiviruses circulating in Ontario have heterogeneity in the primary binding sites used in this study. Sequences of sheep and goat SRLVs from Ontario were combined with other known SRLVs into phylogenetic trees and found to belong to sequence groups A2 and B1, respectively, as described by Shah et al. (2004a). A new goat lentivirus was identified with a double genetic difference of 15.6-25.4% relative to other group B subtypes. Therefore, we propose identifying a new subtype, B4, within the caprine lentivirus-like cluster. Finally, we showed evidence of recombination among ovine lentiviruses. These results highlight the wide genetic diversity of SRLV strains circulating in the province of Ontario and demonstrate that the gag region is suitable for phylogenetic studies and can be applied to monitor SRLV eradication programs. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Santry, L. A.;de Jong, J.;Gold, A. C.;Walsh, S. R.;Menzies, P. I.;Wootton, S. K.

title: Genomic characterization of two novel pathogenic avipox viruses isolated from Pacific rough waters (Ardenna spp.)
abstract: BACKGROUND: Over the last 20 years, many seabird populations have been gradually declining, and the factors driving this continued deterioration are not always well understood. Avipoxvirus infections have been found in a wide variety of avian species worldwide, but little is known about the disease ecology of avian pox viruses in seabirds. Here we present two novel avipoxviruses from pacific shearwaters (Ardenna spp), one from the Flesh-footed Shearwater (A. carneipes) (SWPV-1) and the other from the Wedge-tailed Shearwater (A. pacificus) (SWPV-2). . RESULTS: Epidermal pox lesions, liver and blood samples were examined from A. carneipes and A. pacificus breeding colonies in eastern Australia. After histopathological confirmation of the disease, PCR scanning was performed for avipoxvirus, circovirus, reticuloendotheliosis virus and fungal agents. Two samples PCR positive for poxvirus were further evaluated by next-generation sequencing, which yielded complete Shearwaterpox virus (SWPV) genomes from A. pacificus and A. carneipes, both with the highest degree of similarity to Canarypox virus (98% vs. 67%). . , respectively). The novel SWPV-1 complete genome of A. carneipes lacks 43 genes compared to CNPV and contains 4 predicted genes not found in any other smallpox virus, while the SWPV-2 complete genome is assumed to be missing 18 genes compared to CNPV and 15 genes more severely fragmented, possibly rendering them non-functional. CONCLUSION: These are the first complete genome sequences of avipoxvirus to infect seabirds. In comparison of SWPV-1 and -2 with existing avipoxvirus sequences, our results show that the SWPV complete genome from A. carneipes (SWPV-1) described here is not closely related to any other avipoxvirus genome isolated from avian or other natural host. . species and should probably be considered a separate species.
authors: Sarker, S.;Das, S.;Lavers, J. L.;Hutton, I.;Helbig, K.;Imbery, J.;Upton, C.;Raidal, S. R.

title: Genetic variations of the Hemagglutinin gene of Pandemic Influenza A (H1N1) viruses in Assam, India in 2016.
abstract: Since its emergence in 2009, the Influenza A/H1N1pdm09 virus has evolved continuously. Significant genetic variations occurred in the HAl domain of the hemagglutinin gene, resulting in the emergence of new variants. This study genetically characterized the hemagglutinin (HA) gene of Influenza A/H1N1pdm09 strains from Assam circulating in 2016, causing a mild epidemic with no reported deaths. Sequence analysis of the HA gene of 20 positive Assamese/H1N1pdm09 strains revealed 3 mutations at antigenic sites (K180Q, 5202T, S220T) along with several other reported mutations that are close to the antigenic sites and therefore may affect viral antigenicity. Phylogenetically, the Assam/H1N1pdm09 strains clustered in genogroup 6B. These genetic variations highlight the importance of continuous surveillance and characterization of Influenza A/H1N1pdm09 virus activity to monitor the genetic makeup and diversity that may affect the virus's behavior.
authors: Sarmah, K.;Borkakoty, B.;Sarma, K.;Hazarika, R.;Das, P. K.;Jakharia, A.;Das, M.;Biswas, D.

title: Multi-reassortant G3P[3] A group of rotaviruses in a horseshoe bat in Zambia
abstract: Rotavirus group is the main cause of diarrhea in humans, especially in young children. Bats also harbor group A rotaviruses, but the genetic background of bat rotavirus strains is often different from that of human rotavirus strains. We have identified a new strain of group A rotavirus in the intestinal contents of a horseshoe bat in Zambia. Whole genome sequencing revealed that the identified virus named RVA/Bat-wt/ZMB/LUS12-14/2012/G3P[3] has the genotype constellation G3-P[3]-I3-R2-C2-M3-A9-. N2-T3-E2-H3. Several genome segments of LUS12-14 were highly similar to those of group A rotaviruses identified from humans, cows and antelopes; this indicates interspecies transmission of rotaviruses between bats and other mammals with possible multiple genomic reclassification events.
authors: Sasaki, M.;Orba, Y.;Sasaki, S.;Gonzalez, G.;Ishii, A.;Hangâ€™Ombe, B. M.;Mweene, A. S.;Ito, K.;Sawa, H.

title: Metagenomic analysis of the jumping enteric virome reveals novel viruses related to human feces-associated viruses.
authors: Sasaki, M.;Orba, Y.;Ueno, K.;Ishii, A.

title: How Are Inuenza A Viruses Classified and How Severity Determined?
abstract: As an application of the degree of chaos introduced in the framework of information adaptive dynamics, we examine the classification of Influenza A viruses. What evolutionary processes determine the severity and ability of influenza A viruses to be transmitted between humans? We performed phylogenetic classifications of influenza A viruses sampled between 1918 and 2009 using a measure called the entropic chaos degree developed through the study of chaos in information dynamics. Phylogenetic analysis of the internal protein (PB2, PB1, PA, NS, M1, M2, NS1 and NS2) showed that the human-adapted and inter-human transmitted Influenza A viruses were clearly differentiated from the porcine line and the avian lineage. Moreover, the HA, NA, and internal proteins of the influenza strain that caused a pandemic or a severe epidemic with high mortality were phylogenetically different from the previous pandemic and severe epidemic strains. We conclude that the internal protein has a significant effect on the ability to infect among humans. Based on this study, we are convinced that the degree of entropic chaos is very useful as a measure of understanding the classification and severity of an isolated strain of influenza A virus.
authors: Sato, K.;Tanabe, T.;Ohya, M.

title: Antiviral activities of xanthates
abstract: Strategies in the development of antivirals are preferably directed towards the development of agents that will interact with virus-encoded enzymes, such as polymerases and reverse transcriptase. Xanthates, which are antiviral/antitumor with a different mode of action, interact selectively with cell proteins that regulate cell growth through protein kinase C-mediated phosphorylation pathways. Such regulatory processes seem indispensable for the growth of a variety of taxonomically unrelated viruses. Xanthate structures at the R1 position are substituted with aliphatic cyclic and non-cyclic residues and alkali metal at the R2 position. The antiviral effect of such substitutions was evaluated in plaque reduction experiments using the herpes virus as a rapid reliable test system. The cytotoxicity criteria were based on the ability of logarithmically growing cell cultures to undergo active mitotic divisions. The R1 position must be filled with a lipophilic substituent, which should be constitutively limited to mono-, bi-, and tricyclic residues. The specific antiviral activity of the xanthate compound D609, expressed by its IC50, compares well with that of other herpes inhibitors, for example phosphonoformic acid (10 µM) or phosphonoacetic acid (20 µM). Unlike herpes virus, which encodes its own DNA polymerase, DNA tumor virus 'SV40' depends on cellular DNA polymerase for DNA replication. Xanthate had a selective antiviral effect in the absence of cytotoxicity of bovine papillomavirus (BPV-1) transformed cells. Inhibition of viral gene functions by xanthate in the absence of detrimental effects on indispensable cellular functions indicates the high selectivity of the antiviral effect. Due to the abundance of Coxsackie B4 virus, there was a direct correlation between the amount of viral proteins synthesized despite the presence of D609. In the case of vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV), xanthate did not restrict the synthesis of primary transcripts that serve as messengers as they have positive strand polarity. The antiviral effect of xanthate occurs only under acidic pH, otherwise the antiviral/antitumor effects are reduced. A careful calibration of the D609/monocarbonic acid concentration was required prior to antiviral treatment, as HIV-1 only proliferates in viable lymphoma cells that exhibit the characteristics of transformed cells. Such treatment inhibits the spread of infectious HIV from cultures of chronic virus-producing lymphoma. This is the only compound that prevents the spread of HIV infections from carrier cultures. D609 acts antagonistically to the action of the tumor promoting compound TPA (12-0-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate). The effects of D609 are not directed against the pkc itself. Phospholipase C seems to be the main target. Diacylglycerol, the product of phospholipase C activity, is deficient in D609-treated cells. D609 interacts with the growth signal transduction sequence in a very specific mechanism. As xanthate blocks the pkC activity responsible for proper phosphorylation of these parameters, the transacting mechanisms may lack biological activity. Bolus injections of D609 in combination with monocarboxylic acid exert therapeutic effects on tumor xenotransplants in athymic mice when D609/undecanoic or dodecanoic acid is administered. This compound can be administered intravenously at very high concentrations.
authors: Sauer, G.;Amtmann, E.;Mellert, W.

title: A member of a new genus Picornaviridae sheds in pig feces
abstract: During a study of the fecal microbiomes of two healthy piglets using high-throughput sequencing (HTS), we identified a viral genome containing an open reading frame encoding a predicted 2133 amino acid polyprotein. This novel viral genome exhibited the typical organization of picornaviruses with three structural proteins (VP0, VP3, and VP1) followed by seven nonstructural proteins (2A, 2B, 2C, 3A, 3B, 3Cpro and 3Dpol). Given its special relationship to Parechovirus, we propose to designate it as "Swine pasivirus 1" (SPaV1) as the type species and "Pasivirus" for the Parecho sister clade virus. Fecal samples collected in an industrial farm from healthy pigs and piglets aged 4 to 28 weeks from the same herd (25 and 75, respectively) were analyzed for the presence of SPAV1 by targeting one-step reverse transcription (RT)-PCR. A 3D region of 151 bp. SPAV1 was not detected in faeces samples from 51/75 healthy piglets (68% of animals) and in none of the 25 faecal samples from healthy pigs, suggesting that SPAV1 circulates through enteric infection of healthy piglets. We propose that SPAV1 represents the first member of a new genus Picornaviridae related to parechoviruses. Â© 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Sauvage, V.;Ar Gouilh, M.;Cheval, J.;Muth, E.;Pariente, K.;Burguiere, A.;Caro, V.;Manuguerra, J. C.;Eloit, M.

title: Identification of the first human gyrovirus, a virus related to the chicken anemia virus
authors: Sauvage, V.;Cheval, J.;Foulongne, V.;Gouilh, M. A.

title: New putative Bluetongue virus in healthy goats from Sardinia, Italy
abstract: In recent years, new Bluetongue virus (BTV) serotypes have been isolated and/or sequenced by researchers in the field. During Mavidil surveillance activities, we identified a putative new BTV serotype in healthy goats from Sardinia, Italy. RNAs purified from blood and serum samples were positive for BTV by a generic real-time RT-PCR and c-ELISA, respectively, whereas genotyping and serotyping failed. By NGS, whole genome sequence was obtained from two blood samples (BTV-X ITL2015 strains 34200 and 33531). Overall, Segment 2 of BTV-X ITL2015 had the highest identity (75.3%-78.2%) with the recently isolated BTV-27s from Corsica and the most recently discovered BTV XJ1407 (75.9% nt / 78.2%) from China. 75.5 nt/77.4-78.1% aa). aa) is less associated with BTV-25 from Switzerland (73.0 nt/75.0% aa) and BTV-26 from Kuwait (62.0 nt/60.5% aa). In this study, a specific RT-qPCR targeting Part 2 of BTV-X ITL2015 was evaluated. Considering the Seg 2/VP2 identity of BTV-X ITL2015 with BTV-25, 26, 27s and BTV XJ1407 and the inability of serum of goats infected with BTV-X ITL2015 to neutralize all available serotypes tested, we propose the existence of a new BTV serotype. Wandering goats in Sardinia. Isolation has so far failed and thus hindered proper antigenic characterization.
authors: Savini, G.;Puggioni, G.;Meloni, G.;Marcacci, M.;Di Domenico, M.;Rocchigiani, A. M.;Spedicato, M.;Oggiano, A.;Manunta, D.;Teodori, L.;Leone, A.;Portanti, O.;Cito, F.;Conte, A.;Orsini, M.;Camma, C.;Calistri, P.;Giovannini, A.;Lorusso, A.

title: Morphological, chemical and antigenic organization of mammalian type C viruses
abstract: New features in the architecture of mammalian type C viruses, particularly the knob-like surface protrusions and hexagonally arranged subunits on the core shell, can be demonstrated by electron microscopy utilizing newly developed preparation techniques. Examples are murine leukemia viruses (MuLVs) and newly isolated porcine and bovine C virus. Major proteins of a MuLV were isolated and partially characterized in chemical terms and according to their serological and other biological activities such as interference and hemagglutination (HA) capacity. Many of the identified proteins can be localized to specific substructures of the virion through selective removal or isolation of electron microscopically identifiable components. The information obtained allowed a more detailed model of mammalian C viruses to be designed. Particular attention was paid to further characterization of the interspecies antigens of mammalian C viruses. Different antigenic determinants emerged. Their distribution allows for further subgrouping of mammalian C viruses.
authors: Schaefer, W.;Demsey, A.;Frank, H.

title: Pandemic 1957 H2 influenza A virus origin and persistence of its possible progenitors in the avian reservoir
abstract: H2N2 influenza A viruses caused the 1957 Asian pandemic and disappeared from the human population 10 years later. To assess the potential for similar outbreaks in the future, we determined the antigenicity of H2 hemagglutinins (HAs) from representative human and avian H2 viruses and then analyzed their nucleotide and amino acid sequences to determine their evolutionary properties in different hosts. The results of longitudinal virus surveillance studies were also examined to estimate the prevalence of avian H2 isolates among samples collected from wild ducks and domestic poultry. Reactivity patterns obtained with a large panel of monoclonal antibodies showed antigenic shift in HA of human H2 influenza viruses starting in 1962. Amino acid changes clustered in two regions of HA1 corresponding to antigenic regions A and D of H3 HA. In contrast, the antigenic profiles of the majority of avian H2 HAs were remarkably preserved until 1991, resembling the prototype Japan 57 (H2N2) strain. Amino acid changes were distributed throughout HA1, indicating that antibodies do not play a significant role in the selection of avian H2 viruses. Phylogenetic analysis revealed two geographic region-specific lineages of avian H2 HAs: North America and Eurasia. Evidence supporting the interregional transmission of gull H2 viruses is presented. Human H2 HAs circulating in 1957-1968 form a distinct phylogenetic lineage most closely related to Eurasian avian H2 HAs. Before the emergence of H2N2 viruses in domestic poultry, the prevalence of H2 influenza viruses among wild ducks in North America increased in 1988. As the prevalence of avian H2N2 influenza viruses increased in turkey farms and live bird markets in New York City and elsewhere, more of these viruses came into direct contact with susceptible humans. We conclude that antigenically conserved analogues of the 1957 human Asian pandemic strain continue to circulate in the bird reservoir and become closer to susceptible human populations.
authors: Schafer, J. R.;Kawaoka, Y.;Bean, W. J.;Suss, J.;Senne, D.;Webster, R. G.

title: caliciviridae
abstract: Caliciviruses, as a proposed family of Caliciviridae, have a distinctive virion morphology with cup-shaped depressions on a spherical capsid surface. Viruses have single-stranded RNA with a molecular weight of about 2.6 x 106 and is infectious. RNA is covalently attached to a small protein. There is a single parent polypeptide in the capsid. A subgenomic RNA with a molecular weight of approximately 1 x 10 6 encoding the capsid polypeptide is present in infected cells. Caliciviruses infecting pigs, pinnipeds and cats have been characterized. Viruses that are morphologically identical to known caliciviruses have been identified in human feces; these viruses have been shown to be associated with gastroenteritis, but they have not yet been spread in the laboratory.
authors: Schaffer, F. L.;Bachrach, H. L.;Brown, F.

title: The only major polypeptide of a calicivirus: characterization by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and stabilization of virions by crosslinking with dimethyl suberimidate
abstract: calicivirus externally labeled with 125I, San Miguel sea lion virus serotype 4, was demonstrated by gel electrophoresis that isolate 15FT had a single parent polypeptide. The polypeptide migrated abnormally upon electrophoresis in two sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) systems: slower than bovine serum albumin in a continuous phosphate-buffered system and faster than bovine serum albumin in a discontinuous system. Estimated molecular weights in the two systems were approximately 71,000 and 64,000, respectively. There was no clear evidence for a minor virion polypeptide. Treatment of purified San Miguel sea lion virions with dimethyl suberimidate, a crosslinking reagent, preserves virion integrity during extended storage at 4°C. Oligomeric variants of the polypeptide were observed upon electrophoresis of products from cross-linked virions. Based on a preferred polypeptide molecular weight estimate of 71,000 and the distribution of the oligomeric species, a calicivirion model with 120 monomeric protein units has been proposed as an alternative to a 180-unit model.
authors: Schaffer, F. L.;Soergel, M. E.

title: Searching for the global virome: identification and characterization of HCV-associated animal hepaciviruses.
authors: Scheel, T. K. H.;Simmonds, P.;Kapoor, A.

title: Genome sequence of bubalin alphaherpesvirus 1 (BuHV1) isolated in Australia in 1972
abstract: Bubaline alphaherpesvirus 1 (BuHV1) is a member of the Herpesviridae family, subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae, genus Varicellovirus. To date, the complete genome sequence of BuHV has not been published. Here we report the complete genome sequence of bubalin alphaherpesvirus 1 (BuHV1) strain b6 (BuHV1-b6) isolated from a buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) in Australia in 1972. The virus was propagated in MDBK cells and DNA was extracted and subjected to high-throughput sequencing. Reads were aligned and assembled into a single genome sequence with bovine alphaherpesvirus 5 (BoHV5) strain SV507/99 (accession number NC005261) as a reference. The buHV1-b6 genome is a linear double-stranded DNA molecule with a length of 137,452 bp and a GC content of 76.8%. The genome consists of two unique sequences: the long or UL sequence (103,818 bp) and the short or US sequence (9,586 bp), the latter flanked by inverted IR and TR elements of 12,024 bp each. The arrangement is typical of D-type herpes virus genomes. The overall sequence has 92.2% similarity at the nucleotide level to the reference BoHV5 strain. Our report provides an important milestone in the history of herpes viruses, represented by the genome sequence of this 44-year-old virus isolate.
authors: Scheffer, C. M.;Varela, A. P.;Cibulski, S. P.;Schmidt, C.;Campos, F. S.;Paim, W. P.;Dos Santos, R. N.;Teixeira, T. F.;Loiko, M. R.;Tochetto, C.;Dos Santos, H. F.;de Lima, D. A.;Cerva, C.;Mayer, F. Q.;Petzhold, S. A.;Franco, A. C.;George, T. S.;Spilki, F. R.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Comparison of chicken antibodies and hemagglutination-inhibition tests and Venezuelan encephalitis virus strains
abstract: Twenty Venezuelan encephalitis (VE) virus strains inoculated intravenously in large doses to roosters produced hemagglutination-inhibition (HI) antibodies that were detectable in plasmas within 7 to 10 days. As blood concentrations of infectious virus were consistently reduced after vaccination, no signs of disease were seen and no evidence of viral growth in tissues. HI antibodies in early plasmas were specific to VE virus and did not significantly cross-react with the other two North American alpha viruses, eastern and western encephalitis viruses. VE virus strains can be distinguished by virus dilution, short brood HI, but not by plasma dilution neutralization tests using early rooster antibodies. The distinctions made by the HI test were similar to those described by some strains and the spiny rat antisera used by Young and Johnson to construct subtype classifications of VE virus, but different from other strains. However, results of HI tests with rooster antibodies correlated with equine virulence, as did results with spiny rat antibodies, and distinguished new virus strains that emerged in Central America during the 1969 VE epidemic from pre-existing strains.
authors: Scherer, W. F.;Pancake, B. A.

title: Prevalence of porcine Noroviruses, molecular characterization of porcine sapoviruses emerging from finisher pigs in the United States, and a combined classification scheme for sapoviruses
abstract: Noroviruses (NoVs) and sapoviruses (SaVs) are important human pathogens. Although the role of porcine NoVs in disease in pigs is unclear, they are genetically and antigenically closely related to human NoVs. Human NoV-like strains have been detected in pigs, raising public health concerns about potential interspecies transmission. Pig SaVs are highly diverse and occur in swine populations. Recently, at least three new pig SaV genogroups have been proposed. In this study, we tested 413 pooled fecal samples collected from apparently healthy finisher pigs in North Carolina pig farms in 2009. Reverse transcription (RT)-PCR paired hybridization experiments were performed to detect known porcine NoVs. The overall prevalence of swine NoVs identified was 18.9% based on this method. Samples were then tested by RT-PCR targeting the 5= end of the capsid region for genogroup II (GII) NoVs, a group containing human NoVs, followed by sequence analysis. All identified NoVs belonged to typical porcine NoV genotypes and no human NoV-like strains were detected in samples from these pigs. Porcine NoV-negative samples (n = 335) were then screened using universal calicivirus primers and 17 SaV strains were confirmed by sequencing. Based on the partial RNA-bound RNA polymerase (RdRp) region, they clustered with GIII, GVII and GVIII and currently unclassified SaVs. Based on analysis of complete capsid sequences, 7 representative strains clustered with GVII, GVIII and GIX? SAVs. Based on the complete capsid protein VP1, we tentatively classified SaVs into 14 genogroups. In summary, swine NoVs and quite different SaVs were present in North Carolina finisher pigs. Â© 2013, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Scheuer, K. A.;Oka, T.;Hoet, A. E.;Gebreyes, W. A.;Molla, B. Z.;Saif, L. J.;Wang, Q.

title: Molecular characterization and module composition of p22-associated Salmonella phage genomes
abstract: The genomes of newly isolated Salmonella phages were analyzed by comparison of EcoRI restriction patterns and hybridization. Characteristic hybridization probes were selected from reference phages P22, ES18 and E. coli phage Î». Four probes selected from the cleavage site studied the distribution of lambdoid cleavage genes. Other probes identified were part of replication genes and structural genes. The complex immune domain was investigated through hybridization as well as biological testing. The results showed the association of isolated phages with the P22 branch of lambdoid phages, revealing modular genome organization consisting of P22-related sequences in different proportions. The DNA restriction patterns of phages released from Salmonella strains sampled in limited geographic areas were significantly less heterogeneous than those of phages released from the SARA collection sampled worldwide. The use of prophage restriction models as a tool for Salmonellae typing to support epidemiological classification of pathogenic strains is discussed. Copyright (C) 1999 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Schicklmaier, P.;Wieland, T.;Schmieger, H.

title: Genomic features of human bocaviruses
abstract: Human bocavirus (HBoV) was first discovered in 2005 as the second pathogenic member of the parvovirus family, next to human parvovirus B19. It has since been shown that HBoV is extremely common worldwide and causes a systemic infection in young children, often causing respiratory illness. Three more, possibly enteric, human bocaviruses (HBoV2-4) have been identified in stool samples. Parvoviruses are hypothesized to reproduce through their genomic terminal hairpin-like structures in the "rolling hairpin pattern". These terminal sequences have recently been partially identified in head-to-toe HBoV-PCR amplicons from clinical specimens and are most likely hybrid residues of the precursors of HBoV, namely bovine parvovirus 1 on the left and small virus of dogs on the right. , shown for the first time in this article. Thus, the putative replication pattern for HBoV remains questionable as the occurrence of head-to-toe sequences is not a typical feature of the rolling hairpin replication pattern. However, such episomes can also be forms of permanent storage of the genome.
authors: Schildgen, O.;Qiu, J.;Sderlund-Venermo, M.

title: First identification of porcine parvovirus 6 in North America by viral metagenomic sequencing of serum from pigs infected with porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus Other viruses (eg, smallpox, papilloma, parvo, reoviridae)
abstract: Background: Currently, eight species have been identified in the four parvovirus genera that infect pigs. These include ungulate protoparvovirus 1 (classical porcine parvovirus, PPV), ungulate tetraparvovirus 2 (PPV3), ungulate tetraparvovirus 3 (PPV2, porcine hokovirus, porcine partetravirus and porcine PARV4), ungulate copiparvovirus 2 (includes PPV4 and PPV5). bocaparvovirus 2 (includes porcine bocavirus 1, 2 and 6), ungulate bocaparvovirus 3 (porcine bocavirus 5), ungulate bocaparvovirus 4 (porcine bocavirus 7) and ungulate bocaparvovirus 5 (porcine bocavirus 3, 4-1 and 4-2). The most recently identified porcine parvovirus, PPV6, was first identified in aborted pig fetuses in late 2014 in China. The prevalence of PPV6 in China was found to be similar in finishing-age pigs from farms with and without evidence of pig reproductive failure. Methods: Porcine parvovirus 6 (PPV6) was detected by sequence-independent single primer amplification (SISPA) and confirmed by overlapping and real-time PCR in the serum of porcine reproductive and respiratory virus (PRRSv) positive samples. Results: Almost complete seven genomes of PPV6 were identified in PRRSv genotype 2 positive serum samples sent to state veterinary diagnostic laboratories in 2014. Additional testing using overlapping and real-time PCR determined that PPV6 was present in 13.2% of the sera tested. In addition, PPV6 was present in samples from all geographic locations sampled covering nine states in the United States and one state in Mexico. The presence of PPV6 in serum indicates that the PPV6 infection has spread and is not localized to a particular tissue type. Alignment of nearly full-length genomes, NS1 and capsid genes determined that one in five PPV6 isolates from China (98.6–99.5% identity with North American strains) was the closest relative North American strains. Conclusions: These results are the first to report the presence of PPV6 in North America and show that the virus is present in multiple geographic locations in the United States and Mexico.
