The overall prevalence of PPV6 in PRRSv viremic animals is relatively low. Furthermore, all PPV6 genomes found in North America are closely related to a PPV6 strain first identified in healthy pigs from Tianjin province, China, in 2014.
authors: Schirtzinger, E. E.;Suddith, A. W.;Hause, B. M.;Hesse, R. A.

title: Detection of a Novel Bovine Astrovirus in a Cow with Encephalitis
abstract: Encephalitis can be caused by a variety of infectious agents, including bacteria, fungi, parasites, and viruses. In most cases, the causative agent cannot be identified as the pathogens are unknown or detection methods are not routinely available. In our case, a 15-month-old cow developed central nervous disorders and died within 6 days of the onset of clinical symptoms. Histopathology revealed acute encephalitis predominantly in the brainstem and trigeminal ganglion ganglionitis with massive neuronal necrosis in both the brain and the ganglion. However, a panel of relevant bacterial and viral infections of cattle can be routinely excluded. Therefore, a brain sample from a cow was analyzed using a metagenomic approach with next-generation sequencing. A novel bovine astrovirus (BoAstV-BH89/14) assay line can be identified using RIEMS and the finding confirmed by a specific BoAstV RT-qPCR. The genome length of bovine astrovirus (BoAstV) belonging to the Astroviridae family in the Mamastrovirus genus is 6478 bp. Sequence identities of 71% of a sheep astrovirus from the USA and Switzerland and between 69% and 69% of two recently identified bovine astroviruses were detected. The latter was also linked to cases of encephalitis in cattle. Like these, the novel virus described here was detected in different brain sections using specific BoAstV RT-qPCR and fluorescent in situ hybridization. As a result, astroviruses have been mainly associated with gastroenteritis in animals and humans until now, while recently detected astrovirus infections have also been associated with encephalitis.
authors: Schlottau, K.;Schulze, C.;Bilk, S.;Hanke, D.;HÃ¶per, D.;Beer, M.;Hoffmann, B.

title: Presence of two distinct bovine hepacivirus clusters in Germany
abstract: In recent years, genetic information of hepaciviruses (family Flaviviridae), a human hepatitis C virus, has been identified in a wide variety of primates and non-primate vertebrates. Here, samples collected from 263 German cattle kept in 22 different holdings were analyzed for the presence of hepacivirus N (syn. bovine hepacivirus; BovHepV). One hundred and eighty-six cattle suffering from non-specific clinical signs such as fever and decreased milk yield were included, as well as 77 apparently healthy animals. A total of 39 cattle (14.8%) tested positive for BovHepV by real-time RT-PCR, but no correlation was found between clinical manifestations and virus infection. Sequences of the NS3 coding region were generated from 31 of the virus positive samples, and viral sequences of the complete coding region were generated from two samples and compared with other European and African BovHepV sequences. Based on the NS3 genomic region, two distinct German BovHepV clusters were identified that differed up to 20% at the nucleotide level, with variation within individual clusters reaching up to 10%. Based on the full-length sequences, the newly detected virus variants group together with other German and African viruses in a sibling relationship with other hepaciviruses from primates and other mammals, but form distinct clusters within the BovHepV clade. As a result, a wide variety of hepaciviruses were detected in German cattle, further expanding the known phylogenetic diversity of the genus Hepacivirus.
authors: Schlottau, K.;Wernike, K.;Forth, L.;Holsteg, M.;HÃ¶per, D.;Beer, M.;Hoffmann, B.

title: Insect iridescent virus type 6 encodes a polypeptide related to the largest subunit of eukaryotic RNA polymerase II.
abstract: Cytoplasmic DNA viruses encode a DNA-dependent RNA polymerase (DdRP) required for transcription of viral genes. The amino acid sequences of the known major subunits of ddRPs contain highly conserved regions. Oligonucleotide primers from two conserved domains [RQP(T/S)LH and NADFDGDE] were used in PCR experiments to detect the corresponding gene of the insect iridescent virus type 6 genome, also known as Chilo iridescent virus (CIV). . A specific DNA product of about 150 bp could be amplified and used as a hybridization probe against the CIV gene library to identify the gene of interest. The gene encoding DdRP was identified in the EcoRI fragments M (7099 bp) and L (7400 bp) of CIV DNA between map units 0.310 and 0.347 (7990 bp). The DNA nucleotide sequence (3153 bp) of the gene encoding the largest subunit of DdRP (RPO1) was determined. Northern blot hybridization revealed the presence of a 3.4 kb RNA transcript hybridizing to the CIV DdRP gene in CIV-infected cells. This predicted viral protein consists of 1051 amino acid residues (120K) and showed significantly higher similarity to the largest subunit of eukaryotic RNA polymerase II than homologous proteins of vaccinia virus and African swine fever virus. Phylogenetic analysis suggested that the putative RPO1 of CIV may have evolved from RNA polymerase II after the splitting of three types of eukaryotic RNA polymerases. The putative RP01 of CIV lacked the C-terminal domain conserved in eukaryotic, eubacterial, and other viral RNA polymerases and was similar in this respect to RNA polymerases of Archaea. It is hypothesized that the equivalent of the C-terminal domain may be found in another subunit of the CIV DdRP encoded by an unidentified viral gene.
authors: Schnitzler, P.;Sonntag, K. C.;Muller, M.;Janssen, W.;Bugert, J. J.;Koonin, E. V.;Darai, G.

title: Molecular evolution of influenza viruses
abstract: There are two different mechanisms by which influenza viruses can evolve: (1) Because the RNA genome of influenza viruses is segmented, new strains can be suddenly produced by reclassification, creating new pandemic strains, for example, during antigenic shift. (2) New viruses evolve relatively slowly through gradual mutation and selection, for example, during antigenic or genetic drift. Influenza A viruses have been found in several vertebrate species where they form immiscible reservoirs. Human influenza A viruses do not spread in birds and vice versa, the species barrier to pigs is relatively low, so pigs can act as 'mixing vessels' for the creation of new pandemic reassortants. double infection of pigs by human and avian influenza viruses. Phylogenetic studies revealed that about 100 years ago, an avian influenza A virus crossed the species barrier, possibly forming new stable human and classical swine lineages first into pigs and then into humans. In 1979, again, an avian virus emerged in the Northern European pig population, creating another stable pig lineage. From 1979 to 1985, Northern European swine isolates were extremely genetically unstable. A hypothesis has been put forward stating that a mutator mutation is necessary to enable the influenza virus to cross the species barrier by providing sufficient variants that it can select the most suitable ones for the new host. As long as the mutator mutation is still present, such a virus should be able to cross the species barrier a second time, as it did about 100 years ago. While the latest swine isolates from northern Germany are genetically stable again, we still need to be vigilant to see if a Northern European swine virus emerges in the human population in the near future.
authors: Scholtissek, C.

title: Analysis of influenza A virus nucleoproteins to evaluate the molecular genetic mechanisms that give rise to novel phylogenetic virus strains.
abstract: The nucleoprotein (NP) gene of influenza A viruses is determinant to separate two large reservoirs that develop separately in birds and humans. A phylogenetic analysis of the NP gene revealed that all mammalian influenza viruses - directly or indirectly - descended from an avian ancestor. The steady incorporation of an avian influenza A virus into a mammalian species appears to be a relatively rare event, the most recent occurring in 1979 when such an avian virus was introduced to pigs in Northern Europe, giving rise to a new lineage. At least two simultaneous events are required for such a new and stable entry: (1) the new species must be infected, and (2) a mutation in the polymerase complex will result in a large number of different different types, some of which can rapidly adapt to the new host (or any unusual environment). variant. Since such mutations may only be advantageous during times of stress, variants with less error-prone polymerases may reappear after adaptation. Examples of such fluctuations in mutation and evolution rates are discussed in this short review.
authors: Scholtissek, C.;Ludwig, S.;Fitch, W. M.

title: Characterization of the complete genome of Tupaia (tree mouse) adenovirus
abstract: Members of the family Adenoviridae are widely spread among vertebrate host species and normally cause acute but harmless infections. Special attention has been given to adenoviruses because of their ability to transform host cells, their possible applications in vector technology, and their phylogeny. Primary structure of the Tupaia adenovirus (TAV) genome infecting Tupaia spp. (tree mouse) was determined. Tree shrews are taxonomically assumed to be the basis of the phylogenetic tree of mammals and are often used as laboratory animals in neurological and behavioral research. The TAV genome is 33,501 bp in length and has a G+C content of 49.96% and has 166-bp inverted terminal repeats. Analysis of the complete nucleotide sequence resulted in the identification of 109 open reading frames (ORFs) with a coding capacity of at least 40 amino acid residues. Thirty-eight of these are estimated to encode viral proteins based on the presence of transcription and translation signals and sequence and positional conservation. Thirty viral OPFs were found to show significant similarities to known adenoviral genes, arranged into separate early and late genome regions as known from mastadenoviruses. Analysis of the nucleotide content of the TAV genome revealed a significant depletion of CG dinucleotides at the genome ends, suggesting methylation of these genomic regions during the viral life cycle. Phylogenetic analysis of viral gene products, including penton and hexon proteins, viral protease, terminal protein, protein VIII, DNA polymerase, protein IVa2, and 100,000 molecular weight protein, revealed that the evolutionary lineage of TAV forms a distinct branch within the evolutionary lineage of TAV. took it out. Phylogenetic tree of the genus Mastadenovirus.
authors: Schondorf, E.;Bahr, U.;Handermann, M.;Darai, G.

title: Metagenomic research through iterative assembly of taxonomic units for viruses in West Arctic caribou, Alaska.
abstract: Pathogen surveillance in animals does not provide an adequate level of vigilance as it is generally limited to surveillance of pathogens whose economic impact is known in domestic animals and which are practically not present in wildlife species. Since most (re)emerging viral infections originate from animal sources, it is important to learn about viral pathogens found in wildlife reservoirs from a public health perspective. When monitoring living, free-range wildlife for viruses, sample collection can be difficult and the availability of nucleic acids isolated from samples is often limited. The development of viral metagenomic platforms allows for a more comprehensive inventory of viruses found in the wild. We report a metagenomic viral investigation of a herd of West Arctic barren land reindeer (Rangifer tarandus granti) in Alaska, USA. The presence of mammalian viruses in eye and nose swabs of 39 free-range reindeer was investigated by random amplification combined with a metagenomic analysis approach that applied extensive iterative sequencing results to identify the taxonomic units of each metagenome. Through homology search methods, we identified the presence of several mammalian viruses, including different papillomaviruses, a novel parvovirus, polyomavirus, and potentially a virus representing a member of a new genus in the family Coronaviridae.
authors: SchÃ¼rch, A. C.;Schipper, D.;Bijl, M. A.;Dau, J.;Beckmen, K. B.;Schapendonk, C. M. E.;Raj, V. S.;Osterhaus, A. D. M. E.;Haagmans, B. L.;Tryland, M.;Smits, S. L.

title: Holstein Friesian Lethal Haplotype 5 (HH5) Results of Complete Deletion of TBF1M and Cholesterol Deficiency (CDH) from an ERV-(LTR) Insertion in the Coding Region of APOB
abstract: BACKGROUND: With the availability of large SNP data for several economically important cattle breeds, haplotype tests have been performed to identify unknown recessive disorders. A number of pseudo-lethal haplotypes have been revealed in Holstein Friesian cattle, and causative mutations in candidate genes have been identified for at least seven of them. However, several lethal haplotypes still remain unclear. Here we report the molecular genetic causes of lethal haplotype 5 (HH5) and cholesterol deficiency (CDH). A targeted enrichment for known genomic regions was followed by large parallel sequencing to interrogate causative mutations in a case/control approach. METHODS: Targeted enrichment for known genomic regions, followed by large parallel sequencing, was used in a case/control approach. PCRs causing mutations were developed and compared to routine imposition in 2,100 (HH5) and 3,100 (CDH) cattle. RESULTS: HH5 results from a 138 kbp deletion ranging from 93,233 kb to 93,371 kb on chromosome 9 (BTA9) harboring dimethyl-adenosine transferase 1 (TFB1M) only. The deletion breakpoints are surrounded by the bovine long interspersed nuclear elements Bov-B (upstream) and L1ME3 (downstream), suggesting a homologous recombination/deletion event. TFB1M di-methylates adenine residues in the hairpin loop at the 3'-end of mitochondrial 12S rRNA, essential for the synthesis and function of the small ribosomal subunit of mitochondria. Homozygous TFB1M-/- mice were reported to exhibit embryonal lethality with developmental defects. 2.8% allelic frequency was determined for the German HF population. CDH results from a 1.3 kbp insertion of an endogenous retrovirus (ERV2-1-LTR_BT) into exon 5 of the APOB gene at BTA11:77,959kb. The insertion is flanked by 6bp copies of the target site as described for insertions mediated by retroviral integrases. An early stop codon is produced in the open reading frame of the APOB, resulting in the protein being truncated to a length of only <140 amino acids. These premature discontinuations have been shown to result in inadequate excretion of chylomicrons from intestinal cells, resulting in cholesterol malabsorption. The allelic frequency of this mutation in the German HF population was 6.7%, which is significantly higher than what has been reported so far. Compared to PCR assays that directly remove genetic variants, the routine calculation used so far has shown a diagnostic sensitivity as low as 91% (HH5) and 88% (CDH) for both, with a high specificity (>=99.7). CONCLUSION: With the availability of direct genetic testing, it will now be possible to more effectively reduce carrier frequency and ultimately eliminate disturbances in HF populations. In addition, the presence of repetitive genomic elements (RE) in both diseases underlines the evolutionary importance of RE.
authors: Schutz, E.;Wehrhahn, C.;Wanjek, M.;Bortfeld, R.;Wemheuer, W. E.;Beck, J.;Brenig, B.

title: animal noroviruses
abstract: Among the enteric caliciviruses, noroviruses belong to the genus Norovirus, one of the four recognized genera in the family Caliciviridae. These single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses are highly variable, both genetically and antigenically. Several animal enteric caliciviruses have been described that are morphologically indistinguishable and genetically closely related to human noroviruses. The first bovine enteric noroviruses were identified in Great Britain and are known as Newbury Agent 2. At least three genetic clusters of porcine noroviruses converge into genogroup II noroviruses. Human noroviruses are the most important cause of acute gastroenteritis in people of all ages. In the US, they are associated with approximately 30-50% of all foodborne outbreaks. So far, noroviruses have not been associated with outbreaks of gastroenteritis in immunocompetent animals. Although human norovirus can grow in a complex 3D culture system, neither bovine nor porcine noroviruses can reproduce in cell culture. However, the recently discovered murine noroviruses can replicate in cell culture and are therefore used as model viruses to study human noroviruses. This review focuses on virus classification, virion structure, pathogenesis, epidemiology, immune response and diagnosis of animal noroviruses in comparison with human noroviruses. Classification of animal enteric caliciviruses within the genus Norovirus raises the question of whether transmission to humans from an animal reservoir can occur. Answering this question is important in determining the risk of interspecies infection, which affects the epidemiology and evolution of these viruses and thus complicates the control of human norovirus infections.
authors: Scipioni, A.;Mauroy, A.;VinjÃ©, J.;Thiry, E.

title: Nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequence analysis of fusion protein and hemagglutinin-neuraminidase protein genes among Newcastle disease virus isolates. Phylogenetic relationships among Paramyxovirinae based on their binding glycoprotein sequences
abstract: Highly virulent Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates are List A pathogens for commercial poultry and reports on their isolation between member states should be made to the International Office of Epizootics (OIE). The virus is classified as a member of the order Mononegavirales in the family Paramyxoviridae of the subfamily Paramyxovirinae. Two interacting surface glycoproteins, fusion (F) and hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) proteins play important roles in NDV binding and fusion of cells during infection. Antibodies to F or HN proteins are capable of virus neutralization; however, no full-length sequences are available for these genes from recently obtained virulent isolates. Therefore, nucleotide and predicted amino acid sequences of the F and HN protein genes were obtained from 16 NDV isolates representing highly virulent viruses from worldwide sources for comparison with older virulent isolates and vaccine strains. The F protein amino acid sequence was relatively conserved among isolates, conserving potential glycosylation sites and C residues for disulfide bonds. A dibasic amino acid motif was present at the cleavage site among the more virulent isolates, whereas low virulence viruses did not. However, a Eurasian collared pigeon virus had a K114Q substitution at the F cleavage site, which is unique among NDV isolates. The HN protein among NDV isolates preserved predicted catalytic and active site residues required for neuraminidase activity and hemagglutination. The length of HN for the Eurasian collared pigeon isolate and a previously reported heat-resistant virulent isolate was longer than for the other more recent lethal isolates. Phylogenetically, NDV isolates were divided into four groups, with newer virulent isolates forming a diverse branch, while all avian paramyxoviruses formed their own branch unlike other members of Paramyxoviridae. © Springer-Verlag 2004.
authors: Seal, B. S.

title: Biological properties of Newcastle disease virus vaccines and characterization of the hemagglutinin-neuraminidase protein gene by sequence analysis
abstract: Six commercially available monovalent Newcastle disease virus (NDV) live vaccines were examined for their biological and genomic stability compared to their indicated parent viruses. Thermostability of hemagglutinin at 56°C for 5 minutes was consistently observed among the majority of vaccine viruses. One exception was a recently developed NDV vaccine isolated from turkeys with a thermostability of 15 minutes. Neuraminidase activity, as measured by the elution rate of agglutinated red blood cells, varied between vaccine viruses and correlated with that of the parent isolate. Virulence, as measured by the intracerebral pathogenicity index, was between 0 and 0.39 among NDV vaccine-type viruses and was within the range of avirulent lentogens. The sequence of the fusion protein cleavage site from all NDV vaccine isolates studied was consistent with that for lentogens. The entire hemagglutinin-neurominidase gene sequence was 98% similar among all NDV vaccine viruses studied, and the phylogenetic classification of commercial vaccine strains correlated with their respective parent viruses. In conclusion, the commercially produced NDV vaccines reported here appear to be relatively stable when mass-produced in avian embryonic eggs.
authors: Seal, B. S.;King, D. J.;Bennett, J. D.

title: Bird response to Newcastle disease virus
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is classified as a member of the Mononegavirales superfamily in the Paramyxoviridae family. This virus family is divided into two subfamilies, Paramyxovirinae and Pneumovirinae. In 1993, the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy rearranged the order of the genus Paramyxovirus and placed NDV within the genus Rubulavirus among Paramyxovirinae. The enveloped virus has a 15,186 kb negative-sense single-stranded RNA genome encoding an RNA-oriented RNA polymerase in the 5' to 3' direction, hemagglutinin-neuraminidase protein, fusion protein, matrix protein, phosphoprotein, and nucleoprotein. The virus has a wide host range and most birds have been reported to be infected with NDV. The isolates are characterized by virulence in chickens and are divided into three main pathotypes depending on the severity of the disease. Lentogenic isolates are low virulence, while medium virulence viruses are called mesogenic. Highly virulent viruses that cause high mortality in birds are termed neurotropic or viscerotropic velogenic. Velogenic NDV are List A pathogens that must be reported to the International Office of Epizootics, and outbreaks result in strict trade embargoes. The primary molecular determinant for NDV pathogenicity is the fusion protein cleavage site amino acid sequence. Vaccination for NDV is primarily done by mass administration of live virus vaccines among commercial poultry. Although protection is measured by the presence of antibodies to NDV, vaccinated B-cell depleted chickens are resistant to the disease. Consequently, immune protection includes responses that are not currently fully defined. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Ltd.
authors: Seal, B. S.;King, D. J.;Sellers, H. S.

title: Fusion protein predicted amino acid sequence of first US avian pneumovirus isolate and lack of heterogeneity among other US isolates
abstract: Avian pneumovirus (APV) was first isolated from turkeys in the mid-western United States following the emergence of turkey rhinotracheitis (TRT) in 1996. Subsequently, several APV isolates were obtained from the north-central USA. The matrix (M) and fusion (F) protein genes of these isolates were analyzed for sequence heterogeneity and compared with European APV subtypes A and B. Among the US isolates, the M gene shared more than 98% nucleotide sequence identity and only one nonsynonymous change occurred. a single US isolate. Although the F gene among US APV isolates shares 98% nucleotide sequence identity, nine conserved substitutions were detected in the predicted amino acid sequence. The predicted amino acid sequence of the F protein of the US APV isolate had 72% sequence identity to the F protein of APV subtype A and 71% sequence identity to the F protein of APV subtype B. This compares to 83% sequence identity between the APV subtype. A and B predicted the amino acid sequences of protein F. The US isolates were phylogenetically distinguishable from their European counterparts based on the F gene nucleotide or predicted amino acid sequences. The absence of sequence heterogeneity among US APV subtypes indicates that these viruses have maintained a relatively stable population since the first TRT outbreak. Phylogenetic analysis of protein F among APV isolates supports the classification of US isolates as a new APV subtype C. Copyright (C) 2000 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Seal, B. S.;Sellers, H. S.;Meinersmann, R. J.

title: Genomic sequences of low virulence avian paramyxovirus-1 (Newcastle disease virus) isolates from live bird markets in North America are not relevant to commonly used commercial vaccine strains
abstract: Avian paramyxovirus 1 (APMV-1), also called Newcastle disease virus (NDV), low virulence variants have been isolated from chickens, ducks and other unidentified species found in live bird markets of the northeastern United States. These isolates were characterized as APMV-1 by the hemagglutination-inhibition (HI) test using NDV-specific polyclonal antisera. However, the isolates did not react with a monoclonal antibody with specificity for a wide variety of APMV-1 isolates. Although only highly virulent isolates require reporting to international regulatory agencies, the ability to accurately identify APMV-1 types is important for control and regulatory purposes. The protein gel patterns of the purified isolates were similar to previously reported APMV-1 and anti-NDV polyclonal sera recognized viral proteins. For the three isolates, oligonucleotide primers specific for the nucleoprotein, fusion protein and polymerase genes of NDV were used to synthesize cDNA using viral RNA as template. About 12 kb of the genome was then sequenced for three isolates containing the nucleoprotein, phosphoprotein, matrix protein, fusion (F) protein, hemagglutinin-neuraminidase protein genes and a 5 portion of the polymerase gene. The isolates had an F protein cleavage site sequence of ERQER/LVG, indicating low virulence viruses that were phylogenetically separated with other unique NDV isolates designated as lineage 6 genotype. In addition, a four amino acid adduct was detected in the predicted phosphoprotein, consistent with the "rule of six" among paramyxoviruses. These APMV-1 genotypes have not been previously reported in North America and further confirm the heterogeneous genetic makeup of these commercially important pathogens found worldwide. Â© 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Seal, B. S.;Wise, M. G.;Pedersen, J. C.;Senne, D. A.;Alvarez, R.;Scott, M. S.;King, D. J.;Yu, Q.;Kapczynski, D. R.

title: Evolutionary History and Phylogeography of Rabies Viruses Associated with Outbreaks in Trinidad
abstract: Bat rabies is a disease of emerging public health importance in the United States. The Caribbean island of Trinidad experiences periodic outbreaks in its animal population. We performed molecular characterization of Trinidad rabies virus (RABV) and used a Bayesian phylogeographic approach to investigate which outbreaks were a result of in situ evolution versus import of the virus from the nearby South American mainland. Trinidadian RABV sequences were confirmed as bat variant and clustered with sequences related to Desmodus rotundus (vampire bat). They fell into two largely temporally defined lineages, called Trinidad I and II. The Trinidad I lineage, which includes the 1997–2000 sequences (all but two from the northeast of the island), was most closely related to RABV from Ecuador (2005, 2007), French Guiana (1990) and Venezuela (1993, 1994). ). Trinidad II consisted of sequences from the southwestern part of the island divided into two groups: Trinidad IIa, each containing one sequence from 2000 and 2007, and Trinidad IIb, containing all 2010 sequences. The Trinidad II TV series were most closely related to the Brazilian (1999, 2004) and Uruguay (2007, 2008) TV series. Phylogeographic analyzes support three separate RABV entries from the mainland from which each of the three Trinidadian lineages originated. Estimated dates for entries and subsequent lineage expansions suggest periods of in situ evolution in Trinidad after each entry. These data also show the joint circulation of Trinidadian lineages I and IIa during the year 2000. In light of these findings and the possible vampire bat origin of Trinidad RABV, further studies should be conducted to explore the relationship between RABV spatio-temporal dynamics and vampire bat population ecology. especially any movement between the mainland and Trinidad.
authors: Seetahal, J. F. R.;Velasco-Villa, A.;Allicock, O. M.;Adesiyun, A. A.;Bissessar, J.;Amour, K.;Phillip-Hosein, A.;Marston, D. A.;McElhinney, L. M.;Shi, M.;Wharwood, C. A.;Fooks, A. R.;Carrington, C. V. F.

title: The importance of Campylobacter species in terms of public health. Colonization of wild game pheasants (Phasianus colchicus) in Scotland
abstract: Campylobacter is the most common cause of bacterial foodborne diarrheal disease worldwide. Chicken meat is considered the main source of human infection; however, C.Â jejuni and C.Â coli have also been reported in a number of livestock and wildlife species, including pheasants. Wild pheasant meat reaches the consumer's table due to hunting, but there is a lack of information regarding the risk of Campylobacter infection in humans. This study aimed to determine the prevalence of Campylobacter in wild game pheasants in Scotland, to identify the main sequence types (STs) available and to evaluate their public health impact. A total of 287 cecum specimens were collected from five Scottish sites during the 2013/2014 hunting season. Campylobacter was detected and enumerated using standard culture methods. PCR and High Throughput Multiple Locus Sequence Typing (HiMLST) were used for species identification and sequence typing. In total, 36.6% (nâ€¯=â€¯105; 95% CI: 14-59.2) of the 287 cecum samples were Campylobacter positive. Using PCR, 62.6% (nâ€¯=â€¯99) of the samples were identified as C.Â coli and 37.4% as C.Â jejuni. HiMLST (nâ€¯=â€¯80) identified 19 different STs. ST-828 (nâ€¯=â€¯19) was the most common, followed by ST-827 (nâ€¯=â€¯12) and ST19 (nâ€¯=â€¯7). Of the 19 isolated STs, sixteen are present in humans and eight are C. coli STs, which account for 6.96% of human infections, but the overall public health risk from pheasant meat is still considered low.
authors: Seguino, A.;Chintoan-Uta, C.;Smith, S. H.;Shaw, D. J.

title: Molecular detection and analysis of Sheeppox and Orf viruses isolated from Qalubia, Egyptian sheep
abstract: In this study, an outbreak with Sheeppox virus (SPPV) and Orf virus (ORFV) in a flock of sheep in the Egyptian province of Qalubia was investigated. Both SPPV and ORFV have caused clinically significant infections among sheep. Affected sheep showed skin lesions around the mouth or all over the body. A reliable diagnosis should therefore confirm the etiology of the infection and subsequently reduce the spread of diseases in the affected areas. Clinical samples were investigated by virus isolation, PCR and real-time PCR tests. In addition, PCR products of SPPV and ORFV isolates were sequenced and aligned to reference isolates for phylogenetic analyses. Laboratory diagnostics showed that real-time PCR testing is more accurate and sensitive than traditional PCR and virus isolation. In the phylogenetic analysis of the A29L gene, no genetic differences were observed between the SPPV field strains and the strains showed 100% homology with two SPPV isolates from Kazakhstan and one isolate from Turkey. The ORFV field strains are in the P55 gene, which is genetically distinct from and other isolates published in Egypt 2006 and 2009.
authors: Selim, A.;Elhaig, M.;HÃ¶che, J.;Gaede, W.

title: Molecular characterization of infectious bronchitis viruses isolated from broiler and layer chicken farms in Egypt in 2012.
abstract: One of the biggest problems with avian infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is the frequent emergence of new variants. In this study, 205 tracheal swabs and organs were collected from broiler and layer farms from 19 provinces across Egypt during January-August 2012. Chickens showed respiratory signs and death. Of the samples examined, 130 (approximately 64%) were positive for IBV by real-time RT-PCR. 13 IBV-positive samples were selected for further isolation and characterization. Isolation in specific pathogen-free (SPF) embryos was performed after three blind consecutive passages after studies, and the hypervariable region of spike protein1 (SP1) was amplified by RT-PCR and sequenced to examine genetic variation among isolated viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the resulting sequences of 13 isolates, compared with other strains of IBV from the Middle East and worldwide, revealed that 11 out of 13 isolates had close associations with the Israeli variants (IS/885 and IS/1494/06) with nucleotide homology. increased to 89.9% and 82.3%, respectively. Only two isolates had close association with CR/88121 and 4/91 viruses with 95% and 96% identity, respectively. This study demonstrates the existence of two variant IBV groups circulating in Egypt in 2012. Group I was similar but distinguishable from the Israeli variant IS/885 and group II was related to vaccine strains 4/91 and CR/88121. There was no geographical connection between the 2 groups as they were scattered all over the country. These findings warrant the need to revise vaccination programs and control measures for IBV. © 2013.
authors: Selim, K.;Arafa, A. S.;Hussein, H. A.;El-Sanousi, A. A.

title: â€¦Â Materials: Frequency and Pathologic Phenotype of Bovine Astrovirus CH13/NeuroS1 Infection in Neurologically Diseased Cattle: Towards Assessment
authors: Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Boujon, C. L.;Hilbe, M.;Oevermann, A.

title: Frequency and Pathological Phenotype of Bovine Astrovirus CH13/NeuroS1 Infection in Neurologically Diseased Cattle: Towards an Evaluation of Causality
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) has opened up the possibility of detecting new viruses in unresolved diseases. Recently, astrovirus brain infections in neurologically diseased humans and animals have been described by NGS, including bovine astrovirus (BoAstV) CH13/NeuroS1 found in the brain tissues of cattle with non-suppurative encephalitis. Only a few studies are available on neurotropic astroviruses, and a causal relationship between BoAstV CH13/NeuroS1 infections and neurological disease has been suggested, but not proven. Aiming to take a step towards assessing causality, we collected brain samples from 97 bovine cases diagnosed with unresolved non-suppurative encephalitis to determine the frequency and neuropathological distribution of BoAstV CH13/ and analyzed them by in situ hybridization and immunohistochemistry. NeuroS1 and its topographical correlation with pathology. We detected BoAstV CH13/NeuroS1 RNA or proteins in neurons from all parts of the central nervous system (CNS) in 34% of all cases, but none in cattle of the control group. Overall, brain lesions had a high correlation with the presence of the virus. These findings demonstrate that a significant proportion of cattle with non-suppurative encephalitis are infected with BoAstV CH13/NeuroS1, further confirming the causal relationship between neurological disease and astrovirus infections.
authors: Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Boujon, C. L.;Hilbe, M.;Oevermann, A.;Seuberlich, T.

title: Isolation of new Indonesian bluetongue virus serotypes from sentry cattle in West Java.
authors: Sendow, I.;Daniels, P. W.;Soleha, E.;Erasmus, B.

title: Evaluation of the broad-spectrum lytic capacity of bacteriophage cocktails against various Salmonella serovars and their effects on Salmonella Typhimurium-infected weaning pigs.
abstract: The broad-spectrum lytic capacity of Salmonella bacteriophages against various Salmonella species was evaluated to determine their potential as an alternative to antibiotics, and the safety and preventive effects of bacteriophages on mice and pigs were evaluated. Four bacteriophage cocktails were prepared using 13 bacteriophages and the lytic capacity of the four bacteriophage cocktails was tested using Salmonella reference strains and field isolates. Bacteriophage cocktail C (SEP-1, SGP-1, STP-1, SS3eP-1, STP-2, SChP-1, SAP-1, SAP-2; â‰¥109 pfu/ml) showed the best lytic activity against . Salmonella reference strains (100% of 34) and field isolates (92.5% of 107). Fifty mice were then orally inoculated with bacteriophage cocktail C to determine the distribution of bacteriophages in various organs, blood and feces. The effects of bacteriophages on Salmonella infection in weaned pigs (n=15) were also evaluated through an experimental trial with Salmonella Typhimurium after treatment with bacteriophage cocktail C. All mice exhibited distribution of bacteriophages in all organs, blood and feces up to 15 days post-administration. infection (dpi). After 35 dpi, bacteriophages were not detected in any of these samples. Treatment with bacteriophage cocktail C reduced the level of Salmonella shedding in feces, as demonstrated in a swine-fighting study. Metagenomic analyzes of these pig feces also revealed that bacteriophage treatment reduced the species number of the Enterobacteriaceae family without significant disruption of the normal fecal flora. This study showed that bacteriophages effectively control Salmonella in a pig challenge model and can be a good alternative to antibiotics to control Salmonella infection.
authors: Seo, B. J.;Song, E. T.;Lee, K.;Kim, J. W.;Jeong, C. G.;Moon, S. H.;Son, J. S.;Kang, S. H.;Cho, H. S.;Jung, B. Y.;Kim, W. I.

title: Is Africa the repository of new virulent strains of the Newcastle disease virus?
authors: Servan de Almeida, R.;Maminiaina, O. F.;Gil, P.;Hammoumi, S.;Molia, S.;Chevalier, V.;Koko, M.;Andriamanivo, H. R.;TraorÃ©, A.;SamakÃ©, K.;Diarra, A.;Grillet, C.;Martinez, D.;Albina, E.

title: Genetic diversity of the Newcastle disease virus in Pakistan: A nationwide perspective.
abstract: Background: Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the deadliest diseases for poultry worldwide. The disease is endemic in Pakistan and recurrent outbreaks are regularly reported in wild captive, rural and commercial poultry flocks. While efforts have been made to characterize the causative agent in parts of the country, the genetic nature of the strains circulating throughout Pakistan is currently lacking. Tools and methods. To determine the genetics of NDV, 452 blood samples were collected from 113 herds from all provinces of Pakistan and showed a high mortality rate (30-80%). The samples represented domesticated poultry (broiler, layer, and rural) as well as wild captive birds (pigeons, turkeys, pheasants, and peacocks). Samples were screened by real-time PCR for both matrix and fusion genes (1792 bp), positive samples were subjected to amplification of the whole fusion gene followed by sequencing and phylogenetic analysis. Results: The deduced amino acid sequence of the fusion protein cleavage site showed the presence of the motif (112RK/RQRRâ†“F117) typical for velogenic strains of NDV. Phylogenetic analysis of the hypervariable region of the fusion gene showed that all isolates belong to line 5 of NDV, except for the isolates collected from the Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KPK) region. A higher resolution of the phylogenetic analysis of lineage 5 showed the distribution of Pakistani NDV strains to 5b. However, isolates from KPK belonged to line 4c; first report of such a lineage from this province. Conclusions: Taken together, the data showed the prevalence of multiple NDV lineages in different bird populations, including wild captive birds. Such understanding is crucial to support the nature of circulating NDV strains, their potential for interspecies transmission, and disease diagnosis and control strategies. Â© 2013 Shabbir et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Shabbir, M. Z.;Zohari, S.;Yaqub, T.;Nazir, J.;Shabbir, M. A. B.;Mukhtar, N.;Shafee, M.;Sajid, M.;Anees, M.;Abbas, M.;Khan, M. T.;Ali, A. A.;Ghafoor, A.;Ahad, A.;Channa, A. A.;Anjum, A. A.;Hussain, N.;Ahmad, A.;Goraya, M. U.;Iqbal, Z.;Khan, S. A.;Aslam, H. B.;Zehra, K.;Sohail, M. U.;Yaqub, W.;Ahmad, N.;Berg, M.;Munir, M.

title: Comparative analysis reveals frequent recombination in parvoviruses
abstract: Parvoviruses are small single-stranded DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature. Infections with both autonomous and helper virus-dependent parvoviruses are common in both human and animal populations, and many animals are home to a number of different parvoviral species. Despite the epidemiological importance of parvoviruses, the existence and role of genome recombination within or between parvoviral species is not well defined. Here we show that natural recombination may be common in these viruses. The different genome regions of both porcine parvoviruses and Aleutian mink disease viruses have conflicting phylogenetic histories, providing evidence for recombination in each of these two species. Furthermore, rodent parvoviruses show complex evolutionary histories for discrete genomic regions, suggesting recombination at the interspecies level. © 2007 SGM.
authors: Shackelton, L. A.;Hoelzer, K.;Parrish, C. R.;Holmes, E. C.

title: Phylogenetic analysis and reclassification of goat and ovine lentiviruses based on 104 novel isolates: Evidence of regular sheep-to-goat transmission and worldwide spread through the animal trade.
abstract: We performed a phylogenetic analysis of goat and ovine lentiviruses using the long sequences in gag and pol of 104 novel Swiss isolates and the corresponding six available database sequences. Forty-five isolates that formed five sequence clusters could not be classified by the current classification. Binary DNA distance analysis showed different categories of associations, which required a new classification system. We suggest four main sequence groups AD with 25-37% variation. Groups A and B are further divided into subtypes that differ by 15-27%. Group D and four of the seven group A subtypes, A3, A4, A5 and A7, are formed by new Swiss isolates. Molecular epidemiology revealed that Swiss B1 strains did not differ much from French, Brazilian or US strains, suggesting that the virus was spread through the international pet trade. Furthermore, infection of goats by A3 or A4 subspecies was significantly associated with documented contact with sheep that also harbored these subspecies, thus suggesting that sheep-to-goat transmission occurs regularly. Â© 2003 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Shah, C.;BÃ¶ni, J.;Huder, J. B.;Vogt, H. R.;MÃ¼hlherr, J.;Zanoni, R.;Miserez, R.;Lutz, H.;SchÃ¼pbach, J.

title: Comparison of tissue sample processing methods to collect snapshot of viral metagenome and RNA viral community in turkey gut
abstract: RNA viruses have been associated with enteritis in poultry and have been isolated from diseased birds. The same viral agents are also detected in healthy flocks and their role in health and disease is questioned. To better understand eukaryotic viruses in the gut, this project focused on evaluating alternative methods to purify and concentrate viral particles that do not involve the use of density gradients to generate viral metagenome data. In this study, the sequence results of three tissue processing methods were evaluated and a data analysis pipeline was established for RNA viruses from the gastrointestinal tract. In addition, a view of the RNA viral community in the gastrointestinal tract of a clinically normal 5 week old turkey is presented, using best method and increasing sequencing depth. Viruses from the Reoviridae and Astroviridae families together make up 76.3% of the total viruses identified. The species-level rarity curve also implied that the majority of species diversity was included in increasing sequencing depth, implying that viruses from other viral families were in very low abundance.
authors: Shah, J. D.;Baller, J.;Zhang, Y.;Silverstein, K.;Xing, Z.;Cardona, C. J.

title: Enhancement of Intestinal RNA Virus Community of Healthy Broiler Chickens
abstract: Various RNA viruses such as astrovirus, rotavirus, reovirus and parvovirus have been detected in both healthy and diseased commercial poultry flocks. The aim of this study was to characterize (a) the development of the RNA viral community in the small intestine of healthy broilers from hatch to 6 weeks of age (market age) and (b) the contribution of the breeder source to the bird. the age of development of the community structure. Intestinal tissue samples were collected from breeders and their descendants, processed for viral RNA extraction and sequenced using Illumina Hiseq sequencing technology, resulting in a 100 bp PE read. The results from this study showed that the breeder source affects the RNA viral community only at brood, but then the environment, i.e. bird age, has a more significant effect. The most abundant RNA viral family detected at 2, 4, and 6 weeks of age is Astroviridae, whose abundance decreases with age and Picornaviridae abundance increases with age.
authors: Shah, J. D.;Desai, P. T.;Zhang, Y.;Scharber, S. K.;Baller, J.;Xing, Z. S.;Cardona, C. J.

title: Analysis of Host Parasite Incompatibility in Papilloma Virus Evolution Using Significance Sampling
abstract: Papillomaviruses (PVs) are a family of viruses that infect several mammalian and non-mammalian species that cause cervical cancer in humans. The evolutionary history of PVs is not well understood as they are associated with a wide variety of host species. Mismatches between phylogenetic trees of various viral genes, as well as between these genes and host phylogenies, suggest violations of historical viral recombination as well as strict virus-host co-speciation. However, the extent of recombination events between PVs is unclear and there is little evidence to support the theory of PV propagation via end-host transfers. Using Bayesian phylogenetic methods, we investigated the incompatibility between PV genes and hence the possibility of recombination. We found substantial evidence for phylogenetic incompatibility among the six PV genes E1, E2, E6, E7, L1 and L2, suggesting significant recombination. Analysis of E1 and L1 phylogenies suggests ancestral recombination events. We also describe a new method to study alternative host-parasite association mechanisms by applying importance sampling to Bayesian divergence time estimation. This new approach is not limited to the knowledge of a fixed viral tree topology or viral divergence times, multiple parasite taxa per host can be included and distinguish between pre-detachment of virus before host speciation and host transfer of virus following speciation. Using this method, we find that the pre-separation of PV lineages associated with the ancestral mammalian host gave rise to at least 6 PV lineages prior to the speciation of this host. These PV lineages then followed previous paths of divergence and co-speciation to eventually become associated with existing host species. Only one prime instance of a host transfer is supported; Transfer of the ancestral L1 gene between a Primate and a Hystricognathi host is based on divergence times between upsilon human type 41 and hedgehog PVs.
authors: Shah, S. D.;Doorbar, J.;Goldstein, R. A.

title: Fecal virus of pigs on a high-density farm
abstract: Pigs are an important source of protein worldwide, but they are subject to frequent viral outbreaks and numerous infections that can infect humans. Modern farming conditions can also increase viral transmission and potential zoonotic spread. Here, we describe the metagenomic-derived virome in the feces of 24 healthy and 12 diarrheal piglets on a high-density farm. An average of 4.2 different mammalian viruses were shed by healthy piglets, reflecting high levels of asymptomatic infections. Pigs with diarrhea shed an average of 5.4 different mammalian viruses. Ninety-nine percent of the viral sequences were associated with the RNA virus families Picornaviridae, Astroviridae, Coronaviridae, and Caliciviridae, while 1% were associated with the small DNA virus families Circoviridae and Parvoviridae. The identified porcine RNA viruses consisted of cobuviruses, astroviruses, enteroviruses, sapoviruses, sapeloviruses, coronaviruses, bocaviruses, and tescoviruses, in descending order of sequence reads. Almost complete genomes of many new strains of porcine astroviruses and bocaviruses have been produced and analyzed phylogenetically. Multiple small circular DNA genomes encoding replicase proteins and two quite different members of the Picornavirales order were also characterized. Based on the closest sequence similarities, the possible origin of these viral genomes from protozoans and nematodes infecting pigs is discussed. In summary, an unbiased study of viruses in the feces of heavily farmed animals has revealed frequent coinfections with a wide variety of viruses that provide favorable conditions for viral recombination. Viral studies in animals can easily document the circulation of known and novel viruses, facilitating the detection of emerging viruses and the prospective assessment of their pathogenic and zoonotic potential. Â© 2011, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Shan, T.;Li, L.;Simmonds, P.;Wang, C.;Moeser, A.;Delwart, E.

title: Antiviral drug discovery for the treatment of enterovirus 71 infections
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) is a small, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus of the Picornavirus family Enterovirus. It causes hand, foot, and mouth disease in infants and children and in a small percentage of cases progresses to central nervous system infection ranging from aseptic meningitis to fatal encephalitis. Sporadic cases of EV71 infection occur worldwide, but large outbreaks have recently occurred in Southeast Asia and China. There are currently no approved vaccines or antiviral therapies for the prevention or treatment of EV71 infection. This article reviews efforts to develop antiviral therapies against EV71. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Shang, L.;Xu, M.;Yin, Z.

title: A naturally occurring recombinant enterovirus expresses a torovirus deubiquitinase
abstract: Enteroviruses (EVs) are involved in a wide variety of diseases in humans and animals. In this study, a novel enterovirus (enterovirus strain G [EVG]) (EVG 08/NC_USA/2015) was isolated from a diagnostic specimen from a neonatal swine diarrhea case and identified using metagenomic and whole genome sequencing. The viral genome shares 75.4% nucleotide identity with a prototypical EVG strain (PEV9 UKG/410/73). Remarkably, a 582 nucleotide insertion was found in the 2C/3A junction region of the viral genome flanked by 3Cpro cleavage sites at the 5= and 3= ends. This insert encodes a protease predicted with 54 to 68% amino acid identity to torovirus (ToV) papain-like protease (PLP) (ToV-PLP). Structural homology modeling predicts that this protease adopts a fold and a catalytic site characteristic of minimal PLP catalytic sites. This structure is similar to that of the core catalytic domains of the foot-and-mouth disease virus leader protease and coronavirus PLPs, which act as deubiquitinating and deISGylating (interferon [IFN]-stimulated gene 15 [ISG15]-removal) enzymes in the host cell. substrates. Importantly, this novel enterovirus-derived recombinant ToV-PLP protein also showed potent deubiquitination and deISGylation activities and the ability to suppress IFN-Î² expression. Using reverse genetics, we generated a ToV-PLP knockout recombinant virus. Compared to wild-type virus, ToV-PLP knockout mutant virus showed impaired growth and induced higher expression levels of innate immunity genes in infected cells. These results demonstrate that ToV-PLP functions as an innate immune antagonist; enterovirus G can therefore gain fitness from a recombination event through the acquisition of ToV-PLP.
authors: Shang, P.;Misra, S.;Hause, B.;Fang, Y.

title: Molecular epidemiological investigation of swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus in Northwest China from 2007 to 2010.
abstract: Pig reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) is an economically important swine disease affecting pigs worldwide. Northwest China has a sparse population of pigs and there is currently no comprehensive information available on PRRSV infection. In this study, we analyzed the epidemiological features and genetic diversity of PRRSV from this region. Isolated tissue or serum samples were collected at 322 sites twice over 2 years from 15 herds from aborted pig fetuses or pigs with respiratory disease. PRRSV infection was determined and virus strains were classified by GP5 sequencing. We found that 35.9% of animals were PRRSV-positive and the mean prevalence was 46.5% and 29.3% in 2007-2008 and 2009-2010, respectively. To further investigate the genetic diversity of PRRSV samples collected from 2007 to 2010, 32 strains were isolated for GP5 sequencing and analysis and phylogenetic trees were constructed based on their GP5 amino acid sequences. All PRRSVs were of the North American genotype and belonged to the highly pathogenic HP-PRRSV subgenotype. The isolates from Xinjiang province formed a tightly clustered branch and were closely related to an evolutionary intermediate subgroup isolate. Virus sequences from 2007 to 2008 were compared with those from the same swarm from 2009 to 2010. After 2009, new mutations were found in isolates and focused on nucleotides in the GP5 antibody trap epitope. From 2007 to 2010, PRRSV strains in Northwest China were similar to those from other parts of China, with some regional characteristics. These results add to the knowledge of PRRSV epidemiology in China. © Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2012.
authors: Shang, Y.;Wang, G.;Tian, H.;Yin, S.;Du, P.;Wu, J.;Chen, Y.;Yang, S.;Jin, Y.;Zhang, K.;Liu, X.

title: Occurrence of bird flu H9N2 in Bangladesh
abstract: Avian influenza subtype H9N2 is endemic to many avian species in Asia and the Middle East and has contributed to the generation of potential pandemic threats, H5N1, H7N9 and H10N8. H9N2 viruses that spread to Bangladesh acquired multiple gene segments, possibly from highly pathogenic (HP) H7N3 viruses found in Pakistan and currently circulating together with HP H5N1. However, the origin and geographical origin of these H9N2 viruses are not clear. We characterized the complete genetic sequences of 37 Bangladeshi H9N2 viruses isolated in 2011-2013 and investigated their intersubtype and intersubtype genetic diversity by tracing their occurrence in relation to other H9N2 viruses isolated from neighboring countries. H9N2 viruses in Bangladesh are homogeneous with several mammalian host-specific markers and a novel H9N2 subsequence in which the hemagglutinin (HA) gene is derived from an Iranian H9N2 lineage (Middle East-B Iran), neuraminidase (NA) and polymerase basic 2 (PB2). genes H9N2 (Mideast-C Dubai) from Dubai and non-structural protein (NS), nucleoprotein (NP), matrix protein (MP), polymerase acidic (PA) and polymerase basic 1 (PB1) genes HP H7N3 from Pakistan. Different H9N2 genotypes have been identified in Bangladesh, modified by other reassortants in 2006 and 2009. Phylogenetic and molecular analyzes indicate that the current genotype is descended from the prototypical H9N2 lineage (G1) that circulated in poultry in China and arrived in Bangladesh via the Middle East poultry trade in the late 1990s, and this genotype was later reclassified to H7N3. and H9N2 strains originate from Pakistan and spread to India. Therefore, continued surveillance of Bangladeshi HP H5N1, H7N3 and H9N2 is warranted to determine further evolution and adaptation to humans.
authors: Shanmuganatham, K.;Feeroz, M. M.;Jones-Engel, L.;Walker, D.;Alam, S. M. R.;Hasan, M. K.;McKenzie, P.;Krauss, S.;Webby, R. J.;Webster, R. G.

title: Nucleotide sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the fusion (F) epitope for Egyptian pestes des petit ruminant virus (PPRV) predicts unique criteria, designated as Egypt 2009
abstract: Peste des petit ruminant virus was previously isolated and serologically identified from suspected outbreaks of PPR among sheep and goats in 2006 in Qalyubia Province, Egypt. In this study, six of these PPRV isolates were confirmed using reverse transcriptase-PCR (RT-PCR). The primer set for the fusion protein (F) epitope, followed by cDNA, was sent to the Animal Health Institute of England, Pirbright, UK, for analysis by matching the nucleotide sequences and phylogenetic analysis characteristics of this F protein gene with other reference world recorded isolates. The gene sequencing the 322 nucleotide cDNA fragment of the fusion protein gene was obtained. The isolates showed a unique phylogenetic analysis not previously identified internationally and identified as Egypt 2009. Moreover; using sequences obtained from this gene encoding protein; Egyptian PPRVs were grouped as the fleet genetic ally of lineage IV. To the author's knowledge, this is the first report describing the Fusion protein (F) gene sequence, phylogeny analysis and lineage typing of Maize isolates of PPRVs. Â© 2011 Academic Journals Inc.
authors: Sharawi, S. S. A.;Abd-El-Rahim, I. H. A.

title: Molecular Epidemiology and Complete Genome Characterization of H1N1pdm Virus from India
abstract: Background: Influenza A virus is one of the world's largest uncontrolled pathogens and causes seasonal epidemics as well as global pandemics. This is evidenced by the continuation of the 2009 swine-borne pandemic H1N1 Influenza A virus, which emerged recently, triggering the first true pandemic in the last 40 years. Over its evolution, the virus has acquired many mutations, and multiple unidentified molecular determinants are likely responsible for the 2009 H1N1 virus's ability to cause increased disease severity in humans. The availability of limited data on the whole genome hinders continued monitoring of such events. Outbreaks with significant morbidity and mortality have been reported from all over the country. Methods/Results: Given the large number of clinical infection cases, whole genome-based sequence characterization of Indian H1N1pdm virus and phylogenetic analysis relative to circulating global viruses were performed to reveal the phylodynamic pattern of H1N1pdm virus in India between 2009 and 2011. Clade VII was observed as a major circulating clade in the phylogenetic analysis. Selection pressure analysis revealed 18 positively selected regions in the major surface proteins of the H1N1pdm virus. Conclusions: This study made it clear that chapter VII was defined as chapter that has been in circulation recently in India as well as globally. Several well-defined markers specific to VII have been subjected to positive selection during virus evolution. Continuous monitoring of the H1N1pdm virus is guaranteed to monitor virus development and further transmission. This study will serve as a baseline for future surveillance, as well as for the development of appropriate therapeutics. Â© 2013 Sharma et al.
authors: Sharma, S.;Joshi, G.;Dash, P. K.;Thomas, M.;Athmaram, T. N.;Kumar, J. S.;Desai, A.;Vasanthapuram, R.;Patro, I. K.;Rao, P. V. L.;Parida, M.

title: Epidemiology of Contagious Pustular Dermatitis in Small Ruminants of Punjab
abstract: Infectious pustular dermtitic (orf) is caused by the orf virus classified in the genus Parapoxvirvs of the family Poxviridae. It is a non-systemic rash skin disease in sheep and goats that is transmitted to humans. This article describes the epidemiology of infectious pustular dermatitis in small ruminant animals of Punjab and the molecular diagnosis of the disease by polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
authors: Sharma, S.;Mahajan, V.;Hosamani, M.;Singh, R. K.;Kallesh, D. J.;Kumar, H.;Verma, S.;Sandhu, K. S.

title: Response to wingnet challenge of Rous sarcoma virus subgroups in some chicken breeds
abstract: The response to the wingnet challenge (WWC) of the Rous sarcoma virus (RSV) subgroups was studied in a 4-8 week old light breed, a heavy breed and a cross between a domestic blackhaired Bantam chicken and the Australorp breed. Wing web tumor (WWT) began to develop within one week in response to the challenge of virus subgroups A (BS-RSV) and C [RSV (RAV-49). Chicks challenged with subgroup D [RSV (RAV-50)] virus took at least 4 weeks to develop WWT. Positive response to WWC by A, C, and D virus subgroups was 84%, 100%, and 52%, respectively. The duration of the positive response was maximum for subgroup A virus, followed by minimum for subgroup D and subgroup C virus.
authors: Sharma, S. N.

title: Comparative metagenomics of microbial traits in ocean viral communities
abstract: Viral genomes often contain genes recently obtained from microbes. In some cases (for example, psbA), the proteins encoded by these genes have been shown to be important for viral replication. In this study, we characterize previously undetected microbial metabolic capabilities hidden in the genomes of uncultured marine viral communities, using a unique search strategy on Global Ocean Survey (GOS) metagenomes combined with marine virome and microbiome pyrosequencing-based datasets. A total of 34 microbial gene families were detected in 452 viral GOS scaffolds. Most of the accessory metabolic genes found in these scaffolds have never been reported in phages. The host genes detected in viruses are mainly split between genes encoding different energy metabolism pathways such as electron transport and newly identified photosystem genes or related translational and post-translational mechanisms. Our findings suggest previously undetected ways in which marine phages adapt and improve fitness to their hosts, rather than previously known transcription level control. ISME Journal (2011) 5, 1178-1190; doi:10.1038/ismej.2011.2; Published online February 10, 2011 Subject Category: Integrated genomic and post-genomic approaches in microbial ecology
authors: Sharon, I.;Battchikova, N.;Aro, E. M.;Giglione, C.;Meinnel, T.;Glaser, F.;Pinter, R. Y.;Breitbart, M.;Rohwer, F.;Beja, O.

title: High prevalence and diversity of bovine astroviruses in faeces of healthy and diarrheal calves in South West Scotland
abstract: Astroviruses (AstV) are single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses and are one of the leading causes of infant diarrhea worldwide. Diarrhea is a common and important cause of morbidity and mortality in calves; therefore, we investigated whether the presence of AstV is associated with calf diarrhea. We identified several AstV strains from fecal samples of both healthy and diarrheal calves and healthy adult cattle in South West Scotland. AstV was common in calves (present in 74% (85/115) of samples) but not common in adult cattle (15% (3/20) of samples). No association was found between the presence of AstV and calf diarrhea or the presence of a particular AstV strain and calf diarrhea. AstV was strongly associated with the presence of rotavirus Group A (RVA), and a protective effect of age was evident for both AstV and RVA. Co-infections with multiple AstV strains were detected in several calves, and serial infection with different viruses was also seen by longitudinal sampling of individuals. In summary, our study found genotypically diverse AstV in faeces of calves from South West Scotland. However, no association was detected between AstV and calf diarrhea, suggesting that the virus did not play a primary role in the etiology of calf diarrhea in the study group. (C) 2015 Authors. Posted by Elsevier BV
authors: Sharp, C. P.;Gregory, W. F.;Mason, C.;Bronsvoort, B. M. D.;Beard, P. M.

title: Rapidly fermentable substance modulates interactions between rumen commensals and toll-like receptors in enhancing immune tolerance of goat rumen
abstract: It remains unclear whether carbohydrate non-dietary fiber (NFC), a rapidly fermentable substance, affects rumen immune homeostasis through modulation of interactions of rumen microbiota and epithelial fee-like receptors (TLRs). A combination of 16S rRNA amplicon sequencing and quantitative PCRs was applied to study the synergistic responses of ruminal microbiota and epithelial TLRs to dietary NFC switch in the goat model. The results showed that the 31% NFC diet resulted in radical increases in the richness and diversity of the rumen microbiota. The phylum Verrucomicrobia expanded most significantly, while the opportunistic pathogens, namely Rikenella, Anaeroplasm and Olsenella, decreased significantly. In the rumen epithelium, significantly increased expressions of TLR1, 6, 10 were associated with significantly decreased expressions of the proinflammatory cytokines interleukin-1beta (IL-1β), IL-6 and the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10. Constrained correlation analysis showed that increased commensal bacterial abundance in Verrucomicrobia subdivision 5 contributed to the regulation of TLR10 expression. Finally, significantly increased concentrations of rumen short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) were observed in goats fed the 31% NFC diet, coupled with significantly upregulated expressions of epithelial genes involved in SCFA absorption. Thus, NFC-induced expansion of the rumen microbiota promoted epithelial tolerance by increasing TLR10 signaling intensity. The newly established balance benefited the transport of ruminal energy substances into the blood.
authors: Shen, H.;Lu, Z.;Chen, Z.;Wu, Y.;Shen, Z.

title: Influenza A(H5N6) Virus Reassortant, Southern China, 2014
authors: Shen, H.;Wu, B.;Chen, Y.;Bi, Y.;Xie, Q.

title: Pathogenicity and genetic characterization of a duck Tembusu virus associated with egg laying in Muscovy ducks.
abstract: Duck Tembusu virus (DTMUV) has spread to the major duck farming region in China, causing an acute decline in egg production in the Chinese duck population. In this study, we identified a DTMUV strain (named GD2014) isolated from an egg producing duck farm in Guangdong province, southern China. The virus was pathogenic to Muscovy duck embryos and caused a drastic decrease in Muscovy duck egg laying production. The genome sequence of GD2014 shared 97%-99% identity with other waterfowl Tembusu viruses and 89% identity with the mosquito isolated strain MM1775. Phylogenetic analysis of the entire open reading frame (ORF), E gene and NS5 gene indicated that GD2014 belonged to the Ntaya group. These results have implications for understanding the origin, occurrence and pathogenicity of DTMUV as well as for the development of vaccines and diagnostics based on epidemiological data.
authors: Shen, H. Q.;Lin, W. C.;Wang, Z. X.;Zhang, K.;Yan, Z. Q.;Zhou, Q. F.;Qin, J. P.;Xie, Q. M.;Bi, Y. Z.;Chen, F.

title: Isolation and phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin gene of H9N2 influenza viruses from chickens in Southern China from 2012 to 2013.
abstract: As part of our ongoing influenza surveillance program in southern China, 19 field strains of H9N2 subtype avian influenza viruses (AIVs) were isolated from flocks of dead or diseased chickens in southern China's Guangdong province between 2012 and 2013. these strains were sequenced and analyzed, and phylogenetic analysis showed that 12 of the 19 isolates belonged to the h9.4.2.5 line and the other seven to h9.4.2.6. Specifically, we found that all viruses isolated in 2013 belonged to the h9.4.2. The h9.4.2.5 viruses contained a PSRSSRâ†“GLF motif at the HA cleavage site, while the h9.4.2.6 viruses contained a PARSSRâ†“GLF at the same position. Most of the isolates in the h9.4.2.5 line lost one potential glycosylation site at residues 200-202 and had an additional one at residues 295-297 in HA1. Notably, 19 isolates had an amino acid substitution (Q226L) at the receptor binding site, indicating that the viruses have potential affinity to bind to the human-like receptor. This study demonstrates the importance of continuous surveillance of new H9N2 strains to better prepare for the next outbreak or pandemic outbreak of H9N2 AIV infections in chicken flocks.
authors: Shen, H. Q.;Yan, Z. Q.;Zeng, F. G.;Liao, C. T.;Zhou, Q. F.;Qin, J. P.;Xie, Q. M.;Bi, Y. Z.;Chen, F.

title: Genomic and evolutionary characterization of a novel influenza-C-like virus from pigs.
abstract: We recently described the isolation of a novel influenza virus from pigs in the United States exhibiting respiratory disease distantly related to human influenza C virus. Based on genetic, biochemical and morphological analysis, the virus was tentatively classified as C/swine/Oklahoma/1334/2011 (C/OK). To better understand the genetics and evolution of this new pathogen, we performed a comprehensive analysis of its sequence and phylogeny. The results showed that C/OK and human influenza C viruses share a conserved set of predicted functional domains in the mechanism of viral RNA genome replication and viral entry, but vary in important functional regions. Furthermore, our evolutionary analysis showed that homologous genes of C/OK and human influenza C viruses diverged from each other, presumably several hundred to several thousand years ago. Taken together, the findings described in this study support and extend our previous observations that C/OK is a genetically and evolutionarily distinct influenza virus in the Orthomyxoviridae family. © 2013 Springer-Verlag Vienna.
authors: Sheng, Z.;Ran, Z.;Wang, D.;Hoppe, A. D.;Simonson, R.;Chakravarty, S.;Hause, B. M.;Li, F.

title: A metagenomic investigation on viral abundance and diversity in mosquitoes from Hubei province.
abstract: As one of the most common but important vectors, mosquitoes have the potential to transmit or acquire a large number of viruses by biting, but the viral flora in mosquitoes and its impact on mosquito-borne disease transmission has not been well studied and evaluated. In this study, the metagenomic technique was successfully used to analyze the abundance and diversity of the viral community in three mosquito samples from Hubei, China. Of the 92,304 reads produced by a run with the 454 GS FLX system, 39% have high similarity to viral sequences from identified bacterial, fungal, animal, plant and insect viruses, and 0.02% are classified into unidentified viral sequences, showing high abundance and diversity. In addition, two new viruses were identified in the Densovirinae subfamily and Dicistroviridae family, and six torque tenosus viruses1 in the Anelloviridae family, three porcine parvoviruses in the Parvovirinae subfamily, and one Culex tritaeniorhynchus rhabdovirus in the Rhabdoviridae family. Viral metagenomic analysis provided a deep insight into the viral initiative or passive transmission during the process and the mosquito viral population that plays an important role in evolution.
authors: Shi, C.;Liu, Y.;Hu, X.;Xiong, J.;Zhang, B.;Yuan, Z.

title: Genomic characterization and pathogenicity of a swine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus strain isolated in China.
abstract: Porcine hemagglutinating encephalomyelitis virus (PHEV) is a member of the family Coronaviridae, the betacoronavirus genus that invades and causes encephalomyelitis or vomiting and wasting disease (VWD) in suckling piglets, which invades the central nervous system (CNS) via the peripheral nervous system. Although several complete PHEV nucleotide sequences have been reported so far, they are not annotated. This study aimed to elucidate the genome characterization, phylogenesis and pathogenicity of the PHEV/2008 strain. The full length of the PHEV/2008 strain genome was 30,684Â bp and the G+C content was 37.27%. The genome contains at least 11 predicted open reading frames (ORFs) flanked by the 5'² and 3'² untranslated regions (UTR) of 211 and 289 nucleotides. The replicase polyproteins pp1a and pp1ab, which have 4382 and 7094 amino acid residues, respectively, were predicted to be cleaved into 16 subunits by two viral proteinases. Phylogenetic analysis based on whole genome sequence revealed that strain PHEV/2008 is genetically distinct from other known PHEV types, representing a novel genotype (GI-1). In addition, we found that PHEV/2008 is neurotropic and highly pathogenic for 4-week-old BALB/c mice. Taken together, this is the first detailed annotated, complete genomic sequence of a novel genotype PHEV strain in China.
authors: Shi, J.;Zhao, K.;Lu, H.;Li, Z.;Lv, X.;Lan, Y.;Guan, J.;He, W.;Gao, F.

title: Molecular epidemiology of PRRSV: A phylogenetic perspective
abstract: Since its initial discovery two decades ago, porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) has been the subject of intense research due to its huge impact on the swine industry worldwide. Thanks to phylogenetic analysis, much has been learned about the genetic diversity and evolutionary history of the virus. In this review, we focused on the evolutionary and epidemiological aspects of PRRSV from a phylogenetic perspective. We first described the diversity and transmission dynamics of Type 1 and 2 PRRSV, respectively. Next, we focused on the earlier evolutionary history of PRRSV: the onset time of all extant PRRSVs and an origin hypothesis were discussed. Finally, we summarize the results of previous recombination studies to evaluate the potential impact of recombination on virus epidemiology. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Shi, M.;Lam, T. T. Y.;Hon, C. C.;Hui, R. K. H.;Faaberg, K. S.;Wennblom, T.;Murtaugh, M. P.;Stadejek, T.;Leung, F. C. C.

title: Origin and molecular characterization of the human-infecting H6N1 influenza virus in Taiwan.
abstract: In June 2013, the first human H6N1 influenza virus infection was confirmed in Taiwan. However, the origin and molecular characterization of this virus, A/Taiwan/2/2013 (H6N1), has not been well studied so far. In this report, we performed phylogenetic and combined analyzes of this virus and compared its molecular profile/traits with other closely related species. Molecular characterization of H6N1 revealed that it is a typical avian influenza virus of low pathogenicity, which may not replicate and spread well in the upper respiratory tract of mammals. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the virus clustered in A/chicken/Taiwan/A2837/2013 (H6N1) and seven genes excluding PB1. For the PB1 gene, A/Taiwan/2/2013 clustered with a different H6N1 strain from A/chicken/Taiwan/A2837/2013. While a previous study showed that the PB2, PA and M genes of A/Taiwan/2/2013 may have been derived from H5N2 viruses, combined analyzes revealed that these H5N2 viruses were derived from more recent strains than the ancestors of A. /Taiwan/2/2013. Therefore, we propose that A/Taiwan/2/2013 is a reasortant from different H6N1 strains circulating in chickens in Taiwan. Moreover, compared to avian isolates, a single P186L (H3 numbering) substitution in the H6 of the human isolate hemagglutinin can increase mammalian receptor binding and thus the pathogenicity of this strain in humans. Overall, transmission of this virus to humans appears to be an accidental event and is unlikely to cause an influenza pandemic. However, its co-circulation and potential reclassification with other influenza subtypes is still notable. Â© 2013 Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Shi, W.;Shi, Y.;Wu, Y.;Liu, D.;Gao, G. F.

title: Repeated detection of H7N9 avian influenza viruses in raw poultry meat illegally brought to Japan by international flight passengers
abstract: H7N9 highly and low pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIV and LPAIV, respectively) have been isolated from duck meat products illegally brought to Japan in hand luggage by flight passengers. These H7N9 virus isolates were phylogenetically closely related to those prevailing in China. Antigenic analysis revealed that the hemagglutinin of the H7N9 HPAIV isolate was slightly different from that of the H7N9 LPAIV and older H7 strains. Contaminated with AIVs that are repeatedly brought into Japan, these meat products pose increased poultry and public health risks. Continuous border disease control based on the detection and culling of infected poultry and meat products is therefore essential for preventing the introduction and spread of AIVs.
authors: Shibata, A.;Okamatsu, M.;Sumiyoshi, R.;Matsuno, K.;Wang, Z. J.;Kida, H.;Osaka, H.;Sakoda, Y.

title: Use of S1 nuclease in deep sequencing for detection of double-stranded RNA viruses
abstract: The metagenomic approach using next-generation DNA sequencing has facilitated the detection of many pathogenic viruses from stool samples. However, in many cases, most of the sequences detected originate from the host genome and bacterial flora in the gut. Here, we evaluated the applicability of S1 nuclease in deep sequencing to improve the efficiency of detecting double-stranded (ds) RNA viruses from samples. Treatment of total RNA with S1 nuclease resulted in 1.5-28.4 and 10.1-208.9-fold increases in sequence reads of group A rotavirus in fecal and viral culture samples, respectively. Also, increasing the extent of mapping to reference sequences allowed adequate genotyping using analytical software. These results demonstrate that the library construct using S1 nuclease is useful for deep sequencing in the detection of dsRNA viruses.
authors: Shimada, S.;Nagai, M.;Moriyama, H.;Fukuhara, T.;Koyama, S.;Omatsu, T.;Furuya, T.;Shirai, J.;Mizutani, T.

title: Genetic and phylogenetic characterization of rabies virus isolates isolated from wildlife and livestock in Paraiba, Brazil.
abstract: Thirty-four rabies viruses (RV) were isolated from foxes (8), insecticidal bats (9), cattle (14), sheep (1), goat (1) and donkeys (1) from Paraiba state in northeastern Brazil. genetically characterized. The sequences of the 890 nt nucleoprotein (N) gene of these isolates were analyzed and compared with those of other previously characterized Brazilian isolates. Phylogenetic analysis revealed three genetic RV lineages co-existing in this region. Each lineage was found to be associated with specific host species and circulate independently of each other. The first lineage was found in foxes (Dusicyon sp.) and can be distinguished from native carnivorous isolates from São Paulo, Goias, and Minas Gerais in southern and central Brazil. The second lineage was associated with insectivorous bats (Molossus spp.) and differed from vampire bat-associated RV isolates. The third lineage was found in livestock and clustered with vampire bat-associated RV isolates from Sao Paulo, Tocantins, Goias, and Matto Grosso. These results suggest that the RV of these genetic lineages circulate together in the state of Paraiba and that livestock in this region are infected with vampire bat-associated RV, suggesting that the vampire bat is the main reservoir of livestock rabies in this region.
authors: Shoji, Y.;Kobayashi, Y.;Sato, G.;Gomes, A. A. B.;Itou, T.;Ito, F. H.;Sakai, T.

title: Evidence for interspecies transmission and reclassification of influenza A viruses in pigs in southern China.
abstract: This century's outbreaks of Asia/57, Hong Kong/68, and Russia/77 originated or re-emerged in China. Interspecies transmission and genetic reclassification of influenza viruses have been at the origin of these pandemic influenza viruses. Pigs are suspected to be the 'mixing bowl' where rediversification takes place. To explore this possibility, 104 swine flu viruses randomly collected from Southern China from 1976 to 1982, including 32 H3N2 isolates and 72 H1N1 isolates, were examined using dot blot hybridization, partial sequencing, and phylogenetic analysis. Viruses originally derived from humans had 29 of 32 H3N2 isolate traits; the other 3 isolates were reassortants containing genes from porcine and human influenza viruses.
