Phylogenetic analyzes of the polymerase B1 (PB1) genes showed that interspecies transmission from humans to pigs occurred multiple times in pigs from Southern China. All 72 H1N1 isolates were of porcine origin, characteristic of the classic porcine H1N1 influenza virus. Analysis of 624 genes of swine flu viruses from southern China failed to detect any evidence for bird flu virus genes. This contrasts with those currently found in Europe, where the majority of swine flu virus isolates are of avian origin.
authors: Shu, L. L.;Lin, Y. P.;Wright, S. M.;Shortridge, K. F.;Webster, R. G.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of swine hepatitis e virus isolates from Yunnan province, China in 2011-2012.
abstract: Background: Hepatitis E is an important public health disease mainly in developing countries. Although molecular and sero-epidemiological studies of HEV have been conducted in many provinces in China, epidemiological data from Yunnan Province are limited and genotypes have not been fully characterized. In this study, the prevalence and characteristics of hepatitis E virus (HEV) detected in pigs in Yunnan province of China were evaluated. Results: Of the 187 porcine fecal samples collected in 2011, a total of 13 were HEV positive; Likewise, 7 out of 69 samples collected in 2012 gave positive results. These findings showed that the overall prevalence was 7.8% (20/256). Phylogenetic and molecular evolutionary analysis results showed that there were nine strains in the samples obtained in 2011 and that 87.1% to 99.4% nucleotide sequence identity was shared between these strains; and 77.0% to 81.9%, 52.2% to 53.6%, 77.0% to 88.2%, and 77.9% to 96.8% nucleotide sequence identities represent genotypes 1, 2, 3, and 4. shared with the strains. Five strains were detected in the samples obtained. In 2012, nucleotide sequence identity of 94.2% to 99.3% among strains and 81.0% to 82.5%, 81.8% to 83.2%, 81.0% to 92.7% and strains with 81.0 to 97.8% nucleotide sequence identity is shared. Represents 1, 2, 3 and 4 genotypes. Results: Analysis of the fourteen identified HEV strains revealed that three were subtype 4d and two were subtype 4b; the remaining nine isolated strains were the 4h subtype. These results indicated that the prevalence of HEV in Yunnan pig herds is quite high, additional public health concerns should focus on pig safety.
authors: Shu, X.;Duan, X.;Song, C.;Li, J.;Jiang, L.;Yin, G.;Li, W.

title: Molecular detection and characterization of West Nile virus associated with multifocal retinitis in patients from South India
abstract: Background: In late 2009/early 2010, around 2000 people were affected by a mysterious viral outbreak in the southern region of Tamil Nadu; this has particularly affected those living in coastal areas. Blood samples from affected patients were sent for clinical analysis to determine the true cause of the disease, but reports were inconclusive. Methods: This study describes clinical observations and laboratory investigations involving molecular methods performed on 170 of 2000 clinically suspected cases. These were patients presenting with ocular complications to Aravind Eye Hospital in Madurai, Tamil Nadu. Conventional reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), real-time RT-PCR, and reverse transcription loop-mediated isothermal gene amplification (RT-LAMP) assays were used to detect West Nile virus (WNV) infection. Further investigation of the genetic diversity of WNV involved in ocular complications has been done by sequence phylogeny. Results: Of 170 samples, 25 (15%) were positive for chikungunya IgM antibody, 10 (6%) for chikungunya antigen, and 30 (18%) for dengue IgM antibody. The remaining 105 seronegative samples were further processed for WNV detection by IgM capture ELISA and molecular methods. Of 105 samples, 35 (33%) were positive for WNV IgM antibody, 15 (14%) were positive for WNV by RT-PCR, and 27 (26%) were positive for WNV in both real time. RT-PCR and RT-LAMP tests. Comparative evaluation with acute phase patient serum samples revealed 100% agreement between real-time RT-PCR and RT-LAMP tests. These assays had an overall higher sensitivity than conventional RT-PCR as they took 12 additional samples with a low copy number pattern. Further genotyping via sequence phylogeny revealed that all WNV isolates were grouped into lineage I. Conclusions: The association of West Nile virus with ocular infection during the mystery fever epidemic in South India in the first half of 2010 was clearly established by the molecular approaches used. envelope gene-specific real-time RT-PCR and RT-LAMP assays, followed by nucleotide sequencing. Â© 2011 International Society of Infectious Diseases.
authors: Shukla, J.;Saxena, D.;Rathinam, S.;Lalitha, P.;Joseph, C. R.;Sharma, S.;Soni, M.;Rao, P. V. L.;Parida, M.

title: Whole genomic sequence analysis of swine genotype 3 hepatitis E virus isolated from Shanghai
abstract: The complete genomic nucleotide sequence of a previously identified genotype 3 hepatitis E virus (HEV), strain SAAS-JDY5, was obtained using RT-PCR and rapid amplification of cDNA ends (RACE). The genome consisted of 7225 nucleotides, excluding a poly-A tail at the 3 end, and encoding three open reading frames (ORFs), ORF-1, ORF-2 and ORF-3, 1702, 660 and 113 amino acids. , respectively. Phylogenetic analysis confirmed that SAAS-JDY5 belongs to genotype 3 HEV and is most closely related to the Japanese isolate wbJYG1 (AB222184). SAAS-JDY5 shared approximately 87% nucleotide similarity with human and porcine strains from the United States, compared with 74-75% similarity with Asian (genotype 4) and Mexican strains (genotype 2). Alignment of the SAAS-JDY5 genomic sequence with reference sequences of the same genotype revealed a nucleotide substitution and a deletion at positions 5145 and 7189 (3-² UTR), respectively. Furthermore, SAAS-JDY5 contained two additional nucleotides (AC) at the very end of the 3â€²-terminal before the poly-A tail of the genome. Comparison of the putative amino acid sequence encoded by the SAAS-JDY5 genome with those of other genotype 3 isolates revealed 15 unique amino acid substitutions and one deletion in ORF-1 and three substitutions in ORF-2. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Si, F. s;Zhu, Y. m;Dong, S. j;Yu, S. s;Yu, R. s;Shen, S. y;Yang, Q.;Li, Z.

title: Evolution of the cytoplasmic triple motif (TRIM) protein in cows restraining retroviral infection
abstract: Primate triplet motif 5Î± (TRIM5Î±) proteins mediate innate intracellular resistance to retroviruses. In humans it is found in a paralogous cluster that includes TRIM5, TRIM6, TRIM34, and TRIM22. Although the orthologs TRIM6 and TRIM34 have been found in other mammals, TRIM5 has so far only been identified in primates. Cow cells exhibit early blocks against infection by several retroviruses. We identify a cytoplasmic TRIM protein encoded by LOC505265 that is responsible for restriction of infection in cow cells by several lentiviruses and N-tropic murine leukemia viruses. The susceptibility of N-tropic murine leukemia virus to 505265-mediated restriction is determined primarily by residue 110 of the viral capsid protein. Phylogenetically, bovine LOC505265 is separated by the TRIM5/TRIM6/TRIM34 group, but is not an ortholog of known TRIM genes. The B30.2/SPRY domain of 505265 exhibits long variable regions characteristic of proteins encoded by this paralogous group, showing evidence of positive selection. The cows apparently evolved a retroviral restriction factor independently of the same TRIM family that produces TRIMS in primates. Certain features of this subset of cytoplasmic TRIM proteins may aid the convergent evolution of virus-restrictive factors. Â© 2006 by the US National Academy of Sciences.
authors: Si, Z.;Vandegraaff, N.;O'Huigin, C.;Song, B.;Yuan, W.;Xu, C.;Perron, M.;Li, X.;Marasco, W. A.;Engelman, A.;Dean, M.;Sodroski, J.

title: Herpesvirus strigis, a new avian herpes virus. II. Biochemical and biophysical properties
abstract: Herpesvirus strigis (HSIS), a virus originating from dead owls, has been successfully grown in chicken embryo fibroblasts. Its reproduction is blocked by the IUDR. Tissue cultured virus has proven to be sensitive to ether, chloroform, 0.5% trypsin, and pH levels of 4.0 or less. Infectivity was rapidly destroyed at 56°C. Negatively stained naked virions with an average diameter of 100 nm and enveloped virions 160-250 nm in size were seen. The capsid is made of hollow cylindrical capsomeres arranged in equilateral triangles, bearing 5 capsomeres along each edge. The cubic symmetry and icosahedron structure gave a total of 162 capsomeres. All these biochemical and biophysical data led to the classification of the HSIS virus into the herpes virus genus. The biological features described in a previous article continued such grouping and indicated that the agent was a new avian herpes virus for which the name herpesvirus strigis was suggested.
authors: Sibalin, M.;Gerstl, F.;Pichler, L.;Buerki, F.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 viruses isolated during the 2006-2008 outbreaks in Pakistan reveal genetic diversity.
abstract: Background: Since the first recorded outbreak in the northern regions of Pakistan in early 2006, highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 viruses have been isolated from commercial poultry and wild/domestic birds in different parts of Pakistan until July 2008. Different H5N1 isolates were sequenced. The genetic diversity of these viruses. Results: Phylogenetic analysis revealed close clustering and highest sequence identity in all 8 genes to HPAI H5N1 isolates of the combined H5 clade 2.2, sublineage EMA-3 from Afghanistan over the same time period. Two subgroups of Pakistani H5N1 viruses from domestic and wild birds were observed on the basis of sequence homologies and mutations. The HPAI motif, preferred receptor specificity for Î±-(2,3) linkages, potential N-linked glycosylation sites, and an additional glycosylation site in the globular head of the HA protein of four Pakistani H5N1 isolates. Amino acids associated with susceptibility to various antiviral drugs (Oseltamivir, Zanamivir, Amantadine) were found to be preserved for Pakistani H5N1 isolates. Of note, some significant mutations observed in critical positions of the antigenic regions of HA-1 (S141P, D155S, R162I & P181S) and in the receptor binding pocket (A185T, R189K & S217P). A high sequence similarity was also observed between the Pakistani HP H5N1 and LP H9N2 viruses. Apart from E627K in PB2, K356R in PA, V33I in NP, I28V in M2, and L107F in NS2 proteins, bird-like host-specific markers were also observed. Conclusion: Various point mutations in different genes were observed during the field circulation of H5 viruses from Pakistan. Outbreaks started in Khyber Pakhtoon Khawa (North West) province in 2006 and spread to Southern regions after a while. While migratory birds play a role in this sustained endemic of 2.2 H5N1 viruses in Pakistan during 2006-2008, the possibility of transmission through the cross-border legal or illegal poultry trade cannot be excluded. Â© 2012 Siddique et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Siddique, N.;Naeem, K.;Abbas, M. A.;Ahmed, Z.;Malik, S. A.

title: Isolation and Sequence Analysis of Reassortant Low Pathogenic Avian Influenza Virus H4N6 from Duck and Chicken in Live Bird Markets in Pakistan
abstract: Live bird Markets (LBM) can serve as an important source of AIV infections. During routine Avian Flu surveillance in Pakistan, the low pathogenic avian influenza virus subtype H4N6 was first isolated from Khaki Campbell duck (Anal platyrhynchos) in 2010 and broiler chicken in live bird markets (LBMs) from the port city of Karachi in 2011. in the state of Sindh. Whole genome sequencing revealed the introduction of a new strain of reassortant Eurasian avian virus. Phylogenetically, the HA, NA, M, NP, and PB2 genes were mostly clustered with Russian influenza virus strains and the PA gene and AI isolates from the Netherlands, while the NS and PB1 genes clustered with a Pakistani H3N1 isolate. Sequence analysis revealed an LP amino acid motif (PEKASR), bird-like receptors, conservation of amino acids at receptor binding sites and amino acids known to be associated with susceptibility to antiviral drugs, loss of glycosylation site in the NA gene, and resulting amino acids. Unique PDZ domain motif (ESEI) at the C terminus of the NS gene. Seroconversion against the H4N6 subtype was most observed in bird populations in Sindh and Khyber Pakhtoon Khawa provinces. The isolation disclosed the role of LBM, where mixing of different bird species provided the perfect environment for the spread and potential reclassification of AIV. Furthermore, the various point mutations in these H4N6 isolates and the close association with Pakistani H3N1 and other Eurasian strains also reflect the prevailing diversity among AIVs circulating in local LBMs. (C)2016 PVJ. All rights reserved
authors: Siddique, N.;Naeem, K.;Ahmed, Z.;Abbas, M. A.;Ali, A.;Rafique, S.;Rashid, F.;Begum, I.;Farooq, R.

title: Characterization and classification of hepatitis A-associated virus particles. II. Nucleic acid type and configuration
abstract: Virus particles banded at 1.34 g/ml in CsCl and precipitated at 160S on sucrose gradients were isolated from stool samples of patients afflicted with hepatitis. In the presence of 4 M urea and about 90% formamide, these particles released linear nucleic acid molecules with the characteristic coiled appearance of single-stranded RNA or single-stranded DNA. They can be distinguished from the nucleic acid of phage lambda added to the preparation as a marker for double-stranded configuration. Experiments in which the investigated virus particles were incubated at pH 12.9 at 50 degrees C for 30 minutes revealed that nucleic acid molecules were hydrolyzed as easily as the RNA genome of poliovirus type 2 analyzed in parallel. However, both the single-stranded DNA of phage phiX174 and that of parvovirus LuIII proved unaffected, and the double-stranded DNA of phage lambda was denatured into single-stranded molecules. Therefore, it was concluded that human hepatitis A virus contains a linear genome of single-stranded RNA and should be classified with picornaviruses.
authors: Siegl, G.;Frosner, G. G.

title: Urinary Virome perturbations in kidney transplantation
authors: Sigdel, T. K.;Mercer, N.;Nandoe, S.;Nicora, C. D.

title: Differentiating genotype 1 genes and proteins of human Wa-like rotaviruses versus porcine rotaviruses.
abstract: The group rotaviruses (RVA) are 11-segmented, double-stranded RNA viruses and are important causes of gastroenteritis in the young of many animal species. Previous studies had suggested that human Wa-like RVAs share a close evolutionary relationship with porcine RVAs. Specifically, the VP1-VP3 and NSP2-5/6 genes of these viruses are generally classified as genotype 1 with >. 81% nucleotide sequence identity. Still, it is unknown whether the genotype 1 genes and proteins of human Wa-like strains are distinguishable from porcine strains. To investigate this, we performed extensive bioinformatics analyzes using all known genotype 1 gene sequences. The RVAs analyzed represent wild-type strains isolated from humans or pigs at various geographic locations between 2004 and 2013, including 11 newly sequenced swine RVAs from Brazil. We also analyzed archival strains isolated between 1977 and 1992 and atypical strains involved in interspecies transmission between humans and pigs. Overall, we found that the genotype 1 genes of typical modern human Wa-like RVAs cluster together in phylogenetic trees and are separate from typical modern porcine RVAs. The only exception was for the NSP5/6 gene, which did not show host-specific phylogenetic clustering. Using amino acid sequence alignments, we identified 34 positions that differentiate the VP1-VP3, NSP2 and NSP3 genotype 1 proteins of typical modern human Wa-like RVAs against typical modern porcine RVAs and documented how these positions changed in archival/unusual isolates. No host-specific amino acid positions were identified for NSP4, NSP5, or NSP6. Altogether, the results of this study support the notion that human Wa-like RVAs and porcine RVAs are evolutionarily related, but suggest that some of the genotype 1 genes and proteins diverge over time, possibly as a reflection of sequestered replication and protein co-adaptation. on their hosts.
authors: Silva, F. D. F.;Gregori, F.;McDonald, S. M.

title: Follow-up of the molecular epidemiology of Brazilian Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) isolates.
abstract: Infectious bursal disease is a highly contagious disease of young chickens caused by the Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV). Genome segment A encodes capsid protein (VP2) while segment B encodes RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (VP1). In this study, we trace the molecular epidemiology of IBDV in Brazil by analyzing 29 isolates collected in major regions of poultry production. To genetically characterize the isolates, phylogenetic and population dynamic analyzes were performed using the coding sequences of 68 VP1 (2634nt) and 102 VP2 (1356nt) from IBDV isolates from different regions of the world. Furthermore, the evolution of IBDV was analyzed by characterizing the selective forces at work during the diversification of viral isolates. We show that IBDV isolates were brought to Brazil predominantly from the Netherlands and the USA. These introductions were associated with all Brazilian poultry production regions analyzed in this study. In addition, we show that the evolution of IBDV has been shaped by a combination of very low recombination rates and relatively high rates of nucleotide substitution (2,988×-10-4 for VP1 and 3.2937×-10-4 for VP2). It is a function of purification selection operating on VP1 and VP2. Furthermore, our expanded Bayesian skyline plot shows that the increase in effective population size of IBDV isolates is consistent with its epidemiological history, with a large increase during the emergence of acute IBD outbreaks in the 1980s. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Silva, F. M. F.;Vidigal, P. M. P.;Myrrha, L. W.;Fietto, J. L. R.;Silva, A.;Almeida, M. R.

title: Bat coronavirus related to Appalachian ridge and swine outbreak diarrheal viruses in Brazil
authors: Simas, P. V. M.;A.C, D. E. Souza BarnabÃ©;DurÃ£es-Carvalho, R.;De Lima Neto, D. F.;Caserta, L. C.;Artacho, L.;Jacomassa, F. A. F.;Martini, M. C.;Dos Santos, M. M. A. B.;Felippe, P. A. N.;Ferreira, H. L.;Arns, C. W.

title: Current and Future Surveillance of Antimicrobial Resistance in Animals: A Review of Principles and Practices
abstract: There is broad consensus at the international level that surveillance of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) levels occurring in various systems forms the basis of strategies to address this issue. The main reasons for monitoring resistance are to determine (i) the extent of the problem, (ii) whether resistance is increasing, (iii) whether previously unknown types of resistance are emerging, (iv) whether a particular type of resistance is spreading. and (v) whether a particular type of resistance is associated with a particular outbreak. The effects of acquiring and using this information need to be considered in the design of a surveillance system. AMR surveillance provides a basis for assessing the burden of AMR and providing the evidence needed to develop efficient and effective control and prevention strategies. Co-development of AMR surveillance programs in humans and animals is essential, but there are several key elements that complicate data comparisons between AMR monitoring programs and across regions. Currently, AMR surveillance is based on uncomplicated in vitro antimicrobial susceptibility methods. However, the lack of compatibility between programs and the limitation of genetic information of AMR remain the major disadvantages of these phenotypic methods. The future of AMR surveillance is moving towards genotypic detection, and molecular analysis methods are expected to yield a lot of information. However, the expectation that these molecular techniques will surpass phenotypic susceptibility testing in the routine diagnosis and monitoring of AMR is a distant reality, and phenotypic testing remains essential in detecting emerging resistant bacteria, new resistance mechanisms, and AMR trends.
authors: Simjee, S.;McDermott, P.;Trott, D. J.;Chuanchuen, R.

title: Psittacine herpes virus infection similar to Pacheco's parrot disease
abstract: The herpes virus was detected by electron microscopy in the hepatocytes of psittasine birds that died in a Florida aviary. The virus was identified in hepatocytes of chick embryos and budgerigars given injections of liver suspensions from naturally infected psittacins. Infected hepatocytes had prominent intranuclear inclusions containing bare nucleocapsids. Both naked and enveloped virions were seen in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes, and enveloped nucleocapsids were sometimes seen in the perinuclear cisterns and extracellularly. Experimental and spontaneous disease mimicked a condition in parrots previously described by Pacheco. The viral agent was classified as Herpes virus on the basis of the character of the intranuclear inclusions, the size and nature of the agent determined by electron microscopy and filtration, and the sensitivity of the agent to ether.
authors: Simpson, C. F.;Hanley, J. E.;Gaskin, J. M.

title: Genetic characterization of orf virus associated with severe orf outbreak in goats on a farm in Lusaka, Zambia (2015)
abstract: Orf, or infectious ecthyma, is a neglected and economically important zoonotic disease caused by a dermatotropic parapoxvirus that usually affects domestic small ruminants. Although orf is globally distributed, there is a lack of information about the disease in many African countries. Here, a suspected serious orf outbreak in goats was investigated at a farm in Lusaka. Orf virus (ORFV) infection was confirmed by PCR amplification of viral DNA (RNA polymerase, B2L and virus interferon resistance genes) in clinical samples. Some detected genes were sequenced and analyzed phylogenetically. This is the first report on molecular characterization of ORFV in goats from Zambia.
authors: Simulundu, E.;Mtine, N.;Kapalamula, T. F.;Kajihara, M.;Qiu, Y.;Ngoma, J.;Zulu, V.;Kwenda, G.;Chisanga, C.;Phiri, I. K.;Takada, A.;Mweene, A. S.

title: Interspecies transmission potential of porcine tortoise teno viruses
authors: Singh, G.;Ramamoorthy, S.

title: Identification of the MicroRNA repertoire in TLR-ligan-challenged bubalin PBMCs as a model of bacterial and viral infection.
abstract: In this study, we used high-throughput sequencing, miRNA-seq, to explore and explore the expression profiles of known and novel miRNAs in vis-à-vis unstimulated (i.e. Control) peripheral blood mononuclear cells stimulated with TLR ligand (PBMCs) from the blood of healthy Murrah buffaloes. isolated. Six small RNA (sRNA) libraries were multiplexed on the Ion Torrent PI chip and sequenced on the Ion Proton System. The resulting reads were aligned to the Bos taurus genome (UMD3.1 assemblage), the species phylogenetically closest to the buffalo (Bubalus bubalis). A total of 160 bovine miRNAs were biocomputedly identified in buffalo PBMCs, and 130 new miRNAs (not listed in bovine mirBase) were identified by default. All of these 290 miRNAs identified in six treatment and control samples represent the repertoire of novel miRNAs for buffalo species. Expression profiles of these miRNAs between samples are represented by sample dendrogram and heatmap plots. Uniquely expressed miRNAs were identified in each treatment and control group. A few miRNAs were expressed at very high levels, while most were expressed moderately. The miRNAs bta-miR-103 and -191 were found to be highly abundant and expressed in all samples. Other abundantly expressed miRNAs include bta-miR-19b, -29b, -15a, -19a, -30d, -30b-5p and let family members (let 7a-5p) in LPS and CpG-treated PBMCS. , let 7g & let 7f). and bta-miR-191, -103 & -19b in PBMCs stimulated with Poly I:C. Of the 130 newly identified miRNAs by default, only one new miRNA (bta-miR-11039) was expressed in all six samples, and differentially expressed (>2-fold) miRNAs were identified. Six miRNAs differentially expressed between groups (bta-miR-421, bta-let-7i, bta-miR-138, bta-miR-21-5p, bta-miR-222, and bta-miR-27b) were later released by TaqMan was verified by quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR). Furthermore, target genes of differentially expressed miRNAs were enriched for roles in innate immunity and TLR signaling pathways. This initial study of profiling and cataloging bubalin miRNAs expressed in TLR-ligand-stimulated PBMCs will provide an important reference point for future studies on the regulatory roles of miRNAs in the buffalo immune system.
authors: Singh, J.;Mukhopadhyay, C. S.;Kaur, S.;Malhotra, P.;Sethi, R. S.;Choudhary, R. K.

title: Taxonomic and gene-centered metagenomics of the faecal microbiome of low and high feed conversion ratio (FCR) broilers.
abstract: Individual weight gain in broiler breeders appears to vary, which may be due in part to changes in gut microbiota. In this article, we analyze the fecal microbiota of low and high feed conversion ratio (FCR) broilers. After shotgun sequencing of the fecal microbiome, we used the SEED database to determine microbial diversity and metabolic potential in low and high FCR birds. The domain-level breakdown of our samples was bacteria (>95%), eukaryotes (>2%), archaea (>0.2%), and viruses (>0.2%). At the phylum level, Proteobacteria (78.83% at low FCR and 52.04% at high FCR), Firmicutes (11.97% at low FCR and 27.53% at high FCR), and Bacteroidetes (7.10% at low FCR and 52.04% at high FCR) 17.53% was dominant. fecal microbial community. The poultry fecal metagenomes revealed 33 breed-related sequences in both low and high FCR at significantly different rates. Functional analysis revealed that genes for the metabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids and derivatives and for protein metabolism were most abundant in the SEED subsystem in both samples. Genes associated with stress, virulence, cell wall and cell capsule were also abundant. Indeed, genes associated with sulfur assimilation, flagella, and flagellum motility were overrepresented in low FCR birds. This information can help develop strategies to improve feed efficiency and feed formulation for broilers. Â© 2013 Institute of Plant Genetics, Polish Academy of Sciences, Poznan.
authors: Singh, K. M.;Shah, T. M.;Reddy, B.;Deshpande, S.;Rank, D. N.;Joshi, C. G.

title: Full-sequence analyzes of enterovirus 71 strains from cases of fatal and non-fatal hand, foot and mouth disease outbreaks in Singapore (2000).
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) is an important etiologic agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). In recent years, several epidemics in East Asia have been associated with neurological complications and numerous deaths. An outbreak in Singapore in October 2000 affected thousands of children and resulted in four fatal cases, three of which had EV71 isolated. The genomes of two representative strains of EV71 isolated from a fatal case and a surviving patient were fully sequenced and their nucleotide and amino acid sequences compared with known EV71 strains. The two epidemic strains were classified under genogroup B, together with those previously isolated in Singapore, Malaysia and Japan. Comparative sequence analysis of the two Singapore species revealed 99% nucleotide similarity, while their deduced amino acid sequences were nearly identical except for residue 1506 in the nonstructural 3A region. Given that the outbreak contained closely related genetic variants of EV71, the broad spectrum of disease severity could be attributed to critical factors such as varying doses of viral vaccination or different host immune responses following infection, but it is less likely to result from the emergence of EV71. high virulence strains.
authors: Singh, S.;Poh, C. L.;Chow, V. T. K.

title: Complex virome in excrement of Native American children in isolated Amazonian villages
abstract: The number of viruses circulating in small isolated human populations may be reduced by viral extinctions and rare introductions. Here, we used viral metagenomics to characterize the eukaryotic virome in the feces of healthy children from a major urban center and three American villages with minimal external contact. A large number of human enteric viruses, mainly from the families Picornaviridae and Caliciviridae, were sequenced from each of the regions. Multiple children from the same villages spread closely related viruses, reflecting frequent clusters of transmission. Feces of isolated villagers also contained multiple viral genomes of unknown cellular origin and higher levels of nematode and protozoan DNA from the Picornavirales order and CRESS-DNA group. Despite cultural and geographic isolation, the diversity of enteric human viruses has not decreased in these Amazonian villages. Frequent viral introductions and/or increased susceptibility to enteric infections may account for the complex fecal virus of Amerindian children in isolated villages.
authors: Siqueira, J. D.;Dominguez-Bello, M. G.;Contreras, M.;Lander, O.;Caballero-Arias, H.;Deng, X. T.;Noya-Alarcon, O.;Delwart, E.

title: ENDEMIC INFECTION OF RED SOUTH SEA Otters (ENHYDRA LUTRIS NEREIS) WITH NEW PARVOVIRUS, POLYOMAVIRUS AND ADENOVIRUS
abstract: Over the last century, the southern otter (SSO; Enhydra lutris nereis) population has been slowly rebounding from near extinction due to overharvesting. SSO is a threatened subspecies under federal law and a fully protected species under California law in the USA. Through a joint multi-agency program, trapped animals are rehabilitated and released, while deceased animals are necropsied and tissues frozen to facilitate scientific work. Here, we processed archival tissues to enrich particle-associated viral nucleic acids, which we randomly amplified and deeply sequenced to identify viral genomes through sequence similarities. Anelloviruses and endogenous retroviral sequences account for more than 50% of the observed viral sequences. The polyomavirus, parvovirus, and adenovirus sequences accounted for most of the remaining reads. We characterized and phylogenetically analyzed the complete genome of sea otter polyomavirus 1 and the complete coding sequence of sea otter parvovirus 1 and found that the closest known viruses infect primates and domestic pigs (Sus scrofa domesticus), respectively. We tested archived tissues from 69-lane SSO necropsied for 14 years (2000-13) by PCR. Poliomavirus, parvovirus, and adenovirus infections were detected in 51, 61, and 29% of the animals studied, respectively, and there was no significant increase in frequency over time, suggesting endemic infection. We found that 80% of the SSO tested were infected with at least one of the three DNA viruses whose tissue distribution we determined in 261 tissue samples. Parvovirus DNA was most frequently detected in the mesenteric lymph node, polyomavirus DNA was detected in the spleen, and adenovirus DNA was detected in more than one tissue (spleen, retropharyngeal and mesenteric lymph node, lung and liver). This study identifies virome in the tissues of a threatened species and demonstrates that trapped SSO is frequently infected with multiple viruses, warranting future research to explore associations between these infections and observed lesions.
authors: Siqueira, J. D.;Ng, T. F.;Miller, M.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Dodd, E.;Batac, F.;Delwart, E.

title: Evaluation of the pathogenicity potential of waterfowl type A influenza viruses in chickens.
abstract: Intravenous pathogenicity index (IVPI) tests on 29 mallard-derived type A influenza viruses, two turkey-derived type A influenza viruses, and one chicken-derived type A influenza virus resulted in indices ranging from 0.0 to 0.49. Most mallard viruses and two viruses from turkey have indices of 0.0, indicating that they are not pathogenic. Six of the duck-derived viruses had indices ranging from 0.25 to 0.49 and the IVPI for A/chicken/Alabama/75 (H4N8) was 0.49, indicating their low pathogenic potential. Classification of type A influenza virus as highly pathogenic requires 1.25 IVPI up to a maximum score of 3.0. Gross lesions observed in chickens that died following intravenous viral challenge included kidney swelling with more prominent lobular patterns, but no visceral urate deposits. The utility of IVPI testing may be limited in assessing the pathogenicity potential of non-pathogenic and low-pathogenic strains of avian influenza virus.
authors: Slemons, R. D.;Condobery, P. K.;Swayne, D. E.

title: The dangers of disease transfer from cetaceans to terrestrial mammals: review and recent findings
abstract: In a 5-year study (1972-1977) of microbial agents isolated from both clinically normal and diseased marine mammals, it was shown that certain disease agents are common in various oceanic populations and that some can infect a range of terrestrial organisms. mammal species. Leptospira interrogans serovar pomona has been repeatedly isolated from 2 species of pinnipeds (Zalophus californianus californianus and Callorhinus ursinus). Some of the more important bacterial pathogens for land mammals isolated from wild marine mammals are Pseudomonas mallei, Clostridium chauvoei, C novyi, Neisseria mucosa var heidelbergensis, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Salmonella spp, and Pasteurella multocida. Numerous virus serotypes classified as caliciviruses have been isolated from various marine mammals. Some of these are known to infect many species of land mammals, including pig horses and primates. Therefore, precautions should be taken to ensure that disease agents shed by captive marine mammals are not transmitted to susceptible land mammals, including animal handlers and other humans.
authors: Smith, A. W.;Vedros, N. A.;Akers, T. G.;Gilmartin, W. G.

title: Genetic variability and classification of hepatitis E virus
abstract: Classification of hepatitis E virus (HEV) variants is currently limited to birds, bats, rodents, and fish without agreed definitions for genotypes and subtypes. These conflicts arise due to the viruses being compared and differences in genomic regions and methodology used. We reexamined the published sequences and found that synonymous substitutions were saturated in comparisons between and within virus genotypes. Analysis of whole genome sequences or sequential ORF1/ORF2 amino acid sequences showed that the HEV variants most closely related to those that infect humans can be consistently divided into six genotypes (types 1 to 4 and two additional genotypes from wild boar). Variants isolated from rabbits closely related to genotype 3 occupy an intermediate position. No consistent criteria could be defined for the assignment of virus subtypes. Analysis of amino acid sequences from these viruses in three conserved subgenomic regions (residues 1 to 452 or 974 to 1534 of ORF, or residues 105 to 458 of ORF2) with variants more different from chickens, bats and rodents provided consistent support for a split in humans and pigs. divided into 4 groups corresponding to HEV variants that infect rats and ferrets, and those from bats and chickens. This approach could form the basis for future genetic classification of HEV with a more diverse HEV-like virus (brutal trout virus) derived from fish representing a second genus. Â© 2013, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Smith, D. B.;Purdy, M. A.;Simmonds, P.

title: Classification and genomic diversity of enterically transmitted hepatitis viruses
abstract: Hepatitis A virus (HAV) and hepatitis E virus (HEV) are important human pathogens and are responsible for a significant proportion of severe acute hepatitis cases worldwide. Genetically, both viruses are heterogeneous and are divided into several genotypes that differ in their geographic distribution and risk group associations. However, there is little evidence that HAV or HEV variants differ antigenically or in their propensity to cause serious disease. Genetically different but mainly hepatotropic variants of both HAV and HEV have been found in a few mammalian species; Those of HAV are classified as eight species in the genus Hepatovirus in the virus family Picornaviridae. HEV is classified as a member of the Orthohepevirus A species in the Hepeviridae virus family, a species that also includes viruses that infect pigs, rabbits, and various other mammalian species. Other species (Orthohepevirus B--D) infect a wide variety of other mammalian species, including rodents and bats.
authors: Smith, D. B.;Simmonds, P.

title: Consensus proposals for the classification of the Hepeviridae family
abstract: The Hepeviridae family consists of positive-strand RNA viruses that infect a wide variety of mammalian species, as well as chickens and trout. A subset of these viruses infect humans and can cause self-limited acute hepatitis that can become chronic in immunocompromised individuals. Current published descriptions of taxonomic divisions within the family Hepeviridae are conflicting regarding the assignment of species and genotypes. Through analysis of available sequence information, we propose a taxonomic scheme in which the family is divided into Orthohepevirus (all mammalian and avian hepatitis E virus (HEV) isolates) and Piscihepevirus (brutal trout virus) genera. Species within the genus Orthohepevirus are Orthohepevirus A (human, swine, wild boar, deer, mongoose, rabbit, and camel isolates), Orthohepevirus B (chicken isolates), Orthohepevirus C (rat, great bandicoot, Asian muskrat, weasel, and mink), and Orthohepevirus D (isolated from bat). Recommendations have also been made for the determination of genotypes in human and rat HEVs. This hierarchical system is compatible with hepevirus phylogeny and reflects and is consistent with discontinuities in binary spacing intervals between amino acid sequences of the three classification levels (genus, species, and genotype). Adoption of this system would include avoiding hostnames in taxonomic identifiers and would provide a logical framework for assigning new variants.
authors: Smith, D. B.;Simmonds, P.;Jameel, S.;Emerson, S. U.;Harrison, T. J.;Meng, X. J.;Okamoto, H.;Van der Poel, W. H. M.;Purdy, M. A.

title: Nomenclature updates resulting from the evolution of avian influenza A(H5) virus guidelines 2.1.3.2a, 2.2.1 and 2.3.4 during 2013-2014
abstract: OBJECTIVE: The A/goose/Guangdong/1/96-like hemagglutinin (HA) genes of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) A(H5) viruses have continued to evolve rapidly since the most recent update of the H5 clade nomenclature by WHO. /OIE/FAO H5N1 Evolution Working Group. New branches that go beyond established boundaries should be identified and determined accordingly. METHODS: Hemagglutinin sequences stored in public databases until 31 December 2014 were analyzed by phylogenetic and mean pairwise distance methods to identify new sequences deserving of nomenclature changes. RESULTS: Three new partition assignments were proposed based on partitions 2.1.3.2a (Indonesia), 2.2.1 (Egypt), and 2.3.4 (widespread detection in Asia, Europe, and North America) containing the newly emerged HPAI virus. H5N2, H5N3, H5N5, H5N6 and H5N8 subtypes. CONCLUSION: Timely reporting of continuous global surveillance and sequence data for HPAI A(H5) viruses in all host species will be critical to quickly identify new generations and assess their potential impact on human and animal health.
authors: Smith, G. J.;Donis, R. O.;World Health Organization/World Organisation for Animal, H. F.;Agriculture Organization, H. E. W. G.

title: Dating the emergence of pandemic influenza viruses
abstract: Pandemic influenza viruses cause significant deaths in humans. In the 20th century, 3 influenza viruses caused major epidemics: the 1918 H1N1 virus, the 1957 H2N2 virus, and the 1968 H3N2 virus. These pandemics were initiated by the introduction and successful adaptation of a novel hemagglutinin subtype from an animal source to humans and resulted in antigenic shift. Despite the global concern about a new pandemic influenza, the route of emergence of pandemic strains is unknown. Here, we estimated the evolutionary history of each of the genes for all 20th century pandemic influenza strains and the date of their introduction to humans. Our results show that genetic components of the 1918 H1N1 pandemic virus circulated in mammalian hosts, namely pigs and humans, as early as 1911 and are unlikely to be a recently introduced avian virus. Phylogenetic relationships indicate that A/Brevig Mission/1/1918 virus (BM/1918) was established by reclassification between mammalian viruses and a previously circulating human strain, either in pigs or possibly humans. Also, seasonal and classical swine H1N1 viruses were not derived directly from BM/1918, but their predecessors circulated together during the pandemic. Average estimates of the most recent common ancestry also suggest that pandemic strains H2N2 and H3N2 may have been created through reclassification events in unknown mammalian hosts and spanned multiple avian viruses prior to pandemic recognition. The occurrence of probable pandemic strains in mammals through a series of reclassification events in the years before pandemic recognition suggests that appropriate surveillance strategies for detection of precursor viruses could halt future pandemics.
authors: Smith, G. J. D.;Bahl, J.;Vijaykrishna, D.;Zhang, J.;Poon, L. L. M.;Chen, H.;Webster, R. G.;Peiris, J. S. M.;Guan, Y.

title: Bats and viroma: an important source of emerging viruses that can infect humans
abstract: Bats are increasingly recognized as an important reservoir of zoonotic viruses of different families, including SARS coronavirus, Nipah virus, Hendra virus and Ebola virus. Several recent studies have hypothesized that bats, an ancient group of flying mammals, are the main reservoirs for several important families of RNA viruses from which other mammalian viruses and humans are derived. Although this hypothesis needs further investigation, it is widely accepted that bats carry large numbers of viruses. The question of whether bats have unique biological features that make them ideal reservoir hosts has been the subject of several recent studies. In this review, we will focus on the public health impacts of bat-borne zoonotic viral disease outbreaks, examine the drivers and risk factors of past disease outbreaks, and outline research guidelines for better control of future disease events.
authors: Smith, I.;Wang, L. F.

title: Identification and isolation of a novel herpes virus in a captive mob of eastern gray kangaroos (Macropus giganteus).
abstract: new herpes virus has been identified during diagnostic studies for individuals with ulcerative cloaciditis in a captive population of eastern gray kangaroos (Macropus giganteus). The virus was initially detected in tissues using a consensus herpes virus PCR. No viral inclusions or particles were seen on routine histological or transmission electron microscopic sections of cloacal lesions. Virus was isolated from the samples, and transmission electron microscopy of the obtained isolates confirmed that the virus was morphologically compatible with a herpes virus. Nucleotide sequencing of the PCR product from tissue samples and isolates revealed that the virus was in the subfamily Gammaherpesvirinae and was different from other known herpes viruses. The correlation between the lesions and the new virus is unknown. Two herpesviruses, both in the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae, have been previously described in macropods and are known to cause systemic clinical disease. This is the first gammaherpes virus reported within the order Marsupialia and may provide valuable information about the evolution and phylogeny of this virus family. Based on current herpesvirus nomenclature, the authors suggest that the new herpes virus be named Macropodid herpesvirus 3 (MaHV-3).
authors: Smith, J. A.;Wellehan, J. F., Jr.;Pogranichniy, R. M.;Childress, A. L.;Landolfi, J. A.;Terio, K. A.

title: Reassembly and Analysis of an Ancient Variola Virus Genome
abstract: We report a major improvement in combining published short-read sequencing data from an ancient variola virus (VARV) genome with the removal of adjacent capped sequencing tags and manual searches for gap-spanning reads. The new compilation, together with the camelpox and taterapox genomes, allowed the calculation of new dates for the last common ancestor of all VARV genomes. Analysis of recently sequenced VARV-like cowpox virus genomes revealed that single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and amino acid changes in the vaccinia virus (VACV)-Cop-O1L ortholog that are predicted to be associated with VARV host specificity and virulence prior to the divergence of these viruses. Comparison of ancient and modern VARV genome sequences also revealed a measurable shift towards adenine + thymine (A + T) richness.
authors: Smithson, C.;Imbery, J.;Upton, C.

title: Novel gyroviruses, including chicken anemia virus, in clinical and chicken samples from South Africa
authors: Smuts, H. E. M.

title: A review of strain diversity and pathogenesis of chicken astrovirus
abstract: Although a relatively recent virus and only identified as a separate avian astrovirus species in 2004, chicken astrovirus (CAstV) has been associated with poor growth of broiler flocks, enteritis and diarrhea, and is a candidate pathogen in cases of stunting syndrome. More recently, CAstV has been implicated as the sole etiologic agent in two other diseases of broilers, namely, severe kidney disease of young chickens with visceral gout and "White Chicks" hatchery disease. Examination of the CAstV strains associated with the last two diseases reveals that they are closely related genetically. This review will discuss all factors that can influence disease severity in relation to the strain diversity of CAstV and the effects of vertical and horizontal transmission, viral load, coinfections, and bird age at infection.
authors: Smyth, V. J.

title: Sequence analysis of foot and mouth disease virus type O/IRN/2007 VP1 gene from Iranian isolate
abstract: Foot and mouth disease virus (FMDV) causes a vesicular and contagious disease in hoofed animals. In this study, the virus was isolated from vesicles of infected cattle using cell culture and serotyped by ELISA assay. RNA extracted from infected cells was reverse transcribed and amplified using VP1 gene-specific primer pairs by one-step RT-PCR. The purified VP1 gene was subcloned into the unique KpnI and BamHI cloning sites of the pcDNA3.1+ vector. The DH5Î± strain of E. coli was transformed by the vector. Subcloned FMDV type O/IRN/2007 VP1 sequences were aligned with FMDV type O/UKG/2001 VP1 using MegAlign software. Nucleotide sequence comparisons were made using the BLAST software available on the NCBI website. The amino acid sequences of three subcloned FMDV type O/IRN/2007 VP1 were also aligned with three other similar sequences using MegAlign software. Nineteen of the most similar VP1 nucleotide sequences (by the BLASTN program), the FMDV O/IRN/2007 VP1 sequence, twenty FMDV-O VP1 isolates in Iran, and eight FMDV type O topotypes were aligned by Mega5 to create an FMDV-O VP1. -based sequence similarity tree. Nucleotide sequence comparison, FMDV O1/Manisa/Turkey/69 (99%), FMDV O1/Manisa/Netherlands (98%) and FMDV O1 showed that FMDV O/IRN/2007 VP1 has the greatest nucleotide sequence similarity to the VP1 gene. has shown. /Manisa/iso87/Turkey (98%). It was also observed that the highest identity between the FMDV O/IRN/2007 VP1 sequence and the other nucleotide sequences of FMDV type O VP1 genes isolated in Iran between 1997-2004 was approximately 91%. © 2006 -2013 Folia Biologica.
authors: Soleimanjahi, H.;Sedeh, F. M.;Jalilian, A. R.;Mahravani, H.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of neuraminidase genes of H9N2 avian influenza viruses isolated from commercial broiler chicken in Iran (2008 and 2009)
abstract: total of 512 tissue samples were collected from 30 farms in various provinces of Iran between 2008 and 2009 as part of a program to monitor infection with avian influenza viruses (AIVs) in Iran's poultry population. To determine the genetic relevance of Iranian viruses, neuraminidase (NA) genes were amplified and sequenced from ten isolates of H9N2 viruses isolated from commercial chickens in Iran between 2008 and 2009. The neuraminidase gene of the viruses was >90% similar to the genes of the A/Quail/Hong Kong/G1/97 (H9N2) subclade. The neuraminidase stem regions in these Viruses had no deletions when compared to the chicken/Beijing/1/94 subline (Beijing-like viruses) and the two human isolates, A/HK/1073/99, A/HK/1074/99. Phylogenetic analysis of the neuraminidase (NA) gene showed that the H5N1 virus shares a common A/Quail/Hong Kong/G1/97 isolate that contributes to its internal genes. The results of this study showed that chickens in Iran were free of (Beijing-like) virus and (Korean-like) virus, and the NA genes of H9N2 influenza viruses circulating in Iran in recent years were well conserved and previous Iranians were well preserved. isolates may be considered to represent such a progenitor. Â© 2011 Springer Science+Business Media BV
authors: Soltanialvar, M.;Shoushtari, H.;Bozorgmehrifard, M.;Charkhkar, S.;Akbarnejad, F.

title: Molecular characterization of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes of H9N2 avian influenza viruses isolated from commercial broiler chickens in Iran.
abstract: total of 512 tissue samples were collected from 30 farms in various provinces of Iran between 2008 and 2009 as part of the program to monitor AIV infection in the Iranian poultry population. Avian influenza virus has been isolated from poultry farms with a history of respiratory disease and increased mortality. Nucleotide sequence analysis of five representative isolates confirmed that all isolates have some type of amino acid motif (RSSR/GL) at the cleavage site of HA. indicates a preference for binding of a (2-6) sialic acid receptors. The surface glycoprotein genes of the viruses were >90% similar to the genes of the A/Quail/Hong Kong/Gl/97 (H9N2) lineage. The neuraminidase stem regions in these viruses had no deletions when compared to this A/Dk/HK/Y280/97 strain (Ck/Bei-like viruses) and 2 human isolates A/HK/1073/99, A/HK/1074. /99. The hemadsorbg site of neuraminidase has up to 3 amino acid substitutions and differs from that of earlier Iranian viruses. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the HA and NA genes share a common isolate of Qa/HK/Gl/97 that contributes to the internal genes of the H5N1 virus. Â© 2010 Asian Scientific Information Network.
authors: Soltanialvar, M.;Shoushtari, H.;Bozorgmehrifard, M.;Charkhkar, S.;Eshratabadi, F.

title: Molecular epidemiology of pseudorabies virus in Yunnan and sequence analysis of its gD gene
abstract: There have been epidemics of fraudulent fraud (PR) in Yunnan, China, which have caused significant economic losses. In Yunnan, a total of 791 blood, tissue, semen and serum samples were analyzed by serological methods, PCR and sequence analysis of the gD gene to determine the prevalence and origin of PR, particularly among vaccinated pigs. Detection by viral gI antibody or PCR showed that from 2010 to 2014, annual positive rates of PR virus (PRV) in Yunnan were 48.15%, 21.26, 2.17, 5.22 and 0.35%, with an average of 15.43%, respectively. Overall, the incidence decreased over the period 2010-2014, possibly due to the implementation of PRV eradication strategies. A phylogenetic tree was constructed based on the full sequence of the gD gene, with all strains clustered in two independent branches, i.e. Asian and Euro-American branches. Viruses isolated from Henan, Tianjin, Heilongjiang, Sichuan, Shandong, Fujian, Xinjiang, Hubei, Guangdong and Yunnan fell into the Asian group that harbored the South Korean isolate. Four Yunnan virus isolates entered the Euro-American clade, along with South Korean Namyangju. It indicated that PR was a pandemic as there was no clear clue about the geographical origin of PRV isolates in China since 2010.
authors: Song, C.;Gao, L.;Bai, W.;Zha, X.;Yin, G.;Shu, X.

title: Detection and classification of infectious bronchitis viruses isolated in Korea by spot immunoblotting using monoclonal antibodies
abstract: The spot immunoblotting assay (DIA) using five monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) against infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) was used to detect and classify viruses propagated in embryonated chicken eggs. Using a group-specific MAb 3F5, 10 reference IBV strains and 12 Korean IBV isolates were successfully detected by DIA, with the lowest IBV virus titer detected by DIA less than approximately 103.8 mean embryo infective dose/mil. To evaluate the diagnostic efficacy, DIA was compared with the conventional diagnostic method for infectious bronchitis (IB). IBV antigens in allantoic fluid from embryonated eggs inoculated with IB-suspect field specimens were specifically detected by DIA in only one or two egg passages, whereas the traditional embryonated egg vaccination method required four to seven egg passages to confirm IBV infection. These results demonstrated that DIA can significantly reduce the time and cost of diagnosing IB. Four strain-specific MAbs, 3A4, 2A3, 6F7, and 2C6, were used to examine the possibility of classifying IBV with DIA. According to their MAb reaction patterns to IBV antigens, 10 IBV reference strains were classified into six groups; seven strains belonged to three different groups and the other three strains each belonged to a separate group. In the case of 12 Korean isolates of IBV, they were classified into six groups. Among the six groups, the MAb reaction patterns of the three groups matched those of the IBV reference strains, but not the others. These data suggest that at least three variant serotypes of IBV exist in Korea.
authors: Song, C. S.;Kim, J. H.;Lee, Y. J.;Kim, S. J.;Izumiya, Y.;Tohya, Y.;Jang, H. K.;Mikami, T.

title: Epidemiological classification of infectious bronchitis virus isolated in Korea between 1986 and 1997
abstract: Forty Korean isolates and four reference strains of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were classified by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction and restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis. Each Korean isolate was isolated from different commercial chicken flocks between 1986 and 1997. RFLP models of an amplified DNA fragment (1722 bp) containing the S1 gene of IBV digested by the restriction enzyme HaeIII showed that 40 Korean isolates were classified into five genotypes. , I to V. Six of these belonged to genotype I, which had the same HaeIII and XcmI cleavage patterns as the Massachusetts type (H120 and M41), but the other four genotypes had a different HaeIII cleavage pattern from the four reference IBV strains used in this study. . Since 1990, 29 of the 40 isolates consistently found in chicken flocks belong to this type, therefore genotype III appears to be the major type. and 1995, respectively. Five isolates selected from each of the five genotypes were inoculated into 1-day-old specific pathogen-free chicks to assess their pathogenicity. Genotype III caused 50% mortality along with severe renal urate accumulation in the kidneys, but the other four genotypes showed only respiratory distress 1 to 2 days after vaccination. Live H120 vaccine protected chicks from challenge with selected isolates from genotypes I, but not genotypes IV to V. A live strain KM91p120 selected from parent genotype III protected the chicks from challenge with isolates from genotype III in addition to other genotypes, including two recently. Isolates of IV and V genotypes.
authors: Song, C. S.;Lee, Y. J.;Kim, J. H.;Sung, H. W.;Lee, C. W.;Izumiya, Y.;Miyazawa, T.;Jang, H. K.;Mikami, T.

title: Profiling novel microRNAs elicited by EV71 and CA16 infection in human bronchial epithelial cells using high-throughput sequencing.
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) are the two main etiologic agents associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) worldwide. Although both belong to the Enterovirus genus of the Picornaviridae family, there are many differences in the infection processes of these viruses. However, the underlying mechanisms have not been elucidated. Numerous studies have shown that microRNAs (miRNAs) can play critical roles in host-pathogen interaction. Our previous study reported that EV71 and CA16 infection led to differential expression of miRNAs in human bronchial epithelial (16HBE) cells. Here, we aimed to further investigate the expression profile and possible roles of other miRNAs differentially expressed in 16HBE cells following EV71 and CA16 infections using high-throughput sequencing. We identify 44 new differentially expressed miRNAs in all samples. Among these miRNAs, 7 novel differentially expressed miRNAs show an opposite expression trend during the progression of EV71 and CA16 infections. Subsequently, bioinformatics analyzes, including Gene Oncology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genes (KEGG) databases, were used to identify biological processes, molecular functions, cellular components, and related pathways. The top 10 GO and Pathway annotation showed that 849 target genes are involved in cell development, such as nervous system development, multicellular organism development, and developmental biology. Finally, genes identified in both GO and Pathway analysis were used to construct a co-expression network to further define the potential function of these co-expressed genes. Therefore, our data may be useful in guiding further studies on the molecular mechanism of developmental regulation in the pathogenesis of EV71 and CA16-induced HFMD. Additionally, it provided novel candidate biomarkers or therapeutic targets for HFMD.
authors: Song, J.;Hu, Y.;Jiang, X.;Zhu, W.;Wu, Z.;Dong, S.

title: miR-1303 regulates BBB permeability and promotes CNS lesions following CA16 infections by directly targeting MMP9
abstract: Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) is a member of the Picornaviridae family and causes mild and self-limiting hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in infants and young children. CA16 infection may also progress to central nervous system (CNS) complications; however, the mechanism underlying CA16's penetration of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and subsequent CNS damage remains unclear. This study aimed to investigate the mechanism of CA16 neurotropic tropism by establishing an in vitro BBB model with CA16 infection and an in vivo CA16 rhesus monkey infant infection model. The results showed that CA16 infection induced increased permeability of the BBB along with upregulation of matrix metalloproteinase 9 (MMP9) expression. Next, high-throughput miRNA sequencing technology and bioinformatics analysis revealed that miR-1303 can regulate BBB permeability by targeting MMP9. We then used dual luciferase, qRT-PCR and western blot assays to provide evidence of MMP9 targeting by miR-1303. Further experiments revealed that CA16 infection promotes degradation of junctional complexes (Claudin4, Claudin5, VE-Cadherin and ZO-1), possibly by downregulating miR-1303 and upregulating MMP9. Finally, EGFP-CA16 infection can enter the CNS by facilitating degradation of junctional complexes and ultimately induce neuroinflammation and injury in the CNS, which was validated using the in vivo rhesus monkey model. Our results suggest that CA16 can penetrate the BBB and then enter the CNS by directly regulating MMP9 and downregulating miR-1303, which disrupts junctional complexes, ultimately causing pathological CNS changes. These results provide new therapeutic targets in HFMD patients following CA16 infection.
authors: Song, J.;Hu, Y.;Li, H.;Huang, X.;Zheng, H.;Hu, Y.;Wang, J.;Jiang, X.;Li, J.;Yang, Z.;Fan, H.;Guo, L.;Shi, H.;He, Z.;Yang, F.;Wang, X.;Dong, S.;Li, Q.;Liu, L.

title: Different microRNA profiles reveal the diverse consequences induced by EV71 and CA16 infection in human umbilical vein endothelial cells using high-throughput sequencing.
abstract: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) remain the predominant pathogens in hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), but the factors underlying the pathogenesis of EV71 and CA16 infections remain unclear. Recently, the functions of microRNAs (miRNAs) in pathogen-host interactions have been highlighted. In this study, we performed comprehensive miRNA profiling in EV71- and CA16-infected human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) at multiple time points using high-throughput sequencing. The results showed that 135 known miRNAs showed remarkable differences in expression. Of these, 30 differentially expressed miRNAs presented opposite trends in samples infected with EV71- and CA16. Next, we focused mainly on 30 key differentially expressed miRNAs through further screening to predict targets. Gene ontology (GO) and pathway analysis of predicted targets showed enrichment of 14 biological processes, 9 molecular functions, 8 cellular components, and 85 pathways. Regulatory networks of these miRNAs with predicted targets, GOs, pathways and co-expression genes were identified, suggesting that miRNAs exhibit complex regulatory mechanisms during the infection phase. In conclusion, we specifically analyzed hierarchical GO categories of predicted targets related to biological adhesion. The results showed that the different changes induced by EV71 and CA16 infection may be partially linked to the function of the blood-brain barrier. Taken together, this is the first report describing miRNA expression profiles in EV71 and CA16-infected HUVECs using high-throughput sequencing. Our data provide useful information that may help elucidate different host-pathogen interactions following EV71 and CA16 infection and offer novel therapeutic targets for these infections.
authors: Song, J.;Hu, Y.;Li, J.;Zheng, H.;Wang, J.;Guo, L.;Ning, R.;Li, H.;Yang, Z.;Fan, H.;Liu, L.

title: High-throughput Sequencing of Putative Novel microRNAs in Rhesus Monkey Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells Following EV71 and CA16 Infection
abstract: Objectives: Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) remain the major pathogens in cases of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), but the mechanisms of the different pathogens that follow EV71 and CA16 infection are largely unknown. Methods: Here, we used microRNA (miRNA) deep sequencing to investigate the roles of novel differentially expressed miRNAs in EV71 and CA16-infected peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). Results: The results identified 13 new differentially expressed miRNAs in each group. In addition, target genes were predicted by the miRanda and RNAhybrid programs, and a total of 2,501 targets were found in the two databases. Later, Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) enrichment analyzes showed that these targets are mainly related to cell development and that these targets are mainly related to nervous system development, system development, multicellular organism development, Wnt signaling pathway, PDGF signaling pathway and EGF receptor signaling pathway. Finally, a co-expression regulatory network was constructed with key targets to further predict the functional interactions of targets and their co-expressed genes. Conclusion: Our results not only revealed potential biomarkers or targets for the diagnosis and treatment of HFMD, but also provided new insights to explore the mechanisms of EV71 and CA16 pathogenesis.
authors: Song, J.;Jiang, X.;Hu, Y.;Li, H.;Zhang, X.;Xu, J.;Li, W.;Zheng, X.;Dong, S.

title: Evidence of human-to-swine transmission of the pandemic (H1N1) 2009 influenza virus in South Korea
abstract: As the pandemic (H1N1) 2009 influenza virus continues to infect human populations globally, reports of epidemiologically related animal infections are also increasing. Since December 2009, pandemic (H1N1) 2009-like viruses have been isolated in pigs from different pig farms of South Korea. Genetic and phylogenetic analyzes of viral segments demonstrated several events of human-to-swine transmission with no visible signs of reclassification. These events were also supported by serological surveillance in pig serum collected from April to December; this suggested that reverse transmission probably started between June and July and there was a drastic increase in prevalence in the following months. Although molecular characterization shows that porcine isolates are generally stable, some viruses are genetically engineered, particularly in surface proteins. Animal studies (ferrets and mice) reveal that swine pandemic isolates recapitulate the biological characteristics currently attributed to circulating human pandemic viruses, including replication kinetics and efficient transmission, and demonstrate the potential for these viruses to return to circulation among humans. Overall, these results indicate widespread human-to-animal transmission of pandemic (H1N1) 2009 influenza viruses in South Korea. Because of the important role of pigs in the ecology of influenza viruses, these transmission events must be closely monitored and minimized to avoid the risk of producing viruses of greater human health concern. Copyright © 2010, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Song, M. S.;Lee, J. H.;Pascua, P. N. Q.;Baek, Y. H.;Kwon, H. I.;Park, K. J.;Choi, H. W.;Shin, Y. K.;Song, J. Y.;Kim, C. J.;Choi, Y. K.

title: Chilo iridescent virus encodes a putative helix belonging to a separate family within the 'DEAD/H' superfamily: Implications for the evolution of large DNA viruses
abstract: The full nucleotide sequence of the EcoRI DNA fragment M (7099 bp; 0.310-0.345 map units) of the insect iridescent virus type 6-Chilo iridescent virus (CIV)- genome was determined. A 606 codon open reading frame located in this region encoded a protein (p69) related to a distinct family of putative DNA and/or RNA helices belonging to the 'DEAD/H' superfamily. Unique sequence signatures were derived, allowing the putative helices of the new family to be selectively retrieved from amino acid sequence databases. The family includes yeast, Drosophila, mammalian and bacterial proteins involved in transcription regulation and repair of damaged DNA. It is hypothesized that p69 of CIV may be a DNA or RNA helicase, possibly involved in viral transcription. A distant relationship was observed between this helicase family and another group of proteins consisting of putative poxvirus helices, African swine fever virus and yeast mitochondrial plasmids. The p69 of CIV has been shown to be much more closely associated with cellular helicases than any of the other known viral helicases. Phylogenetic analysis suggested an independent origin for the genes encoding the p69 gene and other viral helicases.
authors: Sonntag, K. C.;Schnitzler, P.;Koonin, E. V.;Darai, G.

title: Small RNA deep sequencing identifies viral microRNAs during malignant catarrhal fever induced by alcelaphine herpes virus 1.
abstract: Alcelaphine herpesvirus 1 (AlHV-1) is an Î³-herpes virus (Î³-HV) carried asymptomatically by antelopes. Upon interspecies transmission, AlHV-1 induces a fatal lymphoproliferative disease called malignant catarrhal fever (MCF) in several ruminant animals, including the bovine and rabbit model. Delay has been shown to be necessary for MCF induction. However, the mechanisms that cause the activation and proliferation of infected CD8+ T cells are unknown. Many Î³-HVs express microRNAs (miRNAs). These small noncoding RNAs can regulate the expression of host or viral target genes involved in a variety of pathways and are thought to facilitate viral infection and/or mediate the activation and proliferation of infected lymphocytes. Numerous miRNA encodings of the AlHV-1 genome have been predicted. However, their precise contribution in viral infection and pathogenesis in vivo is unknown. Here, using cloning and sequencing of small RNAs, we identified 36 potential miRNAs expressed in a lymphoblastoid cell line propagated from a calf infected with AlHV-1 and developing MCF. Among the sequenced candidate miRNAs, 32 were expressed in the reverse chain of the genome in the two main clusters. Expression of these 32 viral miRNAs was further confirmed in lymphoid organs of calves or rabbits developing MCF using Northern blot and quantitative reverse transcription PCR. A recombinant virus was generated to determine the concerted contribution of 28 viral miRNAs clustered in the non-protein-coding region of the AlHV-1 genome in MCF. The absence of these 28 miRNAs did not affect in vitro viral growth or MCF induction in rabbits; this indicates that AlHV-1 miRNAs clustered in this non-protein-coding genomic region are indispensable for MCF induction.
authors: Sorel, O.;Tuddenham, L.;Myster, F.;Palmeira, L.;Kerkhofs, P.;Pfeffer, S.;Vanderplasschen, A.;Dewals, B. G.

title: Adult fulminant subacute sclerosing panencephalitis: Pathological and molecular studies - A case report
abstract: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare progressive neurological disorder caused by a persistently defective measles virus that typically affects children. We present a case of fulminant subacute sclerosing panencephalitis in a 25-year-old man. Brain tissue biopsy showed histological evidence of encephalitis with eosinophilic intranuclear inclusion bodies (Cowdry Types A and B), intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, perivascular lymphoplasmacytic infiltration, and gliosis. Immunohistochemical studies using an anti-measles antibody were positive. Reverse transcriptase-PCR detected measles virus RNA and phylogenetic analysis showed a C2 genotype. The rare adult-onset form is often atypical and difficult to diagnose and should be included in the differential diagnosis of subacute "unexplained" neurological diseases and uncommon infectious disorders. Â© 2009 Dustri-Verlag K. Feistle.
authors: Souraud, J. B.;Faivre, A.;Waku-Kouomou, D.;Gaillard, T.;Aouad, N.;Meaudre, E.;Wild, F. T.;Fouet, B.;Soulard, R.

title: Pathological and molecular manifestations of avian avulavirus type 1 outbreak in pigeons (Columba livia) from southern Brazil.
abstract: Newcastle disease caused by avian avulavirus type 1 strains (APMV-1) is an important avian disease that causes high mortality rates and economic losses. Several outbreaks have been reported in different parts of the world over the last 30 years, caused by an adapted variant of AAvV-1 called pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1) in Columbiformes. A high mortality rate associated with an epidemic in free-living pigeons (Columba livia) was analyzed in a public square in Porto Alegre, southern Brazil. A total of 24 moribund or freshly dead pigeons were subjected to autopsy, histopathological, immunohistochemical (anti-Newcastle), and RT-PCR, five weeks apart, followed by sequencing of analysis of amplification products. They presented neurological manifestations, non-suppurative encephalitis and encephalomyelitis, and mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate in different organs. Immunohistochemical analysis in nine pigeon tissues showed that anti-Newcastle was expressed in brain, kidney, liver and pancreas. The RT-PCR test for the M protein of the Newcastle disease virus was positive in six pigeons. The differential diagnosis of Influenza, West Nile, Mycoplasma gallisepticum and Mycoplasma synoviae was negative in all pigeons. The sequence of amino acids in the cleavage site region of the F protein was 112RRQKRF117, which classified the strain as lethal. Phylogenetic analysis classified this virus strain as Class II and VI genotypes.
authors: Souza, S. O.;Fredo, G.;Dupont, P. M.;Leite-Filho, R. V.;Teifke, J. P.;Pavarini, S. P.;Canal, C. W.;Driemeier, D.

title: Viral diversity of Rhipicephalus microplus parasitizing cattle in southern Brazil.
abstract: Ticks are worldwide ectoparasites and are known to be vectors of many viruses of great importance to human and animal health. However, viral diversity in ticks is still poorly understood, particularly in South America. Here, we characterized the viral diversity found in Rhipicephalus microplus parasitizing cattle in the southern region of Brazil using metagenomics. Our study expands the biogeography of jingmen tick virus (family Flaviviridae), as well as revealing the presence of previously unidentified viruses in the region, including lihan tick virus (family Phenuiviridae) and wuhan tick virus 2 (family Chuviridae). Brazil. We also identified three novel thymoviruses (order Tymovirales), designated guarapuava thymovirus-like 1 to 3. We describe the genomic and phylogenetic characterization of these viruses. Our study sheds light on the viral diversity of Rhipicephalus microplus in South America and further expands the biogeography of tick viruses previously identified only in Asia.
authors: Souza, W. M.;Fumagalli, M. J.;Torres Carrasco, A. O.;Romeiro, M. F.;Modha, S.;Seki, M. C.;Gheller, J. M.;Daffre, S.;Nunes, M. R. T.;Murcia, P. R.;Acrani, G. O.;Figueiredo, L. T. M.

title: Characterization of low pathogenicity H5N1 avian influenza viruses from North America
abstract: For the purposes of early identification of the Asian H5N1 highly pathogenic AI virus, wild bird surveillance for avian influenza (AI) viruses in North America identified at least six low pathogenic H5N1 AI viruses between 2004 and 2006. The hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes from all 6 H5N1 viruses and an additional 38 North American wild avian H5 subtype and 28 N1 subtype viruses were sequenced and compared with sequences available in GenBank by phylogenetic analysis. Both HA and NA were phylogenetically different from viruses from outside North America and from viruses from mammals. Four of the H5N1 AI viruses were characterized as low pathogenicity by standard in vivo pathotyping tests. One of the H5N1 viruses, A/MuteSwan/MI/451072-2/06, was shown to replicate at low titers in chickens, turkeys and ducks. However, transmission of A/MuteSwan/MI/451072-2/06 was more effective among ducks than between chickens or turkeys due to virus transmission. For A/MuteSwan/MI/451072-2/06 and three other wild waterfowl-derived H5 viruses, the 50% chicken infectious dose was also determined, and the 50% egg infective dose ranged from 10 5.3 to 107.5. Finally, seven H5 viruses representing different phylogenetic branches were evaluated for their antigenic kinship by the hemagglutination inhibition assay, showing that antigenic kinship is largely related to geographic origin. Overall, the data support the conclusion that the North American H5 wild avian AI viruses are wild bird-adapted viruses of low pathogenicity and are antigenically and genetically distinct from the highly pathogenic Asian H5N1 virus strain. Copyright © 2007, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Spackman, E.;Swayne, D. E.;Suarez, D. L.;Senne, D. A.;Pedersen, J. C.;Killian, M. L.;Pasick, J.;Handel, K.;Pillai, S. P. S.;Lee, C. W.;Stallknecht, D.;Slemons, R.;Ip, H. S.;Deliberto, T.

title: Prevalence and phylogenetic analysis of hepatitis E virus in pigs, wild boars, roe deer, red deer and deer in Lithuania
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is one of the main causes of acute viral hepatitis worldwide. In Europe, foodborne zoonotic transmission of HEV genotype 3 has been associated with domestic pigs and wild boar. Controversial data exist on the circulation of the virus in animals used for human consumption, and to date no gold standard has yet been defined for the diagnosis of HEV-associated hepatitis. To investigate the current HEV infection status in Lithuanian pigs and wild ungulates, the presence of viral RNA was analyzed by nested reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-nPCR) in randomly selected samples, followed by viral RNA genotyped. RESULTS: Overall, 32.98% and 22.55% of domestic pig samples were HEV-positive when using RT-nPCR targeting the ORF1 and ORF2 fragments. Among hooves, 25.94% of wild boar samples, 22.58% of roe deer samples, 6.67% of red deer samples and 7.69% of deer samples were positive for HEV RNA using primers targeting the ORF1 fragment. Using primers targeting the ORF2 fragment of the HEV genome, viral RNA was detected in only 17.03% of wild boar samples and 12.90% of roe deer samples. Phylogenetic analysis based on a 348 nucleotide-long region of HEV ORF2 showed that all obtained sequences detected in Lithuanian domestic pigs and wildlife belonged to genotype 3. 3i subtype reference sequences from the GenBank database. Sequences from pig farms located in two different counties of Lithuania belonged to the HEV 3f subtype. Boar sequences clustered in subtypes 3i and 3h; this clearly indicates that wild boars can harbor additional HEV subtypes. For the first time, ORF2 nucleotide sequences from roe deer proved that HEV subtype 3i can be found in a novel host. CONCLUSION: The results of viral prevalence and phylogenetic analyzes clearly demonstrated viral infection in Lithuanian pigs and wild ungulates, thus highlighting a major concern for zoonotic virus transmission both in the food chain and through direct contact with animals. The unexpected diversity of HEV genotype 3 subtypes in Lithuania and neighboring countries suggested that further work is needed to understand the mode of transmission of HEV between animals and humans in the Baltic States region.
authors: Spancerniene, U.;Grigas, J.;Buitkuviene, J.;Zymantiene, J.;Juozaitiene, V.;Stankeviciute, M.;Razukevicius, D.;Zienius, D.;Stankevicius, A.

title: Physical and chemical characterization of an avian reovirus
abstract: The avian viral agent S1133 was previously serologically classified as a member of the avian reovirus group. This viral agent grows in chicken embryo fibroblast cells, forms bands with a density of 1.37 g/ml in CsCl equilibrium density gradients, has a particle diameter of 75 nm, and has a morphology similar to that of human reovirus type 3. It consists of double-stranded RNA and adenosine-rich oligonucleotides. The dsRNA is distributed among 10 segments with molecular weights of 2.7 x 106, 2.6 x 106, 2.4 x 106, 1.7 x 106, 1.5 x 106, 1.3 x 106, 1.2 x 106, 0.80 x 106, 0.74 x 106 and 0.68 x. 106 for largest (L1) to smallest (S4) segment, respectively, as determined by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. These 10 segments migrate differently on polyacrylamide gels compared to human reovirus type 3. The capsid proteins of avian reovirus are composed of eight types of polypeptides as determined by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. These are Î»1, Î»2, Î»3, Î¼1, Î¼2, sigma1, sigma2 and sigma3, and their molecular weights are 140, 125, 115, 85, 72, 40, 36 and 32 x 103, respectively. The polypeptide sigma2, found only in the inner capsid or core, migrated together with the sigma2 polypeptide of type 3 reovirus. Antiserum against type 3 reovirus did not neutralize avian reovirus. Avian reovirus core particles were found to have a transcriptase and a methylase activity.
authors: Spandidos, D. A.;Graham, A. F.

title: Dynamic balance of Marek's disease genomes during in vitro serial migration
abstract: Attenuation of Gallid herpesvirus-2 (GaHV-2), the causative agent of Marek's disease, may occur through serial transmission of a virulent domain isolate in avian embryo fibroblasts.
