To better understand the genes involved in attenuation and to correlate observed changes in phenotype with specific genetic variations, the genomic DNA sequence of a single GaHV-2 virulent strain (648A) was determined at defined transition intervals. Biological characterization of these "range isolates" in chickens has previously shown that the ability to cause transient paralysis is lost by passages 40 and after passage 80 the ability to cause persistent neurological disease coinciding with the loss of neoplastic lesion formation. Deep sequencing of range isolates allowed a detailed cataloging of mutations present in a single passage population and the frequency at which a particular mutation occurred between passages. Gross genetic changes were identified in both novel and well-characterized genes and cis-acting regions involved in replication and division/packaging. Deletions in genes encoding the virulence factors vLipase, vIL8 and RLORF4, as well as a deletion in the ICP4 promoter, appeared between passages 61 and 101. Three mutations were also identified in the virus-encoded telomerase that predominates in late passages. Overall, the frequency of mutations fluctuated greatly during serial crossing, and few genetic changes were absolute. This indicates that serial passage of GaHV-2 results in the generation of a genome collection with limited sequence heterogeneity.
authors: Spatz, S. J.;Volkening, J. D.;Gimeno, I. M.;Heidari, M.;Witter, R. L.

title: Dual natural infection with bovine viral diarrhea virus-1 and-2 in a stillborn calf: Tissue distribution and molecular characterization.
abstract: Dual infections with both bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV)-1 and-2 appear unusual. The aim of this study was to identify an infection with both BVDV genotypes in a stillborn calf. Virus isolation and phylogenetic analyzes of the 5Â´UTR and NS5B regions confirmed the presence of BVDV-1b and-2b in the spleen and lung, while BVDV-2b was detected in the brain, heart, liver, kidney and cavities fluid. These results confirm that dual infections with both BVDV-1 and BVDV-2 strains can occur naturally and their tissue distributions may differ.
authors: Spetter, M. J.;Uriarte, E. L. L.;Altamiranda, E. A. G.;Leunda, M. R.;Pereyra, S. B.;Verna, A. E.;OdeÃ³n, A. C.

title: Serological and virological studies of selected cattle with antibodies to bovine herpes viruses
abstract: To investigate the specificity of low-titer antibodies against BHV 1, twelve cattle were subjected to stress and dexamethasone treatment. They were monitored virologically by inoculating cell cultures with nasopharyngeal, ocular, and vaginal or preputial swabs, and serologically by assessing the prevalence and incidence of antibodies to bovine, goat, swine, and equine herpes viruses and bovine leukemia virus. Antibodies were classified as BHV 1-specific if animals secreted IBR virus or if antibodies neutralized BHV 1 and reacted with BHV 1 antigens, or also reacted with CapHV antigens. Animals whose greenhouses recognized BHV 1 and BHV 2 but not other herpes viruses were judged to have experienced both infections. Nine out of twelve animals had specific BHV 1 antibodies. With three animals, the question of the specificity of their antibodies remains open. Two animals had several herpes virus infections. Therefore, the induction of cross-reacting antibodies directed against epitopes common to herpes viruses could not be excluded. In ELISA tests, an animal's serum reacted with BHV 1 and BHV 4 antigens. However, they did not neutralize BHV 1.
authors: Spirig, C.;Ackermann, M.;MÃ¼ller, H. K.;Bruckner, L.;Kihm, U.

title: Orf virus infection in sheep or goats
abstract: Orf virus, a member of the Parapoxvirus genus, is the causative agent of infectious ecthyma ('Orf'). It is a worldwide spread pathogen that causes significant financial losses in animal production. The disease mainly affects sheep and goats, but various other ruminant animals and mammals have also been reported to be infected. It is also a zoonotic disease that mainly affects people who come into direct or indirect contact with infected animals (e.g. farmers, veterinarians). The disease is usually benign and self-limited, but in many cases it can be persistent and even fatal, especially in young animals. Production losses caused by Orf virus are believed to be underestimated as it is not a notifiable disease. This literature review provides the latest information on the virus; Issues related to treatment and prevention will also be discussed.
authors: Spyrou, V.;Valiakos, G.

title: Characterization of infectious bursal disease viruses from four-layer flocks in the United States
abstract: Twenty bursal specimens were obtained from four infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV)-vaccinated layer herds with immunosuppression problems thought to be infectious bursal disease. All samples were found to be positive for IBDV by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis of the samples identified them as classical molecular group 3 and group 4 viruses. Two samples were sequenced from each of the four flocks and within a flock these sequences were identical; however, some differences were observed between the herds. One virus from each of the four flocks was selected for further analysis. The VP2 hypervariable sequence region of GA-1, H-30 and CS-2-35 samples had nucleotide and amino acid similarities with the D78 and Vi Bursa G classical vaccines used in these flocks. The HPR-2 sequence was similar to the Bursa Vac 4 vaccine used in that flock and the STC lethal classical IBDV strain. The inferred amino acid sequence of these isolates revealed that all isolates have proline at position 222, which is characteristic of US classical viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of these isolates clustered GA-1, H-30, and CS-2-35 with D78 vaccine and HPR-2 with STC, based on the VP2 hypervariable amino acid sequence. The pathogenicity of these isolates was tested in specific pathogen-free chickens. Bursa-body weight (B-BW) ratios and histopathological lesion scores in the bursa were determined. Gross lesions were observed in Bursa, and the B-BW ratios of birds infected with all four wild-type viruses were significantly different when compared with the D78 vaccine and unvaccinated control groups. Histopathology of the bursa from the GA-1, H-30, CS-2-35 and HPR-2 infected groups showed varying degrees of follicular depletion and necrosis. A very mild lymphoid depletion was observed 5 days post-vaccination in the D78-infected group, and no microscopic lesions were observed in this group 8 days post-vaccination or any time in the unvaccinated control group. Bursa collected from birds infected with field virus and D78 at necropsy revealed the presence of IBDV by RT-PCR and the VP-2 hypervariable nucleotide sequences of GA-1, H-30, CS-2-35, HPR-. Samples 2 and D78 were identical to the original viral isolates and vaccine, respectively.
authors: Sreedevi, B.;LeFever, L. J.;Sommer-Wagner, S. E.;Jackwood, D. J.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of poly and nonstructural protein in Japanese Encephalitis virus with other related viral families
abstract: BACKGROUND: Japanese encephalitis (JE) causes inflammation of the brain. While the mortality rate from JE is 30%, 10-15% of patients recover fully. The disease is spread through the bites of infected mosquitoes that breed in rice fields and feed on pigs, birds and ducks. OBJECTIVE: Since proteins show significant structure-function relationships, the study was designed to perform the identification of poly- and non-structural proteins in the group of infective viruses using different strains of Japanese encephalitis virus (such as JAOARS982, Nakayama Strain SA (V), Strain SA). -14. METHODS: With reference to nonstructural proteins, we obtained the protein sequences of the following Japanese encephalitis virus groups: Japanese encephalitis virus, Weatnile virus, Kunjin virus. Further comparative and phylogenetic analyzes were performed to explore the evolutionary relationship between these groups. RESULTS: Using multiple alignments, Jal view, ClustalW (1.83) and ClustalW2, the alignment phylogeny score results were 375184. However, analysis between nonstructural proteins of Japanese Encephalitis Virus, Westnile Virus and Kunjin Virus revealed that the phylogeny alignment score via multiple sequence alignment and Tree view was 875, respectively. CONCLUSION: Phylogenetic analysis revealed that these four strains are related to each other and show high similarity with other viruses of this group due to conserved regions between their sequences.
authors: Srivastava, P.;Trivedi, A. C.;Tiwari, A.;Verma, A.;Pant, A. B.

title: Animal models of Ebolavirus infection
abstract: Ebola virus is a highly pathogenic member of the Filoviridae family that causes severe hemorrhagic disease in humans and NHP. The 2013-2016 West African epidemic sparked interest in the development and improvement of animal models of Ebola virus disease. These models are used to test countermeasures and vaccines, gain scientific insight into disease progression and transmission mechanisms, and examine the fundamental correlates of immunology. The Ebola virus is classified as a BSL4 pathogen and a Category A agent that requires the United States government to be prepared in the event of bioterrorism. Rodents such as Syrian golden hamsters (Mesocricetus auratus), mice (Mus musculus), and guinea pigs (Cavia porcellus) are the most common research species. However, NHP is preferred for Ebola virus disease research, especially in macaques, because of its similarity to humans in pathogenesis, clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and causes of death. To meet regulatory requirements for approval of countermeasures against high-result pathogens, the FDA has implemented the Animal Rule, which allows efficacy studies in animal models to replace human clinical data when such studies are not viable or ethical. This review provides a comprehensive summary of the various animal models and their use in Ebola virus disease research.
authors: St Claire, M. C.;Ragland, D. R.;Bollinger, L.;Jahrling, P. B.

title: Genetic heterogeneity of the classic swine fever virus in Central Europe
abstract: The aim of this study was to genetically characterize Central European isolates of classical swine fever virus (CSFV) and to evaluate the applicability of molecular analysis in the epizootiology of CSFV infections. Thirty-four viruses from Central European pigs or wild boars were studied. All of these viruses were detected by each of the three oligonucleotide primer sets designed for specific RT-PCR amplification of different genomic regions. Comparative sequence analysis of the PCR products showed that they were of a genetic type common in Western Europe. It was possible to subdivide the virus isolates into subgroups, which largely overlapped with the regions of origin in Poland, Slovakia, Hungary and Estonia. The technique's discrimination ability was improved by analyzing a composite dataset of all sequence data from all viruses. Using this approach, we were able to distinguish all viruses, with the exception of a single Estonian isolate grouped with viruses from eastern Poland, and group them in a way that exactly matches their geographic origin.
authors: Stadejek, T.;VilÄek, Å ;Lowings, J. P.;Ballagi-PordÃ¡ny, A.;Paton, D. J.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Comparative sequence analysis of the 5' non-coding region of classic swine fever virus strains from Europe, Asia and the Americas.
abstract: Polymerase chain reaction was used to determine the sequence of a 280 base pair fragment from the cDNAs of the 5' noncoding region of 29 isolates of classical swine fever virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the sequences revealed low-level genomic variation that correlated with the geographic origins of the isolates.
authors: Stadejek, T.;Warg, J.;Ridpath, J. F.

title: First detection of swine circovirus type 3 in commercial pig farms in Poland
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 3 (PCV3) is a new strain of circovirus recently discovered in the USA and China in cases of swine dermatitis and nephropathy syndrome, reproductive failure, respiratory disease, and multisystemic inflammation. This study reports the first European identification of PCV3 in serum of pigs from Polish farms. A total of 1,050 serum samples were collected between 2014 and 2017 from pigs and pigs 3-20 weeks old from 14 commercial farms representing different regions of Poland, different sizes and health statuses. Samples were pooled with 4–6 and tested for PCV3 by real-time PCR. PCV3 DNA was detected in 12 (85.7%) of 14 farms. In PCV3 positive farms, the virus was detected in serum pools of 5.9% to 65%. PCV3 was most prevalent among weaned pigs and finishers (26.1% and 28% of serum pools, respectively). Sequence analysis of the 359 nucleotide fragments of ORF2 showed the highest identity of 99.7% from USA to PCV3-US/SD2016. Our results show that PCV3 is a common virus among Polish pigs but has not been linked to unexplained disease conditions.
authors: Stadejek, T.;WoÅºniak, A.;MiÅ‚ek, D.;Biernacka, K.

title: Venezuelan encephalitis virus markers that distinguish enzootic strains of the ID subtype from those of IE.
abstract: Venezuelan encephalitis virus strains isolated from enzootic habitats during interepizootic periods in Central America and northern South America can be antigenically distinguished from each other by inhibition of hemagglutination. This test provided the basis for classifying these virus strains into IE and ID subtypes, respectively. The virus strains of these two subtypes were found to differ greatly in virulence for British shorthair guinea pigs. Studies have been described confirming that virus strains of the ID subtype are guinea pig virulent and that virulence is not the result of co-cycle subpopulations of epizootic subtype I-AB or IC virions. Two additional markers were found to distinguish subtype ID and IE Venezuelan encephalitis virus strains. First, hydroxylapatite chromatography of intact virions at pH 6.5 showed differential elution of the ID and IE prototype strains. Virions of subtype ID strains were eluted at 0.08 to 0.11 M phosphate, while virions of subtype IE strains were eluted at 0.15 to 0.20 M phosphate. Second, the isoelectric points of the E1 envelope glycoproteins of the ID and IE prototype strains were significantly different; pH 6.85 to 7.00 and pH 7.25 to 7.30, respectively. There was no significant difference in the isoelectric points of the E2 envelope glycoproteins. These distinctive features likely reflect a fundamental difference in virion surface structure.
authors: Stanick, D. R.;Wiebe, M. E.;Scherer, W. F.

title: Detection and molecular characterization of swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus in Lithuanian wild boar populations
abstract: BACKGROUND: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) is recognized as an important and economically devastating pathogen in pig production worldwide. Although PRRSV is common in domestic pigs, there is a lack of information about PRRSV infection in European wild boars (Sus scrofa). Currently available information does not provide conclusive evidence that wild boars are a reservoir of PRRSV. However, wild boars can be infected from domestic pigs through occasional direct or indirect contact. Also, wild boars can serve as a reservoir for infectious diseases of domestic pigs. Therefore, the objectives of the current study were to determine the prevalence of the virus and to further investigate the epidemiology and diversity of PRRSV strains in Lithuanian wild boars over a 5-year period. A total of 1597 tissue and serum samples from wild boars living in 44 regions and ten counties in Lithuania were analyzed for detection of PRRSV-specific vulnerability using conventional nested reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and real-time Taqman RT-PCR. reading frame (ORF) 1 and 6 sequences. RESULTS: PRRSV was highly prevalent in Lithuanian wild boar populations with an average of 18.66% using conventional RT-PCR and 19.54% using real-time RT-PCR. PRRSV was detected in 36.71% and 41.77% of 237 prey sites tested by conventional RT-nPCR and real-time RT-PCR, respectively. No statistically significant difference was observed in the prevalence of PRRSV by geographic area in ten Lithuanian counties. Animals infected with PRRSV have been described in all age groups; however, significantly higher prevalence rates were found in sub-adult and adult wild boars than in offspring up to 12 months of age. No positive results were obtained using conventional PCR with type 2 specific primers. Phylogenetic analysis of the partial ORF5 region revealed that ten wild boar harbored virus sequences belonging to genetic subtypes 3 and 4 and thus could pose a serious threat to Lithuanian pig farms where only subtype two strains are circulating. CONCLUSIONS: The results of virus prevalence and phylogenetic analyzes strongly support the role of wild boars as a possible natural reservoir for PRRSV in Lithuania.
authors: Stankevicius, A.;Buitkuviene, J.;Sutkiene, V.;Spancerniene, U.;Pampariene, I.;Pautienius, A.;Oberauskas, V.;Zilinskas, H.;Zymantiene, J.

title: Analysis of H1 subtype influenza A viruses from wild birds, turkeys and pigs in Germany reveals incidences of interspecies transmission.
abstract: Background Despite significant host species barriers, interspecies transmission of influenza A viruses among wild birds, poultry, and pigs has been repeatedly demonstrated. In particular, viruses of the H1 and H3 subtypes were transmitted among pigs and poultry, predominantly turkeys, in areas with high population density of both species. The seizure of the swine flu H1N1 virus from a turkey flock in Germany in 2009 prompted us to molecularly investigate recently detected subtype H1 viruses in wild birds, pigs, and poultry. Objectives The aim of this study was to investigate the relationship between H1N1 viruses originating from wild and domestic animals of Germany and to identify potential interspecies transmission or reclassification events. Methods Hemagglutinin and neuraminidase gene or full-length genome sequences were generated from existing H1N1 viruses selected from wild birds, pigs, and turkeys. Phylogenetic analyzes were combined with genotyping and analyzes of amino acid sequences inferred by biologically active regions. Antigenic associations were evaluated by hemagglutination inhibition reactions. Results Phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin sequences showed that viruses from different H1 subgroups circulate together between domestic animals and wild birds. In addition, these viruses contained different genotypes and were antigenically distinguishable. An H1N1 virus isolated from a turkey farm in northern Germany in 2009 showed the highest similarity to the bird-like pig H1N1 influenza viruses circulating in Europe since the late 1970s. Results The data demonstrate the genetic and antigenic heterogeneity of H1 viruses currently circulating in domestic and wild animals in Germany and point to turkeys as a possible bridge between avian and mammalian hosts. Â© 2011 Blackwell Publishing Ltd.
authors: Starick, E.;Fereidouni, S. R.;Lange, E.;Grund, C.;Vahlenkamp, T.;Beer, M.;Harder, T. C.

title: Circular replication-associated protein encoding DNA viruses identified in feces of various animals in New Zealand
abstract: In recent years, innovations in molecular techniques and sequencing technologies have resulted in a rapid increase in the number of known viral sequences, particularly those with single-stranded (CRESS) DNA genomes encoding circular replication-associated protein (Rep). CRESS DNA viruses are found in the viromes of many ecosystems and are known to infect a wide variety of organisms. The majority of recently identified CRESS DNA viruses cannot be classified into any known viral family, indicating that the current view of the CRESS DNA viral sequence space is greatly underestimated. Animal fecal matter has proven to be a particularly useful resource for sampling CRESS DNA viruses in an ecosystem, as it is cost-effective and non-invasive. This study used a viral metagenomic approach to investigate the diversity of CRESS DNA viruses found in the feces of domestic and wild animals in New Zealand. Thirty-eight complete CRESS DNA viral genomes and two circular molecules (which may be defective molecules or single components of multicomponent genomes) were identified from forty-nine individual animal stool samples. Based on their shared genome organization and sequence similarities, eighteen of the isolates were classified as gemycircularviruses and twelve isolates as smacoviruses. The remaining eight isolates lack significant sequence similarity to any member of the known CRESS DNA virus groups. This research adds significantly to our knowledge of the CRESS DNA virus diversity in New Zealand, highlights the prevalence of CRESS DNA viruses in nature, and reinforces the idea that the majority of CRESS DNA viruses have yet to be identified.
authors: Steel, O.;Kraberger, S.;Sikorski, A.;Young, L. M.;Catchpole, R. J.;Stevens, A. J.;Ladley, J. J.;Coray, D. S.;Stainton, D.;Dayaram, A.;Julian, L.;van Bysterveldt, K.;Varsani, A.

title: Extensive recombination, reclassification and transmission of unstable compound viral genotypes in natural arenavirus infections
abstract: Arenaviruses are one of the largest families of human hemorrhagic fever viruses and are known to infect both mammals and snakes. Arenaviruses pack large (L) and small (S) genome segments in their virions. For segmented RNA viruses like this, new genotypes can be created by mutation, recombination, and reclassification. Neither recombination nor reclassification in natural arenavirus infections has been conclusively documented, although an ancient recombination event is believed to have led to the emergence of a new lineage of mammalian arenaviruses. Here, we used metagenomic sequencing to investigate the viral diversity found in snakes infected with captive arena virus. We identified the complete or nearly complete sequence of 210 genome segments from 48 infected animals grouped into 23 L and 11 S genotypes. Most snakes were multiple infected, with up to 4 different S and up to 11 different L segment genotypes in individual animals. This S/L disequilibrium was typical: in all cases, intrahost L segment genotypes were more abundant than S genotypes, and a particular S segment genotype was dominant in individual animals and at a population level. We supplemented the sequencing results with qRT-PCR and virus isolation and isolates propagated as communities in culture. Numerous examples of recombination and reclassification were identified, including 2 intergenic regions and recombinant segments with unusual organizations with redundant content, capable of stable replication and transmission despite their atypical structures. Overall, this represents a degree and form of intra-host diversity that goes far beyond what is observed for arenaviruses or viruses in general. This diversity can plausibly be attributed to captive interbreeding of subclinically infected wild-caught snakes. Thus, beyond providing a unique opportunity to study arenavirus evolution and adaptation, these findings allow the investigation of undesirable anthropogenic effects on viral ecology, diversity and disease potential.
authors: Stenglein, M. D.;Jacobson, E. R.;Chang, L. W.;Sanders, C.;Hawkins, M. G.;Guzman, D. S.;Drazenovich, T.;Dunker, F.;Kamaka, E. K.;Fisher, D.;Reavill, D. R.;Meola, L. F.;Levens, G.;DeRisi, J. L.

title: Isolation and cloning of two variant papillomaviruses from domestic pigs: Sus scrofa papillomaviruses type 1 variant a and b
abstract: The healthy skin of two female domestic pigs (Sus scrofa domestica) was sampled with cotton swabs. Total genomic DNA was extracted from the samples and subjected to PCR with degenerate papillomavirus (PV)-specific primers. Similarity studies with BLASTN showed that the partial E1 and L1 sequences of the two novel PVs were amplified. Next, the complete genomes of these Sus scrofa papillomaviruses (SsPVs) were amplified by long template PCR, cloned and sequenced using a transposon insertion method. They contained the typical PV open reading frames (ORFs) E1, E2, E4, E6, L1 and L2, but neither viruses had E7 ORFs. The binary nucleotide sequence alignment of the L1 ORFs of the SsPVs showed 98.5% similarity, classifying these viruses as SsPV type 1 'variants' (SsPV-1a and -1b). Based on the sequential alignment of the E1, E2, L1 and L2 ORFs of SsPV-1 variants a and b, as well as 81 other human and animal PV-type species, a neighbor-joining phylogenetic tree was constructed. This phylogenetic analysis showed that variants SsPV-1a and -1b do not cluster with other PVs of the host species of artiodactyls (epidactyls), but cluster at the edge of the genus Alphapapillomavirus, which is very close to the root of this genus. © 2008 SGM.
authors: Stevens, H.;Rector, A.;van der Kroght, K.;van Ranst, M.

title: Small RNA cloning and sequencing strategy influences host and viral microRNA expression signatures
abstract: Establishing microRNA (miRNA) expression signatures is essential for investigating the role these regulatory molecules play in an organism's biology. Marek's disease virus 1 (MDV-1) is an avian herpes virus that naturally infects chicken and induces T-cell lymphomas. During latency, MDV-1, like other herpesviruses, expresses a limited subset of transcripts. These contain three miRNA clusters. Several studies have identified the expression of virus and host-encoded miRNAs from MDV-1-infected cell cultures and chickens. However, a high inconsistency was observed when comparing miRNA cloning frequencies from different cloning and sequencing protocols. Therefore, we analyzed the effect of small RNA library preparation and sequencing on miRNA frequencies from the same RNA samples collected during MDV-1 infection of chicken at different steps of oncoviral pathogenesis. Depending on the strategy used, qualitative and quantitative differences were found in the data. One of the mature miRNAs derived from the latency-associated transcript (LAT), mdv1-miR-M7-5p, showed the highest variation. Cloning frequency was 50% of viral miRNA counts when using a small scale sequencing approach. Its frequency was 100 times less when determined by the deep sequencing approach. Northern blot analysis showed a better correlation with miRNA frequencies found by the small-scale sequencing approach. By analyzing the cellular miRNA repertoire, we also found a gap between the two sequencing approaches. Collectively, our study shows that next-generation sequencing data taken alone is limited for assessing the absolute copy number of transcripts. Therefore, quantification of small RNA should be addressed by compiling data obtained using different techniques such as microarrays, qRT-PCR, and NB analysis to support high-throughput sequencing data. These observations should be considered when examining miRNA variations before addressing functional studies. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Stik, G.;Muylkens, B.;Coupeau, D.;Laurent, S.;Dambrine, G.;Messmer, M.;Chane-Woon-Ming, B.;Pfeffer, S.;Rasschaert, D.

title: Molecular and biological characteristics of avian polyomaviruses: Isolates from different avian species indicate that avian polyomaviruses form a separate subgenus within the polyomavirus genus.
abstract: The isolation and characterization of two avian polyomaviruses from chicken (BFDV-2) and a parrot (BFDV-3) have been reported. Both isolates are closely related to the non-mammalian polyomavirus budgerigar fledgling disease virus (BFDV) isolated from budgerigars (now called BFDV-1), and all three viral genomes were shown to have the same basic size of 4981 bp. However, a 151 bp insertion was observed in the noncoding region of BFDV-2, representing a complete copy of the left half of the noncoding region, including the putative early promoter and amino terminus of the large T antigen. With 15 base pairs exchanged elsewhere across the three genomes, these viruses have varying degrees of tropism for various bird species. The production of antibodies directed against a β-galactosidase-large T antigen fusion protein of BFDV-1 is described. These antibodies detected large T antigen with an M(r) of about 80K and small t antigen with an M(r) of about 24K in cells infected with BFDV isolates. These antibodies will bind with low affinity to the large T antigen of simian virus 40 (SV40), whereas antibodies specific for SV40- or mouse polyomavirus will not bind to the BFDV large T antigen. Antibodies directed against BFDV structural polypeptides exhibit broad, reciprocal cross-reactivities with all three structural proteins of mammalian polyomaviruses. The importance of polyomavirus infections in various avian species is discussed. Based on the unique structural and biological features, we propose that these viruses should be placed in a separate subgenus (Avipolyomavirus) within the polyomaviruses.
authors: Stoll, R.;Luo, D.;Kouwenhoven, B.;Hobom, G.;Muller, H.

title: Whole Genome Sequencing Shows Geographical Variation of Escherichia coli O157 Genotypes Dominates Host Association
abstract: Genetic diversity in an infectious disease pathogen may be driven by differences in ecological niches resulting from different host species and different geographic locations. Whole genome sequencing was used to compare E. coli O157 isolates from Scottish host reservoirs (bovine and sheep) and genetic variation (human, animal, environment/food) of isolates (human, animal, environment/food) from Scotland, New Zealand, the Netherlands, Canada and Canada. UNITED STATES OF AMERICA. Genetic distance of Nei calculated from core genome single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) indicated that the animal isolates were from the same population. Investigation of Shiga toxin bacteriophage and their insertion sites (SBI typing) revealed that cattle and sheep isolates had statistically indistinguishable rarity profiles, diversity and genotypes. In contrast, isolates from different countries exhibited significant differences in genetic distance of Nei and SBI typing. Thus, after successful international transmission that occurs in many cases, local genetic variation occurs, resulting in a global patchwork of continental and intercontinental phylogeographic branches. These findings are important for three reasons: first, to understand the transmission and evolution of infectious diseases associated with multiple host reservoirs and multiple geographic locations; second, emphasizing the importance of the sheep reservoir when considering farm-based interventions; and third, to improve our understanding of why the incidence of human disease varies around the world.
authors: Strachan, N. J.;Rotariu, O.;Lopes, B.;MacRae, M.;Fairley, S.;Laing, C.;Gannon, V.;Allison, L. J.;Hanson, M. F.;Dallman, T.;Ashton, P.;Franz, E.;van Hoek, A. H.;French, N. P.;George, T.;Biggs, P. J.;Forbes, K. J.

title: Detection and subtyping of foot and mouth disease virus in infected cattle by polymerase chain reaction and enhanced VP1 sequencing.
abstract: Rapid and accurate detection of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) outbreaks is essential to limit the spread of disease with appropriate vaccination. The use of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) has revolutionized the diagnosis of viral diseases. Sequence analysis of the amplified VP1 sequence can enable classification of the FMD virus detected in the diseased animal. 2 PCR assays were performed to determine the virus and its serotype in animals suspected of having an outbreak of FMD type O virus. Sequence analysis of the amplified VP1 cDNA showed 78% homology with O1K and over 95% homology between samples. These findings suggest that the 2 outbreaks were caused by infection with the same virus serosubtype.
authors: Stram, Y.;Molad, T.;Chai, D.;Gelman, B.;Yadin, H.

title: Expanding the conversation about high-throughput virome sequencing standards to include consideration of sources of microbial contamination
authors: Strong, M. J.;Lin, Z.;Flemington, E. K.

title: Increase in phylogenetic diversity of bovine viral diarrhea virus type 1 isolates in England and Wales since 2001
abstract: Currently, there are two known genotypes of Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV), type 1 and type 2. These genotypes are subdivided based on phylogenetic analysis, namely ap for BVDV-1 and ac for BVDV-2. In this study, the genetic heterogeneity of BVDV-1 in England and Wales was investigated and compared to the situation in 1996/1997. Viral RNA was extracted from 316 blood samples collected between 2004 and 2009 and previously identified as BVDV-1 positive. A region of the 5' untranslated region (UTR) was amplified by RT-PCR and the PCR products were sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis of 5'UTR, of five BVDV-1 subtypes circulating in England and Wales, namely BVDV-1a (244 samples), BVDV-1b (50), BVDV-1e (3), BVDV-1f (1) and BVDV-1i (18). Phylogenetic analysis of the nucleotide sequence for the Npro region of the viral genome supported the classification obtained by the 5'UTR. Given the fact that only three subspecies were identified in 1999, this report supports the idea of restocking cattle from continental Europe after mass culling and slaughter due to bovine tuberculosis infection during the 2001 FMD epidemic. Increased genetic diversity of BVDV-1 subtypes in England and Wales over the past 10 years. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Strong, R.;Errington, J.;Cook, R.;Ross-Smith, N.;Wakeley, P.;Steinbach, F.

title: Infectious Pustular Vulvovaginitis Virus Infection of Bulls
authors: Studdert, M. J.;Barker, C. A.;Savan, M.

title: A novel psittacid herpes virus found in African gray parrots (Psittacus erythacus erythacus).
abstract: DNA from a novel alphaherpes virus was amplified from a cloacal papilloma, a cutaneous papilloma and normal cloacal mucosa of African gray parrots (Psittacus erythacus erythacus). Phylogenetically, the virus was most closely related to the psittacid herpes virus, but exhibited sufficient nucleotide and amino acid diversity to be considered a novel alphaherpes virus. It is suggested that the previously described psittacid herpes virus be named psittacid herpesvirus 1 (PsHV-1) and that this new strain be classified as psittacid herpesvirus 2 (PsHV-2). It is speculated that PsHV-2 co-evolved with the African gray parrot and therefore must be found in the wild in these birds. © 2005 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Styles, D. K.;Tomaszewski, E. K.;Phalen, D. N.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of gansu sheep pox virus isolates based on the P32, GPCR and RPO30 genes
abstract: Two outbreaks of sheeppox occurred in sheep in China's Gansu Province. P32, GPCR and RPO30 genes were used as markers for differential diagnosis. We confirmed that the outbreaks were caused by the sheeppox virus. Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of the P32, GPCR and RPO30 genes revealed a close relationship between the 2 isolates and Chinese sheeppox viruses. Since sick sheep are imported from Jingyuan, another county of Gansu Province, our results strongly suggest the importance of veterinary surveillance before shipping.
authors: Su, H. L.;Jia, H. J.;Yin, C.;Jing, Z. Z.;Luo, X. N.;Chen, Y. X.

title: Liver rupture bleeding syndrome in chickens caused by a new genotype of avian hepatitis E virus
abstract: Since 2016, outbreaks of severe liver rupture bleeding syndrome (HRHS) in chickens have occurred in various provinces of China, causing huge economic losses to the poultry industry, but its etiological characteristics and pathogenic potential remain unclear. This study sequenced the partial helicase and capsid gene of potentially novel avian hepatitis E virus (HEV) isolated from chickens with HRHS and tested its clinical manifestations, histopathological changes, viral distribution, viremia, and pathogenicity in SPF chicks. viral spread was monitored 14 days post infection (dpi). The analysis revealed that HRHS-associated avian HEV belonged to a new genotype and infected chicks developed typical symptoms of HRHS. Thus, this study developed a successful experimental infection model to study the pathogenicity and role of the novel avian HEV in HRHS. Meanwhile, the new avian HEV was mainly present in the liver and spleen and caused a rapid viremia and chronic viral shedding in infected chicks and can cause 40% mortality before 14 dpi. In conclusion, this study found the new genotype avian HEV and confirmed its role in HRHS.
authors: Su, Q.;Li, Y.;Meng, F.;Cui, Z.;Chang, S.;Zhao, P.

title: Characterization of H7N2 Avian Influenza Virus in Wild Birds and Picas in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau Region
abstract: Qinghai Lake is a major migratory bird breeding ground that has recently experienced several highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAIV) epizootics. We examined wild birds and pikas of Qinghai for evidence of AIV infections from 2006 to 2009. We sampled 941 healthy wild animals and isolated seventeen H7N2 viruses (eight from picas and nine from wild birds). H7N2 viruses were phylogenetically closely related to each other and to viruses isolated in Hong Kong in the 1970s. We determined the pathogenicity of H7N2 viruses by infecting chickens and mice. Our results suggest that picas may play an important role in the ecology of AIVs by acting as intermediate hosts to which viruses are more adapted to mammals. Our findings of AI infection in picas are consistent with previous observations, raising the possibility that pikas play a previously unrecognized role in the ecology of AIVs of peridomestic aquatic environments.
authors: Su, S.;Xing, G.;Wang, J.;Li, Z.;Gu, J.;Yan, L.;Lei, J.;Ji, S.;Hu, B.;Gray, G. C.;Yan, Y.;Zhou, J.

title: Overexpression of Rybp Gene Inhibits Differentiation of Bovine Myoblasts into Myotubes
abstract: The RING1 and YY1 binding protein (Rybp) genes inhibit myogenesis in mice, but there are no reports of the effects of these genes in cattle. The aim of this study was to investigate the role of the Rybp gene on bovine skeletal muscle development and myoblast differentiation. In this study, the Rybp gene was overexpressed in bovine myoblasts via adenovirus. RNA-seq was performed to screen for differentially expressed genes (DEGs). The results showed that overexpression of the Rybp gene inhibited myotube formation. Morphological differences in myoblasts started on the second day and were very significant 6 days after adenovirus induction. After 6 days of induction, a total of 1311 (707 up-regulated and 604 down-regulated) DEGs were screened using RNA-sequence among myoblasts spiked with negative control adenoviruses (AD-NC) and Rybp adenoviruses (AD-Rybp). Gene ontology (GO) and KEGG analysis revealed that down-regulated DEGs were mainly involved in muscle-related biological functions, and those associated with muscle growth through 32 pathways were significantly enriched for the identified DEGs. By discovering the roles of the Rybp gene in myoblast differentiation, this study not only provides a theoretical basis for the regulation of skeletal muscle development in cattle, but also provides a theoretical basis for molecular breeding of beef cattle.
authors: Su, X.;Zhao, Y.;Wang, Y.;Zhang, L.;Zan, L.;Wang, H.

title: Isolation and genetic characterization of a novel adeno-associated virus from Muscovy ducks in China.
abstract: Adeno-associated virus (AAV; genus Dependoparvovirus, family Parvoviridae) was first discovered in 1965 as a contaminant in adenovirus preparations. AAVs are generally considered non-pathogenic and have the ability to reduce the replication of other more pathogenic viruses, making them attractive as potential therapeutic or preventive measures. This study characterized a novel AAV isolated from Muscovy ducks in China. The novel virus (MHH-05-2015) was isolated after spreading a field isolate of DAdV-3 virus (a type 3 duck adenovirus) in duck embryo fibroblasts. The complete genome sequence of MHH-05-2015 was determined, and its nucleotide and amino acid sequences were compared with other avian AAVs. The genomic distribution of structural and non-structural protein-coding genes in MHH-05-2015 was preserved and consistent with other AAVs. Compared to previously isolated avian AAVs, MHH-05-2015 had approximately 63 to 64% sequence identity. Phylogenetic analysis showed that MHH-05-2015 clustered separately from other avian AAVs, suggesting that MHH-05-2015 did not directly descend from other Dependoparvovirus family members. These results indicate that MHH-05-2015 is a new subtype of AAV that differs from other avian AAVs.
authors: Su, X. N.;Liu, J. J.;Zhou, Q. F.;Zhang, X. H.;Zhao, L. C.;Xie, Q. M.;Chen, W. G.;Chen, F.

title: Companion animals symposium: Microbes and gastrointestinal health of dogs and cats Review
abstract: Recent molecular studies have revealed complex bacterial, fungal, archaeal and viral communities in the gastrointestinal tract of dogs and cats. More than 10 bacterial phyla have been identified, with Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, Proteobacteria, Fusobacteria and Actinobacteria comprising more than 99% of the entire intestinal microbiota. Microbes act as a protective barrier against invading pathogens, aid digestion, provide nutritional support for enterocytes, and play a crucial role in the development of the immune system. Important for gastrointestinal health is their ability to ferment dietary substrates into short-chain fatty acids, predominantly acetate, propionate and butyrate. However, microbes can also have a detrimental effect on host health. Specific pathogens (eg Salmonella, Campylobacter jejuni and enterotoxigenic Clostridium perfringens) have been associated with acute and chronic gastrointestinal disease. Compositional changes in the small intestinal microbiota, potentially leading to changes in intestinal permeability and digestive function, have been proposed for canine small intestinal dysbiosis or antibiotic-sensitive diarrhea. There is increasing evidence that microbes play an important role in the pathogenesis of canine and feline inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Current theories for the development of IBD support a combination of environmental factors, gut microbiota, and host genetic susceptibility. Recent studies have revealed a genetic predisposition for defective bacterial clearance in Boxer dogs with granulomatous colitis. Differential expression of pathogen recognition receptors (ie, Toll-like receptors) has been described in dogs with chronic enteropathies. Similar to humans, a microbial dysbiosis has been described in feline and canine IBD. Commonly observed microbial changes are increased Proteobacteria (i.e. Escherichia coli) with concomitant declines in Firmicutes, particularly decreased diversity in Clostridium clusters XIVa and IV (i.e. Lachnospiraceae, Ruminococcaceae, Faecalibacterium spp.). This will show that these groups of bacteria, which are important producers of short-chain fatty acids, can play an important role in promoting gut health.
authors: Suchodolski, J. S.

title: Viruses detected in the cecum contents of healthy pigs representing a new genetic cluster in gengroup II of the genus 'Norwalk-like viruses'
abstract: Viruses of the genus 'Norwalk-like viruses' (NLVs) detected in humans are genetically divided into two main genetic groups, genogroups I and II (GI and GII), which together comprise at least 14 genetic subgroups. However, a comparable classification of other types of NLVs needs to be made. We sequenced a 2 kb region from inside the RNA polymerase gene to the 3–² end of open reading frame 2 (ORF2) of two NLV strains previously detected in the caecum contents of healthy pigs. All ORF2 sequences of these two NLV strains were analyzed for an additional two strains and their genetic associations with 15 human strains previously reported and used as references for genetic classification of human NLV strains; one is a recently reported human strain that appears to represent a novel genetic subset of GII; and the other, an animal NLV strain. Analysis of a matrix showing the binary identities and topology of a neighboring conjoining tree showed that the two porcine strains could be classified into a new genetic subgroup of GII on the basis of the amino acid sequences of the entire capsid protein. The grouping of the two pig lines is well supported by the results of similar analyzes of the nucleotide sequences of the entire ORF2 and the 510 base region at the 3-² end of ORF1. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Sugieda, M.;Nakajima, S.

title: Differentiation of respiratory syncytial virus subsets by cDNA probes in a nucleic acid hybridization assay
abstract: novel approach for respiratory syncytial (RS) virus subgroup determination using a simple nucleic acid filter hybridization technique has been developed. With this method, virus-infected cells are ligated and fixed in a single step, and the viral RNA in the fixed cell preparation is characterized by the ability to hybridize directly to cDNA probes specific to subgroups A or B of the RS virus. Subgroup-specific probes were made from cDNA clones corresponding to a portion of the extracellular domain of the RS virus G protein of a subgroup B RS virus (8/60) or a subgroup A RS virus (A2). The cDNA probes were labeled with 32P and used to analyze RS virus isolates collected over a thirty-year period. Replica templates of infected cell preparations were hybridized with the A or B subset probe. The subgroup assignments of the 40 viruses tested by nucleic acid hybridization were consistent with the results of subgroup determinations based on their reactivity with monoclonal antibodies, which was previously the only method available to determine subgroup classification of RS virus isolates. The nucleic acid hybridization assay has the advantage of providing broad-based discrimination of the two subgroups on the basis of nucleic acid homology, independent of minor antigenic differences detected in assays using monoclonal antibodies. The nucleic acid hybridization technique provides a reliable method for RS virus subgroup characterization.
authors: Sullender, W. M.;Anderson, L. J.;Anderson, K.;Wertz, G. W.

title: Evaluation of an epitope-blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for the detection of antibodies to influenza A virus in domestic and wild avian and mammalian species.
abstract: An epitope-blocking enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (bELISA) has been developed for the detection of antibodies to influenza A virus in taxonomically diverse species of domestic and wild vertebrates. Unlike previously published bELISAs, whose reagent generation requires end-user manipulation or has not been evaluated for use with both mammalian and avian species, this assay is performed using commercially available recombinant nucleoprotein antigen and the corresponding nucleoprotein-specific monoclonal antibody. and has been shown to work with multiple bird and mammalian species. The efficacy of bELISA as a serum screening assay was compared with the agar gel immunodiffusion (AGID) assay using 251 serum samples from experimentally infected mallards (Anas platyrhynchos) and raccoons (Procyon lotor). The agreement between the AGID test and bELISA was 94.1% (95% CI=89.9, 98.3) for raccoons and 71.2% (95% CI=63.5, 78.9) for mallards and 82.8% (95% CI=78.2, 87.3) overall. was. . bELISA was more sensitive than the AGID test, as demonstrated by the detection of antibodies to influenza A virus at earlier time points and at higher serial dilutions in experimental infection studies. The effectiveness of BELISA in monitoring natural influenza A virus exposure was also compared with the AGID test using an additional 745 serum samples from six bird species and six mammalian species. This bELISA provides a fast, reliable and inexpensive technique for large-scale surveillance of influenza A virus exposure in taxonomically diverse vertebrate species.
authors: Sullivan, H. J.;Blitvich, B. J.;VanDalen, K.;Bentler, K. T.;Franklin, A. B.;Root, J. J.

title: Viral metagenomic analysis of picobirnavirus-positive stools from children with sporadic diarrhea in China
abstract: Picobirnaviruses (PBVs) infect humans and a wide variety of animals and can cause diarrhea. The aim of this study was to investigate PPV infection and its association with diarrhea. Here, seven PBV RT-PCR positive stool samples from children with diarrhea and four stool samples from healthy children as controls were analyzed by viral metagenomics. The results showed that all seven diarrheal stool samples contained high titers of PBV arrays, three of the controls were negative and one had low titers of PBV. Three of the diarrheal stool samples were also positive for other viruses, including anellovirus, human gyrovirus, human parecovirus, and circular virus associated with pig feces. PBV sequences from seven patients were combined and produced seven large contigs with the full ORF of RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp). Phylogenetic analysis of the amino acid sequences of RdRp showed that the seven PBVs in this study belonged to three different genogroups. Our data suggest that PBV may be the cause of diarrhea in these seven children.
authors: Sun, G.;Zang, Q.;Gu, Y.;Niu, G.;Ding, C.;Zhang, P.

title: Epidemiological and genetic features of swine pseudorabies virus in mainland China between 2012 and 2017
abstract: An outbreak of false rabies (PR) on most Bartha-K61 vaccinated farms in China in late 2011 severely damaged the pig industry of one of the world's largest producers of pork products. To understand the epidemiological characteristics of the currently prevalent pseudorabies virus (PRV) strains in China, a total of 16,256 specimens collected from pig farms with suspected PRV infection in 27 Provinces of China between 2012 and 2017 were evaluated for PRV detection. Since the widespread use of the gE-deleted PRV vaccine in China, PRV-gE has been applied to detect wild-type virus infection by PCR. Of the 16,256 samples detected, approximately 1,345 samples were positive for PRV-gE detection, giving an average positive rate of 8.27%. Positive rates of PRV detection from 2012 to 2017 11.92% (153/1284), 12.19% (225/1846), 6.70% (169/2523), 11.10% (269/2424), It was 5.57% (147/2640). , and 6.90% (382/5539), respectively. To understand the genetic characteristics of currently circulating PRV strains, 25 PRV strains isolated from these PRV-gE positive samples were selected for further investigation. Phylogenetic analysis based on gB, gC and gE showed that PRV strains common in China have a remarkably different evolutionary relationship to PRVs in other countries; this may explain the observation that the Bartha-K61 vaccine does not provide full protection against emerging strains. Sequence alignments identified multiple amino acid changes in the gB, gC, and gE proteins of PRVs circulating in China after the epidemic compared to those from other countries or those common in China before the epidemic; these changes may also affect the protective efficacy of previously used vaccines in China and may be partly attributed to the increased virulence of current PRV epidemic strains in China.
authors: Sun, Y.;Liang, W.;Liu, Q.;Zhao, T.;Zhu, H.;Hua, L.;Peng, Z.;Tang, X.;Stratton, C. W.;Zhou, D.;Tian, Y.;Chen, H.;Wu, B.

title: Novel triple reassortant H1N1 swine flu viruses in pigs from Tianjin, northern China.
abstract: Pigs are susceptible to both human and avian influenza viruses and have therefore been proposed as mixing vessels for the generation of pandemic influenza viruses by re-diversification. In this study, we report for the first time the isolation and genetic analysis of three novel triple reassortant H1N1 swine flu viruses from pigs in Tianjin, northern China. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these novel viruses contain genes from 2009 pandemic H1N1 (PB2, PB1, PA and NP), Eurasian pig (HA, NA and M) and triple reassortant pig (NS) strains. This showed that reclassification between the 2009 pandemic H1N1, Eurasian swine and triple reassortant swine flu viruses occurred in pigs in Tianjin, resulting in the production of new viruses. In addition, three human-like H1N1, two classical swine H1N1 and two Eurasian swine H1N1 viruses were also isolated during swine flu virus surveillance from 2009 to 2013; this indicated that multiple genetic strains of porcine H1N1 viruses circulate together in the pig population. in Tianjin, China. The emergence of new triple reassortant H1N1 swine flu viruses may be a potential threat to human health and highlights the importance of greater continued surveillance.
authors: Sun, Y. F.;Wang, X. H.;Li, X. L.;Zhang, L.;Li, H. H.;Lu, C.;Yang, C. L.;Feng, J.;Han, W.;Ren, W. K.;Tian, X. X.;Tong, G. Z.;Wen, F.;Li, Z. J.;Gong, X. Q.;Liu, X. M.;Ruan, B. Y.;Yan, M. H.;Yu, H.

title: Separate evolution of virulent Newcastle disease viruses from Mexico and Central America
abstract: An outbreak of Newcastle disease (ND) in poultry was reported in Belize in 2008. Characteristics of the three virulent Newcastle disease viruses (NDV) isolated from this outbreak (NDV-Belize-3/08, NDV-Belize-4/08 and NDV-Belize-4/08) NDV-Belize-12/08, specific pathogen-free (SPF) was evaluated in chickens by genomic analysis and clinicopathological characterization. The results showed that all three strains belonged to NDV genotype V and were lethal as assessed by the intracerebral pathogenicity index and polybasic amino acid sequence at the fusion protein cleavage site. In 4-week-old SPF chickens, NDV-Belize-3/08 behaved like a typical velogenic visserotropic NDV strain, causing severe necrohemorrhagic lesions in lymphoid organs with systemic virus distribution. Phylogenetic analysis of multiple NDV genotype V representatives revealed that genotype V could be divided into three subgenotypes, Va, Vb, and Vc, and that all Belizean isolates tested belonged to the Vb subgenotype. Furthermore, these isolates are nearly identical to the 2007 isolate from Honduras and appear to have evolved separately from other contemporary viruses circulating in Mexico and clustered in a new clade within the NDV subgenotype Vb. Copyright © 2014, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Susta, L.;Hamal, K. R.;Miller, P. J.;Cardenas-Garcia, S.;Brown, C. C.;Pedersen, J. C.;Gongora, V.;Afonso, C. L.

title: Pig as possible source of human hepatitis E virus transmission in Thailand
abstract: This report describes a study that provides evidence of HEV transmission from pigs to humans in Thailand by applying molecular genetic analysis. Viruses from Thai patients were found to be closely related to Thai genotype 3 and swine hepatitis E virus. Based on the analysis of the 302-base-pair ORF2 fragment, the strains investigated belong to subgroup 3e and are closely related to the European strains. Pigs are suspected to be a source of HEV transmission to humans in Thailand, according to the results. © 2010 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Suwannakarn, K.;Tongmee, C.;Theamboonlers, A.;Komolmit, P.;Poovorawan, Y.

title: Potency of an inactivated influenza vaccine prepared from A/duck/Mongolia/245/2015 (H10N3) against H10 influenza virus infection in a mouse model
abstract: The H10N8 influenza virus became a public health threat when cases of fatal infections were detected in China in 2013 and 2014. Therefore, the genetic and antigenic characterization of H10 influenza viruses and the development of an appropriate vaccine are crucial to prepare for a future pandemic by H10. flu viruses. However, available information on these characteristics of H10 influenza viruses circulating in birds is limited. In this study, genetic analysis of H10 influenza viruses revealed that viruses recently circulating in wild birds in East Asia are genetically close to human H10N8 influenza viruses. Moreover, the antigenicity of H10 influenza viruses was stable among viruses circulating in birds. An inactivated vaccine has been prepared from A/duck/Mongolia/245/2015 (H10N3) that is genetically and antigenically close to human H10 influenza viruses. The vaccine induced sufficient neutralizing antibodies against homologous and heterologous viruses in mice. The inactivated vaccine induced sufficient protective immunity in mice to reduce the effect of the challenges of A/duck/Hokkaido/W87/2007 (H10N2) pathogenic in mice. This study demonstrates that an inactivated whole virus particle vaccine prepared from viruses isolated from wild birds would be useful against a future pandemic influenza by H10 influenza viruses.
authors: Suzuki, M.;Okamatsu, M.;Fujimoto, Y.;Hiono, T.;Matsuno, K.;Kida, H.;Sakoda, Y.

title: Ibaraki virus Rift-encoded RNA
abstract: Ibaraki virus, Omori et al. (1969a,b) were obtained from diseased cattle showing clinical signs of paralysis in the upper region of the digestive organs. This virus is an RNA virus and is similar to bluetongue virus in biological (Omori et al., 1969a,b; Matsumoto et al., 1970) and physicochemical (Inaba et al., 1970) features. The virion is 55 nm in diameter and the capsid consists of 32 capsomeres (Saito et al., 1972; Ito et al., 1973). There is no evidence of serological cross-reaction between Ibaraki virus and bluetongue virus (Inaba et al., 1970). It is unknown whether Ibaraki virus RNA is single-stranded or double-stranded; therefore, the classification of the Ibaraki virus is unclear. This article presents evidence that this virus contains double-stranded RNA. It should therefore be classified in the same group as the bluetongue virus, namely an orbivirus.
authors: Suzuki, Y.;Saito, Y.;Nakagawa, S.

title: Past, present and future of hepatitis E virus infection: Zoonotic perspectives.
abstract: The origin of hepatitis E virus (HEV) is not fully understood, but it is recognized as an emerging zoonotic pathogen. To date, HEV has been isolated from many animal species. The family Hepeviridae consists of two genera. The genus Orthohepevirus contains four different species (A, B, C, and D), each with different genotypes. Within the Orthohepevirus strain A, the host ranges of HEV-1 and HEV-2 are limited to humans, whereas genotypes 3 and 4 primarily infect a wide variety of animal species as well as being zoonotic for humans. Pig and wild boar species were previously thought to be the primary natural reservoir of HEV, but more recently rabbits have also been identified as major carriers. Moreover, the increasing number of HEV infections in the food supply chain underlines the important role of farming and food processing practices in limiting virus transmission. In particular, a Chinese commercial vaccine has the potential to protect humans and possibly animal reservoirs from HEV infection. This review summarizes the status of HEV infection in different animal species worldwide and summarizes the various modes of zoonotic transmission, with reference to interspecies transmission and recent vaccine developments.
authors: Syed, S. F.;Zhao, Q.;Umer, M.;Alagawany, M.;Ujjan, I. A.;Soomro, F.;Bangulzai, N.;Baloch, A. H.;Abd El-Hack, M.;Zhou, E. M.;Arain, M. A.

title: Studies on Porcine Enteroviruses. ii. Morphology of Cytopathic Changes Produced in Pig-Kidney Monolayers
authors: Szent Ivanyi, T.

title: Wide interspecies diversity in virulent and vaccine strains of alphaherpes viruses
abstract: Alphaherpes viruses are common in the human population and include herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV-1) and 2 and varicella zoster virus (VZV). These viral pathogens cause epithelial lesions and then infect the nervous system, causing lifelong delay, reactivation, and dissemination. A related veterinary herpes virus, pseudorabies (PRV), causes similar diseases in livestock that cause significant economic losses. Vaccines developed for VZV and PRV serve as useful models for the development of an HSV-1 vaccine. We present whole genome sequence comparisons of the PRV vaccine strain Bartha and two virulent PRV isolates, Kaplan and Becker. These genome sequences were determined by high-throughput sequencing and splicing and offer new insights into the attenuation of a mammalian alphaherpes virus vaccine strain. We found many previously unknown coding differences between PRV Bartha and virulent strains, including changes in GH and gB fusion proteins and more than forty other viral proteins. Interspecies variation in PRV protein sequences is much closer to previously observed levels for HSV-1 than for the highly stable VZV proteome. About 20% of the PRV genome contains tandem short sequence repeats (SSRs), a class of nucleic acid motifs whose length variations are associated with changes in DNA binding site efficiency, transcriptional regulation, and protein interactions. We find SSRs throughout the herpes virus family and provide the first global characterization of SSRs in viruses, both within and between strains. We found SSR length variation among different PRV and HSV-1 isolates, which may provide a novel mechanism for phenotypic variation between strains. Finally, we detected a small number of polymorphic bases within each plaque-purified PRV strain and characterized the effect of migration and plaque purification on these polymorphisms. These data add to the growing evidence that even plaque-purified stable DNA virus stocks exhibit limited sequence heterogeneity, which likely seeds future strain evolution. Â© 2011 Szpara et al.
authors: Szpara, M. L.;Tafuri, Y. R.;Parsons, L.;Shamim, S. R.;Verstrepen, K. J.;Legendre, M.;Enquist, L. W.

title: A new microplate neutralization test for typing herpes simplex virus
abstract: microplate serum neutralization test for the prediction of complement-demanding neutralizing (CRN) antibody was established as a first step to simplify the typing of herpes simplex virus (HSV). When guinea pigs are immunized with type 2 HSV, late sera can often differentiate HSV types better than hyperimmune rabbit sera, with the CRN titer against heterologous type 1 HSV much lower than the homologous titer. Sera from guinea pigs immunized with type 1 HSV cross-reacted to approximately the same level against type 2 HSV as did rabbit antisera. Guinea pig sera with minimal cross-reactivity were selected and their high dilutions (1:160) and their complements were added to serial 10-fold dilutions of virus in microplate titration of virus infectivity. Selective reduction of virus titer by both antisera can identify the type of HSV. No suspicious intermediates were found between a number of stock strains, including many fresh isolates. The typing result coincided with the result determined by a modification of Yang et al's method based on virus titers obtained with Vero and primary chick embryo cells. Plaque-based typing in chick embryo cells sometimes failed to identify type 1 HSV.
authors: Tada, A.;Yoshino, K.

title: Bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 is classified into different subgenotypes depending on the region analyzed within the viral genome.
abstract: Phylogenetic analyzes of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) were performed based on the nucleotide sequences of the 5â€² untranslated region (5â€²-UTR) and the E2 encoding gene. Thirty-six BVDVs identified from naturally infected cattle in the northern region of Japan were divided into three genotypes, BVDV1a, BVDV1b, and BVDV2, in the 5â€²-UTR phylogenetic tree. In a phylogenetic tree constructed from the E2 encoding gene, BVDV1c was identified and viruses classified in BVDV1c were included in BVDV1a in the 5â€²-UTR phylogenetic tree. Also, BVDV1a and BVDV1b in the E2-phylogenetic tree clustered more closely than in the 5â€²-UTR tree. These results indicated that phylogenetic analysis of the E2 gene is more useful for the identification of subgenotypes within BVDV1. Â© 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Tajima, M.

title: Molecular characterization of a novel hepatitis E virus (HEV) strain derived from a wild boar in Japan, which is quite different from previously recognized HEV strains.
abstract: While a consensus classification system for hepatitis E virus (HEV) genotypes is currently not available, HEV variants (JBOAR135-Shiz09 and wbJOY_06) from wild boars (Sus scrofa leucomystax) have been tentatively classified into two new genotypes (5 and 6). In a study of HEV infection among 566 wild boars caught in Japan between January 2010 and August 2013, we found 24 pigs (4.2%) with ongoing HEV infection: 13 with genotype 3 HEV, 10 with genotype 4 HEV and the remainder. pig had a new HEV variant (named wbJNN_13). The entire wbJNN_13 genome consisted of 7247 nucleotides, excluding the poly(A) tail, and was highly different from known genotype 1 to 4 HEV isolates from humans, pigs, wild boars, deer, mongoose and rabbits at 22.4%-28.2%, JBOAR135-Shiz09 and wbJOY_06% 19.6-21.9 and 40.9-46.1% isolates on the whole genome of rat, ferret, bat and avian HEV. Phylogenetic trees confirmed that wbJNN_13 is distantly related to all known HEV isolates. A Simplot analysis revealed no significant recombination among the existing HEV strains. These results suggest the existence of at least three genetic lineages, possibly of wild boar-specific HEV strains. Further studies are warranted to fully understand the extent of the genomic heterogeneity of HEV variants infecting wild boars. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Takahashi, M.;Nishizawa, T.;Nagashima, S.;Jirintai, S.;Kawakami, M.;Sonoda, Y.;Suzuki, T.;Yamamoto, S.;Shigemoto, K.;Ashida, K.;Sato, Y.;Okamoto, H.

title: Phylogenetic characterization of H5N1 avian influenza viruses isolated in Indonesia between 2003 and 2007.
abstract: The wide distribution of H5N1 highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses is a global threat to human health. Indonesia is the country with the highest number of human infections and deaths caused by these viruses. To understand the enzootic conditions of viruses in Indonesia, twenty-four H5N1 viruses isolated from poultry from 2003 to 2007 were phylogenetically characterized. Although previous studies have classified Indonesian viruses specifically into segments 2.1.1-2.1.3, our phylogenetic analyzes showed a new subsequence that did not belong to any of the existing segments. In addition, new reassortant viruses emerging between this new subclade and other generations were detected on Java Island in 2005-2006. H5N1 viruses were introduced from Java Island to Sulawesi, Kalimantan and Sumatra Island multiple times between 2003 and 2007, causing these viruses to spread geographically in Indonesia. These findings identify Java Island as the epicenter of the H5N1 virus spread in Indonesia. Â© 2009 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Takano, R.;Nidom, C. A.;Kiso, M.;Muramoto, Y.;Yamada, S.;Sakai-Tagawa, Y.;Macken, C.;Kawaoka, Y.

title: Line patterns of agar gel precipitate and pathogenicity of infectious bursal disease viruses
abstract: Twenty-nine strains of infectious bursal disease virus can be classified into three groups by line patterns of agar gel precipitate using two representative base antigens of strains F539 and G691. The precipitate line of the first group (16 strains including F539) did not merge with that of the G691 base antigen and a spur was seen. The line of the second group (2 strains) did not combine with that of both base antigens. The line of the third group (11 strains including G691) did not combine with that of the F539 base antigen. Each strain of the first group is highly pathogenic to chickens showing a mortality rate of 40% or more.
authors: Takase, K.;Uchimura, T.;Katsuki, N.;Yamamoto, M.

title: Novel Reassortant Avian Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Human, South Vietnam, 2014
authors: Takayama, I.;Hieu, N. T.;Shirakura, M.;Nakauchi, M.;Fujisaki, S.;Takahashi, H.;Nagata, S.;Long, N. T.;Odagiri, T.;Tashiro, M.;Kageyama, T.

title: A thymus cell marker in murine leukemia virus-induced lymphomas of rats.
abstract: specific marker for an immature thymus cell population in the rat was demonstrated by rosette formation between thymus cells and guinea pig erythrocytes. This method was used to classify rat lymphomas caused by murine leukemia virus. Of the nine Gross virus-derived rat lymphoma lines originating from the thymus, eight formed rosettes; Rat lymphoma lines induced by Friend, Rauscher, or Moloney virus originating from the thymus, spleen, or mesenteric lymph nodes did not form rosettes. The percentage of total cells that formed rosettes in gross lymphoma lines decreased with in vivo passages. If tumor cells are exposed to trypsin treatment, the tumor cells will form rosettes. Lymphoma lines devoid of rosette-forming cells did not show rosette formation after trypsin treatment. An immunofluorescence test showed that none of the lymphoma lines induced by the Gross, Friend, Rauscher, or Moloney viruses carried the surface immunoglobulin property of B cells. These results suggest that Gross lymphomas may be derived from the thymic cortex and that Friend, Rauscher, or Moloney lymphomas may be derived either from mature thymus cells (non-rosette-forming cells) or from a subpopulation of the B cell line. does not have a surface immunoglobulin G receptor.
authors: Takeichi, N.;Suzuki, K.;Kobayashi, H.

title: Swine influenza A viruses (IAV-S) in Vietnam from 2010 to 2015: multiple introductions of A(H1N1)pdm09 viruses into the swine population and diversification of genetic constellations of enzootic IAV-S.
abstract: From 2010 to 2015, active surveillance of swine influenza A viruses (IAV-S) covering 262 farms and 10 slaughterhouses in seven provinces in northern and southern Vietnam yielded 388 isolates from 32 farms; these viruses are classified as H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 subtypes. Whole genome sequencing and subsequent phylogenetic analysis revealed that the isolates represented 15 genotypes based on genetic sequencing of eight segments. The H1N1 viruses were all purely A(H1N1) pdm09 viruses, whereas the H1N2 and H3N2 viruses were all reassortant between 5 different ancestral viruses: H1 and H3 triple reassortant (TR) from North America before 2009 IAV-S human seasonal H1, human seasonal H3N2 and A (H1N1)pdm09 viruses. Notably, 93% of reassortant IAV-S retained M genes derived from A(H1N1)pdm09, suggesting some advantages for their host adaptation. Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo analysis revealed that multiple introductions of A(H1N1)pdm09 and TR IAV-S into the Vietnamese pig population drive the genetic diversity of the currently circulating Vietnamese IAV-S. In addition, our results suggest that a reassortant IAV-S with human-like H3 and N2 genes and an A(H1N1)pdm09 origin M gene is most likely to cause a human case in Ho Chi Minh City in 2010. Our present findings, human-pig-to-swine transmission and co-circulation of different IAV-S have contributed to the diversification of the gene constellations of IAV-S in Vietnam.
authors: Takemae, N.;Harada, M.;Nguyen, P. T.;Nguyen, T.;Nguyen, T. N.;To, T. L.;Nguyen, T. D.;Pham, V. P.;Le, V. T.;Do, H. T.;Vo, H. V.;Tin Le, Q. V.;Tran, T. M.;Nguyen, T. D.;Thai, P. D.;Nguyen, D. H.;Thi Le, A. Q.;Nguyen, D. T.;Uchida, Y.;Saito, T.

title: Whole-genome analysis of the European-type genotype 3 hepatitis E virus variant from a Japanese patient with autochthonous acute hepatitis E.
abstract: unique European-type HEV strain (HE-JA12-0725), which can be classified into the 3f subgenotype, was obtained from a 66-year-old Japanese woman with autochthonous acute hepatitis E, and its entire genomic sequence was determined and characterized. The strain HE-JA12-0725 shared the highest identity over the entire genome of 92.7% with a Spanish pig isolate (EU723514) and had a 111 amino acid long hypervariable region sequence identical to the 3f strains of European origin. The patient had consumed pork liver obtained by home delivery in Japan about two months before the onset of illness. These results demonstrate the circulation of rare 3f HEV strains in Japan.
authors: Takeuchi, S.;Yamazaki, Y.;Sato, K.;Takizawa, D.;Yamada, M.;Okamoto, H.

title: Avian avulavirus-1 complete genome sequencing assays
abstract: Background: Avian avulavirus-1 (AAvV-1, formerly Newcastle Disease Virus) is responsible for disease outbreaks in poultry and wild birds. Numerous whole genome sequencing methods have been reported for this virus. These methods included cloning, specific primer amplification, shotgun PCR approaches, Sequence-Independent Single Primer Amplification, and next-generation sequencing platform kits. Methods: Three methods were used to sequence 173 Israeli Avian avulavirus-1 domain isolates and one vaccine strain (VH). Sequencing was performed on the Proton and Ion Torrent Personal Genome Machine and, to a lesser extent, Illumina MiSeq and NextSeq sequencers. Sequence Independent Single Primer Amplification (SISPA) products sequenced via target-specific primers (SP) and Ion torrent sequencer had a high error rate and truncated genomes. All next-generation sequencing platform sequencing kits produced high sequence accuracy and near-complete genomic size. Results: High level of mutation was observed in intergenic regions between avian avulavirus-1 genes. Within the genes, multiple regions were more mutated than the Fusion region currently used for typing. Conclusions: Our findings show that whole genome sequencing by the Ion torrent sequencing kit is sufficient. However, when higher accuracy was desired, Illumina NextSeq and Proton torrent sequencing kits were found to be preferred.
authors: Tal, S.;Ben Izhak, M.;Wachtel, C.;Wiseman, A.;Braun, T.;Yechezkel, E.;Golan, E.;Hadas, R.;Turjeman, A.;Banet-Noach, C.;Bronstein, M.;Lublin, A.;Berman, E.;Raviv, Z.;Pirak, M.;Klement, E.;Louzoun, Y.

title: Evaluation of the wide-range PCR-electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (PCR/ESI-MS) system and virus microarrays for virus detection
abstract: Advanced nucleic acid-based technologies are powerful research tools for new virus discovery, but need to be standardized for broader applications such as virus detection in biological products and clinical samples. We used well-characterized retrovirus stocks to evaluate the limit of detection (LOD) for wide-range PCR by electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (PCR/ESI-MS or PLEX-ID), RT-PCR assays, and virus microarrays. The results showed that, in the absence of background cellular nucleic acids, PLEX-ID and RT-PCR had a similar LOD for xenotropic murine retrovirus-associated virus (XMRV; 3.12 particles per µL), but not virus microarrays. When virus was added to a background of cellular nucleic acids, the LOD using PLEX-ID remained the same, whereas virus detection by RT-PCR was 10-fold less sensitive and no virus could be detected by microarrays. Expected endogenous retrovirus (ERV) sequences were detected in the cell lines tested, and known species-specific viral sequences were detected in bovine serum and porcine trypsin. A follow-up strategy was developed using PCR amplification, nucleotide sequencing, and bioinformatics to demonstrate the presence of an RD114-like retrovirus sequence detected by PLEX-ID in canine cell lines (Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) and Cf2Th canine thymus). was due to defective, endogenous gammaretrovirus-related sequences. Â© 2014 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Taliaferro, L. P.;Galvin, T. A.;Ma, H.;Shaheduzzaman, S.;Williams, D. K.;Glasner, D. R.;Khan, A. S.

title: Circulation of highly lethal avian contagious bursal disease virus in Finland
abstract: In the spring of 2014, infectious bursal disease (IBD) was confirmed in a Finnish layer herd exhibiting clinical signs and increased mortality. Organ and blood samples were sent to Evira, the Finnish Food Safety Authority, for identification. IBD virus (IBDV) was detected in RT-PCR studies. Associated with increased mortality (7%-10%, worst case 30%) all chickens on six layer farms were diagnosed with IBD in 2014. Antibodies were detected by IBD-ELISA tests in chickens from both farms. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the causative agent of the 2014 IBD outbreak was a non-reassortant, highly virulent type of IBDV. Representative virus strains from previous IBD outbreaks in 1978, 1987 and 1993 were also included in the analysis. The strains isolated in 2014 and 1993 were very similar, indicating that a very lethal IBDV had been circulating in the country for over 20 years. Despite extensive phylogenetic analysis, the exact origin of viruses from 2014 and previous outbreaks remains unclear.
authors: Tammiranta, N.;Ek-Kommonen, C.;Rossow, L.;Huovilainen, A.

title: A general assay for whole genome amplification and deep sequencing of enterovirus A71
abstract: Enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) has emerged as the leading cause of major outbreaks of severe and sometimes fatal hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in the Asia-Pacific region. Outbreaks of EV-A71 have been associated with (sub)genogroup changes, sometimes accompanied by recombination events. Understanding the EV-A71 population dynamics is therefore crucial to understanding this emerging infection and can provide crucial information for vaccine development. Despite the public health burden of EV-A71, relatively few EV-A71 whole genome sequences are available for analysis and from limited geographic areas. The availability of an efficient procedure for whole genome sequencing will spur the effort to generate more viral sequence data. Here, we report for the first time the development of a next-generation sequencing-based protocol for whole-genome sequencing of EV-A71 directly from clinical specimens. We were able to sequence viruses of C4 and B5 subgenogroups, while RNA was successfully amplified from culture materials of various EV-A71 subgenogroups belonging to both genogroups B and C. The nature of in-host genetic variation was investigated in 22 clinical samples, revealing 107 positions carrying minor variants (ranging from 0 to 15 variants per sample). Our analysis of the EV-A71 strains sampled in 2013 showed that they all belonged to subgenogroup B5, representing the first report of this subgenogroup in Vietnam. In conclusion, we have successfully developed a high-throughput next-generation sequencing-based assay for whole-genome sequencing of EV-A71 from clinical specimens.
authors: Tan, L. V.;Tuyen, N. T. K.;Thanh, T. T.;Ngan, T. T.;Van, H. M. T.;Sabanathan, S.;Van, T. T. M.;Thanh, L. T. M.;Nguyet, L. A.;Geoghegan, J. L.;Ong, K. C.;Perera, D.;Hang, V. T. T.;Ny, N. T. H.;Anh, N. T.;Ha, D. Q.;Qui, P. T.;Viet, D. C.;Tuan, H. M.;Wong, K. T.;Holmes, E. C.;Chau, N. V.;Thwaites, G.;van Doorn, H. R.

title: Virome profile of rodents in Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, China: isolation and characterization of a novel Wenzhou virus.
authors: Tan, Z.;Yu, H.;Xu, L.;Zhao, Z.;Zhang, P.;Qu, Y.;He, B.;Tu, C.

title: Suppression of coronavirus replication by cyclophilin inhibitors
abstract: Coronaviruses infect a variety of mammalian and avian species and cause serious illness in humans, cats, mice, and birds, in the form of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), feline infectious peritonitis (FIP), mouse hepatitis, and avian infectious bronchitis, respectively. . No effective vaccine or treatment has been developed for the SARS-coronavirus or FIP virus, both of which cause fatal diseases. It has been reported that cyclosporin A (CsA), a cyclophilin inhibitor, can inhibit the replication of coronaviruses. CsA is a well-known immunosuppressive drug that binds to cellular cyclophilins to inhibit calcineurin, a calcium-calmodulin-activated serine/threonine specific phosphatase.
