Inhibition of calcineurin blocks the translocation of the nuclear factor of activated T cells from the cytosol to the nucleus, thereby preventing the transcription of genes encoding cytokines such as interleukin-2. Cyclophyllins are peptidyl-prolyl isomerases with physiological functions that have been described for many years to include chaperone and fold activities. Also, many viruses require cyclophilin for replication; these include human immunodeficiency virus, vesicular stomatitis virus, and hepatitis C virus. However, the molecular mechanisms leading to suppression of viral replication differ for different viruses. This review describes the suppressive effects of CsA on coronavirus replication. Â© 2013 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Tanaka, Y.;Sato, Y.;Sasaki, T.

title: Characterization of Akabane virus from the native bamboo rat in southern China
abstract: To identify the causative agents of 3 large-scale outbreaks of encephalitis and death among farm bamboo rats (Rhizomys pruinosus). Routine bacterial culture and identification were performed. There were no significant pathogenic bacteria isolated from the brain, heart, liver, spleen, lungs, or kidneys of diseased bamboo rats. Using PCR-based methods, we excluded the following as causative agents: smallpox virus, herpes virus, adenovirus, lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, rabies virus, and sendai virus. In addition, homogenate from diseased bamboo rats was subjected to viral metagenomic analysis that revealed 48506 filtered viral reads annotated to Akabane virus (AKAV) with >75% nucleotide identity, suggesting the presence of AKAVs in bamboo rats. Five novel AKAV isolates were successfully isolated and characterized. Furthermore, the newly isolated AKAV isolate was used to show that bamboo can reproduce severe encephalitic and pneumonic disease in rats and mice. The findings contribute to a better understanding of AKAV epidemiology and to the prevention and control of Akabane diseases in China.
authors: Tang, H. B.;Chen, F. L.;Rao, G. B.;Bai, A. B.;Jiang, J. J.;Du, Y. C.;Ren, P. F.;Liu, J. F.;Qin, S. M.;Yang, L.;Wu, J. M.

title: Metagenomics for the discovery of new human viruses
abstract: As physicians and epidemiologists increasingly deal with infectious diseases caused by new or previously unrecognized pathogens, there is a great need for modern laboratory techniques for the detection of new human viruses. There are many clinical syndromes in which viruses are suspected to play a role but in which conventional microbiology techniques routinely fail to reveal the etiologic agent. In addition, new viruses continue to challenge the human population due to encroachment of human settlements on animals and animal habitats, globalization, climate change, increasing numbers of immunocompromised people and bioterrorism. Metagenomics-based tools such as microarrays and high-throughput sequencing are ideal for responding to these challenges. Pan-viral microarrays containing representative sequences from all known viruses were used to detect novel and distantly related variants of known viruses. Sequencing-based methods have also been used successfully to detect novel viruses and have the potential to detect the entire virus spectrum, including those found in low numbers. Â© 2010 Future Medicine Ltd.
authors: Tang, P.;Chiu, C.

title: Molecular evolution of Japanese encephalitis virus isolated from pigs in Oita, Japan between 1980-2009
abstract: To identify patterns of genetic variation in strains of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) circulating in Oita, the full envelope (E) gene was sequenced for 35 isolates from pigs over a 30-year period. Based on nucleotide and inferred amino acid sequences, genetic variation was examined, phylogeny estimated and selection pressures were also analyzed. This study showed that the major genotype (G) of JEV isolates shifted from GIII to GI in the mid-1990s in Oita. The intensities of selection acting on Oita GIII and GI strains were found to be almost the same. He suggests that such a genotype shift observed in Oita may not be due to selection intensity. Pairwise comparisons revealed high conservation of the E gene at the protein level. Compared with Oita GIII strains, all Oita GI strains shared four amino acid changes in E129 (TM), E222 (AS), E327 (ST), and E366 (AS). Among all 70 JEV isolates covered in this manuscript, the GI strains shared only one amino acid change in E222 (AS) compared with the GIII strains. No strong evidence for positive selection was found, JEV evolution was generally subjected to strong purifying selection, but an ongoing evolutionary pathway in Oita was found to be under relaxed purifying selection. This work is a localized example of JEV molecular evolution in nature. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Tang, W. F.;Ogawa, M.;Eshita, Y.;Aono, H.;Makino, Y.

title: Isolation and characterization of H3N2 influenza A virus from turkeys
abstract: Five 34-week-old turkey brood eggs from a single farm in Ohio, in separate houses of 2550 birds each, experienced a decline in egg production from late January to early February 2004. Tracheal swabs (n = 60), cloacal swabs (n = 50), and convalescent serum from flocks (n = 110) were sent to the laboratory for diagnosis. Virus isolation was attempted in specific pathogen-free embryonated chicken eggs and Vero and MDCK cells. Virus characterization was performed using agar gel immunodiffusion, hemagglutination test, hemagglutination inhibition test, virus neutralization test, reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction, sequencing, and phylogenetic analysis. A possible influenza virus was successfully spread and isolated on first pass in MDCK cells, but not initially in Vero cells or specific pathogen-free chicken embryos. After two passages in MDCK cells, it was possible to propagate the isolate in specific pathogen-free chicken embryos. Preliminary sequence analysis of the isolated virus confirmed that it was influenza A virus with almost 100% (235/236) identity with the matrix gene of a porcine influenza A virus, A/Swine/Illinois/100084/01 (H1N2). However, it was not possible to determine the subtype of the virus using conventional serotyping methods. The results of the genetic characterization of the isolated virus showed that it was the H3N2 subtype and designated as A/Turkey/OH/313053/04 (H3N2). Phylogenetic analysis of eight gene segments of the virus showed that isolate A/Turkey/OH/313053/04 (H3N2) was most closely related to triple reassortant H3N2 porcine viruses [A/Swine/WI/ 14094/99 (H3N2)] from avian, porcine, and human viruses. circulating among pigs in the United States since 1998. A/Turkey/OH/313053/04 (H3N2) isolated from turkeys in this study was classified as low pathogenic avian influenza A virus because it caused a decrease in egg production with only other minor clinical manifestations and no death.
authors: Tang, Y.;Lee, C. W.;Zhang, Y.;Senne, D. A.;Dearth, R.;Byrum, B.;Perez, D. R.;Suarez, D. L.;Saif, Y. M.

title: Detection and characterization of two co-infection variant strains of avian orthreovirus (ARV) in young laying hens using next-generation sequencing (NGS).
abstract: Using next-generation sequencing (NGS) for whole genomic characterization studies of nascent avian orthoreovirus (ARV) field strains isolated in Pennsylvania poultry, we identified two co-infected ARV variant strains from an ARV isolate from ARV-affected young laying hens. . De novo assembly of ARV reads 19 contigs generated from two different ARV variant strains based on 10 genome segments of each ARV strain. The two variants had the same M2 segment. The complete genomes of each of the two variant strains were 23,493-bp in length, and the 10 dsRNA segments encoding 12 viral proteins ranged from 1192-bp (S4) to 3958-bp (L1). Sequence comparison of nucleotide (nt) and amino acid (aa) sequences of all 10 genome segments, 58.1-100% and 51.4-100% aa identity between the two variant strains and 54.3-89.4% and 49.5-98.1% aa identity between revealed. two variants and the classic vaccine strain. Phylogenetic analysis revealed a moderate to significant nt sequence difference between the two variants and the ARV reference strain. These findings demonstrated the first naturally occurring co-infection of two ARV variants in commercial laying hens, providing scientific evidence that multiple strains of ARVs can co-exist in a single chicken species.
authors: Tang, Y.;Lin, L.;Sebastian, A.;Lu, H.

title: Genomic characterization of a novel avian arthritis orthreovirus variant by next-generation sequencing.
abstract: Using next-generation sequencing (NGS) technology, we identified a distinct avian orthoreovirus (ARV) domain variant (Reo/PA/Broiler/15511/13 or PA15511) isolated from broilers with viral arthritis in Pennsylvania in 2013. The complete genome of the PA15511 domain strain was 23,495 bp in length with 10 dsRNA segments encoding 12 viral proteins. The lengths of the genomic segments ranged from 1192Â bp (S4) to 3958Â bp (L1). Genomic analysis revealed that this virus differed from reference ARV strains and met the criteria for a novel or novel strain.
authors: Tang, Y.;Lu, H.

title: Genomic characterization of a turkey reovirus domain strain by Next Generation Sequencing
abstract: Genome of turkey arthritis reovirus (TARV) field strain (Reo/PA/Turkey/22342/13) isolated from a turkey flock in Pennsylvania (PA) in 2013, Illumina MiSeq platform. The genome of the PA TARV domain strain was 23,496bp in length with 10 dsRNA segments encoding 12 viral proteins. The lengths of the genomic segments ranged from 1192bp (S4) to 3959bp (L1). The 5' and 3' conserved terminal sequences of the PA TARV domain type were similar to two recently published Minnesota (MN) TARVs (MN9 and MN10) and avian orthoreovirus (ARV) reference strains. Phylogenetic analysis of the nucleotide sequences of all 10 genome segments revealed a low to significant nucleotide sequence difference between the PA TARV domain type and the reference TARV and ARV strains. Analysis of the PA TARV sequence indicates that this PA TARV domain strain is a unique strain and differs from TARV MN9 or MN10 in M2 segment genes and ARV S1133 vaccine strain.
authors: Tang, Y.;Lu, H.;Sebastian, A.;Yeh, Y. T.;Praul, C. A.;Albert, I. U.;Zheng, S. Y.

title: Open reading frames 1a and 1b of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) jointly initiate viral negative-strand RNA synthesis
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) poses a persistent threat to the swine industry, especially when highly pathogenic PRRSV (HP-PRRSV) emerges. Previous studies have shown that PRRSV RNA synthesis correlates with HP-PRRSV virulence. PRRSV RNA synthesis includes genomic RNA and subgenomic mRNA, and these processes require minus-stranded RNA as template. However, the mechanisms involved in PRRSV minus-stranded RNA synthesis are not fully understood. A mini-genome system can be used to evaluate viral replication mechanisms and to evaluate the effects of potential antiviral drugs on viral replicase activities. In this study, we developed a mini-genome system using firefly luciferase as a reporter. Based on this system, we found that the PRRSV RNA-dependent RNA polymerase nsp9 alone failed to activate virus minus-stranded RNA synthesis. We also show that combinations of open reading frames 1a (ORF1a) and ORF1b are required for viral minus-stranded RNA synthesis.
authors: Tang, Y. D.;Fang, Q. Q.;Liu, J. T.;Wang, T. Y.;Wang, Y.;Tao, Y.;Liu, Y. G.;Cai, X. H.

title: Combining Comprehensive Analysis of Off-site Lambda Phage Integration with a CRISPR-Based Tool to Identify Downstream Physiology
abstract: During the lysogenic life cycle, the phage genome is integrated into the host chromosome by site-specific recombination. In this report, we analyze lambda phage integration into non-canonical sites using next-generation sequencing and target more than 300 unique sites in the host Escherichia coli genome, demonstrating that it generates significant genetic diversity. Furthermore, these integration events can have important phenotypic consequences for the host, including changes in cell motility and increased antibiotic resistance. More importantly, the new technologies we developed to enable this work – sequencing secondary sites using next-generation sequencing and then selecting lysogens of interest using clustered regularly spaced short palindromic repeat (CRISPR)/Cas9-based selection – are broadly applicable to other phage bacteria systems. IMPORTANCE Bacteriophages play an important role in bacterial evolution through lysogeny, in which the phage genome is integrated into the host chromosome. While phage integration usually occurs at a specific location of the host chromosome, it is known to occur at other locations, called secondary sites. In this study, we developed a new experimental technology to comprehensively study the secondary integration sites and discovered that the phage can integrate over 300 unique regions in the host genome, resulting in significant genetic diversity in bacteria. We further developed an assay to examine the phenotypic consequences of such diverse integration events and found that phage integration can result in changes in evolutionarily relevant traits such as increases in bacterial motility and antibiotic resistance. More importantly, our method can be easily applied to other phage-bacteria systems.
authors: Tanouchi, Y.;Covert, M. W.

title: A metagenomic approach to characterize temperate bacteriophage populations from patients with Cystic Fibrosis and Non-Cystic Fibrosis bronchiectasis.
abstract: Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Pa), normally a soil commensal, is an important opportunistic pathogen for Cystic Fibrosis (CF) and Non-Cystic Fibrosis Bronchiectasis (nCFBR). Persistent infection is associated with accelerated decline in lung function and premature death. Horizontal transfer of DNA by temperate bacteriophages can add gene function and selective advantages to bacterial hosts in the restricted environment of the lower lung. In this study, we chemically induced temperate bacteriophages from clonal cultures of Pa and determined their mixed viral communities using metagenomic approaches. We compared 92 temperate phage metagenomes classified from these clinical backgrounds (47 CF and 45 nCFBR Pa isolates) using MG-RAST and GeneWise2. KEGG analysis shows that the complexity of temperate phage accessory gene carriage increases with duration and severity of disease. We also detect the presence of Ig-like motifs in phage structural genes linked to bacterial adhesion and carbohydrate binding, including Big_2, He_Pig and Fn3. This study provides initial clinical support for the proposed bacteriophage adhesion to the mucus (BAM) model and evolution of phages interacting on these mucosal surfaces over time.
authors: Tariq, M. A.;Everest, F. L. C.;Cowley, L. A.;De Soyza, A. D.;Holt, G. S.;Bridge, S. H.;Perry, A.;Perry, J. D.;Bourke, S. J.;Cummings, S. P.;Lanyon, C. V.;Barr, J. J.;Smith, D. L.

title: Genetically Different High Pathogenicity Avian Influenza A(H5N1) Viruses in West Africa, 2015
abstract: To track the evolution of the highly pathogenic influenza A(H5N1) virus in West Africa, we sequenced the genomes of 43 viruses collected in 2015 from poultry and wild birds in 5 countries. In section 2.3.2.1c we found 2 genetic groups circulating together. Mutations that could increase adaptation to mammals raise concerns about possible risk to humans.
authors: Tassoni, L.;Fusaro, A.;Milani, A.;Lemey, P.;Awuni, J. A.;Sedor, V. B.;Dogbey, O.;Commey, A. N.;Meseko, C.;Joannis, T.;Minoungou, G. L.;Ouattara, L.;Haido, A. M.;Cisse-Aman, D.;Couacy-Hymann, E.;Dauphin, G.;Cattoli, G.;Monne, I.

title: Fifth annual meeting on retroviruses
abstract: The fifth annual meeting of the RNA tumor virus group on retrovirus was held in October 1977. More than 100 scientists from France, Belgium and Switzerland and a few more from England, Italy and the United States attended this meeting. They discussed their project and interpretation of results on: Virus cell interaction (cellular changes, oncornavirus and cell differentiation, endogenous viruses); morphogenesis and genetic analysis; cellular restraint against virus infection; and proviral DNA (characterization and gene expression). Some topics are also relevant to research in human and bovine leukemias.
authors: Tavitian, A.

title: Epidemiology of ruminant peste des petits in the Sultanate of Oman
abstract: Virological and serological evidence was obtained to show that Pest des petits ruminant virus is widely distributed in Oman sheep and goats. There was no evidence of the simultaneous presence of rinderpest virus in these species. The two virus isolates were classified as peste des petits ruminant virus on the basis of their pathogenicity in experimental animals and their specific hybridization with nucleic acid probes. However, neutralization tests of nucleocapsid proteins and polyacrylamide gel analysis showed that they were not the same as the highly conserved African strains of this virus.
authors: Taylor, W. P.;al Busaidy, S.;Barrett, T.

title: Virology, serology and demography of hepatitis e viremic blood donors in South East England
abstract: BACKGROUND Hepatitis E virus (HEV) Genotype 3 (G3) in the UK consists of two main phylogenetic groups (Group 1 and Group 2) and can be transmitted by transfusion. Unselected screening identified 79 viremic donors; 76 participated in a follow-up study. STUDY DESIGN AND METHODS Viral RNA dynamics, phylogenetics, and seroconversion in donors were characterized. Detailed demographic, travel, clinical, and lifestyle surveys were conducted. RESULTS Most viremic individuals (57/79) were seronegative at donation, but all were seroconverted. Viremia was short-lived, with a median of 6.5 weeks until viral clearance was confirmed. All infections were acquired in the UK and were G3, Group 2 viruses predominant (43/54; 80%). Infection was associated with some clinical symptoms both during and after donation (8/77; 10%). Viral loads and symptoms were more prominent in Group 1 infections. There was no serological evidence of reinfection. Donors were mostly male (p = 0.002); both male and female donors were older than comparative donors. Contact with animals was unlikely to be a source of infection. Consumption of chicken and pork was common in all infected donors; processed pork was most commonly purchased from a particular retail chain. CONCLUSION Viremic donors represent primary infection in older members of the population and reflect a common zoonotic disease in the UK. The two phylogenetic groups of HEV G3 exhibit different pathogenicity and the more common Group 2 appears to be less adapted to humans. There are no objective demographic criteria to identify donors at increased risk of HEV.
authors: Tedder, R. S.;Tettmar, K. I.;Brailsford, S. R.;Said, B.;Ushiro-Lumb, I.;Kitchen, A.;Morgan, D.;Lattimore, S.;Tossell, J.;Ijaz, S.;Hewitt, P. E.

title: Increased Prevalence of Anellovirus in Pediatric Patients with Fever
abstract: The Anelloviridae family consists of non-enveloped, circular, single-stranded DNA viruses. Three anellovirus strains, TTV, TTMDV, and TTMV, are known to infect humans. Although anelloviruses were initially thought to cause non-AG viral hepatitis, ongoing research to date has not demonstrated a definitive association between anellovirus and human disease. Using high-throughput sequencing, we investigated the association between anelloviruses and fever in pediatric patients aged 2-36 months. Although anellovirus was found in large numbers of samples from both febrile and febrile patients, we determined that they were more prevalent in plasma and nasopharyngeal (NP) samples from febrile patients compared with febrile controls. Using PCR to detect each of the three anellovirus strains that infect humans, we found that the anellovirus strains TTV and TTMDV were more prevalent in plasma and NP samples of patients with fever compared with controls without fever. This was not the case for TTMV strains found in similar percentages of febrile and nonfebrile patient samples. Analysis of patient age showed that the percentage of anellovirus-containing plasma and NP samples increased with age until patients were 19-24 months old, followed by a decrease in the percentage of anellovirus-positive patient samples. This trend was striking for TTV and TTMDV and very modest for TTMV in both plasma and NP samples. Finally, the frequency of detection of TTV and TTMDV increased as the fever of febrile patients increased. Again, TTMV was equally present in both febrile and febrile patient samples. Taken together, these data show that the human anellovirus strains TTV and TTMDV are associated with fever in children, while the highly associated human anellovirus TTMV is not associated with fever.
authors: TeKippe, E. M.;Wylie, K. M.;Deych, E.;Sodergren, E.;Weinstock, G.;Storch, G. A.

title: Viral metagenomics on animals as a tool for the detection of zoonoses prior to human infection?
abstract: Many human viral infections have a zoonotic, that is, wild or domestic animal origin. Several zoonotic viruses are transmitted to humans by direct contact with an animal or indirectly by exposure to the urine or feces of infected animals, or by the bite of a bloodsucking arthropod. If a virus can adapt and replicate in a new human host, human-to-human transmission could occur, possibly resulting in an epidemic such as the 2009 A/H1N1 flu epidemic. Therefore, estimating emerging zoonotic infections is an important issue. This is a challenging task for public health officials in the coming decades. Recent advances in viral metagenomics, i.e. the characterization of complete viral diversity isolated from an organism or an environment using high-throughput sequencing technologies, are promising for the surveillance of such diseases and can be accomplished by analyzing the viromes of selected animals and arthropods in close contact with humans. In this review, we summarize our current knowledge of viral diversity in such animals (especially blood-feeding arthropods, wildlife and domestic animals) using metagenomics and present possible future applications for surveillance of zoonotic and arboviral diseases. Â© 2014 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Temmam, S.;Davoust, B.;Berenger, J. M.;Raoult, D.;Desnues, C.

title: Faustovirus-like asfarvirus in hematophagus-biting midlife and vertebrate hosts
abstract: Faustovirus, a new giant virus related to Asfarviridae, was recently isolated in Vermamoeba vermiformis, a protist found in sewage water in various geographic regions and occasionally reported cases of human eye infection. As part of a global metagenomic analysis of viral communities present in biting midges, we report here for the first time the identification and isolation of a Faustovirus-like virus in hematophagous arthropods and detection in animal hosts. DNA virome analysis of three pools of biting midges Culicoides sp., occluded female Culicoides imicola and non-occluded male/female C. imicola collected in Senegal revealed the presence of amoeba-infecting giant viruses and the majority of sequences among them. Relating to faustovirus. Phylogenetic analyzes performed on various structural genes of Faustovirus confirmed the clustering of arthropod-derived Faustovirus with sewage-derived Faustoviruses with a distinct geographic cluster of Senegalese Faustovirus strains. Transmission electron microscopy identified viral particles with morphology and diameters compatible with Faustovirus. The presence of infectious arthropod-derived Faustovirus was finally confirmed by successful isolation on V. vermiformis amoeba. Global proteomic analysis of the biting midges determined that the arthropod blood meals came from cattle, rodents, and humans. Further screening of bovine serum and rodent tissue resulted in an estimated Faustovirus prevalence of 38% in rodents and 14% in cattle, suggesting a possible origin of the presence of Faustovirus in arthropods through ingestion of contaminated blood meal. Viral loads were highest in urine and kidney samples of rodents, suggesting a possible excretion of viral particles into the environment. Sequences related to Faustovirus DNA polymerase were also detected in more than 9% and 11% of febrile patients and healthy Senegalese human sera, respectively. Therefore, our study highlights the need to investigate the role of arthropods, wildlife, and domestic animals in the life cycle of giant viruses that infect amoebae, and especially in the environmental cycle of Faustovirus.
authors: Temmam, S.;Monteil-Bouchard, S.;Sambou, M.;Aubadie-Ladrix, M.;Azza, S.;Decloquement, P.;Bou Khalil, J. Y.;Baudoin, J. P.;Jardot, P.;Robert, C.;Scola, B. L.;Mediannikov, O. Y.;Raoult, D.;Desnues, C.

title: Genetic characterization of domestic ferret-derived coronaviruses in Japan.
abstract: We detected ferret coronaviruses in 44 (55.7%) of 79 domestic ferrets tested in Japan and classified the viruses into 2 genotypes based on genotype-specific PCR. Our results show that the 2 ferret coronaviruses that cause feline infectious peritonitis-like disease and epizootic catarrhal enteritis are enzootic among ferrets in Japan.
authors: Terada, Y.;Minami, S.;Noguchi, K.;Mahmoud, H. Y.;Shimoda, H.;Mochizuki, M.;Une, Y.;Maeda, K.

title: Avian pox virus infection in flamingos (Phoenicopterus roseus) in a Zoo in Japan
abstract: Two diseased flamingos (Phoenicopterus roseus) with nodular lesions (pocks) characteristic of poxvirus infection were found in a zoo in Japan. Avian poxvirus was isolated from lesions (upper beak) of affected birds and genetically characterized by polymerase chain reaction, nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analysis. According to the phylogenetic analysis, the virus isolated from these flamingos was genetically similar to that isolated from pigeons, suggesting the possibility of interspecies transmission. Â© 2010 American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Terasaki, T.;Kaneko, M.;Mase, M.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolates from Eurasian collared pigeons (Streptopelia decaocto) in Italy.
abstract: Eurasian collared pigeons (Streptopelia decaocto) are thought to have originated in India and have colonized the Middle East for centuries and more recently Mediterranean countries such as Italy and Spain. In this article, the isolation and characterization of Newcastle disease viruses (NDV) from Eurasian collared pigeons between 2000 and 2001 are reported and compared with isolates from wild pigeons (Columba livia) in the same period. All isolates can be classified as avian paramyxovirus type 1 (APMV1) and belong to the pigeon variant group (PPMV1) because their hemagglutination activities were inhibited by the PPMV1-specific mAb 161/617. Intracerebral pathogenicity indices ranged from 0.68 to 1.38, and all isolates contained multiple basic amino acids in the inferred cleavage site of the fusion protein, which is typical of virulent viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the isolates shows that 18/20 of them formed a separate cluster from isolates obtained from pigeons during the same period. These findings suggest that different lineages circulate in wild pigeon populations and a distinct lineage affects Eurasian collared pigeons.
authors: Terregino, C.;Cattoli, G.;Grossele, B.;Bertoli, E.;Tisato, E.;Capua, I.

title: Heterologous viral expression systems in fosmid vectors increase the potential for functional analysis of metagenomic libraries
abstract: The extraordinary potential of metagenomic functional assays to identify relevant activities present in uncultured microorganisms has been limited by reduced gene expression in surrogate hosts. By exploiting viral components that inhibit transcription termination at metagenomic terminators, we have developed vectors and specific E. coli strains as advanced metagenomic DNA heterologous expression systems. One system uses phage T7 RNA-polymerase to direct metagenomic gene expression, while the other approach uses lambda phage transcription anti-termination protein N to limit transcription termination. A metagenomic library was constructed and functionally screened to identify genes conferring carbenicillin resistance to E. coli. Use of these enhanced expression systems resulted in a 6-fold increase in the frequency of carbenicillin-resistant clones. Subcloning and sequence analysis showed that efflux pumps, as well as Î²-lactamases, not only contribute to carbenicillin resistance, but may actually be sufficient on their own to transmit carbenicillin resistance.
authors: TerrÃ³n-GonzÃ¡lez, L.;Medina, C.;LimÃ³n-MortÃ©s, M. C.;Santero, E.

title: Identification of a new aviadenovirus, termed pigeon adenovirus 2, in domestic pigeons (Columba livia)
abstract: Young pigeon disease syndrome (YPDS) mainly affects young pigeons less than one year old and leads to crop failure, vomiting, diarrhoea, loss of appetite and sometimes death. This disease is a major health concern internationally, as it occurs seasonally during competitions such as pigeon racing or ornamental bird display. Although the etiology of YPDS is still unclear, adenoviruses are often discussed as potential causative agents. Electron microscopy of faeces from a YPDS outbreak revealed massive shedding of adenovirus-like particles. Whole genome sequencing of this specimen identified a new adenovirus tentatively termed pigeon adenovirus 2 (PiAdV-2). Phylogenetic and comparative genome analysis suggest that PiAdV-2 belongs to a new species within the genus Aviadenovirus, which we propose the name Pigeon aviadenovirus B. The PiAdV-2 genome shares 54.9% nucleotide sequence identity with pigeon adenovirus 1 (PiAdV-1). . Screening of other YPDS-affected flocks revealed two PiAdV-2 variants (variant A and B) that shared 97.6% nucleotide identity of partial polymerase sequences but only 79.7% nucleotide identity of partial hexon sequences. The distribution of both PiAdV-2 variants was further investigated in stool samples collected between 2008 and 2015 from healthy or YPDS-affected racing pigeons in different lofts. Regardless of their health status, approximately 20% of the young pigeon flocks and 13% of the adult pigeon flocks harbored PiAdV-2 variants. Birds were free of PiAdV-1 or other aviadenoviruses as determined by PCRs targeting the aviadenovirus polymerase or the PiAdV-1 fiber gene, respectively. In conclusion, there is no indication of correlation between YPDS outbreaks and the presence of PiAdV-2 or other aviadenoviruses, opposing a causal role in this disease complex.
authors: Teske, L.;Rubbenstroth, D.;Meixner, M.;Liere, K.;Bartels, H.;Rautenschlein, S.

title: Characterization of a genetically heterogeneous porcine rotavirus C and other viruses found in the fecal virome of a non-diarrheal Belgian piglet.
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies are becoming more and more accessible, leading to a growing interest in the composition of the porcine enteric virome. In this study, fecal viroma of a Belgian piglet without diarrhea was determined. Although only a single piglet virome was analyzed, some interesting data were obtained, including the second complete genome of a pig group C rotavirus (RVC). This Belgian strain was only distantly related to the only other fully characterized porcine RVC strain, Cowden. Association with RVC strains from other host species was also analyzed, and the pig strain in our study was only distantly related to RVCs detected in humans and cows. The gene encoding the outer capsid protein VP7 belonged to the rare porcine G3 genotype, which may be serologically different from most other porcine RVC strains. A new putative RVC VP6 genotype was also identified. A group A rotavirus strain, also found in this stool sample, contained the rare porcine genotype combination G11P[27], but was only partially characterized. Typical porcine RVA genotypes I5, A8 and T7 were found for the viral proteins VP6, NSP1 and NSP3, respectively. Interestingly, the piglet's fecal virome also contained an astrovirus and an enterovirus, whose entire genomes were characterized. The results of the present study show that many viruses can be found simultaneously in stool samples of non-diarrheal piglets. In this study, these viruses could not be directly related to any disease, but still have a potential subclinical effect on pig growth performance. The rapid evolution of NGS will make it a powerful tool for future diagnostics in veterinary practice. Its application will lead to better insights into the relevance of many (sub)clinical enteric viral infections that may not have been noticed using conventional diagnostic techniques. This will encourage the development of new and durable prophylactic measures to improve pig health and production.
authors: Theuns, S.;ConceiÃ§Ã£o-Neto, N.;Zeller, M.;Heylen, E.;Roukaerts, I. D. M.;Desmarets, L. M. B.;Van Ranst, M.;Nauwynck, H. J.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Nanopore sequencing as a revolutionary diagnostic tool for porcine viral enteric disease complexes identifies porcine cobuvirus as an important enteric virus
abstract: Enteric diseases in pigs are often caused by different pathogens and therefore metagenomics is a useful diagnostic tool. The capabilities of nanopore sequencing for viral diagnostics are explored here. First, cell culture-grown porcine epidemic diarrhea virus and rotavirus A were pooled and sequenced on a Minion. Reads were already detected 7 seconds after the start of sequencing, resulting in high sequencing depths (19.2 to 103.5X) after 3 hours. Next, the diarrheal stool of a one-week-old piglet was analyzed. Nearly all readings (99%) belonged to bacteriophages that may have reshaped the piglet microbiome. Contigs matched with Bacteroides, Escherichia and Enterococcus phages. In addition, swine cobuvirus was discovered in the stool for the first time in Belgium. Lactating piglets shed cobuvirus from one week of age, but no association was observed between the peak of viral shedding (10<sup>6.42</sup>-10<sup>7.01</sup> copies/swab) and diarrheal symptoms. follow the lesson. Retrospective analysis showed a prevalence of genetically moderately related cobuviruses (n = 25, 56.8% positive) among Belgian diarrheal piglets. MiniION provides rapid detection of enteric viruses. Such new methodologies will change diagnostics, but more extensive validation should be done. The true enteric pathogenicity of porcine cobuvirus has to be questioned, but its subclinical importance cannot be ignored.
authors: Theuns, S.;Vanmechelen, B.;Bernaert, Q.;Deboutte, W.;Vandenhole, M.;Beller, L.;Matthijnssens, J.;Maes, P.;Nauwynck, H. J.

title: Molecular characterization of positive-strand RNA viruses: pestiviruses and porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV)
abstract: Molecular characterization has become an important tool for the analysis of viruses, including their classification. The manuscript focuses on the molecular analysis of two members of the pestivirus genus (swine cholera virus, HCV and bovine viral diarrhea virus, BVDV) and the recently discovered porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV). The first protein encoded in the single large pestivirus ORF is a nonstructural protein with autoproteolytic activity. The cleavage site between the protease and the capsid protein p14 was predicted, but recent experimental data indicate that processing occurs at a different site. The capsid protein is followed by a putative internal signal sequence and three glycoproteins that are part of the virion envelope. According to a recent proposal for naming the structural proteins of pestiviruses, they are designated C, E0, E1, and E2. The genomes of BVDV pairs isolated from animals with mucosal disease were analyzed. Genomes from cytopathogenic (cp) BVD viruses may contain insertions that are highly homologous to cellular sequences. In addition, cp BVDV may differ from its non-cytopathogenic (non-cp) counterpart only by rearrangement of viral sequences. PRRS, which appeared several years ago, is caused by a single-stranded RNA virus; The viral genome has positive polarity and is 15 kb in size. Data on morphology, morphogenesis, and virion composition have already suggested that PRRSV belongs to a group of arteriviruses that includes equine arthritis virus (EAV), lactate dehydrogenase-promoting virus (LDV), and simian hemorrhagic fever virus (SHFV). This conclusion has now been confirmed by analysis of genome organization, gene expression strategy, and comparison of inferred protein sequences.
authors: Thiel, H. J.;Meyers, G.;Stark, R.;Tautz, N.;RÃ¼menapf, T.;Unger, G.;Conzelmann, K. K.

title: Case reports of hemorrhagic diathesis in calves with bovine diarrheal virus infection
abstract: Clinical and pathological findings were reported in six calves with hemorrhagic diathesis. Other pathological and virological results were highly suggestive of mucosal disease (BVD). Virus isolation or classification was not possible. Autopsy results showed that the virus may be cytopathogenic. Similar field and experimental publications on thrombocytopenia in calf calves in the USA were discussed and compared. These are the first case reports published in Germany.
authors: Thiel, W.

title: Estimation of swine seroprevalence of hepatitis E virus (HEV) using ELISA and Western blot and comparison between human and porcine HEV sequences in Belgium
abstract: Zoonotic transmission of hepatitis E virus (HEV) is of particular concern, particularly in high-income countries where waterborne infections are less frequent than in developing countries. High HEV seroprevalences can be found in European pig populations. The aim of this study was to obtain prevalence data of HEV infection in pigs in Belgium and to phylogenetically compare Belgian human HEV sequences with those obtained from pigs. An ELISA screening prevalence of 73% (95% CI 68.8-77.5) was determined in Belgian pigs and some of the results were re-evaluated by Western blot (WB). A receiver operating characteristic curve analysis was performed and scenarios that changed ELISA specificity relative to WB were analyzed. Estimated seroprevalences by the different scenarios range from 69% to 81%, consistent with the high exposure of the European pig population to HEV. Pig HEV sequences were genetically compared to those detected in humans in Belgium and genotype 3 subtype f was shown to be predominant in both pigs and humans. The high HEV seroprevalence in pigs and the close phylogenetic relationships between swine and human HEV sequences further support the risk of zoonotic transmission of HEV between humans and pigs. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Thiry, D.;Mauroy, A.;Saegerman, C.;Thomas, I.;Wautier, M.;Miry, C.;Czaplicki, G.;Berkvens, D.;Praet, N.;van der Poel, W.;Cariolet, R.;Brochier, B.;Thiry, E.

title: Molecular biology of bovine herpesvirus type 4
abstract: Bovine herpesvirus type 4 (BHV-4) is a ubiquitous bovine virus. Its genome is 144 Â± 6 kb double-stranded DNA and consists of a unique central portion (L-DNA) flanked at both ends by tandem repeats called polyrepetitive DNA (prDNA or H-DNA). The overall arrangement of the genes was obtained by analysis of the homologies between the short BHV-4 DNA sequences and the corresponding Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and herpesvirus saimiri (HVS) genes. Gene expression is transiently regulated. The glycoprotein precursor p(gp10/gp17) is expressed as the gamma 1 polypeptide. The glycoproteins gp1, gp8, gp11 and their precursors are gamma 2 proteins. Analysis of strain variations allows the identification of two types of strains based on their DNA patterns: Movar 33/63-like and DN 599-like strains. M40 strain isolated only in India does not fit this classification. Genomic variations were compiled to create a dendrogram that differed at three levels between BHV-4 strains or isolates. Available molecular data indicate that the BHV-4 genome shares much similarity with the DNA of the two representative members of gammaherpesvirinae, EBV and HVS. Therefore, BHV-4 can be classified in the subfamily gammaherpesvirinae.
authors: Thiry, E.;Bublot, M.;Dubuisson, J.;Van Bressem, M. F.;Lequarre, A. S.;Lomonte, P.;Vanderplasschen, A.;Pastoret, P. P.

title: Origin of lentivirus research: Maedi-visna virus
abstract: Maedi and visna are contagious sheep diseases brought to Iceland by imported Karakul sheep in 1933. Maedi, a slowly progressive pneumonia, and visna, a central nervous system disease, have been shown to be contagious in sheep and most likely caused by a virus. Visna virus was isolated in tissue culture from sheep brain in 1957 and maedi virus was isolated from sheep lung the following year. Both viruses showed similar cytopathic effect in tissue culture. Electron microscopy studies of ultrathin sections from Visna virus-infected cells showed spherical particles 70-100 nm in diameter, formed by budding from the cell membrane. Subsequent studies showed the same particles in cultures infected with maedi virus. These and several other comparative studies have strongly demonstrated that maedi and visna are caused by strains of the same virus, later called maedi-visna virus (MVV). Comparative studies in tissue culture suggested that MVV is associated with animal RNA tumor viruses, oncornaviruses. This was later supported by the finding that MVV is an RNA virus. A few months after the demonstration of reverse transcriptase in oncornaviruses, the enzyme was also found in MVV virions. Thus, MVV was classified as a retrovirus along with oncornaviruses. However, MVV is not oncogenic in vivo or in vitro and in 1975 was placed in a subgroup of retroviruses called lentiviruses, which are noncogenic but cause cytopathic effect in vitro and slow progressive inflammatory disease in animals. In the early 1980s, the AIDS-causing agent was found to be a non-oncogenic retrovirus and classified as a lentivirus. Thus, HIV became the first human lentivirus. Â© 2013 Bentham Science Publishers.
authors: Thormar, H.

title: Prevalence and diversity of H9N2 avian influenza in North Vietnamese chickens, 2014
abstract: Although A/H9N2 viruses are classified as low pathogenic avian influenza viruses (LPAIV), they cause significant losses in poultry in many countries in Asia, the Middle East and North Africa. To date, poultry surveillance in Vietnam has focused on the detection of influenza H5 viruses, and there is limited understanding of influenza H9 epidemiology and transmission dynamics. We determined the prevalence and diversity of influenza A viruses in chickens from live bird markets (LBM) in 7 northern Vietnamese provinces using pooled oropharyngeal swabs collected between October and December 2014. Screening by real-time RT-PCR showed 1207/4900 (24.6%) pooled swabs positive for influenza A virus; Overall prevalence estimates were 5.8% (CI 5.4-6.0) after taking into account pooling (5 swab/pool). Subtyping was performed on 468 pooled swab with the M gene Ct<26. No influenza H7 detected; 422 (90.1%) were H9 positive; and 22 (4.7%) were H5 positive. There was no evidence of interaction between H9 and H5 virus detection rates. We sequenced 17 complete genomes of A/H9N2, 2 genomes of A/H5N6 and 11 partial genomes. All H9N2 viruses have internal genes that cluster with genotype 57 and are closely related to Chinese human A/H7N9 and A/H10N8 isolates. We identified 9 different H9 genotypes using a nucleotide divergence cutoff of 98%. Phylogenetic analysis suggested multiple introductions of H9 viruses into northern Vietnam rather than in situ transmission. Further research into H9 prevalence and diversity in other parts of Vietnam is warranted to assess H9 endemicity elsewhere in the country.
authors: Thuy, D. M.;Peacock, T. P.;Bich, V. T. N.;Fabrizio, T.;Hoang, D. N.;Tho, N. D.;Diep, N. T.;Nguyen, M.;Hoa, L. N. M.;Trang, H. T. T.;Choisy, M.;Inui, K.;Newman, S.;Trung, N. V.;van Doorn, R.;To, T. L.;Iqbal, M.;Bryant, J. E.

title: Chimeric swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses reveal the full function of genotype 1 envelope proteins in the backbone of genotype 2.
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) is classified into two genotypes, type 1 and type 2, which share only about 60% genetic identity. Here, we report live chimeric viruses in which the envelope protein genes of vSHE (type 1) from ORF2a to ORF5 have been changed to the genetic backbone of vAPRRS (type 2). We found that the envelope proteins of genotype 1 are fully functional in genotype 2 PRRSV and that the rescued chimeric lineage viruses show strong genetic stability and similar replication properties to their parent strains in vitro. To our knowledge, this is the first study to report substitution of complete ORFs between different genotypes of porcine arterivirus. These findings pave the way to further elucidate the structure-function relationship of PRRSV envelope proteins and may enable the development of new marker vaccines that can be used to distinguish vaccinated animals from infected animals. © 2010 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Tian, D.;Zheng, H.;Zhang, R.;Zhuang, J.;Yuan, S.

title: Genome sequence of a novel reassortant H3N2 avian influenza virus in southern China
abstract: The distribution and prevalence of H3 subtype influenza viruses in avian and mammalian hosts pose a potential threat to both human and avian health. We report a complete genome sequence of a novel reassortant H3N2 avian influenza virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that HA and NA showed the highest sequence homology with A/white-back munia/Hong Kong/4519/2009 (H3N2). However, internal genes had the highest sequence homology with those of the H6 and H7 subtypes. The data provide further evidence for the existence of a natural reassortant H3N2 strain in southern China.
authors: Tian, J.;Zhang, C.;Qi, W.;Xu, C.;Huang, L.;Li, H.;Liao, M.

title: The immunodominant E2 (gp53) sequences of the highly virulent bovine viral diarrhea group II viruses bear close resemblance to a subset of border disease viruses.
abstract: Genes for the E2 envelope protein, which elicit virus neutralizing antibodies from newly described group II members of bovine viral diarrheal viruses (BVDVs), were cloned and sequenced. These BVDVs included a thrombocytopenic strain from the United States, a fetal bovine serum contaminant, a strain from Western Canada, and two highly virulent strains from Quebec that cause high mortality rates. The nucleotide and amino acid sequences of these E2s had only 60-65% homology with group I BVDV E2s, but >90% homology with the E2 of a subset of sheep border disease viruses. The E2 gene of the NADL strain was expressed and monospecific antibodies were developed in calves and rabbits. The virus neutralizing titers of these antisera were 15 to 80 times lower for the heterologous BVDV group compared to the homologous BVDVs.
authors: Tijssen, P.;Pellerln, C.;Lecomte, J.;Van Den Hurk, J.

title: Invasion of exotic bovine transient fever virus to Taiwan in 2013-2014
abstract: Bovine ephemeral fever virus is a member of the Rhabdoviridae family, and bovine ephemeral fever has frequently affected the cattle population in Taiwan since 1967. During outbreaks in 2013 and 2014, exotic bovine short-lived fever viruses by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction and nucleotide sequencing were detected. Sequence comparison shows that exotic viruses have 99.0-99.4% nucleotide identities (99.4-100.0 amino acid identities) with Chinese viruses and, conversely, 96.2-97.2% nucleotide identities (97.8%- 99.8%) with native Taiwanese. 98.6 amino acid identities). viruses. In addition, our phylogenetic analysis also supported that the newly invaded bovine transient fever viruses were closely related to the Chinese strains. These exotic 2013-2014 viruses have become commonplace since their emergence and have replaced native virus strains.
authors: Ting, L. J.;Lee, M. S.;Lin, Y. L.;Cheng, M. C.;Lee, F.

title: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever in Tajikistan Review
abstract: Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a pathogenic tick-borne disease caused by a single-stranded negative-sense RNA virus classified in the Nairovirus genus of the Bunyaviridae family. Cases of CCHF have been recorded in Tajikistan since 1944, when the disease was first presented to medical attention. However, historical Tajik manuscripts describe features of hemorrhagic fever associated with ticks, indicating that the disease may have been known in this region many years ago. officially characterized. Here we review the historical context of CCHF in Tajikistan, most of which has been described in the Russian literature for several decades, and include reports of recent outbreaks in Tajikistan.
authors: Tishkova, F. H.;Belobrova, E. A.;Valikhodzhaeva, M.;Atkinson, B.;Hewson, R.;Mullojonova, M.

title: Targeted 16S rRNA high-throughput sequencing to characterize microbial communities during composting of animal deaths.
abstract: Purpose A comprehensive understanding of the microbial community is necessary to achieve a significant reduction in pathogens during the composting process. Methods and Results Two bio-safe, static composting systems were constructed that included cattle mortality at sub-zero temperatures. The temperature at each sampling site was measured continuously and samples were grouped at <= 50 or >= 55 degrees C based on exposure to the temperature required for effective pathogen inactivation during composting. High-throughput 454 sequencing was used to characterize bacterial communities in each sample. Clustering of bacterial communities was observed according to temperature. However, neither richness nor diversity differed between temperature groups. Firmicutes was the most abundant phylum in both temperature groups, but was more prominent in samples >= 55 degrees C (P<0 center point 05) (63 center point 6%). Similarly, members of Clostridia, Clostridium sensu stricto (3 centers 64%), Clostridium XI (0 centers 59%), UF (Clostridiaceae 1) (5 centers 29%) and UF (Clostridiales Incertae Sedis XI) (6 centers) point 20%), was evident at >= 55 degrees C (P<0 center point 05), possibly a reflection of spore survival and/or anaerobic microenvironments within passively aerated compost piles. Thermobifida members (3 center points 54%), UO (Actinomycetales) (12 center points 29%) and UO (Bacillales) (19 center points 49%) were also evident at >= 55 degrees C (P<0 center point 05) ). Conclusion Significant spatial diversity exists within bacterial communities in field-scale compost piles. Localized temperature in the sampling area may be one of the contributing factors to this phenomenon. Significance and Impact of Study This is the first study to describe microbial community profile using targeted 16S rRNA high-throughput sequencing in passively aerated compost animal deaths.
authors: Tkachuk, V. L.;Krause, D. O.;Knox, N. C.;Hamm, A. C.;Zvomuya, F.;Ominski, K. H.;McAllister, T. A.

title: A large repertoire of type III secretion effectors in Escherichia coli O157 and the role of lambdoid phages in their dissemination
abstract: Several pathogenic strains of Escherichia coli use type III secretion to inject "effector proteins" into human cells, which then turn eukaryotic cell biology to the advantage of the bacteria. We utilized bioinformatics and experimental approaches to determine that the effector repertoire in the Sakai strain of enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) O157:H7 is much greater than previously thought. Homology searches led to the identification of >60 putative effector genes. Of these, 13 were judged to be probable pseudogene, while 49 were potentially functional. In total, 39 proteins were experimentally validated as effectors: 31 via proteomics and 28 via translocation experiments. At the protein level, EHEC effector sequences are divided into >20 families. The largest family, the NIeG family, contains 14 members in the Sakai lineage alone. EHEC also harbors functional homologs of effectors from plant pathogens (HopPtoH, HopW, AvrA) and Shigella (OspD, OspE, OspG) and two additional members of the Map/IpgB family. Genes encoding proven or predicted effectors occur at >20 switchable effector loci scattered throughout the chromosome. Importantly, the majority of functional effector genes are encoded by nine replaceable effector loci located within lambdoid prophages. Thus, type III secretion in E. coli is associated with a large phage "metagenome" that serves as a crucible for the evolution of pathogenicity. Â© 2006 by the US National Academy of Sciences.
authors: Tobe, T.;Beatson, S. A.;Taniguchi, H.;Abe, H.;Bailey, C. M.;Fivian, A.;Younis, R.;Matthews, S.;Marches, O.;Frankel, G.;Hayashi, T.;Pallen, M. J.

title: Complete Genome Sequence of Porcine Circovirus type 3 from serum of pigs in stillbirth in Brazil
abstract: Two complete genome sequences of porcine circovirus type 3 (PCV3) have been reported. Genomes were obtained from pooled serum samples from pigs who had just given birth to puppies with a variable number of stillbirths. The two circular genomes (PCV3-BR/RS/6 and PCV3-BR/RS/8) are 2,000 nucleotides long and contain two oppositely oriented open reading frames (ORFs) encoding the putative capsid (Cap) and replica (Rep). ) proteins. The intergenic region contains a root-loop motif as reported for other circoviruses. Rolling circle replication motifs and putative helix domains were identified in the Rep coding region. The overall degree of nucleotide similarity between the genomes reported here and those available in GenBank was greater than 97%. No PCV3 sequence was detected in serum samples collected from pigs that have never given stillbirths in the same farms. However, more studies are needed to confirm the association between PCV3 and stillbirths.
authors: Tochetto, C.;Lima, D. A.;Varela, A. P. M.;Loiko, M. R.;Paim, W. P.;Scheffer, C. M.;Herpich, J. I.;Cerva, C.;Schmitd, C.;Cibulski, S. P.;Santos, A. C.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.

title: Circoviruses: immunosuppressive threats to avian species: a review
abstract: Circoviruses are small, non-enveloped, icosahedral viruses that are unique among animal viruses by having circular, single-stranded DNA genomes. Their genomes are also the smallest that animal viruses have. The circovirus family currently consists of three members, chicken anemia virus, porcine circovirus, and psittasine beak and feather disease virus, and pigeon circovirus is classified as a transient member. Infections with each of the four circoviruses are associated with potentially fatal diseases in which damage to lymphoid tissue by the virus and immunosuppression are common features. Experience with other animal virus families indicates that additional animal species will be infected by as-yet undiscovered circoviruses, which may show similar tissue tropism and disease-causing potential. Recent reports describing the association of circovirus-like viruses with immunodeficiency-related diseases of geese and southern black-backed gulls suggest that circovirus infections of avian species may be more common than previously known, raising the question of whether novel circoviruses infect poultry. clinical and/or subclinical diseases that may be economically significant. This review has three purposes. First, it was designed to summarize currently available information on classified circoviruses and viruses that are considered circovirus-like. Second, it aims to alert the reader to the possibility that other bird species, including commercial poultry, may be infected with the new circoviruses. Finally, possible methods for discovering new circoviruses and controlling infections caused by such viruses are proposed.
authors: Todd, D.

title: Morphogenesis of a cytomegalovirus from an American bison affected by malignant catarrh.
abstract: herpes virus isolated from various organs of an American bison affected by malignant flu was cultured in bovine fetal spleen cells and examined by electron microscopy. The fine structural features and mode of virus morphogenesis of the mature virion were found to be similar to herpes viruses classified in the cytomegalovirus subgroup. The capsids contained granular, hexagonal shaped and thin sections pleomorphic nuclei. Encapsulation of the capsids occurred mainly by budding on the cytoplasmic membranes, which appeared to be formed as elongated vesicles of the Golgi apparatus; budding in nuclear membranes was rarely observed. Cytoplasmic inclusions of granular filaments and amorphous electron-dense material were found in association with virions in the late stages of infection. The formation of cytoplasmic inclusions, morphogenesis and superstructure of the virus is consistent with the classification of this virus as a cytomegalovirus.
authors: Todd, W. J.;Storz, J.

title: Distinction between vaccine and wild-type varicella-zoster virus genotypes by high-resolution melt analysis of single-nucleotide polymorphisms
abstract: Background: Analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) enabled differentiation between wild-type genotypes from the Oka vaccine strain (V-Oka). Objectives: To genotype Australian VZV strains using high resolution melt (HRM) analysis of SNPs at five gene targets. Study design: DNA from 78 samples from chickenpox and zoster patients was genotyped by HRM analysis of SNPs in five open reading frames (ORFs): 1 (685 G > A), 21 (33 725 C > T), 37 ( 66 288 G > A), 60 (101 464 C > A) and 62 (106 262 T > C), using double-stranded (ds) DNA saturation dye, LC Green Plus. Results: For each genotype, melting curve temperature (Tm) shifts differentiated the nucleotide found at that locus (P < 0.0001), with melting curve shifts ranging from 0.56 Â°C (ORF 37) to 3.34 Â°C (ORF 62) across alleles. The most common genotypes detected were European Type C (59%) and B (18%) strains. This was followed by African/Asian Type A (14%) and Japanese J1 (9%) strains common in both the Northern Territory and Western Australia. Results: HRM analysis of SNPs showed that European genotypes B and C were most common in Australia and strains A and J were also present. HRM analysis using a dsDNA stain provides a useful tool in the classification of varicella-zoster viruses. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Toi, C. S.;Dwyer, D. E.

title: Discovery of a new nidovirus in cattle with respiratory disease
abstract: The Coronaviridae family represents a diverse group of vertebrate RNA viruses, all with genomes larger than 26,000 nt. Here we report the discovery and genetic characterization of a novel virus found in cattle with respiratory disease. Phylogenetic characterization of this virus revealed that it clusters within the subfamily Torovirinae in the family Coronaviridae. The complete genome consists of only 20 261 nt and represents the smallest coronavirus genome reported. We identified seven ORFs, including the canonical nidovirus ORF1a and ORF1b. Analysis of polyprotein 1ab revealed that this virus, provisionally termed bovine nidovirus (BoNV), shares the highest homology with the recently described python-derived nidoviruses and contains several conserved nidovirus motifs, but does not encode the existing NendoU or O-MT domains. In other viruses in the Coronaviridae family. In agreement with its reduced genome, the atypical domain architecture indicates that this virus represents a unique lineage in the Nidovirales order.
authors: Tokarz, R.;Sameroff, S.;Hesse, R. A.;Hause, B. M.;Desai, A.;Jain, K.;Ian Lipkin, W.

title: Virome analysis of Amblyomma americanum, Dermacentor variabilis and Ixodes scapularis ticks reveals highly different new vertebrate and invertebrate viruses
authors: Tokarz, R.;Williams, S. H.;Sameroff, S.;Leon, M. S.

title: Phylogenetic study of viral isolates of porcine and human hepatitis E virus
authors: Tolari, F.;Del Chiaro, L.;Card, R.;Mazzei, M.;Bandecchi, P.;Banks, M.

title: Birds and viruses at a crossroads - surveillance of influenza A virus in Portuguese waterfowl
abstract: In recent years, a large amount of data on influenza A virus (IAV) in wild birds in northern Europe has been obtained, while information from southern Europe is more limited. Here we present an IAV surveillance study conducted in western Portugal 2008-2009 that analyzed 1653 specimens from six different waterfowl species, most of which were from Mallards (Anas platyrhynchos). Overall, 4.4% of the sampled birds were infected. Sampling results revealed significant temporal variation in IAV prevalence, including a marked peak among predominantly juvenile birds in June, suggesting that IAV circulates within breeding populations in the wetlands of western Portugal. Among the isolated viruses, the H10N7 and H9N2 subtypes were predominant. Phylogenetic analyzes of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase sequences of H10N7, H9N2 and H11N3 virus showed that the sequences from Portugal were closely related to viral sequences in Central Europe, reflecting Portugal's position in Europe-Africa, and IAVs isolated in southern parts of Africa. . bird migratory passageway. This study highlights the importance of Portugal as a migratory crossroads for IAV, connecting breeding dormant waterfowl with birds migrating between continents and enabling transmission and spread of IAV.
authors: Tolf, C.;Bengtsson, D.;Rodrigues, D.;Latorre-Margalef, N.;Wille, M.;Figueiredo, M. E.;Jankowska-Hjortaas, M.;Germundsson, A.;Duby, P. Y.;Lebarbenchon, C.;Gauthier-Clerc, M.;Olsen, B.;Waldenstrom, J.

title: Birds and Viruses at a Crossroads - Surveillance of Influenza A Virus in Portuguese Waterfowl
abstract: In recent years, a large amount of data on influenza A virus (IAV) in wild birds in northern Europe has been obtained, while information from southern Europe is more limited. Here we present an IAV surveillance study conducted in western Portugal 2008-2009 that analyzed 1653 specimens from six different waterfowl species, most of which were from Mallards (Anas platyrhynchos). Overall, 4.4% of the sampled birds were infected. Sampling results revealed significant temporal variation in IAV prevalence, including a marked peak among predominantly juvenile birds in June, suggesting that IAV circulates within breeding populations in the wetlands of western Portugal. Among the isolated viruses, the H10N7 and H9N2 subtypes were predominant. Phylogenetic analyzes of the hemagglutinin and neuraminidase sequences of H10N7, H9N2 and H11N3 virus showed that the sequences from Portugal were closely related to viral sequences in Central Europe, reflecting Portugal's position in Europe-Africa, and IAVs isolated in southern parts of Africa. . bird migratory passageway. This study highlights the importance of Portugal as a migratory crossroads for IAV, connecting breeding dormant waterfowl with birds migrating between continents and enabling transmission and spread of IAV. Â© 2012 Tolf et al.
authors: Tolf, C.;Bengtsson, D.;Rodrigues, D.;Latorre-Margalef, N.;Wille, M.;Figueiredo, M. E.;Jankowska-Hjortaas, M.;Germundsson, A.;Duby, P. Y.;Lebarbenchon, C.;Gauthier-Clerc, M.;Olsen, B.;WaldenstrÃ¶m, J.

title: Development of an RT-qPCR assay for the specific detection of a distinct genetic lineage of infectious bursal disease virus
abstract: Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) is a major health threat to the world poultry industry despite appropriate biosafety practices and intensive controls, including vaccination. IBDV (Avibirnavirus, Birnaviridae) is a non-enveloped virus with a bipartite double-stranded RNA genome. The virus has traditionally been classified as classical, variable and highly virulent strains, each with different epidemiological relevance and clinical implications. Recently, a new genetic lineage spreading worldwide has been identified and designated as distinct (d)IBDV. Here, we report the development and validation of a reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) assay for the specific detection of dIBDVs in the global poultry industry. The assay uses a TaqMan-MGB probe that hybridizes with a unique molecular signature of dIBDV. The assay successfully detected all evaluated strains belonging to the dIBDV genetic lineage and showed high specificity and absence of cross-reactivity with non-dIBDV, IBDV-negative samples and other common avian viruses. Using serial dilutions of in vitro transcribed RNA, we obtained acceptable PCR efficiencies and detection coefficients and relatively small intra- and inter-assay variability. The test showed a wide dynamic range between 103 and 108 RNA copies/reactions. This rapid, specific and quantitative test is expected to improve surveillance and control of IBDV worldwide and increase our understanding of the molecular epidemiology of this economically harmful avian pathogen.
authors: TomÃ¡s, G.;HernÃ¡ndez, M.;Marandino, A.;Techera, C.;Grecco, S.;HernÃ¡ndez, D.;Banda, A.;Panzera, Y.;PÃ©rez, R.

title: Infectious Ecthyma, Rangiferine Brucellosis, and Lungworm Infection in a Muskox (Ovibos moschatus) from the Canadian Arctic, 2014
abstract: An adult male musk ox (Ovibos moschatus) harvested on August 26, 2014 in Victoria Island, Nunavut, in the Canadian Arctic, had proliferative dermatitis on the muzzle and fetlocks suggestive of contagious ecthyma or orf (Parapoxvirus). Histopathological features of the lesions were consistent with this diagnosis. Orf virus DNA phylogenetically similar to an isolate from a captive musk bovine in the Minnesota Zoo, USA, was detected in the lesions by PCR using Parapoxvirus primers. There was also a metaphyseal abscess with cortical fistula in the right metacarpus in which Brucella suis biovar 4 was isolated and supported by PCR. Brucella spp. Antibodies were detected in the serum. Finally, 212 nodules were dissected from the lungs. Stool analysis and lung examination revealed co-infection with the lungworms Umingmakstrongylus pallikuukensis and Varestrongylus eleguneniensis. The zoonotic potential of orf and rangiferin brucellosis adds an important public health dimension to this situation, especially given that muskoxen is a valuable food source for Arctic inhabitants. Careful scrutiny of these pathogens at the population level is necessary as they can contribute to the reduction of the Muskox population and potentially create a driver of food insecurity for local communities. This case highlights the importance of wildlife health surveillance as a management tool to protect wildlife populations and maintain food security in livelihood-oriented communities.
authors: Tomaselli, M.;Dalton, C.;Duignan, P. J.;Kutz, S.;van der Meer, F.;Kafle, P.;Surujballi, O.;Turcotte, C.;Checkley, S.

title: Detection and heterogeneity of herpes viruses causing Pacheco disease in parrots
abstract: Pacheco's disease (PD) is a common, often fatal disease of parrots. We cloned a virus isolate from a parrot with lesions characteristic of PD. Three viral clones were partially sequenced, showing that this virus is an alphaherpes virus most closely related to gallid herpes virus 1. Five primer sets were developed from these sequences. Primer sets were used in conjunction with PCR to screen tissues or tissue culture media suspected to contain virus from 54 PD outbreaks. The primer sets the amplified DNA from all but one sample. Ten amplification patterns were identified, suggesting that PD is caused by a genetically heterogeneous virus population. It was a single genetic variant (psittacid herpesvirus variant 1) amplified by all primer sets and the most common virus variant (62.7%). A single primer set (23F) amplified DNA from all positive samples suggests that PCR can be used as a rapid post-mortem assay for these viruses. PCR was found to be significantly more sensitive than tissue culture for the detection of psittacid herpes viruses.
authors: Tomaszewski, E.;Wilson, V. G.;Wigle, W. L.;Phalen, D. N.

title: Molecular phylogeny of psittacid herpes viruses causing Pacheco's disease: correlation of genotype with phenotypic expression.
abstract: 419 bp fragments of the UL16 open reading frame from 73 psittacid herpesviruses (PsHVs) from the United States and Europe were sequenced. All viruses caused Pacheco disease and the serotypes of European isolates were known. A phylogenetic tree derived from these sequences showed that PsHVs causing Pacheco disease contained four major genotypes, with each genotype containing two to four variants. With the exception of two viruses, serotypes of virus isolates can be predicted by genotypes. Genotype 1 and 4 corresponded to serotype 1 isolates, genotype 2 to serotype 2 isolates, and genotype 3 to serotype 3 isolates. The only serotype 4 virus mapped to genotype 4, DNA from a virus with a unique serotype cannot be amplified with primers that amplify DNA from all other PsHVs, and its classification is unknown. Viruses representing all four genotypes were found in both the United States and Europe, and therefore serotypes 1, 2, and 3 were predicted to be present in the United States. Serotype 4 was represented by a single European isolate that was genetically indistinguishable from serotype 1 viruses; therefore, the presence of serotype 4 in the United States could not be predicted. In the United States, the genotype 4 viruses most commonly associated with Pacheco disease in macaws and cones were found to be the least likely to be isolated from chicken embryo fibroblasts. All four genotypes caused deaths in Amazon parrots, but genotype 4 was only associated with Pacheco disease in European Amazons. Genotypes 2, 3 and 4, not 1, were found in African gray parrots. Although parrots in the Pacific distribution represent a relatively small percentage of the total number of birds with Pacheco disease, all four genotypes were found to cause disease in this species.
authors: Tomaszewski, E. K.;Kaleta, E. F.;Phalen, D. N.

title: Long Read Single Molecule Characterization of the Dynamic Transcriptome of a Herpes Virus by Real-Time Sequencing
abstract: Herpesvirus gene expression is coordinately and sequentially regulated during productive infection. Viral genes can be classified into three different kinetic groups: immediate-early, early and late classes. In this study, a massively parallel sequencing technique based on the PacBio Single Molecule Real-time sequencing platform was used to quantify the poly(A) fraction of the lytic transcriptome of pseudorabies virus (PRV) over a 12-hour productivity window. Infection in PK-15 cells. Other approaches, including microarray, real-time RT-PCR, and Illumina sequencing, can only detect the collective transcriptional activity of certain genomic regions, but not individual herpes virus transcripts. However, SMRT sequencing allows for a distinction to be made between transcript isoforms, including length and splice variants, as well as between overlapping polycistronic RNA molecules. The non-amplified Isoform Sequencing (Iso-Seq) method was used to analyze the kinetic properties of lytic PRV transcripts and then classify them appropriately. In addition, the current work demonstrates the overall utility of long-read sequencing for time-path analysis of global gene expression in practically any organism.
authors: TombÃ¡cz, D.;BalÃ¡zs, Z.;Csabai, Z.;MoldovÃ¡n, N.;SzÅ±cs, A.;Sharon, D.;Snyder, M.;BoldogkÅ‘i, Z.

title: Metagenomic evaluation of adventitious viruses in commercial cattle serum
abstract: Animal serum is an important supplement to the cell culture medium. Incidental contamination of animal serum with viruses has led to major regulatory action and product recalls. We used metagenomic methods to detect and characterize viral contaminants in 26 bovine serum samples from 12 producers. Among the samples, we detected sequences with homology to 20 viruses at depths of up to 50,000 viral reads per million. The viruses detected represented nine viral families plus four viruses that were not taxonomically assigned, and had both RNA genomes and DNA genomes. Sequences ranged from 28% to 96%, similar to viruses in the GenBank database at the amino acid level. The number of viruses ranged from zero to 11 among samples and from one to 11 among suppliers, and only one product from a supplier was completely “clean”. For a common incidental virus, bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV), abundance estimates were calculated from metagenomic data (viral reads per million), obtained from quantitative real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rtq-PCR), metagenomics being approximately as sensitive as rtq-PCR. It closely corresponded to the Ct values. Metagenomics is useful for detecting taxonomically and genetically diverse adventitious viruses in commercial serum products and provides sensitive and quantitative information.
authors: Toohey-Kurth, K.;Sibley, S. D.;Goldberg, T. L.

title: Sequencing approach to analyze the role of demi-species for classic swine fever
abstract: Classical swine fever virus (CSFV) is a positive-sense RNA virus with a high degree of genetic variability among isolates. There is also high variation in virulence, with strains covering the entire spectrum from avirulent to highly virulence. The underlying genetic determinants are far from being understood. Because the RNA polymerases of RNA viruses lack any proofreading activity, different genome variations called haplotypes occur during replication. A set of haplotypes is referred to as a viral half-species. Genetic variability may be a fitness advantage, facilitating a more efficient escape from the host immune response. To investigate the correlation of half-species composition and virulence in vivo, we analyzed next-generation sequencing data of CSFV isolates with varying virulence. Viral samples from pigs infected with the highly lethal isolates "Koslov" and "Brescia" showed higher half-species diversity and greater nucleotide variability compared to pig samples infected with low- and moderate-lethal isolates.
authors: Topfer, A.;Hoper, D.;Blome, S.;Beer, M.;Beerenwinkel, N.;Ruggli, N.;Leifer, I.

title: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrhea virus: Most Slovenian isolates have genotypes 1d and 1f.
abstract: selection of 43 bovine viral diarrheal viruses, mostly isolated from permanently infected cattle, were genetically characterized on 23 Slovenian farms between 1997 and 2001. Viral RNA was extracted from infected cell cultures, reverse transcribed and amplified by PCR with primers targeting the 5-UTR and Npro gene, followed by direct sequencing of the obtained purified PCR products for both genomic regions. Npro sequences provided the best genetic resolution and also gave higher statistical support for the phylogenetic classification of viruses. Thirty-eight of the Slovenian isolates were genetic subtypes 1d and 1f, four were 1b and one subtype 1g. BVDV type 2 virus not found. This genetic prevalence matched those previously reported for neighboring countries, in contrast to findings reported for more distant European countries, eg France, Spain and the United Kingdom. Several virus isolates from eight herds of cattle were analyzed; with one exception, all isolates from each flock were from the same genetic group. Extended sequencing of Npro and a portion of the C gene of virus isolates with identical 5-UTR sequences allowed differentiation between isolates obtained from one flock at different times. Â© 2004 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Toplak, I.;Sandvik, T.;BarliÄ-Maganja, D.;Grom, J.;Paton, D. J.

title: Biological and molecular characterization of avian influenza virus (H9N2) isolates from Iran
abstract: Three Influenza A virus (H9N2) isolates from three separate broiler flocks with varying mortality rates were cloned twice in embryonated SPF chicken eggs by limiting dilution. The biological properties of these isolates were investigated in 4-week-old SPF chickens and chick embryo fibroblast (CEF) cultures. The isolates neither caused death in vaccinated chickens nor produced CPE in cell cultures, indicating low pathogenicity. PCR products of 486 bp containing cleavage site sequences of hemagglutinin (HA) produced from isolates were subjected to nucleotide sequencing. Sequence analysis of the HA region containing the cleavage site of the isolates showed a similar sequence motif (PARSSRG) but different flanking regions. Phylogenetic analysis of the inferred amino acid sequences revealed that the isolates were closely related to those previously isolated, indicating a common origin. Also, the amino acid sequences of the final isolates were very similar to those in Saudi Arabia, Germany, and Pakistan. With the exception of some Chinese isolates, the pathogenicity of Iranian isolates is assumed to be similar to that of other Eurasian isolates. It is possible that an increase in mortality in field conditions was due to co-infection of new isolates with bacteria such as mycoplasma, Escherichia coli and Ornithobacterium rhinotracheale, rather than the emergence of a pathogenic H9N2 subtype of the virus.
authors: Toroghi, R.;Momayez, R.

title: Emergence of amantadine-resistant avian influenza H5N1 virus in India
abstract: This study reports the genetic characterization of a highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus (subtype H5N1) isolated from poultry in West Bengal, India. We analyzed all eight genome segments of two viruses isolated from chickens in January 2010 to understand their genetic association with other Indian H5N1 isolates and possible link between different outbreaks. The hemagglutinin (HA) gene of the viruses showed multiple basic amino acids at the cleavage site, a marker of high virulence in chickens. The major concern was that the viruses showed amino acid substitution from serine to asparagine at position 31 of the M2 ion channel protein, suggesting the emergence of previously unreported amantadine-resistant mutants in HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in India. The amino acid lysine at position 627 of the PB2 protein highlights the risk that viruses have to mammals. In phylogenetic trees, viruses are clustered across all genes in progeny of avian isolates from India (2008-2009) and bird and human isolates from Bangladesh (2007-2009). Both of these viruses were most closely related to the 2008 viruses in West Bengal, which were in subdivision 2.2.3 of the H5N1 viruses. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2010.
authors: Tosh, C.;Murugkar, H. V.;Nagarajan, S.;Tripathi, S.;Katare, M.;Jain, R.;Khandia, R.;Syed, Z.;Behera, P.;Patil, S.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Dubey, S. C.

title: Initial genetic characterization of Peste des Petits Ruminants from Niger: on the advancing front of the Asian virus lineage.
abstract: Peste des Petits Ruminants (PPR) is a serious transboundary infectious disease of small ruminant animals. The causative agent, PPR virus (PPRV), can be separated into four genetically distinct lineages using phylogenetic analysis. In recent years, PPRV's IV. lineage significantly expanded its geographic distribution from Asia to the Middle East and into Africa, where it was gradually replaced by other PPRV lineages. Lineages I and II are historically distributed in West Africa. Currently, lineage II appears to dominate the region, whereas lineage I's last recorded occurrence dates back to 1994. Recent studies reported the existence of lineage IV in Nigeria and suggested that this lineage expanded in West Africa. Despite reports of incidence of PPR in Nigeria's close neighbor Niger, PPRV has never been genetically characterized.
