In this study, pathological samples collected from sick goats in 2013 during a suspected PPR outbreak in southern Niger near the Nigerian border were compared with samples collected in an earlier study in Southwest Niger in October 2001. These strains were characterized by sequencing and phylogenetic analysis to determine their genetic ancestry. Our results, in 2001 I and II. lineages circulate together in southwestern Niger, and that the strain that caused the outbreak in 2013 was IV. ancestry and closely related to strains described in Nigeria. These results confirm the progression of lineage IV in West Africa. The PPRV lineage process and its effects on the epidemiology and control of disease in this region are unclear and should be the subject of further studies in this area.
authors: Tounkara, K.;Bataille, A.;Adombi, C. M.;Maikano, I.;Djibo, G.;Settypalli, T. B. K.;Loitsch, A.;Diallo, A.;Libeau, G.

title: Genetic and biological characterization of an avian-like H1N2 swine flu virus produced by reclassification of the avian-like H1N1 and H3N2 subtypes circulating in Denmark.
abstract: Background: Influenza A virus subtypes H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 are the most common subtypes in pigs. A reclassified H1N2 swine flu virus (SIV) subtype emerged in 2003 and became widespread in Denmark. In this study, the reassortant H1N2 subtype was genetically characterized by an experimental infection study and the infection dynamics were compared with a "bird-like" H1N1 virus. Methods Sequence analyzes of the H1N2 virus were performed. Two groups of pigs were vaccinated with reassortant H1N2 virus and a "bird-like" H1N1 virus, respectively, followed by vaccination with the opposite subtype four weeks later. Measurements of HI antibodies and acute phase proteins were made. Nasal virus excretion and viral load in the lungs were determined by real-time RT-PCR. Results: Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the reclassified H1N2 virus contained a European "bird-like" H1 gene and a European "pig-like" N2 gene, thus being genetically different from, but similar to, most H1N2 viruses circulating in Europe. It was reported in Sweden and Italy in 2009/2010. Sequence analyzes of internal genes revealed that reclassification likely arose between circulating Danish "bird-like" H1N1 and H3N2 SIVs. Infected pigs developed cross-reactive antibodies and increased acute phase protein levels after vaccinations. Pigs vaccinated with H1N2 exhibited nasal virus shedding for seven days, peaking at day 1 post-vaccination two days before and six times higher than H1N1-infected pigs. However, the difference was not statistically significant. Pigs euthanized on day 4 post-vaccination had a high viral load in all lung lobes. After the second vaccination, nasal virus excretion was minimal. There were no clinical signs other than high body temperature under the experimental conditions. Conclusions: The "bird-like" H1N2 subtype, established in the Danish pig population since at least 2003, is a reasortant between circulating pig "bird-like" H1N1 and H3N2. Danish H1N2 has a "bird-like" H1 and differs from many other H1N2 viruses reported in Europe and North America/Asia, which have H1 genes of human or "classic-pig" origin, respectively. However, the variant also appears to be circulating in countries such as Sweden and Italy. The infection dynamics of the reclassified "bird-like" H1N2 are similar to the former "bird-like" H1N1 subtype. Â© 2013 Trebbien et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Trebbien, R.;Bragstad, K.;Larsen, L. E.;Nielsen, J.;BÃ¸tner, A.;Heegaard, P. M.;Fomsgaard, A.;Viuff, B.;Hjulsager, C. K.

title: Neuropathological research reveals underestimation of prevalence of neuroinfectious diseases in cattle in Switzerland
abstract: Neuroinfectious diseases in farm animals pose a serious threat to animal health, but their prevalence is not well documented and the etiology of the disease is often unidentified. The aim of this study was to establish baseline data on the prevalence of neuroinfectious diseases in cattle in Switzerland by neuropathological research and to identify disease-associated pathogens. The survey was conducted over a 1-year period using a representative number of brainstem samples (n = 1816) from fallen cattle. Overall, 4% (n = 73) of animals had significant lesions, the most common types indicative of viral (n = 27) and bacterial (n = 31) etiologies. Follow-up diagnosis by immunohistochemistry, PCR protocols and next-generation sequencing identified infection with Listeria monocytogenes (n = 6), ovine herpesvirus 2 (n = 7), bovine astrovirus CH13 (n = 2), bovine herpesvirus 6 (n = 6) , bovine retrovirus CH15 (n = 2), pulpavirus 1 (n = 2) and porcine astroviruses (n = 2). A retrospective survey has shown that animal owners observe clinical manifestations of neurological disease in approximately one-third of cases with lesions, which is estimated to correspond to approximately 85 cases per year in the adult fallen cattle population in Switzerland. This estimate contrasts sharply with the number of cases reported to authorities and reveals a gap in disease surveillance. Systematic neuropathological examination and follow-up molecular testing of neurologically diseased cattle can significantly increase the effectiveness of disease detection to predict the prevalence of endemic diseases, identify new or re-emerging pathogens, and provide "early warnings" of disease outbreaks.
authors: Truchet, L.;Walland, J.;Wuthrich, D.;Boujon, C. L.;Posthaus, H.;Bruggmann, R.;Schupbach-Regula, G.;Oevermann, A.;Seuberlich, T.

title: High-throughput sequencing elicits differential immune responses in intestinal mucosa of two innate lines affected by necrotic enteritis.
abstract: We investigated necrotic enteritis (NE)-mediated transcripts of immune-related genes in the intestinal mucosa of two highly inbred White Leghorn chicken lines, lines 6.3 and 7.2, that shared the same MHC haplotype and showed different levels of NE susceptibility using high. - output RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) technology. NE was induced by the co-infection model previously described using Eimeria maxima and Clostridium perfringens. The RNA-Seq generated is over 38 million sequence reads for Marek's disease (MD) resistant line 6.3 and over 40 million reads for MD susceptible line 7.2. Alignment of these sequences with the Gallus gallus genome database revealed the expression of more than 29,900 NE-induced gene transcripts in these two lines, among which 7,841 genes were significantly upregulated and 2,919 genes were downregulated in 6.3 chicken lines and 6,043 genes were significantly upregulated. were downregulated and 2,764 genes were downregulated in NE-induced line 7.2 compared to their uninfected controls. Analysis of 560 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) using the gene ontology database revealed explanations for 246 biological processes, 215 molecular functions, and 81 cellular components. Among the 53 cytokines and 96 cytokine receptors, 15 cytokines and 29 cytokine receptors were highly expressed in line 6.3, while the expression of 15 cytokines and 15 cytokine receptors was higher in line 7.2 than in line 6.3 (fold change >= 2, p< 0.01). In a hierarchical cluster analysis of novel mRNAs, the novel mRNA transcriptome showed higher expression in line 6.3 than in line 7.2; this is consistent with the expression profile of immune-related target genes. In qRT-PCR and RNA-Seq analysis, all examined genes showed similar responses to NE in both lines 6.3 and 7.2 (correlation coefficient R=0.85-0.89, p<0.01). This study is the first to describe NE-induced DEGs and novel transcriptomes using RNA-seq data from two inbred chicken lines showing different levels of NE sensitivity. These findings provide important insights into our current knowledge of host-pathogen interaction and the nature of host genes that can serve as markers of NE resistance for molecular reproduction.
authors: Truong, A. D.;Hong, Y. H.;Lillehoj, H. S.

title: Analysis of heterogeneous populations of antihemagglutination antibodies in hyperimmune serum against influenza virus by indirect solid-phase radioimmunoassay
abstract: Antihemagglutinating antibody populations in hyperimmune rabbit sera against influenza A/PR8/34, A/Moscow/PAN/52 and A/Swine Iowa/15/31 viruses were examined by indirect competitive solid phase radioimmunoassay (SPRIA). Under competitive test conditions with the immobilized virus homologous to the tested serum, not all subpopulations of cross-reacting antibodies in serum are identified. Competition in the immobilized heterologous virus system defines a more complete spectrum of cross-reacting antibody. A combined analysis of serum under both competing variants, each of the sera subtypes of hemagglutinin H0, H1 and H0, H1 and Hsw1 according to the 1971 Nomenclature. The identification of cross-reacting antibodies allowed to draw conclusions about both the presence of antigenic markers on the surface of the hemagglutinin molecules of the studied viruses and the analysis of their variability. The pattern of variation of similar determinants in the transition from viruses of one subtype to viruses of another subtype is characteristic of the drift type.
authors: Trushinskaia, G. N.;Rovnova, Z. I.;Berezina, O. N.;Grigor'eva, T. A.;Isaeva, E. I.

title: Analysis of heterogeneous population of antihemagglutinating antibodies in hyperimmune rabbit sera against influenza virus by indirect solid-phase radioimmunoassay
abstract: Antihemagglutinating antibody populations in hyperimmune rabbit sera against influenza A/PR8/34, A/Moscow/PAN/52 and A/Swine Iowa/15/31 viruses were examined by indirect competitive solid phase radioimmunoassay (SPRIA). Under competitive test conditions with the immobilized virus homologous to the tested serum, not all subpopulations of cross-reacting antibodies in serum are identified. Competition in the immobilized heterologous virus system defines a more complete spectrum of cross-reacting antibody. A combined analysis of serum under both competing variants, each of the sera subtypes of hemagglutinin H0, H1 and H0, H1 and Hsw1 according to the 1971 Nomenclature. The identification of cross-reacting antibodies allowed to draw conclusions about both the presence of antigenic markers on the surface of the hemagglutinin molecules of the studied viruses and an analysis of their variability. The pattern of variation of similar determinants in the transition from viruses of one subtype to viruses of another subtype is characteristic of the drift type.
authors: Trushinskaya, G. N.;Rovnova, Z. I.;Berezina, O. N.

title: Relevant oncogenic viruses in veterinary medicine: original pathogens and animal models for human disease.
abstract: Oncogenic viruses are important pathogens in farm and domestic animals. These original pathogens are classified in several virus families such as Retroviridae, Papillomaviridae, and Herpesviridae. Besides their role as pathogens for their original host, animal viruses serve as valuable models for viruses that affect humans, such as hepatitis B virus, and issues of immunity, therapy, as well as basic pathophysiological mechanisms can often only be addressed in these animal systems.
authors: Truyen, U.;LÃ¶chelt, M.

title: There is nothing permanent except change. Emergence of new viral diseases
abstract: The sudden emergence of seemingly new viruses with pathogenic potential is of fundamental importance in medical microbiology and is a constant threat to humans and animals. The emergence of a 'new' pathogen is not an isolated event, as evidenced, for example, by the frequent occurrence of new strains of influenza virus. Often new virus strains circulate in a susceptible population with older strains, but replacement of older strains has also been observed. In rare cases, new viruses can cause dramatic epidemics or pandemics, such as those observed with human immunodeficiency virus, canine parvovirus, or the agent bovine spongiform encephalopathy in the UK. The mechanisms of emergence are not always clearly understood, but an altered host range appears to be a common occurrence. It is often unknown whether there is a true change in host range or whether the virus has adapted to the host and replicated more efficiently. This review attempts to summarize known facts about a wide variety of 'novel' mammalian viruses such as monkey, human and feline lentiviruses, feline coronaviruses, feline parvoviruses, carnivorous morbilliviruses, influenza A viruses. infectious spongiform encephalopathies. Special emphasis will be placed on genetic mechanisms that may have taken place and which may be responsible for their sudden emergence.
authors: Truyen, U.;Parrish, C. R.;Harder, T. C.;Kaaden, O. R.

title: Molecular epidemiological studies on viruses of foot and mouth disease type O Taiwan from the 1997 epidemic
abstract: Sequence diversity was evaluated for the complete VP1 gene directly amplified from 49 clinical samples during an explosive foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) epidemic in Taiwan. Type O Taiwan FMD viruses are genetically highly homogeneous as seen with the minute deviation of 0.2-0.9% occurring in the 20 variants. Viral variants O/HCP-0314/TW/97 and O/TCP-022/TW/97 dominated FMD outbreaks and were common in affected swine farming areas. Comparison of the deduced amino acid sequences around major neutralizable antigenic sites on the VP1 polypeptide revealed no significant antigenic variation. However, variant O/CHP-158/TW/97 had an alternative critical residue at position 43 at antigenic site 3, which could be due to selective pressure at the site. Two vaccine production strains (O1/Manisa/Turkey/69 and O1/Campos/Brazil/71) probably provide partial heterologous protection against O Taiwan viruses of pig. Taiwan variants of type O are clustered in the A1 subclade from the four major lineages in the phylogenetic tree. The O/Hong Kong/9/94 and O/1685/Moscow/Russia/95 viruses in the A2 subclade are closely related to the O Taiwan variants. The causative agent of the 1997 outbreak likely originated from a single common source of O-type FMD virus prevalent in neighboring areas. Copyright (C) 2000 Elsevier Science BV
authors: Tsai, C. P.;Pan, C. H.;Liu, M. Y.;Lin, Y. L.;Chen, C. M.;Huang, T. S.;Cheng, I. C.;Jong, M. H.;Yang, P. C.

title: Novel H1N2 and H3N1 influenza viruses in Taiwan pig herds
authors: Tsai, C. P.;Pan, M. J.

title: Emergence of rabies associated with a syllabic enzootic formosan ferret badger in Taiwan and geographical separation of two phylogenetic rabies virus groups.
abstract: Taiwan had been declared rabies-free in humans and pets for five years, until July 2013, when, surprisingly, three Formosan ferret badgers (FB) were diagnosed with rabies. Since then, various wild carnivores and other wildlife species have been found dead, neurologically ill or displaying aggressive behavior around the island. Animal bodies were examined for rabies by direct fluorescent antibody testing (FAT) to identify affected animal species, geographic areas, and environments. Viral genomes from the brains of selected rabid animals were sequenced for the phylogeny of rabies viruses (RABV). Out of a total of 1016 wild carnivores, 276/831 (33.2%) Formosan FBs were FAT positive, with occasional bite events in 1 dog and suspicious spread in 1 house mouse. All other animals tested were negative for rabies, including dogs, cats, bats, mice, rats, and squirrels. Rabies was associated with the badger and was limited to nine counties/cities in syllabic settings. 59 The phylogeny of nucleoprotein and glycoprotein genes derived from Formosan FB-associated RABV, their distribution to western and eastern Taiwan provided by the Central Mountain Range and south-central rabies-affected regions by a river bisecting northern rabies and western Taiwan. The geographic and genetic separation, syllabic enzooticity, and unique features of FB-joining of RABV suggest a logical strategy for the control of rabies in this nation.
authors: Tsai, K. J.;Hsu, W. C.;Chuang, W. C.;Chang, J. C.;Tu, Y. C.;Tsai, H. J.;Liu, H. F.;Wang, F. I.;Lee, S. H.

title: An Evolutionarily Young Polar Bear (Ursus maritimus) Endogenous Retrovirus Identified from Next-Gen Sequence Data
abstract: Transcriptome analysis of polar bear (Ursus maritimus) tissues identified sequences similar to Porcine Endogenous Retroviruses (PERV). Based on these sequences, four proviral copies and 15 solo long terminal repeats (LTRs) of a newly identified endogenous retrovirus were characterized from the polar bear draft genome sequence. Brown bear (Ursus arctos) and black bear (Ursus americanus) closely related sequences were identified by PCR analysis, but were absent in non-Ursinae bear species. That's why the virus was named UrsusERV. Two distinct sets of LTRs were observed, including a recombinant ERV with one LTR belonging to each group, suggesting that genomic invasions by at least two UrsusERV variants have occurred recently. Age estimates based on transient LTR difference among ursids and preservation of integration sites suggest that the viral group is only a few million years old. The youngest provirus was polar bear-specific, had intact open reading frames (ORFs) and could potentially encode functional proteins. Phylogenetic analyzes of the UrsusERV consensus protein sequences indicate that it is part of a swine, gibbon and koala retrovirus lineage. The young age estimates and lineage specificity of the virus suggest that UrsusERV is a recent cross-species transmission from an unknown reservoir, placing the viral group among the youngest ERVs identified in mammals.
authors: Tsangaras, K.;Mayer, J.;Alquezar-Planas, D. E.;Greenwood, A. D.

title: Identification of a new bat papillomavirus by metagenomics
abstract: The discovery of new viruses in animals expands our knowledge of viral diversity and potentially emerging zoonoses. High-throughput sequencing (HTS) technology yields millions or even billions of sequence reads per run, allowing a comprehensive search of the genetic content within a sample without prior nucleic acid amplification. In this study, we scanned 156 rectal swab samples from apparently healthy bats (n = 96), pigs (n = 9), cattle (n = 9), stray dogs (n = 11), stray cats (n = 11). monkeys (n = 20), using an HTS metagenomic approach. The complete genome of a novel papillomavirus (PV), Miniopterus schreibersii papillomavirus type 1 (MscPV1), with 60% nucleotide identity of L1 to Canine papillomavirus (CPV6) was identified in a sample from the Common Bent-wing Bat (M. schreibersii). . ). About 7.5 kb in length, with 45.8% G+C content and a genomic organization similar to that of other PVs. Despite the higher nucleotide identity between the MscPV1 and CPV6 genomes, maximum likelihood phylogenetic analysis of the L1 gene sequence showed that MscPV1 and Erethizon dorsatum papillomavirus (EdPV1) were most closely related. The estimated divergence time of MscPV1 from the EdPV1/MscPV1 common ancestor was about 60.2-91.9 million years ago and was inferred under strict hours using the L1 and E1 genes. Estimates were limited by the lack of reliable calibration points from the common deviation due to possible host drift. Since the nucleotide sequence of this virus shows only limited similarity to that of the respective animal PVs, the conventional PCR approach using consensus primers is unlikely to detect new virus in the sample. Unlike the first bat papillomavirus RaPV1, MscPV1 was found in an asymptomatic bat with no obvious mucosal or skin lesions, while RaPV1 was detected in basosquamous carcinoma of a fruit bat Rousettus aegyptiacus. We propose MscPV1 as the first member of the new Dyombda-papillomavirus genus. Â© 2012 Tse et al.
authors: Tse, H.;Tsang, A. K. L.;Tsoi, H. W.;Leung, A. S. P.;Ho, C. C.;Lau, S. K. P.;Woo, P. C. Y.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: Discovery and genomic characterization of a novel ovine partetravirus and a novel bovine partetravirus genotype
abstract: Partetravirus is a recently identified group of animal parvoviruses that includes human partetravirus, bovine partetravirus, and porcine partetravirus (formerly known as human parvovirus 4, bovine hocovirus, and porcine hocovirus, respectively). In this report, we describe the discovery and genomic characterization of partetraviruses in bovine and ovine samples from China. These partetraviruses were detected by PCR in 1.8% of bovine liver samples, 66.7% of ovine liver samples and 71.4% of ovine spleen samples. One of the bovine partetraviruses detected in the present samples is phylogenetically different from the bovine partetraviruses previously reported and likely represents a new genotype. Sheep partetravirus is a new partetravirus and is most closely related phylogenetically to bovine partetraviruses. Genome organization is conserved among these viruses, including the presence of a putative transmembrane protein encoded by an overlapping reading frame in ORF2. Results from this study provide further support for the classification of partetraviruses as a separate genus in Parvovirinae. Â© 2011 Tse et al.
authors: Tse, H.;Tsoi, H. W.;Teng, J. L. L.;Chen, X. C.;Liu, H.;Zhou, B.;Zheng, B. J.;Woo, P. C. Y.;Lau, S. K. P.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: A novel activation mechanism of avian influenza virus H9N2 by Furin.
abstract: Avian influenza virus H9N2 is common in waterfowl and has become endemic in poultry in Asia and the Middle East. H9N2 influenza viruses have served as an internal gene store for other avian influenza viruses that infect humans, and the few cases of human infection by H9N2 influenza viruses have demonstrated their pandemic potential. Fortunately, an extensive surveillance program enables close monitoring of H9N2 influenza viruses worldwide and has produced a large repository of virus sequences and phylogenetic information. Despite the large number of sequences in different databases, little is known about specific virus isolates and their pathogenesis. Here we characterize a low pathogenic avian influenza virus, A/chicken/Israel/810/2001 (H9N2) (Israel810), representative of influenza virus strains that cause severe morbidity and mortality in poultry farms. We show that, under certain conditions, Israel810 hemagglutinin (HA) can be activated by furin, a feature of the highly pathogenic avian influenza virus. We show that Israel810 HA can divide in cells with high levels of furin expression, and that a mutation in HA1 that abolishes a glycosylation site allows Israel810 HA to gain universal cleavage in cell culture. Pseudoparticles produced from Israel810 HA or the glycosylation mutant efficiently transduce cells. In contrast, the addition of a polybasic cleavage site to Israel810 HA leads to pseudoviruses that are compromised for transduction. Our data demonstrate a mechanism for an H9N2 evolutionary pathway that may allow it to acquire virulence differently from H5 and H7 influenza viruses. Â© 2014, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Tse, L. V.;Hamilton, A. M.;Friling, T.;Whittaker, G. R.

title: Similarities and differences between the E5 oncoproteins of bovine papillomaviruses type 1 and type 4: cytoskeleton, motility, and invasiveness in E5-transformed bovine and mouse cells.
abstract: Bovine papillomaviruses (BPVs) are oncogenic viruses. In cattle, BPV-1/2 is associated with bladder cancer and BPV-4 with upper GI tract cancer. BPV E5 is a small hydrophobic protein localized in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and Golgi apparatus (GA). E5 is the main transforming protein of BPVs, which can induce cell turnover in cultured mouse fibroblasts and primary bovine cells in cooperation with E7. E5-induced cell transformation is accompanied by activation of several cellular protein kinases, including growth factor receptors, and alkalinization of endosomes and GA. We report that BPV E5 causes swelling and fragmentation of the GA and extensive vacuolization of the cytoplasm. We now show that E5 from both BPV-1 and BPV-4 disrupts the actin cytoskeleton and focal adhesions in transformed bovine cells, and that these morphological and behavioral features are accompanied by hyperphosphorylation of the cellular phosphotyrosine kinase c-src. Both BPV-1 and BPV-4 E5 increase the motility of transformed mouse cells, but only BPV-1 E5 causes the transformed mouse cells to penetrate a matrigel matrix. BPV-1-transformed mouse cells, but not BPV-4-transduced mouse cells, have hyperphosphorylated c-src. Â© 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Tsirimonaki, E.;Ullah, R.;Marchetti, B.;Ashrafi, G. H.;McGarry, L.;Ozanne, B.;Campo, M. S.

title: Dynamics of envelope evolution in pig-tailed macaques infected with class C SHIV during disease progression analyzed by ultra-deep pyrosequencing.
abstract: Understanding the evolution of the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) envelope during disease progression can provide tremendous insights for vaccine development, and monkey-human immunodeficiency virus (SHIV) infection of the non-human primate provides an ideal platform for such studies. A newly developed C SHIV clade, SHIV-1157ipd3N4, capable of infecting Rhesus macaques, closely resembling primary HIV-1 in transmission and pathogenesis, was used to infect several pig-tailed macaques. One of the infected animals later progressed to AIDS, while one remained non-progressive. Viral envelope evolution in infected animals during disease progression was analyzed with a bioinformatics approach using ultra-deep pyrosequencing. Our results showed significant envelope variations that occur in the progressive animal after the onset of AIDS. These envelope variations affected the length of variable cycles and charges of different envelope regions. In addition, multiple mutations were involved in the CD4 and CCR5 binding sites, potentially affecting receptor binding affinity, viral fitness, and these can be selected in late stages of the disease. More importantly, these envelope mutations are not random, as these envelope mutations have been repeatedly observed in a rhesus macaque and a human infant infected with SHIV or HIV-1, respectively, carrying the parental envelope of the infectious molecular clone SHIV-1157ipd3N4. Also, similar mutations were observed in other studies on different types of envelopes, regardless of the host type. These recurrent mutations in different envelopes suggest that there may be a common evolutionary pattern and selection pathway for the HIV-1 envelope during disease progression.
authors: Tso, F. Y.;Tully, D. C.;Gonzalez, S.;Quince, C.;Ho, O.;Polacino, P.;Ruprecht, R. M.;Hu, S. L.;Wood, C.

title: Genetic diversity and recombination of enterovirus G strains in Japanese pigs: high prevalence of strains carrying the papain-like cysteine protease sequence in the enterovirus G population.
abstract: To examine the genetic diversity of enterovirus G (EV-G) among Japanese pigs, metagenomic sequencing was performed on fecal samples from pigs with or without diarrhea collected between 2014 and 2016. Fifty-nine EV-G sequences long, >5,000 nucleotides, were obtained. By full VP1 sequence analysis, Japanese EV-G isolates G1 (17 strains), G2 (four strains), G3 (22 strains), G4 (two strains), G6 (two strains), G9 (six strains), G10 (five strains) strain) and a new genotype (a strain). Remarkably, 16 G1 and one G2 strains identified in diarrheal (23.5%; four strains) or normal (76.5%; 13 strains) stool samples, a papain-like cysteine protease (PL-CP) recently found in the USA He had the sequence. and Belgium at the 2C–3A junction in the EV-G genome. This article presents the first report of the high prevalence of viruses carrying PL-CP in the EV-G population. Also, possible inter-genotype and intra-genotype recombination events were found among EV-G strains, including G1-PL-CP strains. Our findings may advance understanding of the molecular epidemiology and genetic evolution of EV-Gs.
authors: Tsuchiaka, S.;Naoi, Y.;Imai, R.;Masuda, T.;Ito, M.;Akagami, M.;Ouchi, Y.;Ishii, K.;Sakaguchi, S.;Omatsu, T.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Shirai, J.;Satani, Y.;Takashima, Y.;Taniguchi, Y.;Takasu, M.;Madarame, H.;Sunaga, F.;Aoki, H.;Makino, S.;Mizutani, T.;Nagai, M.

title: Identification of a novel bovine enterovirus with highly divergent amino acid sequences in the capsid protein.
abstract: Background: Bovine enterovirus (BEV) belongs to the Enterovirus E or F species, the Enterovirus genus, and the Picornaviridae family. Although numerous studies have identified BEVs in the feces of cattle with diarrhea, the pathogenicity of BEVs remains unclear. We previously reported the detection of new kobu-like virus in calf feces by metagenomic analysis. In this study, we identified a novel BEV in diarrheal stool collected for this study. Whole genome sequences were determined by deep sequencing in faeces. Secondary RNA structure analysis of the 5â€² untranslated region (UTR), phylogenetic tree structure and binary identity analysis were performed. Results: The whole genome sequences of BEV were genetically distant from other EVs and the VP1 coding region contained novel and unique amino acid sequences. We named this strain BEV AN12/Bos taurus/JPN/2014 (referred to as BEV-AN12). According to genome analysis, the genome length of this virus is 7414 nucleotides excluding the poly(A) tail, and its genome consists of 5" UTR, open reading frame encoding a single polyprotein, and 3" UTR. The results of the secondary RNA structure analysis showed that at 5â€²UTR, BEV-AN12 has an additional cloverleaf structure and small stem loop structure similar to other BEVs. In binary identity analysis, the BEV-AN12 polyprotein showed high amino acid (aa) identities to Enterovirus F in the P2 and P3 regions (aa identity -82.4%). Therefore, BEV-AN12 is closely related to Enterovirus F. However, aa sequences in capsid protein regions, particularly the VP1 coding region, showed significantly lower aa identity to other viruses in the Enterovirus genus (VP1 aa identity -58.6%). In addition, although BEV-AN12 clustered with Enterovirus F in trees based on sequences in the P2 and P3 genome region, it branched separately from Enterovirus E and F in phylogenetic trees based on aa sequences of P1 and VP1. Results: We identified new BEV with highly different aa sequences in the VP1 coding region in Japan. Based on the species definition, we proposed to name this strain "Enterovirus K", a new species within the Enterovirus genus. More genomic studies are needed to understand the pathogenicity of BEVs.
authors: Tsuchiaka, S.;Rahpaya, S. S.;Otomaru, K.;Aoki, H.;Kishimoto, M.;Naoi, Y.;Omatsu, T.;Sano, K.;Okazaki-Terashima, S.;Katayama, Y.;Oba, M.;Nagai, M.;Mizutani, T.

title: Evidence of serological diversity in group C rotaviruses
abstract: Cowden strain of porcine group C rotavirus and Shintoku strain of bovine group C rotavirus were classified as different serotypes by two-way cross-neutralization tests. Two neutralization patterns were observed against Cowden and Shintoku strains when hyperimmune or recovery phase antisera against three uncultivated pig group C rotavirus and one human group C rotavirus were used in one-way cross-neutralization tests. Two antiserums against swine group C rotavirus and human group C rotavirus neutralized the Cowden strain at high titers but did not neutralize the Shintoku strain, suggesting that these three strains were serotypically related to the Cowden strain. Antiserum remaining to a porcine group C rotavirus (HF strain) reacted with Cowden and Shintoku group C rotaviruses in cell culture immunofluorescence tests, but did not neutralize either virus in one-way cross-neutralization, suggesting that the HF strain belonged to a third group. serotype. However, confirmation of these findings requires additional analysis with two-way cross-neutralization. Our findings support the existence of at least two distinct group C rotavirus serotypes, and possibly a third, between animals and humans. The observed serotypic similarity between the Cowden strain and a human group C rotavirus suggests that the cultivable Cowden strain and serum antiserum against this virus may provide important reagents for the diagnosis of group C rotaviruses in humans.
authors: Tsunemitsu, H.;Jiang, B.;Yamashita, Y.;Oseto, M.;Ushijima, H.;Saif, L. J.

title: Pig rotavirus C in pigs with gastroenteritis in Thai pig farms, 2011-2016
authors: Tuanthap, S.;Phupolphan, C.;Luengyosluechakul, S.

title: Pig rotavirus C in pigs with gastroenteritis in Thai pig farms, 2011-2016
abstract: Pigs are economically important food animals, but the highly contagious swine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) and rotavirus can affect pig herds and contribute significantly to piglet morbidity and mortality. Although there are studies of rotavirus group A (RVA) in Thailand, reports of rotavirus group C (RVC) are limited. Here we aimed to determine the prevalence of circulating RVC in commercial pig farms in Thailand. We analyzed the fecal and intestinal mucosal contents of 769 diarrhea-affected pigs between 2011 and 2016 using specific RT-PCR for the PEDV spike (S), rotavirus glycoprotein (G) VP7 and protease-sensitive protein (P) VP4 genes. We found that 6.6% (51/769) of the samples tested positive for RVC, of which 11 were co-infected with RVA and four samples were co-infected with PEDV. Three samples tested positive for all three viruses. Phylogenetic analysis of the VP7 gene showed that the most common RVC genotype was G1, grouped with the prototypical RVC Cowden strain. The G6 and G9 were also common, while the G3 was relatively rare. Analysis of the VP4 gene revealed that the most common P type was P[5], followed by P[4], P[7] and P[1]. There were six G/P combinations in total (G6P[5], G1P[1], G1P[4], G1P[5], G9P[4] and G9P[7]), of which G6P[5] was the most dominant.
authors: Tuanthap, S.;Phupolphan, C.;Luengyosluechakul, S.;Duang-In, A.;Theamboonlers, A.;Wattanaphansak, S.;Vongpunsawad, S.;Amonsin, A.;Poovorawan, Y.

title: Seroepidemiology of Bivens Arm virus infections of cattle in Florida, St. Croix, and Puerto Rico.
abstract: Bivens Arm virus (BAV) is a newly discovered rhabdovirus that infects cattle and buffalo in Florida. The virus is classified as a member of the Tibrogargan group, whose members have so far only been found in Australasia. It is thought to be transmitted by Culicoides species. Bivens Arm virus was first isolated from Culicoides insignis, suggesting that BAV is also transmitted by this genus. In the Caribbean, St. Croix and Puerto Rico, a serological study of two small groups of cattle revealed that antibodies to BAV, or a closely related virus, were present on both islands. Retrospective analysis of seroconversions to BAV in sentry calves in Florida failed to show statistically significant correlations to populations of potential Culicoides vectors.
authors: Tuekam, T.;Greiner, E. C.;Gibbs, E. P. J.

title: Antigenic relationship between influenza A viruses of human and animal origin
abstract: The reciprocal antigenic relationships between 17 influenza A viruses of human, porcine, equine and avian origin were investigated by hemagglutination-inhibition (HI) and strain-specific complement-fixation (CF). Cross-reactions were observed between the following strains: (a) Equi/1/Prag/1/56, Fowl plague (Netherlands strain) and Turkey/England/1/63 (Langham strain); (b) Equi/2/Miami/1/63, Quail/Italy/1117/65, Pheasant/Italy/647/66, Duck/England/1/62 and Turkey/Canada/1/63; (c) A2/Singapore/1/57 and Turkey/Massachussets/65; (d) Pig/S15/30 and Chicken/Scotland/1/59. Results of HI tests with post-infection sera showed precisely narrower specificity than those of HI with hyperimmune serum or strain-specific CF. Clearly, the antigenic subtypes of influenza A viruses have no sharp boundaries, and studies of a wider range of strains are likely to reveal a continuous spectrum of antigenic variation for the entire group. The authors suggest that in practice it may be necessary to use host specificity rather than antigenic specificity as the main criterion for classifying influenza A viruses.
authors: Tumova, B.;Pereira, H. G.

title: Gene-centered metagenomic analysis of the cat gut microbiome using 454 junior pyrosequencing
abstract: The feline gastrointestinal microbiota has a direct impact on feline health, as well as human health, as a reservoir for potential zoonotic pathogens and antibiotic-resistant bacterial strains. To identify the gastrointestinal microbial diversity of cats, fecal samples from cats were characterized using both culture-dependent and culture-independent methods. However, data on the overall microbial composition and functions are lacking. The current descriptive study evaluated both phylogenetic and metabolic diversity of the feline intestinal microbiota using GS Junior titanium shotgun pyrosequencing. A total of 152,494 pyrosequencing reads (5405 combined contigs) were generated and classified according to both phylogenetic and metabolic profiles of the feline intestinal microbiota. The Bacteroides/Chlorobi group was the most dominant bacterial phylum containing ~. 68% of the total classified diversity, followed by Firmicutes (~.13%) and Proteobacteria (~6%). Archaea, fungi and viruses made up small communities of general microbial diversity. Interestingly, this study also identified a number of potential enteric zoonotic pathogens (0.02-1.25%) and antimicrobial resistance-related genes (0.02-0.7%) in cat fecal materials. Based on clustering among nine gastrointestinal metagenomes from five different monogastric hosts (dog, human, mouse, cat, and chicken), the cat metagenome was closely clustered with chicken at both the phylogenetic and metabolic levels (>80%). Future studies are needed to provide deeper insights into both intrinsic and extrinsic influences, such as the impact of age, genetics, and dietary interventions on the composition of the feline gastrointestinal microbiome. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Tun, H. M.;Brar, M. S.;Khin, N.;Jun, L.;Hui, R. K. H.;Dowd, S. E.;Leung, F. C. C.

title: Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) virus, Democratic Republic of the Congo, 2017
abstract: In 2017, highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) virus was detected in poultry in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Whole genome phylogeny showed that the virus clustered with H5N8 clade 2.3.4.4B strains from birds in central and southern Asia. The emergence of this virus in Central Africa poses a threat to animal health and food security.
authors: Twabela, A. T.;Tshilenge, G. M.;Sakoda, Y.;Okamatsu, M.;Bushu, E.;Kone, P.;Wiersma, L.;Zamperin, G.;Drago, A.;Zecchin, B.;Monne, I.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of Japanese encephalitis virus: envelope gene-based analysis reveals a fifth genotype, geographic clustering and multiple entry of the virus into the Indian subcontinent
abstract: We report the analysis of the complete nucleotide sequence for the Indian isolate (P20778; Genbank Accession number AF080251) of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV). The phylogenetic tree topology obtained using thirteen whole genome sequences of JEV was reconstructed with the envelope, NS1, NS3 and NS5 genes, revealing wide variation between the two Indian strains included. A more comprehensive analysis of JEV evolution using the sequence of 107 envelopes available for isolates from different geographic locations worldwide revealed five different JEV genotypes that exhibited a minimum nucleotide variation of 7% with high bootstrapping support values. The tree also revealed general clustering of strains and multiple introductions of JEV into the Indian subcontinent based on geographic location. Unnamed nucleotide divergence rates of the envelope gene estimated that ancestry common to all JEV genotypes emerged within the last three hundred years.
authors: Uchil, P. D.;Satchidanandam, V.

title: Studies on Cotia virus; an unclassified smallpox virus
abstract: This article is a report of studies on Cotia virus; this was first isolated in Brazil in 1965 and was later shown to be a smallpox disease. Cotia virus was grown in a wide variety of cell cultures and on chick chorio-allantois (CAM). Its growth characteristics are similar to those of other pox viruses. Microscopy showed that virus factories or type B inclusions arose before the infectious strain virus was proven. Type A inclusions appeared later, after the development of the strain virus; these were shown to differ from type A inclusions of cowpox and other smallpox viruses by electron microscopy, and they were termed Cotia bodies. Immunofluorescent staining also showed ring structures that appeared before the development of Cotia bodies. Growth of Cotia virus in human embryo lung (HEL) cells was sensitive to DNA and protein synthesis inhibitors but resistant to the concentration of rifampicin that inhibited vaccine virus. The sharing of antigens between Cotia virus and vaccinia virus was demonstrated by gel precipitation tests and immunofluorescent staining. There was no cross-neutralization between Cotia virus and vaccine virus, nor did the anti-Cotia sera neutralize representatives of other smallpox virus groups.
authors: Ueda, Y.;Dumbell, K. R.;Tsuruhara, T.;Tagaya, I.

title: Use of DOP-PCR for non-specific virus detection
abstract: Detection and identification of pathogens in any sample without any knowledge of the pathogen requires a combination of sample purification and generic signal amplification. Our universal virus detection assay combines virus capsid purification with a general polymerase chain reaction (PCR) optimized for virus-sized genomes. As a general strategy, biochemical and physical purification by targeted digestion of contaminating host nucleic acids precedes nucleic acid extraction. RNA is transcribed into cDNA; cDNA and DNA are then used as templates for degenerate oligonucleotide primer PCR (DOP-PCR). This PCR uses a pool of related but different primers that combine degenerate and specific annealing conditions. PCR products can be identified by cloning and sequencing, microarray or high-throughput sequencing. We detected enveloped and non-enveloped DNA and RNA viruses by DOP-PCR in cell culture as well as in clinical samples. The test is capable of detecting single- and double-stranded genomes, circular genomes, segmented genomes, and linear genomes. Both large virus genomes such as herpes virus and very small virus genomes (eg, circovirus) can be precisely detected in the same assay. The DOP-PCR test can be used to identify viruses directly from biological samples or cell culture. A powerful feature of DOP-PCR is its ability to amplify viral sequences without prior knowledge of these sequences, increasing the probability of finding mutated or new viruses. Combined with high-throughput sequencing, DOP-PCR is a very sensitive tool that could potentially be used for the characterization of a given sample. ©PDA, Inc. 2011.
authors: Uhlenhaut, C.;McClenahan, S.;Krause, P. R.

title: Complete nucleotide sequence of IT-227/82, an avian paramyxovirus type-1 pigeon strain (Columba livia)
abstract: This article describes the complete genome sequence of IT-227/82, a strain of pigeon avian paramyxovirus type-1 (PPMV-1). IT-227/82 is an antigenic variant of chicken Newcastle disease virus (NDV). The genome is 15,192 nucleotides (nt) long, similar to the previously published NDV strain ZJ1. However, it is six nt longer than the genomes of the NDV strains LaSota/46 and Beaudette C. The six nt insertion was located in the 5'² noncoding region of the nucleoprotein (NP) gene. The presence of this six-nt insert showed no correlation with the virulence or reservoir of the NDV strains sequenced thus far. Genome length of 15,186 or 15,192 nt can be attributed to "old" (I, II, III and IV) and "new" (V, VI, VII and VIII) NDV genotypes, respectively. Comparison of open reading frames showed that PPMV-1 strain IT-227/82 encodes the longest W protein (227 amino acids). The length of the W protein varied considerably even within genotypes and therefore cannot be considered a phylogenetic trait. The hemagglutinin-neuraminidase protein of strain IT-227/82 consists of 571 amino acids, similar to genotype IV, V and VII NDV strains, while genotype I and II strains have longer HN proteins of 616 and 577 amino acids, respectively. The length of the hemagglutinin-neuraminidase protein has phylogenetic significance. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 2006.
authors: UjvÃ¡ri, D.

title: Identification and subgrouping of pigeon-type Newcastle disease virus strains by restriction enzyme cleavage site analysis.
abstract: host variant of the Newcastle disease virus (NDV, Avulavirus genus, Paramyxoviridae family) is responsible for an autonomous disease in pigeons. It originated in the Mediterranean region in the late 1970s. Despite the great genetic diversity, the vast majority of strains belong to a monophyletic group (subline VIb) within genotype VI of NDV strains native to the region at the time. To date, only one monoclonal antibody assay is available for the specific identification of pigeon-type strains. A specific genetic assay suitable for the identification of pigeon isolates is described. Cleavage site analysis of a 1349 bp amplicon of the fusion protein gene was performed using the restriction enzymes (RE) HinfI, BstOI and Rsal. RE analysis of more than 100 strains isolated from 16 countries between 1978 and 2002 revealed nine RE-patterns that are progressive region variants of the parental (group VI) genotype. Despite significant site variations, current pigeon viruses lacked a BstOI cleavage site at nucleotide 1601 shared by other chicken-derived NDV strains. RE analysis is a simple and reliable method for both identification and subgrouping of pigeon-type viruses. Â© 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: UjvÃ¡ri, D.;Wehmann, E.;Herczeg, J.;Lomniczi, B.

title: Genetic characterization of bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) viruses: confirmation of the presence of BVD genotype 2 in Africa
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) has emerged as one of the economically important pathogens in cattle populations with a worldwide distribution and causing a range of disease syndromes. Two genotypes, BVDV 1 and 2, exist and are distinguished on the basis of the sequence of the 5â€² noncoding region (5' NCR) using real-time PCR. Real-time PCR is more sensitive, specific, and less time-consuming than conventional PCR, and has less risk of cross-contamination of samples. Limited information is available on the genetic subtypes of BVDV in South Africa. The aim of this study was to identify the BVDV genotypes currently circulating in South African fattened areas. A total of 279 specimens (219 tissue specimens, 59 trans-tracheal aspirate and 1 blood specimen) were collected from dead and live cattle with lesions or clinical signs consistent with BVDV infection. Homogenates collected from the same animals were prepared and total RNA was extracted. A screening test was performed on the pooled samples and positive pools were investigated individually. A Cador BVDV Type 1/2 RT-PCR Kit (QIAGEN, Hilden, Germany) was used for real-time PCR assay on a LightCyclerÂ® V2. 0 real-time PCR machines (Roche Diagnostics, Mannheim, Germany). Results were read at 530 and 640 nm for BVDV 1 and 2, respectively. Bovine viral diarrhea virus was detected in a total of 103 samples, including 91 tissue samples, 1 blood sample, and 11 trans-tracheal aspirates. Eighty-five (82.5%) of the strains were genotype 1 and 18 (17.5%) were genotype 2. When sequencing data were compared, genotypes 1 and 2 of the field strains did not cluster with the vaccine strains currently used in the cultivation areas. in South Africa. This study established the presence of BVDV genotype 2 in cattle from South Africa based on the high sequence similarity between the genotype 2 field strains and the 890 strain from North America. The presence of genotype 2 viruses belonging to phylogenetically distinct clusters and coexisting in fattening areas is consistent with the probability of multiple virus introductions. These results represent the first documented evidence for the presence of BVDV genotype 2 in African cattle. © 2012 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Ularamu, H. G.;Sibeko, K. P.;Bosman, A. B.;Venter, E. H.;van Vuuren, M.

title: Comparative clinical sample preparation of DNA and RNA viral nucleic acids for a commercial deep sequencing system (Illumina MiSeq())
abstract: Sequence-independent methods for viral discovery are widely used for whole genome sequencing of viruses. Different protocols for viral enrichment, library preparation and sequencing have become increasingly accessible and less costly. However, no studies to date have focused on optimizing viral sample preparation for commercial deep sequencing. Accordingly, the aim of this study was to evaluate an In-House enzymatic protocol for double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) synthesis and also to compare the use of a commercially available kit protocol (Nextera XT, Illumina Inc, San Diego, CA, USA). ) and its combination (Illumina Miseq) with a library quantification kit (Kapa, Kapa Biosystems, Wilmington, MA, USA) for deep sequencing. Two RNA viruses (canine distemper virus and dengue virus) and one ssDNA virus (swine circovirus type 2) were tested with optimized protocols. The tested method for dsDNA synthesis has shown satisfactory results and can be used in vitro especially when enzymes are already available. Library preparation combining commercial kits (Nextera XT and Kapa) provided greater read and genome coverage, possibly due to the lack of small fragment recovery in the normalization step of Nextera XT. Additionally, libraries can be diluted or concentrated to increase genome coverage by quantification of Kapa.
authors: Ullmann, L. S.;de Camargo Tozato, C.;Malossi, C. D.;da Cruz, T. F.;Cavalcante, R. V.;Kurissio, J. K.;Cagnini, D. Q.;Rodrigues, M. V.;Biondo, A. W.;Araujo, J. P., Jr.

title: Characterization of the whole genome sequence of genotypes VI and VII velogenic Newcastle disease virus from Japan
abstract: The whole genome sequences of three Newcastle disease virus (NDV) strains isolated from commercial layer flocks vaccinated over a thirty-year period in Japan were characterized. All strains had genome lengths of 15,192 nucleotides consisting of six genes in the order 3â€²-NP-P/V/WMF-HN-L-5â€². The overall genomic characteristics of the Japanese field strains were consistent with previously characterized class II NDV, except those belonging to early genotypes (genotypes I-IV), which lacked six nucleotide insertions at nucleoprotein (NP) positions 1,648-1,653. gene. Phylogenetic analysis showed that Japanese strains can be classified into genotypes VIc and VIIe using the complete genome sequence and the full coding sequence of the fusion (F) gene according to the combined NDV classification system. Characterization of functional domains and neutralizing epitopes of Japanese field strains F and hemagglutinin-neuraminidase (HN) proteins revealed a total of 31 amino acid substitutions compared with vaccine strains Ishii and B1, widely used in Japan. Approximately two to three-fold reductions in VN titers, although virus neutralization (VN) testing has shown that poor herd immunity due to vaccine failure or partial and non-uniform immunization may be the main factors involved in the infectious mechanism of infection of Japanese field strains. Field NDV strains with a point mutation (E347K or E347G) in the linear epitope of the HN protein were observed in comparison with vaccine strain B1 and field strain 2440/69 without the point mutation. This study may be a useful reference as a genetic map for future research in characterizing future ND outbreaks in vaccinated chickens and developing molecular diagnostic tools to prevent future ND outbreaks in vaccine designs, reverse genetic systems, and vaccinated poultry flocks. Â© 2014 Springer Science+Business Media.
authors: Umali, D. V.;Ito, H.;Shirota, K.;Katoh, H.;Ito, T.

title: Molecular epidemiology of Newcastle disease virus isolated from vaccinated commercial poultry farms in non-outbreak regions of Japan.
abstract: Background: Newcastle Disease (ND) is a highly contagious and economically devastating disease in poultry. Currently, limited molecular epidemiological data are available on the causes of ND outbreaks in vaccinated commercial poultry farms. Knowing the genomic characteristics of Newcastle disease virus (NDV), which infects commercial poultry operations despite vaccination, can provide important information about the infection dynamics of these viruses. In addition, studies on subgenotype level molecular analyzes and association of Japanese NDVs with other isolates from around the world are lacking. Therefore, in this study, a molecular epidemiological study was conducted to characterize nine NDVs isolated from commercial poultry flocks vaccinated in five different Provinces in non-epidemic regions of Japan between 1969 and 2002. Methods. Nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic studies were performed to characterize the complete fusion (F)-protein gene, the 3-prime end of the nucleoprotein (NP)-gene, and the 5-prime end of the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (L)-gene. Sequence data were compared with 180 NDV strains from GenBank representing different NDV genotypes and subgenotypes from different regions of the world at different time periods. The deduced amino acids were analyzed for homologies, recombination and mutation. Recombination events were predicted using the Recombination Detection Program (RDP) version 3.44. Phylogenetic trees were constructed to determine evolutionary relationships between strains. Results: Mean time to death (MDT: 48-56 hours), Intracerebral Pathogenicity Index (ICPI: 1.7-1.9) and deduced amino acid sequences of the F0 proteolytic cleavage site (Â§ssupÂ§112Â§esupÂ§RRQKRÂ§ssupÂ§116Â§ esupÂ§ ), revealed that all nine domain isolates were velogenic. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these isolates can be classified into two genetic lineages and three sublines VIa (lineage 4a), VId (lineage 4d) and VIId (lineage 5d) genotypes. No recombination events were observed, but a point mutation was identified in one of the neutralizing epitopes of the F-protein in field isolates from Japan. Results: All field isolates from commercial poultry vaccinated in non-outbreak areas of Japan were part of much larger outbreaks in provinces and regions and in some cases on continents. Overall, four ND panzootics occurred in Japan, and these outbreaks were mostly characterized by co-circulation of genetically distinct virus strains due to the involvement of infected wild birds. The point mutation detected in field isolates from Japan may be due to evasion of vaccine pressure. Identification of such mutation may be useful for future site-directed mutagenesis to understand the dynamics of NDV infection in vaccinated chickens. Â© 2013 Umali et al.; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Umali, D. V.;Ito, H.;Suzuki, T.;Shirota, K.;Katoh, H.;Ito, T.

title: Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis of newcastle disease virus isolated from clinical cases of Newcastle disease in commercial egg farms in the Philippines.
abstract: Newcastle Disease (ND) is an economically devastating disease in poultry. Currently, limited data on the molecular characteristics of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) are available from the Philippines. Clinical and molecular characterizations were performed on five clinical ND cases in inoculated commercial egg farms from four provinces in the Philippines, namely Bulacan, Pampanga, Zamboanga del Sur, and Davao Del Sur. Clinical signs observed in affected flocks are conjunctivitis, panting, tracheal wheezing, facial swelling, lethargy, greenish diarrhea, torticollis, and paralysis. Disease onset ranged from 21 to 124 days, and mortality rates were 15 to 61%. The gross morphological lesions identified were the presence of serous exudates in the infraorbital sinuses, hemorrhagic trachea, inflamed spleen, liver and kidneys, and petechial hemorrhages in the proventriculus and cecal tonsils. Nucleotide sequencing showed that all site strains, models 112RRRKRz.ast;F117 and 112RRQKRz.ast;F117, were velogenic with the FO proteolytic cleavage site. Phylogenetic analysis showed that all field NDV strains belonged to class II genotype VII, subgenotypes Vila, Vllh and Vili. Evolutionary divergence showed that field NDV strains were closely related (up to 99% similarity) to newly identified subgenotypes of virulent NDVs currently emerging in Southeast Asia and the Middle East.
authors: Umali, D. V.;Lopez, A. L. M.;Torres, M. I. P.;Umandal, M. C.;Katoh, H.

title: Screening human cell lines for viral infections by applying RNA-Seq data analysis
abstract: Although viruses can have an effect on cell physiology and bioactive substances produced by cell cultures can pose a biohazard for laboratory safety and security, monitoring of viral infections of cell cultures is largely neglected. PCR, immunoassays, and enzyme activity tests represent common methods for detecting virus infections. Applying the Taxonomer bioinformatics tool developed by IDbyDNA, we scanned more than 300 Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia RNA sequences and 60 whole exome sequenced human cell line datasets for specific viral sequences and general viral nucleotide and protein sequence evaluation. The results were compared with our previous findings from virus-specific PCR analyses. Results from both the direct alignment method and the Taxonomer alignment method revealed complete agreement with the PCR results: twenty cell lines were found to be infected with five virus strains. The taxonomer also revealed a bovine polyomavirus infection in the breast cancer cell line SK-BR-3, most likely introduced by contaminated fetal bovine serum. RNA-Seq datasets were more sensitive for virus detection, but a significant proportion of cell lines revealed a low number of virus-specific alignments attributable to low-level nucleotide contamination during the RNA preparation or sequencing procedure. Poor quality reads leading to taxonomer false positive results can be eliminated by trimming the sequence data prior to analysis. Another important result is that no viruses were detected in cell cultures, which were never shown to occur. The results prove that currently applied cell cultures testing is sufficient for detection of contamination and risk assessment of cell cultures. The results highlight that next-generation sequencing is an effective tool to determine the viral infection status of human cells.
authors: Uphoff, C. C.;Pommerenke, C.;Denkmann, S. A.;Drexler, H. G.

title: cattle transient fever
abstract: Transient fever remains a viral disease of considerable importance for many countries, including Australia. The virus has only been partially characterized and still awaits final classification. Although the BEF virus was originally thought to contain 6 structural proteins, there is increasing evidence that it contains 5 proteins specific to Rhabdoviridae. Although BEF is thought to be transmitted by arthropods, the vector has not yet been identified, but from the distribution of BEF it is clear that more than one vector is capable of transmitting the disease. Despite rigorous investigation of the clinical manifestations and pathology of transient fever, little progress has been made in the pathogenesis of the disease. This is partly due to the difficulty of spreading the BEF virus in vitro and the failure to identify the replication site. However, there is increasing evidence to suggest that BEF is immunopathological in nature and that the clinical expression of the disease is affected by the release of one or more mediators of inflammation. The disease is characterized by a series of haematological and biochemical changes, and early and long-term treatment with phenylbutazone can reverse many of these changes. Intravenous administration of calcium can now be considered a justified addition to the treatment regimen in combination with long-term phenylbutazone therapy. Currently available vaccines are prepared from live attenuated or killed virus and may be less than reliable. There seems to be a need for a reliable, inexpensive, cold chain-free alternative vaccine.
authors: Uren, M. F.

title: Unmapped reads from bovine RNAseq data: missing and misassembled sequences in reference assemblies and a resource for detection of pathogens in the host.
abstract: Generally, reads from transcriptome sequencing data that are not mapped to the reference genome of the target species are ignored. A recent RNAseq project on the new deadly disease Bovine Neonatal Pancytopenia showed an unexplained signature of immune response to a double-stranded RNA virus. To resolve the background, contigs were de novo assembled from unmapped RNAseq reads and aligned to bovine genome assemblies and multi-species NCBI databases. The absence of the actual virus sequence refuted the hypothesis that a live virus was causative for the unexplained immune response. Alignment data also showed incomplete bovine reference genome assemblies. In addition, we found that several parasite and virus genome reference assemblies at NCBI were contaminated with bovine DNA, confirming recombination of bovine DNA into BVD virus strains. Discovering unpaired reads can extract useful biological information regarding the presence of microorganisms and highlight issues with reference genome assemblies of host and pathogen species.
authors: Usman, T.;Hadlich, F.;Demasius, W.;Weikard, R.;Kuhn, C.

title: Sequencing and sequence analysis of partial nucleoprotein (N) gene and phylogenetic analysis of rabies virus isolates from the state of Gujarat, India.
abstract: This study was carried out to characterize rabies virus (Lyssavirus genus from Rhabdoviridae family under Mononegavirales order) by sequencing the partial nucleoprotein (N) gene of rabies virus and phylogenetic analysis to know the genotype and lineage of current rabies virus. in the Indian state of Gujarat. A total of 32 samples (18 brain samples and 14 saliva samples) were collected aseptically from live and dead animals (ie, dog, buffalo, cow, goat, donkey and hyena) for rabies virus detection. Of the 32 samples, 24 samples were found positive by Reverse Transcriptase Polymerase Chain Reactions, and from these 24 positive samples, 20 samples were selected for sequencing with good gene product concentration. ClustalW alignment of nucleotide sequences and amino acid sequences of field rabies isolates revealed 95.20%-100% and 97.95-100% similarity among themselves, respectively. Multiple sequence alignment of field rabies isolates and reference vaccine strains [Pasteur strain and Challenge Virus Strain (CVS)] showed single nucleotide mutations at a total of 91 positions and amino acid mutations at a total of 17 different positions. Phylogenetic analysis of N gene sequences using our 20 field rabies isolates and 21 other isolates reported in Genbank resulted in 3 phylogenetic clusters. All field rabies isolates showed the same genetic lineage among themselves and as other previously reported Indian rabies isolates, placing them in the Arctic-like lineage of Genotype 1 Rabies virus. However, they were in genetic distance from the reference Pasteur and CVS strains grouped in different phylogenetic clusters.
authors: Vagheshwari, D. H.;Bhanderi, B. B.;Mathakiya, R. A.;Jhala, M. K.

title: Global Distribution of Human Protoparvoviruses
abstract: The development of next-generation sequencing and metagenomics has revolutionized the detection of new viruses. Among these viruses are 3 human protoparvoviruses: bufavirus, tusavirus and cutavirus. These viruses have been detected in the stools of children with diarrhea. In addition, cutavirus was detected in skin biopsy samples of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma patients in France and in 1 melanoma patient in Denmark. We examined IgG seroprevalences against bufavirus, tusavirus and cutavirus in various populations (n = 840) and found striking geographical variation in the prevalence of bufavirus IgG. Bufavirus IgG was highly prevalent in Iraq (84.8%), Iran (56.1%) and Kenya (72.3%), although prevalence was low in adult populations in Finland (1.9%) and the United States (3.6%). Conversely, cutavirus IgG showed equally low prevalences (0-5.6%) in all cohorts, and tusavirus IgG was not detected. These results provide new insights into the global distribution and endemic areas of protoparvoviruses.
authors: Vaisanen, E.;Mohanraj, U.;Kinnunen, P. M.;Jokelainen, P.;Al-Hello, H.;Barakat, A. M.;Sadeghi, M.;Jalilian, F. A.;Majlesi, A.;Masika, M.;Mwaengo, D.;Anzala, O.;Delwart, E.;Vapalahti, O.;Hedman, K.;Soderlund-Venermo, M.

title: Epidemiology of two human protoparvoviruses, bufavirus and tusavirus
abstract: Two human parvoviruses were recently discovered by metagenomics in Africa, bufavirus (BuV) in 2012 and tusavirus (TuV) in 2014. These viruses were examined by PCR only in feces and were detected only in patients with diarrhea despite a low prevalence. Three genotypes of BuV have been identified. With the in-house EIA, we detected BuV1-3 IgG antibodies in 7/228 children (3.1%) and 10/180 adults (5.6%), whereas TuV IgG was found in one child (0.4%). 91% of all children and adults were Finnish, but interestingly, 3/6 adults of Indian descent were BuV-IgG positive. No cross-reactivity was detected between the competing EIA and the BuVs, indicating that the BuV genotypes represent different serotypes. We also analyzed BuV qPCR stool and nasal swab samples from 955 children with gastroenteritis, respiratory disease, or both, and found BuV DNA in three stools (0.3%) and for the first time in one nasal swab (0.1%). This is the first study to document the presence of BuV and TuV antibodies in humans. Although the seroprevalence of both viruses is low in Finland, our results suggest that BuV infections may be common in Asia. BuV-specific humoral immune responses appeared potent and sustained, suggesting systemic infection in humans.
authors: Vaisanen, E.;Paloniemi, M.;Kuisma, I.;Lithovius, V.;Kumar, A.;Franssila, R.;Ahmed, K.;Delwart, E.;Vesikari, T.;Hedman, K.;Soderlund-Venermo, M.

title: S1 gene-based phylogeny of infectious bronchitis virus: an attempt to harmonize virus classification
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is the causative agent of a highly contagious disease that causes serious economic losses to the global poultry industry. The virus exists in a wide variety of genetically distinct viral types, and both phylogenetic analysis and measures of pairwise similarity between nucleotide or amino acid sequences have been used to classify IBV strains. However, there is currently no consensus on the method by which IBV sequences should be compared, and heterogeneous genetic group assignments that are inconsistent with the phylogenetic history have been adopted, leading to the confusing coexistence of multiple genotyping schemes. Here, we propose a simple and reproducible phylogeny-based classification system combined with a clear and logical lineage terminology for assignment of IBV strains. We determined the phylogenetic structure of IBV using the full nucleotide sequences of the S1 gene, which allowed us to identify 6 genotypes, which together included 32 different viral lineages and a number of interlinear recombinants. Due to the wide ratio variation among IBVs, we propose that the inference of phylogenetic relationships alone represents a more appropriate criterion for sequence classification than pairwise sequence comparisons. The adoption of an internationally accepted viral terminology is crucial for future studies of IBV epidemiology and evolution, and new S1 sequences should become available as the classification scheme presented here can be updated and revised.
authors: Valastro, V.;Holmes, E. C.;Britton, P.;Fusaro, A.;Jackwood, M. W.;Cattoli, G.;Monne, I.

title: Genetic typing and prevalence of Border disease virus (BDV) in small ruminant herds in Spain.
abstract: Between 2001 and 2002, samples from 1413 animals from 21 Spanish small ruminant herds, most of which had clinical signs consistent with Border disease (BD), were screened for the presence of Pestivirus antigen and antibodies with an indirect peroxidase monolayer assay (IPMA). ) and virus neutralization test (VNT), respectively. Although seropositive animals were found in all herds, the virus was isolated from animals in only five of the herds. After 4 to 11 months, all animals older than 6 months in three herds were resampled. Currently, 51-83% of them had neutralizing antibodies. The prevalence of persistently infected (PI) animals in two of the flocks was 0.3% and 0.6%, respectively. The third pack had probably destroyed all the PI animals. Fourteen virus isolates were obtained. The 5â€² untranslated regions (5â€²UTR) were amplified by RT-PCR and directly sequenced. Phylogenetic analyzes classified them as a group of Border disease viruses (BDV) that diverged from BDV-1 but showed a relatively low bootstrap value. Three of the 14 isolates were in the same subgroup as previously characterized Spanish isolates from the Basque Country assigned to the BDV-C subgroup. Additionally, they were in the group with the chamois isolate currently allocated in the BDV-4 group. Due to the close association with the mountain chamois isolate, these isolates were tentatively reintroduced into a BDV-4a subgroup. The remaining isolates formed a new subgroup that was related but not in the same cluster as the chamois isolate and was therefore tentatively assigned to a new BDV-4b subgroup. Our results indicate that the classification and nomenclature of BDV needs to be harmonized. Â© 2006 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Valdazo-GonzÃ¡lez, B.;Ãlvarez-MartÃ­nez, M.;Greiser-Wilke, I.

title: Interspecies transmission of rotaviruses between ruminant animals, dogs and humans: current facts and explanations
abstract: Rotaviruses are accepted as an important cause of diarrhea in humans as well as in a wide variety of animals and can cause serious economic losses in livestock, especially pigs and ruminants. This fact, together with the genetic diversity that characterizes members of the Rotavirus group, has raised concerns about the potential for virus interspecies transmission among various animal and human species. Research into the presence and epidemiology of Rotaviruses in ruminant animals with closely related humans and dogs is limited and few data have been presented in recent years. In this review, we present the latest information on the distribution of genotypes of Rotavirus strains in ruminants, dogs and humans.
authors: Valiakos, G.;Chatzopoulos, D. C.;Tsokana, C. N.

title: Anaplasma marginal superinfection attributable to pathogen strains with different genomic histories
abstract: Strain superinfection occurs when a second strain of pathogen infects a host already infected with a primary strain. The selective pressures that drive strain differentiation that underlie superinfection and allow a new strain to enter a host population are critical knowledge gaps regarding changes in infectious disease epidemiology. In endemic areas with a high prevalence of infection, large population immunity develops against Anaplasma marginale, an antigenically highly variable rickettsial pathogen, creating strong selective pressure for superinfection and emergence of strains that differ in their Msp2 variant repertoire. Strains can arise either by duplication and allelic divergence of the msp2 locus on an existing genomic background or by introducing a strain with a different msp2 allelic repertoire on a different genomic background. To answer this question, we developed a multilocus typing assay based on high-throughput sequencing of non-msp2 target loci to discriminate between strains with different genomic histories. The level of technical error was defined statistically based on the percentage of perfect sequence matches of clones of each target locus and validated using experimental single strains and strain pairs. Testing of A. marginale-positive specimens from tropical regions where A. marginale infection is endemic identified individual infections containing unique alleles for all five targeted loci. The data revealed a highly significant difference in the number of strains per animal in the tropics compared to infections in temperate regions, strongly supporting the hypothesis that transmission of genomically distinct A. marginale strains predominates in high prevalence endemic areas.
authors: Vallejo Esquerra, E.;Herndon, D. R.;Alpirez Mendoza, F.;Mosqueda, J.;Palmer, G. H.

title: What's in the tension? Viral metagenomics identifies genetic diversity and contaminating circoviruses in laboratory isolates of pigeon paramyxovirus type 1
abstract: We used next-generation sequencing on randomly amplified viral nucleic acids to sequence the genome of 11 isolates of pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1) from Belgium (period 1998-2011). The PPMV-1 deep sequence data allowed the identification of sequence variability in multiple isolates of PPMV-1, including a STOP codon in the Matrix gene found in 15% of the viral population of one isolate. In particular, mutations previously associated with pathogenicity in chickens were identified as minor sequence variants in a parent laboratory strain. A phylogenetic analysis of the consensus PPMV-1 genome sequences was performed. In addition to providing nearly complete paramyxovirus genome sequences, our sequence-independent approach identified the presence of pigeon circovirus (PiCV) sequences in four of these viral stocks. Real-time quantitative RT-PCR analysis specific for PMV-1 and PiCV showed that these contaminations were present in seven viral stocks of allantoic fluids and were sometimes detected in stocks passed from embryonated chicken eggs. Phylogenetic analysis of the PiCV consensus genome sequences showed a PiCV circulation encompassing the full genetic diversity of known PiCV. This work demonstrates the value of new sequence-independent technologies for accessing sequence information for control of reference virus stocks and other biological materials. Co-infected viruses or sequence variants from the original sample may remain in stock without being identified by routine virus-specific diagnostic tools. The precise role of PiCV in pigeon disease – particularly Newcastle disease – and its potential interaction with PPMV-1 diagnosis remain to be explored. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Van Borm, S.;Rosseel, T.;Steensels, M.;Van den Berg, T.;Lambrecht, B.

title: Complete coding sequence of a novel picorna-like virus in a blackbird infected with Usutu virus
abstract: Using random high-throughput RNA sequencing, the complete coding sequence of a novel picorna-like virus (9,228-nt contig containing 212,202 reads) was determined from a blackbird (Turdus merula) infected with Usutu virus. This sequence shares only 36% amino acid sequence identity with its closest homologue, arivirus 1 (an unclassified member of the Picornavirales order), and shares the diccistronic genome arrangement. The new virus was therefore tentatively named "black bird arylivirus" (bee-like virus). The nearly complete genome sequence consists of at least 9,228Â nt and contains two open reading frames (ORFs) encoding the nonstructural polyprotein (2235 amino acids) and the structural polyprotein (769 amino acids). Two ORF1-specific TaqMan RT-qPCR assays confirmed the presence of high levels of this novel virus in the original sample. Nucleotide composition analysis shows that blackbird arylivirus is of dietary (plant) origin.
authors: Van Borm, S.;Steensels, M.;Mathijs, E.;Yinda, C. K.;Matthijnssens, J.;Lambrecht, B.

title: Genital warts in Burmeister's dolphins: characterization of Phocoena spinipinnis papillomavirus type 1 (PsPV-1) and a second evidence of distantly related PsPV
abstract: We identified sequences from two distantly related papillomaviruses in genital warts from two Burmeister dolphins, including a PV antigen-positive sample, and characterized Phocoena spinipinnis papillomavirus type 1 (PsPV-1). The PsPV-1 genome contains 7879 nt and presents unusual features. An E7 does not contain an E8 and a bona fide E5 open reading frame (ORF) and has a large E6 ORF. The PsPV-1 L1 ORF showed the highest percentage of nucleotide identity (54-55%) with human papillomavirus type 5, bovine papillomavirus type 3 (BPV-3) and Tursiops truncatus papillomavirus type 2 (TtPV-2). This warrants the classification of PsPV-1 as the prototype of the genus Omicronpapillomavirus. PsPV-1 clustered with TtPV-2 in the E6 and E1 E2 phylogenetic trees and with TtPV-2 and BPV-3 in the L2L1 tree. This supports the hypothesis that PV evolution may not be monophyletic among all genes. © 2007 SGM.
authors: Van Bressem, M. F.;Cassonnet, P.;Rector, A.;Desaintes, C.;Van Waerebeek, K.;Alfaro-Shigueto, J.;Van Ranst, M.;Orth, G.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the first complete hepatitis E virus (HEV) genome from Africa
abstract: The hepatitis E virus (HEV) is globally distributed, transmitted enterically and between humans and animals. Phylogenetic analysis identified five different HEV genotypes. The first full-length sequence of an African strain (Chad) is presented and compared to 31 available complete HEV genomes, including the fulminant hepatitis strain from India, swine strains and a strain from Morocco. The two African strains are more closely related to genotype 1 than the other genotypes, and together they likely form a subgenotype or sixth genotype. First evidence for recombination between different HEV strains is presented. Â© 2003 European Federation of Microbiology Societies. Published by Elsevier BV. All rights reserved.
authors: Van Cuyck, H.;Juge, F.;Roques, P.

title: Development and validation of genotype 3 recombinant protein-based immunoassay for hepatitis E virus serology in pigs
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is classified within the Hepevirus family, Hepevirus genus. HEV genotype 3 (Gt3) infections are endemic in pigs from Western Europe and North and South America and cause zoonotic infections in humans. Various serological tests were initially developed based on HEV genotype 1 (Gt1) antigens to detect HEV antibodies in pigs. To develop a sensitive HEV Gt3 ELISA, a recombinant baculovirus expression product of HEV Gt3 open reading frame-2 was produced and plated on polystyrene ELISA plates. After incubation of pig serum, HEV antibodies bound with anti-swine anti-IgG and anti-IgM conjugates were detected. Sets of serum from pigs experimentally infected with HEV Gt3 were used for the primary estimation of the sensitivity and specificity of the assay. 1100 batches of pig serum were used to further validate the test and adjust the threshold. All pig sera were tested using the developed HEV Gt3 assay and two other serological tests based on HEV Gt1 antigens. As the gold standard for HEV antibody testing did not exist, further validation and a precise cut-off adjustment of the HEV Gt3 testing developed using a statistical approach based on Bayes' theorem was performed. The developed and validated HEV antibody assay demonstrated effective detection of HEV-specific antibodies. This assay may contribute to better detection of HEV antibodies and provide more reliable estimates of HEV Gt3 prevalence in pigs in different regions.
authors: van der Poel, W. H. M.;Pavio, N.;van der Goot, J.;van Es, M.;Martin, M.;Engel, B.

title: Microneuraminidase inhibition test for classification of influenza A virus neuraminidases
