abstract: neuraminidase inhibition (NI) assay performed in microtiter plates is described. This micro-NI test is a modification of the NI test recommended by the World Health Organization. It reduces the amount of reagents required and allows antigenic classification of many isolates simultaneously. To determine the accuracy and sensitivity of this micro-NI assay, 110 influenza A viruses representing all subtypes based on nine known neuraminidases (NAs) were classified with both micro-NI and macro-NI tests in two separate laboratories. NAs were accurately identified by micro-NI assay. Mixtures of viruses were detected in both assays, although macro-NI was clearly more sensitive. The micro-NI assay is also suitable for testing serum for the presence of antibodies against NAs. Although the micro-NI test did not quantify the macro-NI test, it proved to be a rapid method for virus classification and antibody studies on influenza A viruses.
authors: Van Deusen, R. A.;Hinshaw, V. S.;Senne, D. A.;Pellacani, D.

title: One world, one health. People, animals and the environment are inextricably linked – a fact that must be remembered and used in our modern approach to health.
authors: van Helden, P. D.;van Helden, L. S.;Hoal, E. G.

title: Complete nucleotide sequence of novel simian T-lymphotropic virus, STLV-PH969 from a hamadryas baboon, and unusual features of long terminal repeat
abstract: With STLV-PH969 as the prototype, a third primate T-lymphotropic virus strain, PTLV-L, was recently isolated from an African baboon (Papio hamadryas). The classification of this virus is based on partial sequence analysis of cDNA from a virus-producing cell line, PH969. We obtained the complete nucleotide sequence of this virus with a proviral genome of 8,916 bp. All major genes homologous to all human T-cell lymphotropic virus (HTLV) related viruses and their corresponding mRNAs, including the appropriate splicing, were identified. An additional non-homologous open reading frame in the proximal pX region is accessible for translation via alternative splicing. The rank comparison shows that STLV-PH969 is equidistant with HTLV type 1 (HTLV-1) and HTLV-2. Across all coding regions, similarity tends to be lowest between STLV-PH969 and HTLV-1. However, the lowest similarity in the long terminal repeat (LTR) region was found between STLV-PH969 and HTLV-2. The U3-R and R-U5 boundaries of the STLV-PH969 LTR were determined experimentally at nucleotides 268 and 52.4, respectively. This 695-bp LTR is 60 and 73 bp shorter than the LTRs of HTLV-1 and HTLV-2, respectively, but its overall organization is similar to that found in the HTLV-bovine leukemia virus genus. Sequence similarity and secondary structure prediction with the HTLV-1 Rex-responsive element (RexRE) core in the long region between the polyadenylation signal and the poly(A) region suggest the presence of a RexRE. The presence of three 21-bp repeats is conserved within the U3 region of HTLV-1, HTLV-2 and BLV. In the STLV-PH969 LTR, only two direct repeats were found that were similar to these Tax sensitive items; this may suggest differences in the Tax-mediated handling of this virus. We conclude that STLV-PH969 has all the genes and genomic regions to suggest a replication cycle comparable to HTLV-1 and HTLV-2.
authors: Van Marianne, B.;Goubau, P.;Rousseau, R.;Desmyter, J.;Vandamme, A. M.

title: Genetic heterogeneity in foot-and-mouth disease virus Leader and 3C proteinases
abstract: Leader and 3C proteinases of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) are responsible for nearly all proteolytic processing of the viral polyprotein precursor. Investigating the genetic heterogeneity of the regions encoding these proteins from isolates of the six FMDV serotypes revealed that 3C proteinase was more conserved than the Leader proteinase. Maximum likelihood analysis showed similar phylogenetic groupings for the nonstructural protein coding regions of both Leader and 3C. These groupings differed from the structural VP1 protein coding region, which was grouped by serotype as previously shown. Two distinct segments were evident for both the Leader and 3C coding regions: one consisted of SAT (South African Territories) isolates from eastern Africa, as well as serotypes A, O, and C. The other branch consisted of SAT isolates from South Africa. Only one virus isolate from a Ugandan buffalo did not fit this phylogenetic model. This SAT 1 virus was grouped with types A, O, and C in the Leader analysis, but with southern African SAT types in the 3C analysis, implying intertype recombination. Leading proteinases of South African SAT-type isolates differed from those found in European-type isolates, particularly in the self-functioning region. A three-dimensional structure was modeled for the Leader proteinase of ZIM/7/83/2, one of the SAT type viruses, and compared with the previously described crystal structure of O1Kaufbeuren Leader proteinase. Despite the observed sequence variation between the two molecules, the active sites of the two leaders were found to overlap closely. Comparison of 3C proteinase P1 cleavage sites indicated that FMDV 3C proteinase may have a broader substrate specificity, as observed in hepatitis A virus 3C proteinase. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Van Rensburg, H.;Haydon, D.;Joubert, F.;Bastos, A.;Heath, L.;Nel, L.

title: Origin of the 1918 Spanish influenza virus: A comparative genomic analysis
abstract: To test the avian origin hypothesis of the 1918 Spanish influenza virus, we searched for influenza sequences from a wide taxonomic distribution and collected 65 full-length genomes representing the avian, human, and "classic" pig H1N1 lineages, in addition to numerous other pigs (H1N2, H3N1). and H3N2), human (H2N2, H3N2 and H5N1) and avian (H1N1, H4N6, H5N1, H6N1, H6N6, H6N8, H7N3, H8N4, H9N2 and H13N2) subspecies. Amino acids from all eight segments were combined, aligned and used for phylogenetic analyses. In addition, the genes of the polymerase complex (PB1, PB2 and PA) were analyzed separately. All our results showed that the Brevig-Mission/1918 strain was in a basal position relative to the rest of the clan containing human H1N1s, and was consistent with a reclassification hypothesis for the origin of the 1918 virus. Our genome phylogeny also indicates a sibling relationship with the "classical" pig H1N1 lineage. Individual PB1, PB2, and PA phylogenies were consistent with reclassification/recombination hypotheses for these genes. These results demonstrate the importance of using a whole genome approach to address the avian origin hypothesis and predict the emergence of new pandemic influenza strains. Â© 2008 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Vana, G.;Westover, K. M.

title: An ecological and conservationist perspective on developments in applied virology of zoonoses.
abstract: The purpose of this manuscript is to explain how modern advances in our knowledge of viruses and viral evolution can be applied to the fields of disease ecology and conservation. We review the latest developments in virology and provide examples of how it informs experimental research in both field ecology and applied conservation. We include a discussion of necessary breakthroughs and ways to bridge the communication gaps between the field and the laboratory. To support this interdisciplinary effort, we have also included a table listing definitions of key terms. The importance of understanding the dynamics of zoonotic pathogens in reservoir hosts is highlighted as a tool both to assess risk factors for spread and to test hypotheses regarding treatment and/or intervention strategies. In conclusion, we highlight the need for intelligent surveillance, viral discovery efforts, and predictive modelling. As the 2009 H1N1 pandemic demonstrated, a shift to a predictive approach is necessary in today's globalized society, as identification once it occurs is often too late to prevent global spread. Integrating molecular virology and ecological techniques will allow early detection of potentially dangerous pathogens, ideally before they jump from wildlife reservoirs to human or animal populations and cause serious public health or conservation problems. Â© 2011 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Vandegrift, K. J.;Wale, N.;Epstein, J. H.

title: Comparative genome sequencing identifies a prophage-associated genomic candidate associated with host adaptation of Lawsonia intracellularis infections.
abstract: Lawsonia intracellularis is an obligate intracellular bacterium and is the causative agent of proliferative enteropathy (PE). The disease is endemic in pigs, occurs in horses, and has been reported in a variety of other animal species, including non-human primates. By comparing the whole genome sequences of a homologous porcine isolate of L. intracellularis grown in vitro for 10 and 60 passages, we identified an 18 kb prophage-associated genomic island at passage 10 (pathogenic variant) and disappeared at passage 60 (pathogenic variant). . -pathogenic variant). This chromosomal island contains 15 genes downstream of the prophage DLP12 integrase gene. The prevalence of this genetic element was evaluated in 12 other L. intracellularis isolates and 53 infected animals and was found to be conserved in all pig isolates reared up to 20 passages and lost in isolates reared for more than 40 passages. In addition, prophage zones were also present in 26 stool samples from pigs clinically affected by both acute and chronic forms of the disease. However, the equine L. intracellularis isolates evaluated did not harbor this genomic candidate, regardless of in vitro passage. In addition, fecal samples from 21 clinically affected horses and four wild rabbits stranded on horse farms experiencing PE outbreaks did not show this prophage-associated candidate. Although the presence of this prophage-associated island is not required for a virulent L. intracellularis phenotype, this genetic element was specific to the porcine isolate and potentially contributed to the ecological specialization of this organism for the porcine host.
authors: Vannucci, F. A.;Kelley, M. R.;Gebhart, C. J.

title: Sequence-based taxonomic framework for the classification of uncultured single-stranded DNA viruses of the Genomoviridae family.
abstract: With the advent of metagenomic approaches, a wide variety of known and unknown viruses have been identified in various environmental, plant and animal samples. One such common group of viruses is the recently established Genomoviridae family, which includes viruses with small (similar to 2-2.4 kb), circular ssDNA genomes, rolling circle replication initiation proteins (Rep), and unique capsid proteins. Here, we propose an array-based taxonomic framework for the classification of 121 novel virus genomes within this family. Genomoviruses are similar to 47% sequence diversity, which is very similar to that within the well-established and extensively studied family Geminiviridae (46% diversity). Based on our analysis, we establish a 78% genome-wide binary identity as the species restriction threshold. We also establish nine genera within the family Genomoviridae, using a Rep sequence phylogeny-based analysis combined with existing knowledge of the classification of geminiviruses. These are Gemycircularvirus (n=73), Gemyduguivirus (n=1), Gemygorvirus (n=9), Gemykibivirus (n=29), Gemykolovirus (n=3), Gemykrogvirus (n=3), Gemykroznavirus (n=1) , Gemytondvirus (n = 1), Gemyvongvirus (n = 1). The presented taxonomic framework presents the rational classification of genomoviruses based on sequence information alone and sets an example for future classification of other groups of uncultured viruses discovered using metagenomic approaches.
authors: Varsani, A.;Krupovic, M.

title: Smacoviridae: a new family of animal-associated single-stranded DNA viruses
abstract: Smacoviruses have small (similar to 2.3-2.9 kb), circular single-stranded DNA genomes, rolling circle replication-associated proteins (Rep), and unique capsid proteins. Although smacoviruses are common in fecal matter of various vertebrates, including humans, none of these viruses have been cultured so far. Smacoviruses are similar to 45% genome-wide sequence diversity, very similar to that found in other families of circular Rep-encoding single-stranded (CRESS) DNA viruses, including members of the Geminiviridae (46% diversity) and Genomoviridae families. 47% diversity). Here, we announce the creation of a new family of Smacoviridae and describe an array-based taxonomic framework used to classify 83 smacovirus genomes into 43 species in six new genera, Bovismacovirus (n=3), Cosmacovirus (n=1), Dragsmacovirus. (n=1), Drosmacovirus (n=3), Huchismacovirus (n=7) and Porprismacovirus (n=28). As with genoviruses, species distinction is based on genome-wide binary identity, while genera are determined based on Rep amino acid sequence identity coupled with strong phylogenetic support. A similar sequence-based taxonomic framework should guide the classification of the surprising diversity of other uncultured and currently unclassified CRESS DNA viruses discovered through metagenomic approaches.
authors: Varsani, A.;Krupovic, M.

title: Influenza virus-h1n1 a new variant of swine flu virus
abstract: In 2009, a type of swine-derived H1N1 virus called swine flu caused the 2009 Influenza Pandemic. Most cold climate countries are affected by the disease. Between 1979 and 2001, an average of 41,000 people died from the flu each year in the United States. Influenza, commonly referred to as influenza, is an infectious disease caused by RNA viruses of the Orthomyxoviridae family that infects birds and mammals. This virus is basically classified into three types 1) Influenza virus A 2) Influenza virus B 3) Influenza virus C. Swine flu belongs to Influenza virus A(H1N1). The virus particle is 80-120 nanometers. In the early stages of swine flu it can be difficult to distinguish between a cold and the flu, but flu can be identified by the sudden onset and high fever with extreme fatigue. It is transmitted in three main ways: direct transmission, air-bone route, and direct personal contact (such as handshaking). Influenza virus can stay outside the body, or it can be transmitted from contaminated surfaces such as banknotes and doorknobs. H1N1 spreads easily, rarely fatal. One of the mechanisms is believed to be inhibition of H1N1 adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which in turn causes cortisol levels to drop. Influenza viruses can be inactivated by sunlight, disinfectants, and detergents. Commonly used antivirals are oseltamivir and zanamivir, these are neuraminidase inhibitors, and amantadine and rimantadine block a viral ion channel and prevent the virus from infecting cells. Mono Valent Vaccines Live Intranasal, Mono Valent Vaccines for Intramuscular injection, fluzone etc.
authors: Veeranjaneyulu, T. N.;Seerishna, B.;Kiran, T. N. R.;Madhulatha, A. V. S.;Bindu, A. H.

title: Autochthonous hepatitis E-virus infection as a cause of acute hepatitis in Germany - A case report
abstract: There is increasing evidence that hepatitis E virus (HEV) triggers acute hepatitis not only in tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, Africa and the Americas with low sanitary standards, but also in highly industrialized countries. Here we report two patients with HEV infection from Thuringia (Germany) who are not resident abroad. All other common causes of hepatitis were excluded. In both cases, transaminases were significantly increased, whereas jaundice could be demonstrated in only one patient. Both patients fully recovered in the long term. Epidemiological and phylogenetic data from viral analyzes suggest that HEV infection should be considered a zoonosis. Viral transmission from animals to humans is likely to occur through undercooked meat or guts, for example from pigs or wild animals. In summary, HEV infection is a relevant differential diagnosis in acute non-A/B/C viral hepatitis. Further studies are needed to identify other routes of transmission, reservoirs of pathogens, and new concepts for prophylaxis, particularly in patients at risk for liver disease. Â© 2010 Georg Thieme Verlag KG Stuttgart Â· New York.
authors: Veitt, R.;Reichardt, M.;Wenzel, J.;Jilg, W.

title: Phylodynamics of the parapoxvirus genus in Mexico (2007-2011)
abstract: In this study, we report for the first time the phylodynamics of the parapoxvirus (PPV) genus in Mexico. Based on PCR analysis of 124 epithelial samples collected between 2007 and 2011 from naturally infected goats, sheep and cows in Mexico, we found that different PPVs were present in 21 of the 24 states sampled during this study. Our phylogenetic analysis confirmed the existence of different PPV species in Mexico and their phylogenetic relationship to other PPVs circulating in the USA and Canada. We also describe the existence of two distinct ORFV phylogenetic groups that are clearly host-related (sheep or goat). Evidence of directional selection at five specific amino acid residues in the enveloped glycoprotein B2L may help support this host preference. Collectively, the results obtained in this study highlight the importance of the PPV genus in Mexico and enable future studies to further elucidate the importance of this genus in North America.
authors: Velazquez-Salinas, L.;Ramirez-Medina, E.;Bracht, A. J.;Hole, K.;Brito, B. P.;Gladue, D. P.;Carrillo, C.

title: Avian influenza viruses in wild birds: virus evolution in a multi-host ecosystem.
abstract: Wild ducks and gulls are major reservoirs of avian influenza A viruses (AIVs). The mechanisms driving AIV evolution are complex where various species of ducks and gulls breed, winter or in phase, from various flight paths. The Republic of Georgia is located at the intersection of three migrant flight paths: the Central Asian flight path, the East Africa/West Asia flight path, and the Black Sea/Mediterranean flight path. During six full study years (2010-2016), we collected AIV samples from various species of ducks and gulls that breed, migrate and overwinter in Georgia. We found a significant diversity of virus subspecies with prevalence varying from year to year. Low pathogenic AIV (LPAIV) subtypes include H1N1, H2N3, H2N5, H2N7, H3N8, H4N2, H6N2, H7N3, H7N7, H9N1, H9N3, H10N4, H10N7, H11N1, H13N2, H13N6, H16N3, and two pathogenic H16. AIVs (HPAIVs) of section 2.3.4.4, H5N5 and H5N8 were found. Whole genome phylogenetic trees showed significant differences in observed reclassification rates, as defined by significant host species lineage restriction and quantification of phylogenetic mismatch for nearly all gene segments, and in nucleotide sequence diversity for LPAIVs among different host species. Hemagglutinin clade 2.3.4.4 H5N8 viruses circulating in Eurasia in 2014 and 2015 did not recombine, but analyzes after their subsequent spread in 2016 and 2017 revealed reclassification in all gene segments except NP and NS. While some virus lineages appeared unrelated to the maintenance of local AIVs in Georgia and AIVs in wild bird populations in other regions, other lineages showed significant genetic associations with viruses circulating in other parts of Eurasia and Africa, despite relatively poor sampling in the region.
authors: Venkatesh, D.;Poen, M. J.;Bestebroer, T. M.;Scheuer, R. D.;Vuong, O.;Chkhaidze, M.;Machablishvili, A.;Mamuchadze, J.;Ninua, L.;Fedorova, N. B.;Halpin, R. A.;Lin, X.;Ransier, A.;Stockwell, T. B.;Wentworth, D. E.;Kriti, D.;Dutta, J.;van Bakel, H.;Puranik, A.;Slomka, M. J.;Essen, S.;Brown, I. H.;Fouchier, R. A. M.;Lewis, N. S.

title: Molecular characterization of Belgian pseudorabies virus isolated from domestic pig and wild boar
abstract: Aujeszky's disease is an economically important disease in domestic pigs caused by suid herpesvirus 1, also called pseudorabies virus (PRV). In several European countries, including Belgium, the virus has been successfully eradicated from the domestic pig population. However, the presence of PRV in the wild boar population poses a risk for possible reinfection of the virus into the domestic pig population. Therefore, it is important to evaluate the genetic relationship between circulating strains and possible epidemiological links. In this study, nine historical Belgian domestic pig isolates circulating before 1990 and five novel wild boar isolates from Belgium and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg since 2006 were genetically characterized by restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis and phylogenetic analysis. was done. While all wild boar isolates were characterized as type I RFLP genotypes, the RFLP patterns of domestic pig isolates suggest that there may have been a shift from genotype I to genotype II in the domestic population in the 1980s. By phylogenetic analysis, Belgian wild boar isolates belonging to both A and B branches were observed, while all domestic pig isolates clustered in A sequence. Joint phylogenetic analysis of both wild boar and domestic pig strains showed that some isolates with the same sequences were present in them. In both populations, this raises the question of whether these strains pose an increased risk for reinfection of the virus into the native population. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Verpoest, S.;Cay, A. B.;De Regge, N.

title: The capacity of the UL49.5 proteins to inhibit TAP is widely distributed among members of the varicellovirus genus.
abstract: Life-long infection by varicelloviruses is characterized by a fine balance between the host's immune response and the immune avoidance strategies employed by these viruses. Virus-derived peptides are presented to cytotoxic T lymphocytes by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules. The transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP) transports peptides from the cytosol to the endoplasmic reticulum, where loading of MHC-I molecules occurs. Bovine herpes virus 1 (BoHV-1), pseudorabies virus, and equivalent herpes viruses 1 and 4 have been found to encode a UL49.5 protein that inhibits TAP-mediated peptide transport. Homologs of five other varicelloviruses, a mardivirus and an iltovirus were examined to investigate the extent to which UL49.5-mediated inhibition of TAP was conserved within the Alphaherpesvirinae family. UL49.5 proteins of BoHV-5, bubalin herpesvirus 1, cervid herpesvirus 1 and felid herpesvirus 1 were identified as potent TAP inhibitors. Varicella-zoster virus and simian varicellovirus UL49.5 proteins fail to block TAP; this is not due to the absence of viral cofactors that could assist in this process, as cells infected with these viruses also did not show reduced TAP function. UL49.5 homologues of Mardivirus Marek's disease virus 1 and iltovirus infectious laryngotracheitis virus did not block TAP, suggesting that the capacity to inhibit TAP via UL49.5 is gained only by varicelloviruses. A phylogenetic analysis of viruses that inhibit TAP via the UL49.5 proteins reveals an interesting heritable pattern pointing to the presence of this capacity in defined branches within the genus Varicellovirus. Copyright © 2011, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Verweij, M. C.;LipiÅ„ska, A. D.;Koppers-Lalic, D.;Van Leeuwen, W. F.;Cohen, J. I.;Kinchington, P. R.;Messaoudi, I.;BieÅ„kowska-Szewczyk, K.;Ressing, M. E.;Rijsewijk, F. A. M.;Wiertz, E. J. H. J.

title: Detection and Genotyping of Classical Swine Fever Virus Isolates in Serbia
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF) is a highly contagious swine disease that causes significant economic losses worldwide. The classic swine fever virus can be classified into three genogroups, each consisting of three or four subgroups. However, there is a lack of information on the genotypes of CSFV isolates in the Republic of Serbia. Based on sequence analysis of the partial E2 gene and 5' noncoding region (NCR) of 15 CSFVs isolated from domestic pigs between 2006 and 2008, this study revealed that they all clustered in genetic group 2.3. In addition, we have shown that the two most commonly used real-time RT-PCR tests can detect all local CSF viruses circulating in Serbia in recent years during the intense vaccination campaign against CSF.
authors: Vesna, M.;Sonja, R.;Valcic, A. M.;Ivovic, V.;Jelena, M. Z.;Radosavljevic, V.

title: Metagenomic detection and characterization of viruses in fecal samples from Australian wild birds
abstract: We present an optimized metagenomic method for the detection and characterization of all virus strains, including single- and double-stranded DNA/RNA and enveloped and non-enveloped viruses. The initial evaluation included both spiked and nailless bird excrement samples, as well as nail-free human stool samples. We detected 21 viruses from non-spiked bird samples (Australian Muscovy duck and Pacific black duck) and also present a summary of several viruses detected in human fecal samples. Next, we present a detailed analysis of selected virus sequences in bird samples that are somewhat similar to known viruses and have good quality (Q20 or higher) and quantity of next-generation sequencing reads, which are of interest from a virological point of view. for example, avian coronavirus and avian paramyxovirus 6. Some of these viruses were closely related to known viruses, while others were more distantly related with 70% or less identity to currently known/ranked viruses. In addition to detecting viruses, this technique also allows for the characterization of available host mitochondrial DNA and thus the identification of host species, while ribosomal RNA sequences provide insight into the "ribosomal activity microbiome"; intestinal parasites; and foods we associate with non-avian host-associated viruses, such as plants or insects.
authors: Vibin, J.;Chamings, A.;Collier, F.;Klaassen, M.;Nelson, T. M.;Alexandersen, S.

title: Metagenomic Analysis of Viruses in Stool Samples from Children with Acute Flask Paralysis
abstract: We analyzed viral nucleic acids in stool samples collected from 35 South Asian children with non-polio acute flaccid paralysis (AFP). Sequence-independent reverse transcription and PCR amplification of capsid-protected, nuclease-resistant viral nucleic acids were followed by DNA sequencing and sequence similarity searches. Limited Sanger sequencing (35 to 240 subclones per sample) identified an average of 1.4 different eukaryotic viruses per sample, while pyro sequencing yielded 2.6 viruses per sample. In addition to bacteriophage and plant viruses, we detected numerous other members of the Picornaviridae family, including parechovirus, as well as known enteric viruses, including rotavirus, adenovirus, picobirnavirus, and human enterovirus types A (HEV-A) to HEV-C. Aichi virus, rhinovirus and human cardiovirus. Viruses with the most divergent sequences to previously reported viruses included members of a new genus Picornaviridae and four new viral species (family Dicistroviridae, Nodaviridae and Circoviridae, and members of the genus Bocavirus). Samples from six healthy contacts of AFP patients were similarly analyzed and also contained multiple viruses, particularly HEV-C, potentially including a new Enterovirus genotype. Determining the prevalence and pathogenicity of the novel genotypes, species, genera, and potential novel viral families identified in this study in different demographic groups will require further work with different demographics and patient groups, now facilitated by knowledge of these viral genomes.
authors: Victoria, J. G.;Kapoor, A.;Li, L. L.;Blinkova, O.;Slikas, B.;Wang, C. L.;Naeem, A.;Zaidi, S.;Delwart, E.

title: Viral nucleic acids in live attenuated vaccines: Detection of minority variants and an incidental virus.
abstract: Metagenomic and one panmicrobial microarray were used to examine eight live attenuated viral vaccines. Viral nucleic acids in live vaccines for trivalent oral poliovirus (OPV), rubella, measles, yellow fever, varicella-zoster, multivalent measles/mumps/rubella, and bivalent oral poliovirus (OPV), were partially purified, randomly amplified, and pyro-sequenced. At depths reaching 8,000 reads per nucleotide, more than half a million sequence reads were generated, covering 20 to 99% of attenuated viral genomes. Mutations and minority variants were detected in OPV, mumps virus, and varicella-zoster virus that were not known to affect attenuation relative to vaccine strains. Detection of expected endogenous retroviral sequences from producer bird and primate cells was confirmed. Avian leukosis virus (ALV), previously shown not to be contagious to humans, was present as RNA in viral particles, while simian retrovirus (SRV) existed as genetically defective DNA. Rotarix, an orally administered rotavirus vaccine, contained porcine circovirus-1 (PCV1), a highly common, non-pathogenic porcine virus that has not been shown to be infectious in humans. Hybridization of vaccine nucleic acids to a panmicrobial microarray confirmed the presence of endogenous retroviral and PCV1 nucleic acids. Therefore, deep sequencing and microarrays can detect attenuated virus sequence changes, minority variants and incidental viruses and help maintain the current safety record of live attenuated viral vaccines. Copyright © 2010, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Victoria, J. G.;Wang, C.;Jones, M. S.;Jaing, C.;McLoughlin, K.;Gardner, S.;Delwart, E. L.

title: Whole genome characterization by deep sequencing of rotavirus A isolates from neonatal diarrheal outbreaks in pigs in Spain
abstract: Since early 2017, there has been a marked increase in reports of rotavirus involvement in neonatal diarrheal outbreaks in Spain that also affected adult sows. This study investigated 16 unrelated diarrheal outbreaks in lactating pigs and sows, in which rotavirus A was the only pathogen detected. Deep sequencing was performed on total RNA from twenty-four positive stool samples. Genotyping, phylogenetic, and bayesian analyzes showed that all isolates had a common porcine ancestor or pig-like origin. The new species was introduced to the population shortly before the onset of epidemics. In addition, a high variation occurred in the VP7 and VP4 genes in a short time. The isolates showed a higher number of amino acid changes in neutralizing epitopes compared to vaccine sequences. This report demonstrates how a new strain of rotavirus A can spread rapidly and the extremely high diversity in which this pathogen can survive in a short period of time.
authors: Vidal, A.;Clilverd, H.;Cortey, M.;Martin-Valls, G. E.;Franzo, G.;Darwich, L.;Martin, M.;Mateu, E.

title: Application of Standard and Molecular Methods in the Diagnosis of Newcastle Disease
abstract: Four pooled samples of whole poultry carcasses with their internal organs were used to determine the presence of Newcastle disease (ND) virus. In January 2007, samples were collected from an epizootiological site in the Republic of Serbia. Newcastle disease virus strains were isolated from four samples. Identification of isolated strains was done using hemagglutination and hemagglutination-inhibition tests. The nucleic acid of the ND virus was identified in all four samples. All strains isolated were confirmed to be velogenic strains. Analysis of the nucleotide sequences of the gene encoding the F cleavage site of the fusion F protein revealed the presence of motifs (112) RRQKRFIG(119) characteristic for velogenic strains of ND virus. Phylogenetic analysis of the F gene sequences revealed that all isolated strains of the virus belonged to class II and genotype VIId.
authors: Vidanovic, D.;Sekler, M.;Polacek, V.;Vaskovic, N.;Asanin, R.;Milic, N.;Nisavic, J.

title: Being vigilant against emerging pathogens worldwide: A phylogeographic approach to determine the epidemiology of Porcine circovirus-2 (PCV-2), taking into account global trade.
abstract: Porcine circovirus-2 (PCV-2) is an emerging virus associated with a number of different syndromes in pigs known as Porcine Circovirus Associated Diseases (PCVAD). Since its identification and characterization in the early 1990s, PCV-2 has achieved worldwide distribution, has become endemic in most pig-producing countries and is now considered the main cause of losses in pig farms. In this study, we analyzed the main pathways of PCV-2 spread among pig producing countries using phylogenetic and phylogeographic approaches. A search of the PCV-2 genome sequences was performed in GenBank and the resulting 420 PCV-2 sequences were grouped into haplotypes (group of sequences with 100% identity) based on the infinite site model of genome evolution. A phylogenetic hypothesis was deduced by Bayesian Inference for the classification of viral strains, and a haplotype network was created by Median Joining to predict the geographic distribution and genealogical relationships of haplotypes. To provide an epidemiological and economic context in these analyses, we evaluated all information on PCV-2 sequences available in GenBank, including published articles on viral isolation and live pig trade statistics available in the UN Comtrade database (http://comtrade). .un.org/). In these analyses, we identified a strong correlation between the PCV-2 distribution means predicted by the haplotype network and the statistics on international trade in live pigs. This correlation provides a new perspective on the epidemiology of PCV-2, highlighting the importance of worldwide animal movement in the emergence of new pathogens and demonstrating the need for effective sanitary barriers to trade in livestock. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Vidigal, P. M. P.;Mafra, C. L.;Silva, F. M. F.;Fietto, J. L. R.;Silva JÃºnior, A.;Almeida, M. R.

title: Hepadnavirus detected in bile and liver samples from domestic pigs from commercial slaughterhouses
abstract: Background: Preliminary studies have demonstrated the prevalence of a virus similar to human hepatitis B virus (HBV-like) in pigs from farms in China and molecular evidence of Hepadnavirus infection in Brazilian domestic pig herds. In this study, we genetically characterized swine Hepadnavirus strains found in pigs from certified abattoirs in the Brazilian State of Rio de Janeiro and evaluated their hepatotropic potential. Results: Bile and liver samples from pigs were positive for partial genome amplification (ORF S and ORF C), direct sequencing, and viral load measurement. Sequencing of the gene encoding the surface antigen allowed Hepadnavirus to be classified into genotypes, similar to the HBV genotype classification. Indirect immunofluorescence confirmed the presence of HBsAg antigen in liver tissue sections. Conclusions: Our data to date indicate that commercial pig harbors an HBV-like virus and this relevant finding should be considered in studies of origin and viral evolution.
authors: Vieira, Y. R.;Dos Santos, D. R. L.;Portilho, M. M.;Velloso, C. E. P.;Arissawa, M.;Villar, L. M.;Pinto, M. A.;De Paula, V. S.

title: Hendra and Nipah infection: Pathology, patterns and potential treatments
abstract: The family Paramyxoviridae consists of several genera that present emerging or re-emerging threats to human and animal health without real and specific effective treatment. Hendra and Nipah virus are members of the Henipavirus genus of emerging paramyxoviruses. Since their discovery in the 1990s, henipavirus outbreaks have been associated with a high potential for economic and public health threats. Compared to other paramyxoviruses, henipaviruses appear to have unique properties. Henipaviruses are zoonotic paramyxoviruses with a wider tropism than most other paramyxoviruses and can cause severe acute encephalitis with features unique among viral encephalitis. There are currently no approved effective prophylactic or therapeutic treatments for henipavirus infections. While ribavirin has been used empirically and appears beneficial during the largest outbreak of one of these viruses, the Nipah virus, its efficacy is controversial in light of the lack of efficacy in various animal models of henipavirus infection. However, due to its highly pathogenic nature, much effort has been devoted to the development of anti-henipavirus therapeutics. In this review, we describe the unique features of henipavirus infections and the different strategies and animal models developed so far to identify and test potential drugs to prevent or treat henipavirus infections. Some of these ingredients have the potential to be broad-spectrum antivirals as they target viral pathogenicity effectors common in other viruses. We will focus on small molecules or biologics rather than vaccine strategies developed as anti-henipaviral therapeutics. Â© 2011 Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.
authors: Vigant, F.;Lee, B.

title: Analysis of the crow lung transcriptome in response to infection with the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza virus.
abstract: The highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 virus currently circulating in Asia causes serious illness in domestic birds as well as in wild birds such as crows. However, the molecular pathogenesis of HPAIV infection in crows and other wild birds is not well known. Therefore, as a step to explore, a comprehensive global gene expression analysis was performed on crow lungs infected with HPAI H5N1 crow isolate (A/Crow/India/11TI11/2011) using high-throughput next-generation sequencing (NGS) (GS FLX). . Titanium XLR70). The crow's reference genome is not available, so RNA sequencing was performed on the basis of a de novo-spliced transcriptome. The RNA sequence result shows that 4052 genes are uniquely expressed in the uninfected, 6277 genes are uniquely expressed in the HPAIV-infected sample, and 2279 genes out of 6814 expressed in both samples are significantly different. Our transcriptome profiling data allow for the ability to understand the molecular mechanism behind the recent deadly outbreak of HPAIV in crows, which until recently was thought to cause lethal infections only in gallbladder birds such as chickens and not in wild birds. The pattern of differentially expressed genes indicates that this isolate of H5N1 virus evades the host innate immune response, possibly by downregulating signaling from type I IFN (IFNAR1 and IFNAR2) and type II IFN receptors, reducing interferon (IFN)-inducible signaling, upregulation. altering the expression of suppressive signaling inhibitors of cytokine signaling 1 (SOCS1) and SOCS3, and toll-like receptors (TLRs). This may be the cause of illness and death in crows.
authors: Vijayakumar, P.;Mishra, A.;Ranaware, P. B.;Kolte, A. P.;Kulkarni, D. D.;Burt, D. W.;Raut, A. A.

title: Evaluation of the envelope glycoprotein Erns of an atypical bovine pestivirus as antigen in a microsphere immunoassay for the detection of antibodies to bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 and atypical bovine pestivirus.
abstract: Atypical bovine pestiviruses are antigenically and phylogenetically related to bovine viral diarrheal viruses (BVDV-1 and BVDV-2) and may cause the same clinical manifestations in animals. The glycoprotein Erns of an atypical bovine pestivirus Th/04_KhonKaen was produced in a baculovirus expression system and purified by affinity chromatography. The recombinant Erns protein was used as an antigen in a microsphere immunoassay for the detection of antibodies to BVDV-1 and atypical bovine pestivirus. The diagnostic performance of the new method was evaluated by testing a total of 596 serum samples and the assay was compared with the enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Based on the negative/positive cut-off median fluorescence intensity (MFI) value of 2800, the microsphere immunoassay had 100% sensitivity and 100% specificity compared to ELISA. The immunoassay was able to detect antibodies to both BVDV-1 and the atypical pestivirus. This new microsphere immunoassay has the potential to be multiplexed for the simultaneous detection of antibodies against different bovine pathogens in a highly efficient and economical manner. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Vijayaraghavan, B.;Xia, H.;Harimoorthy, R.;Liu, L.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Pathotyping of a Newcastle disease virus isolated from a peacock (Pavo cristatus)
abstract: This report describes Newcastle disease in peacocks and the isolation and characterization of the virus. The intracerbral pathogenicity index of the virus was 1.71 and the mean time to death was 47 hours. The isolate had multiple basic amino acids with a phenylalanine at residue 117 in the fusion protein cleavage site sequence ((110)GGRRQRRFIG(119)). Biological and molecular characterization revealed that the virus was velogenic. Phylogenetic analysis placed the isolate in genotype II.
authors: Vijayarani, K.;Muthusamy, S.;Tirumurugaan, K. G.;Sakthivelan, S. M.;Kumanan, K.

title: Complete genomic sequence of human coronavirus OC43: Molecular clock analysis shows a relatively new zoonotic coronavirus transmission event
abstract: Coronaviruses are enveloped, positive-stranded RNA viruses with a genome of about 30 kb. According to genetic similarities, coronaviruses are divided into three groups. Two group 2 coronaviruses, human coronavirus OC43 (HCoV-OC43) and bovine coronavirus (BCoV), show remarkable antigenic and genetic similarities. In this study, we report the first complete genome sequence (30.738 nucleotides) of the prototype HCoV-OC43 strain (ATCC VR7S9). Whole genome and open reading frame (ORF) analyzes were performed compared to the BCoV genome. In the region between the spike and membrane protein genes, there is a 290 nucleotide deletion, corresponding to the absence of the BCoV ORFs ns4.9 and ns4.8. Percentages of nucleotide and amino acid similarity were determined for major HCoV-OC43 ORFs and those of other group 2 coronaviruses. The highest degree of similarity was demonstrated between HCoV-OC43 and BCoV in all ORFs except the E gene. Molecular clock analysis of spike gene sequences of BCoV and HCoV-OC43 suggests a relatively recent zoonotic transmission event and dates their most recent common ancestor to around 1890. The evolutionary rate is on the order of 4 × 10 -4 nucleotide changes per region. year estimated. This is the first animal-human zoonotic coronavirus pair that can be analyzed to learn about the adaptation processes of a non-human coronavirus to a human host, and this is important for understanding the interspecies transmission events that led to the origin of the virus. epidemic of severe acute respiratory syndrome. Copyright © 2005, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Vijgen, L.;Keyaerts, E.;MoÃ«s, E.;Thoelen, I.;Wollants, E.;Lemey, P.;Vandamme, A. M.;Van Ranst, M.

title: Distribution and genetic characterization of Enterovirus G and Sapelovirus A in six Spanish pig herds
authors: Vilar, M. J.;Peralta, B.;GarcÃ­a-Bocanegra, I.;Simon-GrifÃ©, M.

title: Organization and diversity of the 3' noncoding region of the classic swine fever virus genome
abstract: Specific PCR primers were selected to amplify a 359 bp DNA fragment flanking the 3'-portion of the polymerase gene and the 3'-noncoding (3'-NC) region of the classical swine fever virus (CSFV) genome. The fragment selected in RT-PCR was amplified from three vaccine strains of CSFV as well as the genomes of 27 viral strains collected from Europe, America and Asia over a half-century period. Eight PCR products were sequenced using an automated sequencing device. Nucleotide sequence analysis was performed with DNASTAR and PHYLIP computer programs. Comparative studies revealed that the 3'-NC region contains a variable nucleotide region located immediately after the stop codon TGA or TAA. Also, a strongly conserved constant region was identified near its extreme 3'-end. Two defective repeating sequences were found in both the variable and constant regions. In addition, the variable region was characterized by the appearance of a 50 bp long poly AT trace. Phylogenetic analysis with different mathematical approaches (MegAlign, Neighbor-Joining method, Maximum Likelihood, Parsimony) revealed that the examined CSFV strains were divided into two main phylogenetic groups. Group I consisted of former American and European field isolates and a Brazilian vaccine strain, as well as the reference strain Brescia. Group II included the reference strain Alfort (Tubingen) and the recent European field strains. The Congenital Tremor strain formed a distinct lineage that, although quite different, was more closely related to group I than group II. In conclusion, the current phylogenetic grouping yielded very similar results to previous studies based on comparison of the E2 (gp55) region. The agreement of the phylogenetic analysis in the two different regions confirms the reliability of the genetic grouping of CSFV strains in the two main genogroups.
authors: VilÄek, Å ;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Genetic diversity of BVDV: implications for classification and molecular epidemiology
abstract: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is important for the precise classification of viruses and the development of molecular epidemiology. BVDV isolates are usually typed based on comparison of genomic sequences from the 5â€²-untranslated region (5â€²-UTR), Npro and E2 region. We recently identified 11 genetic groups (subgenotypes) of BVDV-1. Our subsequent experiments confirmed a new subgenotype, BVDV-1k, isolated from cattle in Switzerland. BVDV isolates from India are typed as BVDV-1b, while BVDV-1c is the dominant subgenotype in Australia. The results of genetic typing of BVDV show that the distribution of subgenotypes has no relation to the geographical origin of the viral isolates. Â© 2005 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Vilcek, S.;Durkovic, B.;Kolesarova, M.;Paton, D. J.

title: Genetic diversity of recent bovine viral diarrheal viruses from southeast Austria (Styria)
abstract: To characterize bovine virus diarrhea virus (BVDV) isolates circulating in southeastern Austria, namely in the state of Styria, 71 blood samples collected from 62 herds of permanently infected cattle between 1998 and 2000 were subjected to genetic typing. For this, 288bp fragments from the 5â€² untranslated region (5â€²-UTR) were amplified by polymerase chain reaction after reverse transcription (RT-PCR). The products were sequenced and used for phylogenetic analysis. Seventy virus isolates were typed as BVDV type 1 (BVDV-1). Only one isolate was typed as BVDV type 2 (BVDV-2), representing the first isolate of this pestivirus genotype found in Austria. In addition, phylogenetic analysis revealed that viruses belonging to five genetic groups within BVDV-1 circulate in Styria. Most viruses (53) were found in the BVDV-1f group, nine viruses in BVDV-1h, four viruses in BVDV-1b, three viruses in BVDV-1d, and one virus BVDV-1g. No viruses were found in the genetic group BVDV-1a, which is predominant in the UK and common in the US. Similarly, BVDV isolates predominant in a neighboring country, namely Germany, belonged to different genogroups than those circulating in Styria. We conclude that certain BVDV-1 genetic groups predominate in a particular region and environment. New groups, including BVDV-2, may be introduced, for example, through the animal trade. The low incidence of BVDV-2 in Styria is in keeping with the occasional occurrence of these viruses in other parts of Europe. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Vilcek, S.;Greiser-Wilke, I.;Durkovic, B.;Obritzhauser, W.;Deutz, A.;KÃ¶fer, J.

title: Molecular characterization of sheep pestiviruses
abstract: Forty-two ovine pestivirus isolates collected over an 18-year period were compared by phylogenetic analysis. The viruses were mostly field isolates from England; the other two came from Sweden and two from New Zealand. RT-PCR products were obtained from two genomic regions, one within the 5' noncoding (5'-NC) region and the other covering the p20 (N(pro)) and C coding regions. Direct sequencing of the 5'-NC PCR products, followed by computer-assisted phylogenetic analysis, separated the ovine pestiviruses into three main genotypes. The results showed that sheep can be naturally infected not only with border disease virus (BDV), but also with bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) types I and II. BDV isolates were divided into two main subtypes represented by the Moredun strain from Scotland and the 137/4 strain from England. The BVDV-I group consisted of three clusters, two of which were represented by the BVDV reference strains NADL and Osloss, and the third by sheep isolates D1120/1 and D1432/P, respectively. Grouping of ovine pestiviruses based on comparative nucleotide sequence analysis of the 5'-NC region was confirmed by comparative analysis of the p20 (NP(pro)) and C coding regions performed at both the nucleotide and amino acid level. . The presence of three genotypes, including BVDV-I and BVDV-II, in sheep indicates the inadequacy of current host-species-based nomenclature and classification of pestiviruses.
authors: VilÄek, Å ;Nettleton, P. F.;Paton, D. J.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Genetic variability of the classic swine fever virus
abstract: The genetic variability of the classic swine fever virus was studied by comparative nucleotide sequence analysis of 76 virus isolates collected over half a century from three continents. E2 (gp55) portions of the viral genome and polymerase gene coding regions were amplified by RT-PCR and DNA fragments of 254 and 207 bp were sequenced, respectively. Comparative sequence analysis of the E2 region revealed two major phylogenetic groups of CSFVs, indicating that the virus apparently evolved from two ancestral nodes. Group I (represented by the Brescia species) consisted of old and new American and Asian viruses, as well as old British isolates from the 1950s. This group has been subdivided into three subgroups called IA IC Group II (represented by the Alfort strain) consisting of relatively new isolates from Europe, with the Osaka strain isolated in Japan from a European pig. The group was divided into II.A and II.B subgroups according to genetic distances. Malaysian isolates were split into both groups, indicating multiple origins for concurrent outbreaks in that country. All ten vaccine types tested branched into group I, indicating a common ancestor. The Japanese Kanagawa strain isolated in 1974 and the British Congenital Tremor strain from 1964 were the most prominent variants of CSFV in our collection. Comparison of the nucleotide sequences of the polymerase coding region of 32 European strains distinguished subgroups II.A and II.B, which were similar to the corresponding subgroups of the E2 phylogenetic tree. Thus, the results revealed that the E2 region and polymerase-encoding regions appear suitable for grouping CSFV isolates from all over the world, distinguishing the two main groups of the virus. The reliability of these regions for phylogenetic analysis is demonstrated by the similarity of results from two separate segments of the CSFV genome.
authors: VilÄek, Å ;Stadejek, T.;Ballagi-PordÃ¡ny, A.;Lowings, J. P.;Paton, D. J.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Hepatitis E virus genotype 3 diversity: phylogenetic analysis and presence of subtype 3b in European wild boar
abstract: Increasing numbers of domestic hepatitis E cases caused by genotype 3 viruses (HEV-3) have been diagnosed worldwide, especially in industrialized countries. Hepatitis E is a zoonotic disease, and accumulating evidence indicates that the main reservoirs of HEV-3 are domestic pigs and wild boars. A detailed analysis of HEV-3 subtypes can help determine the interplay of human activity, the role of animals as reservoirs, and interspecies transmission. Although whole genome sequences are best suited for HEV subtype determination, in most cases only partial genomic sequences are available. Therefore, we performed a subtype classification analysis using regions from all three open reading frames of the genome. Using this approach, more than 1000 published HEV-3 isolates were subtyped. Newly obtained HEV partial sequences from hunted German wild boars were also included in this study. These sequences were assigned to genotype 3 and clustered in subtype 3a, 3i, and unexpectedly one of them clustered in subtype 3b, the first non-human report of this subtype in Europe.
authors: Vina-Rodriguez, A.;Schlosser, J.;Becher, D.;Kaden, V.;Groschup, M. H.;Eiden, M.

title: Investigation of Human Cancers for Retrovirus with Low-Precision Target Enrichment and High-throughput Sequencing
abstract: Although approximately one-fifth of all human cancers have an infectious etiology, the causes of the majority of cancers remain unexplained. Despite the enormous data throughput from high-throughput shotgun sequencing, viral DNA in a clinical sample typically makes up a fraction of host DNA that is too small to detect. Sequence variation between virus genomes complicates the application of sequence-specific and highly sensitive PCR methods. Therefore, we aimed to develop and characterize a method that allows sensitive detection of sequences despite significant differences. We show that our low stringency in-solution hybridization method enables detection of <100 viral copies. Furthermore, distantly related proviral sequences can be enriched by orders of magnitude, enabling the discovery of hitherto unknown viral sequences by high-throughput sequencing. Sensitivity was sufficient to detect retroviral sequences in clinical samples. We used this method to conduct a new study of retroviruses in samples from three cancer types. According to recent studies, our investigation revealed no retroviral infection in human B-cell lymphoma cells, cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, or colorectal cancer biopsies. However, our generally applicable method enables sensitive detection and allows sequencing of remotely related sequences from complex material.
authors: Vinner, L.;Mourier, T.;Friis-Nielsen, J.;Gniadecki, R.;Dybkaer, K.;Rosenberg, J.;Langhoff, J. L.;Cruz, D. F.;Fonager, J.;Izarzugaza, J. M.;Gupta, R.;Sicheritz-Ponten, T.;Brunak, S.;Willerslev, E.;Nielsen, L. P.;Hansen, A. J.

title: Nucleotide sequence analysis of the variable region of the VP2 gene of two infectious bursal disease virus isolates from commercial poultry farms.
abstract: Two infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) isolates were obtained from commercial poultry farms with a history of severe outbreaks. A 474-bp product spanning the hypervariable region of the IBDV VP2 gene was amplified by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). The nucleotide sequences of two isolates, VMB1 and VMB2, were determined and compared with twenty IBDV strains, including seven highly virulent, four classically virulent, four classically attenuated, three antigenic variants and two avirulent serotype 2 strains. Two isolates, 96.5–98.4% with highly virulent strains, 84.6–94.6% with classical virulent strains, 90.0–91.4% with classically attenuated strains, 83.0–91.9% with antigenic variants, and 65.8–68% with avirulent strains ,7 showed similarity. The deduced amino acid sequences of the two isolates showed amino acid substitutions of V256I, N279D, L294I and N299S specific to the highly virulent strains. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the two isolates were closely related to European, Japanese, and Chinese highly virulent strains showing their evolutionary origins, along with a reported highly virulent Indian strain.
authors: Viswas, K. N.;Muniyappa, L.;Suryanarayana, V. V. S.;Byregowda, S. M.

title: Experimental infection of traditional nursing pigs and dams with Porcine deltacoronavirus
abstract: Porcine deltacoronavirus (PDCoV) is a newly identified virus detected in swine herds associated with enteric disease in North America. The aim of this study was to demonstrate the pathogenicity, course of infection, virus kinetics, and aerosol transmission of PDCoV using 87 conventional piglets and their 9 dams, including aerosol and contact controls, to mimic field conditions. Piglets and their dams aged 2-4 days were administered an oronasal PDCoV vaccine with a quantitative real-time reverse transcription (qRT)-PCR quantification cycle (Cq) value of 22, produced from a field sample with 100% nucleotide identity. USA/Illinois121/2014 was identified by metagenomic sequencing and tested negative for other enteric disease agents using standard tests. 1-8 over the 42-day study for qRT-PCR, histopathology, and immunohistochemistry. Serial samples of blood, serum, oral fluids, nasal and fecal swabs and tissues were collected from sequential autopsy performed daily on days and at regular intervals thereafter. . All vaccinated and contact control pigs, including dams, developed diarrhea occurring 2 days post-vaccination (dpi) and aerosol control pigs and weirs with a resolution of 3-4 dpi to 12 dpi. Mild to severe atrophic enteritis with PDCoV antigen staining between 2 and 8 dpi was observed in the small intestine of affected piglets. The mesenteric lymph node and small intestine were the primary sites of antigen detection by immunohistochemistry and virus RNA was detected in these tissues by the end of the study. Virus RNA was detectable up to 21 dpi in piglet fecal swabs and up to 14-35 dpi in dams.
authors: Vitosh-Sillman, S.;Loy, J. D.;Brodersen, B.;Kelling, C.;Doster, A.;Topliff, C.;Nelson, E.;Bai, J.;Schirtzinger, E.;Poulsen, E.;Meadors, B.;Anderson, J.;Hause, B.;Anderson, G.;Hesse, R.

title: New hemotropic mycoplasmas are common and genetically diverse in vampire bats.
abstract: Bats (Order: Chiroptera) have been widely studied as reservoir hosts for viruses of human and animal health. However, whether bats are equally competent hosts of non-viral pathogens such as bacteria remains an important open question. Here, hemotropic Mycoplasma spp. We investigated blood and saliva samples of vampire bats from Peru and Belize. (haemoplasms), bacteria that can cause undetected infection or anemia in hosts. 16S rRNA gene amplification in blood showed that 67% (150/223) of common vampire bats (Desmodus rotundus) were infected by hemoplasmas. Sequencing of 16S rRNA gene amplicons revealed three new genotypes that are phylogenetically related but not identical to the haemoplasms described from other (non-vampire) bat species, rodents, humans, and non-human primates. The prevalence of haemoplasm in vampire bats was highest in non-breeding and juvenile individuals, did not differ by country and remained relatively constant over time (ie endemic). Metagenomics from D. rotundus saliva collected from Peru detected non-hemotropic Mycoplasma species and hemoplasma genotypes phylogenetically similar to those identified in blood, providing indirect evidence for potential direct transmission of hemoplasmas by biting or social contact. This study shows that vampire bats host several novel haemoplasms and sheds light on the risk factors for infection and its main modes of transmission. Given the high frequency of direct contact that occurs when vampire bats feed on humans, pets, and wildlife, the potential for cross-species transmission of these bacteria should be explored in future studies.
authors: Volokhov, D. V.;Becker, D. J.;Bergner, L. M.;Camus, M. S.;Orton, R. J.;Chizhikov, V. E.;Altizer, S. M.;Streicker, D. G.

title: Pulmonary changes in cases of Norwegian fatal pandemic influenza H1N1 (2009) infection: a morphological and molecular genetic study.
abstract: Background: During the 2009 swine flu (A(H1N1)pdm09) pandemic outbreak, 32 fatal cases occurred in Norway, of which 19 were included in this study. OBJECTIVES: We characterized pulmonary changes in these fatal Norwegian cases. PATIENTS AND METHODS: Detailed clinical information and samples from the upper and lower respiratory tracts were collected after hospitalization. Postmortem lung tissue was collected, fixed with formalin and embedded in paraffin. Immunohistochemical and light microscopic examination were performed to visualize the local expression of the A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and pyro-sequencing of unfixed samples allowed the identification of mutations in the influenza virus surface glycoprotein (hemagglutinin gene), specifically at position 222. 2 to 40 days (9 days on average). Diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) was evident in 11 cases, 4 of which had no obvious underlying disease. Obesity was evident in 12 cases, three of which were classified as healthy. HA D222G mutation was detected in six cases, 3 of which had no underlying disease. Immunohistochemistry showed that the A(H1N1)pdm09 virus was prominent at the site of inflammation both near and inside the alveolar structures in lung tissue. In addition to a possible role for the HA D222G mutation, our findings suggest that host factors and underlying conditions in infected individuals are fundamental for disease outcome in many cases. This study increases our understanding of the determinants for the clinical outcome of pandemic influenza that may guide future treatment.
authors: Voltersvik, P.;Aqrawi, L. A.;Dudman, S.;Hungnes, O.;Norwegian Lung Pathology, G.;Bostad, L.;Brokstad, K. A.;Cox, R. J.

title: 99th Dahlem Conference on Infection, Inflammation and Chronic Inflammatory Disorders: Farm lifestyles and the hygiene hypothesis
abstract: It has been nearly 15 years since Strachan first proposed the idea that infections and unhygienic contact can protect against the development of allergic diseases. The so-called "hygiene hypothesis" has since undergone numerous changes in epidemiology, clinical science and immunology. Three main areas of research have been proposed: investigating the role of overt viral and bacterial infections in the onset of allergic diseases; to explore the importance of environmental exposure to microbial compounds on the development of allergies; and to examine the effect of both exposures on underlying innate and adaptive immune responses. No concept unifying these various aspects was found, but several parts of the complex interplay between the host's immune responses, the characteristics of the invading microorganism, the level and diversity of environmental exposure, and the interactions between an exposed subject's genetic background and the disease were found. environmental exposures become evident. A natural experiment with the hygiene hypothesis is the repeated observation of the protective effect of growing up on a farm for asthma and allergies. This has been demonstrated in numerous epidemiological studies among children and adults worldwide. The timing and duration of exposure is likely to play a critical role. The greatest reduction in risk was shown in those with continued exposure before and after birth into adulthood. The protective factors in these agricultural environments are not fully resolved. Findings from several studies suggest that contact with farm animals, at least in childhood, provides protection. In addition, consumption of unprocessed cow's milk directly from the farm has been shown to protect against childhood asthma and allergies. Increased levels of microbial substances may contribute, at least in part, to the 'farm effect'. However, there are only a few studies measuring microbial exposures in these settings, and results so far indicate that the underlying protective microbial exposure(s) has not been identified, although a number of studies using metagenomic approaches are currently underway. The mechanisms by which such environmental exposures provide protection from respiratory allergies are also not well understood. There is good evidence that innate immune responses are involved, but translation into protective mechanisms for asthma and allergies is lacking. Also, a number of gene x environment interactions have been observed. Â© 2010 British Society of Immunology.
authors: Von Mutius, E.

title: Possible role played by buffalo in recent foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks in South Africa
abstract: African buffalo (Syncerus caffer) acts as a care host for foot and mouth disease (FMD) in South Africa. A single buffalo can be infected with all three of the endemic serotypes of FMD virus (SAT-1, SAT-2 and SAT-3), posing an infection threat to other susceptible equidae. Flooding in South Africa in 2000 greatly damaged the Kruger National Park (KNP) game fence, and there were several accounts of buffalo fleeing the park. The VP1 gene encoding the major antigenic determinant of FMD virus was used to determine phylogenetic relationships between virus isolates from outbreaks and those previously obtained from buffalo in CNP. These results suggest that buffalo is most likely the source of the outbreaks; this shows that, in addition to fencing disease control, vaccination is extremely important to ensure that FMD does not become established in pets.
authors: Vosloo, W.;Boshoff, K.;Dwarka, R.;Bastos, A.

title: Genome variation in SAT types of foot-and-mouth disease viruses common in buffalo (Syncerus caffer) in Kruger National Park and other parts of South Africa, 1986-93
abstract: Dideoxy nucleotide sequencing of a portion of the 1D gene of SAT-type foot-and-mouth disease viruses (FMDV) was used to derive phylogenetic relationships between viruses from esophageo-pharyngeal secretions of buffaloes from Kruger National Park. Other wildlife areas in South Africa. While the three serotypes differed more than 40% from each other, the intratypic variation did not exceed 29%. Within each species, isolates from specific countries were more closely related than isolates from other countries, lending confidence to previous observations that FMDV evolved independently in different parts of the subcontinent.
authors: Vosloo, W.;Kirkbride, E.;Bengis, R. G.;Keet, D. F.;Thomson, G. R.

title: What should be the correct name for the chickenpox virus?
authors: Votava, M.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the polyprotein coding region of an infectious strain of South African bursal disease virus (IBDV)
abstract: Infectious bursal disease virus (IBDV) causes Gumboro disease, which is highly contagious and immunosuppressive in young chickens. A virulent form of IBDV reached South Africa in 1989, and to date very little molecular information has been available for this strain. In this study, the polyprotein coding region of the South African strain SA-KZN95 was sequenced and analyzed together with 52 representative sequences of other serotypes I and II strains. We investigated the relative effect of recombination on phylogenetic remodeling using a multidimensional scaling approach. Phylogenetic analyzes consistently placed the South African isolate in the highly lethal IBDV clade. Selection analyzes were also performed to identify evolutionarily relevant amino acid residues. Previously, 19 residues in the polyprotein were shown to be potentially diagnostic for different IBDV pathotypes. This study identified two additional unique residues in the polyprotein that could be used as genetic signatures in future viral identifications. Better strain identification will aid in the development and administration of vaccines. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Vukea, P. R.;Willows-Munro, S.;Horner, R. F.;Coetzer, T. H. T.

title: Human spermidine synthase: Cloning and primary structure
abstract: Using a synthetic mixture of deoxyoligonucleotides for a tryptic peptide of the bovine enzyme as a probe, cDNA encoding the full-length subunit of spermidine synthase was isolated from a human decidual cDNA library constructed on phage Î»gt11. After subcloning and amplification into the Eco RI region of pBR322, both sequences of the insert were sequenced using a shotgun strategy. An open reading frame was resolved for a 302 amino acid polypeptide, starting from the first start codon immediately preceding a GC-rich region containing four overlapping CCGCC consensus sequences. This peptide had an M(r) of 33,827, started with methionine and ended with serine. The identity of the isolated cDNA was confirmed by comparing the deduced amino acid sequence with the resolved sequences of tryptic peptides of bovine spermidine synthase. The coding strand of cDNA showed no specific regulatory or ribosome binding signal in 82 nucleotides before the start codon and no polyadenylation signal in 247 nucleotides following the stop codon. The coding region containing a 13 nucleotide repeat near the 5' end was longer and very different from its bacterial counterpart. This region appears to be of retroviral origin and shows marked homology with sequences found in a variety of human, mammalian, avian and viral genes and mRNAs. By computer analysis, the first 200 nucleotides of the 5' end of the coding chain appear to be able to form a very stable secondary structure with a free energy change of -157.6 kcal/mol. In Northern blot hybridization experiments, the labeled cDNA specifically recognized a 1.5 kb poly(A)+RNA from cultured human and murine cell lines.
authors: Wahlfors, J.;Alhonen, L.;Kauppinen, L.;Hyvonen, T.;Janne, J.;Eloranta, T. O.

title: Evolutionary insights of the Bean common mosaic necrosis virus and the Cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus.
abstract: Plant viral diseases are one of the biggest constraints on legume production in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), as they are responsible for up to 100% production losses on small-scale farms. In this study, field studies were conducted with viral symptomatic leaf samples collected from the western highlands of Kenya. Next, next-generation sequencing was performed to gain insight into the molecular evolution and evolutionary relationships of Bean common mosaic necrosis virus (BCMNV) and Cowpea aphid-borne mosaic virus (CABMV) in symptomatic beans and cowpeas. Nearly eleven genomes of BCMNV and two genomes for CABMV were obtained from western Kenya. Bayesian phylogenomic analysis and differential selection pressure tests of viral genomes between tree branches and within sites were performed. Three well-supported segments in BCMNV and one well-supported segment for CABMNV resolved and were compatible with individual gene trees. Selection pressure analysis within regions and between phylogenetic branches showed that both viruses evolved independently, but under strong purifying selection with a slow evolutionary rate. These findings provide valuable insight into the evolution of the BCMNV and CABMV genomes and their relationships to other viral genomes globally. The results will greatly add to the knowledge gap involving the phylogenomic relevance of these viruses, particularly for CABMV for which several genome sequences are available, and inform current breeding efforts towards resistance to BCMNV and CABMV.
authors: Wainaina, J. M.;Kubatko, L.;Harvey, J.;Ateka, E.;Makori, T.;Karanja, D.;Boykin, L. M.;Kehoe, M. A.

title: In vivo characterization of two Australian isolates of Marek's disease virus, including neuropathotyping based on pathology, viral load, and clinical signs
abstract: OBJECTIVE: To evaluate the pathogenicity of the Australian Marek's disease virus (MDV) isolate MPF23 (1985) against the reference strain MPF57 based on neuropathotyping based on pathology, viral load and clinical manifestations. PROCEDURE: Two MDV challenge isolates (MPF57 or MPF23) were administered to unvaccinated specific pathogen-free (SPF) layer chicks at three challenge doses (500, 2000, or 8000 plaque-forming units (pfu)/chick) on day 5 post-hatch. Mortality, body weight, immune organ weights, MDV load in peripheral blood lymphocytes (PBL), and clinical manifestations were measured up to 56 days post-challenge (dpc). RESULTS: MPF23 was more pathogenic between the two viruses, resulting in higher mortality (81% vs 62%) and incidence of MD lesions (76% vs. 100%). MPF23 induced earlier, longer duration, and more severe neurological manifestations in the 26-56 dpc period. However, there was little variation in the order of 0-23 dpc used in the neuropathotyping classification under test. The pattern observed during this early period classified both viruses as neuropathotype B, consistent with a highly virulent pathotype. MDV burden in PBL at 7 and 44 dpc did not differ between virus isolates, but burden at 7 dpc was significantly and negatively correlated with time to euthanasia or death. CONCLUSION: MPF23 appears to be as lethal as or more than MDV strains isolated over the next two decades. The neuropathotyping system developed in the USA did not clearly distinguish between the two isolates tested; however, prolonging the evaluation period of clinical signs beyond 26 dpc revealed clear differences.
authors: Wajid, S. J.;Walkden-Brown, S. W.;Vanselow, B. A.;Islam, A. F.;Renz, K. G.

title: ICTV virus classification profile: Rhabdoviridae
abstract: The Rhabdoviridae family includes viruses with 10.8-16.1 kb negative-sense (--) single-stranded RNA genomes. Virions are typically enveloped with bullet-shaped or bacillus-shaped morphology, but may also be non-enveloped filaments. Rhabdoviruses infect plants and animals, including mammals, birds, reptiles, and fish, as well as arthropods that serve as sole hosts or act as biological vectors for infecting animals or plants. Rhabdoviruses include pathogens important to humans, livestock, fish and agricultural crops. This is a summary of the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV) Report on the Rhabdoviridae taxonomy available at www.ictv.global/report/rhabdoviridae.
authors: Walker, P. J.;Blasdell, K. R.;Calisher, C. H.;Dietzgen, R. G.;Kondo, H.;Kurath, G.;Longdon, B.;Stone, D. M.;Tesh, R. B.;Tordo, N.;Vasilakis, N.;Whitfield, A. E.;Lefkowitz, E. J.;Davison, A. J.;Siddell, S. G.;Simmonds, P.;Sabanadzovic, S.;Smith, D. B.;Orton, R. J.

title: A global genomic characterization of nairoviruses identifies nine distinct genogroups with distinctive structural features and host-vector relationships.
abstract: Nairoviruses are basically tick-borne bunyaviruses, some of which are known to cause mild to severe febrile illness in humans or animals. Birds (Farallon, Punta Salinas, Sapphire II, Zirqa, Avalon, Clo Mor, Taggert and Abu Hammad viruses), rodents (Qalub and Bandia viruses) or camels (Dera Ghazi Khan virus). Global phylogenetic analyzes of proteins encoded in their L, M, and S RNA segments and 20 other extant nairovirus genomes identified nine well-supported genogroups (Nairobi sheep disease, Thiafora, Sakhalin, Keterah, Qalyub, Kasokero, Dera Ghazi Khan, Hughes). , and Tamdy). Genogroup-specific structural variations were particularly evident in the M segment, which encodes a polyprotein in which the virion envelope glycoproteins (Gn and Gc) are produced by proteolytic processing. Structural variations include insertion of sequences encoding extension, shortening, or absence sequences encoding an O-glycosylated mucin-like protein in the N-terminal domain, distinctive patterns of conserved cysteine residues in the GP38-like domain, sequences encoding a double membrane spanning sequence. The presence of an alternative long open reading frame encoding the protein (NSm) between the Gn and Gc domains and a viroporin-like transmembrane protein (Gx). We also observed strong genogroup-specific associations with host categories and tick vectors.
authors: Walker, P. J.;Widen, S. G.;Wood, T. G.;Guzman, H.;Tesh, R. B.;Vasilakis, N.

title: The history of bluetongue and a current global view
abstract: Bluetongue (BT) was first reported more than 125 years ago when European sheep breeds were introduced to South Africa. BT viruses (BTV) have been identified in many tropical and temperate regions of the world. IT, disease, is a phenomenon of ruminant animals in temperate regions. There are few clinical diseases in tropical and subtropical regions of the world. At least 24 BTV serotypes have been identified. While viruses are classified antigenically and taxonomically as BTV, each serotype is unique and may not cause the disease CT. BTVs are transmitted among ruminant animals by competent vector species of the genus Culicoides, namely, biting midges or midges. BTV serotypes are predictable worldwide with Culicoides vector species, but are found in limited geographic and ecological cycles or ecosystems. Despite the almost certain movement of livestock and Culicoides species between these ecosystems, there is little evidence that introduced BTV serotypes have been established in these ecosystems. Instead, periodic cyclical extensions and remissions of these virus-vector ecosystems allow viruses and disease to migrate to and away from adjacent non-endemic areas that are characteristic of many other known arthropod-borne viruses (arboviruses). Earlier publications have suggested that a carrier state occurs in cattle fetally infected with BTV. No subsequent natural experience or research supports the unconfirmed hypothesis. The results of the research are not accepted by the scientific community. It is therefore reasonable to suggest that regulatory restrictions against the movement of cattle from BTV affected countries be relaxed or eliminated.
authors: Walton, T. E.

title: Detection of African swine fever virus-like sequences by metagenomic sequencing in ponds in the Mississippi Delta
abstract: Metagenomic characterization of the aquatic virome was performed in four Mississippi catfish ponds. Despite being significantly different from African swine fever virus (ASFV), 48 of the 446,100 sequences from 12 samples were similar enough to show that they represent new members in the Asfarviridae family. Currently, ASFV is the only member of the Asfarviridae, and this study provides the first indication of a similar virus in North America. At this point, there is no indication that the identified virus(s) poses a threat to human or animal health, and further work is needed to characterize their potential risks to both public health and agricultural development. Â© 2013 Springer Science+Business Media New York.
authors: Wan, X. F.;Barnett, J. L.;Cunningham, F.;Chen, S.;Yang, G.;Nash, S.;Long, L. P.;Ford, L.;Blackmon, S.;Zhang, Y.;Hanson, L.;He, Q.

title: Perspective on the emergence and reemergence of amantadine-resistant influenza A viruses in domestic animals in China
abstract: In China, approximately 20% of animal original influenza A viruses have molecular markers of amantadine resistance. This study suggests, through phylogenetic data analyzes and geospatial statistical analyses, that the emergence of amantadine resistance in animal influenza disease may be due to selection pressures in China, such as amantadine use in some regions. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Wan, X. F.;Carrel, M.;Long, L. P.;Alker, A. P.;Emch, M.

title: Identification of novel and differentially expressed MicroRNAs in goat enzootic nasal adenocarcinoma
abstract: Background: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) post-transcriptionally regulate various genes involved in eukaryotic cell growth, development, metabolism and other biological processes, and numerous miRNAs are involved in cancer initiation and progression. Enzootic nasal adenocarcinoma (ENA), an epithelial tumor induced in goats and sheep by the enzootic nasal tumor virus (ENTV), is a chronic, progressive, contact-transmitted disease. Methods: In this study, high-throughput sequencing of small RNA Illumina was used to construct a goat nasal miRNA library. This study aimed to identify novel and differentially expressed miRNAs with ENA in tumor and para-carcinoma nasal tissues of Nanjiang yellow goats. Results: Four hundred six known miRNAs and 29 new miRNAs were identified.
