A total of 116 miRNAs were significantly differentially expressed in para-carcinoma nasal tissues and ENA (54 downregulated; 60 upregulated; two expressed only in the control group); Target gene prediction and functional analysis revealed that 6176 non-redundant target genes, 1792 significant GOs and 97 significant KEGG pathways were predicted for 121 miRNAs (116 significant expression miRNAs and five star sequences). GO and KEGG pathway analysis revealed that many of the target genes in ENA are involved in cell proliferation, signal transduction, and other processes associated with cancer. Conclusions: This is the first large-scale identification of miRNAs in Capra hircus ENA and provides a theoretical basis for investigating the complex miRNA-mediated regulatory networks involved in the pathogenesis and progression of ENA.
authors: Wang, B.;Ye, N.;Cao, S. J.;Wen, X. T.;Huang, Y.;Yan, Q. G.

title: Microbial phylogeny determines the transcriptional response of the resistome to dynamic composting processes.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Animal manure is a repository of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs), which poses a potential health risk globally, especially for resistance to antibiotics (such as tetracyclines, sulfonamides and fluoroquinolones) commonly used in livestock production. At present, the effects of biological treatment (composting) on the transcriptional response of fertilizer ARGs and their microbial hosts are not well defined. Composting is a dynamic process that consists of four different stages, distinguished by the temperature resulting from microbial activity, namely the mesophilic, thermophilic, cooling and maturation stages. In this study, changes in resistome expression during dynamic composting were determined and correlated with active microbiome profiles. This was achieved by integrating metagenomic and time-series metatranscriptomic data for the microbial community that thrives during composting. RESULTS: Composting markedly reduced the bulk expression level of manure resistome, which mainly comprised of genes encoding tetracycline, vancomycin, fluoroquinolone, beta-lactam and aminoglycoside resistance as well as runoff pumps. Furthermore, the diverse transcriptional response of the resistome to composting at ARG levels was highlighted. Expression of tetracycline resistance genes (tetM-tetW-tetO-tetS) decreased during composting, where significant shifts in the four stages of composting were associated with changes in antibiotic concentration. Composting had no effect on the expression of sulfonamide and fluoroquinolone resistance genes, these genes increased slightly during the thermophilic phase and then decreased to baseline levels. As native populations changed drastically throughout dynamic composting, the core resistome persisted and the composition of reservoir hosts was significantly correlated with dynamic active microbial phylogenetic structure. The hosts for the sulfonamide and fuoroquinolone resistance genes changed significantly in phylonetic structure and underwent an initial increase and then a decrease in abundance. In contrast, hosts for tetracycline resistance genes (tetM-tetW-tetO-tetS) exhibited a steady decline over time. CONCLUSIONS: Transcriptional patterns of a core resistome were identified throughout the composting process, and microbial phylogeny was the key determinant in defining the varying transcriptional response of the resistome to this dynamic biological process. This research has demonstrated the benefits of composting for manure treatment. Tetracyclines reduced the risk of introducing clinically relevant pathogens carrying tetracycline resistance genes and ARGs, as well as environmental contaminants such as RNA viruses and bacteriophages.
authors: Wang, C.;Dong, D.;Strong, P. J.;Zhu, W.;Ma, Z.;Qin, Y.;Wu, W.

title: Comprehensive virome analysis reveals the complexity and diversity of the viral spectrum in pediatric patients diagnosed with severe and mild hand-foot-mouth disease.
abstract: Management of the hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) epidemic is challenging due to the frequent occurrence of non-EV71 and non-CVA16 enteroviruses and some cases that tested negative for HFMD-related causative agents. To clarify the virus spectrum of mild to severe HFMD, a comprehensive virome analysis of 238 samples was performed using next-generation sequencing (NGS). The data revealed a total of thirteen families of mammalian and plant viruses and diverse viral populations, including enteroviruses, common respiratory viruses, diarrheal viruses, plant viruses, and anelloviruses. A total of 18 viruses from 7 virus families were detected in severe cases, and 37 viruses from 12 virus families were detected in mild cases. Furthermore, complex mixed infections of enteroviruses with common respiratory viruses were found mainly in severe cases (P = 0.013), while diarrhea-related viruses were found mainly in mild cases (P < 0.001). This study provides a preliminary understanding of viromes in both mild and severe cases that may benefit the detection of etiologic agents and prevention of HFMD.
authors: Wang, C.;Zhou, S.;Xue, W.;Shen, L.;Huang, W.;Zhang, Y.;Li, X.;Wang, J.;Zhang, H.;Ma, X.

title: Isolation, whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of the first Chuzan virus in China
abstract: Chuzan virus (CHUV), identified here as GX871, was first isolated from blood from a sentinel cattle in China, and its full-length genome was sequenced in this study. The GX871 genome contained 10 segments and 18914Â bp, one base less than the CHUV prototype strain K-47 due to a base deletion in the noncoding 5-² region of segment 8. A frameshift mutation was detected in the short coding. The region corresponding to the VP1 protein (1010-1026Â nt); this frameshift resulted in five amino acid mutations from 336CVLSY340 to 336YGAKL340. In addition, there was a base deletion at 1713 nt and a base insertion at 1682 nt in the 3–2 noncoding region of segment 5. Based on the phylogenetic analysis of the inferred VP2 amino acid sequences, Palyam serogroup viruses were divided into three groups. The Chinese CHUV isolate GX871 was categorized in the same group as the CHUV prototype strain K-47. The phylogenetic tree was divided into three clusters according to the geographical distribution of partial nucleotide sequences of VP7, and this arrangement can define the geographical gene pool of CHUV.
authors: Wang, F.;Lin, J.;Chang, J.;Cao, Y.;Qin, S.;Wu, J.;Yu, L.

title: Plasma virome of cattle from forest region revealed various small circular ssDNA viral genomes
abstract: Background: Free-range cattle are common in the region of Northeast China, which has close contact with farmers and can carry viruses that threaten cattle and farmers. Methods: Using viral metagenomics, we analyzed the virome in plasma samples collected from 80 cattle from the forested region of Northeast China. Results: The bovine plasma virome consists of viruses belonging to families such as Parvoviridae, Papillomaviridae, Picobirnaviridae and different viral genomes showing sequence similarity to circular Rep-encoding single-stranded (CRESS) DNA viruses. Five such CRESS-DNA genomes were fully characterized with circovirus and gemycircularvirus-related Rep sequences. Three bovine parvoviruses belonging to two different genera were also characterized. Conclusion: Virome in bovine plasma samples from the forested region of Northeast China emerged, further characterizing the diversity of viruses in bovine plasma.
authors: Wang, H.;Li, S.;Mahmood, A.;Yang, S.;Wang, X.;Shen, Q.;Shan, T.;Deng, X.;Li, J.;Hua, X.;Cui, L.;Delwart, E.;Zhang, W.

title: New phlebovirus with zoonotic potential isolated from ticks, Australia
abstract: Recently discovered tick-borne phleboviruses have been associated with serious illness and death among people in Asia and the United States. We report the discovery of a new tick phlebovirus in the Australian State of Tasmania, closely related to zoonotic viruses found in Asia and North America.
authors: Wang, J.;Selleck, P.;Yu, M.;Ha, W.;Rootes, C.;Gales, R.;Wise, T.;Crameri, S.;Chen, H.;Broz, I.;Hyatt, A.;Woods, R.;Meehan, B.;McCullough, S.;Wang, L. F.

title: Identification of avian influenza A (H5N1) viruses from southern China to Indonesia and Vietnam
abstract: The transmission of the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus to Southeast Asian countries triggered the first major epidemic and contagion wave in late 2003, accelerating the global pandemic threat. Due to the lack of surveillance of influenza prior to these outbreaks, the genetic diversity and transmission routes of H5N1 viruses during this period have not been defined. To identify the possible source of wave 1 H5N1 viruses, we recently performed further sequencing and analysis of samples collected from live poultry markets from Guangdong, Hunan and Yunnan in southern China from 2001 to 2004. Phylogenetic analysis of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes A greater genetic diversity emerged from 73 H5N1 isolates from this period than previously reported in Southern China. Furthermore, the results showed that eight viruses isolated from Yunnan in 2002 and 2003 were most closely related to the 1st part virus subset from Vietnam, Thailand and Malaysia, while two viruses from Hunan in 2002 and 2003 were associated with viruses from Indonesia. shows that they are most closely related (item 2.1). Further phylogenetic analyzes of the six internal genes showed that all 10 of these viruses maintained similar phylogenetic relationships to their surface genes. The 10 progenitor viruses were genotype Z and shared high similarity (-99%) with their corresponding descendant viruses in most gene segments. These results indicate a direct transmission link for H5N1 viruses between Yunnan and Vietnam in 2002 and 2003, as well as between Hunan and Indonesia. While the poultry trade may be responsible for the virus's entry into Vietnam, the route of transmission from Hunan to Indonesia remains unclear. Copyright © 2008, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Wang, J.;Vijaykrishna, D.;Duan, L.;Bahl, J.;Zhang, J. X.;Webster, R. G.;Peiris, J. S. M.;Chen, H.;Smith, G. J. D.;Guan, Y.

title: Transcriptomic Analysis Identifies Candidate Genes and Gene Sets Controlling the Response of Pig Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells to Poly I:C Stimulation
abstract: Polyinosinic-polycytidylic acid (poly I:C), a synthetic dsRNA analog, has been shown to have stimulatory effects similar to viral dsRNA. To gain in-depth insight into the host transcriptional response of pigs to poly I:C stimulation, in this study, we cultured and stimulated peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) from piglets of a Chinese native breed (Dapulian) and a modern commercial breed (Dapulian) (Landrace) with poly He compared I:C and their transcriptional profiles using RNA sequencing (RNA sequencing). Our results showed that poly I:C stimulation could elicit significantly differentially expressed (DE) genes in Landrace (g = 85) as well as in Dapulian (g = 290). We also performed gene set analysis using the Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) package and identified some gene sets that were significantly enriched in Dapulian (g = 18) and Landrace (g = 21). Many of the shared DE genes and gene sets were immune-related and may play crucial rules in the immune response to poly I:C stimulation. In addition, we detected significantly large sets of DE genes and enriched gene sets when comparing the gene expression profile between the two breeds, including the control and poly I:C stimulation groups. Besides immune-related functions, some DE genes and gene sets between the two genera were involved in the development and growth of various tissues that may be associated with the different traits of the two genera. The DE genes and gene sets identified here provide important insights into understanding the immune regulation of antiviral responses in modern and domestic pigs and the molecular mechanisms of differential genetic resistance to viral infection.
authors: Wang, J.;Wang, Y.;Wang, H.;Wang, H.;Liu, J. F.;Wu, Y.;Guo, J.

title: Characterization of Newcastle disease virus isolates emerging in China
abstract: Summary Background: Newcastle disease (ND) is a worldwide devastating poultry disease characterized by increased respiratory, circulatory disorders, hemorrhagic enteritis, and nervous manifestations. Sequence analysis shows substitutions of several amino acid residues in neutralizing epitopes on the F and HN proteins of recent Shaanxi strains. Both Cross-protection and cross-serum neutralization tests revealed that conventional vaccine strains could not provide full protection for herds. Methods: To better understand the epidemiology of the Newcastle disease outbreak, part of the F gene and full-length HN gene were amplified from Shaanxi isolates by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR), followed by sequence and phylogenetic analyzes. In the pathogenicity analysis, both high intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) and mean time to death (MDT) tests of chicken embryos were performed. A cross-protection experiment was also conducted in which specific pathogen-free chickens vaccinated with a LaSota vaccine strain were challenged by the final Shaanxi strain. Results: Nine Newcastle disease (ND) virus (NDV) isolates recovered from ND outbreaks in chicken flocks in China were genotypically and pathotypically characterized. Amino acid sequence analysis revealed that all NDVs recently isolated with Shaanxi have <sup>112</sup>RRQKRF<sup>117</sup> for the C-terminal of the F2 protein, and chicken embryos have high ICPI and MDT'. revealed that all of these were classified as velogenic-type NDVs. Phylogenetic analysis of these isolates indicated that they belonged to subgenotype VIId, which has been implicated in recent epidemics in northwest China. The percent amino acid sequence identity of the F protein between the final Shaanxi dyes and the five vaccine strains was in the range of 81.9%-88.1%, while the percent amino acid sequence identity of the HN protein between the final Shaanxi strains and vaccine strains was in the range of 81.9-88.1%. 87.4-91.2% range. Furthermore, a number of amino acid residue substitutions were observed in the neutralizing epitopes on the F and HN proteins of these isolates, which could lead to altered antibody recognition and neutralization capacity. A cross-protection experiment demonstrated that specific pathogen-free chickens vaccinated with a LaSota vaccine strain could not provide full protection for flocks threatened by the last Shaanxi strain. Conclusions: Taken together, our findings reveal that recent Shannxi NDV strains exhibit antigenic variations that may be responsible for recent NDV outbreaks in northwest China.
authors: Wang, J. Y.;Liu, W. H.;Ren, J. J.;Tang, P.;Wu, N.;Wu, H. Y.;Ching, C. D.;Liu, H. J.

title: Genome sequence characterization of pigeon circoviruses in China
abstract: Pigeon circovirus (PiCV) was detected by PCR in pigeons from China. In total, 48 out of 244 pigeons tested positive for PiCV (positive rate, 19.67%), indicating that the virus is prevalent in China. From 48 PiCV-positive samples, approximately 2040bp of whole genome fragments were obtained by full-length genome amplification and sequenced with a next-generation sequencing platform. The properties of ORFs from different PiCV strains tested in this study were analyzed. Several insertions, deletions or substitutions were discovered during the analysis of the nucleotide sequence compared to previously reported sequences. In phylogenetic tree analysis, 48 sequences isolated in this study can be further divided into five segments (A, B, C, D and F), segment E contains reference sequences only. In the six branches, two main groups were found, distinguished by the initiation codons ATA and ATG. Most of the viruses isolated in the study were in the ATG group, less in the ATA branch.
authors: Wang, K. C.;Zhuang, Q. Y.;Qiu, Y.;Wang, T.;Chen, J. M.

title: New strain of swine epidemic diarrhea virus, United States, 2014
authors: Wang, L.;Byrum, B.;Zhang, Y.

title: Classification of duck hepatitis virus into three genotypes based on molecular evolutionary analysis
abstract: The nucleotide sequences of the complete VP1, VP0, VP3 and partial 3D regions of seven duck hepatitis virus (DHV) serotype 1 (DHV-1) strains isolated in China between 2001 and 2007 and of a DHV-1 strain originally obtained from ATCC The nucleotide sequences are determined and compared to the DHV sequences pre-existing in GenBank. Phylogenetic analysis based on VP1 sequences showed three distinct genetic groups. There was excellent agreement between genetic groups assigned based on full VP0, VP3, and partial 3D regions. Given the increasing importance of molecular techniques in diagnosis, we propose that the three genetic groups should be named DHV types A, B, and C. While all DHV-1 strains were grouped into genotype A, novel serotype strains isolated in Taiwan and South Korea clustered in genotypes B and C, respectively, suggesting a potential genetic correlate of serotype. In pairwise comparisons of the complete VP1, VP0 and VP3 nucleotide and amino acid sequences and the partial 3D nucleotide sequence, DHVs of the same genotype were clearly distinguished from those of heterologous genotypes. Analysis of the amino acid sequences of the three capsid proteins revealed the presence of intervening domains that vary in sequence among strains of different genotypes, as well as conserved elements forming eight-stranded Î²-barrel structures, as seen in other picorna viruses. © 2008 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Wang, L.;Pan, M.;Fu, Y.;Zhang, D.

title: Characterization of miRNAs involved in the response to poly(I:C) in porcine airway epithelial cells
abstract: MicroRNAs (miRNA) have been associated with a variety of pathological conditions, including infectious diseases. Knowledge of miRNAs affected by poly(I:C), a synthetic analogue of viral double-stranded RNA in porcine respiratory epithelial cells (PAECs), contributes to understanding the mechanisms of porcine viral respiratory diseases that cause huge economic losses worldwide each year. contributes. . In this study, we used high-throughput sequencing to profile miRNA expression in poly(I:C)-treated PAECs compared to untreated control. This approach revealed 23 differentially expressed miRNAs (DEMs), five of which had not been previously implicated in viral infection. Nineteen of the 23 miRNAs, including members of the miR-17-92 cluster, a well-known polycistronic oncomir, were downregulated and extensively implicated in viral infection in humans. The target genes of DEMs, which were predicted using bioinformatics methods and validated by luciferase reporter analysis on two representative DEMs, were significantly enriched by various means, including transforming growth factor-Î² signaling. A large amount of sequence variation (isomiRs) was found, including a substitution at position 5, which was confirmed by luciferase reporter assay combined with bioinformatics analysis to direct miRNAs to a novel target spectrum. Twelve novel porcine miRNAs conserved in other species were identified by homology analysis with cloning validation. Furthermore, expression analysis revealed the potential importance of three novel miRNAs in the pig immune response against viruses. Overall, our data contribute to elucidating the mechanisms underlying the host immune response to respiratory viruses in pigs and enrich the repertoire of porcine miRNAs.
authors: Wang, L.;Wang, J. K.;Han, L. X.;Zhuo, J. S.;Du, X.;Liu, D.;Yang, X. Q.

title: Isolation and genetic variability analysis of the “Pig-Human-Bird” type reassortant H1N2 swine Influenza strain
authors: Wang, L. B.;Chen, Q. Y.;Wu, X. M.;Che, Y. L.

title: A new strain of enterovirus identified from severe diarrhea goats
abstract: Backgrounds The Enterovirus genus of the Picornaviridae family consists of 9 Enterovirus species and 3 Rhinovirus species based on the latest virus taxonomy. These viruses contribute significantly to respiratory and digestive disorders in humans and animals. Of the 9 Enterovirus species, Enterovirus EG is closely associated with diseases affecting the livestock industry. Enterovirus infections in cattle and pigs are increasingly reported, while enterovirus infections in small ruminants are largely unknown. Methods Virology, molecular and bioinformatics methods were used to characterize a novel enterovirus CEV-JL14 from goats in China that showed severe diarrhea with up to 84% morbidity and 54% mortality, respectively. Results CEV-JL14 was identified and proposed as a new Enterovirus strain L within the Enterovirus genus of the Picornaviridae family. CEV-JL14 had a complete genome sequence of 7461 nucleotides with an ORF encoding 2172 amino acids and shared 77.1% of genomic sequence identity with TB4-OEV, a sheep enterovirus. Comparison of the structural genes of 5'-UTR and CEV-JL14 with known Enterovirus strains revealed high levels of genetic variation between known Enterovirus strains and CEV-JL14. The VP1 nucleotide sequence identities of CEV-14 were 51.8%-53.5% with Enterovirus E and F, 30.9-65.3 and 43.8-51% with Enterovirus G. 5% with Enterovirus AD, respectively. CEV-JL14 has been proposed as a new strain within the Enterovirus genus according to the current ICTV breakpoints of enteroviruses. Results CEV-JL14 phylogenetically clustered neither Enterovirus E and F nor Enterovirus G. It was identified and proposed as a new L species within the Enterovirus genus. This is the first report of goat enterovirus in China, revealing the first complete genomic sequence of a goat enterovirus and revealing significant genetic variations between sheep enterovirus and goat enterovirus, thus expanding the current understanding of enteroviruses.
authors: Wang, M.;He, J.;Lu, H.;Liu, Y.;Deng, Y.;Zhu, L.;Guo, C.;Tu, C.;Wang, X.

title: Metagenomic insights into the contribution of phages to antibiotic resistance in water samples from swine feed wastewater treatment.
abstract: In this study, using a metagenomic approach, we examined the types of antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs) possessed by bacteria and bacteriophages in swine effluent before and after purification. We found that the relative abundance of ARGs in bacterial DNA in all water samples was significantly higher (>10.6-fold) than in phage DNA, and wastewater treatment did not significantly alter the relative abundance of bacteria or phage-associated ARGs. We also determined the distribution and diversity of different ARG strains according to the antibiotic class to which they confer resistance, tetracycline resistance genes were the most abundant resistance genes, and phages were more likely to harbor the ATP-binding cassette transporter family and ribosomal. protection genes In addition, the colistin resistance gene mcr-1 was also detected in the phage population. When evaluating the contribution of phages in the propagation of different groups of ARGs, the Î²-lactamase resistance genes had relatively high diffusion ability, although the abundance was low. These findings likely indicated that phages not only serve as important ARG reservoirs, but also carry certain ARGs in pig feed effluents, suggesting that this phenomenon is independent of the environment.
authors: Wang, M.;Xiong, W.;Liu, P.;Xie, X.;Zeng, J.;Sun, Y.;Zeng, Z.

title: Complete sequence and evolutionary genomic analysis of the Pseudomonas aeruginosa transposable bacteriophage D3112
abstract: Bacteriophage D3112 represents one of two distinct groups of transposable phages found in the clinically relevant, opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa. To advance our understanding of the transposable phage in P. aeruginosa, we sequenced the complete genome of D3112. The genome is 37,611 bp and the total G+C content is 65%. We identified 53 potential open reading frames, including three previously characterized and sequenced genes (c repressor gene and early A and B genes). The organization of putative coding regions corresponds to published genetic and transcriptional maps and is very similar to that of enterobacteriophage Mu. In contrast, the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy has classified D3112 as a lambda-like phage on the basis of its morphology. Similarity-based analyzes identified 27 open reading frames with significant matches to proteins in the NCBI databases. Forty-eight percent of these were similar to Mu-like phage and prophage sequences, including proteins responsible for transposition, transcriptional regulation, virion morphogenesis, and capsid formation. Tail proteins were highly similar to prophage sequences in Escherichia coli and phage Phi12 from Staphylococcus aureus, while proteins at the right end were highly similar to proteins from Xylella fastidiosa. We performed phylogenetic analyzes to understand the evolutionary relationships of D3112 relative to Mu-like versus lambda-like bacteriophages. In some cases, different results were obtained from similarity-based phylogenetic analyzes. Overall, our findings reveal a highly mosaic pattern and suggest that extensive horizontal exchange of genetic material played an important role in the evolution of D3112.
authors: Wang, P. W.;Chu, L.;Guttman, D. S.

title: Nucleotide sequence analysis of the E2 major protective antigen coding region of 12 strains of swine cholera virus (HCV)
abstract: The cDNA fragments of the HCV envelope glycoprotein E2 major gene from 11 field strains and 1 French reference strain (Thiveral) isolated at different times in China were amplified and sequenced by RT-PCR, respectively. Amplified fragments located 5' 2485 to 2708 of the E2 major domains B and C and encoded the 75 amino acid residues of the E2 glycoprotein. Of the 12 strains in the study, all products of amplifield were 224 bp of the same size by RT-PCR. Comparing the 12 sequences with the other 9 reference strain sequences reported before using the DNAstar software, it was found that Swine Cholera Virus could be classified into two groups by phylogenetic tree analysis. Brescia, Gpe, Ald, Thiverval, C, CW, HCLV, HCVSM, BJCY1/96, BJTX3/96, BJSY2/96, HeNXH2/98, HeNZZ1/82 and GDGZ1/95 strains were assigned to group A and were 85.7%. 100% for nucleotide sequence and 83.8-100% for amino acid sequence in homology; however, strains HCVF98, HCVF94, HeBHH2/95, LN1/84, SZGM1/85, SCCD1/79 and Alfort were assigned to group B and were 84.3-100% for nucleotide sequence and 85.1-100% for amino acid sequence in homology; and 21 HCV strains were 78.1-100% for nucleotide sequence in homology and 78.4-100% for amino acid sequence. In our study, 99.1% homology for nucleotide sequence and 100% homology for amino acid sequence was found between HCLV strains and C strains reported by Rijn's in the Netherlands. It showed that our sequencing method was reliable. There were obvious differences between the two groups in the sequences of the envelope glycoprotein E2 major gene, particularly in the amino acid substitutions of regions 713 and 729, respectively, and it has been shown that the two groups of HCV domain strains may be genetically altered to some extent. The results of the other report on the strain of partial field strains showed that the Chinese stock vaccine virus (HCLV) had good immunity.
authors: Wang, Q.;Wang, Z.;Zhao, Y.;Li, B.;Qiu, H.

title: Prevalence of noroviruses and sapoviruses in pigs of various ages as determined by reverse transcription-PCR and microwell hybridization experiments
abstract: Noroviruses (NoVs) and sapoviruses (SaVs) are emerging as enteric pathogens that cause diarrhea in humans and animals. Pig genogroup II (GII) NoVs reproduce in pigs, but their pathogenesis has not been defined. The swine strain SaV/GIII/Cowden/80/US causes diarrhea and intestinal lesions in swine. Recently, genetically diverse swine NoVs (genotypes 11, 18 and 19 within GII) and SaVs containing at least two genogroups (similar to GIII and GVIa/JJ681) and two unclassified strains (Ga/QW19 and Ga/LL26) have been reported. , defined; however, their prevalence has not been reported. To investigate the prevalence of swine NoVs and SaVs, 621 fecal samples were collected from pigs of various ages from seven pig farms and one slaughterhouse in three states in the United States. Fecal samples were tested by reverse transcription-PCR and microwell hybridization assays with porcine NoV- and SaV-specific primers and probes, respectively. Pig GII NoVs were detected only from terminating pigs with an overall prevalence of 20%. Pig GIII SaVs were detected in 62% of pigs, with the highest prevalence in postweaning pigs and the lowest prevalence in pigs. Pig GVI?/JJ681-like SaVs and G?/QW19-like SaVs were rarely detected in pigs. G?/LL26-like SaVs were detected mainly in young pigs. Because some porcine NoVs and SaVs are genetically or antigenically related to human strains, and recombinants within NoVs or SaVs occur for human and porcine strains, the high prevalence and subclinical infection rate of these viruses in pigs is comparable to that of pigs for human strains. This raises the question of whether there is a reservoir or not. or for the emergence of new human and porcine recombinants. Copyright © 2006, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Wang, Q. H.;Souza, M.;Funk, J. A.;Zhang, W.;Saif, L. J.

title: Classification of US swine epidemic diarrhea virus strains revealed by phylogenetic analysis of nucleocapsid and ORF3 genes.
authors: Wang, S.;Cheng, X.;Chen, S.;Lin, F.;Jiang, B.;Zhu, X.;Li, Z.;Wang, J.;Chen, S.

title: Calculation of evolutionary correlation between individual genes and the full-length genome: A useful method for selecting phylogenetic markers for molecular epidemiology.
abstract: Individual genes or regions are still widely used to predict phylogenetic relationships among viral isolates. Genomic regions that can provide assessments consistent with those predicted by full-length genome sequences are preferred to serve as good candidates of phylogenetic markers for molecular epidemiological studies of many viruses. Here, we used a statistical method to evaluate evolutionary relationships between individual viral genes and full-length genomes without tree structure as a way to determine which gene might well match the genome in phylogenetic analyses. This method was performed by calculating linear correlations between genetic distance matrices of aligned individual gene sequences and aligned genome sequences. We applied this method to phylogenetic analyzes of porcine circovirus 2 (PCV2), measles virus (MV), hepatitis E virus (HEV), and Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV). Phylogenetic trees were created for comparisons and possible factors affecting method accuracy were also discussed in the calculations. The results revealed that this method can produce results consistent with the results of previous studies on suitable consensus sequences that can be used successfully as phylogenetic markers. And our results also suggested that these evolutionary correlates could provide useful information for identifying genes that could be used effectively to reveal genetic relationships. Copyright: Â© 2013 Wang et al.
authors: Wang, S.;Luo, X.;Wei, W.;Zheng, Y.;Dou, Y.;Cai, X.

title: Analysis of codon usage preference in hemagglutinin genes of swine influenza A (H1N1) virus
abstract: Background Porcine influenza A (H1N1) virus (S-OIV) has come to the fore since 2009 and has been identified as a new reassortant strain. Hemagglutinin (HA) glycoprotein mediates virus binding, contains antigenic sites recognized by neutralizing antibodies, and is associated with viral cross-species infection and adaptation. The comparative study of codon usage preferences in influenza viral genomes was less extensive. In this study, we used codon usage pattern analyzes to confirm the adaptation and origins of S-OIV. Methods The codon usage model was used to predict host adaptation of S-OIVs. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA gene was performed to understand the phylogeny of H1N1 viruses isolated from different hosts. The amino acid signature pattern in the antigenic regions of HA was analyzed to understand the antigenic properties. Results The results of the phylogenetic analyzes of the HA gene show that the S-OIVs are grouped into identical clusters. Synonymous codon usage pattern analyzes show that the number of active codons versus GC content at the third codon position in the HA1 gene is slightly different from that in porcine H1N1 and is gradually adapted to human. Our data show that S-OIV evolution occurs according to positive selection within these antigenic regions. Comparison of antigenic region amino acids reveals similar signature patterns between S-OIV and 1918 human influenza strains. Conclusion This study proposes a new and effective way to better understand the evolutionary processes and features of the S-OIV genome based on the codon usage model. It is useful to monitor influenza viral origins and cross-species virus transmission.
authors: Wang, S. F.;Su, M. W.;Tseng, S. P.;Li, M. C.;Tsao, C. H.;Huang, S. W.;Chu, W. C.;Liu, W. T.;Chen, Y. M. A.;Huang, J. C.

title: Different Pathogenic Characteristics of Circulating Coxsackievirus A6 Associated with Emerging Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease
abstract: Coxsackievirus A6 (CV-A6) is an emerging pathogen associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). Its genetic characterization and pathogenic properties are largely unknown. Here we report 39 circulating strains of CV-A6 isolated in 2013 from HFMD patients in northeastern China. Three major CV-A6 clusters were identified and associated with CV-A6, mostly from Shanghai, suggesting that local strains of CV-A6 are responsible for HFMD emerging in northeastern China. Four full-length CV-A6 genomes representing each cluster were sequenced and further analyzed. Bootstrap screening tests showed that all four strains of CV-A6-Changchun were most likely recombinant between the CV-A6 prototype Gdula and the prototype CV-A4 or CV-A4 related viruses, while the recombination pattern was related to but different from the strains. It is isolated from other parts of China. Moreover, different strains of CV-A6 showed different abilities of viral replication, release and pathogenesis in a mouse model. Further analyzes showed that viral protein 2C contributes to the diverse pathogenic abilities of CV-A6 by inducing autophagy and inducing cell death. To our knowledge, this is the first study to report lethal and non-lethal strains of CV-A6 associated with HFMD. The 2C protein region may play a key role in the pathogenicity of CV-A6 strains.IMPORTANCE Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a major and persistent threat to infants and children. Besides the most common pathogens such as enterovirus A71 (EV-A71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16), other enteroviruses are increasingly contributing to HFMD. This study focused on the recently emerged strain CV-A6. We found that strains of CV-A6 isolated in Changchun City, northeast China, were associated with local origins. These Changchun viruses were novel recombinants of CV-A6 prototype Gdula and CV-A4. Our results imply that measures to control CV-A6 transmission are urgently needed. Further analysis revealed differential pathogenicity in strains isolated in a neonatal mouse model. One possible reason was that viral protein was reduced to 2C using phylogenetic studies, viral sequences, and direct testing on cultured human cells. Therefore, viral 2C protein is a promising target for antiviral drugs to prevent tissue damage caused by CV-A6.
authors: Wang, S. H.;Wang, A.;Liu, P. P.;Zhang, W. Y.;Du, J.;Xu, S.;Liu, G. C.;Zheng, B. S.;Huan, C.;Zhao, K.;Yu, X. F.

title: Discovery of a highly different coronavirus in an Asian house mouse from China illuminates the origin of alphacoronaviruses
abstract: Although shrews are one of the largest mammalian groups, little is known about their role in the evolution and transmission of viral pathogens, including coronaviruses. Between 2013 and 2015, we caught 266 Asian house mice (Suncus murinus) in Jiangxi and Zhejiang provinces, China. Coronavirus (CoV) RNA was detected in 24 Asian house mice with an overall prevalence of 9.02%. Complete viral genome sequences were successfully obtained from RNA positive samples. The newly discovered shrew CoV fell into one of four lineages, largely reflecting its geographic origins indicative of allopatric evolution. Notably, these viruses were most closely related to alphacoronaviruses, but they were different enough to be considered a new member of the genus Alphacoronavirus, which we refer to as Wencheng rat virus (WESV). Phylogenetic analysis revealed that WESV is a highly distinct member of the alphacoronaviruses, and more dramatically, the S gene of WESV fell into a genetically distinct cluster from that of known coronaviruses. The diverse location of WESV suggests that coronaviruses have a long association with Asian house mice. In addition, the genome of WESV contains a distinct NS7 gene that exhibits no sequence similarity to any known virus. Together, these data suggest that shrews are natural reservoirs for coronaviruses and may have played an important and long-term role in CoV evolution. contains the pathogen. syndrome coronavirus, Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus, and swine epidemic diarrhea virus. Because of their genetic diversity and phylogenetic relationships, it has been suggested that the ultimate ancestors of alphacoronaviruses are likely bat-dwelling viruses. Here we describe a novel alphacoronavirus (Wencheng shrew virus, WESV) sampled from Asian house shrews in China. In particular, WESV is a highly distinct member of the alphacoronaviruses and has a genetically distinct S gene from all known coronaviruses. In addition, the genome of WESV contains a distinct NS7 gene that exhibits no sequence similarity to any known virus. Together, these data suggest that shrews are important and long-standing hosts for coronaviruses that deserve additional research and surveillance.
authors: Wang, W.;Lin, X. D.;Liao, Y.;Guan, X. Q.;Guo, W. P.;Xing, J. G.;Holmes, E. C.;Zhang, Y. Z.

title: Evidence of Clade 7.1 Avian Flu Virus (H5N1) in Qinghai Lake
abstract: The highly pathogenic influenza A virus subtype H5N1 has spread to Asia since 2003, reached Europe, the Middle East and Africa in 2005, raising global concern for a potential pandemic threat over the past decade. A Clade 2.3.2 H5N1 virus became dominant in the Qinghai Lake area with sporadic cases of mammalian infection in 2009 and was transmitted to Russia and Europe via wild migratory birds. Currently, HPAI H5N1 2.3.4, 2.3.2 and 7 are the dominant H5N1 viruses circulating in Asian poultry. 2.3.2 While the Clade is dominant in wild birds all over the world, there is no clear data about Clade 7 circulation in wild birds. We detected Clade 7.1 HPAI H5N1 virus in Qinghai Lake, which is closely related to Shanxi-like and Vietnam viruses circulating in poultry. This is the first report of Clade 7.1 H5N1 in wild birds. According to phylogenetic analysis, the virus may originate from the Clade 7.1 virus gene pool, which is spread in Vietnamese and Chinese poultry and can spread to Qinghai Lake by migratory birds. Qinghai Lake remains a major hotspot for H5N1 surveillance, as regular outbreaks of wild birds and mammals occur there. Based on these facts and findings, relevant researchers should pay more attention to the Qinghai Lake basin as an important hotspot for H5N1 avian influenza surveillance, as regular H5N1 outbreaks occur in wild birds with sporadic cases of mammalian infection.
authors: Wang, W.;Sharshov, K.;Li, Z.;Zheng, S. S.;Sun, H.;Yang, F.;Wang, X. L.;Li, L. X.

title: Genetic characterization of a novel duck-derived picornavirus with six 2A proteins
abstract: new virus has been detected from diseased ducks and has been fully identified. The virus was shown to have a picornavirus-like genome arrangement. Interestingly, the genome contained up to a total of six 2As, including four 2A (2A1-2A4) each with an NPGP motif, an AIG1-like 2A5, and a parecovirus-like 2A6. The 5-UTR has been predicted to have a hepacivirus/pestivirus-like internal ribosome entry site (IRES). However, the IIIe subdomain consisted of a 3 nt root and five unpaired bases, unlike those found in all other HP-like IRESs. The virus was most closely associated with duck hepatitis A virus, and amino acid identities were 37.7%, 39% and 43.7% in the P1, P2 and P3 regions, respectively. Based on these studies, together with phylogenetic analyses, the virus can be considered as a founding member of a new genus of picornavirus, which we refer to as 'Aalivirus A' as the type species and provisionally 'Aalivirus'.
authors: Wang, X.;Liu, N.;Wang, F.;Ning, K.;Li, Y.;Zhang, D.

title: Genomic characterization and pathogenicity of a strain of type 1 porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus.
abstract: The emergence of type 1 porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) has recently been noticed in China. In this study, the whole genomic characterization of a strain of type 1 PRRSV (designated GZ11-G1) was described and its pathogenicity for piglets was analyzed. The results show that the 15,094 nt whole genome of GZ11-G1, excluding the poly(A) tails, shares 80.2%-96.3% identity with representative strains of type 1 PRRSV, particularly the highest Type 1 PRRSV live vaccine viruses Amervac PRRS and Amervac PRRS. Homology (96.3%) to SHE, a virus recovered from an infectious clone of the virus. Compared to the vaccinia virus, the non-structural and structural proteins of GZ11-G1 exhibited extensive amino acid variations except for ORF5a. GZ11-G1, Cresa3267, Cresa3249, Cresa3256, Olot/91, 9625/2012, ESP-1991-Olot91 and type 1 PRRSV strains including Amervac PRRS vaccine virus were clustered by further phylogenetic analysis. Furthermore, GZ11-G1 has been shown to cause fever, high viremia, and lung and lymph node lesions in piglets. Our findings indicate that GZ11-G1 is genetically related and pathogenic with type 1 PRRSV strains in the cluster of Cresa3267, Cresa3249, Cresa3256, Olot/91, 9625/2012, ESP-1991-Olot91 and Amervac PRRS vaccine virus. for piglets. This study helps to understand the genetic variation and evolution of type 1 PRRSV.
authors: Wang, X.;Yang, X.;Zhou, R.;Zhou, L.;Ge, X.;Guo, X.;Yang, H.

title: RNA-Seq analysis of duck embryo fibroblast cell gene expression in the early stage of egg laying syndrome virus infection
abstract: Egg laying syndrome virus (EDSV), a member of the Adenoviridae family and an economically important pathogen with a wide host range, causes marked reduction in egg production. However, the molecular mechanism underlying the host-EDSV interaction remains unclear. Here, we performed high-throughput RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) to examine dynamic changes in host gene expression in EDSV-infected duck embryo fibroblasts (DEFs) at 6, 12 and 24 h post infection. A total of 441 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were identified after EDSV infection. The Gene Ontology category and the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes pathway enrichment analysis revealed that these DEGs are associated with multiple biological functions, including signal transduction, host immunity, virus infection, cell apoptosis, cell proliferation and pathogenicity, and metabolic process signaling pathways. . We scanned and identified 12 grades for further examination using qRT-PCR. qRT-PCR and RNA-Seq results were quite consistent. This study analyzed viral infection and host immunity caused by EDSV infection from a new perspective, and the results provide valuable insights into the mechanisms underlying host-EDSV interactions that will be useful for the future development of antiviral drugs or vaccines for poultry, and are therefore of benefit. . the entire poultry industry.
authors: Wang, X. P.;Qi, X. F.;Yang, B.;Chen, S. Y.;Wang, J. Y.

title: Integrated analysis of microRNA expression and mRNA transcriptome in lungs of avian influenza virus-infected chickens
abstract: BACKGROUND: Avian influenza virus (AIV) outbreaks pose a threat to both poultry and humans worldwide. Our previous work suggested that microRNAs (miRNAs) play important roles in regulating the host response to AIV infection in laying hens. The aim of this study was to test the hypothesis whether genetic background plays an important role in miRNA regulation of AIV infection in chickens and whether miRNAs differentially expressed in the layer by AIV infection can be likewise modulated in broilers. Furthermore, by integrating with parallel mRNA expression profiling, potential molecular mechanisms of the host response to AIV infection can be further exploited. RESULTS: Total RNA isolated from the lungs of uninfected and low pathogenic H5N3-infected chickens four days after infection was used for both miRNA deep sequencing and mRNA microarray analyses. A total of 2.6 M and 3.3 M filtered high-quality reads were obtained from Solexa GA-I Sequencer infected and uninfected chickens, respectively. A total of 271 miRNAs were identified in miRBase 16.0 and one potential new miRNA was discovered. There were 121 miRNAs differentially expressed at a 5% false discovery rate by Fisher's exact test. More miRNAs were overexpressed in infected lungs (108) than in uninfected lungs (13), which was in contrast to the findings in laying hens. This result suggested that there may be a different regulatory mechanism of the host response to miRNA-mediated AIV infection in broilers. Analysis using the chicken 44K Agilent microarray showed that 508 mRNAs (347 down-regulated) were differentially expressed following AIV infection. RESULTS: A comprehensive analysis combining both miRNA and targeted mRNA gene expression, gga-miR-34a, 122-1, 122-2, 146a, 155, 206, 1719, 1594, 1599 and 451 and MX1, IL-8, IRF -7, TNFRS19 are potent candidate miRNAs or genes involved in the regulation of the host response to AIV infection in the lungs of broiler chickens. Further miRNA or gene-specific knockout assays are warranted to elucidate the mechanism underlying AIV infection regulation in chicken.
authors: Wang, Y.;Brahmakshatriya, V.;Lupiani, B.;Reddy, S. M.;Soibam, B.;Benham, A. L.;Gunaratne, P.;Liu, H. C.;Trakooljul, N.;Ing, N.;Okimoto, R.;Zhou, H.

title: Adelaide River virus nucleoprotein gene: analysis of phylogenetic relationships of ephemeroviruses and other rhabdoviruses.
abstract: The nucleotide sequence of the Adelaide River virus (ARV) genome was determined from the 3' end to the end of the nucleoprotein (N) gene. The 3' leader sequence contains 50 nucleotides and shares a terminal trinucleotide (3' UGC-), a conserved U-rich domain, and an AU-rich variable domain in common with other animal rhabdoviruses. The N gene contains 1355 nucleotides from the transcription start sequence (AACAGG) to the poly(A) sequence [CATG(A)7] and encodes a 429 amino acid polypeptide. The N protein has a calculated molecular mass of 49429 Da and a pl of 5.4 and, like bovine ephemeral fever virus (BEFV) N protein, has a highly acidic C-terminal domain. Analysis of amino acid sequence relationships among all available rhabdovirus N proteins showed that ARV and BEFV are closely related viruses (48.3% similarity) that share higher sequence similarity to vesiculoviruses than to lyssaviruses. Phylogenetic trees based on multiple sequence alignments of all available rhabdovirus N protein sequences showed clustering of viruses according to genome organization, host range, and established taxonomic relationships.
authors: Wang, Y.;Cowley, J. A.;Walker, P. J.

title: Fecal viroma of red-crowned cranes
authors: Wang, Y.;Yang, S.;Liu, D.;Zhou, C.;Li, W.;Lin, Y.;Wang, X.

title: Comprehensive analysis of amino acid sequence diversity in the F protein cleavage site of Newcastle disease virus in fusogenic activity.
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is an infectious agent of Newcastle disease in avian species and severely affects the poultry industry. The cleavage site of the viral F protein (Fcs) is a key determinant of membrane fusion and viral virulence. In this study, we investigated the precise effect of variable amino acid sequences of Fcs on fusogenic activity. Based on viral pathogenicity, Fcs sequences of native isolates (n = 1572) are classified as eight types of virulent Fcs (VFcs) with the motif “G/R/KRQ/R/KR/K-Râ†“F” and “G/R/ Ten types of avirulent Fcs (AFcs) with ER/K/QQG/E-Râ†“L” motifs. VFcs are found only in the Class II viral classification cluster and not in Class I. AFcs are found in both Class I and II isolates. VFc and AFc species present temporal distribution and an evolutionary relationship with host species. Using an in vitro fusion test, VFcs-1 “RRQKR”F” and VFcs-2 “RRQRR”F” show the highest efficiency in inducing membrane fusion. The neutral Q residue at the P3 position of VFcs plays a reinforcing role compared to the effect of the R and K basic residues. A single K residue at P3 or P5, along with all basic residues, is less effective in fusogenic activity in VFcs. Moreover, the cleavage activities of F0 proteins with different Fcs motif types do not appear to affect membrane fusion. Our findings provide insight into the effect of amino acid variation of Fcs on NDV-induced fusion.
authors: Wang, Y.;Yu, W.;Huo, N.;Wang, W.;Guo, Y.;Wei, Q.;Wang, X.;Zhang, S.;Yang, Z.;Xiao, S.

title: Full-length and defective enterovirus G genomes with distinct torovirus protease insertions are quite common in a Chinese pig farm.
abstract: Recombination often occurs between enteroviruses (EVs) classified within the same species of the Picornaviridae family. Here we describe the genomes of two recombinant EV-Gs (strains EVG 01/NC_CHI/2014 and EVG 02/NC_CHI/2014) found in feces of pigs from a pig farm in China using viral metagenomics. The two strains are characterized by the prominent insertion of a papain-like protease gene from toroviruses classified within the Coronaviridae family. According to recent reports, the torovirus protease insertion site was located in the 2C/3A binding site in EVG 02/NC_CHI/2014. For the other EVG 01/NC_CHI/2014 variant, the inserted protease sequence replaced the entire viral capsid protein region up to the VP1/2A junction. These two EV-G strains were quite common in all animals in the same pig farm, while shedding the full-length genome (EVG 02/NC_CHI/2014) and 65% also shed the capsid deletion mutant (EVG 01/NC_CHI/2014). A co-defective virus association is assumed between two circulating EV-G recombinants.
authors: Wang, Y.;Zhang, W.;Liu, Z.;Fu, X.;Yuan, J.;Zhao, J.;Lin, Y.;Shen, Q.;Wang, X.;Deng, X.;Delwart, E.;Shan, T.;Yang, S.

title: hepatitis E virus
abstract: Since the sequence of hepatitis E virus (HEV) was determined in 1989 from a patient with enterically transmitted non-A, non-B hepatitis, similar sequences have been isolated from many different animals, including pigs, wild boars, deer, rabbits, bats. , rats, chicken and trout. All of these sequences have the same genomic organization, including open reading frames (ORFs) 1, 2, and 3, although their genomic sequences are variable. Some have suggested that they be classified as the new Hepeviridae family, which would be divided into different genera and species based on their sequence variability. The size of these virus particles was generally between 27 and 34 nm. However, HEV virions produced in cell culture are different in structure from viruses found in feces. Those from cell culture have a lipid envelope and some ORF3 on their surface, while viruses isolated from feces lack the lipid envelope and ORF3. Surprisingly, most of the ORF2 protein secreted from these two sources is not associated with HEV RNA.
authors: Wang, Y.;Zhao, C.;Qi, Y.;Geng, Y.

title: Genotyping of Newcastle disease viruses isolated from 2002 to 2004 in China
abstract: The major function region of the fusion (F) protein gene of 124 Newcastle disease viruses isolated in China from 2002 to 2004 was amplified and sequenced for further phylogenetic and residue substitution analysis. Most isolates were classified as genotypes VIIc, VIId, VIf, and VIb, while others were classified as genotypes IX, III, or II. Genotype IX, a unique genotype containing strain F48, the first Chinese virulent NDV strain isolated in 1948, has still been found to induce sporadic infections in certain areas. Unlike members of subgenotypes Vila and VIIb, subgenotypes VIIc, VIId and VIIe viruses, which are distributed in clusters in the phylogenetic tree, were responsible for most outbreaks in China and have circulated predominantly in China in recent years. NDV03-026, an isolate of the normally lentogenic genotype II, was found to carry the 112RRQKRF117 motif in the cleavage site of the F protein as the virulent strain. Â© 2006 New York Academy of Sciences.
authors: Wang, Z.;Liu, H.;Xu, J.;Bao, J.;Zheng, D.;Sun, C.;Wei, R.;Song, C.;Chen, J.

title: H13 influenza viruses in wild birds have undergone genetic and antigenic variation in nature.
abstract: Among the 16 hemagglutinin (HA) subtypes of avian influenza viruses (AIVs), H13 AIVs have rarely been isolated in wild waterfowl. H13 AIVs cause asymptomatic infection and are mainly retained in gull and tern populations; however, recorded antigenic information on viruses is limited. In this study, 2 H13 AIVs, A/duck/Hokkaido/W345/2012 (H13N2) and A/duck/Hokkaido/WZ68/2012 (H13N2) genetics and a prototype strain, A/gull/Maryland, were isolated from the same region in the same year in our surveillance. Antigenically analyzed with 10 representative H13 strains, including /704/1977 (H13N6). HA genes of H13 AIVs were phylogenetically divided into 3 groups (I, II and III). A/duck/Hokkaido/W345/2012 (H13N2) has been genetically classified in Group III. This virus differed from a prototype strain A/gull/Maryland/704/1977 (H13N6) and A/duck/Hokkaido/WZ68/2012 (H13N2), both belonging to Group I. Group I viruses were antigenically closely related to those in Group II, but different from viruses of Group III, including A/duck/Hokkaido/W345/2012 (H13N2). In summary, our study demonstrates that H13 AIVs are subject to antigenic variation in nature.
authors: Wang, Z. J.;Kikutani, Y.;Nguyen, L. T.;Hiono, T.;Matsuno, K.;Okamatsu, M.;Krauss, S.;Webby, R.;Lee, Y. J.;Kida, H.;Sakoda, Y.

title: Molecular characterization of the first strain of G24P 14 rotavirus detected in humans
abstract: Here, we report the genome of a novel rotavirus A (RVA) strain detected in a stool sample collected during routine surveillance by the New Vaccine Surveillance Network of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The strain RVA/human-wt/USA/2012741499/2012/G24P[14] has the genomic constellation G24-P[14]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A3-N2-T9-E2-H3. The VP2, VP3, VP7 and NSP3 genes cluster phylogenetically with bovine strains. Other genes occupy mixed branches that include animal and human strains. Strain RVA/human-wt/USA/2012741499/2012/G24P[14] is most likely the product of interspecies transmission and reclassification events. This is the second report of the G24 genotype and the first report of the G24P[14] genotype combination in humans.
authors: Ward, M. L.;Mijatovic-Rustempasic, S.;Roy, S.;Rungsrisuriyachai, K.;Boom, J. A.;Sahni, L. C.;Baker, C. J.;Rench, M. A.;Wikswo, M. E.;Payne, D. C.;Parashar, U. D.;Bowen, M. D.

title: Antigenic analysis of co-circulating highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 sublineages in Egypt.
abstract: The highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 has spread to Eurasia and Africa, and outbreaks are now endemic in many countries, including Indonesia, Vietnam and Egypt. The continued circulation of H5N1 virus in Egypt from a single infected source led to significant genetic variation with phylogenetically separable sublineages, providing an opportunity to examine the impact of genetic evolution on viral phenotypic variation. In this study, we analyzed the phylogeny of H5 hemagglutinin (HA) genes in influenza viruses isolated from 2006 to 2011 in Egypt and investigated the effect of conserved amino acid mutations in HA genes in each sublineage on their antigenicity. The analysis showed that viruses still persist in at least four sub-lineages in poultry in Egypt as of 2011. Using reverse genetics to generate HA reclassification viruses with specific HA mutations, we found antigenic drift in HA in two influenza virus sublineages. Other influenza virus sublines currently circulating together in Egypt. Also, two sublineages with significant antigenic shift were antigenically distinguishable. Our findings indicated that phylogenetically distinct H5N1 viruses that were not antigenically cross-reactive circulated together in Egypt and there was a problem in using a single strain of influenza virus as the seed virus to produce influenza virus vaccine in Egypt and providing data. To design more effective control strategies in areas where H5N1 is endemic. © 2012 SGM.
authors: Watanabe, Y.;Ibrahim, M. S.;Ellakany, H. F.;Kawashita, N.;Daidoji, T.;Takagi, T.;Yasunaga, T.;Nakaya, T.;Ikuta, K.

title: Multiple genotypes of non-pathogenic H6N2 influenza viruses isolated from chickens in California.
abstract: From February 2000 to September 2001, a limited number of H6N2 influenza viruses were isolated from chickens in California. This report describes the genetic characterization of nine of these H6N2 viruses. All analyzed viruses had phylogenetically similar hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase molecules, suggesting that the viruses had a recent common ancestor. Analysis of the HA sequence of these viruses with all available H6 viruses from different hosts and locations showed that these genes were not separated into well-defined North American and Eurasian lineages. The neuraminidase genes of California viruses contain a deletion of 18 amino acids, a possible adaptation to growth in chickens. Analysis of the remaining gene segments of California viruses revealed that three different genotypes of H6N2 viruses exist.
authors: Webby, R. J.;Woolcock, P. R.;Krauss, S. L.;Walker, D. B.;Chin, P. S.;Shortridge, K. F.;Webster, R. G.

title: Antigenic drift, antigenic shift and interferon antagonists: how do bunyaviruses counteract the immune system?
abstract: Members of the Bunyaviridae family are among the most common viruses in the world. They can be found on every continent living at almost any latitude and can infect a wide variety of arthropods, plants and mammals, including humans. There are more than 300 named viruses in the Bunyaviridae family (Virus Taxonomy: Seventh Report of the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (2000) 599) and several members cause significant diseases in humans or pets. Despite being recognized as an emerging threat, relatively little is known about its virulence mechanisms. Here we try to summarize the current state of knowledge on how Bunyaviridae viruses manage to infect against a strong immune system. Â© 2002 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Weber, F.;Elliott, R. M.

title: Characterization of canine serum virus from northeastern Brazil
abstract: Domestic dogs share their habitats with humans, a fact that makes them a potential source of zoonotic viruses. Also, knowledge of possible blood-borne pathogens is important due to the increased practice of blood transfusions in dogs. In this study, we evaluated the serum virome of 520 dogs using yield sequencing (HTS). Serum samples were pooled and sequenced using an Illumina MiSeq platform. Our unbiased method identified common canine pathogens canine protoparvovirus 1 (canine parvovirus 2), canine bocaparvovirus 1 (tiny canine virus) and canine circovirus, circular viruses closely related to viruses recently found in human samples, and little-researched agents as novel parvovirus and anelloviruses. . The canine viroma described in this study further advances knowledge of the viral population in pets. Available data include information on viral agents potentially transmitted through blood transfusion between dogs.
authors: Weber, M. N.;Cibulski, S. P.;OlegÃ¡rio, J. C.;da Silva, M. S.;Puhl, D. E.;MÃ³sena, A. C. S.;Alves, C. D. B. T.;Paim, W. P.;Baumbach, L. F.;Mayer, F. Q.;Fernandes, A. R. F.;Azevedo, S. S.;Canal, C. W.

title: Evaluation of serum virome in calves persistently infected with pestivirus A, with or without mucosal disease.
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus 1, reclassified as Pestivirus A, causes an economically important cattle disease that is prevalent worldwide. Pestivirus A can cause persistent infection as calves secrete the virus throughout their lives and spread the infection to the herd. Most persistently infected (PI) calves die within the first 2 years of life from mucosal disease (MD) or secondary infections, possibly as a result of virus-induced immune depression. Here, (i) clinically significant MD (n = 8); (ii) PI calves without signs of MD (n = 8); and (iii) control, Pestivirus A-free calves (n = 8). All groups were collected at the same time and from the same flock. Serum samples from calves in each group were pooled, submitted to viral RNA/DNA enrichment and sequenced with HTS. Viral genomes of Pestivirus A, Ungulate erythroparvovirus 1, bosavirus (BosV) and hypothetical circular Rep-encoding single-stranded DNA (CRESS-DNA) viruses were identified. Specific real-time PCR experiments were developed to determine the frequency of occurrence of such viruses in each of the groups. The absolute number of different viral genomes detected in both groups of PI calves was higher than in the control group, as revealed by more reads, contigs and genomes representing a wider range of taxa. Genomes representing members of the Parvoviridae family, such as U. erythroparvovirus 1 and BosV, were most frequently detected in all three groups of calves. We found two previously unreported Hypothetical single-stranded DNA genomes co-clustered with CRESS-DNA viruses in PI calves affected by MD only. These findings suggest that the viral genomes most frequently detected in bovine serum are parvoviruses; Since clinically normal or MD-affected/unaffected PI calves are infected with U. erythroparvovirus 1 genome loads similar to those of PI calves, the frequency of detection does not statistically correlate with the status of calves with respect to Pestivirus A infection. Furthermore, PI calves affected by MD have been shown to promote viremia of CRESS-DNA viral genomes; however, the meaning of such a relationship has not yet been determined.
authors: Weber, M. N.;Cibulski, S. P.;Silveira, S.;Siqueira, F. M.;MÃ³sena, A. C. S.;da Silva, M. S.;OlegÃ¡rio, J. C.;Varela, A. P. M.;Teixeira, T. F.;Bianchi, M. V.;Driemeier, D.;Pavarini, S. P.;Mayer, F. Q.;Roehe, P. M.;Canal, C. W.

title: First Evidence of Bovine Viral Diarrhea Virus Infection in Wild Boars
abstract: Background: Wild boar farming is booming due to the interest in this exotic meat for human consumption. Such a development may pose an increased risk of disease transmission between pigs and pets. The wild boar population has increased in South America in recent years due to the absence of predators causing direct damage to crops and economic losses due to the risk of disease transmission. The genus Pestivirus within the family Flaviviridae consists of four species recognized by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV): classical swine fever virus (CSFV), borderline disease virus (BDV), bovine viral diarrhea virus type 1 (BVDV-1) and 2 (BVDV- 2nd). Other putative strains cited as atypical pestiviruses have been reported as 'HoBi'-like virus, giraffe pestivirus, Bungowannah pestivirus, Pronghorn antelope virus, atypical swine pestivirus (APPV), Norwegian rat pestivirus (NrPV) and Rhinolophus affinis bat pestivirus (RaPestV-1). . ). CSFV is commonly detected in wild boars, but despite positive serology, bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) has never been detected in this animal species. Thus, the present communication describes the first detection of BVDV in the lungs of captive pigs using RT-PCR and DNA sequencing. Materials, Methods, and Results: Forty lung samples were collected from wild boars reared after slaughter in a commercial slaughterhouse. The organs were individually crushed, centrifuged and the supernatant stored for further analysis. Total RNA was isolated using a phenol-based protocol and the RT-PCR protocol was performed, amplifying the 118 bp 5' untranslated region (5' UTR). One out of 40 samples gave a positive result. The positive sample had the 5' UTR and partial fragments of the N-terminal autoprotease (N-pro) sequenced and analyzed. The LV Java/ 2012 strain presented 99% identity in the 5' UTR and 98% in the N-pro region with a BVDV-2 previously reported in cattle from Southern Brazil. In both the 5' UTR and Npro phylogenetic analysis, strain LV Java/ 2015 clustered with strains BVDV-2 and is most closely related to subtype 2b identified in cattle in the Southern Brazilian grouping at the same terminal node. Discussion: Wild boars are commonly associated with pathogen transmission to domestic animals. This animal species is considered a reservoir of the pestivirus CSFV and key keys in CSFV control and eradication programs in Europe. Although the indirect presence of BVDV in wild boars has been reported by serology testing, direct detection of the viral agent has never been reported. The present study demonstrated the presence of BVDV-2 genomic segments obtained by RT-PCR followed by DNA sequencing in captive wild boars. Reported data suggest a possible importance of this animal species in the epidemiology of ruminant pestiviruses that may interfere with control and eradication programs of these important pathogens for cattle worldwide. The LV Java/ 2012 strain was closely related to BVDV-2b and presented the highest identity with a strain detected in cattle from Southern Brazil. These data suggest that wild boars and cattle may share this pathogen due to the similarity of the strains, and both have been reported in the same region. This may lead to the need for wild boars to be included in BVDV control programs, as pigs can roam between different regions and carry this pathogen to different cattle herds. This study reported the first molecular evidence of BVDV in wild boars in the literature. The data generated here suggest a possible importance of pigs in the epidemiology of ruminant pestiviruses.
authors: Weber, M. N.;Pino, E. H. M.;Souza, C. K.;Mosena, A. C. S.;Sato, J. P. H.;de Barcellos, Desn;Canal, C. W.

title: Evolution of influenza a virus in wild birds
abstract: The emergence of highly pathogenic (HP) H5 influenza A viruses in Asia and the increase of HP H7 viruses in Europe and America have drawn increased attention to influenza ecology in wild birds. Influenza virus surveillance studies in wild bird populations in the Americas, Europe, and Asia have confirmed that wild waterfowl are reservoirs of all known influenza A viruses. Phylogenetic analysis groups influenza viruses in wild waterfowl into two distinct superfamilies, one in the Americas and the other in Eurasia. The division of viruses into American and Eurasian branches means that transmission of HP H5 to the Americas by wild birds is probably a rare event. The rapid evolution of Eurasian H5NI viruses makes them a constant threat to poultry and humans worldwide.
authors: Webster, R. G.;Krauss, S.;Hulse-Post, D.;Sturm-Ramirez, K.

title: Pan genome of Lactobacillus reuteri strains originating from porcine gastrointestinal tract.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Lactobacillus reuteri is an intestinal symbiont of a wide variety of vertebrate species that diversifies into distinct phylogenetic branches that are largely host-specific. Previous work demonstrated host specificity in mice and set out to identify mechanisms by which intestinal colonization and host restriction are achieved. However, it is unknown how L. reuteri strains colonize the gastrointestinal (GI) tract of pigs. RESULTS: To gain insight into the ecology of L. reuteri in the pig gut, the genome sequence of the porcine small intestine isolate L. reuteri ATCC 53608 was completed and consisted of a chromosome of 1.94 Mbp and two plasmids of 138.5 kbp and 9.09 kbp. , respectively. We also generated draft genomes of four additional strains of L. reuteri isolated from porcine feces or lower GI tract, lp167-67, pg-3b, 20-2 and 3c6, and subjected all five genomes to a comparative genomic analysis with previous ones. Complete genome of strain I5007. A phylogenetic analysis based on whole genomes showed that the porcine L. reuteri strains were separated into two distinct clades, as previously suggested by multilocus sequence analysis. These six porcine L. reuteri genomes contained a core set of 1364 orthologous gene clusters, contributing to a total of 3373 gene clusters, as determined by OrthoMCL analysis. Genome comparisons of six porcine L. reuteri strains and 14 L. reuteri strains from other host origins yielded a total pan-genome of 5225 gene clusters, containing a core genome of 851 gene clusters, but not each pig-specific gene. se. However, genes specific to and conserved between strains of the two porcine phylogenetic lineages were detected; some of these encoded cell surface proteins that may contribute to the diversification of the two lineages and their observed host specificity. CONCLUSIONS: This study extends the phylogenetic analysis of L. reuteri strains genome-wide, pointing to different evolutionary trajectories of porcine L. reuteri lineages, and providing new insights into the genomic events that occurred during their specialization in L. reuteri. homeowner. The emergence of two distinct pig-derived branches may reflect differences in host genotype, environmental factors such as dietary components, or evolution from human and rodent ancestral lineages following contact with pig populations.
authors: Wegmann, U.;MacKenzie, D. A.;Zheng, J.;Goesmann, A.;Roos, S.;Swarbreck, D.;Walter, J.;Crossman, L. C.;Juge, N.

title: Genetic dynamic analysis of the influenza A H5N1 NS1 gene in China
abstract: Direct precursors and reassortants of the A/Goose/Guangdong/1/1996 (GS/GD) virus strain were identified geographically and ecologically. To investigate the variation and evolutionary dynamics of H5N1 viruses, whole genome viral sequences (n = 164) were obtained from the NCBI Influenza Virus Resource. Here, we present phylogenetic evidence for subtype reclassifications among H5N1 viruses isolated from China between 1996 and 2012. On the basis of phylogenetic analysis, we identified four main groups and further divided reassortant viruses into three subgroups. Putative mosaic structures were most commonly found in viral ribonucleoprotein (vRNP) complexes, and 91.0% (10/11) mosaics were obtained from terrestrial birds. Sequence variability and selection pressure analyzes revealed that both surface glycoproteins (HA and NA) and nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) have higher dN/dS ratio and variability than other internal proteins. We also identified 47 positively selected regions in genomic segments except for the PB2 and M1 genes. Hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) are considered highly variable due to host immune pressure, but what drives NS1 variability is unknown. Therefore, we performed a comprehensive analysis of the genetic variation and selective pressure of the NS1 protein (462 existing NS1 sequences). We found that most of the positively selected regions and variable amino acids are located in the C-terminal effector domain (ED) of NS1. In addition, we focused on NS1-RNA and NS1-protein interactions involved in viral replication mechanisms and host immune response. Transcriptomic analysis of H5N1-infected monkey lungs showed that certain PI3K-related genes were up-regulated.
authors: Wei, K.;Chen, Y.;Lin, Y.;Pan, Y.

title: Global genetic variation and transmission dynamics of the H9N2 avian influenza virus
abstract: H9N2 influenza viruses circulate widely in the poultry population and variable genotypes can be generated by mutation, recombination and reclassification; they may be better adapted to infect a new host, resist drug therapy, or escape immune suppression. LPAI H9N2 viruses have the potential to evolve to high virulence levels in humans. Some studies on regional spread have been reported, but global spread and the drivers of the virus are poorly understood, particularly at the genome scale. Here, we analyzed all eight gene segments of randomly sampled 168 H9N2 genomes, aiming to provide a panoramic framework for better understanding the genesis and genetic variation of viruses, and used phylogeographic and spatial epidemiology approaches to reveal the effects of genetic variation, predictors. and the spread of H9N2 viruses. We found that more frequent reassortment events included PA, NP, and NS segments, and 21 isolates had possible mosaicism resulting from recombination events. Estimates of gene-specific global dN/dS ratios indicated that all genes were subject to purifying selection. However, a total of 13 regions under positive selection were detected by at least two of the three methods contained within the HA, NA, M2, NS1 and PA segments. In addition, we conclude that the NA segment has the highest rate of nucleotide substitution and the tMRCA estimate is the youngest from the inference of the remaining segments. Regarding spatial history, human airborne transport was identified as the dominant driver of global viral migration using GLM analysis, and economic factors and geographic distance were modest predictors. Higher migration rates (>0.01) were predicted between the five region pairs, indicating frequent migration of viruses between separate geographic locations. Furthermore, our Markov jump analysis showed that viral migration was more frequent between Southern China and Northern China, and a high rate of gene flow was observed between the Americas and East Asia. Moreover, the Americas, along with Southeast Asia, acted as the main centers of global transmission, forming the trunk of the evolutionary tree. These findings revealed a complex interplay between virus evolution, epidemiology and human behavior.
authors: Wei, K.;Li, Y.

title: Re-emergence of a genotype VIII virulent Newcastle disease virus isolated from Chinese gamebirds 13Â years later
abstract: The circulation of the dominant genotypes VI and VII of the Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is causing significant economic losses to the poultry industry in China. However, reports of Newcastle disease (ND) outbreaks caused by genotype VIII strains of NDV are rare. In this study, a virulent genotype VIII strain of NDV, designated GXGB2011, was isolated from a herd of vaccinated game chickens showing clinical signs of infection in Pinxiang county, Guangxi province, China. The entire genome of the isolate was completely sequenced and found to consist of 15,192 nucleotides (nt) coding for six structural proteins in the order 3â€²-NP-PMF-HN-L-5â€². The cleavage site 112RRQKRâ†“F117 model in the fusion (F) protein and an intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) value of 1.5 indicated that strain GXGB2011 is a velogenic NDV. Results of the challenge experiment with 5-week-old SPF chickens showed that the strain was highly pathogenic with 100% morbidity and mortality in threatened birds. Based on virus detection in different organs of infected birds, the highest viral load was observed in the tonsils of the cecum and the viral levels in the immune organs were higher than in the respiratory organs. Bayesian reconstruction of whole genomes based on the sequences of 66 NDV reference strains showed that the strain belonged to genotype VIII of NDV. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the strain was more closely related to foreign strains gamefowl/US(CA)/24225/98, 1ITTY94060 and IT-147/94 rather than the first domestic strains of genotype VIII that emerged in 1979 in Qinghai, China. €“1985. In summary, the results of the study demonstrated the reemergence of a highly pathogenic, lethal isolate of the VIII genotype of NDV. These results indicate the risk of spreading this VIII genotype of NDV from game animals to commercial chickens.
authors: Wei, T.;Deng, Q.;Zhai, G.;He, C.;Li, H.;Zhang, Y.;Zeng, R.;Mo, M.;Huang, T.;Wei, P.

title: Genetic and pathobiological characterization of pandemic H1N1 2009 influenza viruses from a naturally infected pig herd.
abstract: Since its initial identification in Mexico and the United States, concerns have been expressed that the new H1N1 influenza virus could cause a pandemic of comparable severity to the 1918 pandemic. In late April 2009, viruses phylogenetically related to the pandemic H1N1 influenza virus were isolated from an outbreak in a pig farm in Canada. This outbreak also had epidemiological links to a suspected human case. Experimental infections in pigs using one of the swine isolates and the human isolate A/Mexico/InDRE4487/2009 in this outbreak showed differences in virus recovery from the lower respiratory tract. While virus was consistently isolated from the lungs of pigs infected with A/Mexico/InDRE4487/2009, only one pig infected with A/swine/Alberta/OTH-33-8/2008 gave live virus from the lung despite comparable amounts of viral infection. RNA and antigen in both groups of pigs. The clinical disease was somewhat similar to other influenza virus infections in pigs, with prolonged virus antigen detection and delayed viral-RNA clearance from the lungs. There was also considerable genotypic variability among viruses isolated from farm pigs. This, together with the somewhat erratic pathobiological features observed in experimentally infected animals, suggests that, despite the swine origin of the virus, significant viral evolution may still be ongoing. Copyright © 2010, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Weingartl, H. M.;Berhane, Y.;Hisanaga, T.;Neufeld, J.;Kehler, H.;Emburry-Hyatt, C.;Hooper-McGreevy, K.;Kasloff, S.;Dalman, B.;Bystrom, J.;Alexandersen, S.;Li, Y.;Pasick, J.

title: Proposed family Toroviridae: Enteric infectious agents
authors: Weiss, M.;Horzinek, M. C.

title: Coronavirus pathogenesis and the emerging pathogen severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus
abstract: Coronaviruses are a family of enveloped, single-stranded, positive-stranded RNA viruses classified in the order Nidovirales. This family of coronaviruses consists of pathogens of many animal species and humans, including the recently isolated severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV). This review is divided into two main parts; the first deals with animal coronaviruses and their pathogenesis with an emphasis on the functions of individual viral genes, and the second discusses the newly identified human emerging pathogen, SARS-CoV. The coronavirus part (i) includes a description of a group of coronaviruses and the diseases they cause, the prototype coronavirus, the murine hepatitis virus, one of the recognized animal models for multiple sclerosis, as well as the veterinary viruses that cause the infection. a summary of swine, chicken and feline and human viruses; (ii) a brief summary of the replication cycle of coronaviruses in cell culture; (iii) development and application of reverse genetic systems; and (iv) the roles of individual coronavirus proteins in replication and pathogenesis. The SARS-CoV chapter covers the pathogenesis of SARS, evolving animal models for the infection, and progress in vaccine development and antiviral therapies.
