Data collected on animal coronaviruses continue to assist in understanding SARS-CoV. Copyright © 2005, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Weiss, S. R.;Navas-Martin, S.

title: Investigation of potential causes for the development of pig ear necrosis: different study designs-comparable results? German
abstract: In recent years, two studies have been conducted at the Swine Clinic of the Vienna University of Veterinary Medicine to investigate the etiology of pig ear necrosis. In Study 1, the parameters discussed in this context were collected by veterinarians by completing specially designed questionnaires on farms with symptoms of swine ear necrosis syndrome. In Study 2, piglets and feed samples were collected for laboratory analysis of the most important infectious agents as well as mycotoxins. In this paper, the results of both projects are compared. Even if the selection criteria for both studies were different, the age class affected was comparable (5.5 to ten weeks of survival in study 1 and six to ten weeks of survival in study 2). The herd-specific prevalence of pig ear necrosis syndrome ranged significantly from 2 to 10, 100% to percentages, respectively. Evaluation of the questionnaires in Study 1 showed that 51% of the farms had problems with cannibalism. Particles of plant material frequently seen on the histological slides of Study 2 may have entered the tissue through chewing the pen pals' ears or by cannibalism. While in study 1 the negative impact of parameters such as high pig density, insufficient climate, missing enrichment material and poor feed and water quality was considered, in study 2 all these factors were controlled in sample collection and ignored as precursors of cannibalism. In both studies, bacterial agents proved to be a crucial co-factor for the spread of necrosis into deeper tissue layers, while viral pathogens were classified as less important. In both projects, it was not possible to predict the direct action of infectious agents and mycotoxins as direct triggers of necrosis, as well as their involvement as co-factors or precursors in the sense of an immunosuppression or previous blood vessel or tissue damage.
authors: Weissenbacher-Lang, C.;Voglmayr, T.;Weissenbock, H.;Pyrek, R.;Waxenecker, F.;Hofstetter, U.;Hoelzle, K.;Hoelzle, L. E.;Welle, M.;Bruns, G.;Ritzmann, M.

title: Genomic analysis of some Japanese isolates of Getah virus
abstract: Capsid protein and nonstructural protein 1 (nsP1) regions of Sagiyama virus and eight Getah virus strains were analyzed using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and direct sequencing. The viruses were isolated from Malaysia and various parts of Japan over a 30-year period. Based on available published sequence data, oligonucleotide primers for RT-PCR were designed and sequences determined. Our findings showed 100% amino acid homology, despite differences in nucleotide sequences in the nsP1 region. On the other hand, in the capsid region, the nucleotide differences caused a large difference in the amino acid sequence. Therefore, the difference in capsid region is one of the useful markers in genetic classification between strains of Sagiyama virus and Getah virus and may be responsible for the serological difference in complement fixation test. Genomic differences between Getah virus strains are due to time factor rather than geographic distribution.
authors: Wekesa, S. N.;Inoshima, Y.;Murakami, K.;Sentsui, H.

title: Purification, morphology and partial characterization of a reovirus-like agent associated with neonatal calf diarrhea
abstract: Recently, studies have been carried out on a virus thought to be the etiological agent in widely disseminated cases of calf diarrhea. The virus was isolated from the feces and intestinal mucosa of experimentally infected calves and from cell cultures inoculated with material from infected calves. The virus was purified by differential centrifugation, nuclease treatment, extraction with a gradient of Genetron 113 and cesium chloride (CsC1). Purified and unpurified samples were examined by electron microscopy. Both types of preparations contained non-enveloped particles approximately 64 nm in diameter with a hexagonal core region of 36 nm in diameter. It was observed that the subunits of the capsids were arranged according to cubic symmetry. Essential lipids were not associated with the virus. The supernatant density of the purified virus was 1,359. Viral nucleic acid was determined as ribonucleic acid (RNA) by chemical methods. Morphology and some chemical properties appear similar to the reovirus group. However, the precise classification of this virus and its relationship to other groups have yet to be established.
authors: Welch, A. B.

title: Avipoxviruses: biology of infection and their use as vaccine vectors
abstract: Avipoxviruses (APVs) belong to the subfamily Chordopoxvirinae of the family Poxviridae. APVs are distributed worldwide and cause disease in domestic, domestic and wild birds of many species. APVs are transmitted by aerosols and biting insects, particularly mosquitoes and arthropods, and are often named after the bird species from which they were originally isolated. The virus strain Fowlpox virus (FWPV) causes disease in poultry and associated mortality is generally low, but in stressed flocks (other diseases, high production) mortality can be up to 50%. APVs are also major players in viral vaccine vector development for diseases in human and veterinary medicine. Abortive infection (no production of progeny viruses) in mammalian cells and their ability to host multiple gene insertions are some of the features that make APVs promising vaccine vectors. Although abortive infection in mammalian cells likely represents a major vaccine biosafety advantage, the molecular mechanisms that limit APVs to specific hosts are not yet fully understood. This review summarizes current knowledge of APVs, including classification, morphogenesis, host-virus interactions, diagnosis, and disease, and further highlights the use of APVs as recombinant vaccine vectors. Â© 2011 Weli and Tryland; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Weli, S. C.;Tryland, M.

title: Species and strains: essential roles in understanding protein aggregation in neurodegenerative diseases.
abstract: Protein misfolding and aggregation is an important event in diseases such as Alzheimer's disease (AD) or Parkinson's disease (PD) and is associated with neurodegeneration. Factors that initiate protein misfolding and the role of protein aggregation in disease pathophysiology pose major challenges for the neuroscience community. Interestingly, although accumulation of the same misfolded protein, eg α-synuclein, can be detected in all idiopathic PD patients, the disease spectrum encompasses a variety of different clinical presentations and disease course. In a more recent attempt, this clinical variance is explained by different protein aggregate conformations, similar to prion diseases. In prion diseases, different prion types have been associated with a course of dementia and ataxic disease in Creutzfeldt-Jakob patients, showing a relationship between protein aggregate conformation characteristics and clinical disease course. This principle is currently being transferred to AD, PD and other neurodegenerative diseases by protein aggregation. However, differences in protein aggregate conformation are often treated as disease strains. The term "strain" also derives from prion research and was developed by adopting viral nomenclature when it is assumed that infectious spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs; later referred to as prion diseases) are caused by a virus. The problem is that in virus taxonomy the term "type" refers to the characteristics of the disease agent itself, and the term "strain" refers to host-related factors that interact with the disease agent and can moderately alter the clinical presentation of disease. Strain factors can only be discovered after the agent has been transmitted and transmitted to a number of different species. Misuse of terminology confuses disease agent and host factors and hinders understanding of the pathophysiology of protein aggregation-related neurodegenerative diseases. This review article reviews the inventions that explain how the terms "type" and "strain" for non-conventional disease agents arose. This may help avoid confusion in the terminology of protein aggregation diseases and accurately reflect the influence of protein aggregation conformation as well as the impact of host factor contribution on different clinical variations of AD, PD and other neurodegenerative diseases.
authors: Wemheuer, W. M.;Wrede, A.;Schulz-Schaeffer, W. J.

title: Comments on Duck circovirus (DuCV) genotype definition
abstract: standardized methodology was used to identify genotypes based on pairwise sequence comparisons (PASC). PASC is a widely accepted method in virus taxonomy based on the histogram of binary differences between sequences. Recently, Zhang et al. (2013) concluded that the mean p-distance of duck circovirus (DuCV) between genotypes 1 and 2 was 0.170, and the subtype distance thresholds were 0.032 in DuCV-1 and 0.018 in DuCV-2, respectively. However, there may be some concerns in applying the methodology to identify the genotype of DuCV. Taking into account the aforementioned concerns, our authors performed PASC analyzes of 54 capsid genes (ORF2) and Zhang et al. (2013). Our results confirmed the existence of two DuCV genotypes (1 and 2), and we suggest that the DuCV ORF2 and genomic distance genotype thresholds are 0.061 and 0.038, respectively. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Wen, H.;Wu, Y.;Yang, C.;Zhang, X.;Lian, C.;Chen, H.;Han, L.

title: Characterization of porcine and some ruminant pestiviruses by cross-neutralization
abstract: Serological relationships between 11 pestivirus strains originating from pigs and five pestivirus strains originating from cattle or sheep were examined by cross-neutralization. Experiments were performed with pig and sheep serums grown against the strains. The results were analyzed by a computerized taxonomic procedure. 16 viruses were classified into four different serological groups. All swine cholera virus (HCV) strains were classified in one group; the other three groups consisted of strains capable of infecting pigs but identified as bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) or border disease virus (BDV), or more closely related to BVDV and BDV than to HCV.
authors: Wensvoort, G.;Terpstra, C.;de Kluyver, E. P.

title: Detection of hepatitis E virus (HEV) from pig livers in southeastern Germany and high sequence homology to human HEV isolates
abstract: Background: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) has been identified as an emerging cause of infectious hepatitis in developed countries in recent years. In contrast to travel-associated hepatitis E, zoonotic sources of infection are suspected for autochthonous cases in Europe. Objective: Since pigs are known reservoirs of HEV, we tested pig livers sold as food in Southeast Germany for the presence of hepatitis E virus RNA. Study design: We purchased 200 pork liver samples from 81 butchers and grocers in Regensburg, Germany. Nucleic acid preparations were tested for the presence of HEV RNA by quantitative real-time PCR (RT-qPCR). HEV isolates from positive samples were characterized by partial sequencing of the ORF1 and ORF2 regions in the HEV genome and by phylogenetic analysis. Results: Samples from eight (4%) of 200 purchased pig livers had detectable amounts of HEV RNA. Sequencing and phylogenetic analysis allowed the two new isolates to be classified as HEV genotype 3, subgenotype 3a (swR437) and 3c (swR269), respectively. Both novel porcine HEV isolates showed high sequence homology to isolates from patients with acute HEV infection from the same geographic region. Conclusions: These results support the proposed role of undercooked pork products in food as a source of zoonotic HEV infection for humans. Whether this transmission mechanism is responsible for the surprisingly high prevalence of anti-HEV IgG recently observed in some European countries and the USA remains to be clarified. © 2011 Elsevier BV
authors: Wenzel, J. J.;PreiÃŸ, J.;Schemmerer, M.;Huber, B.;Plentz, A.;Jilg, W.

title: Schmallenberg Virus: A New Virus of Veterinary Importance
abstract: In late 2011, non-specific clinical symptoms such as fever, diarrhea and decreased milk production were observed in dairy cattle in the Dutch/German border region. After excluding classical endemic and emerging viruses by targeted diagnostic systems, blood samples from acutely diseased cows were subjected to metagenomic analysis. An insect-transmitted orthobunya virus of the Simbu serogroup was identified as the causative agent and named Schmallenberg virus (SBV). It was one of the first detections of the introduction of a new virus of veterinary importance to Europe using the new technology of next-generation sequencing. The virus was then isolated from the same samples used for metagenomic analysis in insect and mammalian cell lines, and disease symptoms were reproduced in calves experimentally infected with both this virus grown in culture and blood samples from diseased cattle. Since its emergence, SBV has spread very rapidly throughout the European ruminant population, causing mild nonspecific disease in adult animals, but also severe fetal malformation when naive mothers are infected at a critical stage of pregnancy, such as preterm birth or stillbirth. In the following years, SBV was regularly recirculated to a greater extent; During the 2014 and 2016 vector seasons, the virus was repeatedly detected in the blood of adult ruminants, and a number of malformed calves and lambs were born in the following winter and spring months. The genome of viruses found in viremic adult animals showed a very high sequence stability; In sequences created between 2012 and 2016, only a few amino acid substitutions could be detected compared to the first SBV isolate. In contrast, a high sequence variability was identified in the amino-terminal portion of the glycoprotein Gc-coding region of viruses found in the brain of malformed neonates. This mutation hotspot is independent of the region or host species from which the samples originate and is potentially involved in immune evasion mechanisms.
authors: Wernike, K.;Beer, M.

title: Schmallenberg Virus Relapse, Germany, 2014
abstract: Schmallenberg virus (SBV) originated in Germany in 2011, spread rapidly in Europe and nearly disappeared in 2013. However, new cases have occurred in adult cattle since late summer 2014. Whole genome analysis revealed some amino acid substitution differences from the first SBV sample. Viremia developed in experimentally infected sheep and cattle for 4-6 days.
authors: Wernike, K.;Hoffmann, B.;Conraths, F. J.;Beer, M.

title: Detection and typing of highly pathogenic swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus by multiplex real-time RT-PCR
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) causes economic losses to the swine industry worldwide, and PRRS viruses (PRRSV) are classified into two distinct genotypes, "North America (NA, type 2)" and "Europe (EU, type 1)". . . In 2006, a highly pathogenic strain of PRRSV NA (HP-PRRSV), characterized by high fever as well as high morbidity and mortality, emerged on pig farms in China. Therefore, a HP-PRRSV-specific real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) assay was developed and combined with type 1- and type 2-specific RT-qPCR systems. Moreover, an internal control based on a heterologous RNA has been successfully introduced. This final multiplex PRRSV RT-qPCR had a high diagnostic sensitivity of less than 200 copies per µl for type 1-assay and 20 copies per µl for type 2- and HP assays, detecting and typing PRRSV. A panel of reference strains and field isolates were reliably identified, and samples from an animal trial with a Chinese HP-PRRS strain were used for test validation. The new multiplex PRRSV RT-qPCR system allows for the first time high sensitivity detection and rapid differentiation of PRRSV of both genotypes as well as direct detection of HP-PRRSV. Â© 2012 Wernike et al.
authors: Wernike, K.;Hoffmann, B.;Dauber, M.;Lange, E.;Schirrmeier, H.;Beer, M.

title: West Nile Virus: An Update on Recent Developments
abstract: West Nile Virus arrived in North America a little over 12 years ago, and since then much has been learned about its pathology, transmission of infection, and factors influencing prevalence. Significant advances have uncovered critical risk factors for severe neurological disease and uncovered successful host defense strategies. Currently only equine vaccines are available; Human vaccines remain in various stages of clinical trials. This review discusses advances and limitations in current research regarding the emergence and continued spread of West Nile virus in the Americas. © 2012 Elsevier Inc.
authors: Wertheimer, A. M.

title: Molecular evolution of viral fusion and matrix protein genes and phylogenetic relationships among Paramyxoviridae
abstract: Phylogenetic relationships among Paramyxoviridae, a large family of viruses whose members cause devastating diseases in wildlife, livestock and humans, were studied with both fusion (F) and matrix (M) protein coding sequences. Contiguous trees of the F and M protein sequences showed that Paramyxoviridae was divided into two conventionally recognized subfamilies, Paramyxovirinae and Pneumovirinae. Within the Paramyxovirinae, the results also showed groups corresponding to the three currently recognized genera: Respirovirus, Morbillivirus and Rubulavirus. Relationships between the three genera of Paramyxovirinae were resolved by the M protein sequences and there was substantial bootstrapping support (100%) showing that members of the Respirovirus genus and Morbillivirus genus are more closely related to each other than the Rubulavirus genus. . Both the F and M phylogenies showed that Newcastle disease virus (NDV) was more closely related to the Rubulavirus genus than the other two genera, but was consistent with the suggestion (BS Seal et al., 2000, Virus Res. 66, 1-11). ) classification of NDV as a separate genus within Paramyxovirinae. Both the F and M phylogenies were also consistent with the proposal to classify Hendra virus as a new genus basal and closely related to the Morbillivirus genus (L. Wang et al., 2000, J. Virol 74, 9972-9979). Rinderpest was most closely related to measles and was more of a derived virus than canine distemper virus, phocine distemper virus, or dolphin morbillivirus. Â© 2001 Academic Press.
authors: Westover, K. M.;Hughes, A. L.

title: Exudative cloacidosis potentially due to Escherichia coli infection in Kakapo (Strigops habroptilus)
abstract: METHODS: Metagenomics using neutral RNA or DNA sequencing was performed on fecal material from an 11-year-old female kakapo with exudative cloacid and eight bird pools (male and female aged 1-20 years) with no current symptoms or history. disease. Fecal material from the diseased bird was collected before and after treatment. For RNA sequencing, the extracted RNA/DNA was subjected to DNase and the remaining RNA was reverse transcribed into cDNA and subjected to multiple displacement amplification before sequencing. RESULTS: No significant alignment was obtained for any known avian virus sequences from any faecal sample. However, significant BLAST alignments were obtained in the five bacteriophages known to infect enterobacteria. There was strong evidence for the presence of Escherichia coli bacteriophage Escherichia phage TL-2011b, a bacteriophage known to cause outbreaks of foodborne illness in humans, but in the sample from the non-diseased pool. Differences in E. coli community structure between the diseased bird and the non-infected pond were also evident. CONCLUSIONS: Human-induced Escherichia coli infection is suggested to be a possible cause of exudative cloaciditis, although confirmatory work is required to test this hypothesis. OBJECTIVE: To investigate the initiating causes of cloacidosis (cloaca inflammation) in Kakapo (Strigops habroptilus).
authors: White, D. J.;Hall, R. J.;Jakob-Hoff, R.;Wang, J.;Jackson, B.;Tompkins, D. M.

title: Discovery and complete genome sequence of a novel circovirus-like virus in the endangered Rowi kiwi Apteryx rowi
abstract: Circoviruses are circular, non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA viruses approximately 2000 nucleotides (nt) long and include the pathogenic strains Porcine circovirus 1 and Beak and feather disease virus, which can cause significant morbidity and mortality. This group of viruses may be resistant to degradation by external environments, and avian circoviruses are known to move between closely related hosts. Using a de novo metagenomic approach followed by confirmatory PCR, we detected, for the first time in New Zealand kiwi, a circular Rep-encoding single-stranded (CRESS) DNA virus, Apteryx spp. we defined. . rowi) showing signs of harmful dermatitis. The entire 2085 nt genome has been cloned and sequenced and contains both capsid and replicase genes as well as a conserved 9 nt motif. Phylogenetic analyzes place it within the Circoviridae, which is adjacent to other environmental CRESS-DNA viruses and most closely related to the badger circovirus-like virus (Meles meles circovirus-like virus). Since the rowi is the most critically endangered kiwi, it is vital to understand the role of the rowi kiwi circovirus-like virus as a possible pathogen as well as possible interspecies transmission.
authors: White, D. J.;Hall, R. J.;Wang, J.;Moore, N. E.;Park, D.;McInnes, K.;Gartrell, B. D.;Tompkins, D. M.

title: Serological evidence of exposure to influenza D virus in persons with occupational contact with cattle
abstract: Background: Influenza D virus (IDV), a new influenza virus with the proposed classification: family Orthomyxoviridae, genus Influenzavirus D, Influenza D virus strain has been associated with influenza-like illness in cattle and pigs. More recently, anti-IDV antibodies have also been detected in small ruminant animals. A seroprevalence of approximately 1.3% has been estimated for the general human population. Objectives: To gain insight into the zoonotic potential of IDV for adults with occupational exposure to cattle in north central Florida. Study: A cross-sectional serological study was performed on human serum samples from 35 cattle-exposed and 11 cattle-exposed adults to screen for IDV antibodies using the hemagglutination inhibition (HI) and microneutralization (MN) tests. Results: Seroprevalence was determined 91% by HI test and 97% by MN test in individuals working with cattle in Florida. Among individuals not exposed to cattle, seropositivity as determined by the MN test (only) was lower (18%). Conclusions: IDV poses a zoonotic risk for workers exposed to cattle based on the detection of high seroprevalence (94-97%). While it is still unknown whether IDV causes disease in humans, our studies suggest that the virus may be an emerging pathogen among cattle workers.
authors: White, S. K.;Ma, W.;McDaniel, C. J.;Gray, G. C.;Lednicky, J. A.

title: Characterization of Unknown Orthobunya-Like Viruses from India
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of agents causing idiopathic human diseases has been crucial in the identification of novel viruses. This study describes the isolation and characterization of two novel orthobunyaviruses from a jungle myna and a rice bird from Karnataka State, India. Using an NGS approach, these isolates were classified as Cat Que and Balagodu viruses belonging to the Manzanilla clade of the Simbu serogroup. Closely related viruses in the Manzanilla lineage have been isolated from mosquitoes, humans, birds and pigs over a wide geographical area. Because orthobunyaviruses exhibit a high frequency of reclassification and can cause acute, self-limited febrile illness, these data suggest that human and livestock infections of Oya/Cat Que/Manzanilla virus may be more common and/or underreported than expected. Therefore, it becomes imperative to identify new and unknown viruses to understand their role in human and animal pathogenesis. The current work is a step forward in this regard and will serve as a prototype method for the isolation, identification and detection of several other emerging viruses.
authors: Whitmer, S. L. M.;Yadav, P. D.;Sarkale, P.;Chaubal, G. Y.;Francis, A.;Klena, J.;Nichol, S. T.;Stroher, U.;Mourya, D. T.

title: Prevalence of Antibodies to Hepatitis E Virus Among Ostensibly Healthy Humans and Pigs in Bali, Indonesia: Identification of a Pig Infected with a Genotype 4 Hepatitis E Virus
abstract: In Indonesia, where hepatitis E virus (HEV) is believed to be highly endemic, only three outbreaks of HEV transmission have been documented to date in restricted areas (West Kalimantan and East Java). A total of 1,115 serum samples collected from apparently healthy individuals in 1996 in Bali, Lombok and Surabaya in Indonesia, where epidemic HEV transmissions have never been reported, were tested for IgG class antibodies (anti-HEV) to HEV. In Bali, anti-HEV was detected in 20% (54/276) of the population tested, with notable contrast to 4% (17/446) in Lombok and 0.5% (2/393) in Surabaya. detected. On the other hand, antibodies to hepatitis A virus were quite common in all three regions (95% in Bali, 90% in Lombok and 89% in Surabaya). Although the majority of the population in Indonesia is Muslim, Balinese people are mostly Hindu and have a habit of consuming pork. Therefore, serum samples were obtained from 99 farm pigs in Bali and tested for anti-HEV and HEV RNA. Serum from 71 pigs (72%) was positive for anti-HEV, and a 2-month-old pig had detectable HEV RNA. The porcine HEV isolate from viremic pig was named SB66-Bali. The SB66-Bali isolate was most closely related to genotype 4 isolates from China, India, Japan, and Taiwan, but shared only 82.6-90.0% identity at common 241-412 nucleotides in open reading frame 2 (ORF2). These results suggest that a possibly indigenous HEV strain(s) is circulating in Bali, Indonesia, and that zoonotic HEV infection can occur even in developing countries. © 2004 Wiley-Liss, Inc.
authors: Wibawa, I. D. N.;Muljono, D. H.;Mulyanto;Suryadarma, I. G. A.;Tsuda, F.;Takahashi, M.;Nishizawa, T.;Okamoto, H.

title: Matrix gene of influenza A viruses isolated from wild waterfowl: Ecology and emergence of influenza A viruses.
abstract: Wild waterfowl are the primary reservoir of influenza A viruses, but little is known about the viruses' gene pool in wild birds. Therefore, we investigated the ecology and emergence of influenza viruses by performing a phylogenetic analysis of 70 matrix (M) genes of influenza viruses isolated during >18 years of surveillance from shorebirds and gulls in the Delaware Bay area and ducks in Alberta, Canada. We included 61 published M genes isolated from various hosts in our analysis. We show that the M genes of the Canadian duck viruses and the M genes of the shorebird and gull viruses of the Delaware Bay share ancestry with the M genes of the North American poultry viruses. We found that bird-like lineages in North America and Eurasia split into sublineages, suggesting that multiple branches of virus evolution may be conserved in wild waterfowl. The presence of non-H13 gull viruses in the gull-like lineage and H13 gull viruses in other avian lineages suggested that the M genes of gulls do not preferentially fuse with the H13 subtype or segregate into a distinct lineage. Some North American avian influenza viruses contained M genes closely related to those of Eurasian avian viruses. Therefore, there may be interregional mixing of the two wings. The reclassification of Shorebird M and HA genes was clear, but there was no correlation between HA or NA subtype, M gene sequence, and isolation time. Overall, these results support the hypothesis that influenza viruses in wild waterfowl contain distinguishable M gene lineages.
authors: Widjaja, L.;Krauss, S. L.;Webby, R. J.;Xie, T.;Webster, R. G.

title: A new subset of genotypes emerging within PCV-2b dominates the PMWS episode in Switzerland.
abstract: Post-weaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS) is among the most important swine diseases emerging worldwide. Initially, the insidious nature of the disease made it difficult to detect the pathogen. The presence of porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) in all animals with PMWS has led to its recognition as the causative agent of PMWS, possibly with an unknown factor. In addition, the presence of PCV2 in healthy individuals did not facilitate the understanding of the disease. Phylogenetic classification divides PCV2 viruses into at least two main groups. With the aid of a signature motif, a short amino acid motif encoded in the capsid protein, viruses are determined to belong to PCV-2a or PCV-2b. Recently, this classification has received more attention as it identifies PCV-2b as more lethal. However, this simplification could not be verified experimentally. Therefore, we investigated whether virus genetic drift was an initiator for the PMWS epizooty in Switzerland. From 1973 to 2005, piglet lymphoid tissues were investigated by histology, immunohistochemistry (IHC), and PCR. For genotype classification, a 137 bp sequence amplification covering the signature motif was used. The onset of the Swiss PMWS epizootic exhibited a marked shift to PCV-2b, and one genotype subset in particular, in PMWS diseased and subclinically infected piglets. Complementing these observations, healthy piglets identified as negative by IHC are positive in the PCR reaction and do not contain any PCV-2b virus at the time of the episode. In conclusion, our data support PCV2 genome plasticity as an important contributing factor for PMWS disease manifestation. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Wiederkehr, D. D.;Sydler, T.;Buergi, E.;Haessig, M.;Zimmermann, D.;Pospischil, A.;Brugnera, E.;Sidler, X.

title: Cowpox virus infection in an 11-year-old girl
abstract: We describe an 11-year-old girl with cowpox virus infection who presented with a 14-day-old crusty, ulcerated nodule on the chin/neck and a 6-day-old eroded blister on her left leg. The girl lived in a rural setting, had close contact with several cats from the neighborhood, and was prone to atopy. The presence of orthopox virus in the left leg lesion was demonstrated by electron microscopy (negative staining, transmission electron microscopy) and virus isolation. Classification as a cowpox virus was determined by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) followed by restriction enzyme digestion of the PCR product.
authors: Wienecke, R.;Wolff, H.;Schaller, M.;Meyer, H.;Plewig, G.

title: Molecular detection and characterization of picobirnaviruses in piglets with diarrhea in Thailand.
abstract: Picobirnavirus (PBV) is a small, bi-segmented, double-stranded RNA virus. Taxonomically, the genus Picobirnavirus belongs to the family Picobirnaviridae. PBV infects a wide variety of hosts and causes opportunistic infections, but its role in diarrheal disease remains unclear. To determine the prevalence and genetic diversity of swine PBVs in northern Thailand, 380 fecal samples collected from diarrheal and nondiarrheal piglets reared on 22 pig farms were tested for the presence of PBV. Reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) was performed using primer sets specific to the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp) gene. PBV was detected in 86 of 265 (32.5%) piglets with diarrhea and in 26 (22.6%) of 115 piglets without diarrhea. All PBV strains detected in this study belonged to genogroup I, and highly PBV-positive piglets were co-infected with group A rotavirus (RVA) and bocavirus (BoV). Phylogenetic analysis of representative genogroup I strains revealed extremely high similarity between strains; they formed a monophyletic cluster with 97-100% sequence identity in the RdRp gene. The strains were also closely related to the genogroup I PBV Chinese pig strain. The findings show that PPV infection is common in piglets with and without diarrhea in northern Thailand.
authors: Wilburn, L.;Yodmeeklin, A.;Kochjan, P.;Saikruang, W.;Kumthip, K.;Khamrin, P.;Maneekarn, N.

title: Influenza-A viruses in ducks from northwest Minnesota: Fine-scale spatial and temporal variation in prevalence and subtype diversity.
abstract: Waterfowl from northwest Minnesota were sampled by cloaca swab for Avian Influenza Virus (AIV) from July to October in 2007 and 2008. AIV was detected in 222 (9.1%) of 2,441 ducks in 2007 and in 438 (17.9%) of 2,452 ducks in 2007. 2008. AIV prevalence peaked in late summer. We identified 27 AIV subtypes in 2007 and 31 in 2008. Ten hemagglutinin (HA) subtypes were identified each year (ie, H1, 3-8, and 10-12 in 2007; H1-8, 10, and 11 in 2008). All neuraminidase (NA) subtypes were detected in each year of the study. Subtype diversity varies between years and increases with prevalence until September. Dominant subtypes in 2007 (containing ~5% of subtype diversity) included H1N1, H3N6, H3N8, H4N6, H7N3, H10N7, and H11N9. Dominant subtypes in 2008 included H3N6, H3N8, H4N6, H4N8, H6N1, and H10N7. In addition, within each HA subtype, the same dominant HA/NA subtype combinations were detected each year and included H1N1, H3N8, H4N6, H5N2, H6N1, H7N3, H8N4, H10N7, and H11N9. H2N3 and H12N5 viruses also predominated within the H2 and H12 subtypes, respectively, but were detected only within a single year (H2 and H12 viruses were not detected in 2007 and 2008, respectively). The dominant strain sampled was mallards (63.7% of total) and 531 AIVs from this strain were isolated (80.5% of total isolates). Mallard data collected in both years adequately described the temporal and spatial prevalence observed from the total sample and also adequately represented subtype diversity. Juvenile mallards were adequate in describing subtype diversity as well as temporal and spatial prevalence of AIV.
authors: Wilcox, B. R.;Knutsen, G. A.;Berdeen, J.;Goekjian, V.;Poulson, R.;Goyal, S.;Sreevatsan, S.;Cardona, C.;Berghaus, R. D.;Swayne, D. E.;Yabsley, M. J.;Stallknecht, D. E.

title: Virus–virus interactions and host ecology correlate with RNA virome structure in wild birds
authors: Wille, M.;Eden, J. S.;Shi, M.;Klaassen, M.;Hurt, A. C.

title: Virus-virus interactions and host ecology are associated with RNA virome structure in wild birds.
abstract: Little is known about the factors that shape the ecology of RNA viruses in nature. Wild birds are an important case here, because other than influenza A virus, bird specimens are rarely tested for viruses, especially in the absence of overt disease. Using bulk RNA sequencing ("meta-transcriptomics"), we have revealed viral diversity found in Australian wild birds through the lens of ecological factors that can determine virome structure and abundance. Meta-transcriptomic analysis of four Anseriformes (waterfowl) and Charadriiformes (shorebird) species sampled in temperate and arid Australia revealed the presence of 27 RNA virus genomes, 18 of which represent newly identified species. Viruses identified included a previously described gammakoronavirus and influenza A viruses. We also identified new virus species from the families Astroviridae, Caliciviridae, Reoviridae, Rhabdoviridae, Picobirnaviridae and Picornaviridae. We noted differences in virome structure reflecting key differences in location and influenza A infection status. Red-necked Avocets (Recurvirostra novaehollandiae) from the arid interior of Australia had the greatest viral diversity and abundance, markedly higher than individuals sampled in temperate Australia. In Ruddy Turnstones (Arenaria interpres) and daredevil ducks (Anas spp.), viral abundance and diversity in hosts positive for influenza A infection was higher and similar compared to those negative for this virus, despite the collection of specimens on it. on the same day and from the same place. This study highlights the scope and diversity of RNA viruses in wild birds and lays the foundation for understanding the factors that determine virome structure in wild populations.
authors: Wille, M.;Eden, J. S.;Shi, M.;Klaassen, M.;Hurt, A. C.;Holmes, E. C.

title: A different hepatitis D-like agent in birds
abstract: Hepatitis delta virus (HDV) is currently only found in humans and is a satellite virus that depends on hepatitis B virus (HBV) envelope proteins for assembly, release, and entry. Using meta-transcriptomics, we identified the genome of a novel HDV-like agent in ducks. Sequence analysis revealed secondary structures shared with HDV, including self-completion and ribozyme properties. The predicted viral protein shares 32% amino acid identity with the small delta antigen of HDV and contains a distinct phylogenetic lineage. The discovery of an avian HDV-like agent has important implications for understanding the origins of HDV and sub-viral agents.
authors: Wille, M.;Netter, H. J.;Littlejohn, M.;Yuen, L.;Shi, M.;Eden, J. S.;Klaassen, M.;Holmes, E. C.;Hurt, A. C.

title: Viral Diversity of House Mice in New York
abstract: The microbiome of wild Mus musculus (house mouse), a globally invasive pest found in close contact with humans in urban centers, remains largely unexplored. Here we report the analysis of fecal virus of house mice in residential buildings in New York City, NY. Mice were collected over a 1-year period at seven sites in Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn, and the Bronx. Neutral high-throughput sequencing of faeces revealed 36 viruses from 18 families and 21 genera, including at least 6 new viruses and 3 new genera. A representative scan of 15 viruses by PCR confirmed the presence of 13 of these viruses in the liver. We identified an uneven distribution of diversity, with various viruses associated with specific locations. Higher mouse weight was associated with an increase in the number of viruses detected per mouse after adjusting for site, sex, and length. We found neither genetic footprints of known human viral pathogens nor antibodies to the lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus. IMPORTANT Mice carry a wide variety of infectious agents with zoonotic potential. Their proximity to people in the built environment is therefore a public health concern. Laboratory mice are also the most common experimental model for investigating the pathobiology of infectious diseases. In this survey of mice trapped in multiple locations in New York City over a 1-year period, we found a diverse collection of viruses, some of which had not been previously associated with house mice and included others that appeared novel. Although we did not find any known human pathogens, our findings provide insight into viral ecology and may provide models with utility for clinical microbiology.
authors: Williams, S. H.;Che, X. Y.;Garcia, J. A.;Klena, J. D.;Lee, B.;Muller, D.;Ulrich, W.;Corrigan, R. M.;Nichol, S.;Jain, K.;Lipkin, W. I.

title: Meeting report: 2013 PDA Virus & TSE Security Forum
abstract: The report provides a summary of the presentations and discussions at the Virus and TSE Safety Forum 2013, organized by the Parenteral Medicines Association (PDA) and held in Berlin, Germany from 4-6 June 2013. The conference was accompanied by a workshop, "Virus Removal through Virus Spike Preparations and Filtration: New Trends and Developments". Presentations and discussions at the workshop are summarized in a separate report, which will also be published in this issue of the journal. As with previous conferences in this series, the PDA Virus and TSE Safety Forum 2013 again provided an excellent opportunity to exchange information and views among industry, research organizations and regulatory bodies. Updates on regulatory considerations regarding virus and transmissible spongiform encephalopathy (TSE) safety of biopharmaceuticals have been provided by the agencies of the European Union (EU), United States (US), and Singapore. The epidemiology and detection methods of emerging pathogens such as hepatitis E virus and parvovirus (PARV 4) are exemplified, and the risk of contamination of animal-derived raw materials, especially trypsin, is taken into account. The benefit of using new array-based virus detection methods was discussed. Cases of bioreactor contaminations in the past have drawn attention to root cause investigations and preventive actions, illustrated by a few examples. Virus removal data of certain unit operations provided; The discussion focused on the virus clearance mechanism and the strategic concept of viral clearance integration. As in previous years, the virus safety section was followed by a TSE section covering the latest scientific findings that could affect the risk assessment of blood and cell substrates. These included the understanding that cross-species transmission of TSE by blood components in sheep was greater than predicted by assays in transgenic mice. In addition, the pathogenesis of cell substrates and the possibility of productive TSE infection were considered, and cell-based assays that may be suitable for use in TSE clearance studies are discussed. The present report provides an overview of the results of the 2013 PDA Virus and TSE Security Forum, a unique event in this field. ©PDA, Inc. 2014.
authors: Willkommen, H.;BlÃ¼mel, J.;Brorson, K.;Chen, D.;Chen, Q.;GrÃ¶ner, A.;Hubbard, B. R.;Kreil, T. R.;Ruffing, M.;Ruiz, S.;Scott, D.;Silvester, G.

title: Internet-accessible sexually transmitted infection (e-STI) testing and outcome service: A randomized, single-blind, controlled trial.
abstract: Background: Testing for sexually transmitted infections (e-STIs), which is accessed online, is becoming more and more available as an alternative to testing in clinics. Typically, this testing method allows users to order a test kit from a virtual service (via a website or app), collect their own samples, return test samples to a laboratory, and be notified of results via text message service (SMS) or phone. . e-STI testing is assumed to increase access to testing compared to in-person services, but the evidence is not clear. We conducted a randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of an e-STI test and outcome service (chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV and syphilis) on STI test uptake and diagnosed STI cases. Methods and findings: The study was conducted in the London boroughs of Lambeth and Southwark. Between November 24, 2014 and August 31, 2015, we recruited 2,072 participants aged 16-30, residing in these districts, having at least 1 sexual partner in the last 12 months, willing to have an STI test, and residing in these districts. Internet access. Those who could not give consent and could not read English were excluded. Participants were randomly assigned to receive 1 text message with a web link to an e-STI test and results service (intervention group) or 1 text message with a web link to a bespoke website listing their location, contact information and website. 7 local sexual health clinics (control group). Participants were free to use other services or interventions during the study period. The primary outcomes were self-reported STI testing at 6 weeks confirmed by patient registry controls and self-reported STI diagnosis at 6 weeks confirmed by patient registry controls. Secondary outcomes were the proportion of participants prescribed treatment for an STI, time from randomization to completion of an STI test, and time from randomization to treatment for an STI. Participants received a £10 cash incentive upon submission of self-reported data. We completed all follow-ups, including patient registration checks, until 17 June 2016. In the intervention group, STI test uptake increased at 6 weeks (50.0% vs. 26.6%, relative risk [RR] 1.87, 95% CI 1.63 to 2.15), P < 0.001). The proportion of participants diagnosed was 2.8% in the intervention group versus 1.4% in the control group (RR 2.10, 95% CI 0.94 to 4.70, P = 0.079). Evidence of heterogeneity was not observed in any of the prespecified subgroup analyzes. The proportion of treated participants was 1.1% in the intervention group versus 0.7% in the control group (RR 1.72, 95% CI 0.71 to 4.16, P = 0.231). Test duration was shorter in the intervention group compared to the control group (36.5 days vs. 28.8 days, P < 0.001, limited mean survival time test [RMST]), but no difference was observed for time to treatment (83.2). 83.5 days versus days, P = 0.51, test for difference in RMST). We were unable to recruit the planned 3,000 participants and therefore did not have the power for STI diagnoses and analysis of STI cases treated. Results: The e-STI testing service increased STI testing intake for all groups, including high-risk groups. The intervention required people to go to the clinic for treatment and did not shorten the time to treatment. Service innovations to improve cure rates for those diagnosed online are needed and may include e-treatment and mail-in treatment services. e-STI testing services require long-term monitoring and evaluation. Trial registration: ISRCTN Registry ISRCTN13354298.
authors: Wilson, E.;Free, C.;Morris, T. P.;Syred, J.;Ahamed, I.;Menon-Johansson, A. S.;Palmer, M. J.;Barnard, S.;Rezel, E.;Baraitser, P.

title: Diagnostic Tools for Bluetongue and Epizootic Hemorrhagic Disease Viruses Applied to the Review of North American Veterinary Diagnostics
abstract: This review provides an overview of current and potential new diagnostic tests for blue tongue (CT) and epizootic hemorrhagic disease (EHD) viruses, compiled from international contributors to the Orbivirus Gap Analysis Workshop, Diagnostic Group. The emphasis of this review is on the diagnostic tools available to North American veterinary diagnosticians. Standard diagnostic tests for BT/EHD viruses are readily available, and there are described tests published in the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) Terrestrial Manual. However, there are significant differences in the diagnostic approach to these viruses. Serological tests are well structured and many laboratories are experienced in conducting these tests. Numerous nucleic acid amplification assays are also available for BT virus (BTV) and EHD virus (EHDV). Although there is substantial experience with BTV reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR), there are no standards or comparisons of protocols used by the various state and federal veterinary diagnostic laboratories.
authors: Wilson, W. C.;Daniels, P.;Ostlund, E. N.;Johnson, D. E.;Oberst, R. D.;Hairgrove, T. B.;Mediger, J.;McIntosh, M. T.

title: Reducing the risk of viruses for raw materials: a European perspective
authors: Wisher, M.

title: Classification of Marek's disease viruses by pathotype: Philosophy and methodology
abstract: The concept of pathotype in Marek's disease (MD) probably derives from the recognition of a more virulent form of the disease in the late 1950s (Benton & Cover, 1957). The distinctions between MD virus strains were further broadened by the identification of the vv pathotype in the early 1980s and the vv+ pathotype in the 1990s. Pathotype definitions reflect important biological features associated with vaccine immunity in the field. However, the pathotyping methods applied by the various laboratories were not uniform, preventing critical comparison of results. Better uniformity of pathotyping procedures is desirable. The Avian Disease and Oncology Laboratory (ADOL) method is based on the induction of lymphoproliferative lesions in vaccinated chickens. This method has been used for the pathotyping of more than 45 isolates and is the basis for current pathotype classification of MD virus strains. Its limitations include requirements for a given chicken breed (15 x 7 ab+), a large number of animals, and a statistical method to compare lesion responses with those of JM/102W and Md5 control strains. Due to these limitations, it has not been used and is not likely to be used in other laboratories. Comparability in pathotyping can be improved by comparing field isolates with standard prototype strains such as JM/102W, Md5 and 648A (American Type Culture Collection) or equivalents. Data can be generated by different in vivo procedures that measure tumor induction, neurological disease (both neoplastic and non-neoplastic lesions), or non-neoplastic criteria only (such as lymphoid organ weights or virus replication). Methods based on neoplastic criteria will probably be most closely related to that of the ADOL method and most relevant to the evolution of the MD virus in the field, especially when produced in MD-vaccinated chickens. Based on data from several trials, a modification of the ADOL method has been proposed that uses less chicken and can be run with commercial specific pathogen-free strains. The modified method is based on "best fit" comparisons with prototype strains and is expected to provide results generally comparable to the original method. Various other alternative criteria (see previous) are also considered, both for primary pathotyping and in addition to other pathotyping methods. Advantages and disadvantages of alternative methods are presented. © 2005 Houghton Trust Ltd.
authors: Witter, R. L.;Calnek, B. W.;Buscaglia, C.;Gimeno, I. M.;Schat, K. A.

title: Equine Parvovirus: Initial isolation and partial characterization
abstract: viral agent was isolated from the fetal liver of an aborted equine fetus. Hemagglutinated red blood cells isolated from guinea pig, rhesus monkey and rooster. Hemagglutination inhibition tests showed that the isolate was antigenically different from bovine and canine parvoviruses. Antibody that inhibits specific hemagglutination against the viral isolate was exhibited in 26 of the 136 horse sera tested. The isolated virus showed properties compatible with those of an autonomous parvovirus, including size, morphology, stability against ether treatment and heating to 56°C, presence of 5300 base DNA genome, characteristic protein composition and density (1.405 g/mL). The virus was classified as an equine parovovirus.
authors: Wong, F. C.;Spearman, J. G.;Smolenski, M. A.;Loewen, P. C.

title: Application of enteric viruses for fecal contamination source tracking in environmental waters
abstract: Microbial source monitoring (MST) tools are used to identify sources of fecal contamination in order to accurately assess public health risk and implement best management practices (BMPs). This review focuses on the potential of enteric viruses for MST applications. Following host infection, enteric viruses multiply and are excreted in high numbers in the faeces and urine of the host. Because of the specificity in host infection, enteric viruses have been recognized as one of the most accurate library-independent culture-independent MST tools. In an evaluation of molecular viral assays based on the sensitivity, specificity and density of target virus in fecal affected samples, human adenovirus and human polyoma virus were found to be the most promising human-specific viral markers. However, due to the cross-reactions observed between animal species or the limited number of samples tested for specificity, more research is needed to identify promising viral markers for farm animals. Other viral markers of fecal origin, F+ RNA coliphage and pepper light speckle virus have also been proposed as potential targets for the development of MST markers. Increasing the use of enteric viruses for MST applications through next-generation sequencing (NGS) and virus concentration technology is discussed in the second part of this review. Huge sequence databases created by shotgun and gene-targeted metagenomics enable more efficient and reliable design of MST assays. Finally, recent studies have revealed that alternative virus concentration methodologies may be more cost-effective than standard technologies such as 1MDS; however, improvements in recovery efficiency and consistency are still needed. Overall, advances in metagenomic information combined with efficient concentration methodologies, as well as high host specificity, make enteric viruses a promising tool in MST applications. © 2012 .
authors: Wong, K.;Fong, T. T.;Bibby, K.;Molina, M.

title: Cloning and sequencing of the full-length cDNA of the classic swine fever virus LPC strain
abstract: The cDNAs of the classical swine fever virus (LPC vaccine strain) were cloned by transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction and their nucleotide sequences were determined. In this study, we obtained sequence information of 786 bases of the 5â€²-terminal region, 6049 bases of the middle region, and 1648 bases of the 3â€²-terminal region. Combining our previous results and current data, the entire genomic sequence of the LPC strain was completed (12344 nucleotides long). The genome of LPC has a large open reading frame that can encode a polypeptide of 3897 amino acids and is flanked by untranslated regions (UTR), 373 bases at the 5'² end and 278 bases at the 3'² end. Phylogenetic analysis based on the genomic sequences of several viruses suggested that the LPC strain is closer to the Chinese, Riems, HCLV, Alfort/187, Brescia and Alfort strains, respectively. After further analysis, we found that 13 nucleotides, TTT(C/T)CTTTTTTTT, was added to the 3â€²-UTR of LPC, China and HCLV strains. A unique LPC sequence containing 28 thymidines was observed just downstream of 13 nucleotides.
authors: Wong, M. L.;Peng, B. Y.;Liu, J. J.;Chang, T. J.

title: Neutralizing DNA aptamers against swine flu H3N2 viruses
abstract: Pig triple reassortant influenza A viruses (IAVs), particularly the North American H3N2 subtype, circulate in pig herds and can recombine and give rise to new zoonotic strains. Current diagnostic tools rely on isolation of viruses followed by serotyping by hemagglutination or genome sequencing; both of these can be expensive and time consuming. Therefore, new subtype-specific ligands and methods are needed for rapid testing and subtyping of IAVs in the field. To meet this need, we selected recombinant HA protein versus DNA aptamers from pig IAV H3 cluster IV using systematic evolution of ligands by exponential enrichment (SELEX). Four candidate aptamers (HA68, HA7, HA2a and HA2b) have been identified and characterized. The dissociation constants (Kd) of HA68, HA7, HA2a and HA2b aptamers against the recombinant H3 protein were 7.1, 22.3, 16.0 and 3.7 nM, respectively. The binding site of HA68 to H3 was determined to be between nucleotide residues 8 and 40. All aptamers inhibited H3 hemagglutination. HA68 was highly specific to all four lineages in the North American H3N2 subtype. Furthermore, three other aptamers specifically identified live viruses belonging to phylogenetic clusters I, II/III and IV, particularly the virus closely related to the last H3N2 variant (H3N2v). Aptamer HA68 was also able to bind and detect H3N2v isolated from recent human cases. As a result, we now provide subtype-specific aptamers that can be used in rapid detection and typing protocols for field applications against H3N2 IAVs of pigs. Copyright © 2013, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Wongphatcharachai, M.;Wang, P.;Enomoto, S.;Webby, R. J.;Gramer, M. R.;Amonsin, A.;Sreevatsan, S.

title: Metagenomic analysis of viromes of dromedary stool samples reveals a large and high diversity of circovirus and picobirnavirus.
abstract: The discovery of Middle East Respiratory Coronavirus and another novel dromedary coronavirus UAE-HKU23 in dromedary animals has fueled interest in the search for new viruses in dromedary camels. In this study, faecal samples of 203 dromedary dromedaries in Dubai were pooled and deep sequenced. 1970 of the combined 7330 viral contigs were assigned to mammalian viruses. The largest groups of these contigs paired with Picobirnaviridae, Circoviridae, Picornaviridae, Parvoviridae, Astroviridae, and Hepeviridae. Many of these viral families were previously unknown to dromedaries. In addition to the high abundance of contigs from Circoviridae (n=598 14 complete genomes) and Picobirnaviridae (n=1236), a high diversity of contigs was found from these two families, and 14 Circoviridae complete genomes forming at least five clusters and both genogroup I and genogroups It continues from II, potentially from new picobirnaviruses. Further studies comparing the incidence of these viral families in healthy and sick dromedary dromedaries will reveal their pathogenic potential. (C) 2014 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
authors: Woo, P. C. Y.;Lau, S. K. P.;Teng, J. L. L.;Tsang, A. K. L.;Joseph, M.;Wong, E. Y. M.;Tang, Y.;Sivakumar, S.;Bai, R.;Wernery, R.;Wernery, U.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: High Diversity of Genogroup I Picobirnaviruses in Mammals
abstract: In a molecular epidemiology study using 791 fecal samples collected from different terrestrial and marine mammals in Hong Kong, genogroup I picobirnaviruses (PBVs) were positive by RT-PCR targeting the partial RdRp gene in samples from five cattle, six monkeys, 17 horses, and nine animals. . pig, a rabbit, a dog, and 12 California sea lions, with sequence types 11, 9, 23, 17, 1, 1, and 15, respectively, in positive samples from the corresponding animals. Phylogenetic analysis showed that PBV sequences from each animal species were widely distributed throughout the tree with high diversity, sharing 47.4–89.0% nucleotide identities with other genogroup I PBV strains based on the partial RdRp gene. Nine complete segments 1 (viral loads 1.7 x 10(4) to 5.9 x 10(6)/ml) and 15 segments 2 (viral loads 4.1 x 10(3) to 1.3 x 10(6) )/ml) otarin PBVs were sequenced from serially collected stool samples from California sea lions. In two phylogenetic trees constructed using ORF2 and ORF3 of segment 1, nine segment 1 sequences were clustered into four different clades (C1-C4). In the tree constructed using the RdRp gene of segment 2, 15 segment 2 sequences were clustered into nine different clades (R1-R9). In four sea lions, PBVs were detected in two different years, different clades were present in the same segment 1 Glade (C3) in two consecutive years from a sea lion and in different years from three sea lions. A high diversity of PBV has been observed in a variety of terrestrial and marine mammals. Multiple sequence types with significant differences were present in most of the PBV-positive samples from different animal species, representing multiple strains of PBV.
authors: Woo, P. C. Y.;Teng, J. L. L.;Bai, R.;Wong, A. Y. P.;Martelli, P.;Hui, S. W.;Tsang, A. K. L.;Lau, C. C. Y.;Ahmed, S. S.;Yip, C. C. Y.;Choi, G. K. Y.;Li, K. S. M.;Lam, C. S. F.;Lau, S. K. P.;Yuen, K. Y.

title: Analysis of Bovine viral diarrhea virus subtypes from permanently infected US cattle calves with whole genome sequence.
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is classified into 2 genotypes, BVDV-1 and BVDV-2, each containing different subtypes with genetic and antigenic variation. To effectively control BVDV through vaccination, it is important to know which subtypes of the virus are in circulation and how their prevalence has changed over time. Accordingly, the aim of our study is to estimate the current prevalence and diversity of BVDV subtypes from persistently infected (PI) cattle calves in the central United States. Phylogenetic analysis of the 5'-UTR (5' untranslated region) for 119 virus strains revealed that the majority (82%) belonged to genotype 1b, with the remaining strains distributed between genotypes 1a (9%) and 2 (8%). ; however, the BVDV-2 subtypes could not be resolved safely. Therefore, to better describe the variability of US BVDV isolates and further investigate the subtypes of BVDV-2 isolates, whole genome sequences were obtained for these isolates, as well as representatives of BVDV-1a and -1b. Phylogenetic analyzes of the complete coding sequence provided more precise genetic classification and revealed that the US BVDV-2 isolates belonged to at least 3 different genetic groups, which was statistically supported by both complete and individual coding gene analyzes. These results suggest that a more complex subtype of BVDV-2 is circulating in this region than previously thought.
authors: Workman, A. M.;Heaton, M. P.;Harhay, G. P.;Smith, T. P.;Grotelueschen, D. M.;Sjeklocha, D.;Brodersen, B.;Petersen, J. L.;Chitko-McKown, C. G.

title: Revised and updated nomenclature for highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) viruses
abstract: The heterogeneity of the hemagglutinin gene of A/goose/Guangdong/1/1996-strain H5N1 viruses in 2011 and 2012 (807 new sequences collected up to 31 December 2012) was analyzed by phylogenetic and p-distance methods to identify new generations. predetermined naming system. Eight new divisions were proposed to be assigned according to divisions 1.1 (Mekong River Delta), 2.1.3.2 (Indonesia), 2.2.2 (India/Bangladesh), 2.2.1.1 (Egypt/Israel) and 2.3.2.1 (Asia). . To facilitate this and future updates, a simplification has been proposed to previously defined criteria that adds a letter instead of a number to the rightmost digit of the fifth-degree clades.
authors: World Health Organization/World Organisation for Animal, H. F.;Agriculture Organization, H. N. E. W. G.

title: Genetic characterization of an adapted pandemic 2009 H1N1 influenza virus eliciting improved replication rates in human lung epithelial cells.
abstract: The 2009 influenza pandemic was caused by the porcine H1N1 virus, which is less pathogenic than expected but may acquire additional virulence-related mutations in the future. To estimate the potential risk, we sequentially passaged the A/Hamburg/04/2009 isolate in A549 human lung epithelial cells. After passage 6, we observed a 100-fold increased replication rate. High-throughput sequencing of viral gene segments identified five dominant mutations whose contribution to enhanced growth was analyzed by reverse genetics. An increased replication rate was noted for two mutations near the hemagglutinin (HA) gene segment (HA1 D130E, HA2 I91L), the receptor binding site, and the root domain. The adapted virus also replicated more efficiently in vivo in mice. Improved replication rate is associated with increased fusion pH of the HA protein and a decrease in receptor affinity. Our data may be relevant for the surveillance of pre-pandemic strains and the development of high titer cell culture strains for vaccine production.
authors: WÃ¶rmann, X.;Lesch, M.;Welke, R. W.;Okonechnikov, K.;Abdurishid, M.;Sieben, C.;Geissner, A.;Brinkmann, V.;Kastner, M.;Karner, A.;Zhu, R.;Hinterdorfer, P.;Anish, C.;Seeberger, P. H.;Herrmann, A.;Meyer, T. F.;Karlas, A.

title: Does complexity of rumen microbial ecology hinder methane reduction?
abstract: Ruminant animals are responsible for the production of some of the greenhouse gases, especially methane (61 Tg/year), which is believed to contribute to global warming and climate change. Methane is the end product of fermentation of plant material by the microbial ecosystem in the rumen. Methanogenesis is undertaken by the methanogenic archaea and is a mechanism by which H(2) is removed from fermentation to regenerate biochemical co-factors such as NAD+. The microbial ecosystem is very complex and includes thousands of bacterial species (10(10)-10(11) cells/ml), archaea (10(7)-10(9) cells/ml), protozoa (10(4). -10(6) cells/ml), fungi (10(3)-10(6) cells/ml), and viruses (10(9)-10(10) cells/ml), their host and each other. This ecosystem is relatively poorly understood, particularly interspecies interactions and interactions with the host. Less than 15% of the microbial species in the gastrointestinal tract have been cultured and characterized. However, knowledge about this ecosystem is accumulating, especially with the advent of molecular biology and culture-independent technologies. New high-throughput sequencing methodologies such as pyrosequencing will greatly increase the rate of information retrieval, and techniques such as Stable Isotope Probing will improve our ability to understand interspecies relationships. While we expect an increase in our knowledge of this complex ecosystem and an improved ability to predictably reduce CH(4) emissions, the use of feeds (eg cereal grains) and chemical additives (eg 2-bromo-ethane sulfonate, bromochloromethane) Achieving meaningful reductions in CH(4) emissions may be possible with advances in our knowledge of the intricacies of this complex ecosystem. This article is part of a special issue entitled: Finding the Balance Between Greenhouse Gases, Food, and Emissions in Animal Agriculture, Guest Editor TA McAllister, Chapter Guest Editors: KA Beauchemin, X. Hao, S. McGinn, and Animal Feed Science and Editor. Technology, PH Robinson. (C) 2011 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Wright, A. D. G.;Klieve, A. V.

title: Molecular characterization of H1N1 influenza A viruses from human cases in North America
abstract: While subtypes of the H1N1 influenza virus can be found in humans in North America, they are also associated with swine infection. Characterization of genotypes of viral strains in human populations is important for understanding the source and distribution of viral strains. The genomic and protein sequences of 10 isolates of influenza A (H1N1) virus that emerged in North America in 2009 were obtained from the GenBank database. To characterize the genotypes of these viruses, phylogenetic trees of PB2, PB1, PA, HA, NP, NA, NS and M genes were constructed with the Phylip3.67 program and N-Linked glycosylation sites of HA, NA, PB2, NS1 and M2. proteins were analyzed online with the NetNGlyc1.0 program. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these isolates were nearly identical but could be recombinant viruses as their genomic fragments came from different viruses. The isolates also contain a characteristic low-pathogenic amino acid motif at their HA cleavage sites (IPSIQSRa dagger"GL) and an E residue at position 627 of the PB2 protein, indicating high affinity for humans. The homologous pattern of M proteins has shown that viruses, due to mutation in the drug-susceptible region, anti-amantadine Sequence analysis of NA proteins showed that the viruses were still susceptible to the neuraminidase inhibitor drug (i.e. oseltamivir and zanamivir) because there were no mutations. These findings may further facilitate the treatment and prevention of possible disease transmission from North America to other countries.
authors: Wu, B.;Wang, C. M.;Dong, G. Y.;Luo, J.;Zhao, B. H.;He, H. X.

title: Genetic and molecular characterization of H9N2 and H5 avian influenza viruses from live poultry markets in Zhejiang Province, eastern China.
abstract: Live poultry markets (LPMs) are a major source of reclassified avian influenza viruses (AIVs) due to the density of terrestrial and aquatic poultry and the frequency of AIV infection. H9N2 viruses are common in terrestrial poultry in Asia and have been isolated from poultry epidemics worldwide. They infect both avian and mammalian species and can be important donors of genetic material to emerging human pathogens. LPMs in Zhejiang Province were investigated for AIVs from 2013 to 2014. Three hundred seventy-four (374) AIV strains were isolated from 3,328 specimens. Whole genome sequencing and phylogenetic analyzes were performed. We identified a novel H9N2 virus genotype reclassified by gene segments from Qa/HK/G1/97-like, Ck/BJ/1/94-like and Dk/HK/Y439/97-like viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes suggested that H9N2 viruses are subject to reclassification with other AIV subtypes. The results also showed that two different H5 viruses (2.3.2 and 2.3.4.6) were circulating together in Zhejiang Province. Given that reclassified H5 AIVs have been detected in geese and ducks, it is possible that apparently healthy birds contribute to the resulting H5 AIVs. Constant surveillance is required in poultry in eastern China.
authors: Wu, H.;Peng, X.;Peng, X.;Cheng, L.;Lu, X.;Jin, C.;Xie, T.;Yao, H.;Wu, N.

title: Specific microRNA library of IFN-t on bovine endometrial epithelial cells
abstract: IFN-t is secreted particularly by the conceptus in ruminant animals during early pregnancy and plays a vital role in the immunological function of pregnancy. However, its mechanism involving microRNA (miRNA) is still not well understood. Deep sequencing was used to investigate the specific miRNA library of IFN-t on bovine endometrial epithelial cells (bEECs). The results showed that 574 known bovine miRNAs and 109 new miRNAs were identified. We found 74 differentially expressed miRNAs in the experiment, including 30 commonly expressed miRNAs. Subsequently, qPCR validation of the six selected miRNAs showed that they corresponded to the sequencing data. Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genes (KEGG) pathway analysis of predicted target genes of differentially expressed miRNAs, including influenza A, herpes simplex infection, antigen processing and presentation, viral myocarditis, TNF signaling pathway, graftversus proved to be significantly enriched. - host disease and allograft rejection. These results may provide important contributions to the immune response during early pregnancy in ruminants, but further studies are needed to confirm the proposed cellular/immunological effects and the role of specific miRNA as in vivo biomarkers.
authors: Wu, H.;Zhang, T.;Ma, X.;Jiang, K.;Zhao, G.;Qiu, C.;Deng, G.

title: Common RNA replication signals exist between group 2 coronaviruses: Evidence of in vivo recombination between animal and human coronavirus molecules
abstract: The 5â€² and 3â€² UTR sequences in the coronavirus genome are known to carry cis-acting elements for DI RNA replication and possibly also virus genome replication. 5â€² UTR-adjacent encoding sequences are also thought to contain cis-effect elements. Here we identified 5â€² UTR and adjacent 289-nt sequences and 3â€² UTR sequences for six group 2 coronaviruses and compared them with each other and with three previously reported group 2 members. Extensive regions of highly similar UTR sequences were found, but regions of minor difference were also found, indicating that group 2 coronaviruses could be subdivided into bovine coronavirus (BCoV)-like (BCoV, human respiratory coronavirus-OC43, human enteric coronavirus, porcine hemagglutination). encephalomyelitis virus and equine coronavirus) and murine hepatitis virus (MHV) analogues (A59, 2 and JHM strains of MHV, puffinosis virus and rat sialodacryoadenitis virus). It has been shown previously that the 3–² UTRs of BCoV and MHV are interchangeable. Here, a reporter-containing BCoV DI RNA is shown to be transcribed by all five BCoV-like helper viruses and a representative of the MHV-like subgroup, MHV-H2 (a human cell-adapted MHV strain), indicating that group 2 is common. 5â€² and 3â€² replication signaling elements. In addition, BCoV DI RNA achieved the leader of HCoV-OC43 by leader replacement, demonstrating for the first time in vivo recombination between animal and human coronavirus molecules. These results imply that common replication signaling elements exist between group 2 coronaviruses despite a bicluster pattern within the group, and that there may be a high recombination potential among group members. authors: Wu, H. Y.;Guy, J. S.;Yoo, D.;Vlasak, R.;Urbach, E.;Brian, D. A.

title: Impact of Live Poultry Market Interventions on Influenza A(H7N9) Virus, Guangdong, China
abstract: Since March 2013, three waves of human infection with the avian influenza A(H7N9) virus have been detected in China. To investigate virus transmission within and between epidemic waves, we used surveillance data and whole-genome analysis of viruses sampled in Guangdong between 2013 and 2015. We observed a geographical shift of human A(H7N9) infections from the second wave to the third wave. Live poultry market interventions were made in epicenter cities; however, spatial phylogenetic analysis showed that third wave outbreaks in central Guangdong were most likely due to local virus persistence rather than entry from elsewhere. Although the number of clinical cases in humans decreased by 35% from the second wave to the third wave, the genetic diversity of third wave viruses in Guangdong increased. Our results highlight the epidemic risk of a region reporting relatively few A(H7N9) cases. Furthermore, our results show that live poultry market interventions cannot completely stop the persistence and spread of A(H7N9) virus.
authors: Wu, J.;Lu, J.;Faria, N. R.;Zeng, X.;Song, Y.;Zou, L.;Yi, L.;Liang, L.;Ni, H.;Kang, M.;Zhang, X.;Huang, G.;Zhong, H.;Bowden, T. A.;Raghwani, J.;He, J.;He, X.;Lin, J.;Koopmans, M.;Pybus, O. G.;Ke, C.

title: Molecular detection of hepatitis E virus in sheep from Southern Xinjiang, China.
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is an agent that causes infectious hepatitis in animals and humans in both developing and developed countries. Here, we collected 500 sheep serum and 75 raw sheep liver samples from a slaughterhouse in the southern part of Xinjiang, China, as well as 26 serum butchers from the same slaughterhouse. All serum samples were tested for anti-HEV antibody by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. Both serum and liver samples were evaluated for the presence of HEV RNA by nested polymerase chain reaction targeting partial nucleotide sequences of open reading frame 2 (ORF2). The results show that sheep seroprevalence was 35.20% (176/500) and four (5.3%Â) of 75 sheep livers showed detectable amounts of HEV RNA. The seroprevalence of the butchers was 57.7Â% (15/26). The four amplicons shared 97.8%-100% nucleotide sequence identity and had binary sequence identities of 81.6%-85.3%, 84.2%-85.3%, 82.1%-85.3%, and 84.7%-97.9%. corresponding regions of genotypes 1, 2, 3 and 4 of HEV, respectively. A phylogenetic tree was constructed based on alignments of an amplified 186-bp ORF2 sequence and corresponding reference strains. The analysis showed that the four sheep strains identified in our study formed a lineage within a genotype 4 cluster containing hb-3, bjsw1, T1, swCH189 and swCH25, all belonging to genotype 4, subtype 4d. The results showed high levels of seroconversion in sheep and suggested that sheep liver may be a source of foodborne HEV infection in humans.
authors: Wu, J.;Si, F.;Jiang, C.;Li, T.;Jin, M.

title: High-throughput sequencing of the pituitary and hypothalamic microRNA transcriptome associated with high egg production rate
abstract: Background: MicroRNAs are commonly found in viruses, plants, and animals. As endogenous small non-coding RNAs, miRNAs regulate a variety of biological processes. Tissue miRNA expression studies have discovered multiple functions for miRNAs in various tissues of chicken, but the regulation of miRNAs in the chicken pituitary and hypothalamic development regarding high and low egg laying performance remain unclear. Results: In this study, we sequenced two tissues (pituitary and hypothalamus) in 3 high and 3 low rate egg production Luhua chickens at 300 days of age using high-throughput sequencing technology. Comparing low and high rate egg laying hens, it was determined that 46 known miRNAs and 27 novel miRNAs were differentially expressed (P < 0.05). Six differently expressed known miRNAs expressed in both tissues were used for RT-qPCR validation and SNP detection. Among these, seven SNPs were found that could increase or decrease the production of mature miRNAs in two miRNA precursors (gga-miR1684a and gga-miR-1434). In addition, 124 and 30 mutually expressed miRNA-target pairs were identified by RNA-seq in pituitary and hypothalamic tissues, respectively, and randomly selected candidate miRNA and miRNA-target pairs were confirmed by RT-qPCR in Jiuyuan black chicken. The Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) roadnote showed that multiple pathways related to laying are enriched in highly egg-producing hens, including ovarian steroidogenesis and steroid hormone biosynthesis. Conclusions: These differentially expressed miRNAs and specifically predicted target genes identifying reciprocally expressed miRNA-target pairs advance studies of miRNA identification associated with miRNA function and egg production. Analysis and effects of miRNA-related SNPs have provided insights into the effects of SNPs on miRNA biogenesis and function. The data generated in this study will enable us to better understand the miRNA regulation mechanisms in the chicken laying process.
authors: Wu, N.;Zhu, Q.;Chen, B. L.;Gao, J.;Xu, Z. X.;Li, D. Y.

title: Genetic diversity of Newcastle disease viruses isolated from domestic poultry species in eastern China during 2005–2008.
abstract: Seventy-nine Newcastle disease viruses (NDV) isolated from clinical specimens of different poultry species, including chickens, pigeons (Columba livia), geese, and ostriches, in eastern China between 2005 and 2008, were biologically and phylogenetically characterized. The results showed the genetic diversity of these viruses: three class I viruses of class II circulating in chickens and one genotype I and 12 genotype II viruses were avirulent; The four genotype VIb viruses isolated from pigeons were moderately virulent; and two genotype III viruses and 57 genotype VIId viruses were highly lethal. Three class I viruses were further classified as genotypes 2 and 3. Very high F protein sequence identity of one genotype I virus with the Queensland V4 strain and 12 genotype II viruses with the La Sota strain indicated that these viruses originated from the two vaccine strains. The two genotype III viruses shared more than 99% sequence identity with the moderately virulent vaccine strain Mukteswar, but exhibited significantly higher virulence, suggesting that they evolved from the vaccinia virus and that the Mukteswar vaccine should be banned in China. Fifty-seven of the 63 virulent NDVs in this study belonged to genotype VIId, indicating its dominance in eastern China. Genotype VIId viruses can be further divided into two subgroups. Of the five NDVs isolated from pigeons, four belonged to genotype VIb, indicating host-specific preference. Both genotype VIb and VIId NDVs showed low amino acid similarity to vaccine strains currently used in China, implying an urgent need to develop better vaccines against the most common NDVs in China.
authors: Wu, S.;Wang, W.;Yao, C.;Wang, X.;Hu, S.;Cao, J.;Wu, Y.;Liu, W.;Liu, X.

title: Molecular and antigenic properties of newcastle disease virus isolated from domestic ducks in China.
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the most devastating diseases for the poultry industry. The causative agents of ND are virulent strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV), members of the genus Avulavirus in the family Paramyxoviridae. Waterfowl such as ducks and geese are generally considered potential reservoirs of NDV and may show little or no clinical signs when infected with viruses that are clearly lethal in chickens. However, outbreaks of ND in domestic waterfowl have been frequently reported in many countries over the past decade. In this study, 18 NDV strains isolated from domestic ducks in southern and eastern China between 2005 and 2013 were genetically and phylogenetically characterized. The complete genomes of these strains were sequenced and they exhibited a genome size of 15,186 nucleotides (nt), 15,192. nt and 15,198. Following the "rule of six" required for replication of NDV strains, nt. Based on the cleavage site of the F protein and pathogenicity tests in chickens, 17 of our NDV isolates were categorized as lentogenic viruses and one was characterized as velogenic virus.
