Phylogenetic analysis based on partial sequences of the F gene and whole genome sequences showed that there are at least four circulating NDV genotypes in domestic ducks; GD1, AH224 and AH209 belong to genotypes VIId, Ib and II of class II NDVs, respectively, and the remaining 15 isolates belong to genotype 1b of class I NDVs. Cross-reactive hemagglutination inhibition tests showed that the antigenic relationship between NDV strains may be related to their genotype rather than their host. These results show that although these NDV isolates are from ducks, they still do not form a phylogenetic group because they come from the same species; however, they may play an important role in promoting the evolution of NDVs.
authors: Wu, W.;Liu, H.;Zhang, T.;Han, Z.;Jiang, Y.;Xu, Q.;Shao, Y.;Li, H.;Kong, X.;Chen, H.;Liu, S.

title: DEF cells infected with virulent duck enteritis virus generate a unique viral microRNA model and a novel host microRNA set
abstract: Background: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) belongs to the Herpesviridae family and is an important epornitic agent causing economic losses in the waterfowl industry. Chinese virulent (CHv) and attenuating vaccines (VAC) are two different strains of pathogenic DEV. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a class of non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression in viral infection. However, little is known about miRNAs encoded by virulent duck enteritis virus (DEV). Results: Using high-throughput sequencing, we identified 39 mature viral miRNAs from CHv-infected duck embryo fibroblast cells. Compared to the reported 33 VAC encoded miRNAs, only 13 miRNA sequences and 22 "seed sequences" of miRNA were identical, and 8 new viral miRNAs were detected and confirmed by stem loop RT-qPCR in this study. Using RNAhybrid and PITA software, 38 CHv-encoded miRNAs were predicted to target 41 viral genes and form a complex regulatory network. Dual luciferase reporter assay (DLRA) confirmed that viral giant-miR-D8-3p can directly target the 3'-UTR of the CHv US1 gene (p < 0.05). Gene Ontology analysis on host target genes of viral miRNAs was mainly involved in biological regulation, cellular and metabolic processes. In addition, 598 new duck-encoded miRNAs were detected in this study. Thirty-eight host miRNAs showed significant differential expression after CHv infection: 13 miRNAs were up-regulated and 25 miRNAs were down-regulated, which could affect viral replication in the host cell. Results: These data suggested that CHv encodes a distinct microRNA sequence and forms a unique regulatory network compared to VAC. This is the first report of the expression profile of DEF miRNAs and an analysis of the regulatory mechanisms of these miRNAs during DEV infection. These data provide a basis for further investigation of miRNA regulatory roles in the pathogenesis of DEV infection and contribute to the understanding of CHv-host interaction at the miRNA level.
authors: Wu, X.;Jia, R.;Zhou, J.;Wang, M.;Chen, S.;Liu, M.;Zhu, D.;Zhao, X.;Sun, K.;Yang, Q.;Wu, Y.;Yin, Z.;Chen, X.;Wang, J.;Cheng, A.

title: Peste des Petits Ruminants Viruses Re-emerging in China, 2013-2014
abstract: The peste des petits ruminant (PPR) re-emerging in Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region in northwest China was officially reported in November 2013, and then with the movements of goats and sheep, this disease spread rapidly to other provinces, autonomous regions and other provinces. Chinese municipalities (P/A/M). A total of 256 districts affected by PPR were identified in 22 P/A/Ms until September 2014. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that current circulating strains and Tibetan strains previously isolated in 2007 both belong to lineage IV, but different subclades. However, compared to Tibetan strains, current circulating strains shared a high degree of genetic homology with those from Pakistan and Tajikistan.
authors: Wu, X.;Li, L.;Li, J.;Liu, C.;Wang, Q.;Bao, J. Y.;Zou, Y.;Ren, W.;Wang, H.;Zhang, Y.;Lv, Y.;Liu, F.;Wang, S.;Ma, H.;Wang, Z.

title: A Novel Capillary Electrophoresis Based High Efficiency Multiplex Polymerase Chain Reaction System for Simultaneous Detection of Nine Pathogens in Pigs
abstract: Here we aimed to develop a capillary electrophoresis-based high-throughput multiplex polymerase chain reaction (PCR) system for the simultaneous detection of nine pathogens in pigs. Nine pairs of specific primers and a set of universal primers were designed; multiplex PCR was set up. The specificity and cross-reactivity of this assay were examined and the detection limit was determined using serial 10-fold dilutions of plasmids containing the target sequences. The test was further tested using 144 clinical samples. We found that nine specific amplification peaks were observed and the assay had a high degree of specificity without non-specific amplification. The limit of simultaneous detection for the nine viruses reached 10000 copies of Î¼L-1 when all premixed viral targets were present. Seventy-seven of the clinical samples tested positive for at least one of the viruses; The main viral infections in clinical specimens were porcine circovirus type 2 and porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus. This approach has great potential for the further development of high-throughput detection tools for diagnosing diseases in animals.
authors: Wu, X. L.;Xiao, L.;Lin, H.;Yang, M.;Chen, S. J.;An, W.;Wang, Y.;Yao, X. P.;Yang, Z. X.;Tang, Z. Z.

title: Molecular characteristics of avian influenza viruses (H9N2) from air samples in live poultry markets
abstract: Objective: To examine the molecular characteristics of H9N2 subtype avian influenza viruses (AIVs) isolated from air samples collected in live poultry markets (LPMs) and to investigate their sequence identity with AIVs that cause human infection. Methods: From 2015 to 2016, weekly surveillance of LPMs airborne H9N2 subtype AIVs was performed. H9-positive samples were isolated from chicken embryos. Whole genome sequences of isolated AIVs were obtained by high-throughput sequencing. Phylogenetic analysis of sequences and key locus variations were also analyzed. Results: A total of 327 aerosol samples were collected from the LPMs. Nine samples were positive for H9-subtype AIVs based on quantitative real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (qRRT-PCR). According to whole genome sequence analysis and phylogenetic analysis, 8 gene segments belonging to 8 aerosol H9N2 isolates and 2 H9N2 human isolates were included in the same clade in 2015, except for A/Environment/Zhongshan/ZS201505/2015 (ZS201505) strain. Among key locus variations, except strain ZS201505, H9N2-subtype AIVs did not have mutations in the eight receptor binding sites of hemagglutinin (HA) and stems of neuraminidase (NA) proteins exhibited a deletion region of three bases. The PA gene of ZS201503 and ZS201602 exhibited a L336M mutation. N30D and T215A mutations in the M1 gene and amino acid residues L89V in PB2, P42S in NS1, and S31N in M2 were retained in these 9 strains of H9N2 isolates, which can increase the virulence of the virus. Result: Live H9N2 AIVs survived in the aerosol of LPMs in Zhongshan City. Aerosol viruses had a close evolutionary relationship with human epidemic strains, suggesting that there may be a risk of AIV transmission to humans from contaminated aerosols in LPMs. Mutations in H9N2-subtype AIVs isolated from air samples collected from LPMs suggested that their pathogenicity is enhanced to infect humans.
authors: Wu, Y.;Lin, J.;Yang, S.;Xie, Y.;Wang, M.;Chen, X.;Zhu, Y.;Luo, L.;Shi, W.

title: Pig epithelial cell line infected with Pseudorabies virus generates diverse host microRNAs and a specialized viral microRNA cluster
abstract: Pseudorabies virus (PRV) belongs to the subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae, which has caused great economic losses to the pig industry worldwide. It has been shown recently that many herpes viruses encode microRNAs (miRNAs) that play crucial roles in the viral life cycle. However, information on PRV-encoded miRNAs is still limited. Here, we report a comprehensive analysis of both viral and host miRNA expression profiles in the PRV-infected porcine epithelial cell line (PK-15). Deep sequencing data showed that the ~4.6 kb intron of the large latency transcript (LLT) functions as a primary microRNA precursor (pri-miRNA) encoding 11 different miRNA clusters and 209 known and 39 novel porcine miRNAs in the PRV genome. Detected. Viral miRNAs were further validated by stem loop RT-PCR and northern blot analysis. Surprisingly, all of these viral miRNAs exhibited terminal heterogeneity at both their 5' and 3' ends. Seven miRNA genes produced mature miRNAs from both strands, and two of the viral miRNA genes showed partial overlap in their leader regions. Unexpectedly, a high-abundance terminal loop-derived small RNA and a specific miRNA offset RNA (moRNA) were processed from the same viral miRNA precursor. Polymorphisms of viral miRNAs shed light on the complexity of host miRNA processing machinery and viral miRNA regulatory mechanism. Pig genes and PRV genes were collected for target prediction of viral miRNAs, revealing a complex network formed by both host and viral genes. GO enrichment analysis of host target genes indicates that PRV miRNAs are involved in complex cellular pathways including cell death, immune system process, metabolic pathway, and that these miRNAs play important roles in virus-cell interaction of PRV and its hosts. Collectively, these data suggest that the PRV-infected epithelial cell line generates diverse host miRNAs and a specialized viral miRNA cluster that can facilitate PRV replication in cells.
authors: Wu, Y. Q.;Chen, D. J.;He, H. B.;Chen, D. S.;Chen, L. L.;Chen, H. C.;Liu, Z. F.

title: Discovery of various rodent and bat pestiviruses with different genomic and phylogenetic features in various Chinese provinces
abstract: Bats and rodents are widely distributed worldwide and may be natural or intermediate reservoirs of many important zoonotic viruses. Pestiviruses are a group of virus species of the genus Pestivirus under the family Flaviviridae and can infect a wide variety of artiodactyly hosts, including pigs and ruminants. Two classical pestivirus strains, bovine viral diarrhea virus and classic swine fever virus are major causative agents of mild to severe disease in cattle and swine hosts, respectively, causing enormous economic losses to these industries. Recent reports revealed that bats and rodents can also act as natural hosts of pestiviruses, and that an atypical porcine pestivirus that causes disease in piglets shows a close genetic relationship with a specific bat pestivirus, RaPestV-1. This study aimed to describe the detection and characterization of new pestiviruses from bats and rodents in different localities by analyzing available bat and rodent viroma data from across China. Two strains of bat pestiviruses and four strains of rodent pestiviruses different from other known viruses were identified and sequenced. These viruses were detected from two bat species and four rodent species in different provinces of China. Two different strains were present in these viruses that differed from the artiodactylous pestivirus. These findings expand our understanding of the genetic diversity of pestiviruses in bats and rodents and suggest the existence of a diverse set of pestiviruses in non-artiodactyly hosts. This study may provide new insights for the prevention of future viral disease outbreaks from bats and rodents.
authors: Wu, Z.;Liu, B.;Du, J.;Zhang, J.;Lu, L.;Zhu, G.;Han, Y.;Su, H.;Yang, L.;Zhang, S.;Liu, Q.;Jin, Q.

title: Deciphering the bat virus catalog to better understand the ecological diversity of bat viruses and the bat origin of emerging infectious diseases
abstract: Studies have shown that ~60-80% of human-emergent infectious diseases (EIDs) are caused by wildlife. Bats are natural reservoirs for a wide variety of viruses, including many important zoonotic viruses that cause serious illness in humans and pets. However, understanding of the viral population and ecological diversity found in bat populations is unclear, making it difficult to determine the origins of certain EIDs. Here, virome analysis was performed based on pharyngeal and anal swab samples of 4440 bat individuals from 40 large bat species across China, using bats as a typical wildlife reservoir model. The aim of this study is to investigate the ecological and biological diversity of viruses living in these bat species, to investigate the existence of potential zoonotic viruses originating from bats, and to evaluate the effects of these viruses on public health. Data from this study provided an overview of the viral community found in these bat samples. Many new bat viruses have been reported for the first time, and some bat viruses closely related to known human or animal pathogens have been identified. This genetic evidence provides new clues in investigating the origin or evolution pattern of certain viruses, such as coronaviruses and noroviruses. These data offer meaningful ecological information for estimating and monitoring wildlife-derived EIDs.
authors: Wu, Z.;Yang, L.;Ren, X.;He, G.;Zhang, J.;Yang, J.;Qian, Z.;Dong, J.;Sun, L.;Zhu, Y.;Du, J.;Yang, F.;Zhang, S.;Jin, Q.

title: Virome Analysis for Detection of Novel Mammalian Viruses in Bat Species from Chinese Provinces
abstract: Bats are natural hosts for a wide variety of zoonotic viruses. This study aimed to describe the range of bat viruses, including viruses from mammals, insects, fungi, plants, and phages in 11 insectivorous bat species (216 bats in total) common in six provinces of China. We used sequence-independent PCR amplification and next-generation sequencing technology (Solexa Genome Analyzer II; Illumina) to analyze viromes. Viromes were identified by sequence similarity comparisons with known viruses. Mammalian viruses include Adenoviridae, Herpesviridae, Papillomaviridae, Retroviridae, Circoviridae, Rhabdoviridae, Astroviridae, Flaviridae, Coronaviridae, Picornaviridae, and Parvovirinae; insect viruses include viruses of Baculoviridae, Iflaviridae, Dicistroviridae, Tetraviridae and Densovirinae; fungal viruses belonging to Chrysoviridae, Hypoviridae, Partitiviridae and Totiviridae; and phages included Caudovirales, Inoviridae and Microviridae and unclassified phages. We identified the complete or partial genome sequences of 13 novel mammalian viruses, in addition to viruses and phages associated with insects, plants, and bacterial flora associated with bat diet and habitat. These include herpesviruses, papillomaviruses, a circovirus, a bocavirus, picornaviruses, a pestivirus, and a foamy virus. Pairwise alignments and phylogenetic analyzes showed that these new viruses showed little genetic similarity to previously reported viruses. This study also revealed high prevalence and diversity of bat astroviruses and coronaviruses in some provinces. These findings expanded our understanding of bat viruses in China and pointed to the existence of a wide variety of unknown mammalian viruses in many common bat species in mainland China.
authors: Wu, Z. Q.;Ren, X. W.;Yang, L.;Hu, Y. F.;Yang, J.;He, G. M.;Zhang, J. P.;Dong, J.;Sun, L. L.;Du, J.;Liu, L. G.;Xue, Y.;Wang, J. M.;Yang, F.;Zhang, S. Y.;Jin, Q.

title: Investigation of virome of cattle with non-suppurative encephalitis of unknown etiology by metagenomics.
abstract: Non-suppurative encephalitis is one of the most common pathological diagnoses in cattle with neurological disease, but there is a lack of knowledge about disease-associated pathogens. To identify viruses associated with non-suppurative encephalitis in cattle, we used a viral metagenomic approach in a sample set of 16 neurologically diseased cows. We identified six virus candidates: parainfluenza virus 5 (PIV-5), bovine astrovirus CH13/NeuroS1 (BoAstV-CH13/NeuroS1), bovine polyomavirus 2 (BPyV-2 SF), ovine herpesvirus 2 (OvHV-2), bovine herpesvirus 6 (BHV-6) and a new bovine betaretrovirus named BoRV-CH15. In a case-control study using PCR, BoAstV-CH13 (p=0.046), BoPV-2 SF (p=0.005) and BoHV-6 (p=4.3E-05) were statistically associated with disease. These data expand our knowledge of pathogens associated with encephalitis in cattle and point to the value of NGS in solving complex infection scenarios in a clinical disease setting.
authors: WÃ¼thrich, D.;Boujon, C. L.;Truchet, L.;Selimovic-Hamza, S.;Oevermann, A.;Bouzalas, I. G.;Bruggmann, R.;Seuberlich, T.

title: At rhinovirus serotypes 1 and 2: Relationship with each other and with aftoviruses and cardioviruses
abstract: Equine rhinoviruses (ERVs) are picornaviruses that cause a mild respiratory infection in horses. The disease is similar to the common cold in humans caused by rhinoviruses; however, the presence of a viremia during ERV-1 infection, the occurrence of persistent infections, and the physical characteristics all more closely resemble foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV). CDNA cloning and sequencing of the ERV-1 and ERV-2 genomes between the poly(C) and poly(A) pathways showed that the serotypes were heterogeneous. However, the genomic architecture of both serotypes is most similar to that of FMDV. Indeed, a comparison of ERV-1-derived protein sequences shows that their identity is the largest FMDV. In contrast, most ERV-2 proteins are more associated with encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) proteins than with FMDV or ERV-1. These results place ERV-1 next to FMDV in the aphthovirus genus of the picornavirus family and indicate that this virus may serve as a model system for studying FMDV biology.
authors: Wutz, G.;Auer, H.;Nowotny, N.;Grosse, B.;Skern, T.;Kuechler, E.

title: Sequence analysis of human virus in children with and without fever
authors: Wylie, K. M.;Mihindukulasuriya, K. A.;Sodergren, E.

title: Virome genomics: a tool to identify the human virome
authors: Wylie, K. M.;Weinstock, G. M.;Storch, G. A.

title: Enhanced virome sequencing using targeted sequence capture
authors: Wylie, T. N.;Wylie, K. M.;Herter, B. N.;Storch, G. A.

title: Comparative Transcriptomics Highlights Role of Activator Protein 1 Transcription Factor in Host Response to Ebola Virus
abstract: Ebolavirus and Marburgvirus contain two types of negative-sense single-stranded RNA viruses that cause severe hemorrhagic fevers in humans. Despite significant research efforts, the molecular events following Ebola virus (EBOV) infection are poorly understood. To identify host factors promoting EBOV pathogenesis, we compared the transcriptomes of EBOV-infected human, porcine, and bat kidney cells using a transcriptome sequencing (RNA-seq) approach. Despite a significant difference in viral transcription/replication between cell lines, all cells responded to EBOV infection through a potent induction of extracellular growth factors. Furthermore, a significant increase in activator protein 1 (AP1) transcription factor complex members FOS and JUN was observed in the allowed cell lines. Functional studies focusing on human cells have shown that EBOV infection induces protein expression, phosphorylation and nuclear accumulation of JUN and, to a lesser extent, FOS. Using a luciferase-based reporter, we show that EBOV infection induces AP1 transactivation activity in human cells at 48 and 72 hours post infection. Finally, we show that JUN knockdown reduces the expression of EBOV-induced host gene expression. Taken together, our study highlights the role of AP1 in developing the host gene expression profile that defines EBOV pathogenesis.IMPORTANCE Many questions remain about the molecular events underlying filovirus pathophysiology. The rational design of new intervention strategies, such as post-exposure therapeutics, will be significantly enhanced by an in-depth understanding of these molecular events. We believe that new insights into the molecular pathogenesis of EBOV may be possible by examining the transcriptomic response of taxonomically diverse cell lines (derived from human, pig, and bat). We first identified the responsive pathways using an RNA-seq-based transcriptomic approach. Further functional and computational analyzes focusing on human cells highlighted an important role of the AP1 transcription factor in mediating the transcriptional response to EBOV infection. Our work sheds new light on how host transcription factors respond to and support the transcriptional landscape following viral infection.
authors: Wynne, J. W.;Todd, S.;Boyd, V.;Tachedjian, M.;Klein, R.;Shiell, B.;Dearnley, M.;McAuley, A. J.;Woon, A. P.;Purcell, A. W.;Marsh, G. A.;Baker, M. L.

title: Microbiological safety of the first clinical trial of porcine islet xenotransplantation in New Zealand
authors: Wynyard, S.;Nathu, D.;Garkavenko, O.

title: Molecular phylogenetic analysis of bovine viral diarrhea virus: Bayesian approach
abstract: Genetic typing of bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) is important for the precise classification of viruses. Traditionally, the inferred BVDV phylogeny has been performed by the distance-based method, that is, by neighbor splicing for single genes. In this study, Bayesian approach was used to analyze the five genetic regions of the BVDV genome (5-² UTR, Npro, E2a, E2b and NS3) for 68 taxa from GenBank. The results showed that all taxa in the consensus tree of E2a were correctly assigned to the corresponding groups, namely type-2 BVDV and BVDV-1a, -1b, -1c, -1e and -1g, supported by a high posterior probability. . In contrast, subgroup 1a formed polytomies in the consensus trees of the 5â€² UTR and NS3. Polytomies also emerged between subgroup 1b in consensus trees of Npro and E2b. Analysis of a combined dataset produced a clear, well-supported phylogenetic hypothesis. The individual and combined topologies were different for each genetic region, but the differences were mainly poorly supported by the data. Combining the data allowed the identification of well-supported strain groups corresponding to some predefined subgroups. Only a combined approach will allow the safe insertion of new strains into the current classification of viruses as genotypes and subgenotypes. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Xia, H.;Liu, L.;Wahlberg, N.;Baule, C.;BelÃ¡k, S.

title: Sequence analysis of peste des petits ruminant virus from mountain goats in Xinjiang, China
abstract: Peste des petits ruminants (PPR) is an infectious disease caused by the peste des petits ruminant virus (PPRV). While PPR mainly affects domestic goats and sheep, it also affects wild ungulates such as mountain goats, blue sheep and gazelles, although there are few reports of PPRV infection in the wild. Between January 2015 and February 2015, wild ibex were found to have died from PPRV infection for the first time in Bazhou, Xinjiang, China, where a total of 38 ibex (including juvenile and adult ibex) were found to have died from PPR abnormally. related topics. First, we tested the presence of the F gene of PPRV by RT-PCR. Next, we compared the sequence of the F gene isolated from the mountain goat strain named PPRV Xinjiang/Ibex/2015 with that detected from small domestic ruminants and other areas in the nearby localities where the previously reported isolate was collected. The current sequence was phylogenetically classified as a strain IV virus and shared a high level of sequence identity (99.7%) with a previously described Xinjiang PPRV isolate.
authors: Xia, J.;Zheng, X. G.;Adili, G. Z.;Wei, Y. R.;Ma, W. G.;Xue, X. M.;Mi, X. Y.;Yi, Z.;Chen, S. J.;Du, W.;Muhan, M.;Duhaxi, C.;Han, T.;Gudai, B.;Huang, J.

title: Spread of Newcastle disease viruses from poultry to wild birds in southern China's Guangdong province
abstract: Despite intensive vaccination programs in many countries, including China, Newcastle disease has been sporadically reported and remains a significant threat to the poultry industry in China. Newcastle disease virus (NDV) is contagious to at least 250 bird species, but the role of wild birds in virus epidemiology is largely unknown. 14 NDV isolates were obtained from 2040 samples collected from wild birds or the environment between 2013 and 2015 in southern China's Guangdong province. The highest rate of isolation is during the wintering period, while the lowest is spring migration, nesting and postnesting. Maximum clade reliability phylogenetic analysis revealed that at least four genotypes circulate in southern China: three class II genotypes (II, VI, and IX) and one class I (1b). We also showed that most isolates from wild birds were quite similar to isolates from poultry, and two isolates were associated with viruses from wild birds in northern China. These data suggested that wild birds could spread NDV and that poultry-derived viruses could spread to wild birds. Accordingly, vaccine development and poultry management strategies should be considered to prevent future NDV outbreaks, especially given the strength of the poultry industry in developing countries such as China.
authors: Xiang, B.;Han, L.;Gao, P.;You, R.;Wang, F.;Xiao, J.;Liao, M.;Kang, Y.;Ren, T.

title: Cloning and structural analysis of the Chinese mouse genomic nucleophosmin gene
abstract: Nucleophosmin (NPM) is an abundant nucleolar phosphoprotein. Chromosomal translocations in the NPM gene were found in patients with anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL), myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), acute myeloid leukemia (AML), and acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). To generate NPM gene knockout mice and examine its biological function in vivo, we screened the lambda phage genomic library derived from 129S1 mice with the mouse NPM cDNA probe. A positive phage clone containing full-length NPM genomic DNA was obtained and the insert of 15.3 kb genomic DNA in this clone was sequenced by shotgun method. BLAST analysis showed that the insertion sequence was 99.8% identity to that of the NPM gene of the C57BL/6 mouse strain. Based on the sequence, bioinformatic analysis was performed on the genomic structure of NPM and transcription factor binding sites in the NPM 5' flank region.
authors: Xiang, Y. G.;Lu, S. Y.;Gu, M. M.;Wang, S. Y.;Ren, S. X.;Fu, G.;Wang, Z. G.

title: Characterization of porcine parvovirus type 2 (PPV2), which is highly prevalent in the USA
abstract: novel porcine parvovirus, designated porcine parvovirus 2 (PPV2), was first identified in Myanmar in 2001, in China during 2006-2007, and in Hungary in 2012. To investigate the presence and prevalence of PPV2 in the USA, a novel TaqManÂ® real-time PCR method was developed and used for a PPV2 study using 483 lung samples, 185 fecal samples, and 122 serum from pigs from 295 farms in 18 US states. The overall prevalence of PPV2 was 20.7% (100/483) in lung samples and 7.6% (14/185) in stool samples from pigs of different age groups and 1.6% (2/122) in serum or chest fluids derived from them. was. newborn pigs. Further genomic sequence comparisons show that the 2011 US PPV2 sequences have 95.4-97.7% nucleotide identities with the 2006-2007 strains detected in China, 94.7% with the 2001 strain detected in Myanmar, and this showed the persistent evolution of the virus. Phylogenetic and sequence homology analyzes have shown that PPV2 is closely related to members of the proposed PARV4-like virus, and it is recommended that PPV2 be classified within this proposed genus. © 2012 Elsevier BV
authors: Xiao, C. T.;Gerber, P. F.;GimÃ©nez-Lirola, L. G.;Halbur, P. G.;Opriessnig, T.

title: Molecular evolutionary genetic analysis of emerging parvoviruses identified in pigs
abstract: Parvoviruses infect a wide variety of vertebrates and arthropods and are associated with a variety of clinical manifestations. Due to the emergence of new sequence-independent PCR methods and high-throughput sequencing, several new parvovirus members within the Parvovirinae subfamily have been recently identified. Many of these viruses do not fit into the current classification, and others now have confusing or conflicting designations, as two or more names are used for similar or identical groups of parvoviruses, or the same names are used for different groups of viruses. In this study, recently described vertebrate parvoviruses were classified through phylogenetic analyzes based on the sequences of their complete or near-complete genomes, with emphasis on those identified in pigs, open reading frame (ORF) 1 (nonstructural protein, NS1), ORF2 (capsid protein, VP1) and ORF3 (nuclear phosphoprotein, NP1) genes were investigated using Bayesian Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), Maximum Likelihood (ML) and Neighbor-Joining (NJ) methods. Among all existing vertebrate parvovirus lines, eight different clades were identified, corresponding to the five well-established genera Parvovirus, Erythrovirus, Denpendovirus, Amdovirus and Bocavirus. In addition, three new segments of the PARV4-like virus, new segment 1 and new segment 2, were identified and tentatively identified. All porcine parvoviruses identified to date were organized according to the available analysis. The current analysis will help clarify the nomenclature of parvoviruses in pigs and facilitate future uniform assignment of names for novel parvoviruses within the Parvovirinae subfamily. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Xiao, C. T.;Halbur, P. G.;Opriessnig, T.

title: Identification and classification of endogenous retroviruses in cattle
abstract: The aim of this study was to identify endogenous retrovirus (ERV) sequences in a bovine genome. We subjected bovine genomic DNA to PCR with degenerate or ovine ERV (OERV) family-specific primers aimed at amplifying the retroviral pro/pol region. Sequence analysis of 113 clones obtained by PCR revealed that 69 of them were of retroviral origin. On the basis of the OERV classification system, these clones from degenerate PCR can be divided into Î²3, Î³4 and Î³9 families. PCR with primers specific to the OERV family revealed an additional ERV classified within the bovine endogenous retrovirus (BERV) Î³7 family. In conclusion, we report here the results of a genome-scale study of BERV. While our study indicates that ERV family expansion in cattle may be somewhat limited, more diverse family members of ERVs have been reported from other artiodactyls such as pigs and sheep. Copyright © 2008, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Xiao, R.;Park, K.;Lee, H.;Kim, J.;Park, C.

title: Understanding PRRSV infection in pig lung based on genome-wide transcriptome response identified by deep sequencing.
abstract: Pig reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) has been one of the most economically important diseases affecting the pig industry worldwide and causes huge economic losses every year. PRRS virus (PRRSV) replicates mainly in porcine alveolar macrophages (PAMs) and dendritic cells (DCs) and develops persistent infections, antibody-dependent potentiation (ADE), interstitial pneumonia, and immunosuppression. However, the molecular mechanisms of PRRSV infection are still not fully understood. Here we report the first genome-wide host transcriptional responses to infection of the classical North American type PRRSV (N-PRRSV) strain CH 1a using the digital gene expression (DGE) system of Solexa/Illumina, a tag-based high-throughput transcriptome sequencing method. and systematically analyzes the relationship between pulmonary gene expression profiles and infection pathology after N-PRRSV infection. Our results demonstrate that N-PRRSV employs multiple strategies for its replication and dissemination in infected pigs, including disrupting the host innate immune response, inducing an anti-apoptotic and anti-inflammatory state, as well as developing ACE. Expression of virus-induced pro-inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, adhesion molecules and inflammatory enzymes and upregulation of inflammatory cells, antibodies, complement activation was likely to result in the development of inflammatory responses during N-PRRSV infection processes. N-PRRSV-induced immunosuppression may be mediated by apoptosis of infected cells, which causes depletion of immune cells and induces an anti-inflammatory cytokine response that they are unable to eliminate the primary infection. Our systems analysis will be of benefit to better understand the molecular pathogenesis of N-PRRSV infection, develop new antiviral therapies, and identify genetic components for susceptibility to swine resistance/PRRS. © 2010 Xiao et al.
authors: Xiao, S.;Jia, J.;Mo, D.;Wang, Q.;Qin, L.;He, Z.;Zhao, X.;Huang, Y.;Li, A.;Yu, J.;Niu, Y.;Liu, X.;Chen, Y.

title: Abnormal host immune response induced by highly virulent PRRSV identified by digital gene expression tag profiling
abstract: Background: There was a large-scale outbreak of highly pathogenic swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS) in China and Vietnam in 2006 and 2007, resulting in unusually high morbidity and mortality among pigs of all ages. The mechanisms underlying the molecular pathogenesis of the highly virulent PRRS virus (H-PRRSV) are unknown. Therefore, the association between pulmonary gene expression profiles and infection pathology after H-PRRSV infection was analyzed in this study using high-throughput deep sequencing and histopathology. Results: H-PRRSV infection caused severe lung pathology. The results suggest that the induction of aberrant host innate immune responses against H-PRRSV and an anti-apoptotic state may be responsible for the aggressive replication and spread of H-PRRSV. Prolific rapid replication of H-PRRSV may have triggered aberrant sustained expression of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines, resulting in a markedly robust inflammatory response combined with significant cell death and increased oxidative damage. The result was severe tissue damage and high pathogenicity. Conclusions: The systems analysis used in this study provides a comprehensive basis for better understanding the pathogenesis of H-PRRSV. It also enables the identification of genetic components related to H-PRRSV resistance/susceptibility in swine populations. © 2010 Xiao et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Xiao, S.;Mo, D.;Wang, Q.;Jia, J.;Qin, L.;Yu, X.;Niu, Y.;Zhao, X.;Liu, X.;Chen, Y.

title: Reverse Genetic Creation of an Effective, Stable, Live-Atenuated Newcastle Disease Virus Vaccine Based on an Currently Circulating, Highly Virulent Indonesian Strain
abstract: Newcastle disease virus (NDV) can cause serious illness in chickens. Although NDV vaccines are available, there are frequent reports of outbreaks in vaccinated chickens. In 2009-2010, despite intensive vaccination, NDV caused major outbreaks among commercial poultry farms in Indonesia. These outbreaks have raised concerns about the protective immunity of current vaccines against virulent strains circulating in Indonesia. In this study, we investigated whether a recombinant attenuated Indonesian NDV strain could provide better protection against common Indonesian viruses. A reverse genetics system was constructed for the highly virulent NDV strain Banjarmasin/010/10 (Ban/010) isolated in Indonesia in 2010. Ban/010 virus is classified in genotype VII of class II NDV, which is genetically different from commercial vaccine strains B1 and LaSota belonging to genotype II and shares only 89% and 87% amino acid identity for the protective antigens F and respectively. HN. A mutant virus named Ban/AF was developed, in which the lethal F protein cleavage site motif "RRQKRâ†"F" was modified to an avirulent motif "GRQGRâ†"L" with three amino acid substitutions (underlined). Ban/AF vaccinia virus did not infect or produce plaques in cell culture even in the presence of added protease. Pathogenicity tests showed that Ban/AF was completely avirulent. Ban/AF was efficiently amplified and remained genetically stable in chickens during 10 consecutive passages. Serological analysis showed that Ban/AF induced higher neutralization and hemagglutination inhibition antibody titers against common viruses than commercial vaccines B1 or LaSota. Both Ban/AF and commercial vaccines protected against clinical disease and mortality after challenge with the virulent NDV strain Ban/010 (genotype VII) or GB Texas (genotype II). However, Ban/AF significantly reduced virus transmission from vaccinated birds compared to B1 vaccine. These results suggest that Ban/AF may provide better protection than commercial vaccines and is a promising vaccine candidate against NDV strains circulating in Indonesia.
authors: Xiao, S.;Nayak, B.;Samuel, A.;Paldurai, A.;Kanabagattebasavarajappa, M.;Prajitno, T. Y.;Bharoto, E. E.;Collins, P. L.;Samal, S. K.

title: Design and validation of a universal influenza virus enrichment probe set and its use in deep array analysis of primary cloacal swab surveillance samples from wild birds
abstract: Influenza virus infections in humans and animals are important public health problems. In the current study, a set of universal influenza enrichment probes was developed to increase the sensitivity of sequence-based virus detection and characterization for all influenza viruses. This universal influenza enrichment probe set contains 46,953 120nt RNA biotin-labeled probes designed based on all available influenza viral sequences and can be used to enrich influenza sequences without prior type or subtype knowledge. Significant enrichment was demonstrated in influenza A/H1N1, influenza B, and H1-to-H16 hemagglutinin plasmids inserted into human DNA, and cultured influenza A/H2N1 virus. In addition, enrichment effects and mixed influenza A virus infections were revealed in wild bird cloacal swab samples. Therefore, this universal influenza virus enrichment probe system can selectively and effectively capture and enrich influenza viral sequences in different samples, especially those with gradient RNA or those containing low amounts of influenza RNA.
authors: Xiao, Y.;Nolting, J. M.;Sheng, Z. M.;Bristol, T.;Qi, L.;Bowman, A. S.;Taubenberger, J. K.

title: Characterization of Fecal Virus and Fecal Virus Shedding Patterns of Commercial Mink (Neovison vison)
authors: Xie, X. T.

title: Analysis of miRNA expression profile in an Aedes albopictus cell line in response to bluetongue virus infection.
abstract: Cellular microRNAs (miRNAs) have been reported to be key regulators of virus-host interactions. Bluetongue virus (BTV) is an insect-borne virus that causes great economic losses to the livestock industry worldwide. Aedes albopictus cell lines have become powerful and useful tools for studying BTV-vector interactions. However, the role of miRNAs in A. albopictus cells during BTV infection is not well understood. In this study, we performed a deep sequencing analysis of small RNA libraries of BTV-infected and mock-infected A. albopictus cells, and a total of 11,206,854 and 12,125,274 clean reads were identified, respectively. A differential expression analysis showed that 140 miRNAs, including 15 known and 125 novel miRNAs, were significantly dysregulated after infection, with a total of 414 and 2307 target genes annotated, respectively. Real-time quantitative reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction confirmed the expression patterns of 11 selected miRNAs and their mRNA targets. Functional annotation of target genes suggested that these target genes are mainly involved in metabolic pathways, oxidative phosphorylation, endocytosis, RNA transport as well as FoxO, Hippo, Jak-STAT and MAPK signaling pathways. This is the first systematic study of the effect of BTV infection on miRNA expression in A. albopictus cells. This research provides information on the cellular miRNA expression profile in response to BTV infection and provides clues to identify potential candidates for vector-based antiviral strategies.
authors: Xing, S.;Du, J.;Gao, S.;Tian, Z.;Zheng, Y.;Liu, G.;Luo, J.;Yin, H.

title: First identification of swine parvovirus 7 in China
abstract: Porcine parvovirus (PPV) are small, non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA viruses that can be taxonomically classified within the Parvoviridae family. To date, seven PPV genotypes (PPV1 to PPV7) have been identified. PPV7, the most recently discovered PPV genotype, was first reported in US pigs in 2016. To investigate the status of PPV7 in Chinese pig populations, a total of 64 serum samples collected from two commercial farms in Guangdong province in 2014 were analyzed. PPV7 DNA was detected in 32.8% (21/64) of the samples tested. In the pig circovirus type 2 (PCV2) positive farm, the prevalence rate of PPV7 was 65.5% (19/29); this was significantly higher than in the PCV2 negative farm (2/35, 5.7%), suggesting a possible association between them. PCV2 and PPV7 infections. The sequences of the three PPV7 strains were determined. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the identified strains of PPV7 circulating in China shared 98.7%-99.7% nucleotide homology with the US strain. Further sequence comparison analysis showed that GD-2014-2 and GD-2014-3 had sequential 9-nt deletion in the VP gene. This is the first report of the presence of PPV7 in China, and this finding will strengthen the understanding of the epidemiology of porcine parvovirus in Chinese pigs.
authors: Xing, X.;Zhou, H.;Tong, L.;Chen, Y.;Sun, Y.;Wang, H.;Zhang, G.

title: Investigation of Pig Endogenous Retrovirus in the Conservation Population of Ningxiang Pig
abstract: Pig endogenous retrovirus (PERV) differs between pig breeds. Screening and analysis of PERV in putative pig breeds can provide key parameters for assessing the biological safety of xenotransplantation from pigs to humans. In this study, PERV was investigated among the conservation population of Ningxiang pig. The result was that the genotype of the PERV distribution was subtype A, 100%; subtype B, 100%; and subtype C, 100%. The env sequences of PERV-A and -B showed 11 clones detected by KpnI and MboI digestion, indicating multiple variants of PERV-A and -B in Ningxiang pig. Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction results showed that PERV had transcriptional activity in these individuals. In addition, PERV A/C recombinant was detected in most individuals of Ningxiang pig. The strain may not be a suitable donor for xenotransplantation, as PERV A/C recombinants increase the potential risk of infection. Crown Copyright © 2009.
authors: Xing, X. W.;Hawthorne, W. J.;Yi, S.;Simond, D. M.;Dong, Q.;Ye, B.;Tong, Q. J.;Ye, Z.;Wang, W.

title: Detection and phylogenetic analysis of porcine bocaviruses carried by murine rodents and house mice in China.
abstract: Bocaparvovirus infections in humans and both wild and domestic animals have been widely reported worldwide. In this study, we detected and genetically characterized the porcine bocavirus (PBoV) carried by mouse rodents (Rattus norvegicus, Rattus grainzumi and Rattuslosa) and house mice (Suncus murinus) in China. Between May 2015 and May 2017, 496 murine rodents and 23 house mice were caught in four provinces of China. Nested polymerase chain reaction was used to investigate the prevalence of PBoV in throat swab, stool and serum samples. A total of 7.5% (39/519) throat swab samples, 60.5% (309/511) stool samples and 22.9% (52/227) serum samples were PBoV-positive. The prevalence among R. nor norvegicus and R. tane grainzumi was higher than that of R. Los Losa and house shrews. PBoV positive samples were found in all four provinces. Phylogenetic analysis based on partial viral capsid protein 1/2 (VP1/VP2) showed that the sequences obtained in this study formed a new group (PBoV G4). In addition, close to five full-length PBoV genomes (4,715–4,798Â nt) were obtained. These genomes encoded two nonstructural proteins, NS1 (1,908Â nt in four genomes and 1,923Â nt in the remaining genome) and NP1 (600Â nt), and the structural proteins, VP1/VP2 (1,851Â nt). Phylogenetic analysis showed that PBoV G4 differed from rodent, human and other bocaviruses. In conclusion, the prevalence of PBoV G4 was high among the two common murine rodents in China, and the pathogenicity of PBoV G4 needs further clarification.
authors: Xiong, Y. Q.;You, F. F.;Chen, X. J.;Chen, Y. X.;Wen, Y. Q.;Chen, Q.

title: Metagenomic analysis of the Rhinopithecus bieti fecal microbiome reveals a wide variety of bacterial and glycoside hydrolase profiles related to lignocellulose degradation.
abstract: BACKGROUND: The animal gastrointestinal tract contains a complex microbe community whose composition ultimately reflects the co-evolution of microorganisms with their animal hosts and the diet adopted by the host. Although the importance of the human gut microbiota has been well demonstrated, there is little research on non-human primates (NHPs), particularly herbivorous NHPs. RESULTS: In this study, 97,942 pyrosequencing reads generated from Rhinopithecus bieti fecal DNA extracts were analyzed to aid in a better understanding of the microbial diversity and functional capacity of the R. bieti gut microbiome. Taxonomic analysis of metagenomic reads indicated that the R. bieti stool microbiome was dominated by the phyla Firmicutes, Bacteroidetes, Proteobacteria, and Actinobacteria. Comparative analysis of taxonomic classification revealed that the R. bieti metagenome is characterized by an overrepresentation of bacteria from the phylum Fibrobacteres and Spirochaetes compared with other animals. The primary functional categories were mainly associated with protein, carbohydrates, amino acids, DNA and RNA metabolism, cofactors, cell wall and capsule and membrane transport. Comparison of the glycoside hydrolase profiles of R. bieti with those of other animals revealed that the R. bieti microbiome is most closely related to the cow rumen. RESULTS: Metagenomic and functional analysis showed that R. bieti has a wide bacterial diversity and multiple glycoside hydrolases responsible for lignocellulosic biomass degradation, which may reflect adaptations associated with a diet rich in fiber. These results will contribute to the limited number of NHP metagenome studies and provide a unique genetic source of plant cell wall-degrading microbial enzymes. However, future studies on metagenome sequencing of R. bieti regarding the effects of age, genetics, diet, and environment on the composition and activity of metagenomes are needed.
authors: Xu, B.;Xu, W.;Li, J.;Dai, L.;Xiong, C.;Tang, X.;Yang, Y.;Mu, Y.;Zhou, J.;Ding, J.;Wu, Q.;Huang, Z.

title: Hybrid DNA virus in Chinese patients with seronegative hepatitis discovered by deep sequencing
abstract: Seronegative hepatitis – non-A, non-B, non-C, non-D, non-E hepatitis – is poorly characterized but strongly associated with serious complications. Between 1999 and 2007, we collected 92 serum samples from patients with non-AE hepatitis in Chongqing, China. Ten serum pools were scanned by Solexa deep sequencing. We discovered a 3,780-bp contig found in all 10 pools that gave BLASTx E scores of 7e-05-0.008 against parvoviruses. The full sequence of the in silico-assembled 3,780-bp contig was confirmed by gene amplification of overlapping regions over nearly the entire genome, and the virus was tentatively named NIH-CQV. Further analysis revealed that the contig consists of two main ORFs. With the BLAST protein, ORF1 and ORF2 were most homologous to the replication-associated protein of bat circovirus and the capsid protein of porcine parvovirus, respectively. Phylogenetic analysis showed that NIH-CQV is located at the interface of Parvoviridae and Circoviridae. The prevalence of NIH-CQV in patients was determined by quantitative PCR. Sixty-three (70%) of 90 patient samples were positive, but all from 45 healthy controls were negative. The mean virus titer in patient samples was 1.05 e4 copies/microL. Specific antibodies against NIH-CQV were searched by immunoblotting. Eighty-four percent of patients were positive for IgG and 31% were positive for IgM; in contrast, 78% of healthy controls were positive for IgG, but all were negative for IgM. Although further studies are needed to determine the etiological role of NIH-CQV in human disease, our data suggest that a parvovirus-like virus is highly prevalent in a cohort of patients with non-AE hepatitis.
authors: Xu, B.;Zhi, N.;Hu, G.;Wan, Z.;Zheng, X.;Liu, X.;Wong, S.;Kajigaya, S.;Zhao, K.;Mao, Q.;Young, N. S.

title: Comprehensive serological profiling of human populations using a synthetic human virome
authors: Xu, G. J.;Kula, T.;Xu, Q.;Li, M. Z.;Vernon, S. D.

title: Transcriptome analysis of orf3-expressing HepG2 cells from porcine hepatitis e virus to determine the effects of ORF3 on host cells
abstract: Hepatitis E virus- (HEV-)-mediated hepatitis has become a global public health problem. ORF3, an important regulatory protein of HEV, affects multiple signaling pathways in host cells. In this study, to investigate the function of ORF3 from the porcine form of HEV (SHEV), high-throughput RNA-Seq-based screening was performed to identify differentially expressed genes in ORF3-expressing HepG2 cells. The results were validated by quantitative real-time PCR and gene ontology was used to assign differentially expressed genes into functional categories. The results showed that in resident ORF3-expressing HepG2 cells, mRNA levels of CLDN6, YLPM1, APOC3, NLRP1, SCARA3, FGA, FGG, FGB and FREM1 were upregulated, whereas SLC2A3, DKK1, BPIFB2, and PTGR1 were downregulated. Deregulated expression of CLDN6 and FREM1 may contribute to changes in integral membrane protein and basement membrane protein expression, expression changes for NLRP1 may affect apoptosis of HepG2 cells, and altered expression of APOC3, SCARA3 and DKK1 may affect lipid metabolism in HepG2. cells. In conclusion, ORF3 plays a functional role in virus-cell interactions by affecting the expression of integral membrane protein and basement membrane proteins and altering the process of apoptosis and lipid metabolism in host cells. These findings provide important insights into the pathogenic mechanism of HEV.
authors: Xu, K.;Guo, S.;Zhao, T.;Zhu, H.;Jiao, H.;Shi, Q.;Pang, F.;Li, Y.;Li, G.;Peng, D.;Nie, X.;Cheng, Y.;Wu, K.;Du, L.;Cui, K.;Zhang, W.;Wang, F.

title: Isolation and genetic analysis of a novel triple reassortant H1N1 influenza virus from a pig in China
abstract: Influenza A viruses of the H1N1 subtype have been widely reported in association with clinical disease in pigs in China. These mainly include the classic porcine H1N1, bird-like H1N1 and human-like H1N1 viruses. In this study, we reported a novel triple reassortant H1N1 virus (A/swine/Guangdong/1/2010) containing classical porcine (NP, NS), human (PB1) and avian (HA, NA, M, PB2) genes. , PA) strains were first reported in China. Moreover, phylogenetic analysis further confirmed that five gene segments (NS, NP, PB2, PB1, PA) of the isolate were closely related to the novel reassortant H1N2 viruses isolated in 2006 in China, while the other three (HA, NA, M) were. It was closely related to the bird-like H1N1 viruses in China. Isolation of triple reassortant H1N1 influenza virus provides further evidence that pigs serve as exit hosts or "scrambling vessels," and high priority should be given to swine flu virus (SIV) surveillance in China. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Xu, M.;Huang, Y.;Chen, J.;Huang, Z.;Zhang, J.;Zhu, Y.;Xie, S.;Chen, Q.;Wei, W.;Yang, D.;Huang, X.;Xuan, H.;Xiang, H.

title: Characteristics of highly virulent infectious bursal disease viruses isolated from Chinese broilers (2012-2013)
abstract: The aim of this study is to characterize infectious bursal disease viruses (IBDVs) circulating in broiler farms in China between 2012 and 2013. The VP2 gene sequences of nine newly isolated IBDVs obtained using reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction were determined and compared. with previously well-characterized worldwide reference isolates. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that nine broiler IBDV isolates were closely related to the highly virulent IBDV (vvIBDV) strains. Analysis of the predicted amino acid sequences of VP2 from nine vvIBDV isolated from broilers revealed that they shared 99.2 to 100% sequence similarity. In addition, amino acids A222, I242, I256, I294, and S299 of VP2, which are conserved among previously characterized vvIBDV strains, are also encoded by nine isolates. This study confirms that the circulation of vvIBDVs in Chinese broiler farms is slowly evolving and is relatively stable in China.
authors: Xu, M. Y.;Lin, S. Y.;Zhao, Y.;Jin, J. H.;Tang, N.;Zhang, G. Z.

title: Epidemiological and Evolutionary Inference of the 2014 Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza H5N2 Outbreak Transmission Network in British Columbia, Canada
abstract: The first North American epidemic of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) involving a virus of the Eurasian A/goose/Guangdong/1/1996 (H5N1) lineage began in the Fraser Valley, British Columbia, Canada, in late November 2014. commercial and 1 non-commercial (backyard) business were infected before the epidemic ended. Control measures included movement restrictions placed in a total of 404 individual buildings, 150 of which were located within a 3 km radius of the infected building(s). A full epidemiological investigation revealed that the source of this HPAI H5N2 virus and the only non-commercial IP for 4 of the commercial IPs most likely involved indirect contact with wild birds. Three IPs were associated with movement of birds or service providers, and local/environmental spread was suspected as a source of infection for the remaining 4 IPs. Viral phylogenies determined by Bayesian Inference and Maximum Likelihood methods were used to validate the epidemiologically inferred transmission network. The phylogenetic clustering of the assembled viral genomes and the median-confluent phylogenetic network of viruses mostly supported the transmission network that was drawn from the epidemiological analysis.
authors: Xu, W.;Berhane, Y.;DubÃ©, C.;Liang, B.;Pasick, J.;VanDomselaar, G.;Alexandersen, S.

title: A new Enterovirus 96 circulating in China causes hand, foot, and mouth disease
abstract: Enterovirus 96 (EV-96) is a recently identified member of the Enterovirus C strain and is associated with paralysis and myelitis. In this study, we identified a novel strain of enterovirus 96 (EV-96-SZ/GD/CHN/2014) as the sole pathogen causing hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) using metagenomic sequencing. A genomic comparison showed that EV-96-SZ/GD/CHN/2014 was most similar to strain EV-96-05517 (85% identity) also detected in Guangdong Province. This is the first time that metagenomic sequencing has been used to identify an EV-96 strain shown to be associated with HFMD.
authors: Xu, Y.;Sun, Y.;Ma, J.;Zhou, S.;Fang, W.;Ye, J.;Tan, L.;Ji, J.;Luo, D.;Li, L.;Li, J.;Fang, C.;Pei, N.;Shi, S.;Liu, X.;Jiang, H.;Gong, S.;Xu, X.

title: H9N2 influenza virus isolated from minks increased virulence in mice
abstract: H9N2 is one of the major subtypes of influenza virus circulating in poultry in China, which has a wide host range from birds to mammals. Two H9N2 viruses were isolated from a mink farm in 2014. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the internal genes of H9N2 viruses are closely related to those of H7N9 viruses. Interestingly, two H9N2s were separated in the phylogenetic trees, suggesting that they were introduced to this mink farm on two independent events. And further mouse studies showed that one H9N2 caused marked weight loss and 20% death in infected mice, while another virus did not cause any clinical signs in infected mice at the same dose. Genetic analysis showed that the lethal H9N2 contains a natural mutation in the PB2 protein 701N, which has been reported to contribute to mammalian adaptation. However, there is no such substitution in mouse avirulent H9N2. The circulation of H9N2 in mink may direct the virus to adapt mammals; Constant surveillance of the influenza virus in the mink is guaranteed.
authors: Xue, R.;Tian, Y.;Hou, T.;Bao, D.;Chen, H.;Teng, Q.;Yang, J.;Li, X.;Wang, G.;Li, Z.;Liu, Q.

title: Sequence and phylogenetic analysis of surface protein genes of emerging H9N2 influenza viruses isolated from poultry in two geographic regions of China.
abstract: The H9N2 subtype avian influenza viruses (AIVs) circulating in China have raised growing concern about their effects on poultry and their risk to public health. This study was an attempt to elucidate the phylogenetic relationship of H9N2 AIVs in two geographically diverse regions of China where vaccination is routinely practiced. A total of 18 emerging H9N2 isolates were identified and genetically characterized. Phylogenetic analysis of the hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes confirmed that the isolates belonged to the Y280 lineage. The isolates were divided into two subgroups according to their HA genes. Viruses from Zhejiang Province clustered together in Group I, while isolates from Guangdong Province clustered together in Group II. Antigenic characterization showed that the tested viruses were antigenically different compared to the currently used vaccine strain. It was noteworthy that 14 out of a total of 18 isolates had an amino acid substitution (Q?L) in the receptor binding site at position 216 (226 with H3 Numbering), suggesting that the virus has potential affinity for binding to the human-like receptor. . These results suggest that emerging viruses pose greater public health risks than previously thought. Therefore, continuous surveillance studies of the H9N2 influenza virus are crucial for the prognosis and control of future influenza pandemics. Â© Springer Science+Business Media 2014.
authors: Xue, Y.;Wang, J. L.;Yan, Z. Q.;Li, G. W.;Chen, S. Y.;Zhang, X. B.;Qin, J. P.;Li, H. Y.;Chang, S.;Chen, F.;Bee, Y. Z.;Xie, Q. M.

title: Isolation and characterization of Oya virus, a member of the Simbu serogroup, Bunyaviridae family, isolated from Karnataka, India.
abstract: During a research on Japanese encephalitis (JE) in Kolar district of Karnataka state of India in 1986; Two virus isolates were obtained from a pig and a human serum sample in infant Swiss albino mice. For the characterization of these virus isolates, they were propagated in Vero CCL-81 cells. These virus isolates were screened and found negative for flaviviruses (Japanese encephalitis, West Nile, Dengue, Kyasanur forest disease) and Alphavirus (Chikungunya) by RT-PCR. They were also screened for bunyaviruses using genus-specific primers. A virus isolate from a human sample was sequenced using next-generation sequencing; He defined it as Oya virus, which is the Simbu group of the Orthobunyavirus genus of the Bunyaviridae family. Phylogenetic analysis of L, M, S (N and NSs) revealed close association of Oya virus in Simbu serogroup with the Chinese strain with a distance of 6.5%>4.2>3.2% for nucleotides and 2.4>0.8>0.0% for amino acid. . L>M>S segments respectively. According to the PCR results; One isolate from the pig sample was also confirmed as Oya virus. This study was strengthened by the findings of IgG antibody positivity against Oya virus in retrospective serum samples of suspected febrile disease cases from this region with a locally developed ELISA. Oya virus positivity was also recorded in human samples collected from Karnataka using nested RT-PCR. This is the first report of the presence of Oya virus in human samples. Further studies are needed to determine its potential to cause disease in humans.
authors: Yadav, P.;Shete, A.;Bondre, V.;Patil, D.;Kokate, P.;Chaudhari, S.;Srivastava, S.;Jadhav, S.;Mourya, D.

title: Molecular analysis of the genome of Chuzan virus, a member of Palyam serogroup viruses, and phylogenetic relationships with other orbiviruses.
abstract: The nucleotide sequence of the entire genome of Chuzan virus, which belongs to Palyam serogroup orbiviruses and causes congenital abnormalities in cattle, was completed by analysis of genes encoding minor core proteins (VP1, VP4 and VP6) and nonstructural proteins (NS1, NS2 and NS3). The genome of Chuzan virus is 18,915 bp long and the coding capacity of open reading frames is 6071 aa. Comparative sequence analysis with other serogroups of the Orbivirus genus showed that the neutralizing antigen, the outer capsid protein VP2, appeared to be the most variable, and the main core protein VP3 was the most conserved. In general, structural proteins, except VP2, are more conserved among orbiviruses than nonstructural proteins. Chuzan virus is phylogenetically most closely related to African horse sickness virus.
authors: Yamakawa, M.;Kubo, M.;Furuuchi, S.

title: Genomic analyzes of bovine viral diarrhea viruses isolated from cattle imported into Japan between 1991 and 2005.
abstract: Thirty-one bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) isolates isolated from cattle imported by the Japanese Animal Quarantine Service (AQS) over the past 15 years were used in this study, in which a 5â€² untranslated region of each isolate was genetically analyzed. . Of the 31 isolates, 26 were classified as BVDV1 and the remainder as BVDV2. Phylogenetic analysis of RT-PCR fragments amplified from isolates showed the presence of viruses belonging to BVDV1a, BVDV1b, BVDV1c, unclassified BVDV1 genotypes and BVDV2. Of the 17 isolates from Australian cattle, 16 were classified as BVDV1c. This result was in line with a report showing that BVDV1c was a dominant subgenotype in Australia. Both BVDV1 and BVDV2 strains were found in cattle from North America. From North American cattle, BVDV2 was identified as the same cluster as the BVDV 890 strain, the prototype of BVDV2. These results indicate that BVDVs isolated from cattle exported in the AQS reflect the dominant genotypes of BVDVs found in exporting countries. The Chinese unclassified BVDV1 genotype was in the same cluster as the ZM-95 strain isolated from pigs in China. In this study, the genomic characteristics of 31 BVDV isolates collected in AQS were investigated. We conclude that the isolates are genetically heterogeneous but geographically limited. Information from this report will be useful when conducting epidemiological studies of BVDV isolated in Japan. Â© 2007 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Yamamoto, T.;Kozasa, T.;Aoki, H.;Sekiguchi, H.;Morino, S.;Nakamura, S.

title: Three male patients with sporadic acute hepatitis E domestically infected with genotype III or IV hepatitis E virus in Sendai, Japan
abstract: Recent research shows that hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection occurs not only in developing countries but also in industrialized countries. However, the characteristics of domestic infections of hepatitis E in Japan are not fully understood. We analyzed serum samples from 34 patients diagnosed with sporadic acute hepatitis of non-A, non-B, and non-C etiology, seen at a city hospital in Sendai, Japan, between January 1997 and December 2002. . Of these 34 patients, 3 (9%; all men; 54, 59, and 61 years old) were positive for both IgG and IgM anti-HEV antibodies and HEV RNA. HEV isolates (HE-JAS1 and HE-JAS3) from case 1 and case 3, respectively, were divided into genotype III; They both had the highest nucleotide sequence identity of 99.5% and 99.0%, respectively, with HE-JA7 and HE-JA8 isolated in Iwate, a neighboring province of Sendai. In contrast, the remaining HEV isolate (HE-JAS2) from case 2 was differentiated into genotype IV; had the highest nucleotide sequence identity of 99.8% and 99.3% with JKK-Sap and HE-JA3, respectively, both isolated in Hokkaido, Japan, but case 2 had never been found in Hokkaido. Three of our patients with hepatitis E had not traveled abroad, had contact with pigs or had a history of blood transfusion in the last 1 year. These results show that HEV should be considered as the etiologic agent of acute hepatitis with non-A, non-B, and non-C etiology in Japan. The risk factor(s) for contracting domestic HEV infection in Japan needs to be clarified in future studies. © Springer-Verlag 2004.
authors: Yamamoto, T.;Suzuki, H.;Toyota, T.;Takahashi, M.;Okamoto, H.

title: Characterization of variant infectious bursal disease virus using vaccinated sentinel chickens from a broiler farm in Japan.
abstract: We attempted the isolation of variant infectious bursal disease (IBD) viruses using sentinel chickens immunized with inactivated classical-type IBD vaccine. Vaccinated sentinel chickens and unvaccinated sentinel chickens with high neutralizing antibodies were bred with broilers on a commercial farm. Severe atrophy of the bursa of Fabricius was observed in unvaccinated sentry chickens from the second week after cohabitation. However, atrophy was observed in vaccinated sentry chickens and broilers from the third week after cohabitation. IBD virus (IBDV) isolated from Fabricius bursa of vaccinated sentry chickens, designated IBDV TY2 strain, showed severe atrophy of the bursa in infected SPF chickens. Antiserum for strain IBDV TY2 showed higher neutralizing activity against heterologous IBDV strains than antiserum against strain K strain vaccinia virus. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the nucleotide sequences encoding the hypervariable region of virus protein 2 of strain IBDV TY2 do not cluster with the classical, variant, or highly lethal IBDV groups. Based on these results, we propose that the IBDV TY2 strain could generate a new IBDV variant type.
authors: Yamazaki, K.;Ohta, H.;Kawai, T.;Yamaguchi, T.;Obi, T.;Takase, K.

title: Hepatitis E Virus in Yellow Cattle, Shandong, East China
authors: Yan, B.;Zhang, L.;Gong, L.;Lv, J.;Feng, Y.;Liu, J.;Song, L.;Xu, Q.;Jiang, M.;Xu, A.

title: Phylogenetic analysis of the S1 gene of infectious bronchitis virus isolates from China
abstract: Between 2006 and 2009, seven infectious bronchitis (IB) virus (IBV) strains were isolated from vaccinated chicken flocks at different poultry farms in China. Pathogenic characters of seven IBV strains were evaluated. Each of the seven strains was infective for the test chickens and could induce an immune response. Results from chicken embryo cross-neutralization experiments showed that these strains H120, M41, Conn and Gray were antigenically different from classical IBV strains. Compared with the H120 vaccine strain, point mutations, short insertions and deletions occurred at multiple positions in the S1 protein of seven strains. Five of the seven strains had the same motif (HRRRR) as that of the epidemic IBV strains in China. Two new motifs (HRLRR and RRIRR) emerged in the isolated strains. The homology of the nucleotide and amino acid sequences of the S1 gene among the seven isolates was 81.7-99.7% and 79.0-99.4%, respectively. These seven strains were also genetically different from the vaccine strains and non-Chinese IBV strains, but were closely related to a large number of Chinese strains. Seven isolates and 36 reference IBV strains clustered in six different groups (IVI). Seven strains were categorized into groups I, II, and III, forming a large phylogenetic branch closely related to Chinese IBVs, while VI. The vaccine strains belonging to the group are genetically far from groups I, II and III. The results of this study show that different strains of IBV circulate together in the chicken population in China. Â© American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Yan, F.;Zhao, Y.;Yue, W.;Yao, J.;Lv, L.;Ji, W.;Li, X.;Liu, F.;Wu, Q.

title: Failed detection of bovine viral diarrhea virus 2 subgenotype a (BVDV-2a) by direct fluorescent antibody test on tissue samples due to reduced reactivity of field isolates to crude anti-BVDV antibody
abstract: Bovine viral diarrhea virus 1 (BVDV-1) is associated with mild or subclinical infections, while BVDV-2 is often involved in severe thrombocytopenia and acute fatal disease outbreaks. In this study, carcass samples of a bovine cow and tissue samples of a calf were taken for laboratory diagnosis. Both animals exhibited severe clinical signs consistent with thrombocytopenia or hemorrhagic syndrome. The direct fluorescent antibody test (DFAT) failed to detect the BVDV antigen in the tissue samples of both cases. However, immunohistochemistry (IHC) revealed the presence of BVDV antigen in the oral and esophageal mucosa and Peyer patches of bovine cows. Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (real-time RT-PCR) detected BVDV-2 in selected tissues of both animals. Subsequently, BVDV was isolated from both cases and subjected to genetic and serological characterizations. Mutations in the 5'-untranslated genomic region (5'-UTR) primer and probe binding sites and in the E2 gene were associated with reduced efficiency of an established real-time RT-PCR assay and amino acid changes in the E2 glycoprotein, respectively. Both viral isolates were classified as BVDV-2 subgenotype a by real-time RT-PCR and phylogenetic analysis. Unlike the BVDV reference strains Singer and 125c, the isolates cross-reacted with anti-BVDV-1 and anti-BVDV-2 reference sera showing antigenic variations in field isolates. The isolates also showed low reactivity to porcine anti-BVDV antiserum (crude serum used to produce BVDV DFA conjugate). In summary, data from the present study demonstrated that genetic and antigenic variations affect the performance of detection assays, particularly DFAT, highlighting the need for regular evaluation and modification of BVDV tests.
authors: Yan, L.;Pace, L. W.;Baughman, B.;Wilson, F. D.;Zhang, S.;Zhang, M. Z.

title: Genome-wide identification of copy number variations between two chicken lines that differ in genetic resistance to Marek's disease.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Copy number variation (CNV) is an important source of genome polymorphisms that directly contribute to phenotypic variation, such as resistance to infectious diseases. Lines 63 and 72 are highly inbred experimental chicken lines that differ greatly in susceptibility to Marek's disease (MD) and are widely used in efforts to identify the genetic and molecular basis of genetic resistance to MD. Using next-generation sequencing, we present a genome-wide assessment of CNVs potentially associated with genetic resistance to MD. METHODS: Three randomly selected chickens from each line were arrayed to an average depth of 20x. Two popular software, CNVnator and Pindel, were used to separately call genomic CNVs. The results were combined to obtain a combined set of genomic CNVs in the two chicken lines. RESULTS: After combining the two datasets, a total of 5,680 CNV regions (CNVRs) were identified, of which 1,546 and 1,866 were MD resistant or susceptible line specific, respectively. More than half of the line-specific CNVRs were shared by 2 or more chickens, reflecting reduced diversity in both self-raised lines. CNVRs fixed in susceptible lines were significantly enriched in genes involved in the MAPK signaling pathway. We also found 67 CNVRs overlapping with 62 genes previously shown to be strong candidates of the underlying genes responsible for susceptibility to MD. CONCLUSIONS: Our findings provide new insights into the genetic architecture of the two chicken lines and additional evidence that the MAPK signaling pathway may play an important role in the host response to MD virus infection. The rich source of line-specific CNVs is valuable for future disease-related association studies in two chicken lines.
authors: Yan, Y.;Yang, N.;Cheng, H. H.;Song, J.;Qu, L.

title: Isolation and Characterization of a Novel Tembusu Virus Circulating in Muscovy Ducks in Southern China
abstract: Duck Tembusu virus (DTMUV) is an infectious pathogen that can cause epidemics in laying ducks. Here we isolated and characterized a DTMUV, designated GDLH01, which has been thought to be responsible for the noticeable egg drop in flocks of Muscovy ducks in Southern China since 2011. The genome sequence of GDLH01 shared 97-99% homology with other avian Tembusu viruses, and 99.5% homology with the mosquito-borne strain SDMS recently reported in China. Phylogenetic analysis based on the nucleotide sequence of the entire open reading frame confirmed that the isolate was of avian origin and closely related to a mosquito-borne strain. Our findings characterize a novel Tembusu virus circulating in Muscovy ducks in southern China and highlight the importance of strengthening biosecurity measures and developing vaccines to prevent the spread of this viral pathogen.
authors: Yan, Z.;Shen, H.;Wang, Z.;Lin, W.;Xie, Q.;Bi, Y.;Chen, F.

title: Sequence analysis of the middle RNA segment of three Simbu serogroup viruses, Akabane, Aino and Peaton viruses.
abstract: Sequence analysis was performed for the media (M) RNA segment of Akabane virus (AKAV), Aino virus (AINV) and Peaton virus (PEAV) of the Simbu serogroup of the Orthobunyavirus genus of the Bunyaviridae family. The complementary sequences of the M RNA segments of AKAV, AINV, and PEAV contain a single large open reading frame (ORF), like other orthobunyaviruses. ORFs potentially encode 1401 amino acids (aa), 1404 aa and 1400 aa polypeptides, respectively. The identity of the M segment among these viruses is quite low, but previous researchers have reported that the small RNA segments are highly conserved. Because the M segment encodes the viral surface glycoproteins G1 and G2, the variability of the M segment may affect the antigenicity of these viruses. Phylogenetic studies based on M and S segment sequences suggested that genetic reclassification occurred among the ancestral viruses of the three Simbu serogroup viruses during their evolution. (C) 2003 Elsevier Science BV All rights reserved.
authors: Yanase, T.;Yoshida, K.;Ohashi, S.;Kato, T.;Tsuda, T.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of swine pegivirus in pigs in the United States
abstract: Porcine pegivirus (PPgV) was first identified and genetically characterized in the United States. Further screening using RT-PCR revealed that 24 (15.1%) of 159 serum samples were positive for PPgV. Future studies are needed to understand the clinical effects of the virus.
authors: Yang, C.;Wang, L.;Shen, H.;Zheng, Y.;Bade, S. A.;Gauger, P. C.;Chen, Q.;Zhang, J.;Guo, B.;Yoon, K. J.;Harmon, K. M.;Main, R. G.;Li, G.

title: Newcastle disease virus isolated from recent outbreaks in Taiwan is phylogenetically related to viruses (genotype VII) from recent outbreaks in Western Europe
abstract: Three major Newcastle disease (ND) outbreaks have occurred in Taiwan over the past three decades (in 1969, 1984, and 1995). Newcastle disease viruses (NDVs) isolated in three outbreaks, along with those isolated in 1998, were sequenced between nucleotides 47 and 435 of the fusion gene. A phylogenetic tree based on the sequences obtained showed that NDV isolated in 1969 was similar to genotype III viruses. In contrast, all isolates in 1984 and seven out of eight isolates in 1995 entered genotype VII with all isolates in 1998. These results show that the 1969 ND outbreak in Taiwan was caused by the genotype III virus, while the 1984 and 1995 outbreaks were caused by the genotype VII viruses. To date, genotype VII viruses have caused many epidemics in East Asia and Western Europe. We suspect that these outbreaks constitute the fourth panzootic of ND, which differs from the third panzootic caused by "pigeon PMV-1 viruses". NDV, isolated in Taiwan in 1984, was the earliest isolation of genotype VII virus.
authors: Yang, C. Y.;Shieh, H. K.;Lin, Y. L.;Chang, P. C.

title: Genetic analysis of H3N2 avian influenza viruses isolated from live poultry markets and poultry slaughterhouses in Shanghai, China, in 2013.
abstract: Five H3N2 avian influenza viruses (AIVs) were isolated from live poultry markets (LPMs) and poultry slaughterhouses in Shanghai, China, in 2013. All viruses were characterized by whole genome sequencing with subsequent genetic comparison and phylogenetic analysis. The hemagglutinin cleavage site of all viruses indicated that five strains were low pathogenic AIVs. Phylogenetic analysis of all eight viral genes showed that five H3N2 viruses clustered in the Eurasian influenza viruses lineage. Eight genes showed evidence of reclassification events between these H3 subtype viruses and other subtype viruses, particularly H5 and H7 subtypes, possibly pigeons, domestic ducks and wild birds. These findings highlighted the importance of AIV surveillance in LPMs and poultry slaughterhouses to understand the formation and emergence of new reassortants with pandemic potential.
authors: Yang, D.;Liu, J.;Ju, H.;Ge, F.;Wang, J.;Li, X.;Zhou, J.;Liu, P.

title: Phylogenetic Characterization Genome Segment 2 of Bluetongue Virus Strains of Serotypes 5, 7, and 24 Isolated in China for the First Time in 2012-2014
abstract: Bluetongue is endemic in China and Bluetongue virus (BTV) belongs to eight different serotypes (BTV-1, BTV-2, BTV-3, BTV-4, BTV-9, BTV-12, BTV-15 and BTV-16). ) was isolated between 1996 and 1997. However, there has been a long pause in research into the epidemiology of BTV infection since then. During 2012-2014, eight BTV strains belonging to serotypes 5, 7 and 24 were isolated from the blood of sentry animals for the first time in Yunnan and Guangdong provinces. Phylogenetic analyzes of genome segment 2 of these Chinese BTV strains grouped them together with reference strains of the same serotype in nucleotypes E, F, and A, respectively. For each serotype, the Chinese strains cluster closely together to form a Chinese subclade. Additionally, these strains were most closely related to African strains, indicating that they may have recently shared a common ancestry with African strains. To our knowledge, strains BTV-5, BTV-7 and BTV-24 were isolated for the first time in Southeast Asia. These data will be useful to understand the epidemiology of BTV and to develop diagnostic analyzes and control measures against bluetongue in China and its neighboring countries in the Asia-Pacific region.
authors: Yang, H.;Xiao, L.;Wang, J.;Meng, J.;Lv, M.;Liao, D.;Song, J.;Gao, L.;Xiong, H.;He, Y.;Niu, B.;Chuang, X.;Li, H.

title: Isolation and genomic characterization of a novel chicken-derived orthreovirus causing gossip hepatitis.
abstract: serious infectious disease characterized by nephritis, hepatitis and splenitis has attacked geese in China's Shandong province since 2016. A novel avian orthoreovirus (ARV) of chicken origin was isolated from affected geese with Reo/Goose/SDPY/1116/17 LMH cells. (SDPY-ARV) strain and infection were successfully reproduced experimentally. ARV-SDPY whole genome sequencing was performed on the Illumina HiSeq platform using Next Generation Sequencing (NGS). The complete genome of SDPY-ARV was 23,427 bp long and consisted of 10 dsRNA segments ranging from 1192 bp (S4) to 3958 bp (L1) encoding 12 viral proteins. Genomic sequence analysis revealed that the SDPY-ARV strain is in the same branch as broiler, pheasant ARV isolates and shares 51.8-96.2% of the nucleotide identity of the sigmaC gene with them; in waterfowl isolates, it is only 49.3-50.3%. In addition, 10 segment genetic reassortment of SDPY strain has been confirmed to occur between strains PA15511, 1733 and PA13649 from the USA. In conclusion, the causative agent of gosling hemorrhagic necrotic hepatitis and nephritis in China is a new chicken-derived goose orthreovirus.
authors: Yang, J.;Tian, J.;Chen, L.;Tang, Y.;Diao, Y.

title: Isolation and genomic characterization of gosling gout caused by a novel goose astrovirus
abstract: Gout, a serious infectious disease characterized by bleeding and kidney swelling, has affected geese in major goose-producing regions in China since November 2016. A new strain of goose astrovirus (AStV) (AStV-SDPY), designated AStV/SDPY/Goose/1116/17, was isolated from diseased geese and experimental breeding of gout using the AStV-SDPY strain was successful. In addition, AStV-SDPY was performed for whole-genome sequencing characterization using next-generation sequencing (NGS) technique on the Illumina HiSeq platform.
