A complete genome of AStV-SDPY was 7,252 nt in length and encoded three viral proteins. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that strain AStV-SDPY belonged to an independent branch of avian astroviruses and that the nucleotide homology between AStV-SDPY and other classical avian astrovirus strains was only 48.8%-68.2%.
authors: Yang, J.;Tian, J.;Tang, Y.;Diao, Y.

title: Molecular characterization of avian influenza virus (H7N8) isolated from poultry in central China in the mid-1980s.
abstract: The molecular and pathogenic properties of avian influenza virus (A/duck/Hubei/216/1985/H7N8) isolated from Hubei Province of China in 1985 were characterized. The hemagglutinin gene (HA) of Dk/Hb/216/85/H7N8 had multiple amino acid sequences (-PEIPKGRG-) in the junctional peptide between HA1 and HA2, which is considered a distinctive molecular feature of low pathogenicity. Key regions of host markers among the genes of Dk/Hb/216/85/H7N8 (M, NP, NS, PA and PB2) were similar to those of H5N1 viruses. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the Dk/Hb/216/85/H7N8 genes (M, NS and PB2) clustered closely with the Gs/Guangdong/1996/H5N1 (Gs/GD/96) genes, suggesting that three ancient genes of Gs implied that. Viruses like /GD/96 were circulating in central China in the 1980s. In experimental infection, Dk/Hb/216/85/H7N8 was low pathogenic to chickens and mice, consistent with the molecular feature of the HA gene.
authors: Yang, J. L.;Xia, H.;Zhao, J. R.;He, X. B.;Pan, L. M.;Tang, S. A.;Zhang, Z.;Kou, Z.;Li, T. X.

title: Genomes and seroprevalence of severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome virus and Nairobi sheep disease virus in Haemaphysalis longicornis ticks and goats in Hubei, China.
abstract: Ticks are medically important arthropods that protect and transmit numerous emerging viruses. China suffers severely from tick-borne viral diseases such as tick-borne encephalitis and severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome (SFTS), but the background of tick-borne viruses is very limited. Here we report the virome profile of ticks and goat sera from SFTS-outbreak areas and the serological investigation of SFTS virus (SFTSV) and Nairobi sheep disease virus (NSDV). The results revealed different viruses in the sera of ticks and goats, including SFTSV and NSDV. Sequence and phylogenetic analyzes showed that SFTSV described here was most closely related to human SFTSV in the sampling and surrounding areas, and NSDV to NSDV previously identified from northeast China. Serological investigation of SFTSV infection in goats revealed intense activity in these areas. Surprisingly, two different NSDV serological research methods showed no sera positive for this virus.
authors: Yang, L. E.;Zhao, Z.;Hou, G.;Zhang, C.;Liu, J.;Xu, L.;Li, W.;Tan, Z.;Tu, C.;He, B.

title: Western Human Spread of High Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H7N9) Virus, China
abstract: We report human transmission of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H7N9) virus in Shaanxi, China, in May 2017. We obtained complete genomes for samples from 5 patients and from live poultry markets or farms in 4 cities.
authors: Yang, Q.;Shi, W.;Zhang, L.;Xu, Y.;Xu, J.;Li, S.;Zhang, J.;Hu, K.;Ma, C.;Zhao, X.;Li, X.;Liu, F.;Tong, X.;Zhang, G.;Yu, P.;Pybus, O. G.;Tian, H.

title: A new rodent Chapparvovirus in the feces of wild rats
abstract: Chapparvovirus, a recently identified new genus in the Parvoviridae family, can infect many animal species, including bats, chickens, and pigs. Here, using the viral metagenomic method, we identified a novel Chapparvovirus from feces of wild rats and designated it as rat parvovirus 2 (RPV2). The nearly complete genome of RPV2 is 4222-nt long and contains two ORFs encoding 654-aa nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) and 472-aa capsid protein (VP), respectively. Phylogenetic analysis on the amino acid sequence of NS1 revealed that RPV2 forms a separate segment with Eidolon helvum parvovirus 2 (EHPV2), porcine parvovirus 7 (PPV7) and Turkey parvovirus 1 (TP1). Sequence analysis showed that the NS1 protein of RPV2 shares the highest amino acid sequence identity (51%) with that of EHPV2. According to criteria based on genetic distance, RPV2 identified here belongs to a novel Chapparvovirus strain.
authors: Yang, S.;Liu, Z.;Wang, Y.;Li, W.;Fu, X.;Lin, Y.;Shen, Q.;Wang, X.;Wang, H.;Zhang, W.

title: Domestic mink, a new bocavirus from China
abstract: Bocaviruses have been found in the feces of humans and various animals, including pigs, cattle, dogs, gorillas, cats and sea lions. Here, we characterized the nearly complete genome (5224 nt) of a novel bocavirus from feces of domestic mink, tentatively termed mink bocavirus. The NS1 protein of mink bocavirus shared 36.9-52A amino acid sequence identity with those of other known bocaviruses and clustered phylogenetically with bocaviruses from other carnivores. According to criteria based on genetic distance, mink bocavirus qualifies as a new bocavirus species. PCR of faeces from a group of domestic mink containing both healthy animals and animals suffering from diarrhoea revealed 30Â (9/30%) shedding of virus. However, a relationship between viral shedding and the presence of diarrhea could not be determined.
authors: Yang, S.;Wang, Y.;Li, W.;Fan, Z.;Jiang, L.;Lin, Y.;Fu, X.;Shen, Q.;Sun, Z.;Wang, X.;Deng, X.;Zhang, W.;Delwart, E.

title: High-throughput nucleotide sequence analysis of diverse bacterial communities in leachate of decomposing pig carcasses
abstract: Leachate generated by the decomposition of animal carcasses has been implicated as an environmental pollutant surrounding the burial site. High-throughput nucleotide sequencing was performed to investigate bacterial communities in leachates from decomposition of pig carcasses. We obtained 51,230 reads from six different samples (from 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 14 week old carcasses) and found that sequences representing the Firmicutes phylum predominate. The diversity of bacterial 16S rRNA gene sequences in the leachate was highest at 6 weeks as opposed to those at 2 and 14 weeks. The relative abundance of Firmicutes decreased, while the proportion of Bacteroidetes and Proteobacteria increased from 3-6 weeks. The phylum representation was restored after 14 weeks. However, the community structures between the samples taken at 1-2 and 14 weeks differed at the bacterial classification level. The trend in pH was similar to the changes seen in the bacterial communities, suggesting that the pH of the leachate may be related to the change in the microbial community. The results show that the composition of bacterial communities in the leachate of rotting pig carcasses changes continuously over the study period and can be affected by the burial site.
authors: Yang, S. H.;Lim, J. S.;Khan, M. A.;Kim, B. S.;Choi, D. Y.;Lee, E. Y.;Ahn, H. K.

title: Next-generation sequencing enables discovery of a wider variety of positive clones from a phage-displayed antibody library
abstract: Phage display technology provides a powerful tool to screen a library for a binding molecule through an enrichment process. It has been adopted as a critical technology in the development of therapeutic antibodies. However, a major disadvantage of phage display technology is that it often results in a limited number of clones, as the degree of enrichment cannot be controlled during the bioscrolling process. In this study, we applied next-generation sequencing (NGS) to screen for clones from a library and determined whether a larger number of clones could be identified using NGS than with conventional methods. Three chicken immune single chain variable fragment (scFv) libraries were bioannealed on prostate-specific antigen (PSA). After each round of bioscrolling, phagemid DNA prepared from the original libraries and Escherichia coli pool was analyzed using NGS and heavy chain complementarity determining region 3 (HCDR3) sequences of scFv clones were determined. Next, by two-step linker PCR and cloning, the entire scFv gene was retrieved and analyzed for its reactivity to PSA in a phage enzyme immunoassay. After four rounds of bioscrolling, the traditional colony screening method was applied for comparison. The scFv clones from NGS analysis included all clones identified by the conventional colony screening method, along with many additional clones. Enrichment of the HCDR3 sequence throughout the bioscrolling process was a positive predictive factor for selection of PSA-reactive scFv clones.
authors: Yang, W.;Yoon, A.;Lee, S.;Kim, S.;Han, J.;Chung, J.

title: Genetic characterization of a densovirus isolated from the great tit (Parus major) in China.
abstract: During a study of ornithophyll viruses in China, a novel densovirus (DNV) was isolated from lung tissue of Parus major (PmDNV-JL). The complete genome of PmDNV-JL was cloned and sequenced. Five open reading frames (ORFs) were identified in the 5166nt sequence based on the deduced amino acids. In addition, this virus has been shown to cause cytopathic effects (CPE) in Feline kidney cells. The NS1 gene sequence of PmDNV-JL shares 70-99% nucleotide sequence identity with isolates of Blattella germanica densovirus (BgDNV) and BgDNV-like virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the predicted amino acid sequences of the capsid (VP) and nonstructural domain (NS1) of PmDNV-JL clustered with BgDNV and were similar to BgDNV-HB within the genus Densovirus.
authors: Yang, W. T.;Shi, S. H.;Jiang, Y. L.;Zhao, L.;Chen, H. L.;Huang, K. Y.;Yang, G. L.;Wang, C. F.

title: Genome characterization of a novel porcine bocavirus
abstract: Using a high-throughput DNA sequencing method, a DNA sequence suspected to belong to a novel porcine bocavirus (PBoV) (contig0106) was found with a high detection rate (19.6%) in stool samples from healthy piglets. In addition, a new PBoV (provisionally named PBoV3C) with a nearly complete genome sequence (5235 bp) was identified. PBoV3C exhibits typical genome features of bocaviruses and shows the highest genomic sequence identity (78 vs 81%) for PBoV3A/B (PBoV3/4-UK) and PBoV3D/E (PBoV3/4-HK), respectively. Phylogenetic and recombination analysis showed high diversity, prevalence and complexity among PBoVs. The phospholipase A2 (PLA2) region of VP1 and the secondary structure of VP2 of PBoV3C were also analyzed. In addition, we propose a uniform PBoV nomenclature based on the VP1 gene. © 2012 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Yang, W. Z.;Yu, J. M.;Li, J. S.;Cheng, W. X.;Huang, C. P.;Duan, Z. J.

title: MicroRNA transcriptome analysis in chicken kidneys in response to different virulent infectious bronchitis virus infections
abstract: Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) is highly contagious and can cause acute respiratory illness in poultry. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) have emerged as a class of crucial regulators for gene expression and are involved in the regulation of virus defense and immunological processes. To understand miRNA regulation in chickens in response to IBV infection, high-throughput sequencing was performed to compare small RNA libraries from SCK2, SCDY2 and LDT3-A infected chicken kidneys. By comparing these data with healthy chickens, a total of 58 differentially expressed (DE) miRNAs were identified. DE miRNAs were further classified into five miRNA expression patterns (up- or down-regulation compared to control). Using Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment prediction, it has been shown that DE miRNAs are mostly associated with metabolic processes, catalytic activities, gene expression, binding activities, and immune responses. Seven highly expressed miRNAs (gga-miR-30d, gga-miR-1454, gga-miR-7b, gga-miR-215-5p, gga-miR-1a-3p, gga-miR-3538, and gga-miR -2954) ) was selected for miRNA-mRNA confluent analysis. In addition, miRNAs were inversely proportional to their corresponding target gene mRNAs. These seven miRNAs were considered to play an important role in IBV-host interactions and differential virulence of IBV strains. This is the first demonstration that infection with different virulent IBVs elicits differential miRNA expression in chicken kidneys; this expression also appears to be related to the virulence of IBV. These results are important for studying the interaction between chicken host and IBV, as well as immune responses to infection with different virulent IBVs mediated by miRNAs.
authors: Yang, X.;Gao, W.;Liu, H.;Li, J.;Chen, D.;Yuan, F.;Zhang, Z.;Wang, H.

title: New features of the avian gyrovirus 2 genome
abstract: Avian gyrovirus 2 (AGV2) was the second member of the viral genus Cyclovirus to be discovered. This virus poses a significant potential threat to humans and poultry due to its global spread and contagiousness. We used three overlapping polymerase chain reactions (PCR) to map the entire genome of AGV2. We then modeled the evolutionary history of these new sequence data in the context of related sequences from GenBank. We analyzed viral protein characteristics of different phylogenetic groups and investigated differences in evolutionary trends between Chinese strains and strains from other countries. From 2015 to 2016, we obtained 17 bird-derived AGV2 complete genomes from different regions of China. Phylogenetic analyzes of these Chinese AGV2 sequences and related sequences produced four distinct groups (AD) with significant bootstrapping values. We also generated phylogenies using predicted viral protein sequences. We found a potential hypervariable region in VP1 at sites 288-314 and identified the amino acid changes responsible for the different VP2 and VP3 groups. Three new motifs in the AGV2 5'-UTR direct repeat (DR) region were discovered and grouped. New features and diverse studies on the AGV2 genome provide a valuable framework for further research.
authors: Yao, S.;Gao, X.;Tuo, T.;Han, C.;Gao, Y.;Qi, X.;Zhang, Y.;Liu, C.;Gao, H.;Wang, Y.;Wang, X.

title: Isolation of a new serotype strain of the infectious bronchitis virus ZZ2004 from ducks in China.
abstract: In chickens, the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) often causes respiratory distress, decreased egg production, poor egg quality, and occasionally nephritis. However, ZZ2004, a Chinese IBV isolate, was obtained from ducks with clinical growth suppression and mild respiratory symptoms bred with chickens in central China. Virus isolation, virus neutralization test and RT-PCR were used to determine the causative pathogen, sequence alignment was used to analyze gene variations of S1 subunit and M genes. The results showed that ducks were infected with IBV due to the emergence of a dwarf phenotype and death of embryos 48 to 144 hours after inoculation. RT-PCR also confirmed the presence of the expected fragment sizes of the S1 subunit and M genes by RT-PCR. Meanwhile, the results of the virus neutralization test showed that strains JX/99/01, GD, SAIBK, LDT3 showed cross-reactivity with isolate ZZ2004, and almost no cross-neutralization of IBV ZZ2004 with strains M41 was observed. , H120, Grey, Holte or Aust-T. Phylogenetic analysis suggested large differences between ZZ2004 and other IBV reference strains in the S1 subunit. Meanwhile, homologies in the nucleotide and amino acid sequences of the M gene of IBV ZZ2004 were 86.9%-92.0%Â and 91.1%-93.9%Â, respectively, compared to 35 other IBV reference strains derived from different regions. This result revealed significant differences between the selected strains. Furthermore, the results showed that the IBV strains common in ducks had no antigen homology with the vaccine strains commonly used in China, except for the LDT3 strain, making the research and development of new IBV vaccines urgent.
authors: Yao, S.;Ou, C.;Liu, X.;Wang, X.;Yao, Z.;Liu, J.

title: Isolation and characterization of a natural avirulent Streptococcus suis serotype 2 strain: a vaccine development perspective.
abstract: Streptococcus suis, an emerging infectious pathogen, is the cause of two large-scale human streptococcal toxic shock syndrome outbreaks in China and has attracted great interest from the scientific community. The genetic basis of its pathogenesis remains enigmatic and no effective prevention measures have been established. To better understand the virulence differentiation of S. suis and develop a promising vaccine, we isolated and sequenced a natural avirulent S. suis strain (05HAS68). Animal experiments revealed that 05HAS68 is an avirulent strain and can protect piglets from attack by virulent strains. Comparative genomic analyzes demonstrated the genetic basis of virulence deficiency in 05HAS68, which is characterized by the absence of some key virulence-related factors and an intact 89K island of pathogenicity. The lack of virulence was also demonstrated by the reduced survival time of 05HAS68 compared to a lethal strain in pig whole blood. Further investigation revealed a large-scale genomic rearrangement in 05HAS68 that was suggested to be mediated by transposase genes and/or prophages. This genomic rearrangement may have resulted in the genomic diversity of S. suis and may have resulted in biological differences between 05HAS68 and the highly virulent S. suis strains.
authors: Yao, X.;Li, M.;Wang, J.;Wang, C.;Hu, D.;Zheng, F.;Pan, X.;Tan, Y.;Zhao, Y.;Hu, L.;Tang, J.;Hu, F.

title: Novel microRNAs encoded by duck enteritis virus
abstract: Duck enteritis virus (DEV) is an important herpes virus pathogen associated with an acute, highly contagious fatal disease in waterfowl. Using a deep sequencing approach on RNA from cultures of infected chicken embryo fibroblasts, we identified several novel DEV-encoded micro(mi)RNAs. Unlike most mardivirus encoded miRNAs, DEV encoded miRNAs mostly map to the uniquely long region of the genome. The precursors of DEV miR-D18 and miR-D19 overlapped, suggesting similarities to miRNA-offset RNAs, but only DEV-miR-D18-3p was functional in reporter assays. The identification of these new miRNAs will add to the growing list of virus-encoded miRNAs, enabling investigation of their role in pathogenesis.
authors: Yao, Y.;Smith, L. P.;Petherbridge, L.;Watson, M.;Nair, V.

title: Relationship of SARS-CoV to other pathogenic RNA viruses discovered by its tetranucleotide utilization profile
abstract: BACKGROUND: The exact source of the cause of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS) is still an open question. The genomic sequence association of SARS-CoV with 30 different single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) viruses from various families was studied using two non-standard approaches. Both approaches began with a vectorial profile of the tetra-nucleotide utilization pattern V for each virus. In the first approach, a distance measure of a vector V based on the correlation coefficient was designed to construct a relationship tree with the neighbor-joining algorithm. In the second approach, a multivariate factor analysis was performed to derive embedded tetra-nucleotide utilization patterns. These models were then used to classify selected viruses. RESULTS: Both approaches yielded association results consistent with known virus classification. They also noted that the genome of RNA viruses from the same family conformed to a particular pattern of word usage. Based on the correlation of overall tetra-nucleotide usage patterns, Infectious Gastroenteritis Virus (TGV) and Feline CoronaVirus (FCoV) are closest to SARS-CoV. Surprisingly also, RNA viruses that did not go through a DNA stage showed remarkable discrimination against CpG and UpA di-nucleotide (z = -77.31, -52.48) and UpG and CpA selection (z = 65.79.49.99, respectively). . Potential factors influencing these biases are discussed. CONCLUSION: Genomic word usage study is a powerful method to classify RNA viruses. The agreement of association results with known classification indicates phylogenetic signals in tetra-nucleotide usage patterns, most evident in replicase open reading frames.
authors: Yap, Y. L.;Zhang, X. W.;Danchin, A.

title: Frequency of D222G and Q223R hemagglutinin mutants of the 2009 influenza virus pandemic (H1N1) in Japan between 2009 and 2010
abstract: Background: A new swine-derived influenza A virus (H1N1pdm) emerged in April 2009 and spread rapidly around the world, including Japan. It has been suggested that, unlike contemporary seasonal H1N1 viruses, which have a preference for 2.6-linked sialic acid, the virus can bind to both 2.3- and 2.6-linked sialic acid receptors in infected mammals. Methods/Results: To elucidate the presence and transmissibility of Î±2,3 sialic acid-specific viruses in H1N1pdm, amino acid substitutions within viral hemagglutinin molecules, particularly D187E, D222G and Q223R, were investigated for a shift from human. to bird receptor specificity. Samples from individuals infected during the first and second waves of the outbreak in Japan were analyzed using a high-throughput sequencing approach. In May 2009, three samples from mild cases showed D222G and/or Q223R substitutions in a small subpopulation of viruses infecting these individuals. However, in samples from five mild cases in December 2010, the substitutions nearly disappeared. The D187E substitution was not common in samples, even in May 2009. Conclusions: These results showed that Î±2.3 sialic acid-specific viruses, including G222, and R223 were present as a small population in humans in the early phase of the pandemic, and D222 and Q223 became more predominant through human-to-human transmission during the first and second waves of the epidemic. These results are consistent with the low rates of substitution identified in seasonal H1N1 viruses in 2008. Â© 2012 Yasugi et al.
authors: Yasugi, M.;Nakamura, S.;Daidoji, T.;Kawashita, N.;Ramadhany, R.;Yang, C. S.;Yasunaga, T.;Iida, T.;Horii, T.;Ikuta, K.;Takahashi, K.;Nakaya, T.

title: Isolation and molecular characterization of influenza A/H5N1 viruses isolated during avian influenza epidemics among birds in the European part of Russia in 2005: A virus strain with the Ozeltamivir-resistance mutation was found.
abstract: The operation Karalat Furrow was performed for the isolation and characterization of influenza A/H5NI viruses isolated from chickens that died during the avian flu epidemic in the village of Yandovka (Tula region) in autumn 2005, and from a wild swan that died in the area near the mouth of the Volga River. Molecular-biological and phylogenetic analyzes were carried out to determine possible geographical origins of strains, phylogenetic similarities of viruses, as well as to predict their pathogenicity, epidemic hazards for humans and possible resistance to antiviral drugs. The virus has been shown to belong to highly pathogenic variants that originated in China as a result of reclassification of viruses of the Z and V genotypes circulating among poultry and wild birds. A number of molecular markers were revealed that characterize the high pathogenicity of the virus for gallinaceous birds and mammals, but not specific mutations in the hemagglutinin gene that support the high rate of virus replication in a human organism, and also adaptation mutations to it. found. Variants of the circulating influenza A/H5N1 virus in this epizootic have been shown to be susceptible to remantadine. The strain isolated from the wild swan had the mutation causing resistance to Tamiflu/ozeltamivir.
authors: Yatsyshina, S. B.;Shestopalov, A. M.;Evseyenko, V. A.;Astakhova, T. S.;Braslavskaya, S. I.;Ternovoi, V. A.;Kondratieva, T. Y.;Alekseev, A. Y.;Zolotykh, S. I.;Rassadkin, Y. N.;Zaikovskaya, A. V.;Durymanov, A. G.;Netesov, S. V.;Shipulin, G. A.

title: ISOLATION AND CHARACTERIZATION OF 15 NM DIAMETER SMALL ROUND VIRUS FROM diarrhoeaeal pig pox
authors: Yawei, N.;Huishen, Q.;Guoan, L.

title: Phylogenetic analysis and pathogenicity assessment of two strains of avian influenza virus subtype H9N2 isolated from migratory birds: high homology of human H10N8 virus and internal genes.
abstract: Two human-infecting avian influenza viruses (AIVs), H7N9 and H10N8, have emerged in China, which also cross-species infectivity and pathogenicity as an internal gene donor of the H9N2 subtype of AIVs. H9N2 viruses containing such internal genes are commonly found in poultry but are rarely reported in migratory birds. In this study, two strains of H9N2 virus were isolated from stool samples of migratory birds in 2014: one from Caizi Lake in Anhui Province and the other from Chen Lake in Hubei Province, China. Nucleotide sequence analysis revealed high homology of all six internal genes of these two strains with internal genes of human H10N8 virus from Jiangxi Province, as well as human H7N9 virus. Phylogenetic analysis indicated a possible origin of these two strains from southern China poultry. Both of the two tested viruses could be replicated in the respiratory organs of infective mice without adaptation by both strains of H9N2 AIVs from wild birds, suggesting their potential capacity to directly infect mammals. Our findings indicate the existence of H9N2 viruses containing internal genes that are highly homologous to human H10N8 or H7N9 viruses. Wild birds may contribute to the spread of H9N2 virus containing the "harmful" internal gene complex, leading to gene rearrangement with other influenza viruses and the formation of new pathogenic viruses. Therefore, strengthening AIV surveillance in wild birds can promote understanding of the presence and prevalence of viruses and provide scientific evidence for the prevention and control of AIVs and AIVs that infect humans.
authors: Ye, G.;Liang, C. H.;Hua, D. G.;Song, L. Y.;Xiang, Y. G.;Guang, C.;Lan, C. H.;Ping, H. Y.

title: Full sequence analysis of hemagglutinin and neuraminidase genes and proteins of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus detected in Iran, 2015
abstract: In the last two decades, the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus has received great attention due to its zoonotic and mutated nature. Iran is among the countries that have been significantly affected by the virus, as it hosts migratory birds during seasonal migration. In this study, molecular characterizations of hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) genes and proteins of H5N1 strain A/chicken/Iran/8/2015 detected in backyard chickens of Mazandaran province were investigated. Phylogenetic analysis classified this virus as a member of the 2.3.2.1c subset with the 'PQRERRRK-R/GLF' cleavage site motif. HA carried several mutations that altered affinity for mammalian cells; however, the virus was classified as avian. The NA protein had a 20-amino acid deletion at position 49-69 aa, similar to those isolated since 2000. NA had H253Y and H274Y mutations that contributed to antiviral resistance. From this analysis it can be concluded that wild migratory birds flying from West Asia to East Africa are probably the main carriers of seasonal H5N1 in the country.
authors: Yegani, S.;Shoushtari, A. H.;Eshratabadi, F.;Molouki, A.

title: Molecular characterization of low pathogenic avian influenza viruses isolated from food products imported into Singapore.
abstract: We completed the genetic characterization of all eight gene segments for four low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) viruses. The aim of this study is to detect the presence of new signatures that can serve as early warning indicators of the transformation of LPAI viruses into highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) viruses. This study included three H5N2 and one H5N3 viruses isolated from live poultry imported into Singapore as part of the national avian influenza virus (AIV) surveillance programme. Based on the molecular criteria of the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE), sequencing analysis with the translated amino acid (aa) sequence of the hemagglutinin (HA) gene revealed the absence of multibasic aa at the HA cleavage site and identified all four viruses. Isolates as LPAI. Detailed phylogenetic tree analyzes using the HA and neuraminidase (NA) genes clustered these isolates in the Eurasian H5 lineage, but away from the HPAI H5 subtypes. This analysis also revealed that internal genes clustered into different avian and pig subtypes, suggesting that the four isolates could possibly share ancestry with these different influenza subtypes. Our results show that the four LPAI isolates in this study mainly contain avian signatures, and the phylogenetic tree for internal genes also reveals the potential for reclassification with other different avian subtypes in circulation. This is the first comprehensive report on the genetic characterization of LPAI H5N2/3 viruses isolated in Southeast Asia. Â© 2009 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Yeo, D. S. Y.;Ng, S. H.;Liaw, C. W.;Ng, L. M.;Wee, E. J. H.;Lim, E. A. S.;Seah, S. L. K.;Wong, W. K.;Lim, C. W.;Sugrue, R. J.;Tan, B. H.

title: Presence of bovine hepacivirus in Turkish cattle
abstract: Hepatitis C virus (HCV), a common human pathogen worldwide, causes one of the most important viral infections in humans. HCV is the type species of the Hepacivirus (Flaviviridae) genus to which recently discovered animal viruses, namely horse, bat, rodent and cattle, are assigned. A broad distribution of bovine hepacivirus (BovHepV, Hepacivirus N) was proposed following preliminary reports from German and African cattle in 2015. We investigated the possible presence of BovHepV in serum samples from cattle from different regions of Turkey. Analysis of a total of 120 samples from 98 female (dairy) and 22 male (cattle) cattle by real-time RT-PCR yielded 15 (12.5%) positive results. BovHepV infection was detected in 6 of the 10 locations included in the study. There were positive samples from both the eastern and western parts of the country showing the possible wide distribution in the Turkish cattle population. Phylogenetic analysis of 9 selected positive samples clearly assigned 8 sequences to a separate cluster on the basis of NS3 gene region, while one of the sequences from an animal imported from northern Italy was grouped with sequences from cattle in Germany. The second finding may indicate the possible occurrence of this genetic group of BovHepV not only in Germany but also in other European countries. The results of this study indicate the presence of BovHepV infections in Turkey and the Middle East region.
authors: Yesilbag, K.;Baechlein, C.;Kadiroglu, B.;Toker, E. B.;Alpay, G.;Becher, P.

title: Detection and genetic characterization of feline bocavirus in northeastern China
abstract: Background: Bocaviruses have been reported to cause respiratory tract infection and gastroenteritis in most animal species. Different genotypes of bocaviruses have been identified in cats in the USA, Japan, Hong Kong and Portugal. However, the clear relationship between clinical symptoms and FBoV infection is unknown, and the prevalence of FBoV and the distribution of FBoV genotypes in China is still unclear. Results: In this study, 197 fecal samples were collected from cats with diarrhea (n = 105) and normal cats (n = 92) in different regions between January 2016 and November 2017 and investigated using PCR targeting different FBoV genotypes. Screening results showed that 51 of 197 samples (25.9%) were positive for FBoV and a higher positive rate was observed in cats with diarrhea (33.3%, 35/105) than in normal cats (17.4%, 16/92). Of these FBoV positive samples, 35 were identified as FBoV-1, 12 as FBoV-2, and 4 as FBoV-1 and FBoV-2 coinfections. A phylogenetic analysis based on the partial NS1 gene showed that 24 sequences from randomly selected FBoV-positive samples were separated into 2 different FBoV groups: FBoV-1 and FBoV-2. In addition, 6 strains were randomly selected and the whole genome was sequenced and analyzed. These strains exhibited the typical genome organization of bocavirus and were closely related to FBoV. The two FBoV-2 identified strains shared high homologies with the whole-genome and whole-coding gene-based FBoV-2 reference strains, but lower identities in the NP1 and VP1 regions for the other 4 strains identified with FBoV-1 compared to the FBoV-1 reference strains. Conclusion: These findings suggest that genetically diverse FBoV-1 and FBoV-2 are widely circulated in cats in Northeast China, and FBoV-1 is more prevalent. The high prevalence of FBoV in cats with diarrheal symptoms suggests that FBoV infection may be associated with diarrhea in cats.
authors: Yi, S. S.;Niu, J. T.;Wang, H. L.;Dong, G. Y.;Zhao, Y. L.;Dong, H.;Guo, Y. B.;Wang, K.;Hu, G. X.

title: Highly different sapoviruses detected by metagenomic analysis in straw-colored fruit bats in Cameroon
abstract: Sapoviruses (SaVs) belong to the genus Sapoviruses in the family Caliciviridae. It has been associated with gastroenteritis in humans and pigs, but not in other animals. In addition, some strains from pigs, chimpanzees, and rodents show close sequence identity with human SaVs, thus suggesting the possibility of interspecies transmission. Bats are known to be an important reservoir of zoonotic viruses, but little is known about the genetic diversity of SaVs in bats. To investigate the genetic diversity of bat SaVs, fecal samples of Eidolon helvum and Epomophorus gambianus were processed according to the NetoVIR protocol and sequenced with Illumina technology. Nearly complete genome sequences of six highly distinct SaVs and one partial SaV (VP1 region only) were identified in Eidolon helvum, and based on sequence identities and phylogenetic analysis, they represent two novel genogroups that are potentially only distantly related to known SaVs. . Furthermore, comparison of these sequences with currently used screening primers and probes showed that new SaVs would not be detected in routine epidemiological screening studies in humans if interspecies transmission occurred. Therefore, we designed and validated novel primers capable of detecting both human and bat SaVs. In this study, we identified a large number of novel bat SaVs, but further epidemiological studies in humans are needed to reveal their potential role in gastroenteritis.
authors: Yinda, C. K.;ConceiÃ§Ã£o-Neto, N.;Zeller, M.;Heylen, E.;Maes, P.;Ghogomu, S. M.;Van Ranst, M.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Cameroon fruit bats harbor different viruses, including rotavirus H, bastroviruses, and picobirnaviruses, using an alternative genetic code.
abstract: Most human-emergent infectious diseases originate in wildlife, and bats are major reservoirs of viruses, a few of which are highly pathogenic to humans. In some parts of Cameroon, bats are hunted and eaten as a delicacy. This proximity between humans and bats provides ample opportunity for zoonotic events. To elucidate the viral diversity of Cameroon fruit bats, we collected and metagenomically screened eighty-seven fecal samples from Eidolon helvum and Epomophorus gambianus fruit bats. The results showed that there are many known and new viruses. Phylogenetic analyzes of eleven gene segments of the first complete bat rotavirus H genome showed clearly segregated clusters of human, porcine, and bat rotavirus H strains, without showing recent interspecies transmission events. In addition, we identified and analyzed a bat bastrovirus genome (a new group of newly identified viruses related to astroviruses and hepatitis E viruses), confirming their recombinant nature, and providing further evidence of additional recombination events among bat bastroviruses. Interestingly, picobirnavirus-like RNA-linked RNA polymerase gene segments were identified using an alternative mitochondrial genetic code, and further principal component analyzes suggested that they may have a lifestyle similar to mitoviruses, a group of virus-like elements known to infect mitochondria. mushrooms. Although the identified strains of bat coronavirus, parvovirus and cyclovirus belong to established genera, most of the identified partitiviruses and densoviruses form putative new genera in their own families. Finally, the results of phage community analyzes of these bats show a very diverse geographically diverse bat phage population, possibly reflecting different diets and gut bacterial ecosystems.
authors: Yinda, C. K.;Ghogomu, S. M.;Conceicao-Neto, N.;Beller, L.;Deboutte, W.;Vanhulle, E.;Maes, P.;Van Ranst, M.;Matthijnssens, J.

title: Phylogenetic evidence for intertype recombination in the emergence of the human enterovirus 71 subgenotype
abstract: Background: Human enterovirus 71 (EV-71) is a common causative agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD). In recent years, the virus has caused several outbreaks, with numerous deaths and serious neurological complications. Several new EV-71 subgenotypes were identified from these outbreaks. The mechanisms that contribute to the emergence of these subgenotypes are unknown. Results: Six EV-71 isolates from an outbreak in Malaysia in 1997 were fully sequenced. These isolates were identified as EV-71 subgenotypes, B3, B4 and C2. Using these whole genome sequences and all other available whole genome sequences of EV-71 and human enterovirus A (HEV-A), a phylogenetic tree was constructed that correlates well with the current enterovirus classification scheme. However, using genomic regions 5–² UTR, P2 and P3, isolates of EV-71 subgenotypes B3 and C4 were isolated from other EV-71 subgenotypes, coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16/G10) and EV-71. divided into clusters. Subgenotype C2 clustered with CV-A8. Results from similarity plot analyzes supported clustering of these isolates with other HEV-A. In contrast, at the same genomic regions, Tainan5079, a CV-A16 isolate, clustered with EV-71. This indicates that only structural genes are conserved between EV-71 and CV-A16. The 3–2 ends of the virus genome were variable and consisted of very similar sequences to various HEV-A viruses. Multiple recombination cross breakpoints were identified in the nonstructural genes of some of these newer EV-71 subgenotypes. Conclusion: Phylogenetic evidence from whole-genome sequence analyzes supports possible intertype recombination involving EV-71 and various HEV-A, including CV-A16, the most common causative agent of HFMD. It has been suggested that these recombination events play important roles in the emergence of various EV-71 subgenotypes. Â© 2006 Yoke-Fun and AbuBakar; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Yoke-Fun, C.;AbuBakar, S.

title: Tracing the genetic history of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses derived from the complete ORF 5-7 sequences: a Bayesian combinatorial approach.
abstract: To trace the genetic history of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV), we identified the complete sequences of the ORFs of 5 to 7 of the four PRRSV isolates. These sequences were analyzed together with published sequences from 146 isolates from various regions of the world using Bayesian inference and maximum likelihood methods, as well as the Bayesian combinatorial approach. All viruses of the European type (type AB) were classified into either group or unclassified (4 isolates), while all viruses of the North American type (type NA) belonged to one of the three main groups or were not classified (5 isolates). Within each genotype, no significant periodic and/or geographic effects on the evolution of PRRSVs were observed. The evolutionary rate of PRRSV isolates was estimated to be 1.55 × 10-3 substitutions/place/year and the most recent common ancestor (TMRCA) time was 491.2 years ago. Here, TMRCA for EU and NA type viruses was 58.7 and 62.6 years ago, respectively. A Bayesian skyline plot revealed that viruses evolved at an almost constant population size until the late 1970s, when they experienced a population expansion that continued into the late 1980s. Population size remained stable again until the early 2000s, when a rapid and sharp decline in the number of effective infections occurred. © 2012 Springer-Verlag.
authors: Yoon, S. H.;Kim, H.;Park, B.;Kim, H.

title: Phylogenomic and molecular evolution of the foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: This report describes the use of Bayesian methods to analyze polyprotein coding region sequences (n = 217) obtained from GenBank to define the genome-wide phylogeny of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV). The results strongly supported the monophyly of the five FMDV serotypes, O, A, Asia 1, C, and SAT 3, while the sequences for the remaining two FMDV serotypes, SAT 1 and SAT 2, did not branch completely apart. The phylogenomic tree revealed three sister group relationships, serotypes O + Asia 1, A + C and SAT 1 + 3 + 2, with a new branching pattern: {[(O, Asia 1), (A, C)], (SAT 1 , 2, 3)}. Within each serotype, there was no apparent periodic, geographic, or host species influence on the evolution of global FMDVs. Analysis of the polyprotein coding region of these sequences provided evidence for the impact of purification selection on the evolution of FMDV. Using the Bayesian combinatorial approach, the evolutionary rate of FMDV isolates circulating between 1932 and 2007 was estimated to be 1.46 × 10-3 substitutions/place/year, and the most recent common ancestor of the virus existed about 481 years ago. . The Bayesian silhouette graph revealed a population expansion in the early 20th century, followed by a rapid decline in population size from the late 20th century to the present. These findings provide new insights into the mechanisms that influence the evolution of this important livestock pathogen. © 2011 KSMCB.
authors: Yoon, S. H.;Park, W.;King, D. P.;Kim, H.

title: Polymerase chain reaction-based genetic typing of Japanese swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses
abstract: Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome viruses (PRRSVs) are classified into 2 different genotypes: the North American type and the European type. Japanese PRRSVs were genotyped by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction using reported primer pairs, either North American type specific or European type specific, which were reactive to both types. All PRRSV genomes from 66 tissue homogenates or serum and 55 infectious viruses were of the North American type, while the European type of viral genome was not detected. The two PCR primers specific to the North American type showed different detection efficiency. Half of the tissue samples and 15% of infectious viruses were not detected with one primer pair, but all were detected with the other primer pair. Nucleotide sequencing analysis of the forward and reverse primer binding sites of non-reactive viruses showed that all these viruses have nucleotide mismatches within 4 bases corresponding to the 3-² end of the reverse primer. These incompatibilities turned out to be responsible for the old primers being unresponsive to these viruses.
authors: Yoshii, M.;Kaku, Y.;Murakami, Y.;Shimizu, M.;Kato, K.;Ikeda, H.

title: Molecular and serological epidemiology of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) on a remote island of western Japan: an effect of JEV migration over the East China Sea.
abstract: Background: Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV). About 1-10 cases with severe central nervous system symptoms are consistently reported each year in Japan. To clarify the maintenance mechanism of JEV, this study sought isolated JEV strains and serological evidence of JEV infection from pigs and mosquitoes in Isahaya City (Isahaya) and Goto City (Goto) on the islets of Goto, Nagasaki State, from 2008. Results: Serological investigation of pigs showed increased IgM seropositivity to JEV in July or August and was maintained until October or November in both Isahaya and Goto each year. Including the isolates in this study, there were 47 JEV strains isolated in Nagasaki between 2001 and 2014 and belonged to genotype 1. Thirty-four of the isolated strains were from pigs from Isahaya, and six subsets (1-A-1, 1-A-2, 1-A-3, 1-A-4, 1-A-5, and 1-A-9) . Thirteen strains were isolated from pigs and mosquitoes in Goto and classified into three subsets (1-A-5 (2008); 1-A-1 (2009); and 1-A-2). In the 1-A-2 subset, there are three different monophyletic subgroups, 1-A-2-2 (2010), 1-A-2-3 (2011) and 1-A-2-1 (2013, 2014). Appeared on goto. Conclusions: These data strongly suggest that the appearance of the JEV in Goto appears to be due to frequent off-island entry of the JEV and that this pattern is different from that observed on subtropical islands such as Okinawa and Taiwan in the East China Sea. the same JEV populations (1-A-7 (1998-2008) in Okinawa; genotype 3 (until 2012) in Taiwan) were conserved for a long time.
authors: Yoshikawa, A.;Nabeshima, T.;Inoue, S.;Agoh, M.;Morita, K.

title: Molecular epidemiology of coxsackievirus A6 derived from hand, foot, and mouth disease in Fukuoka between 2013 and 2017.
abstract: Coxsackievirus (CV)-A6 has been the primary causative agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in Japan since 2011. In Fukuoka, CV-A6-associated HFMD caused outbreaks in 2013, 2015, and 2017. This article reports. Genetic characteristics of CV-A6 complete viral protein 1 (VP1) obtained from patients with HFMD in Fukuoka between 2013 and 2017. CV-A6 was detected in 105 of 280 clinical samples and all VP1 sequences could be analyzed for 90. 105 samples. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the CV-A6 strains were classified in clan A and subdivided into sub-clan A3 or sub-clan A4. Each sub-clade strain carried amino acid substitutions in the putative DE and GH loops of VP1, and no amino acid substitutions were identified as detrimental to protein function. No significant difference in clinical symptoms was found between genetic sub-branches using statistical analyses. In conclusion, this study clarified the genetic diversity of CV-A6 in Fukuoka from 2013 to 2017. The emergence of CV-A6 strains was classified into new subclades derived based on the phylogenetic analysis of the VP1 gene, which may be the CV-A6-related cause. HFMD outbreaks occur approximately every 2 years.
authors: Yoshitomi, H.;Ashizuka, Y.;Ichihara, S.;Nakamura, T.;Nakamura, A.;Kobayashi, T.;Kajiwara, J.

title: VIRAL INFECTIONS IN MARRIED ANIMALS
authors: Young, G. A.

title: Isolation and genetic characterization of avian-like H1N1 and novel resortant H1N2 influenza viruses from pigs in China.
abstract: Because pigs are susceptible to both human and avian influenza viruses, it has been suggested that they are intermediate hosts or mixing vessels for the generation of pandemic influenza viruses through reclassification or adaptation to the mammalian host. In this study, we report avian-like H1N1 and novel resortant H1N2 influenza viruses from pigs in China. Homology and phylogenetic analyzes showed that H1N1 virus (A/swine/Zhejiang/1/07) was close to bird-like H1N1 viruses and appeared to be derived from European porcine H1N1 viruses first reported in China; and two H1N2 viruses (A/swine/Shanghai/1/07 and A/swine/Guangxi/13/06), classic porcine (HA, NP, M and NS), novel resistant H1N2 influenza viruses containing human genes (NA and PB1 ) and avian (PB2 and PA) strains claimed that reclassification between human, avian and swine flu viruses occurred in pigs in China, resulting in the production of new viruses. The isolation of the avian-like H1N1 influenza virus from European swine H1N1 viruses, particularly the emergence of two new resortant H1N2 influenza viruses, provides further evidence that pigs serve as intermediate hosts or "mixing vessels", and swine flu virus surveillance in China is needed. should be given high priority. © 2009.
authors: Yu, H.;Zhang, P. C.;Zhou, Y. J.;Li, G. X.;Pan, J.;Yan, L. P.;Shi, X. X.;Liu, H. L.;Tong, G. Z.

title: Genetic diversity of H9N2 influenza viruses from pigs in China: a potential threat to human health?
abstract: Pandemic strains of influenza A virus can arise through genetic reclassification between viruses from different hosts. Pigs are susceptible to both human and avian influenza viruses and have been suggested to be intermediate hosts or mixing vessels for the generation of pandemic influenza viruses through reclassification or adaptation to the mammalian host. In this study, we summarize and report for the first time the coexistence of 10 (AJ) genotypes in pigs in China by analyzing eight genes of 28 porcine H9N2 viruses isolated in China from 1998 to 2007. Porcine H9N2 viruses in genotypes A and B were entirely derived from Y280-like and Shanghai/F/98-like viruses, respectively, indicating that interspecies bird-to-swine transmission of H9N2 viruses is present in China. The other eight genotype (CJ) viruses may be double reassortant viruses in which six genotypes (EJ) viruses have 1-4 H5-like gene segments, indicating that they are reassortants of H9 and H5 viruses. In conclusion, the genetic diversity of H9N2 influenza viruses from pigs in China provides further evidence that interspecies bird-to-swine transmission of H9N2 viruses occurs and can result in the generation of new reassortant viruses by genetic reassortment with swine H1N1, H1N2 and H3N2 influenza viruses, therefore , these swine H9N2 influenza viruses may be a potential threat to human health, and maintaining swine flu virus surveillance in China is of paramount importance. © 2010 Elsevier BV
authors: Yu, H.;Zhou, Y. J.;Li, G. X.;Ma, J. H.;Yan, L. P.;Wang, B.;Yang, F. R.;Huang, M.;Tong, G. Z.

title: Further evidence for infection of pigs with human-like H1N1 influenza viruses in China
abstract: Classical swine and avian-like H1N1 influenza viruses have been widely reported in the worldwide pig population, but human-like H1N1 swine viruses have been reported occasionally. In 2006, a human-like H1N1 swine virus (A/swine/Guangdong/96/06) was isolated from pigs in Guangdong province, which was first reported in China. To obtain further evidence of infection of pigs with human-like H1N1 influenza viruses, three human-like pig H1N1 viruses (A/swine/Guangdong/96/06, A/swine/Tianjin/01/04 and A/swine/Henan/01) /06) Isolated in China. All eight genes of the three viruses are highly homologous to recent (about 2000) and early (in the 1980s) human H1N1 influenza viruses, respectively. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that A/Swine/Guangdong/96/06 is directly derived from approximately 2000 human H1N1 influenza viruses, while A/swine/Tianjin/01/04 and A/swine/Henan/01/06 appear to be human descendants. took it out. H1N1 viruses circulating in the 1980s. Seroprevalence of our isolate (A/swine/Guangdong/96/06) confirmed the presence of human-like H1N1 virus in pigs from China. The presence of these influenza viruses, particularly older viruses (A/swine/Tianjin/01/04 and A/swine/Henan/01/06), indicates that human-like H1N1 influenza viruses may remain invariant for long periods in pigs, and that pigs may have been used for human pandemics. evidence that it serves as its reservoir. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Yu, H.;Zhou, Y. J.;Li, G. X.;Zhang, G. H.;Liu, H. L.;Yan, L. P.;Liao, M.;Tong, G. Z.

title: Detection of new viruses in pig stool samples from China
abstract: Background: Pigs are well-known sources of infectious diseases in humans. To better understand the spectrum of viruses present in pigs, we used the 454 Life Sciences GS-FLX high-throughput sequencing platform to sequence fecal samples from healthy pigs. Results. Total nucleic acid was extracted from stool samples of healthy piglets and randomly amplified. The amplified materials were pooled and processed using a high-throughput pyro-sequencing technique. Raw sequences were parsed on the basis of barcodes and then processed through a standard bioinformatics pipeline. The unique reads (348, 70 and 13) had limited similarity to known astroviruses, bocaviruses and parecoviruses. Specific primers were synthesized to assess the prevalence of viruses in healthy piglets. Our results show extremely high positivity rates. Results: Several novel astroviruses, bocaviruses and Ljungan-like viruses were identified in stool samples from healthy pigs. Isolation rates for new viruses were high. The high detection rate, diverse sequences and categories indicate that pigs are well-established reservoirs and possible sources for different enteric viruses. © 2013 Yu et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Yu, J. M.;Li, J. S.;Ao, Y. Y.;Duan, Z. J.

title: Identification of a Novel Picornavirus in Healthy Piglets and Seroepidemiological Evidence for Its Presence in Humans
abstract: In this study, we describe a novel porcine parechovirus-like virus (provisionally named PLV-CHN) from healthy piglets in China using 454 high-throughput sequencing. The complete genome of the virus consists of 6832 bp (32% identity) encoding a predicted polyprotein of 2132 amino acids most similar to Ljungan virus. A similar virus belonging to a new genus Picornaviridae named swine pasivirus 1 (SPaV-1) was reported during the preparation of this article. Sequence analysis revealed that PLV-CHN and SPAV1 shared 82% nucleotide identity and 89% amino acid identity. Further genomic and phylogenetic analyzes suggested that both SPAV1 and PLV-CHN share similar genomic features and belong to the same new genus Picornaviridae. A total of 36 (20.0%) stool samples from 180 healthy piglets were positive for PLV-CHN by RT-PCR, while no stool samples from 100 healthy children and 100 children with diarrhea and no cerebrospinal fluid samples from 196 children with suspected viral encephalitis were positive for the virus. However, Western blot and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays using recombinant PLV-CHN VP1 polypeptide as an antigen showed a high seroprevalence of 63.5% in the healthy population. When grouped by age, antibody positivity rates showed that the majority of children under the age of 12 were infected by the virus. It has been suggested that PLV-CHN, SPAV1, or a yet uncharacterized virus could infect humans early in life. Therefore, it is vital to investigate the role of this new virus. © 2013 Yu et al.
authors: Yu, J. M.;Li, X. Y.;Ao, Y. Y.;Li, L. L.;Liu, N.;Li, J. S.;Duan, Z. J.

title: Molecular features of the full-length genomic A segment of three infectious bursal disease viruses in China: two attenuated strains and one virulent domain strain
abstract: Full-length cDNA of genomic segment A of three infectious bursal disease viruses, two attenuated strains (HZ2 and JD1) and one virulent domain strain (ZJ2000), amplified in a single step by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction, cloned into pGEM - T Easy Vector and sequential. The full length of the cloned segment A contains 3259 nucleotides containing two partially overlapping open reading fragments (ORFs) ORF1 and ORF2 flanked by 5' and 3' non-coding regions. These strains shared high sequence identity with each other at either the nucleotide level or the deduced amino acid level. HZ2 and JD1 strains were highly associated with two attenuated strains, CEF94 and P2, while ZJ2000 was closely associated with two other virulent strains, Cu-1 and Harbin. Substitutions of four amino acids at positions 253, 279, 284 and 330, a common feature of attenuated and most virulent strains, were also observed in these three strains. Two major hydrophilic peaks were preserved in the three strains; however, there are two amino acid substitutions at positions 280 (N to S) and 290 (M to L) at the second minor hydrophilic peak for all three strains, which can have a critical effect on antigenicity. Two amino acid substitutions near the VP2-VP4 cleavage site were identified in the virulent strain JZ2000, which may play a role in enhancing the virulence of the virus. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that these three Chinese strains are most closely related to some European virulent strains but distinct from the highly virulent infectious bursal disease virus and variant strains.
authors: Yu, L.;Li, J. R.;Huang, Y. W.;Dikki, J.;Deng, R.

title: Growth characteristics and whole genomic sequence analysis of a novel pseudorabies virus in China
abstract: Pig liars (PR) have re-emerged in Bartha-vaccinated pig herds and have killed millions of piglets in China since the last part of 2011. We isolated a novel pseudorabies virus (PRV) strain HNX from the brains of abortion fetuses. to diagnose the disease. To reveal the genomic organization and characterize the HNX strain, the complete genomes of an isolate HNX and Fa strain were sequenced and analyzed in the 1960s. The genomic size of HNX and Fa strains was 142,294 and 141,930 nt, respectively, and their corresponding GÂ +Â C contents were 73.56% and 73.70%Â. The two strains consistently had 70 open reading frames. In addition, comparative genomic analysis was performed between HNX and Bartha strains to understand the possible cause of immunodeficiency. The HNX strain had slight changes in the major virulence-related genes, while the HNX strain had 73 mutations in the glycoprotein B and glycoprotein C genes; Homology at the whole genomic level between HNX and Bartha strains was 90.6%. Genome-wide comparison between HNX and Fa strains showed that the strains shared approximately 96.4% homology and clustered in a separate group of Chinese isolates; both strains are far from isolates from other countries. Similarity plot and bootstrap analysis of whole genome sequences of nine PRV strains, including HNX and Fa, four novel Chinese strains and three traditional reference strains, revealed that non-recombination events occurred in strain HNX. The PRV HNX strain with genomic variations may contribute to the PR epidemic in China since the last part of 2011.
authors: Yu, T.;Chen, F.;Ku, X.;Fan, J.;Zhu, Y.;Ma, H.;Li, S.;Wu, B.;He, Q.

title: Influenza H7N9 and H9N2 viruses: coexistence in poultry linked to human H7N9 infection and genome features
abstract: Avian influenza virus A of the novel H7N9 reassortant subtype was recently found to cause severe human respiratory infections in China. Based on the exposure histories of the cases and sequence similarities between viral isolates, sources of human H7N9 infection were suspected in live poultry markets. To investigate the role of live poultry markets in the source of the novel H7N9 virus, we systematically examined poultry and environmental samples from local markets and farms in Hangzhou, using real-time reverse transcription-PCR (RT-PCR) and then high throughput. - generation sequencing (NGS). RT-PCR identified positive samples for the H7 and N9 genomic segments in all 12 poultry markets epidemiologically associated with 10 human H7N9 cases. Chickens, ducks and environmental samples from the markets contained heavily mixed subspecies including H7, N9, H9 and N2 and sometimes H5 and N1. The idea that H7N9 and H9N2 subtypes coexist in chickens was further supported by metagenomic sequencing. In contrast, all human H7N9 infection cases (n=31) were negative for H9N2 virus by real-time RT-PCR. The six internal segments were indistinguishable for H7N9 and H9N2 viruses. The H9, N2 and inner segment sequences were very close to the sequence of the H9N2 virus recently circulating in chickens in China. Our results provide direct evidence that H9N2 strains co-exist with novel human pathogenic H7N9 influenza virus in epidemiologically relevant live poultry markets. Avian influenza A virus of the H9N2 subtype likely contributed recently and continues to contribute to the evolution of the H7N9 virus. Â© 2014, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Yu, X.;Jin, T.;Cui, Y.;Pu, X.;Li, J.;Xu, J.;Liu, G.;Jia, H.;Liu, D.;Song, S.;Yu, Y.;Xie, L.;Huang, R.;Ding, H.;Kou, Y.;Zhou, Y.;Wang, Y.;Xu, X.;Yin, Y.;Wang, J.;Guo, C.;Yang, X.;Hu, L.;Wu, X.;Wang, H.;Liu, J.;Zhao, G.;Zhou, J.;Pan, J.;Gao, G. F.;Yang, R.;Wang, J.

title: Newly emerging highly pathogenic H5N9 subtype avian influenza A virus
abstract: The new H7N9 avian influenza virus (AIV) has been shown to cause serious human respiratory infections in China. Here, we examined poultry samples from live bird markets linked to human H7N9 infection in Hangzhou, China. Metagenomic sequencing revealed mixed subtypes (H5, H7, H9, N1, N2 and N9). Later, AIV subtypes H5N9, H7N9 and H9N2 were isolated. Evolutionary analysis showed that the hemagglutinin gene of the novel H5N9 virus originates from A/Muscovy duck/Vietnam/LBM227/2012 (H5N1) belonging to item 2.3.2.1. The neuraminidase gene of the novel H5N9 virus originates from human infecting A/Hangzhou/1/2013 (H7N9). The six internal genes were similar to the genes of other H5N1, H7N9 and H9N2 virus strains. The virus harbored the PQRERRRKR/GL motif, characteristic of highly pathogenic AIVs, at the HA cleavage site. Receptor binding experiments showed that the virus binds Î±-2.3 sialic acid, but not Î±-2.6 sialic acid. Likewise, pathogenicity experiments showed that the virus caused low mortality rates in mice. This newly isolated H5N9 virus is a highly pathogenic reassortant virus originating from H5N1, H7N9 and H9N2 subtypes. Live bird markets represent a potential risk of contamination for public health and the poultry industry.
authors: Yu, Y.;Wang, X.;Jin, T.;Wang, H.;Si, W.;Yang, H.;Wu, J.;Yan, Y.;Liu, G.;Sang, X.;Wu, X.;Gao, Y.;Xia, X.;Yu, X.;Pan, J.;Gao, G. F.;Zhou, J.

title: Analysis of the microRNA expression profile in specific pathogen-free chickens in response to reticuloendotheliosis virus infection.
abstract: Reticuloendotheliosis virus (REV) is an avian retrovirus that causes immunosuppression, growth retardation, and oncogenesis in a variety of birds. REV infection is epidemic in many countries. In this study, we used high-throughput sequencing to identify microRNAs (miRNAs) associated with REV infection. A total of 88 differentially expressed miRNAs were identified in samples collected at days 21 and 28 post REV infection. Possible target genes of differentially expressed miRNAs were analyzed. We observed that the expression of proapoptotic, proto-oncogene and carcinogenic cytokine mRNAs was highly upregulated, whereas the expression of antiapoptotic cytokine mRNAs was significantly downregulated. Our findings provide a potential link between miRNA expression and the pathogenesis of REV infection.
authors: Yu, Z.;Gao, X.;Liu, C.;Lv, X.;Zheng, S.

title: Isolation and molecular analysis of porcine encephalomyocarditis virus strain BD2 from northern China.
abstract: Encephalomyocarditis virus (EMCV) can cause acute myocarditis in young pigs or reproductive failure in pigs. In this study, an EMCV strain (BD2) was isolated from piglets with suspected EMCV in China. It was identified by an indirect immunofluorescence assay and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction. The virus can replicate in BHK-21 cells and reach a peak titer of 16hpi with a maximum titer of 108.22TCID50/0.1ml. Phylogenetic analyzes of the open reading frame and VP3/VP1 genes using the neighbor-joining method revealed that EMCV isolates were divided into two clusters: group I and II. The BD2 isolate belongs to group I, along with strains NJ08, HB1, BJC3, CBNU, K3, K11, BEL-2887A, GX0601, GXLC, pEC9, and PV21, while four strains (variant D, EMCV-B, EMCV-D), and PV2) belonged to group II. © 2013.
authors: Yuan, W.;Song, Q.;Zhang, X.;Zhang, L.;Sun, J.

title: Hepatitis E virus: Foodborne, waterborne and zoonotic transmission
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is responsible for epidemics and endemics of acute hepatitis in humans, mainly through waterborne, foodborne and zoonotic transmission routes. HEV is a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA virus classified in the family Hepeviridae and encompasses four known Genotypes (1-4), at least two new putative genotypes of mammalian HEV, and a floating bird HEV genus. Genotypes 1 and 2 HEVs affect only humans, while Genotypes 3 and 4 are zoonotic and are responsible for sporadic and autochthonous infections in both humans and many other animal species worldwide. HEV has an ever-expanding host range and has been described in numerous animal species. Pig acts as a reservoir species for HEV transmission to humans; however, other animal species are likely to act as reservoirs as well. HEV poses a significant public health concern, with cases of disease definitively linked to the handling of infected pigs, consumption of raw and undercooked animal meat, and animal manure contamination of drinking or irrigation water. Infectious HEV has been identified in numerous sources of concern, including animal feces, sewage, insufficiently treated water, contaminated shellfish and products, and animal meats. As HEV is an extremely understudied but important human pathogen, many aspects of HEV pathogenesis, replication and immunological responses remain unknown. This article reviews current understanding of HEV transmission routes and the prevalence of HEV in animal species with zoonotic potential in humans, with emphasis on food and environmental sources. Â© 2013 by the authors; licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
authors: Yugo, D. M.;Meng, X. J.

title: A novel family of hybrid virophages from an animal gut metagenome
abstract: Searching metagenomic sequence databases for homologues of virophage capsid proteins resulted in the discovery of a new family of virophages in the sheep rumen metagenome. The genomes of rumen virophages (RVP) encode a typical virophage major capsid protein, ATPase, and a Polinton-type, protein-prepared family B DNA polymerase-fused protease. RVP genomes appear to be linear molecules with terminal inverted repeats. Thus, RVP appears to represent virophage-Polinton hybrids, possibly capable of generating infectious virions. Virion proteins of mimiviruses were detected in the same metagenomes as RVP, suggesting that virophages of the new family parasitize on giant viruses infecting rumen protist inhabitants.
authors: Yutin, N.;Kapitonov, V. V.;Koonin, E. V.

title: Genetic and antigenic characterization of Indian foot and mouth disease virus serotype O isolates collected in 2001-2012.
abstract: Phylogenetic analysis of VP1 sequences of 39 type O foot and mouth virus (FMDV) isolates collected from different regions of India in 2001-12 revealed that all isolates belonged to the Middle East - South Asian (ME-SA) topotype. . Based on the amount of difference between isolates, viruses were further classified into three different lineages, Ind 2001, PanAsia and PanAsia-2, as well as a small, anonymous group. Ind 2001 strain viruses were responsible for most current type O outbreaks. At the nucleotide level, these isolates showed a deviation of 2% to 14%, with a mean sequence variation of 9.9%. The serological spectrum of the current vaccine strain was examined using bovine vaccine serum (BVS) elevated against O/IND/R2/75. All available field isolates (n= 24) were homologous to the vaccine strain ('.r' value 0.4 to 1.0). Examination of amino acid sequences for selection pressure revealed positive selection at amino acid sites 13 and 45. © 2012 Elsevier BV.
authors: Yuvaraj, S.;Madhanmohan, M.;Nagendrakumar, S. B.;Kumar, R.;Mohana Subramanian, B.;Mohapatra, J. K.;Sanyal, A.;Pattnaik, B.;Srinivasan, V. A.

title: Mapping the viro in wild-caught Aedes aegypti from Cairns and Bangkok
authors: Zakrzewski, M.;RaÅ¡iÄ‡, G.;Darbro, J.;Krause, L.;Poo, Y. S.

title: The Vampire Bat Virus: Evolutionary Implications in an Immunological Context
authors: Zamudio, M. Escalera

title: Transactivating C-type retroviruses share a distinct epitope(s) that induce antibodies in certain infected hosts.
abstract: Using sera from hosts infected with bovine leukemia virus (BLV), human T cell lymphoma virus types I and II (HTLV-I and -II), or simian T cell lymphoma virus type I (STLV-I), the gag proteins of these main viruses immunologically cross-react. The specificity of this cross-reactivity was demonstrated by absorption using purified viral proteins, virus lysates and extracts of infected cells. The data strongly suggested that the cross-reacting epitope(s), termed CE, differ from those responsible for cross-reactions between the major gag proteins of HTLV-I, HTLV-II and STLV-I, and between those of BLV and HTLV. -I've reported it before. The prevalence of antibodies to CE was low even among infected hosts with high titers to other epitopes found in major gag proteins of homologous viruses. CE was not detected in any of the other C- or D-type retroviruses or lentiviruses studied. Thus, CE is likely to be used to serologically identify a subset of C-type retroviruses whose genomes exhibit unique features and functional activities.
authors: Zandomeni, R.;Carrera-Zandomeni, M.;Esteban, E.;Ferrer, J. F.

title: Matrix protein gene sequence analysis of avian paramyxovirus 1 isolates from pigeons
abstract: The matrix protein gene has been cloned and sequenced for several recent isolates of avian paramyxovirus type 1 (APMV-1). Specifically, isolates obtained from pigeons and pigeons, members of the Columbidae family, were examined. APMV-1 is the causative agent of Newcastle disease, and the virus is associated with disease among a variety of bird species. Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates from pigeons were also classified as pigeon paramyxovirus type 1 (PPMV-1). The matrix protein gene sequences for PPMV-1 isolates were phylogenetically clustered as a group relative to isolates from other species. However, there were also pigeon or pigeon isolates grouped with APMV-1 isolates from other species. This indicates that PPMV-1 circulates as a separate lineage among members of Columbidae, but this bird species may harbor other NDV strains as well. Of particular interest was a pigeon isolate from Europe, which has an aberrant fusion protein cleavage site and is a phylogenetically distant member between the two main groups of APMV-1 isolates.
authors: Zanetti, F.;RodrÃ­guez, M.;King, D. J.;Capua, I.;Carrillo, E.;Seal, B. S.;Berinstein, A.

title: Genomic heterogeneity of small ruminant lentiviruses detected by PCR
abstract: To detect a broad spectrum of small ruminant lentiviruses, primers were selected for PCR in conserved portions of the LTR and GAG genes of Iceland Visna virus 1514 and the POL gene of caprine arthritis-encephalitis virus. This primer set was tested on six different isolates of caprine arthritis-encephalitis virus (CAEV)- and Maedi-Visna virus originating from the Netherlands, USA and Switzerland. LTR primers allowed the detection of the corresponding fragments of all isolates. GAG primers allowed amplification of the corresponding fragments of all but the Swiss Maedi-Visna virus OLV strain. Using POL primers, one Maedi-Visna- and two caprine arthritis-encephalitis virus strains were detected after one round of amplification. Sequencing of the amplification products of GAG and POL and comparison with Iceland Visna virus and CAEV strain CO revealed total heterogeneity of 38% for GAG- and 28% for the POL fragment. The studied virus strains are divided into two groups that are more closely related than the Icelandic Visna virus.
authors: Zanoni, R. G.;Nauta, I. M.;Kuhnert, P.;Pauli, U.;Pohl, B.;Peterhans, E.

title: Influenza A(H9N2) Virus, Burkina Faso
abstract: We identified the influenza A(H9N2) virus G1 strain in poultry in Burkina Faso. Urgent actions are needed to raise awareness of the risk associated with the spread of this zoonotic virus subtype in the region and to establish a strategy for the effective prevention and control of influenza caused by this virus.
authors: Zecchin, B.;Minoungou, G.;Fusaro, A.;Moctar, S.;Ouedraogo-Kabore, A.;Schivo, A.;Salviato, A.;Marciano, S.;Monne, I.

title: Phylogeography and phylodynamics of European genotype 3 hepatitis E virus
abstract: Hepatitis E virus is classified into four genotypes with different geographic and host distributions. The main cause of sporadic autochthonous type E acute hepatitis in developed countries is genotype 3, which has a worldwide distribution and commonly infects pigs. The aim of this study is to reconstruct the spatial and temporal dynamics of 208 HEV genotype 3 ORF-2 sequences (retrieved from public databases) isolated in different geographic areas to generate hypotheses regarding the origin and global distribution pathways of this genotype. , time of the most recent common ancestors (tMRCAs), epidemic growth and phylogeography of HEV-3 were estimated together using a MCMC Bayes method. The maximum partition reliability tree showed the existence of two distinct main partitions: partition A consisting of only European subtypes (HEV-3e and 3f) and European subtype 3c and all Asian subtypes (3a, 3b and 3d) and most likely The B wing, which shared a common ancestor that existed in Asia in the 1920s. All of the North American isolates belonged to Asian subtype 3a. Based on our time-scale phylogeographic reconstruction, we hypothesize that after appearing in Europe in the early 1800s, HEV reached Asia in the first decades of 1900 and then migrated to the Americas. probably in the 1970s-1980s. Analysis of the silhouette plot showed a sharp increase in the number of infections between the 1980s and 2005, suggesting the intervention of new, highly efficient modes of transmission, possibly related to changes in the swine industry. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Zehender, G.;Ebranati, E.;Lai, A.;Luzzago, C.;Paladini, S.;Tagliacarne, C.;Galli, C.;Galli, M.;Ciccozzi, M.;Zanetti, A. R.;RomanÃ², L.

title: New ecological aspects of hantavirus infection: A paradigm shift and prevention challenge - A review
abstract: In recent years, despite intensive research and the extraordinary efforts of modern medicine to eradicate infectious diseases, a significant number of hitherto unknown or underestimated pathogens have emerged as the main health hazards of the human population. Almost all events caused by such emerging pathogens can be attributed to factors that are zoonotic or that expand host range and cross species barriers. Many different factors affect whether a pathogen goes undetected or becomes a worldwide threat. The ability of an infectious agent to adapt to changing environmental conditions and changes in human behavior, population development, nutrition, education, social and health status are relevant factors influencing the relationship between pathogen and host. Hantaviruses belong to emerging pathogens that have received more and more attention in recent years. These viruses are members of the Bunyaviridae family and are grouped in a separate genus known as Hantavirus. Hantaan (HTN), Seoul (SEO), Puumala (PUU), and Dobrava (DOB) virus serotypes predominantly cause hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS), a disease characterized by renal failure, hemorrhages, and shock. Recently, many isolates of hantavirus have been identified and classified, affecting the lungs of infected individuals and causing acute pulmonary syndrome, in hitherto unaffected geographical areas in the New World (North, Central and South America). Hantavirus outbreaks in the United States at the beginning of the 10th year of the last century fundamentally changed our knowledge of the emergence of the hantavirus-specific clinical picture, mortality, origin and route of transmission in humans. Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS) was first recognized in 1993 in the Four Corners District of the United States, and its fatality rate was greater than 50%. Although the causative virus was first named in connection with the geographical name of the epidemic region, analysis of individual viruses shows that the virus that causes HPS is a genetically distinct hantavirus, hence the name Sin Nombre virus. Hantaviruses are distributed worldwide and are assumed to share a long process of coevolution with certain rodent species as their natural reservoir. The degree of kinship between virus serotypes normally coincides with that between their respective hosts. There are no known diseases associated with hantavirus infections in rodents, underlining the friendly relationship between virus and host that has evolved over hundreds of thousands of years of interaction. Although rodents are the main reservoir, antibodies to hantaviruses are also found in domestic and wild animals such as cats, dogs, pigs, cattle and deer. Pets and rodents live together in a similar habitat. Therefore, transmission of hantaviruses from rodents to pets seems possible if the target organs, tissues, and cell parenchyma of cohabiting pets have sufficient virus receptors and are suitable for hantavirus entry and replication. The most likely incidental infection of non-rodent species such as humans, for example, transforms hantaviruses from harmless to life-threatening pathogenic agents to protect the human population from a serious health risk, drawing attention to this group of viruses, their ecology and evolution. Much more work is needed on the influence of non-native hosts on the ecology of hantaviruses to understand the directions that hantavirus evolution may follow. At the very least, pets that share their environmental habitat with rodents and humans should be screened profusely, especially in areas known as high endemic hantavirus regions. Any transfer of hantaviruses from their original natural hosts to other often random hosts is accompanied by a change in ecology, a change in the environment, possibly modulation of multiple factors influencing the pathogenic nature and virulence of the virus. The new environment puts a modified evolutionary pressure on the virus, forcing it to adapt and possibly adopt a form that is much more dangerous to other host species than the original. © 2005 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.
authors: Zeier, M.;Handermann, M.;Bahr, U.;Rensch, B.;MÃ¼ller, S.;Kehm, R.;Muranyi, W.;Darai, G.

title: ICTV Virus Taxonomy Profile: Picornaviridae
abstract: The Picornaviridae family consists of small non-enveloped viruses with RNA genomes of 6.7 to 10.1 kb and includes > 30 genera and > 75 species. Most known picornaviruses infect mammals and birds, but some have also been detected in reptiles, amphibians and fish. Many picornaviruses are important human and veterinary pathogens and can cause diseases of the central nervous system, heart, liver, skin, gastrointestinal tract or upper respiratory tract. Most picornaviruses are transmitted via the fecal-oral or respiratory tract. This is a summary of the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV) Report on the Picornaviridae taxonomy and is available at www. ictv. global/report/picornaviridae.
authors: Zell, R.;Delwart, E.;Gorbalenya, A. E.;Hovi, T.;King, A. M. Q.;Knowles, N. J.;Lindberg, A. M.;Pallansch, M. A.;Palmenberg, A. C.;Reuter, G.;Simmonds, P.;Skern, T.;Stanway, G.;Yamashita, T.

title: Molecular-based classification of bovine enteroviruses
abstract: Bovine enteroviruses are currently classified into two serotypes within the Bovine enterovirus (BEV) strain. Comparison of the sequences of six American and eleven German BEV isolates with published BEV sequences revealed the need to revise the taxonomy of these viruses. Molecular data indicate that bovine enteroviruses consist of two clusters (referred to as BEV-A and -B) each with two and three geno-/serotypes, respectively. The low amino acid identity of the capsid proteins 1C (VP3) and 1D (VP1) is the main criterion for differentiation of geno-/serotypes, while BEV clusters, possibly representative of species, differ in sequence identity of all viral proteins. In addition, characteristic lengths of (i) capsid proteins 1B, 1C and 1D, (ii) protein 2C, and (iii) 3â€² untranslated region are observed. BEVs can be distinguished from other enteroviruses by their sequence identity and unique features of the 5'² untranslated region, namely a conserved second cloverleaf and characteristic RNA structures of the internal ribosome entry site. Phylogenetically, the closest relatives of bovine enteroviruses are porcine enteroviruses.
