Incompatible phylogenies; Capsid proteins of the 5–² untranslated region and 3D polymerase show frequent intraserotypic and interserotypic recombination within the non-capsid and capsid region of the BEV genome. © 2006 SGM.
authors: Zell, R.;Krumbholz, A.;Dauber, M.;Hoey, E.;Wutzler, P.

title: Application of genome sequence information in classification of bovine enteroviruses: importance of 5'- and 3'-untranslated regions
abstract: Comparative genomics of viruses are well established in evolutionary and phylogenetic studies. Previous nucleic acid sequence analyzes have shown that enteroviruses and rhinoviruses of the Picornaviridae family exhibit a similar structure of the 5'-untranslated region (NTR), which differs significantly from the 5'-NTR of cardiovirus, aphtovirus, hepatovirus and echovirus 22 (temporarily parecovirus). . one). The available nucleotide sequence information of the 5'- and 3'-untranslated regions of more than 70 enterovirus, bovine enterovirus and rhinovirus serotypes was compared and correlated with previous findings obtained after analysis of the coding and non-coding genome regions. Consequently, the 5'- and 3'-NTRs of all three virus groups are characterized by group-specific nucleotide sequences. When focusing on bovine enterovirus (BEV) serotypes, unique features were observed in all secondary structures of NTRs. These features clearly distinguish BEVs from human enteroviruses and rhinoviruses. Regarding the 5'-NTR, the most striking feature is the insertion of about 110 nucleotides between the putative cloverleaf structure and the IRES element at the very 5'-end of the viral genome. This addition was shown for BEV I and :! and has a predictive folding pattern very similar to the 5'-cloverleaf structure. One root ring of this second cloverleaf is almost identical to the 3CD(pro)-binding domain of rhinoviral 5'-clover leaves. Moreover, IRES elements and 3'-NTRs of both enteroviruses and rhinoviruses have been shown to have group-specific features that differ significantly from the corresponding genome regions of BEV. These results indicate that bovine enteroviruses occupy an exceptional taxonomic position alongside the established Enterovirus and Rhinovirus genera. The existence of virus clusters representing subspecies within the Enterovirus and Rhinovirus genera has been suggested previously. The 5'-NTRs of the four human enterovirus clusters are divided into two groups, while all four clusters have characteristic secondary structures at the 3'-NTR, supporting the concept of enterovirus clusters. The existence of two virus clusters was confirmed for rhinoviruses.
authors: Zell, R.;Stelzner, A.

title: â€¦Â New Human-Like H3N2 Influenza A Viruses, A/swine/Oklahoma/65980/2017 (H3N2) and A/Swine/Oklahoma/65260/2017 (H3N2), Detected in Pigs in the United States â€¦
authors: Zeller, M. A.;Li, G.;Harmon, K. M.;Zhang, J.

title: Whole genome sequence analysis of goat pox virus isolated from China shows high variation
abstract: Goat pox virus (GTPV), a member of the Capripoxvirus genus of the Poxviridae family, is the causative agent of variolo caprina (goat pox). GTPV can cause significant economic losses and threaten breeding stocks in native ruminants in endemic areas. In this study, we report on the compilation of the complete genomic sequence of an isolated GTPV domain strain FZ (GTPV_FZ). 150,194. The bp GTPV genome consists of a central coding region bounded by two identical 2301. bp inverted terminal repeats and contains 151 putative genes. Comparative genomic analysis reveals that the distinct genetic relationships between Capripoxviruses are close, but sufficient genomic variants have been identified in the field isolate strain FZ to distinguish it from other GTPV strains and other Capripoxvirus strains. Phylogenetic analysis based on p32 and the complete GTPV genome can be used to distinguish between SPPVs, GTPVs, and LSDVs. These data can contribute to the epidemiological study of Chinese capripox virus and assist in the development of more specific detection methods to distinguish between GTPVs, SPPVs and LSDVs. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Zeng, X.;Chi, X.;Li, W.;Hao, W.;Li, M.;Huang, X.;Huang, Y.;Rock, D. L.;Luo, S.;Wang, S.

title: Integrative analyzes of transcriptome sequencing identify functional miRNAs in chicken embryo fibroblast cells infected with reticuloendotheliosis virus.
abstract: In this study, we found that chicken embryo fibroblasts (CEF) infected with reticuloendotheliosis virus (REV) were much higher in active cell division phase, suggesting that REV may influence the fate of CEF. Therefore, to understand the possible mechanism in the interaction of REV with CEF, we performed high-throughput sequencing and transcriptomic analysis to identify functional miRNAs. In total, 50 differentially expressed miRNAs (DEmiRNAs) were identified. The target genes of DEmiRNAs were then predicted and identified by the transcriptome profile results. The Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) enrichment was performed to analyze the identified target genes of miRNAs, showing that metabolism, cell cycle and apoptosis are the most relevant pathways involved in REV infection. We analyzed cell cycle-related genes showing that the CyclinD1-CDK6 complex plays an important role in regulating the transition of the cell cycle from G1 phase to S phase during REV infection. Fluorescent microscopy identification showed that REV inhibited CEF apoptosis, in agreement with transcriptome results. A new miRNA named Roman-72 was found, KEGG analysis was performed to predict the biological function of its target genes and showed that these target genes are significantly enriched in the mTOR signaling pathway and function to promote cell cycle and cell growth during REV infection. . In conclusion, REV can induce upregulation of cell metabolism, cell cycle and mTOR signaling pathway while inhibiting cell apoptosis.
authors: Zhai, J.;Ga, C.;Fu, L.;Jing, L.;Dang, S.;Zheng, S.

title: Viral metagenomic analysis shows the diversity of viral flora in piglet diarrheal stool in China.
abstract: To investigate the diversity of the viral flora, we used metagenomics to examine viral communities in a stool sample of 27 diarrheal piglets collected from busy commercial farms in China. The 15 different mammalian viruses identified in the pooled diarrheal sample, in order of nucleic acid sequence abundance, were Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV), sapovirus, porcine bocavirus-4 (PBoV-4), sapelovirus, torovirus, coronavirus, PBoV-. 2, fecal-associated single-stranded DNA virus (poSCV), astrovirus (AstV), cobuvirus, posavirus-1, porcine enterovirus-9 (PEV-9), porcine circovirus-like (po-circo-like) virus, picobirnavirus (PBV), and Torque teno sus virus 2 (TTSuV-2). The prevalence rate of each virus was confirmed by PCR assay from diarrheal and healthy piglets. Piglets with diarrhea shed an average of 5.5 different viruses, and in fact one piglet was co-infected with 11 different viruses. In contrast, healthy piglets shed an average of 3.2 different viruses. A high prevalence rate of PEDV and PBoV co-infection in diarrheal samples compared with samples from healthy piglets suggests a correlation with the appearance of diarrhea in piglets. In addition, we report here for the first time the existence of several recently identified viruses and the identification of new genotypes in China. Therefore, our research results provide an unbiased investigation of viral communities and prevalence in stool samples of piglets.
authors: Zhang, B.;Tang, C.;Yue, H.;Ren, Y.;Song, Z.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel rodent bocavirus from different rodent species in China
abstract: Members of the genus Bocaparvovirus are closely related to human health and have a wide host range. Diverse hosts increase the likelihood of crossing the species barrier, which is a feature of emerging viruses. Among mammalian hosts, rodents are generally recognized as important reservoirs of emerging viruses. Here, rodent samples collected from six provinces and autonomous regions of China (Liaoning, Inner Mongolia, Tibet, Xinjiang, Guangxi, and Yunnan) were used to investigate the prevalence and distribution of bocaparvoviruses. First, using next-generation sequencing, the partial nonstructural protein 1 (NS1) gene of a possible novel bocaparvovirus was discovered. Subsequently, PCR-based screening of the NS1 gene was performed in 485 rodent samples, and 106 positive results were found in seven rodent species (Rattus norvegicus, Mus musculus, Apodemus agrarius, Cricetulus barabensis, Rattus flavipectus, Rattus rattus and Rhombomys opimus). Finally, six nearly full-length genomes and three complete CDS were obtained, and the newly identified bocaparvovirus was tentatively named rodent bocavirus (RoBoV). RoBoV has three ORFs: NS1, NP1 and VP, which are features of bocaparvoviruses. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that the porcine bocavirus isolate PBoV-KU14, a member of Ungulate bocaparvovirus 4, is the virus most related to RoBoV, with 92.1-92.9% amino acid identity in the NS1 protein. Alignment of RoBoV-related sequences showed that RoBoV isolates could be classified into two clades with an inter-host genetic variation. The results demonstrate potential interspecies transmission of RoBoV between rodents and pigs and expand our knowledge of bocaparvoviruses in rodent populations.
authors: Zhang, C.;Song, F.;Xiu, L.;Liu, Y.;Yang, J.;Yao, L.;Peng, J.

title: [Phylogenetic analysis of 2009 H1N1(A) influenza virus based on genomic sequence features]
abstract: Beginning in April 2009, a new strain of human H1N1 influenza virus swept the world. The genome of the influenza virus consists of 8 segments coding for 10 proteins, respectively. Reclassification between 8 segments results in variation of influenza virus. Therefore, phylogenetic analysis of 8 genes is very important. In this paper, we select the neighboring word frequency as genomic features using VC++ programming to analyze the evolution of 8 segments of the H1N1 virus. As a result, we found that the PB2 genes and PA genes of these three isolated viruses originate from the North American avian influenza virus, the PB1 genes originate from the human seasonal influenza virus, and the HA genes, NS genes, and NP genes come from. From the North American classic swine flu A virus. The NA segments and M segments originated from the European swine flu virus.
authors: Zhang, F.;Guo, X.;Cheng, W.;Wang, Y.;Zhang, S.

title: Complete nucleotide sequence of a coxsackie B5 virus and association with porcine vesicular disease virus
abstract: We report the first complete nucleotide sequence of picornavirus coxsackievirus B5 (CB5), strain 1954/UK/85 isolated from a hand-foot-mouth disease. We compared the array with other coxsackie B viruses, coxsackievirus A9, poliovirus and porcine vesicular disease virus (SVDV). The genes encoding the three major capsid proteins are most closely related to those of SVDV, but the 5' and 3' noncoding regions and the P3 gene are more similar to the corresponding regions in other coxsackie B viruses than those of SVDV. These observations are evaluated in light of the antigenic and biochemical relationships between SVDV and CB5.
authors: Zhang, G.;Wilsden, L. G.;Knowles, L. N. J.;McCauley, J. W.

title: Characterization of an Enterovirus strain E isolated from naturally infected cattle in China.
abstract: Bovine enteroviruses belonging to the Picornaviridae family can cause clinical symptoms in cattle and are excreted in the faeces. In this study, a cytolytic virus was isolated from Madin-Darby bovine kidney (MDBK) cells from bovine stool samples with severe diarrhea and hemorrhagic intestinal mucosa, originally diagnosed as bovine viral diarrhea (BVD) by a bovine viral diarrhea virus Ag. point-of-care testing (IDEXX, American). Random priming PCR was used to amplify the underlying viral sequences and identify the isolated virus. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the isolated virus closely matched the EV-E2 strains, which differed from other previously isolated Chinese strains. The newly identified virus was named HLJ-3531/2013. We infected sullen mice with isolated virus. Reverse transcription PCR, hematoxylin and eosin (HE) staining, serum neutralization (SN) testing, and virus isolation from various tissues revealed that HLJ-3531/2013 can infect the gut, liver, and lung of lactating mice. The present study is the first to report the reproduction of clinical symptoms by an isolated virus in an experimental infection model of animals and provides a solid basis for the development of the pathogenesis of bovine enteroviruses.
authors: Zhang, H.;Liu, H.;Bao, J.;Guo, Y.;Peng, T.;Zhou, P.;Zhang, W.;Ma, B.;Wang, J.;Gao, M.

title: Genome-wide analysis of differentially expressed genes and modulation of PEDV infection in Vero E6 cells
abstract: PEDV remains one of the most important swine diseases infecting pigs of all ages. It causes devastating viral enteric disease in piglets with a high mortality rate, causing significant threats to the pig industry and huge economic losses. In this study, a transcriptomic shotgun sequencing (RNA-Seq) procedure was used to examine gene responses to PEDV infection. Genome-wide analysis of differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in Vero E6 cells after PEDV infection was performed. mTOR signaling pathway activator-MHY1485 and inhibitor-PP242 were used to study antiviral function. The results revealed that IRF3 was significantly upregulated after PEDV infection. While most of the IFN regulatory and IFN-related genes evaluated in this study were either downregulated or unchanged, IL11 acted significantly upregulated with a peak at 16 hpi. While approximately 90% of PEDV infections were suppressed in cells pretreated with PP242, The opposite effect was observed in cells pretreated with MYH1485. The results showed that the mTOR signaling pathway plays a vital role in PEDV antiviral regulation in Vero E6 cells. Future studies will contribute to a better understanding of the cellular antiviral mechanism against PEDV.
authors: Zhang, H.;Liu, Q.;Su, W.;Wang, J.;Sun, Y.;Zhang, J.;Shang, K.;Chen, Z.;Cheng, S.;Wu, H.

title: Pig bocaviruses: genetic analysis and prevalence in the Chinese pig population
abstract: Of the members of the Bocavirus genus, which includes the three open reading frames (ORFs) of the Parvovirinae subfamily, porcine bocaviruses (PoBoVs) exhibit the greatest genetic diversity. According to the ORF2-encoded viral protein (VP1) classification, the six reported porcine bocaviruses were divided into four types: PoBoV1 (swine boca-like virus or PBoLV), PoBoV2 (swine parvovirus 4 or PPV4), PoBoV3 (PBoV1/PBoV2) and PoBoV4 (6V/7V). ), PoBoV3 and PoBoV4 each have two genotypes of virus. All four PoBoV strains were detected in 166 samples collected from pig herds in ten provinces of China in 2010. Detection rates for PoBoV1-4 were 28Â·9%, 6Â·6%, 19Â·3% and 39Â·7%, respectively. The combinations of co-infections involving these six swine bocaviruses in the samples collected were very complex. In addition, mixed infections with viruses from other families (swine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus, classical swine fever virus and porcine circovirus type 2) were also detected. Â© Cambridge University Press 2011.
authors: Zhang, H. B.;Huang, L.;Liu, Y. J.;Lin, T.;Sun, C. Q.;Deng, Y.;Wei, Z. Z.;Cheung, A. K.;Long, J. X.;Yuan, S. S.

title: Response to "Classification of US swine epidemic diarrhea virus strains revealed by phylogenetic analysis of nucleocapsid and ORF3 genes"
authors: Zhang, J.;Chen, Q.;Gauger, P. C.;Harmon, K. M.;Yoon, K. J.

title: Molecular Characterization and Seroprevalence in Pigs SC0806, a Feline Que Virus Isolated from Mosquitoes in Sichuan Province, China.
abstract: The Simbu serogroup currently consists of a highly diverse group of related arboviruses that infect both humans and economically important animal species. Cat Que virus (CQV), a Simbu serogroup virus of the genus Orthobunyavirus (family Bunyaviridae), was first isolated from mosquitoes in 2004 during surveillance of arbovirus activity in acute pediatric encephalitis in northern Vietnam. Here we report the complete genome sequence of SC0806 isolated from mosquitoes (Culex tritaeniorhynchus) in Sichuan Province, China. Consistent with the genomic organization of Simbu serogroup viruses, the SC0806 genome contains three RNA segments - a large (L) segment (6928 nucleotides), a middle (M) segment (4481), encoding 2261-amino acid RNA-dependent RNA polymerase. nucleotides encoding a 1433 amino acid polyprotein) and a 234 amino acid nucleocapsid protein and a small (S) segment (984 nucleotides) encoding a 95 amino acid nonstructural protein. The corresponding lengths of the 5â€²-untranslated region (UTR) and the 3â€²-UTR of L, M and S are 56 and 86, 43 and 136 and 44 and 238 nucleotides. Sequence (nucleotide and deduced amino acid) comparison and phylogenetic analysis revealed that SC0806 is closely related to the reported Vietnamese isolate CQV. This is the first time that CQV has been isolated in Sichuan Province, China. Anti-SC0806 immunoglobulin M (IgM) and IgG antibodies were found in locally reared pigs, indicating that CQV forms a natural cycle in the local area. Surveillance of the distribution and pathogenicity of SC0806 should be strengthened.
authors: Zhang, J.;Wang, J.;Wang, L.;Fu, S.;Li, M.;Zhao, G.;Zhu, W.;Wang, D.;Liang, G.

title: High-throughput whole genome sequencing of Pig reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus from cell culture materials and clinical specimens using next-generation sequencing technology.
abstract: Next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies have played increasingly important roles in biological and medical research, but are not yet in routine use in veterinary diagnostic laboratories. We have developed and implemented a procedure for high-throughput RNA sequencing of Porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome virus (PRRSV) from cell culture-derived isolates and clinical specimens. Ten PRRSV isolates with known sequence information, 2 mixtures each containing 2 different PRRSV isolates, and 51 clinical samples (19 serum, 16 lung and 16 oral fluids) with various PCR threshold cycle (Ct) values were subjected to nucleic acid extraction, cDNA. library preparation (24 floors) and sorting. Whole genome sequences were obtained from 10 reference isolates with expected sequences and PRRSV real-time reverse transcripted serum from lung tissues with Ct - 23.6, Ct - 21 and oral fluids with Ct - 20.6. For mixtures containing PRRSV-1 and -2 isolates (57.8% nucleotide identity), NGS was able to distinguish them as well as obtain their respective genome sequences. For mixtures with 2 PRRSV-2 isolates (92.4% nucleotide identity), sequence reads with nucleotide ambiguity were observed at various sites, indicating mixed infection; however, individual virus sequences can be separated only when the identity and sequence of 1 isolate in the mixture is known. The NGS approach described here offers the possibility of high-throughput sequencing and is adaptable to routine workflows in veterinary diagnostic laboratories, although further improvement of sequencing results from clinical specimens with higher Ct values remains under investigation.
authors: Zhang, J.;Zheng, Y.;Xia, X. Q.;Chen, Q.;Bade, S. A.;Yoon, K. J.;Harmon, K. M.;Gauger, P. C.;Main, R. G.;Li, G.

title: Insights on the response of leghorn male hepatocellular cells to fowl adenovirus serotype 4 infection by transcriptome analysis
abstract: Poultry adenovirus serotype 4 (FAdV-4), a member of the Aviadenovirus genus of the Adenoviridae family, causes hepatitis-hydropericardium syndrome (HHS) in chickens. It poses a significant threat to the poultry industry, causing mortality rates of up to 80% in 3-6 week old broilers. However, specific host responses to the virus are not well understood. To better understand the interactions between the host and FAdV-4 and investigate the pathogenesis of this virus, a high-throughput RNA-seq technology was used with leghorn male hepatocellular (LMH) cells at 12, 24 and 48 hours after FAdV. 4 infections. Using Gene Ontology (GO) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genes (KEGG) pathway enrichment analysis, we identified a total of 7000 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) enriched in various biological processes and pathways. Many immune-related pathways, including the Toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling pathway and the cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction pathway, were activated after FAdV-4 infection. Transcriptional data were confirmed by quantitative real-time PCR. The expression profiles of 10 genes involved in FAdV-4-infected chicken livers, including TLR2A, TLR3, TLR5, MyD88, IL12B, IL15, IL18, CCL20, TNFRSF21, and CD30, were consistent with their RNA-seq profiles. By transfecting small interfering RNA into LMH cells, our results confirmed that MyD88 mediates FAdV-4-induced inflammation. To our knowledge, this was the first study to use transcriptome analysis to investigate host responses to FAdV-4 infection. These findings provide insight into the pathogenesis of FAdV-4 and the mechanisms of host-FAdV-4 interaction.
authors: Zhang, J.;Zou, Z.;Huang, K.;Lin, X.;Chen, H.;Jin, M.

title: Human infection with Orf virus from goats in China, 2012
abstract: Orf virus, belonging to the genus Parapoxvirus, induces a zoonotic infectious disease characterized by acute, highly vascularized cutaneous pustular lesions in sheep and goats. A number of Orf outbreaks have been reported in sheep and goats in recent years, but there have been no reports identifying a strain of Orf virus from humans in China. In this study, we diagnosed Orf virus infection in two individuals, mother and son, in Gansu province of China. Human Orf virus was isolated and its phylogenetic characterization analyzed on the basis of a complete B2L gene. The results are useful for developing prospective programs to control Orf virus infections in both goats and humans Â© Copyright 2014, Mary Ann Liebert, Inc. 2014.
authors: Zhang, K.;Liu, Y.;Kong, H.;Shang, Y.;Liu, X.

title: Identification and analysis of differential miRNAs in PK-15 cells after FMD virus infection
abstract: Changes of MicroRNAs (miRNAs) in the host cell after foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) infection are still unclear. To increase our understanding of the pathogenesis of FMDV at the level of post-transcriptional regulation, Solexa high-throu MicroRNAs (miRNAs) play an important role in both the post-transcriptional regulation of gene expression and host-virus interactions. Despite miRNA expression studies, ghput sequencing and bioinformatics tools were used to identify differentially expressed miRNAs and analyze their function during FMDV infection of PK-15 cells. The results showed that 9,165,674 and 9,230,378 clean reads were obtained with 172 known and 72 novel miRNAs differentially expressed in the infected and uninfected groups, respectively. Some of the differentially expressed miRNAs were confirmed using real-time quantitative RT-PCR. GO annotation and KEGG pathway analysis for target genes revealed that differentially expressed miRNAs are involved in immune response and cell death pathways. Â© 2014 Zhang et al.
authors: Zhang, K. S.;Liu, Y. J.;Kong, H. J.;Cheng, W. W.;Shang, Y. J.;Tian, H.;Zheng, H. X.;Guo, J. H.;Liu, X. T.

title: Molecular Detection of Indigenous Hepatitis E Virus (HEV) from Tibetan Pigs in Tibet, China
abstract: Hepatitis E is an important public health problem all over the world. Many molecular and serological studies have reported the prevalence and genotypic characteristics of HEV in humans and animals worldwide. However, genotypic characterization of this virus is very limited in Tibetan pigs. Therefore, we aimed to investigate the prevailing HEV genotype among Tibetan pigs in China. For this purpose, bile samples of 253 Tibetan pigs (free range animals) were collected from different slaughterhouses between 2017 and 2018 and then tested for HEV RNA by RT-nPCR. A total of 11 (4.35%) of 253 samples tested were positive for HEV RNA. Based on sequence alignment and phylogenetic analysis, all isolated HEV strains belonged to genotype 4 and clustered in subtype 4b, sharing more than 84.8%-95.2% identity with other reported strains. Our results concluded that HEV genotype 4 was dominant among Tibetan pigs in Tibet, China.
authors: Zhang, L.;Huang, S.;Li, K.;Rehman, M. U.;Jiang, X.;Tong, X.;Zhang, H.;Iqbal, M. K.;Mehmood, K.;Liu, S.;Shen, Y.;Li, J.

title: Identification and characterization of microRNA in lung tissue of pigs with differential susceptibility to PCV2 infection
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) is the leading cause of postweaning multisystemic wasting syndrome (PMWS) and other PCV-related diseases. Based on our previous RNA sequencing analysis, differences in susceptibility to PCV2 infection were due to genetic differences between Laiwu (LW) and Yorkshire Ã—Landrace crossbreed (YL) pigs, but differentially expressed cellular microRNA (miRNA). It remains to be determined between LW and YL pigs before and after PCV2 infection. In this study, high-throughput sequencing was performed to determine the abundance and differential expression of miRNA in lung tissues from PCV2-infected and non-PCV2-infected LW and YL pigs. In total, 295 known and 95 new miRNAs were identified, and 23 known and 25 new miRNAs were significantly differentially expressed in PCV2-infected and non-PCV2-infected LW pigs and/or PCV2-infected and non-PCV2-infected YL pigs. Expression levels of ssc-miR-122, ssc-miR-192, ssc-miR-451, ssc-miR-486 and ssc-miR-504 were confirmed by quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR). Analysis of potential targets of four up-regulated miRNAs (i.e., ssc-miR-122, ssc-miR-192, ssc-miR-451 and ssc-miR-486) identified pathways and genes that may be important for disease resistance. . Among the upregulated miRNA, ssc-miR-122 can suppress protein expression and viral DNA replication of PCV2 and downregulate the expression of activated T-cells 5 (NFAT5) and aminopeptidase puromycin sensitive (NPEPPS) nuclear factor. It binds to the 3â€² untranslated regions (3â€²UTR) in PK15 cells. Therefore, ssc-miR-122 can indirectly suppress PCV2 infection by targeting host immune system-related genes such as NFAT5 and NPEPPS.
authors: Zhang, P.;Wang, L.;Li, Y.;Jiang, P.;Wang, Y.;Wang, P.;Kang, L.;Wang, Y.;Sun, Y.;Jiang, Y.

title: Characterization and whole genome sequence analysis of a novel virulent Siphoviridae phage against Staphylococcus aureus isolated from bovine mastitis in Xinjiang, China.
abstract: Bovine mastitis is one of the most costly diseases in dairy cows worldwide. It can be caused by more than 150 different microorganisms, of which Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequently isolated and the main pathogen responsible for heavy economic losses in the dairy industry. Although antibiotic therapy is most commonly used, alternative therapies are needed due to increasing antibiotic resistance. Using phages for pathogen control is a promising tool in the fight against antibiotic resistance. Mainly using high-throughput sequencing, bioinformatics, and our proposed method of phage termini identification, we isolated and characterized a novel killer phage, designated vB_SauS_IMEP5, from manure collected from dairy farms in Shihezi, Xinjiang, China. Staphylococcus aureus infections. The latent period was about 30Â min and the burst size was about 272PFU/cell. The phage vB_SauS_IMEP5 survives in a wide pH range from 3 to 12. A treatment at 70Â°C for 20Â minutes may cause the phage to become inactive. Morphological analysis of vB_SauS_IMEP5 revealed that the vB_SauS_IMEP5 phage was morphologically similar to phages in the Siphoviridae family. Among our tested multiplicity of infections (MOIs), the optimal multiplicity of infection (MOI) of this phage was determined as 0.001, indicating that the phage vB_SauS_IMEP5 has high bacteriolytic potential and good efficacy to reduce bacterial growth. The complete genome of IME-P5 is a 44,677-bp, linear, double-stranded DNA with 34.26% G+C content, containing 69 putative ORFs. The termini of the genome were determined by next-generation sequencing data using our previously proposed termini identification method; this indicates that this phage has 9nt 3â€² non-redundant termini with protruding sticky ends. The genomic and proteomic features of IMEP5 show that this phage does not belong to any of the previously recognized Siphoviridae Staphylococcus phage groups, suggesting the creation of a new lineage, thus adding to the knowledge about the diversity of Staphylococcus phages. One N-acetylmuramoyl-1-alanine amidase gene and several conserved genes were predicted, while no virulence or antibiotic resistance genes were identified. This study isolated and characterized a novel S. aureus phage vB_SauS_IMEP5, and our findings suggest that this phage could potentially be used as a therapeutic or prophylactic candidate against S. aureus infections.
authors: Zhang, Q.;Xing, S.;Sun, Q.;Pei, G.;Cheng, S.;Liu, Y.;An, X.;Zhang, X.;Qu, Y.;Tong, Y.

title: Phylogenetic and pathotypical analysis of two virulent Newcastle disease viruses isolated from domestic ducks in China.
abstract: In this study, two velogenic Newcastle disease viruses (NDV) from outbreaks in domestic ducks in China were characterized. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that both strains clustered with class II viruses, one phylogenetically close to genotype VII NDVs and the other genotype IX. The deduced amino acid sequence of the cleavage site of the fusion (F) protein confirmed that both isolates contained the lethal motif 112RRQK/RRF117 at the cleavage site. Two NDVs had severe pathogenicity in fully susceptible chickens and resulted in 100% mortality. One of the isolates also showed some pathogenicity in domestic ducks. This study suggests that multiple NDV genotypes circulate in domestic ducks in China and there may be viral transmission between chickens and domestic ducks. Â© 2011 Zhang et al.
authors: Zhang, S.;Wang, X.;Zhao, C.;Liu, D.;Hu, Y.;Zhao, J.;Zhang, G.

title: Serological and virological investigation for evidence of infection with velogenic Newcastle disease virus in Chinese duck farms
abstract: serological and virological study was conducted to determine the prevalence and distribution of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) infection in Chinese duck herds. NDV infection was detected in nine of the 12 farms sampled across the two geographic regions covered by the survey. The percentage of antibody positivity among 406 serum samples was 35.7%. Three velogenic NDVs were obtained from different flocks of ducks identified by hemagglutination and hemagglutination-inhibition tests, a pathogenicity test, and reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction on fusion (F) genes. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that all three isolates clustered with class II viruses; two were phylogenetically close to genotype VII NDVs and the other was more closely related to genotype IX NDVs. These findings suggest that NDV infections are common and that at least two different virulent genotypes may be responsible for recent outbreaks in Chinese duck herds. Â© American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Zhang, S.;Zhao, L.;Wang, X.;Zhang, D.;Zhao, J.;Zhang, G.

title: Transcript Profiling Identifies Early Response Genes to FMDV Infection in PK-15 Cells
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is a highly contagious disease that causes huge economic losses worldwide. Although the protection afforded by vaccination during early infection is limited, it is considered the best method of preventing foot-and-mouth disease outbreaks. Furthermore, the mechanism of early host responses to foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) infection remains unclear. In our study, a porcine kidney cell line (PK-15) was used as a cell model to reveal the mechanism of early porcine responses to FMDV infection. Four untreated control and four FMDV-treated PK-15 cells were sequenced by RNA-seq technology and differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were analyzed. The results showed 1212° in FMDV-infected PK-15 cells, including 914 up-regulated and 298 down-regulated genes. The Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathways were significantly enriched in tumor necrosis factor (TNF), cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction, NOD-like receptor, toll-like receptor, NF-kappaB, and chemokine signaling pathways. To validate the results of DEGs, 30 immune-related DEGs (19 up-regulated and 11 down-regulated) were selected for Quantitative Reverse Transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) validation. The results showed that genes measured by RT-qPCR exhibited a similar pattern as RNA-seq analyses. Based on the bioinformatic analysis, during FMDV early infection, a set of cytokines such as interleukins (IL6), chemokines (CXCL2, CCL20 and CCL4) and transcription factors (ZFP36, FOS, NFKBIA, ZBTB3, ZNF503, ZNF283), dymeclinic (DYM) and orthodenticle homeobox 1 (OTX1)) took part in the battle between FMDV and the host. Along with its characteristics and functions, we propose inflammation as the main early mechanism by which the host responds to FMDV infection. These data provide an additional panel of candidate genes to decipher the mechanisms of a host's early response to FMDV infection.
authors: Zhang, T.;Chen, H.;Qi, L.;Zhang, J.;Wu, R.;Zhang, Y.;Sun, Y.

title: Effects of PrPC on biological processes of DF-1 cells and RNA-seq-based analysis of differential genes
abstract: To reveal the effects of PrPC on cells' biological processes and gene expression. We generated stable DF-1 (PrPC-knockdown (KD)) cells and fused them with previously generated DF-1 (wt) and DF-1 (PrPC-overexpression (OE)) cells and examined the effects of chicken PrPC (PrPC) DF -1 in the processes of cells. Next, we analyzed genes (DEGs) differentially expressed among these cells, using high-throughput sequencing technology (HTS) and bioinformatics. The results show that, when compared with DF-1 (wt) and DF-1 (PrPC-scramble), DF-1 (PrPC-KD) significantly decreased in terms of adhesion, proliferation, colony formation rate and colony cell number, scratch wound. recovery rate, number of cell invasion and migration, S phase cell populations, but apoptosis rate and G1 phase cell populations were significantly increased. Conversely, it is the opposite of all these features in DF-1 (PrPC-OE). We also found a total of 1055 DE genes between DF-1 (PrPC-KD) and DF-1 (PrPC-OE) cells compared with DF-1 (wt). After Go and pathway enrichment analysis, we know that these DEGs are significantly enriched in cell, cell fragment, cellular process and metabolic pathway. In short, we found that PrPC can promote processes of DF-1 cells other than apoptosis. Moreover, PrPC involves focal adhesion, cancer, ribosome, metabolic pathways and so on, and overexpression of PrPC can promote the amoebiasis pathway, but its downregulation can promote the serotonergic synapse pathway. However, the details are unknown and this will be our next investigation.
authors: Zhang, T. L.;Wan, X. R.;Wu, R.;Wang, C.

title: Evolution and variation of the H3 gene of influenza A virus and interaction between hosts
abstract: Objective: Continuous mutations in the hemagglutinin (HA) gene of influenza A virus produce new antigenic strains that cause annual epidemics. The aim of this study is to evaluate the evolutionary trend of the H3 gene over a long period of time. Methods: 1842 H3 HA1 nucleotide strains of different hosts were collected for analysis. A two-step clustering method was used to group the strains into groups, and then a phylogenetic tree was constructed based on the cluster results. The rate of evolution in lineages was predicted in the future. Results: The tree structure showed three lineages: horse/dog, human/pig, and bird. As a single trunk, the human/pig lineage consisted mainly of human lineages, and larger branches have emerged in recent years. The tree topology showed no evidence that pig influenced the major evolutionary trend of human H3 strains. The evolutionary rate of H3 strains varied between lineages. We observed that the proportion in the human lineage decreased from 3.2 substitutions/year before 1980 to 1.8 after 1997. Conclusion: We conclude that human H3 gene variation is associated with swine strains but independent of others including avian strains. Although the evolution rate of human H3 strains seems to have decreased in recent years, the reasons for the change in rate need to be further investigated. Copyright © 2007 S. Karger AG.
authors: Zhang, W.;Jiang, Q.;Chen, Y.

title: Fecal viroma of cats in an animal shelter
authors: Zhang, W.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Kapusinszky, B.

title: What's for dinner? US store's viral metagenomics buys beef, pork and chicken
abstract: Here, we describe metagenomic-derived viral sequences detected in beef, pork, and chicken purchased from stores in San Francisco. We detected four previously reported viruses in beef (two parvoviruses of different genera, an anellovirus and a circovirus-like virus) and a novel strain of bovine polyomavirus (BPyV2-SF), its closest relatives infecting primates. Detection of swine hocovirus in beef showed that this parvovirus could infect both ungulate species. In pork, we detected four known parvoviruses from three genera, anellovirus and porcine circovirus 2. Chicken meat contained multiple gyrovirus sequences, including chicken anemia virus and a new strain of gyrovirus (GyV7-SF). Our results provide the first characterization of some viruses commonly found in US store-bought meats containing a diverse group of parvoviruses and viral families with small circular DNA genomes. Whether any of these viruses can infect humans will require testing human serum for specific antibodies.
authors: Zhang, W.;Li, L.;Deng, X.;Kapusinszky, B.;Delwart, E.

title: Hepatitis E virus infection among pets in eastern China
abstract: Hepatitis E virus (HEV) is a zoonotic pathogen of which several animal species have been reported as reservoirs. Antibodies to HEV and HEV RNA have been detected in some Chinese population and pig groups, but few other domestic animals. In this study, we tested serum for anti-HEV immunoglobulin G (IgG) from 788 pigs, 100 cows, 50 goats, 49 horses, 101 domestic dogs, 105 chickens, 47 ducks and 45 pigeons in eastern China to investigate the prevalence of HEV. . We also tested 50% of pig serum positive for anti-HEV immunoglobulin M (IgM) for HEV RNA, all serum from other domestic animals, and 13 Shanghai human serums using reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction. Our results showed that 82.5% (222/269) of pigs, 53.9% (104/193) of pigs 4 to 6 months old, 63.4% (168/265) of pigs 1 to 3 months old . old pig, 55.7% (34/61) of slaughter pigs, 24% (12/50) of goats, 16.3% (8/49) of horses, 17.8% of domestic dogs ( 21/101), 6% of cows (6/100), 12.8% of ducks (6/47), 4.4% of pigeons (2/45) and 1.9% of chickens (2/ 105) showed anti-HEV IgG positivity. The inhibition test confirmed infection with HEV or HEV-like viruses in these domestic animals except pigeons and chickens. We isolated 18 porcine HEV strains, one equine HEV strain, and two human HEV strains from greenhouses. Sequence analysis showed that a horse HEV isolate and a pig isolate belonged to genotype 3. Other isolates belonged to genotype 4. The two human isolates were phylogenetically closely related to the eight pig isolates. In short, the presence of anti-HEV antibody was confirmed in various domestic animal species in eastern China, and HEV RNA was detected in pig, human and horse. This indicated that authorities should pay more attention to the prevalence of HEV in eastern China. Â© 2008 Authors.
authors: Zhang, W.;Shen, Q.;Mou, J.;Gong, G.;Yang, Z.;Cui, L.;Zhu, J.;Ju, G.;Hua, X.

title: Identification and genomic characterization of a new feline anellovirus strain
abstract: Here, a new strain of feline anellovirus (FelineAV621 and GenBank no. KX262893) was detected in two cats with diarrhea. The complete genome of FelineAV621 is 2409 nt in length with a G+C content of 56.67%, including three open reading frames (ORFs). Phylogenetic analysis based on the amino acid sequence of the putative capsid protein (ORF1) showed that FelineAV621 belonged to a new anellovirus species, but far from all previous feline anelloviruses, within a clade that includes seal anellovirus, canine TTVs, and porcine TTVs.
authors: Zhang, W.;Wang, H.;Wang, Y.;Liu, Z.;Li, J.;Guo, L.;Yang, S.;Shen, Q.;Zhao, X.;Cui, L.;Hua, X.

title: Virome comparisons in wild diseased and healthy captive giant pandas
abstract: Background: The giant panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca) is a vulnerable mammalian herbivore that lives in the wild in central China. Viral infections have become a potential threat to the health of these endangered animals, but limited information is available regarding these infections. Methods: Using a viral metagenomic approach, we investigated viruses in the faeces, nasopharyngeal secretions, blood, and different tissues of a wild giant panda that had died of an unknown disease, a healthy wild giant panda, and 46 healthy captive animals. Results: Previously uncharacterized complete or near-complete genomes of four viruses from three genera in the Papillomaviridae family, six viruses in a proposed novel Picornaviridae genus (Aimelvirus), two unclassified viruses associated with pulpaviruses in the Picornaviridae order, 19 anellovirus families in four different divisions of Anelloviridae, four putative circoviruses, and 15 viruses belonging to the recently described Genomoviridae family were sequenced. Numerous insect virus sequences belonging to the subfamilies Iflaviridae, Dicistroviridae, Iridoviridae, Baculoviridae, Polydnaviridae and Densovirinae, reflecting the diet of giant pandas, and plant virus sequences belonging to the families Tombusviridae, Partitiviridae, Secoviridae, Geminiviridae, Luteoviridae and Rhabdoviridae, Virgadoviridae; Umbravirus, Alphaflexiviridae and Phycodnaviridae genera were also detected in stool samples. A small number of insect virus sequences were also detected in the nasopharyngeal secretions of healthy giant pandas and lung tissues from dead wild giant panda. Although viral families in the sick giant panda were also detected in healthy ones, higher rates of papillomavirus, picornavirus and anellovirus readings were detected in the sick panda. Conclusion: This viral research increases our understanding of eukaryotic viruses in giant pandas and provides a basis for comparison with viruses detected in future infectious disease outbreaks. Similar viral families detected in sick and healthy giant pandas suggest that these viruses cause commensal infections in immunocompetent animals.
authors: Zhang, W.;Yang, S. X.;Shan, T. L.;Hou, R.;Liu, Z. J.;Li, W.;Guo, L. H.;Wang, Y.;Chen, P.;Wang, X. C.;Feng, F. F.;Wang, H.;Chen, C.;Shen, Q.;Zhou, C. L.;Hua, X. G.;Cui, L.;Deng, X. T.;Zhang, Z. H.;Qi, D. W.;Delwart, E.

title: İnsan koronavirüs suşu hemoglutinin / estrogen genes OC43: S ver and murin koronavirüsleri ve influenza C virus filigenetic player
abstract: The complete nucleotide sequences of the hemagglutinin/esterase (HE) genes of human coronavirus (HCV) strain OC43 and bovine respiratory coronavirus (BRCV) strain G95 were determined from single-stranded cDNA fragments generated and amplified by reverse transcription of virus-specific mRNAs. polymerase chain reaction. The open reading frame of 1272 nucleotides was identified as the putative HE gene with homology to the bovine coronavirus HE gene. This open reading frame encodes a 424 amino acid protein with an estimated molecular weight of 47.7 kDa. Ten potential N-linked glycosylation sites were predicted in the HE protein of HCV-OC43, while nine of these were present in BRCV-G95. Fourteen cysteine residues were conserved in the HE proteins of both viruses. The two hydrophobic sequences at the N-terminus and C-terminus can serve as signal peptide and transmembrane anchoring site, respectively. The predicted HE protein of HCV-OC43 was 95% identical to HEs of BRCV-G95 and other bovine coronaviruses and 60% to HEs of mouse hepatitis viruses. Phylogenetic analysis shows that the HE genes of coronaviruses and influenza C virus have a common ancestor and are closely related to bovine coronaviruses and HCV-OC43.
authors: Zhang, X.;Kousoulas, K. G.;Storz, J.

title: Deciphering the Sharp Decline in H7N9 Human Infections
abstract: The H7N9 virus has caused five waves of human infections since 2013. However, human infections have almost disappeared in the past year. In a recent study, Shi et al. revealed that the use of bivalent H5/H7 vaccine successfully prevented chicken infections and thus prevented and almost completely eliminated human infections.
authors: Zhang, X.;Luo, T.;Shen, Y.

title: Complete Genome Sequence of the Deadly H9N2 Influenza Virus for Chickens
abstract: In 2012, a virulent H9N2 virus for chickens was isolated from a flock of acutely ill chickens. Phylogenetic analyzes showed that this virus was phylogenetically related to the Y280 lineage. Sequence analysis showed 1 amino acid deletion in HA1 and 3 amino acid deletions in the NA stem region.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Guo, X.;Qi, J.;Liu, L.;Wang, J.;Xu, S.;Wang, J.;Yin, Y.

title: Integration analysis of miRNA and mRNA expression profiles in pig testicular cells infected with Japanese encephalitis virus.
abstract: To elucidate the role of microRNAs (miRNA) in the regulation of gene expression in Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV)-infected pig testicular (ST) cells, we compared the miRNA and mRNA expression profiles of JEV-infected ST cells with high-throughput sequencing technology. to uninfected controls. The results showed that 104 known miRNAs and 9 new miRNA candidates were differentially expressed in ST cells after JEV infection. We identified 396 differentially expressed mRNAs. Bioinformatics analysis identified 435 known miRNA-mRNA interaction pairs and 94 new miRNA-mRNA interaction pairs containing miRNAs and were inversely correlated with the expression of their predicted target mRNAs. Known miRNAs were involved in the biological processes of immunity, cytokine production, inflammation, and apoptosis, inversely proportional to their target genes. Selected miRNA-mRNA interactions were confirmed by luciferase reporter assay. Overall, our findings suggest that miRNAs may play critical roles in the pathogenesis of JEV infection.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Jing, J.;Li, X.;Wang, J.;Feng, X.;Cao, R.;Chen, P.

title: Characterization of the ÏƒC-encoding gene from Musocvy duck reovirus
abstract: The ÏƒC-encoding gene of two strains of musk duck reovirus (DRV) S14 and C4 was cloned and fully sequenced. The open reading frame (ORF) consisted of 810 bp and encoded 269 amino acids with a predetermined molecular mass of 29.5 kDa. ÏƒC fusion protein expressed in Escherichia coli BL21 strain can be detected by Western blotting under duck anti-reovirus polyclonal serum. DRV ÏƒC has two large gap insertions in the N-terminal portion of DRV ÏƒC as needed to optimize the alignment of amino acid sequences. All DRVs are grouped in a specific genogroup within the Orthoreoviruses genus subgroup II. The extent of differences between S14/C4 and ARV was only 23-24% and 21-22% at both nucleotide and deduced amino acid levels, respectively, suggesting that DRVs are quite different from ARVs and should give a precise classification. For DRVs of the genus Orthoreovirus. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, Inc. 2006.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Liu, M.;Hu, Q.;Ouyang, S.;Tong, G.

title: Isolation and characterization of the H7N9 avian influenza A virus from people with respiratory diseases in Zhejiang, China.
abstract: In 2013, new reassortant avian influenza A (H7N9) virus was reported in China. Through enhanced surveillance, transmission of the H7N9 virus in humans was first identified in Zhejiang Province. Real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) was used to confirm infection. Embryo chicken eggs were used for virus isolation from pharyngeal swabs taken from infected human patients. H7N9 isolates were first identified by hemagglutination testing and electron microscopy, then used for whole genome sequencing. Bioinformatics software was used to construct the phylogenetic tree and calculate the average evolutionary rate of the HA gene in H7Nx and NA in HxN9. Two novel H7N9 avian influenza A viruses (A/Zhejiang/1/2013 and A/Zhejiang/2/2013) were isolated from positive infection cases. Substitutions were found in both Zhejiang isolates and identified as human-type viruses. All phylogenetic results showed that the novel reassortant in H7N9 originated from viruses infecting birds. Sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of the whole genome revealed that the average evolutionary rate of the HA gene in H7NX was 5.74E-3 (95% Peak posterior density: 3.8218E-3 to 7.7873E-3) while the NA gene showed 2.243. E-3 (4.378E-4 to 3.79E-3) substitutions per nucleotide site per year. It was confirmed by molecular methods that the new reassortant H7N9 virus originated in poultry, with mutations occurring during the spread of H7N9 virus infection. Live poultry markets played an important role in the entire H7N9 circulation. © 2014 Elsevier BV
authors: Zhang, Y.;Mao, H.;Yan, J.;Zhang, L.;Sun, Y.;Wang, X.;Chen, Y.;Lu, Y.;Chen, E.;Lv, H.;Gong, L.;Li, Z.;Gao, J.;Xu, C.;Feng, Y.;Ge, Q.;Xu, B.;Xu, F.;Yang, Z.;Zhao, G.;Han, J.;Guus, K.;Li, H.;Shu, Y.;Chen, Z.;Xia, S.

title: Epidemiological and virological analysis of an outbreak of hand, foot, and mouth disease in Inner Mongolia in 2007
abstract: In 2007, an outbreak of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) occurred in Jungar Banner, Erdos city, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, China Fever, most places presenting vesicular exanthema on the hands, feet, mouth, and buttocks. patients. Most of the patients were infants younger than 5 years of age, and there was a clear peak period in the disease outbreak. For enterovirus isolation from 28 hospitalized patients, 23 stool specimens and 6 throat swab specimens were collected and 15 enteroviruses were isolated, 9 identified as Human Enterovirus 71 (HEV71, isolation rate 31.03%) and 1 as Coxsackievirus A16 (CVA16). Based on extensive analysis of clinical manifestations, epidemiology data, and laboratory results, this outbreak was likely primarily caused by HEV71. The variability in nucleotide acid level and amino acid level among the 9 HEV71 was relatively low, with homology greater than 99.4% and 99.0%, respectively, indicating that this outbreak originated from only one viral transmission chain. Phylogenetic analysis of the 9 HEV71 strains isolated during this outbreak revealed that they all belonged to the C4 subgenotype, which has been in continuous circulation in mainland China since its occurrence was first reported in Shenzhen City in 1998. It was also suggested that the subgenotype C4 HEV71 has a wide distribution. and transmission in mainland China.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Nan, L. J.;Wu, G. S.;Tan, X. J.;Xu, D. D.;Gu, S. Y.;Zhu, S. L.;Yan, D. M.;An, H. Q.;Xu, W. B.

title: The potential for the human immune system to develop broadly neutralizing HIV-1 antibodies: Implications for vaccine development
abstract: OBJECTIVES AND DESIGN: Developing an effective HIV-1 vaccine that broadly neutralizes HIV-1 human antibodies (bnAbs) remains a challenging goal. Extensive studies of HIV-1 have revealed several strategies the virus uses to evade host immune surveillance. Here, we investigated the human antibody gene repertoires of uninfected and HIV-1 infected individuals at genomic DNA (gDNA) and cDNA levels through deep sequencing followed by high-throughput sequencing analysis to determine the frequencies of putative germline antibody genes of known HIV. 1 monoclonal bnAbs (bnmAbs). METHODS: Combinatorial gDNA and cDNA antibody libraries were constructed using gDNAs and mRNAs isolated from uninfected and HIV-1 infected human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). All libraries were deeply sequenced and sequences analyzed using IMGT/HighV-QUEST software (http://imgt.org/HighV-QUEST/index.action). The frequencies of putative germline antibodies of known bnmAbs in gDNA and cDNA libraries were determined. RESULTS AND CONCLUSION: Human gDNA antibody libraries were more diverse in their use of heavy and light chain V-gene sequences than cDNA libraries; This indicates that human gDNA antibody gene repertoires may have greater potential than cDNA repertoires for developing HIV-1 bnAbs. The frequencies of heavy and kappa and lambda light chain variable regions with V(D)J recombinations identical to known HIV-1 bnmAbs were extremely low in human antibody gene repertoires. However, regardless of (D)J-gene use, we found relatively high frequencies of heavy and kappa and lambda light chain variable regions using the same V-genes and having the same CDR3 lengths as known HIV-1 bnmAbs. B cells bearing B cell receptors of such heavy and kappa and lambda light chain variable regions can be stimulated to induce HIV-1 bnAbs. Â© 2013 Wolters Kluwer Health | Lippincott Williams & Wilkins.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Yuan, T.;Li, J.;Zhang, Y.;Xu, J.;Shao, Y.;Chen, Z.;Zhang, M. Y.

title: Complete genome sequence of a subgenotype VIId newcastle disease virus circulating predominantly in chickens in China
abstract: At least 11 genotypes of class II viruses have been identified since the discovery of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) in 1926. Here we report the complete genome sequence of a common NDV variant from China belonging to the VIId subgenotype in class II. viruses have been the dominant strains circulating in China over the past decade, occupying more than 80% of the strains prevalent in China and differing phylogenetically from existing vaccines. Â© 2012, American Society for Microbiology.
authors: Zhang, Y.;Zhang, S.;Wang, X.;Zhang, G.

title: [Investigation on the production of sheep lung adenoma virus pEGFP-C1/exJSRV-env and the induction of malignant transformation in NIH3T3]
abstract: This study aims to establish a eukaryotic expression system for the envelope gene of Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus, to observe its localization in 293T cells, and to investigate its potential to induce malignant transformation of NIH3T3 cells. By RT-PCR, the full-length cDNA of the envelope gene of Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus (exJSRV-env) was amplified from the extract of naturally infected sheep lung. The clone of the target gene was subcloned into the eukaryotic expression system pEGFP-C1 and verified by PCR, restriction endonuclease and sequencing. Bioinformatic analysis of the biological function and cellular localization of exJSRV-env was also performed. The recombinant clone of exJSRV-env was transfected with Lipofectamine LTX into 293T cells and NIH3T3 cells. Expression and cellular localization in 293T cells were confirmed by confocal microscopy. The soft agar colony formation assay was used to test the anchorage-independent growth of NIH3T3. DNA sequencing and restriction enzyme digestion with Kpn I and Hind III showed the correct structure of the recombinant plasmid named pEGFP-C1/exJSRV-env. Amino acid sequence alignment of exJSRV-env with reference sequences found 85-100% homogeneity. A YRNM motif found only in exogenous viruses was discovered in the cytoplasmic tail of the envelope gene. Phylogenetic tree analysis showed that our exJSRV-env clone clustered closely with pathogenic exogenous Jaagsiekte sheep retroviruses. Fluorescence microscopy showed typical membrane localization of the exJSRV-env protein. NIH3T3 cells transfected with exJSRV-env lost contact inhibition and gained the ability to form colonies on soft agar. This study demonstrated that the envelope protein of Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus can induce malignant transformation of mouse fibroblast cell NIH3T3. The discoveries of this study provide a basis for further structural and functional research on the Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus envelope protein.
authors: Zhang, Y. F.;Liu, Y.;Wang, Z. J.;Sun, X. L.;Liu, S. Y.

title: Molecular characterization of chicken-derived genotype VIId Newcastle disease virus isolates in China between 2005 and 2012 reveals a new length in hemagglutinin-neuraminidase.
abstract: Newcastle disease (ND) is one of the most important diseases of poultry and causes serious economic losses in the global poultry industry. Although all Newcastle disease virus (NDV) isolates belong to a single serotype, significant genetic variation has been identified among different NDV isolates. Here, we report the molecular characterization of 23 virulent genotype VIId NDV isolates of class II II circulating in China. Phylogenetic structure and analysis revealed the presence of distinct genomic and amino acid differences that clearly distinguish these isolates from other typical NDV genotypes and vaccine strains. We also report a novel 582-amino-acid hemagglutinin-neuraminidase in genotype VII NDV strains. This is believed to be the first study to systematically investigate the most dominant NDV strains and provides further insight into the genetic nature of class II genotype VIId NDV circulating in China. © 2013 Elsevier BV
authors: Zhang, Y. Y.;Shao, M. Y.;Yu, X. H.;Zhao, J.;Zhang, G. Z.

title: A simple method for high-throughput quantification of genome-wide DNA methylation by fluorescence polarization.
abstract: To rapidly determine DNA methylation levels from large numbers of biological or clinical samples, we developed an accurate and sensitive method for high-throughput quantification of global methylation of 5'-Cm(5) CGG-3' regions in the genome, visualized by fluorescence polarization of DNA methylation (FPDM). with FP) based measurement. In FPDM, methyl-sensitive HpaII and methyl-insensitive MspI restriction enzymes were used to induce DNA cleavage, followed by incorporation of fluorescent dCMP into enzyme cleavage products via polymerase chain extension, resulting in a ratio of FP between HpaII- and MspI. - limited preparations as a measure of methylation. FPDM provided stable estimates of the methylation level of submicrograms of lambda or human DNA and a 255-bp DNA segment containing a single HpaII/MspI restriction site that is more accurate than and suitable for detection by gel electrophoresis. FPDM was also applied to measure dose-dependent DNA hypomethylation in human embryonic kidney 293T cells treated with the DNA-methyltransferase inhibitor 5-aza-dC.
authors: Zhao, C.;Xue, H.

title: Unfolded protein response induced by Tembusu virus infection
abstract: OBJECTIVE: Tembusu virus (TMUV), classified in the Flavivirus genus, causes decreased egg production and neurological problems in poultry. Flavivirus replication is dependent on the host endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and induces ER stress leading to activation of the cellular unfolded protein response (UPR), an important signaling pathway that regulates many biological functions involved in viral pathogenesis and innate immunity. However, the mechanism of TMUV-induced UPR activation remains unclear. CONCLUSIONS: In this study, we systematically investigated three UPR pathways in TMUV-infected BHK-21 cells. Our results showed that the expression of glucose-related protein 78 (GRP78) and GRP94 is upregulated during TMUV infection. Next, we show that TMUV activates the PERK pathway in the early phase of infection, resulting in the upregulation of ATF4, GADD34 and CHOP with the induction of CHOP leading to caspase-3 activation. We also found that the IRE1 pathway was activated, leading to splicing of X box-binding protein 1 (XBP1) mRNA and increased expression of p58IPK. Finally, we observed increased expression of ATF6 and activity of ER stress-response elements, suggesting stimulation of the ATF6 pathway. In addition, ATF6 pathway activation correlates with the induction of the downstream chaperones calnexin, calreticulin, ERp57 and PDI. UPR activity was also observed in TMUV-infected DF-1 cells with marked elevation of GRP78 and sXBP1 levels. CONCLUSIONS: This is the first report that ER stress induced by TMUV infection activates three branches of the UPR, and these results provide the basis for elucidating the pathogenesis of TMUV and understanding the host response as well as the natural mechanism of TMUV infection.
authors: Zhao, D.;Yang, J.;Han, K.;Liu, Q.;Wang, H.;Liu, Y.;Huang, X.;Zhang, L.;Li, Y.

title: Transcriptomic analysis of porcine PBMCs in response to FMDV infection
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is an important zoonotic infectious disease. It has a significant economic impact worldwide. It is also a significant threat to food security. At present, the molecular mechanism of FMDV infection is largely unclear. The innate immune response is the first line of defense against infectious diseases. Systematic analysis of the host immune response to infection has an important role in understanding the pathogenesis of infection. However, there are few reports on the effect of immune regulation in virus and host cellular interaction on virus replication. As a powerful and efficient tool for transcript analysis, high-throughput RNA-seq technology provides a new perspective on FMDV study. In this study, RNA extracted from porcine PBMCs infected with O subtype FMDV at 4 dpi. A total of 29942658 and 31452917 Illumina read pairs were obtained from the uninfected (NI) group and the infected (I) group, respectively. The clean bases for all samples are 3.61G (NI group) and 3.79G (I group), respectively. The clean reads of NI and group I mapped to pig genome data were 47195073 (81.82%) and 46556714 (76.85%), respectively. Most of the clean reads were distributed in the exon region, followed by the intron region and the intergenic region. Differentially expressed (DE) genes were analyzed using edgeR software. 451 genes were differentially expressed between the infected and uninfected groups. According to the comparison analysis, more genes were down-regulated in uninfected samples than in FMDV-infected ones. Of 451 genes, 66 were down-regulated, followed by FMDV infection, 385 of 451 genes were up-regulated. For function classification and pathway analysis, among the 17741 merged unigenes, there were 349 genes with distinct genes of GO annotations. Also, 49 genes were down-regulated, 300 genes were up-regulated in relation to the GO term. 1621 was successfully annotated by GO designations that belonged to one or more of three categories: biological process, cellular component, and molecular function. According to the KEGG analysis, the major pathway involved in protein processing in the endoplasmic reticulum, phagosome, cell cycle and cytokine-cytokine receptor interaction was represented. Some key DE genes related to the immune process and signaling pathways were analyzed and quantified by RT-PCR. This is the first systematic transcriptome analysis of FMDV-infected porcine PBMCs. These findings will help us better understand the host Cell-FMDV interaction and its relationship to pathogenesis, and will also contribute to the prevention and control of FMDV.
authors: Zhao, F. R.;Xie, Y. L.;Liu, Z. Z.;Shao, J. J.;Li, S. F.;Zhang, Y. G.;Chang, H. Y.

title: Characterization of an H6N6 influenza virus isolated from pigs in China.
abstract: There is ample evidence that swine can act as a vessel for the generation of new influenza A viruses. In this study, we analyzed the evolution and pathogenicity of an H6N6 influenza virus strain isolated from pigs with clinical signs of infection in China. Although phylogenetic analysis revealed that this virus could originate from domestic ducks, pathogenicity experiments showed that the virus replicated in mice without prior adaptation. These findings suggest that the virus was transmitted from ducks to pigs in China and replicated in mammalian hosts without prior adaptation, which could pose a threat to both veterinary and public health. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Zhao, G.;Chen, C.;Huang, J.;Wang, Y.;Peng, D.;Liu, X.

title: Isolation and phylogenetic analysis of the pandemic H1N1/09 influenza virus from pigs in Jiangsu province, China.
abstract: total of 1029 nasal swab samples were collected from healthy pigs between January and May 2010 in Jiangsu province, China, to investigate whether the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza A virus is still transmitted in pigs. Eight H1N1 influenza viruses were isolated and identified and their full-length genomes sequenced. We found that all eight of the H1N1 viruses shared sequence identity greater than 98.0% with the 2009 pandemic virus A/Jiangsu/1/2009 (JS1). In addition, some of these viruses had D225G (3/8) mutations in the receptor binding sites of the hemagglutinin (HA) protein, indicating increased affinity for their binding to the sialic Î±2, 3Gal receptor. As a result, the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza A virus was retro-infected from humans in mainland China to pigs, and significant viral evolution is still ongoing in this species. © 2011 Elsevier Ltd.
authors: Zhao, G.;Fan, Q.;Zhong, L.;Li, Y.;Liu, W.;Liu, X.;Gao, S.;Peng, D.;Liu, X.

title: Molecular evolution of H6 subtype influenza a viruses from poultry in eastern China from 2002 to 2010.
abstract: Background: Although extensive data indicate that the majority of H6 duck isolates belonged to a single H6N2 virus strain with a single gene constellation in southern China from 2000 to 2005, the prevalence of H6N2 virus in poultry in eastern China is largely unknown. Results: Epidemiology revealed that H6N2 viruses were the most frequently detected influenza subtype in live bird markets in eastern China from 2002 to 2008, but from 2009 they were replaced by new H6N6 viruses. We analyzed phylogenetically and antigenically 42 H6 viruses isolated mainly in domestic ducks from 2002 to 2010 in eastern China. Surprisingly, none of these isolates grouped with previously described H6N2 viruses, which belonged to a single H6N2 virus strain with a single gene constellation in South China domestic ducks from 2000 to 2005. multiple virus subtypes from the natural gene pool, but few reassortants were persistent or widespread. Conclusions: In eastern China, five subtypes of H6 influenza viruses (H6N1, H6N2, H6N5, H6N6, and H6N8) circulate together, constituting a significant part of the natural reservoir of influenza virus in domestic ducks, and significant viral reclassification in this species is still ongoing. © 2011Zhao et al; licensee BioMed Central Ltd.
authors: Zhao, G.;Lu, X.;Gu, X.;Zhao, K.;Song, Q.;Pan, J.;Xu, Q.;Duan, Z.;Peng, D.;Hu, S.;Wang, X.;Liu, X.

title: Bayesian evolutionary characterization of the VP1 sequence of Coxsackievirus A16 isolates
abstract: Background: Coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16), an important etiopathological cause of pediatric hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) worldwide, has been reported to cause several deaths. Uncovering the evolutionary and epidemiological dynamics of CV-A16 in time and space is crucial to understanding its epidemic potential. Methods: In this study, we isolated six CV-A16 strains in Jilin province, China, and constructed a maximum clan confidence (MCC) tree for the CV-A16 VP1 gene by the Bayesian Markov Chain Monte Carlo method using 708 strains from GenBank with epidemiological information. The evolutionary features of the CV-A16 VP1 gene were also dynamically analyzed via Bayesian silhouette plot. Results: All identified CV-A16 strains can be classified into five major genogroups denoted by GI-GV. GIV and GV have been in common circulation in China since 2007, and the CV-A16 outbreak strain isolated in Jilin province of China can be classified as GIV-3. The CV-A16 genogroups recently circulating in China have the same ancestry since 2007. The genetic diversity of the CV-A16 VP1 gene has been increasing steadily since the mid-1990s, with sharp increases in genetic diversity in 1997 and 2007, and has peaked in recent years. 2007. There was very low genetic diversity after 2010. The CV-A16 VP1 gene evolution rate was 6,656E-3 substitutions per site per year. Conclusions: We predicted dynamic phylogenetic trends showing the epidemic trends of CV-A16 and providing theoretical foundations for clinical prevention and treatment of a CV-A16-induced HFMD.
authors: Zhao, G.;Zhang, X.;Wang, C.;Wang, G.;Li, F.

title: Metagenomic Analysis of Jinding Duck Fecal Virome
abstract: Ducks play an important role in the transmission and protection of mammalian viruses in nature and are reservoir hosts of many animal viruses. We analyzed fecal virus of four duck strains (A, B, C and D) living in isolation using metagenomic analysis. The feces of the tested ducks contained 18 families of animal viruses. Percentage values of RNA virus reads compared to the total animal virus reads in each of the four strains were 96.96% (A), 97.30% (B), 98.01% (C), and 67.49% (D), and were primarily Orthomyxoviridae, Mimiviridae, Bunyaviridae, Picobirnaviridae and reoviridae Meanwhile, the paucity of DNA virus reads was associated with Herpesviridae, Adenoviridae, Iridoviridae and other low abundance viral families. The percent values of Orthomyxoviridae, Mimiviridae, Bunyaviridae, Picobirnaviridae, and Herpesviridae readings were not significantly different between strains A, B, and C; however, there were marked differences in the abundance of these reads in strain D. In summary, this study provides an unbiased examination of viral diversity in faeces of four duck strains during specific pathogen-free periods and the percentage of viral families present. These results can be used as a reference to detect duck viral pathogens and estimate zoonotic potential.
authors: Zhao, L.;Niu, Y.;Lu, T.;Yin, H.;Zhang, Y.;Xu, L.;Wang, Y.;Chen, H.

title: Sequence analyzes of representative strain of avian nephritis virus common in China in healthy chicken flocks
abstract: Avian nephritis virus (ANV), belonging to the Astroviridae family, has been associated with acute nephritis in chickens. Cases of ANV infection have been recorded in Japan and several European countries. However, relevant studies have never been conducted in China. Therefore, this study isolated ANV in Chinese chicken flocks. ANV RNA was detected by reverse transcription-PCR in stool samples collected from healthy layer hens in Sichuan Province, China, in 2009. Of the 192 stool samples collected, 32.3% (62/192) were positive for ANV infection. The entire genome of ANV-Sichuan54, the first representative Chinese strain, was 6941 nucleotides long, including 5â€² untranslated regions, three open reading frames (ORFs), 3â€² UTRs and a poly-(A) tail. . Comparative and phylogenetic analyzes based on partial RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (ORF1b) showed that most ANV studies were more closely related to the US ANV strain (DQ324827-324836) rather than G-4260 (AB033998). Â© 2011 American Association of Bird Pathologists.
authors: Zhao, W.;Hua, X. G.;Yuan, C. L.;Cui, L.;Shan, T. L.;Dai, X. Q.;Zhu, A. L.;Yu, Y.;Zhu, C. X.;Yang, Z. B.

title: Confirmed diagnosis by RT-PCR and phylogenetic analysis of peste des petits ruminant viruses in Tibet, China
abstract: This article reports the results of nested RT-PCR-confirmed diagnosis and phylogenetic analysis of PPR cases in Tibet, China, in 2007. Results showed that 11 samples tested were positive for PPRV by nested RT-PCR; 2 samples genetically close to strain X7443 (Nigeria 75/1) of strain I and 3 samples close to strain AY560591 (Sungri96) based on partial sequence of F gene from 5 samples and full sequence of N/M/F/H genes from one sample IV with nucleotide sequence homogeneity of 96.6%, 97.3%, 97.6% and 98%, respectively. This study suggested that there are at least 2 origins of PPRV in China. Â© 2009 Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer Berlin Heidelberg.
authors: Zhao, W. H.;Yang, S. B.;Han, J. Q.;Jiang, M.;Li, H. C.;Zhang, N. Z.;Li, Q. H.

title: [Detection of an NA gene molecular marker in H7N9 subtype avian influenza viruses by pyrosequencing]
abstract: This study aimed to establish a method for the detection and identification of NA gene-based H7N9 avian influenza viruses by pyrosequencing. According to the published NA gene sequences of avian influenza A (H7N9) virus, 15-nt deletion was found in the NA gene of H7N9 avian influenza viruses. The 15-nt deletion of the NA gene was targeted as a molecular marker for rapid detection and identification of H7N9 avian influenza viruses by pyro-sequencing. Three H7N9 avian influenza virus isolates were pyrosorted using the same assay and proved to have the same 15-nt deletion. Pyro-sequencing technology based on the NA gene molecular marker can be used to identify H7N9 avian influenza viruses.
authors: Zhao, Y. G.;Liu, H. L.;Wang, J. J.;Zheng, D. X.;Zhao, Y. L.;Ge, S. Q.;Wang, Z. L.

title: Genomes and seroprevalence of severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome virus and Nairobi sheep disease virus in Haemaphysalis longicornis ticks and â€¦
authors: Zhao, Z.;Hou, G.;Zhang, C.;Liu, J.;Xu, L.;Li, W.;Tan, Z.;Tu, C.

title: Molecular characterization of Japanese encephalitis virus strains common in Chinese pig herds.
abstract: Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is the leading cause of viral encephalitis in Asia, and domestic pigs serve as replicative hosts. In this study, the complete genomic sequences of two JEV strains (HEN0701 and SH0601) isolated from pigs in China were determined and compared with 12 other JEV strains stored in GenBank. These two strains had 88.8% nucleotide sequence identity and 97.9% deduced amino acid sequence identity. HEN0701 had high nucleotide sequence and high amino acid sequence identity with genotype I (GI) strains, while SH0601 had high nucleotide sequence and high amino acid sequence identity with GIII strains at both the gene and whole genome levels. Further phylogenetic analyzes indicated that HEN0701 belonged to the JEV GI group and SH0601 was classified as a GIII strain. Analysis of codon usage revealed few differences between GI and GIII strains in nucleotide composition and codon usage for open reading frames. Â© 2013 Korean Veterinary Science Association.
authors: Zheng, H.;Shan, T.;Den, Y.;Sun, C.;Yuan, S.;Yin, Y.;Tong, G.

title: Occurrence of swine circovirus 3 without clinical signs of infection in Shandong Province
abstract: Porcine circovirus type 3 (PCV3) was detected in Shandong, China. One hundred and thirty-two (59.46%) of 222 samples were PCV3 positive, while 52 (39.39%) of 132 samples were co-infected with PCV2. Neither the multiparous sows nor the liveborn babies showed any clinical signs of infection. Two strains of PCV3 have been identified from naturally stillborn fetuses. Phylogenetic analysis showed that the two PCV3 strains were 96% identical to the known PCV3/Pig/USA (KX778720.1, KX966193.1 and KX898030.1) and closely related to Barbel Circovirus. Further studies are needed on the epidemiology of PCV3 and coinfection with PCV2.
authors: Zheng, S.;Wu, X.;Zhang, L.;Xin, C.;Liu, Y.;Shi, J.;Peng, Z.;Xu, S.;Fu, F.;Yu, J.;Sun, W.;Xu, S.;Li, J.;Wang, J.

title: Genetic typing and epidemiological observation of bovine viral diarrhea virus in western China.
abstract: Whole blood samples (472) were collected during 2006-2008 from 15 cattle farms in seven counties of Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, which represents 1/6 of the Chinese territory and is an important pastoral region. Bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) was detected by nested reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction assay (RT-nPCR) and sequenced within the 5-untranslated region of the genome. About 43% (202 samples) were BVDV-positive. Of the positive samples, 24 were selected for further sequencing, sequence comparisons, and phylogenetic reconstructions. Phylogenetic reconstructions showed that these isolates clustered into the subgenotypes BVDV1b (18 samples) or BVDV1c (six samples). None of the sequenced isolates showed cytopathic effects in culture. Contrary to previously published studies in Chinese cattle, no BVDV2 genotype was detected. These results suggest that the dominant subgenotypes in Xinjiang are BVDV1b and BVDV1c. This finding may be useful for further BVDV epidemiological studies in China. © 2010 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Zhong, F.;Li, N.;Huang, X.;Guo, Y.;Chen, H.;Wang, X.;Shi, C.;Zhang, X.

title: Single-reaction genomic amplification accelerates sequencing and vaccine production for classical and porcine human influenza A viruses
abstract: Pandemic influenza A viruses emerging from animal reservoirs are inevitable. Therefore, rapid genomic analysis and the creation of vaccines are vital. We developed a multi-segment reverse transcription-PCR (M-RTPCR) approach that simultaneously amplifies eight genomic RNA segments regardless of virus subtype. M-RTPCR amplicons can be used for high-throughput sequencing and/or cloned into modified reverse genetic plasmids via sequence identity regions. We used these procedures to recover a contemporary H3N2 virus and a porcine H1N1 virus directly from human swab samples. M-RTPCR and the modified reverse genetic plasmids we designed together facilitate the establishment (9 to 12 days) of vaccine seed stocks. Copyright © 2009, American Society for Microbiology. All rights reserved.
authors: Zhou, B.;Donnelly, M. E.;Scholes, D. T.;St. George, K.;Hatta, M.;Kawaoka, Y.;Wentworth, D. E.

title: Reticuloendotheliosis virus and avian leukosis virus subgroup J synergistically enhance the accumulation of exosomal miRNAs.
abstract: BACKGROUND: Co-infection with avian leukosis virus subgroup J and reticuloendotheliosis virus causes synergistic pathogenic effects and increases mortality. However, the role of exosomal miRNAs in the molecular mechanism of synergistic infection of the two viruses is unknown. RESULTS: In this study, exosomal RNAs from CEF cells infected with ALV-J, REV or both at the optimal synergistic time of infection were analyzed by Illumina RNA deep sequencing. A total of 54 (23 up-regulated and 31 down-regulated) and 16 (7 up-regulated and 9 down-regulated) miRNAs were identified by comparing co-infection with two viruses, single infected ALV-J and REV, respectively. Furthermore, five key miRNAs, including miR-184-3p, miR-146a-3p, miR-146a-5p, miR-3538 and miR-155, were confirmed by qRT-PCR in both exosomes and CEF cells. GO annotation of miRNA target genes and KEGG pathway analysis showed that five differentially expressed miRNAs participate in virus-vector interaction, oxidative phosphorylation, energy metabolism, and cell growth. RESULTS: We show that REV and ALV-J synergistically enhance the accumulation of exosomal miRNAs, shedding light on the synergistic molecular mechanism of ALV-J and REV.
authors: Zhou, D.;Xue, J.;He, S.;Du, X.;Zhou, J.;Li, C.;Huang, L.;Nair, V.;Yao, Y.;Cheng, Z.

title: Identification and genome characterization of the first sicinivirus isolate from chickens in mainland China using viral metagenomics.
abstract: Unlike traditional virus isolation and sequencing approaches, the viral metagenomic technique based on sequence-independent amplification allows one to efficiently discover unexpected or new viruses while skipping the culturing step. Here, we report the discovery of the first Sicinivirus isolate (termed JSY strain) of picornaviruses using a viral metagenomic technique from commercial laying hens in mainland China. Containing the entire 9,797 nucleotide (nt) genome except the poly(A) tail, this Sicinivirus isolate has one of the largest picornavirus genomes ever reported, but shares only 88.83% and 82.78% of amino acid sequence identity.
