ChPV1 100C (KF979332) and Sicinivirus 1 strain UCC001 (NC-023861), respectively. The full 939 nt 50UTR of the isolate strain contains at least twelve root loop domains (AL), representing the highest group of loops reported within the Sicinivirus genus. The conserved 'barbell-like' structure was present in the 272 nt 30UTR of the isolate as well as in the 30 UTR of Sicinivirus 1 strain UCC001. The 8,586 nt wide open reading frame encodes a 2,862 amino acid polyprotein precursor. Furthermore, Sicinivirus infection may be widely present in commercial poultry farms in Yancheng District of Jiangsu Province, as evidenced by positive (17/17) fecal samples tested from three different farms for detection of Sicinivirus. This is the first report on the identification of Sicinivirus in commercial layer hens with a serious clinical disease in mainland China, but further studies are needed to evaluate the pathogenic potential of this picornavirus in chickens.
authors: Zhou, H.;Zhu, S.;Quan, R.;Wang, J.;Wei, L.;Yang, B.;Xu, F.;Wang, J.;Chen, F.;Liu, J.

title: Characteristics of codon usage bias at two sites downstream of the initiation codons of foot-and-mouth disease virus
abstract: The mechanism of use of the two alternative AUGs in foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) is still unknown to date. In this study, the features of codon usage bias (CUB) of the region between two AUGs (region-La) and the same-sized region behind the second AUG (region-Lb) in 94 different FMDV RNA sequences were determined. analyzed using relative synonymous codon usage (RSCU) values. The results showed that many codons with negative CUB were used preferentially in the -La region. There were two conserved residues (Thr and Cys) at residue positions 4 and 6 of the La region. Conserved residues had a general tendency to select codons synonymous with negative CUB. Although most positions in the -La region did not contain conserved residues, many positions tended to use codons with negative CUBs in this region. The majority of these codons belonged to amino acids containing codons synonymous with clearly positive and negative CUB, including Asp, Val, Ile, Leu, Thr, Ala, Ser, Asn, and Arg. The presence of many codons with negative CUB in the La region may impair the efficiency of the initial AUG selection. The phylogenetic mismatch of region-La and region-Lb implied that intertype recombination played an important role in the evolution of FMDV. Also, due to the presence of more positions with positive CUB and more widespread phylogenetic incompatibility in the -Lb region than in the -La region, a possible association between the degree of CUB and the evolution of the two target regions emerged. © 2010 Elsevier Ireland Ltd.
authors: Zhou, J. H.;Zhang, J.;Ding, Y. Z.;Chen, H. T.;Ma, L. N.;Liu, Y. S.

title: Global binary RNA interaction landscapes reveal key features of protein recognition
abstract: RNA-protein interactions permeate biology. Transcription, translation, and splicing all depend on the recognition of structured RNA elements by RNA-binding proteins. Models of RNA-protein interactions are often limited to short linear motifs and structures due to the large sequence sampling required to access longer elements. Here, we develop an integrated approach that calculates global binary interaction scores from in vitro selection and high-throughput sequencing. We examine four RNA-binding proteins of phage, viral and human origin. Our approach uncovers regulatory motifs, distinguishes between edited and unedited RNAs in their native genomic context, and accurately predicts the outcome of mutational events on binding activity. We design binding elements that increase binding activity in cells and infer mutational pathways between regulated motifs that reveal permissive and destructive evolutionary trajectories. These splicing landscapes are broadly applicable for the discovery and characterization of protein-RNA recognition at single nucleotide resolution.
authors: Zhou, Q.;Kunder, N.;De la Paz, J. A.;Lasley, A. E.;Bhat, V. D.;Morcos, F.;Campbell, Z. T.

title: Rovac is a possible ancestor of the Russian lapinized vaccines LK-VNIVViM and CS strains, but not a Chinese strain (C-strain) vaccine against classical swine fever
abstract: Classical swine fever (CSF), or swine cholera, is a highly contagious disease that emerged in the first half of the nineteenth century. Different vaccines have been developed to combat the disease and protect pigs, including the early generation lapinized Rovac strain and later the "Chinese" strain (C-strain). However, the details of the development of these vaccines have been lost to history. To investigate the phylogenetic relationship between Rovac and other lapinized vaccines, this study determined Rovac's genome sequence of 12,304 nucleotides specifically with the 3' untranslated region (3'UTR) containing 13 nucleotide insertions. The nearly complete genome of the Russian vaccine strain LK-VNIVViM was determined by next-generation sequencing on the Illumina MiSeq platform. Whole genome phylogenetic analysis revealed a closer relationship between Rovac strain and Russian LK-VNIVViM, CS strain and its derivative RUCSFPLUM (genotype 1.2) than C-strain (genotype 1.1). In addition, it demonstrated an ancestral role of LK-VNIVViM in relation to strain CS and RUCSFPLUM. The study suggested that the Rovac vaccine is the possible ancestor of the Russian vaccine strains, but not the C-strain vaccine.
authors: Zhou, W.;Gao, S.;Podgorska, K.;Stadejek, T.;Qiu, H. J.;Yin, H.;Drew, T.;Liu, L.

title: Molecular studies on the prevalence and viral load of enteric viruses in pigs from five European countries
abstract: Enteric viral infections in pigs can cause diarrhea, resulting in substantial savings and economic losses. This study reports enteric infections with porcine astrovirus type 4 (PAstV4), porcine group A rotavirus (GARV), porcine group C rotavirus (GCRV), porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2) and porcine cobuvirus (PKoV) in 419 pigs containing both. . Healthy and diarrheal animals from 49 farms in five European countries (Austria, Germany, Hungary, Spain and Sweden). Real-time RT-PCR tests have been developed to test stool samples and compare prevalence and viral load in relation to health status, farms of origin, and age groups. The results showed that PAstV4 (70.4%) was the predominant virus strain, followed by PKoV (56.7%), PCV2 (42.2%), GCRV (3%), and GARV (0.9%). . Pigs with diarrhea had a higher PAstV4 viral load in the nursery and rear-end groups. Rotaviruses were detected mainly in pigs with diarrhea, whereas PCV2 was detected more frequently in clinically healthy than in pigs with diarrhea, suggesting that most PCV2 infections were subclinical. PAstV4, PCV2 and PKoV were considered ubiquitous in European pig farms and co-infections were frequent among them regardless of disease status, in contrast to the low prevalence of classical rotavirus infections.
authors: Zhou, W.;Ullman, K.;Chowdry, V.;Reining, M.;Benyeda, Z.;Baule, C.;Juremalm, M.;Wallgren, P.;Schwarz, L.;Zhou, E.;Pedrero, S. P.;Hennig-Pauka, I.;Segales, J.;Liu, L.

title: MicroRNA expression profile in alveolar macrophages of native Chinese Tongcheng pigs infected with PRRSV in vivo
abstract: Porcine respiratory and reproductive syndrome (PRRS), caused by the PRRS virus (PRRSV), is one of the most serious infectious diseases in the swine industry worldwide. Native Chinese Tongcheng (TC) pigs are reported to show strong resistance to PRRSV infection. The miRNA expression profiles of porcine alveolar macrophages (PAMs) of control TC pigs and those infected with PRRSV in vivo were analyzed by high-throughput sequencing to investigate infection-induced changes. A total of 182 known miRNAs, including 101 miRNA-5p and 81 miRNA-3p, were identified with 23 upregulated differentially expressed miRNAs (DEmiRNAs) and 25 downregulated DEmiRNAs. Gene Ontology analysis showed that the predicted target genes for DEmiRNAs were enriched in immune response, transcription regulation, and cell death. Integrative analysis of mRNA and miRNA expression revealed that downregulated methylation-related genes (DNMT1 and DNMT3b) were targeted by five upregulated DEmiRNAs. Moreover, 35 pairs of miRNAs (70 miRNAs) were co-expressed after PRRSV infection and six pairs were differentially co-expressed. Our results describe the miRNA expression profiles of TC pigs in response to PRRSV infection and provide a strong basis for developing new treatments to control PRRS in pigs.
authors: Zhou, X.;Michal, J. J.;Jiang, Z.;Liu, B.

title: Complete Genome Sequence of Genotype III Japanese Encephalitis Virus Isolated from Pigs in Sichuan, China
abstract: complete genomic sequence of Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) was detected by viral metagenome analysis on discontinued piglets. Phylogenetic analysis of this genome reveals that it is highly similar to previously reported Indian JEV genomes. The full JEV sequence is 10,718 nucleotides long.
authors: Zhou, Y.;Zhuo, X.;Ye, J.;Cai, Y.

title: Molecular characterization of a novel bat-associated circovirus by a poly-T pathway in the 3â€² intergenic region
abstract: The Circoviridae family includes a large group of small circular single-stranded DNA viruses, several members of which cause serious swine and poultry diseases. In recent years, the number of new viruses within the family has increased explosively, showing a high level of genetic diversity and a wide host range. In this report, we describe two more circoviruses detected from bats in Yunnan and Heilongjiang provinces, China. Whole genome sequencing revealed that these bat-associated circoviruses (bat ACV) should be classified as new species within the genus Circovirus based on the International Committee on Virus Taxonomy (ICTV) limitation criteria. The most striking result is the new finding of the 21-28 nt polythymidine (poly-T) pathway in the 3-2 terminal intergenic region of bat ACV isolates from Heilongjiang province. To understand its role in viral replication, a wild-type bat ACV and a mutated version with all deletion of poly-T were rescued by constructing infectious clones. In vitro replication comparison showed that poly-T is not required for viral replication. The identification of additional bat ACV isolates and the study of their biological characteristics will be the main task to understand the potential roles of bats in the transmission of circoviruses to terrestrial mammals and humans in the future.
authors: Zhu, A.;Jiang, T.;Hu, T.;Mi, S.;Zhao, Z.;Zhang, F.;Feng, J.;Fan, Q.;He, B.;Tu, C.

title: Comparative genomic analysis identifies structural features of CRISPR-Cas systems in Riemerella anatipestifer
abstract: Background: Riemerella anatipestifer infection is a contagious disease that causes great economic losses to the duck industry worldwide. This study sought to characterize CRISPR-Cas systems in the disease-causing agent Riemerella anatipestifer (R. anatipestifer). The CRISPR-Cas system confers adaptive immunity against foreign genetic elements in prokaryotes, and CRISPR-cas loci are commonly found in archaeal and bacterial genomes. However, the structural features of R. anatipestifer CRISPR-Cas systems have not been clarified due to the limited availability of genomic data. Results: To identify structures and components associated with CRISPR-Cas systems in R. anatipestifer, we performed comparative genomic analysis of CRISPR-Cas systems in 25 R. anatipestifer strains using high-throughput sequencing. The results showed that most of the analyzed R. anatipestifer strains (20/25) had two CRISPR loci (CRISPR1 and CRISPR2). CRISPR1 has been shown to be flanked by cas genes on one side, while CRISPR2 has been designated orphan. Other strains analyzed harbored only one locus, either CRISPR1 or CRISPR2. The length and content of the consensus direct repeat sequences and the length of the spacer sequences associated with the two loci differed. Only three cas genes (cas1, cas2 and cas9) were inserted upstream of CRISPR1. CRISPR1 was also shown to be flanked by a 107 bp long putative leader sequence and a 16 nt long anti-repeat sequence. Combined with analysis of the spacer organization similarity and phylogenetic tree of R. anatipestifer strains, CRISPR sequences can be subdivided into distinct subgroups. Diversity of spacer organization was observed in the same subgroup. Overall, spacer organization in CRISPR1 was different than in CRISPR2. In addition, only 8% (13/153) of the spacers were homologous to phage or plasmid sequences. The cas operon surrounding CRISPR1 was observed to be relatively conserved based on multiple sequence alignments of Cas amino acid sequences. Cas9-related phylogenetic analysis showed that the Cas9 sequence from R. anatipestifer is closely related to Bacteroides fragilis and forms part of the II-C subset. Conclusions: Our data revealed for the first time the structural features of R. anatipestifer CRISPR-Cas systems. Elucidating the structural features of the CRISPR-Cas system may aid in studying the specific mechanism associated with CRISPR-mediated adaptive immunity and other biological functions in R.
authors: Zhu, D. K.;Yang, X. Q.;He, Y.;Zhou, W. S.;Song, X. H.;Wang, J. B.;Zhang, Y.;Liu, M. F.;Wang, M. S.;Jia, R. Y.;Chen, S.;Sun, K. F.;Yang, Q.;Wu, Y.;Chen, X. Y.;Cheng, A. C.

title: Prevalence of hepatitis E virus in animals in Changchun region, China
abstract: Objective: To analyze the prevalence of hepatitis E virus (HEV) in animals in Changchun Province, China, as well as the phylogenetics of the virus. Methods: Pig, cattle, sheep, deer, chicken and horse sera were tested for antibody against HEV with anti-HEV antibody kit by RT-PCR, some for HEV RNA, and those positive were subjected to gene cloning. and sorting. Results: 427 (86.61%), 122 (45.86%), 7 (7.53%), 348 (43.61%), 18 (4.88%) serum from 493 pigs, 266 cattle, 93 sheep, 798 deer, 369 chickens and 197 horses ) and 31 (15.74%) were positive for anti-HEV antibody, respectively, and 5 of 493 pig sera were positive for HEV RNA. The homology of the 5 HEV RNA positive clones was 91.2%-99.1%, and those of 348 hp in the ORF2 domain to HEV genotypes 1,2,3 and 4 were 77.8%-82.3%, 77.2%-78.1%, 77.2%- was. 99.1% and 85.2%-95.2%, respectively. Conclusion: The prevalence of HEV was observed in various animals in Changchun District. The prevalence was much higher in pigs than in other animals. The common HEV gene sequence in pigs showed high homology to that of HEV -4 isolated from the sporadic case of HE in humans. Phylogenetic analysis proved that HEV in pigs and humans from Changchun District belonged to the same clade.
authors: Zhu, G. Z.;Liu, T. M.;Sun, Z. F.

title: Origins and Evolutionary Dynamics of the H3N2 Canine Flu Virus
abstract: UNLABELED: Influenza A viruses (IAVs) are primarily found in wild birds, and despite the frequent spread of infections by avian IAVs to mammals, only a small number of viruses have become established in mammalian hosts. A new avian H3N2 canine flu virus (CIV) emerged in Asia in the mid-2000s and is now circulating in dog populations in China, South Korea and possibly Thailand. The emergence of CIV offers new opportunities for zoonotic infections and interspecies transmission. We examined 14,764 complete IAV genomes, along with all CIV genomes available to the public, from their initial isolation to 2013. We show that CIV may have emerged as a result of segment reclassification between Eurasian and North American avian IAV lineages as early as 1999. We also identified amino acid changes, some of which were not previously identified in other interspecies jumps, that may have played a role in the emergence of CIV. CIV evolves at a lower rate than H3N2 human influenza viruses, and viral phylogenies display geographic structure consistent with high levels of local transmission. We detected multiple intrasubtypic and heterosubtypic reclassification events, including acquisition of the NS segment of a previously overlooked H5N1 avian influenza virus. In summary, our results provide insight into the adaptive changes required by avian viruses to settle in mammals, and also highlight the potential role of dogs, particularly to act as intermediate hosts from which, by an approximate estimate, viruses with zoonotic and/or pandemic potential can emerge. ~700 million dog population. IMPORTANT: Influenza A viruses circulate in humans and animals. This multi-host ecology has important implications, as past pandemics have been caused by IAVs carrying gene segments of both human and animal origin. Adaptive evolution is central to interspecies jumps, and therefore understanding the evolutionary processes that have shaped influenza A virus genomes is key to elucidating the mechanisms underlying viral emergence. An avian canine flu virus (CIV) has recently emerged in dogs and is spreading across Asia. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of CIV and showed that it originated in both Eurasian and North American avian lineages. We also identified mutations that may be responsible for the interspecies jump. Finally, we present evidence of multiple reclassification events between CIV and other influenza viruses (including an H5N1 avian virus). This is a cause for concern as there is a large global dog population to which humans are highly exposed.
authors: Zhu, H.;Hughes, J.;Murcia, P. R.

title: Phylogenetic and pathotypical characterization of newcastle disease virus in Tibetan chickens, China.
abstract: Chickens are considered a potential reservoir of Newcastle disease virus (NDV). In this study, six strains of Newcastle disease virus were isolated and characterized in Tibetan chickens. The HN gene was sequenced and the phylogenetic relationship with reference strains was investigated. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these six isolated strains were closely related to the reference strains GQ245823, KT002186, KU527561, KJ563939, AY225110, EU305607, KM056357, Y18898, GQ245832, AF077761 and NDV isolates of lasota. Among them, EU305607, KJ563939 and KM056357 were isolated from India, while the lasota strain came from the attenuated vaccine widely used in China. Then, mean time to death (MDT) and intracerebral pathogenicity index (ICPI) were used to estimate the pathogenicity of the isolates. The pathogenicity assay showed that HNH1 and HN17 were lethal. Our results showed that genetically diverse viruses circulate in Tibetan chickens, and based on fluorogeographic analysis, we predicted the origin of ancestral viruses of isolates and sister strains found in India and China (lasota strain). It demonstrates the importance of continued surveillance to improve current understanding of the genetic evolution of NDV strains.
authors: Zhu, H.;Zhang, H.;Wang, Y.;Ciren, D.;Dong, H.;Wu, Q.;Rehman, M. U.;Nabi, F.;Mehmood, K.;Li, J.

title: Molecular characterization of H3N2 and H4N6 subtypes isolated from mallards in Lake Poyang, China in 2010 avian influenza viruses.
abstract: Poyang Lake is the largest inland freshwater lake in China and contains many species of wild birds and waterfowl. From January to March 2010, we conducted a study of avian influenza viruses at nine semi-artificial waterfowl farms in Poyang Lake. Three H3N2 and one H4N6 influenza virus were isolated from healthy mallards from 1036 cloacal swabs collected. All isolates were genetically and phylogenetically characterized. Analysis of putative HA cleavage sites showed that all four isolates had molecular characteristics of low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) virus (QTRGL for H3N2 viruses, PEKASR for H4N6 virus). Phylogenetic analysis of viral genomes showed that all four virus isolates clustered in the Eurasian influenza viruses branch. The M gene of the viruses had the highest homology with the highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza viruses. Also, co-infection of H3N2 and H4N6 was observed in the same farm. And interestingly, we isolated two subtypes of viruses (H3N2 and H4N6) and their progeny virus (H3N2) with evidence of genome reclassification from the same farm, in which the PB1 and PB2 gene segments of H4N6 replace those of the H3N2 strain. Results of animal infection experiments showed that all four isolated viruses were low pathogenic to chickens and nonpathogenic to mice; this was consistent with the results of the genetic analysis.
authors: Zhu, N.;Zhao, J. R.;Li, Y. D.;Ding, C. Q.;Xia, H.;Tang, S.;Zhang, Z.;Yu, J. F.;Chen, J.;Fan, Z. J.;Kou, Z.;Li, T. X.

title: Phylogenetic and pathogenic analysis of Newcastle disease virus isolated from house sparrow (Passer domesticus) living around poultry farm in southern China.
abstract: The house sparrow (Passer domesticus) is one of the most common wild birds in China. Five strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV) were isolated from house sparrows living around poultry farms in southern China. These isolates were characterized by pathogenic testing and phylogenetic analysis. The results showed that all NDV isolates except one were velogenic and virulent for chickens. For chickens, these four virulent strains have the amino acid sequence 112R/KRQK/RR-F117 at the F0 cleavage site typical of velogenic NDV. Phylogenetic analysis showed that these isolates belong to genotype VII and are closely related to strains isolated from NDV outbreaks in chickens since 2000. An NDV isolate from the house sparrow was proven to belong to genotype II and to be a vaccine strain (Chicken/US/LaSota/46). The result of this study proved that the house sparrow can carry virulent strains of NDV and that the same genotype viruses circulating in poultry are also found in house sparrows living around the poultry farm in southern China. Â© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 2009.
authors: Zhu, W.;Dong, J.;Xie, Z.;Liu, Q.;Khan, M. I.

title: Human monoclonal antibodies as candidate therapeutics against emerging viruses and HIV-1
abstract: More than 40 monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) have been approved for a number of disease indications with only one of them (Synagis) - for a viral disease and for prevention, not treatment. However, in the last decade new potent mAbs have been discovered and therapeutically used against viruses of great importance to public health and biosecurity, including Hendra virus (HeV), Nipah virus (NiV), severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV). characterized by potential. ), Ebola virus (EBOV), West Nile virus (WNV), influenza virus (IFV), and human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1). Here we review such mAbs with an emphasis on antibodies of human origin and highlight recent results as well as technologies and mechanisms relevant to their potential therapeutically. Â© Wuhan Institute of Virology, CAS and Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 2013.
authors: Zhu, Z.;Prabakaran, P.;Chen, W.;Broder, C. C.;Gong, R.;Dimitrov, D. S.

title: First detection of foot and mouth disease virus O/ME-SA/Ind2001 in China
abstract: Foot and mouth disease (FMD) is endemic in China and is predominantly caused by the foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) serotype O Mya-98 strain. In recent years, the FMDV O/ME-SA/Ind2001 strain has spread from the Indian subcontinent to Southeast Asia, the Middle East and Africa, which may pose potential threats to future interregional livestock movements. In this study, we determined the appearance of FMDV O/ME-SA/Ind2001 in China; This strain of viruses was found there for the first time. Sequencing and phylogenetic analysis of VP1 sequences revealed that this newly identified strain belongs to the O/ME-SA/Ind2001 subclade and is closely related to strains that have recently caused FMD outbreaks in Nepal, Myanmar, Russia, and South Korea. The results suggest comprehensive movements of current O/ME-SA/Ind2001 sublineage d viruses and provide essential information for an effective national FMDV control program in China.
authors: Zhu, Z.;Yang, F.;He, J.;Li, J.;Cao, W.;Li, J.;Xia, Y.;Guo, J.;Jin, Y.;Zhang, K.;Zheng, H.;Liu, X.

title: Selected microRNA-192 mutant shows association with several function genes in bovine cells
abstract: MicroRNAs are involved in many cellular processes such as cell differentiation and development, tumorigenesis, and immune regulation. In this study, miR192 was detected using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) when MDBK cells were exposed to Escherichia coli. bta-miR-192 defective cells were generated using transcription activator-like effector nuclease (TALEN) technology. Finally, bta-miR-192 mutant cells were screened for differentially expressed genes using RNA sequencing (RNA sequencing). The results showed that miR192 was significantly reduced in cells exposed to E. coli F18ac and E. coli K88ac. RNA-seq results showed that 1673 differentially expressed transcripts were identified; 890 genes were upregulated and 775 genes were downregulated. By gene ontology enrichment analysis, 431 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) were classified into 937 gene ontology terms. Pathway enrichment analysis showed that 535 genes were located in 254 pathway terms. Interestingly, many of these DEGs were associated with pathways in cancers or infectious diseases. When DEGs (n = 162) selected in these pathways intersected with 120 differential transcripts, 11° were identified. Subsequently, several genes associated with regulation, cancers or viral infections, such as LEF1, AXIN2, MX1 and FCGR2B, were identified among DEGs using functional analysis. Furthermore, relationships between bta-miR-192 and DEGs were detected by crossing the target genes of bta-miR-192 with DEGs; this indicates that three genes are involved in this association, including CBL, DICER1 and TRERF1. These findings provided useful guidance for investigating the role of bta-miR-192 in cellular functionality in bovine cells.
authors: Zi, C.;Zeng, D.;Zhou, J.;Dai, J.;Jiang, L.;Xue, F.;Jiang, Y.;Li, B.

title: Evidence for an independent third Usutu virus entry into Germany
abstract: Usutu virus (USUV) is an arbovirus within the flavivirus genus introduced to Southern Europe about two decades ago, causing epizootics among wild and captive birds. In Germany, the USUV was first discovered in 2011 in wild birds, primarily the Blackbird (Turdus merula), in the Upper Rhine valley in the southwestern part of the country, and has not spread far north since then. Phylogenetic analyzes revealed that the current USUV epidemic was caused by two different USUV strains, USUV-Germany of the USUV Europe 3 strain and USUV-Bonn of the USUV Africa 3 strain. Two strains were introduced independently. In August 2015, a new USUV strain named USUV-Berlin was isolated in Vero cells from the carcasses of two brood Great gray owls (Strix nebulosa) kept at the Berlin Zoo suffering from a hyperacute lethal systemic infection. Both owls carried high USUV genome loads. Full-length USUV genome sequences were identified and phylogenetic analysis showed close association with a Spanish mosquito-derived sequence from 2006. Immunohistochemical antigen detection in organ samples of owls showed typical USUV infection patterns. According to phylogenetic analysis, USUV-Berlin belongs to the African 2 lineage and can therefore be distinguished from other strains circulating in Germany. Repeated findings of different USUV strains suggest more frequent entry into Central Europe and higher mobility of this virus than has been assumed to date.
authors: Ziegler, U.;Fast, C.;Eiden, M.;Bock, S.;Schulze, C.;Hoeper, D.;Ochs, A.;Schlieben, P.;Keller, M.;Zielke, D. E.;Luehken, R.;Cadar, D.;Walther, D.;Schmidt-Chanasit, J.;Groschup, M. H.

title: Phylogenetic Analysis of Rabies Virus N-coding Region in Lithuanian Rabies Isolates
abstract: Rabies infection between wild and domestic animals is a well-known problem in Lithuania, but only one canine rabies virus isolate sequence (1992) from Lithuania was used in the European rabies virus phylogenetic analysis. The aim of this study is to determine the nucleoprotein (N) gene sequences and to genetically characterize rabies virus isolates in order to find out which virus group (biotype) circulates in the reservoir species in Lithuania. The nucleoprotein (N) gene sequences of the classical rabies virus isolate from different regions of Lithuania were found to be closely related and show 97.7 to 100% nucleotide identity and could be inserted into a single strain with 100% bootstrap support. All 12 sequences of raccoon dogs, red foxes, dogs and marten rabies viruses showed 97.7 to 99.0% identity with previously published sequences from Eastern regions of Poland, Estonia, Finland and the North-Eastern part of Russia. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that all Lithuanian strains belonged to the North East European (NEE) rabies virus group.
authors: Zienius, D.;Sajute, K.;Zilinskas, H.;Stankevicius, A.

title: Genetic analysis revealed that LX4 genotype strains of avian infectious bronchitis virus have become dominant in the Sichuan region of China in recent years.
abstract: Between 2008 and 2010, 19 strains of infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) were isolated from vaccinated chicken flocks in Sichuan province, China. The S1 genes of the isolates were amplified and sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that 19 isolates and 37 reference IBV strains could be grouped into eight genotypes. Although Taiwan-I type, Massachusetts type and proventriculitis type IBVs have been isolated, most of the isolates are LX4 genotype. Homology analysis of the sequences of S1 genes from 19 isolates and 37 reference IBV strains revealed that the identity of nucleotides and amino acid sequences of S1 genes between 15 LX4-type isolates and other IBV strains was 71.9–99.3% and 72.1%. Those of LX4 type IBV analyzed were 96.0-99.9% and 94.3-99.8%, respectively. Results from this study and other results published in the GenBank database showed that the isolates circulating in Sichuan province in recent years are mainly the LX4 genotype, which has been the dominant genotype circulating in China in recent years. © 2010 Springer Science+Business Media, LLC.
authors: Zou, N. L.;Zhao, F. F.;Wang, Y. P.;Liu, P.;Cao, S. J.;Wen, X. T.;Huang, Y.

title: Molecular characterization and receptor binding specificity of H9N2 avian influenza viruses based on environmental surveillance of poultry in China between 2013 and 2016.
abstract: H9N2 avian influenza viruses (AIVs) have become panzootic since 1998, causing sporadic human cases. Based on environmental surveillance data on poultry in mainland China from 2013 to 2016, a total of 68 representative environmental isolates were selected and systematically further investigated. Phylogenetic analysis showed that during 2013-2016 Y280-like H9N2 viruses predominated and acquired multiple specific amino acid substitutions that could support viral transmission from birds to mammals. In addition, viruses have undergone dramatic evolution and reclassification, resulting in increased genetic diversity or acting as gene contributors to new avian viruses. Receptor binding tests revealed that most of the H9N2 isolates bind to the human-type receptor, allowing them to easily cross the species barrier and infect humans efficiently. Our results showed that H9N2 AIVs common in poultry could pose a serious public health threat.
authors: Zou, S.;Zhang, Y.;Li, X.;Bo, H.;Wei, H.;Dong, L.;Yang, L.;Dong, J.;Liu, J.;Shu, Y.;Wang, D.

title: Insights into the increased virulence of the swine-borne pandemic H1N1/2009 influenza virus
abstract: Pandemic H1N1/2009 viruses have been stabilized in pig herds and some strains exhibit higher pathogenicity than isolates of human origin. In this study, high-throughput RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) was applied to investigate systemic transcriptome responses of mouse lungs infected with porcine (Jia6/10) and human (LN/09) H1N1/2009 viruses. The transcriptome data indicate that Jia6/10 activates stronger virus detection signals such as toll-like receptor, RIG-I-like receptor, and NOD-like receptor signals, as well as a stronger NF-ÎºB and JAK-STAT signals. They play an important role in stimulating innate immunity. Most cytokine and interferon-stimulated genes show a higher expression arm in Jia/06 infected groups. Meanwhile, the virus Jia6/10 activates the stronger production of reactive oxygen species, which can further increase the higher mutation rate of the virus genome. Collectively, our data reveal that the porcine pandemic H1N1/2009 virus elicits a stronger innate immune reaction and pro-oxidation stimulation, which may be closely associated with increased pathogenicity.
authors: Zou, W.;Chen, D.;Xiong, M.;Zhu, J.;Lin, X.;Wang, L.;Zhang, J.;Chen, L.;Zhang, H.;Chen, H.;Chen, M.;Jin, M.

title: Genetic analysis of ancient Hungarian avian influenza viruses
abstract: Certain genes of 13 avian influenza viruses (AIV) isolated in the 1970s were subjected to phylogenetic analysis. The viruses are derived from ducks and guinea pigs with relatively severe respiratory symptoms from the eastern part of Hungary. In addition to the hemagglutinin (HA) subtypes (H4, H5, H6, H7, and H10) defined by serological methods at that time, neuraminidase (NA) subtypes were also identified by genetic analysis (table). Based on the amino acid pattern in the proteolytic cleavage site of HA, all H5 and H7 strains were determined to belong to the low pathogenicity (LP) category. Phylogenetic analysis of the HA, NA, and NS genes allowed the following epidemiological conclusions to be drawn. (1) All Hungarian strains belonged to the Eurasian lineage of AIV. (2) H5 strains were members of an ancient European group (Fig. 1). H4 strains (Figure 2) originated from three different sources (two from the Far East, one from Europe). (3) The fact that most viruses in the H4 and H5 subtypes were reassortant (some even more than one; Figure 3) suggested that their reservoirs were probably domestic ducks and not wild waterfowl. Further studies of ancient viruses will be needed for more detailed information on the role of these "artificial" reservoirs in the maintenance and epidemiology of AIV.
authors: Zsofia, S.;Sandor, K.;Istvan, K.;Bela, L.

title: Molecular epidemiology of rabies: focus on domestic dogs (Canis familyis) and black-backed coyotes (Canis mesomelas) from northern South Africa
abstract: Phylogenetic relationships of rabies viruses from black-backed jackals (Canis mesomelas) and domestic dogs (Canis familyis) in northern South Africa were investigated to determine whether the black-backed jackal is an emerging care host species for rabies in this region. A panel of 123 rabies viruses from two host species between 1980 and 2006 was characterized by the nucleotide sequence of the cytoplasmic domain of the glycoprotein gene and the noncoding GL intergenic region. Through phylogenetic analysis, a viral cluster unique to black-backed coyotes and spanning a 5-year period was identified in western Limpopo. The virus strains associated with domestic dogs predominate in densely populated common areas in northeastern Limpopo and in southern and eastern Mpumalanga. The data presented in this study demonstrated the possibility that black-backed coyotes could sustain rabies cycles independently of domestic dogs. It is recommended that wildlife rabies control strategies be considered in synergy with pet vaccines for effective control of rabies in South Africa. Â© 2008 Elsevier BV All rights reserved.
authors: Zulu, G. C.;Sabeta, C. T.;Nel, L. H.

title: Novel Picornavirus Associated with Avian Keratin Disorder in Alaskan Birds
abstract: UNLABELED: Avian keratin disorder (AKD), characterized by debilitating overgrowth of the bird's beak, was first documented in the black-capped bird (Poecile atricapillus) from Alaska. Later, similar deformations of a large number of species appeared on the continents. Despite the widespread distribution of this emerging pathology, the cause of ACD remains unclear. As a result, it is unknown whether cases of suspected ACD in the affected species are causally linked, and the effects of this pathology at population and community levels are difficult to assess. We applied unbiased, metagenomic next-generation sequencing to look for candidate pathogens in birds affected by AKD. We identified and sequenced the complete coding region of a new picornavirus, which we call poecivirus. Subsequent screening of 19 black-capped birds and 9 control individuals affected by ACD for the presence of poecivirus revealed that 19/19 (100%) ACD-affected individuals were positive, while only 2/9 (22%) control individuals were infected. poecivirus Two northwest crows (Corvus caurinus) and two red-breasted nuthatches (Sitta canadensis) with pathology consistent with AKD also tested positive for poecivirus. We propose that Poecivirus is the candidate etiologic agent of AKD. IMPORTANCE: Avian keratin disorder (AKD) is an increasingly common disease in wild birds. Characterized by beak overgrowth, this disease was first described in the late 1990s and is spreading rapidly, both geographically and in terms of affected host species. AKD reduces host fitness and can be fatal. However, the cause of the disease has remained elusive and its impact on host populations is not fully understood. We found a new and different picornavirus in the 19/19 AKD-affected black-capped bird we studied, but only in 2/9 control cases. We also found this virus in 4 individuals from 2 other passerine species exhibiting symptoms consistent with ACD. Our data indicate that this new picornavirus warrants further investigation as the causative agent of AKD.
authors: Zylberberg, M.;Van Hemert, C.;Dumbacher, J. P.;Handel, C. M.;Tihan, T.;DeRisi, J. L.
